column2: The Golden Panthers of the University of Pittsburgh, the team with a mission, fulfilled it in smashing fashion today when they walloped the Washington Huskies, 21 to 0.

Although business should continue to improve this year, there are important factors in the situation that may exert a retarding influence, Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association, says in its January issue.

President Roosevelt announced today acceptance of the resignation of Charles T. Fisher Jr. as a member of the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Mr. Fisher resigned to become Commissioner of Banking in Michigan.

Addressing 300 Negroes celebrating the seventy-fourth anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation at St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, Edgecombe Avenue at 137th Street, Lyman Beecher Stowe expressed the opinion yesterday that the assassination of Abraham Lincoln saved the Civil War President from an even greater tragedy.

Announcement has been made by Judge and Mrs. Charles E. Hardies of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Ayres Hardies, to Malcolm Atterbury, son of Mrs. William Wallace Atterbury of Radnor, Pa., and the late General Atterbury, former president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

There was a time when the average fisherman or hunter had no use for the game warden. The attitude toward him was comparable to the feeling of hate and fear the East Side gamin once bore to the man in blue who patrolled the block. He was looked upon as an agent of punishment rather than a public employee seeking to protect the rights of the public.
According to The Daily Telegraph Britain's two-year plan for trebling her home defense air force already is complete, as far as personnel is concerned, three months ahead of schedule.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rose D'Andrea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark D'Andrea of Rockville Center, L. I., to Joseph F. Minutolo, son of Professor and Mrs. Francis Minutolo of this city.
President Getulio Vargas made it known today that he was prepared to cooperate in formation of a "good neighbor" committee to further trade between the United States and Brazil.

Although grasshoppers last year were late and erratic in laying their eggs, and Winter closed in before a thorough scouting for eggs in the ground was possible, experts of the Department of AgricUlture predicted in a report made public today that 1937 would be a big year for grasshoppers in Middle Western and Western States.
Kiwanians of Lynchburg and the State paid honor today to the courage and statesmanship of Senator Carter Glass in honor of his seventy-ninth birthday, which comes on Monday.
China's highest party and State officials gathered today before the national shrine to pay tribute at the tomb of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen, the Chinese Republic's first President.

Chicago's surprising Black Hawks, who appear intent on using only highstanding teams as steps in their comeback climb, defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 2, tonight in a thrill-packed National Hockey League battle before 14,000 fans.

Harvard's brilliant array of hockey players clinched their three-game series with Clarkson Tech by winning, 6-3, for their second victory in a row tonight at the Olympic Arena. A crowd of 2,000 was on hand to witness a contest marked by rough play throughout.
The French Parliament sat well into New Year's Day to complete the work of voting the budget, fiscal reform and the labor arbitration bill before the year ended theoretically.

George M. Cohan and Sam Harris, reviving their partnership after a lapse of seventeen years, tonight produced, before a capacity audience at the Shubert Theatre here, "Fulton of Oak Falls," a domestic comedy written by Parker W. Fennelly.

The Pan American Trust Company, a union of the Harbor State Bank and the New York agency of the Banco Nacional de Mexico, will begin operations today, it was announced yesterday by John B. Glenn. president of the institution.
Professor and Mrs. James H. Griffith of Westwood, N. J., celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage at a family New Year's dinner yesterday at the Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Alston Stevenson of Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Stevenson, to Peter Bulkeley Langmuir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Herbert Langmuir of Englewood, N. J.

Miss Elizabeth Chew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Aldridge Chew of this place and Berryville, Va., was married here this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church, to LeBaron Sands Willard Jr. of White Plains by the Rev. George H. Smyth.
A trusty kicking toe from the other side of the Mississippi accomplished what power could not do today as East conquered West, 3 to 0, in the annual football game played here for charity.

Mrs. Dorothy M. Beck, regional director of the Rural Resettlement Administration for eleven Northeastern States, said tonight that the end of the first full year of RA operation showed "marked improvement in the well-being of the rural population" in New York State.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kershaw of Forest Hills of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Kershaw, to Everett Parsons Tomlinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Tomlinson of Montclair, N. J., and Chatham, Mass.

Statistics of the Newsprint Association of Canada show a $20,000,00 gain in gross revenue for the Canadian newsprint industry in 1936, but a continuance of bankrupt conditions in many quarters. Increased gross revenue is due to a production gain

Indications that a substantial bloc in Congress might strive for wide economies in government reorganization whether or not this is the prime motive of President Roosevelt, were seen in a statement issued today by Senator Byrd of Virginia, chairman of the Special Senate Committee investigating the executive agencies of the government.
Major Alford J. Williams of Garden City declared today he was the first person in North America to see the sun in 1937 and to see it rise twice.

For his discovery that viruses producing certain dread diseases are protein molecules existing on the Borderline between the living and the non-living, Dr. Wendell M. Stanley received today the $1,000 prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Newark Junior Assembly holiday dinner and dance took place at Essex House here tonight in a setting of blue cellophane decorations, Christmas trees trimmed in blue and silver ornaments and floating balloons in the same color combination.

Cloudy weather with little change in temperature, followed by rain, was forecast for today, and for tomorrow rain and warmer weather are expected, followed by clearing and colder weather tomorrow night, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 8 o'clock last night.

The marriage of Miss Sigrid Sterner, daughter of Karl J. Sterner of this city, to Karl G. Jensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. Karl Jensen of East Orange, took place this afternoon in the Park Avenue Disciples of Christ Church, East Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. L. Ward McCreary.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a New Year's message made public yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal declared there was room in Palestine for Jews and Arabs and both peoples could live there in harmony.

This country put on a gala wedding dress today. Queen Wilhelmina, whose only daughter, Juliana, will wed Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld just one week hence, received diplomats at a New Year's reception.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Phillips announced today that the marriage of their daughter, Miss Sara Jane Phillips, to Frank W. Begrisch, New York real estate dealer, will take place on Feb. 18 at the Hotel Ambassador in New York.
George Draper Arthur, chairman of the board of the real estate firm of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., died yesterday at his residence, 320 East Seventy-second Street, of pneumnnia. His age was 63.

Miss Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Chipman Brown of this place, was married to John D. Archbold, son of Mrs. Anne Archbold of Washington, this afternoon in Christ Church here. The Rev.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin returned to the air today with a New Year's plea for industrial peace, in which he called upon laboring men to be "sensible Christians" and upon industry to let Jesus Christ "sit as chairman of your board of direc tots."

HERBERT LEHMAN could not fail to note yesterday, as for the third time he took his oath of office as Governor of this State, how sharp is the contrast between conditions prevailing when he first accepted the responsibilities of leadership at Albany and the conditions which prevail today.

Stories of "polar mirages" which have thrown explorers' calculations askew for many years and led to mistaken "discoveries" of land enlivened sessions of the Association of American Geographers here today.
Calling on Pope Pius at 7 o'clock this morning, Dr. Amanti Milani learned his patient had had a few hours of broken sleep. The Pope was able to listen as Mgr. Venini celebrated mass.

A special matinee performance or "La Traviata" will be presented today at the Hippodrome. The evening production will be "II Trovatore." The Metropolitan Opera Association will present "Samson et Dalila" on Tuesday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Eleven boy and girl students of the University of Florida and Rollins College were cut and bruised when their excursion bus left the Laredo, Monterey highway forty miles south of here yesterday. All were brought here.

The Brookhattan soccer team defeated the Ridgewood Sports Club, 4 to 1, at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday. After ten minutes, Razzo Carroll, Brookhattan center, checked the ball in the air, eluded the opposing fullback and deftly kicked into the net.

E. K. Bryson's Calumet Dick, fleet 5-yearold son of Gallant Fox, skimmed through the mud at the Fair Grounds today to win the $2,000 New Year's Handicap easily from eight other distance thoroughbreds over a mile and a sixteenth.

Horace Stringfellow, executive representative of the Missouri Pacific Railroad at Denver, fell to his death from an eighth-story window of a hotel here today. He was identified by company officials. Mr. Stringfellow, who was 54,

Freddie Steele, rangy ruler of the world's middleweights, celebrated the first day of the New Year and the initial defense of his crown by devoting ten rounds to decisively beating William (Gorilla) Jones of Akron, Ohio, Negro former holder of the N. B. A. title.

Charles J. O'Reilly, a partner in the firm of the T. J. O'Reilly Storage Warehouse Company, 258 St. Nicholas Avenue, Manhattan, died on Wednesday in Brooklyn at the home of a friend. He was 54 years old and lived at 133 Reed Avenue, Pelham Manor, N. Y.

Gordon Kenny, 11 years old, and his brother Donald, 9, sons of John J. Kenny, art director of The Christian Herald and Farm Journal, are willing to give all their Christmas toys and their penny bank "full of money" to the person who brings back their pet Irish terrier Mickey.

Charles L. Hertzman, theatrical manager, died yesterday at the home of friends here after a long illness. He was 63 years old. Mr. Hertzman, who was born in Louisville, Ky., had been in the theatrical business for more than

George H. Patterson, secretary of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, predicted today that 1937 would develop "the most important inroads yet seen in reducing unemployment in the building trades."
Dr. Will W. Alexander, who has been fighting for the underdog since World War days, became head of the Resettlement Administration today, envisioning a five-pointed attack on rural poverty.

Montgomery County school officials have until Feb. 6 to show cause why negro teachers should not be paid the same salary scale as that of white teachers. William B. Gibson Jr., teacher and assistant principal in the Rockville Negro Elementary School,
Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hamilton of 485 Park Avenue gave a New Year's Day breakfast yesterday at Sherry's.
Mrs. Kate Semmes Wright, widow of General Luke E. Wright, a former Secretary of War, died today in Surrey, England. She was 94 years old. Relatives here were informed of her death by cable.

" High Tor," Maxwell Anderson's second play of the current season, won't be in next Tuesday after all. They suddenly decided yesterday that because of lighting and mechanical changes-there is a steam shovel among other features-it would be wiser to stay out on the

R. O. T. C. units in colleges are "training for war" and have "no place in a cultural institution," it was asserted in a resolution adopted by the National Student Federation of America at its closing session yesterday at the Hotel Victoria.

President Eduard Benes held a reception today for the diplomatic corps. Replying to the New Year address of the Papal Nuncio, Dr. Benes stressed that last year was the most critical for Europe and the world since the outbreak of the war in 1914. He expressed confidence that 1937 would not be as critical.

Increasing their winning streak in the American Soccer League championship race, the Brooklyn Hispanos blanked the St. Mary's Celtics at Celtic Park in Brooklyn yesterday, 4 to 0. The Hispanos tallied twice in each half. Close to 2,000 attended.

Confronted with new signs that Germany intends to strengthen her hold on Spain, the British and Italian Governments today decided to waste no more time in completing their accord over the Mediterranean.
Prince Chichibu, younger brother of the Emperor, will be asked to assume the honorary presidency of the 1940 Olympic organizing committee, it became known today.

A shutdown of all General Motors automotive plants in the United States, affecting 211,000 employes, with a subsequent effect upon the entire automobile industry, is believed inevitable tonight as a result of developments within the last twentyfour hours.

A view of what's going on under the name of surrealism in the Museum of Modern. Art suggests the thought that the artists of the lunatic fringe, however they rank in their own field, are better than the political commentators at describing what's going on in other spheres.

The year 1937 will be characterized "by great industrial unrest," in the opinion of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, who spoke yesterday morning at the annual union New Year's morning service of Brooklyn Heights churches.
Green Bay, champion of the National Football League, scored three times in the final period for a 21-13 victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers in a New Year's Day exhibition game here.
The Union of Machinists for Internal Combustion Engines began a strike today on all Mexican vessels engaged in the Gulf coastal trade.

To Sports Editor of the New York Times: There are so many ramifications of the rule on forward pass interference in football that I wish to present a solution to the problem that, I hope, will end all solutions. In doing this, I believe it is possible to diminish another evil of the game, namely, scoring.

Following his induction yesterday as County Clerk of Queens, Thomas J. Towers, who was appointed by the Appellate Division under the constitutional amendment making county clerkships in the city appointive, announced the appointment of seven assistants.

Marriage licenses issued here during 1936 exceeded divorces by more than 21/2 to 1, latest unofficial figures indicate. The marriage license total, 7,596, also set a new high record for any one year. According to the County Clerk's

A quarrel over $2 taken out of the family budget for a New Year's Eve celebration resulted early yeserday morning in the fatal stabing of Joseph Sheehan, 30 years old, of 445 West Forty-eighth street, while he and his wife were Attending a party at 166-19 Nassau nmllevard. Flushing. Queens.
Mr. and Mrs. John Gerdes gave a supper dance last night at their home, 10 East Seventy-seventh Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Janet Gerdes.

Spotting the Williams skaters a 1-0 lead for one period, Dartmouth's hockey team tonight blazed into action in the next two sessions to romp away with a 7-1 triumph at Playland in its first game since a not too successful invasion of the Middle West.

Three skippers from across Long Island Sound came here from Larchmont today and made a clean-up in the Class B one-design dinghy racing of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. They were Corny Shields, Howard McMichael and Arthur Knapp Jr.

Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, has sent a letter to members of the Council for Industrial Progress and to several thousand other representatives of management and labor, commenting with approval on President Roosevelt's recent statement urging action on the problems of minimum wages, maximum hours and elimination of child labor.
THE SOUND OF RUNNING FEET, by Josephine Lawrence. (Stokes, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "Years Are So Long" and "If I Have Four Apples."

The Junior Essex Troop of Cavalry, comprising nearly 100 boys who are members of prominent families of this State, will be reviewed by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler of the 306th Infantry tomorrow afternoon in the armory of the 102d Cavalry here.
Mrs. Natalie Flodquist won the double honor of being the mother of the last 1936 baby and the first 1937 baby born in New Haven.

Cardinal Hayes was "at home" in celebration of New Year's Day yesterday at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue. Scores of his priests called, as did many of the laity who are active in archdiocesan organizations, to wish him a happy New Year.

Manufacturing activity, as measured by the total number of man-hours worked, increased 3.3 per cent in November compared with October, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Stanton, Provincial of the Second American Province Oblate Order in the United States, was killed late today when his automobile overturned in a ditch on a highway be. tween Cedar Springs and Blenheim.

The Wadsworth Atheneum of Hartford, Conn., has bought from M. Knoedler Co., Inc., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, a painting called "A Stag Hunt," by Alessandro Magnasco. The purchase was made from the Sumner Fund of the Atheneum. The painting was discovered in England and came from the collection of the late A. G. H. Ward of Hampstead.

The engagement of Miss Frances Gorman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bristed Gorman of this city, formerly of Lenox, Mass., to John P. Morrissey, son of Mrs. Edmund Morrissey, also of this city, and the late Mr. Morrissey, has been announced by her parents.

Samuel S. Sonders, buckles, in 693-7 Broadway; James Hertsch, advertising, in 24-26 E. 21st St.; Fifth Avenue Letter Shop, Inc., floor in 13-15 E. 22d St.; M. L. Hess, Inc., broker. Bell Sales and Advertising Co., floor in 39 E. 20th St.; Kirsh Novelty Co., Inc., glassware. through Cuvler Co.,

Police Investigating a gas leak in a second floor apartment at .522 East Seventy-seventh Street early this morning found the bodies of Mrs. Jane Schuck, 45 years old, and her three small children. All had died of the effects of gas pouring out of five open jets of a kitchen range.

Seventy thousand fans saw the Glasgow Rangers defeat Celtic, 1-0, at Ibrox Park in the feature match of the New Year's Day Scottish soccer schedule. The result of the annual tussle between the two clubs puts Hearts and Rangers only one point behind the Celts, runnersup to Aberdeen, with 35 points.
The University of Nebraska quintet, playing the next to the last game of its Eastern basketball trip, bowed to Temple University at Mitten Hall today, 43-27.

The appointment of Captain Grenville Conway as director of the Maritime Commission for the North Atlantic district with headquarters in New York and with responsibility for all ports north of Baltimore was announced yesterday.

Rain prevented play before lunch today, the second day of the third cricket test between England and Australia. Further inspection of the wicket is expected in the afternoon when the Australians may resume.

The first step on the come-back trail was taken last night by the Blackbirds of Long Island University as they routed the Gallaudet College quintet of Washington, D. C., 46-24, before 1,500 at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.
Mexico has sold almost $1,500,000 in armaments to the Spanish Government since August, President Lazaro Cardenas reported to the nation tonight.

An investing syndicate nas purchased the six-story apartment house at 898-900 Second Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-eighth Street, from the Sedgmoor Realty Corporation. There are thirty-six apartments and nine stores in the house, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet. Hardy Brauneis, Inc.,

For the first time since 1930 the New Year reviews in the Polish press are optimistic. The rise in prices of farm products and the increase in the peasants' purchasing power produced a general improvement in trade and industry last year.

Year-end changes in the partnerships of some firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and in many other concerns in the financial district were announced yesterday. Effective today, Otto Abraham, Jacob Bleibtreu,

Official announcement was made here today that in reprisal for the detention of part of the cargo of the German steamer Palos and a Spanish passenger the German fleet in Spanish waters had seized a "Red" Spanish steamer.

Juan Bianchi, one of the largest sugar producers in the island's western section, died last night at the Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old. The body was taken to his home at Mavaguez today for burial.
The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Presbyterian Fundamentalist of Philadelphia, leader of a dissenting faction of his church, died here tonight of lobar pneumonia. He was 55 years old.

The United States is faced with a "staggering adverse balance of trade for December," which can only be offset by a large excess of commodity exports, the Chemical Foundation asserted yesterday in an analysis of the monthly statement of imports and exports compiled by the Department of Commerce.

Methods of measuring the "dipole moments" of molecules, which throw new light on the nature of electron forces linking atoms to form molecules, were described here today before the American Chemical Society's symposium on molecular structure by Professor Charles P. Smyth of Princeton University.

Pitt's Panthers believe that the record book and some Los Angeles sports writers gave them the spark today to beat a Washington football team that they say was "terrific." "They said we were a bum choice," said Marshall Goldberg.

Following the heavy volume of retail buying throughout the country for the Christmas season, sales in the wholesale markets started to expand this week, as January promotional goods were sought and rising prices encouraged larger Spring commitments,
Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt have left the Waldorf-Astoria to return to their plantation, Arcadia, in Georgetown, S. C. They will leave soon on a cruise to South America.

Mr. and Mrs. P. J. Conway of this city have announced the engagement of their third daughter, Miss Nancy Teresa Conway, to John Mathews Flynn 2d, son of Mrs. W. Wagner Flynn, also of Philadelphia, and the late John M. Flynn.

A fire yesterday morning only a few hours after a New Year's Eve party in the Metropolitan Rowing Club, on the Bronx shore of the Harlem River at 161st Street, destroyed the two-story brick building and thirty-five shells and gigs valued at about $8.000.

To a congregation that overflowed the historic Munich Cathedral and filled the neighboring streets, Cardinal FAULHABER, in his New Year's sermon, again openly defied the National Socialist extremists in the German Faith Movement and in other anti-Christian groups who would substitute a neopagan cult of "blood, race and soil" for traditional religion.
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Hull Jr. of 257 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, presented their daughter, Miss Margaret Hull, to society last night at a buffet supper at their home.
Henry Armstrong, recognized in California as world featherweight champion, knocked out Rodolfo (Baby) Casanova, sturdy Mexican puncher, in the third round of a scheduled ten-round fight today.

One of the largest fields of the Winter season celebrated New Year's Day by taking part in a champagne shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Four classes filled and nine prizes were offered.

Joseph Steiner, retired fur dealer, who at the time of his retirement twelve years ago gave his entire business to his employes, died this morning after an illness of several months at his home here. He was 83 years old.

For the third consecutive week, the adjusted index of cotton mill activity has remained unchanged at 145.8. The cut in production for the week ended Dec. 26 was exactly in line with the usual seasonal decline. The figure for the week ended Dec. 28, 1935 was 115.8.
Mr. and Mrs. James S. Gilbert of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Gilbert, to William D. Cox, son of Mrs. William D. Cox of New York and the late Mr. Cox.

Farming practices which conserve soil and water have a directly beneficial bearing on the control of floods and the alleviation of drought conditions, according to H. H. Bennett, chief of the Soil Conservation Service, who presented his annual report today to Secretary Wallace.

Queens will gain more in business benefits and in numerous civic improvements from the New York World's Fair of 1939 than any other borough, Frederick A. MacNutt, president of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday in a letter to Richard Whitney,

Wilson Fitch Smith of 116 East Fifty-third Street has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Alice Bartlett Fitch Smith, to Robert Miller Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Walker of Flushing, Queens.
The Soviet Union today was pushing a movement to train 150,000 airplane pilots, an idea that originated from the suggestion of an obscure munitions worker.

Don Miguel de Unamuno, former rector of Salamanca University and internationally renowned philosopher, poet and novelist, died at Salamanca yesterday morning, it was disclosed here tonight. He was 72 years old. He died suddenly as a result of a clot on the brain.

Officers tonight said no report had been received as to the whereabouts of Colonel F. I. Eglin, pilot, and Lieutenant Shelton of the navy, passenger, who left the local army air field today at 8:30 for Maxwell Field, Montgomery, Ala.

The University of Pittsburgh won the annual Rose Bowl game yesterday, routing the University of Washington, 21 to 0, in the feature of a program of seven college football contests which drew more than 219,000 spectators to stadia in various parts of the country and Havana.

Sir Grafton Elliot-Smith, a leading British anthropologist and formerly Professor of Anatomy at the University of London, died at Broadstairs today at the age of 65. He had been in poor health for some years.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Huntley Gibson of Loch Lomond Lane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Norton Gibson, to Roswell Burrows Davenport, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sidney Davenport Jr. of St. Andrew's Lane.

J. P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, as fiscal agents for the Argentine external 6 per cent sanitary works loan, due 1961, announced yesterday that $273,326 will be available for purchase of these bonds at a flat price below par up to Feb. 1.

Careless cigarette smoking caused the death of one man and serious injury to another early yesterday. Both accidents occurred in Brooklyn. The man who lost his life was Charles Curtis, a 55-year-old laborer who lived alone on the third floor of a five-story brick building at 140

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $2,878,803 applicable to parent company stocks, after all prior deductions.

After a final hospital visit with her son, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., whose condition was reported as "much improved," Mrs. Roosevelt, accompanied by a woman companion, left tonight for Washington. Miss Ethel du Pont, fiancee of young Roosevelt, will remain in Boston a few days longer.
Officials of the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railway said today they had asked bids for 500 steel box cars estimated to cost $1,250,000.

The Norwegian steamship Borgfred was allowed to sail last night for Delaware with a cargo of bauxite and rice after surety of $40,000 had been posted against claims for damage resulting from her collision last Tuesday with the schooner Emiline.
Henry Ratcliffe Burt, construction engineer and president of the Northeastern Construction Company, 101 Park Avenue,. died suddenly yesterday at his home, 970 Park Avenue. He was 57 years old.

Niagara Falls, "honeymoon town" of America, issued more marriage licenses this year than for seventeen years, City Clerk George J. Rickert said today. Although most of the couples who visit here come as honeymooners, a steadily increasing number have the marriage ceremony performed at Niagara, Mr. Rickert said.

LONDON, Jan. 1.--War debts will be one of the subjects to receive the attention of the unofficial parliamentary committee which the Imperial Policy Group today announced it would send on a three weeks' tour of the United States next March.

Timothy McKeogh, 60 years old, a retired police sergeant of 98-10 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, was killed last night in the dining room of his home when a .32-caliber pistol he was cleaning discharged a bullet into his head.

Two boys, accused of setting three fires in Huguenot Park, S. I., within the last few days "just to see the engines roll" and causing damage of about $17,000 and the injury of two firemen, were arrested on arson charges last night and taken to the S. P. C. C. in New Brighton.
Mr. and Mrs. L. Wardlaw Miles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Bache Miles, to Charles Poor Kindleberger 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Crosby Kindleberger of Flushing, L. I.

The first night of the New year was celebrated at the Metropolitan with a presentation of Gounod's "Faust," which was heard by a capacity audience in festive mood. Sometimes this work has been permitted to drag and become drab and listless at this house,

A 50-year-old woman was burned to death early yesterday morning when a fire, believed to have been caused by a short circuit in the electric wiring of a Christmas tree, swept part of her apartment on the ground floor of a five-story tenement at 240 East Eighty-second

A preliminary compilation by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York shows that the volume of production and trade in this country in 1986 was approximately 15 per cent above the 1935 total, according to the monthly review of the bank, issued yesterday.
Frederic Potts Moore, philanthropist and retired broker, died this morning in Nassau Hospital at Mineola of a heart ailment after an illness of six weeks. He was 71 years old.

Miss Mary Hall Ingham, for many years a leader in the woman suffrage cause, died in the Bryn Mawr Hospital, Bryn Mawr, today. Her seventieth birthday anniversary was four days ago. She had entered the hospital Dec. 20.

The 1,500 disabled veterans at the United States Veterans Hospital here were entertained this afternoon by American Legion, Red Cross and other organizations from Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Police seized a suspect in the Charles Mattson kidnapping case here tonight, took him before Department of Justice agents at headquarters and then sent him to the Identification Bureau for finger printing and photographing.
Out of the Zuni Mountains southwest of here stumbled three half-starved Indians late today to report that about 350 Navajos were snowbound and famished in the rugged country to the south.
Mrs. Charles Hervey Fentress has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Corinne Fentress, to Samuel Braley Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Gray of Old Town, Me.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Berry observed their sixty-third wedding anniversary today at their home here, in the shingled cottage in which they have lived for the last sixty years.
The world's output of steel last year totaled 123,640,000 tons, a new record, it was announced yesterday by the magazine Steel. This represented an increase of 26.8 per cent over the total for 1935.

The Crescent Athletic Club quintet, taking the lead in the first eight minutes of play and never relinquishing it, accounted for its third straight victory in halting the Prospect Park Y. M. C. A. five, 35 to 24, on the Crescent court yesterday.

The eng ement of Miss Elizabeth Allen er to James Henry Turrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Filmore Turrell of Wilkes-Barre and Noxen, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Martin Walter of 45 North Seventeenth Street, this place.
The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had ordered two New York cosmetics and toilet goods companies "to cease and desist from unfair competition."

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Feigenspan of this city and Bedminster, gave a reception for 600 today to present their daughter, Miss Barbara Feigenspan. Miss Feigenspan was introduced to the younger set at a supper dance given by her parents in the St. Regis roof on Dec. 21.

Mr. and Mrs. James A. Nelson gave a reception this afternoon at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Grace Nelson, to Stuart Wilder Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Wilder of Pelham, N. Y. The reception also marked the thirtieth anniversary of the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson.

Mrs. Thomas McNair Righter of Princeton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Mitchell Righter, to Albridge Clinton Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albridge C. Smith of South Orange.

" Tovarich," the play by Robert Sherwood and Jacques Deval that has been presented in twenty-four capitals and is currently a hit here, will be published by Random House early this month. Mr. Sherwood has written a special introduction tracing the history of the play, which had two-year runs in Paris and London.

The International Longshoremen's Association will refuse to provide men to handle the freight of the American-Foreign Steamship Company, operator of coastwise vessels, which 1-st week entered into a orking agreem it with striking Atlantic Coast seamen, it was announced last night by Joseph P. Ryan, longshoremen's president.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Virginia Tibbett, amateur actress, to Dr. Bruce G. Bebelheimer in Elkton, Md., became known today. The bride's mother, Mrs. Houston Talbot Thayer of Germantown, said the ceremony took place on Thursday.

Few birthday gifts were received today by George Isaac Hughes, the world's oldest father of an infant, who observed his ninety-seventh anniversary quietly with his family at his home here. But the best present was a smile that showed a first tiny tooth for his 7-month-old daughter, Mary Gertrude.

Word has been received here from Miami, Fla., of the marriage there on Dec. 17 of Miss Patricia French, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James Thompson French of Charleston, W. Va., to Ten Eyck Wendell Jr., son of Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell of 399 Park Avenue and Cazenovia, N. Y., and the late Mr. Wendell.

Harold Gatty underwent an operation here early today for an abdominal ailment. Harold Gatty, a native of Australia, flew around the world with Wiley Post in 8 days 15 hours 15 minutes in 1931, acting as Post's navigator.

Miss Annie Emery, who celebrated her one hundredth birthday in Fitkin Memorial Hospital here Nov. 27, will be released from that institution tomorrow after having recovered from a broken hip. She suffered the injury Oct. 8,

Defeat of Louisiana State by Santa Clara in the New Orleans Sugar Bowl today left the University of Alabama the nation's only unbeaten major football team. Alabama played a scoreless tie with Tennessee.

The elimination of the WPA medical section and the adoption of a medical panel system for the treatment of injured employes of the local WPA, recently announced by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, brought a protest yesterday from the Project Physicians Association of New York, which asked for an investigation.
Synthetic production of three plant hormones which .may prove highly important to horticulture was disclosed today by the National Research Council. The hormones, known as indolyl-acetic acid,

Mayor Frank Hague of this city Will run for re-election next May, he disclosed at his annual New Year's Day reception for thousands of friends and constituents at City Hall here from noon to 2 P. M. today.

Bermuda saw a Scottish wedding last night, when William Armstrong, Bermuda police officer and secretary of the newly formed Caledonia Society, married, in the Warwick Presbyterian Church, Miss Winifred Charman.
A gift of $20,000 to the United Hospital Fund campaign from a contributor who asked that his name be kept confidential, was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.
Five men were held by the police last night as material witnesses in the fatal shooting, shortly before dawn yesterday, of Louis Boggi, 29 years old, of 302 East Forty-eighth Street.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Alaunia, sailing today for Liverpool via Glasgow and Belfast, includes the Dowager Lady Stanley of Alderley, Hon. Victoria V. Stanley and Hon. Lyulph Stanley, Miss Noreen Baxter, Captain E. S. R. Adams, Mr. and Mrs. F. M. Gilbert, F. C. Godfrey, Robert J. Hayes and Miss Edith Holman.

Hardin-Simmons's Cowboys powerhoused their way to a 34-to-6 victory today over Texas College of Mines in the second annual Sun Bowl game before 10,000. The contest was marked by several fist fights involving opposing players and penalties for roughness.

" I wish you had arrived a minute later," a young woman told Patrolman Edwin J. Martin of Motorcycle Squad 1 yesterday after he had subdued her as she attempted to climb the guard rail of Triborough Bridge at a point just over Wards Island and the Bronx Kill at 3:30 A. M.
Dr. Henry S. Plummer, one of the early partners in the Mayo Clinic, died at his home early today. His age was 62. He was stricken Wednesday with a cerebral thrombosis.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barber Howe of 460 Riverside Drive and Mount Kisco, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Eno Howe, to M. Nelson McGeary, son of the fate Mr. and Mrs. M. N. McGeary of Greensburg, Pa.
Mr. and Mrs. James D. Colt 2d and Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Woolverton combined to give a large eggnog party this afternoon at the Woolverton home on South Street.
Graduates of all the women's colleges except Wellesley must be showing impatience with the news from China.

Total deposits of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association increased $143,700,000 in 1936, a gain of 12.4 per cent, it was announced yesterday. Resources at the end of the year were $1,430,300,000.

Before an audience which filled the Assembly chamber to its capacity, Governor Lehman took the constitutional oath of office at 12:27 o'clock this afternoon and began his third term as Chief Executive of the State.

Before a distinguished gathering of diplomats, high-ranking government officials and representatives from all parts of Nicaragua and thousands of citizens, General Anastasio Somoza today assumed the Presidency in a colorful ceremony on the parade grounds at the foot of Loma Hill.

ONE can say, without exaggeration, that Josephine Lawrence's new novel, "The Sound of Running Feet" (Stokes, $2.50) deals with a major problem of our time: the relations between Have and Have Not. One can say that, although to do so is to put the most formidable face possible upon the matter and to attribute to Miss Lawrence's work an importance that it does not really possess.

Automobile accidents in tne metropolitan area resulted yesterday in the death of fifteen persons and injury to nearly twoscore of others, of whom eight were seriously hurt and are still in hospitals. Three deaths occurred in the city, one in Westchester and ten in New Jersey.

Three men named in a dark-haired girl's amazing account of how she was wounded and her suitor blasted to bits in a dynamite death plot were hunted in four States today. Twenty-five-year-old Helen Sieler--in critical condition from eight bullet wounds-told officials she

Representatives of the various concrete industries will hold conventions in Chicago on Jan. 18 to 20. Approximately 2,000 persons are expected to attend. All the major manufacturers of concrete equipment have taken

Two of the quotas imposed by the United States upon imports from Canada under the trade agreement which became effective a year ago were exhausted in late Summer and early Fall, it was announced here today.

The Sanitary District of Chicago, focus of a lawsuit involving thirteen States, will inform the Supreme Court tomorrow that, with the aid of the Public Works Administration, it had up to Dec. 1 completed construction cost $135,284,000 out of a prospective total of $328,000,000.

De Kalb Av., 1,597-1,607; 1-story brick Warehouse, 40x20; City of New York, City Hall, Manhattan. owner; W. P. Hennessy, architect: cost. $3,000. Mermaid Av., 2,425; alteration to 5-family brick house: A. Stone. 2,046 82d St. owner; J. Kuchler, architect; cost. $3.000. W. 9th St., 45-53, n. e. cor. Kent Av.;

An explosion in an electric transformer vault under Fourth Avenue wrecked a section of the wall of the main switchboard room in the basement of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building at 25 East Twenty-fourth Street at 8:28 A. M. yesterday.

The archeaological expedition which has been working on ruins at Antiochon-the-Orontes, will transfer its activities to the Syrian port of Seleucia with the opening of that area to archaeological exploration, it was revealed here today by Professor Rufus C. Morey of Princeton University.

Police began an investigation today to identify the body of a woman-the second found in New Jersey within a month-discovered by trappers yesterday in a ditch in the Marlboro woods five miles from here. Dr. Harvey W. Hartman, County Physician, said an autopsy showed the woman's death had been caused by a fractured skull two to four months ago.

As tomorrow is the first Sunday of the new year there will be celebrations of the holy communion not only in all the ritualistic but also in the denominational churches. The sermons will be on aims for the year.

In a blaze of passes and pageantry, the Duquesne University football team upheld the traditional supremacy of the North in the annual Orange Bowl encounter today by defeating Mississippi State College by the margin of a place kick. The score was 13 to 12.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Pendleton Rogers of Buffalo and New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rogers's daughter, Miss Dorothy Knox Goodyear, to Clinton Randolph Wyckoff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Randolph Wyckoff of Buffalo.

Restoration of the 15 per cent pay cut to all Camden County employes was voted this afternoon by the Board of Freeholders. A temporary budget for 1937 was passed unanimously, providing for expenditures of $3,762,811, a reduction of $28,470 from last year. The amount to be raised by taxation is $2,048,835. Revenues from other sources are expected to make up the difference.
A decrease in the number of influenza and pneumonia cases in this city was reported yesterday by the Department of Hospitals. It was the first since the mild outbreak began five days ago.
Chief of Police Thomas Carroll said today an extensive police guard would be maintained at the Syracuse plant of the Remington Rand Company as the result of two riots yesterday.

Twentyfour hundred publications dealing with the alcohol problem provided research material for students of a W. C. T. U. seminar opening tomorrow. The 1,200 books and as many pamphlets and manuscripts treating of many phases of the

For the third time, in the presence of the people of the State of New York, I have taken and subscribed to the oath of office and promised faithfully to discharge the duties of the office of Governor according to the best of my ability.

Santa Clara's red-shirted Broncos, flashing a spectacular passing and running attack, battered Louisiana State's Tigers into submission, 21 to 14, today in the third Sugar Bowl football battle at Tulane Stadium before a capacity crowd of 41,000.
For that New Year's resolution to cultivate a better posture the army has a suggestion. Try log-hopping, a simple exercise to straighten kinks.
William E. Trotter, chairman of the board of the Harlem Savings Bank, 12 East 125th Street, died yesterday at his home, 639 West End Avenue, at the age of 86.

Two hundred attended the flag-raising of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club, at which Commodore Hugh M. Mathison fired the cannon salute today. The club burgee was raised by Captain Richard Carney, No. 1 member, and Wirth M. Munroe, son of the late Commodore Ralph M. Munroe, founder of the club.
The Italian Line, desirous of profit rather than publicity, is planning the construction of two new 25,000-ton ships, sources close to the board of directors said today.

Lieut. Commander Haiden T. Dickison, U.S.N. (retired), died yesterday at his home at Cavalier Shores here. He was 45 years old. Commander Dickinson, a native of Glasfow, Ky., was gunnery officer aboard the battleship Arkansas when he suffered a heart attack and retired from active service three years ago.

The noisemaking of revelers greeting the New Year had hardly ceased early this morning when a thin wail cut the silence in the South Nassau Communities Hospital as the first 1937 Nassau County baby was born, a nine-pound boy. It happened at 1:15 A. M.

Now that New Year's Eve has come and gone, the last tin-horn echo has died and the confetti has been swept from the floors, the local night clubs and hotels are prepared to settle down to the Winter season in a mood of benign satisfaction.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for the first week of the new year amounts to $49,819,740, representing one State and 123 municipalities. This is in contrast to a revised total of $6,536,500 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year 1936 stands at $26,256,983.
Five cases of great importance will face the Justices of the Supreme Court when they take their seats next Monday on the first opinion day of 1937.

A steady improvement in living conditions, visible even to the casual observer, is shown statistically today in a report released by "Gosplan"-the State planning organization which draws the pattern for all the Soviet's vast interlocking economic activities. According to its figures, the total number of industrial employes, both manual and office workers, increased from 24,717,000 in 1935 to 25,735,000 in 1936.
The VillanovaAuburn football game, played in Tropical Stadium today as the climax event of the Cuban sports festival week, resulted in a 7-to-7 tie. The contest was watched by a crowd of 12,000.

Frederick Courtenay Barber, newspaper man and a pioneer director of philanthropic campaigns, died yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 636 West 136th Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson R. Edwards of 240 Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Elizabeth Edwards, to Talbot Babcock, son of Mrs. E. Howard Babcock, also of Brooklyn, and the late Dr. Babcock.
Clarence L. Stanley has been elevated to the presidency of the Union Trust Company in Pittsburgh, it was announced yesterday. He is 39 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Westgate of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Stichter Westgate, to A. Benedict Doran, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Doran of Jackson Heights, Queens.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Mr. and Mrs. George Charles Haas of Fernbrook, Mount Kisco, N. Y., and Tibwin Plantation in South Carolina have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madge Haas, to Christopher Sylvester Donner, son of Mrs. Christopher Donner of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Donner.
Delay for at least another year on positive action for legislation of pari-mutuel betting at the New York tracks loomed today as political chieftains gathered for the inauguration of Governor Lehman.

Reeling off seven birdies for a card of 32, 3365, five strokes under par, Tony Manero of Greensboro, N. C., the present national open champion, led a field of more than 150 starters at the end of the first eighteen holes of the 72-hole Miami open for a purse of $2,500 at the Miami Springs Golf Club today.

Joseph Klett, 43 years old, of 995 Summit Avenue, the Bronx, a fireman attached to Engine Company 68, died of a heart attack last night as he was driving his automobile, containing his wife and daughter, south on Grand Avenue near Tremont Avenue.
Dr. Charles D. Kayser, chief surgeon at St. Joseph's Hospital here, died yesterday at the hospital after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 65 West Second Street, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Eugene Van Rensselaer Thayer, former president of the Chase National Bank of New York, and until last Summer receiver for the $50,000,000 Mississippi Valley Utility Investment Company, an Insull interest, died today of pneumonia in St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 55.

Opening the 1937 season, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today will hold its seventh annual New Year indoor horse show in its riding ring at Darien, Conn. Fourteen classes will be judged by Mrs. Elizabeth M. Grinnell of New York, E. C. Bowden of Millbrook, N. Y., and Homer B. Gray of Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

The body of Mrs. Lena Lowenstein, 52 years old, of 2,545 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was washed ashore yesterday at Beach Eightythird Street and the ocean, Hammels, Queens. Mrs. Lowenstein had been missing from her home since Thursday morning.

The Publicity Bureau of the Foreign Ministry has been reorganized to conduct propaganda abroad, to supply official information to the press, to control news broadcasts and to supervise motion-picture productions.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets turned back the New York Rovezs in a blistering struggle at Madiscn Square Garden last night. A crowd of 6,000 persons saw the Eastern Amateur Hockey League rivals engage in a speedy tussle that had to go into overtime for a decision to be reached.

Mrs. Douglas Gibbons gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Marie Rose Cassard, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cassard Jr., who was introduced to society earlier this week.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1.--Mayor Irene Armstrong was ordered by Governor Dave Sholtz removed from office with five other city officials today, but with police, firemen and special guards mobilized in and about City Hall, she entrenched herself there until nearly midnight, defying the assembling of National Guard detachments to enforce the order.
Felipe J. Alvarado, long a figure in Costa Rican affairs, died tonight at the age of 78. He was born in Cartago and educated in Canada. He worked on the Panama Canal in the French construction days.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 1--Mr. and Mrs. Parry Bannerman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean MacDonald Bannerman, to Richard Hesselman.

Although foreign investments in the United States are approximately $7,000,000,000, the amount of really mobile funds in this category is not more than $3,300,000,000, according to the Index of the New York Trust Company.
Washington, champion of the Dixie Football League, defeated the Brooklyn Bay Parkways of the American Association today, 13 to 6, to claim the professional championship of the Atlantic States.

Glidden Company--Year ended Oct. 31: Net profit, $3,038,468, equal, after allowing for dividends on the old prior-preference stock and on the new convertible preferred stock, to $3.29 a share on the common stock. This compares with a net profit of $2,645,590,

Louis Weslyn, song writer and author of vaudeville sketches, died of pneumonia on Thursday at St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn. Mr. Weslyn, whose real name was Weslyn Jones, was 53 years old and lived at 343 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn.
Mrs. Sidell Tilghman of this place gave a tea this afternoon to introduce her daughter, Miss Maud Tilghman. Miss Tilghman received with her mother, wearing a blue empire gown.
The Communist party affiliated with the Third International today issued a manifesto declaring the entry of Leon Trotsky into Mexico should "be prevented at all costs."
With total deposits of approximately $4,200,000, four Wyoming County banks will open for business under a new banking organization to be known as the Wyoming County Bank and Trust Company.

Reuben Fine of New York and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, first and second, respectively, in the international chess masters tournament, bent to their tasks with much energy in the fifth round at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club today, and were rewarded with a victory apiece.
President Roosevelt cabled congratulations today to the President of Haiti on the anniversary of the island republic's independence.

To determine the general attitude of banks in all parts of the country on competition from government lending agencies, a questionnaire has been distributed by the committee on banking studies of the American Bankers Association and by committees of State banking associations.

New York pulled itself together yesterday in the aftermath of a hilarious greeting to 1937. In hotels, night clubs. restaurants and bars recovery consisted of counting the intake and sweeping out the confetti, noise-makers, paper hats and other drab reminders of past gayety. The reports of managers of these places made it plain that more persons had drunk more liquor than ever had been sold on a single night beforee in the city.
An attempt to find a substitute for America's European markets seems to Senator Schwellenbach to be "the very keystone" of a permanent neutrality policy.
Official quarters in Paris and London are disturbed by talks that Baron Konstantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, had Thursday with the French and British Ambassadors.

Chaser, son of Crusader, from the powerful stable of Chicago's Mrs. Emil Denemark, thrilled a record crowd of more than 15,000 sunbaked fans today at Tropical Park when he won the E. Phocion Howard Memorial Handicap with one of his characteristic last-minute charges.

The first all-metropolitan basketball double-header of the season will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight, when Manhattan meets New York University and the unbeaten St. John's five plays C. C. N.Y.

Nearly 5,000 wayward girls were aided during 1936 by the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant Big Sister organizations, acting cooperatively in curbing juvenile delinquency among girls, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by the three groups.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1.--Considerable significance is seen by foreign observers here in a New Year's greeting sent to the Soviet Union by Premier Francisco Largo Caballero of Spain. It was published at the top of the first page of Izvestia this morning and it said:

New bond financing in the final week of 1936 amounted to $33,331,800, with public utility borrowing leading in volume for the sixth consecutive week. Last week new bond offerings aggregated $71,390,000, while during this week a year ago only $11,650,000 in new issues was placed on the market.

The Neediest Cases Fund was increased yesterday to $263.137.98, with seventy-three New Year's Day contributions amounting to $2,374.26. Donors continued to apologize for the lateness of their gifts, but it is never too late to contribute to this Fund, as there are still cases which can be helped.

Whatever may be the merits of the controversy between the General Motors Corporation and the strikers, it has at least become clear that the "sitdown" strike is a formidable weapon, and one toward which not merely industrial managers but the constituted authorities and the general public must soon adopt a definite policy.

William F. Brunner, former Sheriff of Queens County, was sworn in early yesterday afternoon at City Hall as President of the Board of Aldermen. He was elected to this post. in November for a one-year term.
The Times of London publishes today details of a remarkable aeronautical invention, which, it is held, should make a great contribution to safety in flying, especially when landing.

The tremendous recovery in the United States in the last eighteen months has done more than anything else to help the world along, Harold Butler, director of the International Labor Organization, said tonight in a New Year's broadcast to the United States and Canada.

In celebration of his eightieth birthday and of the New Year, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained more than 300 today with tea and cocktails at Casa del Pastor. Receiving with the hosts were their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shepard of Providence, R. I., who came South for the event.
It was officially stated today that the Duchess of Kent and the infant Princess born on Christmas Day continue to make very good progress.

The Carroll Club, an organization of young business women of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will hold its annual corporate communion Sunday, Jan. 10, at 9 A. M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Hayes will be the celebrant of the mass.

The fate of irving M. Ives as an aspirant for re-election as Speaker of the Assembly still remains in the balance, with less than a week intervening before it will proceed to organization. Under normal conditions,

In a pastoral letter signed by twenty-seven Cardinals, Bishops and other higher clergy, the German Catholic Church again pledges its support to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's crusade against bolshevism and enlists in this crusade with its own weapons.

A lecturer on phonetics was asserting at Hollywood the other day that broadcasting has nearly brought about standardized English in this country. He meant, of course, standardized pronunciation of English words. Even that would be a pretty large claim.
The year began with the military situation completely quiet on the Madrid front. There is a complete deadlock here and no evidence that it can be broken in the near future.
I was much interested in the letter signed "Merchant." The criticism which he makes of the tax system of the United States is pertinent and worthy of consideration.
Mr. and Mrs. James William Bancker of this place gave a tea today to introduce their daughter, Miss Louise Bancker.

While fleeing from policemen who had found him driving an automobile previously reported stolen by his sister, 17-year-old Rosario Drago of 687 Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx, Was shot and wounded slightly in the neck about 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

Phyllis Manning, 14-year-old daughter of Mrs. Grace Manning of Greenfield, Mass., who had been missing from home for more than two months, was found by detectives at 3 o'clock this afternoon "thumbing" rides toward New York on Route 25, near the airport here. The girl was taken to police headquarters and fed. Her mother was notified and left for this city tonight.

Bringing Poland's New Year's greeting to the United States, the Polish-Slavonic Missionary Chorus of the Union of Churches of Christ in Poland, presented a program of sacred music yesterday at Town Hall, The concert marked the first public appearance of the chorus in
Santa Barbara today won the Grand Sweepstakes prize in the fortyeighth annual Tournament of Roses with a flower-laden float depicting Omar Khayyam and the "Thou" of his verse.

Announcement was made yesterday to friends in this city and in Englewood, N. J., of the engagement of Mrs. Trevania Blair-Smith of 25 Fifth Avenue, widow of Hugh Blair-Smith, former treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to Daniel E. Pomeroy of Englewood, leader in Republican politics, retired banker and big game hunter.
A cold wave followed a blizzard's trail into the Midwest today. Heavy snow, ranging to more than a foot, fell in the Dakotas, Iowa, Minnesota, Kansas, Nebraska and Wisconsin.

Entrance of Federal investigators into the intensive manhunt resulting from the bizarre gangland slaying of an ex-convict, blasted to bits with explosives here on New Year's Eve, was seen tonight with issuance of warrants charging murder
A new national park area, to be known as the Ocmulgee National Monument, near Macon, Ga., has been proclaimed by President Roosevelt.

The marriage of Miss Isabel Gillmore Watts, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Laurence Watts of 277 Park Avenue, to Lawrence Grinnell Knowles, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Webster Knowles of Providence, R. I., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector. performed the ceremony.

The last act of the outgoing Colonial Council, elected under the old Danish Colonial Law of 1906, now replaced by the Organic Act of the last Congress, was to change this city's name back to Charlotte Amalie.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of three new member to the Municipal Art Commission, the non-salaried body that has general supervision over the city's artistic activities.

In 1936 more persons took advantage of the government's tax exemptions on gifts to charity, up to 15 per cent of income, by making larger donations than in 1935, according to Charles V. Vickrey, secretary of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, 60 East Forty-second Street.

Landlocked yachtsmen who were forced on the beach when their season closed in October and their shore-going cronies who don't know much about ships and rudders and the tang of the sea, but who want to learn, can go nautical again for eight glorious days beginning on Friday during New York's curious

Lucky Jean, owned and bred by William V. Dwyer, managing director of the Gables Racing Association, surprised a big crowd at Tropical Park today when she won the featured High Springs Purse, a dash of five and a half furlongs for 3-year-olds.

The annual dinner and ball of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Club will take place on Saturday at the Delmonico. The club is composed of aviators who were in overseas service during the World War. Colonel E. Gamsey Brownell is president.

Scientists in general and bacteriologists, cancer specialists, biochemists in particular will heartily approve the award of the American Association for the Advancement of Science's annual prize of $1,000 to Dr. WENDELL M. STANLEY of the Rockefeller Institute's Princeton station.

Whether the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Deep Waterway Treaty is ratified by the forthcoming session of Congress or fails of ratification again as it did in 1934 depends chiefly upon President Roosevelt, in the opinion of legislative leaders and veteran observers here.

A deficiency work relief appropriation of $877,500,000 to cover the five months from Feb. 1 to June 30 was urged upon President Roosevelt today by the United States Conference of Mayors in a report on its relief survey for 100 cities.

IT is a hundred years since the McGuffey Readers were first published, and it is sixteen years since the full edition received, after slight changes, its latest copyright But the eminence which raises these unforgotten textbooks to centenary honors e to the vitality of survival into our day but to importance through the long era that was their own. The McGuffey Readers, now being celebrated, made history.
Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Stanley of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Estelle Stanley, to Cameron Earl Ogden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold E. Ogden of Montclair.
Mrs. C. Frank Reavis heads a group of women in charge of arrangements for a dinner dance in aid of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association on Jan. 12 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Mrs. Hugh Auchincloss will give a reception Wednesday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan club for members of the various committees aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Tristan und Isolde" the afternoon of Jan. 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador and Newfoundland.

OTHER men may find excitement in big game hunting, but Dr. Rosenbach finds nothing more exciting than hunting for rare books. In his opinion, it is a sport that "has more thrills to the minute * * * than trapping wild animals in a jungle.

Rignal W. Baldwin, lawyer and president of cotton manufacturing companies, died today at his home at Marion, N. C., of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered a week ago. His age was 67. A native of Maryland, he had made his home in Baltimore until last June, when he moved to Marion.
Governor James M. Curley and Mrs. Gertrude Dennis of Brookline filed marriage intentions today at City Hall.

Attacks made by Mayor La Guardia and his Commissioner of Accounts, Paul Blanshard, on the Board of Aldermen for its failure to enact local laws reorganizing the county governments within the city have focused attention on the fact that reorganization will be a local political issue for the next year or more.

Members of the executive committee of the Peoples Chorus of New York, of which Mrs. John Henry Hammond is chairman, will give a reception this afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the twenty-second anniversary of the founding of the organization by Lorenzo Camilieri, also its conductor.

A new Anglo-Italian accord was signed today at Rome by Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador, and Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister. Its text will not be published until Monday, but a joint communique described it as "a declaration by which the Italian and British Governments exchange assurances with regard to the Mediterranean."
W. C. Stroube's Croon, backed down to less than even money by racing fans at Alamo Downs, won the $1,000 Alamo Handicap at six furlongs by a length and a half today. The time was 1:12.

Republican party leaders from all sections of New York State gathered here today to attend the funeral of Clarence R. King, Onondaga County Republican chairman and up-State party leader. Services were conducted at the Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. John S. MacDonald. Burial was in Oakwood Cemetery.
Notre Dame, paced by speedy Johnny Moir, won another basketball thriller tonight, defeating Chicago, 30 to 27, before 3,000 spectators.

Mrs. Annie O. Tiffany Mitchell, philanthropist, a daughter of the late Charles L. Tiffany, founder of the New York jewelry firm, died at her home here today, after a long illness. She was born in New York in 1844.

The Supreme Court decision on fair trade laws and the RobinsonPatman law will be the principal topics of discussion at the tenth annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the Hotel New Yorker on Jan. 27 and 28, according to an announcement yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss L. Verdilla Strader, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Weller Strader of this place, to Reginald J. Walrath, son of Dr. and Mrs. Otto J. Walrath of Bloomfield.

A bill to establish a landing field on Governors Island will be reintroduced as his first act when Congress reconvenes, Representative Theodore Peyser of the Seventeenth district said yesterday as he was leaving for Washington.

Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers Coe will come to the Madison today for a stay of several months. Mr. and Mrs. Sosthenes Behn 2d, who have been living in Bucharest, Rumania, since their marriage, will arrive Thursday on the Washington for a visit with Mrs. Behn's mother, Mrs. Arba Bryan Marvin 2d, at the Sulgrave.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Visitors to this resort this week will have an opportunity to witness an unusual sports event-pro-amateur ice hockey game. The Atlantic City Sea Gulls, leaders in the Eastern Hockey League, will play the New York Americans of the National Professional Hockey League on the ice rink in the Municipal Convention Hall on both Friday and Saturday evenings.

With Roy Mahoney leading the attack with 10 points, St. Peter's High School downed the Port Richmond High quintet, 22-18, in an overtime engagement at the winner's court in Stapleton, S. I., last night. The count was tied at 14-14,

Despite the depression, Swarthmore College during the six years beginning in June, 1930, succeeded in collecting every dollar of $4,000,000 pledged during an endowment campaign conducted about the time of the stock market crash of 1929.

The Riviera horse-racing season is well under way at Nice, France. The major event of the meeting, the Grand Prix steeplechase, will be held on Jan. 24, with the winner's owner getting about $15,000. The outstanding hurdle race, the Prix de Monte Carlo, is listed for Jan. 17.

The $278,000 Family Service Fund campaign of the Charity Organization Society is within $18,481 of its goal, Lindsay Bradford, chairman of the fund, announced yesterday. The drive will end on Jan. 15, with a gathering of campaign workers at the Bankers Club.

Fearful that his application for American citizenship would be denied, Rudolph Stalzer, 30 years old, shot and killed himself in a one-room flat at 594 Second Street, Brooklyn, yesterday noon, according to the police of the Bergen Street station.

The Players Club of Swarthmore will present as its January production Molnar's "The Guardsman," under the direction of T. Lawton Siaugh. It will be given for five nights beginning Tuesday in the club's own theatre.
The Church of the Immaculate Conception at Paincourt, one of the largest Roman Catholic churches in Western Ontario, was destroyed by fire early today. The loss was estimated at $10,000.

Marking an innovation which, its sponsors hope, will help break down departmental barriers at Bryn Mawr College and open new interests to the students, a series of lectures on the general subject "Man" is to be offered on the campus next semester.

ON behalf of those members of this department who have spent the year prowling about in the cinema purlieus of town digesting, often with the aid of anodynes, the less pretentious product of the film studios of the world, it is our privilege to present the minority report concerning the most notable motion pictures of 1936.

MR. ARMSTRONG takes the quoted part of his title from a declaration made by Premier Mussolini in October, 1930: "The struggle between two worlds can permit no compromise. Either we or they! Either their ideas or ours! Either our State or theirs!"
Plans for the Colby Winter carnival to be held on Feb. 5 and 6 have been announced by Charles T. Russ, '38, of Hartford, Conn., president of the Colby Outing Club.

District Attorney Dodge's office has made public figures on the disposition in General Sessions of the 3,492 felony indictments handed up during 1936 by the three New York County grand juries. They showed a decrease of 314 indictments from last year, but an increase of 108 in the number of jury trials, the total being 996.

Edwin Hale Lincoln, Civil War veteran, who observed his eighty-ninth birthday today, holds the offices of commander, senior and junior vice commander, adjutant and quartermaster of Rockwell Grand Army Post, of which he is the only surviving member. He pays his dues regularly as he has done for sixty years.

Although the bill for sterilization of mental detectives introduced by the New Jersey League of Women Voters last year died in committee, the social hygiene department will, according to Mrs. Theodore Robie, acting chairman, "continue its edunational campaign for the sterilization of the unfit."

The National Civil Service Reform League urged the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Junior Chamber of Commerce yesterday to warn business men throughout the nation to be on guard against "misleading legislation" soon to be introduced in State Legislatures which purport to do away with political patronage and set up merit systems.

OFF-WHITE and other light tones, much in favor for room decoration. are now appearing in furniture woods. Mahogany, walnut and other woods are made much lighter in color than they naturally are when pickled in brine or treated with chemicals. The process does not injure the grain or structural qualities of the material.
When it comes to developing corps spirit among high school boys, L. W. Fahrner thinks learning to build and fly airplanes is better than football.
Former Supreme Court Justice Burt Jay Humphrey of Queens, who was retired on Thursday because he had reached the age limit of seventy years, was sworn in yesterday as an official referee.

Construction in Chicago is recovering rapidly, Richard E. Schmidt, Building Commissioner, said today in his annual report to Mayor Kelly. Permits in 1936 numbered 1,625, with a value of $18.989,322, against 965 valued at $12,916,409 in 1935. In only two months in 1936. January and Octoher, did dollar value fail to surpass the same month in 1935, as is shown in the following table:
ABRAHAM--LEVY--Mrs. Minnie Levy anounces the marriage of her daughter, Leona, to Mr. Jerome S. Abraham. son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Abraham. on Sunday. Dec. 27. 1936.

The six apartment buildings at 2,731-37 Broadway and 250-56 West 105th Street, a plot 106.9 by 127.5 feet at the southwest corner of those thoroughfares, will be sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings on Thursday by Henry Brady in the Vesey Street rooms.

Metropolitan real estate will be sought to a greater degree in 1937 as an outlet for the investment of funds which for lack of a profitable medium have been accumulating recently, states Charles F. Noyes, realty broker, who points out that while bonds, stocks and other commodities have risen in price, real estate has experienced no appreciable advance.
Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close, of Tuckahoe, received notification today from Governor Lehman of his appointment to the Appellate Division, Second Department, in Brooklyn.

The trial of twelve men indicted in the $2,000,000 a year restaurant and cafeteria "shake-down" racket was put off yesterday until Jan. 18 by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook. It was scheduled to begin tomorrow.
Seventeen cars in a freight train were derailed and spread across the New York Central Railroad's main line near here early today. No one was hurt.

SNOW trains, headed for a day's trip into the Berkshires, the Poconos and other near-by hilly areas, or for a weekend journey to slopes further afield, have been making heavy reservations for New York's growing army of Winter sportsmen.

By breaking 91 out of a possible 100, A. Mulhaupt led in a field of twenty at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He also gained a leg on the handicap cup at 155 targets with a total of 141.
James F. Ronin, Chamber of Commerce athletic chairman, announced today that Albany had been promised first chance at the Toronto International Baseball League franchise.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Henry Kendal of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Kendal, to Fletcher P. Thornton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Parrott Thornton, also of Summit.

Kansas City Power and Light Company-Year ended Nov. 30: Net income, $4,719,742, equal to $117.99 a share on 40,000 no par shares of $6 first preferred series B stock, comparing with $3,623,385, or $90.58 a share, in the preceding year. Gross revenue, $16,783,534, against $15,641,250. November:
Passenger airliners were grounded at the Newark Airport today in the late afternoon and early evening as a result of fog and rain.

THEY went around the world in eighteen months--eighteen months and ten minutes, to be exact. And it would not surprise the reviewer to learn (if it were possible definitely to learn such things) that they had established a record:

In a New Year's letter to 3,700 alumni of the college, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, announced today that a general plan for the future development of the Stevens campus at Castle Point had been drawn and that construction of the first two buildings in the project would begin in the Spring.

Queen Mother Marie of Rumania is leaving tomorrow for England incognita as the Countess of Avala. Her grandson, Prince Tomislav, will accompany her to enter the same school near London where his brother, King Peter, spent almost a year before ascending the throne on his father's tragic death.

Alderman Edward J. Sullivan, Manhattan Democrat, announced yesterday that he would introduce tomorrow in the Board of Aldermen a resolution aimed to end the tenement housing crisis. The resolution, he said, will urge legislation for State financing of tenement rehabilitation or new housing construction.
The Montreal Canadiens spotted the Americans a first-period goal tonight, then came on with an all-round offensive to defeat the injury-riddled New Yorkers, 5-1, in a National Hockey League clash.

Premier Leeon Blum's Popular Front government has reached the end of another session without disaster either to itself or to France, and there are a great many people who are filling the air with indignant protest that this should be so.

A pronounced increase in the commerce flowing in both directions between Cuba and the United States and attributable to the reciprocal trade agreement of Sept. 3, 1934, was reported today by an interdepartmental committee consisting of representatives of the Departments of State, Commerce and Agriculture and the Tariff Commission.

The woman Mayor of Daytona Beach, defiant in the face of a Gubernatorial ouster, stood her ground behind heavily armed guards today while the man designated to replace her hurled charges of "fascism" at her administration.

An increase of 88 per cent in attendance since 1929 at the ten neighborhood and community centers affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City was announced yesterday in a report issued by Ralph E. Samuel, chairman of the committee on public information of the federation.

A fundamental principle of the Neediest Cases Fund is that all F the money contributed shall go for necessities of life and the permanent rehabilitation of the unfortunate, and not be dissipated on trivialities.

Miss Paula Hubig, 16, of 44 Bleecker Street, Newark, N. J., was instantly killed on the Moe Mountain Road near Warwick today when the coupe in which she was riding, driven by Charles Rendale, 17, also of Newark, overturned against a concrete culvert on the mountain top.
A general decline in business indices occurred during the week ended on Dec. 26 on account of the Christmas holiday, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary.
