A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Lohengrin" with Kirsten Flagstad in the leading role, the afternoon of Jan. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by members of the Vassar Club of New York to augment their scholarship fund.

Under its revised by-laws, dating from last Spring, the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will hold its first annual meeting scheduled in January at Delmonico's, Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow.
Five favorites were listed tonight for the $8,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament, richest in California's 1937 Winter schedule. Picked from 200 entries,

Funeral services for Mgr. William J. Flynn, who established Indian schools and chapels in New Mexico and Texas, were conducted today in the Sacred Heart Church here. Final absolution was given by Archbishop Edward Mooney.

Considered a record late departure for ocean-going craft, the freighters Avon Valley and Fagerstrand sailed down the St. Lawrence River today, accompanied by the icebreakers Montcalm and N. B. McLean.

The turn of the year marked a transition for two phases of the Federal Social Security Act. Unemployment Insurance: The act required employers of eight or more persons to pay a Federal tax, beginning at 1 per cent on their 1936 payrolls. In those States which had adopted unemployment insurance plans approved by the Social Security Board, however, contributions to the State insurance fund could be credited against 90 per cent of the Federal tax.

A four-and-a-half-inch rain which overflowed Town Creek forced 100 families to evacuate their homes today in a Murfreesboro low-rent area. The Red Cross established headquarters to care for refugees. S. B. Christy,

A Federal market expert looked over the list of rising prices at the East Buffalo stockyards tonight and expressed the opinion men that the pocketbooks of housewives will feel the pinch of rising meat prices early in 1937.

Remarkable progress has been made in recent years in converting the Chinese to Catholicism, Bishop James E. Walsh, superior general of the Maryknoll Foreign Mission Society, reported last week at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Mount St. Mary's Alumni Association at the Waldorf-Astonria.

Canadians may look to 1937 for continuance of the economic improvement that enabled them to emerge from 1936 more prosperous than at any time since the beginning of the depression, business and industrial authorities suggested today in the annual commercial and financial review of The Montreal Gazette.
Ten deputy commissioners and clerks received a new year's present today when the City Council at a special meeting voted them the restoration of normal salaries.
THE Postoffice Department's program for 1937 will make the coming year one of the busiest on record so far as the issuance of new stamps is concerned.

The social pace of Washington is distinctly accelerated these days, with the White House swinging into its six weeks' program of receptions, teas, musicales and dinners; the return of officials, hurrying to establish themselves before the opening of Congress, and the late arrival of many of the diplomats.
After four years of spectacular success Adolf Hitler finds himself faced at the start of the year with a definite challenge to his program of German expansion as outlined in his book "Mein Kampf."

The Fred F. French Management Company, is preparing to erect a 285-foot outdoor ski slide over the tennis courts at East Forty-first Street and Prospect Place, for the use of the tenants in Tudor City. The plans have been prepared by the Chesebro-Whitman Company, which constructed the Madison Square Garden ski slide for the Winter Show a few weeks ago.
W. Lowell Robertson, general manager of the Robertson Steel and Iron Company and president of the Hill Brown Fence Company, died today after a brief illness. He was 44 years old.

Commenting on the action taken by the United States Golf Association in limiting the number of clubs to fourteen, John G. Jackson, president of the organization, pointed out advantages to the game that he believed would follow the ruling.

AS reported in these columns some weeks ago, the American Artists Congress opened simultaneously in thirty cities an Exhibition composed of 100 prints by as many artists, the collection carrying this title: "America Tolay."

The development of schools in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn in the fifteen years since Bishop Thomas E. Molloy became head of the diocese is reviewed in a recent report of Mgr. Joseph V. S. McClancy, diocesan school superintendent. Sixty-four new school buildings have been constructed, according to the report.

A single breaker may recede, but the tide is evidently coming in," may be said of the upward movement of the Neediest Cases Fund. Last year the turn came in the totals that had been ebbing since 1930.
The 112th Field Artillery Polo Club scored a decisive victory over the Camden Polo Club in the East Orange Armory tonight, 17-8.

Andrew W. Mellon's art collection comprises about seventy paintings. all of exceptional quality, which he has assembled in the last thirtyfive years, according to his agents, M. Knoedler Co., Inc., New York art dealers.

THE Schola Cantorum, under the leadership of Hugh Ross, continues the tradition inaugurated so fruitfully by the late Kurt Schindler of refusing to follow the hackneyed choral repertory, and constantly enriching our acquaintance with great music by producing important novelties of music new and old.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets came through with a 4-1 victory over the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in an Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League game tonight. Red Sherwood tallied two goals for the Smoky City sextet and Grant and Bessone each chalked up a single marker. Papike scored the loan goal for the Sea Gulls.

Professor Aminta Milani, the physician who has been in sole charge of the health of Pope Pius since he took to his bed on Dec. 4, showed himself distinctly optimistic in speaking to this correspondent tonight in the first interview he has granted to the press.

A FTER a recent visit to Tropical Park at Coral Gables, Fla., this observer is willing to admit that he knows all too little about how horses can run, but, even so, the news that Jesse Owens had outrun a horse in Cuba caused a moderate amount of surprise in this corner.

THE magic of the Low Country, the rice coast of South Carolina and Georgia has been captured with rare beauty and fidelity in the paintings of Alice R. Huger Smith. Her water-colors of sea-island beaches, of sea marshes, of black waters in cypress swamps, and of Carolina gardens have been one of the glories of her State,

The three-mile extension of the Hutchinson River Parkway from Westchester Avenue to King Street, which cost the State about $1,000,000 for construction and Westchester County about $600,000 for land acquisition, probably will be opened for traffic on or about Jan. 15, Superintendent Herman Merkel of the Westchester County Park Commission announced today.

Frankie Parker, the nation's second ranking tennis player, combined great backhand stroking and deftly placed baseline shots to defeat Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, 7--5, 6--2, 7--5, in the final of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today.

Smart jumping performances characterized the seventh new year indoor horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, held today in the club's riding ring. Both of the open events required two jump-offs with the bars raised eventually to 4 feet 10 inches. Some smart timber-topping also marked the hunter classes.

Miss Elizabeth Mae Langford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ward Langford of Gastonia, N. C., was married tonight to Winthrop Davenport, son of former Representative and Mrs. Frederick Morgan Davenport of Clinton, N. Y., at the latter's home here.

Scoring with impressive regularity, especially in the final two periods, the First Division trio downed the New York A. C., 12 1/2 to 6, at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night and moved into a tie for first place in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League competition.
The list of the Stella Polaris, leaving today for her second cruise to the West Indies, Bermuda. Kingston, Havana and Nassau, includes:
A group of 132 etchings by Anders Zorn, from the private collection of Stanton Griffis of this city, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries on Friday evening.
Two specialty events next week will usher in the 1937 dog show year. Both the American Spaniel Club and the Pekingese Club of America will hold their annual competitions a week from tomorrow.

Cleveland's Falcons participated in their seventh consecutive overtime game tonight by deadlocking, 0 to 0, with the Springfield Indians in an International-American League hockey game. It was also the seventh tie game on Springfield's record.

BASED on what he terms "the great strides in development work during 1936," O. B. Hanson, chief engineer of the National Broadcasting Company, forecasts that 1937 holds forth a number of prospects of which television is paramount.

A goal by Vito Genchi, on a long shot that was more of a defensive gesture than a scoring attempt, enabled the New Utrecht High School sextet to vanquish Brooklyn Tech, 1 to 0, to give the Green and White skaters undisputed possession of first place in the city P. S. A. L. hockey tournament as play in the second round of the annual competition got under way at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday.
President Eamon de Valera, who has suffered from severe eye trouble, announced today he would go to Zurich, Switzerland, to consult Dr. Alfred Vogt.
New Year's resolutions are getting harder and harder to keep. Once upon a time it was simply a case of human frailty. A man gave up cigars on

Colonel Pierre Lorillard Jr. will not be a candidate for re-election as president of the American Horse Show Association, it was learned yesterday through Arthur Naul, assistant secretary of the association.

ABELSON--Jacob, on Saturday, Jan. 2, beloved husband of Bertha and loving father of Dr. Harry E. and Dr. Josephine M. Riesner and Rebecca; dear brother of Dr. Paul Abelson, Frieda Loewenstein and Sophie Prager. Funeral from his late residence, 35 Wegman Parkway, Jersey City, on Sunday, Jan. 3, at 1 P. M. Interment at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island.
Dr. Robert Cunningham Myles, physician and inventor of several types of surgical instruments for use in eye, ear, nose and throat treatment, died Friday at his home, 1,075 Park Avenue.

The State Department today announced that it found that no grounds existed for a diplomatic protest to Mexico on the score that American planes recently sold to Mexico might have been trans-shipped to Spain.
The New England Golf Association has awarded its 1937 amateur championship to Ekwanok, Manchester, Vt., according to word received from George R. McKee, Vermont member of the board.

The current flurry of sneezes, sniffles and chills has wafted additional business to the city's 3,700 drug stores-and just in time, too, with the end of the Christmas rush on their cosmetic, cigar and candy counters.

Judge J. Boyd Sears of the Thirteenth Judicial Circuit of Virginia, a former State Senator and of a family prominent in the social life of Tidewater, Va., died yesterday at the residence of his sister, Mrs. M. B. Garnett, near here. He was 67.

WARS within wars are being fought on Spanish soil today. There is a Spanish civil war; there are German and Italian civil wars on a minor scale; there is a sort of European war of Germany and Italy against Russia;

More than 1,000 concerts were given in hospitals and other public institutions in New York by musicians of the WPA Federal Music Project last year. It is estimated that 85,000 patients and inmates heard these concerts.

Alignments in the nursing profession of factions for and against either of two bills to be submitted during the session of the Legislature at Albany, opening Tuesday, are inevitable from the nature of the measures. Both refer to standards under which nurses may work in the State.

Judging from the large subscription already received, much interest is being evidenced in the special performance of "The Flying Dutchman," in which Kirsten Flagstad will make her debut as Senta, Thursday afternoon at the Metro-. politan Opera House for the benefit of the Florence Crittenton League.

Miss Catherine Deacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Harold Deacon of Merion, was married this afternoon to Ralph William Rymer, son of Mrs. W. Worbinson Rymer of Middletown, Conn., and of R. W. Rymer of Scranton.

Catastrophe looms for the cattlemen of Western North America if the Argentine Sanitary Convention is ratified by the United States, according to Albert K. Mitchell, president of the American National Livestock Association.

PARIS. THE month of November in Paris has offered a goodly harvest of interesting musical programs; indeed, at times a profusion of them. Four orchestral concerts take place every Saturday and five each Sunday.

Samples of more than 100,000 garments being made by the Trade Union Committee to Manufacture Clothing for Spain, will be presented to Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, at a meeting tomorrow evening at the Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by S. Baron, secretary of the United Spanish Societies.
The Manhattan building records for 1936 showed only one plan for the erection of a single-family home--a small residence at 308 West 107th Street, estimated to cost $3,500.

THE opening of Congress marks the beginning of the Winter tourist season in Washington in a year where the order of events has been somewhat changed by the effect of the Norris amendment, which eliminated the "lame duck" session and advanced the date of the inauguration.

Reuben Fine of New York and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, first and second, respectively, in the international masters' tournament at the annual Christmas congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, left the field far behind today as they won their games in the sixth round.

George H. Hartman of Chicago will defend his title in the twentyninth annual tournament of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests, which is to be staged over the Palm Beach Country Club course from Jan. 16 to 23.

The winners of the 1936 fishing contest of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association will receive their prizes at a meeting of the association in East View High School, White Plains, on Tuesday night.
A veritable parade of heavyweight wrestlers is scheduled for tomorrow night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory under the direction of Promoter Jack Curley.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $20,000. To Helena Van Kortlandt Cammann, widow, executrix, 52 E. 92d St., $25,000. life estate in $150,000 trust and residue; Robert Livingston Cammann, son, executor, same address, real estate and remainder interest in residue; Church of the Holy Redeemer, Merrick, L. I., $8,000 trust. G. Forrest Butterworth Jr Rve N. Y.. executor.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Elisabeth Smyth, daughter of Judge and Mrs. George W. Smyth of Crestwood, Yonkers, N. Y., to Warren w E. Hendrickson, son of Mr. and a Mrs. Burt E. Hendrickson of Woodhaven L.I.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Gould Madison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Madison, to James Frederick Ellis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Ellis, took place this evening at Grace and St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Reginald Mallett performed the ceremonv.

The building containing fifty apartments and eight stores at 77 Cooper Street, corner of 207th Street, was sold by the Trans-Boro Management Corporation (Leon and Harry Minskoff, builders) to Watson Estates, Inc., Joseph Schultz, president.
RUTH DRAPER--Miss Draper will give performances this evening at the Guild Theatre and Thursday afternoon at the Morosco.
The steady upward trend in building work in Manhattan was reflected in the increased number of building plans filed in this borough during the past year.

FOR many years Mr. N. C. Wyeth, the illustrator, has studied and admired Henry Thoreau. He knows Concord, its old houses and surrounding countryside as he does the inside of his hat, so his paintings,

THE season's at the half, and Max Gordon has had enough of it. "Othello," arriving this Tuesday night, is his last show of the September-to-June semester. Come Jan. 20, he will be off to Hollywood for a month, then Florida, then Europe, and somewhere on the way he hopes to recover his health, which has not been good.

Members of the Carroll Club will hold their annual communion breakfast next Sunday at the Biltmore Hotel after a 9 o'clock mass celebrated by Cardinal Hayes at St. Patrick's Cathedral, when they will receive communion in a body.
On every front 1936 has marked solid gains for aeronautics. New records for altitude and in certain speed categories were important as indications of technical progress.

Charles F. Noyes, chairman of the advisory committee on real estate for the World's Fair of 1939, has named Irving I. Rosenbaum as executive vice president of the committee, which includes about 300 real estate men of the metropolitan district aiding in the plans for the exposition.

Building construction in many parts of the Southern States has been very active recently, particularly in Texas and the northern areas of Louisiana, points out Moise H. Goldstein of New Orleans, director of the American Institute of Architects for the Gulf States division.

Mrs. Percy V. Pennybacker of Austin, Texas, a past president of the GeneralFederation of Women's Clubs, will arrive in New York on Tuesday to complete arrangements for an epochal departure in the history of the Chautauqua Woman's Club, of which she is president.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., has reduced prices of nickel in Europe to [Pound]180 to [Pound]185 a long ton, depending on quantity, as of Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by Robert C. Stanley, president.

The fire-blackened hulk of an abandoned oil tanker yielded two bodies this afternoon, confirming fears that five men perished in an explosion while salvaging its valuable gasoline cargo far out in upper Lake Michigan.

Heralded as one of the strongest sextets in Harvard's history, the Crimson hockey team made a clean sweep of its three-game series with the hard-fighting Clarkson Tech skaters by winning the final match of their holiday meetings tonight.

WHEN the lights eventually go down in the Manhattan Opera House tomorrow evening and the longawaited premiere of "The Eternal Road" begins, there will arrive at its ultimate climax a saga of the theatre which is--though less cosmic in import--quite as fabulous as the epic traffic upon the stage.

In the hope that a peace conference of world-wide scope, patterned on the one recently concluded at Buenos Aires for the Western Hemisphere, will be called within the year, the People's Mandate to Governments to End War has renewed its campaign for signatures to its petition to be presented at that time.

The importance of the Atlantic Coast shipyards in the national construction program has been greatly enhanced in recent months, according to a survey published yesterday by Marine Engineering and Shipping Review.

HOLLYWOOD keeps creeping into the music news, and the day may come when it may cast as large a shadow on tonal business as it does on the stage. Latest advices from the film center are that a moving picture version of "Madame Butterfly" is being considered by Paramount.

Gust Christian, 6 feet 3 and 203 pounds, ate these things to win a wager: Four and a half pounds of fried pork liver, two pork chops, two bowls of soup, a can of corn, several helpings of potatoes, six cookies and nine large slices of bread. He also drank nine cups of coffee.

Out of the full and wide experience that has crowded her seventyeight years, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt reiterated yesterday as an anniversary message to the women of the nation, her credo that another century of consistent education of the nations will have to intervene before her fervent hope of world peace can be realized.

Joseph Clark Baldwin. former State Senator. will be the speaker at a meeting of the West End Association on Tuesday night in the office of Charles Griffiths Moses, 119 W. 57th St. He will discuss the plans for the World's Fair of 1939.

The payroll of the City of New York, which now approximates $200,000,000 a year, amounted to $124,484.11 in 1833, according to records discovered in the Municipal Building by the archivists for the Works Progress Administration.

The residence at 406 North Fulton Avenue, Mount Vernon, has been sold by the New York Teachers Retirement System to Mrs. Hannah K. Schwarts of New York City through Harry Levy, broker. The house occupies a plot 185 by 135 feet containing four master bedrooms, three baths, a large library and maids' rooms. It was held at $60,000.

Mrs. David C. Johnson will give a luncheon tomorrow at the Rockefeller Luncheon Club for members o fher committee on arrangements for the bridge party to be held Wednesday at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, for the benefit of Willoughby House Settlement, 97 Lawrence Street, Brooklyn.
FIVE giants of a past age, reproduced in steel and concreate on ground they once trod in quest of plant food, will soon look down from Hangman's Hill near here on some of the wonders of the present.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Betty Stern of the Windsor, daughter of Mrs. M. Leon Stern of Savannah, Ga., and Jacksonville, Fla., and the late Mr. Stern, to Paul J. Buechler of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max J. Buechler of Bridgeport, Conn.

For the first time since before Christmas the fishing smacks that operate up and down the Atlantic Coast are bringing heavy catches to Fulton Market. Their arrival is timely, for New York consumersafter two weeks of over-rich and spicy diet-are ready and willing to eat simple food for a change.

A SYSTEM of posted speed limits related to conditions on each stretch of highway in the State, instead of the present no-limit speed law for motorists on the open road, is to be advocated in the coming session of the Michigan State Legislature by the State Safety Council, formed to decrease traffic accidents.

BEATRICE LILLIE, currently appearing in the Broadway production, "The Show Is On," has been signed to replace Fannie Brice, now touring in the Ziegfeld Follies, as star of the "Revue de Paree" broadcast, on Wednesday nights at 8 o'clock over WJZ. Miss Lillie, whose first appearance on the program is scheduled for Jan. 6, will offer her unusual style of musical monologues and word caricatures.

Radcliffe has followed the lead of many other Eastern women's colleges in establishing a well-organized outing club in connection with the regular athletic association activities. Members can get off into the country for week-end hiking, camping and canoeing trips and, right at this season, for skiing treks.

The thirteenth annual benefit for the Episcopal Actors Guild of America will be the performance of "The Wingless Victory" on Tuesday night at the Empire Theatre. In extending aid to members of the theatrical profession, the Guild works in close cooperation with the Catholic Actors Guild, the Jewish Theatrical Guild and the Actors Fund of America.

As conservator for the Pacific Life Insurance Company, Samuel Carpenter, state insurance commissioner, filed suit today for recovery of $990,000 from George I. Cochran, former president of the company, and five former directors.
Abraham Gridley, District Attorney of Yates County for three terms beginning in 1904, died yesterday of pneumonia at the age of 85. He had been an attorney for sixty-six years.

Joseph H. Nassoit, president of the Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation, yesterday expressed the belief apartment buildings would be a feature of investment purchases during the coming year. "There has been a steady upward movement in realty bonds over the past two years," said Mr. Nassoit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Carleton Brown of New York University is quoted as telling the members of the Modern Language Association of America that in many of the attacks on the castle of education "the foreign label is easily discernible."
A taxicab operated by Cornelius O'Connor, 47, went astray amid dense fog and struck a fire plug early today, and that was only the beginning.
FOUR years ago a taciturn, intensely alert man carrying a card index of every stage and screen player of the past twenty-five years in his head went out to Hollywood on a vacation.

BOYS of 10 to 14, and, one suspects, older members of the family, who open this tale of strange adventure on the Spanish coast will probably sit, immovable and unhearing, until its final page is turned. Geoffrey Household. apparently a newcomer in the field of juvenile fiction, can spin a yarn as weird as any conceived by Jules Verne with a disarming plausibility, in a crisp and fluent style far superior to the average thriller.

Dr. William T. Corlett, professor emeritus of the School of Medicine of Western Reserve University, has furnished and endowed a study in the Cleveland Medical Library dedicated to research in dermatology and syphilology.

THERE were giants in America in the old days. West of the Alleghanies, when the Republic was new, the men of the frontier strode through the backwoods, across the plains, over mountains, with mighty steps, leaving behind them the tremendous yarns and echoes of the great, gusty laughter that are America's peculiar heritage.

Dr. Glenn Frank's battle to retain the presidency of the University of Wisconsin moved today to a showdown as Harold M. Wilkie. president of the Board of Regents, served "fair warning" - on Dr. Frank that he would not tolerate delay in the ouster proceedings scheduled to open Wednesday.

Organ recital by Dr. Charles M. Courboin: WOR, 9-9:30 A. M. To Thee I Cry, Lord Jesus Christ Bach In Thee Is Joy Bach Adagio from Concerto No. 10 Handel Allegro, Concerto No. 2 Handel Le Carillon de Cythere Couperin Largo, "Xerxes" Handel

LEADERS of the radio industry, who at this season of the year are invited to look into the crystal ball of science and tell what they see ahead for the new year, say that they have only to look back at the boom year, 1936, to confidently predict greater expansion and magic in 1937.

AMERICAN all-wave listeners have a good long-distance goal to "shoot" for at this season of the year in station VQ7LO, British East Africa, which has been heard during the past two weeks along the Eastern seaboard at 2:30 P. M., on the 6,085 kilocycle channel.

Members of the younger set were honored this evening at two dances. The Westchester Assembly dinner dance at the Apawamis Club here attracted many young persons from Rye, Scarsdale, Pelham and Bronxville.

The St. Paul's School hockey team from Concord, N. H., trounced Gilman Country School tonight, 8--0. The boys from the Northern school took complete control of matters from bell to bell, Franchot scoring three goals.

The Federal Reserve System's credit policy underwent an important change in direction last year. Whereas for the three preceding years the efforts of the authorities had been concentrated upon making possible and stimulating credit expansion, last year the system began to prepare for restrictive measures to control a possible boom.
The Greek Government today issued an official statement regarding the non-aggression pact now being negotiated between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, to which there is not the slightest objection here.

Mrs. Ella M. Romig, who went to Alaska on her wedding trip with her husband, Dr. Joseph H. Romig, forty years ago and remained as a medical missionary of the Moravian Church, died at her home in Anchorage, Alaska, last night, according to word received here today. Her husband is in the government medical service there.

Harvard's undergraduate body of 3,000 students will be represented by June by at least ten publications and will find itself with more newspapers and magazines per capital than almost any other similar unit in the world.

The Women's College of Middlebury will be represented in regular Winter sports activities outside of the usual program at the Middlebury Winter Carnival when its competitors take part in the Skidmore Winter Carnival on Friday and Saturday.

Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, although its classes are organized on a yearly basis, has made special arrangements for the entrance of a February freshman group this coming semester, it was announced yesteday by Joseph T. Shipley, secretary of the faculty.

Those who read the newspapers casually must by this time have come to the conclusion that periodically devils with sharp-pronged pitchforks pry into the WPA Federal Theatre. The publicity which the showshop on the dole achieves is seasonal, for a little over a year ago Elmer Rice, then director for New York, coined his historic remark:
Yachtsmen will sail from New London, Conn., on June 27 in a 475mile ocean race to Gibson Island in the Chesapeake Bay near here.
The Golden Panthers of Pittsburgh, conquerors of Washington in the Rose Bowl, looked over the calendar today and promised to come back next New Year's Day.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Rice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Rice of Mount Vernon, to Roland F. Roche, son of Mrs. John J. Roche, also of Mount Vernon, took place this morning at St. Catherine's Church here.

Resuits of research to develop knowledge of fundamental facts of chemical reactions were discussed at today's final session of the American Chemical Society symposium on molecular structure at Princeton University.
How farmers have been trained as auxiliary weather observers was related before the Association of American Geographers at its final sessions here today.

Mayor and Mrs. Oscar P. Myers of Boonton gave a supper dance tonight for their daughter Barbara at the Mountain Lakes Club. Miss Myers, a graduate of Centenary Junior College at Hackettstown and now a sophomore at the Connecticut College for Women, wore a gown of powder blue brocade and carried an old-fashioned bouquet. Her mother received with her.

Mrs. Maxwell Lester of 35 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, will give a tea at her home tomorrow for the membets of the annual benefit committee and the executive board of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum.
AS the wave of interest in Winter sports reaches new heights many thousands of Americans are discovering that it is as much fun to slide down a mountain in January as it is to climb it in July.

The Gran Chaco peace negotiations were resumed this week under the routine conciliation procedure sponsored by six American mediating nations: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru, the United States and Uruguay.

New York City is on the verge of a shortage of low-rental housing that many observers fear may prove as grave as that of 1921, when the State Legislature was called upon to pass emergency rent laws to save thousands from becoming homeless.

The Duffy Florals of Chicago will provide the opposition for Kate Smith's undefeated Celtics and Barney Sedran's Whirlwind five will face a strong rival in the Philadelphia Hebrew quintet in the professional basketball double-header at the New York Hippodrome tonight.

To the Miusic Editor: Last night I listened to Richard Wagner's ageless music in "Tristan und Isolde." This morning I read the fine appraisal by Mr. Downes in THE NEW YORK TIMES. I wonder where Mr. Downes sat. If his seat had been near mine he would have had several other things to chronicle.

Spain might be called the classic land of foreign intervention. In his interesting article in the last number of Foreign Affairs, Professor PHILIP JESSUP recounts the extraordinary number of times. during the past two hundred years, that Spain has been threatened with intervention or actually suffered it.

RADIO and the telephone strengthened their scientific alliance in 1936, for as both arts develop from year to year it is seen that they have much in common, although one holds messages to a wire and the other scatters them in space.
Franklin Mittau, podiatrist and one of the twenty-one justices of the peace elected in November, is making a valiant effort to revive the dying "marriage business" in Stamford.

A gang of eight or nine robbers, who subsequently killed one of their number in a quarrel over the loot, terrorized more than one hundred customers and clerks in the store of Barney's Clothes, Inc., 111 Seventh Avenue, at about 8 o'clock last night, and escaped with cash and jewelry estimated at more than $22,000.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Washington, daughter of Mrs. Henry A. Washington of 1,044 Madison Avenue, and the late Mr. Washington, to Lucius Elverton Robertson, son of Mrs. H. P. Robertson of Jamestown, N. Y., and the late Mr. Robertson, has been announced by her mother.
The International Shoe Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $8,416,927 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Seldom in the history of New York City have the possibilities been brighter for excellent investments in real estate, declares Roland F. Elliman, vice president of the firm of Douglas L. Elliman Co. Many properties, he points out, may still be purchased at less than their intrinsic worth.

LITTLE KNOWN HISTORY OF NEWARK. DEL., AND ITS ENVIRONS. By Francis A. Cooch. 8vo. Newark. Del.: The Press of the Kells. Sketches in local history. DEATH VALLEY PROSPECTORS. By Dane Coolidge. 12mo. New York: E. P. Dutton Co. $2.50. A history of the men of Death Valley.

Mr. and Mrs. Irving F. Ridlon of Wakefield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Elizabeth Ridlon, to Harry Rathbun Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Harry Jackson of Plandome, L. I.

CHIANG KAI-SHEK has often startied China and the world. His recent kidnapping by Chang Hsuehliang and his release after two weeks of mysterious negotiations were the latest in a series of stirring events that began ten years ago when he occupied Nanking after a revolutionary march from Canton. Since then, by fair means and. according to his critics, means not so fair.

Establishment of a department of nursing at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president. The degree of Bachelor of Science will be conferred for the first time on nursing graduates in 1939.

Mrs. June Leonard Raymond of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Leonard and widow of Charles M. Raymond of ew York and California, was married to Ira Barrows of 860 Park Avenue yesterday at noon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, performed the ceremony.

Strikes in the basic industries occupy both the background and foreground of national affairs as the Seventy-fifth Congress assembles for its opening session next Tuesday. Many other problems confront the lawmakers and the President. But every one of them is fundamentally affected by the causes and possible consequences of the strikes.
Mickey Cochrane, vice president and manager of the Tigers, announced today the Spring exhibition schedule of his team.

Clarification and revision. of anti-trust statutes to facilitate voluntary agreements covering interstate business and industry which would eliminate "obviously unfair trade practices" was urged today by Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in the first concrete proposal from an official source for carrying out President Roosevelt's expressed determination to abolish child labor and sweatshop wages and hours.

Waclaw O. Gorski, writer on Polish affairs and stepson of Ignace Jan Paderewski, died on Thursday at Bellevue Hospital of pneumonia. He was 59 years old and lived at 37-25 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
The engagement of $3,563,000 of gold abroad--$2,268,000 in England and $1,295,000 in India--for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
THE Seventy-fifth Congress assembles next Tuesday for the somewhat cloudy business of registering the people's will in the laws of the Republic.

Skidmore College will hold a three-day Winter Carnival here beginning Friday. Mirabelle Vinson, Dorothy Hoyt and Otto Schneibs will give demonstrations, and guests from Barnard, Vassar, Mount Holyoke, Smith, Union, Dartmouth, Colgate, Middlebury, Williams and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute will participate in the activities.

Homer J. Whitman, active in the development of secondary schools, died at his home here today of a heart ailment at the age of 70. He had served as Superintendent of Schools at Vineland, N. J.; Lewis, Del.; Ardmore and Altoona. Pa., and Nyack.

Miss Emily Lucretia Comstock, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Comstock of this place, was married here to Richard Anthony Duff of Schenectady, son of Dr. and Mrs. Cary E. Duff of Lawrenceville, Ill., this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Archie A. Comstock, her uncle and aunt.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Sara Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar William Heller of this city and Rumson, to Joseph F. Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell G. Lord, also of Newark.

Mosaic depictions of fish, uncovered in Antioch by the international expedition carrying on the excavating of that city, were today definitely identified by two members of the Princeton University, biology department as accurate representations of Mediterranean fish.
New England's first camp for unemployed women will open Monday at Chepachet, Ralph G. Winterbottam, a director of the National Youth Administration, announced today.

Construction budgets of $41,000,000 for operating companies in the Commonwealth and Southern group of public utility companies in 1937 were revealed yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie, president of the corporation, in a statement contrasting the situation of subsidiaries operating in the area of the Tennessee Valley Authority with that of other affiliates operating in North Central States.
After learning a few cultural essentials the indoor gardener can easily prolong the life of the array of berries and blossoms that brighten holiday gift plants.

Ellsworth Vines, world's professional tennis champion, arrived here from Pasadena, Calif., yesterday for his match with Fred Perry of Great Britain, the world's amateur champion, at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

On its last Sunday the 1936 annual appeal for the Neediest Cases of all New York reached a grand total of $263,879.98 today, following the receipt yesterday of forty-three new contributions, amounting to $742.

The body of Samuel Wheaton, 60 years old, a Negro, of 139 Mount Vernon Street, was found late this afternoon lying in a large piece of horizontal pipe in the yard of the Public Service Company plant here.

A holiday greeting for Mayor La Guardia from Mary Williams, 12 years old, of 165 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, was a postscript to a letter received last week by Whitfield C. Coates, president of the South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association.

Nick Pastore of Greenpoint gained the decision over Johnny Horstmann, East Side battler, in the feature eight-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove before 2,500 persons last night. Each weighed 143 pounds.

MIAMI, Fla.--Tennis, which since the opening of the Winter season in the greater Miami area has been topped by golf in the field of major sport events, comes into its own tomorrow with the opening of the fifth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament to be played on the courts of the Miami Biltmore Country Club during the remainder of the week and through next Sunday.

Every major college basketball team in the city will swing into action during the coming week with two more double-headers and several single games listed. The first of the twin bills will be held on Tuesday at the Hippodrome and the second on Saturday at Madison Square Garden.
New Year's Eve celebrations fell into two categories, watch night services at St. Paul's and other churches and special programs of gayety at every hotel and restaurant.

A campaign for a permanent workers' education program as a "non-relief" project of the government is being launched by American labor forces. A $4,000,000 bill for a four-year experiment to that end is being drafted for introduction into the next Congress.

PLAYGOING, says John Mason Brown, is, or ought to be, a matter of "multiple enjoyment." In writing this book, the critic's purpose has not been to lay down rules but to make suggestions which may increase that enjoyment on the part of the audience. Complete pleasure in the theatre, he sums up, is made possible only by complete awareness.

That some form of design protection legislation will be enacted at the session of Congress about to open is regarded as practically certain in trade circles here. During the last two years various forms of copyright or patent protection for designs have been considered by Congress, but have been dropped, due to opposition from varied quarters, including retailers who have felt that the measures proposed placed an undue burden upon them.

Rehabilitation loans totaling nearly $1,000,000 have been made to 1,368 New York State farm families by the Rural Resettlement Administration in its first full year, Mrs. Dorothy M. Beck, regional director for eleven Northeastern States, said today.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sumner Joy of this city, to Oliver Mecartney Willard, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Patten Willard of San Francisco, has been announced by her parents.
THE recent granting to Henry Ford of two patents relating to rear engine cars has stimulated new interest in a subject which, though very much alive, has been largely dormant for some months past.

The situation in Europe is complicated by a colonial issue. According to a declaration by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, "the future of European peace" depends on satisfying Germany's demand for the return of the oversea possessions which she lost during the war.

With a substantial part of the assorted snow removal machines that the city bought at his behest already delivered, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey looked forward yesterday to the first real snowfall of the season with confidence that he and his men will be able to do an adequate snow removal job.

Beginning what he expects will be one of the busiest years of his exciting career, Lou Ambers, world's lightweight champion, will clamber into the ring at Madison Square Garden Friday night for a tenround battle with Enrico Venturi, Italian, who is undefeated in twelve ring engagements since coming to this country.

In a recent report on native customs, Sir Hubert Murray, Lieutenant Governor of Papua, or British New Guinea, lying north of Australia, asserted that some Papuan girls accept marriage only when suitors accompany offers with the fingers of defeated warriors.

While the year 1936 witnessed a remarkable rise in home-building activity in scores of suburban communities throughout Long Island, the coming year, in the opinion of Russell Clark of the Health Homes Building Corporation, Seaford, L. I., will doubtless show increases in home production of from 50 per cent to even 100 per cent above the 1936 total.

Miss Helen Hayes and Postmaster General James A. Farley, as two of the leading residents of Rockland County, yesterday assisted in launching the final drive to obtain money for the completion of the $400,000 building fund of the Good Samaritan Hospital at Suffern.

With three of its components higher, three lower and one unchanged, THE NEw YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined for the week ended Dec. 26 to 109.6 from 110.5, the revised figure for the previous week. For the corresponding week last year it was 95.3.

James (Sunny Jim) Bottomley, Browns' first baseman who last Summer was talking about retiring from baseball, has changed his mind and said today he will report to the San Antonio Spring training camp ahead of the regular squad.

DUBLIN. THE atmosphere of Irish literary circles has been galvanized recently by a recrudescence of that old bogy of literature--censorship. Four Irish novels have been banned in a batch, on the usual ground that "they are in their general tendency indecent."

When Governor Lehman, after announcing last Spring that he did not want a third term, changed his mind under pressure from Washington, there arose rumors that he might resign soon after being re-elected. At his third inauguration last Friday the Governor set those rumors at rest.

Acceptance by Mrs. Calvin Coolidge of an invitation to be sponsor for the sixteenth annual luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club, on Jan. 16 at the Hotel Astor, completes a quartet of four wives of former Presidents of the United States who will head that list. The other three are Mrs.
Mr. and Mrs. John Ansbro of 254 Eighty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathlyn Frances Ansbro, to Edward Vanuxem Wurts Jr.

WHETHER Boston's Back Bay Brahmins of an earlier decade were, as they seemed sometimes to believe, a breed apart; or whether, as John P. Marquand, in this finely perceptive novel, appears to hold, their aloofness was a facade which they interposed between themselves and the Untouchables outside the pale, their insistence on caste was nevertheless a definitely established social Dhenomenon of the time.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Merrick of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Eugenia Merrick, to John J. Dougherty, son of James Dougherty of Mount Carmel, Pa.

Slumping to the extent of nine strokes over his performance on the first eighteen holes yesterday, Tony Manero, the 1936 National Open champion, slipped back to second place, behind Ray Mangrum of Dayton, Ohio, as the half-way mark was reached today in the seventy-twohole Miami open tournament at the Miami Springs Golf Club.
Paul Scheffer, the German journalist who is perhaps the best known abroad, ceased to be editor-in-chief of the Berliner Tageblatt today. He will go to Washington to represent it there.

Sharp advances in livestock prices in the last month have increased the total value of animals still on farms to well over $250,000,000, it was estimated at the stockyards today. Buyers have this week paid an average of $3 a head more for steers than a month ago, while hogs averaged $2.50 a head higher; lambs, almost $1 higher, and calves, $3 higher.

Senator Holt, youthful West Virginia Democrat, warned today that he would fight back if his party in the Senate "declares war" on him for opposing the re-election of a Democratic colleague and conferring during the Presidential campaign with Governor Landon.

From the furthest depths of depression to a vantage point of prosperity is the experience within the past year of this city of approximately 75,000 population, which looks to the new year for its greatest industrial activity since war days.
THE White Motor Company is entering 1937 with the addition of a new line of trucks priced under $1,000 a unit, it was announced last week by Robert F. Black, president.

Sharp gains this year in factory and commercial building as well as in new home construction have been forecast by Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation. An increase of 45 to 55 per cent in commercial and factory building expenditures was predicted by him.

Present indications show that Bermuda may license as many as 17,000 bicycles in 1937 for a population of approximately 30,000. Last year the total was 16,500, an increase from the former year of about 2,500.

Miss Mary Tefft Schwarz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tefft Schwarz of Merion, Pa., was married this afternoon to John Haden White 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwood White of Old Greenwich, Conn., in St. Paul's Memorial Church, Overbrook, by the rector, the Rev. Charles E. Snowden.

Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott announced yesterday that the total amount of revenue taken in at the Brooklyn Postoffice for the year 1936 was $8,455,662, a 6 per cent gain over the amount for 1935, which was $7,974,674.

A preview of the annual exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today will be held Friday afternoon at W. and J. Sloane's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. The exhibition will be opened to the public the morning of Jan. 11 and will continue through Jan. 23. Proceeds will be donated to the philanthropic activities of the New York Association for the Blind, Lighthouse No.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Webb Bucklin, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Dailey Bucklin of this city and the late Mr. Bucklin, to John Ellsworth Flemming Jr. of Summit, N. J., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John E. Flemming of Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Sarah Johnson Forsyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Forsyth of Esmont, Albemarle County, Va., to Larned Donaldson Randolph, son of Mrs. George A. Randolph of Estouteville, Keene, Albemarle County, Va., and Washington, D. C., and of the late Mr. Randolph.
Mr. and Mrs. William Staudenmaier have announced the engagement of their daughter, Norma, to Robert Soper Jr. Both are dormer students of Huntington High School.

Students at Lehigh University have become camera conscious this year with the organization of a course in photography in connection with the journalism instruction provided for the student newspaper, The Brown and White. The class has had to be divided into two sections.

Before leaving the Netherlands for England, Reuben Fine of New York, upon whose young and slight figure the international spotlight of chess publicity now is beating fiercely at Hastings, where he is engaged in so close a race for first prize with Dr. Alexander Alekhine, the ex-champion of the world, engaged in an exhibition tour which took him to most of the outstanding chess centers of the country.
Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity unexpectedly increased sharply over the preceding week. Calling of large amounts of public utility bonds featured the notices.
James A. Flaherty, attorney and one of the country's best known Catholic laymen, died of pneumonia at his home here this evening in his eighty-fourth year.
Behind the British-Italian agreement signed in Rome today there lies much more than will appear in the text of the declaration to be published tomorrow evening.
Harold T. Donaldson of Lansing, Mich., president of the United States Building and Loan League, predicted today that home building in 1937 would increase as much as it did in 1936.
Interest in herb gardening has been growing rapidly in the last few seasons. Extensive collections of herbs have been assembled at several of the leading botanic gardens.

The engagement of Miss Gertrude Upson Richardson, daughter of Mrs. John MacLaren Richardson of Bridgeport and the late Rev. John MacLaren Richardson, former pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of this city, to Thomas Leroy Bennett was announced by her mother at a tea at her home this afternoon.
Aviation jobs develop so much more rapidly than they can be filled that training for them should begin in high school, Max M. Pollet, president of the State Aviation Association, asserts.

PINEHURST, N. C.-With the holiday season over, this resort is turning its attention from the social functions which complement the holidays to the sports program on for this month, including weekly trapshooting contests, golf tournaments, gymkhanas, tennis tournaments and the twentieth annual field trial events, which begin on Thursday and continue to Jan. 11.

The office of Hussey Hoeh reports the sale of ten Brooklyn properties during December. A onefamily house at 1,372 East Eighth Street was sold by William Becker to H. Boise; another at 950 East Seventh Street by Fred Becker to V. Kaave; another at 1,220-22 East Forty-ninth Street by Ida Camen to R. H. Meehan and another at 1,533 East Twenty-ninth Street by G. Berkowitz to J. Goldner.
Unorganized Imperfection FREE citizens on their own peripatetic feet may resent regulation by policemen in uniform.

Members of the Alumnae Association of St. Joseph's College for Women have arranged their annual card party and fashion show in behalf of their charitable activities for the afternoon of Jan. 17 at the Hotel Roosevelt. Mrs. Patrick J. Carty heads the executive committee for the benefit.

Commander Edward W. Hanson of the gunboat Erie, sole Amercan vessel subjected to gunfire by a foreign power in 1936, has authorized the first detailed account of the "incident," Dec. 17, when a battleship, reputedly the Spanish Rebel ship Espafia, sent three shells across the Erie's bows.

A NEW kind of query is coming into automobile association offices at New York this Winter. Surprising numbers of members want to know "How are the roads" into arious Winter sport centers in the forests and hills of the back country.

The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation announces its thirteenth annual series of auditions for pianists, violinists, violoncellists and singers "who are of mature talent and ready for professional careers, but who have not already had a New York recital reviewed by critics."

Executives and representatives of local civic and educational organizations will hear a discussion of probation by President Judge James R. Erwin of the Hudson County Common Pleas Court at a meeting of the Woman's Club of Morristown, N. J., at 2:30 P. M. Tuesday.

Plans for extension of the Connecticut College campus to the south, with the Frank Loomis Palmer auditorium probably occupying a site south of the library and the Bill chapel taking a place south of Fanning Hall, are discussed by President Katharine Blunt in her annual report.

ON every Jan. 6 in Tarpon Springs an ancient Greek custom is revived in Cross Day. It is observed now only in the Greek Isla ds and in this sponge fishing village of Florida. For a day the price of sponges, the diver whose life-line fouled, and the "hooking" boats that will never return, are forgotten. Choirs chant.

THE first of Maxwell Ander son's three plays for the current season is "The Wingless Victory," in which Katharine Cornell is now appearing as a Malay princess. The second is to be "High Tor," in which Burgess Meredith and Peggy Ashcroft are scheduled to appear next Tuesday;

An almost complete return of public confidence in the institutions under the supervision of the State Department of Banking and Insurance was noted by Commissioner Carl K. Withers in a summary today of activities of his department in 1936.

THIS is a joyous time of the year for the reporter of fashions, for when the rigors of Winter are setting in she is looking over play togs destined to be worn in sunny lands. They are as fresh as the first crocuses that break through the snow. The fabrics of which the clothes are made are the novelties of the year and many are unlikely to reappear when Summer comes.

Having increased its gross receipts in 1936 by approximately $250,000,000 to a total of $1,000,000,000, the motion picture industry entered 1937 with the brightest prospects in its history, according to R. H. Cochrane, president of the Universial Pictures Company.

Despite the continuance throughout 1936 of large-scale Japanese and Korean smuggling through many North China ports, China's maritime customs revenue for the year showed an increase of $9,000,000 (silver) as compared with 1935.
Major. Gen. John J. Phelan of New York City has been reappointed by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn as a member of the State Athletic Commission.

Executives of the Y. W. C. A have been summoned to a city-wide staff meeting on Wednesday at the Central Club for Nurses, 132 East Forty-fifth Street, by Miss Margaret Webster, general secretary of the association in New York.

Dr. Dorian Feigenbaum, psychoanalyst and a founder and editorin-chief of The Psychoanalytic Quarterly, died early yesterday at his home, 885 Park Avenue, of pneumonia. He was 49 years old. Dr. Feigenbaum, a specialist on paranoia, came to this country in 1924 after having practiced in Austria, Switzerland and Palestine.

IT is a significant commentary on our changing times that McSorley's Old Ale House in Seventh Street has discontinued its raw onion bowl. The omission of this once indispensable freelunch item is proof, in itself, that even McSorley's recognizes. despite the fact that no woman has been permitted to cross its threshold in eighty-odd years. t? at women and the foaming flagon are no longer sworn enemies.
Three men who were arrested on Tuesday on burglary charges and questioned about the activities of an alleged arson ring, were arraigned today before City Judge Charles W. Boote.

A visit to Chicago by the varsity basketball team to meet Western Reserve University and the opening of the varsity wrestling schedule in a dual meet with Columbia, both contests being slated for next Saturday, feature this week in athletics at City College. The fencing,

The annual Gnomes Ball was held in the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity House tonight. Three hundred guests attended. Known as the Bachelors Ball in recent years, the event is traditionally held in the first week of each new year.
Plans were filed with the Bronx Department of Buildings for 798 new structures during 1936, carrying an estimated cost aggregating $48,831,015, according to figures compiled yesterday.

Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco and Palm Springs, Calif., displaces Miss Helen Hull Jacobs at the top of the national rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1936 and J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., succeeds Wilmer Allison as the No. 1 man of American tennis.

Herbert Abraham, president of the Ruberoid Company, makers of building products, predicts an acceleration of home construction in 1937 which may bring activity close to 1929 levels. He said in a yearend statement that the improvement should carry on for four or five years.

Miss Jeanne DeWolfe Wilmarth daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. C. Wilmarth, 316 Glen Street, this city, was married to Donald C. Hallenbeck, this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hallenbeck of Albany, tonight at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. John Lyon Caughey, pastor of the First Press byterian Church.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Douglas Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gage Austin, to Lieutenant Edwin Van Valkenburg Sutherland, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Hugh Brock Sutherland of Germantown, Pa., and the late Mr. Sutherland, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 180 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Representative Matthew J. Merritt of New York City, athletic-looking chairman of a special gymnasium committee, began today the task of keeping members of the seventy-fifth Congress in physical shape for the session which will open Tuesday.

Expounding a principle of law that has not been passed upon for nearly a century, John C. Knox, presiding judge of the United States District Court here, upheld yesterday the right of a citizen to follow up a successful criminal prosecution with the arrest of the convict in civil proceedings.

Higher real estate values and increased building activity are predicted by Albert M. Greenfield, president of the company bearing his name, in a comment on the real estate outlook for the coming year.

For the eleven months ended Nov. 30, the Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department handled 31,389 cases of missing persons and unidentified dead from all parts of the world, of which only 1,400 remain "open" or unsolved on the bureau's books.

A possible reduction in executive personnel will be the chief result from a management standpoint of the current widespread rush of large organizations to absorb their subsidiaries, according to opinions expressed in business circles here yesterday.

Dean M. Lyle Spencer of the Syracuse University School of Journalism left today for New York City to sail Tuesday for Cairo, where he will direct the organization of a journalism curriculum at the American University.

A funeral service for the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Fundamentalist Presbyterian leader who died of penumonia at Bismarck, N. D., last night, will be held at 3 P. M. on Tuesday in the Spruce Street Baptist Church in this city.

Beginning on Feb. 1 and continuing until April 1, the Commodity Credit Corporation and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will release to producers of cotton who have borrowed on their output a "reasonable" amount of the 3,000,000 bales of cotton purchased under the 11 and 12 cent loans that remains after the 1,400,000 bales liquidated in 1936 are subtracted from the total on which the loans were made.
Stocks of lead in the United States at the end of November amounted to 260,192 tons, compared with 269,950 on Oct. 31, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

William A. Pothier, a coal merchant in Brooklyn for half a century, who had been active in the campaign for more playgrounds in Brooklyn, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 523 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old. For a year Mr. Pothier had been suffering from illness intermittently and six months ago he underwent an operation.
The correspondence between Andrew W. Mellon and President Roosevelt concerning Mr. Mellon's offer to give his art collection to the government was as follows:

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss M. Virginia Hunter, daughter of the Rev. John Merritt Hunter of All Saints Episcopal Church in this city, and Mrs. Hunter, to Charles Wesley Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. Jenkins of Margaretville. N. Y.

Taking your own home with you when going away to school is the latest fad adopted by American youth. Furthermore, when this same portable home has served the four-year period as dormitory for its knowledge-seeking occupant, it may again take to the open road on job-hunting expeditions.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--For the first time in several years, an invitational tennis tournament is being held at the Orlando Country Club where courts are in excellent condition. The first round was played yesterday with the second slated for today.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributiofis ordered by the directors follow:

Naval Academy squads will start preparations tomorrow for a busy season of Winter sports. The basketball team reported for work yesterday but the game with the University of Baltimore, originally scheduled for New Year's Day, was postponed to Jan. 11.

Following the International Longshoremen's Association's refusal to handle freight for ship owners reaching settlements with the striking seamen, the American-Foreign Steamship Corporation, disclosed yesterday that its ships would clear in ballast for South American ports this week.

A pilotless army airplane dived on this community from a height of 1,000 feet about 4 A. M. today, struck the power lines and left the village in darkness and then crashed into a two-story house occupied by eight children and their parents. Three of the children were slightly injured.

WILE the industry regards late Summer as its New Year, that being the season when announcements of forthcoming astounding and herculean epics are made, the public and its observers lean toward a more normal division of the year,
Tossing in a barrage of field goals in the final half, Wooster College of Wooster, Ohio, routed the Rider College five, 51-35, tonight.

THIS volume is a model monograph on a desperate condition. In it the dean of the University of Chicago's School of Social Service Administration has gathered together the fruit of twenty-five years of special studies of the tenement and slum areas of America's second city.

"Further progress in the development of recreation in this country will depend more and more upon the interest which the individual brings to his leisure-time activities," Dr. Hugh P. Baker, president of Massachusetts State College, declared today in restating objectives of the annual conference on outdoor recreation to be held at the college in March.

Thumb-sucking, the habit of almost all infants, need not be a matter of great concern, according to Dr. Frederick L. Stanton, chief of the division of child research in the New York University College of Dentistry.

A cemetry which will not contain a tombstone is about to be established at Warlingham, Surrey. The site, consisting of thirtytwo acres, is to be administered by a trust whose first consideration will be to preserve the natural beauty of the location.

Contrary to a belief in many quarters, the new city charter, adopted by the voters last election day, did not go into effect on Jan. 1 this year, but will become operative Jan. 1, 1938, the day following the expiration of the terms of the present city officials.
LONDON, Engiand--"The creation of a squadron of anti-aircraft warships was announced by the British Government today in a note delivered to the United States and Japanese Embassies here.

The Japanese Navy is purely defensive, Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu, Supreme War Councilor and former commeander of the Grand Fleet, declared today. He assured the nation in an article for the newspaper Nichi Nichi that Japan never would take the initiative in world naval construction rivalry.
The Geneva College basketball team defeated John Marshall, 35 to 23, in a game played last night in the Edison School Gym at Union City, N. J.

Six hundred and fifty-eight schools and academies representing approximately 80,000 student participants are enrolled to date in THE TIMES Constitution Essay Contest in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

The house in Vienna in which Beethoven wrote the "Eroica" symphony may soon be converted into a heurige, or inn. It is a little one-story house in the Eroica gasse in Grinzing, a suburb of Vienna which slopes up into the hills to the north where the big vineyards used to be.

Optimistic, but faced with the necessity of relearning the technique of merchandising in a rising market, retail buyers will begin to arrive in the wholesale trades here this week in what are expected to prove the largest numbers since 1929.

The Chicago Title and Trust Company reported today net earnings for 1936 of $1,565,343, or $13.04 a share on the 120,000 shares of $100 par stock, compared with $1,671,821, or $13.93 a share, in the preceding year.

The second annual marionette performance of "Much Ado About Glinda," an original play in four acts by Ernest Thorne Thompson, head of the Department of Fine Arts at the College of New Rochelle, will be given in the sports building on the campus on Thursday.

Europe is plainly getting ready for another big war. If that conflict becomes a reality, it is distinctly possible that Uncle Sam may become involved, and Greater New York may then be completely depopulated.

At a time when the fate of some of Spain's greatest cathedrals and churches remains uncertain in the present civil war, John Taylor Arms, president of the Society of American Etchers, is completing plans to place on exhibition this week at the Grand Central Art Galleries drawings and etchings he has made of some of Spain's great ecclesiastical buildings.

Miss Harriette Odell Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Williams Bacon of this place, was married this afternoon to Edward Lower Dingler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lower Dingier of Philadelphia.

The rapprochement between Great Britain and Italy expressed in the gentlemen's agreement regulating the relations of the two Powers in the Mediterranean, signed yesterday, has come sooner than MUSSOLINI himself could have anticipated when he said last year to the British Ambassador in Rome:

General all-round superiority of stroke and a more seasoned tournament type of play were the very good reasons why Don McNeill, Kenyon College student, defeated Marvin Kantrowitz, De Witt Clinton High School player, in straight sets, 6--4, 6--4, 6--3, for the national junior indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.
St. Joseph's College recorded its fifth straight basketball victory tonight by beating Davis-Elkins, 29-26, but came perilously close to dropping its first home game in four years.

An attempt to revive the famous pineapple test case, by which Florida agriculturists sought to upset the administration's reciprocal trade treaty program on constitutional grounds, was made here last week when John G. Lerch, attorney for George S. Fletcher of Miami, head of the agricultural group, petitioned the United States Customs Court for a rehearing of the suit.
Returning the only victory among English Football League championship contenders, Charlton Athletic drew within a point of the leading Arsenal squad by defeating Liverpool, 2--1, today.
Place--Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Fortysixth and Forty-seventh Streets. Dates--Jan. 8 to 16, excepting Sunday, Jan. 10, when show will be closed.
The fourth victim of fire at a holiday costume ball, Mrs. Bernard Reynolds died in a hospital today, and grave concern was expressed for Mrs. Ed Smith and Mrs. Richard Williams.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Royal W. Leith of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Dunham Leith, to Minot Grose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Grose of Great Neck, L. I.

HANDEL'S "Acis and Galatea," which is rarely heard in England with its proper scoring and a choir of the right size, was given a performance of the kind recently in London at the Queen Mary Hall by Arnold Goldsborough and his forces.

MEXICO, which only a few years ago was almost unknown to American tourists, is fast becoming a popular goal. Though the climate is such that a Mexican visit is pleasant any time of year, Americans are increasingly seeking out our neighbor to the south as a place in which to avoid the blustery winds and zero temperatures which harass the United States in Winter months.

Mrs. Ella Maude Williams Barrett of Katonah died last night at the White Plains Hospital at the age of 62. She was the widow of William G. Barrett, a realty operator, and was a member of a prominent Westchester family.

In a resume of the situation in the real estate business at the end of 1936, the National Association of Real Estate Boards finds that practically every branch of the industry showed a marked increase over the previous year.
Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell,

An 18-year-old freshman from the University of Wisconsin, Paul Bietila, furnished the most spectacular performance of the collegiate and invitation ski jump held today on Intervales Hill under conditions that probably have never been witnessed before at this pioneer Winter sports spot.

Republican lawmakers remaining ovtr at- the capitol after yesterday's inaugural ceremony tonight were eagerly awaiting the arrival of William S. Murray, chairman of the State committee, for conferences which are expected to prepare the way for the re-election of Irving M. Ives of Chenango as Speaker of the Assembly.
BERLIN.--The latest phase of the transformation of the German capitalist system assumes more distinct shape with the progress of the four-year raw materials selfsufficiency plan.

Miss Anne Cutler heads a group of younger members of society who will sell flowers and cigarettes at the performance of-"High Tor," a new play by Maxwell Anderson, Wednesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the New York Kindergarten Association.

Despite a cold, drizzling rain, twenty-two boats competed today in the second session of the three-day celebration of the fifth anniversary of frostbite sailing. Skippers and crews of a dozen or more dinghies preferred the warmth of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

The Stalin-Trotsky feud that is causing an upheaval in Catalonia is strikingly reminiscent of the events the same feud recently caused in Russia. Catalonia has gone so far on the way of "collectivization" that it may be now described as Western Europe's first Communist State.

A remarkable story of the friendly behavior of a Spanish Rebel detachment guarding a detained Soviet merchant ship at Ceuta in November was told today by Ivan Lesovikoff, the political assistant to the captain who has arrived in Moscow on leave.

HAVANA, Cuba.--The coming week will be one of social activity throughout Cuba, centering around the "Day of the Three Wise Men," on Wednesday, when the children receive long-awaited gifts and grownups attend the customary fiestas.

Combining most of the extraordinary features they adopted in the past and adding to these a few new ones, the Giants, ever the pioneers in novel Spring training ventures, apparently have another most strenuous campaign mapped r them by Manager Bill Terry, according to the 1937 plans revealed yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Willard Curtis of Darien have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mina Ballard Curtis, to C. Frederic Underwood of Shippan Point.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis St. Clair Burr of East Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elena Lois Burr, to Donald Trigg Sargeant, son of Mrs. George H. Sargeant of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mr. Sargeant.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harlan Ellett gave a dinner dance last night at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Joan Ellett. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of white net and carried a bouquet of gardenias. Mrs. Ellett's gown was of white satin and she wore a corsage of gardenias.
Lehigh University's three varsity Winter sports teams, basketball, wrestling and swimming, will be busy with the resumption of classes Monday. Four contests are scheduled for the coming week.

As a new year starts, developers in many parts of New Jersey are preparing. to open new areas for residential development. Activity is rising in estate and acreage property, and sales of small homes continue to be brisk.

Every retailer should plan now to take advantage of the unusually heavy demand for Spring suits, according to Tobe, fashion authority and merchandising consultant. Women all over the country are buying suits for under-coat wear, and this demand offers retailers an immediate opportunity for increased sales volume.

More than 20 per cent of the youths enrolled in the Civilian Conservation Corps in October had never held any other job, it was revealed today by Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work.

ANY one who travels from Arkansas to Georgia by automobile. as I did recently, cannot help realizing that the agricultural problem is far from solved. In this area there are hundreds of thousands of miserable. unpainted shacks, constructed more than fifty years ago, some of them with holes in the roof and some without glass in the windows or doors in the door openings.

ONE of the most notable examplea of nature's handwriting is to be found at Kelley Island, In Lake Erie, not far from the Ohio city of Sandusky. Here every crag tells to the initiated in nature's handwriting what took place in the Ice Age.

Professor Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work will address provisional members of the New York Junior League tomorrow at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to inaugurate this year's lecture course on economics for debutantes who are in training to become active members of the Junior League.

Thirteen Harlem bartenders appeared in Harlem Court yesterday in answer to summonses given by Inspector Gelman of the Board of Health, charging them with not properly washing glasses before serving patrons.

FOR a year Eberhard Wolf gang Moller's play, "Rothchild siegt bei Waterloo," has been spooking around the German theater horizon where It received much publicity, though, significantly enough, none of the productions were at either State or civic stages.
Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, announced tonight he had sold Outfielder George Puccinelli back to the Baltimore Orioles, from which he was drafted a year ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Van Divort of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Olive May Van Divort, to Robert Edward Fendrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Fendrich, also of Nutley.
William Van Anden Hester, treasurer of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, has resigned, it was announcedyesterday. He is the great-greatnephew of Isaac Van Anden, who founded the paper in 1841.

Rival captains engaged in a tactical battle on the second day of the third test cricket match between England and Australia today. As a result, the Aussies, with one wicket down in their second innings, are 127 runs ahead of their opponents, winners of the first two tests.

Chief City Magistrate Schurman has issued a statement on the work of the four parts of the Traffic Court in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx for 1936. The statement does not cover the Queens Traffic Court, which was opened only last Dec. 1, nor the handling of traffic cases on Staten Island by the two ordinary magistrate's courts there.
The greatest secrecy is being maintained concerning the procedure in General Chang Hsueh-liang's trial last Thursday In connection with the Sian mutiny.

An overwhelmingly Democratic Congress, elected last November, will meet on Tuesday of this week to take stock of the present situation, to air its views and to consider such proposals as the President may lay before it.

For weeks shops showing abundant stocks of ski clothes and accessories have been doing business with enthusiasts whose optimism defied the spell of balmy weather. Some shops offered the girl skier small kits in which to carry cosmettics, creams to keep the skin from burning or taking on freckles from the glare of sun on snow and other odds and ends.

The number of home-relief recipients quitting the rolls because private jobs and other new sources of income had made them independent of city aid increased by 119 per cent during the last three months of 1936, as compared with the corresponding period of 1935, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, reported yesterday.

Miss Priscilla St. George, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. St. George, was married to Angier Biddle Duke this afternoon in St. Mary's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. S. W. Wood, rector of St. Mary's, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Samuel S. Drury of St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H.

American young people will not be out of the woods of discouragement and ineptitude until schools and colleges give them more practical job training, John A. Lang of the United States Office of Education told the National Student Federation convention last week.
Home construction will register as great an increase in 1937 over 1936 as the past year showed over 1935, according to Harold T. Donaldson, president of the United States Building Loan League.

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's program of physical and academic expansion was largely responsible for its gain in the number of freshmen entering last Fall, according to Dr. Ray P. Baker, assistant director.
