Play in-the semi-final round of the sixteenth annual Gold Racquet court tennis tournament, scheduled to have been held this morning at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club, was postponed until a week from tomorrow.

John Erskine will open on Wednesday the first of a series of ten free lectures and recitals arranged by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters in the academy auditorium, 632 West 156th Street.

Two patrolmen, seeking last night to find out why for the last three weeks the Misses Mary and Kate Murphy, recluses in their fourth floor rooms at 338 East Thirtyninth Street had not, as was their custom, asked neighbors to make their purchases of food for them, found the answer in the bedroom of their three-room cold-water flat.
A motion picture in natural color entitled "American Campuses in the Near East" will be shown at the Colony Club on the night of Jan. 14 under the auspices of the trustees of the Near East Colleges.
From tomorrow Westminster Abbey will be closed to the public and Dean Foxley Norris will surrender the keys to the governmental department known as the Office of Works.

As a result of the fatal shooting Thursday of Pius Lanzetti and two other persons, Mayor S. Davis Wilson today instructed Edward Hubbs, his new Acting Superintendent of Police, to oust every known gangster and racketeer from the city.

The Montreal Maroons retained second place in the National Hockey League's international group and the Toronto Maple Leafs moved into third place as they played to a scoreless tie before 10,028 fans tonight. The draw put Toronto a point ahead of the defeated New York Americans in the standing, but still two points behind the Maroons.

Invention of a disk which looks like a tin waffle and which it was said might revolutionize branches of the oil refining and synthetic chemical industries was reported today by the National Research Council.

THAT native American flavor usually so in evidence at the Fifteen Gallery has been replaced for the time being by a more exotic atmosphere. The current guest exhibitor is Mateo Hernandez, whose drawings,

A police captain and three lieutenants have been assigned to the Board of Transportation to supervise the force of 140 special officers at work in the Independent Subway system, it was announced at police headquarters yesterday.

New Year's resolutions of all kinds being in season, it is but fitting that the gardener should treat himself to a few; and if they are not too numerous they are more likely to be carried out if put down on paper.

While the usual seasonal letdown -in activity was felt in most lines of business last week, the lull was not as appreciable as the recessions during similar periods in recent years, according to reports received from the various Federal Reserve districts.

With the recent appointment by Mayor La Guardia of Roderick stephens, president of the Bronx board of Trade, as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority, realty and civic interests in that borough are looking forward to comprehensive action in the near futuree for a coordinated highway systemm in the Bronx.

The undefeated Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. wrestling team will seek its nineteenth consecutive triumph and its fourth of the current campaign when it opposes the Flatbush Boys Club in a return test at the latter's mats on Tuesday night.
The office of director of athletics at the University of Kansas, held since 1919 by Dr. F. C. (Phog) Allen, was abolished today by the State Board of Regents.

With his left foot still in a cast from minor fractures near the ankle, Richard T. Merrill, veteran pilot of Eastern Air Lines, who brought his Douglas transport down in the wooded hills near Port Jervis, N. Y. two weeks ago without injuring any of his eight passengers,

Miss Elizabeth Jones and Bradford R. Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther H. Frost of Wakefield, Mass., were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Jones of West Hartford.

Solomon Baumann, a veteran pickpocket with a love for music, attempted to combine business and pleasure New Year's night with the result that he will spend the first four months in the workhouse. Baumann,

FREQUENT criticism is made of the number of annual bridge tournaments advertised as national championships. In 1937, according to announcements already made, all of such tournaments previously established will be renewed, and there may be one or more new ones.
Opening up with a four-goal scoring spree in the second period, Princeton's hockey team downed the Williams sextet, 5-1, in Baker rink this afternoon.
Terence Preece, seven-goal poloist from New York, led the Long Island quartet in an 11-to-6 victory over San Mateo today in the annual Del Monte New Year's tournament.
william F. Dee of 14 Overlook Terrace, a merchant, revealed today that he has just been called to serve upon two juries at the same time.

Although mail requisitions were light last week in the wholesale market, a larger number of buyers than usual arrived to make purchases, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Many buyers are expected this week to make Spring purchases and to obtain goods for special January sales efforts. The report continues:

Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Muhlenbrock of Lincoln Park, Cranford, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Muhlenbrock, to Roy Milton Henwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Henwood of Rutherford. N. J.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Vining, daughter of Mrs. Ernest J. T. Vining of this city and the late Mr. Vining, to Malcolm Graeme Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Peter Duncan of Tenafly, N. J., has been announced.

The Spanish civil war, with its desperate military struggle between General Francisco Franco and the Left Popular Front government and its grave international complications, has tended to obscure the fact that in Madrid, Valencia, Barcelona and other territory still controlled by the Loyalists there has been a swing toward radicalism.

The fourteen-story apartment house at 1,160 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Ninety-second Street, will be sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings tomorrow in the Vesey Street rooms by Edwin J. McDonald. The plot is 150 by 100.8 feet.

IN all the communities of Florida that are more than villages Winter visitors have turned to activities that will keep them entertained for several months. The tourist season, now definitely under way, has a calendar that includes numerous diversions ranging from simple games in civic recreation centers to dazzling social functions in the seclusion of private estates.

Interstate scholastic basketball warfare held the spotlight at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon when four quintets from New Jersey clashed with four local teams, the latter emerging with three of the four victories.
The engagement of Miss Virginia Cleaveland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wightman Cleaveland of this city, to Lawrence B. Murdock of St. Louis, has been announced by her parents.
Re-establishlishment of the emergency rent Laws as a means of solving current housing problems was proposed here today by Assemblyman Phelps of New York.

The national Capitol, deserted since last June except for a few clerks and a horde of sight-seers, hummed with activity last week as members of the Seventy-fifth Congress converged on Washington to pass on the legislation President Roosevelt wants to complete his New Deal program.
Ross Alexander, 29, motion picture actor, committed suicide by shooting himself in the temple with a pistol tonight, according to the police.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his company brought its week of holiday opera offerings to a close yesterday at the Hippodrome with two presentations. The afternoon production of "La Traviata" attracted 2,500 persons. In the evening "II Trovatore" was given before an assemblage of 3,500 auditors.

Two Deputy Sheriffs stood guard today while workmen combed the debris and sifted ashes, hoping to salvage $15,000 to $20,000 worth of jewelry in the burned home at Fishkill of David Marcus of 101 Hollywood Avenue, Yonkers, a New York executive of a publishing concern.

BEING little in Cambridge in the Seventies and Eighties meant, if one were an Abbott, that the people of one's adult world numbered most of the names which were then making that city famous as the intellectual capital of the country.

A project for a National Gallery of Art centering around the great $19,000,000 collection of masterpieces gathered over a period of many years by Andrew W. Mellon of Pittsburgh, former Secretary of the Treasury, which it is hoped may eventually make Washington a rival of Paris as an art capital, was announced today in an exchange of letters between President Roosevelt and Mr. Mellon.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago last May Gustav Mahler died, and sixty years ago this past September Bruno Walter was born. In Vienna the conjunction of anniversaries has had various literary and biographical results.

Sit-down strikes which have curtailed the production of bodies and accessories for assembly lines will throw 135,000 employes of the General Motors Corporation out of work by the end of next week, according to W. S. Knudsen, executive vice president, who declared today that the corporation would not negotiate with the United Automobile Workers so long as any of its members occupied the plants.

"CAMILLE," which stands in literary history as one of the greatest of all love stories and has been performed by more famous names than any other stage play, and Which in its operatic form is one of the most popular in the entire musical field, comes for the first time as a talking picture to the Capitol's screen early in January.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick, steeplechase rider, horse owner and polo player, after three vain attempts to win the Grand National, England's famous steeplechase, has decided to stay home this year and play polo, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
King Gustav of Sweden, who usually passes a part of the Winter in Monte Carlo and the vicinity, is postponing his departure for that resort until late in February.

Miguel de Unamuno, noted Spanish philosopher and writer who died suddenly at Salamanca on New Year's Eve, told the Diario de Noticias shortly before his death that "the sight of Germans in Spain is enough to kill me," the newspaper said today.

A slight fire which started backstage at the Oxford Theatre, a burlesque house at 552 State Street, near Flatbush Avenue. Brooklyn, while a midnight show was going on early this morning was quickly extinguished by firemen who were answering another alarm around the corner.

THE three immemorial themes of lyric poetry are death, love and nature. David Morton, in "Spell Against Time," is, for this sheaf at least, almost exclusively engaged with nature. Not only does he find in mother earth, and in her children,

Increases in gross revenues in 1936 realized by Canadian railways justify confidence in the outlook, S. J. Hungerford, chairman and president of the Canadian National Railways, says in his review of events of the year. He notes also that the Canadian National (West Indies) Steamships, Ltd., continued to increase earnings.

Federal legislation, which would divest child labor goods of their interstate character, compel such goods to be labeled and ban their handling by transportation companies in States where the law prohibits them, was suggested here yesterday by Mortimer Fishel, attorney, as a solution to both the child-labor problem and the workweek problem.
Ossie M. Solem, head football coach and director of athletics at the University of Iowa and former Minnesota player, has been appointed as Syracuse's new football coach.
After four years of study the preliminary Fairfield County Plan has been completed by the Fairfield County Planning Association under the direct supervision of Joseph T. Woodruff, consultant.

Two outstanding amateur outboard drivers, Bedford Davie of Tuxedo Park and Paul Sawyer Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., will represent the United States in France in the 1937 Spreckels Trophy race on the Seine, according to an announcement yesterday by George W. Sutton Jr., president of the American Power Boat Association.
Nineteen grants for research in fourteen fields have been awarded to members of the faculty at Wesleyan University by the Faculty Committees on Research. The awards include the following:
Morning Mail, a 5-year-old son of Morvich, showed some of his sire's famous speed today to carry Mrs. E. Oros's silks to victory in the six-furlong Sapphire Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
A nine-game football schedule for 1937, featuring the addition of Minnesota, Illinois and Drake in the places of Ohio State, Wisconsin and Washington University, was announced for Notre Dame today.
A marked improvement in Cuba's tourist traffic last year has been reported to the Commerce Department by its Havana Office.

Based on statistics for the first ten months of 1936, indications at the year-end were that for the full year the nickel industry would establish new high records for volume and diversification of world consumption, according to Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in his review of that industry.

The dinner dance and entertainment for the benefit of the National Bureau for Blind Artists that had been planned for last Sunday will take place tonight at the French Casino. A new revue, French Casino Follies, will be presented during the evening.

Representative Rankin of Mississippi pulled out of the contest for the House Democratic leadership tOnight and Representatives O'Conn?? of New York and Rayburn of Texa settled down to fight it out alone.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, dc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

The opening of a trading market in soy bean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last October a definite indication of the necessity for marketing facilities, marked another forward step in the amazing advance of the soy bear in the industrial and farming field.

More than 500 persons today attended funeral services in St. Paul's Episcopal Church for the Rev. John Gammack, rector emeritus of the church, former City Clerk and Commissioner of Public Safety in this community.

Three metropolitan senior indoor titles will be at stake in the championship A. A. U. swimming meet at the Downtown A. C. on Friday night, which is expected to attract a stellar field of men and women performers for the six events on the program.
Mrs. Margaret M. Sawyer of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, formerly of Brooklyn, will give a luncheon and bridge at the hotel on Jan. 26 for the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

The gray goods industry closed 1936 with unfilled orders of approximately 325,000,000 yards of printcloth yarn goods on the books, the highest ever achieved, according to reports in the local market yesterday. This figure is equivalent to fifteen to sixteen weeks of production at the current rate of 20,000,000 to 21,000,000 yards a week.

Mr. and Mrs. Hector L. Belisle of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Belisle, to Oscar F. Wiedeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Wiedeman of this place, and Upper Montclair, N. J. Miss Belisle attended House-inthe-Pines, Wheaton College and Thibodeau Business College.

A pair of galagas, a species of South African lemur, sometimes likened to the honey bear, is ineluded in a collection of wild animals, reptiles and fishes arriving in Brooklyn tomorrow morning aboard the American-South African liner City of New York, consigned to the Staten Island Zoological Society.

Bill Zimmerman. young Augusta golfer, carded 74, 71 in two rounds over the rain-drenched Forest Hills course today to win the third annual Southern Star amateur golf championship with a seventy-twohole score of 290.

SERGE PROKOFIEFF, Russian composer-pianist, who is returning to this country after several years' absence, will make a tour of four cities. He will appear with the Chicago Symphony Jan. 21 and 22, the St. Louis Symphony Jan. 29 and 30 and the Boston Symphony Orchestra Feb. 5 and 6.

New techniques which make it possible for the first time to strip bacteria of their immunity-giving substances in pure, concentrated form, promising production of potent and effective vaccines and serums against many of mankind's most serious bacterial diseases, were described here today before a joint meeting of the American Philosophical Socity and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Brooklyn Association for the Hospitalization of Crippled Children will hold the third in a series of bridge teas on Tuesday at Grace Church parish house, Brooklyn Heights. Miss Mabel L. Moore is president of the association.

THE ETERNAL ROAD-Tomorrow evening at the Manhattan Opera House. This is the spectacle which has been in preparation for many months: Franz Werfel wrote the dialogue, Ludwig Lewisohn adapted it and Kurt Weill contributed the music.

A campaign by the city to collect more than $500,000 in delinquent taxes on about 350 houses constructed by the United States Housing Corporation during the World War has been stopped, at least temporarily, by the Federal Government.

The hand being quicker than the eye, City College's slick basketball operatives completely baffled the big St. John's quintet at Madison Square Garden last night, riddled the Redmen's defense with their clever ball handling and handed the Brooklynites their first defeat after seven straight victories this season.
fast, sharp-shooting George Washington University basketball team routed the University of Nebraska, 41 to 22, tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dike Bixby of Vincoma, Huntington, have an- a ounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Bixby, to Ralph Henry Huff, son of Clarence Reed Huff of Huntington.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn Genevieve McManus, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael McManus of New York and niece of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Flannery of Montclair, to John Quincy Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Albeus Adams, also of this place, took place here this morning in the Church of the Immaculate Conception.

Miss Gertrude Virginia Park, laughter of Professor and Mrs. James W. Park of 303 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn, was married last hight to Walter Roosevelt Koch, on of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Koch of Corpus Christi, Texas. The Rev. Dr. William E. Dudley perEormed the ceremony in the Flatbush Congregational Church, BrookLyn.

Up and down the land this Winter millions of Americans are talking things over in public forums. In lecture halls, school rooms and community centers from coast to coast, people as never before, are getting together to hear and debate such timely topics as War and Peace, Democracy versus Dictatorship, Why We Have Depressions, The Supreme Court, The Constitution, and Where Should We Go from Here?

CAVALLERIA RUSTICANA -- Opera in Italian in one act. Music by Pietro Mascagni; book by Targioni-Tozzetti and Menasci. Conductor, Gennaro Papi; stage director. Desire Defrere. Presented at the Metrooplitan Opera House.
Thirteen wholesalers and distributors of sponges were accused of monopolistic practices today by the Federal Trade Commission and allowed twenty days to file answers to the charges.

OCCURRENCE of four accidents to transport airplanes, involving in each case fatalities, and another forced landing in which skill and luck averted death, within a period of two weeks, have focused attention once again on the safety factor of commercial flying.
Wider use of broad-leaved evergreens -- rhododendron, evergreen azaleas, laurel, and the like--makes the problem of their protection through the Winter one of growing importance.

Edgar G. Johnson of the real estate firm bearing his name reports considerable activity in Fieldston and Riverdale, especially for better-class homes. Completion of the Henry Hudson Bridge and the Riverside Drive Extension makes that locality at the present time more readily accessible from lower New York, he points out.

The Harlem Y. C. is going in for cruising in a big way during 1937. At Wednesday's annual meeting at the clubhouse on City Island further deliberation will be devoted to a proposal that the club sponsor a members' cruise to Newport, R. I., the end of July to view at least one of the days of the international races for the America's Cup.
THE coming week will be outstanding for orchestras. In addition to the ministrations of the Philharmonic-Symphony, there will be visits by both the Philadelphia and Boston ensembles.

The German public learned today that the first shot by an outside power in the Spanish civil war had been fired by the German cruiser Koenigsberg on New Year's Day. That was also the day on which Vice Admiral Rolf Carls took over the command of the German fleet.

Twenty-three families were routed from their beds in the six-story apartment house at 134 Bleecker Street at 4:30 A. M. yesterday by an explosion of gas in a ground floor rear apartment Julian Fossen,

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Renaissance Sculpture," Edith R. Abbot, 2 P. M.; "The Making of a piece Bronze Statue; Behind the Scenes in the Metropolitan Museum," motion out pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Symbolic L. Forms in Chinese Art," Pauline Simons, 3 P. M.; Gillender Lecture. "The Stage Designer's Interpretation of Reality," John Mason Brown, 4 P. M.

Warden Lewis E. Lawes announced -today that during 1936 526 of the 1,885 prisoners received, or 28 per cent, came from Long Island. Out of 33 admitted to the death house during the year 21 were from Long Island, 18 being from Kings and 3 from Nassau.

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia arrived late yesterday from Liverpool with 100 passengers and will sail at 12:05 A. M. Thursday, on her tenth round-the-world cruise. She will have 375 passengers, fifty more than she had last year. Thirty-three of the number came from England to make the cruise.
Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Fund campaign, reported last night that many contributors asked that their gifts be used to restore the health of ill and injured children.
Mount Holyoke range may soon become officially the "Coolidge State Reservation" in honor of Calvin Coolidge, who spent much of his life in Northampton.
William Woodward's Omaha, champion 3-year-old of America in 1935 and outstanding in England last year, probably will make another effort to win the famous Gold Cup at Ascot June 17.

Miss Hallie Fairbank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clair W. Fairbank of Pelham Manor, and Miss Beverly Bender, daughter of Mrs. Robert J. Bender, also of Pelham Manor, made their debuts this afternoon at a tea dance given at the Larchmont Shore Club here.

A bellboy, who had been employed only two hours before, was seriously injured yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Claridge, Broadway and Forty-fourth Street, when he fell down an elevator shaft from the lobby to the basement-a drop of three stories.

Miss Virginia Elizabeth Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Gallagher of Garden City, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to William Andrew Nugent, son of Mrs. William A. Nugent of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Nugent.

The market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange did little more than mark time yesterday as prices fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits in light trading. Transactions for the two hours amounted to $6,004,500, compared with $10,400,600 on Saturday, Dec. 19.

Miss Valerie Angel, 21 years old, daughter of a Canadian wheat exchange operator, was instantly killed today when the coupe in which she was riding struck two trees and broke in two. Her escort, Louis S. Hatzfeld, 27 years old, of Rye, was critically injured. He was taken to the St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains.

United States cane sugar refiners await urgently needed revision of the United States Sugar Plan which permits quotas of tropical refined sugar to enter this country to supply more than 13,000,000 persons, according to Earl D. Babst, chairman of the board of the American Sugar Refining Company.
IN his earlier stories Stuart Palmer has written of the adventures in detection of Hildegarde Withers, an elderly schoolteacher.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter Livingston Titus gave a dinner with dancing last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Margaret Louise Titus.

A general improvement in the condition of public schools from the distress occasioned by the depression was reported today by John W. Studebaker, Commissioner of Education, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior.

Leading cities throughout the country report generally better local fiscal conditions at the start of the new year than they did a year ago. Better tax collections, coupled in most cases with curtailed spending, have put municipalities from coast to coast in a sounder financial position than they occupied at the start of 1936.
Miss Mary Louise Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rogers Hall of Hingham, was married this afternoon to Dr. William Hunter Stearns, son of Mrs. Hunter Stearns of New York.
Senator Glass, reflecting today that he will start a new six-year term on his seventy-ninth birthday Monday, expressed a hope that he might live to see 80.

The trustees of Tuckahoe, N. Y., will consider bids on Jan. 11 for a new issue of $87,000 of general improvement bonds dated Feb. 1, 1937, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1938 to 1957. The interest rate is not to exceed 6 per cent.

Described by the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street station as "the maniac who has kept the Bellevue Hospital district in a state of jitters" for the last year by turning in false fire alarms, Jerry O'Connor, 42 years old, of 295 Third Avenue, a discharged member of the Fire Department, was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail after he had been found guilty of turning in a false alarm Friday.
LONDON. FROM time to time there arise discussions of the question whether American books receive a fair deal in this country.

A move by export trade organizations to get early action by the Senate in approving the sanitary agreement with Argentina, will be made as soon as Congress convenes, it was learned here yesterday. The convention, once ratified, will make it possible for the United States to lift the embargo now placed on meats from Argentina.

Motor boat racing champions of two continents are to gather for the second annual "Dinner of Champions" at the Hotel Montclair on Thursday evening, Jan. 14, according to an announcement yesterday by William Edgar John, executive secretary of the American Power Boat Association.

Cooperation of the Commissioner of Education of the State of New York will be asked by Mrs. William Dick Sporborg in inaugurating a campaign of education among the pupils of junior and senior high schools covering the devastating effects of the use of the marihuana weed.
An allowance of $25,000 a month for Mrs. Margaret A. Couzens, widow of Senator Couzens, has been authorized by Probate Judge Thomas C. Murphy.

With Winter and cold weather at hand, the old coal pile down in the cellar is melting like a cake of ice on a July afternoon. The hurried worker or housewife who leaves a shovelful of coal in the furnace these frosty mornings may think, "Well, it keeps us warm but it's dirty and dusty black stuff."

Ontario's fifty-three producing gold mines had a total output of $73,096,538 in the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, the Department of Mines reported this week. This compared with $67,622,332 in the same period last year.

Those of us who have long venerated the Middle West as the seat of all the virtues and the mighty mother of a treasured regional literature will read with pain what Mr. JOHN ABBOT CLARK says about it in The Southern Review.
Teams representing New York and Chicago made impressive showings today in the first round of the men' intercity matches of the national table tennis tournament.

Promoted and Assigned The following sergeants having been promoted to the rank of lieutenant are transferred and assigned as indicated: To take effect Jan. 1: Edward M. Donlan, from Traffic Precinct C to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector. Assigned to desk duty:

AN exhibition of old tavern signs like that now being held at London could well be staged in the United States. There are numerous American collectors of such symbols of hospitality and a short while back some of them contributed to a loan display held at the Metropolitan Muscum of Art. Since then the votaries of this hobby have greatly increased.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the Snow Ball in behalf of the Lenox Hill Hospital, which will be held on Jan. 20 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Ladies' Aid Society of the hospital. Mrs. Card Eggers heads the executive committee for the benefit and assisting are members of the Junior Aid League of the hospital.

The status of the League of Nations and its prospects as the new year opens depend on how the world situation develops in 1937. That situation was likened today by a high League official to a huge dam capable of producing either undreamed-of wealth if the water it has stored up is kept under control or unimaginable disaster if a flood breaks loose.

Stocks sagged and closed lower in slowest Saturday trading since Oct. 24; sales, 690,660 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds irregular, South American issues higher; transactions, $5,918,500.
Harry Morrison Cheney, one-time speaker of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, and secretary of Masonic grand bodies of New Hampshire since 1909, died suddenly yesterday at his home here.

LOOKING back over the events of the past twelve months, a survey of recording activities during 1936 discloses fresh vigor on the part of the producers, an increasing interest on the part of the public and immeasurably higher standards of recording to justify an even better state of affairs.

Alice Nielsen, former opera singer, has brought suit to compel her husband, Dr. Leroy R. Stoddard, who has offices at 29 West Fortysecond Street, to pay her $15,000 under an agreement made six years ago, which he repudiates, and force him to pay her $325 a month for life, it was disclosed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

More than twice as much work in private industry engaged in supplying materials as In those industries actually engaged in construction on the site has been provided by PWA activities, officials said today in a further favorable appraisal of PWA work.

Opposition to the return of the NRA system to their particular line of business was expressed by 89 per cent of the 200 members of the Economic Credit Council of the National Association of Credit Men in a survey just completed. The members queried represent companies in the banking, manufacturing and wholesaling fields.

Forty-five organizations operating in the fields of health, civic matters, welfare and peace will be represented at a luncheon under the auspices of the trustees of the Public Education Association on Jan. 16 at the Hotel Commodore.

Statistics compiled at the Duke University Law School show that 50 per cent of the students are sons or daughters of men engaged in business, manufacturing, banking, construction, wholesale or retail merchandising.
Five spills gave polo fans extra thrills today as the daring Mexican Army riders defeated a picked United States Army team, 7 to 4, for their first victory in three games.

With the almost airtight goal tending of Bert Gardiner featuring his team's victory, the Philadelphia Ramblers defeated the New Haven Eagles, 2-1, in an International American League hockey game tonight before a capacity crowd of 5,000.

Soccer in the East departs from its customary mid-season competition with the listing of all-star games today which will bring together selected elevens of the professional leagues against picked teams of the various State football associations.
Mr. and Mrs. George Estabrook Brown of 1,172 Park Avenue gave a buffet dinner dance last night in the Tapestry Room of the SherryNetherland for their debutante daughter, Miss Miriam Harriett Brown.
AUTHORS and publishers are invited to submit entries in the sixth annual California Literature Medal Award Contest of the Commonwealth Club of California. There are five rules:

The orchestra seats have been taken over by the Little Italy Neighborhood Association for the performance of "The Wingless Victory" on Jan. 18 at the Empire Theatre. Miss Louise Goetze is chairman of the benefit committee.

The first in a series of lectures by the Rev. Cyprian Truss, O. S. F. C., to help the philanthropic work of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd will be given Wednesday night at Sherry's. The subject will be "The Dreamers."
Contracts will be awarded Jan. 15 for a $950,000 general library building of the University of Virginia. It must be completed by Jan. 31, 1938.

Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Foreign Minister and head of the Brazilian delegation to the Inter-American Peace Conference, tendered his resignation from the Foreign Office today and President Getulio Vargas accepted it.

The supposed "contact" advertisement in the Charles Mattson kidnapping reappeared tonight, indicating a continuation of family efforts to deal with the abductor regardless of sudden police pursuit of several "clues."

American Legion Auxiliary (Teaneck, N. J. Post)-Party at home of president, Mrs. Laura Traggorth, West Englewood. Athena Club of Freeport-Meeting, 2:30 P. M., Presbyterian Church parish house. Musical.
The annual specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America will be held Jan. 11 at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals. Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren,

Miss Sallie Mellon and Miss Margaret Rives head the junior committee for the supper dance to be given on Jan. 11 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Christadora House, which provides educational recreation privileges for hundreds of children and their elders in the neighborhood surrounding its location at 147 Avenue B.

Passage by Congress of new laws "to protect the smaller industries and smaller merchants is the only way we are ever going to get consistent prosperity in this nation," George J. Burger, secretary treasurer of the National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, Inc., writes in a letter to the editor of the business page, commenting on an article appearing on this page last Sunday.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Peters of Flushing, Queens, and Dorset, Vt., gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Polly Peters, to Anthony Kohout Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Kohout of East Rockaway, L. I.

Efforts of the railroads to have the fourth section of the Interstate Commerce Act repealed or changed at the coming session of Congress will be fought by water transportation interests, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
Mr. and Mrs. Roy H. Kiroh of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Kirch, to Donald K. Sleburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Sieburg Jr. of New York.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to its list Francisco Sugar Company no-par capital stock and United Paperboard Company, Inc., $10 par common stock. It has suspended from dealings the following issues: Second National Investors CorporationCommon stock. $1 par value, and $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock, $1 par value.

In accepting a commission as lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps Reserve, James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, has joined a civilian force whose members, in the event of a national emergency, would receive an early call.
Dr. Charles R. Skinner, editor of The Hoosick Falls Democrat before he studied medicine, died in a hospital here yesterday of pneumonia. He was 65 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Auth of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Auth, to Joseph T. Gallagher, son of Joseph F. Gallagher of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Gallagher.

MAKING music for America on and off the radio is both a challenge and a very great responsibility, John Barbirolli, conductor of the Philharmonic Symphony Society, told the audience of station WQXR, New York, in a recent broadcast.

Philip Daley, 23 years old, was killed, and James Corvan, also 23, was severely injured early today when the automobile in which they were driving from their homes in Flushing, Queens, New York City, to Philadelphia, struck a telephone pole on the Lincoln Highway near Morrisville.

The State Mortgage Commission will concentrate this year on facilitating the refinancing of mortgages based on certificated issues which have not paid any interest, show no promise for the immediate future and hold out little likelihood that investors will receive more than a part of the money which they invested.

The University Club of Stamford basketball team opened its schedule in the Eastern Athletic Club League by defeating the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A., 38-31, on the losers' court last night. The victors led at half time, 19-10.

PROOF that Metro-Goldwyn' Mayer intend to make their English productions as important as their Hollywood films is given by the fact that they, have appointed one of Britain's best-known and most energetic pros ducers, Michael Balcon, to be pros duction manager for MGM a? Elstree.

Mrs. Yetka Levy-Stein of Berlin arrived here last week on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to make a three-month tour of the United States on behalf of the Youth Aliyah movement, which is concerned with the settlement of German-Jewish children in the cooperative colonies of Palestine.

Canny as they never were before, chastened by their failures yet stimulated by their successes at the last session, the indefatigable delegations from feminine organizations swerve from other objectives this week to Albany, and the reopening of the Legislature.

Interest in writing and publishing has increased at Wheaton with the growth of the Wheaton College Press, which is celebrating its third birthday. It was founded as something of a rarity, for few women's. colleges have presses of their own.

The engagement of Miss Saradora Denton, daughter of Mr. And Mrs. A. Penn Denton of this place, to Karl G. Plitt Jr., son of Mr. And Mrs. Karl G. Plitt of St. Louis, has been announced. Miss Denton is a senior at the School of Journalism at the University of Missouri.

Members of the public speaking course at Wesleyan University are hearing themselves as others hear them. Through the use of speechrecording equipment the twentyfour members of the class have made records of their voices and are analyzing the results.

A SINGLE political dynasty, the La Follette. has been dominant in Wisconsin for a generation and more. and tomorrow, with the inauguration of Philip F. La Follette as Cover or for the third time, another chapter ?? open in the history of the family's political fortunes.

TEN years ago the Old Vie was a theatre chiefly devoted to usefully pious but often slightly dull productions of Shakespeare. You went there in confidence that a reasonable and ungarbled performance would be your reward but seldom in expectation of the bold, the experimental or the adventurous.

Opening of the subway extension of the municipal system as far as Kew Gardens last week was hailed by civic and real estate interests in Forest Hills, Kew Gardens and the surrounding neighborhoods as one of the most important events in the history of the area.

Constitutionality of the act requiring coal companies to file every three months with municipalities maps showing the extent of mining operations was questioned by Judge Clarence D. Coughlin today in a decision dismissing proceedings against John A. Gavern of Scranton, president of the Gavern Coal Company.

Twenty or more highway workers were reported today to have been killed when thirty boxes of dynamite exploded on the Bermejillo el Palmito Road. Bodies of the victims were said to have been hurled high into the air.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Somerville, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Joan Somerville, to William F. Stafford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Stafford of New York and Huntington, L. I.
In twelve trial grounds, located in widely separated parts of the country, flower novelties from all over the world are grown for a season in advance of their introduction to American gardens.

The officially inspired press campaign against Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld, fiance of Princess Juliana of The Netherlands, for his alleged failure to protect "German honor" in his new fatherland apparently came to a close tonight with the mutual severance of friendly relations between the Prince and the National Socialist authorities.

LONDON.--The amazing growth of the London press with its millions of circulation has not suppressed the many sturdy local English newspapers, entrenched as they are in the interests of the regions they faithfully serve.

With 258 of its 502 projects completed, the Federal Public Works Administration in this State has provided more than 200,000,000 man-hours of work and made possible the expenditure of $423,000,000 on new schools, hospitals, water supply and sewage disposal plants, highways, bridges and other public works, Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, declared yesterday in his annual report to Administrator Harold L. Ickes.

FOR Boston, Helen Jerome's dramatization of "Jane Eyre" was more than just a play. With Katharine Hepburn in the cast, the first performance at the Colonial bore the marks of an event. To add to the occasion, the playwright was present.

The statement of condition of the First National Bank of New York as of Dec. 31, published yesterday, discloses that the bank's surplus was increased $20,000,000 in the last quarter of the year, thus being restored to the level of $100,000,000 that prevailed before 1932.
ALTERBAUM--SILVERMAN--Mrs. Gussie Silverman of 798 Hopkinson Av., Brooklyn, announces the engagement of her daughter, Isabel, to Richard Alterbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Alterbaum. Brooklyn.

The speed and skill of Dartmouth's hockey team were insurmountable obstacles to the ambitions of the Colgate skaters tonight and the Maroon went down to a 12-1 defeat before a Playland crowd of 2,000.

Ernest Saumier, 14, of Saranac Lake, was drowned today in a skating accident in which a chum was rescued by Bennett Cerf, New York publisher, and William Morris Jr., son of the late theatrical producer.

Hundreds of patrons of music representing society and the fine arts have made reservations for the tribute dinner to Lucrezia Bori which will take place tonight in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
The interposition of a holiday last week not only reduced the trading totals of the markets by one day, but also influenced irregular movements of prices, notably in the case of stocks.

TRADE reports turned somewhat spotty in the week, with some centers describing post-holiday volume as holding up better than usual, while others found recessions. It was indicated that the heavy holiday buying was bringing along the usual reaction and also that prospects of labor trouble might be influencing reduced consumer expenditures.

HERE is the book about the modern dance which--whether consciously or not--we have been looking for. "Modern" is not a good word; in its art connotations it is in fact, declares Mr. Martin, an execrable word.
Two New York City residents were the first couple to be married in 1937 in the Municipal Building Chapel.

Killed by monoxide gas, Miss Marie Hucul, a night club singer and factory girl, and Frank Kroupa, a New Haven railroad mechanic and former soldier in the Philippines, both 23 years old, were found dead this morning in Kroupa's car, which was parked on a street In Guilford, twenty miles east of here.

The Bronx Terminal Market may house the city's first food trades' vocational high school, if Mayor La Guardia approves a plan to be laid before him this week by Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Bronx member of the Board of Education.

This week's order to plants of the Commissariat of Heavy Industry to reorganize their office staffs along American lines is the latest of many attempts to conquer bureaucracy, which is one of the greatest single concrete handicaps upon Soviet development.

Now that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is safe again in Nanking and the government has rejected his two purely formal offers to resign his office, one great question remains: Where does the recent amazing Chinese melodrama leave China and China's relations with Japan and Russia?

What is believed here to be the first ski museum in America has been started by the Dartmouth Outing Club. Taking its cue and its inspiration from the Norwegian ski museum near Oslo, the club has collected a dozen pairs of skis of historic interest, along with a miscellaneous assortment of poles and bindings, and has put its embryo display into a room provided by the Wilson Museum.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has discussed With representatives of the New York Stock Exchange tentative drafts of its regulations covering preliminary steps in the commission's program for the partial segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers and expects that they will be made applicable, in complete form, not later than Feb. 1.

THE title Mr. Howe gives his book about Denmark makes one think he must have been reading Mr. Childs's book about Sweden. In fact, Mr. Howe began to think about cooperation a long time before Mr. Childs did, and his present volume, although mostly new, is really a bringing down to date of his "Denmark".
IF justice is served this morning I shall be. amazed. for there is no procedure more arbitrary, unreasonable, tortured and meaningless than the selection of an annual best-ten list.

AN illuminated scroll bearing he signatures of a committee of prominent citizens, headed by Mayor La Guardia, Olga Samaroff Stokowski and Richard Welling, will be presented to David Mannes this Saturday night at the first orchestral concert of his twentieth season at the Metropolitan Museum.

For nineteen years two men have struggled to control a political machine that involves the fate of millions. The machine is the Third International, which rules in large degree the U.S.S.R. and has weight in the internal politics of many nations.

It is with a sigh of relief, rather than of regret, that one bids farewell to the past year. It is true that conditions in our own country have steadily improved and that all signs point to continued progress if only peace can be preserved. In the United States,

Eastern real estate bond average prices, based on market action of 200 typical issues, comprising the Amott-Baker realty bond price averages, increased 3 per cent in December, the largest increase recorded for any month of the year.

Interest in writing and publishing has increased at Wheaton with the growth of the Wheaton College Press, which is celebrating its third birthday. It was founded as something of a rarity, for few women's. colleges have presses of their own.

WHEN the theatre was the theatre and the road was the road, the Florodora Girls were the delight of audiences throughout the land. Even today that name conjures up memories of all that was romantic and gay on the stage.

Sixteen States and four foreign countries are represented by 112 resident graduates at Rutgers University, Dr. Walter C. Russell, executive secretary of the graduate faculty, announced today. Two graduate students are from Canada and one each from China, Germany and India.

"Our wish above all for Europe and the world is peace. May the year to come be a peaceful one and may it make way for long peaceful years thereafter." Such was the hope expressed by Leon Blum, Premier of France, in his radio talk to the French people on New Year's Eve.

Sun-rose or Rock-rose (Hielianthemum) is one of several flowers which make a gorgeous display in the garden in late May and June. It grows from six to ten inches high; its inch-wide blossoms are white, yellow, red or else pink.

Stimulated by the threat of a general European war, and prodded to immediate activity by the discovery of a loophole in our present laws by which it is possible for Americans to help arm one or the other faction in Spain, neutrality advocates this week plunged once more into a debate over the question of executive discretion as opposed to specific Congressional mandate.

James B. Thorsen, 77 years old, retired insurance broker, died in his apartment at Evanston today of bronchial pneumonia Mr. Thorsen retired two years ago as head of the James B. Thorsen and Sons insurance firm which he organized in 1900.

As the first of five outstanding American women to be honored by the Catholic Young Women's Club, Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, founder and president of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, will be the guest this afternoon at a reception-tea to be held at the clubhouse, 641 Lexington Avenue.
The estate of the late Mrs. Ida E. Wood, widow of Benjamin Wood, publisher, was appraised at $877,598.32 in an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Public Administrator James F. Egan.
Of 844 new criminal cases prosecuted during 1936 by Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, 660 were completed either by convictions or pleas of guilty. There were 581 guilty pleas.

IT has been a bewildering week for this vigilant observer of scientific progress. In Atlantic City there was the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science; in New York the American Chemical Society convened to review important advances in its field;
With the terms of the British-Italian accord still undisclosed, London's Sunday newspapers are hesitant to comment, although it is generally acclaimed.

A son, their first child, born recently to Mr. and Mrs. Daniel K. Cadwell is the sixth generation from father to son to live on the Cadwell farm, South Mountain Road, which never has been transferred by the family from the original grant by King George II to Abel Cadwell in 1748.

Mrs. Leigh J. Sessions, president of the Hudson Avenue Boys Club, has announced additional subscribers for the card party and sale to be held under the auspices of the executive committee on Jan. 13 at The Towers, Brooklyn.
Play in the Tri-County Hockey League will be resumed tomorrow night when Baisley Park plays Crown Heights and Lynbrook tackles Baldwin in a twin bill at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

Seventy canvases of old and new masters, one of the finest colleo tions ever presented here, eom prised the second exhibit of the So city of the Four Arts, opening this afternoon with a tea and prehvie to members at the galleries.

Air Minister Caranfil unexpectedly resigned today and his post was taken temporarily by Premier George Tatarescu. The cause of the resignation was officially declared to be a lack of understanding with War Minister General Paul Angelescu.

Stabbed to death with the same long-handled kitchen knife, the bodies of Major Peter Charles Geyer Jr. of the Marine Corps and his mother, Mrs. Eliza Geyer, were found at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in a third-floor rear apartment at 214 West Ninety-sixth Street, at the southeast corner of Broadway.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, sees the new year as presenting "important opportunities to labor," one of the greatest of which will be its "contribution to the observance and enforcement of the Social Security Act."

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that, effective immediately, Pacific Railroad of Missouri 5 per cent bonds, due in 1938, should be quoted ex interest 2 1/2 per cent and that the following bonds should be dealt in "flat":

Hershey defeated the New York Rovers, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight. Less than five minutes before the end Tom Graboski, a first-year man, flipped in the winning goal. The players were milling around Inglis, the Rover goalie, who had just dropped to the ice to bar Russell's rush. Instead of shooting, Russell passed to Graboski.

As Senators and Representatives gathered in Washington today for the opening of Congress next week, the question of a Constitutional Amendment granting the Federal or State Governments power to regulate hours, wages and working conditions was raised to a place of importance among the issues to be considered at the coming session.

Miss Jeanne Maguire gave a supper dance at her home tonight. Her guests included the Misses Victoria Worrell, Gypsy Boag, Polly Storey, Marie Grandeman, Marcelle Figueroa, Dorothy Black, Jean Summersgill, Dorothy Calcagno, Jean Egly, Virginia Green, Vivian Martin,

President Roosevelt seems to take particular delight in testing the savoir-faire of his officials and of others who have occasion to telephone the White House. He tried it the other day on Secretary Wallace.

The early date of Easter this year--March 28-will probably result in a "difficult delivery and production situation," Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday. He pointed out that, although Easter fell on April 12 last year, the productive capacity of the industry was actually exceeded in March and manufacturers were unable to make timely deliveries.

Mrs. Frederick Edey of the National Organization of Girl Scouts will be the speaker at a luncheon of the education committee of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum on Friday. "The Meaning of Recreation in the Lives of Young People" will be her subject.

The tidal wave of sit-down strikes that has been sweeping General Motors factories in other cities struck here as the old year ended, forcing more than 30,000 men out of work when seven plants closed and five more were affected.

AIRPLANES are the moving vans of Canada's northland beyond the railways, carrying everything from a carton of eggs to motor boats. Recently an entire mining town was transported from the end of rail and water transportation in Northern Ontario to a site nearly 100 miles distant in the virgin bush where a prospestor had struck pay dirt.

The first all-professional figureskating show ever to tour the country will reach the Madison Square Garden the night of Jan. 11. Called S the "Ice Follies of 1937" and headlined by such famous stars as Roy Shipstad, the crack comedy team of Eddie Shipstad and Oscar John- C son and Heinie Brock, comedy soloist, the troupe will offer a full evening's entertainment of group numbers, pair and solo skating specialties.
Branch Rickey, general manager of the Cardinals of the National League, tonight announced the appointment of Robert L. Finch as vice president of all Cardinal minor league baseball clubs.

FROZEN cream--2,000 pints of it are being shipped to Russia for the use of Ambassador Davies--is the latest addition to the long list of fresh foods which are being processed in America for delayed consumption.
"Brooklyn and Brooklyn's Part in the World's Fair" will be the topic of a meeting tomorrow afternoon arranged by the educationcivics department of the Brooklyn Woman's Club, 114 Pierrepont Street.

THE unaccountable Martha Graham has accomplished another surprise. In the week which elapsed between the first and second performances of her new work, "Chronicle," she not only made revisions in its choreography and costuming, but actually managed to alter its general direction and manner of functioning.

AFTER a quarter of a century of realistic fiction, most novelists are still groping in a kind of romantic fog. Nine-tenths of every human life is made up of the commonplace but absorbing business of trying to get along in the world on any terms.
The Squadron A polo team defeated the Bluebirds, 15 to 10 1/2, in the feature game of a special matinee program arranged for members of the Boys Club at Squadron A Armory yesterday.
In an unusually rough contest the Red Bank Polo Club triumphed over the Nassau Polo Club of Long Island, 7 to 3 1/2, at the Essex Troop Armory tonight.

The rejuvenated Canadiens of Montreal, still skating along at the head of the pack in the International Group of the National Hockey League, will seek to make their position more secure when they tackle Red Dutton's tumbling New York Americans at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The Spanish Government declared through its embassy here today that the attack upon the freighter Soton had been an "act of war" by Germany and it warned of reprisals.

HERE is a very handsome book which is as delightful as it is informing. It presents a panorama of American life through 200 years. or from the Mayflower to the Civil War, in twelve scenes, each of which centers about a room of the period.

The engagement of Miss Beryl Elise Fine of 40 West Seventy-second Street, daughter of Harry Fine of Laurel, Miss., and the late Mrs. Fine, to Nathan W. Goldstein, son of Mrs. Harry B. Goldstein of this city and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Goldstein, has been announced by her father.
Dr. Louis I. Newman, rabbi of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, will speak over WHN tomorrow at 8:45 P. M. on the Gustave Hartman Memorial Appeal Committee program. The committee,

The Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School natators will be seeking to clinch the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming championship when they engage St. Michael's High in one of the three concluding dual meets of the season in the Columbus Council K. of C. pool next Sunday afternoon.

ASCH--To Mr. and Mrs. Dudley J. Asch, a son, on Dec. 29, 1936, at Park East Hospital. BEARCE--A son to Mr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Bearce, on Dec. 28, 1936, at Park East Hospital. BERNSTEIN-Dr. and Mrs. Lionel H. (nee Hilda Mormar), daughter, Jan. 2.
BENEFACTOR: The 70-year-old founder of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, Sir Henri Deterding, gave up active direction of his great oil empire last week and
THE near future will probably witness the establishment of an interesting new Schubert shrine, not in Vienna but in Czechoslovakia (specifically in Northern Moravia).

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marion Vincent Pollock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Vincent Pollock of Adelphi Hall, Jackson Heights, Queens, to Carl George Witte, son of Mrs. Charles J. Witte of Verona, N. J.. and the late Mr. Witte.

Miss Marguerite Adele Heine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bernard Heine of 285 Riverside Drive and Lake Mahopac, N. Y., was married to Ferdinand Barlow, son of Halsted Barlow of Granite Springs, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Barlow, last night in St. Peter's Lutheran Church by the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Moldenke, the pastor.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Lrynam Hikes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lynam Hikes of this city, to Arthur Turner Sutherland, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Arthur Sutherland of New York.

The recent collapse of two tenement buildings in South Philadelphia, at a cost of seven lives, has had the effect of centering attention on the city's slum areas to a degree which any number of housing surveys and any amount of oratory would have failed to accomplish.

Heart trouble and the keen eye of Jacob Bastocky, a 22-year-old drug store messenger who is an avid reader of detective story magazines, have led to the transfer of his erstwhile fellow-patient from Presbyterian Hospital to the prison ward in Bellevue.

Present developments are putting a premium on good management service, Jeremiah Cronin, vice president in charge of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York, told members of the Real Estate Committee of the Young Men's Board of Trade at a recent meeting.
Stand Pat, E. F. Seagram's 6-year-old chestnut horse, staged a stretch drive today to win the $3,500 added Santa Margarita Handicap, feature race at Santa Anita Park.

Princeton University's wrestling squad was the one Tiger varsity team to submit an unblemished record in dual competition over the course of the calendar year 1936 and with the opening 1937 meet a week in the offing Princetonians expect the Nassau matmen to enjoy another highly successful season.
WHEN we brought up the subject, in a spirit of pure wonderment, Irving Berlin, the Broadway-Hollywood commuter, seemed inclined to deprecate his amazing productiveness.

LOST EXPLORER: For nearly a quarter of a century Sir Hubert Wilkins has been exploring the vastnesses of the Arctic. His skill and intrepidity have won him a knighthood and dozens of medals. Last week the explorer got lost--in the city of Halifax, N. S.--while hunting for his hotel.

IT is time for the trotting horses to be out competing on the frozen lakes and rivers of Northern New England, where this thrilling form of harness racing is expected to attract extra attention this year.
New York State Assemblymen will have a Danish knight in their midst when the Legislature meets Wednesday, but Sir Otto Hillig doesn't plan to be "high hat."

A gown and ivory gavel will be presented to City Court Justice John A. Byrnes tomorrow at 11:30 A. M., at the City Court Building, 52 Chambers Street, by his former associates in the State Legislature.

The Italo-British exchange of assurances of peace in the Mediterranean has eliminated another danger spot in Europe by burying the last aftermath of sanctions, at least so far as Italy and Britain are concerned.
Troy Agnew, manager of the Augusta Baseball Club of the South Atlantic League, said today the New York Yankees will operate the local club this year.

Headed by Donald R. Lash of Indiana, Joe McCluskey of the New York A. C. and Marty Glickman of Syracuse, all members of the 1936 American Olympic team, a brilliant field will vie for prizes in the eleventh annual Columbus Council K. of C. indoor track meet at the 106th Infantry Armory on Saturday night.

IN her preface to this new volume of lyrics Sara Bard Field states her own apology for not writing revolutionary verse. And hers is many another poet's position- She has for many years taken part in movements for greater freedom, but she finds that her poetry for the most part remains aloof.

Among the major planning objectives of the Division of State Planning are a wiser and planned distribution of industry to constitute a first line of defense against recurring periods of depression; the reduction of excessive financing costs for permanent public improvements by a more general application of the pay-as-you-go method; adoption of an adequate program of flood protection; planning for future municipal water supplies, and better control of stream pollution.

With the total of new influenza cases for the last week rising to 699, a high mark for the current outbreak of the "mild type" of the disease, ambulance calls to police headquarters in Brooklyn and Manhattan last night indicated a continued increase in the number of persons affected.
The second of the Junior Assemblies for this season will take place on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton and will be preceded by many dinners for debutantes of the Winter.
Atilio Sabatino, Puerto Rican middleweight, knocked out Bobby Cortez of Mexico at the Rockland Palace last night before a crowd of about 3,000.

Mrs. John A. Donohue of 120 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mildred M. Donohue, to Walter E. Fitzpatrick, son of -Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Fitzpatrick.
Clark H. Newcomb's career as a barber shop proprietor ended just as it began thirty-six years ago, with Edmund L. Dininny in the chair.

The year 1937 sees the world perilously close to international war, but there is reason to believe that disaster will be avoided, Salvador de Madariaga, Spanish author and diplomat, said here in an interview.
Lindsey Hopkins of Miami Beach, formerly of Atlanta, with the members of his immediate family, today made a contribution of $100,000 to three Atlanta charities.
Dr. Louis Anspacher, author and dramatist, will talk on "Shakespeare as Lover and Poet" at a meeting of the Century Theatre Club on Friday at 1:30 P. M. in the Hotel Commodore.

Daughters of the American Revolution will concentrate their efforts during 1937 on helping the underprivileged, particularly boys and girls, young men and young women, who need assistance and guidance, says Mrs. William A. Becker, President General.

Discussing recently some trends of population growth and their effect upon mortgage security, Homer Hoyt, housing economist in the Federal Housing Administration, pointed out that trends in higherpriced areas usually enter in some degree into calculations of risks involved in loans on properties in other price ranges.

NAPLES-Naples is preparing to celebrate with its characteristic enthusiasm an event which has for the time being obscured interest in events in the Spanish war, in Geneva, in Ethiopia and lesser happenings.

King George and Queen Elizabeth draw few of their friends from the smart international set which was so sternly rebuked by the Archbishop of Canterbury in his broadcast speech after Edward's abdication. They have entertained the same small group, many of whom were companions of the Queen's girlhood days.

The question whether a county liquor authority can refuse to renew the package sale licenses of chain stores that undersell the independent dealer, on the ground independents are thereby tempted to illegal practices, will go to the State Supreme Court in Trenton during the term beginning Jan. 19.

Holiday paroles for Alabama's 494 best behaved prisoners were over today, but at least three convicts had decided to "extend" the two-week Christmas vacation that was given them by Governor Bibb Graves.

An atmosphere of informality, against a background of quiet elegance, will characterize the opening tomorrow afternoon of the new and completely furnished home of the Great Neck Woman's Club. Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be the speaker at the meeting, scheduled for 2:30 o'clock, which will be followed by a reception and inspection of the property.

Pressing the development of its program for the protection of the investor, the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to place in operation in 1937 several proposals on which much of the "spade work" was accomplished last year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Early in December Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, gave probably the best definition of credit which this writer has come across. He said: "Our last great boom was characterized by a very excessive expansion of credit, which means it was characterized by a very excessive creation of debt.

There is no information now available on which opinion may be based regarding the much-discussed purpose of the Italian Government to float a loan abroad in 1937. It is known, however, that within certain limits the government will not throw obstacles in the way of cooperation between foreign and Italian capital for development of the Ethiopian territory.

Van Cortlandt Av. (12-3335), s. e. cor. Rochambeau Av., 63x131; Lena Silver to Frances K. Teplitz, 808 West End Av.; installments, 4 per cent; $20,000. Crotona Av., 2,357 (11-3103); Mariannina Verde to Central Savings Bank, extends mtge. to Oct. 1, 1941, at 4 1/2 per cent; $26,700.

Much of the pressure in Tammany for a show-down on the future leadership of the organization is coming from the younger and newer members of the executive committee, it was said in informed quarters yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Suss, formerly of Brooklyn, N. Y., today announced the engagement of Mrs. Suss' daughter, Miss Helen Brown of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, to Arthur Morton Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Morton Brown of Hamden, Conn.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Glass of Rockville Center, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Delta Helen Glass, to James Sims Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Sims Wilson of Paris, Ky.

A belief that year wheat prices are to work irregularly higher is becoming more important to traders on both sides of the market, and there is a feeling among those who study foreign markets and conditions closely that grains, especially wheat, should be bought on all weak spots. Domestic trade leaders are working in and out on fair-sized lines, the desire being to take profits on sharp price upturns and replace on breaks.

To be unfailingly cheerful, polite and charming at home is one of the "very best New Year resolutions anybody can make," Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at high mass yesterday.

A wanderer who confessed, police said, that he broke into the house where Louisa Alcott wrote "Little Women," but could find "nothing worth stealing" in its collection of rare manuscripts and antique furniture, was in police hands today.

Speculative and consumptive trade in lard is said to have increased and there is also a liberal consumption of cottonseed oil. Prices hardened here at times last week, but ran into selling, which caused moderate recessions. At the finish.

Last year served to demonstrate the progress and stability of the gas industry in the United States, according to Alexander Forward, managing director of the American Gas Association, who adds that the year-end finds this century-old utility setting new records of service and usefulness.
Economic recovery continued throughout 1936 with a constantly widening base and may be considered an accomplished fact, according to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation.

The outlook for retail trade this year is fundamentally bright and a "very real source of increased buying may be expected from the expansion of residential construction likely to take place in 1937," acdording to Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company and chairman of the housing committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 88.8, which compares with 87.9 the week before, 87.3 two weeks before, 86.6 three weeks before and 86.7 four weeks before.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has purchased $250,000 of New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, it was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the fair's bond sales committee. The Rockefeller subscription was the largest individual purchase since the fair's committee of 1,600 volunteer salesmen undertook the campaign to distribute the $27,829,500 issue which will defray pre-fair costs.
Mrs. Alexander Bryan Johnson will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 115 East Ninety-second Street, for members of the executive committee of the Yankee Doodle Ball to be held on Jan. 16 at the

A message to the directors of many large corporations, urging them to "exercise wisely their privilege of responsibility" by supporting the United Hospital Campaign, has been sent by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Arthur A. Ballantine, Sloan Colt, Clarence Francis and John Sloane, leaders in the drive, it was announced yesterday.

A visiting barber from Torrington, Conn., who had lost $20 in an outdoor card game, was obliged to sign a complaint which sent the dealer to jail yesterday, even though the dealer made good his losses in Yorkville magistrate's court.

The year opened with little relaxation from the confident movement, in finance and industry, with which 1935 ended. The two events of January were the Supreme Court's decision against the government's Agricultural Adjustment statutes, and the passage of the Soldiers Bonus Bill by Congress over the President's veto, though with an inflationary amendment voted down by large majority in the Senate.
LONDON--The Anglo-Italian accord, made public yesterday, contains a strong clause declaring that both parties disclaim any desire to modify or see modified the Mediterranean status quo.

Swelled by industrial expansion, building construction in the South during 1936 totaled $939,264,000, a record for all time, according to figures compiled by the Manufacturers Record. Last month contract awards in the same territory amounted to $79,851,000, of which amounted to $79,851,000, of which $41,875,000 was for industrial improvements.

Playing one of their best games of the season, the New York Jewels downed the Kingston Colonials, third-place club of the American Pro Basketball League, by 32 to 21, last night in Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, The Associated Press reports.

Five Negroes were locked up last night in the West 135th Street station as members of a gang of holdup men responsible for sixty-five robberies of insurance company collectors in Harlem during the last two months. One of them was found to be armed with a stolen police service revolver.

Progress is not to be judged by time but by the ideas circulating within the minds of men, the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared yesterday morning at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
A new organization of milk producers entered the controversy in New England's milkshed tonight with a threat to "strike and dump" its milk unless dealers accepted a price it fixed.
Eugene O'Neill, American playwright and Nobel Prize winner, and his wife, the former actress, Carlotta Monterey, are both ill in Merritt Hospital. Oakland.

Twenty touches scored in each of the semi-final and final rounds gave Yale University's trio of Captain William Randall, Maurice Grasson and Philip Viscidi a surprise victory in the national junior epee team championship competition at the Fencers Club yesterday.

Penetrating areas for two years uninhabitable to missionaries because of unsettled military conditions, the Right Rev. Charles Stauffacher of Kansas City, Mo., Bishop for the Orient of the American Evangelical Church Mission, arrived here today.

A uniform style of architecture for buildings along Queens Boulevard, with jurisdiction vested in the Municipal Art Commission, will be proposed to the Board of Estimate today by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens.

The Rev. Valerius Nelles, O. F. M., retreat master of the St. Francis Retreat League, died today at the-St. Francis Retreat House at Mays Lake, the former Francis Peabody estate, near here. He was 67 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Mason Cook of Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Whiting Cook, to John Tyrrell Cheney Jr., son of John Tyrrell Cheney of this city and the late Mrs. Cheney.

It is on a very hopeful note that England enters 1937. That attitude necessarily implies this market's hope and faith that greater tranquillity and good will will be restored, not only to the economic but to the political world.

The Ohio Edison Company has advised holders of its first and consolidated mortgage bonds, 5 per cent series, due in 1960, that the bonds will be redeemed at the Bankers Trust Company on Feb. 1 at 105 and accrued interest.

Five years of monetary disorders reached a turning point last year with the collapse of the old gold standard in its last stronghold, the gold-bloc nations of Europe, and the beginnings of international efforts to restore currency stability.

Freezing weather with temperatures probably hovering around 25 degrees was predicted for the early hours this morning by the Weather Bureau. There were indications that this coming cold wave would be caused in part by the drifting eastward of the Midwestern subzero weather.

The prospects for the electrical manufacturing industry are very bright at the turn of. the-year, according to Andrew W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

Dr. Joseph E. Fuld, consulting surgeon at City Hospital, on Welfare Island and a specialist on hand injuries, died yesterday at his home, 125 East Eighty-fourth Street. Dr. Fuld,-- who was 64 years old, was stricken with a heart attack while in bed.

The Big Ten basketball race, bearing promise of being one of the liveliest in several seasons, will get under way tomorrow night with five highly regarded quintets seeing action.

Last year was marked by aggressive resistance on the part of most of the important public utility companies to new legislation, regulation, regulatory measures and government competition set in motion by Congress and various Federal organizations.

The new $3,500,000 United States Destroyer Lamson, built at Bath, Me., and commissioned last October, will leave the Navy Yard here tomorrow on a shakedown cruise to Caribbean and South American ports.
Even allowing for the difference in the dates on which the Bank of England's return is made up, it is evident that circulation is being maintained at a record level, thanks to the expansion of trade.
Despite unsettled conditions in labor and the threatening international situation, the underlying trends are favorable, Robert Lehman, president of the Lehman Corportion, said yesterday.

Free advance copies of "Invasion," by Maxence van der Meersch, the author who won this year's Prix Goncourt, are offered by the Viking Press to the first fifty persons, not connected with reviewing or bookselling, who write to them offering to give a reader's report on the novel. The publishers followed the same practice when they brought out, "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" by Franz Werfel in 1934.

After being delayed by the fog outside the harbor yesterday morning the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic, with 482 cruise passengers, was held in Quarantine for forty-five minutes because of engine trouble.

The meeting scheduled to be held tomorrow at the Harvard Club may have an important bearing on whether the National Retail Dry Goods Association affiliates with the American Retail Federation, according to reports here yesterday.

Despite new funds created by the Bank of France, the money market here was slightly tight as usual at the yearend. Although the acceptance discount rate still was 2 1/3 per cent, day-to-day money advanced from 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 per cent.

In diversification of activity as well as dealer and investor particination, the 1936 over-the-counter market in New York was the most productive since 1929, according to Colonel Oliver J. Troster of Hoit,

The Swedish Soccer Club yesterday won from the Segura eleven, 5 to 2, in a Metropolitan League game at Dana Park in Brooklyn, after leading by 2-0 by half-time. Midway in the first half, Anderson opened the scoring for the victors, then Nelson drove in a second tally.

LONDON, Jan. 3.--The new Anglo-Italian agreement faces in two directions. On the one hand, its object is to liquidate a past that both governments now wish to forget--namely, the quarrel over Ethiopia. On the other hand, the agreement, with its annexes, published and secret, represents a move to prepare the way for close collaboration of Britain and Italy in the Mediterranean.

Encouraged by the increase in the volume of business and prospects for the future, the railroads moved forward with quickened pace in 1936, according to A. D. McDonald, president of the Southern Pacific Company.
