Her right leg jammed in the triangular space between a drain pipe, a brick wall and a steel bracket supporting the pipe, a young woman dangled nine stories above ground early yesterday morning after what police described as an attempt at suicide.

Peace will be achieved only when men live in a world where truth has universal application, Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street. Rabbi Perilman

Mr. and Mrs. James A. Thomas of Homeside, White Plains, N. Y., will give a large dinner this evening in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, and Mrs. Sze.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has paid a semi-annual dividend at the rate of 2 per cent annually, George MacDonald, chairman, announced yesterday. The disbursement covers the six months to Dec. 31.
The petroleum industry enters 1937 with its house in good order, according to Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in his year-end review of the industry.

With the increase of business, the amount that is being spent for better living is a healthful indication that America is on a solid foundation, according to George W. Mason, president of Kelvinator Corporation.

A prediction that the 1929 level of activity in the machine-tool industry would be matched this year was made in a statement prepared by Clayton R. Burt, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association and president of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company.

The new year is seen as one in which progress will continue to be made, but one in which the lessons of the past decade should be applied to safeguard the gains, in a review by Joseph Wilshire, president of Standard Brands, Inc.

While asserting that it would be difficult to appraise the railroad outlook for 1937, W. P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern Railway, predicted that favorable agricultural conditions would bring further improvement to his company's earnings.

The stock market was quiet in the last week of the year, but raw-material securities, particularly lignites, advanced substantially. Foreigners bought Farbenindustrie, Siemens Halske and leading potashes with blocked marks.
Dr. Hermann Rauschning, former Nazi President of the Danzig Senate, in an interview published in today's papers here, accuses Germany of being the chief disturbing factor in the Free City of Danzig.

The chemical industry made substantial progress in 1936. with sales running from 12 to 15 per cent ahead of- 1935, according to the executives of leading companies. The possibility of labor troubles in 1937 is the only cloud on the horizon of increased activity for that year, it was said.

Studying a rapid increase in America's farm tenant population, agricultural leaders in Congress were divided today over forms of legislation to combat what they viewed as a possible system of "rural serfdom".

The Union Temple quintet opened defense of the George V. McLaughlin Trophy by turning back the Crescent Athletic Club five, 37-28, on the losers' court yesterday. Union Temple has held the trophy for two years.

Grain future purchases on the Chicago Board of Trade for the four days last week showed a slight decrease in wheat and oats, but an increase in corn and rye, compared with the five days' trading in the previous week, while there were increases in all grains over the same time last year.

A large but well concealed body of government manhunters "moved in" formally on the Charles Mattson kidnapping case tonight. There was no direct information on the number of Federal men in the case, although during midweek forty or more were reported on the job. The sudden increase became noticeable last night.

Robert Rowlett, managing editor of The Nashville Tennessean, died today at the Jewish Hospital. His age was 48. A native of La Grange, Ky., Mr. Rowlett was a student at Ohio State University, 1912-13.
James M. Munroe, one of the oldest members of the bar of Anne Arundel County, of which Annapolis is the county seat, died last night at his home here of pneumonia. He was 80 years old.

Year-end changes in the partnership arrangements of more than a score of firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and in many other financial organizations were announced yesterday. Lehman Brothers announced the admission as partners of Thomas Hitchcock Jr. and Joseph A. Thomas. Mr. Hitchcock,

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,522,790,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
Representatives of local oil unions in Central Oklahoma agreed unanimously today to support employes of the Empire Oil and Refinery as Company in their sit-down strike at eight gasoline plants.

Senator Copeland of New York said here tonight that he understood that J. F. T. O'Connor "wanted to quit" as Controller of the Currency, but had heard nothing of a rumor that William T. McCaffrey, banker of Syracuse, N. Y., would take over the post.

116th St., 358 W., 18.9x100.11; Endurance Estates, Inc., to 1935 Realty Corp., 295 Madison Av. Same Property; 1935 Realty Corp. to Lenore Cohen, 315 North Gay St., Baltimore, Md. 131st St., 39-41 W., 25x99.11: same to same. 131st St., 62 W., 16.4x99.11; Everlasting Pealties, Inc., to same.
The year 1936 closed with business at the highest level since the depression began and 1937 opens with great expectations, says the National City Bank in its January bank letter, published today.

Following reports today of five commissariats, telling of overfulfillment of production plans for 1936, Soviet officials are hailing the past year as the best so far in Soviet industry. At the same time they call attention to some failures in the year, the most important being the deficit in coal production, and the government is already hammering for improvement in laggard departments.

The first large West Side housing operation of the new year was announced over the week-end when Morris Morgenstern and associates bought for cash the plot 96 by 100 feet at 5 to 11 West Eighty-sixth Street from George Ruppert.

Mrs. Ray Kashuk, 46 years old, of 481 Fort Washington Avenue, was killed at 4:35 P.M. yesterday when she jumped or fell from the roof of a seven-story apartment house at 569 West 150th Street, near Broadway. Her body was identified

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Carl Rawolle gave a tea this afternoon at their home here for 100 guests in honor of Miss Helen Brewster Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Morton of Glenbrook, Conn., whose engagement to Frederick Carl Rawolle Jr. was announced last Monday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 79 per cent of capacity, up from the week containing the Christmas holiday but down 4 points from the week before that, when tonnage output was the largest since September, 1929. Production was estimated on

Production of electricity by the electric light and power industry, together with power purchased from other sources, was estimated at 109,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours for 1936, a gain of 13.5 per cent over 1935 and 17 per cent over 1929.

Activity in the wool textile industry during 1936 was somewhat below that of 1935 but higher than during any other year since 1929, according to Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Business should be good, and common stocks should rise during 1937, provided that no obstacles are presented in the form of excessive regulation by the government, labor troubles and the international situation, according to Wallace Groves, president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation.

Freight-car loadings in the first quarter of 1937 will run about 9.2 per cent ahead of the total for the same period last year, according to estimates by the thirteen Shippers Regional Advisory Boards. Increases are anticipated in all but the Central Western and Northwest regions.
The official return to the end of November shows an abnormally heavy consumption of wheat due to the shortage of meat, to the use of wheat as fodder and to the inferior quality of the crop.

Miss Anne'Dieffenbach, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Hagen Dieffenbach of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to George Pettengill 3d, son of Rear Admiral TO and Mrs. George Pettengill of Washington.

The annual Christmas entertainment by the children in the St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum for Girls, 735 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, was held yesterday at the orphanage for members of the Emerald Association of Brooklyn.

Oxford University is making an appeal for one hundred thousand pounds for the promotion of biblical research. This is thought not to be an excessive sum for Oxford's part in a work of such magnitude and importance for future biblical scholarship.

The American Radio and Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that it had requested the Federal Communications Commission to make public the results of tests still being conducted on an automatic device for intercepting distress signals from ships at sea.

With business surging ahead, prospects of 10 to 15 per cent increases in advertising volume are foreseen for the new year by leaders in the field. Problems facing advertisers include more government control, the need for "selling" American business policies and rising costs of mediums.
The Syracuse Stars defeated the a speedy International-American League hockey game. The Stars rained pucks at the Pittsburgh goal, but close checking by the visitors kept the score down.

Corn traders were active buyers of futures on breaks here last week, absorbing the hedging sales by speculators. Country holders, particularly in Illinois and parts of Iowa, are not disposed to sell corn to any extent, so that the marketing movement is not heavy.
The death of Ross Alexander, screen actor, was pronounced as suicidal today by Detective Lieutenant Ray Giese.
Arturo Toscanini's triumphant progress through Palestine was marked today by a presentation of the title and deed to an orange grove in the Jewish settlement here.

The Reich's tax revenue for the first eight months of the financial year was 7,369,000,000 marks, against 6,223,000,000 marks in the same period of 1935. Analyzing Germany's total indebtedness, the Institute for Trade Research virtually declares that the Reich has no undivulged short-term debts for civil work-creation or rearmament, except its bills.

The blouse and skirt industries closed the year with the largest Fall volume in twenty years, according to B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Association of Blouse and Skirt Manufacturers. Gains for each industry averaged 20 per cent. Due to favorable style indications, manufacturers anticipate even greater gains during the coming season.

Detective Joseph Downey of the pickpocket squad dresses in the colleglate manner and is so boyish and guileless in appearance that pickpockets think they can ply their trade in his presence. Singlehanded, Downey arrested seven suspects in subway stations Saturday

On the whole, it seems likely that this year will see the West standing on its own feet, for the first time in five years. To some extent, immediate continuance of recovery, with the meagre crop returns of many farmers in 1936, depends on continued government aid.

Opening a nation-wide observance of the centenary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, famous evangelist, speakers representing the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago appealed here today for a return to "Moody's faith in the Bible as the inspired word of God."

Temperance education is one of the most important factors in liquor control, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, member of the New York State Liquor Authority, says in the current issue of ABC News, the official monthly publication of the authority, which appears today.

Two small boys, brothers, surprised while pilfering fruit and crackers from a market at 1,296 Third Avenue between Seventy-second and Seventy-third Streets, were taken into custody at 6 o'clock last night as juvenile delinquents.

Hundreds of thousands of families will suffer mental anguish and material hardship during 1937 because of deaths from accidents of a wholly preventable nature, Dr. J. V. DePorte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health, stated today in the department's Health News.

Elaborate financial and statistical studies of the $416,000,000 rapidtransit unification plan prepared by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. are being completed by the technical staff of the Transit Commission.
Cases of colds, grip, influenza and pneumonia treated in the hospitals in New York City yesterday were about the same in number as the day before, according to the Deapartment of Hospitals.
Indications point to improvement in life insurance business in 1937, according to Thomas A. Buckner, chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company.

Electricity had a more prominent part in American life during 1936 than ever before, in the opinion of J. F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, who says that "its increased use, both in greater quantities and in new applications, reflected continued improvement in general business."

Lawrence B. Simpson, the 35year-old Seattle seaman who introduced the toy balloon into the armory of "high treason," returned to this country yesterday after eighteen months in German jails and concentration camps.

" At the turn of the year we emphasize the two characteristics that are the strongest in the human race-memory and hope," the Rev. Wallace MacMullen said yesterday in his sermon at the Metropolitan Temple of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

The presence of mind of Anita Olsen, 7 years old, of 41-43 Fortythird Street, Sunnyside, Queens, probably saved the life of her cousin, Thomas Anderson, 4, when his left foot became wedged between a passenger elevator and the shaft yesterday.

William A. Dalton, president of the New York Athletic Club, and his board of governors yesterday accounted for their 1936 stewardhip to members of the Winged Foot organization in the sixty-eighth an-I nual report of the world's largest athletic club.

The Venezuelan Government has sequestered all properties there belonging to General Vicenzio Perez Soto and General Rafael Maria Velasco, valued at 18,000,000 bolivars in each case. General Perez Soto, formerly Governor of the rich oil State of Zulia, was once regarded as a likely successor to the late Prestdent Juan Vicente Gomez. He is now living in exile.

The struggle between democracy and dictatorship is a modern variant of the eternal struggle between Christianity and the deification of the State, the Rev. Dr. Hugh Black, Professor of Practical Theology at Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday

Louis Samuels, originator of the string band division of Philadelphia's traditional Mummers' parade, died today in the Graduate Hospital in his sixty-first year. He entered the hospital on Friday and missed seeing this year's parade.

Williams E. (Billy) Nesselhous, a leader in the machine that dominated Omaha politics for almost thirty years, died yesterday at Rochester, Minn., at the age of 72. He began as a street gambler in Omaha fifty years ago and his fortune was estimated at $2,000,000 at his death. He was a partner of

Rosalyn Tureck devoted her piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon to the three B's. She began with Beethoven's sonata, Op. 31, No. 2. The central arch of the program was Bach's "Goldberg" variations, complete.

As Democratic leaders made final arrangements here today for the opening Tuesday of the biennial general session of the Legislature, Representative Ellwood J. Turner, Delaware County Republican, announced

The large dividend declarations authorized toward the close of the year as a result of the tax on undistributed profits served to make more difficult the computation of stock values. Established rules for these' estimates were upset by the tax development.

Another term in prison, where he has spent more than half his life, faced Charles McCarthy of 210 East Eighty-fourth Street yesterday after seven policemen, with revolvers drawn, had battered down the door of his top-floor apartment and arrested him for threatening his two brothers with a pistol.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the California and Illinois "fair-trade" cases may set a precedent for design copyright legislation, giving the creator of a design the right to set the resale price, "thus opening a vast new field to the vagaries of pricefixing and price restrictions,"
Fifty-six card and dice players, arrested in three Saturday night raids, were discharged yesterday for lack of evidence by Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Washington Heights court.

The rise in bond prices and the marketing of new long-term corporate loans at record low interest rates were outstanding developments in the securities markets in 1936. While the steady and substantial advance in stocks, real estate and other markets had more of a "recovery" character, the rise in bond values to abnormally high levels had, by early Fall, reached the "boom stage."
Aimee Semple McPhersonandRheba Crawford, warring evangelists, today preached to their respective flocks, but made no reference to each other.
" The Eternal Road" will not open tonight at the Manhattan Opera House, as scheduled. It was postponed yesterday until Thursday evening. Last - minute problems
CROTON, Jan. 3.--The heavy rainstorm that swept the Croton River Valley today proved beneficial to the Croton water works of the New York City water system.

Investment trust management in this country is emerging from a period of "experimental development" and reaching an improved status, according to Merrill Griswold, chairman of the Massachusetts Investors Trust.

The City Commission will be asked to include in its 1937 budget an appropriation for the purchase of an incubator for the City Hospital as a result of charges made by Mr. and Mrs. William Weber of 395 South Orange Avenue, parents of a 2-dayold child who died at the hospital Oct. 31 after treatment in a respirator that had been used as an incubator.

An unusual volume of dress orders was received in the wholesale markets here last week, at a time when a seasonal lull is to be expected. Wide-spaced prints for street and evening wear sold well in all price groups.

An avalanche of rock, estimated to weigh as much as 10,000 tons, roared 500 feet down the side of Hook Mountain, about three miles from here, early last night, rattling windows and dishes in homes within a fivemile radius and spreading alarm through the countryside.

Three trainmen were killed tonight in the explosion of the locomotive of a westbound Wabash freight train a quarter of a mile west of the Adrian station. The victims were identified as Roy Mead, engineer; G. E. Johnson, fireman, and Charles R. Hudson, brakeman, all of Detroit.

Sherman S. Krellberg, lessee of the Belmont Theatre, 125 West Forty-eighth Street, announced yesterday that the house would be reopened within the next two weeks as a first-run motion-picture theatre. Its last tenant-on the...

Two hundred andfiftyrepresentative real estate issues experienced during 1936 an increase of 16.1 per cent in the average bid price, according to the real estate bond index prepared by Eli T. Watson Co. The index shows a total gain of 156 per cent for the four-year period from Jan. 1, 1933, to Jan. 1, 1937.

The course of bank credit in 1936 was, one of steadily expanding deposits, reflecting the rise of bank loans and investments. As in previous years, government deficit financing was an important factor in the expansion, but, for the first time since the recovery began, increasing demand for commercial loans played a decisive role.

Heavy drafts have been made on the world's carry-over of wheat during the last three years, and in 1936 particularly, due to deficit in production. The rapid increase in stocks from 1926 to the record-breaking total in 1934, and the subsequent decline, are shown in the following table,

The Coast Guard here reported today that only the airtight bulkhead was keeping the disabled freighter Lafcomo of the Lykes Line above water. Her crew of thirty-five till remained aboard the vessel despite the rain, fog and a raw wind that kicked up a choppy sea.

A plan for the reorganization of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad will be submitted tomorrow to Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks here. Irving A. Sartorius of Sartorius Smith, chairman of the bondholders' protective committee for the railway, will submit the plan of reorganization previously outlined before the court.

Offering will be made early this week of $10,000,000 of Union Oil Company of California fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures at 105 1/2 to holders of the company's 4 per cent debentures and to the public.

Police said today that three youths had admitted seizing Almedo Alfaro, 15, son of the Minister of Ecuador, on Christmas Eve, holding him captive in an automobile for several hours and robbing him of $20.

The net income of the Class I railroads in 1936 was about $150,000,000, compared with $7,539,127 in 1935, an increase of 1,889 per cent, and compared with a net loss of $16,887,078 in 1934, according to a review of the railroad situation by J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. The results for 1936 were the best since 1930.
Dr. H. S. J. Walker of the Buccaneer Yacht Club, Mobile, Ala., won the Interclub Fish race, feature event of the second annual Sugar Bowl regatta in a thrilling finish on Lake Pontchartrain today.

Governor Walter Welford, defeated Republican candidate for re-election, has served notice of an attempt to deprive William Langer, Independent, of the Governorship, claiming violation of the Corrupt Practices Act.

There was a decided gain in the amount of life insurance in force with virtually all companies in 1936, Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, reports in his review of the year. He declares there Is every reason to expect that 1937 will see more life insurance in force than ever before.

The University of Iowa athletic board will meet early this week to start the quest for Ossie Solem's successor. Apparently surprised by Solem's acceptance of an offer to succeed Victor Hanson as head football coach at Syracuse University, the board will be forced to start from scratch when it meets Tuesday or Wednesday.

Joseph Gaston Brenner of 39 West Fifty-fifth Street, president of Brennen, Joseph White, Inc., 36 West Forty-seventh Street, manufacturers of ladies' dresses, died on New Year's Day in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a brief illness following an operation for appendicitis. He was 57 years old.

The Detroit Red Wings scored their third straight victory of the season over Toronto's Maple Leafs, 4-2, before 12,644 spectators tonight to gain a tie for the leadership of the National Hockey League's American Group with the New York Rangers.

French business remained active up to the end of the year, particularly in retail trade. Fears of further rises in prices because of the introduction of the forty-hour work week have been inducing people to buy beyond their current needs, thus benefiting trade.

The Securities and Exchange Laws are seen as a menace to Stock Exchanges by W. W. Spaid, president of the Associate Stock Exchanges. "For 1937 I am bullish on general business, but bearish on Stock Exchanges," he said.
Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Forsythe of Arrowhead, Albemarle County, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Johnson Forsythe, to Larned Donaldson Randolph,

An unofficial check showed tonight that 13 of the 494 convicts at Speigner prison who received Christmas paroles from Governor Graves on Dec. 17 had broken their promise to return by New Year's Day. Warden J. H. Smith said, however: "I believe they are all on their way back, just running late.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend announced today that, effective Jan. 11, the weekly publication of his National Recovery-Old Age Pension organization would assume entire responsiability for financial support of the national headquarters.

The Treasury issued today new blue, green and white forms for filing income and excess profits tax returns. One form will be used for making returns under both the corporation and excess profits taxes.

Argentina's outlook for 1937 is highly promising, according to Conrado Traverso. Argentine Consul General. Agricultural prospects are very good, the nation's finances are on a sound basis and the foreign trade situation points toward a substantial export balance in 1937.

If the picture presented in the past six months of sustained, substantial and confident recovery in the United States can be taken as a guide to the future, your country's economic outlook for 1937 becomes altogether favorable.

Recent statements by importers "dwelling at length on the insecurity of crude botanical drug supplies" are dismissed by J. L. Hopkins, president of J. L. Hopkins Co., as "attempts to frighten manufacturers and other users of crude botanical drugs into needlessly unsafe quantity purchasing.

That racing in New York has made some large and important gains since it came under the supervision of the State Racing Commission is shown in the annual report which Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the racing body, submitted yesterday to Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State.
Mr. and Mrs. Forrest G. Purinton of Waterbury, Conn., had forty at a house-warming buffet luncheon yesterday at a log cabin they have just completed on the slope of Mount Sterling.
The law department of the National Association of Manufacturers opposed changes in the anti-trust laws today in a memorandum sent to members of the organization.

What is regarded as an important literary discovery, the autobiography of a pioneer militant feminist and evangelist who lived 500 years ago, has ben found in the archives of an ancient English family. It was identified and will be interpreted by Miss Hope Emily Allen, staff member of the Early Modern

Hotels in key cities are in line for substantially increased business during 1937, according to Ralph Hitz, president of the National Hotel Management Co., Inc. Hotels, as a general rule, he said, are the first to feel industrial retrenchment and about the last to show increased earnings when business begins to expand.

Clicking off three birdies on the final nine, Tony Manero, 1936 United States open champion, overtook Ray Mangrum of Dayton, Ohio, and the pair finished in a tie for first place today in the Miami open tournament at the Miami Springs Golf Club.
While holding that improvement depends on broad currents in national development, further gains in retail trade this year are foreseen by Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

American exporters enter the new year convinced that they will attain better than a $3,000,000,000 total of foreign sales in 1937. Last year's efforts approximated $2,500,000,000 compared with $2,282,000,000 in 1935.

Burden From Resorts Heavy-Weather Hampers Airlines-Bus Seats Sold Out. The homeward rush of holiday travelers over the New Year weekend taxed all avenues of transportation yesterday, as did passenger traffic over the Christmas weekend, which reached peak proportions of the 1929 boom period.

Mrs. Loretta Ryan, 46-year-old widow of Thomas G. Ryan, Democratic leader of the Second Assembly District in Brooklyn and general clerk of the Supreme Court in Kings County at the time of his death last May, was found unconscious from gas poisoning, at 8 o'clock yesterday morning on the floor in the kitchen of her home at 2,033 East Eighth Street, near Avenue U, Sheepshead Bay.
Rocco Esposito, who was known in Northern Ontario mining camps for twenty-three years as Rocco Strange, was en route tonight to New Castle, Pa., to face a thirty-year-old murder charge.

Sales of office equipment in 1936 ran about 25 per cent ahead of 1935, ames H. Rand Jr., president and chairman of Remington Rand, Inc., reported. He predicted that sales this year would show at least as great a percentage gain, adding that this indicated steadily rising business.

Belief that Dr. Harry W. Woodruff Jr., 28, missing eye specialist at the City Hospital, is "either the victim of amnesia or under the influence of powerful sedatives," was expressed today by his father, Dr. Harry W.

Very seldom has there been so sweeping and dramatic a change in the home agricultural situation as has been witnessed in 1936. The country has now, for the fourth straight year, harvested less wheat than normal domestic requirements.

Rebounding sharply from the discouraging experience of the first quarter of the year, when the elimination of the processing taxes dried up trading, the cotton textile industry soared to recordbreaking activity in 1936.

Economic conditions in Latin America continued to improve most of last year, the Pan American Union reported today, but in several countries exchange and other difficulties brought about business recessions.

Economically, China enjoyed better times in 1936 than in many previous years, while politically the country has never been more united than it is today, in the opinion of C. H. Wang, co-manager of the New York agency of the Bank of China.

Clark Gable is the screen's most popular star, according to the national poll conducted annually by Boxoffice, film trade magazine, and announced yesterday. Shirley Temple, last year's leader, now is in second place, with the team of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers third, Robert Taylor fourth and William Powell fifth.

Three passenger ships are scheduled to leave this port in the next seven days on cruises around the world that will entail nearly 100,000 miles of travel at sea and many hundreds more to points of interest inland.

William Dodge carried off the honors today in a Larchmont Yacht Club dinghy regatta that was reduced to six Class X boats. The rest of the fleet was on the other side of Long Island Sound for the Manhassett Bay anniversary celebration.
William J. Scully, president of W. J. Scully Co., building contractors, 1 Park Avenue, Manhattan, died suddenly here this morning of a heart attack at his home, 53 Henhawk Lane, at the age of 47.
Chang Hsueh-liang, sentenced to ten years in prison for his revolt against the government and the kidnapping of Premier Chiang Kai-shek, was pardoned unconditionally today by the Council of State.

Before going to Washington, United States Senator-elect William H. Smathers of this city will go to Trenton and hold down his seat in the State Senate, at least until Feb. 1 and possibly until the Legislature adjourns, it was announced today.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against IDA SLONIM, doing business as Pearle Specialty Shop, women's apparel, 737 East Tremont Av.--By Snug-Fit Brassiere Co., for $185; Jacqueline Products, Inc., $85; W. B. Foundations, Inc., $300.
A second driving clinic will open today at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Tests will be given every day and evening for several weeks.
Whichever side wins in the civil war, Spain will for the next decade be a factor of complete economic unimportance. The sweeping and continuous fall of Spanish securities confirms this view.

The banking outlook is more encouraging than it has been for some time, and the banking machinery is being put into shape to serve business more efficiently than ever before, according to Tom K. Smith, president of the American Bankers Association and president of the Boatmen's National Bank, St. Louis.

ARTHUR--On New Year's Day, of pneumonia, at 320 East 72d St., George Draper Arthur, beloved husband of Agnes Belden Arthur and father of George D. Arthur Jr. Funeral private. Kindly omit flowers. BAER--Selma, Jan. 1, 1937, 1,054 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; beloved daughter Samuel and Sarah, sister of Harry, Freda.

The prospect of the railroads increasing their gross revenues by from 10 to 15 per cent in 1937, compared with 1936, is envisaged by Thomas M. Schumacher, trustee and chairman of the executive committee of the Western Pacific Railroad.

Max Baer, former world's heavyweight champion, would like a return bout with Joe Louis. Baer, who lost his crown to Jim Braddock and later was knocked out by Louis, will leave in a few weeks for London and a bout with either Walter Neusel or Ben Foord.

To Germany the year 1936 brought many outward indications of prosperity, but it witnessed an increasing financial and social strain. Although no budgetary accounts are assured, it is unquestioned that public expenditure rose rapidly.
The last of the unbeaten metropolitan college basketball teams fell by the wayside in a week which proved that New York did not have a monopoly on court talent.

Notwithstanding continuance of the deflation policy in the first half of 1936, the heavy export of French capital and its failure to return in full (as it did in Holland, Switzerland and Belgium) after revaluation, and notwithstanding also the strikes and seizure of factories, improvement in the French economic situation occurred last year.
The Rev. R. H. Edwards, who for the last eighteen years has been director of the Cornell United Religious Work, will retire on Oct. 31, it was announced today.

John W. Loud, former Canadian railroad official, died at his home here today. His age was 90. From 1900 until his retirement in 1911, he was freight traffic manager of the Grand Trunk Pacific and Central Vermont Railwavs.

Governor Lehman put the finishing touches today to the annual message which he will present to the Legislature when it opens its 1937 session on Wednesday. Housing legislation, social security, milk control and labor measures will be stressed, it is understood.

The village of Amityville, L. I., because of what its citizens hope is a temporary rather than a permanent condition, has an official animal committee. Moreover, things being the way they are on Long Island, it is possible that other settlements adjacent to the wilds
The present year is seen as one of increasing good times and also of unprecedented good-will by Edward A. Filene, president of William Filene's Sons Company, Boston.

Last year Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, delivered thirty-three speeches in twenty cities in thirteen States, but the "keynoter" of the year, as far as stockbroking was concerned, was Jeremy Bentham, an English lawyer-philosopher, whose advocacy of "the greatest good for the greatest number" has influenced Anglo-American jurisprudence since 1789.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 3.--Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, Papal Legate to the International Eucharistic Congress at Manila, who had an audience of a half hour with the Pope this morning, gave the press an optimistic report on the Pontiff's condition.

The New York State law requiring all felony cases to be submitted to a grand jury is archaic, unnecessary and expensive, in the opinion of Magistrate Frank Oliver. He said yesterday that he intended to recommend to the Judiciary Committee of the Legislature and he Constitutional Convention a changee in the Constitution
A special ward was set aside today for more than twenty nurses of Guys Hospital who are suffering from influenza, which caused ninetyseven deaths during Christmas week.

The net result of the four trading days in the cotton market last week was small and irregular changes. On the New York Cotton Exchange the net changes were from an advance of 4 points on the near-by January delivery to a decline of 9 points on the distant December.
Drastic revision of the old-age insurance and unemployment insurance sections of the Social Security Act is necessary if the law is to provide real and permanent security for those covered by it,

The waste material industries registered a sharp comeback in 1936, with price advances following the rise in raw materials and with consumption increasing substantially, in line with the economic betterment, dealers reported. Usage of some waste materials, such as scrap rubber, reached an alltime high.

" Moral insight," or the capacity of adults and children to think for themselves, is "the only hope that democratic countries like America, England and France have against overpowering and engulfing by dictatorships," Dr. Stanton Coit of London declared in an address

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Dec. 30 at 79.3, compared with 77.8 three weeks before, 76.3 on Nov. 25, 71.4 a year ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Four deacons and as many elders of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church and of Elmendorf Chapel, 121st Street Am near Third Avenue, were installed T yesterday morning at a joint service of the two congregations held at the Eighty-ninth Street Church, between Park and Madison Avenues.

Increase of industrial activity during 1936, especially in the war industries, has been reflected by the Stock Exchanges at Vienna, Budapest and Prague. Between January and December the principal Austrian iron shares, Alpine, advanced from 13 to 36 schillings.

Expansion of corporate refunding operations, stimulated by the continuance of a money market unusually favorable for this type of financing, was the outstanding development in the investment security business in 1936.

The rubber industry established in 1936 the best record since 1929 for both sales and profits, it is asserted by J. D. Tew, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company. He described this as resulting primarily from general business improvement, ending of price wars and increased production of motor vehicles.

The turnover was much smaller this week on the Bourse because of the absence of traders, but the price tendency was firmer. International manufacturing and commodity stocks advanced further and government bonds also were firmer.

If our lives are not well balanced in the spiritual as well as the material sense we will find ourselves out of harmony with God and His universe, the Rev. Coleman Nevils, the pastor, said in his sermon at high mass yesterday at the Jesuit Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

Preliminary estimates by the American Petroleum Industries Committee place the petroleum tax bill in 1936 at $1,173,413,000, of which consumers of petroleum products contributed more than $900,000,000. State sales taxes on gasoline are estimated at $685,000,000, and the Federal tax on gasoline is estimated to have cost consumers $190,000,000.

William Langdon, 30 years old, of 4,521 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, accidentally shot and killed himself in his home late last night when he was cleaning a .32 caliber pistol he had carried on a week-end hunting trip.

Those who make New Year ressolutions to lead better lives should turn to religion for assistance, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector, asserted in a sermon yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Nineteenth Street.

" Importers today stand in the most favorable position they have occupied in a generation," James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., said last week in commenting on the conditions in import trade and the prospects of the present year.
Montreal's speedy Maroons tightened their grip on second place in the National Hockey League's international division tonight by defeating the Black Hawks, 3 to 1, before 13,000 spectators.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "The Ferment in Europe," John C. DeWilde. Meeting of the Advertising Men's Post No. 209, American Legion, the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, 12:30 P. M. "Improved Personnel in Government," Robert W. Johnson.
However much the Spanish civil war may have excited apprehension due to the attitude of other powers toward it, Spanish events in 1936 can hardly be said to have affected the Paris market materially.

The New York Celtics pro basketball team, undefeated this season, trounced the Duffys of Chicago, 42 to 33, in an exciting game before 4,500 at the Hippodrome last night. It was the second defeat of the day for the touring Chicago team, which had lost to the Jersey Reds at Union City in the afternoon, The Associated Press reports.

Despite the gloomy prospects for peace as they may appear at this moment, "war, in time, will go the way of torture chambers, religious persecution, slavery and a hundred other social evils that once ruled the world," was the prediction of the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson

Confidence in the value of a cooperative attack on industrial problems and appreciation of the opporunity afforded by the established trade association as the medium for action were expressed by G. H. Conze, new president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., in his first general message to the membership of the 65-year-old organization, made public yesterday.
Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, holds that business should show a "possible 10 or 15 per cent increase in 1937," given favorable conditions.

The American Academy in Rome will revive this year the Summer session of its School of Classical Studies. There has not been a Summer session at the school since 1932, when its former director, the late Professor Grant Showerman, retired.

An eight-year down trend prices, volume and profits in the coat and suit industry was terminated last year and an upturn began that appears certain to gain sharp impetus in 1937, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc. Discussing the industry's prospects for the new year, Mr. Klein said:

The statement of the Bank of France dated Dec. 23 shows that the government has to use bank advances for current expenses. These advances were further increased by 800,000,000 francs to 8,500,000,000.
As its second Philadelphia offering of the present season, the Metropolitan Opera Association will present Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila" at the Academy of Music on Tuesday evening.

Dr. Philip Embury Browning, for thirty-eight years a member of the chemistry faculty of Yale University, died at New Haven Hospital last night of a heart weakness. He went to the hospital for a major operation several weeks ago and was thought to be convalescing when stricken.

Results of a business census of motor bus transportation in the United States in 1935, announced today by the Bureau of the Census, showed that 1,751 bus companies received $167,933,000 in revenue in that year and had an annual payroll of $55,267,000.

Not even the shy presence of that departmental favorite, Peter Lorre, can save "Crack-Up" from complete collapse with oddments of plot scattered about the landscape and most of the Globe's audience in a mood to inquire whether there's a story doctor in the house.

Further gains in the fur industry this year are foreseen by Victor W. Asselin, partner in Harry H. Hertz, who reported that the industry last year experienced one of the best fin periods in its history.
Exceptionallyy exciting chess play was witnessed yesterday in the ninth round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club. Four games were decided.

Although he had been handcuffed to an iron ring in his cell, Floyd McCloe, 20. of Waverly, N. Y., escaped today from the Sayre jail. McCloe, charged with two assaults and the theft of an automobile, was arrested Saturday afternoon. When officers took one of
The Brooklyn Visitations gave the leading Jersey Reds their second defeat of the American Pro Basketball League season at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn, last night, 27 to 25.

As a result of the reported assault on a British freighter by an armed trawler of the Spanish Insurgents, the Foreign Office today instructed Sir Henry Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, to lodge a vigorous protest with the Rebel junta.

THE TIMES publishes today, in its annual financial review and forecast, the judgment of a long list of expert correspondents, home and foreign, on what has really been achieved in 1936 and what there is reason for expecting in 1937.
The electric light and power industry of the United States faced contradictory trends during 1936, according to Charles W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute.

If the upward swing in the demand for knitted outerwear noted in the second half of 1936 continues into 1937, as it shows every indication of doing, the coming year should mark an all-time high in consumption of knitted dresses and suits, according to Iser P. Cohen, president of the Knitwear Institute.

The final quarter of last year witnessed a general increase in bank deposits and total assets, it is shown in the year-end statements of leading local and out-of-town banks which have just been made public. The increase, however, was not large in the case of several banks and in general appeared relatively smaller than the gain that is normally disclosed in year-end figures compared with those of the third quarter.

The Dutch financial view regarding the past year in the United States is a mixture of undisguised envy with some anxiety concerning the future. Holland will never follow in the wake of the Roosevelt administration's spending policy;

PARIS, Jan. 2.--When financial observers seek to forecast the coming year, or even to summarize the year-end attitude of experienced financiers, it will not do to take into reckoning economic factors alone.

It appears that Sao Paulo will lead all other States with three strong candidates for the Presidency. The resignation of Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, as Foreign Minister, opens a wide field for speculation.

Whitman P. Conn, editor of The Constructor, died here today after a two weeks' illness. He formerly was a Washington correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and The New York Journal of Commerce, and later was on the editrial staff of The Washington Post.
The South's full participation in the reviving trade of 1936 was largely attributable to the active demand which developed in recent months for all forms of manufactured cotton goods. This demand,

It is customary for the financial community to face the new year with hope and with optimism in varying degree. The expressions at this season are not contrary to the rule, qualified though they may be on some phases of the outlook.

The WPA Federal Music Project's new "Theatre of Music," 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, will be opened to the public the week of Jan. 24 with a series of presentations which will include symphonic and chamber-music programs and an operatic premiere, Lee Pattison, New York director of the project, announced yesterday.

By contrast with the preceding year, when sixteen railroads operating 29,000 miles of line went into bankruptcy, virtually no railroads took refuge in the courts last year. There were, however, no reorganizations.
Wesley Wheeler filed a kidnapping charge with police tonight, accusing Arthur Spence of Columbus of abducting his 18-year-old wife, Mrs. Onie Wheeler.
The Rhode Island Reds and the Philadelphia Ramblers played a 2to-2 overtime tie in an International American League hockey game tonight.

With sitdown strikers still defying an injunction to vacate two Flint Fisher Body plants and the Sheriff failing to serve the injunction order on the leaders of the strikers, a step toward a general strike in the sixtynine plants of the General Motors
It was reliably reported today that more than 5,000 well-armed Italian troops had disembarked during the past few days at Cadiz from three Italian warships.

Outstanding advances of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks to their member thrift and homefinance institutions have increased steadily for twenty months, in keeping with the revival of residential building, says a year-end summary of the activities of the system.
Expansion of the insurance business in this country by the use of American capital was forecast yesterday by Edgar H. Boles, president of the General Reinsurance Company. American funds, he said,

Although the output of the steel industry in 1936 was approximately 87 per cent of the 1929 peak, earnings were only about 30 per cent of the 1929 level, Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said in an analysis of the progress made by the industry last year.
Charles Errett Cord, son of E. L. Cord, automobile and aviation executive, was married today at Immanuel Presbyterian Church to Miss Mary Alice Mack, daughter of Mrs. Fannie Day Mack of Los Angeles.

Robert Tully, 38 years old, of Audubon, admitted to the New Jersey State prison here in January, 1930, to serve a life term for murder, slashed himself with safety razor blades and a small knife today.

Individual and partnership enterprises still account for two-fifths of the national income, it was reported yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc. Corporations too small to be included in the "big business" category account for another fifth, and corporations ranging in size from "moderate" to "colossal" make up the remainder.
Confidence is entertained in French financial circles regarding the economic situation in the United States, and the rise of securities which has occurred is thought justified.

The sun was shining on the April day in 1923 when Lincoln Caswell became pastor of the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church. The future was bright with promise. Yesterday, as rain beat against the old timber- of the building at 231 East Seventy-sixth Street, Mr. Caswell told of the impending closing of the church after the deed transferring the property is signed today.

Investment companies with good management have a very definite field of work in serving the smaller investor who does not possess the facilities or the experience to handle his own investment funds properly, Harry A. Arthur, president of American International Corporation, declared yesterday.
Soy bean specialists report a lighter speculative and consumptive movement, and the market runs into selling orders on all evidence of weakness. The movement from the country has fallen off.

The upward trend which carried retail sales to profitable levels in 1936 is likely to continue well into the new year but a leveling off must be anticipated, according to Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill, president of the American Retail Federation. The profits to be derived

The New Haven Eagles repulsed an uphill fight by the Cleveland Falcons tonight and won a rough International - American Hockey League battle, 3 to 2. Trailing, 3-0, on goals by Drouin, Smith and Asmundson, the Falcons rallied to score shortly after the midway mark in the second period and again just before the threequarter point in the final session. Asmundson led the victors' attack.

Emphasizing that its hands were tied in so far as intervening in maritime labor disputes was concerned, the United States Maritime Commission, in its annual report to be presented to Congress tomorrow,

THE grounds on which Jolan Foldes's "The Street of the Fishing Cat" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50) was selected as the winner of the $19,000 All-Nations Novel Competition appear to be obvious but hardly inspiring. It seemingly was selected less for its quality than as simply the most appropriate tale submitted in a contest for which funds had been subscribed by publishers, book clubs, motion picture companies and literary agents in thirteen countries.

The outlook for retailing in 1937 is decidedly mixed, in the opinion of Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Biele of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thelma E. Biele, to Charles Dana Corey of Florham Park, N. J. Miss Biele attended the New Jersey College for Women and' Wagner College on Staten Island.

Optimism was not prevailing in France at the end of 1936. Although Premier Blum and the Popular Front government succeeded in having the budget passed and establishing an arbitration procedure for labor disputes, the majority supporting the government was not like-minded.

Belief here is that a new chapter in world agriculture has begun. Europe's wheat crop of 1936 was extremely unsatisfactory; import requirements of European-wheat deficit countries this coming season will greatly exceed the past year's needs.

The first comprehensive exhibition of prints made by members of the graphic arts division of the WPA Federal Art Project was opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the International Art Center, 310 Riverside Drive.

New Year begins with fairly unanimous prediction, in seasoned business circles, that the forward movement of industrial activity will continue into 1937. This conviction is based chiefly on the momentum of the past season's rise in production, consumption, general prices and on the rapid increase in volume of freight transportation.

Having completed six rounds and finished all adjourned games, the ten competitors in the international masters tournament of the Hastings and the St. Leonard Chess Club rested today. They will resume play

Gains to workers in the silk dress industry resulting from a union agreement later incorporated in the NRA code and now being continued by union agreements, were given as better wages, shorter hours and increased employment, in a study by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, made public today by Secretary Perkins. Mrs. Ethel L. Best,

Oscar Carlson today turned in 81-16-65 to win the sixth qualifying round of the twenty-eighth Snobirds tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club. Twenty competed, but only nine turned in cards. The final will be held on Feb. 7.
Sought by authorities for seven weeks, John S. Leonard, 44, former Assistant District Attorney of Chautauqua County, surrendered to Sheriff Roy L. Chadwick at the county jail in Mayville late today.

The outlook in Mexico for 1937 is on the whole encouraging, according to a statement by John B. Glenn, New York agent of the Banco Nacional de Mexico. President Cardenas has been able to create an almost unprecedented era of political stability, Mr. Glenn said, and this situation has been reflected in the very favorable situation of the national treasury.

The trend of municipal bond prices over the next few years should be upward in accordance with increased demand and diminfishing supply, Louis S. Lebenthal of Lebenthal Co. declared in a year-end review and forecast of the municipal bond market.

The year's notable industrial revival in Great Britain really started two or three years ago, but it was not until the past year that it made marked headway. During 1936 many branches of British industry staged a spectacular recovery. Steel production,

The vast need for social reforms in this city was emphasized by the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, executive secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in an address yesterday morning before the men's class of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
Taking advantage of almost every trick that came their way, the Canadiens of Montreal hung another defeat on the Americans last night. The high-flying Frenchmen,

A trade revival that has surprised all parts of the country and which, in this market's view, promises to last for a year or more, has featured business activities powerfully during the past year. It came on so

Charles Warren Stevens, who retired in 1907 as president of Stevens Co., manufacturers of hatmaking machines, died last night in a nursing home in Packanack, N. J., after a two years' illness, at the age of 86.

The savings banks of this State look back over the last year with a certain amount of justifiable satisfaction, Andrew Mills Jr., president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York and president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, said in a year-end statement just made public.

It is more than mere "wishful thinking" that leads the cotton textile industry to believe its present improved situation and even brighter prospects for 1937 are established on firm foundations, in the opinion of Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc.

Inspection today of twelve voting machines opened by the Secretary of State, Louis W. Cappelli, under a Supreme Court order, revealed no net change in the plurality of 791 votes by which the Board of Vote Tabulation declared Mayor James E. Dunne, Democrat, re-elected over John F. Collins, Republican.

Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffman," which has not been heard at the Metropolitan for five years, will be revived at that house during the fourth week of the season. Other features of that week will be the debut of Stella Andreva and the first appearances this season of Lotte Lehmann and Lily Pons.

The upward swing of business recovery that featured 1936 shows no sign of lagging as the new year opens, according to reports telegraphed to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday from the Federal Reserve districts. The chief danger,

Business should continue to improve in 1937. but there are important factors in the situation that may exert a retarding influence, says Banking, the official journal of the American Bankers Association, in a year-end review and forecast of business conditions in its current issue.
The housewife Mayor of Daytona Beach expressed more concern today over being pictured as a "mean old woman" than in the outcome of her fight against the effort of Governor Sholtz to oust her.

The old year ended on the markets and the new year began with the usual relaxation of activities. For the week, stock market averages rose moderately, reaching a figure some 5 points above December's lowest but 11 1/2 below November's best. Yet, when the high mark of the season indicated advance of 31 1/2 points from the closing of 1935 and 66 1/2 from that year's low average,

When final figures are tabulated, it is expected that the sales of deapartment stores and apparel specialty shops will show an increase of approximately 12 per cent for 1936 over 1935, making the volume for this division of retailing the largest experienced since 1930, according to David Moeser, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and treasurer and general manager of Conrad Co., Boston.

Of all the great nations, the United States has most reason to be grateful for progress made in 1936, according to Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank and president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The day's mail brings tidings from such widely separated points as Florida and Maine. From West Palm Beach comes a note from Francis McBride, the wiry, capable skipper of the Black Hawk, well known to offshore fishermen who put out of Hoffman's Anchorage at Brielle, N. J.

The tin container industry has reason to expect in 1937 the largest volume of business in many years according to O. C. Huffman, president of the Continental Can Com pany Inc. Increased demand for containers by the canned food, beverage and oil industries was predicted by Mr. Huffman.

A new plan for refunding $15,488,500 of bonds and notes of the township of North Bergen, N. J., now in default, will be submitted today to the holders of those securities by a committee of refunding managers, of which W. E. Wetzel, president of the First National Company of Trenton, is chairman.

Ocean City Coast Guards took up residence today in a new $60,000 station on Great Egg Harbor Bay, fronting the yacht club lagoon. The crew of fourteen, under charge of Captain Christopher Bentham, spent the holiday period moving equipment and personal effects from the old building at Fourth Street and Atlantic Avenue, built more than forty years ago when the island was barely settled.

The paper industry closed the year with production and sales breaking all previous records, according to executives in the field. The volume was about 15 per cent ahead of 1935, although continued low prices prevented any sharp upswing in profits.
Department of Commerce inspectors and officials of United Air Lines today flew over the wreckage of the transport plane which crashed near Saugus last Sunday night, killing twelve persons.

Cessation of "the present reactionary movement to absolutism and dictatorship" and a return to Christian ideals of justice and community life throughout the world was the wish expressed yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning in a New Year's message read at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, whose grandparents were born in County Meath, Ireland, stole the show yesterday afternoon at the fifty-third annual installation of officers of the County Corkmen's Benevolent, Patriotic and Protective Association, held at Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eightysixth Street.
THE STREET OF THE FISHING CAT, by Jolan Foldes. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) The international winner of the $19,000 AllNations Prize Contest, this is a story of emigres in Paris.

Closing with the largest holiday trade since 1929, the broad upturn in virtually all lines of retail distribution in 1936 surpassed retailers' expectations. Further substantial increases in turnover of consumers' goods are confidently expected this year.
Corporations resorted to the issuance of new stock for the raising of funds to a greater extent in 1936 than in any previous period since the beginning of the depression.

The first trek from the Rose Bowl began tonight with the departure for Seattle of the beaten Washington Huskies, while Pittsburgh will head for home tomorrow afternoon. Coach Jock Sutherland's Panothers, 21-to-0 victors over the Pacific Coast Conference champions Friday. sent the day "on their own."
A peasant's daughter and a future queen, both named Juliana, will be the only girls in all The Netherlands to wed next Thursday. One is the Crown Princess Juliana, born to royalty.

German manufacturers have reported a shortage of materials. Dr. Hjaimar Schacht, Minister for Economics, has imposed new restrictions on the use of pulpwood and forbidden the consumption of rustless steel in many branches of industry, including cutlery.

Flood waters from rivers in northern Alabama and sections of Georgia and Tennessee drove lowland dwellers from their homes today, but clearing skies apparently ended the threat of major damage. Two persons lost their lives in the Birmingham area.

A trend toward mutualization of investment companies developed during 1936, according to Andrew J. Lord of Lord, Abbett Co., Inc. Mr. Lord said it was highly probable that a "sounder and a far less complicated investment trust structure" would be built upon the tion, principle of self-imposed restriction and regulation.

Activities of the wire communications companies in 1936 were directed mainly toward the stimulation of increased use of the various services available rather than toward new construction. These efforts were attended by marked success for all companies.
In two indoor polo matches played today in the Red Bank armory the 112th Field Artillery team defeated Winmont Farms, 14-9, and the Ponolo riders won over the 112th F. A. Jayvees, 11-7.
There is reason to believe that American sulphur producers will increase their domestic sales this year, it is predicted by Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company.

Italo Picchi, Italian operatic basso, died unexpectedly in a hospital tonight of spinal meningitis following an ear infection. His age was 60. A member for nine seasons of the Metropolitan Opera and previously with La Scala of Milan, Mr. Picchi

Registering sales increases of 15 to 40 per cent over 1935, dry goods wholesalers have rounded out one of the most successful years in the last decade, according to. Flint Garrison, director general of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute. The wholesale dry goods house that does not show a satisfactory profit for 1936 will be the exception, he said.

A straw that shows the way the wind is blowing in the Spanish civil war is the small but steady stream of deserters coming into the government lines on the various fronts. Sometimes they come singly and sometimes in groups, which rarely exceed four or five men.
Forty contributions amounting to $665.50 were received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total that has been raised through the present appeal to $264,545.48.
Twenty-five Massachusetts women will leave tomorrow to join forty Rhode Island women in opening New England's first camp for jobless women at Chepachet. R. I.

The food industry in 1936, because of its larger volume of business, increased employment about 3 per cent and expanded payrolls about 5 per cent., according to C. M. Chester, chairman of General Foods Corporation, in giving a review of the industry.

Renewed interest on the part of the American people in the consumer cooperative method of operating retail businesses was witnessed last year, according to Herbert E. Evans, vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, the central wholesale organization for the league of cooperative department stores planned by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant.

From the point of view of Federal taxation, the year 1936 was especially harsh to corporations. The corporate form of business enterprise, it would seem, was the target at which the most trenchant provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936 were aimed.

In an exceedingly hard-fought court tennis exhibition marked by long rallies, Frank (Bunny) Gannon, home club- pro, conquered Mike Giglio, Boston pro, in five sets at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club today.
A keenly-fought Metropolitan Soccer League game between the Norwegian Turn Society and the Danish A. C. resulted in a 1-1 tie at Bay Ridge Oval yesterday.

With the phenomenal growth of skiing in the past few years, there has been a corresponding increase in the interest shown in this sport in men's and women's colleges throughout the East or, for that matter, the entire snow-belt area of this country.
Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del Vayo declared tonight that Spain henceforth would resist with all the means at her disposal any act of aggression on the part of the German fleet.

A great audience in Westminster Abbey, attending the last service to be held there before the coronation next May, was again reminded of King Edward's abdication tonight when the Bishop of Knaresborough delivered a sermon on "The Consecrated Duties of the Kingship."

Preaching his first message of the New Year from the opening verse of the Bible-"In the beginning God"--the Rev. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared yesterday that the - Bible shows its divinity in its opening phrase.

Practically every division of the home furnishings industry closed 1936 with sales volume up 15 per cent or more compared with the preceding year and spokesmen for major lines predict even larger gains for the new year. In the furniture industry orders rose sharply in January to a point well above the highest levels of the preceding year.
Last year was a record-breaking period in many respects for the shoe and leather industries, according to Merrill D. Watson, president of the Tanners Council of America.

A bill designed to curb the "illicit trade" of unqualified psychologists will be introduced into the next session of the State Legislature by the Association of Consulting Psychologists in an effort to end what the organization describes as a Statewide racket in this field.

A ski carnival will be held on Jan. 24 at Skytop for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery, the oldest institution of its kind in this city. The committee on arrangements is composed of Mrs. Turnbull Wood,

Members of New York City's higher music circles relaxed last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and were privileged to see Miss Lucrezia Bori, for many years a prima donna soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, in the role of leader of a highly unorthodox orchestra which played Ravel's "Bolero" on typewriters, watering pots full of buckshot, anvils and similar instruments.

Four additional results were recorded yesterday in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, in which Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion, and E. Martinson were earlier winners.

After the customary holiday lull, the first week of the year is distinguished not only by a renewed rush of exhibitions but also by the fact that among these are many that would make any week of the season notable.

Rain washed out all of the important interleague soccer games in the metropolitan area and New Jersey yesterday. Contests were slated at Starlight Park, in the Bronx; Grand Stadium, in Brooklyn; Clark's Field, in Newark,

Christmas trade in this section a year ago was described as the largest since 1929; but last month's Christmas trade largely surpassed it. The volume of purchases took all business interests by surprise.

A six-point legislative program to be urged at Albany by the American Civil Liberties Union was made public yesterday by the New York committee of that organization. The program follows: "Cooperation with teachers' groups in repeal of the Ives Loyalty Oath Law.

It will not be merely Dr. GLENN FRANK who will be on trial in the hearings that will open Wednesday to decide whether he shall retain the presidency of the University of Wisconsin. It will be the Board of Regents itself, and its method of selection.
In the lately discouraged farming West bankers and business men are still basing their expectations, for the next six months at any rate, on continuance of Federal assistance to farmers.

Drawing of a panel of 300 jurors is scheduled for tomorrow in the Greene County court house as the State's first move in the second trial of Manning J. (Manny) Strewl for the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. in 1933.

Paris dressmakers are giving velveteens important places in their latest collections. Afternoon tailleurs .trimmed with silver fox and evening suits flashing with gold embroideries appear in velveteens. Jackets of that material button up above pleated, plaid skirts.

Professor Arthur J. Hill of Yale University and Mrs. Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth White Hill, to Burel Henry Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Lane of Trumansburg, N. Y.

Reflecting a general improvement in domestic business, copper companies in the United States have just completed their best year, from many angles, since 1929. At the close of 1936 operations were at or near capacity, with prices at the best levels in six years.

Many dinner parties were given last night in conjunction with the dinner dance held at the French Casino for the benefit of the National Bureau for Blind Artists. Miss Joan Long, debutante daughter of Captain and Mrs. Byron A.

Winding up in blazed streaks of bright sunset after three days of hard going, the anniversary celebration of five years of Winter dinghy sailing was concluded this afternoon at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
The improvement in earnings realized by manufacturers of agricultural machinery and implements in 1936 should continue in 1937, according to Poor's industry and investment survey.

Curtailment of the Federal WPA rolls was protested in a special bulletin made public yesterday by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches of America. "The desire to balance the budget Is laudable." the bulletin said.

The new year has begun with an outbreak of strikes and threats of strikes which naturally cause concern and cloud the immediate future. To some extent, of course, the present trend is a natural phenomenon of recovery.

For the fourth consecutive year the stock market moved upward in 1936 under the stimulus of steadily expanding industrial activity. The gains in leading issues, however, were smaller than in 1935; as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks the rise amounted to 21 per cent against 33 per cent in the previous year.

George R. Sweeney, 47 years old, general manager of the Live Poultry Shippers Association, was found dead tonight in his office, his wrists slashed with a razor blade. Police declared him a suicide; he had been suffering from nervous spells.

Comments made here at the year-end on business results in the United States during 1936, also the forecasts for 1937, are entirely optimistic. In retrospect, results of the November election considerably modified German views of the President's economic policy, which was originally regarded without much favor.

Another rooming house fire similar in cause to the one which cost five lives a few weeks ago caused one death early yesterday morning when Leo Hoyt, a 60-year-old actor, died in his third-floor room at 47 West Seventy-fifth Street when he fell asleep with a lighted cigarette burning.
Business improvement in 1936 created an impetus which augurs well for this year, Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, founder and president of Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, was the guest of honor of the Catholic Young Women's Club at a reception tea yesterday at the clubhouse, 641 Lexington Avenue.

An active demand for hogs last week sent prices up 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight on all classes. The top of $10.70 was a new high level for the Winter and the highest price for December in ten years. On Dec. 31, 1932, the top price on hogs was $3, the lowest in fifty-four years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--Gross income of farmers from agricultural production has increased more than $4,000,000,000 in the last four years, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today. Farmers' gross income for 1936 was estimated at $9,530,000,000, compared with $8,508,000,000 in 1935, $7,276,000,000 in 1934, and $5,337,000,000 in 1932. No figures for 1933 were given.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls, already far out in front in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race this season, gave further proof of their qualifications for the position yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden.

A policeman battled in the waters of the Harlem Ship Canal early yesterday to save the life of a young man who had jumped thirty-five feet from the bridge at 225th Street and Broadway at about 2 o'clock in the morning.

Extension of unlisted trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission and increase in volume of transactions and new listings were features of the year on the New York Curb Exchange, according to a statement issued yesterday by Fred C. Moffatt, president.

The year 1936 has been a trying one for the individual bond investor because of recurrent inflationary scares, record low-interest rates on new offerings, restricted volume of new financing other than refunding and the continuation of social and legislative trends seemingly adverse to his interests, T. E. Hough, vice president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., says in his annual review of the bond market of 1936.

Matthew Broderick, 43 years old, of 43 Arlington Avenue, Brooklyn, who explained to Magistrate Mark Rudich in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday that he drinks only on holidays and then takes refuge in a railroad station to keep away from traffic, pleaded guilty to a disorderly conduct charge and received a suspended sentence after he promised to "detour" from railroad stations in the future.
Sales of electricity in 1936 by light and power companies in the United States, with the last two months estimated, are put at 89,800,000,000 kilowatt-hours by the Edison Electric Institute.

Fourteen sticks of dynamite, stored on the street on First Avenue between Seventieth and Seventy-first Streets for blasting on a WPA sewer project, were stolen early yesterday morning or late Saturday night.

William S. Murray, new chairman of the Republican State Committee, arrived here this afternoon, opened personal headquarters at a hotel and told newspaper men at a subsequent press conference that he would make his "home" here while the Legislature, which begins work Wednesday, remains in session.

The economic recovery of the countries on the West Coast of South America-Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia and Chile-promises to continue in 1937, in the opinion of D. Stewart Iglehart, president of W. R. Grace Co.

Sales of railroad securities to the public increased greatly in volume last year, reaching levels comparable to so-called normal years. Although sales of equipment trust certificates rose substantially, only a small amount of the railroad securities sold was to defray costs of new construction.

A Masonic funeral service was conducted today in the chapel of Ferncliff Mausoleum for Frederick Courtenay Barber, newspaper man and director of philanthropic campaigns. Mr. Barber, who lived at 636 West 136th Street, New York, died Jan. 1.

Edgar S. Bloom, president of the Western Electric Company, announces that sales for 1936 would exceed $140,000,000, compared with $105,417,000 in 1935, and that orders now on hand pointed to a continued increase in sales during 1937.

Driven from every other argument, the believers in the "inevitable war" in Europe always fall back upon one last contention. Ah, yes, they say, it may be true that all national interests are against war, but there is the danger that it may be brought on by some irresponsible mad act, some "frontier incident."
The Mexican Government will prohibit the shipment of planes or other war materials from the United States to Spain via Mexico, the United States Embassy in Mexico, D. F., was informed yesterday.

George Zengara and Jimmy McLeod, lightweight rivals who brought down the house with their furious battling in a preliminary at the St. Nicholas Palace a week ago, will meet in a return bout of eight rounds at the same club tonight.

The affairs of the Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company flared up again yesterday when six former officials of the old Pacific Mutual Company of California, which was reorganized, were sued for $990,990 by Samuel L. Carpenter Jr., State Insurance Commissioner, as conservator of the company.

Our national leaders are beginning to realize that human values are permanent and must not be slurred over for the benefit of a few if our democratic society is to survive, said the Rev. John Walter Houck in a sermon yesterday in the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx.

More or less permanently higher clothing prices for the coming years were forecast by William Goldman of Cohen, Goldman Company, who based his prediction on rising wool levels and increased manufacturing costs, which are not easily adjustable. He said that while it is
Queen Mary left Sandringham House today for the first time since she arrived there for the Christmas holidays.

Of two official pronouncements by the German Government today, one shows that Germany is standing pat on her demands upon the Spanish Leftist Government but also makes it plain that the retaliatory measures she is taking will cease if these demands are complied with.

Dr. Adolph Baron, a member of the consulting staff of the Lenox Hill Hospital, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 51 East Ninetieth Street, after an illness of four months. He was born in this city seventy-two years ago.
