Weight-saving alloys and other special steels designed to meet certain needs will be used increasingly this year, according to W. F. Detwiler, executive vice president of the Allegheny Steel Company.

Investors and investing institutions should recognize dangers inherent in an abnormal money market which tends to distort prices, and should endeavor more than ever to conduct their affairs in such manner that a change in interest rates and its resulting effect on long-term bond prices would not be seriously embarrass ? according to Edward B. Hall of Harris,

More than 200 persons, many of them prominent in the newspaper field, attended funeral services for Albert J. Kobler, former publisher of The Daily Mirror and president of The American Weekly, a Hearst publication, at noon yesterday in

Glenn Cunningham, great middledistance runner, will begin his 1937 indoor campaign on Saturday night at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn, where the Kansan will take part in the 800-meter invitation run of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, track and field games.

There has been no general exodus of manufacturing concerns from New York City in recent years, in fact the city shows a greater gain in new concerns in the last three years than does the nation as a whole.

What is certain to prove one of the most important art events of 1937 has already taken place, with the year just begun. The significance of the proposed gift to our Government by ANDREW W. MELLON, as reported in yesterday's paper, becomes at once manifest to all who realize the richness of the great art collection he has been for many years assembling.

Mrs. Catherine Lewis, 36 years old, of 25 South Westfield Avenue, Trenton, N. J., leaped to her death last night from the thirteenth floor of the Hotel Pennsylvania, where she had registered as Mrs. Isaac Lakoos a few hours before.

The automobile industry last year produced more than 4,500,000 vehicles, with a wholesale value of nearly $2,500,000,000, a gain of 11 per cent over its 1935 output, according to A. E. Barit, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company.

The market for municipal bonds appears to be in a thoroughly satisfactory condition at the start of the year and there seems to be little reason to expect any substantial immediate change in market values, according to John S. Linen, second vice president of the Chase National Bank.

Chandler A. Mackey, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., says that members and all those connected with the coffee and sugar business "may look back with gratitude upon the year 1936," when more than 2,500,000 tons of sugar and about 10,000,000 bags of coffee were traded on the Exchange, the coffee total being the largest since 1931.

The electric light and power industry this year will undertake the largest new construction campaign since 1930 and, if plans now being made are maintained, new construction in 1938 will be the largest for any year in the history of the industry.
Edward C. Huffaker, pioneer airplane ??odeler and one-time associate of ??he Wright brothers and Samuel ?? Langley, died today after a short illness. His age was 80.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Plant of 920 Fifth Avenue will be guests at a bon-voyage dinner tonight in the Explorers Club, 10 West Seventysecond Street, on the eve of their departure for what is believed to be the first expedition by automobile trailer in Africa.

Elimination from the pension rolls of veterans who suffered no war disability and creation of an appellate agency similar to the Canadian Pension Commission and divorced from the Veterans Administration are among the recommendations expected to be made to Congress and governmental agencies by the American Veterans Association.

Arrested on charges of possessing slips in an Italian lottery, Louis Scarlino, 58 years old, reputed proprietor of the Century Press, at 1,975 Third Avenue, and Arthur Lacetto, 17, of 210 East 108th Street, an errand boy employed in the profit printing shop, were held in $500 bail each for examination Thursday when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Frank Oliver in Felony Court.
Urging his congregation to set the example, the Rev. David Rhys Williams, pastor of First Unitarian Church, in a sermon today, advocated the taxation of church property.

Plain notice that Catalonia has broken with the Spanish Constitution, as far as internal administration is concerned, was served on the Valencia government today by a delegation of three members of the Catalan Generalidad sent here from Barcelona for that purpose.

No Sabbath calm prevailed today in Capitol Hill's marble halls. An army of overalled men pushed about furniture and crated possessions of 166 Congress members, including 95 elected for the first time, who were changing offices or taking up quarters for their first session.

An investigation into the amount of "common sense" that a public school education gives to a young man or woman seeking a job has been undertaken by the Regents Inquiry into the character and cost of public education, according to an announcement yesterday.

Year-end statements by directors of the Merchants Association expressed more confidence than they have at any time since 1929. These officials report better conditions in their businesses and all give voice to the conviction that the upward trend will continue.

Tangible results of the gold-bloc devaluation and the "tripartite agreement" for exchange stabilization are still highly uncertain. At the year-end the former "gold countries," after their initial rather insignificant abolition of some import quotas and a few tariff reductions, have ceased to continue the policy.
Treasury officials said today that government acceptance of Andrew W. Mellon's proposed $19,000,000 art gift to the nation would not affect a claim of $3,089,000 against his 1931 income.

THE group that was strongly opposed to participation in the Olympic Games at Berlin is now entrenched at the head of the A. A. U. That's something like locking the stable door after the horse has won the race. A special committee of the N. C. A. A. reported that "first and foremost" what was wrong with football was subsidizing and recruiting.

LONDON, Jan. 3.--The texts of the Anglo-Italian Mediterranean accord and the notes exchanged by the British Ambassador, Sir Eric Drummond, and the Italian Foreign Minister, Count Galeazzo Ciano, follow:...

The pet cat of Mrs. Edward Moats was recovering today from a seventy-five-foot fall down a well. The cat disappeared three weeks ago and was believed to have died. Mrs. Moats's daughter heard a feeble "meow" from the well. She peered down, and there was Tabby, perched on a ledge just above the waterline.

There is no hope for progress unless we get beyond the man-to-man morality and develop a group-togroup morality, Dr. John L. Elliott said yesterday morning in an address before the New York Socity for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

Details of the regional conference to be held by the American Bankers Association in Pittsburgh on Jan. 28 and 29, the first of three meetings of bankers in various sections of the country, were announced here yesterday by F. N. Shepherd, executive manager of the association.

Asserting that the re-established liquor industry has displayed an Trust active sense of social responsibility, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, Inc., holds that the sale of alcoholic beverages has taken its place as a major factor in American industrial and marketing activity.
Two former heavyweight wrestling champions, Gus Sonnenberg and Dan O'Mahoney, will furnish the action in the feature exhibition at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory tonight.

The normal parallel movement of volume of transactions in listed securities and the price of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange was disrupted last year by the prospect of new Federal restrictions on trading by members.

Alarms were out last night for three known thugs believed to have taken part in the hold-up of Barney's Clothes, Inc., 111 Seventh Avenue, at 8 o'clock Saturday night, when loot estimated at approximately $20,000 was taken from thirty-five clerks, sixty customers, and the store cashier.

Entering 1937 the jewelry industry is in better condition than at any time since the peak days of 1929 and indications are favorable for the future, according to A. Merchant Clark, editor of The Jewelers Circular-Keystone.

BERNSTEIN-Dr. and Mrs. Lionel H. (nee Hilda Mormar), daughter, Jan. 2. GANS-Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan R. Gans (nee Dorothea R. Gottlieb), a son, Jan. 2, Park West Hospital. GLICK-Mr. and Mrs. Louis Glick announce the birth of a son, Saturday, Jan. 2, Fifth Av. Hospital.

From a financial as well as an industrial point of view, the year 1936 will take a prominent place in British history. Despite political storms of varying intensity at home and abroad, industrial recovery continued steadily last year.

Sporting goods. lines in 1936 enjoyed their oest year since 1929, with sales running 25 to 30 per cent over 1935, manufacturers reported last week. The development of skiing as a popular Winter sport was the outstanding feature of the year, with a number of other games, such as badminton and table tennis. coming along rapidly.
Rail travel into Atlantic City increased nearly 500,000 in 1936, according to figures made public here today by Harry Burchinal, general passenger agent for the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets and the Baltimore Orioles fought to a 2-to-2 tie tonight in an Eastern League ice hockey game. Baltimore outplayed the visitors in the first two periods, but the Yellow Jackets spurted to tie the count in the third. There was no scoring in the overtime period.

Plain notice that Catalonia has broken with the Spanish Constitution, as far as internal administration is concerned, was served on the Valencia government today by a delegation of three members of the Catalan Generalidad sent here from Barcelona for that purpose.

While trying to get rid of a Christmas tree, set aflame by a short circuit of the wiring as they dismantled it this afternoon, Mrs. Eleanore O'Brien, 27 years old, and her mother-in-law, Mrs. Annie O'Brien, 64, were burned here at 68 Hoover Avenue, the former seriously. The younger woman suffered burns of the hands, legs and back when she picked up the tree and

The past year has closely reproduced most characteristics which in the past marked entire emergence from depression and entry upon new prosperity. Steady rise in staple prices, especially grain; rapid and sustained increase of production and transportation;

Deploring the "genial humanism" that has come to take the place of Christianity in a large section of the church in the past generation or two, the Rev. Bernard Iddings Bell, a canon of St. John's Episcopal Cathedral of Providence, R. I., declared yesterday in a sermon in

The German wholesale price index on Dec. 23 stood at 105.1, against 105 on Dec. 16, 103.4 in December, 1935, and 92.4 in December, 1932. In the first eleven months of 1936 Germany's wholesale price average ranged between 104.8 on Aug. 13 and 103.5 on Jan. 29.

Three hundred pupils in the Deepwater Public School prepared today to go on strike tomorrow morning in protest against the dismissal of Patrolman William Eckley from the two-man police force of Lower Penn's Neck Township.
On the basis of their record in the recent past, investment trusts have been found not wanting and their future is bright, Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, said yesterday.

Jerome Av. (12-3321), e. s., 25 ft. n. of Bedford Park Blvd., 75x100; Brosnar Realty Corp. to Ralmor Realty Corp., 2,525 Aqueduct Av.; mtg. $37,000. Manida St. (12-2765D), e. s., 216 ft. n. of Randall Av., 29x100; Jamestown Mutual Insurance Co. to Murray M. Salzberg, 666 West End Av.

Indicative of the wider interest last year in securities trading was an increase in the number of bid and asked quotations furnished by the quotation bureau of the New York Stock Exchange to a new high record of approximately 24,000,000.

Miss Ruth Strother, 28 years old, believed to have been a nurse, was found dead about 4 P. M., yesterday in her tenth-floor room in the Hotel Plymouth, 143 West Forty-ninth Street. The body was discovered by a maid.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3.--Picturesque desert lands of the State will be consolidated in one California park of 500,000 acres. The Department of Natural Resources, working through the State Park Commission already has acquired the first unit, Borego Desert State Park with 104,914 acres including Borego...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--Settlement of the hotly contested race for majority leader of the House, now confined to Representatives Rayburn of Texas and O'Connor of New York and constituting the principal prerequisite to organizing the Seventy-fifth Congress, will take place tomorrow at a caucus of House Democrats.

The rise in national income, the movement of the population from congested areas into suburbs and rural sections, and increase in the total population all point to a much wider use of automobile transportation, Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers' Association and of the Packard Motor Car Company, declares in a review of the favorable statistical position of the the automobile industry.
Henry S. Tallard, president of the Universal Coal and Wood Company and chairman of the City Board of Compensation and Assessment, died last night in the Hartford Hospital. His age was 66.

Mr. and Mrs. Adelrick Benziger of Diamond Tail Bar Ranch, Jelm, Wyo., have announced to friends and relatives in New York the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Benziger, to Robert Carter Nicholas Townsend,

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein denied today charges of the Newark Real Estate Board that "other taxpayers" were being discriminated against in the city's plan to exempt from real estate taxation eighteen acres of Port Newark land, which it is proposed to lease to Swift Co. for an edible oil refinery.

A very notable year has ended in the steel trade; its achievement makes possible comparisons which a year ago would have seemed incredible. Total output of steel ingots in the year was approximately 48,000,000 gross tons. That places the year under

Clarence C. Pinneo, 80 years old, formerly treasurer of the American Seamen's Friend Society, died early yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, to which he had been taken after a fall from the window of his home at 51 Hamilton Place.

Seeing no lights in a boat clubhouse at 180th Street and the Bronx River, Patrolman John Murphy of the Webtser Avenue station decided to investigate early yesterday morning. He entered the door, which was unlocked, and by the light of his electric torch saw Edmond

A report that John Crempa, whose wife, Mrs. Sophie Crempa, was shot fatally in September, 1935, when deputy sheriffs arrested Crempa and his son, John Crempa Jr., had disappeared was denied today by relatives.

To the tunes of "The Halls of Montezuma" (La Guardia campaign theme song), "Yes, We Have No Bananas," "Onward, Christian Soldiers," "Yipi-addy-i-ay" and other songs, and with dramatic skits marked by the scream of sirens, pistol shots and spirited dialogue, Mayor La Guardia and fourteen cf his commissioners broadcast a review of his administration yesterday.

Dorothy Eichman, switchboard operator in a downtown hotel, pushed in the plug on a signal from Room 530 today and heard a man's voice say: "I'm going out the window. Come and get me." A bellboy she sent to the room found the window open and saw the man's crushed body in an areaway five floors below.
More than 300 Navajo Indian pinon harvesters, hungry and numb from exposure, were rescued late today from the rugged Zuni Mountain area where they were snowbound almost a week.

Baroness von Eidlitz, Mrs. Edward M. Burghard and Mrs. Louis D. Conley gave a tea dance yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis for their debutante niece, Miss Virginia Ehret, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ehret.

Overcast skies made the shooting conditions difficult at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. However, A. Mulhaupt finished with a fine card of 97 for the high-over-all honors, the Class A gunner leading the field for the second day in a row. He scored Saturday with a 91.

The Federal Maritime Commission's contention that it was without power to take further steps toward settlement of the ship strike was challenged last night by representatives of American shipping interests, who asserted that the commission had not yet exhausted the authority vested in it by the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

Two radio car policemen were critically injured last night in a crash at Eighty-sixth Street and Central Park West as they raced their car south in answer to a fire alarm that later proved false. With red headlights glowing and siren whirring, they came down Central Park West from the region of 100th Street at about 7 P. M.

Since most companies predicate their sales quota and promotional campaigns for a new year on the preceding year's experience, advertising volume in a number of lines will achieve a new all-time record in 1937, it was pointed out by executives.

Short-sighted business men who have a vision of a "streamlined profit system with a permanent upward trend in business, prices and profits" are among elements menacing the permanency of the present business recovery, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, declared in a summary issued yesterday presenting the views of purchasing executives on the 1937 outlook.

As the year ends, Italy's internal prices are feeling a tendency toward increase, therein coinciding with the world-tendency in the same direction. But the rise is being severely controlled, both by government and by the corporative system, so as to avoid any artificial or speculative rise.

The mutual savings banks of the country, holding about one-fifth of the nation's bank deposits, face the new year in the strongest position in their history, according to Carl M. Spencer, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The electrical manufacturing industry is now within striking distance of its 1929 peak of activity and may well equal that high point this year, according to W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The public has accepted air transportation as a necessary adjunct of modern business throughout the year, C. R. Smith, president of American Airlines, Inc., said yesterday. Mr. Smith said he was confident the gains of the air transportation industry in 1937 would be as large as in 1936.

State Senator John J. McNaboe, who recently charged that Cornell University was a "hot-bed" of communism, broadened his list yesterday to declare that subversive activities exist at Brooklyn College, the College of the City of New York, Evander Childs High School, Morris High School and "many other institutions."

The Englewood Field Club and the Montclair Athletic Club, both undefeated, registered sweeps in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racauets Association today. Englewood conquered the Short Hills club here, 7-0, and Montclair downed the Elizabeth Town and Country Club at Montclair, 7-0.

Dartmouth's game but tired hockey team, playing its sixth game in eight days, was unable to match the speed and brilliant stick-handling of the University of Montreal sextet tonight as the Canadian outfit registered a 6-4 triumph before 2,000 persons at the Playland rink.

The liquor industry has been one of the major contributors to national recovery and this year will contribute more than $600,000,000 in taxes to the Federal government, according to Laurence B. Davis, vice president of Seagram-Distillers Corporation.

Eddie (The Great) Shore served notice that he was in his old-time form tonight by caging a pair of third period goals that gave the Boston Bruins a 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers before a capacity crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.
Police sought an incendiary today as responsible for the fifth suspicious fire in the City Hall within two months. In each case the flames were discovered on Sunday morning.
The powerful Penn A. C. quintet strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League by beating the Prudential A. A. tossers over the weekend.

A two months' search through ten States for Irving H. Rodwell, 34, Rochester insurance leader, ended today with the finding of his body in his auto in the barge canal about ten miles east of the city. Rodwell had been missing since Nov. 7, when he left here to call on two clients in Geneva.
James A. Moffett, chairman of the board of the California-Texas Oil Company, Ltd., and former head of the Federal Housing Administration, predicted today that oil prices would rise in 1937.

Army recruiting officers in New York and New Jersey will begin examinations tomorrow of 1,296 candidates for the Civilian Conservation Corps. The group is the first of several to be selected from this area in connection with the 50,742 CCC enrollment authorized throughout the country by Jan. 20.
The "tripartite agreement," which Switzerland and Holland subsequently endorsed, has made it possible for devaluation by the gold bloc to take place without upsetting the exchange market.

49th St., 240-242 W., 40x100.5; 242 W. 49th St. Realty Co. to Metropolitan Savings Bank,; 5 years, 3 per cent, $19,390. West End, n w cor 87th St., 100.10x100; Sari Corp. to Equitable Life Assurance Society; building loan, due Jan, 1, 1948, 6 to 5 per cent; $760,000.

Definitely out of the yawning traps after a weary struggle, American golf is back on the greens and ready for another golden era. Every sign points to a boom year in 1937. Golf equipment manufacturers and country clubs are back on a sound basis, and the country is jammed with veterans and rising young stars who promise some of the liveliest free-for-all competition in years.

The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Dec. 30: CAPTAIN Cobey, E. A. (S. C.), Naval Academy, to Bureau Aeronautics, Navy Dept., in February. COMMANDER Train, S. C., the Vestal, to Bureau Navigation, Navy Dept., about Jan. 16.

The New York State Conservation Council will seek some radical changes in the fish and game laws during this legislative session. A number of the measures are decidedly progressive and worthy of active support from licensed s ortsmen.

With the Garden all but sold out and a frantic scramble on for tickets by late seekers, Frederick J. Perry, British and American tennis champion, and Ellsworth Vines, the world's professional titleholder, went through a workout together at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn last night in preparation for their meeting tomorrow evening.

The suggestion of William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, that the United Automobile Workers of America address their complaints to plant managers was denounced today as a failure to recognize fundamental issues in a reply from Homer Martin, president of the union.

Subsidiaries of the Standard Gas and Electric Company will spend $28,932,000 on construction in 1937, Bernard W. Lynch, president, announced yesterday. Expenditures for completion of work in progress will reach $6,784,000. In addition, $4,538,000 has been appropriated for work to continue.

A shortage of nurses was reported by the Department of Hospitals, as the Department of Health reported 302 cases of influenza and 144 cases of pneumonia for the forty-eight-hour period ended 10 A. M. yesterday.

The Ottawa Valley Power Company issued today a writ claiming a total of $1,483,239 from the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario. The writ alleges the amount is payable for power held available by the company for the Hydro-Electric Commission under a contract dated Jan 15, 1930.

The Federal Maritime Commission was urged last night by John Lawrenson, secretary of the Join Marine Strike Council, to use it influence in obtaining a general referendum among Atlantic and Gulf seamen, under the direction the National Labor Relations Board to determine whether the men prefer the strike committee or officials of the International Seamen's Union as their labor spokesmen.

Shipping traffic through the Panama Canal during December marked a decline of 34.6 per cent compared with the number of transits in December, 1935, figures issued today disclosed. Tolls decreased 31.7 per cent.
Pierre S. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals today for redetermination of a $238,319 deficiency assessed against his 1932 income by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

A banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co. and including the William R. Staats Company, Blyth Co., Inc.; Dean Witter Co., the Pacific Company of California and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation will announce formally today the offering of a new issue of $10,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent
Joe Lubin, unattached, won from Dominick Risko of the Yonkers Catholic Youth Association in the heavyweight special on the amateur boxing program at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Heavier receipts of hogs, 36,000 head, including 7,000 direct to packers, proved too much for the market today and prices declined 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight. A good demand developed at the lower level, as fresh pork loins were quoted 1 to 2 1/2 cents higher at 18 to 22 1/2 cents a pound wholesale.

William M.Hines, publisher of The Boston Evening Transcript, said tonight that he had signed an agreement with a committee authorized to act for the paper's employes which provided for general salary increases.

ABRAMS-Leonard David, beloved husband of Blanche, devoted father of Eleanor Star. Funeral services at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 1,406 Pitkin Av. (at Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn), 1:30 P. M. today. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery. BAHNER-Annie, beloved wife of Walter, sister of Lena Calman. Services Central Funeral Chapel, 109 West 87th St., Wednesday, Jan. 6, 10:30 A. M.

Here, in the Capitol of the State his family has dominated politically for most of the last forty years, Philip M. La Follette was sworn in today for the third time as Governor. In the crowd of 5,000 persons who witnessed the ceremony was Dr. Glenn Frank, president of Wisconsin State University, whom the 39-yearold Governor seeks to depose from his present eminence.
The threatened strike in the automotive industry was considered a factor in the decline of some of the leading commodity markets yesterday.

Racial hatreds and the dictatorship in Germany are the most dangerous threats to world peace today although the forces making for war or peace are in better balance now than at any time since the World War, Dr. Hans Simons told the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday afternoon.

Averaging 240 miles an hour, Frank Sinclair, test pilot of the Seversky Aircraft Corporation, landed yesterday in New Orleans after a record 1,200-mile flight from here, according to word telegraphed back.

In the delicate balance of Nature, when she encounters civilization the scale is easily tipped in a way not at first anticipated by interfering man. From the National Park Service comes the report that there were fifty cases in the parks in 1936 in which bears bit visitors. In the Yellowstone, rangers
A father's fervent plea abruptly halted the search for Charles Mattson and his kidnapper tonight as the belief grew that the release of the 10-year-old boy might be a matter of hours.
Actuated by growing fear of becoming involved in any future war, Norway is taking steps to defend her territory from aggression and has just completed fortification of her northern coasts.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, after a visit to the White House today said that while the matter of his resignation was still in an indefinite stage he would "certainly stay with the government service at least through the Summer."

County reorganization, adoption of a modern building code and repeal of the 10 per cent penalty on overdue taxes were listed yesterday as the most important matters confronting the Board of Aldermen by William F. Brunner as he took office as Aldermanic President for a one-year term.

General Motors in notice to its employes said it would recognize no union as sole bargaining agent and would permit no labor dictatorship. Homer Martin, union leader, in replying to Knudsen letter of Saturday, gave terms of an "ultimatum" to the corporation. Page 14.

MOST of the "timely" books we see-books written on the run and almost torn from the presses to make the most of a temporary public interest-are pretty sad affairs, slipshod and brummagem. John Langdon-Davies's "Behind the Spanish Barricades" (McBride, $2.75) is a clearcut exception. Though composed in the space of
Nebraska's unicameral legislators spent ninety minutes today deciding how to seat themselves in a chamber devised for 100 members of a defunct two-house system.
The Duke of Windsor was shaken but uninjured when his car sidewiped another at the foot of Semmering Mountain, where the Duke planned to go skiing, yesterday, it was revealed here today.

Dave Levin, 198, Jamaica, tossed Gino Martinelli, 190, Italy, in the feature wrestling exhibition at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the local grappler score the fall with a series of body slams in 36:39.
I have been requested to make a brief statement, giving my views on matters which will occupy the House of Representatives during the earlier period of its session.

An application for a Federal grant to aid in constructing the proposed $26,785,000 midtown Manhattan underpass was sent to State WPA headquarters yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, who said he was prepared to start work on the project as soon as Federal funds were made available.

Charles Weill, Inc., resident buyers, opened offices yesterday at 101 West Thirty-first Street. Retail stores served by this new organination include S. Kann Sons, Washington, D. C.; H. P. Wasson Company, Indianapolis, Ind.; George B. Peck Co., Kansas City, Mo.;

Parole Commissioner Joseph. A. Canavan said yesterday that Charles McCarthy, veteran convict, who was arrested after he was alleged to have threatened his two brothers with a pistol, will have to serve two terms in prison for violation of paroles if he is again conevicted of a felony.

Chief of Police H. C. Riebau disclosed today that he was holding two men in connection with an attempt to extort $30,000 from W. W. Norton, treasurer of the Laird-Norton Lumber Company under penalty of death.
Thomas W. Lamont, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co.; A. Stirling Calder, sculptor, and Ernest Peixotto, painter, were sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as members of the Municipal Art Commission.
Plans for President Roosevelt's Birthday Ball, to be held on Jan. 30, were started yesterday with the first meeting of the Birthday Ball Committee in the Astor Gallery of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Creation of new fabrics and fashions and the use of national advertising were advocated to develop public favor for the darker shades of silver fox furs by Frank G. Ashbrook, chief of the Government Fur Resources Division, speaking last night before the annual convention of the Milligan Morrison Fox Producers Association in the auditorium of the New York Auction Company, Inc.
The statement issued yesterday on the automobile strike situation by Alfred P. Sloan Jr. president of the General Motors Corporation, was as follows:

Steel operations for this week were estimated yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute at 79.4 per cent of ingot capacity, the highest level since March, 1930. Last week the rate of operations was 77 per cent.

Two gavels were presented to Saul S. Streit yesterday in induction ceremonies as he took his seat on the General Sessions bench in the presence of his eight colleagues. Judge Streit was elected to a fourteen-year term on the Democratic ticket last Nov. 3.
Unanimous approval was given by the Supreme Court today to the Ashurst-Sumners act barring the shipment of prison-made goods into States which have laws against sale or possession of such goods.

Pope Pius entered the second month of his illness yesterday, and Professor Aminta Milani, his physician, took the occasion to issue a communique explaining the origin and nature of the Pontiff's maladies and giving a carefully worded estimate of his present condition.

Reynoldstown, winner of the Grand National the last two years, will not be entered in the classic steeplechase this year, his owner, Major Noel Furlong, announced today. "I think Reynoldstown has done enough," said Major Furlong.

Their traditional competitive rivalry keener than ever, but doubtless with their pugilistic impulses checked, the New York Rangers and the New York Americans will take the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight for the fourth episode in the metropolitan district's stirring hockey serial.

106th St., 303-305 E., 50x100.9; Retweb Corp. to The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p. m., demand, int. per bond, $40,246. Same property; same to same; bldg. loan and pr. mtg., $40,246; demand, int. per bond, $22,500. 29th St.. 221 W., 23.5x98.9; Irene Gross and another to Central Savings Bank: D. m. 5 yrs. int. per bond: $23,500.

Five planes delivered within the past two weeks to the hangar of the North Beach Air Service, North Beach Airport, Queens, to be dismantled and packed for shipment abroad were placed aboard lighters yesterday and taken to the steamer Mar Cantabrico at Pier 35, Brooklyn. The planes, it was said
Sunshine today proved that almanacs were wrong in predicting a 15-day downpour, but only after a record rainfall exceeding 16 inches in eight consecutive days.

The nation's leading concert-giving organizations and individual concert managers formed a new society at a meeting at the Hotel Plaza yesterday. It will be called the Concerts Association of America. The purpose of the association
The first day of the new account of the Stock Exchange here was quiet because of nervousness over the European situation and news of weakness in Wall Street.
Authorization for a $16,000,000 loan to prevent Price Brothers Co. from being sold at auction on Feb. 3 was granted in Superior Court on Saturday by Chief Justice Sevigny.

The Hearts were victorious over the Glasgow Rangers today for the second time this season. Playing at Ibrox Park, the Edinburgh soccer squad triumphed, 1--0, and went into a tie with the cup-holders for third place in the Scottish Football League, behind Aberdeen and Celtic.
An automobile accident removed one seeded player from the fifth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament, but other favorites took their first-round matches without much difficulty today.

Franklin L. Gunther, retired furrier, left a gross estate of $1,160,279 and a net of $1,052,598 when he died on Jan. 19, 1935, the transfer tax appraisal disclosed yesterday. Mr. Gunther, who was formerly president of C. G. Gunther's Sons, was a grandson of Christian G. Gunther, founder of the firm.

Launching a two-night stand at Playland, an amazingly fast McGill University sextet routed the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York, 16 to 0, tonight, completely winning the fancy of the crowd by its remarkable team work and deadly accurate shooting.
Insurgent commanders in Spanish Morocco tightened restrictions against travel in the zone today amid reports of an uprising of some tribes against their officers.

Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Barkdull of Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., entertained at tea yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza for Miss Mary Elizabeth Elines, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Stanley Elines, also of Irvington-on-Hudson. Miss Lines is a student at Wellesley College.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Nichols of Glenbrook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shirley D. Nichols, to Edward J. Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Grant of this city.

Attorney General Cummings ordered today the transfer of seven wardens and deputy wardens at four Federal penitentiaries. In announcing the changes Mr. Cummings said they were to obtain "a uniformity of practice and standardization or methods" for treatment of prisoners.

The rug and carpet field will substantially increase its advertising and promotional efforts this year, with budgets going up 15 to 20 per cent, according to opinions expressed yesterday by both manufacturers and retailers at the opening of Spring and Summer lines. Fear of consumer resistance to the rise in prices will be one reason why the trade is expected to spend considerably more in advertising its products.

The National State Bank of this city, W. Paul Stillman, president, announced today, will celebrate its 125th birthday this year. The bank was organized on Feb. 9, 1812, and opened its doors June 1 of that year.

A 23-year-old truck driver wearing a smudged sailor hat became the first purchaser yesterday of a $100 bond for the 1939 World's Fair. He got it from Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, who sloshed through an icy puddle on the fair grounds in Flushing Meadow Park to reach him.

Robert Henry Treman, banker, merchant and former acting governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died early today of heart failure. He was 78 years old. Mr. Treman died forty-five minutes after he was taken ill at 1 A. M. Funeral services will be held at the First Presbyterian Church here at 3:30 P. M. Wednesday.
Good Politian won the Woodlawn Handicap, feature race at Alamo Downs today, by coming from last place in the stretch to beat Crout Au Pot by a head. The mile and seventy yards was run in 1:433-5.

Saved from a bitter Winter on bleak Karagin Island, 107 passengers and the crew of the wrecked steamer Kamo arrived here tonight en route to their homes in Vladivostok. [Karagin Island is in the Bering Sea east of the neck of Kamchatka peninsula.]

The announcement New Year's Day that Yugoslavia and Bulgaria had agreed on a treaty of arbitration and non-aggression is further evidence that the Balkans are no longer the cockpit of Europe. On the contrary, in recent

The marriage of Miss Susan Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David ~Thomas Moore, to Joshua Bryant Powers of Pelham, N. Y., son of Albert Douglas Powers of St. Augustine, Fla., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 141 East Seventy-second Street.

Speed and experience told against the Princeton sextet tonight as the Manhattan Arrows, composed of former Big Three hockey stars, combined a fast-breaking attack with strong defense to down the Tiger skaters, 3-1, in Baker Rink.

A first mortgage of $8,000 at 5 per cent for five years was placed on 532 E. 171st St., a five-story building with stores, for Henry Schultz by Felix Bartfeld. Former Mayor John P. O'Brien will speak at a meeting of the Midtown Real Estate Association at the Hotel Newton, 2,528 Broadway, on Thursday evening. Eric W. Hunt Co.. Inc., has moved its realty and insurance offices to 295 Madison Av.
Mr. and Mrs. James A. Thomas of Homeside, White Plains, N. Y., gave a dinner last night at the Ambassador for Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, and Mrs. Sze.

Kenneth S. Templeton was elected president of the Chicago Board of Trade today in one of the most closely contested elections in the history of the Exchange. He received 392 votes to 378 for Lowell S. Hoit. Barnett Farol was elected second vice president. Siebel C. Harris, under rules of the Exchange, advanced from second vice president to first vice president.

Improvement of the merit system for public appointments, a stronger food, drug and cosmetic act, continuation of the reciprocal trade agreements program and neutrality legislation are the legislative measures the National League of Women Voters will support during the forthcoming session of Congress.

Creation of a Federal board to promote compacts between contiguous States for milk control with a view to preventing unfair trade practices which were found to exist in some instances was recommended to Congress today by the Federal Trade Commission.

MANHATTAN GUNTHER, FRANKLIN L. (Jan. 19, 1935). Gross assets, $1,160,279; net, $1,052,598. To Helene B. Gunther, widow, personal effects, $500,000 and life estate in $300,000; Franklin M. Gunther, son, paintings, specific personal effects, remainder in $300,000, and one-half residue outright and life estate in one-half residue; seventeen varying and contingent bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,689,479. John Wallace Young. attorney, 72 Wall St.

Charles Lewis, Sunshine Sportwear, in 225 W. 35th St.; Cotler Frocks, Inc., in 237 W. 35th St.: Sportmade Frocks. Inc.; Levbro Dress, Elias Sportwear, in 261 W. 35th St.; Chesterfield Dress Co., Inc., in 1,359 Broadway; Junior Fashion Frocks, Inc., in 491 7th Av.; Kane Co., Inc., broker.

George (Potsy) Clark, former Illinois quarterback and for the last three years coach of the Detroit Lions, signed yesterday as coach of the Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League, The Associated Press reports.

A group of New York pilgrims leaving at 1:30 P. M. today from the Grand Central Station for the International Eucharistic Congress in Manila next month will include Mrs. John O'Connell of 2,411 Poplar Street, the Bronx, mother of the Rev. John R. O'Connell, pastor of the Mission of Tangub, Mindanao, P. I.

Legislation will be presented early in the Congressional session, which opens tomorrow, to extend the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund and Presidential authority for further devaluation of the dollar, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

Joseph J. B. Ferry, organist of St. Peter's Church in Jersey City for thirty-nine years, and supervisor of music in the public schools of Harrison and East Newark for the last thirty years, died yesterday at the Medical Center after an illness of several months. His age was 60.
Offering will be made today of 149,084 shares of common stock of $20 par value of The National City Bank of Cleveland by an underwriting group consisting of Brown Harriman Co., Inc.;

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 26 totaled 562,218 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 167,478 cars, or 23 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 95,530 cars, or 20.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week of 1935, and 136,814 cars, or 32.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week of 1934.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 125-A. L. Shapleigh et al, petrs., V. Pascual Mier. On writ of cert. to the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals. Decree affirmed and cause remanded to the U. S. District Court for the Western District of Texas. Opinion by Justice Cardozo.

The trend in the United States toward displaying great art treasures in public galleries instead of in private collections is applauded editorially today in The Times in commenting on Andrew W. Mellon's gift to the nation.

Gifts in excess of $100,000,000 have accrued to Columbia University since Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler became its head in October, 1901, according to the annual report of the university's financial operations made public yesterday by Frederick A. Goetz, treasurer.

President Roosevelt's appearance on Wednesday before a joint session of Congress will be his sixth. House officials pointed out that the Chief Executive "had a long way to go" to equal the record of Woodrow Wilson.

The tobacco division of the Department of Commerce reported today exports of leaf tobacco from the United States in the JanuaryNovember period of 1936 amounted to 383,805,914 pounds, valued at S123.070.172. compared to 354,269,-

Thirty-fifth Annual Championship Show of the Atlantic Cat Club for the benefit of the Bide-A-Wee Home, Hotel Taft, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. Continues tomorrow. The New York Poultry Show opens at the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street, at 10 A. M. and continues all week. Open daily 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Sir Charles Kirkpatrick, ninth holder of a baronetcy created in 1685, died today at the age of 62. He is succeeded by his 18-yearold nephew, James Alexander Kirkpatrick. Sir Charles succeeded his father in 1899.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--In one of the most striking rulings of recent years, the Supreme Court today, in a unanimous opinion written by Chief Justice Hughes, upset the conviction and seven-year jail sentence of Dirk de Jonge, Oregon Communist, accused of violating the State's Criminal Syndicalism Law.
Harry Otis Winsor, president of Henry A. Maurer Sons, New York manufacturers of fire brick and hollow tile, died today of pneumonia at the White Plains Hospital. He was 57 years old.

Soloman Edman of 327 Central Park West, shirt and blouse manufacturer and father of Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, died yesterday, presumably of a heart attack, in front of 17 West Thirty-first Street, while returning from luncheon to his office at 31 West Thirtyfirst Street. He was 72 years old. He had shown no signs of illness when he left his home in the. morning.
Mr. and Mrs. William C. Marko of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel Renee Marko, to J. Nathanael Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Stern, also of Brooklyn.

The Hartman solution, which had been hailed as a concoction that would eliminate the pain in dental drilling, was declared last night to "have a definite value in dental practice, though in a much more limited range of circumstances than was at first assumed by the public." The pronouncement was

Sale of a large corner property at the end of the new municipal subway line in Jamaica was reported yesterday by the Oppenheimer Realty and Management Corporation. The parcel is at the northeast coroner of Hillside Avenue, 169th Street and Homelawn Avenue, to which the subway will be opened next Spring.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that the customers of the old Bronx Gas and Electric Company would soon begin receiving refunds, totaling $400,000 for all residential customers, representing the difference in rates paid for the current and the lower rates ordered by the Public Service Commission and since sustained in the courts.

Municipal Court Justice John C. Boylan was reported last night in a "very serious condition" with pneumonia at his home, 176 Hart Boulevard, West New Brighton, S. I., where his wife, Mrs. Lila Cronin Boylan died of the disease on Saturday.
Mr. and Mrs. Walton Hopkins of Annapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah C. Hopkins. to Ensign Leslie Martin Slack,

The Spanish Leftist government will not encourage the raising of volunteer combat columns in this country for service with its forces, Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Ambassador to the United States, said in an interview yesterday.
The Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 240,000 shares of capital stock of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.
James Hardwick Stagg, member of the firm of Stagg, Mather Hough, public accountants at 141 Broadway, died of pneumonia Sunday night at his home, 1,160 Fifth Avenue. His age was 58. Mr.

France invaded the United States yesterday with thirty-six steeplechase jumping horses which are expected to inject new life into steeplechase racing in this country. Rating a gang-plank of their own, the foreign-bred horses stepped nimbly from the American Merchant liner American Farmer, on which they had been housed for ten days, and were swiftly driven away to their new home at Belmont Park. [Pound]
To get the Capitol spic-and-span for the seventy-fifth Congress, 400 workmen have just finished the nation's biggest job of housecleaning. Their task included dusting 2,500 rooms.

The Rev. Michael Gori, pastor of St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Hoboken since 1921, died last night of a heart ailment in St. Mary's Hospital in Hoboken. He was 63 years old. During his pastorate he built a new church and a rectory.
When Oliva Dionne came to town today he had a story to tell of a big event in the life of his quintuplet daughters. The babies had an automobile ride New Year's Day, declared Papa Dionne.

Backed by determined parents, most of Deepwater's 323 grade school pupils went on strike from classes today to demand the reinstatement of William (Pete) Eckley, village policeman, ousted on New Year's Day by the Lower Penn's Neck Township Commission.

The Joseph Milner Company, with Lloyd B. Cox, sold to a client for occupancy the Linus Johnson farm at Towners, Putnam County, including a dwelling of twelve rooms, with 200 acres of land and a private lake. The same brokers, with I. B.

Expenditure of $252,796,450 on combined rivers and harbors and flood control projects during the fiscal year beginning July 1 was recommended today by Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, chief of army engineers.

Further reductions in interest rates on short-term city revenue notes and revenue bills were announced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor, following their approval by the committee of banks under the city's agreement with its bankers.

Presiding Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions was in a critical condition today at the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital, according to Dr. Harold F. Morrison, chief of staff at the hospital.

Travelers: Sylvia Sidney left yesterday by train for the coast to resume her picture work.... Sonja Henie, the figure skating champion and a new movie recruit, leaves today for Providence on the first leg of a skating exhibition tour .... Sophie Tucker, who returned last week from a three-month tour of London and British provinces, starts today for Hollywood to appear for Metro in "Broadway Melody of 1937."
Walter H. Donovan, secretary-member of the State Racing Commission, resigned today and plunged into the work of organizing the American Turf Alliance, an association of track owners and operators.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Dec. 12 amounted to 287,909,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

The city of Miami, Fla., through its exchange agent, B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., will offer immediately new refunding bonds to be exchanged for the balance of $2,442,000 of outstanding city obligations not previously converted into the refunding issue, it was announced yesterday.
The compensation of officers of three companies whose issues are listed on the New York Stock Exchange was disclosed yesterday in reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A spirited advance in South American dollar bonds featured yesterday, otherwise quiet trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The advance in LatinAmerican issues, however, carried the loans of Chile, Peru, Brazil, Rio Grande do Sul and some of the Sao Paulo bonds to new high levels for several years as gains ranging from 1 to more than 5 points spread throughout that list.

John J. Eagan of 768 Central Avenue, Woodmere, L. I., a realty dealer who had been called "the man who brought the bungalows to the Rockaways," died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while driving his automobile along Regina Boulevard near Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway. He was alone at the time and his death became known when a policeman discovered his body.

At the time of the original consideration in Congress of the undistributed profits tax, THE TIMES contended editorially that except in a very moderate form the tax was unsound in principle. Subsequent experience has emphasized this fact. The unparalleled

The question of ring supremacy between George Zengara, undefeated Greek lightweight from the East Side, and Jimmy McLeod, Tacoma boxer who was unbeaten in more than fifty battles, was settled last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, where a crowd of about 3,000 saw Zengara fight his way to a decision in eight torrid rounds.

The 8,000-ton American-South Affrican steamer City of New York arrived in Brooklyn from African ports yesterday with a new shipment of animals and reptiles under the care of Albert M. Vida, chief radio operator of the ship.
The text of the Anglo-Italian agreement has had a rather cool reception in League of Nations circles, but has aroused interest in Geneva regarding what Italy got for signing.

Mr. and Mrs. James F. McDonnell of New York and Wickapogue, Southampton, L. I., and Mrs. Robert Emmett McDonnell of New York and Rumson, N. J., gave a supper dance last night at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Catherine McDonnell and Miss Mary Angela McDonnell. Silvered and green smilax and silvered cedar trees were used in the decorations.

Lieut. Gov. Robert Peterson, charged with embezzlement in connection with a shortage of $170,000 reported in his bank at Centerville by Federal examiners, waived preliminary hearing in Federal court today and was bound over to the March grand jury. He was released on $15,000 bond.
Wooster College defeated Lehigh at I basketball tonight, 45 to 21, as the Engineers resumed their schedule following the Christmas vacation.

Representatives of strikers and labor organizations in the Berkshire Mills at Wyomissing, Pa., appealed to the White House today for "aid and assistance" in negotiating settlement of a labor controversy.

Support of the Republican party for the renomination of Mayor La Guardia was urged last night by Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney, in an address at a forum of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club, 2,390 Broadway.

John S. Leonard, 44, former Assistant District Attorney of Chautauqua County, pleaded guilty today to three indictments charging grand larceny and was sentenced to from three to six years in Attica prison.
After leading nearly all the way, Mrs. E. B. Shipp's Irene's Bob was beaten by A. Randolph's Forced Landing in a photo finish in the five and a half furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

Reports for the year-end issued by banks yesterday showed a general increase in total resources and deposits. Most of them added to undivided profits and additions to capital through transfers from reserves were to be noted.

Congress was urged to pass a Federal anti-lynching law in a resolution adopted yesterday at the twenty-eighth annual meeting of the officers and members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 69 Fifth Avenue.

Amoskeag bondholders received their final liquidating checks today, clearing the books of all indebtedness to these creditors. The sums distributed represented the interest due to individuals or companies for the period beginning in December, 1935, to the present.

Foreign exchanges advanced in terms of the dollar yesterday. The pound sterling was up 5-16 cent to $4.91 1/4 and the fra--c rose 1-16 point to 4.671-16 cents. The belga jumped 5 1/2 points to 16.90 cents and the Swiss franc advanced 1/4 cent to 22.98 1/4 cents.

Six relatives applied to the Kings County Surrogate yesterday for shares of the estate left by Christopher Hassett, former baseball player who died in Cumberland Hospital on Dec. 23. Application for letters of administration were filed by Ethel Oettinger of 190 Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, a niece, on behalf of herself, two nephews, two grandnephews and one grandniece.

A sentence of death in the electric chair the week of Feb. 8 was imposed by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday on Chew Wing, 33 years old, a native-born Chinese, in the hold-up killing of another Chinese, Yip Chow, in the victim's home at 305 Broome Street the night of Nov. 29, 1935.
Japan's re-entry into the wool sales both here and in Sydney following settlement of the trade dispute was marked by an advance of 10 to 15 per cent in prices compared with the December auctions.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 4.--Through its press service the government made public today a sharp note it had sent to the German Government concerning Nazi charges of an affront to the Reich in the absence of the German flag at festivities in connection with the forthcoming wedding of Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld of Germany.

The problem of farm tenancy, admitted by leaders of the administration to be one of the most important agricultural questions facing the Seventy-fifth Congress, will be tackled almost at once, it was indicated today. Representative Jones of
Federal intervention in Matto Grosso, sought by the majority in the Matto Grosso Assembly four days ago, was asked again today in a petition to President Getullo Vargas.
William Langer took office as Governor of North Dakota for the second time today. He faced a legal fight, however, to retain the office he once lost through a court decision.
Miss Rosemary Clark, daughter of Mrs. Joseph V. Clark of this city. has chosen Feb. 3 for her marriage to John F. McDonough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. McDonough of New York. The ceremony will be
Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, headed a list of foreigners decorated with the Order of Brilliant Jade, published today in the Chinese Government's New Year honors.

The ramifications of basketball defense were revealed by Nat Holman to the Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday and the scribes discovered that court defense has as many intricacies to it as a table of the national debt.

Although the Army Air Corps received delivery of 506 new airplanes during the calendar year just ended, it finds itself today with only about 1,400 serviceable craft, probably less, but with nearly 1,600 able fliers who must await their turn to "put in time" or else double up with a brother pilot to keep themselves in flying trim.

The New York film critics, voting by closed ballot yesterday, selected "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" as the best picture of 1936. They chose Walter Huston's performance in "Dodsworth" as the best of the year among the actors; decided

The committee on bonds of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday, that effective today, bids and offers in Erie Railroad Company 4 per cent bonds, due in 1951, which have been called for redemption, should be made in variations of 1-32d of a point.

The ballot box for the First district of the Second Ward in Wildwood, which had been "missing" for a week, was found today-incorrectly labeled-in the hearing before Judge Wilfred H. Jayne in Circuit Court here of charges a Republican State Senator was elected last Nov. 3 by fraud.
Campaign expenditures of $822,767 were reported for 1936 by Jay Cooke, treasurer of the Pennsylvania Republican Committee, in final reports filed today with the Clerk of the House.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 31 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Honus Wagner, commissioner of the National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress, yesterday appointed Fred Clarke, former manager of the Pirates, director of the semi-pro national championships at Wichita, Kan., next August.

Mrs. Hollister Sturges will give another in a series of receptions today at the Gotham for her daughter, Mrs. Henry Field of Chicago, and her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sturges of Cambridge, Mass.
Spokesmen for the railroads and their employes have agreed to confer in the near future in a cooperative effort to iron out differences over the handling of retirement annuities for railroad workers,

The monotonous regularity with which the horses of Mrs. Emil Denemark have been winning feature events at Tropical Park continued today. Chief Cherokee, a close third in his last start despite being knocked out of contention, ran the fastest mile of the meeting to win the Istokpoga Purse for his Chicago owner.
Clifford Odets, Left-wing playwright, and Luise Ralner, Viennese film actress, today gave notice of their intention to marry.

Allocation of funds for the erection of an American Legation at Monrovia, capital of Liberia, was announced today by Representative McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the Foreign Service Buildings Commission. The cost was not specified.

A court order removed F. I. Struble from the Morrow County Sheriff's office today after he refused to give up the position-to Sheriff-elect Oscar George. George walked into the county jail with an order from CommonI Pleas Judge Frank E. Slabaugh to restrain Struble from occupying the office.

A memorial exhibition of work by George Pearse Ennis, who died last August at the age of 52, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street. It will be current until Jan. 16.

About 100 pin boys in a Flint bowling alley copied the methods of labor unionists tonight and staged a "sit down" strike just as a local league tournament was to start. The youths, mostly from 16 to 18 years old, set up the pins for the first frame and then sat down, demanding an increase of 4 to 5 cents a line.

At the conclusion of play in the seventh round of the international masters' tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club today the destination of the first and second prizes was definitely limited to two of the ten competitors, although two more rounds remain to be contested.
Two New York mining engineers were preparing here tonight for a six-month journey into the jungles of British Guiana in quest of gold.

Proposed changes in the partnership arrangements of four firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange, effective at the year-end but not yet formally approved, were announced yesterday by the Exchange.

Gene Venzke of the New York A. C. will make his first serious bid as a long-distance runner on Saturday in the games of the Columbus Council, K. of C., at the 106th Infantry Armory, in Brooklyn. Famed as a miler during the

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican leader of Suffolk County and center of the storm raging for some weeks in connection with the proposal to re-elect Irving M. Ives Speaker of the Assembly, arrived here this evening and intimated that the Assemblymen from Suffolk would stay out of the Republican caucus tomorrow, when the Speaker will be nominated.

The Athletics will play fifteen Spring training games, exclusive of those at their Mexico, D. F., training camp, it was announced today. Other than a five-game city series with the Phillies, the Browns are the only major league team to appear on the schedule.
Purchase of thirteen small apartment houses in the Bronx by an investing syndicate and the sale of several warehouse and business properties in Manhattan were reported by brokers yesterday.
Pleas for executive clemency for three youths convicted of first degree murder, based on the ground that their "confessions" were forced from them by the police, were heard today by Governor Lehman.

Federal Judge William H. Holly today approved a voluntary petition of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for permission to reorganize under the amended Bankruptcy Act. At the same time he issued a restraining order enjoining other suits against the company.

What happens in the Supreme Court between now and May will probably be the final factor in determining whether this Congress will prepare and submit to the people a constitutional amendment relating to social and industrial conditions in the United States.

The Panama Railroad Company is an instrumentality of the government, and the salary of Richard Reid Rogers of New York, its general counsel, cannot be made subject to any State income tax, the Supreme Court held unanimously today in an opinion by Justice Sutherland.
Rexford Guy Tugwell, who recently resigned as Under-Secretary of Agriculture, entered the ranks of private industry yesterday at 10:45 A. M.

The Giants' first venture in chainstore baseball on a Class AA scale, made possible with the purchase last week of the Albany International League franchise and which is to be operated in Jersey City this year, will begin to take definite shape today with the arrival in town of Manager Bill Terry and his field captain, Travis Jackson.
In a "spirit of humility" Senator Norris received tonight the American Farm Bureau Federation's disFarm Bureau Federation's distinguished service medal. for his contributions to agriculture.
The influenza epidemic spread through the British Isles today, with hospitals fighting to keep enough of their staffs working to care for the victims.

The Westchester trustees appointed by former Supreme Court Justide William F. Bleakley to administer the rehabilitation of the certificated mortgages of Westchester mortgage concerns now in liquidation were criticized today in a decision by Justice Sydney A. Syme, who was appointed by Governor Lehman to succeed Mr. Bleakley.

Dr. David Fraser-Harris, author and lecturer, died last night in a London nursing, home. He was 69 years old. Dr. Fraser-Harris was secretary of the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Birmingham, England, and former Professor of Physiology at Dalhousie University, Halifax, N. S.

Miss Kathleen Knapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Knapp of East Orange, N. J., was married here to Jean Manceau, son I of Mr. and Mrs. Helix Manceau of Paris, last night in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Harold Lemoine. The bride, who
At their new residence in Via del Lago Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Johnson were hosts to fifty colonists today for cocktails.
The American Professional Football League yesterday voted Rochester into the league, according to an announcement through The Associated Presss.

The Maryland Racing Commission recommended today that the Legislature pass a law "making it a criminal offense to tamper in any way with a race horse." The commission called attention to the epidemic of sponging last Fall at the Bowie track.

Due to the holiday and to curtailed production caused by strike difficulties in supply plants, automobile production receded last week, and the adjusted index dropped to 96.0 from 96.8, the figure for the previous week.

Getting more persons into jobs will be industry's most important problem in 1937, Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper said today in an address at the National Shoe Fair here. More than 600 persons are in attendance. He suggested that important units of industry should train persons for industry through plant schools.

The Florida Supreme Court kept hands off today in the dispute over the refusal of Daytona Beach's housewife Mayor to relinquish her office so that the incoming Governor, Fred P. Cone, might have a chance to intervene if he desired.

The conservation of farm people ranks with the saving and upbuildling of soils as "a major objective of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration," Dr. H. R. Tolley, AAA Administrator, said at the opening session of the fourth annual Rutgers Institute of Rural Economics here today.

Mrs. J. Mitchell Hoyt of Noroton, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Hoyt, to Lieutenant Ridgway P. Smith Jr., U.S.A., son of Major Ridgway P. Smith, U.S.A., and Mrs. Smith of New York.

Governor Hoffman appointed today Mrs. Mary G. Roebling of Trenton, widow of Siegfried Roebling, as a member of the unsalaried commission created by the Legislature to administer the State's new unemployment compensation law.

Deaths Announced Captain George J. Lachat of H. L. 125, Jan. 2. Funeral will take place from his late residence. 122-08 Hillside Av., Richmond Hill, at 2 P. M., Tuesday, Jan. 5. Interment at Mount Olivet Cemetery, Maspethi, Queens.

The American Sugar Refining Company will make today an advance of 20 points to 5 cents a pound in the price of refined sugar. Yesterday the company was accepting business subject to confirmation at 4.80 cents.

The Ford Motor Company appeared as a defendant in a Supreme Court auto negligence suit here today as the result of a charge by the owner of the car alleged to have caused damages that the machine was of faulty construction.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4.--With at least twelve children burned to death and hundreds injured in New Year's tree fires, the newspaper, Za Kommunisticheskoye Proveshcheniye (For Communist Education) announced today that those responsible would be arrested and tried.

The directors of the Beaunit Mills, Inc., have authorized the purchase for $100,000 of 52 per cent of the common stock of the National Weaving Company, Inc. The acquired company is to be organized under North Carolina laws after they have been reorganized under the bankruptcy law.

Irving Ettelman, 34 years old, a shipping clerk, of 515 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested last night at his home and charged with the theft of merchandise from his employer, the Clover Brassiere Company, 31 East Thirty-first Street.

The Department of Agriculture reported today in a survey of the world trade in cotton that Japan had replaced the United Kingdom as the largest cotton importer since 1929, while South American countries had expanded as exporters.

The unpleasant prospect of practicing his trumpet playing on the deserted sands of Coney Island was opened to 23-year-old Sol Buchman in the Flatbush court yesterday, after Magistrate Jacob Eilperin heard testimony indicating that Sol's "swing" technique is not appreciated by his neighbors.

Peter M. Daly, former City Court justice of Queens, who was elected to the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District last November, was inducted into office yesterday at ceremonies held in Part I of the Supreme Court in Queens County Court House, Long Island City.

The Government Club, a civic organization of women founded in 1905, held its first meeting of the year yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor. Mrs. Edmund Cooper was acting president in the absence of Mrs. C. Hampton Smith.

Class A One-Mile Handicap-Won by Ed Quimby, Texaco S. C. (40 yards); Herman Esselman, Paterson S. C. (60 yards), second; Henry Swoidsma, Paterson S. C. (50 yards), third. Time-3:00.8. Class B Two-Mile Point Race-Won by James Wood, Staten Island S. C., 35 points; Stanley Lasker, Niagara S. C.. 30 points, second; Roger Place, New York S. C., 10 points, third. Time-6:65.

The first week of 1937 started with evidence of active trading in Brooklyn and Queens. Four corner properties in Brooklyn changed hands, two of these for improvement with buildings. Apartment houses in Elmhurst and Sunnyside also figured in the day's deals.

Geneva outclassed Rider College tonight to hang up its fourth basketball victory of the season, 55-43. Paced by Captain George Pennedaker and Tom Hurley, the visitors counted twenty-one times from the floor and gave the impression that they could have run up a greater score.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Chick Evans, who has been roaming the fairways for twenty-five years, thinks ten clubs are enough for any golfer in any kind of competition.

The vanguard of what is expected to prove the greatest influx of buyers for any Spring season since 1929 began to arrive in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Almost all sections of the country were well represented in the arrivals, with active interest shown in merchandise for immediate selling this month or in February.

SOMEWHERE in the offing the Rangers and Americans were sharpening up their skatesand maybe their sticks-for their hockey debate that is scheduled for this evening, but M'sieu Lestairre Patrick, the Silver Fox of the skating zone, was peacefully tilting back in his swivel chair and saying that everything was lovely, including the weather.

Lee Parsons Davis, former District Attorney of Westchester County and widely known as a trial lawyer, was formally inducted today as a justice of the Supreme Court at exercises in Trial Term, Part One. About 300 friends filled the court room. Justice Graham Witschief,
An international commission to preserve the scenic beauty of Niagara Falls will be proposed to the new Congress by Representative Alfred F. Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y.

Business failures rose slightly in the five-day week which concluded 1936, according to Dun Bradstreet. The total of 173 delinquencies compared with 162 in the preceding five-day period, but was well under the aggregate of 206 reported for the corresponding week of 1935.

Nonresidents of New York must pay an income tax to that State on profits derived from sale of a Stock Exchange seat, the Supreme Court unanimously decided today in the case of C. Handasyde Whitney, a Boston broker.

Fortyeight hours after they had been served with a Circuit Court injunction ordering them to vacate, several hundred striking members of the United Automobile Workers of America continued to hold possession of the two Fisher Body plants here.

Additional detectives were assigned yesterday to hunt the thugs who looted Barney's Clothes, Inc., at 111 Seventh Avenue on Saturday night. One of the fugitives, Lawrence (LaLa) Mullins, Sing Sing parolee, was probably wounded after the hold-up, the police disclosed.
Dr. Francis D. Donoghue, recognized as an authority on cancer, tuberculosis and industrial accidents, died today, after a month's illness, at the age of 72.

When the steering gear of their automobile locked as they were driving on the Fallsway, Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Frye of Baltimore were trapped in the car as it plunged over a 10-inch curbing into sixteen feet of water.

Cathedral College and Cathedral Prep of Brooklyn scored victories over two Huntington Seminary basketball teams yesterday on the Cathedral court. Cathedral College triumphed over the second-year combination, 30 to 24. The Cathedral Prep team defeated the Huntington first-year squad, 40 to 21.

Postal receipts at the Newark postoffice in 1936 set a record, it was announced today by Postmaster John F. Sinnott Jr. The figure of $4,825,269 was 6.27 per cent above the 1935 total of $4,540,406 and exceeded also the 1929 figure of $4,714,814, the previous record.

The last column of the editorial page of Jan. 2 contains a letter under the appropriate caption "Humanizing Republicans," by Emil Prantner, whose treatise on Republican policies and practices possesses considerable merit and much that is true.

Mrs. Alexandre Hoppin gave a dinner dance last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to introduce her niece, Miss Nancy Schenck, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Schenck of New York and London and the late Mr. Schenck.

Six cruising ships arrived yesterday from the Bahamas and the West Indies bringing 4,500 passengers, the last contingent of the Americans who went on the Christmas holiday trips. The only one under the American flag was the Manhattan of the United States Lines with 720 passengers.
New York's table tennis team won its third consecutive intercity championship by defeating St. Louis, 5 to 3, in the final round of the national table tennis tournament today.
An army pursuit ship from near-by Chanute Field fell within the city limits today, carrying two fliers to their deaths. The victims, Captain Reginald Gillespie, 35, and Sergeant Clarence
The Madrid defense authorities admitted tonight that their troops had evacuated Wajadahonda on the important Escorial road, northwest of the capital.

Expiration of the freight surcharges at the end of 1936 in accordance with a ruling by the Interstate Commerce Commission should not have a serious effect on railroad finances, Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said yesterday.

Mrs. Herbert I. Foster gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 3 Beekman Place, to introduce her cousin, Miss Audrey Pile, daughter of Sterling Pile of Manhasset. Miss Pile made her debut in Baltimore at the first Bachelors Cotillion this season.
A Federal grand jury indicted today John T. Hull of Leominster, and Morey Getz

Colonel Daniel W. MacCormack, Commissioner General of Immigration and Naturalization, was buried today with military honors in the National Cemetery at Arlington, after funeral services attended by members of Congress, members of the diplomatic corps and high officials of his own and other departments of the government.

The question of the ability of Father Divine, Negro cult leader, to pay a $6,500 judgment against him was referred yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman to official Referee Joseph I. Green for hearing.

Many Republican members of the Rhode Island Senate and House of Representatives, who will take their seats tomorrow in Providence, were dinner guests of former State Senator William H. Vanderbilt at his home, Oakland Farm, in Portsmouth last night. There were between fifty
A spurt of 5 points during the week sent Larry Aurie of the Detroit Red Wings back into the National Hockey League's scoring leadership ahead of Dave (Sweeney) Schriner of the New York Americans.

The Rev. Felix Kloman, assistant rector of Grace Church, 802 Broadway, was elected yesterday as president of the New York Churchmen's Association to succeed the Rev. Worcester Perkins, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion, 49 West Twentieth Street.

Dr. Louis Bloch, labor economist, expressed the belief today that unemployment could be banished "if only we have the intelligence to know how to proceed." His optimistic outlook was expressed as he prepared to leave for Washington tonight to become chief statistician for the National Social Security Board.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. McIntyre of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Louise McIntyre, to Morton Albertson Howard Jr. of Larchmont, N. Y.
Passengers sailing today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria include Lady Lindsay, wife of Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States; Sir George

Automobile accidents, fatalities and injuries all showed a large increase in the final week of 1936 and beginning of the new year, according to the figures compiled in the office of First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler. Mr. Fowler ascribed the heavy increase to weather conditions.

Federal Judge T. M. Kennerly was asked today to appoint a receiver for the 1,000,000-acre King Ranch estate. The petition, charging "mismanagement," was filed for Richard Atwood of Illinois and others. T. H.

Despite the pardon granted to General Chang Hsueh-liang yesterday for the Sian revolt, his future remains obscure. The "young marshal" is being placed under the Military Affairs Commission for disciplinary observation, and it is noteworthy that the pardon failed to restore his former titles and did not mention a possibility of his return to Sian, capital of Shensi Province.

Representatives of eight associations of cloak and dress manufacturers and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union met yesterday at the call of the union to consider a legislative program to be submitted to Congress. The meeting was held at the Hotel New Yorker.

Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, announced last night the receipt of anonymous contributions of $10,000 and $5,000, the sums representing an increase of 40 per cent each over the gifts made by the same donors last year.

Sales of three New Jersey residential properties are reported by J. I. Kislak, Inc. A six-room house at 1,730 Midway Place, North Bergen, was sold to Bertha Klein for occupancy by the Town of Union Building and Loan Association. Lina Harris purchased a two-family residence and garage at 73 Hauxhurst Av.
