In the Hauxhurst Park section of Weehawken and Henry Kaufman purchased from Lena Eller a four-family house at 531 28th St., Union City.

Robert Hathaway of East Orange, N. J., Yale '13, and now. governing head of the Channel island of Sark, will sail for home on the Berengaria today with his wife, Mme. La Dame de Serk et Dependences, and a special request.
Pickets and policemen were in combat today at the Fisher Body plant of General Motors here as strikers temporarily barred 300 office workers from the plant.
A son, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brownell O'Brien of this place on Dec. 29 at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola.

Governor Hoffman accepted today for the State a deed to about twentytwo acres of land at Menlo Park, given by heirs of the late Thomas A. Edison, to be added to another tract of similar size for the proposed park in memory of the famous inventor.

With the Mediterranean pact concluded and friendship with Italy restored, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will return to London from his holiday tomorrow to deal with the constantly growing complexities of the situation in Spain.
While tenants of the fashionable River House apartment building watched, four detectives rescued a drowning man at 4:20 A. M. yesterday from the East River at the foot of East Fifty-third Street.

A report reached here early today that Ralph Fox, 36year-old British author and newspaper man, had died at Madrid. Mr. Fox had been political comissar for the British contingent with the Spanish international brigade defending Madrid.

Relatives here received notice tonight of the death in Deland, Fla., today of Edwin Asbury Kirkpatrick, psychologist and educator. Mr. Kirkpatrick, born in Peoria, Iowa, in 1862, lived in North Leominster until about a year ago when he moved to Eagle Bridge, N. Y. He was a fellow in

Australia's score in the second innings stood at 252 runs for five wickets at lunch on the fourth day in the third cricket match with England today. The Aussies led England by 318 runs when play was resumed before 40,000 spectators and they increased their margin to 370 without the loss of another wicket.

Enactment by Congress of a law authorizing the President to bring under civil service all positions which have been exempted from it by legislation or otherwise, and inclusion within the classified service as soon as practicable of all other than policy-forming posts, were major recommendations urged by the Civil Service Commission in its annual report, made public today.
The Princeton Club's Class B squash tennis team scored another victory in the metropolitan league series last night by blanking the New York A. C. representatives, 5 to 0.

The text of the unanimous Supreme Court opinion in the case of Dirk De Jonge, Oregon Communist, follows: Supreme Court of the United States Number 123-October Term, 1936 Dirk De Jonge, appellant, vs. the State of Oregon. Appeal from the Supreme Court of the State of Oregon.

The United States Circuit Court heard argument yesterday on an appeal taken by the General Utility Investment Corporation, an Associated Gas and Electric Company affiliate, from the dismissal by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum of a reorganization petition filed by creditors of the National Public Service Corporation, an Insull concern.
Six months ago, at its national convention in Philadelphia, the Democratic party gave a promise which has now come home to roost. It had to do with the civil service. The Republicans were

A reshuffling of the controlling interests in the newspaper and publishing enterprises of Lords Camrose, Kemsley and Iliffe was announced here today. It does not affect the operating personnel of any of their ventures.

Market irregularly lower; motor shares weakened on strike news; turnover, 1,507,753 shares. United States Government bonds lower, corporation issues irregular, foreign loans higher, South American bonds active and strong; transactions, $12,784,100.

A consolidation of public utilities serving Marion and other points in Ohio through an affiliate of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York is to be brought about through financing approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Offering will be made to the public today of an issue of $300,000 of Peoples Bridge Corporation firstcollateral-lien 5 per cent bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1946, at par and accrued interest, by Stemmler Co., Brooke, Stokes Co. and F. J. Young Co.. Inc.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 1: Knight, Brig. Gen. H. E., General Staff Corps, appointed as Major General. Pratt, Brig. Gen. H. C. (Colonel), Air Corps, appointed as Brigadier General. He will remain on present duty as Wing Commander, Second Wing, Air Force, Langley Field, Va.

This nation today is drama-conscious to a degree not equaled anywhere since Elizabethan days. Mayor, LA GUARDIA had the support of a troupe of no less than fourteen city department heads in his radio dramatization of the La Guardia administration the other night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The first session of the overwhelmingly Democratic Seventy-fifth Congress will convene at noon tomorrow, perhaps to be faced immediately with a demand, growing out of the situation in Spain, for "emergency action" to reinforce the Neutrality Law intended to keep the United States out of war.

Fairfield County legislators voted unanimously this afternoon to authorize the immediate issuance of $8,520,000 in bonds to complete the Merritt Parkway, which will connect the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester County with New Haven County, paralleling the Boston Post Road.

Virginia Woolf has done so much work on the galleys of her new novel, "The Waves," that its publication, planned for last Fall by Harcourt, Brace, now is only hoped for this Spring. Some sections of the novel have been rewritten since it was in type, and further changes Probably will be made.

Columbia's basketball team meets Union tonight as it returns to action on its home court after an absence of nearly three weeks. The Lions, with six victories in their last seven games, expect a close battle from the up-Staters, who have an outstanding forward in Ted Podbielski.

Amazed when Mr. and Mrs. Larry Berman of 4,701 Snyder Avenue told him they had been compelled to move eighteen times in two years because of their domestic squabbles, Magistrate Blanchfield, in Felony Court in Brooklyn, advised the couple yesterday to keep away from each other for the sake of peace.

The Crown Heights sextet strengthened its hold on first place in the Tri-County Hockey League, halting the Baisley Park Hockey Club, 7-2, for its fourth victory in six starts at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, Frank E. Barrows of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 3950-United States v. Kelvin and Wilfrid O. White Co., Rice Co. Opinion by Judge Bland. The U. S. Customs Court Judgment is reversed.

The newspaper Libre Belgique said today that the body of Baron Jacques de Borchgrave, 35, First Secretary of the Belgian Embassy in Madrid, who disappeared on Dec. 31, had been found at Fuencaral with his head smashed and his identity papers and automobile missing.

With representatives of his new colleagues on the bench, his former colleagues in the State Legislature and his family attending, City Court Justice John A. Byrnes was inducted into office yesterday in a ceremony in a court room of the Old County Court House on Chambers Street. Justice Byrnes, who

President Roosevelt and his labor aides kept close tab today on every development in the General Motors strike. If there were any government peace manoeuvres, however, they were executed behind the scenes.

A few minutes after he called his wife and mumbled unintelligible phrases over the telephone, Thomas Kennerly Sexton, 37-year-old chief of enforcement division of the State Liquor Board, was found shot through the head in his office here early today.
Bernard M. Stone, one of Alaska's foremost editors and publishers for the last thirty years, died here today at the home of his sister-inlaw, Mrs. M. A. Malaby, at the age of 62.

Colonel Walter Frank, commandant at this army air post, exonerated today Lieutenant Thomas F. Moorman of any blame in connection with his jumping out of an army plane early last Saturday morning over the village of Bellmore.

The recently developed principle of bone conduction of sound has been brought to such a remarkable degree of perfection in the new Fortiphone that clear hearing even at a distance is now possible in the great majority of cases.
Elmer A. Benson, Farmer-Laborite, took his oath of office today as Governor of Minnesota, the third member of his party to hold the position.

Pravda, organ of the Communist party, tonight bitterly assailed three men formerly high in Soviet councils, and authoritative sources interpreted the article as foreshadowing another big political trial.

The largest annual premium income and the largest total income from premiums and investments in the seventy-three-year history of the Travelers insurance companies were announced yesterday by Edmund Zacher, president.

Ray Mangrum, 26-year-old professional from Dayton, Ohio, defeated Tony Manero, 1936 national open golf champion, in the eighteen-hole play-off today to capture first prize money in the Miami open tournament at the Miami Springs Golf Club.

Trial of a damage suit for $75,000 growing out of the publication of a photograph of Crawford Burton, gentleman jockey, which appeared in a testimonial advertisement for cigarettes, began yesterday in Federal Court.
A fresh attempt to organize business behind an "industrial agreements act," containing some features of. the NRA, has been undertaken by a band of trade association executives.

Plans for utilizing all the facilities of the British Broadcasting Corporation and its network of regional stations have been in progress for months, with clear indications that at the first threat of hostilities involving Britain the whole system will pass to direct operation by the government.

Manhattan 11th Av., 200; 24.8x72, for one-story dining car; 11th Av. Dining Car, Inc., owner; Charles N. Selig Whlnston, architect; cost, $18,000. 3d Av., 1,529-33; alteration to three-story stockrooms and store; estate of Jacob Lauchheimer, 27-17 Bayview Av., Far Rockaway. owner; A. H. Winter, architect, cost, $50,000.

County officers tonight captured Harry Reeves, wanted in connection with an explosion which killed Harold Baker in Sioux Falls, S. D., on New Year's Eve. Sheriff W. R. Tice and Deputy Sheriff Glen Hauser caught the former convict about 10 o'clock after going to a farm near this city on a tip from an undisclosed source.
Sub-zero weather, the first of the season, pressed toward Chicago tonight from the Mackenzie River basin of Western Canada.

Major Peter C. Geyer Jr. of the Marine Corps was suffering from a virulent lobar pneumonia when he fatally stabbed his mother, Mrs. Eliza Geyer, 82 years old, and then killed himself with the same knife, an autopsy performed by Acting Chief Medical Examiner Thomas A. Gonzales, disclosed yesterday.
A renewed plea for greater decorum in the courts was heard here today as the house delegates of the American Bar Association convened for their second annual meeting.

Al Ettore, chunky Philadelphian, climbed back into the front rank of heavyweight contenders before 13,000 tonight with a ten-round decision over John Henry Lewis of Phoenix, Ariz., light heavyweight champion. Ettore weighed 191 1/2, Lewis 183.
Herbert Courtney, State amateur pocket billiard champion, defeated Albert Berman, a former holder of the title, 75 to 38, in the first of four blocks at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy last night.

Admiral Paul Behncke, former chief of the navy, died here tonight. His age was 70. Admiral Behncke, who was wounded in the Battle of Jutland, became chief of the navy after the World War. He held that post until 1924, when he retired.

Fifty-six more contributions, totaling $655.50, increased the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to a grand total of $265,200.98. Some sent gifts to "start the New Year right" by helping those of New York City who most need help; others wrote apologizing for the lateness of their contributions, not realizing that it is never too late to aid the Neediest.

Danno O'Mahoney, Irish wrestler who once held the heavyweight championship, defeated Gus Sonnenberg of Boston, also an erstwhile champion, in the main wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

Owing to the postponement of the opening of "High Tor," a new play by Maxwell Anderson, the performance for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association that had been planned for Wednesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre will be held the night of Jan. 13.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 30 shows a decrease of $10,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $24,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $68,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $41,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Trading opened fair to good on most classes of locally dressed meats. Prices were sharply higher on practically all classes of traefa meats. The kosher markets opened slightly stronger on beef and lamb and sharply lower on veal.
Final eviction notices were posted yesterday in 1,100 buildings in East 134th and 135th Streets that are to be razed to make way for the new Bronx approach to the Triborough Bridge.

Formation of the Bendix Aviation Export Corporation, through which will be cleared all the export business done by the Bendix Aviation Corporation and its affiliated companies in the $60,000,000 organization headed by Vincent Bendix was announced yesterday.

In a three-hour session today the City Council discarded the proposed 1937 budget for Philadelphia city and county, which they had been working on for a month, and began scrutinizing the new budget sent in Wednesday by Mayor Wilson.

Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that tenders for two series of Treasury bills, of approximately $100,000,000 to be dated Jan. 6, 1937, which were offered on Dec. 31, 1936, amounted to $236,305,000, of which $100,180,000 was accepted.

Mrs. Wallis Simpson definitely is not beautiful, but her outstanding attractions are vitality, personality and a sense of humor, according to Cecil Beaton, English photographer and artist, who opened an exhibition of his stage designs and sketches yesterday at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fiftyseventh Street.

The fourth intercollegiate basketball double-header will be staged in the New York Hippodrome tonight when St. Francis clashes with Manhattan and L. I. U. faces Davis and Elkins. The Blackbirds will seek to stay on the victory trail after Stanford so rudely brushed them off it last week.

Eugene J. Flnnegan, Assistant District Attorney, said yesterday he would ask Judge Collins in General Sessions tomorrow to schedule the second trial of J. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, for Jan. 18 on an extortion indictment on the complaint of Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former governor.

About 800 persons attended a funeral service yesterday morning for Frederic Potts Moore, retired broker, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 133 West Forty-sixth Street. Mr. Moore died last Friday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, at the age of 71.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange showed a loss of 15 points at one time yesterday on increased selling pressure following developments in the motor industry and the announcement that cotton held by the government would be available on Feb. 1. Trade-price fixing appeared

Just now I was thumbing over the cards representing new players added to the rosters of our eight National League clubs. I venture the prediction that our league, in its sixty-second season of championship competition, will present a younger average age in its teams' regular line-ups than has been the case for many years.

Demanding higher wages, 1,800 employes of the Electric Storage Battery Company began a "sit-down strike" today. Eight hours later they were notified by company officials that the plant would be closed temporarily.

Clear decks for speedy Congressional action to plug the loophole in existing neutrality legislation which allows the export of arms to the Spanish belligerents were foreshadowed today with the announcement that the House Foreign Affairs Committee will be selected by special resolution as soon as the House meets tomorrow.

The Cuban-American Sugar Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1936, a net profit of $1,148,259 after depreciation, interest, United States and Cuban income taxes and other charges.

Spurred on apparently by a warning on what happened in Spain, Lithuanian Catholics are seriously contemplating socializing and redistributing lands and other property of the Roman Catholic Church and clergy in Lithuania.
The General Motors strike picture last night was as follows: Eight plants closed by strikes; six closed wholly or in part by lack of material or by orders stopping shipments.

Sales of copper were made yesterday in the export market at the equivalent of 12.05 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base ports, the best level since June, 1930. Other sales were made as low as 11.95 cents, but the greater part of business was done at 12 cents.

Mrs. Wallis Simpson definitely is not beautiful, but her outstanding attractions are vitality, personality and a sense of humor, according to Cecil Beaton, English photographer and artist, who opened an exhibition of his stage designs and sketches yesterday at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery, 11 East Fiftyseventh Street.

The fourth intercollegiate basketball double-header will be staged in the New York Hippodrome tonight when St. Francis clashes with Manhattan and L. I. U. faces Davis and Elkins. The Blackbirds will seek to stay on the victory trail after Stanford so rudely brushed them off it last week.

Eugene J. Flnnegan, Assistant District Attorney, said yesterday he would ask Judge Collins in General Sessions tomorrow to schedule the second trial of J. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, for Jan. 18 on an extortion indictment on the complaint of Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former governor.

About 800 persons attended a funeral service yesterday morning for Frederic Potts Moore, retired broker, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 133 West Forty-sixth Street. Mr. Moore died last Friday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, at the age of 71.
Eugene O'Neill's "Strange Interlude" was performed for the first time in Austria at the Deutsche Volk Theatre tonight. It was given in an
A 5-year-old child was burned to death while playing with matches in her home here today, despite the efforts of her 65 year-old grandmother to save her.

At 11:30 this morning thirteen Insurgent Junkers bombers, escorted by five Heinkel pursuit planes, dropped forty to fifty bombs in Madrid. The toll was believed to be the highest in any bombing of the city, with perhaps as many as 100 persons killed and 200 injured.

The swearing in of Frank H. Innes as District Attorney of Richmond County was postponed for a second time in Staten Island yesterday when his formal certificate of appointment failed to arrive. Delay in delivery of the certificate by mail from Albany was attributed to-the holiday week-end.

Harold and Samuel Fox, owners of the former Fox Credit Clothing Company at 220 West Forty-second Street, pleaded guilty yesterday in the new branch of Special Sessions in the Municipal Building to violating Section 440 of the Penal Law by failing to file a trade certificate with the County Clark in the name of the concern.
The auditorium atop the Chanin Building, seating capacity 191, gets this evening's premiere: that of "Pepper Mill," an intimate revue assembled by Erika Mann.

THE HUMAN COMEDY, by James Harvey Robinson. (Harper, $3.) A survey of the activities of man in the drama of civilization, by the author of "The Mind in the Making." BEHIND THE SPANISH BARRICADES, by John Langdon-Davies. (McBride, $2.75.) An eye-witness account of the Spanish Civil War.

Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, replied yesterday to State Senator John J. McNaboe's claim that he was "opposing" the joint legislative committee named to investigate radical and subversive activities in the schools. Mr. Baldwin challenged Mr. McNaboe, chairman of the committee, to hold a "public hearing of his grotesque charges."
George A. Logan, 68 years old, formerly a walking champion of Hudson County, dropped dead yesterday in his Jersey City home at the end of his daily walk. He resided at 24 Storms Avenue. Mr.

New high prices for the season were established today on the Board of Trade here on all deliveries of corn futures, which advanced 1 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel. The prices also were the best for a January since 1925.

64th St., 47-51 E., 52x100.5; Herco Realty Corp. to Harry Wolfe, 566 5th St., Brooklyn; mtg., $375,000 (50 cents). Same Property; Harry Wolfe to Herco Realty Corp., 299 Madison Av.; mtg., $375,125 (50 cents). Spring St., 149, 25x100; May Dachs to Capital Paper Co., 106 7th Av.; mtg., $22.500 ($6.50).

The regional offices of the Home Owners Loan Corporation in the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street, have been expanded, and the organization now occupies nearly 70,000 square feet of space there.

Presentation of the defense of Charles C. Wright, George S. Simpson, Jere Sexton and others charged with manipulating common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corpoation, Ltd., was begun yesterday by Isidor J. Kresel before E. C. Johnson, trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Robert Starr Allyn, a Deputy Commissioner of Docks and one of the four lawyers in the city's service whom Mayor La Guardia recently appointed as magistrates for thirty days to help relieve congestion in the lower courts, took the bench yesterday in Essex Market court.

A total of 10,105 passengers passed through the turnstiles of the eight stations on the new branch of the city's Independent subway in Queens from Kew Gardens to Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights between the hours of 7 A. M. and 10 A. M. yesterday, the first rush-hour on a normal business day since the line was opened Dec. 31.

Class 1 railroads had a net railway operating income of $597,012,442, during the first eleven months of 1936, and had a rate of return on their property investment of 2.45 per cent, it was announced today by the Association of American Railroads.

Net operating earnings of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company last year were $2,604,617 after providing for expenses, taxes and losses, according to the detailed profit and loss account which the bank, following its custom of the last five years, made public yesterday.

Governor Earle described the Pennsylvania Bar Association and the American Bar Association today as "wholly Tory in point of view, directly reflecting the anti-social views of big business," and said that "reactionary interests have always owned" the State organization.
The diplomatic corps was largely represented today at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's Ninety-second Musicale Morning, at which she presented Georges Enesco, violinist, and Felix Salmond, 'cellist.

The new clubhouse of the Great Neck Woman's Club was dedicated and opened formally this afternoon. The building and grounds, on Old Mill Road, valued at $250,000, were given and furnished by Mrs. William Slocum Barstow of Kings Point, L. I., who was treasurer of the club in 1916.

News comes from Linz, in Upper Austria, that the Austrian provincial authorities have ordered that the house in which HITLER was born at Braunau on the Inn, hitherto open to visitors as a Hitler museum, may hereafter be shown to tourists from Germany, on request, but not to Austrians.

Proposals for drastic alterations in the curricula offered to freshman and sophomore students in Columbia College, worked out in the last year and a half by a special subcommittee on curriculum, will be laid before the entire faculty of the college on Thursday afternoon.
Charles W. Froessel was named today by Governor Lehman to be a justice of the City Court, filling the vacancy caused by the election of Justice Peter M. Daly to the Supreme Court.

BERLIN--The German press began featuring incidents in the "guerrilla warfare" of the Bay of Biscay with the obvious intention of rallying the public behind a firmer stand against the Spanish Loyalists. As a German ship was reported fired on Dec. 20 the press denounced what it termed "Red pirates."

The Beekman Street Hospital will begin today its fifteenth annual campaign for funds with which to carry on its operations. The goal this year is $125,000, representing the hospital's deficit for the year.
Turpentine firm, 43c.: sales 43 barrels: receipts 589 barrels; shipments 3,954 barrels: stock 31,896 barrels. Resin firm; sales 755: receipts 3,060: shipments 6,881; stock 78,277.

Charles A. Jones, general manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, announced today that Leo P. Dorsey of Douglaston, L. I., had been appointed acting New York State manager of the HOLC to succeed Vincent Dailey, who resigned last week. Mr. Dorsey has been State
The former Elaine Barrie disclosed today that her fifty-seven days of wedlock with John Barrymore had ended in a separation after a New Year's Eve quarrel and announced "the next move is up to him."
William Wallace Cowan, New Hampshire magazine publisher for a number of years, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at the home of his cousin, Mrs. Edna Cowan Dobbins. He was 53 years old.

Half the panel of 300 men from which the jury which will hear the trial of nine defendants in the alleged $2,000,000 a year restaurant ring will be chosen, reported yesterday morning to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, before whom the case is to start Jan. 18.
German Jews have been barred from Nazi golf clubs, the government disclosed today. All Jews were ousted from country clubs just before Christmas, officials said. They will be allowed
Deputy Inspector Richard J. Sheridan in charge of Traffic in Queens applied yesterday for retirement from the police department, having reached the age of 65 years on Jan. 1.
Mr. and Mrs. Manton B. Metcalf of 9 East Seventy-ninth Street gave a dinner last night at their home to celebrate the fifteenth anniversarv of their marriage.

Several thousand furniture buyers were here today as two major furniture markets opened midwinter exhibits. At the American Furniture Mart, 2,864 visitors had been registered toward the end of the day, compared to

Warning him never to drive an automobile again, Judge Lester W. Patterson, in the Bronx County Court, yesterday fined Rocco Grassi, 54-year-old contractor, $250 on his plea of guilty of leaving the scene of an accident in which a woman was fatally injured. The court suspended an indeterminate sentence to the penitentiary on the same charge.

A Raphael masterpiece, hidden and unknown for more than a hundred years and believed to depict a sweetheart of the great painter's youth, was disclosed to the world of art today by the director of the famous Borghese Gallery here.

Dr. William Bowie, chief of the division of geodesy of the Coast and Geodetic Survey of the Department of Commerce, has retired after more than forty-one years of service, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Bowie, who is 65 years old, has been recognized as a world authority on the structure and composition of the earth.
Sultana, $1,000,000 queen of yachts in 1890, lay keeled over in a muddy channel of Los Angeles Harbor today, doomed as a battered, worthless wreck.

While conflicting reports concerning the possibility of a peace conference tomorrow between officials of the General Motors Corporation and officers of the United Automobile Workers of America developed tonight, union officials planned to tighten their grip on strategic "bottle neck" plants in an attempt to compel the corporation to make peace.

London's thetrical New Year made a most auspicious beginning tonight with a new "Hamlet" at Old Vic. Laurence Olivier, playing the part for the first time and without entirely discarding tradition nor yet imitating others, brought his own natural energy and special sympathy into the part.

The foremost danger to a continued steady improvement in business in 1937 is the possibility of runaway price advances, according to George T. Trundle Jr., president of the Trundle Engineering Company of Clevenland.
Mayor Irene Armstrong went back to her neglected housework today after the calming political situation allowed police to quit their five-day tour of guard duty at City Hall.

Officials of the Labor Department expressed hope tonight that a talk could be arranged soon between William Knudsen, operating vice president of the General Motors Company, and leaders of the automobile union, but they said that they had no assurance that such a meeting had been agreed upon.
Syracuse University officials announced today that William G. Boelter, back field coach at the University of Iowa, had been named assistant to Ossie Solem, newly appointed Orange football coach.

The Distinguished Flying Cross was presented today by Secretary Woodring to Brig. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Assistant Chief of the Air Corps, for his "splendid achievement" in leading a flight of ten bombing planes from Washington to Fairbanks, Alaska, in the Summer of 1934. He was then a lieutenant colonel.

THE late George Apley was not the sort of man to tolerate showy descriptive epitaphs. Had he been, however, his tombstone in Mount Auburn Cemetery would read something like this: GEORGE APLEY 1866-1933 Born in Boston Died in Boston

The Department of National Revenue today issued a memorandum to customs and excise collectors drawing attention to an order-in-council extending to the Panama Canal Zone benefits of Canada's intermediate tariff.

Hearings in the proceedings of the Securities and Exchange Commission against Charles C. Wright and eleven others for alleged manipulation of common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., were continued yesterday at the regional office of the SEC, 120 Broadway, with Mr. Wright on the witness stand.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions ANDINO CHOCOLATE CO., INC., 52 Wooster St.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $29,763, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $45,080.

The Bankers Trust Company of New York, executor for the estate of the late Elizabeth Morrow Morgan, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to set aside a $54,185 estate tax levy. The executor contended that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue erred in computing the taxable estate of Mrs. Morgan,

The field for the 800-meter invitation event at the Columbus Council, K. of C., games Saturday night in the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, was completed yesterday. In addition to Glenn Cunningham, the runners will be Ernest Federoff, Millrose A. A.; Lou Burns, Manhattan; Bill Ray, Manhattan, and Larry Quinlan of Columbia.

Several apartment houses in the Bronx figured in realty transactions reported yesterday. One of the largest deals involved the six-story building at 1,056-58 Sherman Avenue, near the Grand Concourse, which was bought by the Sherose Estates, Inc., represented by Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer, from Real Equities, Inc.

A schedule of twenty-one dual meets for the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League, organized during the Christmas holidays, was announced today by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics at the University of Pennsylvania, who is secretary and treasurer of the circuit.

Increased appropriations for newspaper advertising by retailers of rugs and carpets would result in substantial gains in sales, Louis A. Silverstein of the Kaufman Department Stores, Pittsburgh, told producers, wholesalers and retailers of rugs who attended the annual goodwill dinner of the industry last night in the Hotel Commodore.

On government orders the police intervened today and prevented "occupation" of a number of large laundries in Paris and its suburbs, where workers had proclaimed stay-in strikes. In a dozen or more laundries the workers were already in possession

With motor and steel shares leading, stocks regained losses and closed higher; turnover, 1,869,400 shares. United States Government bonds lower, domestic corporation issues irregular and foreign loans higher; transactions, $15,298,900.

The latest news on the "Gone With the Wind" casting problem is that Wendy Barrie is being tested for the role of Scarlett O'Hara. Also from the Selznick lot comes word that John Cromwell will direct Ronald Colman in "The Prisoner of Zenda."

Enthusiasm for his studies almost cost Irving Ehrlich of 343 Neptune Avenue, Coney Island, an 18-yearold sophomore at Brooklyn College, his life yesterday when he accidentally touched an X-ray machine during a physics lecture and was knocked unconscious by the 10,000 voltage current of the apparatus.

After leaving a note instructing his wife to avoid an "expensive funeral" for him, George Joel, 62 years old, committed suicide by shooting himself in the chest with a shotgun in the bathroom of his five-room apartment at 706 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, at 10:20 A. M. yesterday.

Miss Mary McCord, a theatre matron who received the city's distinguished service certificate from Mayor La Guardia on Dec. 23 for having prevented a panic among 400 children in a burning motion picture theatre, was employed yesterday as a matron in the Loew theatres.

It is believed that Rexford Guy Tugwell, who recently resigned his government position to accept the post of executive vice president of the American Molasses Company, 120 Wall Street, will make a tour of the company's plants to survey operations and study the process of production and distribution of molasses.

Progressives and Farmer-Laborites in the House joined forces today in a bid for equal recognition with Republicans as a minority party. They proposed a political realignment which leaders hoped would be a powerful factor by the 1940 elections.

The new Federal income tax forms, for the calendar year 1936, were made available to the public yesterday by the two Collectors of Internal Revenue in the city. The individual tax returns were made more imposing by the addition of two more spaces, one of them being the schedule for dividends taxes.

Miss Alice Ansbacher Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cohen of 35 East Eighty-fourth Street, was married yesterday at the Ambassador to Howard M. Sonn, son of Mrs. Samuel Sonn, also of this city, and the late Mr. Sonn, by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Starm.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Bryant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Bryant of this place, to James A. Crane, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Crane of Westfield. Miss Bryant was graduated from Our Lady of the Elms Academy and in 1935 from the College of New Rochelle. Mr. Crane is a graduate of Fordham and Northeastern Universities.

Using part of the income of the new Samuel Hopkins Memorial Fund of $2,400,000, Williams College tonight increased the salaries of twenty members of the instruction staff, and promoted four young faculty members.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company has prepared the third edition of its annual price survey of the municipal bond market. The pamphlet contains the year-end price-yield record of 151 representative issues and affords a comprehensive picture of the upward trend of the last few years.

The average total tax rate for 259 cities in the United States and Canada for 1936 was S35.08, compared with $35.20 for 301 cities reporting in 1935, according to an analysis of comparative tax rates made by Rosina Mohaupt of the Detroit Bureau of Governmental Research, and published in the National Municipal Review.

Mrs. Julius Frostmann will give a luncheon at her home, 22 East Seventy-first Street, today for members of the auxiliary to Strykers Lane Community Center and their friends. Brief addresses on the work of the center and on its significance as a social experiment will be made by the chairman of the auxiliary, Mrs. Walter Gordon

Miss Ethel du Pont, fiancee of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., left today for her Delaware home. Miss du Pont has been in Boston since Christmas Day, when she and Mrs. Roosevelt, the President's wife, came here to be with young Roosevelt after a sinus operation.

David Rumsey of 103 East Eightieth Street, an Assistant Corportion Counsel in the Van Wyck, Low and McClellan administrations, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, Eighty-seventh Street and East End Avenue, after an illness of several weeks. He was 61 years old.

ALEXANDER--On Tuesday, Jan. 5, 1937, J. Harry Alexander, at his residence, Atlantic Beach, L. I., beloved husband of Jennie R. Jones and father of J. Harry, Jr. and Viola Alexander Lindrier. Services at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Thursday, at 1 P. M., Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

Profits of the Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company in the twelve months ended onDec. 31 is estimated at $2,625,700 after operating expenses and development charges, but before depreciation, depletion and Federal taxes.

Franklin O. Nichols of New York City has been appointed by Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator, as resident manager of Harlem River Houses, PWA's low - rent housing project, which will provide 574 living units for low-income families in the Harlem area.

Mrs. Roosevelt explained today her membership in the American Newspaper Guild and denied another published story of an alleged exchange between herself and Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth. It was quite true, the President's wife said at her press conference, that as a columnist she had joined the New York branch of the guild ten days ago.

Additions to the Modern Library in coming months will include Ferdinand Lundberg's "Imperial Hearst," Robert Graves's "I, Claudius," D. H. Lawrence's "Women in Love," Charles Reade's "The Cloister and the Hearth," Franz Werfel's "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh,"

The first annual report of the National Labor Relations Board is a remarkable document. With complete absence of the restraint and sobriety usual on such occasions, the report attacks the American Liberty League and the National Association of Manufacturers for their "floods of expensive

PASSAIC, N. J., Jan. 5.--The 5-cents an hour parking fee in the business section of this city went into effect this afternoon on five short blocks here for a four-month trial. One hundred slot machines, costing $58 each. were put into use.

Paced by Bob Lewis, who tallied nine points, the New York University freshman basketball team defeated the Brooklyn College junior varsity five, 37 to 15, yesterday on the University Heights gymnasium court.

The Borough Council accepted tonight a gift by H. Raymond, Monroe and J. Lester Eisner, brothers, of a three-story frame dwelling and large grounds on the Shrewsbury River to be used as a public library. The Eisner brothers gave the property, which was the home of their parents, the late Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Eisner, as a memorial to their father and mother.

An improvement in the shipping industry in 1937 as a result of the world situation and recently enacted Federal merchant marine legislation was predicted by R. J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, in his annual survey published yesterday.

A building boom is general in the countries of Northern Europe, C. S. Snider, in charge of export sales for the American Hard Rubber Company, told members of the Export AManagers Club of New York, Inc., at the organization's

Mrs. Rachel Baba, head nurse at the Loomis Sanitarium at Liberty, was killed on Route 17 near Monticello late last night when a car in which she was a passenger hit another, plunged down an embankment and overturned. Mrs. Baba was pinned beneath the car and was dead when released. The auto was driven by Amos Champlin, 60, of Loomis, who escaped injury.

The Hos death toll from the Phantoms Club holiday dance fire here a week ago reached six today as Mrs. Richard J. Williams, 27, succumbed to burns. Two other victims remained in a hospital. Mrs. James Rowell reported "holding her own." Mrs.

Detroit whipped in a pair of third-period goals in 44 seconds to nose out the Bruins, 3-2, tonight before 15,000 at the Boston Garden. The victory enabled the Red Wings to continue in a first-place deadlock with the Rangers in the American division of the National Hockey League.
Complaints against thirty-five food merchants charged with maintraining open markets on upper Broadway were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Smith in West Side court.

The Benedicts' Ball was given tonight in the Adam Period Ballroom of the Ritz Carlton Hotel and attended by 500 guests from here, New York, Boston and Baltimore. The patronesses were Mrs. John Hampton Barnes, Mrs. Livingston L. Biddle, Mrs. Robert Kelso Cas??att, Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall. They received in the rotunda.

Plans for new dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens and alter- of nations to several buildings in Manhattan featured the building plans filed yesterday. The Bronx plans included one for a $200,000 apartment house. The list of filings follows:

Four fires in Brooklyn early yesterday morning caused injuries to fifteen firemen and four other persons. In one blaze three women, whose ages ranged from 75 and 80 years, were rescued. Damage from the fires was reported as slight, but ten of the fifteen firemen hurt at one fire remained in the hospital, some being seriously injured.

The retail group was the only trade classification to show a rise in failures for the five-day week ended Dec. 31, according to Dun Bradstreet. The retail defaults rose 19 to a total of 111. The manufacturer division showed a decline of 2, wholesale 1, construction 3 and commercial service 2.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Balking, equaling the world and track record set last year by another Vanderbilt youngster, Airflame, won the $1,000 added three-furlong event for 2year-old fillies at Santa Anita today in 33 seconds flat.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Robert F. Shelare was admitted to Seligsberg Co. on last Saturday. Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., has notified the Exchange of the resignation of Eliot Bailen and Francis McTiernan as directors and the appointment to the board of R. Martinez Varras to succeed Mr. Bailen.

ALLEN, BERNARD (Dec. 14). Estate, $744. To Bernard Allen Jr., son, executor, 446 W. 57th St., residue. HINCK, CATHERINE (Dec. 19). Estate, more than $20,000. To Ollie Sievers, Arthur, Ill., $3,000; Lena Russell, sister, Tuscola, Ill., personal effects and one-half residue; Herman, Korte, half-brother, Tuscola, Ill., one-third residue; Le E. Vermillion. Villa Grove, Ill.;

A four-story factory building at 804 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Twenty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was sold for Russell T. Starr by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., to Harry Slotkin, ship chandler and wholesale grocer who will alter the property for his own occupancy.
Although Madrid passed a quiet day, because of fog, which any Rebel aerial attack, heavy fighting continued in the Escorial road sector near Las Rozas, northwest of the city.

Democrats not only filled every seat on their side of the aisle as the Seventy-fifth Congress met for the first time today but they overflowed the other side until little knots of Republicans stood out noticeably.

A substantial increase in influenza cases was reported yesterday by the Department of Health for the twenty-four-hour period ending at 10 A. M. There were 271 cases and 11 deaths as compared with 302 cases and 6 deaths for the preceding forty-eight hours over the weekend.

Except for a momentary reaction on the Stock Exchange, the Interstate Commerce Commission's refusal on Dec. 19 to extend into 1937 the expiring "emergency railway rates" established April, 1935, has created no great commotion. Chairman JONES of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation
Animosity between West Virginia's two Democratic Senators flared up on the floor of the Senate today when Rush Holt, youthful "rebel," failed to escort his colleague, M. M. Neely, to the rostrum.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having had some experience in Federal court proceedings in connection with corporate reorganizations, I must take slight issue with Congressman Celler in whose letter to THE TIMES an appeal is made for higher salaries for Federal judges.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to good and price trends generally upward on most traefa meats. The kosher beef and veal markets opened firm, calf and lamb steady.

William Delano Russell, retired vice president of the International Paper Company, died at his home here last night at the age of 85. He was one of the founders of the International Paper Company, of which he was vice president from 1911 until his retirement in 1922.

Expenditures of $41,094,000 this year, including a carry-over from last year, were approved yesterday by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway's directors. The budget provides $20,000,000 for purchase of equipment. About $2,195,000 will

Indicating increased use of bank funds, loans and discounts of fifty-four Chicago national and State banks rose to the highest level in four years during the last quarter of 1936. This was disclosed today by a compilation of reports made public by the banks.

National and international radio hook-ups are scheduled to carry President Roosevelt's address to Congress today on the state of the nation. Mr. Roosevelt, speaking in the House of Representatives, is expected to begin his message soon after 1:45 P. M., Eastern standard time. He will be heard locally over WABC, WEAF, WJZ, WOR, WMCA and WEN.
P. P. Steintorf, United States Trade Commissioner in Tokyo, reported today to the Department of Commerce that Japan had greatly increased the number of spindles in cotton mills in recent months.

A brisk demand for commercial space was indicated as reports on leasing for the new year came in from brokers yesterday. Garment center renting was particularly active and clothing manufacturers and firms dealing in specialties associated with the clothing business were prominent among the lessees.
The Joe Humphreys memorial beefsteak dinner, scheduled for Madison Square Garden Jan. 18, gives every indication of developing into an unusually large gathering.

A project to send the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on a transcontinental tour next Spring, with Arturo Toscanini as conductor, has fallen through because the Italian maestro had previous engagements. it became known yesterday.

Liberal receipts of hogs met only a fair demand today, and while early prices were steady to 10 cents lower, the late trade declined 10 to 20 cents. An early top of $10.60 a hundredweight, or 5 cents under Monday's best price, was paid early, but it was hard to beat $10.40 at the close.

A gift of $6,000 to the United Hospital Fund campaign from the Bank of the Manhattan Company and a donation of $5,000 from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company were announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.

A hearing was held before the Public Contracts Board today on the question of continuing for three months an order giving the cotton textile industry permission to retain in its employ girls of 16 and 17.

A terrific right hand punch in the final round helped Phil Furr, 146 1/4, Washington welterweight, to earn draw with Eddie Carroll, 148, clever Canadian, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Alan Schaff of Bronxville, N. Y. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Alan Schaff, to Edward Austin Byrne, son of Mrs. Vincent Byrne of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Byrne.

The holders of Chinese Republic 5 per cent bonds of 1925 have been notified that under the terms of! the amortization plan 50,482 of the bonds have been drawn for redemption on Jan. 15 at their face value of $50 each.

William Crum, 29 years old, who spent six months in the Sing Sing death house and was the first condemned prisoner to emerge from there alive in 1937, was taken today for a new trial in Orange County.

Foreign copper prices broke sharply yesterday. Sales were made as low as 11.80 cents a pound, c.i.f. European base ports, but most of the trading was around 11.85 cents. Early sales were made at 12.05 cents a pound, unchanged from the previous day.

The body of Archduke Frederick, the former commander-in-chief of the AustroHungarian imperial forces during the World War and head of the Hungarian branch of the Hapsburgs, was laid to rest today in the family vault at Magyarovar, on one of the Archduke's many vast estates.

Feeling, doubtless, that their position as world champions demands something more imposing than the conservative training routine they so strictly have adhered to in recent years, the Yankees this Spring will take a turn at one of the most arduous and extensive campaigns they have undertaken in many seasons.
Germany was told today by an official decree and by a newspaper editorial to stop building up a taste for butter and to use street cars in preference to buses.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook completed yesterday his examination of the 300 talesmen who had been summoned to appear before him to provide the panel from which will be drawn the blue ribbon jury that will try the defendants in the alleged $2,000,000-a-year restaurant shakedown racket.

Assessment of damages against the Eastman Kodak Company in a patent infringement suit will not be undertaken until determination of an appeal, attorneys said today. Newton M. Perkins, chief patent attorney of the Kodak Company, said such action was highly probable. The company has thirty days from Dec. 29, date of the decision, in which to file an appeal.

The ancient Delaware Indians called Pennsylvania's old Pymatuning Swamp "Crooked-mouthed man's dwelling place." But Leo Luttringer of that State's game commission says that the new Pymatuning Lake is one of the favorite play spots of the Commonwealth and is destined to attract sportsmen and vacationists from all parts of the country.

Under surveillance by the police since last Aug 10 at the suggestion of the German Vice- Consul, Otto August Ritter, 42 years old, a German who came to this country in April, 1936, was arrested last night in his sumptuously furnished apartment overlooking the East River at 434 East Fifty-second Street on a charge of grand larceny for having given an acquaintance a worthless check for $800.

At the closed session of the Royal Commission of Inquiry yesterday Lieut. Gen. J. G. Dill, commanding the British forces in Palestine, submitted the plan for maintaining public security in the country in the event of further disturbances.

President Anastasio Somoza was injured yesterday when he fell between two boats when going ashore after a ride on Lake Nicaragua, near Managua, where delegates who attended his inauguration were being entertained.

LIEUTENANTS-Emil Jahelka, from 42d Precinct to 3d Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform. Joseph Rosenstock, from 7th Division to 42d Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Bernard Gabriel, pianist, will discuss and illustrate the piano music of the modern French composers tonight at the Sherman Square Studios. The operetta "Chonita" will be presented tonight and tomorrow night at the Educational Alliance.

Two former vice presidents of the defunct Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, which was the largest concern of its kind in the country before it collapsed in 1933, were sentenced to one-year penitentiary terms yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions.

A 16-foot skiff identified as one rented to Leslie Slocum, Plainfield (N. J.) insurance man fast Friday, was found awash in breakers near Slater Path late today, but no trace of the missing man was found. Slater Path is a lonely fishing village on Bogue Island about eight miles west of Beaufort Inlet.

Former United States Senator George Wharton Pepper and Mrs. Pepper of Devon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Adeline Pepper Paul, to Fitz-Eugene Dixon Newbold of Fox Creek Farm, Devon. The wedding will take place soon.
In a final report to the Clerk of the House, the Republican National Committee disclosed today that it spent $8,065 in the 1936 campaign. Contributions totaled $7,693,855.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was almost double those of the preceding week, the total was well belowv the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The Lantana Handicap for 3-yearolds provided the tightest finish of the Tropical Park meeting today. After long deliberation the official numbers flashed, showing I. J. Collins's Bernard F. the winner.

There was a halt at 5 P. M. yesterday in the loading of airplanes aboard the steamer Mar Cantabrico for shipment to Spain. Reports last night at Pier 35, at the foot of Coffey Street, Brooklyn, where the vessel is tied up, were that the halt, after two airplanes had been placed in the hold, was the result of a message from Washington.

A law enacted by the Legislature in 1934 providing for imprisonment of persons convicted as "gangsters" was upheld by the State Supreme Court today in an opinion rejecting the appeal of James Jackson Bell, Arthur J. Gaynor and Frank Foy.

Retired Lieutenant John J. Hynes, formerly assigned to Engine 159, residing at 125-05 Hillside Ave., Queens, died Jan. 4. Fine Imposed Fireman 1st grade James J. Farrell, H. L. 33. Fined $5 for loss of coat badge 1698.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $241,429,251 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Jan. 1 was $44.02,

The hardy fisherfolk of this spray-swept island outpost put aside their nets today to observe Christmas. The people of Rodanthe celebrate the coming of Santa Claus just about like it is celebrated the world over, but they wait until Jan. 5.

Brooklyn planned a total of 1.422 more new buildings last year than in 1935, but the estimated cost of the new structures was less in 1936, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Edwin H. Thatcher, Brooklyn Building Commissioner.

Notre Dame completely outclassed the University of Kentucky tonight to win a one-sided basketball game, 41 to 28, before 10,000 fans. Grabbing an early lead Notre Dame was ahead, 28 to 9, at the half.

Announcement of the sale of the Cape Cod Ship Building Corporation to a group prominently identified with yachting activities was made yesterday by Harvey L. Williams, who has been elected president of the company to represent the new owners.

The medical panel that Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, has substituted for the WPA medical section in the treatment of injured relief workers began functioning yesterday.
Senator George W. Norris, father of the unicameral Legislature, attended today the starting of the nation's only law-making Assembly of that kind.

There was little change in the character and underlying price trends of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government obligations continued to drift to lower levels on a slightly heavier turnover and South American dollar bonds extended their recent gains.

Peter A. Mortensen, 67, superintendent of the Chicago Public Schools from 1918 to 1924, was found dead today in his gas-filled apartment. The police said it was evident that he had ended his own life.

Secretary Swanson of the navy, who has been in uncertain health for some months, became ill tonight at the White House, where he had gone to attend the Cabinet dinner. He was taken to his home. Physicians said his condition was not serious.

Temple Management Corporation of New York sold to the Ormond Realty Corporation the five-story apartment at 85-91 Van Reypen Street, Jersey City. The parcel, which was acquired from the Leland Holding Company several months ago, is valued for taxation

Robert W. Hathaway, former resident of East Orange, N. J., and now Seigneur of the feudal island of Sark in the English Channel, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, accompanied by his wife, La Dame de Serk et Dependences.
Dr. Joseph M. Baldwin of Woodbridge died here this afternoon in Muhlenberg Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 27. He was born in Simsbury, Conn., a son of William and Sarah Baldwin.

The Maryland Legislature at this Winter's biennial session will investigate conditions at the University of Maryland at College Park pertaining to an official report that athletes imported for the football team figure prominently in lists of non-residents given free education.

Voters of 122 municipalities in twenty-seven States approved in December municipal bond issues aggregating $9,420,867, compared with $109,770,355 bonds approved in November, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
Employes and General Motors officials here declared today that there were no present indications of a strike in the Fisher Body and Chevrolet factories in this village.

The International Tin Committee today ratified an agreement extending control and restriction on tin production for five years from Jan. 1. Production quotas for the first quarter of 1937 were fixed at 100 per cent of basic tonnages, in contrast with 105 per cent for the last quarter of 1936.

Legislation will be introduced at the coming session of Parliament to protect debtors under Canadian law from having to pay premiums because of gold clauses in bonds, C. A. Dunning, Finance Minister, stated tonight.

Although Republican Senators attending a legislative conference here today said no decision had been reached as to the seating of William C. Hunt of Cape May County, it was indicated he was being counted on to give the party a majority at the 1937 session.

Mrs. Homer L. Loomis gave a luncheon followed by bridge yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's. Among her guests were Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin, Mrs. Henry Bergh, Mrs. Skinker Matthews, Mrs. Duane Armstrong, Mrs. James Hope Caldwell, Princess Vladimir Koudacheff, Mrs. Victor Harris, Mrs. Woodin Miner, Mrs. Noah MacDowell,

Walter Hoving, chairman of the board of Lord Taylor, announced yesterday the appointment of the following as merchandise managers for these respective lines: Felix McGowan, yard goods and yard goods accessories; Mrs. Anne Roberts, fashion accessories; M. L. Rivard, smallwares;

John Barbirolli will conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the last time of the current season on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. On that occasion, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, duo-pianists, will appear as guest soloists.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,121,400 barrels, compared to 3,133,250 in the preceding week, a decrease of 11,850, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

M. W. Baumgartner, at 8 Hillburn Road, Scarsdale, from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Co.; Raymond R. Beatty Organization, broker. Nathan Sacks, at 1,039 Beach 9th St., from Title Guarantee Trust Co.; Horace Rapport, at 1,320 Central Av., from J. Elliot Crawford; Louis Rosen,

In the supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 254--Homer S. Cummings, attorney general, , et al., petrs., v. Deutsche Bank und Disconto-Gesellschaft. Argument continued and concluded for petrs.; continued for respondent; leave granted respondent to file additional brief within one week.

John W. Thompson, who came to Trenton twenty-five years ago as a War Department engineer to direct a Delaware River channel-digging project, died today at his home, 24 Fischer Place, after a brief illness. His age was 59.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP).--The Armenian colony here tonight mourned the death of Kerekin Manoukian, a national hero of Armenia's revolutionary struggle against Turkey. He was 68 years old.

Franco-British general staff talks to prepare the defenses of the two nations against a European war probably will follow the conference between the countries' War Ministers, a source close to the Defense Ministry said tonight.

Herman A. Brand, a lawyer, specializing in real estate matters, with offices at 525 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday in his apartment in the Bretton Hall Hotel, Eightysixth Street and Broadway, after a month's illness of heart disease, at the age of 55.
These orders were issued in Corps Area: 1st Lieut. Alexander Friedman, 534 27th St., Union City, N. J., sion, is ordered to active duty of six months, effective Jan. 4.

Mrs. Charles de Rham will give a dinner tomorrow at her home, 78 East Seventy-third Street, for her sister, Baroness Terrage de Villiers of Paris. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Schermerhorn Stearns are leaving Jan. 13 for Charleston, S. C., where they will pass the rest of the Winter.
The Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants here, closed by a strike since Nov. 18, presented a scene similar to a small army camp today with pickets' tent-huts lining the property.

The seventieth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will open with a private view this evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, and to the public tomorrow. The pictures will remain through Jan. 21.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa sailed last night for the Channel ports with 753 passengers, of whom 245 were in the cabin class. Among them was Joseph E. Davies, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Russia, accompanied by Mrs. Davies and Miss Emlen K. Davies.

Directors of Best Co. declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to a dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock. Both dividends are payable on Jan. 21 to holders of record of Jan 15.

Showing no mercy to their stricken neighbors, the New York Rangers piled into the Americans with abandon at Madison Square Garden last night and buried Red Dutton's skaters under an avalanche of goals. The Patrick men showed no civic tenderness whatever in slamming the highest number of points of the National Hockey League season into their rivals' nets to register a 7-1 triumph.

The great armament race in which almost every country in the world has been forced to join has already more than tripled the world's armament expenditures, compared with the last year before the "war to end war," according to a survey by the German Business Research Institute issued today.
Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, editor and vice president of Doubleday-Doran, publishers, sailed yesterday for England on the Manhattan of the United States Lines, accompanied by Mrs. Roosevelt.
The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, founder of the Presbyterian Church of America, was buried today in Green Mount Cemetery, Baltimore, after services in Spruce Street Baptist Church, this city.

Calendar reform had fresh endorsement in 1936, notably by the States of the Americas through their delegations at the labor conference at Santiago in Chile, where by unanimous resolution the approval of the perpetual calendar of twelve months of equal quarters was voted.

Dr. and Mrs. Gustave M. Meyer of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Meyer, to Jacques de Mattos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph de Mattos of Woodside. Mr. de Mattos is with the brokerage firm of Baar, Cohen Co. in New York. The wedding will take place in the early Summer.

This being a year for Shakespeare--already two Hamlets are in the records-Walter Huston will appear at the New Amsterdam tonight in the title role of "Othello." Costarred with him is Brian Aherne, as Iago, and Nan Sunderland is Desdemona.

DEPUTY TAX COMMISSIONER- (a) railroads: (b) telephones: (c) general utillties (will include combustion equipment); (d) electric utilities; (e) gas utilities; (f) utility structures. Separate lists will be established for each of the above specialized groups. Candidates may make application for more than one of these fields. Salarv-S4.000 per annum; pension; fair

Dr. Walter J. Mullin, Professor of Physics at Fordham University, died of pneumonia yesterday after a brief illness at the Webb Sanitarium, the Bronx. Dr. Mullin, who resided at 211 Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx, was one of the youngest professors at Fordham. His age was 35.

The Marchioness of Aberdeen, wife of the second Marquess, died of pleurisy today at the family seat, Haddo House, Aberdeenshire, at the age of 79. She was twenty-two years older than her husband, who was at Oxford simultaneously with her son by a former marriage to E. S.

A considerable amount of "dressing up and refurbishing" of homes and buildings in New York City will have to be undertaken within the next two years to prepare for the New York World's Fair, it was said yesterday by Thomas S. Holden, chairman of the construction industries group which has undertaken the sale of fair debentures.

Joseph Lewis, president of the Freethinkers of America and secretary of the Thomas Paine Bicentennial Committee, sailed yesterday on the French liner Champlain with a bust of Thomas Paine executed by Gutzon Borglum, which will be presented to the French Government.
At the end of the first half of the 1937 fiscal year on Dec. 31, the Federal Government had a deficit of $1,394,523,665 and a public debt of $34,406,920,961, the Treasury announced today.

Members of the Stock Exchange were gratified yesterday to learn there was a possibility the Federal Reserve Board might delegate to the securities exchanges the duty of adopting and administering new rules designed to prevent margin traders from taking three-day "free rides." It was feared the proposed

Cliff Olsen, Minneapolis heavyweight, last night threw Eli Fischer of Brooklyn in 26 minutes 41 seconds of the feature on the wrestling card at the St. Nicholas Palace. Olsen, who weighed 215 pounds, pinned his rival with a body slam and arm hold.

A Yonkers ordinance aimed at stopping the appearance on city streets of persons inadequately clothed. especially women clad in halter-top costumes and shorts, was upheld today in a decision by County Judge Gerald Nolan.

Richard L. Dineley of San Francisco, who obtained licenses today for the shipment of munitions to Spain, told reporters his contract calls for the delivery of goods worth about $9,000,000. In addition to the war materials for which he obtained a license, he said, it calls for gas masks and other items not covered by the Licensing Law.

Stunned in the first by a right to the jaw, Wildcat O'Connor of Carbondale, Pa., came back to gain a ten-round decision over Irish Tommy Bland of Toronto at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 3,800 watched the show.

The Toronto varsity hockey team swamped Dartmouth, 10-1, tonight in a game played before 2,200 students. It was Dartmouth's first game in the newly formed International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League.

The Vatican has taken measures usually adopted only when all hope for a Pope's life has been abandoned. The Cardinals who head the three orders into which the Sacred College is divided have been asked not to absent themselves from Rome.

Following a successful campaign last year in which he was in the money in fourteen of his twenty-nine starts, Clyde Troutt's Golden Quest started his 1937 season successfully today by winning the mile and an eighth race for claimers at the Fair Grounds.

The new Commissariat for Defense Industries, created under the new Soviet Constitution, has already launched an ambitious program to speed up armament production. It is determined to overfulfill all production schedules.

A demand for an early meeting of the Tammany Hall executive committee to discuss the future leadership and policies of Tammany Hall was made yesterday by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, in a letter sent to all district leaders.

Net sales by 1,046 establishments producing alcoholic beverages totaled $777,928,000 in 1935, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was the first full year of operation covered by the Census Bureau since repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Following their purchase of the northeast corner of Broadway and 172d Street from the SpinglerVan Beuren Estates, William and Charles Lipman, trading as Lipman Associates, have bought an adjoining plot 50 by 94.6 feet from Joseph S. Ward.

Mrs. Francis Holhan of 950 Park Avenue has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Cartwright Hooker, the former Miss Winifred Cartwright Holhan, to Dimitri Sergius von Mohrenschildt. The wedding will take place on the afternoon of Jan. 19 at the home of Mrs. Holhan.

The thirty-six steeplechase horses purchased In France and which are to be allotted to subscribers to the fund next Sunday were safely stabled at Belmont Park yesterday in the care of John Hastings, who will have charge of them until they pass into the hands of their new owners.

Emmet Crozier and Bruno Klerings triumphed in national Class C 18.2-balkline billiard matches at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Crozier defeated K. Ohashi, 150 to 72, in twenty-seven innings, while Klerings disposed of Hugo Doob, 150 to 63, in thirty-two frames. High runs were:

Travis Calvin Jackson, for nearly fifteen years star shortstop of the Giants and at the close of the 1936 season field captain of the National League pennant winners, yesterday took his first official step into a managerial career.
Both the Long Island University and Manhattan College quintets triumphed in the New York Hippodrome program last night before a crowd of 2,000, but neither managed to add greatly to its prestige.

With Gertrud Wettergren, Swedish contralto, and Rene Maison, Belgian tenor, in the title roles, the New York Metropolitan Opera Association presented "Samson et Dalila" to an enthusiastic audience in the Academy of Music tonight. The Philadelphia Inquirer said:

The Neediest Cases Fund passed another milestone yesterday as ninety-five contributors added $1,104.50 to the year's total, increasing it to $266,305.48. With the addition of yesterday's gifts the Fund exceeded 1932's final total and now is larger than that of any year since 1931.

With the friendliest intentions in the world a handful of German performers has crossed the ocean and installed a drawing-room entertainment entitled "Pepper Mill" in the aerie of the Chanin Building, where it opened last evening.

Foreign gold in the amount of $4,242,000 was engaged yesterday for United States account. All of the metal was taken in England. Actual receipts of gold were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank as $10,833,400, including $10,070,200 received late on Monday from England but unreported hitherto, together with $763,200 that arrived yesterday from 1 England. In addition, the bank

The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked by receivers of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company today for authority to assume liability for $2,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates proposed to be issued to aid in financing

Compensation in 1935 of the principal executives of Paramount Pictures, Inc., A. I. Namm Son and Mandel Brothers, Inc., was disclosed yesterday in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Finland began today her fourth Presidential campaign. The President will be elected Feb. 15 by the Electoral College of 300. Four candidates have been nominated, former President Kaarle Stahlberg. Progressive; Kyosti Kallio, Farmers party; Vaino Tanner, Socialist, and the present President, Pehr Evind Svinhufvud, nonpartisan. The small Fascist party

A clash between the judge of the Security Tribunal and a defense witness, General Manoel Rabello, marked the second day of the trial of Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, accused of abetting the Leftist revolt in November, 1935.

The United States Circuit Court heard argument yesterday and reserved decision on appeals filed by William F. Warms, acting master of the Ward liner Morro Castle, and Eben S. Abbott, chief engineer, both convicted of criminal negligence which caused the loss of 134 lives when that vessel burned off Asbury Park on Sept. 8, 1934.

An underwriting group of sixtytwo investment houses, headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., the First Boston Corporation and Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will offer today 547,788 shares of Consumers Power Company $4.50 dividend preferred stock at a price of $100.50 a share.

By a unanimous decision on Monday the Supreme Court of the United States forbade the removal of one of the ancient landmarks of our liberty. It is the right of American citizens freely to meet and to discuss public affairs and to seek the redress of grievances.
Parliament unanimously accepted today the terms of the French loan to Poland. It simultaneously voted that four-fifths of the loan be spent for armaments, in addition to the regular army budget.
Governor William Langer proclaimed tonight a moratorium prohibiting real and personal property mortgage foreclosure sales and execution sales of livestock and other personal property in North Dakota.
After early dullness induced by the foreign political outlook, the stock market here today tended to recover toward the close of the session.

The German Government announced today that the admiral commanding the Reich naval forces in Spanish waters had sent the following ultimatum to "the Red powers in Valencia" by radio from the cruiser Koenigsberg:

William A. Brady and Brady Enterprises, Inc., of New York City, filed exceptions in Federal District Court today to the recommendations of the special master that the Baldwin Locomotive Works plan of reorganization be approved.

For the first time in the history of the London Salon of Photography, the 206 pictures comprising the British section of this outstanding annual exhibition have been lent for showing in this country. Photographic enthusiasts of America thus will have an opportunity to see some of the outstanding work of British photographers.

It long has been the contention of the motor car industry that because of the huge volume of raw materials it draws from every State in the Union it rightfully can claim to be the nation's number one industry.

Among the eight properties figuring in Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday was the eleven-story building at 132-38 Lafayette Street, occupying a plot 100.5 by 87.3 feet. The plaintiff, who was awarded the property on a bid of $150,000, was the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, and the defendant, the Lafayette Holding Corporation.

A campaign for $1,200,000 to finance new buildings and modernized facilities for White Plains Hospital was started tonight at a dinner of 125 members of the hospital board of governors and medical staff and the White Plains Clinical Society in the Westchester Country Club here.
There are 1,525 petitions for divorce down for a hearing in the London court term starting next Monday. A large percentage of them, however, will be delayed until the end of this year.

Arrested without a fight in a restaurant in Williamsport, Pa., before noon yesterday, Isidor Lipschitz and Michael Prochorchick, two of the gang charged with holding up Barney's Clothes, Inc., a shop at Seventh Avenue and Seventeenth Street, last Saturday, were brought

A vacant plot 100 by 100 feet at the corner of Forty-eighth Avenue and 196th Street. Flushing, was purchased from Alex Heller by the Clancy Homes Corporation which will build two homes sold from plans there. Two weeks ago.

Lexington Avenue and the midForties for a few hours yesterday looked like yachting waterways and canals instead of city streets, when the first of the craft to be exhibited at the National Motor Boat Show began to enter Grand Central Palace.

Automobile strikes threw additional Youngstown district workers out of employment today when Republic Steel Corporation dropped another open-hearth furnace from the active list, as a result of reduced steel demand.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent and the Bank of New York and Trust Company registrar for the no-par capital stock of the Snider Packing Corporation. Joseph Byrne is with Mackay Co. Herman H. Lind has been made executive vice president of the American Institute of Bolt, Nut and Rivet Manufacturers.

After Beulah Gibson, 19-year-old Negro maid, had testified that the only way she knew to "quit her job" was to write a note threatening to kidnap Leonora Taormina, 5-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Taormina of 81-10 Penelope Avenue, Rego Park, Queens,

Belief that between 90 and 95 per cent of 2,200 men employed in the Fisher Body plant here would fail to respond to a strike call was expressed tonight by George Tierney, spokesman for the Employes Association of the Fisher Body plant, St. Louis division, and for the plant's collective bargaining agency.

Mrs. William E. Howley of Yonkers, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eunice Howley, to Lieutenant John J. Phelan, son of Major Gen. John J. Phelan of this city and the late Mrs. Phelan. Miss Howley, who is the daughter of the late Dr. William E. Howley, was graduated from the College of the Sacred Heart, Manhattanville. Lieutenant Phelan, whose father is chairman of the State Athletic

Approval was given today by the Federal Trade Commission to the New Mexico Utilities Company's application for authorization to sell all of its facilities to the Texas Utilities Company. Properties of the two companies are interconnected and were found by the commission to be susceptible of operation as a single system without impairing service.

Charles Weill, Inc., announces that the following stores have been added to their list of accounts: Korricks Dry Goods Company, Phoenix, Ariz.; Gold Co., Lincoln, Neb.; Pelletier Stores Company, Topeka, Kan.; C. C. Anderson, Boise, Idaho, and Davidson Brothers, Sioux City, Iowa.

Another Protestant pastor has been arrested. This time the arrest was made at Luebeck in connection with action of the German Christian Protestant Bishop of that district. The Bishop expelled from their pulpits all Confessional Synod pastors under his jurisdiction, apparently on charges of disobedience. One of these pastors was

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave their annual dinner tonight in honor of the members of the Cabinet and their wives. Eighty-two guests were invited to the dinner, and more than 200 additional guests joined them afterward for the entertainment given in the East Room by Miss Alice Wynne, dancer; Miss Juliet,
