The status of the American woolmanufacturing industries is not only far more favorable today than at any time during the depression, but it is also greatly improved over either 1928 or 1929, according to The Index of the Guaranty Trust

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Republican members of the Assembly failed to agree on a choice for the Speakership at a meeting tonight after two revolts against the re-election of Irving M. Ives had broken out during the day and at midnight were forced to leave the question open until 10 A. M. tomorrow.

Mrs Wallis Warfield Simpson, from her villa, gave the following statement today regarding a serial story that has been appearing in the ParisSoir, in which she denies any cooperation with the author, Newbold Noyes:

The Federal Reserve Board is considering a plan by which the New York Stock Exchange and other securities markets would be permitted to adopt and administer the additional margin requirements announced on Nov. 19, last, by the board as proposed amendments to its Regulation T.

An echo of an Atlantic Ocean tragedy in August, 1933, was heard today with the discovery on the south shore of Bermuda of a sealed bottle containing a message thrown overboard from a lifeboat bearing survivors of the schooner Augustus G. Hilton which sank after a fire.
William Walter Henry Mustaine, supervisor in the Health and Physical Education Division of the State Education Department, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 58.

Trailing far behind Australia m the third cricket test match, England started its second innings today and had compiled 98 runs for the fall of two wickets at the tea hour. The Antipodeans, paced by Captain Don Bradman's 270, completed their second innings just before lunch with a score of 564. England,
Lumber production increased 20 per cent last year, according to a report of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, which placed the 1936 output at about 23,000,000,000

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 31: Taffinder, Capt. H.A. Hydrographic Office, to Navai Operations, Washington, D.C. Ayrault, Lt. Comdr. A.D., to duty as aide to Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations.

Luis Araquistatn, the Spanish Ambassador, said today that the Loyalists have begun to produce their own munitions and airplanes and could win the war "on our own" if foreign assistance to both sides were curtailed.

Stanton St., 14, 25x100; Patrick H. Sullivan, referee. to Central Savings Bank (foreclosure) ($2). Columbia St., 134. 24x100; Samuel Krakower to Loupry Realty Corp., 135 William St.: mortgage. S27,750; (50 cents).

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia leaves tonight on her annual cruise around the world with 375 passengers, fifty more than she had starting from New York a year ago. Her passenger list includes Dr. Victor Heiser, A. A. Hutchinson, Mr. and Mrs. Max Epstein, E. R. Behrend, Sir Llewelyn and Lady Anderson, Mrs. Frank L. Greenewalt, Countess von

The expenditure of $23,453,000 for flood control and other projects in New York State during the fiscal year beginning July 1 was recommended today by Brig. Gen. E. M. Markham, chief of army engineers.

A 17-year-old girl, Louise MacLean, went to law today to fight for legal recognition as chieftainess of a Highland clan, that of MacLean of Ardgour. If an Edinburgh court upholds her claim against that of a cousin, Lieut. Commander H. H. MacLean, it is believed she will be the first woman to be head of a Scottish clan.
Back on its home court after an absence of nearly three weeks, Columbia's basketball team turned back Union College, 51-21, last night.
For the first time in many years Democrats will be admitted to membership in the Union League Club, if the members adopt a resolution to be introduced at the next regular monthly meeting on Jan. 14.

Before a Legislature controlled in Senate and House by Democrats for the first time in more than ninety years, Governor Earle presented in person tonight a broadly liberal message urging many of the social security bills which failed at the 1935 session, and other sweeping reforms.
George F. Hall of 26 Third Street, retired inventor, who assisted Thomas A. Edison in his work at Menlo Park about thirty years ago, died last night from a heart attack. He was 86 years old.

Brown maintained its undefeated hockey record by defeating Northeastern, 5 to 4, tonight. The Bruins' 3-0 lead in the first period was cut by the individual brilliance of Captain Bialek of the visitors. Two Brown markers were made, with Northeastern shorthanded.

The Board of Elections was served yesterday with summons and complaint in an action seeking to void proportional representation as unconstitutional, and to enjoin the board from spending funds to carry out the new system of voting.

Formation of a committee to act for holders of common stock of the Pittsburgh United Corporation in connection with the proposed retirement of its preferred stock was announced today by Elmer Whitehill, secretary to the committee.

Inca farmers of South America faced centuries ago the same soilerosion problems that today have turned millions of American acres into barren land, according to Charles Collier, special assistant to the director of the United States Soil Conservation Service.

Encouraged by the weather report that snow is in the air, hundreds of skiers in the metropolitan district are preparing to visit the Poconos, Catskills, Adirondacks and Green and White Mountain areas this week-end. Reservations for the many "snow trains" due to leave Friday, Saturday and Sunday, provided, of course, that the weather forecast is correct, are pouring into railroad bureaus.

Foreign dollar bonds declined 0.12 per cent in December, according to Foreign Bond Associates, Inc., its index of fifty representative issues being recorded at 57.89 per cent on Dec. 31, compared to 57.96 per cent on Nov. 30. The sixteen South American issues in the index rose 8.60 per cent, while the thirty European issues fell 4.28 per cent.

An agreement to refund the Mexican Government's $275,000,000 foreign debt on the basis of a peso for each dollar was declared by an authoritative source tonight to be before President Lazaro Cardenas for approval.
The cynic said that one place where a person could always find justice is the dictionary. So a look around the world today suggests that one

Brother Andre, the "miracle man of Montreal," died early today. The chronic allment that had kept the 91-year-old man in almost continual pain since childhood took him at 12:50 A. M. while priests and sisters chanted prayers at his bedside.

Six striking seamen who live in California, but have directed their activities in the strike to the New Jersey waterfront, were held for hearing before a grand jury yesterday morning in Hoboken on charges growing out of an assault last Friday on a longshoreman.

Crawford Burton, gentleman steeplechase rider and member of the New York Stock Exchange, who says he was held up to public ridicule in 1934 when Collier's Weekly and The American Magazine published offensive photographs of him, testified yesterday in Federal court in his $75,000 damage suit against the Crowell Pubfishing Company.
Two Senators, Guy V. Howard, Republican of Minnesota, and Willlam Hill, Democrat of Florida, heard their credentials read today, although neither will ever take his seat.
President Roosevelt expects to announce on Friday his decision as to whether the United States shall begin the construction of one or two new battleships, he stated at a press conference today.

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, former world champion, today defeated Reuben Fine of New York and gained the point he needed to wrest first place from the young American player in the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club.

To the accompaniment of loud crowing and cackling, the New York Poultry Show opened yesterday morning in the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, Fourteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. More than 5,000 birds, the largest number ever exhibitedchickens, bantams, ducks, geese, swans, turkeys, pheasants, doves, pigeons-all contributed to the din that made the noise of the traffic outside the armory sound restful.

Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman" will be revived tomorrow afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance will be for the benefit of the Florence Crittenton League and will mark the first appearance of Charles Kullmann in a German role at the Metropolitan.

With a legislative investigation into their motives threatening them, members of the Board of Regents bent upon ending Dr. Glenn Frank's tenure as president of the University of Wisconsin were prepared tonight to turn against him the major point in his defense.

Members of the Junior Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery have arranged their annual dinner dance in behalf of the nursery for Jan. 15 at the Pierre. Proceeds will be used for the kindergarten maintained by the auxiliary at the headquarters, 249 East 117th Street, where care and necessities are provided for the children of needy families and employed mothers.

Indications that Generals Yang Fucheng and Yu-Hsueh-chung will not be punished for their share in the recent Sian revolt were contained in a brief official announcement today that petitions from these worthies requesting that they be punished had been accepted by the Executive Council and that "the two generals have been instructed

A suit for $2,000,000 damages for alleged libel, brought against Nathan S. Jonas, president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, by officers of Hospital Employes Union, Local 171, of the Building Service Employes International Union, was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday when Mr. Jonas

Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran were honored by Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. at a dinner tonight in their home. Guests were Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman, Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Cheek, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Johnson, Mrs. James H. Kennedy, Miss Margaret Crowley, Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow and William Q Cain.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," H. V. Kaltenborn. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The American Wing," General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Tapestries," Margaret B. Freeman, 2 P. M.; "Introduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.

The Louisville Nashville Railroad soon will request bids for 3,000 box cars and other freight cars, according to the magazine Steel. The Chesapeake Ohio has ordered fifty cabooses from the Magor Car Company and fifty stock cars from the Greenville Steel Car Company.
Intervention by Mayor Wilson to bring about a settlement of the "sitdown" strike of 1,800 workers at the Electric Storage Battery Company's two plants here is expected tomorrow.

The old age benefit provision of the Social Security Act was challenged as unconstitutional yesterday in Federal Court. The test, reported to be the first in this city, was filed by Norman C. Norman, wealthy retired jeweler and opponent of the New Deal,
Harry Reeves, 36, who confessed he saw his gang wipe out one of its members with five tons of dynamite, was sentenced today to forty years in prison for robbery sixteen hours after his capture.

In a game that was much more fiercely waged than the final score might indicate, McGill University's hockey team conquered the University of Montreal sextet, 5 to 0, tonight as Playland's fourth annual college hockey series came to an end.

The Seventy-fifth Congress went promptly through the routine business of organizing itself yesterday and is now prepared to receive the message which the President will read to it today. On Friday the budget message, together with the official estimates for the next fiscal year, will be submitted

The hero, as composer and pianist, of the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, was Sergei Rachmaninoff. Two of his compositions made the program.

Fletcher Warren, consul and secretary of the United States Legation in Riga, Latvia, accompanied by Mrs. Warren and their 2-yearold Boston terrier, Big Boy, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. The dog carried a diplomatic passport inscribed with his name, photograph and pedigree to facilitate his passage through foreign frontiers. It is understood that
Compulsory State health insurance was sought in a bill filed in the Massachusetts House today by Dr. Guy M. Gray of Greenfield, one-time Townsend plan candidate for Senator.

The maritime strike was held responsible today by F. H. Rawls, Chief of the Foodstuffs Division of the Department of Commerce, for a decrease of nearly 50 per cent in United States food exports during last November.

Special permits for the holding of fire sales, liquidation sales, bankruptcy sales and others of that type must be obtained from the License Department upon payment of a $25 fee under an ordinance signed by Mayor La Guardia and published yesterday in the City Record.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt of Newark, N. J., was nominated today by the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association for president of the association. No opposition is expected, although, under the rules, nominations may be made from the floor at the association's convention.

Mrs. J. Winston Fowlkes held a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 130 East End Avenue, for members of the patroness committee for the annual Blue Ridge ball to be held Jan. 29 at the Plaza for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Green County, Va. Mrs. Fowlkes is chairman of the executive committee for the benefit.

Cardinal Hayes presented the decoration of a Knight Commander of the Order of St. Gregory with Plaque, one of the highest Papal honors accorded to laymen, to Antonio C. Gonzalez, United States Minister to Ecuador, at the Cardinal's home at 452 Madison Avenue last night.
In the first broadcast ever made by a Japanese Foreign Minister in defense of his policy, Hachiro Arita again explained the German-Japanese pact in an address radioed throughout Japan tonight.
A nine-game 1937 football schedule, with one date yet to be filled, was announced for Catholic University today by Coach Arthur J. Bergman. The schedule:
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 4 unless specified: At San Pedro: Brazos, Bridge, Marblehead. At Pearl Harbor: Lark, Oglala, Quail, Tanager.

At the close of each year it is customary for those who are interested in any sport or group of sports to prophesy that the next year will be better than the year that has just passed. This is because we all indulge in wishful thinking. It is safe to say, however, that 1936 saw the attendance at college games considerably improved over 1935.

The city of Chicago awarded yesterday to a group of Chicago banks a new issue of $11,000,000 of judgment funding bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1936, and maturing Jan. 1, 1956, on a bid of 103.57 for a fixed rate of 3 per cent.

Several large apartments, including two of the duplex type, were among those reported rented yesterday. Manolo Wiechers leased the eleven-room duplex with five baths at River House, 435 East Fifty-second Street, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.,

Average weekly earnings of wage earners in the automobile industry in November, 1936, were about 40 per cent higher than the average for twenty-five manufacturing industries for which figures are regularly compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board.

A yowling horde of 1937-model cats invaded the Hotel Taft yesterday morning for the opening of the thirty-fifth annual two-day show of the Atlantic Cat Club, but before the show was well under way they settled back in their cages, stopped snarling and yawned sleepily.
J. Mortimer Bell, 73 years old, of Salisbury, a lawyer, who will begin his seventh term in the Connecticut House, was nominated tonight for Speaker by the Republican caucus.
The in Seventy -fifth Congress convened and organized today, and then stood by to await the sailing orders of President Roosevelt tomorrow.

The conductor refused to conduct but the band played the Nazi "Horst Wessel Song" anyway tonight at a gala pre-nuptial celebration of the wedding Thursday of the Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld.

General Motors Corporation made public today a list of its plants in the United States, noting those that are affected by the strike situation. While general conditions in the plants were mentioned, the company did not give the number of employes in the individual concerns, standing on its estimate that 135,000 would be affected by the end of the week.

Sit-down strikers abandoned the Chevrolet automobile assembly plant and the Fisher Body Company works tonight under an agreement with company officials that the plants would discontinue opernations until a settlement is reached of a strike closing other General Motors Corporation properties. About 2,500 men were made idle.

Information concerning Federal income and excess profits taxes as well as surtaxes on undistributed profits should be included in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an opinion expressed today by Carman G. Blough, chief accountant of the commission.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, stated today that he had been "reliably informed" that Circuit Court Judge Edward D. Black of Genesee County, who issued the temporary injunction against the sit-down strikers in Flint on Saturday, was the owner of 3,665 shares of General Motors

A total of $2,500,000 was expended by the Jewish Agency for Palestine on immigration, colonization, security and other activities, including the settlement of German Jews, during the year ended Oct. 1, 1936, it was announced yesterday by Louis Lipsky, chairman of the board of the Palestine Foundation Fund, the fund-raising organization in the United States of the Jewish Agency.

A very commendable calm is being shown by the French press in its comment on all the complications that have arisen from the Spanish situation and except among the extreme Communists and the extreme nationalists the determination to adhere to the non-intervention policy laid down by the government last August is still approved.

Confident that the rights of the Spanish Government have been safeguarded in the Mediterranean agreement just completed between Great Britain and Italy, Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, predicted a victory for the Loyalist cause in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Fortyeighth Street.

Former Representative and Mrs. Michael J. Hogan of Rockville Center, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annmarie Bernadette Hogan, to James Francis Watson, son of Mrs. Charles F. Watson of New York and the late Mr. Watson.
A call for condition of national, Federal Reserve member and non-member banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was issued today. The status of those banks as of Dec. 31 was asked.

The presidium of the Central Executive Committee by special decree tonight deprived the scientists Professor Vladimir N. Ipatieff and Dr. Alexis Chichibabin of their citizenship. The decree forbade the scientists ever to return to the Soviet Union.

The rapid growth in the use of radio throughout the world in the past few years was emphasized today in the second annual report of the Federal Communications Commission, submitted to Congress by Anning S. Prall, chairman, and covering the fiscal year ending June 30, 1936.

Richard M. Backus of 2,501 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, died suddenly yesterday afternoon while seated at his desk in the Bronx Savings Bank, 429 East Tremont Avenue, near Park Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 71.
A slight increase in immigration visas in the fiscal year 1936 was reported today by the State Department, with 41,202 visas of both the quota and nonquota types issued, compared with 38,146 in 1935.
News from Washington of the probable reintroduction of the St. Lawrence seaway pact in the new Congress was received with mixed feeling here. It was provided in the pact

YES, Ellsworth Vines was in. He was in tan pajamas and it was close to high noon. Surprise! Casual meetings with the elongated larruper of tennis balls had led to the conclusion that Ellsworth was one of those apple-a-day and up-with-the-lark chaps. The pajama party at midday didn't look the part.

The strike by elementary school pupils here to protest the dismissal of William (Pete) Eckley, popular policeman on duty at the school crossing for the last seven years, was broken today by Eckley himself.
Mrs. Harriette Weems Doud, retired Shakespearean actress, known on the stage by her maiden name of Harriette Weems, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness.

The Brooklyn College basketball team defeated the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, 44 to 28, at the latter's gymnasium last night. The Pharmacists held a 11-10 lead after the first 15 minutes of play, but the Kingsmen registered four goals and five fouls to lead at the half, 23-13. Milt Perkel led the winners with 15 points while Capt. Mike Galante with 8, was top scorer for the losers.

Steel ingot production increased last week but adjustment for seasonal variation caused the index to recede to 123.2 from 125.7, the figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 4, 1936, the index stood at 78.6.

A $50,000 damage suit brought against the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation by an 18-year-old youth, who contended his likeness had been used in a motion-picture film without his consent, was settled out of court for $70, it was revealed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan approved, the settlement.
The Railway Staff Tribunal today rejected the claim of the Locomotive Engineers Union for a six-hour day and a thirty-six hour week.

The world's two leading tennis players will walk out under the calcium at Madison Square Garden around 9 o'clock tonight, and looking down upon them will be the greatest crowd to gather for a tennis match in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--A race between the President and Congress on the one hand and some American dealers and American exporters of arms, munitions and other implements of war, including airplanes and airplane parts, on the other hand, is on tonight.

After passing more than two hours in the death house at Sing Sing talking with the six Brooklyn robbers condemned to die in the electric chair tomorrow night, District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn recommended to Governor Lehman last night that the six men be put to death as scheduled.

The stock market rallied briskly yesterday, and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks rose 1.22 points to more than cancel the combined losses in this index in the three previous trading days of Dec. 31, Jan. 2 and Jan. 4.
Disturbed by reports that 14,000 Germans and 10,000 Italians had been rushed to Spain to aid General Francisco Franco's drive against Madrid, the
Some 2,500 bills went "into the hopper" in the House as Congress began today. No bills were introduced in the Senate, but there were many forecasts of measures from various Senators.

Both the Squash Club and the Downtown A. C. squash racquets teams continued to head their groups in the Class B series of the metropolitan league, following matches last night. The Squash Club, unbeaten thus far, chalked up its fourth triumph by the slim margin of 3-to-2 over the Harvard Club.

The Staten Island Advance printed a separate edition of one copy yesterday so that Municipal Court Justice John C. Boylan, who is seriously ill of pneumonia, would not see a notice of the funeral of his wife, Mrs. Lila Cronin Boylan, who died of pneumonia on Saturday.

Merger of Dorrance, Sullivan Co., Inc., with the Eastern division of Brooke, Smith French, Inc., into a new agency, Brooke, Smith, French Dorrance, Inc., was announced yesterday. Brooke, Smith French, Inc., of Detroit, will continue to serve advertisers throughout the Middle West, with no change in personnel or corporate structure, but with the facilities of the Eastern organization available to clients.

Franklin D. Roosevelt will be elected President of the United States again tomorrow, to begin his second term. The electoral vote will be counted in the House of Representatives between noon and 1 P. M.

A series of tributes to Dr. Melvil Dewey, who founded the Columbia School of Library Service in 1887, marked the school's golden jubilee, celebrated yesterday afternoon in the Harkness Academic Theatre of South Hall, Columbia.

President Roosevelt said he expected to announce Friday his decision regarding new battleship construction; discussed neutrality legislation with Senator Pittman and Representative McReynolds; conferred with Secretary Perkins on the disturbed labor situation and gave, with Mrs. Roosevelt, the annual White House dinner to members of the Cabinet.

Legislation to curb large chain organizations and other stores of large buying capacity from using tobacco products as "loss leaders" was urged by Jack Miller, president of the Independent Retail Tobacconists Association, last night at the annual dinner at the Roger Smith Restaurant.

The family of kidnapped Charles Mattson cleared a path again today for dealings with his abductor and indicated that it was expecting momentarily a development-possibly payment of the $28,000 ransom or release of the 10-year-old boy.

The wedding of Miss Janet Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Powell Davis of 73 Calvin Avenue, to the Rev. John J. Randolph, vicar of St. Peter's Church in Plymouth and St. Mark's Church in Terryville, Conn., took place at Trinity Episcopal Church here this morning. Mr. Randolph is the son of the late Carl and Elizabeth Kemp Randolph of this city.

Thirty-six trappers, dressed in canvas jackets and hipboots and carrying doublebarreled shotguns, set off in motor boats at daybreak this. morning to hunt foxes that have been robbing muskrat traps and killing wildfowl in the marshes along the Delaware River shore ten miles south of here.

Eleven Jamaicans who were deported from Costa Rica told the police on their arrival here today that they had been hurried out of that country after suffering ill treatment because they were charged with practicing voodooism.

Mrs. Arthur Lehman will give a tea tomorrow afternoon at her home, 45 East Sixtieth Street, for the presidents and officers of the organizations which took part in the 1936 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York. Mrs. Lehman was chairman of the Women's Division of the

Mrs. Lottie Blair Parker, actress and playwright, who wrote "Way Down East," one of the greatest successes in the history of the American stage, died here this morning at her residence after an illness of a few days.

The Treasury Department advised Representative D. Lane Powers of Trenton today that the offer of Governor Hoffman of New Jersey to lease the old Trenton Postoffice Building for the State Unemployment Insurance Commission had been accepted. Under the agreement, the State would pay $280 a month rental.

Except during the heat of a national campaign, the American people have become pretty well acquainted with the fact that usually there is nothing more personal between two candidates for office than the wish of each to get it.

Canadian Government, Provincial and municipal financing last year continued the improvement that had taken place in recent years, amounting to $1,065,900,922, compared with $881,383,368 in 1935 and $633,501,978 in 1934, according to figures for 1936 compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

A field goal by Rector in a fiveminute overtime period enabled Trinity School to defeat Poly Prep, 25--23, in an Eastern Private Schools Basketball League contest on the winning team's court yesterday. Captain Bill Hartog featured the Trinity attack with 12 points.

Between in the inaust 800 and 900 sit-down strikers at Fisher Body Plant No. 1 here are armed and prepared for trouble, the city police were told today by a striking employee who, when arrested, had a 16-inch home-made blackjack. The weapon was a length of garden hose filled with metal and then wrapped in heavy tape.

Those of us who have long admired Senator NORRIS'S steady and unselfish devotion to the public interest as he sees it will share in his generous hopes for his unicameral Legislature that began its sessions yesterday. It is his child.

The United States Army transport St. Mihiel, carrying 737 enlisted men, 41 non-commissioned officers and 106 officers and their wives, sailed at noon yesterday from the army base at the foot of Fiftyeighth Street, Brooklyn, for San Francisco via the Panama Canal.

Rich Steers, Inc., and the Standard Dredging Company, which submitted a joint bid on Dec. 3, 1935 for construction of the proposed port terminal on the New York Bay shore, withdrew the bid today and asked the city commission to return its surety bonds, amounting to $1,502,305. The board deferred action on the request.
James Francis McCormick, former vice president of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, died suddenly of a heart attack today at his residence here. He was 64 years old.

Further modernization of the New England Power Association's capital structure is contemplated in a plan filed yesterday by the Massachusetts Utilities Associates, a subsidiary, with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Budapest University Chorus, composed of forty-two male voices, under the direction of Victor Vaszy, leader of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra, will arrive Friday on the President Washington. The choristers will be heard in a concert on the evening of Jan. 16 at Carnegie Hall.

Miss Mary Malcolm, granddaughter of the famous English actress, Lily Langtry (Lady de Bathe), was married today to Sir Basil Bartlett, actor and newspaper man. She is the daughter of Sir Ian Malcolm. The Archbishop of Canterbury, head of the Church of England, performed the ceremony.

The city's snow-removal program has been imperiled by the automobile strike situation, which is holding up delivery of 400 new trucks essential to the plans for clearing the streets of snow, Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey revealed yesterday.

After the conclusion of arguments yesterday the United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision on an application to reverse District Judge Mandelbaum's decision dismissing a petition to reorganize the National Public Service Corporation on the ground that there was virtually nothing left to reorganize.

Barbara Blatherwick, coloratura soprano, appeared in her annual recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The program consisted of works by Pergolesi, Scarlatti, Paradies, Granados, Palcios, Morato, Massenet, Chopin, Thomas, Mendelssohn, Rubinstein, Schubert, Wagner. Maheboob Khan, Rasbach, Cornelissen, Dr. George Liebling and Morgan. Claude Gonvierre played the accompaniments.
Captain Michael J. Brennan, in command of Company H, Ninth Infanty Regiment, Pennsylvania National Guard, during the Spanish-American War, died at his home in Pittston today of pneumonia.

Herman Hormel, former surveyor for the port of Boston, and for many years prominent in city and State political affairs, died today at Faulkner Hospital, where he had been a patient for several weeks. His age was 63.

Declaring that under present conditions "it is almost impossible for a child to be adequately taught in his home," Judge Joseph Siegler of the Juvenile Court here ruled today that Mr. and Mrs. Benno Bongart of 123 Watchung Avenue, West

The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain and Hapag Lloyd liner Reliance, which will sail this week on world cruises, have dropped Spanish ports from their itineraries because of the Spanish civil war, it was announced yesterday. The ports had been booked

Miss Anne Bigelow Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Rosen of this city, was married yesterday afternoon to Janos Scholz of Sopron-Oedenburg, Hungary, in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector emeritus of the church, and the Rev. Dr. Arthur Ketchum of Katonah, N. Y.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Reinhold G. von Kokeritz of 212 Major Avenue, Arrochar, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsa Clarissa von Iokeritz, to Henry Bruce Alexander, also of Staten Island, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Alanson Alexander of Jersey City.

Intense cold, ranging down to 37 below in Minnesota, harassed the Prairie States today. Subzero temperatures were reported in the Dakotas, Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, Colorado, Montana, Wyoming and Nebraska, but moderation, setting in tomorrow, was promised.

Ontario Treasury Department officials tonight announced the sale of a $20,000,000 Province of Ontario long-term loan of 2 1/2 per cent and 3 per cent serial debentures. The flotation is the first serial issue to be sold by the Ontario Government since it assumed office in 1934. The proceeds will be used

Denouncing the undistributed profits tax feature of the 1936 Revenue Act as preventing the sound financial management of railroads, which since the depression it has been trying to build up, the Interstate Commerce Commission urged in its annual report today that Congress reconsider the measure at least in so far as it affects the railroad industry.
The new faces in the Seventy-fifth Congress displayed to the public today numbered 111, ninety-five of them in the House and sixteen in the Senate. Of the new Senators, four were

The Apawamis Club brought a strong women's Class B team to the squash racquets courts of the Junior League yesterday and defeated the Montclair A. C., 4 to 1, in the first round of the triangular metropolitan interclub competition. Apawamis is favored to turn in a similar result against the Staten Island players today.

Repercussion of the strikes in the automotive industry was felt in Rochester today. The Vogt Manufacturing Company, which supplies upholstery materials to General Motors and several other large automobile manufacturers, has received notice to be ready to stop production immediately if difficulties with the unions are not settled soon.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, No. 3 seeded player, advanced through two rounds today in the fifth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament and will meet a seeded opponent Thursday if he wins his next match.

George A. Richards, president of the Detroit Lions professional football club, announced today the signing of Earl (Dutch) Clark, outstanding Lion quarterback, to coach the team next season. Clark succeeds George (Potsy) Clark, who notified Richards today he had signed to coach the Brooklyn Dodgers. His contract expired Jan. 1 and was not renewed.
With sixteen Republicans grouped on a little island surrounded by seventysix Democrats and four Independents, the Senate of the Seventyfifth Congress assembled today.

Emperor Hirohito expressed the hope today at the annual New Year's banquet at the Imperial Palace that relations of the nations of the world with Japan would become increasingly friendly and productive.

Expenditures by the veterans' administration for pensions to dependents and participants of all wars amounted to $589,564,326 during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1936, which was $28,958,015 less than in the 1935 fiscal year, Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, advised President Roosevelt today in his annual report.

JUST a minute, Inspector. Who are those strange miscreants in the hockey homicide line-up ? Where are the old offenders who were always telling it to the judge? Just the other day the crime sheet was exposed to view and a comparatively mild gent named Allan Shields, apprehended a few times in the star-spangled uniform of the Dauntless Dutton tribe, was topping the penalty list.

The Lewine Realty Corporation leased to Italian Peoples Theatrical Enterprises, Inc., the property at 199 to 205 Bowery and 167 to 175 Chrystie Street consisting of stores and the old Peoples Theatre.
A recommendation that the law be amended to put brewers under a permit system was contained in the annual report of W. S. Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, submitted to Congress today.

Cooperative newspaper advertising has played a considerable part in lifting the Jayson shirt line of F. Jacobson Sons into national prominence with country-wide distribution in the space of two years,

Eighteen-year-old Miss Maria Cerra, representing the Salle d'Armes Vince, captured the first fencing tournament of the new year last night on the strips of the Fencers Club when she led a field of twentyone.
Governor Wilbur L. Cross was inaugurated this afternoon as the first fourth-term Governor of Connecticut since the Civil War.

With a bullet wound through his left eye, David Goldberg, 55 years old, of 9,502 Avenue N, Brooklyn, was found dead on the floor of his stationery store at 451 Sumner Avenue, near MacDonough Street, Brooklyn, at 12:30 A. M. yesterday.

The first public announcement by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, that United States Senator A. Harry Moore would be the party's candidate for Governor this year, was made at a caucus of the Democratic majority of the new State Assembly at the Essex House here today.
The Senate Committee on 1936 Campaign Expenditures reported today that Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell of Somerville, N. J., heiress to the Duke tobacco fortune, gave $50,000 to aid the Democratic cause.

The famous marching song of the United States Naval Academy, "Anchors Aweigh," now become also a radio and night club dance tune, was made the subject yesterday of a $1,000,000 damage suit by one of its authors, Alfred H. Miles.
Non-union employes of the General Motors Corporation's Guide Lamp plant, closed by a "sit-down" strike, circulated a petition tonight to be permitted to return to work.

The Interstate Commerce Commission took up an issue which is important to railroad recovery when in its annual report issued on Tuesday it denounced the undistributed profits tax, according to opinion expressed in railroad circles yesterday.

Remington Rand, Inc., in a letter to stockholders yesterday, notified them that the first of the serial rights to subscribe for additional common stock would expire on Jan. 15, and that an agreement had been made with individuals and firms for purchase of stock not taken by stockholders.

Members of the American Iona Society of New York were urged yesterday afternoon to help preserve Scottish-Gaelic and Scottish culture by Dr. John L. Gerig of the Department of Romance Languages at Columbia University.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public the following list of companies filing reports on Form 8-K showing special changes that occurred since their registration statements became effective or their last annual report filed with the commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934:

The German answer to the French and British memoranda warning against the continued influx of alien volunteers into the ranks of the warring forces in Spain was dispatched to London by special courier today.

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, which recently acquired all the stock of the Bachmann-Emmerich Co., Inc., yesterday announced that the business of the latter organization will be conducted under the name of the Bachmann-Emmerich Factors Corporation. It will operate as an
The Federal Trade Commission today cited the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and sixteen members, whose customers included the government, for alleged unfair trade practices.
The baby members of the new Congress, Lyle H. Boren of Oklahoma, and Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana, can qualify for any allstar football team that might be picked among the legislators.

Miss Dora Catherine Gallagher, daughter of, Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Gallagher of 102 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, was married to Alfred W. McCann Jr., yesterday morning in St. Augustine's Catholic Church, Brooklyn. The Rev.

United States mints in 1936 coined 722,976,721 pieces of money having a value of $46,388,101, Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, Director of the Mint, announced today. In the year before 560,760,047 pieces, valued at $38,580,923, were coined.

G. H. Marlman's Bill Donoghue, 5year-old son of Master Charlie, ran his usual honest race and chalked up his fourth straight victory in the Tavares Handicap, six-furlong feature of the card at Tropical Park today.

A garden apartment house at 8 Rutherford Street, White Plains, was purchased from the Marine Midland Trust Company through Low Gross, Inc., by Loomis J. Grossman, who immediately resold the property to Mrs. Anna Colodney, an investing client of Stephen Tiston, broker. Purchase and

Mrs. Eleanor Greene Moody, wife of Professor Lewis Ferry Moody of the School of Engineering at Princeton University, died at Princeton Hospital tonight after a week's illness of pneumonia. Her age was 56. She was a member
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lillian Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Goldstein of Brooklyn, to William Furst of Newark.
John F. Murphy, vice president of the Sloan Valve Company of New York and a member of the Westchester Country Club here, died yesterday of pneumonia at the United Hospital. He was 55 years old.

Mrs. Mary Holz, well known in Salvation Army circles and wife of Richard Holz, former Salvation Army commissioner in charge of Eastern headquarters in New York, died at her home in Ocean Grove near here this morning.
Five new-term members were elected to the corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, announced tonight.

Further accusations of espionage against Japanese residents of Vladivostok, Siberia, came to light today when the Foreign Office learned that Daiji Takagi, manager of the Vladivostok branch of the Japan Mercantile Marine Union, had been arrested on suspicion of espionage.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 5 unless specified: At San Pedro: Kanawha, Tracy. Antares, Quantico to Naval Operations Base, Norfolk, Jan. 6. Balch, at Guayaqull, Ecuador. Barracuda. at St. Thomas.

The Board of Representatives of the city of Tampa, Fla., has approved the refunding program recently submitted by Norman S. Taber Co. of New York, fiscal agents for the city, according to word received yesterday by Taber Co.

Against seemingly hopeless odds, President Glenn Frank of the University of Wisconsin defended himself today against charges of incompetence, extravagance and maladministration filed against him by a group of regents, of whom all but one were appointed by Governor Philip F. La Follette.

The engagement of $531,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $241,000 i. England and $290,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The total of gold secured in England since Sept. 26. last, now amounts to $173,300,000. A shipment of $78,800 gold was received here yesterday from Russia.

Joseph Di Alto, 18 years old, was accidentally wounded in the left eye with shot fired from an air rifle yesterday afternoon while playing in a lot near his home at 183 Lake Street, in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading continued fairly active on most classes of locally dressed meat. Veal and pork supplies were scarce and prices strong to sharply higher. Lamb business was none

Two investigators for the Emergency Relief Bureau, who were arrested last Dec. 15 by direction of Mayor La Guardia for defrauding homeless men of part of their relief clothing vouchers, pleaded guilty yesterday as they were about to be called for trial in Special Sessions. They were Louis B. Starr and Joseph Fisher.
An estate valued at $6,620,298.52 was left by Oliver Gould Jennings in Fairfield County. He died in New York on Oct. 13. The inventory was accepted today by Judge Bacon Wakeman in the Probate Court.

Appointment of G. E. Gilliland of Deland, Fla., president of the Florida State League, as executive assistant to William O. De Witt, vice president and general manager of the St. Louis Browns, was announced by the American League team today.

Frank M. Gregg, former Cleveland manufacturer and writer, died at his home here yesterday .at the age of 72. Funeral services were held here this morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Delos Hawk officiated.

The Rev. Dr. George Herman Fickes, Professor. of Religious Education and director of personnel at Lafayette College, died today at his home here after a short illness. His age was 58. Although feeling ill yesterday, he conducted one of his classes.

An additional issue of $4,500,000 of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation rapid transit collateral trust 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due May 1, 1966, will be offered today at 103 1/2 and accrued interest by an underwriting group consisting of Hayden, Stone Co., Brown

The marriage of Miss Ruth Becket, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Mark Becket, to Sefton Tranter of New York took place yesterday noon in the chapel of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of the church, in the presence of members of the families.

The Hudson Building Company has purchased the plot 100 by 136 at 174-180 Jewett Avenue, Jersey City, from Samuel Stock, receiver of the National Bank of North Hudson, and proposes to erect on it a threestory apartment to house twentyfour families.
Presentation of the "voluntary agreement" or code for retailers, based on many of the NRA principles but stressing State laws, will feature the opening session on the evening of Jan. 18 of the

Robert Hudson, an actor, who made his last stage appearance in N'ew York in support of Leslie Howard in "The Petrified Forest" in 1935, died Tuesday in a private hospital at 293 Central Park West. He was born in Lexington, Ky., forty-nine years ago.

The pension plan for employes of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiary companies will be maintained for the present, even though the Social Security Act is in effect, Thomas N. McCarter, president of the company, announced yesterday.

A heavyweight bout between Gunnar Barlund, Finnish title prospect, and Clarence (Red) Berman, Baltimore protege of Jack Dempsey, was approved yesterday by the State Athletic Commission as an attraction for the Twentieth Century S. C. at the Hippodrome on Jan. 20.

The Cunard White Star Line and its associate, the Donaldson Atlantic Line, led all ship lines in the volume of transatlantic passenger traffic carried last year with a total of 176,104, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the company, 25 Broadway.
The beautiful concerto for strings in E minor of Antonio Vivaldi opened the Philharmonic- Symphony concert conducted by John Barbirolli last night in Carnegie Hall.

The Davis and Elkins College five defeated John Marshall last night, 47 to 43, at the Edison School Gym in Union City. Allman, with 18 points, and Gutowski, with 15, were high scorers for Davis and Elkins.

Stuart Hedden has been admitted as a general partner in Fuller, Rodney Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. Robert C. Johnson and Stephen M. Hart have joined the sales department of Lobdell Co.

Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner today on the Board of Trade here, with aggressive selling attributed to Eastern operators appearing on all the minor upturns. Prices held within a range of around 2 cents a bushel, with the finish well toward the low point.
An investigator for the United States Soil Conservation Service is back from Peru, where he studied ancient methods in fighting

Frederick Coykendall has been renamed chairman of the Columbia University board of trustees, it was disclosed yesterday by university authorities. Mr. Coykendall has served in this capacity since 1933, when he succeeded General William Barclay Parsons.

There are four ways by which the Supreme Court can be made responsive to -the President's call in his message today for "liberal and not narrow interpretation of new laws consistent with an historic constitutional framework to meet new national needs."

Word that Governor Lehman had commuted their death sentence to life imprisonment was brought to Samuel Kimmel, 19 years old; Eugene Bruno, 20, and Dominick Zizzo, 22, in the quarters of the condemned in Sing Sing Prison at noon today by Warden Lewis E. Lawes.

The Guaranty Trust Company, as agent for the Lerner Stores Corporation, will accept 4% per cent cumulative preferred stock (convertible until Feb. 1, 1942) of the corporation for conversion into common shares.

The Spanish steamer Mar Cantabrico slipped her moorings at 1:47 P. M. yesterday at Pier 35, Atlantic Basin, Brooklyn, and raced to sea with a cargo of more than $2,000,000 worth of supplies for the Madrid government. Efforts to force her return were futile.

The $75,000 libel suit brought by Crawford Burton, amateur jockey and member of the New York Stock Exchange, against the Crowell Publishing Company over the publication in Collier's Weekly and the American Magazine of a testimonial advertisement for a brand of cigarettes, will go to the jury today.
Mr. ROOSEVELT'S first message to the Seventy-fifth Congress yesterday is, in effect, a schedule of future public business. Immediate action by Congress is necessary in only two matters.
In a memorial ceremony at 11:30 A. M. today Lambert Brothers, jewelers at Lexington Avenue and Sixtieth Street, will unveil a plaque to the late August V. Lambert, the founder. The ceremony will be a

Mrs. Rose W. Cordts, 55 years old, was drowned accidentally in a bathtub at 493 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday. Her body was taken from the tub by the police, who said that Mrs. Cordts apparently had fainted while bathing and was drowned. She was employed as a

Mrs. Phoebe Carey Brisbane, widow of the journalist, and her two oldest children applied to Surrogate J. L. Donahay here yesterday for joint guardianship of three Brisbane children of minor age. Samuel C.

Another appeal by Dr. W. N. Mattson, father of Charles Mattson, who was kidnapped on Dec. 27, for a cessation of all surveillance in the case and the appearance of another contact advertisement in The Seattle Times led to the belief today that negotiations for the payment of $28,000 ransom and the return of the boy were nearing a successful conclusion.

The engagement has been announced here of Miss Barbara W. Dixon of London, daughter of the late Mrs. Cecil Campbell and of the late William H. Dixon of New York, to Samuel C. R. Allen, youngest son of Mrs. William E. Allen of Commonwood House, Chipperfield, Herts, England, and the late Mr. Allen.

Leon Trotsky will arrive at Tampico from Norway Saturday or Sunday, according to information in the hands of the Mexican Government, Ernesto Hidalgo, Acting Secretary for Foreign Affairs, declared today.

Considerable pressure was put on President Lazaro Cardenas today by Leftists in his government and Spanish Loyalists to alter his order prohibiting a shipment of United States aircraft from Mexico to Spain.

In the reactions of a London family and a captured airman to a sudden air raid, L. du Garde Peach made his play "Night Sky," at the Savoy Theatre tonight reproduce all the arguments being waged in British homes today on the pros and cons of rearmament as a means of defense.

Devaluation of the dollar and rising gold production present the "ominous possibilities" of a great rise in commodity prices, Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson, economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, said today at a luncheon of the Chicago Association of Commerce in the Stevens Hotel.
Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas showed a rise of 7 per cent for the week ended Jan. 2 over the same week a year ago,

Miss Sarah M. Dean, who was acting principal of the Brearley School for girls at her retirement in 1921, died yesterday at her residence, 424 East Fifty-seventh Street, after a brief illness, at the age of 66.

Through a 3-to-2 victory on their home courts over the Short Hills Club, the New York A. C. representatives continued undefeated in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League Class A team competition last night.

A total of 71 full pages, 58 half pages and 114 quarter pages will be used in leading newspapers throughout the country this month in connection with the exploitation in retail stores of the new E-Z-DO ROL-A-DOR storage closet, according to the Decorative Cabinet Corporation.

A sailing class, formed at the Rochester Yacht Club in the Spring of 1935, skyrocketed into international yacht racing importance today with announcement of the organization of the 14-Foot International Dinghy Association.

In a message crowded with recommendations for new legislation, many of these resulting from the fact that Republican lawmakers in the past had refused to cooperate with his proposals, Governor Lehman today demanded that the Legislature make the passage of his social security measure, defeated last year, its "first order of business" at the session which began at noon today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the upholding by the Supreme Court of the Ashhurst-Sumners act prohibiting interstate transportation of convict-made goods in violation of State statutes is received with enthusiastic approval by all proponents of sound labor standards, it is disturbing to note the advocacy of similar procedure as a means of wiping out sweated labor conditions in industry generally.
Henry Holt Co. will publish next month a volume called "In 1936," by A. C. Eurich and E. C. Wilson. A first prize of $25 and

Marion Bergman, pianist, will be heard tomorrow afternoon at the Studio Club of the Y. W. C. A. The compositions of Marion Bauer will be featured in the Composers' Forum-Laboratory tomorrow evening at the New School for Social Research.

Freddie Miller of Cincinnati, former N. B. A. featherweight champion, moved along the come-back trail tonight, winning the judges' decision over Frankie (Kid) Covelli of Brooklyn after ten fast rounds.

Some two months ago it became an established fact that I had definitely become a professional tennis player and that, instead of winning trophies and pats on the back, my future was to be centered around the pass books of local banking institutions.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today increases in the rate of payment under the 1936 soil conservation program for three sections of the country.

The $82,833,477 business in 1936 of James Talcott, Inc., factoring, was the largest for any twelve months in the concern's eighty-three years of existence, the company reported yesterday. It compared with $68,076,000 in 1935, an increase of 21.68 per cent.

Federal Judges of the Southern District of New York are to have a lunch club, permission to operate one having been obtained yesterday from Justice Samuel H. Rosenman of the State Supreme Court, a procedure necessary under the membership corporation law of the State.

Employe representatives from eighteen Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation plants called today on fellow-workers to "unite" against the Committee for Industrial Organization in defense of their company-sponsored collective bargaining plan.
For the first time in forty years Negroes sat on a Craven County Superior Court jury here today, and they helped convict a member of their race of first-degree murder.

Hugo Doob defeated Phil Meise, 150 to 124, in forty-six innings in a national Class C 18.2 balkline billiard championship match at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Doob was substituting for Jake Ward, who is ill. Seymour Prince, former class champion,

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that 1936 sugar quotas for offshore areas amounted to 5,049,389 tons, raw value, and of these all but 15,379 of the Philippines were filled. The revised quotas were: Cuba, 2,102,607 tons; Philippines, 1,000,829; Puerto Rico, 909,445; Hawaii, 1,032,812; Virgin Island, 3,696.

The New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday made its 1937 appeal for funds for the maintenance of the organization by sending out 25,000 letters to firms, individuals, former contributors and prospective supporters. The sum of $70,000 is

Three armed thugs robbed the real estate office of John J. Reed at 100 Fourth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, of about $300 at 3 P. M. yesterday. Two collectors of rents had just returned to the office.

Higher prices for farm products were both espoused and opposed, and lease contracts were suggested as means to relieve the Southern tenants who cannot be assisted by land purchases, at the southeastern farm tenancy hearing of the President's special committee on farm tenancy, attended by more than 300 persons from seven States today.

Controller Taylor announced yesterday that he would refinance with a $22,600,000 issue of 1 1/2 per cent revenue notes an equal amount of revenue bills issued in anticipation of real estate tax collections for the second half of 1936, under the provisions of the Bankers' Agreement.

Hearings by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its investigation of the stock registration statement of the Bagdad Copper Corporation were adjourned yesterday at the regional office of the SEC, 120 Broadway, until 10 A. M. today.

Rain squalls over Holland, lashing to fury the brown waters of its innumerable canals and the shallows of the Zuider Zee, soaking its miles of pasture, still bright green in January, and beating down on the trains bringing the romantically inclined of half Europe to Holland's capital to applaud the culmination of a royal romance.

Germany apparently is fortifying that part of the German-Polish frontier nearest Berlin. She also is building military airdromes in that area. It is on the border of the Polish province of Poznan, which formerly was German territory.

A brief curtain speech-the first he has ever made in New Yorkwas spoken at the conclusion of yesterday's matinee performance of "Hamlet" at the St. James Theatre by John Gielgud, the young English actor appearing in the title rOle, to mark the 103d consecutive performance of the play and the establishment of a record continuous run by it on Broadway. Mr. Gielgud's record has only been approached by John Barrymore and Edwin Booth.

Arthur E. Holder, organized labor leader, died today at Lake Wales, Fla., it was announced here today. His age was 66. Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, paid tribute in the following message of condolence to his. widow:

Mrs. Alexander B. Johnson will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 115 East Ninety-second Street, for members of the junior committee aiding in the arrangements for the Yankee Doodle Ball to be held Jan. 16 at the Delmonico for the benefit of Auxiliary 6 of the Stony Wold Sanatorium.

As the battle continued to rage around the Escorial Road all day, Madrid itself received two shocks-when a fleet of fourteen German Junkers bombers and many pursuit planes flew over the city at noon and, forty minutes later, when the Telephone Building and the Gran Via were subjected to heavy shelling for half an hour with murderously accurate shots.
Dorothy B., a rank outsider from the Lone Star Stable, staged a strong finish to capture the five and a half furlong dash, which topped the Fair Grounds card today.
All previous records for attendance at Winter markets were broken today when registration of buyers at the major furniture show in the American Furniture Mart headed toward the 5,000 mark.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Irwin Branigan of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Allen Branigan, to Dr. Edward Campbell Berger, son of Dr. Grace Berger, 77 Park Avenue, New York, and the late Dr. Theodore Berger.

Modern business men, recognizing that business enterprises are an integral part of the community as well as profit-making institutions, should subscribe to the debenture issue in process of distribution to finance the New York World's Fair of 1939, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, declared yesterday.

The text of President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress follows: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES For the first time in our national history a President delivers his annual message to a new Congress within a fortnight of the expiration of his term of office.
Brisk real estate activity in Manhattan was featured yesterday by the sale of the thirteen-story loft building at 344-348 West Thirtyeighth Street by Benjamin Winter to Charles Walzer, operator.

Sergei Rachmaninoff was received with enthusiasm tonight by a large audience of music lovers of Northern New Jersey who came to the Mosque Theatre here for the second in a series of benefit concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra under the auspices of L. Bamberger Co.

Dougan. in 311 E. 72d St., through Pease Elliman, Inc.;

Starting news from Nanking that government armies are actually moving against the forces of General Yang Fu-cheng, which participated in the December Sian rebellion, may mean the entire upset of the Sian settlement.

Three of seven large groups of silk and rayon textile manufacturers showed small net profits for the last half of 1935, the Federal Trade Commission reported today after a study of costs, sales and investments of this industry.

Net assets applicable to the debentures and capital stock of the General American Investors Company, Inc., at the close of 1936 were $37,036,680, compared with $30,557,817 on Dec. 31, 1935, Frank Altschul, president, announced yesterday. Mr.

Their forces riddled by injuries and illness, and their berth in the international section of the National Hockey League the cellar, the New York Americans will take to the ice in Madison Square Garden tonight against the Detroit Red Wings.

Proceedings to oust Mrs. Irene Armstrong, housewife Mayor of Daytona Beach, begun five days before his term ended by Governor Dave Sholtz, were revoked today by his successor, Governor Fred P. Cone, who assumed office yesterday.

Miss Ruth Leet Pitcairn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bruce Pitcairn of 6,333 Ellenwood Avenue, was married to Thomas Franklin James Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Franklin James of 6,425 Wydown Boulevard, here today at the Second Presbyterian Church.

Organization of the Federal Reserve Banks for 1937 was announced today by the Federal Reserve Board. Owen D. Young was reappointed deputy chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, in which capacity he is acting chairman.
Holding the pace set by the industrial and mercantile worlds, baseball shared in the prosperity of 1936. I would not say "baseball has come back," for the reason it never went away.

The Rev. Charles Reuben Trowbridge, D. D., a retired minister of the Lutheran Church, died at his home here today. His age was 78. His first charge was at Trenton, which he served for three years. coming to Easton in 1888.
A $500 gift and three $100 contributions helped to increase the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to $267,429.48. The day's mail brought fifty-five donations totaling $1,124.

The great collection of paintings that Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, will give to the nation as a nucleus for a National Gallery of Art in Washington has been enriched further by the purchase of three important paintings from the collection of J. P. Morgan.

The War Department released these orders today, dated Jan. 5: McNair. Brig. Gen. L. J., 1 month and 24 days leave, Jan. 10, with permission to visit foreign countries. Hotchkiss, Col. C. R., General Staff Corps, 15 days leave, Jan. 16.

Leasing of the building at 841 Broadway, as recorded on Monday, will give Ohrbach's Affiliated Stores, Inc., an addition of 40,000 square feet to its selling space. Nathan M. Ohrbach, president, announced yesterday that the Broadway structure would be remodeled and opened about Feb. 1.
With Manager Bill Terry and his former field captain, Travis Jackson, now pilot of the new Jersey City club, still in town, things continued to move with a zip in the offices of the Giants yesterday.
Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Kate Leilani van Heemskerck Duker, daughter of William Frederick van H. Duker of Honolulu. to Dr. Hugo Peter Kortschak of this city.

That the Winter racing season which opens at Hialeah Park, Miami, Fla., next Wednesday will have a social significance similar to that of Belmont Park and Saratoga is indicated by the list of members of the Hialeah Club just issued by Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club.

The Central California Utilities Corporation and the Gas Fuel Service Company, its subsidiary, were held today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to be wholly intrastate in character and exempt from the provisions of the Holding Company Act requiring registration of such interstate companies.

The nation's railroads began today their fight before the Interstate Commerce Commission to regain part of the emergency freight surcharges that were terminated on Dec. 31 and had netted them about $10,000,000 monthly.

All of the leading polo clubs in New York, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut have been invited to compete in the New York Athletic Club's eleventh annual midwinter indoor polo tournament, which will be held at the 105th Field Artillery Armory, Bronx, Feb. 6-13. The bids were issued

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Anne E. Atherton of 425 Riverside Drive of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Atherton, to Robert Bulkeley Winslow of New York and Greenfield, Mass., son of Mrs. Lawrence Ewing of Greenfield and the late Edward B. Winslow of Beverly, Mass.

A large number of awards for textile garment supplies for the Civilian Conservation Corps were made today at the quartermaster depot on six invitations, bids on which were opened here a few days ago. The awards were as follows:

In view of the labor crises developing throughout the country, the American Management Association yesterday issued a call to 2,182 companies and to industry at large to have representatives attend a conference in Philadelphia on Feb. 9, 10 and 11. It is expected that
A large part of the radio facilities of the country yesterday carried President Roosevelt's address on the state of the Union, delivered in the House before the joint session of Congress.

The Hamburg-American liner Reliance arrived yesterday from Channel ports via the West Indies and will start on her round-the-world cruise on Sunday at 10 A. M. On board were two champion piping bullfinches, Peter I and Peter

Pensioned For physical disability: Capt. James P. T. Flynn, Eng. 276, annual pension S2.250. Fireman First Grade Thomas J. Lee, H. L. 9, annual pension $1,500. Foreman First Grade George R. Kingsley, H. L. 82, annual pension $1,500. Fireman First Grade John J. Hallanan, H. L. 29, annual pension $1,500.

An aggregate rental of about $1,000,000 is involved in the lease of the six-story building at 493-95 Fulton Street, corner of Bridge Street, Brooklyn, to Russeks Fifth Avenue, according to the David Jaret Company, brokers who negotiated the deal in conjunction with the Brown Company.

Two and a half acres with a house, garage, greenhouse and caretaker's cottage on Cedar Swamp Road, Jericho, L. I., was sold to Mrs. Charles Van Rensselaer of Oyster Bay, J. Edward Breuer, broker, reports. The property was once occupied by John Barrymore.

Army overwhelmed Lehigh at basketball today, 46 to 15. Although showing signs of unsteadiness at times, the Cadets excelled in passing and floor work. The invaders' defense was weak and they had trouble getting the range of the basket.
Ida Samuel, long an opponent of woman suffrage and for forty-five years an instructor at the New England Conservatory of Music, died at her home tonight at the age of 76.

Twin Coast Guard cutters, built at a cost of $2,400,000 each in the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, were named yesterday afternoon for Alexander Hamilton and John C. Spencer. The latter was Secretary of the Treasury and Secretary of War under President Tyler.

Gaston Cherau, French journalist, Marquis Melchior de Polignac, Judge Paul Myron Linebarger, Professor Etienne Sorrel, Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Rollin and Count Gosta Morner are among the passengers due to arrive -today from Havre via Southampton on the French Line motorship Lafayette.
Immediate consideration of continuation of certain powers and authorizations which will soon expire was asked of Congress today by President Roosevelt. Expiration dates of the principal ones are:
Electric power production declined slightly last week and the adjusted index receded to 103.1 from 103.8, the figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 4, 1936, it stood at 98.7.

The text of the statement of Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, in reply to a statement of Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, was as follows:

RINGS EARLE, WILLIAM P., Sr. (March 15, 1935). Gross assets; $8,724: net, $2,363. To . asephine and Sophie Pitman. Mrs. Julius Snowden and Annie E. Bird, $250 each: Helen and Estelle Priestley, $500 each; Justine Nienenber, S100; sons. Russell W. and William P. Earle Jr.: daughters. Louise B. Hughes and Helen T.

The Federal Trade Commission issued an order today forbidding the National Electrical Manufacturers Association of New York City and sixteen member manufacturers of power cable and wire, from maintaining uniform selling prices.

Business men and movie stars got the highest salaries paid in this country in 1935, a Treasury report to Congress disclosed today. The public inspection of private pay envelopes was made possible by the Ways and Means Committee, which released for publication the incomes of every person who made more than $15,000.
The F. W. Woolworth Company announced yesterday that its sales in December amounted to $45,505,958. This was the largest volume
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, Donald C. Harrison, New York City, was admitted to practice today and the following cases were argued:

Lieutenant R. H. Gorsline, a naval aviator attached to the United States cruiser Louisville, now in the repair basin at Pearl Harbor, was killed this afternoon when the training plane in which he was flying dived 2,000 feet and crashed in the mud flats near the John Rodgers Airport.

ALEXANDER-Onn Tuesday, Jan. 5, 1937, J. Harry Alexander. at his residence, Atlantic Beach, L. i., beloved husband of Jennie R. Jones and father of J. Harry, Jr. and Viola Alexander Lindner. Services at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Thursday, at 1 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

In 1935 it was a mellophone. Now it's a helicon, and if you can play one of the "Bass bb Flat" variety, to quote the Army Information Service, there is a job waiting for you in the military band in the Canal Zone.

Justice Louis Wendel, senior justice of the City Court, was unanimously elected Chief Justice of the court yesterday by vote of his colleagues. He succeeds Chief Justice Edward B. La Fetra, who retired on Dec. 31 upon reaching the 70year age limit. Justice La Fetra had held the post for about ten years.

The peak of the influenza outbreak probably will be reached by the end of this week and the number of new cases developing thereafter will decline, Dr. Charles F. Bolduan, director of public health education of the Department of Health, said yesterday.

While the normal flow of motor traffic in the midtown area was slowed part of yesterday, the gigantic task of transporting and installing the 120 pleasure craft, hundreds of powerful engines and other paraphernalia that form the National Motor Boat Show neared completion last night at the Grand Central Palace.

" Our inventions are ignored. Even "when they are not, months pass be"fore they are introduced. Besides, "are not adequately rewarded." Whence comes this familiar complaint? Sit back, hold tight. It is the Communist inventor of the Soviet Union beating his head against the Wailing Wall of bureaucracy and lamenting.
Joe Cambria, the baseball man who recently sold Albany out of the International League, may buy it right back in again through the Toronto club.

Asserting in his will the belief that "the good Lord inspired me" to disseminate anti-war propaganda, the Rev. Pasquale Maltese, pastor emeritus of St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church at Van Nest, N. Y., provided a $3,000 trust fund for the reprinting and distribution of his compilation of an Italian war hero's messages from the trenches during the World War.

Pensions for widows and orphans of all World War veterans, regardless of the cause of death, which would provide $22 a month for a widow without children and a sliding scale for the number of children in other cases, headed the list of World War veterans' "demands" placed in the hoppers of Congress today.
George Schneiter, Ogden (Utah) professional, led qualifiers for the $8,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today with a 69. Par for the Rancho course, where the Utahan played, is 70.
Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey officially dedicated yesterday a departmental educational float which will tour the city drawing attention to the department's snow removal plans.
The volume of trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange in 1936 amounted to 77,558 contracts, against 41,240 in 1935, Carlos A. Scholtz, president, announced yesterday.

Endeavour II, T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger for the America's Cup, will leave Gosport for New York early in May. She is now being fitted out by Charles Nicholson with a jury rig for the transatlantic voyage and is having special water tanks installed and heavy hatches fitted over her racing hatches.

Commissioner Frank C. Keller of the Queens Building Department announced yesterday that building plans filed in the borough for 1936 showed an increase of 65 per cent over 1935. The total estimated expenditures on building activity in 1936 amounted to $50,203,085 and the 1935 total was $30,424,219.

Next week's calendar is jammed with indoor shindigs for outdoor fellows. If it weren't for the pleasant prospect of running into a lot of old sidekicks of field and stream and sea, the impending round of gustatory events would hold a deal of terror for this old epicure, now conscientiously engaged in a weightreducing regimen. The whole thing probably is a conspiracy.
The Town Council has decreed that it would be a nuisance to establish an automobile trailer camp in this resort.

Insurance in force of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia at the close of 1936 was $358,463,000, a gain of $1,743,000 over 1935, according to Walter L. Talbot, president. New paid insurance during the year amounted to $27,081,000.
In farewell to Countess Alexander K. Tolstoy, who will leave tomorrow for New York to sail for Paris, Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer were dinner hosts tonight at Capricho.

Here are conspicuous points of the President's message to Congress: The vital need is not an alteration of our fundamental law (the Constitution), but an increasingly enlightened view with reference to it.

John Henry Lewis, world light-heavyweight champion, and Harry Thomas, hard - punching heavyweight from Eagle Bend, Minn., will meet in a ten-round bout at the Chicago Stadium Jan. 15, Matchmaker Jim Mullen announced tonight. A tenround battle between Davey Day,

Resales figured prominently in deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday. A four-story apartment house at 369 St. John's Place was resold by Loomis J. Grossman, who purchased it from the Poughkeepsie Savings Bank in November, to J. Misrok.

Manhattan BENDER, KENNETH E. (Dec. 23).--Estate, more than $20,000. To St. Peter's Church, Albany, N. Y., and St. Paul's Church, Albany, N. Y., $2,500 each as memorials to parents; Andrew P. Bowne, Asbury Park, N. J., and Stacey Bender, cousin, 526 E. Broad St., Westfield, N. J., $5,000 each; Louise D. Bender, widow,

Coming from behind with a rush in the last few minutes to erase a 25-18 deficit, the Eastern District quintet defeated Seward Park, 28 to 26, on the victors' court yesterday. Isadore Gold scored the winning points with a toss from midcourt with a minute to play.

69th St., 15 E.: to 15-story tenement and store; Henry Phipps Estates, 465 E. 57th St., owner; Rosario Candela, architect; cost. $10,000. Pitt St., 18; to 5-story tenement and stores: Peternoff Realty Corp., 8 Clinton St.. owner; Jacob Fisher, architect; cost, S8.0O0.

The more the German-Japanese "anti-Communist" pact is defended, the more suspect it becomes. Its defenders do protest too much. The latest defense, that of the Japanese Foreign Minister, HACHIRO ARITA, in a radio talk last Tuesday, adds nothing substantial to what had been said before.
France, China and Britain, next to Spain, were the largest purchasers of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States in December.

Complaints of American business men that the negotiation of reciprocal trade agreements was conducted in "star chamber" sessions which deprived them of essential information for their own protection, were recognized today in a material modification of practices followed in this respect.

A rather substantial reaction in the more volatile South American dollar bonds and continued weakness in United States Government obligations marked trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The main body of

Representative John Toussaint Bernard, Farmer-Laborite from Minnesota, who objected to consideration of the neutrality resolution in the House today, and later cast the lone vote against it, was born in Corsica, the birthplace of Napoleon Bonaparte.

Mr. and Mrs. Justus Ruperti of Cedarhurst, L. I., and Clearwater, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Ruperti, to Allan Gerdau, son of Mrs. Otto Gerdau of 983 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Gerdau.

Dr. Aaron M. Gold of New York won the Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Brown Orthopedic Research Fellowship at the Hospital for Joint Diseases for 1937, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Gold held the fellowship last year, and the present award is a reappointment.

A banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including thirty members, submitted yesterday the highest bid for an issue of $24,824,000 of Boston Metropolitan District bonds.

The Brooklyn Poly basketball team turned back the Wagner College five, 38 to 27, at Odd Fellows Hall, Brooklyn, last night. The victors led at the half, 22 to 12. Henry Johnson-of Poly and Frank Quintana of Wagner each tallied eight points. In a preliminary, the Poly junior varsity quintet conquered Newark Prep, 28 to 25.
The tremendous changes in every phase of Russian life wrought by the Bolshevist Revolution were shown today in the preliminary findings of the census which is being taken throughout the Soviet Union.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:
