Henry G. Barbey, for twentyeight years a member of the board of governors of the Society of the New York Hospital and active in health service and welfare work, was elected president of the board of the society, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late

Greater activity in cotton goods quarters, where the possibility of legislation increasing production costs stimulated business, created more demand for contracts on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices recovered.
Deputy Commissioner I. James Brody of the Bureau of Motor Vehides directed yesterday the mailing of the first of the new automobile operators' licenses issued here.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, who left his sick bed to go to headquarters Tuesday after the arrest of two of the bandits who robbed Barney's clothing store on Saturday, suffered a relapse yesterday and was ordered by his physician to remain in bed until his recovery is complete.

Among the business leases yesterday was one involving space in West Forty-fifth Street for an art gallery, and another in East Eightysixth Street for quarters of the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce. The list follows:

A saga of theatrical production unparalleled in modern Broadway history brings "The Eternal Road" to the Manhattan Opera House at 8:30 o'clock this evening. First announced as "The Road of Promise," and postponed ten times since the original date set for (Dec. 23, 1935), it is Max Reinhard's production of a play by Franz Werfel, translated and adapted by Ludwig Lewisohn, with music by Kurt Weill and scenery by Norman Bel Geddes.

Holders of more than 50 per cent of the total claims against the city in the Grand Central Parkway condemnation proceedings in Queens have agreed to accept less than the amounts awarded to them by Supreme Court Justice Faber, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday.

ZOLLINGER SCHROTH, INC., silks, 58 W. 40th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing assets of $812,233, not allowing for depreciation of plant and machinery located at Emaus, Pa., and liabilities of $420.658. The RFC has started court proceedings to enforce payment of a loan of $138,745 and Judge Coxe issued a stay order.
Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley and Miss Hope Kingsley of the Beekman sailed on the Franconia yesterday for a world cruise. Mr. and Mrs. Gifford Pinchot of Milford, Pa., are at the Ambassador.

Little change was shown in the general average of hog prices today. A somewhat firmer undertone prevailed in the market early, but as soon as the urgent buying ceased easiness developed and some late sales were regarded as 5 cents lower.

Not as Mayor of Jersey City but as the head of the Demooratic party Mr. FRANK HAGUE told a caucus of Democratic Assemblymen yesterday that Senator MOORE is to be the Democratic candidate for Governor this year. This was no news.

When the Union League Club lets down the bars and admits Democrats to membership, as it is expected to do shortly, there will be at least three of that now verboten faith who will be comparatively at home within the club's still walls at Park Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The Securities and Exchange Commission in its annual report submitted today to Congress indicated that among its plans for further effective control of activities on the Exchanges and in the over-the-counter market are formulation of rules for the regulation of "pegging" operations
Mrs. Sherburne Prescott gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for her niece, Miss Muriel Selden, daughter of Mrs. Lynde Selden.
In the Supreme Court of the United States, the following proceedings were had today: 255--The Elmhurst Cemetery Co. of Joliet, petr., v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue.--Argued for both.

Governor Hoffman presented today to Colonel John M. Rogers of this city a commission as Brigadier General in the New Jersey National Guard. Completing fifty-one years in the service, forty-one of which were in the Adqutant General's department, General Rogers retired as Deputy Adjutant General.
Dr. and Mrs. Hunter Holmes McGuire of Winchester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Tucker McGuire, to Thomas MacCaulay Booth Jr. of London.

Alone among ten competitors without a single defeat scored against him, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine emerged today as winner of the international masters' tournament, which has been in progress at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club since Monday of last week.

The Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will offer a course for flower exhibitors and judges at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria from Monday through Thursday of next week, it was announced yesterday.

Ten firemen in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn, with injuries received Tuesday when the roof of a building at 176 Noll Street fell on them after a small fire had been extinguished, all showed improvement yesterday, it was said at the hospital. Fifteen firemen were hurt
A donor who wishes to be anonymous made an additional gift of $25,000 to the United Hospital Fund campaign, it was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.

Brig. Gen. William Wilson, U. S. A., retired, formerly of Geneva, N. Y., who was in command of Camp Wadsworth, Spartanburg, S. C., in the early months of 1919, died today at his home in Nobleton after several years of illness at the age of 81.

Miss Joyce Weathered, one of the greatest women golfers of all time, was married to Sir John Heathcoat-Amory at St. George's Church in Hanover Square today. Sir John proposed during a Scottish golfing holiday.

The report of the J. Henry Schroder Trust Company as of Dec. 31 showed total deposits of $16,359,945 and total assets of $19,007,510, compared, respectively, to $12,390,442 and $14,686,413 on Dec. 31, 1935.

The Jacob Wendell Scholarship, a Harvard College award of $500 founded by Jacob Wendell of New York, has been won by Robert M. Bunker of West Roxbury, Mass. It is given each year to a top scholar in the sophomore class and includes an invitation to the annual Wendell family dinner.

A "school for jurors" to arouse an interest that will check a "tendency of the courts to grow overlegalistic" will be conducted by Federal Judge William Clark in his chambers here Jan. 16 at 10:30 A. M. The school is believed the first of its kind in the country.
Plans for recodification of the Banking Law of this State were disclosed in the annual report of the Superintendent of Banks, William R. White, made yesterday to the Legislature in Albany.

A sentence of one to two years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday on Philip Travis, 22 years old, of 189 Livonia Avenue, Brooklyn, on his recent conviction of assaulting Sidney Fein,a textile manufacturer, last Sept. 23, when mass picket ing by labor union members was in progress in front of 50 West cars. Twenty-ninth Street.

Turpentine firm, 44 1/2c; sales 18 barrels; receipts 210 barrels; no shipments; stock 31,728 barrels. Resin firm; sales 640: receipts 1,387; shipments 20; stock 79,536. Quote: B, D. $10.05; E, F. $10.15; G. H, $10.20; I to WG, $10.30; WW, X, $11.50.

West End Av., 145, 40x100; Beatrice Ranz to Ann Smiley 20 Magau P1.; mtg., $28,000 (50 cents). 132d St., 69 W., 25x99.11; 1935 Realty Corp. to Elite Estates, Inc., 295 Madison Av. Pearl St., 256, 20x58.10; Gustave Lippmann to Nivia Realty Corp., 270 Broadway; mtg., $10,750 (50 cents). 114th St., 71 E., 25x100.11; Samuel Rosengarten to Bowery Savings Bank; mtg., $11,550 ($14.50).

Chandler Co., Inc., head of the banking group which offered $2,051,000 of San Jose (Calif.) Water Works first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series A, due 1961, announced yesterday that the offering had been oversubscribed and the books closed.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had closed the case against R. H. Macy Co., New York City, after the company had agreed to discontinue advertising that a type of razor blade sold by it was made under its own supervision.

To Clough Gates, business manager of The Superior Telegram and a new regent of the University of Wisconsin, was delegated the task today of replying to the assertion of Dr. Frank that during his tenure it had risen in academic rank from seventh place to second. On this subject he said:
Republican Assemblymen fought bitterly today for the one bone they snatched from the election slaughter-control of the Assembly.

A bill to put all postmasters under civil service and thus deprive future members of Congress of their greatest source of patronage was introduced in the House today by Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, chairman of the Civil Service Committee.

Substantial increases in employment in rice mills from 1933 to 1935 were reported today by the Census Bureau. For 1935 there were 2,025 persons employed in sixty-eight establishments, compared with 1,636 in fifty mills in 1933. The figure for 1935 was larger also than that for either 1931 or 1929.

The second annual report of the Securities and Exchange Commission, released yesterday, brought to light two of its studies that have been accumulating statistics for almost two years without attracting a great deal of attention. They were the surveys preliminary to the formulation of rules by the commission to regulate pegging,
Elias Lustig, president of the Adams Hat Stores, yesterday stated that a bonus has been given to all employes, in addition to the 20 per cent increase in salary announced recently.

A petition for the impeachment of Judge Edward D. Black of the Circuit Court was forwarded today to the House of Representatives at Lansing by Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America. The petition, charging

Frank Hutley, 24 years old, of 6131 Madison Street, Ridgewood, died in Trinity Hospital, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon from burns of the body he received in a small fire in a warehouse at 3,354 Atlantic Avenue, near Pine Street, Brooklyn, at 11:30 A. M.

Wiliiam Peter 2d, president of the William Peter Brewing Company of Union City, N. J., died suddenly of a heart attack tonight at his home at 68 Edgemont Place here. He collapsed soon after returning home from his office. His age was 76.

Announcement was made yesterday of the marriage on Monday afternoon of Mrs. Phyllis High Metford of this city and London to Bernard E. Pollak, also of New York, son of Mrs. Emil Pollak of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Pollak.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America sent a communication yesterday to all manufacturers of men's clothing in the United States with whom it has contractual relations, asking a horizontal increase of 15 per cent in all wage levels, affecting all branches of the clothing industry, effective May 1.

Here are the outstanding recommendations which were included in Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today: SOCIAL SECURITY-That his Social Security Bill, defeated last year in the Assembly, be made the first order of business of the present Legislature.
OTHELLO, the Shakesperian play in two acts and ten scenes. Scenery, costumes and staging by Robert Edmond Jones; presented by Max Gordon. At the New Amsterdam Theatre.

In line with the current trend toward making all banking operations profitable, or at least self-supporting, the New York Clearing House Association announced yesterday an amendment to its constitution together with regulations requiring its member banks hereafter to charge a fee for receiving or delivering securities for domestic banks, trust companies, brokers and dealers.

Stocks closed irregular, with utility shares firm; turnover, 1,921,010 shares. United States Government and South American bonds lower, foreign and domestic corporation issues irregular; transactions, $15,171,500.
Lafayette College opened its home basketball season tonight with a 29-19 victory over Albright.

Mrs. Brownell Gage, Yale graduate I and wife of the headmaster of Suffolk Academy, died at her home today following a long illness at the age of 61. Mrs. Gage, a native of Norwich, formerly taught pediatrics in Yalein-China Medical School.
Steel ingot production last year totaled 46,919,362 gross tons, 40 per cent more than the 33,417,985 tons produced in 1935, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The League of Nations received today from Julio Alvarez del Vayo, the Spanish Foreign Minister, a long telegram informing the Council officially of recent German "aggressive activity" in Spanish waters as "the latest form of the German Government's systematic breach of the non-intervention agreement."
New Orleans, just recovering from the merry New Year celebration, formally opened the gay carnival season tonight with the elaborate ball of the Twelfth Night Revelers.

Attorney General Cummings ruled today, in an opinion requested by Secretary Woodring, that the Robinson-Patman Act of 1936 did not apply to government contracts for supplies. The act forbids any person engaged in commerce to discriminate in price between different purchasers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today receipt of the following applications for registration from brokers and dealers in New York City: (Symbols: S-Sole proprietor; P-Partnership; C-Corporation.) Abraham, Nathan, 652 West 163d Street (S). Graubard Co., 25 Broad St. (S). Harriman Keech, 11 Broadway (Lucius

Willie Hoppe, veteran New York star, and young Jake Schaefer of San Francisco will play their championship 3,000-point match at 28.2 balkline billiards for a side wager of $1,000 in Chicago Jan. 25-30, Schaefer announced today.

Nedick Stores, Inc., of this city has made a gift to 450 employes by paying one month's cost of triplecoverage group insurance, which includes $500,000 life insurance, weekly sickness and accident benefits, and $500,000 accidental death and dismemberment protection, A. M. Rosenthal, president, announced yesterday.
The VictoriaHockeyClub strengthened its hold on first place in the Tri-County Hockey League by playing to a 2-2 tie with the New York Insurance Hockey Club at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.
After a poor record on the road during the Christmas vacation, the Dartmouth quintet resumed its campaign with a 48-38 victory over Brown tonight.
President Roosevelt delivered to Congress his annual message on the state of the nation.
The stock market here continued dull today, with price movements small and irregular. British Government securities, where changed, were marked down because of lack of support.
A move to settle the "sit-down" strike of nearly 1,800 employes of the Electric Storage Battery Company, which started Monday, was made today by M. Herbert Syme, counsel for the Mayor's Labor Board.

Admiral Albert Gleaves, U. S. N., retired, who was commander of the cruiser and transport force during the World War, was responsible for taking United States troops to Europe and bringing them home, died of pneumonia today at his home at Haverford. He was 79 years old
Demetrios Psarakis, an ice cream parlor proprietor, 40 years old, formerly a resident of Jamaica, L. I., defeated twenty-three other Greeks today in diving for a golden cross in Spring Bayou.

A new attack on "Mother Goose," was launched yesterday by Professor Allan Abbott of Teachers College, Columbia University, in a pamphlet in which he suggested that the nursery rhymes be rewritten "to agree with the purpose and activities of modern education."

The Chicago, Rock Island Gulf Railway applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to guarantee payment of its proportionate share of principal and interest of $5,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds proposed to be issued by the Union Terminal Company at Dallas, Texas, to pay prior to maturity $5,000,000 of 5 per cent bonds now outstanding.

The marriage of Miss Elaine Burns Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew J. Barry of 16 East Sixty-third Street and Abbeyleix, Rumson, N. J., to Wallace J. Grove of New York, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Wellington Grove of Buffalo, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre.
The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that a jig-saw puzzle was a game and not a sport and, therefore, not taxable.

Pope Pius passed another fairly good night and enjoyed several hours of rest, although his sleep was neither so long nor so profound as the night before. He had considerable difficulty in falling asleep after his physician's last visit at midnight and he did not doze off till about 1:30.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels received yesterday from Hugh J. Sheeran, receiver for the New York Railways Company, a check for $349,421.97 in full payment of the city's paving claims against, the transit company, representing money spent by the city from 1919 to 1925.

Jose Cardozo de Mello Netto was inducted as Governor of the State of Sao Paulo this afternoon. He urged the citizens to be calm and declared his program was one of constructive work and loyal collaboration with President Getulio Vargas to maintain order.

The Dartmouth College athletic council tonight announced a change in the staff of Earl Blaik, football coach, and a nine-game gridiron schedule for 1937 that ends a twenty-six-year series with Norwich (Vt.) University.

The house at 14 Mulberry Place here in which Stephen Crane, author of "Maggie" and "The Red Badge of Courage," was born in 1871 will be torn down to make way for a memorial playground, under a WPA project approved today by the City Commission.

Though the seamen's strike, which began ten weeks ago, has plainly lost much of its force in this area, shipping on the West Coast is still severely handicapped and large losses continue to accumulate.
North Olmsted High School seniors employed the "sit-down" technique, refusing to change classrooms today in protest against acceptance of Schools, L. E. Hayes, an"a lot of junk."

Addressing a joint session of the Seventyfifth Congress today, President Roosevelt was cheered to the rafters when in effect he challenged the judicial branch to join the legislative and executive branches of the Federal Government in the march for social progress, or risk a curb on its powers.

Continuing their impressive play, the women's Class B squash racquets team of the Apawamis Club yesterday won the final honors in the triangular metropolitan interclub competition, defeating the Staten Island Club, 4 to 1.

In the competition for an annual award of $2,500 established byDoubleday, Doran Co. as a memorial to Theodore Roosevelt, more than 100 manuscripts had been received by yesterday, the anniversary of the President's death and the closing date for the competition, it was announced at the publishers' office.
Mrs. George Montgomery gave a luncheon today at the Garden City Hotel in honor of her niece, Miss Valerie Higgins, who will be married to Alfred R. Heath on Jan. 16.

Delegates of several teachers' organizations throughout the city voted yesterday in favor of the immediate refund of salary deductions for absence due to illness. They met under the auspices of the Teachers Union at the Town Hall Club.
Gene Venzke will not start in the 3,000-meter race at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, games scheduled for the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn, Saturday night.
Brooklyn College's basketball team went over the .500 mark for this campaign by taking the measure of Seton Hall, 44 to 17, at Union Temple in Brooklyn last night.

The hunt gets the right-of-way even over express trains. At today's meet of the Belvoir hounds, the fox and hounds swam the river here twice and then crossed the railway tracks just as the approach of a London express was signaled.

Consideration of Panama's budget, totaling $18,197,700, for the next two years, was begun at the special session of the National Assembly today. The largest allotment, $4,997,100, is for public works, hygiene and beneficence.

William A. White Sons arranged with the Bowery Savings Bank for extension of the first mortgage of $140,000 on the block front on the east side of Seventh Avenue, 125th to 126th Streets. The White organization has managed the property for over forty years for the owners. Cyril J. Redwood acted as attorney for the owner and Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft were attornevs for the bank.

The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company, Inc., announced yesterday that neither it nor its subsidiary, the Remington Arms Company of Bridgeport, Conn., had supplied war materials to either of the fighting forces in Spain.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that a hearing be held on the application of Bristol Willett for termination of unlisted trading privileges on the New York Curb Exchange in 7 per cent convertible preferred stock of $100 par value and no-par common stock of the American District Telegraph Company of New Jersey.

A denial by Henry Ford that he had any connection with the antiJewish book, "The International Jew," published in Germany, was made public here yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, president of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League.

Lawrence (La La) Mullins, sought by the police as one of the men who held up the store of Barney's Clothes, Inc., at 111 Seventh Avenue, last Saturday, was arrested at the home of his stepfather, last night, and was taken to the West Sixty-eighth Street police station for questioning.

A table of expenses charged to the State by Dr. Glenn Frank as president of the University of Wisconsin was presented to the Board of Regents today by Clough Gates, one of the regents. In it were cited these as being unauthorized:

Dr. Victor G. Heiser, president of the International Leprosy Association and a pioneer in the investigation of leprosy for more than thirty years, sailed last night to study the disease in Central Africa, where it is believed to manifest itself in a form not found elsewhere.
Junior League of the City of New York, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Lecture by Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, 11 A. M. Luncheon in honor of Mrs. Roosevelt, 12:30 P. M.
After lengthy deliberations and discussions the Arab High Committee this evening decided unanimously to cooperate with the British Royal Commission of Inquiry on Palestine.

Madrid troops who have clung to positions in the Guadarrama Mountains since the civil war broke out were virtually cut off today from Madrid when Insurgents captured the heights of Mount Cumbre, dominating the highway to Escorial.

The story of a wild ride through Jersey with an armed 17-year-old boy, who said he had never driven before, at the wheel, was told last night by a Brooklyn mechanic who charged he had been kidnapped in his own car at Twenty-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue at 11:50 P. M. Tuesday.

Supreme Court Justice Faber handed down a decision yesterday in Queens denying to Charles G. Guth, largest stockholder in Loft, Inc., an order enjoining a proposed sale of 97,210 shares of Loft stock by Happiness Candy Stores, Inc., to the Phoenix Securities Corporation.

Archibald Fenner Brockway, secretary of the Independent Labor party, today announced that a new contingent of Britons, "all men of military experience," was about to leave for Spain to fight for the Leftist Government. Their number was not stated.

Burlap shipments from Calcutta to the United States and Canada in 1936 reached the highest level since 1929, according to figures received here yesterday by C. E. Rockstroh Co. The total for last year was 26 per cent greater than the shipments of 1935.

The Cunard White Star liner Franconia sailed last night with 385 tourists on her annual cruise round the world. Three hundred and twenty-five of them were booked for the entire 35,000-mile cruise, and the other sixty tourists from port to port.

The University of Pittsburgh downed Temple University, 32-28, in an Eastern Collegiate Conference basketball game tonight. The Owls never had the lead after the first few minutes, but kept close throughout.

Standardized forms devised by WPA workers for use in city departments are saving taxpayers here $150,000 a year, according to a report made public yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

Federal attempts to arrange for a joint conference between General Motors Corporation and the auto workers union struck several snags today, but they will be resumed tomorrow in an effort to halt a strike that threatens to make 135,000 of the company's employes idle by the end of the week.
The Board of Taxes and Assessment was petitioned yesterday to reduce real estate assessment in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn.
The Association of Sugar Producers today announced the appointment of committees to intensify efforts being made to improve living conditions and educational facilities for laborers.

Peering down disdainfully upon his lesser fellows, Glenn Echo September Sunshine of Dunesk, imported 15-pound blue Persian cat, smirked in satisfaction yesterday afternoon when he was chosen as the best entrant in the Atlantic Cat Club's thirty-fifth two-day show at the Hotel Taft.

With the air charged with rumors over a possible Franco-Turkish crisis in Southern Anatolia, President Kemal Ataturk, who has been in Istanbul for the last week, left unexpectedly by special train early this morning for Konyas.

Edward A. Metzler, 51 years old, of 1,703 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, who was convicted by a jury last Dec. 11 of sending a threatening letter through the mails, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the Brooklyn Federal Court to serve two years in a Federal penitentiary.
A tentative plan for the reorganization of the Warner-Quinlan Company, the third to come to the attention of the court, was described yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

The Spanish Consulate here announced tonight that all Germans captured by the Leftist forces on the Basque front in Northern Spain would be tried by courtsmartial and might be sentenced to death before firing squads.
Elizabeth Pyle, who at the age of 72 earned her master's degree in science at the University of Cincinnati, died at her home in Covington, Ky., today. She was 81 years old.

Miss Joan Blair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Insley Blair and greatgranddaughter of the late John I. Blair, founder of the banking firm of Blair Co., was married to Henry 0. Havemeyer Jr., this afternoon at Blairhame, the home of her parents here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis P. Le Buffe, in the presence of only near relatives of the couple.

The Western Auto Supply Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for March 9 at Kansas City to vote on a proposal to change each share of Class A and B common stock into three shares of new common stock, all of one class and having equal voting rights.
Bronx real estate transactions reported yesterday again included sales of several apartment houses. Two of the houses and a taxpayer were sold by the same operator, Charles Walzer.

A Federal investigation of charges by striking seamen that ships have left the port of Boston lacking their legal quota of trained seamen and officers has been started at the direction of Secretary of Commerce Roper, it was learned last night.

A technicality prevented today an immediate ban on the export of arms, munitions or other implements of war from the United States or any of its territorial possessions to Spain or to any other country for transshipment to Spain.

James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, became a member of the Executive establishment today with the announcement that he will fill a long-vacant post as "administrative assistant" until July 1 and thereafter will become a full-fledged Presidential secretary.

Only the signature of President Lazaro Cardenas was necessary today to bind Mexico to a "good neighbor" agreement providing for refunding the principal of direct government obligations on a basis of a peso for each dollar.
An increase of 93,000 telephones in service in December was reported yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. In December, 1935, the gain was 47,900 telephones.

Duncan MacInnes, first deputy controller and for years the city's fiscal wizard, was the guest of his colleagues of the Finance Department yesterday on his seventy-fifth birthday at a reception in the Municipal Building.
The Herald says that Governor James M. Curley, whose term expires tomorrow, will be appointed Governor General of the Philippines by President Roosevelt within a month.
An extra Kings County grand jury was impaneled yesterday at the request of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan to make a wide investigation of a number of rackets.

A series of prints of "The Beaufort Hunt," engraved more than a century ago by the English artist Henry Alken, brought $12,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the first appearance of this rare lot in an American auction room.
Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan Opera star, delighted the audience attending the third of the Fuld Hall music series in Fuld Hall here tonight by singing a group of German lieder.

Miss Mildred Grace Clinton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Mancil Clinton of Yonkers, N. Y., formerly of Hankow, China, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church to the Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gordon Priestley of London. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick.

In my Inaugural Address on Friday of last week, I reviewed the road the State of New York has traveled since I first assumed the duties and responsibilities of the office of Chief Executive. I sketched generally the objectives toward which the State should push in its march of progress.

Before a crowd of 17,630, the largest ever to witness a tennis match anywhere, Fred Perry of Great Britain signalized his entry into the professional ranks with a stunning victory over Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Calif., the world's professional champion, last night at Madison Square Garden.

ON Tuesday of this week the first and only unicameral State Legislature met in Nebraska. The States are often referred to as forty-eight laboratories for social experimentation; but their experiments in governmental structure have been singularly timid.

The report of the Manhattan Shirt Company for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, 1936, released yesterday, showed a net profit of $438,398 after depreciation, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges.

After prolonged debate, the house of delegates of the American Bar Association late tonight adopted a resolution urging the appointment of State judges. Delegates said the vote was about four to three.
I love to walk in Winter rain And know that Spring will come again, Though heaps of sodden leaves lie here To whisper that the dying year Is nearly dead. I love to walk With chin uptilted.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler approved yesterday a plan permitting trustees of a mortgage certificate issue to salvage the investment of certificate holders in a "sick" parcel of real estate by accepting mortgage certificates in payment for the property and retiring the certificates thus accepted.
Senator Wagner of New York was chosen by the Democratic Steering Committee of the Senate today to head the Senate Banking Committee.

Weems, Gettysburg guard, stood near mid-court in the closing minute of today's basketball game with the Naval Academy and neatly ringed the ball to break a 24-24 tie and give his team victory by 26 to 24. It was the only field goal Weems made in the battle.

The Federal Government was enjoined from collecting taxes on admissions to football games from the State-supported University of Georgia and the Georgia School of Technology in a ruling today by Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood.
St. Joseph's College recorded its sixth straight victory tonight, rolling up a 41-19 score on Loyola of Baltimore at Kenny Gymnasium.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress today evoked enthusiastic praise from many Democrats and approving comment from several Republicans, but there was some dissent from his views on the courts and the Constitution. Some of the comments follow:
A pair of fur gloves nearly proved disastrous for Frank Hawks today, causing him to damage his new plane Time Flies in an emergency landing at Rentschler Field.

The International Harvester Company and the Reo Motor Car Company, manufacturers of motor trucks, have agreed to conform to the labor standards set up under the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department stated today after the Tre?? ury Procurement Division had made awards to these companies.
The Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill was reintroduced today by its author in somewhat changed form.
The Socialist party made public here today a fifteen-point legislative program for the session of 1937.

Specific recommendations to speed the handling of criminal cases in six respects, without depriving defendants of substantial rights, will be made to Congress by the Justice Department, Attorney General Cummings said today in his annual report.

More than fifty friends and admirers of the late Theodore Roosevelt, most of them members of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Association, made their annual visit to his grave in Youngs Cemetery here this morning to mark the eighteenth anniversary of the former President's death.

In replying to a charge by H. M. Wilkie, president of the Board of Regents, that he had lost the confidence of those with whom he must deal as president of the University of Wisconsin, Dr. Glenn Frank said today:

Governor LEHMAN'S message to the State Legislature yesterday was in the tradition which he and his immediate predecessors have established at Albany. Its emphasis was heavily upon a program of progressive social legislation-not as a matter of class interest,
Pennsylvania rallied in the second half to defeat Penn State by 41-33 at the Palestra tonight before a crowd of 4,000 basketball fans. This was the fifth straight for the Red and Blue.

The executive board of the Eastern Racing Association rejected Walter E. O'Hara's bid for a controlling interest in the Suffolk Downs horse racing track and voted today to continue operation under its own management.

Regarding a report that she is in possession of jewels bequeathed to the Duke of Windsor by Queen Alexandra, Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson today said: "I have never been presented with these jewels, and formally deny these reports."
Australian cricketers won the third test match against England today by 365 runs, dismissing the English batsmen for a total of 323 runs in their second innings.
A man who died alone and helpless in a Bowery lodging house yesterday was found to have a bank account of $7,500 when detectives made an investigation of the death.
The Harvard and Yale Club teams continued their dominance over the others in the race for honors among the Class C teams in Group 1 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League yesterday.

Directors of the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., yesterday declared an interim dividend of 1s 6d a share on the ordinary shares of the company, payable on Jan. 30, to stock of record on Jan. 9, according to a cable to the Chase National Bank.
Senator Josh Lee of Oklahoma and Thomas P. Gore, the man he replaced, exchanged brief greetings in the Senate chamber just before Congress convened.
Mr. and Mrs. James Wilson Riley of Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenie Ward Riley, to Lieutenant Joseph Crook Anderson, U. S. A., of Memphis, Tenn.

The Apparel Industries InterTrade Bureau voted yesterday afternoon to "proceed at once in an effort to formulate and effectuate an arbitration arrangement with the National Retail Dry Goods Association through that organization's vendors' relations committee."

Despite strikes in automotive plants and the threat of further labor troubles, steel production was maintained this week at 79.5 per cent of capacity, unchanged from last week, according to Iron Age's summary, released yesterday.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Mutiny on the Bounty" was voted the year's best picture in the fifteenth annual nation-wide poll of more than 500 film critics conducted by The Film Daily.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. Jamieson of this community have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doreen Blanche Jamieson, to Robert J. Clarkson, son of Harry C. Clarkson of Boston and grandson of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Clarkson of Brooklyn, with whom he resides.
Winter came in earnest to the Western States today. A new cold wave, accompanied by snow in some States, spread over the Middle West and Rocky Mountain areas.

Producers of alcoholic beverages had total net sales in 1935 of $777,928,000, according to William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census, in a business census report on the distribution of manufacturers' sales.

William Leahy, 21 years old, of 707 Tenth Avenue, and Joseph de Cesare, 33, of 417 West Forty-ninth Street, were taken to Polyclinic Hospital early today after they had been shot from an automobile which passed them at Forty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue. Leahy,

203d St. (12-3309), n. s., 220 ft. e of Grand Concourse, 100x100; A. A. S. Realty Corp. to Morris Sopshin, 24 Van Zandt St., South Norwalk, Conn.; mtg., $150,000. 173d St. (11-2914), s. w. cor. Bathgate Av., 70x48: Fannie Siegel to 1,663 Bathgate Av., Inc., 160 Broadway. 162d St. (9-2444), s. w. cor. Grant Av., 55x 55; David Shapiro, executor, to Lillian S. Slushkind. 1,337 President St., Brooklyn.

Much of the crowing, cackling and honking of the 5,000 birds at the New York Poultry Show in the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, Fourteenth Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, was attribute yesterday to a pigeon that escaped from its cage Monday night and has not been recaptured.

Executors of the estate of Colonel H. H. Rogers, oil man, who died on July 25, 1936, were sued yesterday in the Supreme Court for $4,984 by the jewelry firm of T. 4.zeez, 561 Fifth Avenue. The plaintiff alleges that six pieces of jewelry were sent to Colonel Rogers's widow, Mrs.

Progressive shoe retailers are thoroughly in sympathy with enactment of legislation to establish minimum standards of hours and wages, Ward Melville, president of the National Council of Shoe Retailers, said today.

Smetana's opera, "The Bartered Bride," received its second performance of the current season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. A large audience gave its approval to the comical and emotional complications of the story.
The Bureau of Navigation released these orders today, dated Jan. 4: Joses, Lt. Cmdr. M., Medical Corps, the Dobbin, to Naval Air Station, San Diego, Calif.
Frankie Parker of Spring Lake, N. J., reached the quarterfinals of the fifth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament today after allowing only one game to his opponents.
The new White Plains Hospital, preliminary plans for which were announced last night at a dinner in Rye, will be as nearly noiseless as a hospital can be made, it was learned today.

The trial of Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Rio de Janeiro Mayor, accused of participation in the Leftist revolt of November, 1936, neared its close today. The verdict of the Security Tribunal is expected this month.
Many Akron motorists, their gasoline supply sharply curtailed by strikes, left their automobiles -in garages today and used buses and street cars.

Mayor La Guardia will toss up the first ball to open the Municipal Athletic League's basketball season at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory tomorrow night. Six games, each to consist of one fifteen-minute period, will be played.

The newspapers of Nov. 4 were proved right this afternoon. Franklin Delano Roosevelt of the State of New York and John Nance Garner of the State of Texas were elected President and Vice President of the United States.

Included in auction sales held yesterday in Manhattan were the two apartment buildings at 120 and 125 Riverside Drive. Together they occupy a plot 137.5 by 79.2 and are nine and twelve stories in height.
On the theory that an actor's name is his stock in trade, the Actors Equity Association has reserved to itself the right to pass on the names, real or assumed, used professionally by its members.
Two bequests of $40,000 each are left to Yale University in the will of Mrs. Ethel Boies Morgan, just admitted to probate here by Judge Harold L. Knapp.

Two Coast Guard boats proceeded early today to the assistance of the freighter El Occidente, reported afire in the Gulf of Mexico. The Coast Guard station here said the Kimball and Triton were already en route to the vessel. Other vessels prepared to go to the freighter's assistance.

Manhattan St. Nicholas Av., 224-6; 50xlO0; 171st North Corp., 12 E. 41st St., owner; Miller Goldhammer, architect; cost, $100,000. Bedford St., 46; 22.6x45; for 1-story repair shop; A. Boero, 37 1/2 Bedford St., owner; Rene Brugnoni, architect; cost, $4,000.
Four American Federation of Labor craft unions stepped into the dispute between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America, supported by John L. Lewis, today.

The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today the resignations of two department heads. Ed Falck. director of the division of rates and research, resigned to complete work on a thesis for his Ph. D. degree at Columbia University.
Frank H. Stevens, assistant treasurer and general purchasing agent of Warren Webster Co., heating system manufacturers of Camden, died at his home here last night in his fifty-fourth year.

Submerging Yale beneath a barrage of scoring shots, McGill University tonight monopolized the attack during three periods of clever hockey to win by 11-1 before 1,500 spectators in the New Haven Arena. This was an International Intercollegiate Hockey League match.

Father Charles E. Coughlin's weekly review, Social Justice, criticized John L. Lewis in an article today, referring to the "rebel" labor leader as an "unofficial spokesman of the government, although he represents less than 2,000,000 organized laborers. "
Lord Taylor yesterday joined the list of department stores to declare extra disbursements to stockholders with the voting of a special dividend of $10 a share on the cornmon stock. The action of the

An 11-week-old boy was saved from injury yesterday when his parents snatched him from his crib after the blankets had taken fire from an electric vapor lamp with which the infant's mother was treating him for a cold.

Miss Virginia Saunders Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Foster of the Oliver Cromwell, was married to William Roger Salomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy F. Salomon, also of this city, last night at the Gotham by the Rev. Dr. Isaac Landman of Brooklyn.

Night marriages at Westchester Gretna Greens struck a new snag today when Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme ordered a woman seeking an annulment on the ground she was married while intoxicated to produce in court the Harrison town clerk and justice of the peace who officiated at the ceremony.

The leasing of an additional 91,000 square feet of space in the building at 475 Tenth Avenue by the United States Treasury Department gives the Federal Government the complete occupancy of the structure, which is thirteen stories in height. The transaction was

Stockholders of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation adopted a resolution today recommending adoption of a plan of recapitalization to enable the corporation "to resume active participation in the automobile industry."
Sentiment for a constitutional amendment to cover the whole broad field of President Roosevelt's objectives in social legislation appeared to be increasing today in both Houses of Congress.

The Vatican today issued a statement about the Pope's health. It follows: "The Pope's condition, though it cannot be said to have improved in an absolute sense, nevertheless shows a tendency toward improvement. The Pontiff's mind continues to be as active and as lucid as ever. He remembers everything in its minutest details and in conversation often delights, especially in the afternoon, to go back to the days of his youth, even of his infancy.

Unseasonable weather conditions again have shattered the hopes of hundreds of skiers for a week-end in the open. Only one "snow train" will run. The New York, New Haven Hartford announced last night that one section of its Ski Meister train
The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the receipt of applications to list the following securities:

A new issue of $24,973,000 of Boston Metropolitan District 2 1/4 per cent bonds will be offered to the public today by a banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., following official award of the bonds yesterday by the trustees of the district.

William Hoffman, 44 years old, the jobless painter who was indicted two weeks ago on a second-degree manslaughter charge-in connection with the deaths of five persons in a boarding house fire at 273 West Seventy-third Street on Dec. 18, pleaded not guilty before Judge Collins in General Sessions yesterday.

Heavy buying of housing properties in the Bronx was accompanied yesterday by the sale of a large taxpayer containing fourteen stores. The taxpayer occupies a blockfront on Westchester Avenue, between Soundview and Stratford Avenues, and was sold by Reliance Equities, Inc., represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, to an investing syndicate formed by L. J. Phillips Co.

Damage estimated at $55,000 or more resulted from fire. this morning which leveled the Hall Boat Corporation boathouse at Hague, destroying two cabin cruisers and eighteen smaller boats stored for the Winter.
Dr. Glenn Frank was removed from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin tonight by a Board of Regents dominated by appointees of Governor La Follette.

Next week, when Secretary of State Hull returns from his good-will visit to South America to resume negotiation of reciprocal trade treaties with the nations of the earth, he will find that negotiation seriously menaced by the prevailing intent of Congress with respect to a neutrality policy. The menace is incidental, not direct or intentional; but it is there all the same.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the Port Authority, leader in civic, philanthropic and business matters and director-receiver for the Roxy Theatre, examined the motion picture industry for social awareness last night before Professor Frederick Thrasher's classes in film appreciation at New York University.
The Townsend National Weekly, organ of the old-age pension movement, was under attachment today as the result of a $2,600 suit filed by Charles Dalziel.

The New Amsterdam Casualty Company announced yesterday that it would offer to its stockholders 150,000 convertible preferred shares of the United States Casualty Company, a subsidiary, at $10 a share.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 6: Blanding, Major Gen. A. H., Chief of the National Guard Bureau, leave extended one day. Ruggles, Col. A., F. A., Philippines, to Presidio of San Francisco, Calif.

The first performance of this Metropolitan season of Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman," an interpretation of historic eloquence, was given as a special matinee yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings in Manhattan, issued his annual report yesterday showing that new construction and alteration plans in Manhattan rose about $11,000,000 in 1936 over the previous year. Plans were filed for 313 new

Manhattan's eminent position in indoor track, built up during the last five years, received recognition in the entry list of more than 500 athletes for the Columbus Council, K. of C., games at the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, tomorrow night.

At the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today the American Horse Show Association will hold its twentieth annual meeting. Delegates from member organizations all over the country will gather first this morning for the election of directors, to receive reports, claim show dates for the current year and transact such other business as may be presented.

Dr. James Alexander Miller, in his inaugural address last night as president of the New York Academy of Medicine, told an audience of physicians and surgeons that the medical profession "stands on the brink of more exact knowledge of metabolic disease, of respiratory affections, of numerous virus diseases, and even has hopes that, before long, dreaded cancer itself may yield up its secrets to the methods of modern research."
The State of California made public today its findings opposing release of Tom Mooney from prison on a writ of habeas corpus. The findings will be filed Monday with the Supreme Court.

Dry forces whipped into shape today a legislative program to be placed soon before the Legislature. Fred A. Victor, superintendent of the AntiSaloon League, said that bills are being drafted for two purposes:
While Chancellor Adolf Hitler was closely watching the outcome of a struggle for life by two mountain climbers near here, six days of perilous efforts to rescue them succeeded this afternoon.

Ready to begin installation of modern equipment with a $1,000,000 order for sixty cars, already placed with the St. Louis Car Company, the Los Angeles Railway Corporation's officials revealed today that complete motorization of the facilities was being effected through the estate of the late Henry E. Huntington, art patron and former president of the company.
President Roosevelt devoted the day chiefly to preparing material for messages to Congress on the budget and governmental reorganization.

Agitation for expansion of the WPA program, as against government plans for its retrenchment, was intensified yesterday with the announcement by the Trade Union Committee for the Continuation and Expansion of the WPA that a parade and mass meeting would be held tomorrow under its auspices to emphasize the committee's demand for a deficiency appropriation by Congress of $1,250,000,000 to continue the WPA until June 30.

Captain Francis J. Schaeffer of 160 Chatfield Road died this morning of pneumonia at Lawrence Hospital. He was 42 years old. He was commanding officer of the military police of the Twenty-seventh Division, New York National Guard. He went overseas during

The American Liberty League reported to Congress today that it received contributions of $441,380 last year, spent $518,123 and had to dip into a balance carried over from 1935 to make up the difference of $76,743.

Having lost 12,000,000 out of the [Pound]3,000,000 advanced by the banks in the past year, the British film industry is facing a grave crisis. According to The Daily Film Renter-the exhibitors' organ here-"the bubble has burst."

The educational bill that has been pending in Congress for several months was unanimously approved this afternoon by the House of Representatives without discussion. It will now go to the Senate, where it is expected to pass tomorrow, and will become law immediately with its signature by President Federico Laredo Bru.

The first Pan-American Press Conference, which will open at Valparaiso tomorrow, will bring together more than 150 delegates from American countries. President Arturo Alessandri is expected to inaugurate the first session in the Royal Theatre, Foreign Minister Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal assisting.
In Battersby's salesrooms in Dublin today one of the most beautiful parts of Killarney's famous scenic spots came under the auctioneer's hammer. This was the Dunloe

Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $2,302,865 in the week ended yesterday, according to the bank's weekly statement, issued today. Deposits of chartered banks increased $378.700.

The Columbia College faculty in an extraordinary session yesterday voted unanimously to accept the proposals of a specially appointed subcommittee on curriculum calling for a new two-year sequence in the humanities, revising the language and writing requirements and dropping the required freshman English course.
Adolphe E. Smylie, retired licorice manufacturer, died yesterday at his home, 333 East Fifty-seventh Street, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
Turpentine firm, 45c; sales, 24 barrels; receipts. 91 barrels: shipments, 225 barrels; stock, 31.594 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 857; receipts, 1,024; shipments, 5,546;stock, 75,014.

Two rear-steerer boats of the Musconetcong Ice Boat and Yacht Club have been selected to make that organization's bid in the initial race for the Eastern Championship Ice Boat Pennant of America, the new prize of the Rumson Country Ice Club for open competition.

The Robert Gair Company, Inc., has acquired the business, equipment and inventory of the Pa Pro Company, Utica, N. Y., and the Holyoke Fibre Box Company, Inc., Holyoke, Mass., it was announced yesterday by E. Victor Donaldson, president of the Gair organization.

Traffic through the Panama Canal in December, 1936, was lower than in the previous corresponding month of 1935, but revenue from July to December last year was greatly increased, according to a War Department survey made public today.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 0.8 point to 137.9 on Tuesday from 137.1 the Tuesday previous.

James A. Austin, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today at the conclusion of a hearing by the SEC that it had been shown that the Prince Whitely Trading Corporation was set up by the now defunct brokerage firm of Prince Whitely as a "device for speculating with other people's money."
John J. Ryan, one of the oldest civil service employes in term of service of the city, died on Wednesday night at his residence, 741 St. Ouen Street, the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

Harvey L. Williams of the Cape Cod Shipbuilding Corporation gave a luncheon yesterday in the Harvard Club, at which he showed the various boats that will be built this year at that organization's plant in Wareham, Mass., on Cape Cod.
The Rev. Alfred C. Church of Andover, once an assistant pastor of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church of Brooklyn, N. Y., died today in North Station. He was 65 years old.

Steel, motor and utility shares were features of strong and active market; turnover, 3,055,970 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds irregular, domestic corporation issues higher with rails strong; transactions, $21,824,400.

Walter (Death Valley) Scott's wife sued the mysterious gold prospector today for separate maintenance. Mrs. Ella Josephine Scott, whom the prospector wooed out of a New York candy store, has long realized, she said, that her husband would not keep his pledge to "settle down and raise a lot of babies."

As an aftermath of Ellsworth Vines' surprising defeat by Fred Perry before the largest crowd in tennis history at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night the possibility looms of another meeting between the two players in New York.

Germany today rejected the French and British proposals for immediate legislation to halt the influx of alien volunteers into the warring forces in Spain and returned the whole problem to the London non-intervention committee.
American Yvette Company, Inc., and Subsidiaries-Year to Aug. 31: Net loss after depreciation and other charges, $51,328, against $54,382 loss in preceding year.

Alan Campbell, Dorothy Parker. in 1 East End Av.; Dr. Daniel Catlin, in 1,148 5th Av., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.; J. Hamilton Coulter, duplex in 162 E 83d St., through Colny Realty Corn.: Mrs. Brenda T. Parsons, in 405 E.
A quarter-million armed men were reported today to have joined in a movement to create a great Communist State in Northwest China, with an American woman playing a spectacular role in the uprising.

Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, suave head of the live-poultry racket in New York, and David Diamonstone, president of the Chicken Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, Local 167, were arrested on charges of grand larceny yesterday by members of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's staff.

Magistrate Aurelio decreed in the Felony Court yesterday that because the police in a raid last Saturday on a printing establishment at 1,917 Third Avenue suspected a truckload of pads and paper slips were policy slips, that was not proof the Anti-Policy Law had been violated. He accordingly discharged

Robert H. A. Fleer, retired chewing gum manufacturer, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Overbrook in his seventy-second year. He was found slumped over the Mayo wheel of his automobile in the driveway adjoining the residence.

Hundreds of Catholic laymen and clergymen, representing Canada as well as most parts of this country, and many civic leaders and city officials attended a funeral service here today for James A. Flaherty, Past Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus.
Appointment of Tell Berna of Cleveland, Ohio, as general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association was announced here yesterday by C. R. Burt, president of the association. Mr. Berna,

DETROIT, Jan. 7.--The General Motors Corporation held out little or no hope tonight of an early settlement of the strikes which have thrown about 52,000 men out of work in its plants in various cities.

Modification of that section of the Motor Vehicle Law which makes it mandatory for the courts to revoke the licenses of drivers who fail to report injuries to animals caused by their driving was advocated yesterday by George M. Woolsey, president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Miss Peggy Cambie, daughter of Mrs. Charles Cambie and the late Mr. Cambie, was married to Viscount Carlow, son of the Earl of Portarlington, in Chelsea Old Church today. Mr. Cambie, for many years, was in the service of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, notably as London manager.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Morehouse of Mansfield Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann Morehouse, to William French Jones, son of Mrs. Frederick H. Jones, also of Darien, and the late Mr. Jones.
Dodd, Mead will publish next Wednesday the second Maxwell Anderson play of the season, "High Tor." The first was "The Wingless Victory," issued Dec. 24, the day following the Broadway premiere.
One of Japan's famous golden dolphins crowning the roof of the great castle in the city of Nagoya has been despoiled of fifty-eight of its solid gold scales, valued at 850,000 yen (about $242,000).
From an international competitive standpoint, the season of 1936 will go down in tennis history as disappointing to the United States because the Davis Cup was not regained. Nevertheless the margin

The Brooklyn Polytechnic quintet defeated the Webb Institute basketball team, 27-24, at the Tolentine High School gymnasium yesterday. The victors led at half-time, 11-5. William Donavan of the losers was high scorer with 8 points.
Paul J. Feuchtwanger, a member of the New York Curb Exchange, has been admitted as a general partner in Bruce, Lohr Stuart.

Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion, scored another victory in his comeback campaign by outpointing Joey La Faucia of Astoria in an eight-round feature bout last night at the Star Casino. Three thousand attended.

More than 500 ardent young Irishmen drawn from Dublin and the counties of Clare, Tipperary, Limerick and Kildare, acting under secret orders, converged on the little fishing village of Passage, in Waterford, last night.

Cincinnati, proud of its reputation as the "best-governed city," learned today that in the face of five years of depression it had reduced its gross general bonded debt by $14,000,000 since 1931 and had closed the year of 1936 "with substantial balances in all operating funds."

Former United States Senator W. Warren Barbour was elected chairman of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission at its organization meeting here today and James G. Robinson was named acting executive director.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
A sitdown strike of 650 members of the United Automobile Workers Union started today at the Walker Ajax Company, manufacturer of automobile accessories.

Walter Runciman, unsentimental and hardbargaining President of the Board of Trade, is sailing from Glasgow for the United- States aboard the liner Montclare tomorrow on what he describes as "a private visit." It is understood, however,

Police reinforcements were called out today as some of thousands who filed past the coffin of Brother Andre, "miracle man of Montreal," attempted to obtain as religious relics bits of the plain black gown in which he lay in state.

The 2-year-old fight for control of the Tennessean papers once published by Colonel Luke Lea, former Senator from Tennessee, ended on a wet sidewalk in front of Davidson County's temporary court house today when they were sold under the hammer to Paul M. Davis, Nashville banker and brother of Ambassador Norman H. Davis, for $850,000.
Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle and Rabbi Jonah B. Wise unveiled a bronze plaque of the late August V. Lambert, jeweler, yesterday morning at the Lambert Brothers store, Lexington Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the transfer of two of its memberships and the proposed sale of another, to be voted upon by the committee on admissions on Jan. 21.
Mrs. New bold Morris, who has been at the Pierre since closing Brookhurst, her Summer place in Lenox, Mass., gave a dinner last night at that hotel.

The women's division of the United Hospital Fund campaign reported yesterday that it had raised a total of $650,635. The reports of the various groups within the division were made at a meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, at which Mrs. William Woodward, chairman of the division, presided.

After a three-month struggle over a 1937 financial program for Philadelphia, the way was opened today for a balanced budget, and Robert C. White, City Controller, exacted a written pledge from members of the City Council that they would live within the proposed appropriations, totaling $76,635,383.

Mrs. Mary Chauvenet Holden, widow of Dr. Edward Singleton Holden, former president of the University of California, director of the Lick Observatory, and librarian at West Point, died on Wednesday at Florence, Italy, where she had resided since 1923, according to word received here yesterday. She was 92 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook denied yesterday a motion by the New York Stock Exchange to vacate an order requiring the Exchange to turn over $40,836 to Marcel Levy, receiver, for distribution to customers of the permanently enjoined German-American Securities Company.
The Duke of Windsor lunched at a hotel here today with former King Alfonso of Spain, who was returning from the funeral of Archduke Frederick in Hungary.

The American Bar Association's House of Delegates directed the association's ethics and grievance committee today to investigate the action of Circuit Judge Edward D. Black of Flint in enjoining strikers at two Fisher Body plants while he owned stock in the parent General Motors Corporation.
One of the recommendations in the Governor's message dealt with the present mortgage moratorium. He recommended that the State extend the Moratorium Law for another year, adding, however:
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," Frank Bohn. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Although the volume of trading was fairly small, the stock market reflected a more cheerful tone today. British Government issues were steadier, some of the securities recovering from their recent dullness.

Salvatore Spitale, underworld intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, today served notice on County Solicitor Robert R. Taylor that he would ignore Mr. Taylor's ultimatum giving him until tomorrow morning to leave Dade County.
When I first came to this country with a British team; in 1930, I as one of England's supposed "hopes," had to play in a team match against some of America's coming stars. Among them was a

Commercial aviation's first flying club car a new Douglas BC-3 transport plane purchased by United Air Lines, has arrived at the Chicago Airport after averaging 210 miles an hour on a 2,000 mile one-stop flight here from Los Angeles.

Members of the Rules Committee of the Board of Aldermen, in executive session in City Hall yesterday, discussed the resolution requesting relief from the Legislature to ease the housing crisis caused by enforcement of the Multiple Dwellings Law.

The 1,409 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $46,280,123,462 par value as of Jan. 1, had a total market value of $45,053,593,776, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Dec. 1, there were

Accused of wrecking with gunfire the Summer home of Frank C. Paine, naval architect and designer of the yacht Yankee, one-time candidate for defense of the America's Cup, David Durante, 16, and Arthur Sampson, 15, both of Boston, were held for trial here today in bail of $10,000 each.

A double bowling championship holder early in the century, William Cordes of 345 West Fourteenth Street died of a heart attack yesterday morning as he opened the alleys, of which he was co-partner, in the building at the same address. His age was 69.

While theatre and supper crowds sauntered along last night past the Adam Hat Store at 218 West Fortysecond Street, near Seventh Avenue, two young gunmen rifled the shop's cash register after forcing two clerks to remove their trousers and stand in a rear room.

Magistrate Aurelio was skeptical for a time in the Felony Court yesterday when 17-year-old Carroll Majors of Baltimore admitted that on Tuesday night he kidnapped a 58-year-old man in the victim's automobile from Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, after threatening him with a pistol, robbed him of a little more than $5, and three hours later released him at Hackettstown, N. J.
Governor Landon appealed today for the enactment by Congress of legislation to protect adult labor from the competition of children.

Cross Ruff, an inconsistent 5-year-old from F. H. Carpenter's stable, found a field he could beat today when he led six other $2,000 players in the Fair Grounds' feature of a mile and seventy yards. It was the second score in the colt's last seventeen starts.

Forced by the reluctance of copper and steel producers to respond to advertisements for bids, the Navy Deapartment in the past two days has bought "in the open market" two lots of copper totaling 400,000 pounds.

1. The German Government must, first of all, express its unhappy astonishment over the fact that the British and French Governments have considered it a necessary parallel with proceedings of the London non-intervention committee to address for a second time a special and direct appeal to other governments represented on this committee.
Siegel-Lyttle, Inc., manufacturer of women's dresses, has opened a new showroom at 1,400 Broadway. The firm was formerly at 1,384 Broadway.

Lumber production increased slightly last week, but allowance for the number of working days and the adjustment for seasonal variation caused the index to recede to 83.1 from 98.3, the figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 4, 1936, it was 77.4.

Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister, and Lady Marler are at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dixon Ewing have left their place in Bedford Village and will be at 340 East Seventy-second Street until April 1.

The last year was a profitable one for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Federal Reserve System as a whole, although not so profitable as was 1935, it is indicated in this week's reports of the system, which give effect to the year-end adjustments of surplus.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 7.--In the fifteenth century Groote Kerk, or Church of St. James, and in the presence of a brilliant gathering, the Crown Princess Juliana of Holland was wedded today to the German Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld.

Dr. Clellan Asbury Bowman, former president of Albright College, died today at his Winter home at Coral Gables, Fla., according to a message received here by Dr. J. Warren Klein, present head of the college. He was 75 years old.

THE big tennis party was "tops" every way except in the minor matter of the brand of tennis played by the headliners, Frederick John Perry of Merrie England and Ellsworth Vines of sun-kissed (advt.) California. The setting was top hole and the garnishings were top hat.

Villa del Sarmiente was the setting tonight for a dinner at which Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien were hosts. Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman gave a dinner at their home for Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran, Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr., Mrs. Lawrence A. Furlong and Clarence M. Chauncey.

A large tanker went aground 500 yards off Conimicut light house in Narragansett Bay tonight. Warwick police reported. The tanker could be seen from shore when the beam from the lighthouse nicked her up.

Chateau Gloria, an imposing mansion on Cap Ferrat on the Riviera, near Cannes, France, has been placed on the market by Mrs. Gloria Thompson, according to Pease Elliman, who have been appointed American agents.

Larry Kelley, all-America end on the Yale football team last year, said today he had "about decided" to play professional football. "I didn't think I would enter professional football some time ago, but I have just about changed my mind," he said.

A "1937 Almanac for New Yorkers, Compiled by Workers of the Federal Writers Project of the Works Progress Administration in the City of New York" was put on sale here yesterday by Simon Schuster, publishers, at 50 cents a copy, of which the government indirectly gets a nickel royalty.
Negotiations between Luli Deste, Continental screen star, and B. P. Schulberg were terminated abruptly today on the eve of her arrival in Hollywood.
Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., upset Frankie Parker of Spring Lake, N. J., the country's second ranking tennis star, in the quarterfinals of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament today.

Lou Ambers, lightweight champion of the world, will engage Enrico Venturi, holder of the European 135-pound crown, in a tenround bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although Ambers's title will not be at stake, the fight is an important one for him, since it may result in his having to fight his opponent of tonight in a championship struggle.

A first-mortgage loan of $1,350,000 at 4 1/2, per cent for ten years has been arranged with a savings bank by Charles F. Noyes Company, in conjunction with Riker Co., on the property at 927-33 Flatbush Av., running through to 21 Snyder Av., Brooklyn.
Awards to the highest bidders on forty-four issues of municipal securities pledged as collateral for public works loans were announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
A resumption of liberal purchases of cash wheat in the world's markets by the United Kingdom and various European nations sent prices soaring today.

After insisting all day that the United Automobile Workers Union must be recognized as the sole bargaining agency for all employes of General Motors Corporation, the union board of strategy late last night, during a conference with Governor Frank Murphy, dropped this demand as a prerequisite for entering a joint conference with the spokesmen for the employers.
Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and Bosworth, Chanute, Loughridge Co. were the successful bidders yesterday for $5,000,000 of trustee certificates of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company.

Salvatore Balbo of Italy threw Baboo Ali of Turkey in 53:17 of the feature wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night. The winner, weighing 185 pounds, employed a body hold preceded by a series of flying tackles to gain the fall. The loser scaled 182.

The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority yesterday reelected Frank C. Ferguson and Howard S. Cullman chairman and vice chairman, respectively, at their annual meeting at the Commerce Building. 111 Eighth-Avenue. They also re-elected John E. Ramsey general manager and Julius Henry Cohen general counsel.

Ruggero Vene will conduct the Nassau Philharmonic Society Orchestra at its second concert tomorrow morning at HempsteadL. I. Vlado Kolitsch, violinist, will be heard in a recital on Sunday evening at the Educational Alliance.

An attack on R. O. T. C. units in college as "training schools for war" and as working "an injustice on men who are forced to attend land grant colleges because of finances," by the National Student Federation of America, the members of which are supposedly able to ascertain the truth about R. O. T. C., reveals the distortion prevalent in these charges against our system of national defense.
Secretary Morgenthau dropped his bill offerings in the open market from $100,000,000 to $50,000,000 today.

Grace Moore, who is ill with influenza, has canceled her scheduled appearances at the Metropolitan Opera House for the present. Edward Johnson, general manager, received a letter yesterday from Miss Moore's physician, Dr. Joel J. Pressman of Los Angeles, stating that it is imperative for her to cancel her appearances at the Metropolitan next week as she is unable to undertake the trip East and to sing.

An attempt by an incendiary to burn the home of Police Chief Henry T. Copenhagen was balked early today by the chief's barking dog. A few hours later the chief received a scrawled card mailed to his office warning him to "look out for your face."

After an eternity of postponements "The Eternal Road" has finally arrived at the Manhattan Opera House, where it opened last evening. Let it be said at once that the ten postponements are understood and forgiven. Out of the heroic stories of old Jewish history Max Reinhardt and his many assistants have evoked a glorious pageant of great power and beauty.

As usual, Mrs. Emil Denemark was represented by the winner of the feature race today at Tropical Park. This time it was the 4-yearold colt Higher Cloud that carried the familiar canary and blue racing livery to victory in the Marlin Handicap, for Class C sprinters.
Influenced by marked activity in wholesale cotton goods quarters and buoyant outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced steadily yesterday and ended 1 point lower to 16 higher.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Trading was again fairly active on most classes. The lamb market was sharply higher late Wednesday and veal and calf hindsaddles were sharply higher yesterday.

Dr. James Chalmers, president of the Framingham State Teachers College from 1916 to 1930, died today at Melbourne, Fla., according to word received by friends here. Surviving are his widow, four sons and three daughters.

Mrs. Anna Crimmins Haggerty, active in Catholic philanthropies and widow of J. Henry Haggerty, oil company executive, died on Wednesday at her home, 137 East Seventy-first Street, at the age of 74. Mrs. Haggerty was a sister of the late John D. and Thomas E. Crimmins, building contractors. She was vice president of St. Rose's Settlement.
New York State's revenue from the sales of motor fuel last October was about $385,000 more than the same month in 1935, State Tax Commissioner Graves said today.
A new "contact" advertisement today signified dealings were in progress between the kidnapper of Charles Mattson and his family, but tight secrecy covered preparations for the climax.
The estate of Mrs. Charles S. Peabody, consisting of eight acres of land with a fourteen-room dwelling on Inningwood Road in New Castle, Westchester County, has been sold to Paul D. Merica

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Jan. 6 were announced today: Coler, Lieut. K. A., Intelligence Office, New Orleans Division, orders of Dec. 21 canceled. King, Chief Boatswain N. F., relieved from all active duty, to retirement. Ormsby, Boatswain A. N., issued permanent appointment as Boatswain (life saving).

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 6 unless specified: At Washington Yard: Owl, Jan. 7; Leary. Antares, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Kanawha, San Pedro to Pearl Harbor. Lexington, at Puget Sound Yard. Relief. sea to San Pedro.

Amid mutual shouts for order, hisses and an occasional parliamentary free-for-all, about 400 lawyers organized last night and elected temporary officers as a New York chapter of the recently launched National Lawyers Guild.

Influenza, pneumonia and bronchitis took 566 lives in the Greater London area this week, the Health Department announced tonight, and physicians said they believed the "flu" wave had not reached its peak.

Although declining 2.7 per cent from the corresponding six-day week of 1936, clearings made an exceptionally good showing for the five days of the opening week of 1937, which included the settlements incident to the first of the month.

Mrs. William T. Morgan has formed a church committee to organize the theatre party of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation for the benefit play, "The Three Bears," to be given Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey today will advance the price of Diesel fuel oil 20 cents a barrel to $1.85 at Boston, New York, Baltimore, Charleston and Philadelphia. At New Orleans and Baton

It will cost $11 per capital to conduct a special election in Caddo Sewerage District No. 1 next Tuesday. Twenty-five ballots have been printed for the referendum which will determine whether a $10,000 bond issue is approved for a sewage disposal plant for Rodessa, but the maximum number of votes that may be cast is two. J. H. W.

Arabs' red fezzes made their first appearance today in the court room of the Royal Commission, although no Arab evidence is expected until next week. Since the Arab boycott of the commission has been rescinded many extremist leaders even put in an appearance.

The President's Cup, awarded annually to the winner of a speed boat race held on the Potomac River near here, was given personallybyPresident Roosevelt today to the winner of last year's race, John M. Rutherfurd, owner and driver of Ma-Ja II.

Stockholders of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company are expected at their annual meeting tomorrow to ratify amendments to the bank's charter which will result in lessening the nominal control over the affairs of the institution now held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The number of cases of influenza and pneumonia showed an increase again yesterday, according to officials of the Department of Health. They denied that the weather was responsible for the prevalence of the diseases.

The chap who labors across the aisle tells me he has a week coming to him in February and that he's going to grab a plane for Florida and try to catch a sailfish. He has never been to Florida and he has never caught a sailfish.

Five thugs, four of whom were armed, escaped with $700 yesterday morning after a holdup in a meat market at 405 First Avenue, near Twenty-fourth Street. Their victims were forced into a large ice box while the thieves rifled the safe and a cash drawer.
