Fresh from triumphs in Palestine, the newly formed Palestine Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert abroad tonight in Cairo, conducted by Arturo Toscanini and repeating its earlier success before an audience of more than 1,500, who filled the hall to capacity.
Lieut. Col. Sir David Semple, founder and first director of the Pasteur Institute in India and an authority on the treatment of tropical diseases, died here today at the age of 80.

Columbia oarsmen worked out yesterday on Morningside Heights for the first time this season and there were fifty-two candidates on hand. Daily drills will be more or less informal until after semester examinations early next month.

Edward C. Foster, 49, who played with the Washington Senators as a third baseman twenty years ago, was found unconscious early today on a highway near here. Officers expressed the belief he had been struck by an automobile while searching for a garage.

Germany is loud in her praise of the United States' embargo on arms shipments to Spain. The American attitude is compared favorably with that of all other nations, and regret is expressed only that the present definition of neutrality was not adopted twenty years ago.

Moving upward for the third consecutive year, the combined sales of department, dry goods and specialty stores in this country in 1936 showed a gain of 11.8 per cent over 1935, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

For some days the European stage has seemed more like a phantasmagoria than a regular production. Every few minutes the setting is entirely changed. New actors suddenly appear or old ones assume a novel role. Through it all, Spain continues to be the central figure, looming through a kind of fog. Concerning the actual military situation in the Peninsula, there is a great dearth of exact knowledge. No one seems to know precisely

Illness caused two substitutions in the Metropolitan's second production of "Rigoletto" for the current season last night. Nino Martini, who was to have made his first appearance of the season in the role of the Duke, was stricken with the grippe. He was replaced by Frederick Jagel.

Team competition in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's Group I tightened yesterday when the Jackson Heights Squash Club was defeated for the first time and three teams moved up to within one match of the leader.

Harry J. Althouse, retired advertising man and father of Paul Shearer Althouse, Metropolitan opera tenor, died at his home here today after a three months' illness. His age was 65. Mr. Althouse for many years was head of the advertising office of the old Kline, Eppihimer Co. department store.

The Secret Political Police, the most taciturn National Socialist institution, issues from the pen of its director, Dr. Werner Best, an apology and frank confession of its character. The document appears as a booklet published by Minister of Justice Hans Frank.
236th St. (13-3416), n. w. cor. of Riverdale Av., 128x94; Interurban Apartments. Inc., to 236 Riverside Realty Corp., 122 E. 42d St.

Nearly 3,000 maritime strikers held a meeting last night at 66 East Fourth Street that lasted five hours and roared their approval of Joseph Curran, chairman of the local strike committee, after he had demanded that charges of incompetence against him, which he said had been whispered along the waterfront, be brought into the open.

Jewelry valued at $6,025 and $200 in cash were stolen from the safe of the Hotel Ritter on Madison Avenue here between last midnight and 8 o'clock this morning, it was reported to the police today. Herman Kirschbaum, manager of the hotel, discovered the theft when he began work this morning.

ALPINE SHOES, INC., 780 E. 138th St.Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of about $31,000. Petitions Filed-By NAT BLANK, chauffeur, 2,161 Barnes Av. -Liabilities $1,221, no assets. GENERAL STATIONERY CO., INC., 681 8th Av.-No schedules filed. H. WILSON HOFFMAN. salesman. Pelham Manor.-Liabilities $13,000, no assets. PHILIP KLEINMAN, manager, 2,911 Barnes Av.-Liabilitles $4,730, no assets except insurance. EDWARD LEHANE, clerk, 460 E. 145th St.-Liabilities $329, no assets except insurance.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Louise Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dunn of Tenafly, N. J., to John Randolph Rutherford of this city and Chicago, which will take place here next Thursday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension.

The first week of the new year shows a gain in engineering construction awards for private work, but a loss for public work, as compared with the preceding week, and a loss in the total amount of awards in both classifications, according to The Engineering News-Record.

A brisk advance in secondary railroad bonds which carried prices up fractions to more than 4 points in heavy volume was the feature in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A generally better tone was evident. The upward movement, however,

The will of Dr. Tracy Farnam, who died suddenly in New York City Dec. 30, made his brother, Thomas W. Farnam, associate treasurer and controller of Yale University, chief beneficiary of his estate, it was revealed today in Probate Court.

The National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D. C., under the direction of Hans Kindler, its conductor, will play the official concert on the Inauguration Day program of Jan. 20, when President Roosevelt begins his second term.

The Marquis Melchior de Polignac and Charles Millard, members of the Franco-American committee for the Paris Exposition, arrived yesterday on the French liner Lafayette to tour the United States and invite Americans to participate in the exposition, which will open next May.

" The Eternal Road," which opened last night at the Manhattan Opera House after ten postponements, had been more than three years in preparation since its production was originally proposed by Meyer W. Weisgal, co-producer, to Dr. Max Reinhardt.

The Brooklyn College freshman basketball team defeated the Nassau Collegiate Center, 28-17, at Lawrence Gymnasium yesterday. Lou Lubin, former James Madison star, set the scoring pace for the victors with 8 points.

The Postoffice Department had a total deficit of $88,316,324.29 in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1936, more than $22,000,000 greater than in the previous year, when it was $65,807,950.73, according to the department's annual report made public today by Postmaster General Farley.

The most extensive building activity in the Greater Miami area since the boom of 1925-26 appeared somewhat in jeopardy today after a deadlock developed between union painters, most of whom are reported on strike, and the Master Painters Association.

Rejecting a proposal by a group of interested insurance companies, individual holders of Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville (Monon Route) first and refunding general mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1966 voted yesterday to be represented in the company's bankruptcy proceedings by an independent committee.

A. L. Miller, assistant general passenger agent of the New York Central Railroad, was elected president of the General Eastern Passenger Agents Association of New York at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday. Other officers elected were:
The New York University freshman basketball team scored its seventh consecutive victory yesterday afternoon by turning back George Washington High School, 65-21, on the Violet court.

Retail food costs showed a small increase between Nov. 17 and Dec. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average as 100, was 82.9 on Dec. 15, compared with 82.5 on Nov. 17, and 82 on Dec. 17, 1935.

Emmet Crozier defeated Phil Meise, 150 to 96, in thirty-five innings, while Bruno Klerings vanquished K. Ohashi, 150 to 93, in thirty-six frames, in Class C 18.2 balkline tournament matches at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

After Mayor La Guardia and other city officials had made an inspection of the stage. "The Eternal Road," Meyer Weisgal's production under the direction of Max Reinhardt at the Manhattan Opera House in West Thirty-fourth Street, was allowed to open last night.

A program to organize the literary field on a trade-union basis, with a closed shop in all publishing houses and on magazines and union pay for all manuscripts as the objective, was announced last night at a reorganization meeting of the American Writers Union at its headquarters, 812 Broadway.

Miss Alison Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace and a granddaughter of the late William R. Grace, one time Mayor of New York and founder of W. R. Grace Co., was married to John Frederic Byers Jr. this afternoon at The Crossroads, home of her parents here. The Rev. Thomas J. Delihant of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, New York, performed the ceremony.
Joseph Bolognia, 24 years old, and Theodore di Donne, 31, were put to death at Sing Sing prison tonight for the murder of Edwin Esposito in a Brooklyn hold-up in 1935.

MONTREAL, Jan. 7 (AP).--The Montreal Canadiens turned back a Toronto challenge to their supremacy in the National Hockey League's International Division by downing the Maple Leafs, 4 to 1, tonight before 6,500 fans.

Duquesne University will tune up for its game with Long Island University tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden by meeting Villanova tonight at Philadelphia. The Dukes will arrive in New York tomorrow morning. Ohio State,
Dr. Claire L. Straith of Detroit called facial disfigurement today an even more tragic by-product of automobile accidents than sudden death.

It is interesting now to recall that once before, and in circumstances more dramatic than those which marked his message to Congress on Wednesday, the President affirmed his faith that the problems of modern democracy can be solved within the existing framework of the Constitution.

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 20, 1934.
A scathing indictment of the inadequacy and inefficiency of airplanes in the British Air Force was made today by C. G. Grey, editor of the technical publication Aeroplane.
Pope Pius XI has conferred the rank of domestic prelate upon two priests of the Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday.

Miss Katharine Frances Pardee daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Pardee of Hazleton, Pa., was married to James Lindsay Kirkpatrixk of Pittsburgh yesterday in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George A. Buttrick, the pastor, in the presence of the families.

The Treasury issued last night an urgent, temporary ordinance tightening the exchange control regulations, designed to strengthen the yen by controlling imports. The weakness of the yen has been giving anxiety recently and the government's action confirms the impression that banks would not be able to hold it at its present level if free importation were permitted.

A white-hackle gamecock, adjudged the best in the New York Poultry Show Wednesday, was choked to death last night after it had been taken from its cage at the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, Fourteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, where the show is in progress.
John H. Thom, vice president and director of the Standard Accident Insurance Company, died on Monday at Melbourne, Fla., at the age of 77. Funeral services were held yesterday at Detroit, his home.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Wholesale prices in the week ended on Jan. 2 continued their upward is climb, begun early in November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics an- b nounced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average is 100, rose to 84.7 from 84.1 the preceding a week, and compared with 80.9 a year ago.

JAMES HARVEY ROBINSON, who died about a year ago, was best known outside professional historical circles as the author of a cogent and extraordinarily popular volume entitled "The Mind in the Making." Among his literary effects were found sufficient quantities of material to make up another book for the general reader. It is this material that Harry Elmer Barnes has edited into "The Human Comedy" (Harper, $3).

Nine American-owned horses, five of which have raced in the United States, were listed among the sixty nominations posted today for the ninety-ninth running of the classic Grand National Steeplechase over Aintree's testing course of four and a half miles on March 19. Only fifty-four were named last year.
LONDON, Jan. 7.--The National Provincial Bank reported today for 1936 a profit of 1,670,173, an increase of 1,004,736 over 1935. The dividend was unchanged at 15 per cent.

New England: Cloudy, with snow, sleet, freezing rain, then warmer over north and central portions; cloudy, occasional rain and warmer, with thawing temperatures over central and south portions. New York State:

Ernest Ackerman, 65, for thirty-three years a motorman for the Cleveland Railway Company, stepped forward today as the first man in Cleveland and maybe the first in the country, to apply for his social security old-age pension. Ackerman will make a net profit of 12 cents.
Mrs. Adelaide Hitchcock Brown, widow of Archer Brown, philanthropist and author of "Top or Bottom," died today at her home here. She had celebrated her eightieth birthday on Tuesday.

Lucienne Bloch, WPA artist who assisted Diego Rivera on his Rockefeller Center frescoes, will speak on murals before the Hunter College Art Club at noon today. This is the third in a series of five WPA art lectures being given under the supervision of the-Lecture Service Division of the WPA Federal Art Project.
The Brooklyn Trust Company in its report for Dec. 31 shows deposits of $124,458,495 and total assets of $140,238,349, compared, respectively, with $119.240,808 and $135,163,206 on Sept. 30, 1936.

The Thomas Jefferson quintet won an uphill battle with Franklin R. Lane scoring 30 to 28, in overtime, at the victor's gymnasium yesterday to move into a tie for first place with Alexander Hamilton in the Brooklyn Division I P. S. A. L. basketball tournament.

Edwin Bradway, sheet-metal contractor and husband of Mayor Doris W. Bradway of Wildwood, was arrested here today on a charge of aiding illegal voting in the Nov. 3 election that gave William C. Hunt, Republican, a 437vote majority over Jesse D. Ludlam, Democrat, for State Senator from Cape May County.

Hogs were in active demand today, with prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. Big packers were aggressive buyers on the advance, paying up to $10.50 for the best, compared to $10.40 yesterday.

The French liner Lafayette last night from Havre and Southampton with 243 passengers, including two ballet groups, the Viennese Boys Choir and several concert musicians who will make Winter tours of the United States.

Standard Gas and Electric Company Earnings of the Standard Gas and Electric Company's subsidiaries for the year ended on Nov. 30, except in the case of Northern States Power Company, which reported for the year ended on Oct. 31, follow:

Frank F. Walker, president of the Bond Club of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee to supervise publication of "The Bawl Street Journal," which is issued by the club each year in connection with its annual field day.

Off and on yesterday there appeared to be enough endless bickerings between exhibitors in the National Motor Boat Show, many of them firms from distant cities, and New York labor union delegates to threaten serious delays, if not a postponement, of the opening scheduled for tonight at 7 o'clock.

Mrs. Rosa M. Thomas of Hollywood declared yesterday morning at a hearing before Referee Jeremiah F. Connor that her adopted son, Robert E. Thomas, 28-year-old actor, was the son of May Yohe, internationally known actress of the Nineties, who is now Mrs. John Smuts. She said the child was born "about" Oct. 1, 1908.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,481,000,000, a decrease of $37,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

Another defeat was chalked up against the New York Americans last night. Engaging the world's champion Detroit Red Wing sextet at Madison Square Garden, Red Dutton's hapless crew absorbed its seventh successive setback, yielding to the Automobile City skaters by the score of 4 to 2.
Improvement in business conditions this year by 10 to 15 per cent was predicted today by the directors of the National Association of Credit Men at their annual meeting.
The Theatre Guild made known yesterday that next season will bring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in "Amphitryon," as adapted by S. N. Behrman from the French original of Jean Giraudoux.

Norris Albert Huse, executive assistant to the general manager of The Associated Press, former newspaper publisher and contract bridge authority, died at 10:30 o'clock last night at the New York Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 54 years old.
Charles Henderson, Governor of Alabama from 1915 to 1919 and one of the State's wealthiest men, died here tonight of influenza at the age of 77.

Charging that he was induced by another. false representations to sell for $4,000 a Franz Hals painting worth $100,000, Arne Quisling has brought suit in Supreme Court for $96,000 damages against three art dealers. Papers in the suit were filed yesterday.

In an account of the neutrality resolution debate in the Senate, published under a Washington date line in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, Senator William E. Borah at one point was quoted as having said: "I am more desirous of cooperating with Great Britain than I am with Italy."
Hundreds of telegrams were said by the White House officials today to have been received by President Roosevelt on his message to Congress. All were reported to have been favorable.
CATHERINE DE' MEDICI AND THE LOST REVOLUTION, by Ralph Roeder. (Viking, $3.75.) A biography by the author of "The Man of the Renaissance."

Unemployment in automotive plants of General Motors Corporation mounted slowly last night toward the 135,000 which William S. Knudsen, executive vice president, predicted would be out of work by the end of the week.

Automobile plant shutdowns, closing mills at some of the steel centers, have not reduced activity so far this week in the plaits of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, largest producers in the Pittsburgh area.
Earnings of the Federal Reserve Banks in 1936 amounted to $37,898,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today on the basis of preliminary returns. Of these earnings,

In their third and final competition of the season, held on the Junior League courts last night, the women's team again was vanquished by the men at squash racquets, 6-1, with Miss Barbara Williams of the Rockaway Hunting Club the lone feminine victor.

Jose de Capriles of the University Fencers Club last night scored one of the big surprises of the new year in fencing by emerging triumphant in the senior individual foils competition which was held at the Salle Santelli under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

Construction of a causeway and tunnel or a bridge across the Hudson River between the villages of Nyack and Tarrytown was characterized today as "an expensive proposition and inadvisable financially" by two of the three members of the Bridge Authority created by the last Legislature to study the proposal.
Representative Mary T. Norton of New Jersey called for cheaper cosmetics for American women today. "Lipstick, perfume and the like," she said, "were once a luxury. Times have changed.

Worn and all but forgotten indictments for treason against General Robert E. Lee and thirty-two other leaders of the Confederacy were uncovered at the postoffice here today by F. B. Morris, a WPA Archives Project worker.
Horace Binney, one of the earliest of Newport's Summer residents, died today at his home in Boston in his seventy-seventh year, according to word received here.

Edward R. Johnston of counsel for 3,800 stockholders of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, said tonight that his attitude on an appeal from a Federal court decision in favor of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would not be affected by payment of the Dawes family's liability for stock.

After three postponements, Frank H. Innes, dean of the Richmond County Bar Association, was sworn in yesterday as District Attorney of Staten Island, upon the delayed arrival of his certificate of appointment. He succeeded Thomas J. Walsh, who was elected to the municipal court.

With the University of Iowa alumni seeking his services, Howard Jones has asked the University of Southern California for a new football contract to replace the one expiring at the end of the 1937 season.
Joe Cambria, Baltimore baseball man, said today he expected to acquire an interest in the Toronto International League Club and that if he did, "the club positively will remain in Toronto."

A conference of railway management and labor called by President Roosevelt recently in an effort to promote agreement on employes' old-age pensions adjourned today after a discussion of "matters of mutual interest," but without reaching any "final conclusions."

Valuable additions to the collections of the Library of Congress and establishment of an endowment fund of $100,000 to provide for an annual series of concerts were announced today by Herbert Putnam, librarian, in his report for the fiscal year 1936.
Charles McCabe, Internal Revenue Collector, dug into today's mail, found a $126,000 check for payment of income tax, several months in advance, and came up with the assertion:

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, returned last night to Carnegie Hall and to an audience that applauded and cheered the magnificent performances. The sheer splendor, fullness and brilliancy of the orchestral tone would have been enough to have delighted connoisseurs, outside of qualities of masterly interpretation.
Harvard's skaters played brilliantly tonight to defeat the University of Toronto in an overtime International Intercollegiate Hockey League contest, 5 to 4, at the Boston Arena.

American as well as British extile exporters will benefit from tariff reductions to be announced at the session of the Canadian Parliament which opens Jan. 14, it has been learned. British manufacturers of cotton textiles received certain preferences under the Ottawa agreements of 1932 and these were increased in last year's budget. The yare to be further

Newbold Noyes, author of a series of recent newspaper articles dealing with Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, made public last night an exchange of cablegrams purporting to show that Mrs. Simpson was grateful to him for the articles about her.

ALBANY, Jan. 7.--Strong pressure was being brought to bear on Irving M. Ives tonight to withdraw from the race for Speaker of the Republican - controlled Assembly after four more ballots today revealed a further loss of his strength.

Declaring that many developments in business have been carried on at the wrong time, Chapin Hoskins, a director of the American Management Association, last night suggested that management needs two entirely separate sets of policies, one providing for a period of improvement and other for a period of decline.

A contention by an engineer of the Federal Communications Commission today that the American Telephone and Telegraph toll-line system was "overbuilt" brought a company reply that the network was necessary to speed up long-distance telephone connections.
The Insurgents tonight announced the capture of Pozuelo de Alarcon and Humera, about three miles west of Madrid, and declared they had a virtual strangle-hold on the capital.

The plant of the Blue Dale Dress Company at Archbald was closed today and will not be operated further, as the result of a decision handed down recently by the New York courts. Officials made the announcement today when they dismissed sixty employes.

D. S. Milford, English schoolmaster who holds the British open racquets championship as well as the amateur title, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic to play for the world's championship in the sport.
The marriage of Mrs. Gertrude Marion Casey Dennis to Governor James M. Curley took place this morning at a nuptial mass in St. Mary's Chapel of Boston College.

In an address last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Plaza, given by the Pilgrims of the United States, Sir Herbert M. Marler, Canadian Minister to the United States, paid tribute to the leaders who had helped to maintain the friendliness between the two nations. He contrasted these conditions with the relations between nations in other parts of the world.
The Bendix Products Corporation laid off more than 450 workers here today. Walter J. Buettner, vice president and treasurer, explained that the lay-off had been caused by automotive strikes.

Her flag at halfmast, the twenty-ton North Sydney fishing schooner Percy F. Russell reached port today to report the loss of one seaman and the rescue of another in one of the worst gales to whip the Cape Breton coast in years.

Fear that Harvard's "athleticsfor-all" program was threatened by decreasing football gate receipts today prompted the student council to draw up a resolution calling for a thorough study of the university's extensive sports program.
Secretary Wallace followed President Roosevelt's course today in refusing to accept certain interpretations placed upon the Constitution by the Supreme Court. In announcing an

Former Governor and Mrs. Curley, accompanied by a wedding party of relatives and friends, arrived at Grand Central Station yesterday shortly after 9:30 P. M. Mr. and Mrs. Curley registered at the Hotel Biltmore, where they will stay until 6 o'clock tonight, when they will sail for Nassau aboard the Britannic.

From time to time physicians report numerous cases of what may be colds or influenza to the city's Department of Health. The number rises in two or three weeks to a peak and then as rapidly subsides. The curve indicates plainly whether or not the outbreak was one of influenza-after the event.
The Seventy-fifth Congress has its own genuine little Corsican. He is the Farmer-Laborite Representative from Minnesota,

" Shovel leaners" in the ranks of WPA workers were defended yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. She said that although some of those employed on Federal projects "are no good and never will be," many others are obviously so unsuited for certain types of manual labor that "it is no wonder, they lean on their shovels."

At a moment of increasing anxiety over the civil war and foreign intervention in Spain, the British Admiralty quietly announced tonight that it was sending virtually the entire Home Fleet into the Western Mediterranean soon on its annual Spring cruise.

Drastic changes in the executive branch of the Federal Government, including a single six-year term for President, were advocated last night at the first of the America's Town Meeting of the Air gatherings for 1937, in Town Hall, under the joint auspices of the League for Political Education and the National Broadcasting Company.

Subzero cold and heavy snowfalls were prevalent in wide areas of the West today. The heaviest snowstorm in twenty years burdened Arizona. Motorists, turned back because of impassable highways, crowded Gallup (N. M.) hotels.
Any citizen planning to cut the corners on his income tax return should beware the spite of neighbors, discharged office help or business rivals.

Government officials here were dismayed today but hardly surprised by the German and Italian replies on Spain. They had expected a temporizing answer from Berlin and Rome and they have received it. Both Germany and Italy have evaded the main point raised by the Anglo-French appeal of Christmas Eve, which called for immediate action to check the flow of fighting men to Spain.
Miss Alice Gillen, a resident of New York City for more than eighty years, died here today at the home of her niece, Mrs. A. J. Grenet, at 19 Clubway. Her age was 98.

Mrs. Maude Robinson, a British subject who, according to Department of Justice investigators, figured in the famous "Mr. A." blackmailing case in London and Paris in 1924, was released in $500 bond from Ellis Island yesterday pending a final decision by the Department of Labor as to whether she shall be deported.
A very intense earthquake, the location of which was not definitely determined, was reported yesterterday from seismograph stations in various parts of the world, according to The Associated Press.

Frank Gardner Smith, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Smith, Frank Co., 200 Fifth Avenue, which he helped to form in 1932, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Hotel Duane, 237 Madison Avenue, after a brief illness. His age was 57.

Two apartment houses, six and seven stories in height, and four five-story buildings with a combined frontage of 106.9 by 127.5 feet, at 2,731-33-37 Broadway and 250-256 West 105th Street, southwest corner, were sold in foreclosure proceedings yesterday to the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company in rehabilitation, as plaintiff, on a bid of $5,000 above a mort??ae of S380,000.

Withstanding a spectacular lastperiod rally by the Tiger skaters, the University of Montreal hockey team won an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game from Princeton, 2-1, in the Baker Rink tonight.

General John Ross Delafield, a member of the Hudson River Conservation Society, asked yesterday afternoon that steps be taken to save Mount Taurus from being furother scarred by quarrying that is marring the scenery of the Hudson River near West Point.

Dr. Herbert Newhard Shenton, Professor of Sociology and head of the department at Syracuse University, died of a heart attack yesterday in the headquarters at 415 Lexington Avenue of the International Auxiliary Language Association.

The Sutherland Paper Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of the election of William Race as treasurer, succeeding W. A. West. The Virginia Electric and Power Company has informed the Exchange of the death of Herbert W.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 7.--The smoldering feeling among local automobile workers over the closing of General Motors plants by less than 1,000 striking members of the United Automobile Workers of America came to the surface here today and as a result a tense situation grips this industrial center tonight.

Manager Bill Terry, concluding his brief mid-Winter visit to New York which, among other things, saw him help install Travis Jackson as manager of the Giants' new farm in Jersey City, left yesterday after a rush and a flourish that barely left him time to catch his train.
Two more motor truck owners were arraigned in the Felony Court yesterday on charges of hauling alleged stolen coal into this city from mines in the Pennsylvania anthracite regions. They were Anthony
District employee representatives of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation tonight ousted as their chairman Elmer J. Maloy, champion of the John L. Lewis drive to unionize steel.

The interests of organized skiing will be concentrated on the highly important meeting of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's board of directors, slated for tomorrow night at the Hotel Kimball, Springfield, Mass.

A pledge to make a donation to a hospital campaign fund without any consideration to the donor is not enforcible, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook declared yesterday in dismissing a suit brought by the I. I. Holding Corporation to collect $5,000 pledged in 1929 by I. Gainsburg, attorney, to the Beth Israel Hospital Association, Stuyvesant Park East.

A robust schedule of twenty-eight games, with no fewer than seven major league clubs supplying most of the opposition, has been drawn up by Manager Burleigh Grimes for the Dodgers' Spring training campaign, it was announced yesterday.

New York insurance agents and brokers have formed a committee under the chairmanship of Bennett Ellison of Hoey Ellison, to distribute $200,000 of World's Fair bcnds in the campaign to finance pre-fair expenses, it was announced yesterday at a meeting at the Empire State Club.

70th St., 407-409 E., 50 by 55.4; Ungber Realty Corp. to Chas. Bock, 218 E. 79th St.; mortgage, $6,000 ($11.50). 67th St., 240 W., 25 by 100.5; Louis Gonzales to Julia Martin, 836 9th Av.; mortgage $15,950 and purchase money $1,350. Waverly PI.. 156, 22.2 by 97.9; Ray Parofi to Hera Realty Corp., 156 Waverly Pl.; purchase money $13.000 (50 cents).

Turkey may withdraw from the League of Nations unless she obtains a favorable settlement of her dispute with France over administration of the Syrian cities of Antioch and Alexandretta, it was reported here tonight.

David Griffith Colwell, Yale fullback, has won the Class of 1904 Ledyard Mitchell punting prize, it was announced tonight by Malcolm Farmer, chairman of the Yale Athletic Association. Colwell is a junior and is from Loveland, Colo.

A comprehensive census of unemployment was urged yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, when it adopted a resolution of its executive committee at a membership meeting in the chamber's headquarters, 65 Liberty Street. Richard W.
1st Av., w. s., 80 ft. n. of 52d St., 20x63.10x irreg.: Effkay Associates, Inc.. to Guaranty Trust Co., trustee, to Eleanor A. McGill Mayor, purchase money; five years at 4 to 5 per cent; $16,000.
The Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Lieutenant Richard Aidworth, manager of Newark Airport, by an executive order of President Roosevelt, it was disclosed here today.

" Moonshining" still thrives in Kentucky, the leading liquor-producing State, if a report of the alcohol tax unit is any criterion. In 1936, the Federal Bureau reported, it seized in Kentucky 665 illegal stills, an

Dr. William Squires, for forty-two years a Professor of Philosophy, Logic and Psychology at Hamilton College, three times a candidate for the State Assembly and leader in education fields, died this morning following a three weeks' illness. He was 73 years old.
Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, urged the State's citizens today to "become State-minded" and buy "homegrown" farm products.

Lawrence (La La) Mullins, one of the gang that looted the shop of Barney's Clothes, Inc., of $10,000 in cash last Saturday night, collapsed on the police line-up platform yesterday after he admitted he toook part in the robbery.

A copy of Edward Orme's "British Field Sports," a rare coloredplate sporting book published in London in 1807-08, was sold for $5,800 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of a part of the library of Fitz Eugene Dixon. Mr.

American friends of Turkey and admirers of President KEMAL ATATURK are unwilling to credit the current rumors from Paris and Istanbul that he contemplates forcible seizure of the sanjak (district) of Alexandretta in Northern Syria, or even the threat of such a coup, in order to compel France to accept the Turkish view of the future status of that strategic area.

The Wesleyan ski team has elected Albert E. Van Dusen of Syracuse, N. Y., captain and Alan H. Thorndike, New York City, as manager, it was announced today. The team will be coached by Payson T. Newton.
General Abel Davis, president of the Chicago Title and Trust Company and World War military leader of an Illinois troop, died at his home here tonight of a complication of ailments. His age was 62.
Francis P. Murphy, shoe manufacturer, became the Governor of New Hampshire today. He is the first Roman Catholic to become Chief Executive.

The Palestine Economic Corporation, with its predecessors, the Palestine Cooperative Company and the Reconstruction Committee, has since 1922 issued loans through subsidiaries aggregating $17,500,000 to help urban and rural groups in Palestine to become self-supporting, it was reported yesterday by Bernard Flexner, chairman of the board of directors.
German activities in Spanish Morocco today caused a special meeting of French military technicians to be held at the Foreign Office.

Two more important art purchases by Andrew W. Mellon for the collection he will give to the nation were disclosed yesterday. The former Secretary of the Treasury not only has offered his art collection, valued at $19,000,000, to the nation as the nucleus for a national gallery of art, but also is ready to pay for the construction of a museum building in Washington and to endow the collection.
The bodies of Lieut. Col. James J. Fitzgerald and his 45-year-old wife, Florence, were found last night in the living room of their Hull home in what police said was a case of murder and suicide.

Crawford Burton, amateur steeplechase rider, who testified last Tuesday in Federal court that fellow-members of the New York Stock Exchange had given him an unmerciful "ribbing" in October, 1934, when his photograph was published in a testimonial advertisement, admitted last night that he had offered to sell his seat on the Exchange.
The Neediest Cases Fund received forty-five contributions yesterday totaling $759.02. The Fund's total to date is $268,188.50.

It was Morley (Christopher) vs. Morley (Felix) yesterday morning at the Town Hall and the topic debated by the two brothers was: "Do Newspapers Do More Harm Than Good?" Christopher, the novelist, took the affirmative side, and Felix, the editor of The Washington Post, defended the press.

The Tennessee Coal, Iron Railroad Company, United States Steel subsidiary, posted printed bulletins today saying it "has always stood for the open shop and will continue to do so." It employs about 17,500 men in the Birmingham district.
Bales M. Campbell, for many years an active figure in Youngstown's business and industry, died today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident.

The United States liner Washington arrives today with 713 passengers from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Her passengers include the Budapest University Chorus under the direction of Victor Vaszy.

The United States liner Washington arrives today with 713 passengers from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Her passengers include the Budapest University Chorus under the direction of Victor Vaszy.

Rounding out a plot he purchased about a month ago at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-third Street, Irving I. Lewine has bought 25 East Eightythird Street from the East River Savings Bank.

Mrs. Mary Odell Reissman, 23 years old, former assistant postmaster at North Bellmore, L. I., pleaded guilty yesterday when arraigned in Federal court in Brooklyn on an indictment charging her with embezzlement of $2,168 of postal funds.
Copper exports decreased last November from the previous month, but increased slightly over November, 1935, the Department of Commerce said today.

William Kennedy Jr. of 35 Prospect Park, Brooklyn, treasurer of the William Kennedy Construction Company, Inc., at 215 Montague Street, Brooklyn, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Aurelio in the Felony Court on a grand larceny charge.

An investigation by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of alleged instances of recruiting in New York and San Francisco for the Spanish civil war began today as a prospect developed that, because of delay in the signing of the neutrality resolution applying to that conflict, Richard L. Dineley, the San Francisco munitions dealer, may be able to get some planes out of the country for the Loyalist government of Spain.

The Seth Low College five defeated Cooper Union, 44-22, at the Columbia University gymnasium last night. Seth Low gained a 20-7 lead in the first half. In a preliminary the New College varsity gained a 30-24 victory over the Seth Low jayvees.

Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., a member of the Charter Revision Commission, will receive the annual gold medal award of the Downtown Brooklyn Association for "most distinguished service" to the borough, Henry J. Davenport, president, announced yesterday. The medal will be presented at a luncheon in the Hotel Bossert on Jan. 27.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Whitehouse and Miss Louise Whitehouse, who have been at the Vanderbilt, will sail today on the Ulua for Jamaica, B. W. I., where they have a Winter home.

The Westchester grand jury voted first-degree arson indictments today against the three men arrested in Yonkers Dec. 30, when they entered a house on Edgewood Road to set a fire which had been "arranged" by a private detective who had rented the house to trap them.
The Yale freshmen dropped their opening basketball game of the season today to the strong New Haven Boys Club five, 34 to 33. The score was tied at 27--all as the final period started.

Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Watt of East nie Orange, N. J., entertained with a tea at their home today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Eddy of Ridgewood, N. J., who are passing several weeks at the Carolina.

Don Budge, the nation's No. 1 ranking player, and Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, No. 3 nationally, were forced to extend themselves today to win the right to meet each other in the final of the Miami Biltmore tennis tournament.
John F. Mullen, a sheet-metal worker, was found guilty today of the murder of his wife, Mrs. Sara Mullen, in their Plainfield home last Aug. 3.

German business ethics and the influence' of American practices were discussed last night by Dr. Ernst Reichard of Berlin, president of the National Council on Economic Publicity, a semi-public organization under the supervision of the German Government.

Professor Albert Einstein has reached a solution of the problem of gravitational waves, first discussed by him nineteen years ago, and, with Dr. N. Rosen of the Institute for Advanced Studies here, has submitted proof of the existence of a new realm of radiation, in a paper published in the Journal of the Franklin Institute of Philadelphia.

The fears of national advertisers, who always expect some action from State Legislatures to worry them, were confirmed this week when the Kentucky Legislature received a bill requiring registration of trade-marks and similar to legislation which was defeated in five States last year. What the

Roundlot trading and purchases and sales of stocks by members were somewhat smaller on the New York Stock Exchange in the week to Dec. 12 than in the preceding week, but the percentage of the total volume represented by member trading increased, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
L. Werner Knoke, formerly assistant vice president, has been appointed a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, it was announced yesterday.

Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, was dismissed from the service, effective at midnight Thursday, after approval of the sentence of a general court-martial which tried him on Governors Island last March had been received from Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Resuming play after a three weeks' lapse over the holidays, the Class C teams of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League provided the action on five fronts yesterday, with one result, that the Harvard Club lost sole possession of the lead and now shares it with the New York Athletic Club.

For the eleventh renewal of the rich Hambletonian Stake at Good Time Park, Goshen, N. Y., next August, thirty-nine of the greatest 3-year-old trotters in the United States remain eligible, it was announced yesterday.

George Middleton, the playwright, whose wife is Fola La Follette, denied yesterday statements attributed to him by Dr. Glenn Frank in which the former was quoted as saying that the La Follette family did not wish Dr. Frank to accept the presidency of the University of Wisconsin. Mr. Middleton was reported
I appreciate the honor you have done me by asking me to serve as member of a special commission of three to make an informal inquiry into the present situation at the University of Wisconsin.

The dropping of thirty-four political appointees from clerkships in the municipal courts and their replacement by persons taken from a civil service eligible list was ordered yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission. Chief Justice Pelham St. George Bissell of the court was informed of the commission's order, which was handed down under authority of a 1934 Court of Appeals decision that the clerkships should be competitive and not exempt jobs.
At King George's request, no portraits of himself and Queen Elizabeth will appear in coronation issues of the Bible.

Output of the motor-car plants this week was only slightly affected by strikes and shut-downs, Ward's Automotive Reports said today, putting the aggregate assemblies at 92,142, which compares with 79,538 last week and 101,096 during the comparable week a year ago.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company will supervise the preparation and certify to the genuineness of signatures and seal of $125,000 of improvement bonds of the town of Morristown, N. J.; $165,000 of school loan bonds of the city of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and $182,000 of refunding bonds of the Borough of Deal, N. J.

Three senior Metropolitan A.A.U. swimming titles were decided in the seventy-five foot pool of the Downtown Athletic Club last night, with a brilliant triumph by Miss Harriet McCarthy of the Women's Swimming Association in the 220-yard free-style event providing the only upset on the program.

Before sending his budget message to Congress today President Roosevelt revealed his intention to seek an amendment to the Social Security Act to wipe out or curtail the proposed $40,000,000,000 old-age reserve fund and to put the pension payments on a pay-as-you-go basis.
New York University's swimming team opened its 1937 campaign by. defeating St. Francis College of Brooklyn, 39 to 32, in a dual meet in the pool of the Park Central Hotel last night. Each team scored

Commodity markets here were generally higher in heavy trading yesterday. Active buying in sugar futures was the feature. In the cash markets, cocoa, raw sugar and silk were higher, while all the grains, tin, dairy products, cotton and rubber were lower.

The President's budget message did not hold many surprises so far as the Wall Street community was concerned. It had been generally expected that the President would forecast what may be called a "cash" balance, although not a
Plans for thirty-two new buildings, at a total cost of $4,006,600, were filed last month in Manhattan, according to official figures announced yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Commisioner of Buildings.
The Flint Alliance, an anti-strike organization of automobile workers, continued to gain in membership today.

Patrolman George Butler of the Greenburgh Police Department successfully delivered a baby born to a woman on the relief rolls here early yesterday morning, while he received instructions over the police two-way radio system from a physician speeding to the scene in a police automobile.

Communism is "the insidious enemy" which Roman Catholic missionaries in every land are having to battle today, Cardinal Hayes declares in a pastoral which will be read tomorrow in every church in the Archdiocese of New York at each of the masses.
Every company in the chain store or mail order group which so far has reported sales for December and twelve months has shown an increase over the corresponding periods of the preceding year.

The father of Charles Mattson, kidnapped twelve days ago, sought new instructions from the boy's abductor tonight after Federal officers, suddenly re-entering the case, sped on a secret mission early today.
Enrico Venturi, Italian lightweight, hurdled his most important American bout last night without victory or defeat but with added prestige.

The Russian Trio, composed of Nina Mesirow-Minchin, pianist; Michel Wilkomirski, violinist; and Ennio Bolognini, 'cellist, gave its first New York recital last night at the Town Hall. The program included Brahms's Trio in C minor, Opus 101, and Rachmaninoff's Trio, "Elegiaque," Opus 9. The recital was under the sponsorship of the Lake Shore Chamber Music Society.
President Roosevelt set aside an hour today to discuss methods of combating infantile paralysis while he talked at a White House tea with a group of men interested in this work.

Ezio Pinza, Metropolitan Opera basso, who was to have sung the role of the Toreador in this afternoon's production of "Carmen," instead will appear in the evening performance of "Samson et Dalila," in the part of the High Priest of Dagon. Mr. Pinza appeared in this part at its first revival performance.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The market for wool is stronger this week both here and abroad. Average fine wools are up a cent or so in the last week, and medium wools are also against the buyer.

The Harlem Savings Bank sold to the Jacob Goodman Realty Corporation the four-story tenement on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 239 West 126th Street, the four-story flat on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 253 West 126th Street and the twelve-room dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 138 West 121st Street.

As a result of having the best year in its history from the viewpoint of earnings, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company voted today to retire on Feb. 1 an additional $10,000,000 of preferred stock held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to distribute a stock dividend of an equivalent amount to the holders of its common stock.
Harry Frankel, the secretary and treasurer of Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert's chicken truckers' union, was surrendered to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday by his attorney, Sol Tekulsky.

All shipments of arms, munitions or implements of war, including airplanes, to Spain came under embargo at 12:30 P. M. today when President Roosevelt signed a joint resolution creating the embargo, which had been passed as the first act of the new Congress.

After a fourteen-hour battle, the Alabama Senate tonight defeated, 20 to 12, a proposed State-store Liquor Control Bill that would have repealed the State's 22-year-old Prohibition Law, which permits the sale of near-beer only.

Presenting the brightest picture of Federal finances since the depression began, President Roosevelt told the new Congress in a message sent to the Capitol today that it could expect a "layman's" balance of the budget in the fiscal year 1938, with a complete balance and resumption of reduction of the public debt in 1939.

The La Salle Military Academy sextet of Oakdale, L. I., will make its first start in defense of its Private Schools Hockey League title when it encounters St. John's Prep in the opener of a double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace at 1 o'clock today. Poly Prep and St. Francis
A bill to supplement the law enacted last year for reform of county governments was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Desmond and Assemblyman Mailler, Republicans.

Federal Judge John Boyd Avis appointed today Thomas L. Gaskill, referee in bankruptcy, as special master to take testimony and make recommendations in connection with an application for reorganization of the Guanajuanto Reduction and Mines Company, which operates

Caesar Finn will speak on "The Value of Community Music" tomorrow afternoon at P. S. 136, Manhattan. Hugo Gottesman, violinist, and Uarda Hein, pianist, will be heard tomorrow evening at the New York College of Music.

The stock market generally was firm today and greater activity was noted in certain groups. A reassuring factor was that the latest European political developments seemed to be regarded as less disturbing.

In a letter to stockholders accompanying the bank's statement of condition for Dec. 31, Edwin G. Merrill, chairman of the board of the Bank of New York and Trust Company, and J. C. Traphagen, president, call attention to the bank's undivided profits account, which amounted to $3,993,049, reflecting for the year a net increase of $2,234,961 after payment of dividends.
Debutantes of the Winter and several hundred of their young friends gathered in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the second of the Junior Assemblies of this season.

A suit for $25,000 and an injunction was filed yesterday in Federal Court by Time, Inc., publishers of Time magazine and the monthly motion picture, "The March of Time," against "The Voice of Time," 1 Park Place, a radio broadcast enterprise, charging trademark infringement and unfair trade practices.

MEXICO, D. F., Jan. 8.--Millions of dollars of American property is being seized in Mexico, together with British, French and other foreign estates, without a gesture toward compensation and in violation of the Mexicon Agrarian Law.

305--Wayne United Gas Co., petr., v. Owens-Illinois Glass Co., et al.--Argument concluded for the respondents. 309--S. P. Kelly. trustee in bankruptcy , petr., v. United States, et al.--Submitted for both.

It is announced that Mr. DAVID MANNES, in the opening concert of his twentieth year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight, will be playing an ancient Stradivarius which is one of the three owned by the museum-and which may be used only in the museum--thus fulfilling in its "mellow shapeliness" the genius of an "omnipotent destiny," as the late English Laureate has written of instruments "fashioned by AMATI or STRADIVARI ":

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 7: Brougher, Lieut. Col. W. E., Infantry, Charleston. W. Va., to Army War College, Washington, D. C., as student for the 1937-38 course, about Aug. 16.

The professional New York Americans defeated the amateur Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 8 to 4, tonight in an exhibition hockey game. The New York team overwhelmed the locals from the beginning, scoring three tallies in the first period to the Sea Gulls' one.

Herbert G. Williams, resident manager and European representative of Brooks Brothers, New York clothing firm, at London, England, died there on Wednesday after a brief illness, according to word received here yesterday by business associates. He was 67 years old.

Genie Palatine, one of the powerful Chicago-owned string belonging to the amazingly successful Mrs. Emil Denemark, breezed away with another feature event for her popular owner at Tropical Park today. The 4-year-old daughter of Genie-Sun Palatine made her own pace and annexed the Dick Merrill purse of one mile by two lengths.

Senator Bankhead of Alabama introduced a Farm Tenant Bill today which is in most respects similar to the Bankhead Bill which passed the Senate last session, but was not acted on in the House, and identical with one introduced in the House by Chairman Jones of the Agriculture Committee.

Funeral services were held today for Admiral Albert Gleaves, United States Navy, retired, the World War commander of the cruiser and transport force. The navy accorded honors of the service, as he was buried in Arlington National Cemetery. Admiral Gleaves died at his

James M. Curley, former Governor of Massachusetts, went aboard the Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic last night for a wedding trip with his bride, the former Mrs. Gertrude Casey Dennis, to whom he was married in Boston on Thursday.
Thomas A. Tully, vice president of the contracting firm of Tully Di Napoli in Long Island City, died on Thursday at his home, 26-36 Fourteenth Street, Astoria, Queens. He was 50 years old.

Rutgers's powerful basketball team handed Springfield its first defeat of the season, winning 44-41, tonight at the Armory court. A crowd of 1,500 fans saw Acting Captain Roy Lines of the visitors lead his mates to victory in a sparkling individual exhibition of basketball.

A stockholder's suit to compel restoration of $610,000 in bonuses and gifts paid in 1929 and 1932 to officers of the Consolidated Edison Company system and others was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when some of the defendants moved to dismiss the causes of action based on the 1929 payments on the ground that they were outlawed by the statute of limitations.
Cheering General Motors employes gave the management of two Baltimore plants a vote of confidence today and announced that outside organizers will not be welcome in employe-management dealings.

Cotton mill activity for the week ended Jan. 2 showed a greater than seasonal rise, with the result that the adjusted index advanced four points. The figure now is 149.8, as against 145.8 for the previous week and 117.7 for the week ended Jan. 4, 1936.

After consultation with the British Government, the Australian Government has announced it is prepared to order forty airplanes and a number of spare engines for the Royal Australian Air Force from the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation's factory at Fishermen's Bend, Port Melbourne. The order's estimated value is [Pound]250,000.

The Budapest University Chorus of forty-two male voices, which will make a tour of the United States under the direction of Victor Vaszy, leader of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington and was greeted later in the day by Mayor La Guardia. Their first concert here will be at Carnegie Hall next Saturday.
Several department stores announced yesterday declarations of dividends. Those whose fiscal years end on or before Jan. 31 will reduce the tax on undistributed profits.

Compelling need for Federal regulatory legislation of investment trusts and companies has been demonstrated by the evidence already taken in the inquiry that it is conducting into their affairs, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today in a preliminary report to Congress.
Paramount Pictures announced yesterday a $30,000,000 production program for the next twelve months, one of the most ambitious schedules in its history.
A trapped beaver rejoined its colony in Little Otter Pond near this St. Lawrence County community today, thanks to the rudimentary surgery of two forest rangers.

Trustees of the New Haven Railroad system were authorized today by the Federal District Court to complete payments amounting to $57,038 on equipment purchased is 1935, consisting of fifty-one motor trucks and two Pullman dining cars. The total cost amounted to

State and municipal financing in December aggregated $91,573,721, compared with $126,454,434 in December, 1935. During the month Public Works Administration financing amounted to $318,406, and Reconstruction Finance Corporation operations to $2,192,000, compared with $4,623,000 and $12,096,000, respectively, in December, 1935.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Wild Life in Old England," Captain C. W. R. Knight.
Turpentine firm, 45 1/2c; sales, 45 barrels; receipts, 90 barrels; no shipments; stock, 31,684 barrels. Resin firm; sales. 490; receipts, 670; no shipments; stock, 75,684.

PARIS--France lodged a protest with the Spanish Rebels against landing of German troops in Morocco, pointing out it is a violation of the treaty of 1912. War Minister Daladier will go to Morocco to look after defense plans as the navy appears off the coast. Page 1.

The Central Republic Company, E. H. Rollins Sons, Lawrence Stern Co. and Coffin Burr are offering $5,100,000 of North Shore Gas Company and North Shore Coke and Chemical Company joint first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series A, due Jan. 1, 1942, at 100 and interest.

Belgium served a sharp ultimatum on the Spanish Leftist Government today, giving it forty-eight hours to deliver with military honors the body of Baron Jacques de Borchgrave, allegedly slain first secretary of the embassy in Madrid, and to submit apologies and pay a $35,000 indemnity.

A step to remove the national lottery from the control of civil authorities and place it under army control was taken today. The Cabinet agreed to President Federico Laredo Bru's sending a message to Congress recommending an enabling law.

Modification of its national consolidation plan was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to permit acquisition by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway of control of the 200-mile Fort Worth Rio Grande Railway.
Three attorneys were disbarred by the Appellate Division yesterday for professional misconduct in dealings with their clients.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 7 unless specified: Antares, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk to Cristobal. Barracuda, St. Thomas to Philadelphia Yard, Jan. 8. Chaumont, at Hong Kong, Jan. 8.
Mrs. June Walker has leased her residence at 31 Sutton Place North to Bradshaw Crandall, illustrator, through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., broker.

Tammany politics took a holiday last night as the Anawanda Club of the old Twelfth Assembly District, the "gas-house" district, held its seventieth annual entertainment and reception at the Astor Hotel.

149th St. (9-2293), s. w. cor. Bergen Av., 180x98; C. Padgett Hudson to Provident Trust Co. of Philadelphia, trustee. Seton Av. (17-4939), e. s., 175 ft. s. of Nelson Av., 50x100 Catherine Michaels to Anna Carrigan, 98 Hill St., New Rochelle,
A sitdownn" strike among army officers held in jail on charges of having participated in the Leftist revolt of November, 1935, was broken today by special policemen.

Even the greatest violinists cannot suffer with impunity weather conditions like those prevailing last night. The dank mist that enshrouded the city permeated the atmosphere of Carnegie Hall sufficiently to dampen the instrument on which Jascha Heifetz was performing at his third recital of the season, to a degree which made absolute control of tone precarious and often impossible.
The engagement of $1,270,000 of gold in India for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank also reported the

CASNER, BESSIE (Nov. 18). Estate, less than $5,000. To Robert H. Casner, Park Central Hotel, Stanley J. Casner and Ambrose L. Casner, sons, both of 230 West End Av., and Viola Krozner, daughter, 200 E. 16th St., one-fourth residue each. Louis Freiman, 615 W. 173d St., and Louis Broter. 22 William St., executors.

Henri W. Simaika, the Egyptian Consul General in New York, and Mrs. Simaika gave a reception and tea yesterday afternoon in their suite at the Ambassador. Among those invited were Carol Tarcauanu, the Rumanian Consul General, and Mrs. Tarcauanu Etienne Jalenques, the French Consul Suppleant, and Mrs. Jalenques:

Fireman 1st grade Paul M. Enders of Engine 272, died Jan. 7. Funeral will take place from Funeral Parlor of George Dowdall, 91-05 37th Av., Jackson Heights, at 9:45 A. M., Monday, Jan. 11. Interment at St. Michael's Cemetery.
For more than an hour today President Roosevelt discussed what was described as the general business situation with Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 2 amounted to 587,953 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Mrs. Florence Johnson Bachmann, wife of Norbert H. Bachmann, New York woolen merchant, died yesterday at her home, 791 Park Avenue, at the age of 57.

Striking seamen will stage a "march" on Washington within the next ten days to register their opposition to the terms of the Copeland Act, which requires seamen to carry continuous discharge books as a record of their service on American ships, it was announced yesterday.

RESEARCH ASSISTANT (IMMUNOCHEMISTRY)-Salary: $2.520 per annum: pension; fair sick leave. Ages: 25 through 44, on Jan. 22. Applications: Received to 4 P. M., Friday, Jan. 22, Room 1400, Municipal Building. Manhattan. Vacancies:

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Tagart Steele Jr. will assume his duties on Ash Wednesday, Feb. 10, as vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street. Dr. Steele, who was recently chosen for the local congregation by the Rev.

Hog prices advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight in the early trading today, but as soon as the aggressive e buying let up the market reacted, and later trading was at about the same level as yesterday.

An upward trend again characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Although interest was centered on the secondary railroad liens and more speculative industrial loans, a good demand also was in evidence for the higher-grade investments, including United States Government obligations.

The Junior Assembly last night at the Ritz-Carlton was followed by a unique breakfast party and "dawn dance" given by Mrs. Charles Burton Scoville of Pasadena, Calif. in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria for two of this season's debutantes-Miss Helene L. Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Peters, and Miss Pamela Brinton, daughter of Mrs. Laurence Eyre.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Louise Wefferling, daughter of, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Wefferling of Maplewood, N. J., to John Lewis Schaffner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Schaffner of Syracuse, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Mrs. Henry Latrobe Roosevelt, widow of the Assistant Secretary of the Navy, who was a cousin of President Roosevelt, announced today the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Katherine Roosevelt, to Reverdy Wadsworth, son of Representative and Mrs. James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo, N. Y.

In a direct effort to obtain ratification of an amendment to the Constitution outlawing child labor, President Roosevelt has written personal letters to the Governors of nineteen non-ratifying States in which Legislatures will meet this year, asking them to make ratification "one of the major items in the legislative program of your State this year."

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Jan. 7, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of history in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
The New York Conservation Department describes an interesting wildlife incident involving two forest rangers and a beaver.

A block in Forest Hills, L. I., bounded by Stafford and Baldwin Avenues, Fleet and Exeter Streets, has been chosen by the Cooperative Housing Association of Civil Service Employes as the prospective site of its first low-cost housing project.

The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, which in 1929 exposed and condemned the commercialization of athletics in American colleges, will not make a new survey along the same lines, as requested by the National Association of State Universities, it was announced yesterday.

The appointment of Frank Flaherty of Niagara Falls as a special Deputy Superintendent of Banks was announced in the department's weekly bulletin. He is to assist in liquidating several closed banking institutions. They are Bank of Angola, Angola:

Answers to the first part of the test for social investigator taken recently by 10,000 ERB investigators and social service workers under the direction of the Municipal Civil Service Commission will be broadcast Monday afternoon from 5:30 to 6 P. M. over the city radio station, WNYC, it was announced yesterday.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1936, a net income of $12,127,559 after Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits, depreciation. interest, subsidiary preferred dividends and other charges.

Plans for industrial buildings filed last year in up-State New York amounted to $16,413,545, an increase of $5,783,713 over 1935, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner of the State Department of Labor, reported yesterday.

The New York Curb Exchange won a victory today when the Securities and Exchange Commission denied an application by Tweedy Co., overthe-counter brokers in New York, for termination of unlisted trading on the Curb in the $10 par value capital stock of City and Suburban Homes Company.
The second junior dinner dance of the season was given tonight in the Bellevue Stratford. Mrs. Daniel L. Hutchinson Jr. heads the patronesses for these dances.

John Toohey, father of New Jersey Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 531 Garden Street, Hoboken, at the age of 89. Mr. Toohey, whose birthplace was Ireland, had retired in 1927 after fifty years with the Fleitmann Textile Corporation in New York.

By B. HOLLANDER SON. Sedgwick Av.. 2,290-2,300, 6-story apartment, 169.4x110.6xirreg.; Title Guarantee and Trust Co. against Rosewell Realty Co.: due. S56.294: taxes, , $1,432: to plaintiff for $25,000.

Checking a determined rally at the close, the Pratt Institute quintet topped the Davis and Elkins five, 40 to 38, at the Pratt Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. The victors enjoyed a 15-13 lead at the intermission. Nick Zuraw, with nine field goals, was the high scorer.

Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, veteran Democratic leader of the Second Assembly District, loomed yesterday as a strong candidate, with reputed backing of the Roosevelt administration, to supplant James J. Dooling as leader of Tammany Hall.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Miss Mary Cook, daughter of Mrs. Mary Cook of New York and Bellport, L. I., was married to William Henry Hatch Jr., son of William H. Hatch of New York and North Brookfield, Mass., and the late Mrs. Hatch, this evening at the home here of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Bunnell.

Blizzards, fog, rain, sleet and icy winds crippled the Western half of the nation today. Many trains and buses were halted or delayed. Schools were closed. Drifts blocked highways. Air travel was areatly impaired.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in 1936 aggregated $326,823,807,959, a gain of 9.9 per cent over the preceding year and the largest for a year since 1931. This compares with the record turnover of $727,848,371,330 in 1929.

Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, addressed two letters today in the name of the committee to Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, asking information concerning the ownership and control of broadcasting chains and the number of newspapers owning and operating stations.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 6: Trammell, Commander W., Washington, D. C., to command Destroyer Division 62, in March. Nolan, Commander R. A., Medical Corps, San Diego, Calif., to the Dobbin.

The condition of Frederic Kernochan, Presiding Justice of the New York Court of Special Sessions, was reported "very critical" tonight by Dr. Harold F. Morrison, chief of staff at Tuxedo Memorial Hospital. Justice Kernochan was removed to the hospital from his home here last Saturday, suffering from pneumonia. Dr. Morrison said

Miss Frances A. Wister, recipient of the 1936 Gimbel award, was honored at a tea at the Civic Club today. Miss Margaret A. Lennig, president of the club, was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Daniel D. Warriner, Miss Helen Semple, Mrs. James A. Richardson, Mrs. Fisher L. Boyd, Mrs. Edward W. Biddle,

Members of the Automobile Manufacturers Association completed 1936 with an aggregate volume of 3,512,436 units for the year, it was disclosed in the monthly report of the Association released yesterday.
one-acre plot on Indian Trail. Spencer Glen. Harrison. Westchester County, has been sold to the Lomard Building Company b Harmon s. Auguste.

Miss Ada Neumeyer, 33 years old, of Port Monmouth, N. J., was injured fatally here this afternoon shortly after 3 o'clock when the ambulance in which she was being rushed to the Monmouth Memorial Hospital was struck by a coal truck. She died an hour later in the hospital.

Oscar Burenjensen, 18 years old, lost the sight of his right eye and suffered injuries to his face and left eye shortly after 4 P. M. yesterday when a siphon bottle containing water and dry ice exploded suddenly. as he was experimenting with it in the kitchen of his home, at

The mortgage held by the Trustees of Prudence Bonds, Inc., on the property at 1,601-21 Kings Highway, Brooklyn has been reduced to $297,000 and extended for five years at 5 per cent. The extension was negotiated by David Jaret Co., in cooperation with Brunswick, Praver Nassof, Inc.

The ever-popular and ever-colorful Duquesne University quintet will match points with the sharpshooters from Long Island University in the feature of the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight, with N.Y.U. meeting Ohio State in the other half of the program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--President Roosevelt ordered today the construction of two new battleships as the reply of the United States to foreign powers which declined to renew treaties for limitation of naval armaments that expired on Dec. 31 and began the construction of eleven capital ships.

The sale of $50,000,000 of New York City corporate stock set for Tuesday lifts the total of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week to $64,132,250, with one State and fifty-three municipalities represented. The figure compares with the revised total of $76,693,740 this week.
Still another Waterloo for the expert forecasters was staged in Madison Square Garden when FRED PERRY and ELLSWORTH VINES
Arnold Lakhovsky, Russian landscape and portrait painter, died yesterday at the Beth Israel Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 160 West Seventy-first Street.

A dense fog settled over the harbor yesterday, causing serious delay to maritime traffic. Although it lifted long enough in the afternoon to permit two large ships from the West Indies and Bermuda to dock, it settled again, delaying the departure of the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic and the American Caribbean Line steamship Scanpenn.
This statement was issued today by Governor La Follette in connection with the ousting of Dr. Glenn Frank as president of the university:

The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain will sail today on her annual voyage around the world with 425 passengers, and will embark another 125 passengers at Villefranche on her way through the Mediterranean and the Suez Canal to the Far East, steaming 30,000 miles and calling at twentynine ports.
Tallying twice in the second period and four times in the third, the Princeton junior varsity hockey team defeated the Lions Hockey Club tonight by 6 to 1.

The conflict between the new Spanish Minister, Mrs. Isabella de Palencia, and her predecessor, Alfonso Fiscovich, who is a supporter of Generalissimo Francisco Franco and had refused to leave the legation, has ended.

Greenwich House with the community about it is as a village in the midst of the city in that it has its own common local interests fairly separacely defined yet in close relationship with the great nourishing city. It has a Village Association and a Village Planning Committee.

The estate of John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, had a gross value of $818,574.05 and a net value of $719,288, according to an appraisal filed yesterday by David F. Soden, State Transfer Tax Appraiser, with the Kings County Surrogate's Court.

Copper was quoted in the export market yesterday at a price equivalent to 12.275 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the highest for the current movement. On Thursday the price was 12.05 cents,

Senator Glass introduced in the Senate today three bills to extend the life of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, the Gold Devaluation Act and the government's authority to issue currency against Federal Reserve credit.
Wheat prices were on the down grade today, despite reports indicating increased tension in the European political situation. General precipitation

Harold Talbot Hartwell, vice president of the Hartwell-Delap Company and a practicing lawyer In New York for more than twenty years, died this morning after a brief illness. A resident of Stamford for eighteen years, he lived at 122 Stamford Avenue, Shippan Point. He was in his forty-eighth year.

Definite progress toward the time when man can determine at will which sex his children shall be wap reported today by Dr. Richard B. Goldschmidt, a recognized authority in research on sex determination.
Nick Pastore, 142?? Williamsburg fighter, knocked out Ernie Ratner, 142. of Newark, N. J., in 2:11 of the third session of the scheduled eightround main bout at Henderson's Flatbush Arena last night.

Building plans filed in Manhattan yesterday included specifications for two comfort stations to be erected by the Department of Parks and a downtown storage building. Owners filed, in addition, a long list of plans for altering existing structures.

The Federal Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that manufacturers who paid processing taxes under the Agricultural Adjustment Act cannot sue collectors of internal revenue for recovery of such taxes.

The Rev. William Ward Ayer, who came here seven months ago from the pastorate of the Philpott Tabernacle, Toronto, Canada, to be the acting pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, was called to the permanent pastorate of Calvary last Wednesday evening, it was announced yesterday.
Nicaragua's inaugural fete ended today. More than twenty representatives from foreign countries will leave Managua tomorrow.

Stocks generally higher, steel and aviation shares strongest; turnover, 3,217,010 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds irregular, corporation issues higher, with rails in demand; transactions, $22,107,300.
The Neediest Cases Fund received twenty-nine contributions yesterday, totaling $260.50. The Fund's grand total is now $268,449. The list of donations follows:

A further gain in higher-fare railway travel was disclosed in a statement for November and the first eleven months of 1936 issued yesterday by the Pullman Company, sleeping and parlor car operating subsidiary of Pullman. Inc.

The Rev. James Henry Gorham, an instructor at the Kent School, Kent, Conn., formerly missionary to Africa and descendant of an old New England family, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 46 years old.
Peiping was shocked this morning to learn that the body of a British girl had been found under the Tartar Wall, between Hatamen Gate and Fox Tower.

A jury before Federal Judge Galston awarded yesterday a $7,500 verdict to David Levy, 25-year-old restaurant manager of Philadelphia, who had charged he suffered a fractured skull and other injuries in a melee at the Yankee Stadium that followed his attempt to grab a foul ball.
President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, who has been touring the Southern provinces, returned to the capital today and presided at a meeting of the Cabinet.

Edward Dana, for five years general manager and executive vice president of the Boston Elevated Railway, has been appointed president. He continues as general manager. Henry L. Wilson, treasurer, retired.
