Twenty hours of searching for stolen diamonds valued at between $250,000 and $300,000 left Brooklyn authorities bewildered last night over the story told by Joseph Rose, a retired diamond merchant now on home relief, who accused his best friend of filching the secret hoard from his mattress last July.

Thirty-six members of the Models Union were arrested yesterday morning when they staged a demonstration in front of the Art Students League of New York, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, by locking arms and blocking both entrances to the building.

An advance to 12.49 cents a pound for the March delivery ran the cotton market into an increased supply of contracts yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and a reaction left the list with losses of 1 to 8 points on the day.

The type of executive at the head of some of our great banking institutions would very likely set a new standard in statesmanship if they could be persuaded to enter public life, Russell S. Sims, vice president of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., told members of the Association of Bank Women yesterday at a meeting held at the Chase National Bank after banking hours.
It is reported that the honeymoon of the Crown Princess JULIANA and her husband, Prince BERNHARD of the Netherlands, might be extended to include a motor trip through Great Britain.

Dr. George Gilbert Platt, one of the oldest practicing dentists in New York State, died suddenly this morning at his home, 25 Sterling Avenue. He was 89 years old. Dr. Platt practiced regularly for more than sixty-three years until the Christmas holidays when he became ill.

College Av., 1,264 (9-2436), Abraham Jacobson to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtgs. to Nov. 1, 1941, at 3 1/2 per cent; $12.000. Washington Av., 1,514 (11-2912), North County Development Co. to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg. to Aug. 1, 1941, at 4 1/4 per cent; $15.450.
Overcoming an eight-goal handicap early in the fourth period, the Cornell University polo team avenged an early season setback at Ithaca by defeating the 112th Artillery tonight. 24-17.

THEY are saying in the hinterlands, with a chuckling accompaniment, that the New York zone defense in basketball, once a rubbercovered, high-pressure barrier, has been badly deflated by the puncture process. The story is that the rollicking roisterers from colleges in other sectors romped into the metropolitan area land let all the wind out of Father Knickerbocker's basketball.

Another chapter in an odyssey that began twenty years ago when he left New York to become co-leader of the Russian revolution is scheduled to end tomorrow with the rearrival in the New World of Leon Trotsky.

Members of Congress and their wives, high officials of the government and department clerks and others to the number of more than 300 attended this afternoon the reception given by the National Woman's Party in honor of Mrs. Stephen Pell of New York.

President Roosevelt sent his budget message to Congress, ordered construction of two new battleships, signed the Spanish arms embargo resolution, announced that he had written letters to Governors of nineteen non-ratifying States asking ratification of the child labor amendment and conferred with Myron C. Taylor on the industrial situation, Jesse Jones on extension of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Ernest O. Thompson on oil compact legislation.

Miss Eleanor Long Dow, daughter of Clinton Sibley Dow of Orange, N. J., was married here yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis to Henry Walcott Farnam, son of Mrs. Henry Walcott Farnam of New Haven, Conn., and the late Professor Farnam of Yale University.
William (Pete) Eckley, ousted village policeman whose reinstatement was demanded by nearly 300 school pupils who went on strike last Monday, got his job back early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Forty-nine per cent of the government's receipts of $4,116,000,000 during the 1936 fiscal year ended last June were derived from miscellaneous internal revenue, which is made up of the liquor, tobacco, manufacturers' excise and other incidental taxes, Secretary Morgenthau announced today in his annual report to Congress.

Properties in the West Bronx figured in two of the transactions in that borough reported yesterday. The five-story apartment house at 1,506-14 University Avenue, containing forty suites and occupying a plot 100 by 119 feet, was sold by Isadore B. Geller, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $115,000.

Many colonists entertained with dinners at tonight's opening for the season of the Beach Club. Gurnee Munn was host to Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair, Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, Mrs. Lucius Pond Ordway, Mrs. Arthur Somers Roche, Miss Grace Munn Amory, Milton W. Holden and John de Bracanza.

Mrs. Howard Berolzheimer, "Lu" of the radio team of "Clara, Lu and Em," died today in Evanston Hospital. She had been suffering from a streptococcic infection for two weeks. Death was due to pneumonia, which developed three days ago. She was 31 years old.

Five minority stockholders of the James Butler Grocery Company have brought suit in Supreme Court charging a "fraudulent scheme" on the part of James Butler who died Feb. 20, 1934, and members of his family, the majority stockholders, to divert the assets of the company to themselves, it was disclosed yesterday when two defendants moved for dismissal of the action -against them.

Although the Federal Theatre has some problem children on its hands, it also has some enterprising artists on its staff. Some of them got together at Maxine Elliott's Theatre last evening and put on a brilliantly original production of Christopher Marlowe's "The Tragical History of Dr. Faustus," which dates from 1589.

New bond flotations this week amounted to $62,826,000, of which State and municipal financing accounted for $45,975,000. This compared with $33,331,800 last week, and with $56,879,000 a year ago this week.

Miss Mary Rutherfoord Rose, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Rutherfoord Rose and the late Mr. Rose, was martried to George Riley Mercer, son of Mrs. Warren Hill Mercer of this city and the late Mr. Mercer at St. Thomas Episcopal Church tonight.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, and the union's board of strategy held a long meeting with Governor Frank Murphy early today discussing a union reply to a proposal made by the General Motors Corporation yesterday in negotiations to pave the way for conferences to settle the strikes in the company's plants.

The death on Dec. 23 of Francis C. Williams, wealthy stock trader, at first reported to have been due to natural causes, will be the subject of an inquiry next Tuesday afternoon, Dr. Louis Lefkowitz, Assistant Medical Examiner, announced yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday a letter which it is sending to all its members outlining the procedure that they are to follow under provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936.

The Securities and Exchange Commission called today a hearing for Jan. 25 on an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 for issuance by the North American Gas and Electric Company of Summit, N. J., of $2,248,819 of 6 per cent cumulative income debentures to fund unsecured indebtedness pursuant to an amended reorganization plan.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had stricken from listing and registration American Telephone and Telegraph Company 35-year sinking fund 5 per cent gold debentures, due Jan. 1, 1960, the security being called for redemption.

New Utrecht's fast-skating sextet strengthened its hold on first place in the P. S. A. L. hockey championship by making a brilliant come-back to defeat Jamaica, 3 to 2, on the Brooklyn Ice Palace rink last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 8.--The Republicans in the Assembly remained today in the deadlock which has continued for days over the election of a Speaker, and after one more ballot had been taken, the eighth so far, adjourned for the week-end.

More than half the estate of the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Presbyterian Fundamentalist leader who died a week ago at Bismarck, N. D., will be devoted, under the terms of his will, to furthering the cause that he had championed during the battle over modernism in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.
The Tennessee Valley Authority asked the Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to give a "go ahead" signal on its expansion program.

The Horace Mann School for Boys basketball team launched its campaign in the Eastern Private Schools League with a 35-29 triumph over Poly Prep on the latter's court yesterday. However, the champions of the last two seasons were forced to an overtime period before winning.

8.-Invitations have been sent out for the marriage on Jan. 30 of Miss Kathleen Carpender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Bleecker Carpender of this place, to Arthur Lowe Connell of Scranton, Pa., son of Mrs. Robert Fish of Scranton and Edgar W. Connell of New York.

The problem of dealing with the excess reserves of member banks, amounting to about $2,000,000,000, will not be solved by the Treasury's new policy of placing all gold imports and other purchases of that metal on an inactive basis; that is,

Chatting on topics of the day, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, who will celebrate her seventy-eighth birthday anniversary tomorrow, expressed the opinion at her home here today that the countries of the world now regard war as "foolish," and predicted that the next war "is a long wav off."

While lacking final formalities, and consequently an official announcement, events as they developed here today indicated a successful conclusion for the so-called company plan for reorganization of the bankrupt newsprint concern, Price Brothers Co., Ltd. Gordon W. Scott,

All the intricacies of baseball law which for a time threatened to make a hopeless tangle of Manager Bill Terry's attempt to retire himself only "temporarily" for 1937 were summarily tossed out of a window yesterday when Horace C. Stoneham, owner of the Giants, announced that he would sign his pilot to a new contract that would put a definite end to the difficulty.
The thirty-six-story Maritime Exchange Building, standing on a leasehold at 78-86 Broad Street, will be sold at foreclosure Thursday, Jan. 28, by Henry Brady, auctioneer.

Miss Nannie Deaver Cooper Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benson Mann Jr. of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Robert Walter Hamilton, son of Major Walter C. Hamilton, U.S.A., and Mrs. Hamilton of this city, in the Church of St. James the Less, Falls of Schuylkill.
The Board of Transportation announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph Lee Weiner of 299 Riverside Drive as its counsel at an annual salary of $9,000.
Burton Rascoe's autobiographical "Before I Forget," covering the period 1892-1932, will be published by Doubleday, Doran on March 26.

Miss Alma Lackey Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Bright Wilson of New York and Washington, was married to T. Ames Wheeler, son of Professor Carleton Ames Wheeler of Tufts College and Mrs. Wheeler of Boston and Peterboro, N. H., yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria.
While weather conditions were not particularly favorable during the last few days, retail trade here gave a good account of itself during the week. The response to white

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to good on traefa meats. The lamb market was strong to slightly higher and some steer cuts sharply higher.

Barbara LeVeque. bertha Louise Leak. Beatrice Cole. Ruth M. Cornell, also Arthur E. Miller, in Hatfield House; W. F. Caulfield. Seward Simmons Lee, L. Raynes, August L. Volk, Van L. Vendope, W. C. Lotocks, Lee H. Wood, John K. Gordon Jr., Daniel I. Taradash, harry H. Heuser, Robert N. King, B. Raymond Calder, W. A. Dudley, Morris Geringer. Haskell Walker.
An announcement by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that the Duluth, South Shore Atlantic Railway had entered bankruptcy caused a sharp decline in the company's bonds.

The fight of Catriona Louise MacLean for legal recognition as chief of the Highland clan of MacLean of Ardgour was suspended today until an expert definition can be obtained of the words "chief" and "chieftain."

The season's second performance of "Die Walkuere" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night brought a reshuffling of the cast. Three of the leading roles were in hands different from those of the opening night presentation of the music-drama. Marjorie Lawrence, making her first appearance of the season, was the Bruennhilde. Ludwig Hofmann took the role of Wotan. And Kirsten Flagstad, who

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 920,000 bales, against 909,000 a week ago, 882,000 two weeks ago, 834,000 three weeks ago and 726,000 a year ago; of which American 339,000 bales, against 341,000 a week ago, 334,000 two weeks ago, 305,000 three weeks ago and 399,000 a year ago.

Californians hold a virtual monopoly on the leading positions in the 1936 national junior, boys' and girls' rankings announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Julius Heldman of Hollywood, John Kramer of Monticello and Margaret Osborne of San Francisco top their respective divisions in singles and also are ranked first in doubles.
The Pan American Press Conference opened here today with 155 delegates from thirteen countries present.
Fred Perry of England defeated the ailing Ellsworth Vines, top professional tennis star, tonight, 13-11, 6-3, in their second match of a tour for which the British former amateur champion turned pro.

Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Semler of this village have announced the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Anne Marie Semler, to John E. Mahoney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis A. Mahoney of Freeport and Brooklyn.

With as much cause for rejoicing as the American light harness turf has in looking backward at 1936, its best season in ten years, the eyes of the trotting sport are turned confidently ahead to 1937, which bears every promise of exceeding the past season in number of race meetings, value of purses, development of amateur matinee driving clubs for both men and women, and new, richer stakes for all-aged horses.
The first execution here this year under the anti-narcotic law occurred today. A dealer caught with sixty ounces of heroin was shot in public after having been paraded through the main streets.

A shut-down of General Motors factories in Canada was reported today as an imminent possibility unless strikes paralyzing the United States automobile industry are settled by the end of the month. About 8,000 men would be affected.

All available official sources in Berlin mock and deride reports from Paris and from London that barracks are being prepared for German troops in Spanish Morocco or that Germans have undertaken to arm Ceuta.

Alexander J. Glennie, principal of the Miller Street School and general supervisor of evening schools here, died today of pneumonia at the Women's and Children's Hospital. He had been with the Newark school system for thirty-one years, coming here after teaching for seventeen years in New York State.

A "clearing house" for those who have useful information about leisure to share with those who have time to spare has been opened at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie is rector. The Leisure Clearing House. as it

Braving frost-laden winds, crack golfers of the nation started down the $8,000 trail of the annual Los Angeles open today. At the end of eighteen holes, and with a gallery shivering like the gay banners strung around Griffith Park's municipal course,

The interstate ski jump, scheduled to be held at Bear Mountain Park tomorrow, was called off owing to the lack of snow, it was announced last night. The event was to have launched the elaborate program arranged for this season by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association.

Eight holders of preferred stock of the Baldwin Locomotive Works petitioned the Federal District Court today to require the company to seek a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to refinance its funded indebtedness instead of completing its reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws.
ALEXANDER, LOUISE (May 4, 1930). Gross assets. $46.999: net, $38,865. To Sarah M. Alexander, daughter, residue. Chief assets, real estate, $30,097. Briessen Schrenk, attorneys, 49 Wall St.

The Royal Academy of Arts, often host to some of the most notable collections of works of the world's master painters and sculptors, today threw open its doors to an exhibit of British architecture from the beginning of the seventeenth century to the present.

President Roosevelt's budget message was favorably received in Wall Street yesterday. The stock market, which had been advancing prior to the reading of the message, became stronger and more active as the text of the President's statement was tapped out on the news tickers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I must be getting old; for I can remember the Itata, and I see that these folk who are having bright ideas for keeping the United States out of war do not remember it. If they did, they would not have some of the ideas they have. For instance, Franklin Roosevelt.

Miss Joyce Childs, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Stauffen Jr. and Alfred De Forest Childs of this place, was married this afternoon to William Mackay, son of Mrs. Malcolm S. Mackay of Tenafly and the late Mr. Mackay.

Martin (Farmer) Burns, dean of American wrestlers, died tonight at his daughter's home. He would have been 76 years old on Feb. 15. The "Farmer," a name he gained when a gangling Iowa youth seeking honors in the matted arena, was heavyweight champion from 1895 to 1898. He won the championship by

On a balmy evening, so Springlike that it was almost yachting weather four months before its seasonal time, New Yorkers and their back-country cousins got a sample and an inkling last night of what 1937's vacation days will be like for those who own and navigate pleasure craft.

The marriage of Mrs. Adeline Pepper Paul, daughter of former United States Senator George Wharton Pepper and Mrs. Pepper of Devon, to Fitz-Eugene Dixon Newbold, son of Mrs. Arthur E. Newbold of Chestnut Hill and the late Mr. Newbold, took place this afternoon.

Two just opened exhibitions lengthen the French list for the week. These are a group show of work by Cezanne, Degas, Derain, Gauguin, Picasso, Pissarro, Renoir and Toulouse-Lautrec at the Marie Harriman, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, and a one-man show of paintings by Utrillo at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The Federal Trade Commission charged ten card clothing manufacturers and the Card Clothing Manufacturers Association today with suppressing competition in their industry and with maintaining uniform prices and terms of sale for their product.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn will ordain eight candidates for the priesthood from the diocesan Seminary of the Immaculate Conception at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.
Simon. Elwes and the Hon. Mrs. Elwes gave a reception yesterday afternoon at Mr. Elwes studio, 36 Central Park South, for Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador.

THE recent appearance of Milton Waldman's book on Catherine de' Medici and her children reminded the reading public that sixteenth-century France was a land of dramatic and sorrowful fortune. Ralph Roeder's newly published "Catherine de' Medici and the Lost Revolution" (Viking, $3.75) preaches the same lesson. Aside from that, the resemblance between the two is slight.

Thomas Midgley Jr., vice president of the Ethyl Gasoline Corporation, received the Perkin Medal for 1937 last night "for distinguished work in applied chemistry, including the development of antiknock motor fuels and safe refrigerants."

Several downtown properties passed to new control in transactions announced yesterday. Emanuel Frank, retired veal merchant now investing in real estate, bought the property at 52-58 Gansevoort Street from Paul W. Vollenweider through J. F. Cahill Co., brokers.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Jan. 8.--Mrs. Mabel E. Emerson of Boston was elected president of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America at the organization's forty-fourth annual convention, which closed here today. Other officers...

John H. Wright, president of the Jamestown Telephone Corporation of Jamestown, N. Y., said tonight he would take his case to the Supreme Court of the United States if the Federal Communications Commission decided his concern was under its jurisdiction.
Thirty-one thousand bales of wool, one of the largest shipments ever to arrive in this port, are being unloaded at the Commonwealth Pier from the motorship Thermopylae.
Pope Pius had one of the best night's rest since the beginning of his illness. He awoke this morning rested, free from pain and in a cheerful mood.

The Anchor Cap Corporation, it was revealed yesterday by a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public through the New York Stock Exchange, borrowed $600,000 from the Manufacturers Trust Company and $400,000 from the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company last October.

120th St., 308 W., 25x100.11; prior mtg., $21,750; also 120th St., 315 W., 25x100.11; prior mtg., $23.500; Kellong Holding Corp. to Peck-Salisbury Corp., 2,701 Webb Av.; purchase money; 6 per cent; $12,250.

A categorical answer to the question of whether Russia would be willing to cease sending military aid to Spain if Germany ceases was unobtainable here for the simple reason that no Soviet official admits, even in the most private of conversations, that Russia is sending or ever has sent such aid.

Raymond R. Guest, polo player, was re-elected president of the United Hunts Racing Association at the annual meeting yesterday. Retained in office with him for another year were John Hay Whitney as vice president and Lewis E. Waring as secretary and treasurer.

Workers in the United Hospital Campaign, continuing their efforts through the busy holiday season, have raised $259,000 since the last general report on Dec. 18, Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the drive, announced yesterday.
By newspapers and radio Madrid's population is being warned that the capital is facing the most serious crisis since General Francisco Franco first reached the gates of the city two months ago.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

The Outdoor Cleanliness Association launched yesterday its Winter campaign for clean streets at a joint meeting of its directors with Sanitation Department officials in the department's offices, 125 Worth Street.
The United States liner Washington arrived yesterday two days behind schedule. Captain Giles Stedman said the ship was held in Hamburg twenty-four hours behind sailing time, and had other delays in

A slate-blue bus, with a large "Ice Follies-1937" sign on its side, pulled up to the Hotel Lincoln last night, and out tumbled dozens of girls, in fur coats, hatless, in ski pants, in high white boots, in abbreviated skirts, in all varieties of informal sports costumes-this the travel-worn but eagerly enthusiastic cast of the first all-professional touring ice show ever to "play"
The rental of stores for additional units of chain merchandising organizations as well as for individual enterprises was a feature of the activity reported yesterday by brokers.
Villanova's basketball team scored a surprising 32-20 victory over Duquesne tonight in the first game of a double header at the Philadelphia Arena before 4,000 fans.
The resignation of Nelson Ruttenberg as counsel for the State Liquor Authority and the appointment in his place of William H. Ticho was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman.

The appeal of Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, widow of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, the oil man, from Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau's adverse ruling on her suit to invalidate provisions of her husband's will, was filed yesterday in the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

This city will celebrate tomorrow the fifty-ninth anniversary of a wreck of the Spanish bark Providencia, which early settlers assert resulted in the planting of the coconut palm trees which now beautify Florida's southeast coast.

While expansion was less marked in some branches of business this week, momentum gathered force in other divisions, following the interruption of the holidays, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The marriage of Miss Doris Marion cFleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Fleming of this city, to Charles Welles Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Spencer, also of this city, took place this evening in Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Compensation in 1935 of the principal executives of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company was disclosed yesterday in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange. H. D. Pillsbury, chairman of the company, received $41,949; N. R. Powley, president, $41,774; C. E. Fleager, a vice president, $23,349, and six other officers, a total of $97,930.

Dead for more than a week and perhaps since Christmas, the bodies of Mrs. Lavinia Williams, 43-yearold widow, and her 12-year-old daughter, Margaret, apparently victims of coal gas poisoning, were found yesterday noon in their three-room bungalow at 144-53 231st Street, Springfield Gardens, Queens.

The city opened a drive to protect city employes from loan sharks on two fronts yesterday, with Mayor La Guardia warning the employes against paying usurious interest, and the Municipal Credit Union cutting its loan rates to the level used by banks and personal loan corporations.

The longer the efforts of the Republican majority to elect a Speaker and organize the Assembly continue, the deeper appears the rift in the party. On the last test ten Republican members of the Assembly refused to vote to re-elect Speaker IVES.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in November have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with November, 1935.
Fiftyone of the nation's 531 lawmakers prefaced their personal history in the Congressional Directory with this-"Born on a farm" Three varied their themes with "born in a log cabin."

Tentative dates for horse shows for 1937 were approved, officers elected and reports received at the twentieth annual meeting of the American Horse Show Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

H. Wendell Endicott of Dedham has been elected president of the Boston Opera Association, succeeding the late Colonel Pierpont Langley Stackpole, who had become president of the association only a few days before his death.
The situation in Sian, capital of Shensi Province, was becoming increasingly dangerous today.

A decrease in the number of influenza and pneumonia cases in the city was reported yesterday by the Department of Health, while the number admitted to hospitals showed a slight gain over the previous day.

The Glenn Cunningham-Gene Venzke rivalry, track's stellar attraction for some five years, will be renewed tonight when the Columbus Council, K. of C., opens the post-Olympic footracing season with its eleventh annual games. The meet will be staged at the 106th Regiment Almory in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Grinnell Noyes of 1,120 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Irving Noyes, to William Raymond Driver Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Raymond Driver of Milton, Mass.
President Leon Cortes and his Cabinet tonight gave a farewell dinner for the retiring United States Minister, Leo R. Sack, and Mrs. Sack. The President, toasting Mr. Sack, declared:

Edward Bedell, 43 years old, an architect, accused of choking a gamecock to death on Thursday night at the New York Poultry Show, was freed of a charge of petty larceny by Magistrate Harris in Jefferson Market court yesterday after a friend paid $50, the value of the bird, to Charles Rippon of Carbondale. Pa., its owner.
Edmund Noble, author, journalist and commentator on foreign affairs, died today on his eightyfourth birthday.

103d St., 131-133 E., 32x100.11: Freda Trachtenberg to Louis Mesner, 133 E. 103d St.; mtg.. $11,000 (50 cents). 120th St., 315 W., 25x100.11; Ironside Estates, Inc. to Kellong Holding Corp., 831 Kelly St.; mtg., $23,500 ($6). 120th St., 308 W.. 25x100.4; Same to same; mtg., $21,750 ($6).

Judge Clarence G. Galston, in Brooklyn Federal court, issued yesterday an order directing the Compania Espanola de Navegacion Maritima of South America, owners of the Spanish freight steamship Navemar, to show cause on Tuesday why a decree awarding the vessel to the company should not be reopened and why Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to this country, should not be allowed to intervene in the matter.
Charles Hayden, senior partner of Hayden, Stone Co., bankers, died at 10 o'clock last night in his apartment at the Hotel SavoyPlaza. He was 66 years old. He had been seriously ill for several weeks.

An inquiry into complaints by the United Automobile Workers that the General Motors Company has hired professional strikebreakers is being "seriously considered" by the Senate committee appointed to investigate civil liberties violations.

The $35,026,000,000 public debt on next June 30 indicated in President Roosevelt's budget message today would make a new all-time high, exceeding that of last June 30 by $1,128,000,000, and the 1919 war high by $9,544,000,000.

Road and rapid transit facilities to the New York World's Fair of 1939 will be coordinated to permit the entrance or exit of 168,000 persons an hour at the fair site, Colonel John P. Hogan, chief engineer of the-fair, announced last night at a joint meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers and allied organizations at the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Arrangements were announced yesterday for the sale of two New York Stock Exchange memberships. The first was the initial sale of the year, made at $130,000, unchanged from the last previous transaction. The second was at $134,000, an increase of $4,000.

The Reliable Cotton Felt Co., Inc., purchased from the Hilltop Building and Loan Association the dwelling at 1,107 Madison St., Hoboken. The property adjoins the present plant of the buyer, who acquired it for expansion. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Samuel S. Strauss, former president of the Strauss Packing Company, 534 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, died yesterday of pneumonia at the Lenox Hill Hospital after recently undergoing an operation. Mr. Strauss, who lived at the Hotel Alden, 225 Central Park West, was 73 years old.

Sueo Oye of Japan, one of the world's greatest pole vaulters, will compete in the United States this Winter during the indoor season, it was learned yesterday from Daniel J. Ferris, secretary treasurer of the A. A. U.

Grover P. Heinzmann, former Controller of the city of Passaic and World War hero, was sentenced to five to ten years in State prison today after pleading non vult to payroll defalcations amounting to $41,000. Heinzmann was sentenced by Judge Robert H. Davidson in Common Pleas Court.

The great earthquake that rocked British seismographs at about 1:30 P. M., Greenwich mean time, Thursday and threw the needle off the instrument altogether at Singapore, is estimated by British officials here to have had its epicenter in the vicinity of Lhasa. Tibet.
The picturesque village of Igls today was plunged into depression by the "mysterious disappearance of the royal Netherland honeymooners."
The British Government decided today to take Germany and Italy at their word and begin a new effort toward achieving real neutrality in the Spanish civil war.

The John B. Stetson Company, hat manufacturer, yesterday reported a net profit of $485,334 for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, after Federal and State income taxes. interest, depreciation and other charges. After allowing for annual dividend requirements on 60,000 shares of $25-par, 8 per cent cumulative-preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to $1.50 each on 243,188 shares of no-par common stock outstanding.
Lotte Lehmann, soprano, in her first Westchester concert, sang tonight to more than 2,400 persons when she appeared in the annual subscription concert series presented by Mrs. Julian Olney.
Charles Kennedy, formerly connected with the production department of Julius Kayser Co., has been placed in charge of the fabric glove division of Fownes Bros. Co.

While the world situation today is confused, "common sense and a feeling of responsibility" will do much to settle France's internal and external difficulties, Marquis Melchoir de Polignac, associate manager of Pomery's, France, told members of the Advertising Club of New York yesterday.

Displaying a brand of basketball seldom seen in scholastic circles here, the De Witt Clinton High School team of New York rode on to its seventh consecutive victory by deeating South Side High School today, 47--37.

A suit naming as defendants the Atlas Corporation, the National Securities Investment Company and the Federated Capital Corporation was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by R. Myrtle Mankovitch, holder of thirty-one shares of stock in Federated Capital.

Twelve persons testified behind closed doors yesterday at the unofficial inquiry of a special committee of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association into the conduct of Magistrate Overton Harris on the bench. The identity of the witnesses was withheld, as well as the nature of their testimony, but it was reported that one of the witnesses was a prosecutor on District Attorney Dodge's staff and another a police captain.

As one interested in most sports and also as one who has actively participated in a variety of games. both American and British, the undersigned is impelled to write these lines after reading an account of the current test match in Melbourne between the English and Australian cricket teams.

A boycott of the proposed heavyweight championship fight between James J. Braddock, the titleholder, and Max Schmeling, German fighter who formerly held the crown, was launched yesterday by the NonSectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, Inc., an organization listing Samuel Untermyer as its president, with offices at 20 West Forty-seventh Street.
Police Officer Walter Whitted charged a woman listed as Anna M. Kross, magistrate of the Women's Court in New York City, with reckless driving today.
Rider College defeated the touring Ithaca quintet in a thrilling basketball game tonight. The score was 50-49, with a field goal by Sam Siciliano, The line-up:

The situation among European countries and the address of President Roosevelt to Congress last Wednesday will be discussed in sermons tomorrow. Some of the pastors will preach on "Spiritual Security."
Professor Henry Tonks, who, as Slade Professor of Fine Arts in the University of London, made Slade School one of the finest art schools in the world, died here today at the age of 74.

EDMUND RANDOLPH, whom Mr. ROOSEVELT quoted in his message, was a member of the Continental Congress, Governor of Virginia, Attorney General and Secretary of State of the United States. He is less well remembered than he deserves. He was the victim of long injustice.

More than 1,000 of the 9,000 students of the University of Wisconsin cut their classes today and stormed the Capitol to demand an accounting from Governor Philip F. La Follette on the ousting of their president, Dr. Glenn Frank, by a board of regents which the Governor controlled.
One man was injured and two others badly shaken yesterday afternoon when two airplanes crashed almost head on while taxiing across Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.
If, as economic statisticians used to believe, volume of steel production is a safe measure of prosperity, then 1936 ought to rank high, not only in this country but in others.

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of Arthur G. Jaeger of Jackson Heights as Sheriff of Queens County. He fills the place left vacant by the elevation of William F. Brunner to the Aldermanic presidency.

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of Arthur G. Jaeger of Jackson Heights as Sheriff of Queens County. He fills the place left vacant by the elevation of William F. Brunner to the Aldermanic presidency.

The General Motors Corporation appeared more determined than ever today to maintain its position that it will not consent to negotiations for settlement of the strike called by the United Automobile Workers of America until the stay-in strikers evacuate the five factories they have occupied.

W. Starling Burgess, naval architect, who designed the Enterprise and Rainbow, last two defenders of the America's Cup in the international yacht races, has brought suit in Supreme Court against Boyd Donaldson, his partner in the designing of the two boats, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Midland 4 Bank and Lloyds Bank, the last of the "Big Five" to issue profit and dividend statements, both disclosed tonight that they, in common with the other leading banks, have earned appreciably larger profits.

Though a number of important "if's" overhang the President's budget message, it is far and away the most cheering report on the nation's finances that has been sent to Congress since the Roosevelt Administration entered office.

Manhattan's minor basketball units broke even in a double-header at the Jasper gymnasium last night. The' Green junior varsity overwhelmed the New York University School of Dentistry, 55-23, while the cubs succumbed to a secondhalf rally by St. Peter's High School of Staten Island, 25-23.
Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, admitted today as he boarded the liner Caledonia for New York that he would act, if need be, in the capacity of commercial traveler.

In a fast and hard-fought basketball game, Lowell Textile tonight defeated Panzer College of East Orange, N. J., 36 to 30. Doukszewicz and Bassett, each with ten points, were the leading scorers. Dispenziere and Brody starred for the visitors.

Displaying a brand of basketball seldom seen in scholastic circles here, the De Witt Clinton High School team of New York rode on to its seventh consecutive victory by deeating South Side High School today, 47--37.
Miss Jane Peterkin of Garden City was honored at a luncheon given today by Miss Janet Trull of Brooklyn at Sherry's. Miss Peterson's marriage to John Kirkman Gurney will take place next Saturday.

Judge R. M. Gibson in Federal court today directed three officials and an employee of a private detective agency to surrender Tuesday to a United States Marshal and answer charges of failing to appear before a Senatorial subcommittee investigating alleged labor espionage by industrial firms.

Pope Pius passed another fairly good night and his condition today was described as "unchanged." When his doctor called at 6:30 A. M. the Pope obtained leave to have two windows of his bedroom thrown wide open.

What happens to the messages which our Presidents send to Congress? In the case of Mr. Roosevelt's message read in person last Wednesday in the House of Representatives, the original manuscript, carefully guarded by the House parliamentarian, was sent the next day to the third floor of the Capitol for preservation in the archives of the House file room.
Mr. and Mrs. Mark Matthews entertained with a large supper dance tonight at their home here. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Forrest Butterworth,

Building for 1936 in Greenwich reached the highest peak in five years, with a total well above any preliminary estimates. Figures released by Building Inspector Charles D. Crosby revealed that the total for the year was $3,237,302, or $1,596,021 above the total for 1935.
The George Washington University Colonials tonight avenged a defeat of last year in downing the fast St John's five of Brooklyn, 48 to 28. It was the Colonials sixth straight victory.

Dr. Fred G. Fielding, widely known in Northern New York, died at his home here today. He was 71. Dr. Fielding, a native of Glens Falls, began the practice of medicine in Hartford, Washington County, in 1890. Three years later he came to Glens Falls. He was graduated from Columbia University in 1889.

The American Box Board Company reported yesterday for the year to Nov. 28, last, a net profit of $316,009 after having made allowances for interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

President ROOSEVELT'S broad program of cooperation clearly looks to working agreements with the States. He remains of the mind that the country's needs cannot be met by the separate action of the forty-eight States. But it is plain also that he considers it necessary for State and Federal legislation to supplement and strengthen each other.

IN an effort to relieve the acute shortage of worthy material for outstanding pictures, a problem of increasing concern to the industry, Columbia this week embarked upon a drastic program by which it is hoped a minimum of ten stories can be assured each season for its more pretentious offerings.
MIAMI, Fla.--That infallible index of "the season" here in the Greater Miami area and, for that matter, of all South Florida--opening of horse racing at Hialeah Park--is set for Wednesday.

All but one component of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity declined for the week ended Jan. 2, and the combined figure slumped sharply to 103. This compares with 107.8 (revised) for the previous week and 94.7 for the week ended Jan. 4, 1936.

Miss Margery Delano Robinson, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Alson Haven Robinson of Plainfield, was married this afternoon to Laurence Walker Collins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence W. Collins of Littleton, N. H., in the First Unitarian Church, Plainfield, of which the bride's father is pastor.
Four Rochester concerns, each the largest in its field, placed this city first among up-State communities in the number of patents obtained, Frank B. Keiper, patent attorney, said today.

PEOPLE have been talking across the Atlantic now for ten years; the transoceanic radiophone has celebrated its tenth birthday. Since Jan. 7, 1927, thousands of phone calls have been routed across the ocean "talk-bridge."

A deal which involved the sale of one of the oldest residences in Madison, N. J., and which will also initiate a new home development in that community was closed last week in the purchase by Charles J. McKenna of the Benjamin Bruen home at 250 Main Street, Madison.

Again serving the double purpose of providing funds for the Bellevue Hospital Social Service and an evening of gayety for household staffs of New York, Long Island and Westchester homes, the fourth annual butlers' ball will take place on Wednesday night at the Commodore.

Wesleyan's basketball team conquered Connecticut State College, 46 to 36, tonight. At half-time the home team was leading. 20 to 18. In the closing minutes of play the Cardinals launched a strong attack. with Richards and Havens on the scoring end. Pringle and Janiga were the high scorers for the visitors.
Deadlocked after the regulation 40 minutes of play, Columbia won a 34-to-28 victory over Cornell in the overtime period of an Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight.
The Fisher Lumber Corporation's plant, a subsidiary of General Motors, will be closed by the end of next week unless the.strikes in the North are settled, Keith Spurrier, manager, said today.
The streets of this little model town at Norris Lake, owned by the government through the TVA, were laid out aesthetically in curves, with many turns and intersections.
Fun-loving Bavarians, carefully dodging the error of another German region which called their carnival king "Adolf," frolicked today through the first stages of a monthlong fiesta.

Dr. Frances Allen deFord, a widely known physician who, with her husband, Dr. Moses deFord, pioneered in obtaining improved hygienic conditions in Northeast Philadelphia, died of pneumonia today in Jewish Hospital after a short illness. She was 81 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dora Harriett Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Kelly Jr., of this place, to Charles A. Sullivan, also of Port Chester, son of Peter A. Sullivan of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Sullivan.

Rare books and manuscripts, which include several of the first biblical texts printed in Hebrew and English, will be exhibited today at the opening of the Founders Exhibit of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America at 122d Street and Broadway.

Again asserting its guardianship of the fundamental rights of American citizens, the Supreme Court of the United States last Monday sustrained a citizen's right to participate in a peaceable assembly--to meet with others for public discussion-free from any governmental restriction.

A mighty concentration of Anglo-French sea power began to take shape off the coasts of Spain and Spanish Morocco this week at a time when Anglo-French. diplomacy needed every ounce of its strength to keep the Spanish civil war from spreading.
In our rotogravure picture section this morning Page 1 shows no immediate connection with the next two pages;

Victims to a large extent of the depression, two of Pittsfield's best known hotels--the Maplewood, which catered exclusively to Summer resort visitors, and the New American, for the most part a commercial house--will soon be history. Demolition of the 200-room Maplewood already has started.
The third Piccadilly Dance of Achievement was given tonight in the Rose Garden of the Bellevue-Stratford. Guests were received by Miss Eleanor Widener Dixon and by Miss Helen W. Foxe.
A suit to recover $314 from Ethel Barrymore Colt, "also known as Ethel Barrymore," was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Mme. Frances, Inc., modiste of 17 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Mrs. John Mullaney of 621 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Regina Mullaney, to J. Edwin Skelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Skelly of Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Alice Jean McDermott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McDermott of this city, to Captain Guy B. Henderson of the United States Army air service.

The ninth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Young Folks Temple Leagues, Union of American Hebrew Congregations, was formally opened yesterday afternoon with a reception to the delegates held at the Marcus Loew Auditorium of Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

Eight thousand persons paraded through the midtown district yesterday afternoon to emphasize their dissatisfaction with the $650,000,000 asked by President Roosevelt to continue the WPA until June 30.

WEATER extremes through the country in the week had a slackening effect upon retail trade. In the Northwest snow and subzero temperatures curtailed shopping, while in other centers, such as New England, unseasonal warmth had the same influence. However, average volume continued to show a fair increase over a year ago.

The American Committee for the Relief of the Needy of Poland has arranged a reception and dance which will be held on Saturday at the Savoy-Plaza under the patronage of Mrs. Sylvester Gruszka, wife of the Polish Consul General at New York, and of M. S. Szymczak, a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

Miss Helen Adams, debutante daughter of Mrs. Andrew Leland Adams, has been appointed chairman of a group of young women who will serve as cake and candy vendors at the annual bridge and sale of the Hudson Avenue Boys' Club on Wednesday afternoon at The Towers, Brooklyn.

MELANCHOLY days are here, the saddest of the year. The rains and gales of Winter, the slush underfoot have made the annual chorus of snuffles sneezes and coughs resound in office, subway and home. I have, thou hast, he hath--a cold. Patent medicines, drugs, vaccines and other cures are discussed. used and discarded.
Alice Stone Blackwell, now in her eightieth year, recalled today the more than six decades she fought for women's rights and expressed a wish that women had made better use of their suffrage.
The Mediterranean, mother of civilization, artery of trade, is entering upon a new phase of its history.

Back in 1911 Kaiser Wilhelm sent a German cruiser to the small port of Agadir in Northern Morocco. There followed a severe international crisis which was settled at the conference of Algeciras the following year by the Germans giving up any claim to Agadir.

Jubilation in Chicago tomorrow over the joint anniversaries of the National Council of Jewish Women and of its founder, sprightly 79year-old Mrs. Hannah Solomon, will be echoed at headquarters in New York as 200 communities celebrate.
The Chaco peace conference today initialed an accord for maintenance of the military status quo in the disputed Chaco region and for free commercial traffic in its western section.

Many years ago, when George W. Norris despaired of ever getting Congress to do those things which he thought it ought to do, and to stop doing those things he thought it ought not to do, he was wont to take comfort in a dream.

BRUTAL, skillful and preposterous, Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna looms above better men between the decisive rules of Cortez and Diaz. He was born in Mexico in 1794--and a good deal of Mexico's reputation for turbulence and tragedy may be laid to the fact that he did not die until 1876.
Bloomington has its musical mouse, also. He has been named Mickey as a compliment to his singing relative, Minnie, in the Chicago Industrial Home for Children in suburban Woodstock.

The largest offering of United States stamps announced for auction in this city for some time will be held on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons at the J. C. Morgenthau galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street.

A new Yale magazine. The Campus Cop, was suppressed by the faculty today on the ground that Yale has enough magazines already. The Harkness Hoot. a magazine habit ually critical of college life, died a year ago after two years of effer vescent cynicism.

Harley L. Clarke, Chicago and New York capitalist and former head of the Utilities Power and Light Company, filed a $400,000 slander suit in the Circuit Court today against Dwight H. Green, former Federal District Attorney.

With the sailing of the Grace liner Santa Paula yesterday to South and Central America and the West Coast, William A. McLean, her purser, started his twentieth year at sea. He has sailed about 1,500,000 miles, he estimates.
The twenty-third annual meeting of the Association of American Colleges will be held on Thursday and Friday at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.

Trust Serge Koussevitzky to remember an occasion and to observe it in the proper fashion and spirit. At yesterday afternoon's concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Koussevitzky and his men twined a tonal wreath in memory of the late American composer, Edward MacDowell, who was born seventy-five years ago last December.

Schwartz Gross, architects, have been commissioned to prepare plans for alteration of two buildings. One is the structure at 57 West 105th Street, owned by Marion E. Hinchliffe. It will be remodeled into one-room apartments with kitchenettes, dressing rooms and baths and three-room units with dining bays. Accommodation will be provided for four families on each floor.
Pat Tanner, vice president and general manager of Johnson, points out the remarkable development of these midget power plants in spite of the fact that the industry was born only fifteen years ago.

Many reservations have been received for the annual supper dance to be held under the auspices of the Democratic Junior League of New York on Saturday night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for the benefit of the league's Social Service Bureau.

A jury of seven judges will select the winner of the Irwin D. Wolf award in the contest among retail stores for creation of the best package in use last year, it was announced yesterday. The award will be made in connection with the second annual packaging clinic of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania during the week of Jan. 18.

The recent insertion of a humanities survey course into its lowerclass undergraduate curriculum, following a half century of "liberalization" in Columbia University's courses of study, lends "a better and deeper meaning" to education, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Columbia president, declared yesterday.

Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador, and Countess Potocka, as official guests of honor are expected to attend the fourth annual Night in Poland Ball--entitled "A Night in Old Krakow"--which will be held on Feb. 3 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf Astoria.

Running by far the fastest five and a half furlongs shown thus far at the Tropical Park meeting, the 6year-old mare, Lady Higloss, carried the Purple and White colors of Miss A. Doris to a scintillating triumph in the Clearwater Purse today as the last Saturday program of the current session was decided.

Official Referee Joseph I. Green fixed Jan. 28 and 29 yesterday as hearing days in the contempt of court action against Father Divine, religious cult leader in Harlem. Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman referred the question to Mr. Green.

Among those who had guests at the thirty-eighth annual dinner dance of the Maryland Society of New York last night at the Plaza were Paul C. Whipp, president of the society; Paul Kieffer, a former president; Dr. Edward McPherson Armstrong and Herbert T. Magruder, vice presidents.

VARSITY SHOW" is the title of a new WEAF series opening Jan. 22, which, boasting genuine college atmosphere, will be broadcast from the campuses of many of the country's leading universities "with all the pep and variety undergraduates can muster."
Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta made the country's top-ranking tennis player, Donald Budge, look like a novice today as he routed him, 6-2, 7-5, 6-0, to win the Miami Biltmore tournament.
Trailing for the greater part of the first half, the Brooklyn College quintet rallied to conquer the University of Newark, 44-38, at Union Temple in Brooklyn last night.

From the standpoint of the motor boat sportsmen there is every indication that 1937 will be a "vintage" year-one to be long remembered. Every form of motor boating is headed for a great expansion in the season now opening-cruising, cruiser racing, fishing, inboard and outboard boating of all types.

IT IS, of course, axiomatic among those who are up on their popular literature that the great North Woods are peculiarly endowed with a somewhat vague and shadowy power to change men, to mold and modify habitant and transient alike.
The Hamburg-American liner Reliance starts today on her second around the world cruise. She will cover 31,570 miles and call at thirtyseven ports in 136 days. Among her passengers are:

A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY-Tomorrow evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. This is a melodrama by Melvin Levy, one which tells of a group of squatters who take over a gangster's farmhouse just as he wants to use it. In the cast are Tom Powers, Louise Campbell, Teddy Bergman, Fredrica Slemons, Leon Ames, Alfred Herrick, Will Geer, Roy Gordon and Elmer Brown.

Rutgers' well-balanced swimming team opened its season with a victory over Columbia tonight, 42 to 33. Although without the services of Jimmy Reilly, the Scarlet natators took four of the seven individual events and finished second in the three others.

Business conditions were spotty in most sections of the country last week, with the rising level of retail distributive totals being checked to some extent in many areas by unfavorable weather conditions, according to reports from the various Federal Reserve districts.
An attractive educational exhibit in which scenes of New York's waterfront in sailing ship days are depicted is one of the features sponsored by the Seamen's Church Institute at the Motor Boat Show.
THE quality of the "Jungle Books" by Kipling which have been coming to mar ket seems to have improved with each new arrival.

Miss Elizabeth Miller Hoskins, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Roy Hoskins, was married tonight to Edwin Parson Young Jr. of Baltimore, son of Edwin Parson Young of Towanda, Pa., and the late Mrs. Diana Montayne Young, in Christ Episcopal Church, Mathews Court House, Va. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George B. Shaw.

Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the United Hospital Fund Campaign Committee, announced last night a contribution of $6,000 from the Bank of the Manhattan Company and one of $5,000 from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

FOR years and years the name Sophie Tucker has been a synonym for ancientness in the theatre--ancientness combined with a certain monolithic ruggedness and solidity, like the name Gibraltar in the Mediterranean.

The kernel of the Italo-British Mediterranean agreement is the status quo clause, which binds the two powers not only to refrain from disturbing the existing territorial situation but also to discourage any attempt by a third power to seize territory.

In the United States Court of Claims today the following calendars were announced: Calendar for Monday, Jan. 11: Call of the January calendar. Rule to show cause. Plaintiffs to show cause Monday, Jan. 11, why case should not be dismissed in the following:

WITHIN the Boy Scout program there is considerable journalistic activity. Through troop periodicals and local Scout press clubs thousands of young men may learn something of the work of the newspaper craft.

Wellesley College has established a posture clinic for children which is maintained during the Winter months by the Department of Hygiene and Physical Education for pupils in the Wellesley public schools.

PEOPLE who ride on rubber tires recently marked a momentous anniversary. It was sixty years ago that an Englishman named Wickham turned up at Kew Botanical Gardens in London with 70,000 wild rubber seeds which he had smuggled out of the Amazon forests in Brazil.
The Toronto Maple Leafs gave the Montreal Canadiens a 2-1 setback before 13,000 fans tonight in the fastest and most fiery game played in Toronto in the National Hockey League season.

The first performance of the revival of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "Le Coq d'Or," with Lily Pons and Ezio Pinza in the leading roles, the afternoon of Feb. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera has been taken over to augment the maintenance fund of the chorus of the Schola Cantorum.

THE title of the French original of this novel is "Remorques." In the English edition it becomes "Tug-Boat," which conveys nothing whatever either of the magnificent sea-drama which fills the bulk of the book, or of the human drama which is enacted ashore.

Announcement has been made to the engagement of Miss Elsie Mary, Medlicott, daughter of Mrs. Elsto, M. Medlicott of this place, to H. Myles Jacob, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Martin Jacob of Verona. N. J.

Outboard racing was once considered purely a man's game, but one now finds girls rivaling boys in this sport. In outboarding every type and class of person are gathered and the implied question to a newcomer is not "Who are you?" but "What can you do?"
AMERICANS are nowadays making a study of all things British. The sovereignty, Constitution and empire of Britain are subjected to a friendly but searching scrutiny.

The all-match-play method used for the last three years in the national amateur championship has been abandoned, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association.

Light Horse Harry Cooper and two "dark horse" entries, Jules Huot of Canada and Art Bell of Pasadena, Calif., ran a dead heat late today to lead at the half-way stage of the $8,000, seventy-two-hole Los Angeles open.

The proposal that relief throughout the city be conducted as "one public welfare operation for all classes" was made yesterday by Commissioner William Hodson of the Department of Public Welfare in an address under the auspices of the Trade Union Institute of the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
Emma Maud Perkins, professor emeritus of Latin at Flora Stone Mather College of Western Reserve University when she died Jan. 1, left $30,000 of a $85,000 estate to Vassar College.

James Waterman Wise, who has just returned from Brazil, where he examined the situation with regard to fascism, and Rabbi Milton Sternberg of the Park Avenue Synagogue will present their views on the future of the Jewish race, at a symposium tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

The German and Italian answers to Great Britain and France on the question of alien volunteers in Spain, together with military and naval events in and around Spain, confirm the impression that Chancellor Adolf Hitler, like Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, is determined to continue his Spanish campaign while seeking to sidestep that extension of the war beyond the borders of Spain-a possibility envisaged in the neutrality resolution of the United States Congress.

WITH the publication of "Washington: City and Capital," the Federal Writers' guide to the District of Columbia, which is about to see the light, Uncle Sam steps out in the role of Baedeker, preparing to give his vast constituency a vivid modern picture of their own country.

Harris Mathewson Hanshue of Los Angeles, a pioneer air transport operator and air mail carrier on the West Coast, died on Friday night in the Flower Hospital here of a stroke, after an operation ten days before. He was 55 years old.

The armaments race in Europe has reached a point at which the German Navy seems to be cracking under the strain. Things have come to such a pass that the Minister for War, General von Blomberg, has issued a decree authorizing naval ratings to cease addressing their officers in the third person and to use the pronoun "you" instead.

An old-established New England hardware manufacturing firm, Thomas Laughlin Company of Portland, Me., is featuring a new metal finish at the National Motor Boat Show. The new metal finish is known as "camelyte."

Governor Lehman and the 1937 Legislature met face to face for the first time on Wednesday when the Governor appeared at a joint session of the Senate and Assembly and outlined his latest legislative program in a lengthy address.

Captain E. Erskine Looh, leader of the Andes-Amazon Expedition which has been active in the field for fifteen months, has returned with his men to Quito, reporting success in locating an airline through the Llanganatis and Mulatos Mountains (chains of the Andes) to the Oriente in the East, a route hitherto believed impossible.
DEBT: "The world owes more to the tillers of the soil than to any other class, and I think we are coming to the point where the farmer has a place in the sun."-Senator Norris.

REHEARSALS have run over time at the Metropolitan Opera this season, and there have been a number of extra sessions. All of which means added expense. It is estimated roughly that the management has spent about $15,000 for extra rehearsal time thus far.
Nazi authorities renewed action today against Franciscan lay brothers, charged in the past with immorality and smuggling money from the country, with a bankruptcy proceeding.

Many of the larger flower shows now make a practice of including in their schedules a number of classes calling for the use of plant material of genera native to certain definite geographical regions of the world-namely China, Japan, Iran, India and North or Central and South America.
A Congress, composed mostly of members of the old one, took its place in Washington this week and dug in for a session that will likely run into the Summer.

Dr. and Mrs. Phillips Foster Greene of Yale-in-China Mission, who are friends of Generalissimo and Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, will speak on their life in China at a meeting tomorrow at the Hotel St. Regis of the Daughters of Ohio in New York.

A deficiency relief appropriation of $1,040,100,000, instead of the $650,000,000 asked by President Roosevelt for the rest of the current fiscal year, has been demanded in a statement issued by David Lasser, president of the Workers Alliance, the union of WPA workers.

Rising costs of fabrics and other garment components have not precipitated speculative buying in the apparel field, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

SYDNEY, Australia.--Australia enters the world market with a new commodity as the result of the researches of Dr. G. H. Vernon, noted scientist who made a voyage of exploration in her mandated territory.

An estate of $236,874, most of which ultimately will go to the University of Pennsylvania, was left by Dr. Horace Phillips, who died in Atlantic City on July 23. An inventory and appraisal was filed today.

A Colonial ball and pageant will be presented by 150 members of the young men's division of the Sons of the American Revolution and junior members of the Daughters of the American Revolution on Friday at the Plaza as a benefit for the D. A. R. Student Loan Fund, which operates as a revolving fund and is not restricted to the membership of either of the two patriotic societies.

In the report for 1936 of the Committee on Professional Economics of the New York County Lawyers Association are many interesting facts and some recommendations even more so. In New York State there is one lawyer for every 456 persons; in this city for every 378.

Mrs. George Douglass died yesterday at her home here. She was 90 years old. Mrs. Douglass, a native of Chillicothe, Ohio, came to Richmond about fourteen years ago to live with a daughter, Mrs. Samuel Clay, widow of the former United States Minister to Egypt.

Health conditions in the United States continue to improve, with new low death rates recorded in 1935 for typhoid fever and diphtheria, Surgeon General Parran said today in his annual report on the work of the Public Health Service.

Making its first start in defense of the championship, the La Salle Military Academy hockey team defeated the St. John's Prep sextet, 1--0, in the Private Schools Hockey League play at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday.
Shirley E. Brown, one of Steuben County's oldest practicing attorneys, died here tonight. His age was 81.

More than 1,300 foreign-born adults are enrolled in the 265 home classes conducted in the five boroughs by the Neighborhood Teachers Division of the WPA-Adult Education program of the Board of Education, according to Miss Elizabeth Woodward, supervisor of the project.

In an unexpected move designed to draw an early decision on proposed freightrate adjustments now pending before it, the Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by the nation's railroads to decide on the rates suggested for certain leading commodities without waiting for the completion of testimony on all of the rates involved in the case. The request will be submitted to the full commission on Monday.

Popular among boating areas on the Eastern seaboard is Long Island's South Shore with its many protected inland waterways, sizable bays and ready access to ocean fishing grounds through East Rockaway, Jones and Fire Island inlets.

The first important step in the development of Fordham University's newly established Italian Department was made yesterday when the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university, announced the appointment of the Rev. Gerald Groveland Walsh as dean of that branch of the Graduate School.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the eleven months to Nov. 30 a net operating income of $21,251,645, and for November one of $2,643,133.

Launching his indoor campaign at the New Jersey National Guard Armory in Jersey City last night, Bob Rodenkirchen of the New York Athletic Club, world's record-holder for the 200 meters, captured the special invitation 300-yard dash that featured the twenty-seventh annual Dickinson High School track and field meet.

The Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossining, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of a card party to be given on Jan. 19 at the Roosevelt under the auspices of the King Edward VII Chapter of the Daughters of the British Empire.

The effectiveness of the Soviet's internal propaganda machine in producing the desired mass reactions was shown strikingly again this week in its success in inducing good humor on both sides when a census was made.
WESTERN history is still "Western" in color, and its heroes were all big gunmen, admits Cecil B. De Mille, who recently finished making "The Plainsman."
Among the valuable services available to seagoing men at the New York Field Station of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey are several which appeal particularly to yachtsmen.

B. L. are their initials. Beatrice Lillie and Bert Lahr are their names. Since Christmas night they have been warming the old Winter Garden with the sunniest comedy it has contained in a musical revue laconically entitled "The Show Is On."

A series of pre-rushing-season smokers, started at chapter houses this week, gave Group A fraternities on the University of Pennsylvania campus their first opportunity to entertain freshmen and other new students eligible for membership.
As is his annual wont, the respected and experienced Brock Pemberton penned a collection of notes on theatrical happenings of note occurring during the past year, which appeared in your columns.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, and Raymond N. Ball, president of the New York State Bankers Association, will be guests of honor at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee, to be held Jan. 18 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

SOMETHING.new in American labor tactics has stirred the imagination of large numbers of wage-earners of all classes-white collar unskilled, semi-skilled and skilled. It is the sit-down strike. The name is not quite accurate for the disaffected employes stay in the plants and seldom sit down at their machines, preferring, if anything, to stand up or roam about their workshops.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, today had authorized four steel workers to act as a "Little Supreme Court" in settling disputes between the management and its 100,000 employes.

Miss Mary Rose Freschi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Freschi of Brooklyn and niece of Judge John J. Freschi of the Court of General Sessions in Manhattan, was married yesterday morning to Dr. William R. Ferraro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rosario Ferraro of Canton, Ohio.

" Pickled porkers" were the center of attraction today as their squealing brought out an inquiring crowd of citizens. A supply of sour cider had been placed near a pump by a farmer who hoped he might find some use for it.

Jack Trammel, Youngstown (Ohio) heavyweight, knocked out Al Walker, Harlem, in 1:31 of the second round of a scheduled tenround bout before 2,000 at the Rockland Palace last night. Trammel weighed 190 1/2 pounds and Walker 189 1/4.

Simulated snow, dazzling ice and prismatic crystal effects will transform the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria into a Winter setting for the annual snow ball for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Hospital on the night of Jan. 20 under the
To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 11: LIEUTENANTS--Morris Coon, 4th Divis ion, assignment changed from duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform to duty as supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen.
The State Department refuses to believe that Europe is about to commit the "suicidal adventure" of war, notwithstanding the alarming reports concerning Spain and Morocco.

A fellowship for observation and training in radio network procedure has been granted to Allen Miller, head of the University Broadcasting Council of Chicago, by the General Education Board, a Rockefeller foundation, it was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.
To the long-recognized activities of the Corps of Engineers in connection with commercial navigation has been added a new duty. Pleasure boating is now recognized as having a Federal interest.

Following the approval by the Federal Government of the $631,000 yacht basin to be built between West 145th and 155th Streets in the Hudson River, metropolitan yacht owners are anxiously awaiting the development of the marina, which, when completed, will be the fulfillment of desires of the marine trades industry, a number of local nautical clubs, chambers of commerce and civio and taxpayers associations.

Announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Samuel D. Friedman, president of the Palestine Lighthouse, only institution in the Near East caring for the blind, of the formation of an advisory council on education, which will aid officers at the executive headquarters here.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Ogden of Boston have come to the St. Regis. Mrs. Robert M. Wood has returned from Sheridan, Wyo., and has joined Mr. and Mrs. John Stilwell at Mayfair House.

About 4,000 persons attended the twelfth annual entertainment and dance of the Jewish Postal Workers Welfare League of New York City, Inc., last night at the Hotel Riverside Plaza, 253 West Seventy-third Street.
The death of Professor Leonardo de Torres Quevedo, noted Spanish engineer and inventor of the cable railway at Niagara Falls, was disclosed tonight.

LATEST of several hundred New York almanacs all but a very few of which have vanished. An AlInanac for New Yorkers, a local Federal Writers Project, is soon to be issued. With the new year the oldest of such American publications still continuing. the Old Farmer's Almanac of Boston.

A Federal grand jury voted conspiracy indictments today against thirty-six persons, mostly election officials, in a drive to purge the city of notorious November vote frauds. Judge Albert L. Reeves admonished the jury three weeks ago to "reach for all, even if you find them in authority."

TO start the new year right the Materiel Division, at Wright Field, Dayton, has issued a special number of the Air Corps News Letter devoted entirely to its manifold and important activities. The functions of procurement, maintenance, testing and development of new material in a host of different applications to the military flying arm are here described and portraits reproduced of the men who make these complicated wheels go round, from Brig. Gen. A. W.

Christodora House will be the beneficiary of a special supper dance in he Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night when a rhumba contest, to be judged by a dance expert, will be the main feature.

A prediction that more industrial products will be sent to the College of Applied Science at Syracuse University for commercial testing in 1937 than at any other time in the past twentyfive years was made today by Dr. E. F. Berry, Assistant Professor of Civil Engineering and director of the laboratory.

Heavy bookings on steamships sailing during the weeks before the coronation of King George VI on May 12 were report yesterday by line officials here. The last sailing to arrive in time for the coronation will be on May 5.

Props and Paint, dramatic society of the College of New Rochelle, will present its annual mid-year play Thursday evening in Chidwick Auditorium. Miss Miriam Little Simons, Professor of Speech, is directing the play.

The increase in the population of beaver colonies in Canopus Hollow and Putnam Valley eight miles north of here has reached such proportions that the farmers of the section now regard them as a nuisance with their timber cutting and dam building activities.

Henry M. Hutchings, a lawyer for the last forty-three years, died yesterday at his home in Beacon Hill. He was 66 years old. Survivors are his widow, Mrs. Mary M. Hutchings, and a daughter, Miss Mary Hinckley Hutchings.
A score of destitute Chinese staged a "sit-down" protest in the middle of the street car tracks on Eighth Avenue, the city's main thoroughfare. here today.
John Barbirolll conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall in the last of the students' concerts to be given this season under his baton.
The wheat market on the Board of Trade reersed its action today with the greater part of the news favorable for a higher level of prices.

A law office building without exterior openings except for the chambered entrance doors, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, architect, is under construction in Racine, Wis., to house the office personnel of S. C. Johnson Son, Inc. It will be completed in the Summer of 1937.

The Building Trades Employers Association of Westchester County will be host to the State association at a three-day convention which will open here Wednesday night. A special car will be attached to one of the regular New York Central trains and will carry the up-State delegates to Harmon, where they will complete the journey by bus to the Roger Smith Hotel here, where the convention will be held.
Before the hearings were held which preceded the virtual dismissal of GLENN FRANK as president of the University of Wisconsin, the question uppermost in the minds of disinterested observers was this:

The North Shore of Long Island experienced in 1936 one of the most active years in some time, Sidney D. Ripley of the country department of Douglas L. Elliman Co. declares in a review of real estate developments in that area during the past twelve months.

The varsity unit of Manhattan College's Debating Society will oppose speakers from Georgetown University at Washington tomorrow night and a team representing the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia Tuesday night.

Magistrate Overton Harris, who has been known to criticize the police harshly on occasion, publicly commended Patrolman John Grundman of the West Twentieth Street station yesterday when he learned that the patrolman had probably saved a World War veteran's $500 in bonus bonds.
STOWE, Vt.--New York skiers arriving here by the first of the Winter snow trains today will throng the Mount Mansfield toll road and near-by Practice Hill.

Mr. and Mrs. William P. Hardenbergh Jr. of Bernardsville, N. J., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Clark Hardenbergh to George W. Knight, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Aston Knight of this city and Manoir de Chantereine, Beaumont le Roger, France.
Among the glad tidings to greet the new Congress as it assembled here this week was the assurance from President Roosevelt that, at long last, a balance of the Federal budget is in sight.

IN the Ocala National Forest of spring and lake sprinkled Central Florida the United States Forest Service lately completed and opened as recreational areas Fern Hammock Springs and Juniper Springs. Juniper Springs, the newest development, is called a swimmer's paradise.

The Social Security Board today announced Federal grants totaling $2,724,615 today for public assistance in California, Hawaii, Maryland, Michigan, Nebraska, Rhode Island and Vermont. The grants are for the period Jan. 1-March 31. Amounts to each State:
