The president's house at Dickinson College, now occupied by Dr. Fred P. Corson and his family, is to be remodeled once more. Mrs. Paul Appenzellar of Bronxville, N. Y., wife of Paul Appenzellar, '95, has offered to meet the cost.

Joseph Thum, proprietor of Thum's White Elephant Alleys, at Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway, who had long been known as "the father of American bowling," died yesterday afternoon in the Parsons Hospital, 35-06 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. He would have been 79 years old on the 24th of this month.

THE final concert under the direction of John Barbirolli this season and the first appearance of Igor Stravinsky as guest conductor will mark the week's concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. At the Metropolitan the revival of "Tales of Hoffmann" will be presented.
PURRED on by improved new tools, woodworking hobbyists have begun their annual re treat from society after business hours to pursue the delights of craftsmanship in workshops at home.

Final decrees totaling $26,427,302 were awarded to New York real estate owners last year for property condemned by the city for public purposes, according to figures compiled in the office of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels.
Japan's foreign trade in 1936 reached an alltime high figure of 5,725,875 yen, it was announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Roderic B. Barnes of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Barnes, to Jesse Angell Hall, son of Mrs. John R. Hall, also of Washington, and the late Mr. Hall.
Bride-training is something more than teaching the art of homemaking, the Santa Barbara State College has decided..A girl also should know how to make a living, as well as how to run a home.

The Pan-American Press Conference took a vigorous stand today against censorship in all its forms. In a plenary session which began at 10 A. M. and continued with a brief recess until late at night two resolutions were adopted repudiating all censorships.
Country house gatherings, always popular at this time of year, are being prolonged this season, by way of escaping the influenza epidemic in London

Bizet's "Carmen" received its second performance of the present Metropolitan season yesterday afternoon, with Rosa Ponselle in the leading part. There was a new Jose, Sydney Rayner, and the Escamillo on this occasion was Julius Huehn.

Frank Tilghman Dilworth, retired manufacturer, died here yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Joseph Skirm, in his seventy-eighth year. Born in Port Penn, Del., Mr. Dilworth was a member of the

An optimistic view of the real estate situation for 1937 is held by Harold C. Samuels of the realty firm bearing his name. Mr. Samuels looks for steady increase in values and much larger absorption of space. Among the bright features to which he points are the

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Krell of Naugatuck, Conn., formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean MacLean Krell, to Lloyd Chipman Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Carpenter of Scarsdale.

The anti-noise campaigns that started in cities and municipalities have now spread to the motor boat industry. Boat builders have become aware of the fact that boat owners like peace and quiet with their cruises, and the result is a tendency toward quiet motors.
Two Spanish merchant vessels flying the flag of the Leftist regime narrowly escaped being torpedoed today by a submarine off the Mediterranean coast, the Ministry of Marine announced tonight.
Chi Omega, national women's fraternity, installed its ninetieth chapter today when the local Gamma Phi sorority of Gettysburg College became a member of the national organization.

Harvard defeated Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight, 52 to 38. The ame opened the league season for of the Tigers, but it was the Crimson's It third circuit contest and its second un victory.

-Thirteen-year-old King Peter assumed for the first time Wednesday the Orthodox Church's Christmas Eve-the duties of head of his family in the absence of his mother, Queen Marie, who is in England supervising arrangements for sending his brother, Tomislav, to school.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The controversy in Wisconsin concerning the administration of the university by President Frank leads me to describe briefly the administration of another institution of higher education in which there is almost ideal cooperation among all the factors in the administration, the board of trustees, the president, the faculty, the students and the alumnae, namely, Vassar College.

Mrs. William H. Price will be hostess in the Women's Opera Committee box on Tuesday night, when the Metropolitan Opera Association presents "Samson et Delila" as the second in a series of five operas in its Brooklyn season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

These orders were issued in the 2d Corps Area: Capt. James B. Jarnagin, Inf-Res., now at Station Hospital, Fort Jay, New York, is relieved from further active duty with the CCC, and will proceed to his home, 610 W. 116th St., New York. N. Y.,

The Department of Psychology at St. Lawrence University has been engaged for some four years in a study of student personality, primarily as a matter of adjustment to the college world, but looking later to work in vocational guidance, both for men and women.

Veterans lost no time in placing before the Seventy-fifth Congress numerous demands for additional payments to themselves, their dependents and beneficiaries, despite the fact that they lately received their long-sought bonus.
Twenty-two Brooklyn all-scholastio football players were honored at a luncheon yesterday as guests of the Abraham Straus store.
Defying a Sheriff's proclamation, striking hosiery workers assembled outside the plant of the Berkshire Knitting Mills today and rioting flared anew.

Launched under conditions best designated in nautical terminology a bad list to starboard, the tentative "women's charter" drafted by twenty-odd of the women leaders of the country has encountered squally weather early in its voyage.

BASCOM HALL, where President Glenn Frank and the Regents of the University of Wisconsin have been engaged in public controversy, looks down from its hill upon the smoking chimneys of Madison and the spokelike streets which meet at the hub that is the great State Capitol.

SPEED may truly be said to typify the spirit of our age. Our airliners today travel at about 200 miles an hour cruising speed, spanning the continent with but three intermediate stops in seventeen hours.

Venetian blinds, floor screens, piece goods and drapery hardware, in addition to curtains and draperies, will be displayed tomorrow at the opening of the New York Curtain and Drapery Show at the Hotel New Yorker. More than 1,500 buyers from all parts of the country are expected to visit the trade showing during the five days it will be open.

WHAT highways of the future will resemble and how they will serve traffic will be discussed by members of the American Road Builders Association at the thirty-fourth annual convention and exhibit to be held in New Orleans.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Louise Dick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Dick of this place, to Howard R. Kelso, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Kelso of Syracuse, N. Y.

Plans have been completed for the presentation on Tuesday evening of the New Rochelle Choral and Art Society in concert at the Daniel Webster High School here. Miss Antonia Brico, internationally known choral director and conductor of the Women's Symphony Orchestra of New York, who has arranged and will conduct the concert, announced today that the program would be the most pretentious in the history of the society.

Republican leaders through the State are conducting week-end conferences in the hope of resolving the strife among the Republicans in the Assembly over election of a Speaker. Irving M. Ives, Speaker last year, departed for his Norwich home more confident than in some time that he would be able to break the deadlock and win re-election when the Assembly resumes its sessions Monday night.
THE story of one of the greatest naval battles in history is told by a sur vivor, A. Novikoff-Priboy, in "Tsushima," which Alfred A. Knopf will publish on Jan. 25.
A dinner dance was held at the Greenwich Country Club tonight, after the second day invitation squash racquet tournament at the club and field club. Nearly 150 members and guests attended.

Cuba's 1937 sugar crop was officially set at 2,939,033 long tons by a Presidential decree which appeared in the Official Gazette today. This is the second year of the six-year restriction plan which began last year.
The secret police announced today that they had obtained documents from a Leftist prisoner indicating a conspiracy to interfere with the trials of those who took part in the revolt in November, 1935.

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce will oppose the application of Philadelphia for an increase of its present rail freight differential of two cents on 100 pounds below the New York rate, it was announced yesterday.
Immigration officers considered today the plight of Miss Rosheen Blynn, a passenger aboard the Japanese liner Buenos Aires Maru, who was detained after the vessel reached New Orleans from HOuston.

Fourteen thousand persons attended the symphony orchestra concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night when friends and admirers of David Mannes, the conductor, presented a testimonial scroll to him in honor of his twentieth year as leader at the Metropolitan's free musical entertainments.

" The much-married tend to mate with the much-married," statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company conclude from an analysis of the marital data of New York State, excluding New York City, for the years 1932 through 1934.

A proposal that a Cadman Memorial Church be established as a memorial to the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Central Congregational Church, who died on last July 12, was made last night by Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett at the annual meeting of the board of deacons of Central Church at the church, 64 Jefferson Avenue, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.

Opening its active campaign to boycott the proposed heavyweight championship bout between James J. Braddock, the present titleholder, and Max Schmeling, former champion, the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, Inc., appealed yesterday to several organizations, athletic and otherwise, for support.

Miss Imogene M. Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Richmond of 695 Newark Avenue, was married to Robert E. Schluer Jr., son of Robert E. Schluer of West Orange and the late Mrs. Schluer, in the Church of the Immaculate Conception here this morning. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clarence Heavey of St. Bernard's Church, Plainfield.

Opposite the Rock of Gibraltar, symbol of the power of the British Empire at the entrance to the Mediterranean, lies the Spanish zone of Morocco. It was there last July that Spanish troops revolted against the Madrid government and under the leadership of General Franco started the bitter civil war still raging in Spain.

A reliable source said tonight that Dr. W. K. Mattson, father of kidnapped 10-year-old Charles Mattson, "positively would not" pay $28,000 demanded ransom until sure he is dealing with the "right party" and the boy is "alive."

The attention of retailers and manufacturers of branded lines of merchandise throughout the country will center tomorrow on the New York State Court of Appeals in Albany, when it will hear arguments in the first test case on "fair trade," or price maintenance, legislation in this State since the United States Supreme Court handed down its "surprise" decision last month upholding the Illinois and California Fair Trade Acts.

DAVENTRY, England, has begun short-wave transmissions on the best channel for Winter night reception in America. GSL, on 6.11 megacycles, now sets the standard of clarity and volume of reception from Britain between 6 to 8 and 9 to 11 P. M., Eastern standard time.

Addressing the new Seventy-fifth Congress, in which he was assured the strongest majority enjoyed by a Chief Executive since the days of Washington, President Roosevelt last week sounded the keynote of his second New Deal administration.

An engine set up in matched pairs with balanced reciprocating parts, thus forming a perfect right and left for twin cruiser service, is the outstanding feature of the Buda Company exhibit of engines at the Motor Boat Show.

CONSTERNATION reigns on the banks of the Niagara. The placid reaches of the Erie (Canal) are ruffled with indignation; the near-by hills of Cattaraugus and Chautauqua echo with sympathetic protest; and even the staid aristocratic denizens of the flats of the Geneseo have added their voices to the general chorus of outraged disapproval.

Chairmanship of the "Sponsors Committee of One Hundred and One" for opera day, to be held Jan. 30 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the auspices of the Cardiac Division of the Social Service Auxiliary of Kings County Hospital, has been accepted by Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard. Singers of the National Music League Opera Company will present "Hansel und Gretel" in the afternoon and "Martha" at night, under the direction of Rudolph Thomas.

Industrial and labor leaders will participate in a series of public and private meetings on employer-employe relationships in American industry to be started next Thursday at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.

A discussion of "The School Child and Crime Prevention" will be held at a luncheon under the auspices of the Public Education Association on Saturday at the Hotel Commodore. More than 500 persons are expected to attend. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Roger Williams Straus are honorary chairmen.

ROME.--The Italian Government has intensified its police surveillance throughout the country in order to prevent possible infiltration of Bolshevist agitators into the kingdom. All suspected persons are constantly under watch of the political police.

" Church at Keyhoe's Bar" J.S. M. wants the poem, entitled above, that begins about like this: "There were three hundred men in Keyhoe's Bar, and such men!" It described a mining town to which came a minister of the gospel to try to establish a church.
Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 8 unless specified: San Pedro to Marc Island Yard: Argonne, San Francisco.
Count Kosho Otani, 27-year-old supreme pontiff of a religious sect with 4,000,000 followers, completed his military training today as a private in the Emperor's army.

WHEN will we have television? Albert F. Murray, chief television engineer of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, asked the question at a recent meeting of the engineering alumni of the University of Pennsylvania.

The Department of Parks, in keeping step with municipal boat basin construction activities which are on the increase throughout the country, has planned twelve harbors to meet the needs and growing enthusiasm among boat owners in the metropolitan area.
Construction of new homes in New York State under the FHA mortgage insurance plan reached a total of $33,661,445 in 1936 which involved 7,081 commitments, according to Thomas G Grace, State Director.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran German dirigible designer and commander, said on his arrival here yesterday that plans of the Hindenburg and her sister ship, the LZ 130, now under construction, will be made available to builders of a proposed American airship.

The Right Rev. John Taylor Smith, formerly chaplain general to the British armed forces in the World War, has arrived in America to take part in centennial celebrations of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, evangelist. He will be here about two and one-half months visiting America cities where the evangelist's birth will be marked by services.
Professor Moritz Winternitz, authority on Sanskrit and author of many works on Indian literature, religion and art, died here today at the age of 74.
There may be joy in other sections of the country over Andrew Mellon's gift to the nation of his wonderful art collection, but there certainly is not very much joy in this city.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court this week in the case of Dirk de Jonge has revived one of Oregon's long-standing legislative feuds: the controversy between the defenders and the assailants of the State Criminal Syndicalism Law.

Nation-wide observance by colleges and universities of the centenary of the death of Alexander Pushkin, Russian post, were announced yesterday by the American Pushkin Committee, 56 Went Forty-fifth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. James F. Thompson of Durham, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Gayle Thompson, to Carl Rudolph Wesselhoft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Wesselhoft of Linden Place, Bay Shore.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology in conjunction with the University of Denver will establish a unique laboratory on top of Mount Evans in Colorado to carry on important cosmic ray and meteorological research and investigations of the biological and physiolegical effects of high altitudes on human beings.
THE Federal Communications Commission has submitted its second annual report to the Congress on the status and growth of radio within the Union.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of the dates indicated, to the following applicants who have met the eligibility and. examination requirements therefore:

Kenneth I. Walton of New York City has purchased the former Sperry estate tract of 108 acres at Southbury, Conn., and is preparing plans to erect a residence on the property in the near future. The tract overlooks the Shepaug Valley near Roxbury Falls.

State control of the minimum price of milk has proved an "utter failure" and should not be continued, H. A. Cronk, president of the Borden's Farm Products division of the Borden Company, yesterday advised Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Markets.

THE way toward improvement among the underprivileged farmers is not to ask ourselves what we want but to ask ourselves what we can get. Sociological ideals in this matter can do little more than confuse issues.

The automobile industry-specifically that large segment represented by the General Motors Corporation with its 211,000 employes-has become the testing ground for the ideas of mass unionization which have been set forth for the last fourteen months by the Committee for Industrial Organization, of which John L. Lewis is chairman.

Mr. and Mrs. George A. Kuhn of Long Hill Road, Gillette, N. J., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Marjorie Donna Rohrer to Stanley Bertram Webster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram L. Webster of Summit, N. J.

Wholesale glove business increased by more than 15 per cent last year, according to Jerome Rice of Wimelbacher Rice, importers and manufacturers. Retail store sales increased 7 to 10 per cent, and retail stocks at the end of the year were about the same as the previous year, although assortments were spotty.

HOLLYWOOD, which has passed its camera eye over many arts and with its raking fingers drawn to it almost every kind of talent, a fortnight ago entered its most important liaison with the creative dance.

Heads of households who spent most of yesterday at the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace probably are reeling off some salt-sea nautical chatter to wives and children at this morning's breakfast, affecting the use of the word galley for kitchen, for instance, and glibly talking about ship's gear, starboard rudder and engine revs.

John Brown, 29-year-old English author of "I Was a Tramp" and "I Saw for Myself," arrived yesterday on the Hansa of the HamburgAmerican Line to lecture here and study conditions among working classes, which is his specialty. For several years he has been living and toiling among workers in several European countries and writing stories and books about the problems they meet.

Into the field of crime prevention the Publio Education Association will throw the influence of its informed lay opinion-an influence which in forty-two years of the organization's existence has run the gamut of interest in the ordinary and extraordinary affairs of the public school child.

Mrs. Dorothy T. Dyer, assistant to the junior dean in the College of Arts and Sciences at Ohio State University, has been appointed dean of women at Bucknell University. She succeeds Mrs. Paul G. Stolz, who has been acting dean since Miss Amelia E. Clark resigned last Summer.

Alarmed at the prolongation of the seamen's strike, the Women's Organization for the Advancement of the American Merchant Marine has petitioned President Roosevelt to intervene to bring about a settlement of the dispute between longshoremen and ship owners.

In the sense that it will open with prayer, close with music and inelude visits to historic sites here, the eight-day program which the Chautauqua Woman's Club will begin today in this metropolis is referred to as a "pilgrimage."
The former Governor of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Gifford Pinchot have opened their house for the midseason and will entertain at a large reception on Monday. Mr. and Mrs.

WITHOUT going so far as to say that the theatrical season is moving away from here, there is going to be a deal of excitemen at the Geary Theatre, San Francisco, on Feb. 1. For on that evening there will be unveiled a play called "Return of Hannibal," by Amory Hare, of which the cast will include Jerome Lawlor, Helen MacKellar, William Farnum, Fritz Leiber George MacQuarrie.
The police announced today that fifteen Japanese had been rounded up in different parts of Japan on charges of planning an armed revolution and the creation of anarchist communes.

I believe the people of the United States are more- interested in keeping our country out of war than almost any other one thing. - In fact, I have never seen such a unanimity of sentiment on any one question.

WHILE New York City has met with official opposition the suggestion that perking meters be installed along some of its major thoroughfares, Providence, capital of Rhode Island, has authorized the installation of parking machines for a six months' trial period.

Bishop John A. Duffy of Syracuse, N. Y., was named Bishop of Buffalo today, Vatican officials announced. Bishop Duffy will succeed the late Bishop William Turner, who died several months ago. The Rev. John C. Cody of Assumption Church in Eastview, a suburb of Ottawa, Canada, was appointed Bishop of Victoria, British Columbia.
Chamber music was featured this morning in the second of the 19361937 series of youth concerts under the auspices of the Nassau Philharmonic Society in the Rivoli Theatre, Hempstead.
Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont entertained today with a tea at Sandrift Cottage. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sims Wyeth,
Turkish nationalists and supporters of the French administration in Syria staged orderly demonstrations here today.

Miss Joan Dowsett, daughter of a prominent family of Hawaii which gave an estate to be used for the Honolulu unit of the Shrine hospitals for crippled children, has just completed a month's study of methods at the Springfield unit of the Shrine hospitals to qualify herself for work among children in Hawaii.

NEW YORKERS motoring to New England are apparently going to get full relief from the present traffic congestion on this side of New Haven and Danbury through a series of highway projects in New York City, Westchester County and Fairfield County, Conn., which may be entirely completed by 1942.

Miss Virginia Frances. Dick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Dick of Mount Vernon, N. Y., was married here late yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Dr. Eugene Henry Moyle of this city, son of Mrs. Daniel Vincent Moyle of Elkins, W. Va., and the late Mr. Moyle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.
The business of Hayden, Stone Co. will be continued without interruption, it was announced yesterday in a statement issued by the firm. The statement read:

With approximately twenty foreign nations already having signified their intention of participating in the World Two-Way Trade Fair, scheduled here for May 10 to 22, officials sponsoring the nonprofitmaking venture predicted yesterday that 250,000 to 500,000 visitors, many of them from foreign countries, will be attracted to this city during the exhibition.

The Ministry of Colonies announced tonight that the populace of Togo, former German African colony now under French administration, had asked continuance of French rule. "Notables" among the natives unanimously declared their opposition to any change, the Ministry said.
The Protestant churches of this city will hold a series of neighborhood meetings next week as part of the national "preaching mission" started by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
LOND0N. QUEEN MARY, the widow of one King and the mother of two others. holds a special place in British af fections as the reign of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth begins.

Following its Winter custom, the Bourse resumed short Saturday morning sessions today, but the occasion proved to be an unhappy one. The news of the complication that has been added to the Spanish question by the influx of Germans into Spanish Morocco and the protest of the French Government to the Insurgent junta produced a feeling of agitation and disquiet which caused heavy selling in the first hour and prices fell steeply.

IN its survey of the literature of 1936, Whitaker's Almanack describes it as a good average output without phenomenal features. The topical element has been prominent in the successes of the year. Thus.

Miss Katharine Greenway Russell was married to the Rev. Hampden Harrison Smith Jr. of Lynchburg, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Hampden Harrison Smith of Ashland, this afternoon at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Russell, here. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

Dr. Leon Wolf Goldrich, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance since its inception and an educator and social worker of wide experience, died Friday night of a heart attack at his home, 425 Riverside Drive. His age was 61.
More than 200 homes of residents are being moved and streets are being realigned and widened, at a cost of $2,000,000, to provide traffic approaches to the nearly completed Golden Gate Bridge.
Harry Bragg, manager of the Automobile Merchants Association, said last night that New York City dealers had not felt as yet any effect of the strike in General Motors and parts plants.
A 47-year-old furnace tender was arrested last night in the Bronx and charged with arson following a suspicious fire in the cellar, of his home at 761 East 165th Street.

Officials of Hayden, Stone Co., bankers, announced yesterday a list of honorary pallbearers for the funeral of Charles Hayden, senior partner of the firm, would be made public today. Mr. Hayden, who was 66 years old, died Friday night in his apartment at the Hotel SavoyPlaza after an illness of several weeks.
Commodore Egbert Moxham was re-elected last night to head the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club for another year. The organization's annual meeting was held in the clubhouse in Port Washington, L. I.

Amendments to the rules goverring dog shows will be submitted to the delegates to the American Kennel Club at their annual meeting in February. They have been considered by the board of directors, which has put them directly into the hands of the delegates without recommendations.

Harold J. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, will take part in a discussion of the question, "Shall all Federal employes be under civil service?" Thursday night in the radio Town Meeting of the Air, it was announced yesterday by Robert L. Johnson, president of the National Civil Service Reform League.

Annual Corporate Communion of the Carroll Club at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 9 A. M., to be followed by communion breakfast at the Hotel Biltmore, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, the Rev. Father Cyprian, Mary Ellen Chase, Dr. Elizabeth Lynskey.

State Athletic Commissioner Joseph H. Rainey announced tonight that Al Ettore's disputed victory over John Henry Lewis here last Monday night would be entered on the books of the commission as a draw.

The diamonds which Joseph Rose insisted had been stolen from him turned up in a safety deposit box in Jersey City yesterday, and the sallow-faced, bushy-eyebrowed former gem dealer who charged robbery found himself positively identified as the man who had secreted them.

SOME future generation may look back to this strange period of ours and select a few men on whom it will bestow the adjective "modern," just as we now look back to the thirteenth century and pick out Roger Bacon, or to the early sixteenth and pick out Erasmus.
Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Davis of West Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Davis, to Harold D. Seeling, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Seeling of New York.

The New York Stock Exchange obtained yesterday from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court a temporary stay on the order by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook directing it to pay $40,836 to Marcel Levy, trustee, for distribution to customers of the German American Securities Company.
James C. Haggerty of Whitestone, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Veronica Rosemary Haggerty, to John O'Leary Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John O'Leary of Malba, L. I.

When the planetarium which bears the name of CHARLES HAYDEN was dedicated the wish was expressed that till the time comes when each has to quit the earth alone we may strive together for a better world under the stars.

The spell the New York Rangers started to weave against the Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League play-offs in 1935 held good tonight as the Gothamites scored a 3-2 victory over the Mdntrealers before slightly more than 7,000 fans.
IN past years Florida has been the most popular State among New York bridge players who can go to warmer climes when the Winter winds blow. This year California seems to be equally popular.

John Webster Knowles, former New Bedford textile man, died at a hospital here today. His widow, the former Lydia Grinnell, and a daughter, Miss Shirley Knowles, were reached by wireless on board a West Indies steamship, and will leave Puerto Rico for home tomorrow.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Katherine Gasper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chris Gasper of Rockaway Beach, Queens, to Cadet Godfrey Roland Ames, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. O. F. Ames of Sausalito, Calif., and Vancouver, B. C.

OR the first time in seven years New York is going to have an aviation exhibit. The aircraft industry, builders of private planes and military aircraft, operators of airlines and the army and navy are joining with Aviation Post 743, American Legion, in putting on the National Aviation Show at the Grand Central Palace from Jan. 28 to Feb. 6, inclusive.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Perot of this city and Washington, D. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Lee Perot, to Harvey Wright Branigar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Branigar of Chicago.

Recent inquiries by New Yorkers regarding the comparative taxes on real estate in various Westchester communities have revealed a misunderstanding of the assessment system which results in unfair discrimination against certain municipalities, declared A. C. Brower, clerk of the equalization committee of the Board of Supervisors, this week.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton P. Higgins were honored by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Aldus C. Higgins, at a reception for 300 this afternoon at their home in Worcester. Mr. and Mrs. Prentiss L. Coonley, parents of Mrs. Milton P. Higgins, motored over from Great Barrington for the event.

Nine telegraph messages filed at Columbia, Mo., last night for points west of that city were delivered to their destinations by way of East Orange and New York City, with short-wave radio playing the leading role.

Members of the University of Michigan Alumnae Association in the metropolitan area, who were organized last November, will hold a dinner Tuesday at 7 P. M. at the New York Junior League, for which arrangements have been made by Mrs. George Chase Lewis.

Mr. and Mrs. S. C. Schenk Sr. of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Schenk, to Raymond Einnon Thomas of Newburgh, N. Y., son of Mrs. John Thomas of Yonkers.

The first showing of films included in Series III of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, under the classification "The Film in Germany and in France" will be presented to members of the museum at 8:30 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

An unusual spectacle for this time of the year is the appearance of goldfish in an artificial pond on the estate of Frank Bulley on Shore Road, which have come out of their hibernation on the bottom and are swimming around the surface as if it were a mild day in April.

Student leaders on the Colgate University campus agree that most of the old freshman customs are gradually being dropped and that the first year student is subject to less disciplining and hazing than in past years.
In spite of the upturn shown last year in the commercial field, the returning prosperity of people in the United States is not reflected in the dollar volume of their benevolences.

A boy, tentatively identified as John Denela, 10 years old, of 182 Mott Street, was killed early last night at Forsyth and Hester Streets when a truck being towed by a sedan ran over him after. the towing chain had broken.
THE world has heard of the Fijian firewalker, but it is not so familiar with a new development of Fijian life, Rugby football.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in December totaled 1,067,365 tons, or 184,722 tons more than November's shipments of 882,643 tons and 405,850 more than the 661,515 tons shipped in December, 1935.

The United Theatrical and Motion Picture Workers of America, 358 West Forty-fourth Street, has started a movement to organize in an industrial union all theatre and motion picture employes, it is disclosed by the union's literature distributed among theatrical and motion picture employes.

The Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation of Morris Heights, which has maintained a prominent position in the boat-building industry during the past fifty-three years, has never missed displaying its products at the National Motor Boat Show.

Executives of the copper and brass industry see in 1937 an encouraging outlook due to the revival of building, rural electrification, increasing use of home electrical appliances and the prospects for large automobile sales, according B. B. Caddie, secretary of the Copper and Brass Research Association.

Through the efforts of a crusading commuter of this village, who has climbed the stairs from the lower level in Grand Central Terminal every morning for nearly ten years, thousands of daily travelers from the suburbs may soon have the luxury of riding to the street level in escalators.

Long Island schools emerged with the major share of the honors in the scholastic basketball program at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Three of the Island representatives were victorious in the four games staged before a crowd of 4,000.
The steel industry of the Pittsburgh district began this week to feel the pinch of the automobile strike.

WITH the increasing demand for color reproductions of works of art by both old and modern masters, a comprehensive catalogue of approximately one thousand of the best has been published for the Carnegie Corporation by Raymond Raymond.

Mrs. Fanny Addison Pitt, whose career on the American stage extended over a period of forty-five years, died at the Edwin Forrest Home here Thursday after a slight accident earlier in the week. She was in her ninety-fourth year.

Establishment of the Cornelius prize of $100 in mechanical engineering was announced today by President Williams of Lehigh University. The donor is William A. Cornelius, '89, executive secretary of the Lehigh Alumni Association.
SOME time this month, weather permitting, steel-shod yachts will be placed on starting line on the frozen surface of the Shrewsbury River, down behind Sandy Hook in New Jersey.

A sleek fleet of seven new models, all built to designs and specifications personally approved by the noted speed boat pilot form the 1937 custom-built fleet displayed by Gar Wood at the National Motor Boat Show. Runabouts and utility boats are featured.

Edward Steichen, known as a photographer and painter, will make his first appearance as a lecturer next Thursday evening at the Park Central Hotel, under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York. His subject will be "The Modern Delphinium."

Half-way through the three-year administration of Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson as president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, members of the board of directors of the organization will convene in the national capital on Wednesday.

Three Brooklyn (N. Y.) men were injured, one of them seriously, when the car in which they were. riding telescoped under the rear of a moving trailer in the heavy fog on the southwest cut-off in Auburn about 5:30 o'clock this morning.

Speoial emphasis is being placed on extra-curricular activities during the current session of the New Jersey College for Women. In cooperation with the Associate Alumnae, eight meetings are being held in various parts of the State, at which undergraduate speakers describe the methods by which avocational interests of students are developed in the college of today through extra-curricular activities.

Burglars, choosing with discrimination among the silverware and clothing in the home of Charles H. H. Gristede, president of Gristede Brothers, Inc., grocers, at 2,186 University Avenue, the Bronx, ransacked the two-story dwelling between 3 and 6:30 P. M. yesterday and escaped with loot valued at more than $2,000.

The engagement of Miss Lillian Brill. daughter of Mrs. Sol Brill of 145 Central Park West and the late Mr. Brill, to Dr. Abner Kurtin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kurtin of this city, has been announced by her mother.

The immediate adoption by the Chinese Republic of a strong policy of resistance to Japan is "absolutely indispensable" if China is to preserve her political independence and sovereignty, Ch'ao-ting Chi, Chinese economist and author, declared yesterday.

In order to provide a shorter and safer route for skippers journeying from the Hudson to Long Island Sound, the flag officers of the Englewood Basin Y. C. have started a movement to open the Bronx Kills.

The first committee meeting for the annual card party of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor will be held this afternoon at the home of the chairman, Miss Madeleine W. Smith, 205 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. The benefit will be held the afternoon of March 13 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
Another figure-skating carnival will be held at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, but it will differ from the ones that New Yorkers have become accustomed to see in past seasons.

Although the administration has gone outside the foreign service in selecting Joseph E. Davies as Ambassador to Soviet Russia, the government has placed a number of career men in high embassy posts abroad.
Fordham's basketball team defeated Upsala College of East Orange, N. J., last night, 35-14, but failed to look particularly impressive in doing it.
Assignment of Eugene H. Dooman of New York, veteran Foreign Service officer, as counselor to the American Embassy at Tokyo was announced today by the State Department.

Three European women, each of whom has long been prominent in her own country in feminine organizations and movements, will arrive in New York this week. Dr. Magda de Spur of Hungary, who is an active partner in a glass factory at Budapest and an officer of various associations of Hungarian women, is scheduled to reach the city today.

When the nation's astronomers met at Hood College last month they found a novelty. On the college campus is a line of white posts representing the relative distances of eight planets from the sun. This way of showing the distances is said to be unique.
SARK'S PROBLEM: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hathaway, rulers of Sark Isle in the English Channel, revealed last week that their most vexatious problem is the philatelist.

A series of "field trips" to the New York theatres is being planned this week by the Briarcliff Junior College students, in place of the usual forum, lecture, or concert held at the college as a regular weekly feature of the study program.

Commercial real estate in New York City is about to experience one of the best periods in its history during the next four years according to Tankoos, Smith Co., chain store leasing and business property specialists.
WHAT started the discussion was that Everett McGowan's name was mentioned as one of the performers who would appear in the impending figure skating festival at Madison Square Garden.

After being inactive in motor boat regattas since the death of my father, I have decided again to enter competition. The fact that probably nothing would please him more than to have an important boat race held in his honor, has prompted me to sponsor the first annual 22.6-mile race around Absecon Island to start and finish off the Steel Pier, Atlantic City, May 30.

As a result of a growing demand for its marine products the Chrysler Corporation has set up a new division to handle marine activities. This is to be known as the Chrysler Corporation, Marine Engine Division, of which D. A. Wallace will be president.

The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held on Friday at the Pierre under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the organization. Divertissements by professional entertainers will be presented.

A NEW book by the author of "Joanna Godden" has come to mean a literary event of signal importance. Of one thing we may be assured in advance: She will not disappoint us. In style, substance and that aura of feeling peculiarly her own she will be the old Sheila KayeSmith, with the added richness bestowed by constantly widening sympathies.

Five lecturers will participate in the Winter forum sponsored by the Monmouth County Round Table and the New York University Division of General Education in the Long Branch (N. J.) High School auditorium starting next Tuesday evening, Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the Division of General Education announced yesterday.

Critics of the Supreme Court are planning a "conference on constitutional amendment" under the chairmanship of Senator Norris of Nebraska. An attempt will be made to organize such a conference as a clearing house for proposals to enlarge Federal powers and curtail the jurisdiction of the courts, either by amendment or by simple statutory action.

If you have any snapshots of outdoor scenes-a bird a-wing, a foaming brook, a trout or a marlin leaping, a beautiful sunset-and you feel they are pretty nice examples of amateur photography, an opportunity is now offered to find out just how good they are.

Two new models, a 30-foot cruiser and a 53-foot motor yacht, contribute to the largest and most comprehensive line of cruisers the Elco Works has ever shown, a line that alms at luxury as well as efficiency.

VISITORS to Australia find the birds there almost as unusual as the strange, primitive animals. If he inquires, the tourist will be told that there are 431 varieties which cannot be found elsewhere in the world. Many travelers know Australia as a birdlovers' paradise.
Victor A. Vedova, Professor of English at the American International College in Smyrna, died at the home of his son, Egbert Vedova, here yesterday. Professor Vedova was 73 years old.

In my opinion there has always been one pronounced drawback to the sport of outboard racing, and that is the problem of travel to cover the important regattas. We folks up-State hit upon a plan early last season which resulted in one of the finest dinner discussions with representatives from all over the State at the Century Club in Syracuse recently.
The burial of Horace Binney, yachtsman and long a Summer resident here, who died at his Boston Winter home, took place in the Berkeley Memorial Church cemetery in Middletown, R. I., this afternoon.

Governor Talmadge will retire next week to the life of a country squire and begin a program which he calls "loving folks away from the New Deal." A vociferous critic of the Roosevelt administration, he was thwarted by Richard B. Russell Jr. in his Say ambitions to become a Senator. E E. D. Rivers will take over the Governorship Tuesday.

The Manhattan College Alumni Society will hold its sixty-eighth annual dinner at the Hotel Astor on Feb. 6. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, '73, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, who will be celebrating the sixty-fourth anniversary of his graduation, will be honored.
Housekeeping, the eternal problem of woman, is not half as hard on shipboard as cynical landlubbers imagine. For want of a better word let us call it "yacht-keeping." Doesn't it sound easier already?
ANDREW W. MELLON started off our just-concluded art A week the opening week of a new year, with his stunning offer to the government of a collection of masterpieces valued at nineteen million,

ALEXAN'DER AFINOGENEV, the Soviet playwright, is a venturesome man in his field. Perhaps it is not difficult to be daring when one has his record of successes. But the point is debatable; the higher one soars in Soviet art, the greater the thud if things go wrong.

Mrs. Frank E. Simmons is chairman of the motion-picture entertainment to be held under the auspices of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, of which Mrs. Dean C. Osborne is president, on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

APPARENTLY Columbia was in earnest when it reopened its operatic series. The January addition is Verdi's evergreen "Rigoletto," re-pressed from the La Scala recording of some years back (Album Set No. 18, in two volumes).

A new link in the chain of children's museums established throughout the world in the last thirty years has been added in Greater New York. It is the Children's Museum of Queens, situated in Jackson Heights but already drawing young habitues from all parts of the borough.

MISS ATKINS begins her book with Miss Millay's childhood and youth in Maine, when "milk and tarts and honey and white bread all in one day" were an extravagance, and when the Aeneid and Caesar were the young girl's refuge and delight. Miss Atkins finds a lasting influence of the Aeneid in Miss Millay's verse.

PROPHECIES of a new world war that will engulf our capitalist civilization have frequently been made in the course of the last few years. "Hitler Over Russia?" is Ernst Henri's latest interpretation of an only too familiar theme. Everything about the author-his real name, nationality and residence-is surrounded by an impenetrable wall of secrecy.
Dr. Sidney Meeker, obstetrician and sugeon. died of a heart ailment today a fortnight after making plans to have his own blood transfusion device put on the market. His age was 66.
New gifts totaling $85,458 have been received by Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, announced yesterday.

Paintings, arms and armor and other art property from the residuary estate of George D. Pratt, trustee and treasurer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, trustee of the American Museum of Natural History and vice president and trustee of Pratt Institute, will be sold at auction, together with property of Mrs. Pratt, at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

SEPARATELY and in groups thousands of persons devoted to Winter sports have of late been reciting "The Ski-Runners' Prayer." Throughout the land and even in New York, where the Mayor and the Department of Sanitation are harassed at each light fall of snow, these enthusiasts have been asking for more and heavier snowfalls.

Miss Bernice Agnes Haley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Haley of Caldwell, was married to Joseph St. John Neglia, son of Mrs. Harry Neglia of Lyndhurst, this morning at a Nuptial Mass at St. Aloysius's Church, Caldwell. The Rev. James Sullivan, assistant pastor, performed the ceremony.

FOLLOWING the vogue of the week-end ski special on land, steamship lines are inaugurating ski or snow ships. Parties en route to well-known European Winter resorts are expected to find a congenial atmosphere on the ski ships, for there groups of professionals and amateurs will exchange views on ski technique and data about new jumps and fields.

LEOPOLD ATLAS, whose play, "But for the Grace of God," the Theatre Guild will present, by arrangement with Sidney Harmon, as its third production of the season at the Guild Theatre Tuesday night, is not, so far as he knows, related to the gentleman of the same name who carried the world around on his shoulders.

The First Division officers rode into an undisputed lead in the Metropolitan Indoor League last night. The army men charged through the Gypsy Polo Club, 12 1/2 to 9, in the final game of a tripleheader at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

Angered because the automobile strike had deprived many members of the metal trade division of the American Federation of Labor of employment in the General Motors factory at Cleveland, and asserting that "we don't intend to allow the automobile workers to run away with to our union," John P. Frey, president of the metal workers of the A. F. of L., sent this telegram to the Cleveland chapter today:

THE gaudy booths and rollercoasters of the street fair around Neptune's landlocked fountain were still there when Mr. Landon-Davies went back to Madrid in August. War had caught that show in full swing one hot July night and no one had bothered to put it away.

Miss Mary Valentine Shepard, daughter of William E. Shepard and the late Mrs. Shepard, was married yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Mercy, the Bronx, to John Francis Mallon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Mallon.

In a whirlwind tour yesterday afternoon by automobile and tugboat, Mayor La Guardia inspected three important projects being developed on the shores of Rockaway Inlet by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Premier Benito Mussolini, in ordinary street clothes, bought a workman's ticket to the Argentina Theatre today, entered quietly and seated himself between two women laborers. He received an ovation when recognized after some moments.
The first luncheon meeting for the new year of the West of Central Park Association will be held Wednesday noon at the Circle Club, 1,819 Broadway.

Despite its recent protestations, the average American college is not yet doing much to help its students think clearly on social issues. Professor S. Ralph Harlow of Smith College, who has come to this conclusion, bases it on an investigation of eighty-seven colleges made by 100 of his students.

Fifty-five young women, each carrying a candle for a giant birthday cake, will take part in the pageant featuring the fourth Birthday Ball, to be held on President Roosevelt's anniversary, Jan. 30, in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. McWilliams of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Angela McWilliams, to Dr. Edmund A. Trewhella, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Trewhella of Jersey City.
The Metropolitan Museum's current exhibition of paintings by John Singleton Copley has attracted more than 23,000 visitors during the two weeks that it has been open.

The January meeting of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will be held on Friday in Essex House Newark. S. William Walstrum, retiring president, will turn the gavel over to his successor, Samuel D. Walker. Other officers to be inducted are A. N. Lockwood, Harry J. Stevens, Max Tieger, Theodore F. Appleby, George B. Robeson and Richard P. Bloom, vice presidents: Alexander Summer. treasurer, and George F. Lacombe, secretary.
FRANKFORT, Ky. NATIVE sons of Kentucky are trying to save from the auctioneer's hammer one of their State's historic mansions, Liberty Hall in Frankfort.

Louis Meeser, president of the Woodmere Exchange Club, an nounced today the appointment of committees for the year. He took office recently as the new president of the club to succeed Harold Spitzer, Assistant District Attorney who served during 1936.

Gilbert Goodmanson, 22 years old, walked into the detective division of the Mercer Street station house last Thursday and said he was wanted by the Chicago police. While working in a financial agency he had converted $400 to his own use and fled last May. Now, he said, he wanted to clear up that matter because he had met a girl in Passaic he wanted to marry and she suggested he surrender himself first.

IN impeccability of taste, in enthusiastic appreciation, in extent of reading coupled with scholarship and as a writer of distinguished prose the author of this book has few peers among the literary critics of today.

TWO of America's better known painters are well represented in the new attractions at the Kraushaar Galleries (through January). Recent water-colors by H. E. Schnakenberg reveal all that artist's meticulous care that yet escapes labored effects and successfully combines strength and lyricism.

A card party will 'be held by St. Francis College Auxiliary on Tuesday at the college, 41 Butler Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. William J. Mahoney is chairman of the committee, which includes Miss Jane McGuigan, Mrs. Ambrose O'Brien, Mrs. Anthony Fasullo, Miss Josephine Armstrong, Miss May Boden, Miss Regina Sheehan, Miss Catherine Cunningham, Miss Madeline Kenny and Mrs. Charles McDonough.

Galleries of modern art in New York City are no longer places where only the erudite tread. Thousands of men and women, newcomers to gallery audiences, are gaining an informal art education through the guided tours offered free by the Federal Art Project at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street.

-Vassar, taking figures from its experience, has attempted to find out the cost to the student of A college education. The Economics Department, the warden's - office and the Vocational Bureau produced the necessary statistics, and from them it is estimated that the average annual expense is $1.855.

The engagement of Miss Helen Elliott Belding, daughter of Mrs. Albert G. Belding of this place and Lawrence, L. I., and the late Mr. Belding, to Henry P. Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Smith of North Tonawanda, has been announced by her mother.

The sale of boats has progressed from the time when it was a game to its present important status as an important industry, and along with this progress have come some problems the solution of which was absolutely necessary.

The Daily Orange, Syracuse university student newspaper, recommended in an editorial today that Dr. Glenn Frank, ousted president of the University of Wisconsin, be considered as a successor to Dr. Charles W. Flint as chancellor at Syracuse.

Roy Brown has won the American Water Color Society Medal, the society announced yesterday. The medal was given for Mr. Brown's picture, "From a Balcony" now hanging in the society's annual exhibition at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.
The inquest today at the British Embassy produced proof that the body of the girl found yesterday at the Tartar wall was that of 17-year-old Pamela Werner.
Those who begin their season's gardening operations by planting seeds and bulbs indoors, in order to get an extra-early start, derive from this practice an additional advantage.

While reaffirming its support of the movement for improved food and drug legislation, the executive committee of the Proprietary Association announced yesterday that the bills introduced by Senator Copeland and Representative Chapman last week to amend the present act were not satisfactory in every detail to the members of the packaged medicines organization.

The Voyager, a 42-foot twin screw and twin rudder cruiser, a newcomer in the A. C. F. fleet of thirteen boats, is attracting much attention at the Motor Boat Show. It is the largest of three models in the popular-price range.

Governors Island remained among the undefeated in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League last night by upsetting the Winged Foot Trio, 9 1/2 to 4, in the second contest of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory.

Directors of the Soaring Society of America at a special meeting here yesterday took the first step to effect a change in the charter of the organization which would make it, legally, an educational institution and permit donations to it to be deducted from income taxes.

Gaily responsive to the festive atmosphere that surrounded her in observance of her seventy-eighth birthday, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt appeared yesterday in better health than for some time, in the opinion of close friends.

A gift of $100,000 has been received by Rutgers University for unrestricted purposes, President Robert C. Clothier announced today following the regular quarterly meeting of the board of trustees in Atlantic City last night.

Miss Donna Schuyler Beekman, daughter of Mrs. William Schuyler Beekman of 1,060 Park Avenue and the late Lieut. Col. Beekman, was married yesterday to William Worthy Coleman of this city. President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell performed the ceremony in his apartment at 270 Park Avenue.

DR. MANFRED SAKEL, a young Austrian physician, has made history by successfully treating a form of insanity known as schizophrenia with insulin. Like others before him, he found that morphine addicts were driven almost frantic by total abstinence. Relief followed when insulin was administered.

In the course at the WaldorfAstoria for flower exhibitors and judges John Taylor Arms, etcher, will lecture on "Design in Flower Arrangement" tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock; at 2 o'clock in the afternoon Ugo Mochi, Italian sculptor, will discourse on "Composition in Silhouette Studies in Plastic Black." On Tuesday at 10:30 A. M.

Miss Anna Elizabeth Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Roy Phillips of Montclair, was married to Henry Hicks Hurt of Harrisburg, Pa., son of Mrs. Henry Hicks Hurt of Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Mr. Hurt, this evening at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Craven of Montclair.
LIKE most jury decisions, the New York Film Critics' selection last week of the best pictures, performances and direction of 1936 was an approximation, not a realization, of justice.
EVERYBODY will have to admit that they are pretty cute, these little frocks and suits that are in readiness to bask In sunny lands. They look as if they were made to enjoy life in.

Retail customers of dry goods wholesalers have started to purchase their Fall requirements about five months earlier than usual, according to reports in the local market yesterday. A substantial volume has already been placed on Fall items, such as underwear, blankets and outing flannels, whereas last year, stores did not start to cover until May.

George Frederick Reinhardt of Oakland, Calif., has won a fellowship offered by the Alfieri Institute of Florence, Italy, for study at its postgraduate school of international political science, for the current session beginning this month, it was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education 2 West Forty-fifth Street.
Montreal University closed its first hockey invasion of the United States tonight before 1,500 persons with a 7-to-1 victory over Yale in an International Intercollegiate League contest.

The eight most recent five-year reunion classes of Rutgers University will each have a representative on a committee of alumni which will meet at Winants Hall on Monday evening to select a candidate for alumni nominee to the board of trustees of the university.
City Island offers a sharp contrast to the hustle and bustle of metropolitan New York. Many years ago it was included in Westchester County, and was part of the village of Pelham.

William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, declared in a statement tonight that the "arbitrary action" of union officials was responsible for the breakdown of Governor Murphy's efforts to bring the company and union together in collective bargaining conferences.

Many chiuldren in the Southern mountains area have been prevented from attending the schools of that section during the Winter for lack of food and clothing, Dr. John R. Voris, president and executive director of the Save the Children Fund of America, Inc., 156 Fifth Avenue, said yesterday.

H. Thoens, S. B. Masten and W. Black each finished with a card of 96 to tie for the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Thoens broke 24 clays to triumph in the shoot-off, the others carding 23 apiece.

A story of Kentucky mountaineers who wore old stockings with eye holes over their heads on midnight raids on cabins to beat up neighbors of whom they did not approve was related here today, following indictment of twenty-five alleged "Black Legs."

OUR world has become so complex that seldom are great inventions made by a an working alone in his shop: the machines of today are too complicated. and the ideas and labor of many men are generally necessary to perfect them.

A special corps of clerks working at the Customs House late today computed the total value of the current week's imports at the Port of Boston at $5,941,028, as compared with $4,189,078 for all of December, a record month.

Chancellor Kurt Schuchnigg's organ the Weltblatt revealed yesterday, In sharp article, how Austrian hopes for an influx of German Winter sport visitors for Christmas had been dashed by the failure of the Reichsbank to allot necessary funds.

For 118 years residents of the city of Binghamton have walked, driven and motored about the Dobson Clubhouse at 272 Washington Street. The building, an early landmark, has seen the city grow and become more modern.

In order that boat owners may benefit by the experiences of others the Lycoming Manufacturing Company has in daily attendance at its exhibit some of the best known speed-boat owners, drivers and builders who have used Lycoming engines.

Pan-American Press Conference and disinterred the corpse of "Yankee imperialism" this morning and spent most of the day reviving it and giving it new life. The conference finally pledged itself to a continental campaign for the liberation of Puerto Rico.
A fivepoint program "in the interest of the nation's wage-earners" was advocated today by Secretary Perkins in her annual Labor Department report.
A new trend in higher education has been definitely established by faculty, student and trustee approval of the "intensive course" plan at Hiram College in Ohio after three years' trial.

A special salute to President Roosevelt will climax the traditional midnight parade at the 111th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York, which will take place on the night of Jan. 29 at the Commodore.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and Miss Helen Keller head the committee of patronesses for the performance of "The Show Is On" Tuesday night at the Winter Garden, which has been taken over in behalf of the Palestine Lighthouse in Aid of the Blind.

A Chinese Government spokesman declared today that the Nanking authorities were "highly indignant" over the anti-government, proCommunist broadcasts made almost daily from Sian by an American woman who, the authorities charge, is the well-known author Agnes Smedley "Her talks have been highly inflammatory," the spokesman said.

The courts have sometimes held that so-called relief provisions in revenue acts may be liberally construed. But this does not apply in the application of limitations of time, or in respect to prescribed dates, stated in a statute, however arbitrary such provisions may be.

To the Music Editor: It was but little more than a year ago that Sophie Braslau passed on. It hardly seems that long to those who were fortunate in having heard that glorious voice, known her generous and kindly nature.

Five members of the women's "flying delegation" to Buenos Aires to deliver the people's mandate to governments to the Inter-American conference were honored yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore by 350 members of the New York People's Mandate Committee.

Share prices moved substantially higher last week; bonds, moderately so, and wheat and cotton were slightly easier. President Roosevelt's address and subsequent budget message to Congress, together with the General Motors strike, afforded the principal financial topics of the week.
Officials of the nation's major airlines advocated extension of the construction program for ground' facilities this year during the Air Transport Association of America's meeting today.

TO facilitate travel, thereby making a further bid to the foreign tourist, Germany has just completed a bridge across an arm of the Baltic Sea that separates the island of Ruegen from the mainland. This Ruegen causeway has been a dream of the north country for the past seventy-five years. A portion of it was being built by the Danes when the World War interrupted the work.

Miss Jacqueline M. Nock of New Haven, Conn., was married today to Dr. John Mertz of the Lehigh University faculty. The Rev. Dr. Claude G. Beardslee, head of the department of Moral and Religious Philosophy, performed the ceremony in the Packer Memorial Chapel at the university.

James G. K. McClure Jr. of Asheville, N. C., has been elected president of the American Forestry Association, succeeding Henry S. Graves, dean of the Yale Forest School and former chief of the Forestry Service, who retired Dec. 31.

A racing sloop originally designed for a group at Fishers Island and particularly adapted to the waters of Long Island Sound has become one of the leading exhibits in the Luders Marine Construction Company display at the Motor Boat Show.

The National Child Labor Committee is opposed to proposals, including one by Governor Landon, to regulate child labor on the principle of the Ashurst-Sumners Congressional Act. Approved last Monday by the United States Supreme Court, the act bars the shipping of prison-made goods into States which have laws against their sale or possession.
Although Palm Beach had virtually barred its gates today against automobile trailers, the tourist who drags his home behind him found plenty of welcome signs in other Florida cities.
Dr. Frederick V. Coville, botanist of the Department of Agriculture and life trustee of the National Geographic Society, died today at his home here after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

The government moved definitely closer today to an early decision by the Supreme Court on the broad question of Federal loans to municipalities trying to set up their own power systems in competition with private utilities.

Experience being an excellent, If severe, teacher, Long Island University learned enough about zone defense in its losing venture with Stanford a fortnight ago to trounce its feared Duquesne foe, zone and all, 33 to 26, at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 16,000.
The Rev. and Mrs. Edwin I. Stearns of Caldwell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Chandler Stearns, to the Rev. David A. Hughes, son of Mrs. Helen M. Hughes of Baltimore.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Mitchell Barry, daughter of James Beamer Barry of this place and the late Mrs. Barry, to Stephen Hawes Bacon, son of Mrs. John Fairbanks Bacon of Tarrytown, N. Y., and the late Mr. Bacon, has been announced by her father.

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday that he had appointed the Right Rev. Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, to be chaplain of the Center Association, an organization of 1,000 Catholic college graduates, with headquarters at 120 Central Park South.

The marriage on Thursday of the future Queen of the Netherlands to Prince Bernhard zu LippeBiesterfeld, scion of a mediatized German house whose principality has been extinguished in the Nazi unification of the Reich, might normally have been expected to strengthen the relations between the Dutch and their more powerful neighbors wholly to the advantage of the latter.
After trailing 14 to 11 at the end of the first half, the Brooklyn Poly Tech quintet rallied to defeat the Stevens Tech five of Hoboken, 30 to 25, on the Odd Fellows court, in Brooklyn, last night.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson ordered inspectors of the Department of Health today to visit the two plants of the Electric Storage Battery Company, where 2,400 workers are engaged in a sit-down strike.

The whole market for used American civil aircraft and aircraft engines in foreign countries is threatened by certain provisions of the present Federal ban against the export of instruments of war, in the opinion of Charles H. Babb of Glenukle, Calif., one of the country's largest dealers in second-hand airstart.
Farm problems were discussed by President Roosevelt today with Louis J. Taber, Master, and members of the executive committee of the National Grange at a conference solicited by them.
Dr. Edmund W. Sinnott, head of the botany department at Barnard College, was elected president of the Botanical Society of America at a recent meeting of that organization in Atlantic City.

Mrs. Kenneth C. Brownell gave a tea this afternoon at her home here on Edgewood Drive. It will con- and tinue tomorrow. Thirteen paintings by her father, Dr. Fritz C. Hyde of Dennis, Mass., are on exhibition. One hundred and fifty persons were invited.

Purchases made in the wholesale market here last week were characterized by "sane" anticipation of needs, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Where prices had increased substantially buyers were not inclined to place orders for more than their normal requirements. The report continues:

George Clifford Shedd, novelist, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 59. He was a native of Ashland, Neb. Several of his stories were made into. movies. His widow, Mrs. Alice Nelson Shedd, whom he married in 1921, survives.

The sale of English furniture, silver and other objects from two private collections which was conducted Thursday, Friday and yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, netted $54,325.

In the presence of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who welcomed and introduced her, and about one thousand men and women, Dr. Maude Royden of London today warned the people of the United States against going to war in any cause, anywhere, at any time.

Dr. Le Roy E. Bowman, director of the United Parents Association, will speak on "The Cooperative Movement and Peace" at the annual international relations dinner of the Flushing Peace Society Wednesday night at 7:30 o'clock at the Amber Lantern, 150-24 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

IN China today there is the spectacle of thousands of men and women seeking eleventh-hour "cures" for the drug habit in the hospitals of the great cities, hoping thereby to escape the death penalty inflicted upon "second-time addicts."

With the leading player of each team forced out of the competition owing to illness and an injury, New York defeated Philadelphia by 7 to 2 yesterday in the annual intercity court tennis doubles match at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Miss Rosalind Baldwin Taggart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Credighton Harris Taggart of Caldwell, was married to Herbert Alfred Leikauf, son of Mrs. John E. Leikauf of Upper Montclair, tonight in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Essex Fells.

With perfect cruising conditions in Biscayne Bay, game fishing at its best in the Gulf Stream and ample accommodations in the Miami Yacht Basin for a flotilla of privately owned craft, Miami is again serving as the Winter yachting capital of the nation.
Liquid assets in the estate of Arthur W. Cutten, grain trader, once reputed to control a fortune of $100,000,000, total about $400,000, the inventory, filed in the Probate Court, revealed today.

The one-day school for jurors which Federal Judge William Clark will conduct in Newark next Saturday will be the first in the United States courts and one of the first in any court system in the country.

HISTORY was made last Tuesday evening at the St. James Theatre when John Gielgud, the remarkable young English actor, appeared for his 102d performance on Broadway ir in William Shakespeare's "Hamlet." It was an occasion--though unobserved--for Mr. Gielgud and for "Hamlet."

WINTER PARK, Fla. TRAPSHOOTING has come back, this season, in the Southern vacation belt. At the leading amateur champion shoots, beginning this month, entries are expected to be twice as numerous as in any year of the past decade.

Extravagant demands for government housing will be laid on the doorsteps of the current session of Congress, according to News and Opinion, a publication of the Building Trades Employers Association, which attributes the excessive demands to the fact that the public has been made conscious of inadequate living quarters.
James O. Spearing, automobile editor and former motion-picture critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died of pneumonia early yesterday morning at his home, 14 Sutton Place. at the age of 49.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Leroy Sparks of 130 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Somerindyke Sparks, to Dr. Merlin Treadwell Ryman of Chatham, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wells Ryman of Summit, N. J.

MILAN. AN enlarged foyer greeted the habitues of La Scala Opera when the new season opened on Dec. 26. The famous "ridotto" now becomes a hall in two naves, separated by columns in opulent Empire style.

THE strikes in General Motors plants, and a shortage of parts and materials resulting from strikes in parts factories and in the glass industry, are playing hob with car production schedules for January.
Andrew Jackson stepped aside today for the inauguration of President Roosevelt. In fact, he was put aside.

The Cabinet Council met today under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship and approved the budget for the fiscal year from July 1, 1937, to June 30, 1938, which calls for the greatest expenditure of public money ever made in the whole Italian financial history.

The year 1937 will be one of momentous political activity in the Irish Free State. When the Dail Eireann reassembles in February President de Valera will disclose to the Leglislators the details of his promised new constitution.

Though displaying better form than that shown in Wednesday's game against Gettysburg, the navy quintet lost to Duke today, 33 to 29, the ninth team in a row to be defeated by the Blue Devils this season.

A 30-foot two stateroom sedan is on display, sponsored by the Owens Yacht Company, now located at Dundalk, Baltimore, at the Boat Show. The exhibit is an example of the trend toward greater room and comfort in the low-priced cruiser class.
The States' rights question confronted the government today in R a new guise-the objections of State-supported colleges to paying the Federal sports admission tax.

Salvatore Spitale, underworld intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, whose presence in the Miami area has been a source of displeasure to county authorities, today promised Solicitor Robert R. Taylor that he would leave on the next train if Mr. Taylor would drop vagrancy charges which were preferred after Spitale defied an official order for him to go.
With a field depleted by illness, the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament got under way yesterday afternoon at the Yale Club after a week's postponement.

J. Raymond Britton, business agent of the Springfield Bricklayers Union, whose defense of a local bricklayer's attempt to fill the role of a writer in a WPA project was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, won support this week in a letter from Leslie Horton, Professor of English at Haverford College.

A Diesel engine equipped with a 3:1 reduction gear and installed in a sectional boat showing the engine room and the attachments to the motor is an attractive part of the Hall-Scott Motor Car exhibit at the Motor Boat Show.

Advancing prices on all types of candy are considered certain in the coming year, manufacturers commenting on last year's business said last week. During 1936, they explained, the industry made substantial strides in regaining lost sales volume, but the failure of producers to adjust their price structures deprived them of profits from the added business.

More than 600 persons, including many alumnae, saw the second annual marionette performance of "Much Ado About Glinda," a fouract play by Ernest Thorne Thompson, head of the department of Fine Arts at the College of New Rochelle, which was given in the Sports Building on the campus here Thursday for the benefit of the library fund.
A. N. Smallwood reports that fourteen log cabins were erected during the month of December at Mountain Lakes, at Smallwood, N. J.

Boat owners particularly keen on angling are showing great interest in the new Sport Fisherman, a type of craft featured in the exhibit of Wheeler Shipyard, Inc. This is designed especially for the angler and equipped with everything he needs in addition to providing the necessary accommodations for living aboard.

The old Constitution is good enough for the President-with reservations. He said so in his message delivered in person to Congress this week. But he couched his statement in terms which automatically put on trial the "fundamentalist" majority of the Supreme Court of the United States to which this part of the message was addressed.

Representative Robert L. Bacon, in a telegram from Washington, announced today that $1,520,000 is included in the War Department budget to purchase land to the south and west of Mitchel Field. This will give Mitchel Field an all-way runway-of 2,700 feet, which will add to the safety of takeoffs and landings by the army bombing planes assigned there. The longest present runway is 1,800 feet.
French naval authorities at Toulon have sent a warship to Valencia, Spain, to bring back the body of Baron de Borchgrave, first secretary of the Belgian Embassy in Madrid.

There is one aspect of the Spanish civil war that has been touched most closely this week by the series of German reprisals against Spanish shipping with the implied threat to blockade the Spanish coast.

Under the auspices of the Alumnae of Notre Dame de Lourdes Academy a dance will be held the night of Jan. 29 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador for the benefit of the educational work of the French nuns of Sainte Ursule de la Sainte Vierge.

William Carlton Mitchell, railroad executive and general traffic manager of the United States Leather Company, died yesterday at his home, 84 Grandview Avenue, North Plainfield, after an illness of three weeks. He was 61 years old.
