Uncle Robert, organizer of the annual Parents' Day program in New York City, announced yesterday that this year's exercises would be dedicated to a long-married couple who lost a son in the American Army during the World War. He hopes to find the couple in the city who have been longest married and requests all couples who think they can qualify to write to him at his home, 333 West End Avenue.

" This is the way we hang cattle thieves," said 11-year-old Frank DeVoti as he attempted to demonstrate to his chum, Filomeno Gonzales, his version of the Wild West's attitude toward pilferers of stock. With a rope around his neck he jumped from a tree branch. Luck was with the boy, for his toes just touched the ground.

THE little island of Dominica in the Lesser Antilles of the West Indies, just north of Martinique, is being discovered by Americans. It is British, and small freighters which carry a few passengers touch there regularly, but when one discovers Dominica for the first time it is a unique experience.

Many additional subscriptions have been received for the postponed performance of "High Tor," the new play by Maxwell Anderson, that had been planned for last week in behalf of the New York Kindergarten Association, which will be held on Wednesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre. The benefit was deferred because of the change in the date of the opening of the play.
The demand for multifamily buildings that has marked trading during the week continued yesterday, when apartment houses in three boroughs changed hands.

Pennsylvania lawyers laid plans here today to investigate Governor Earle's charges, made last week, that "toryism" permeated both the State and American Bar Associations, which reflected "the anti-social views of big business."

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Iselin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Iselin of the Wheatley Hills colony here, to George Crawford, son of Mrs. William Crawford of 580 Park Avenue, New York, and the late Mr. Crawford, took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Advent on the Jericho Turnpike.

IT has long been recognized that a great need of the American composer was a practical lab oratory for experimental scoring and for hearing his works. In Europe, at least in years antedating the present disordered conditions, a composer who had shown reasonable talent and industry in perfecting himself in expression was Quickly given the test of a hearing.

Net income of the Class I railroads in October was $46,233,661, against $31,380,529 in October, 1935, according to the Interstate Commerce Commission. For the first ten months of 1936, there was a net income of $89,208,327, against a net loss of $34,799,764 in the same period in 1935.

Six radio patrol cars were sent to 363 West Sixteenth Street at about 6 o'clock last night to aid in the arrest of a Negro accused of stabbing a companion, after the prisoner had resisted the efforts of a six-foot detective to subdue him

The Richardson Boat Company this year has come to the Motor Boat Show with a 26-foot model Little Giant, among others, which, In the opinion of the officials of the company, should have a wide appeal to yachtsmen.
THERE are so many reasons why Catherine de' Medici is a fit subject for a readable and

Mrs. Harry Whitney, for the last few years chairman of the New York City League of Women Voters, has been succeeded by Mrs. Donald Hutchinson of Riverdale, one of the younger members of the organization, who "won her spurs" through her distinguished and efficient direction of the organization's campaign in behalf of the new city charter and proportional representation.
FEW literary men of the past century have equaled Bayard Taylor in the interest, adventure and sheer brimming activity of their lives.

The Sea Scouts of Brooklyn Council, Boy Scouts of America, under the supervision of the regional flagship, the S. S. S. Flying Dutchman II, are acting as guards, ushers and messengers at the National Motor Boat Show.

The second annual conference of the New York Housing Guild School, sponsored by the JohnsManville housing guild division, opened at the Hotel Victoria last Monday with 220 building material men from States between Virginia and Maine and from five Canadian Provinces in attendance.
The number of influenza cases reported yesterday by the Department of Health showed a slight decrease, but the number of neumonia cases reached a new high.
A trainman was crushed to death and another Injured this morning in a rear-end collision of freight trains of the Lehigh Valley Railroad here.

Long the recognized as one of the most controversial problems in North Carolina history, the liquor battle facing the General Assembly, which convened here Wednesday in biennial session, started with a bombshell Thursday when the new Governor, Clyde R. Hoey, urged that no legislative abrogation be made of ter prohibition without another Statewide referendum.

Skippers who make extensive cruises along the Atlantic seaboard will be interested in learning that the State of New Jersey has offered to turn over to the Federal Government the Delaware and Raritan Canal.
Almost anything that can be done to stabilize the situation in the Mediterranean and assure peace in that dangerous sea would just now be welcomed by France.

Great Lakes yachtsmen are looking forward to the opening of the 1937 season with a firm belief that it will be the greatest year in boating history. The crowded coneditions in yacht harbors everywhere show clearly that 1936 brought many new boats.
Charles Edmund Isbells, manager of the Manhattan Print Works of Passaic for thirty-five years. died of a heart attack today at his home, 147 Aycrigg Avenue. He was 76 years old.

The Official Gazette announces today that a Portuguese-German agreement was signed last June 29 and became effective Dec. 18, under which Portugal abrogated as of Sept. 1, 1929, all rights to German property within her home territory and in colonies acquired under the Versailles treaty.
The number of new notices of bonds called for redemption before maturity continued large last week, but the amounts were smaller than in the preceding week.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 8: Colonels Ruggles, F. A., F.A., two months' leave, Feb. 12, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Fred Perry, British star who relinquished the world amateur tennis throne to play the game for money, defeated Ellsworth Vines tonight, 6-0, 6-2, 6-3, for his third consecutive triumph of their tour, before 12,602 spectators in the Chicago stadium.
During the past year the various committees of Region 2 of the American Power Boat Association, of which I was chairman, achieved, in my opinion, remarkable things.
Talking is doing more to relieve 14-year-old Ruth Rorick's constant hiccoughing than anything else, doctors disclosed today.
PARIS. SELLING water has become one of the prosperous industries of France, giving employment directly or indirectly to more than 150.000 persons.

The reason Chiang Kai-shek's attitude toward Chang Hsueh-liang is so incomprehensible to us is that, having become converted to Christianity, he is following literally the teachings of Jesus. We accept those teachings in principle, but not in fact.

Dr. Seuss, admiral-in-chief and cartographer of the fast-growing Seuss "Navy," has informed all admirals of the annual manoeuvres and target practice luncheon to be held at the Commodore Hotel on Thursday.

Holding on grimly to the gains they have made in the waterfront strike, which began in the last days of October. New York leaders of the so-called "outlaw" action moved yesterday to bring all their influence to bear on legislators in Washington to force an amendment to the Maritimee Law providing for the continuous discharge book.

A conference has been called by the real estate boards of New York, Brooklyn, the Bronx, Staten Island, Long Island and Westchester County to discuss problems relating to real estate in New York and the metropolitan area, to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday, Jan. 27.

Mrs. Frederic Rhinelander King was elected on Friday to the presidency of the Art Workshop, 309 East Thirty-fourth Street, to take the place of Mrs. John S. Borg, who died recently, according to an announcement made yesterday by the board of directors of the Rivington Neighborhood Association, parent body.

THE author's feeling of deep affection for the Croatian people speaks through every page of this book. And, along with that, her feeling of indignation against their oppressors speaks as plainly, and in even louder tones. "Portrait of a People" is, indeed, a book of feeling first of all, warm-hearted, outspoken, earnest. Miss Orr and an artist friend went to Zagreb to spend a week or two.

When students seek relief from academic tomes in the comfortable browsing room of Williston Memorial Library at Mount Holyoke College, they usually choose books suggested by current trends in the movies and the theatre, according to Miss Henrietta Hall, custodian of the Stimson Room.

Through the various units of the United States Power Squadrons, Inc., many boat owners as well as enthusiastic prospective yachtsmen are availing themselves of the opportunity to learn the whys and wherefores of navigation.

From the Cleveland headquarters of the Winton Engine Corporation comes word of startling developments in the Diesel field. It is the unit injector system which operates without the use of the long individual pipe lines, or rails to the individual cylinders.
Asa L. Carter, identified at the War Department as a resident of Cleveland, Ohio, proposed today to connect the Great Lakes and the Atlantic seaboard by a subway under the Alleghany Mountains.
Miss Marjorie Knapp, Dansville's 10-year-old golf star, is planning to leave soon for Pinehurst, N. C., to polish her game in preparation for the State women's championship next August in Syracuse.

Mrs. Foster Gardiner of Brookline and Beverly Farms will announce the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabel Gardiner, to Royall Victor Jr., son of Mrs. Royall Victor of Syosset, L. I., at a small tea she will give at Stellenbosch, her Brookline home tomorrow afternoon.

Purchases abroad by the twenty member stores of the Associated Merchandising Corporation this year will show an increase of 10 per cent over those made in 1936, according to Colonel P. J. Reilly, executive director of the buying agency, who recently returned from a five weeks' study of market conditions in England and Europe.

The problems of the recreation movement in America will be studied in a special Winter course now under way at the School of Education of New York University, it was announced yesterday by Dean John W. Withers of the School of Education.

Special arrangements by Ira S. Hirschmann of Saks-Fifth Avenue with THE NEW YORK TIMES made possible the appearance today of the first telephotos for commercial use. This marks a milestone in transmitting photographic styles in record time.

In introducing its new line of products, the Scripps Motor Company of Detroit announces that rubber mountings will be available for all models, an improvement that will provide greater safety, smoother performance and afford longer life, with increased economy of gas and oil consumption.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had ordered the Retail Furniture Dealers Association of St. Louis to "cease and desist from certain unfair trade practices in the interstate sale of furniture and allied products, including electric refrigerators and radios."

Mrs. Dorothy M. Beck, regional director, said today that more than $300,000 will be available in January for rural rehabilitation loans under the Resettlement Administration program for eleven Northeastern States.
Frederic Kernochan, presiding justice of the Court of Special Sessions of New York, died here at 11:35 o'clock tonight in the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 60.

William Langer entered his second term as Governor of North Dakota this week by officiating at the betrothal of his faction to the Democratic party, with the marriage of the two groups anticipated as an event of the future.

The "parliamentary session," a new form of debating developed at the Pennsylvania State College, is spreading to other colleges and universities this year, Professor John H. Frizzell said here today in announcing this season's debating schedule.

The engagement of Miss Florence Scheer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Scheer of 1,135 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, to J. Martin Seiler, son of Mrs. Louis Seiler, also of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Harvard gained its thirteenth consecutive hockey victory on the ice Of the Garden tonight, 2 to 0, before 10,000 persons, the largest crowd to see a college game in Boston since the depression. However, the thirteenth victory came hard for the Crimson.

Elmer E. Dawson of Winthrop, former vice president of the Boston Flour and Grain Exchange and member of the State House of Representatives from 1921 to 1924, died on Thursday at the Winthrop Community Hospital after a long illness. His age was 75.

Members of the Smith College Club of New York have taken over a special performance of "Die Meistersinger," with Lotte Lehmann in the leading role, the afternoon of Feb. 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the scholarship fund of the organization.
It was September, 1934. We were ready to make the trip from Stamford to Block Island aboard the yacht Danell, with bright hopes of seeing the last two America's Cup races.
The industrial unrest that always follows a severe depression, with its concomitant wage cuts and lay-offs, reached a momentary climax this week in the automobile industry.

The Domei (Japanese) News Agency reported today fifty-two prisoners, including many Manchukuoan bandits, were shot to death after wrecking a military prison at Tsitsihar, Manchukuo. Sixty-five others, the dispatch said, were recaptured.
SHALL Hawaii overlook, forget, ignore -- forgive -- the production of a musical farce called "Royal Koko" by undergraduates of the University of Hawaii? Shall Hawaii pretend that it never happened,
PERSISTENT LITIGANT: Constitutional decisions of the Supreme Court are remembered by the names of the parties to the test case.

The performance of "Tovarich," with Miss Marta Abba and John Halliday in the leading roles, on Tuesday night at the Plymouth Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Italian Welfare League. At the close of the performance Miss Abba will read in Italian Canto Five of Dante's "Inferno."

Some of the shoes to be worn in warm climates this Winter are as gayly colored as Easter eggs. These are daytime shoes, too. They can be worn with plain suits or dressy afternoon frocks One shoe of highly polished kid that comes in sky-blue, bright red or a lively light green has a high front that straps around the ankle.
Alfred University alumni are buying what experts say is one of the world's outstanding carillons as a memorial to President Emeritus and Mrs. Boothe C. Davis.

Held up by two youthful robbers sa he was walking on Fourteenth Street shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning, John Shore of 1,875 Riverside Drive, bookkeeper for the Excellent Fruit Company, 60 Gansevoort Street, was forced into the hallway of 354 West Fourteenth Street and robbed of a company payroll of $775.
LONDON.--One of the most eagerly awaited developments of the new reign in Great Britain is the issuance of the George VI stamps and coinage.

Mme. Catherine R. Branchard, proprietor for a half century of the famous old rooming house at 61 Washington Square South, died in her sleep there early yesterday. She was 80 years old and was taken ill shortly before Christmas with diabetes.

Yacht decoration is fast taking its rightful place among the absolute necessities. Time was when the interior was the last thing given consideration. But today, thanks to the demand for attractiveness plus comfort, we find much thought given to the appearance of cabins.

COLLEGE presidents, Bishops and hospital boards, looking about for endowers of good works, are taking up the study of the new capitalist. For daily the signs multiply that the oldfashioned type, their main benefactor in decades past, is changing character.

Six blind young women who comprise a theatrical troupe known as the Lighthouse Players will present three one-act plays on the evenings of Jan. 15 and 16 in the auditorium of the Lighthouse, headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

London clubs continue to force the pace in the English Football League. As a result of today's round of games Arsenal and Charlton Athletic are contending for the leadership with Brentford in second position only two points behind.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--The first major sports event of the season here is the annual Lake Worth Invitational Tournament, for which golfers from all parts of the country will swing into qualifying play tomorrow on the Palm Beach Golf Club course.
John M. Lambert, typewriter manfacturer and engineer, died yesterday at his home, 163 Woodside Avenue, at the age of 78. Born in England, Mr. Lambert was educated at Crew.

THE season, having definitely recovered from the holiday doldrums, has entered upon its second half with breath-taking energy. The present week fairly teems with major events and premieres of new productions.

The plan announced last week for sale of the 3,000,000 bales of cotton held under 12-cent loans by the government has thrown a damper over the cotton market and caused confusion in the cotton trade. The opinion is that it will result in virtually pegging the price around current levels and at the same time will not result in the disposal of a material quantity of the cotton.

New York State leads in progressive legislation, but it has lagged in adopting a sound mortgage program despite the splendid example set by the Federal Government, State Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink declared in his annual report to the Legislature.

" This Mad Whirl," the forty-ninth annual production of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania, was presented last night at the Hippodrome as the final performance of its holiday tour. A virtually sold-out house greeted the musical comedy with considerable enthusiasm.

Members of the Ladies' Auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital are sponsoring the annual midwinter indoor polo tournament of the New York Athletic Association to be held the night of Feb. 13 at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in Franklin Avenue for the benefit of the sick poor at the hospital.

The police are holding Michael Memoli, 21, of Darien, and August L. St. Charles, 23, of Stamford, in connection with. the removal of a 500pound safe from a bakery here last night. The safe contained $157.

Sixty-one Teachers College students have been elected to Pi Lambda Theta, Kappa Delta Pi and Phi Delta Kappa, national honorary educational fraternities, Miss Margaret E. Sober, director of student activities, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON. THIS Spring new honors will accrue to the memory of John James Audubon when the first museum ever constructed for the great ornithologist and artist will be dedicated near Henderson, Ky., the city in which Audubon spent ten years of his life.

Business in the handbag industry in 1936 was the best since the peak year of 1929, according to A. Mittenthal, director of the National Authority for the Ladies Handbag Industry. The increase in sales volume averaged from 15 to 20 per cent, and was general in all price lines, he said.

Professor Carlos de Zafra of the New York University College of Engineering will present a series of lectures on industrial engineering to inmates of Sing Sing prison, beginning Tuesday, it was announced yesterday at the university.
An intimation that any legislation to put business under Federal regulation, void of any infringement of civil liberty guarantees, would pass a constitutional test came today from Donald R. Richberg.
Two men, WPA employes attached to a Health Department Project, were arraigned before Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Felony Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on charges of extortion.
Setting a new record in dollar value, gold production in 1936 amounted to $150,959,270, compared with $126,324,900 in 1935 and $101,035,700 in 1915, the year of highest ounce production.

The secret political police's determined persecution of the church has driven the government's own Protestant Church administrators to issue publlicly in The Journal of the German Evangelical Church a bitter protest against secret police activities at Luebeck.
With the temperature soaring to 64 degrees at 3:10 P. M., heavily clad New Yorkers "suffered" in another day of unseasonably warm weather yesterday.
The dahlia, which has already proved its variability, has now been induced to develop an altogether new dwarf type for Winter forcing under glass.
Pennsylvania boosted its Eastern Intercollegiate League lead by outplaying Dartmouth at the Palestra tonight, 49-32, before a crowd of 6,500 fans.

Salvatore De Pasquale, 55 years old, of 53 Havemeyer Street, Brooklyn, was shot dead about 3 P. M. yesterday in a bakery owned by his son-in-law at that address. The shooting was the result of a family quarrel, the police said.

NEW ENGLAND left its impress not only upon spiritual and political America but upon that by which the people also live-its cookery. Almost every part of the country has adopted or adapted the dishes Yankees achieved under hard conditions.

DURING the next four weeks, while Frederick Stock, conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, is taking his midwinter vacation, the orchestra will be directed by Hans Lange, associate conductor, and Jose Iturbi and Serge Prokofieff, guest conductors.

Resolutions calling for enactment of a model Robinson-Patman law for this State, and demanding more effective action by the Federal Trade Commission against those infringing fair trade practice regulations, will be presented today to the sixteenth annual reunion of the United Independent Retail Grooers and Food Dealers Association, Ino.

Discussing the present status of New York hotels and apartment hotels with reference to certain improvements in those properties, Lawrence B. Elliman, head of the firm of Pease Elliman, pointed out that some of the recent offers for purchase have come from those looking for a speculative profit rather than from experienced hotel men seeking properties to operate.

Many of us remember the days of naphtha launches, converted sailcraft of ancient vintage, and back yard bateaux which constituted the nearest thing to a motor boat attainable by the average man. Regular stock boats were quite uncommon and extremely high-priced.

Two dance recitals were held yesterday in the Brooklyn Museum as part of the institution's Saturday dance series. The pupils of Sima Borisovana demonstrated the Isadora Duncan technique at the morning recital and in the afternoon the Brooklyn Museum Dance Group illustrated the Rudolph von Laban method.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Greene County, Va., on Jan. 29 at the Plaza. Mrs. Whitney Stone has enlisted the aid of several younger members of society to assist in the arrangements.

A mass of data on the lives and activities of persons in need of relief, which is expected to be of great value in improving public relief and laying the foundation for future needs of this sort, has been compiled in the normal course of their work by the Works Progress Administration and its predecessor, the Emergency Relief Administration, Administrator Hopkins said today.

School students should be taught to be realists but not cynics, Dr. Milton Hoffman, Professor of Church History at New Brunswick Theological Seminary, Rutgers University, told a meeting of the New York Schoolmasters Club last night at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

A locomotive's whistle howls up as it rushes toward us and down as it rushes away. Similarly with stars. Their light howls up toward the violet and down toward the red as they speed toward or from us.

" That all electric utilities should be owned and operated by the government" is the topic selected for the debate between the Current Events Club and the Council of Debate, Monday, 7:30 P. M., in the Science Lecture Hall of the College of New Rochelle, Miss Marcella a Newcomb of Yonkers, chairman, announced here today.

SEVERAL shows have just been added to the season's lengthening French perspective. At the Valentine Gallery you will find drawings by Renoir and water-colors by Cezanne, both artists well represented.

Founder's Day exercises, sponsored by the General Alumni Society of the University of Pennsylvania in trib ute to the memory of Benjamin Franklin, the institution's founder, will be held on the campus on Jan. 23.

Concerned over the number of city school teachers who have asked to be excused from their regular duties so they might seek to influence legislation at Albany, Dr. Harold G. Camrbell, Superintendent of Schools, warned the 38,000 employes of the Board of Education yesterday that such absence would be permitted only to representatives of associations with "a vital interest" in specific legislation.
Two boys, searching for firewood in a vacant building at 554 West Forty-third Street yesterday afternoon, discovered what was apparently the suicide of an unidentified man.

The board of trustees and overseers of the Philadelphia Divinity School have elected the Rev. Allen Evans Jr. of Hewlett, L. I., as dean of the school to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Rev. Dr. George G. Bartlett, it was disclosed today.

During the past decade great strides have been made by yacht station owners along the Atlantic seaboard in providing boat skippers with the ultimate in convenience for servicing their craft. Elaborate and well-appointed piers with giant, modern equipment have been constructed.

THOMAS O. SHECKELL needs no introduction as a photographer of trees. His vivid and portentous study. "In the Path of the Storm." not only won the American Forestry Association's first prize as 'the most beautiful photograph of trees in America," but has been exhibited in thirteen foreign countries as well as in many salons in the United States.

Alexander Potter of Grand View, in a minority report of the Rockland Westchester Hudson River Crossing Authority, announced today that he had advised Governor Lehman to order a legislative inquiry as to why the construction of a causeway and tunnel between Nyack and Tarrytown was opposed-by Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works. Mr. Potter agrees with the majority report that a bridge at this point is impractical.
Nickey Jerome, 123 1/2, Greenpoint, outpointed Joey Wach, 1261 1/4, East Side, in the feature attraction of eight rounds before 3,000 at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night.

The New York Rangers will oppose the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle will be the second in as many days for the rival sextets, who engaged in the first half of a doubleheader on the Maroon's ice last night.

After easing a few points in early trading yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered under persistent buying of the near months and ended with net changes ranging from a gain of 6 points to a loss of 1 point.

When Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated on Jan. 20 he will take on for another four years the duties of President, chairman of the board and general manager of the world's largest corporation, the executive branch of the United States Government, with approximately 840,000 employes and an annual payroll of more than $1,500,000,000.

Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, will deliver the annual address to the State Bar Association in the ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 28, it was announced yesterday.

The Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, which cites trends of "sensationalism in journalism" and the "resurgence of 'redbaiting'" as factors demanding its attention, is drafting plans for the 1937 sessions, to be held this Summer at Williams College.

The Neediest Cases Fund received yesterday thirty-two contributions totaling $860.18. This brought the grand total of the Fund to $269,309.18. There was one contribution of $500 from Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berlin.

JUDGED by the increasing demands made upon the French Information Center, which was opened last March at 610 Fifth Avenue, the service is proving of considerable value to persons in search of data on France and French institutions.
The French and British Governments today exchanged views and concerted plans for dealing with German infiltration into Spanish Morocco.

EDDIE BERGEN, the ventriloquist, and his dummy, known as "Charlie McCarthy," have opened the gateway to radio for his profession, which hitherto has been shunned by the microphone in its sixteen-year conquest of talent.

Act I, "Die Walkuere," presented by the symphony orchestra and soloists of the "Music Hall of the Air" in an hour concert, Erno Rapee directing. The other acts will be heard on successive Sundays: WJZ, 12:30 P. M.

Undergraduates who formally complete their college careers have a better chance of success in life than those who withdraw from college or fail before the end of their fouryear term, a study of the Princeton University alumni listed in "Who's Who in America" has revealed.

One man was injured and six other persons were shaken, but refused medical aid, in a collision between two street cars at University Avenue and Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, last night. They all were in a car operated by Jack Paddy, which was standing at the intersection, facing south on the avenue.

The native shrubs and plants of Eastern America have long been appreciated by horticulturists everywhere-except at home. English nurserymen feature many of our plants in their catalogues, but in this country commercial growers, with few exceptions, have been slow to recognize their value.

With the close of 1936 the motion-picture industry of the United States was in the best position that it has occupied since the boom year of 1929, Nathan D. Golden, chief of the Motion Picture Section, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said today.

C. J. Kappelman was re-elected commander of the Brooklyn Power Squadron at the annual meeting held recently at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island. Also renamed were Lieut. Commander H. W. Haedrich and Treasurer Jules A. Shaper.

Seven more suspects were arrested last night by detectives of the West 135th Street station as members of a gang of Negroes responsible for a series of hold-ups of insurance collectors within the last six weeks. Four of five men arrested last Sunday are being held for the grand jury on similar charges. The fifth was discharged.

Subfreezing temperatures bringing the coldest weather in fifteen years to semi-tropical Southern California caused damage to crops, chiefly citrus fruits, which unofficial estimates today indicated might run into several millions of dollars.

Augustus Samuel Beatman, head of the History Department of Julia Richman Higlf School and a member of the New York State Board of Regents, died yesterday of heart disease in the Harkness Pavilion of the Medical Center. Professor Beatman, who was 58 years old, had been ill for more than a year.

Whole wheat bread has just joined the list of staple foods for which higher prices are asked. The standard loaves of whole wheat, cracked wheat and rye now sell at 11 cents instead of 10. The three sizes of b white loaves remain at 7, 10 and 12, respectively.
SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga.Negro spirituals, sung by the descendants of those who helped create this folk music, will be featured in the south lounge of the Cloister here on Friday evening.

FERNANDO GERMANI, organist of the Augusteo Orchestra and Professor of Organ in the Royal Conservatory, Rome, will open the series of organ recitals to be given on four consecutive Wednesday nights at 8:30 o'clock at Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

The marriage of Miss Constance Cabell Hillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Frazer Hillman of this city, to John Cunningham Oliver Jr., son of Mrs. John Cunningham Oliver of Sewickley, took place here this afternoon in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Clifton Macon, who was assisted by the Rev. Louis Hirshon.

The steady improvement in the demand for better merchandise, which began during the Christmas period of 1935, continued consistently during 1936, according to H. L. Brooks, general manager of Coty and president of the Toilet Goods Association. This culminated, in the last few weeks, he said, in the best demand in five years for the better and more expensive packages.

To reinforce its prohibition of the export of German currency and notes, the government has issued an additional order prohibiting the importation of German bank notes, even of the smallest denomination.
TO commemorate the sixteenth anniversary of the Little Entente two new stamps from Rumania have appeared. The adhesives are surcharges of the current 7.5 lei (ultamarine) and 10 lei (blue) values.

Wisconsin legislators belonging to camps hostile to Governor Philip F. La Follette threatened today to use the issue of Dr. Glenn Frank's removal from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin as a rallying point.
Governor Alf M. Landon will become a "country gentleman" after he retires from office Monday.

HERE are adventures in controversy -- adventures as variegated as they are spirited, to the number of twenty-three. Twenty-one of them take the form of papers reprinted from periodicals; the other two, both on Mark Twain, were composed for use as addresses. In scope they range from five-page reviews to one newly amplified magazine essay running to some 20,000 words.

The clatter of riveting machines and the pounding of carpenters' hammers are spreading and becoming more insistent in New York as the city gradually regains its normal stride in construction activity.

In an effort to provide security for their homes, their jobs and their community, more than 35,000 men and women workers of Flint have gone on record in opposition to the present strike situation, which tonight finds 28,275 of them in idleness.

Matthew De Stephano, who has been active in Democratic politics in the Greenwich Village section for many years, died Friday at his home, 326 Bleecker Street, of pneumonia after a nine-day illness, at the age of 75. His widow, Theresa, and two sons.

EDDIE BERGEN, the ventriloquist, and his dummy, known as "Charlie McCarthy," have opened the gateway to radio for his profession, which hitherto has been shunned by the microphone in its sixteen-year conquest of talent.

Act I, "Die Walkuere," presented by the symphony orchestra and soloists of the "Music Hall of the Air" in an hour concert, Erno Rapee directing. The other acts will be heard on successive Sundays: WJZ, 12:30 P. M.

Figures showing a reduction in all boroughs in the number of cases undisposed of on the trial calendars of Municipal Court on Dec. 31, 1936, as compared with Dec. 31, 1935, have been made public by President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell.

Undergraduates who formally complete their college careers have a better chance of success in life than those who withdraw from college or fail before the end of their fouryear term, a study of the Princeton University alumni listed in "Who's Who in America" has revealed.

One man was injured and six other persons were shaken, but refused medical aid, in a collision between two street cars at University Avenue and Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, last night. They all were in a car operated by Jack Paddy, which was standing at the intersection, facing south on the avenue.

The native shrubs and plants of Eastern America have long been appreciated by horticulturists everywhere-except at home. English nurserymen feature many of our plants in their catalogues, but in this country commercial growers, with few exceptions, have been slow to recognize their value.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Pierson of Nutley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Jeannette Pierson, to George G. Hooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Hooper of Newark.
Graduation exercises for the students in the Department of Nursing of Skidmore College were held today in the Florence Nightingale Hall at Mary McClellan Hospital, Cambridge, N. Y.
BREAKING with tradition, the Postoffice Department for the first time is preparing to print a booklet which will carry illustrations of all postage stamps ever issued by the United States.

The marriage of Miss Constance Cabell Hillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Frazer Hillman of this city, to John Cunningham Oliver Jr., son of Mrs. John Cunningham Oliver of Sewickley, took place here this afternoon in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Clifton Macon, who was assisted by the Rev. Louis Hirshon.

The steady improvement in the demand for better merchandise, which began during the Christmas period of 1935, continued consistently during 1936, according to H. L. Brooks, general manager of Coty and president of the Toilet Goods Association. This culminated, in the last few weeks, he said, in the best demand in five years for the better and more expensive packages.

To reinforce its prohibition of the export of German currency and notes, the government has issued an additional order prohibiting the importation of German bank notes, even of the smallest denomination.
TO commemorate the sixteenth anniversary of the Little Entente two new stamps from Rumania have appeared. The adhesives are surcharges of the current 7.5 lei (ultamarine) and 10 lei (blue) values.

Wisconsin legislators belonging to camps hostile to Governor Philip F. La Follette threatened today to use the issue of Dr. Glenn Frank's removal from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin as a rallying point.
Governor Alf M. Landon will become a "country gentleman" after he retires from office Monday.

HERE are adventures in controversy -- adventures as variegated as they are spirited, to the number of twenty-three. Twenty-one of them take the form of papers reprinted from periodicals; the other two, both on Mark Twain, were composed for use as addresses. In scope they range from five-page reviews to one newly amplified magazine essay running to some 20,000 words.

The clatter of riveting machines and the pounding of carpenters' hammers are spreading and becoming more insistent in New York as the city gradually regains its normal stride in construction activity.

In an effort to provide security for their homes, their jobs and their community, more than 35,000 men and women workers of Flint have gone on record in opposition to the present strike situation, which tonight finds 28,275 of them in idleness.

Critics of the Social Security Act are loading their guns for a major attack on this legislation in the present session of Congress. Target for broadsides of criticism during the Presidential election campaign, the act is certain to draw fresh fire in the form of proposals for amendatory legislation.

Several young women, headed by Miss Virginia McD. Prout, are taking an active interest in the arrangements for the dinner dance in behalf of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to be held Tuesday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

Funeral services were held yesterday at Greenwich, Conn., for Mrs. Adelaide Hitchcock Brown, widow of Archer Brown, one of the founders of the Rogers, Brown Co. N mining firm. She died at her home there on Thursday morning. Mrs. Brown, who was 80 years old, suffered a heart attack.

IT appears to me that the big business men, the "captains of industry," as they were called a few decades ago, have reached a definite crisis with reference to their permanence as part of our modern social machinery.

Congress was urged today in a report of a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to take action to make easier the path of business under the Robinson-Patman act on price discrimination pending clarification of the law.
George Hiram MacBeth has been appointed manager of the sales and rental department of the Johnston Bros.-Chambers Realty Company of Brooklyn.
Foreign embassies in Nanking are openly admitting genuine alarm over the safety of their nationals in Shensi and Kansu Provinces.
The troubled course of a less than 100 per cent Aryan love affair in Nazi Germany will occupy the stage of the Westminster when "Crooked Cross" opens there on Wednesday evening.

A realistic Simulation of amphibian warfare wm be enacted around the beaches of San Clemente Island Feb. 8 to 18 by the United States Fleet and some 9.000 troops of the fleet marine force and army forces of the Pacific Slope.

THE Vigilantes were active in California in the Eighteen Fifties and they had work to do. This book goes back to pioneer and gold rush records, and shows a remarkable picture of crime and punishment in the San Francisco of those too-rich days.

Narrow and mixed price changes characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Although prices generally were firm to moderately higher, the secondary corporate loans lacked the buoyancy of the preceding session, while the high-grade investments held as good as unchanged in quiet dealings.

Mr. and Mrs. Jesse A. De Nyse of 234 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Edna De Nyse, to the Rev. G. Ernest Wright, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ernest J. Wright of Shreve, Ohio.

In an article appearing in the January issue of The Real Estate and Building Management Digest, Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, points out that in 1935 and again in 1936 the Real Estate Board of New York warned the city authorities that to enforce the sanitary and fire provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law would bring about a shortage in low-rental housing.

P. A. O'Connell, president of the Charitable Irish Society, announced tonight that President Roosevelt had accepted an invitation to address the organization on St. Patrick's Day, the 200th anniversary of its founding.

AMONG the numerous exhibitions of the week, the John Taylor Arms retrospective at a the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries ranks high in interest. He calls it, aptly enough, "Twenty-one Years of Drawing."
The Count of Covadonga announced today he would file suit for divorce in the Cuban courts against the former Edelmira Sampedro.
A. W. A.-Tea dance, 4:30 P. M., at American Woman's Club. A. W. A.-Program of "Characters and Caricatures," by Miss Helen Howe, monologist, 8:30 P. M., at American Woman's Club.

The basketball team of Western Reserve University, routed by Stanford last week, 67 to 27, and defeated by a local rival, John Carroll, only three days ago, sprang a surprise tonight by beating Nat Holman's C. C. N. Y. quintet in an overtime battle, 38 to 34.

An informal survey of club life in New York-inspired by the fact that the Union League Club may decide this week to admit Democrats to membership-reveals that a large percentage of New Yorkers, regardless of political affiliations, are "joiners" of the first order.
Estate, less than $1,000. To Carolyn C. Cammen, widow, executrix, 529 W. 111th St. LETTERS OF ADMINISTRATION Granted by Surrogate James A. Delehanty on the following estates:

The Rev. Robert W. Courtney, who was associate pastor of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, from 1918 to 1925, died yesterday afternoon in the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, 218 Second Avenue, at the age of 60.

A COURSE in elementary physics might make better drivers of many who are now licensed to sit behind steering wheels with feet on brake and accelerator pedals. Any moving body develops momentum, which is the product of its mass and velocity.

The Nichols Copper Company of New York was sued for $100,000 in the Federal District Court here today under the terms of the RobinsonPatman bill, which declares it unlawful to sell merchandise at an unreasonably low price to eliminate competition.

Madison is a city of about 50,000 inhabitants. It is a big city as cities go, but it is not big enough to hold Glenn Frank and the La Follettes, Robert and Phil, the heirs to the political dynasty bequeathed to them by their father, Fighting Bob, of sainted memory hereabouts.
Fox tails have been popular as decorations for radiators of automobiles, but Miss Agnes Stolgitis of Gilbertville has bettered this fad by training a live red fox to ride in her sedan.

Under the Mexican flag today Leon Trotsky asked that the case between him and Joseph Stalin be tried before the court of world opinion through the medium already suggested, a non-partisan international body.

On Wednesday noon the legislative mills of New York State began to grind again at Albany. Before a joint session of the Legislature, in which Democrats dominate the Senate and Republicans have an Assembly majority of two, Governor Lehman read his annual message.

Officials of the Social Action Department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, the Industrial Division of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America and the Social Justice Commission of the Central Conference of American Rabbis have sent this telegram to William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, and Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America:

LET it be said at once that there are some thoroughly good and robust and original things, along with work that is at any rate competent, in the national exhibition called "Prints for the People," a WPA Federal Art Project, which opened at the International Art Center, 310 Riverside Drive, Jan. 4 and will remain current through the month.

TOBACCO ROAD is more than a fictional name. For more than a century before it be came famous as the name of a novel and a play, it stretched its serpentine length for miles over Georgia's red-clay hilltops.

The fifteen largest banks in this city, including J. P. Morgan Co., reported, as of Dec. 31, total deposits of $11,950,208,000, a rise of $360,961,000, or 3.11 per cent, in the last, quarter of 1936 and a gain of $887,590,000, or 8.02 per cent, in the year, a compilation of their condition statements shows.

Mr. and Mrs. Mathew Negrini of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Negrini to Gardener F. Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon F. Fox of Bellrose, L. I., formerly of Brooklyn.

Dr. and Mrs. Luther M. Allen of Mount Holly announce the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Dorothea Allen Foucar, to T. Montague Carson, son of Mrs. J. Preston Carson of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Carson.

Vork on two new projects at the University of Pittsburgh, the great Commons Room of the forty-one-story Cathedral of Learning and the Heinz Memorial Chapel, is progressing so rapidly that it is hoped both can be dedicated at the June commencement.

PARIS. ON the walls of some French schools hangs a symbolic picture entitled "The Conquerors." It shows six figures standing elbow to elbow--Rameses II, Nebuchadnezzar. Alexander the Great, Julius Caesar, Attila and Napoleon L I imagine that if in future

More than 1,450 students at City College earned $89,764 last year, according to the seventeenth annual report of the college employment bureau to the faculty committee on student employment, of which Professor Edmund Burke is chairman.

Willis Lawrence, engineer in charge of the main power plant of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company at Fifty-ninth Street and the North River, died yesterday in Sydenham Hospital, 123d Street and Manhattan Avenue, of coronary thrombosis. He was 68 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Isabelle Shaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilbert Shaffer of this place, to Dr. William Clyde Wycoff, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Alexander Wycoff of Pittsburgh.

Governor Murphy's attempts to conciliate the dispute involving the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America collapsed today, the union informing him that his efforts had proved unavailing "due to the rejection by General Motors of all responsible proposals" for a truce.

A program for the abolition of child labor "and other obnoxious practices" without recourse to a constitutional amendment was suggested today by Dr. E. Stagg Whitin, executive chairman of the National Committee on Prisons and Prison Labor.

BONAVENTURA TECCHI belongs to that class of writers which develops very slowly. His first book, "Il nome sulla sabbia" ("The name in the sand") was published as long ago as 1924, when he was already 28.

AFTER many months of filming in Mysore and, lately, in the Denham Studios, Robert Flaherty has finished "Elephant Boy," an adaptation of Kipling's "Toomai of the Elephants," and it will be shown in London early in the new year.

Comprehensive examinations for seniors at Russell Sage College are to be extended this year to the various professional schools. In effect for some years past in the School of Arts and Sciences, this type of examination is now to be applied also to the fields of physical education, home economics, business education and nursing.

A total of 2,506 enlisted soldiers, the quota for a complete infantry regiment in the United States Army, was selected by the New York recruiting district during the year just closed, it was announced yesterday by Colonel William H. Patterson, in charge of that bureau at 39 Whitehall Street.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 7 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Various health stations for underprivileged children and mothers fgstered by the New York Diet Kitchen Association in crowded districts of the city will be the beneficiaries of a special performance of "The Tales of Hoffman" Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Many luncheon parties in the cafe at the opera house will precede the performance. Many boxes and seats have been sold for the benefit.

The New York City Tunnel Authority received yesterday from the PWA a check for $500,000, the initial payment from the Federal loan of $47,130,000 made a year ago to help finance construction of the Queens midtown vehicular tunnel under the East River.

General Francisco Franco's hard-hitting Insurgent troops tonight reached the banks of the Manzanares River, skirting Madrid. Fighting up to the capital under terrific gunfire, the soldiers occupied several strategic points along the edge of the city.

Captain Joseph S. Wood, president of the Lake Carriers Association, announced today that the bulk freight commerce on the Great Lakes during the eight-month navigation season in 1936 was the largest of any year since 1929.

For the first time since 1922, it was said yesterday, the upper floors of the Cunard White Star piers, 54 and 56 at the foot of West Fourteenth Street, are stacked with westbound freight because there is not sufficient space on the lower floors.

Winning six of the eight bouts, the City College wrestling team defeated Columbia, 24 to 8, yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Three of the Beavers' victories came by way of falls. The competition featured a triple sports bill.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Jan. 7: Haynes, Capt. J. P., Med. Corps, when discharged from treatment Naval Hospital. Philadelphia, Pa., to home, relieved all active duty.

The 1937 indoor track and field season was launched last night with an old feud serving as the piece de resistance for 5,000 persons at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn, where the eleventh annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, games were staged.

The policy of integrating courses in related fields of study through faculty exchange is gaining fresh impetus at Elmira College this year. The students themselves voice their approval of such measures which, in cutting across departmental barriers, make their work more interesting and significant.

The Pan-Hellenic Association, the organization to which all Hunter College sororities, local and national, belong, is keeping step with other extra-curricular groups at the college in training its members to become socially minded.
Army staged a stirring second-half rally to overcome Yale in a hardfought basketball game today, 37 to 29. The Cadets also won at indoor polo, beating a Squadron A trio by 11 to 3.
JAMES STEPHENS in his whimsical and yet serious preface to Ruth Pitter's last book of poems divides poets into major, minor and pure.

Announcement was made here yesterday that Henry G. Hanford, assistant to the business manager of The Washington Star, died Friday night of pneumonia at his residence, 3,706 Military Road, Washington, D. C. Born in Sterling, Va., sixty-two years ago, he had been with The Star since he was 21.

In commemoration of the 180th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton, Regular Army troops from the Eighteenth Infantry stationed at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, will conduct ceremonies at his grave in Trinity Churchyard, Manhattan, tomorrow at noon, according to orders issued by Colonel Royden E. Beebe, commanding the Eighteenth Infantry.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities, for the week ended Jan. 6 aggregated $10,481,000,000, or 8 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 4 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year. Each of the three weeks included only five business days.
LAWRENCE KEARNY. SAILOR DIPLOMAT. By Carroll Storrs Alden. l2mo. Princeton. N. J.: Princeton University Press. 82. A life of Commodore Kearny of the United States Navy.

A device of interest to small-boat owners faced with the problem of transporting craft any considerable distance to water is being shown by Armstrong Galbraith, Inc. This is known as the Vaco Grip and is a carrier for a boat or canoe which attaches at the top of an automobile.

MOUNT MANSFIELD, VT. NOW that the Winter sports season is under way, expert skiers are training for the main racing events, most of which are fashioned after celebrated European contests, such as the Swiss "Inferno" and the "Arlberg Kandahar."

LA EMOCION DE LA MUSICA," by Solomon Kahan, is published by the Editorial Independencia of Mexico, D. F. It is a book of good size and of substantial and varied content, including essays on many subjects, put in a terse, thoughtful and idiomatic way by the leading music critic of Mexico's capital.
A loan exhibition of Italian baroque paintings is on view in the Vasssar College art gallery under the auspices of the college department of art.

Eighteen members of the Armenian-American Democratic Club, 362 Audubon Avenue at 183d Street were lined up against the wall of the clubhouse at 11:30 P. M. yesterday and robbed of $150 in cash and $75 in jewelry by three armed men.

Such hardships as tramping 70 miles over frozen tundra and eating "old (dead) seal" while faced with starvation on the Arctic Coast were called merely "incidents" by the Rt. Rev. Peter Falaize when the veteran Roman Catholic Coadjutor Bishop of MacKenzie came back to Edmonton by airplane.

Governor Elmer Benson's inaugural message leaves no doubt that he intends to keep the Minnesota Farmer-Labor party in the forefront as a standard bearer of the left wing of national politics. His message began with an attack on the shortcomings of private industry, which, he said, "has given ample proof of its inability to supply even our most elementary social and economic needs."

WALTER STARKIE is the perfect Scholar Gypsy of our modern day. He fiddles his way from place to place, picking up the coppers that are the wandering minstrel's wages, in cafe and at street festival, and among the peasants in the crowded country trains.

Biography, scratched from the fourth race, made good in the mile and an eighth of the Martin Behrman Memorial Handicap at the Fair Grounds today when he carried Butsy Hernandez's New Orleans-owned silks to victory.

Reports detailing expenditures of more than $100,000 in philanthropies during the last year will feature the eighty-sixth annual convention of the Grand Lodge of the United Order of True Sisters, opening this afternoon at the national headquarters, 150 West Eighty-fifth Street.

THE tip of Manhattan Island has always been a sight worth seeing, although "pleasant" -- rather than "magnificent" or "stupendous"--was the word that was applied to it in 1524, when a European ship first rode at anchor in New York Bay. and white men stepped ashore where there is now an elevated station.

Carrying on her family's railroading tradition, Miss Ellen Brennan, grayhaired and bespectacled, has operated crossing gates of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad here for eighteen years. She was assigned to the job during the World War, when the eight-hour day was effected.

City, State and Federal officials spoke last night at the annual installation dinner of the Women's Regular Democratic Organization of the Fifth Ward, Queens, in the Commodore Hotel, Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 127th Street, Rockaway Park.

Fatalities from motor vehicle accidents declined 127 for 1936 in Net York City as compared with 1935, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. Accidents also dropped, the Mayor reported, the 1936 total of 32,975 being 2,357 fewer than in 1935. The Mayor attributed much of this decrease to the Police Department's Safety Campaign.

The American Committee for the defense of Leon Trotsky, Bolshevist tile now on his way to Mexico, has ked the Soviet government to perit the presence of an international missionn at the forthcoming trial Karl Radek, former Soviet commentator, and Gregory Pyatakoff, rmer Assistant Commissar for eavy Industry.

In the famous Borghese Gallery at Rome for many years hung a painting of St. Catherine, attired in a flowing cloak. The painter was unknown, but the work was obviously old and bore the touch of a master hand. Experts dated it about 1500 and attributed it to some artist who had studied under Perugino, master of the great Raphael.

With the question of rebates for rug volume still unsettled, buyers for large retail establishments returned to their home cities yesterday, leaving behind a variety of orders for sample lots of new rug lines. Despite the fact that largevolume retail buyers are holding up commitments until word of the rebate decision is ready, the week's sales were the heaviest for any Spring opening in years.

Former Police Commissioner James S. Bolan, whose term of office lasted nine months from April, 1933, until Jan. 1, 1934, joined the James E. Branigan Detective Bureau, Inc., 295 Madison Avenue, yesterday as "police consultant." He spent his first day "working on a case."

The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy officially announced the designation of its new dormitory as Wilson House at a tea and house warming on Tuesday. The building was named in honor of Professor George Grafton Wilson of Harvard, international lawyer, author and educator, who has served on the school's faculty for three years.
Boston University has received an unusual gift with the new year in the presentation of the Deering Community Center here.

Governor Lehman asked business men of the State to back ratification of the child labor amendment and his entire program of labor and social legislation in an address tonight before the Albany Chamber of Commerce.

The Fifth Avenue shopping district and adjacent thoroughfares are undergoing decided changes. Several important new buildings are under construction there, and scores of retail establishments in the midtown section which have benefited by the upward surge of trade during the past two years have been improving the appearance of their stores.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 7 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Various health stations for underprivileged children and mothers fgstered by the New York Diet Kitchen Association in crowded districts of the city will be the beneficiaries of a special performance of "The Tales of Hoffman" Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Many luncheon parties in the cafe at the opera house will precede the performance. Many boxes and seats have been sold for the benefit.

The New York City Tunnel Authority received yesterday from the PWA a check for $500,000, the initial payment from the Federal loan of $47,130,000 made a year ago to help finance construction of the Queens midtown vehicular tunnel under the East River.

General Francisco Franco's hard-hitting Insurgent troops tonight reached the banks of the Manzanares River, skirting Madrid. Fighting up to the capital under terrific gunfire, the soldiers occupied several strategic points along the edge of the city.

An effort to settle a trade dispute before it begins opened yesterday when the American textile delegation landed at Yokohama. The delegation was met by representatives of the Japanese cotton industry. Later, at a reception at the United States Embassy in Tokyo, they met Japanese bankers and business leaders.

All of Japan is rapidly falling into one of two opposing camps and girding for a struggle that will determine within the next few months whether this empire is to follow the path taken by Germany and Italy or return to the ways of the great democratic powers.

Two new departments, those of chemistry and physics, will be represented in the division of graduate studies at Brooklyn College next term, Professor Joseph G. Cohen, divisional director, announced yesterday.

IN his Perry Mason stories, Mr. Gardner introduced us to a lawyer who frequently found himself in conflict with the District Attorney and who just as frequently confounded that functionary by means of some legal trick and made him look exceedingly silly.

Gunfire sounded over the Narrows guarding the entrance of New York Harbor yesterday morning when Brig. Gen. Perry L. Miles arrived from Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, to assume command of the First Division.

Mrs. Martha Nelson Crego of 230 East Forty-eighth Street was married to Ledyard Heckscher of Bolingbroke, Radnor, Pa., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent, the rector, assisted by the Rev. Richard L. Gurley, rector of St. Martin's Church in Radnor, in the presence of a small group of friends and relatives.

Amine Youssef Bey, Egyptian Minister to Washington, who returned recently from Europe, said in an interview at the Hotel Ambassador that three facts about America had greatly attracted his attention since he had come to this country, They were:

President Roosevelt enters upon his second term of office as he did the first one, with economic problems, but of a different sort, in the forefront. Then the task was to overcome the forces of deflation, increase prices and build for permanent prosperity.
The Cabinet met at 10 Downing Street this morning under the direction of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to consider the Spanish situation and reports that German troops had landed in Spanish Morocco.

IT is of interest to contrast "The Witch of Edmonton," discussed here last week, with two mod ern treatments of murder"Death Asks a Verdict," by Christopher Vye, and "A Busman's Honeymoon," by Dorothy L. Sayers and M. St. Clare Byrne.

President. Lazaro Cardenas faced down powerful Mexican labor leaders today by forcing them to issue orders through the press to forbid their followers to demonstrate against Leon Trotsky, the former Russian leader, when he arrives here tomorrow morning. This development is regarded here as being of prime importance, for it is held to indicate that the President is determined to, and can, curb the recent tendency of Mexican labor to run wild.

Dr. Floyd Faust, pastor of the Broad Street Church of Christ, asserted today in his weekly sermon that Ohio State University was "openly anti-religious," and urged the removal of all professors who, "ridicule" regligion.
Feneralissimo Francisco Franco's Rebel drive against the northwestern sector of Madrid appears to have been halted.

Prince Kimmochi Saionji, last of the Elder Statesmen in Japan, is suffering from severe cold with a high temperature. As the Prince is 88 years old, his illness causes anxiety and physicians are in constant attendance.

Since the "banking holiday" of March, 1933, 551 national bank receiverships have been closed finally or restored to solvency, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. In December the Controller reported completion of the liquidation of twentyone receiverships.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Henry Matthiessen of. Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Eda Matthiessen, to Clarence E. Galston, son- of Judge and Mrs. Clarence G. Galston of Woodmere, L. I.

6th St., 644-46 E., 64x97; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee, to Bankers Trust Co., trustee. 8th Av., s. e. cor. of 43d St., 20.4x80; Edna A. Ruprecht, et al., trustees of Adelaide B. Alfke, to Altrup Realty Corp., 678 8th Av.; mtg., 30.O00 ($150).

The Bronxville Field Club squash racquets team went into a deadlock for first place with the Sleepy Hollow Country Club yesterday in the Westchester division of the. Metropolitan League by conquering the Ardsley Country Club, 6--1, on the Ardsley courts. Sleepy Hollow, which has been triumphant in two starts, was idle, having drawn a bye.
Detective Joseph Downey's oneman drive on subway vagrants resulted yesterday in the arrest of sixteen men, fourteen of whom were discharged when they were arraigned in court.

Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College and the Friends of Barnard will be hostesses tomorrow night at a musical program at Barnard Hall, at which a harpsichord and other early instruments of the piano type will be played.
Mrs. Howard Frost King of Windsor has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Frost King, to Wilfred Clapp Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Crook Schneider, also of Windsor.
Serving notice that they would permit no mass demonstrations on Capitol Hill, Washington police awaited tonight the first of two threatened protest marches.

Government circles here continue to refuse to release for publication the facts concerning the situation in Sian and elsewhere in Shensi Province and in Kansu. They also refrain from issuing denunciations of the Sian rebel leaders, which is taken to indicate that hopes are. still entertained for a peaceful settlement.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Q. Trowbridge of Oyster Bay, L. I., will come today to the Savoy-Plaza for the rest of the Winter. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Neave have left the Westbury for San Francisco, whence they will sail for Honolulu to pass the remainder of the Winter.

A modern patriot should be a sane and true leader who will help to overcome the modern doubt that God or man, or both, can set the world right, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, said yesterday.

Leaders in science, industry, chemistry, education and business met here today at memorial exercises for the Rev. Julius A. Nieuwland, C. S. C., University of Notre Dame chemist and botanist, who died last May. Father Nieuwland, one of America's best-known chemists, is credited with having made the synthetic rubber -industry possible as the result of his researches.

A New England branch of the Committee for Industrial Organization was formed in Boston tonight with the announced purpose of organizing more than 1,000,000 non-union workers in mass-production industries in the Northeastern States. The first objective of the new group will be the unionizing of 15,000 steel workers in Worcester County.

The Neediest Cases Fund was augmented by seven contributions yesterday amounting to $29. They brought the total received by the Fund in this appeal to $269,338.18. A-check -for -$5 came from "A. E. A." in a note which said: "I'm sorry to be so late this season."

The findings of a two-year survey designed to answer the question "How big is 'big business'?" were made public last night by the Twentieth Century Fund. The research organization drew no inferences from its statistical report, which showed a wide variation in the extent to-which wage-earners in given industries were concentrated in the employ of large corporations.
Charles W. Devereaux has been retired as captain of the steamship Shawnee after forty-four years with the Clyde Mallory Lines.
Uncertain preaching was denounced by the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan; rector of St. James Epicopal Church, Madison Avenue.and Seventy-first Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

The necessity of a vigorous youth movement in American Jewish life and ways of accomplishing it through the synagogue were discussed yesterday at the ninth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Young Folks Temple Leagues.

The Paris money market was easier after the monthend, and day-to-day money delined from 2 to 1 1/4 per cent. The statement of the Bank of France, dated Dec. 30, shows the usual year-end increase in the bill portfolio of about 1,000,000,000 francs.

Coroner W. R. Toalson said today Mrs. Albert E. Trombly, wife of a University of Missouri professor, shot and critically wounded her 9year-old daughter while the child slept, then took her own life today while another daughter screamed in terror.

From the tenor of the replies now received to their communication to the governments of Germany, Italy, Portugal and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics of Dec. 24 last His Majesty's Government is happy to note that there is in principle a general agreement among the powers mainly concerned that immediate measures should be taken to stop the inflow of foreign volunteers into Spain.

The three-year reign of St. Francis Prep as swimming ruler of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association came to an end yesterday when Bishop Loughlin Memorial High clinched the crown as the 1936-37 dual meet series came to a close at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

The Association of Hospital and Nursing Professionals, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday that it would advocate legislation at Albany granting State reciprocity to nurses.

John Barbirolli, the 37-year-old British conductor, took leave of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. At the end of the concert the audience remained and applauded, recalling Mr. Barbirolli repeatedly. Finally he spoke.

The proposed New York State World War Memorial will be discussed tomorrow at a luncheon meeting of the American Institute of Architects at the Architectural League, 115 East 40th St. James Riely Gordon, Richmond H. Shreve and' Matthew W. Del Gaudio will speak.
Women teachers in the Delmar grade school are determined never to be dependent on a man who is handy around the house.

William Church Osborn, president of the Hudson River Conservation Society, issued a statement today aligning the society with the village of Cornwall and various individual property owners who are opposing the proposed location for the Storm King Highway by-pass.

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels announced today that the fourth anniversary of Adolf Hitler's accession to power on Jan. 30 will be observed "with great political demonstrations which will take full account of the dignity and importance of that day."

This week's financial markets reflected uncertainty owing to anxiety over the position of Spain, to which was added new reports that the Reichsbank was virtually compelling the sale of foreign currency securities.

The champion Red Wings of Detroit, jumping into the lead six seconds before the close of the second period, defeated the Boston Bruins for the fourth time this season before 13,498 spectators tonight to take undisputed possession of the lead in the American Division of the National Hockey League. The score was 4 to 2.

Swiss authorities have decided to refuse permission to reside in Switzerland after Friday to Carlo Aprato, assistant correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the ground that unspecified articles they attribute to him in the Journal des Nations, as well as that newspaper's general policy, "were of a nature to trouble Swiss foreign relations." They expressly state that no complaint has been made against his work for THE TIMES.

Employers subject to the State Unemployment Insurance Law who have been delinquent in paying their contributions or who have filed reports and contribution statements under varied names, may find themselves having to pay double taxes unless discrepancies are cleared up, the Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews, warned today.

The needlework of four former Presidents' wives will be included in the third exhibition entitled "Amateur Needlework of Today," which will be opened this morning at W. J. Sloane's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.

Religion contributes to the -individual a security fully as important as social security, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of the All Souls TJnitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

The purchase of $468,000 of New York World's Fair debentures by R. H. Macy Co. was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the fair's bond sales committee. This was the largest subscription to fair bonds to be made thus far by any New York business concern.
Pope Pius's condition is still described as "stationary," although he is greatly relieved both in body and in mind by subsidence of the pains in his left leg that had tortured him for a fortnight.

President Roosevelt this week will send to the new Congress one of its hardest and, many believe, most disagreeable tasks when he submits recommendations for a wholesale reorganization of the executive branch of the government.

A contribution of $5,000 from John A. Hartford and one of $1,000 from Mrs. Hartford to the United Hospital Campaign through the women's campaign committee were announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman of the drive.

Stocks higher on week in heavy trading; turnover, 13,019,805 shares. Corporation issues higher with second-grade rails strong and active, United States Government bonds irregular, foreign loans higher; transactions, $96,986,100.
Robert Hazelhurst McAdoo, third son of United States Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, died of double pneumonia at 6 o'clock last night at his home, 503 East Fifty-fifth Street. He was 38 years old.

Samuel Bridges, well known horseman, who bought and sold riding and driving horses for Berkshire Summer residents, died today. He was 86 years old. A native of Williamstown, his father established here in 1862 the Bridges Livery, of which the son had been proprietor from 1872 until 1925, when he made the stable into a garage.
Accounts reaching Paris regarding German infiltration into Spanish Morocco present the situation somewhat as follows:
A well-mounted and powerful-hitting trio representing the 112th Field Artillery of Red Bank defeated the Essex troop of Newark today in the Red Bank Armory.

Dr. Julius Oscar Stieglitz, chemist and retired administrative head of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Chicago, died of pneumonia at the Chicago Memorial Hospital today. He was 69 years old.

Disapproval of any bill in the Legislature that would require a municipality operating its own utility to devote any surplus funds from such operation to rate reduction instead of using them for the general fund was voiced here today by the New York State Conference of Mayors.

Upon the shoulders of a veteran campus politician, whose name has been anathema to the sons of old "Fighting Bob" La Follette for nearly two decades, there falls tomorrow the task of holding together the faculty of the University of Wisconsin in the most bitter controversy that has arisen in its history.

In her annual report as Secretary of Labor, Miss PERKINS deals at large with the "objectives " still to be sought in the relations between capital and labor, employers and workers. She admits that there is as yet a lack of economic and political definition.

Mrs. Rebecca- Y. Hicks, widow of Leonard Hicks and a member of one of the oldest families in Oyster Bay Township, died today in the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove of lockjaw, following a brief illness. Her age was 62.

Many reservations have been made for celebration of the Russian New Year to be held Wednesday night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis in a floral setting of white, blue and red, the colors of the Russian flag under the Czarist regime.
Colonel Charles Moore Gandy, Acting Surgeon General of the United States Army in 1912-13, died of a heart attack at his home today. He was 79 years old.
This city, first to buy Tennessee Valley Authority power and retail it to consumers, reported today a profit on the deal of $15,084.07 during. 1936.

Residential building should gain impetus this year from an increasing housing shortage, higher rentals and continued recovery in public purchasing power, according to the F. B. Industries Service, a bi-monthly survey of twenty-eight industries distributed by Fenner Beane.

While Governor Frank Murphy renewed at Detroit today his efforts to settle the General Motors strike, the United Automobile Workers of America held demonstrations outside the two Fisher Body plants and the Standard Cotton Products plant here, where sit-down strikes are in progress.
Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Chancellor of Germany, will discuss the "Crisis of Democracy" in a series of four public lectures on the Vanuxem Foundation at Princeton University next week.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10.--Dr. Charles Delancey Alton, dean of the Hartford medical profession and for sixty years connected with the medical department of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Friday night at the age of 91.
The strictly male tradition of the Columbia College varsity show, built up through the years by spindly legged male choristers, is shelved this week,

Resolutions calling for a drastic revision of immigration and naturalization laws were unanimously adopted yesterday at a conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the American Committee for the Protection of the Foreign Born. More than 400 delegates, representing nearly 200 religious, social, fraternal and labor organizations, attended.

Ebenezer Tiffany, town treasurer of Barrington for thirty-eight years, died here today. His age was 67. He was the fourth Tiffany to hold the office, which had been filled by members of the family since 1822, with the exception of two two-year terms.

With "real progress" recorded during 1936 in the $33,000,000 slumclearance and low-rent housing program being carried on in New York State by the Public Works Administration, Dwight L. Hoopingarner, associate director of the PWA housing division, informed Administrator Harold L. Ickes yesterday that
