Further progress in liberalizing the attitude of society toward illegitimate children was made last week when Justice Jacob Panken ruled in Domestic Relations Court that a husband must support the illegitimate child of his wife.

The cost of living at the end of last year was 2.6 per cent above 1935 and 20.1 per cent above April, 1933, the low point of the depression, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday. However, it was still 14.2 per cent below December, 1929.

Eleven fishermen were drowned today in the sinking of two trawlers. The trawler San Sebastian struck a rock and sank off the island of Islay, Scotland, with the loss of four men. Richard Wilfred Pook, skipper of the trawler, clung to rocks for ten hours before he was rescued. Eight others were also saved.

The first performance of the season of Wagner's "Siegfried" will take place next week during the fifth week of the season, it was announced yesterday. Kirsten Flagstad will sing the role of Bruennhilde in her initial appearance in this opera here.

In the last year the people of the United States have shown themselves to be impervious to anti-Jewish propaganda, regarding antiSemitism as a violation of the ideals of the better American institutions, it was observed yesterday in the yearly report of the executive committee of the American Jewish Committee.

The late Dr. Philip Embury Browning, former Professor of Chemistry at Yale University, left to the university rare element mineral salts and other products of his chemistry research covering a period of thirty-eight years as a member of the chemistry faculty of the university.

With the opening of the second week of the new year the season keeps up its pace, some thirty exhibitions being on the calendar. A few of these are group shows but the great majority are devoted to work by one artist. And diversity may be said to be the keynote of the week.

Four jobbers in New York in the foodstuffs and flavoring extract lines have been ordered to discontinue unfair representations in the interstate sale of flavoring extracts, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Joseph Igoe of 126 Stratford Road, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Elizabeth Igoe, to Dr. James Emerson Dailey of Olena, Ohio.
A test case concerning the right of natives with a certain standard of education to obtain liquor was heard in the Cape Town magistrate's court last month, reports Wine and Spirit of Stillenbrock.

The Jews have. ceased to be a reading people, the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, declared yesterday morning in his sermon-at the services of that congregation in Carnegie Hall. Rabbi Wise,

A large number of buyers in the wholesale market here last week bought generously, both for Spring selling and for special promotional events. Considerable activity was noted throughout the ready-to-wear field, where new items are -being shown daily.

Party leaders have tacitly agreed to maintain Premier Koki Hirota's government in power and avoid forcing a crisis during the coming Diet session. They will launch a demonstration against Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita's management of foreign affairs, but will pass the budget and accept tax increases.

A statement deploring the action of the Socialist party in encouraging Socialists fo enlist in the combat service of the Spanish Leftist Government was issued yesterday by the executive committee of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, a Christian Socialist group.

Wilson Co., Inc., meat packers, earned $4,066,457 net in the year to Oct. 31 after all charges, including provision for Federal income taxes, according to the annual report, which will be released today by Edward Foss Wilson, president.

Aided by government exploration parties and supported by a steadily increasing amount of capital, the Ontario gold mining industry again this year will extend greatly its development activities in both new and old fields.

THE literary output of the Roosevelt administration apparently knows no bounds. There have been surveys of progress under the New Deal. There have been defenses of special agencies, the NRA and others.

Out of the legends of the Hudson Highlands and out of his own imagination Maxwell Anderson has composed the gustiest fantasy in the American drama, "High Tor," which was faultlessly -acted at the Martin Beck on Saturday evening.

Tom K. Smith, president of the American Bankers Association, will be among the speakers at the midWinter trust conference to be held by the trust division of the American Bankers Association on Feb. 9, 10 and 11 at the Waldorf-Astoria, according to the program of the conference which was issued

A sharp upward curve in the foreign trade of the United States in iron and steel products, both semi-finished and finished, has prevailed for several months, and exports of these commodities in November reached the highest level for that month since 1930, the metals and minerals division of the Department of Commerce reported today.

A poster contest, open to all artists, has been announced by the American Civil Liberties Union. The contest, according to the union, is to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the drafting of the Constitution and designs should illustrate the significance of the Bill of Rights.

Liberal selling of lard futures, particularly around the middle of the week by commission house longs, weakened thee market here last week. Stocks are unusually heavy, having increased 16,000,000 pounds at the seven principal markets in December.

Manhattan and Long Island university will try to uphold local prestige in tonight's basketball doubleheader at the Hippodrome. The Jaspers will meet Niagara, one of the three teams to defeat them last season, and the Blackbirds will face La Salle, one of the strongest teams in the Philadelphia district.

The thirteen city branches of the Young Men's Christian Association will open their annual campaign for funds today, this year's goal being $215,839. The sum represents the amount necessary to "balance the budgets" of the branches.

One of the curious developments of the American system of handling fish and game resources is that every man who goes hunting once a year, or goes fishing once a year, thinks that by so doing he qualifies at once as an expert on all the problems that have to do with wild life.
The tug Director, owned by William Gaynor of Philadelphia, was destroyed by fire early today in the Delaware Bay off Elbow Light as it towed a barge with a cargo of coal bound for Milford. Del.

Germany's attempt to conserve rubber has had the benefit of improved trade relations for foreign rubber products. Over 100 products formerly made in Germany which contain rubber are now banned in so far as manufacturing is concerned, according to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce here.

In his budget message last week the President predicted that the upward movement of the national debt will be halted when the debt reaches $35,000,000,000. This is only slightly above the point at which it stands today.

Uncle Dan Allen, observing his ninety-eighth birthday today with a daughter, a grandson and four great-grandchildren at his home at 216 Bayview Avenue, received a congratulatory telegram from Mayor Frank Hague mentioning Jersey City's healthful climate as one of the reason's for Uncle Dan's longevity.
A Cadiz informant states that 3,000 Japanese troops and volunteers are expected to land at Jerez and Cadiz shortly, en route to the Madrid front to serve under General Francisco Franco.

A healthy trend in the natural gas industry in 1937 is indicated by the balance sheets and income statements of natural gas companies and an expanding market for the product seems assured, according to Robert S. Robertson of John Nickerson Co., Inc., in a summary yesterday.
Frederick Benjamin MacKinnon, president of the United States Independent Telephone Association, died suddenly of a stroke today at his home in Kenilworth.

Clarence Eddy, the veteran organist whose name had been associated with Chicago music history for more than half a century, died today in his apartment of heart and kidney complications. His age was 86.

Ernest Eidlitz, formerly for several years a confidential employee of the late William J. Fallon, the lawyer, died Friday afternoon at his residence, 6 East Fifty-second Street, of acute indigestion after a brief illness.

Three committees of the PanAmerican Press Conference were in session all this morning, clearing up projects for presentation at the last plenary session, which is expected to continue almost all day tomorrow.

Although official confirmation Is, lacking and the contract has not been signed by both parties, it is understood on excellent authority that the film rights to "You Can't Take It With You" will go to Columbia Pictures for $200,000said to be a record for such deals since the advent of talking films.

Long Island University's basketball team survived two tests during the week, gaining its twelfth and thirteenth victories of the season and continuing to set the pace for its metropolitan rivals with only a single defeat in fourteen games.

The marriage of Mrs. Natalie Johnson Van Vleck of New York and Ballyshear, Southampton, L. I., daughter of Mrs. Caleb Johnson of this city and Orange Park, Fla., and the late Mr. Johnson of Milwaukee, to William de Wilder Atkinson, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Cleary, also of New York, and of the late Clarence Alfred Atkinson of Atkinson, Va., took place here last night at the home of the bride, 1,107 Fifth Avenue.

BERLIN, Monday, Jan. 11.--The European situation, which had seemed to have eased following the delivery of the German and Italian answers to the Franco-British memoranda regarding the influx of volunteers into Spain, took a decided turn for the worse last night as seen from Berlin.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 10.--Former President Herbert Hoover today joined President Roosevelt in urging ratification of the child labor constitutional amendment. The statement was the first formal one issued here by Mr. Hoover since the Presidential election last November, prior to which he frequently and caustically attacked the administration in speeches on behalf of the Republican nominee, Governor Landon of Kansas.

The discrimination against Negroes in industry and the professions may appear to stem from the attitude of the management, but it may really be the power of organization of the white workers themselves,

An enormous, accumulated deficiency of production was seen today by the Brookings Institution, in its annual report, as a powerful stimulus to further economic recovery and the means of reabsorbing the unemployed, which was set forth as an underlying necessity if standards of living and business are to be improved.

DETROIT, Jan. 10.--Confident of ultimate victory, the General Motors Corporation decided today to "sit tight" in a policy of "watchful waiting" for the next few days at least, to see what results from the breakdown in Governor Murphy's peace negotiations.

Samuel Douglass Flood, 69 years old, -retired consulting engineer, died today in his home in Kenilworth. His son, Samuel D. Flood Jr., is now bound for Barcelona Spain, where he is to serve as United States Vice- Consul.

One person was killed and eight wounded when Turks and Arabs rioted near here in the presence of League of Nations officials investigating reports of Syrian-Turkish clashes around Alexandretta and Antioch.
Great Britain set an example in practical nonintervention tonight by stopping any further flow of British volunteers to Spain and inviting other countries to follow suit immediately.
Best known of all the Tammany district organizations is the Anawanda Club of the Twelfth Assembly District. Its seventieth annual grand reception the other night

It is comforting to know that there are still three members of Congress who had the fortune to be born in a log cabin. It is, or was once, the ideal start for a politician. Fifty-one members, a little less than a tenth, were born on a farm.

ReSounds and repayments of internal revenue receipts for the 1936 fiscal year, ended on June 30, last, amounted to $38,701,820, including Interest of $7,367,546, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced in his annual report today.

Contending that it represents the "most solvent country in the world" the Soviet government announced today a balanced budget for 1936 and reiterated that it had not changed its foreign policy of complete independence of foreign credits.

Services "to remember those who during their lifetime advanced the honor of the university," and particularly to honor professors and students who died in 1936, were held yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 80 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week and 3 points below the recent high level.

John Weldon Clarke, secretary of the Fire Companies of the America Fire Insurance and Indemnity Group, died at his home in Atlanta on Thursday, friends here learned yesterday. Mr. Clarke was 53 years old. His widow and two brothers survive.

Mrs. Beulah Wilds Plowman, widow of Garrett Hynson Plowman, a Philadelphia shoe manufacturer, died today at her home in Ridley Park, after a short illness. Prominent in the civic and social life of Ridley Park, she was the daughter of James Francis Wilds and Lydia Ellen Wilds of Dover,

Chicago's Black Hawks, scoring one goal with two opposing players in the penalty box and cashing in on their opponents' over-anxiousness for a second, trimmed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, in a fast National Hockey League game tonight.

The Public National Bank and Trust Company will open a new office today at Spring and Varick Streets. Fenner Beane will open a branch office in Fort Wayne, Ind., under the management of W. D. Criswell.
An eighteenth century church in this Valencian town has been converted into a thriving bar and cafe.

While the security markets have lost some of the exuberance and activity with which they closed 1936, they have entered 1937 with quiet optimism and faith that the events of the new year will justify fully the current level of prices.

Foreseeing the possibilities of a "new NRA" to regulate the relations between capital and labor, a plan was put forward yesterday for the formation of a Federal agency to guard the interests of consumers. Drafting of a bill for a Federal consumer agency will be discussed at Town Hall today at a luncheon called by Miss Andree Emery, chairman of the Consumers Section of the New York City League of Women Voters.

Governor Lehman will confer tomorrow evening with a committee representing Teachers Union, Local No. 5, of New York City, regarding full salary restoration, Charles Poletti, the Governor's counsel, said tonight.

Rain or no rain, a capacity audience assembled yesterday afternoon at the Majestic Theatre to welcome Uday Shan-Kar and his company of Hindu dancers and musicians after an absence of -three years. That its enthusiasm was in no wise diminished by a renewal of old acquaintance was evidenced by the fact that at the end of an unusually long-program there were persistent demands for repetitions.

Supplementing an appeal by antiNazis to the Madison Square Garden Corporation to boycott Max Schmeling as a contender against James J. Braddock, heavyweight champion, a protest will be pressed likewise before the New York State Athletic Commission, which has license authority over the proposed prize fight.

Reasonableness is needed in the approach to men with the offer of religion, the Rev. Avides Demerjian, pastor of St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 126th Street, said in his sermon there yesterday.

A crowded, exciting week for power boat people will get under way when the thirty-second annual National Motor Boat Show reopens this morning at 10:30 o'clock in the Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue after a Sabbath of rest.

Although not subpoenaed, William A. Wilding, Town Clerk of Harrison, said today he would appear before Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme- tomorrow. and defend Harrison's nocturnal marriages whether litigants in a pending annulment suit like it or not.

Forecasts of the outlook for German industry in 1937 concentrate on the supply of materials, labor and capital as determining factors. If the Statedirected boom in production continues there will be shortages of steel, iron, cement and non-ferrous metals, and a more stringent rationing will be inevitable.

Reservoir Av., 2,755 (12-3249); Claire Urstadt to Franshaia Realty Corp., 29 Audubon Av.; installments, 5 per cent, $21,895. Crotona Park E., 1,700 (11-2940); Kleban Leaders Sons, Inc., to Empire City Savings Bank; extends mortgages to Dec. 31, 1939, at 5 1/2 per cent; $334,000.
Dr. Frank C. Bunn, surgeon and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home here following an illness of nine weeks. He was in his sixtyninth year.

The Penn A. C., defending titleholder, maintained its position at the top of the Eastern Athletic Club League last week by nosing out a strong University of Stamford Club quintet at the latter's court for its fourth victory in as many starts in the tournament race.
St. Thomas College of Scranton, Pa., defeated St. Bonaventure's basketball team today, 33 to 30.

Mild weather has fooled even the chickens, and as a result, egg prices have declined from three to five cents in Western New York wholesale markets since Jan. 1 to the lowest prices since last July. Hens have been laying more eggs than usual, farmers report, and with roads open throughout the Winter, farmers have found it comparatively easy to rach the markets.
Prices for hogs moved erratically here last week. They reached $10.75 a hundredweight on Friday, or 5 cents under the Winter's peak, while the day's average was $10.50.
Two Genevans were killed today and three others hurt when a car in which they were riding and a bus were in head-on collision on the Geneva Road, two miles west of here.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota declared yesterday that this nation's only hope of a true neutrality lay in arousing public opinion in favor of a constitutional amendment that would enable and compel the government officials to withstand pressure of interested banking and munitions groups. He spoke at the morning meeting of the Community Church in Town Hall.

A gift of $90,000 to the Semi-Centennial Fund of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America from Mrs. Felix M. Warburg was announced yesterday by the institution on the ninetieth anniversary of the birth of her father, the late Jacob H. Schiff.

It is man's duty in the present world situation not to speculate about the imminence of war but to pray and hope for peace, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison. Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

Funeral services for Frederic Kernochan, presiding justice of the Court of Special Sessions of New York City, will be held at 11 A. M., Tuesday, at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, Tuxedo Park. Burial will be in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

Scoring a decisive 5-2 victory over the Salle d'Armes Vince representatives, who captured the title last year, the formidable team of the New York Athletic Club yesterday won the national junior saber championship at the Fencers Club.

The Englewood Field Club and the Montclair Athletic Club maintained their succession of victories in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association today, Englewood defeating the Racquets Club of Short Hills here, 5--22, and Montclair winning over the Essex Club of Newark at Montclair, 6-1.

Frank D. Carr, formerly associated with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and long active in civic affairs in the Bedford section, died Friday at his home, 112 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 70.

With his skull fractured, apparently with an axe that lay near by, Ignasio Valentino, 86 years old, was found dead this evening in the tiny kitchen of his home a half mile west of the Cedarbrook railroad station, about eighteen miles southeast of Camden.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "What I Saw in the Dictator Countries," John Brown.
Offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,384,000 of 4 1/4 per cent serial funding and general refunding bonds of the township of Woodbridge, N. J., by a syndicate headed by J. S. Rippel Co.

Death has so depleted the ranks of the "Boys in Gray" that fewer than 3,800 fo these veterans are left, according to a national census of Confederate veterans whose reults were made public today by W. Scott Hancock, commander-in-chief of Sons of Confederate Veterans.

Reduction of the number of Class B pictures, even if it means a curtailment in all production, has been recommended to Paramount executives by the company's theatre operating partners who have been visiting the studios in connection with the Adolph Zukor silver jubilee.

Rain kept the field down to twenty gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. G. E. Churchill, a Class A gunner, took the High-Over-All Cup with a card of 94 out of a possible 100 targets. In the handicap competition the Class A prize went to F. A. Scola who had a total of 95. The Class B trophy was won by W. S. Pate with a full card.

Some unusually sensible and thoughtful remarks about the motion picture industry were made the other day by HOWARD S. CULLMAN, who, in addition to his post as vice chairman of the Port Authority, is director-receiver for the Roxy Theatre.
Because of greater activity in trade, the Bank of England's circulation, which usually contracts sharply after the turn of the year, is falling comparatively slowly.

With an eastbound express train of the Long Island Railroad bearing down on his stalled kerosene tank truck at the Elizabeth Street crossing in this village, Benjamin Goerke, 49 years old, crippled in both feet by inverted toes, scrambled out of the machine and ran to safety at 11 o'clock this morning.

It is announced here officially that a "positive result" has been achieved in the Polish-Danzig negotiations for a settlement of the League of NationsDanzig dispute. Arthur Greiser, President of the Danzig Senate, as representative of the Free City Government, and Counselor Lalicki of the Polish Foreign Office, signed an agreement tonight, which will be published at the League Council session on Jan. 18.

The birth rate and maternal mortality in the State were lower in November than in any month in the history of the State Department of Health, according to Dr. J. V. DePorte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10.--Low temperatures that threatened Southern California's $100,000,000 citrus crop for the third successive night kept anxious growers busy firing orchard heaters tonight.

A prehistoric human skull found in East Africa provides a new relative for man's family tree. Dr. L. S. B. Leakey, British anthropologist, contends this African was different from any man heretofore known.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.1, which compares with 88.8 the week before, 87.9 two weeks before, 87.3 three weeks before and 86.6 four weeks before.

An audience of 400 heard the Budapest University Chorus, under the direction of Dr. Victor Vazzy, leader of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra, in its first concert to be given in America at the Greenwich Country Club tonight.

More interest is being taken in oats by the speculative and consumptive trade. Commission-house and processor buying, too, has increased. The strength and advance in corn was reflected here last week to a considerable extend in the action of oat prices.

Woman's present equality with man politically and as a wageearner is ,directly contrary to the Word of God, the Rev. Mr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning on "God's Ideal Woman."

For the fifth consecutive week the number of cases on direct unemployment relief in Pennsylvania increased during the seven-day period ended on Jan. 2, it was announced today by Karl de Schweinitz, executive director of the State Emergency Relief Board. Fewer persons left the rolls that week than in any week in more than two years.

American art has encompassed a new and broader horizon with the discovery of a first-rate Alaskan Eskimo artist, according to Rockwell Kent. There arrived in New York yesterday some examples of the work by his "find," whom Mr. Kent, a veteran of many years practice and extensive journeys into Greenland, Labrador and Alaska,

The Donnacona Paper Company announced today the Issue of $750,000 in 5 1/2 per cent tenyear unsecured notes to defray the cost of a $500,000 plant and equipment improvement program and provide additional working capital.
The rise of French prices was accentuated at the end of December, and on Jan. ? the general wholesale price index stood at 500, against 496 on Dec. 26.

The police of the Coney Island precinct are accustomed to dealing with boys and girls. On a hot midsummer Sunday the back room of their station house is usually jammed with lost children, and the bluecoats stationed there have developed to a high degree the art of soothing forlorn, frightened youngsters.

The constant threats of war and widespread unrest in the world today were deplored by the Rev. Edwin Favier, a Capuchin, of London, England, who preached at the 12:20 P. M. mass yesterday at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Shrine Church, 110 East Twelfth Street. The service was conducted by the Rev. C. J. Smith.
The annual dance of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents of New York was held Saturday night in the Hotel Lombardy, Fifty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.
A "freshly" abandoned shack was reported discovered late today in a lonely cove on Squaxin Island, in Southern Puget Sound, by police hunting Charles Mattson's kidnapper.

Charles H. Baldwin, vice president and treasurer of Conrow Brothers, paper dealers in Manhattan, with whom he had been associated for fifty-two years, died on Saturday at his home, 530 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn.

Whether next Spring's twenty-fifth annual reunion of the Harvard class of '12 will develop into a battle for sartorial supremacy between New York and Boston factions remained a question today following a meeting here of the reunion committee.

The Institute for Trade Research declares that there will, be no labor shortage in Germany to hamper expansion. On the contrary, it estimates that the number of employed persons will increase by 2,000,000 in the next two years.

The Federal Trade Commission has ordered Giacomo LaGuardia, 537 Broadway, trading as the Herba Medicinal Laboratory, to discontinue unfair representations in the sale of preparations said to be derived from herbs and to have medicinal value.

With Marlene Dietrich's romantic expedition to the Garden of Allah behind it, Technicolor dashed off to the- more rugged timberlands of Longview (Wash.) where, amid thetall trees and one of James Oliver Curwood's tall stories, it filmed "God's Country-and the Woman."

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Dec. 28 totaled 288,517,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the week before, this is an increase of 333,000 barrels, comprising a rise of 395,000 barrels in domestic crude,

Ray Grill, secretary-manager of the Beaumont Chamber of Commerce, died last night in his home here. His age was 62. Mr. Grill also was known for his pioneering in fingerprinting. He brought the fingerprinting identification system before an international meeting of police chiefs in Hot Springs, Ark., in 1904.
The general public let loose a figurative gasp when the Income Tax Division of the United States Government revealed salaries drawn by the leading stars and producers in the motion picture industry.

158th St. (10-2655), s. w. cor. Union Av., 113x36; Randolph Trading Corp. to Bunbuck Realty Corp., 52 Vanderbilt Av. Intervale Av. (11-2974), s. e. s. at w. s. Fox St., 97x95; Gruenstein Mayer Corp. to Benjamin M. Gruenstein, 16 W. 77th St. Reservoir Av. (12-3249), n. w. cor. 195th St., 150x150; Fanshaw Realty Corp. to Claire Urstadt, 13 W. 195th St.; mtg., $178,105.

Pettingell Fenton, Inc., advertising agency, in International Building, Rockefeller Center. La France Trimming Co., bathrobe trimmings, in 127 W. 24th St.; Eden Textiles, Inc., cotton piece goods, store in 15 W. 26th St.; Abo Popkin, clothing, in 3 W. 18th St.; Bastine Co., Inc., broker.
Miss Constance R. Beale, a great-granddaughter of Commodore Thomas Truxton, naval hero, died here yesterday at her home after a short illness. She was 85 years old.

Services for James O. Spearing, automobile editor and former motion-picture critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be held at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, tomorrow at 1 P. M.

Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., winner of the tournament in 1933 and again a year ago, and William C. Wright of Philadelphia earned the right to meet in the final of the sixteenth annual Gold Racquet court tennis competition when each came through his semi-final engagement at the Tuxedo Club today.
Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion, was again a winner in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, the second round of which was contested yesterday.

Radio policemen were praised yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott for their help in the campaign against false fire alarms. Mr. McElligott reported a total of 8,560 malicious false alarms in 1936, a reduction of 2,614 from the previous year.

Police reported tonight they had to kill a dog guarding the body of Mrs. Margaret Bruce McLain Hughes, 72-year-old recluse, whose one-room cabin contained newspaper clippings and legal papers indicating that she was a participant in or the wife of a participant in the Klondike gold rush.

In a brief, colorful ceremony immediately preceding solemn high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, Cardinal Hayes invested the Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, as a domestic prelate.

Another indication of the present unfriendly trend toward Germany in official quarters here was furnished in the Weltblatt today in an article dealing with the prospects of AustroGerman commercial negotiations which again have been suspended.

Displaying the same top form as in previous matches of the tourney, David McMullun and Muffin Large of Philadelphia triumphed in the final of the fifth annual invitation squash racquet tournament of the Field Club and Greenwich Country Club on the latter club's court today.
A $100,000,000 program of State loans to municipal housing authorities for slum clearance was urged today by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, New York Republican.

A reorganization of the WPA Federal Music Project's symphonic units is now in progress, Lee Pattison, New York director, announced yesterday. The reorganization, he said, will be coincident with the opening of the project's new Theatre of Music at 254 West Fiftyfourth Street on Jan. 24.

Henry Jansen, retail pharmacist, who was chairman of the fair trade committee of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association, died this morning in the Mount Vernon Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 51.

The Flatbush Wanderers and Belfast United-played to a 3-3 tie in a New York State Cup match at St. Mary's Park in the Bronx yesterday. Belfast United was off to an early 2-0 lead, the Wanderers starting with a short-handed team.
Tommy, the alley cat who gained fame last year by reaching the age of 21-and received a birthday party from business men for his feat-is to have another, on his twenty-second birthday anniversary.

56th St., 10 E., 20x100.5, except strip two inches wide on west side; also 56th St. 12 E., 22.6x100.5; Column Holding Corp. to Edna W. Feltman, 1,163 E. 27th St. Brooklyn; purchase money prior mtg. $72,000 due as per bond, 6 per cent; 25,000.

Emery C. Read, oldest active surveyor and civil engineer in Western Pennsylvania, died today at the age of 82. A resident here since 1892, he conducted preliminary surveys for the Jamestown, Franklin Clearfield Railroad,

Government purchases under the terms of the Public Contracts Act from Jan. 5 to Jan. 7, inclusive, amounted to $5,260,911, the Department of Labor announced yesterday. Nine agencies awarded seventy-nine contracts, of which twenty-four valued at $1,679,287 were made to concerns in New York State.

The enduring beauty and poetry of the music of Brahms was demonstrated impressively at the concert given by the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, when the Jacques Gordon String Quartet; Karl-Ulrich Schnabel, pianist;

John Joseph Donovan, civil engineer and lumberman, one of the industrial leaders on the Pacific Coast, died yesterday at his home in Bellingham, Wash., according to an announcement made here last night by his son-in-law, Leslie Craven of Chicago.
Because of the steady rise of prices, French foreign trade has been unable to take advantage of the devaluation of the franc.

Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., won the doubles final of the fifth annual Miami Biltmore tennis tournament today with a 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta and Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles.
MICHAEL'S 19 40-Yard Free Style-Won by Martin Hayden, Loughlin; Frank Zegers, Loughlin, second; Carmine Gaiti, St. -Michael's, third. Time--:20.8.

Science, secularism and materialism are "hell-bent," and "can but reap the fruition of war," the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, rector of St. George's Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street near Third Avenue, said there in his sermon yesterday morning.
A Bureau of the Mint report indicated today that the Treasury will begin moving within a week or so about $4,000,000,000 of its vast gold hoard to the new bombproof vault at Fort Knox, Ky.

Breaking par by seven strokes, Horton Smith of Chicago took full command of the $8,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today. Cheered by a gallery of several thousand, he posted a 64 on the par-71 Griffith Park course for a

It is now possible to assure art lovers throughout the world that literally all the masterpieces in Madrid and many other treasures in surrounding villages have been collected and saved by government authorities.

The last home mortgages in the State of New York held by the RFC have been sold to Morris Tremaine, New York State Controller, as trustee for various sinking and trust funds of the State, Chairman Jones announced today.
Occupants of Resettlement Administration communities have paid 92.5 per cent of all money due the administration from them up to Dec. 31, 1936, the RA announced today.

The present outbreak of influenza, now in its fourth week, is more widespread than those of 1933 and 1926, but is somewhat less severe than those of 1929, 1928 and 1922, according to comparative statistics in a statement issued by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, yesterday. None of the recent outbreaks approached the severity of the world-wide epidemic that prevailed from 1918 to 1921.

Following the pattern of most Second Avenue productions, "Let's Get Married," the new operetta by William Siegel and Sholom Secunda at the Public Theatre, depends for its effect more on the personalities of its performers than on its content. It is, therefore, a pretty cheerful thing.
Mrs. Rubye Louise Nix Zioncheck, 21, widow of Representative Marion A. Zioncheck, became a freshman today at the University of Washington.

Plans for a campaign against communism in the United States and Canada, including more than 350 special meetings in the two countries, were approved yesterday afternoonn by the supreme board of directors of the Knights of Columbus at its quarterly meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Academy of Natural Sciences announced today that the 175-foot schooner Cressida will sail on a marine expedition Jan. 14, under George Vanderbilt of New York.
C. C. Slapnicka, assistant to Alva Bradley, president of the Cleveland Indians, annuonced today that Bob Feller, sensational schoolboy pitcher from Iowa, had signed a Cleveland contract.

Harrison Smith, who recently resigned from his editorial position at Random House, has joined the staff of Doubleday, Doran. In his new post he will devote himself primarily to American literature and the promotion of American literary talent.
The present world-wide rise in commodity prices, although arousing much comment, is, causing no serious uneasiness here.

Dr. Maude Royden, English preacher and peace advocate, who arrived in the United States recently to make a speaking tour in the interest of the Emergency Peace Campaign, told an audience of nearly 1,000 Mount Vernon residents tonight that there was no justification for war, not even dishonor, because "the supreme dishonor is war."

A city-wide movement for public cooperation in crime prevention will be started at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore next Saturday, sponsored by forty-five civic, educational and welfare organizations, it was announced yesterday by Howard W. Nudd, director of the Public Education Association, one of the sponsoring group.

In view of the marked expansion in industrial production, the rise in the volume of imports has not been unduly large, while so far as there has been a movement from imports of manufactured goods to raw materials, the development has been favorable rather than unfavorable.
Embattled Republican Assemblymen began returning to Capitol Hill tonight, seemingly no nearer a solution to their problem of electing a Speaker for the lower house of the Legislature.

In resolutions adopted unanimously at its first annual convention at the Labor Lyceum today, Labor's NonPartisan League of New Jersey scored the labor policies of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and requested the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee of the United States Senate to come to Hudson County to investigate conditions there.

Ellsworth Vines, who entered St. Luke's Hospital today suffering from influenza and tonsillitis, definitely will not be able to appear at Detroit Tuesday night on the professional tennis tour in which heis engaging with Fred Perry, British star.
A total of 2,381 new accounts was opened by the four offices of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn in December, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles Froeb, president.
Fifteen skiers were killed and three others were feared dead today in two mountain snowslides in Switzerland.
Colonel Reuben Alexander Mitchell, senior vice president of the Alabama Power Company, died tonight at his home here. His age was 84.

It will come as a surprise to many who read yesterday of the death of Justice KERNOCHAN to know that as a lad he risked his life to save that of a nurse who fell from a boat and was in peril of drowning.
R. Alvin Beisel, Mayor of Hazleton, died of a heart ailment today in the Hazleton State Hospital at the age of 64.

The thirty-six steeplechase horses recently imported from France by the subscription committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association to stimulate interest in cross-country racing found new owners yesterday when they were allotted to the subscribers to the $90,000 purchase fund following a luncheon at Belmont Park.
Disruption of production scneaules in the automobile industry by strikes has had less adverse effect than expected upon the output of steel mills, according to the magazine Steel.

The 18,805 incorporations in 1936 numbered 181 more than in 1935, the division of corporations of the Department of State announced today. Of last year's number, 16,423 were credited to the five counties of New York City and 2,382 were distributed among the other counties, Westchester leading with 510, Erie County second with 316 and Nassau third with 287.

A special service in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody was held yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street. Hymns sung by the congregation as well as the anthems by the choir were selections made famous in the Moody and Sankey services.

Mrs. Francis T. Christy will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 55 Grace Court, Brooklyn, for women working in behalf of the 1937 Appeal of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association in the campaign to raise $150,000 to carry out the organization's minimum nursing Program for this year.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Vroman Crary gave a reception and buffet supper last night at their home, 30 Sutton Place, to celebrate the thirty-fifth anniversary of their marriage.

The trend of the franc in the spot market was more favorable this week. United States dollars declined slightly and sterling was maintained at 105.15 francs to the pound, without official control. In the forward market, discounts on sterling and the dollar declined.

Nicholas Tucci, 46-year-old furniture mover, yesterday confessed seting fire to a pile of newspapers in the cellar of 761 East 165th Street, the Bronx, where he lived on the second floor. He blamed a radio broadcast put on by the Fire Department over Station WHN Saturday night for the impulse that led him to arson.

Jewish leaders, closing the twenty-first annual convention of the New York State Federation of Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Associations, urged tonight that activities of Jewish recreational and educational centers be more closely integrated with those of the temple and synagogue.
COHEN--FRANK--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Frank of Brooklyn announce the marriage of their daughter. Isabelle, to Albert Cohen, on Jan. 10, 1937.
Terror-stricken inhabitants of Portbou, Spain,.took refuge in the International Railway tunnel during the night, while Fascist warships cruised off the coast.
Eugene N. Strom, retired Chicago manufacturer and President of the Golden Beach Town Council, died at his home here today at the age of 53.

The Federal Trade Commission-has ordered the Retail Furniture Dealers Association of St. Louis, its officers and thirty-six merchant members, all of St. Louis, Mo., and East St. Louis, Ill., to cease unfair trade practices in the interstate sale of furniture and allied products.
Dr. and Mrs. Charles Coffing Beach of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Llewellyn Powell, to George Cleveland Capen of West Hartford.

Premier Benito Mussolini's eldest son, Vittorio, will be married in Rome Feb. 6 to a young Milanese girl, Miss Orsola Buvoli, to whom he was secretly engaged shortly before his departure for the East African campaign.

A "jungle" colony consisting of fifty to seventy-five shacks housing nearly 200 otherwise homeless men along the East River in the Hunts Point section or the Bronx are to be torn down beginning today by WPA workers, it was revealed last night when twenty-two men, most of them residents of the

John J. Halleran, Queens Commissioner of Public Works, revealed yesterday that he had written to Corporation Counsel Paul Windels asking an explanation of the city's method of condemning land for the World's Fair.

The curtain was rung down on the Chiang Kai-shek kidnapping episode when his captor, CHANG HSUEH-LIANG, was pardoned by the Chinese Council of State. But the end and meaning of that political drama are not yet-a week later-discernible.
A feature in grain futures purchases on the Chicago Board of Trade last week was a sharp decrease in wheat from the previous week, although the volume largely exceeded that of a year ago.
With ten dinghies braving the cold wind in four races, Leonard Romagna and Jack Prokop were the winning skippers in the weekly frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay today.

The tendency of the Stock Exchange was much better this week. The turnover of securities was larger and prices were higher. For the first time in a long while the rise was general in French as well as foreign securities, and government bonds also were favored.

Plans for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia are being developed by a group of the Mayor's friends, it became known yesterday. While the Mayor has refrained from publicly indicating whether or not he will run, the identity of the group working toward a 1937 Fusion movement is taken as an indication that he will be a candidate.

Brother Andre's body rested again in his imposing oratory of St. Joseph tonight after a funeral service in downtown Montreal. Thousands attended the requiem mass for the friar yesterday, packing St. James Cathedral for their tribute to the "Miracle Man of Montreal," who died Wednesday at the age of 91.

Soy beans sold at new high prices here last week, with shippers and speculators buying. Prices had a good range and the May position closed at $1.80 3/4 a bushel, a net advance of 5 1/2 cents for the week.

With a settlement apparently nearing on the seventy-third day of the maritime strike on the Pacific Coast, there was no change yesterday in the situation here. Shipping over the week-end continued to move to the satisfaction of the operators.

Louis Gorelick, 32 years old, of 2,311 Avenue Y, Brooklyn, accused on Friday by Joseph Rose, itinerant gem merchant, of having stolen a fortune in diamonds, was paroled in Felony Court yesterday at the request of William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney.
When the "Ice Follies of 1937" goes on at 8:30 o'clock at Madison Square Garden tonight, there will be mixed feelings in the cast of thirty-six that will skate in the opening ensemble number.

Although they managed at one time to overcome a two-goal deficit and go into a tie, the New York Rangers were beaten by the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night. The Canadian contingent, coming through with a three-goal surge in the final period,

THE horses will start running at H?a;eah Wednesday afternoon. Beautiful spot. An avenue of royal palms leading from the main gate to the clubhouse. Flaming hibiscus and poinsettia in full bloom. Oleanders in profusion. Purple drapes of bougainvillea hanging from the walls and running along the fences.

If manufacturers adhere rigidly to the principle of price maintenance, a number of large retailers may completely eliminate national brands from their shelves, according to Martin Ullman, package designer.
Five national outdoor skating records were bettered in the wind-up of the fifth annual Ten Thousand Lake championship tournament today.

Almost $5,000 has been received from the sale of subscription tickets to the Actors Fund benefit show to be held next Sunday night at the New Amsterdam Theatre, it was said yesterday by Daniel Frohman, who has announced that this will be the last benefit staged under his personal direction.
The Hamburg-American liner Reliance sailed at noon yesterday on her second annual voyage round the world with 218 passengers.

A medical relief expedition with sufficient surgical, medical and wardroom equipment to set up a fifty-bed hospital in Madrid will sail Saturday aboard the French Line steamer Paris, according to an announcement yesterday by Saul Carson, executive director of the medical bureau of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy.
The election of officers and naming - of chairmen of committeescomprised for the most part thee business of the organization meeting of the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. at the Columbia Club yesterday.
Investment buying of houses in Brooklyn formed the bulk of real activity in the city reported over the week-end.

Selection of Frank M. Starr of the General Electric Company, Schenectady, N. Y., as this country's "outstanding young electrical engineer" for 1936 in a competition sponsored by Eta Kappa Nu, honorary electrical engineering society, was announced yesterday by the organization.

Francois de Tessan, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, speaking for the government at a Radical Socialist congress in Belfort, today issued the new warning of French determination to act against any invasion of Moroccan territory.

When we make God our senior partner in the business of life we show that we have rightly understood the meaning of the Christian religion, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said in his sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, Twentyninth Street east of Fifth Avenue.

German regimentation of youth was condemned and the need for education based on a "definite philosophy" was emphasized by the Rev. Dr. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, in an address yesterday to the members of the Fordham Preparatory School Alumni Society at their semi-annual communion breakfast. The breakfast was served in Bealey Hall on the Rose Hill campus.

It was learned tonight from a source close to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, that notice would be given tomorrow that the 1937 State Senate will be prevented from organizing Tuesday noon unless the Republicans give their word no attempt will be made to fill the Cape May County seat until the courts have acted.
THINK FOR YOURSELF, by Robert P. Crawford. (Whittlesey House, $2.50.) On creative thinking. SQUASH RACQUETS, by John Skillman. (Whittlesey House, $2.50.) Advice on the technique of the game.

Although it was a more routine performance than officiating at a childbirth, a recent achievement of a Greenburgh policeman, the part two local policemen played in resuscitating the victim of a heart attack added luster to the reputation of Westchester County police as practitioners of first-aid medicine.

Valencia celebrated the closing of New Year festivities today with a huge anti-Fascist parade. Dozens of floats, designed principally for the edification of children, purported to portray the roles the various European nations are playing in the Spanish civil war.

Terming idleness "the devil's work," the Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, urged the members of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, to give their lives a meaning by purposeful activity and kindliness.
During the past two Summers I have conducted a survey of the nutrition, health and dental conditions in the most primitive and populous Eskimo district left on the American Continent.

J. Edgar Hoover's school to teach policemen how to be better policemen, officially known as the Federal Bureau of Investigation and National Police Academy, will resume its sessions tomorrow with representatives of municipal, county and State law enforcement organizations in attendance. The classes will continue for twelve weeks.
Grain traders the world over last week experienced the repercussions of political, market and crop news, a situation which created extreme nervousness and resultant wide fluctuations.

ADAMS-Sunday, Jan. 10, Philip B., beloved husband of Elsle H. Adams, at 95 Christopher St. Notice of services later. ADLER-Rose Lissauer, beloved wife of Leon Nathaniel Adler and mother of Stanley Adler, on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 9. Notice of funeral services later.
Removal of marriage' from ecclesiastical control was advocated by the Rev. Dr. Charles Francis Potter yesterday before the First Humanist Society of New York, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Orders on the books of German shipbuilding companies amount to 900,000 tons. As their capacity is only 650,000 tons, fulfillment of orders is being deplayed. The steel syndicates declare
Crown Princess Juliana and her husband, Prince Bernhard, traveling under the name of Count and Countess Sternberg, arrived at this Polish Winter resort yesterday to spend half of their honeymoon.

The Insurgents' present left-flank drive is viewed here as a supreme effort to storm the capital, and full confidence that Generalissimo Francisco Franco will succeed leads every one to refer to the offensive as the beginning of the end of the civil war.

Viscount Feilding, eldest son and heir of the ninth Earl of Denbigh, died today. He was 51 years old. The Viscount was a son of the Earl of Denbigh and his first wife, who was the Hon, Cecilia Mary Clifford, daughter of the eighth Baron Clifford of Chudleigh. She died in 1919. Of their three sons two were killed in the World War. Seven daughters survive.

" When embittered men say that religion is a spent force and that the church no longer influences the life and thought of men in America we know they are talking nonsense and the facts are against them," the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday.
Changing of May contracts to July was a feature of speculative operations in corn here last week, with a general evening up.

Sir Josiah stamp, economist and a director of the Bank of England, spoke optimistically yesterday of the economic outlook for 1937 in a radio talk from London heard here on the Columbia Broadcasting System's station.

The National Council of Wool Selling Brokers reports that 1,425,701 bales were sold in the semester ended on Dec. 31, at an average price for greasy wool of 15.12d a pound, compared with 13.40d in the corresponding semester in 1935.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it endorsed, in principle, the proposed ordinances aimed at curbing traffic in stolen coal and ending short-weight deliveries by unscrupulous dealers.
The taxes in the port of Cherbourg for passengers landing from or embarking for the United States are more than doubled by a decree published by the official Journal.

The Baltimore Ohio, the Chesapeake Ohio, the Norfolk Western and the Western Maryland had th highest percentages of return, compared with total revenues, from the emergency freight surcharges that expired on Dec. 31, according to a compilation by Weingarten Co. The review notes that,

" Strange is the manner in which mankind measures the value of religion," the Rev. Dr. William H. Kephart declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Congregational Church of North New York, 411 East 143d Street, the Bronx.
The Norwegian steamer Utsire, bound for Halifax and New York, sent out a distress call tonight off the Newfoundland coast.
Governor La Follette of Wisconsin visited the White House today and discussed with President Roosevelt the relief problems of his State, it is understood.
Engagement of $2,020,000 of gold in Switzerland for shipment here
The newly constructed cruiser Vincennes will leave the Fore River Shipyard tomorrow morning for a ten-day trial run off Rockland, Me.
According to the radio reports received yesterday from the navigators of incoming liners from Europe, the North Atlantic is again stormy after the lull of the past week.

BERLIN, Jan. 9.--This week's stock market opened on a dull and irregular note, with lower prices predominating. The volume of foreign buying declined, and uncertainty as to the effect of the new depreciation-profit tax on dividends induced selling of steel trust and other corporations having foreign debts.
The Maritime Commission notified agents of the four government-owned and operated merchant lines today to prepare for private ownership or operation by June 29, 1937.

Miss Carola de Peyster Kip, daughter of Mrs. Garrett B. Kip of this city and Rhinebeck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Kip, has completed plans for her marriage to Benjamin R. Kittredge Jr., 'son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge of Carmel, N. Y., and Dean Hall Plantation in South Carolina.
The recent price reaction in wheat was merely a normal incident in a market which had experienced a pronounced buoyancy over a considerable period.

An effort to organize holders of United Kingdom 5 1/2 per cent dollar ponds, with a view to obtaining payment in gold equivalent when the obligations mature on Feb. 1, has been undertaken by Francis G. Allen, an investment counselor.

A dual celebration of the ninth anniversary of the Church Army movement in America and the ninetieth birthday of Wilson Carlile, founder of the Church Army in England fifty-five years ago, was held yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest,

Women headed by Mrs. Sherman Post Haight will meet this morning at Mrs. Haight's home, 64 East Fifty-fourth Street, to complete plans for the annual card party for the benefit of Roosevelt House, which will be held on Jan. 26 at the Plaza.

With the raising of an American flag, with a bishop's blessing and with high hopes in the hearts of thousands of laborers who are its new owners, the Central Lafayette, Puerto Rico's first cooperative sugar enterprise and probably the only sugar cooperative in the Americas, was inaugurated today when the first trainload of sugar cane was started through the crushers.

Lawrence W. Wallace, director of the equipment research division of the planning and research department of the Association of American Railroads, will speak on the air-conditioning of passenger cars before the New York Railroad Club on Friday night in the Engineering

The Green Bay Packers gave a convincing demonstration today of why they rule the national professional football ranks with a crushing 42-7 victory over the Salinas Iceberg Packers, Pacific Coast champions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt's plea for a more enlightened view of the Constitution is sound. Such a policy acts more for the preservation of constitutional principles than would a process of continual amendment to meet changing needs. Were the more violent opponents of the present administration to realize where strict interpretation leads, they would be among the first to advocate as few amendments as possible.

A card party for the benefit of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children in Claverack, N. Y., will be held the afternoon of Jan. 25 in the Embassy Room and Garden of the Ambassador.

The Rev. Dr. William G. Ballantine, author, who was professor of Bible at International Y. M. C. A. College here, 1897-1920, died tonight after an illness of a week. He was born in Washington, D. C., eighty-eight years ago.

George Washington died of septic sore throat, a streptococcus infection, according to a case history- of his last illness compiled by Dr. Creighton Barker, a member of the clinical staff of the Yale University School of Medicine. The review of the case, presented in the form of a present-day record, appears in the current issue of The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine.

Fearing that the experiences of the depression may imbue the city's children with a belief that they can safely set aside personal initiative and industry and rely on public relief for their future happiness, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, called on teachers yesterday to make the schools a force for social rehabilitation by stressing the principles of selfreliance in the classroom.

General August Nogues, the French High Commissioner at Rabat, French Morocco, will send a "warning" tomorrow to the Spanish High Commissioner at Tetuan, Spanish Morocco, through the French Consul General at that town.

Despite the inclement weather, the Scots-Americans of the American Soccer League and the Patapsco Rangers of Baltimore staged their match in the first round of the National Challenge Cup competition at Clark's Field today.
The Rev. W. Glenn Roberts, Quaker preacher of Brooklyn, challenged yesterday the evangelical churches actually to believe in Jesus and lead the world from war.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Cone of West Hartford have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cone's daughter, Miss Harriet Louise Goodrich, to Arthur W. Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Gregory, also of this place.
Lude Wareing played the role of hero yesterday afternoon and sent 14,239 fans home from Madison Square Garden pretty well pleased with their New York Rovers.
" The Supreme Court must be made to follow the election returns," Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, declared yesterday in an address from station WOR.

In a semi-annual report embodying the twelve-point program of investment-trust procedure recommended last year to the Securities and Exchange Commission by Robert Lehman, president of the Lehman Corporation, it announced yesterday that profits for the six months ended on Dec. 31, last, were $5,474,271, or $7.97 a share on the 686,855 shares outstanding.

In the line-up at police headquarters yesterday was Miss Deborah Lane, 23 years old, a nurse of 299 West Ninety-second Street, who confessed, the police said, that she had forged the name of Andrew Keating, Democratic leader and first deputy county clerk, to a check which she had cashed at a midtown department store.

General Chang Hsueh-liang, under technical detention as a resuit of his coup at Sian Dec. 12, when he abducted Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, played golf at the Nanking Country Club today under the muzzles of eight submachine guns.
Joe Louis of Detroit knocked out Stanley Ketchell of Bloomfield, N. J., in the second round of a scheduled four-round exhibition bout tonight. Louis weighed 2093 pounds, Ketchell 216.

More than 2,500 persons, from ticker boys to international financiers, attended the funeral services for Charles Hayden, senior partner of Hayden, Stone Co., bankers, yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Mr. Hayden, who was 66 years old, died Friday in his apartment at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

A "serious shortage" of properly trained salesmen exists today, and some companies which "cut their wash staffs to the bone during the depression and were slow to replace them as business grew better, are now clamoring for men," Walter A. Lowen, placement specialist, told the meeting yesterday of the Sales Executives Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Walter A. Huxman, a Democrat, became Governor of Kansas today, succeeding Alf M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee in the last election.

SERGEANT John T. Schmitt, from 13th Precinct to 3d Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen, for four days. PATROLMEN-For sixteen days, from 8 A. M., Jan. 16: John J. Sasek, from 17th Precinct to Motor Transport Maintenance Division, assigned to clerical duty.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 6, 1937, shows decreases for the week of $78,000,000 in total loans and investments, $146,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $15,000,000 in time deposits and $22,000,000 in borrowings, and an increase of $121,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Slaughter of most classes fully normal. Demand for fresh pork rather slow; trading in other traefa meats fair to good.

Two meat distributors, appearing as witnesses at the opening of a hearing in which Swift Co. is answering a complaint of unfair trade practices, charged yesterday that the meat packing concern had taken customers away from them.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Doris Carver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Carver of this place, to Charles F. Fearon of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fearon of Oneida, N. Y.

A Wildwood mail carrier, testifying in the Senate election contest hearing today, declared he attempted to deliver sixtyseven letters to voters whose names were obtained from the poll books, but that they were all returned.
Well-timed publicity has done something to relieve the anxiety caused by the recent evidence of German encroachment in the Spanish zone of Morocco.

The Westchester County Park Commission informed the Board of Supervisors today it had gone on record requesting the State to assume the operating and maintenance cost of the regularly used Westchester parkways on the theory that they are "gateways" to New York City and served as arterial highways.

Joseph J. Kelleher, vice president and general manager of the United Fruit Company, was elected president of the International Lifeboat Racing Association at the annual luncheon meeting yesterday at the India House, One Hanover Square. He succeeded Robert L. Hague, general manager of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
Disorderly scenes marked the resumption today of the trial of former army officers accused of having participated in the Leftist revolt of November, 1935.

In its annual report the Brookings Institution returns once more to a point that it has emphasized several times in the past. This is the complete fallacy of the belief that we can restore employment and prosperity by a further reduction in working hours. Yet the leaders of the American Federation of Labor still cling to this belief.

Following an address on peace last night by Sherwood Eddy, author. 1,200 Brooklyn residents voted to authorize the committee which called the meeting to continue its activities through "organizing a permanent Brooklyn council for peace."
An unexplained sit-down strike of 650 employes of three Walker Manufacturing Company plants here ended today without explanation.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, said last night that he would seek reelection to that office next Spring if he is chosen by the nominating committee that will be named in March.

After more than five hours of hand-to-hand fighting with the police, in which at least twentyfour persons were injured by bullets, stones, clubs, knives and teargas bombs, a siege was on this morning at the Fisher Body plant No. 2, where "sit-down" strikers are defying the courts and the State authorities.

Leading by four strokes, Leon Sikes of West Palf Beach won the medal in the qualifying round for the annual Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He turned in a card of 38, 34-72, only three strokes over par for the layout.

Edward P. Mulrooney, the Correction Commissioner, announced today the election of Mrs. Cecelia D. Patten of Saratoga Springs as chairman of the State Probation Commission. Mrs. Patten, the first woman to serve as chairman since the commission was established in 1907, succeeds Edmond J. Butler of New York, who resigned because of health.
A $67,000,000,000 income for the United States in 1937 was estimated today by officials of the Department of Commerce, who based their forecast orr the nation not being involved in a war.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran airship commander and director of the Zeppelin Company, flew to Washington from New York today to confer with government officials on his plans. for operating the Hindenburg between the United States and Germany on a regular schedule next Spring and Summer. With him was F. W. von Meister, representative in this country of the Zeppelin Company.
Harold G. Blaney, restaurant Keeper, does not permit customers to complete sentences which begin: "Has any one ever told you-" "--That I look like President Roosevelt?" Mr. Blaney interrupts.

Sam Franklin, director of Dr. Sherwood Eddy's Delta cooperative farm at Hillhouse, Miss., said today that the colony obtained "an encouraging return both in material and human values" in its first year of operation.

Mrs. Albert B. Kerr gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 1,136 Fifth Avenue, for members of the executive committee serving with her in behalf of the Ski Carnival to be held Jan. 24 at Skytop Lodge in the Poconos for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery.

Plans for conference here today of Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, and John L. Lewis with leaders of the automobile strike were disrupted when the latter, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers.

Expert markmanship by Manhattan's once-beaten basketball forces gave the Jaspers a smashing victory over Niagara, 55 to 42. at the New York Hippodrome last night before a crowd of 2,000, but powerful-Long Island University, slightly less than masterful in the same department of play, had to go into overtime to conquer La Salle, 34 to 30.

The Duke of Windsor seems always to find fresh charm in the neighborhood of Vienna and to become more and more reluctant to leave. Today he took a second skiing lesson at Semmering and at its close he expressed himself as so well satisfied with the district that he probably would do all his skiing here without going to Tyrol at all.

Outstanding women in London, Paris, Prague, Stockholm, Geneva, Toronto, San Francisco, Chicago and New York joined yesterday in a one-hour radio broadcast marking the forty-fourth anniversary of the National Council of Jewish Women and the seventy-ninth birthday of its founder, Mrs. Hannah G. Solomon of Chicago.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the Alleghany Corporation, a holding company, through which the Midamerica Corporation controls the former Van Sweringen railroads,
Charles Odle, 24, was in the market today for an "amphibious" automobile. His car skidded on an icy pavement and plunged into Middle Fork Creek last night. He swam ashore.

Politics and baseball, making a strange mixture, mingled amid an air of royal conviviality last night at the Hotel Commodore when some seventy-five guests attended a testimonial dinner tendered by the New York baseball writers to Eddie Brannick, the Giants' dashing secretary and man about town.

Ernest Hemingway, the novelist, who was an ambulance driver with the Italian Army during the World War, has been named chairman of a committee formed to send an ambulance corps to Spain, according to an announcement yesterday by Saul Carson, executive director of the medical bureau of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy.

A news dispatch from Boston published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 5 reported the indictment of John P. Hull of Leominster and Morey Getz of New York for conspiracy to violate the Securities Act of 1934.

Felled by heavy hammer blows in the head while working in her kitchen, Mrs. Mary H. Case, 25 years old, a bride of one year, was found slain at 6:35 o'clock last night in the overflowing bathtub of her three-room apartment on the fourth floor of 37-06 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
Mae Scheible and Joe Ryan of New York, convicted under the white slave laws, lost their fight today for a review of -their case by the Supreme Court.

With the increased interest of the public in home furnishings a major stimulating factor, installment sales in the department store field scored a gain of 33 per cent during 1936 over 1935, according to a report issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The report of John Morrell Co., meat packers, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 was issued yesterday. It showed a net profit of $619,490 after interest, depreciation, Federal income and processing taxes. This was equal to $1.60 each on 385,698 shares of no par capital stock, excluding 14,302 shares held in the treasury. In the year ended on Nov. 2, 1935, the net profit was $338,595 or 87 cents a share.

Another big increase, bringing the Soviet military budget to 20,102,000,000 rubles for 1937, was announced by Gregory T. Grinko, Finance Commissar, at the opening session tonight of a full meeting of the Soviet Central Executive Committee in the Kremlin Palace.

Charles H. Dickerman was found dead early today in his room in the Philadelphia Country Club. Death was attributed to a heart attack. His father told attaches of the coroner's office that he had suffered from a valvular heart, ailment since childhood.

When the Socony-Vacuum Company, formerly the Standard Oil Company of New York, raises or lowers its prices on gasoline, the other companies almost invariably follow suit, it was said yesterday by most of the witnesses representing large oil concerns at a public hearing of the joint legislative committee investigating the price of gasoline in New York State.

In another unanimous opinion, the Supreme Court yesterday upheld as constitutional a tax imposed by the Government in connection with the silver purchase program which it has diligently pursued since 1934. The question at issue was whether this tax was illegal in so far as it was levied retroactively on profits made by dealers in silver before the Government launched its program.

Champion Torohill Trader, the famous black cocker owned, by Leonard J. Buck of Great Neck, L. I., and handled in the ring by Bain Cobb, last night gained the highest honors in the twentieth annual specialty show of the Amerlean Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.
All the excitement and alarm of the past few days over Germany's activities and intentions in Spanish Morocco came to a sudden end this evening.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday appointed Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and Alderman Alexander A. Falk as the three members of the traffic commission provided in the new traffic code.

Upon recommendation of Governor. Lehman, the Senate passed tonight as its first approved bill of the current session a measure urged by Mayor La Guardia and designed to prevent wholesale evictions from oldlaw tenements.

Two of the seeded players in the ninth annual Clyde Martin memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club moved a notch ahead of the field yesterday as each came through with a victory in the third round.

The New Deal won a victory in the Supreme Court today when the government was upheld by a unanimous vote in its imposition of a retroactive 50 per cent tax on profits made from deals in silver while the Silver Purchase Act of 1934 was being formulated and passed through Congress.

Robbery indictments against William Maloney, 40 years old, and Charles Simpson, 23, were dismissed yesterday in the Queens County Court by Justice Thomas Downs. The dismissals were granted on the motion of their counsel after the State had presented its case.

The Court of Appeals was asked today to reverse its own decision made a year ago on the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act. The petitioner, the Bourjois Sales Corporation, asked that the court accept a recent ruling of the Federal Supreme Court under which manufacturers in interstate commerce are permitted to fix a minimum resale price for their products.
Adam Schneider Jr., who started work as an office boy, with the Roosevelt Savings Bank, has been elected its first vice president, it was announced yesterday.

All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented in the audience which today applauded Miss Hilda Burke, soprano, and Charles Kullmann at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musical morning at the Mayflower Hotel.

Two years and seven months of bitter litigation ended yesterday when Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, acting with consent of all parties, dismissed proceedings to reorganize the Associated Gas and Electric Company under Section 77b of the National Bankruptoy Act.

The War Department has bought a 175-acre tract at the northern end of Pinelawn Cemetery on Wellwood Avenue in Pinelawn Village, five miles north of here, and will use the plot for a national burying ground.
Another quiet day on the northwestern Madrid front confirms yesterday's impressions that the Insurgent drive has been checked.

The Johnson Educator Biscuit Company of Cambridge, holding company of the Johnson Educator Food Company, petitioned in Federal District Court today for a reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

The Braeburn Alloy Steel Corporation of Braeburn, Pa., sued the United States in the Court of Claims, today for $98,259, which it said would cover the loss of its office building in a flood last Spring.

Herbert I. Allen, treasurer of the Electron Chemical Company, organized to develop chemical discoveries he made in connection with the paper manufacturing trade and in other lines, died today at the age of 61.

" Sir: I read your article about Jesse Owens and the horse Julio Macaw twice and I failed to find any mention of the start. Without ever having had .personally the opportunity to compare the speed of a horse from a standing start, I should think that Owens could attain full speed much more quickly than the horse and that would make a vital difference in such a short distance as 100 yards.
Charles Mattson, 10-year-old son of Dr. William W. Mattson, physician and surgeon, was snatched from an enclosed sun porch in his father's Tacoma home at 8:45 P. M., two nights after Christmas.

The list of the motorship Vulcania of the Italian Line, leaving today for a cruise to South America, includes Colonel and Mrs. W. L. Rawlinson, Mrs. F. V. du Pont, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Connolly, Mr. and Mrs. W. Franklyn Best, Mr. and Mrs. George W. Borg,

Norman MacCallum, who as an Associated Press writer on the Buffalo staff handled the first news break of the shooting of President McKinley, died here tonight at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Frank Clark, at the age of 65.

A goal by Fred Selinger in 10:04 of the second period enabled the Baldwin Hockey Club to turn back the Baisley Park sextet, 1-0, in a Tri-County Hockey League match at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

Leon Trotsky, the exiled former Russian leader, descended from a magnificent private railroad car at a point twenty-two miles from this capital today and was driven by automobile over a roundabout route to the luxurious home of the artist Diego Rivera in the suburb of Coyoacan.

Further evidence of a return of prosperity on the turf was revealed yesterday by the announcement of the Westchester Racing Association of nominations for the Futurity Stakes at Belmont Park in 1939. Entries for the event closed Ja. 4 with 1,070 names listed by 101 different interests.

The Industrial Rayon Corporation of Cleveland has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for 247,625 shares of no par value capital stock, of which 151,625 are to be offered to stockholders at the rate of one share for each four shares held.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan . 10, unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: Argonne, Dent Rathburne, Sirius Talbot, Waters. Bass, at San Diego. Chaumont, at Manila, Jan. 11. Clark, Boston Yard to sea, Jan. 11. Flusser, at Chatham, Jan. 9. Luzon, at Nanking.

The value of vegetables, grains and fruits from New Jersey farms totaled $49,628,600 in 1936, an increase of 22.7 per cent over that for 1935 and of 11.7 per cent over the average for the last ten years, it was announced here today by the State Department of Agriculture.

Albert Morris Bagby's 395th Musical Morning attracted the usual large representative gathering of members of society yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Miss Suzanne Fisher of the Metropolitan Opera,

A total of $125,862,000 was bid for $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury bills, dated Jan. 13 and maturing on Oct. 13, which were offered on Jan. 8, the Treasury announced tonight. Of the amount offered, $50,022,000 was accepted.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn yesterday adjourned until Jan. 18 condemnation hearings for land proposed for a school site at Tilden Avenue and East Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn. because the city may want another site.
