Governor Harold G. Hoffman was among the mourners at the funeral in Hoboken yesterday of John Toohey Sr., 89 years old, father of Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr.

The names of twenty-six men and women who have contributed $100 or more to the $500,000 campaign of the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant Big Sisters Cooperative Committee were announced yesterday by Mrs. Lowe Fiske, chairman of the group. The list follows:

Eduard C. Lindeman, national director of the recreation division of the Works Progress Administration and a professor at the New York School of Social Work, predicted yesterday afternoon that work relief would soon change in character.

George J. Trojan, a retired policeman better known as "Boots" Trojan from the vigorous methods with which he maintained law and order in Hell's Kitchen forty-odd years ago, died early yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 33-20 167th Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 68 years old.

Speculative activities abroad in copper have reached a point where they are causing some concern to leading copper producers here. Domestic producers in an effort to keep both markets on a price parity must follow the advances made abroad.

When the United States entered the World War it was to Professor JULIUS STIEGLITZ that the Government turned for advice on chemical warfare. When the American Medical Association needed a strong man on its Council of Chemistry and Pharmacy to pass on drugs it was to him that it extended its first appeal for assistance.
The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corportion announced yesterday that the formal opening and Inspection of its new 100-inch semi-continuous plate mill at Homestead, Pa., would take place on Friday.

Permission to intervene in the voluntary 77b reorganization proceedings of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation was sought today in petitions filed in the United States District Court on behalf of the Atlas Corporation, investment trust headed by Floyd B. Odlum, and the Associated Investing Corporation, an affiliate of the American Gas and Electric Company.

Nervously upset after perpetrating a $41 hold-up in a lower East Side cafe, James Leskowitz, 18 years old, shot at a policeman who met him outside the place soon after 3 A. M. yesterday. His bullet went wild, while the policeman drew his own revolver and shot and killed the young robber. An accomplice escaped.

Although it deferred a definite decision, the Interstate Commerce Commission today acceded partly to the request of the nation's railroads for speedy handling of their proposal for increased freight rates on basic commodities.
More than 100 persons, five of them feared dead, were snowbound in the blizzard-scourged West today, while Southern California fruit growers counted losses that might run to $10,000,000.

A marked increase in automobile accidents, fatalities and the number of persons injured last week and over the week-end compared to the figures of the corresponding periods of 1936 marred the safety campaign records of the Police Department, it was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler. First Deputy Commissioner.
Chosen from a slate of twenty-one nominees, seven members of the New York Stock Exchange were elected as the new nominating committee in an election held yesterday by Exchange members.

Many more telegrams of condolence were received here today at the home of Justice Frederic Kernochan, but members of his family did not care to reveal their contents. It was said, however, that among the messages was one from James A. Farley, chairman of the National Democratic Committee, and another signed by members of the Wigwam of Tammany Hall.
Miss May Piper Spear, magazine writer and fashion expert, was found dead by her maid yesterday afternoon in the small penthouse apartment in which she lived at 713 Madison Avenue.
William and Robert Bongart, 12 and 11 years old, whose home instruction by their parents was held to be inadequate under the School Law, will go back to public school in West Orange tomorrow.

SUBJECTS for satire meet the eye in every walk of life and on. every street corner. They cluster almost as thickly, indeed, as Connemara blackberries in August. Yet a good satirical book is of the greatest rarity. While the lists abound in lady poets, romancers and makers of textbooks,
With patent royalties estimated at millions of dollars at stake, a law suit involving the hosiery manufacturing industry began today before Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson.

President Roosevelt submitted to Congress today a request for an immediate appropriation of $790,000,000 to continue relief and work relief for the next five months, coupled with another warning to private business that costs for these activities could be reduced only by reemployment of the idle in industry.

The National Labor Relations Board lost by a two-to-one decision of the Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today in an action seeking enforcement of a ruling by the board against the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company.
The Detroit Red Wings monopolized National Hockey League honors during the past week.

The New York Americans, after a rest of almost a week, will try to get back on victory road tonight when they skate against the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
The New York World's Fair of 1939 was envisioned yesterday by F. Trubee Davison, former Assistant Secretary of War, as a "vast and orderly museum" upon which the world of tomorrow will be built.

To Miss Sirarpie Der Nersessian, Armenian Professor of Art at Wellesley College, has been awarded the highest scholastic degree conferred in France, that of Docteur des Lettres, and with highest honors of any candidate.

Leading educators and social workers were among the more than 1,000 persons who attended funeral services yesterday for Dr. Leon Wolf Goldrich, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
The Chicago Corporation, largest investing and financing concern in the Middle West, disclosed today in its annual report an improvement in both net asset values and income last year.

Rumors of a bituminous coal strike in April were answered today by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, with the statement that a strike would come only if the operators refused to negotiate for a new agreement.

Steve (Crusher) Casey of Ireland required only 20:31 to pin Bill Sledge of Houston, Texas, in the feature wrestling contest to a finish before 3,000 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. The victor, who scaled 231, downed Sledge, 215, with his customary Killarney flip.

The stock market here, after a quiet opening today, became more active in the afternoon. Some gilt-edged issues were lower on intimations of new financing, but among the industrial stocks, iron and steel shares were active.

The Tammany Hall executive committee will convene at 4 P. M. today for a meeting designed to end the controversy over the leadership of the organization. The session was decided upon yesterday by James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, and was called at his request, Mr. Dooling's friends said.
Pope Pius suffered a recurrence of extreme pain in his legs and shortness of breath early today.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, the Reich's highest Nazi official next to Chancellor Hitler, will leave for Rome tomorrow on what diplomatic circles believe is an "important mission" in connection with the Spanish crisis.
Announcement has been made by Andrew Lustbaum of Long Branch of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Lilian Lustbaum, to Dr. Nathan M. Frankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Frankel of this city.

Senator Philip N. Kleinfeld of Brooklyn won the chairmanship of the Judiciary Committee, it was disclosed tonight as committee assignments were made public. He was the ranking Democrat on the committee upon election of former Chairman Byrne to Congress.
51st St., 305 E., n. s., 16.9x85xirreg.; Thos. Reilly to Amy L. Kaufman, 18 E. 41st St.; 3 yrs., 5 per cent; $3,000.

Developing its program for taking testimony in connection with application by Exchanges for unlisted trading privileges in securities registered and listed on another Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission called today a public hearing for Feb. 2
Counsel for the Carnegie-Illnois Steel Corporation told the Labor Relations Board today that it was "inconceivable" that the corporation would discharge an employee for "too vigorous" union activity.
French diplomacy can congratulate itself on the success of one of the neatest moves the game of international politics has shown since the World War.

James D. P. Wingate, publisher of The Medford Mercury, former business manager of the old Boston Journal and one time manager of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Thumb, died today in his sleep at his home here at the age of 81. He established his first newspaper when only 14 years old.

Steel operations for this week were estimated yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute at 78.8 per cent of ingot capacity, a decrease of 0.6 point, or 0.75 per cent, from last week's six-year high level of 79.4 per cent. A month ago, the rate was 79.2 per cent.

Many dinners were given before the second in the series of coffee dances for this season held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. The hosts and hostesses took their guests later to the club for coffee and dancing.

The number of building loan contracts filed in 1936 in the New York County Clerk's office increased by more than 25 per cent over 1935, according to a report made public yesterday by County Clerk Albert Marinelli. The number for 1936 was 140, compared with 109 in 1935.

Reflecting the strength in the price abroad, domestic producers yesterday advanced the quotation of copper for immediate delivery a half cent a pound to 12 1/2 cents. On Dec. 31 the domestic price was raised from 11.625 to 12 cents.

Antonio M. Delgardo, 51 years old, Mayor-elect of Ponce, who was to have taken office today, was buried at his former home at Yauco. While a guest at a dinner Saturday night Mr. Delgado complained of feeling ill. He died less than twenty-four hours before he was to have assumed office.
Snow fell yesterday in Sicily, a rare event. The dispatches from Palermo said that Winter sport fans were departing for
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, talked with President Roosevelt today On labor's problems of a general nature, but not on the automobile Strike.
The text of President Roosevelt's letter today to Speaker Bankhead was as follows: THE SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES:
Matthew Plese, who last week lost $991 through a hole in his trousers pocket, retained his faith in the innate goodness of mankind today, although $140 had not been returned.
Henry H. Pierce of Wollaston resigned tonight as State Commissioner of Banks to become president of the Merchants Cooperative Bank of Boston, the largest cooperative bank in Massachusetts.

The Pan-American Press Conference put aside everything else today and fought bitterly throughout its last two plenary sessions over a demand for the liberation of about fifty newspapermen now in jails throughout Latin America because they dared criticize their governments.

To the Guild Theatre tonight comes Item No. 3 of the nineteenth subscription season, this being "But for the Grace of God," by Leopold L. Atlas. It was he who created no little stir three years ago with "Wednesday's Child,"
The alternate-or happy-ending of "Beloved Enemy" was substituted last night for the original tragic conclusion by the management of the Rivoli Theatre as a local experiment on audience reaction.
Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, on a wedding visit here with her consort, Prince Bernhard, today exploited her knowledge of the Polish tongue as she took lessons in skiing.

Extensive reconstruction of what is known as Conservatory Range, one of the largest public greenhouses in the world, on the west side of Bronx Park, will be commenced early this year, it was announced yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the officers and directors of the New York Botanical Garden in the office of Henry W. de Forest, president, at 165 Broadway.
Mrs. Mary Rita O'Brien, wife of Dennis F. O'Brien of the New York law firm of O'Brien, Driscoll Rafferty, died here today of pneumonia at her home, 125 A?a Avenue.

The twenty-story building at 1622 East Thirty-fourth Street, running through the block to 15-19 East Thirty-third Street, has been purchased by Charles F. Noyes as a personal investment, from the Prudential Insurance Company.

The New York office of Columbia Pictures yesterday confirmed the reported purchase of the film rights to "You Can't Take It With You," the Moss Hart-George S. Kaufman comedy, one of the outstanding hits of the current Broadway season.

William J. Casey, president of the William J. Casey Trucking and Rigging Company, at 247 Water Street, and formerly vice president of the United States Trucking Corporation, died of pneumonia on Saturday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital. He was 66 years old and resided at 918 Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn.

Details of the policy of higher waged, shorter hours, vacations and sick benefits announced Saturday by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company were disclosed yesterday in a letter from John A. Hartford, president of the company, to employes.

The Rev. Charles Matthew Hosey, for two years pastor of St. Agnes Church here and assistant pastor at various Catholic churches of the State since his ordination in 1918, died of a heart attack yesterday at the rectory. His age was 44.

Last week Spanish Morocco usurped the place previously occupied by Madrid. An extraordinary series of charges and denials, reports and contradictions had their origin in Morocco. It was stated that 2,000 German marines had landed at Ceuta, directly across from Gibraltar, and were fortifying that Spanish base. This seemed incredible and, in fact, soon turned out to be a misunderstanding or distortion of some kind of aid offered the Spanish Rebels by Germans.
Sportsmen from all parts of the East, about 300 in round numbers, will get together at the WaldorfAstoria Thursday night to talk about ducks. It will be a dinner of the American Wildlife Institute.

Dr. and Mrs. Walter P. Anderton will give a dinner Friday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for their daughter, Miss Audrey K. Anderton. Mr. and Mrs. Maximilian Agassiz have come from Boston to the RitzCarlton. Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Dempsey, who had been at the Westbury, left yesterday for Miami Beach.
King George VI ended today his first month on the throne of Great Britian. A month ago today his elder brother, then King Edward VIII, abdicated to be able to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson.

Accused of snatching an envelope containing $1,300 from a young Woman on Thirty-eighth Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, Frank Spiess, 18 years old, who said he had no home, was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.

Holders of 239,000 shares of Consumers Power Corporation stock living in Michigan, the region served by the company, subscribed to 180,000 shares of its new issue of $4.50 no-par preferred stock, an amount equal to 75 per cent of their holdings, Wendell L. Willkie,

The closing formalities of the deal whereby the Giants have taken title to the Albany International League franchise for the purpose of transferring it to Jersey City this year were enacted yesterday when Joe Cambria, Albany owner, paid another visit to the offices of the New York club.

E. G. Buckland, chairman of the board of directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said today that the road needed only a "reasonable prosperity to show its old-time strength." He spoke before the Hartford Rotary Club.

Clarence S. Rose gave a luncheon yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador for Amine Youssef, Egyptian Minister to the United States. Guests included Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky, Count and Countess Vincent Orssich, Princess Laura Rospigliosi,

Mrs. Henry B. Close and Mrs. Robert Livingston Ireland were hostesses at a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza last night for Miss Barbara M. Hill, debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Miner C. Hill of Oyster Bay, L. I., and this city.

The General Motors Corporation announced today the complete or partial closing of five additional factories, throwing 19,500 more employes out of work, because of the shortage of glass and other consequences of the widespread strikes in the automotive and allied industries.

The Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association submitted its demand for recognition as the bargaining agency of licensed engineers emplayed on ships of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company yesterday morning at a hearing before Robert Gates, examiner of the Labor Relations Board. The hearing was held at 45 Broadway.

Mrs. Louis H. May, wife of a former partner in the New York underwriting firm of Chubb Son, and a daughter of the late Justice Byron Britton of the Court of Appeals at Ottawa, Canada, died yesterday at her residence here at the age of 60.

The New York Society of Women Artists opened its annual show with a reception yesterday afternoon in- the galleries on the thirtythird floor of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue. It will remain current through Jan. 26. The hours are 10:30 A. M. to 5:30 P. M. Fifty members are exhibiting at this time and there are several guest artists.
Among the properties sold at auction in Manhattan yesterday was the apartment house at 203-7 West 106th Street, a fifteen-story building, occupying a plot 100 by 100.11 feet.

A queer blend of gangsterism and politics was revealed by the police today when they announced that thirty-three members of a revolutionary organination called the Agrarian Youths Society had been committed for trial.

Miss Margaret Mary Hoyt, daughter of Mrs. J. Mitchell Hoyt of Noroton, Conn., was married to Lieutenant Ridgway P. Smith Jr., U.S.A., son of Major Ridgway P. Smith, U.S.A., and Mrs. Smith of New York,
Real estate transactions in Brooklyn reported yesterday included the transfer of a forty-family apartment house, a combination dwelling and store and a business property.

There's a new headstone marking a lonely grave on Colorado's plains. It is a cowboy's tribute to Midnight, the buckingest bronco of them all. On its face is graven an epitaph, a gem of sincerity, if not of poetic execution. It reads:
A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY, a comedy in three acts, by Melvin Levy. Staged by Melville Burke: setting by P. Dodd Ackerman; produced by Murray Jay Queen. At the Vanderbilt Theatre.

Two of the oldest and most dearly prized trophies in the possession of the Pekingese Club of America, the James Gordon Bennett and J. P. Morgan Challenge Cups, concurrently presented in 19;12, passed from competition last night at the thirty-ninth show of the organization in the Roof Garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Nine firemen were injured, three seriously, and four others enough to require hospital treatment, when flames swept through the top floors of Lyman Hall, the College of Natural History at Syracuse University, this afternoon.
Larruping Lou Gehrig, iron man of the New York Yankees, was baseball's highest salaried player of 1935. The heavy-hitting first baseman drew $31,000.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, has been appointed a member of the Federal Advisory Council, to serve for 1937 as representative of the New York Federal Reserve District, it was announced yesterday.
A destroyer for the German Navy, declared to be of "an entirely new type," will be laid down here on Thursday, it was announced today.
James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed dean of the Harvard Law School today by the university board of overseers.
The Welsh Presbyterian Church, 505 West 155th Street, was received into the Presbytery of New York at a meeting of the Presbytery held in the church yesterday afternoon and evening.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull was prepared tonight to plunge immediately on his return to Washington into State Department problems that have arisen during his two months' absence.

Subsidence of the latest "Morocco crisis" through Chancellor Hitler's assurances came today as a vast relief to the British Government, whose overpowering impulse ever since the start of the Spanish civil war has been to prevent the conflict from spreading.
Miss Natalie. F Couch, manager of the women's campaign in the Eastern States for Alfred M. Landon, and defeated candidate for Representative-at-Large in New York State

Louis Greif, printing, in 105 E. 29th ST.; Bastine Co., Inc., agent. Zolan Siegel, Inc., dresses, in 545 8th Av.; Maison France, Inc., Iaces; Astor Ribbon Co., Inc., and Aladdin Textiles, Inc., in 101 W. 37th St.; Abe Levin, dresses; Max Dorros, coats, in 330 W. 38th St., Dublirer Sporteens, Inc., skirts, in 1,372 Broadway, Reliable Button Co., Inc., covered buttons, in 229 W. 36th St.; Spear Co., Inc., broker.

Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, director of the Hall of Fame, and former Ambassador to Italy, will be 84 years old today. Owing to an illness late in the Winter of 1935, from which he is gradually recovering, the day will be marked with a quiet family observance at his home, 327 Lexington.Avenue.
Transfer of the property at 2733 West Twenty-third Street, running through to 8-18 West Twentyfourth Street, improved with a six-story building, was recorded yesterday.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Lucille Fusz O'Malley, daughter of Charles J. O'Malley of Chestnut Hill and Cohasset, Mass., and the late Mrs. O'Malley, to Maurice E. McLoughlin, son of Mrs. Maurice E. McLoughlin of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McLoughlin.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange were held within a narrow range yesterday in quiet trading. Liquidation by tired longs filled domestic and foreign trade buying orders at slight reactions, but there was little disposition to make fresh commitments in advance of the release of cotton from loan stocks on Feb. 1.
California and Florida citrus growers tonight faced financial loss from extremes of weather - California from subnormal and Florida from abnormal temperatures.

Germany's grain shortage, which had previously been estimated at some 2,000,000 tons, was confirmed today when Richard-Walther Darre, the Minister of Agriculture, issued a decree providing for additional pressure on peasants to deliver their grain to the central marketing authorities and prohibiting the purchase of bread grains for feeding purposes.

The Wood, Field and Stream snapshot contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs. Open to amateurs anywhere.

In a race run to order for his type of horse, Chancing, 6-year-old son of Chance Play in the stable of Phil Bieber, easily won the Newspaper Guild Class B Handicap of six furlongs at Tropical Park today. Closing at 13-5 in the field of five, Chancing ran over the leaders to score by three lengths under Nick Wall. His time was 1:113-5.
Three men were burned, one critically, in a fire that followed an explosion in the workroom of the E. E. Waeldin cutlery and optical supply store at 117 Fulton Street yesterday morning.
The third suicide in the United States Army here in the last four weeks occurred this morning when Sergeant Reuben A. Johnson killed himself with his service pistol military headquarters.
The savagely battered body of 10-yearold Charles Mattson was found today lying nude and frozen stiff in snow-covered brushland near Everett.
The arraignment of an automobile driver in Homicide Court yesterday revealed that he could see with only one eye and that he had killed a pedestrian while driving a car that he planned to buy for $5.

Mayor La Guardia was chosen yesterday by the students of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn to receive the Lincoln Medal awarded annually by the school on Lincoln's Birthday to the citizen deemed to have rendered the greatest service to the city during the preceding year.

The special meeting of Kresge Deapartment Stores, Inc., has been adjourned until Jan. 25. Arnold T. Koch has become a member of the firm of O'Connor Farber. The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 662,546 shares of capital stock of the Lockheed Aircraft Company.
Subscriptions to the "People's Egyptian Defense Fund," used for buying planes and armament from Great Britain, today totaled $5,000,000. Money is pouring in from all parts of the country.

A bill to make a crime the transporting or sale of goods, manufactured or mined wholly or in part by child labor, to any State or Territory of the United States where anti-child labor laws are in effect was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Clark of Missouri. Clark of Missouri.

Another version of the Sian coup of Dec. has been received by this correspondent. According to it, the detention of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was not actually mutiny and the generalissimo's life was far more endangered by the government's punitive expedition and the government's aerial bombers than by his captors.

ASSOCIATE HOME ECONOMIST, $3,200 a year, office of experiment stations, Department of Agriculture. Age under 45. The closing date is Feb. 4, if application is received from the following named States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming; Feb. 1 if received from States other than those named.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Jan. 8: McDowell, Capt. C. S., ordered home, relieved of all active duty, being placed on retired list Feb. 1. Kelly, Comdr. J. A., Dental Corps, the Colorado, to San Diego, Calif., naval training station.
United States Government obligations continued in supply at declining prices yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Not only are the current automobile strikes eliminating a substantial volume of advertising for the time being, but the vagaries of the weather are contributing their share to cutting down copy, it was pointed out here yesterday.

Harry Cooper of Chicago, smashing par, the tournament record and all opposition in a dramatic nine-hole drive, won the $8,000 Los Angeles Open today. Horton Smith of Chicago and Ralph Guldahl of St. Louis tied for second place.

The new proposal of Representative Patman giving the Federal Trade Commission control over manufacturers engaged in retailing and retailers doing manufacturing, was attacked as "bad economics that will prove costly to the consummer, while unnecessary from a legal standpoint," at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor, attended by about twenty-five executives of national chain systems and manufacturers.

The Washington Headquarters Association of the D. A. R. will give a bridge tea today in Schrafft's Florentine Room at 220 West Fiftyseventh Street to raise funds for the restoration, repair and upkeep of Colonial and Revolutionary relics in the Washington Headquarters

During the twelve-year period from 1920 to 1932 the number of Massachusetts textile workers dropped from 209,506 to 96,478, while in Pennsylvania the number increased from 211,798 to 217,584, the National Economy League has announced after a survey.
Futurity Stake-First, Mrs. W. Morgan Churchman's Orthodox Brevity; second, Mrs. Leonard Buck's Found third, Mrs. Henry A. Ross's Nonquitt Naiad; fourth, Mrs. Everett T. Young's Stonelea Black Sambo.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, trustee for the Municipality of Bogota, Colombia, Power and Light Consolidation twenty-year 6 1/2 per cent bonds, has instructed its representative, D. A.

Officials of the Orleans Levee District, La., will consider bids on Jan. 28 for a new issue of $3,784,000 of refunding bonds, to be dated March 1, 1937, and mature March 1, 1939 to 1968. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.
Derrick Lane Hall, secretarytreasurer of The Hoosick Falls Standard Press, died here this evening at his home of pneumonia after an illness of six days at the age of 76.

Stewart Raynor has sold his tenacre estate in Old Brookville, L. I., to Dorothy L. Sheldon, who will occupy the old Colonial residence on the place after enlarging and remodeling it. The estate is near the properties of Winthrop Brooks, Mrs. Walter S. McClure and Fairman Dick. Warren Murdock was broker in the deal.

Automobile production recovered sharply last week from its holiday levels, despite labor stoppages suffered by the leading company, and the adjusted index has advanced to 101.2 from 96,0 in the previous week and compares with 114.8 for the week ended Jan. 11, 1936.

The Association of City Hall Reporters yesterday re-elected as president Barnard R. Mullady of the City News Association. J. W. Haslett of the World-Telegram was re-elected secretary-treasurer, and Leo Egan of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle, was elected vice president.

Central Illinois Securities Corporation-For 1936: Net income was $200,194 after expenses and ordinary taxes, but exclusive of $132,773 profit realized from sale of investments, which was credited to capital surplus account.
Democratic members of the New Jersey Senate abandoned last night the projected "stay-away" strike to prevent organization by the Republicans of the upper house when it convenes at Trenton today.

Gallienne, 4-year-old filly owned by Mennie and McGregor, regained the winning stride she showed at Lincoln Fields and Arlington Downs last Fall in accounting for the six-furlong feature at Alamo Downs today.

The Neediest Cases Fund was increased yesterday by $47, bringing the total amount that has accrued to the fund in this appeal thus far to $269,385.18. Ten contributors were represented in the donations received during the day.
President Roosevelt is expected to intervene in the General Motors strike situation by the week-end if Governor Murphy fails in his renewed efforts for conciliation, it was indicated here today.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted the following securities to listing: Bell Aircraft Corporation, common stock, $1 par; J. W. Carter Company, common stock, $1 par; Hussman-Ligonier Company, common stock, no par; Ryerson Haynes, Inc., common stock, $1 par.

A first mortgage loan of $88,000, at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent has been placed by E. Osborne Smith, Inc., for the 15 North Street Corporation, Philip Aginsky, president on the new six-story apartment house at 15 North St., the Bronx. Walter Samuels, Inc., placed for Thomas Peilly a first mortgage of $3,000, at 5 per cent, on the dwelling at 305 E. 51st St.

Dr. James A. Tobey of Rye, N. Y., was re-elected president of the Westchester Tuberculosis and Public Health Association at the annual meeting of the directors yesterday in the Town Hall Club. Mrs. John F. O'Reilly of Mamaroneck, first vice president; Edward M. Ames of White Plains, treasurer, and James E. Bryan of White Plains, secretary, were all re-elected.

Yesterday's throng at the National Motor Boat Show got down to business and started to buy. The start of a solid six-day week brought to the million-dollar display of cruisers, windjammers, motors and accessories a serious-minded parade of yachtsmen and would-be skippers with certified checks in their wallets and determination in their minds.

With the legislative session entering its second week, the Assembly failed at a brief session tonight to elect a Speaker and adjourned until tomorrow with a distinct threat that if the Republicans fail to .unite on a candidate for the speakership the Democrats may organize the House in spite of its Republican. majority.

Moses L. Parshelsky, Brooklyn realty man, yesterday paid the Federal Government $2,000,000 in back income taxes, pleaded guilty to an indictment charging income tax evasion and then received a suspended sentence from Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn, carrying five years' probation.

Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, successor of William F. Bleakley, renewed today his attack on the Westchester trustees appointed by former Justice Bleakley to rehabilitate certificated mortgages of defunct Westchester mortgage companies when he denied a motion to sell a Larchmont apartment house for $145,000.

George F. Baker of New York City has asked the Board of Tax Appeals to revalde 3,000 shares of capital stock in the First National Bank of the City of New York, on which the Commissioner of Internal Revenue levied a gift tax of $246,821.
Dean George C. Sellery, who was catapulted into leadership of the University of Wisconsin when Dr. Glenn Frank was ousted by the regents, won a tacit vote of confidence from his faculty today.

The General Investment Corporation and Henderson Brothers of Boston have acquired in the market or by private purchase 40 per cent of the common stock of the Standard Investing Corporation and henceforth will manage it, Brown Brothers Harriman Co., announced yesterday.
With the number of buyers here yesterday much larger than on last Monday, the pace of both immediate and Spring buying activities increased notably.

Eugene J. Driscoll, Deputy Commissioner of Records of New York County, died yesterday of pneumonia at Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 64 years old. Mr. Driscoll received his appointment in 1918 from Mayor John F. Hylan after having been a political figure as treasurer of the Down Town Tammany Club for many years.
Turpentine firm, 45 1/2c: sales, 150 barrels; receipts, 282 barrels; shipments, 443 barrels; stock, 31,523 barrels. Resin, firm: sales, 221; receipts, 1,982: shipments, 639; stock, 77,027.

The advance guard of what threatens to develop into an army of 2,000 striking seamen appeared in Washington this morning. A dozen pickets of the rank and file members of the International Seamen's Union from Baltimore, carrying large placards, began pacing back and forth in front of the Department of Commerce Building early this morning and kept it up all day.

The New York Hanseatic Corporation's statement for Dec. 31, made public yesterday, disclosed a surplus account of $725,022, an increase of $74,642 in 1936 and equal to $12.73 a share for the year on the capital stock.

The third volume in Charles M. Andrews's "Colonial Period of American History," originally announced for publication this Spring by the Yale University Press, will be postponed until the early Autumn.

Mrs. Andrea Fenwick Luckenbach, wife of Edgar Luckenbach of Sands Point, died today in the Nassau Hospital at Mineola of pneumonia. She was 50 years old. She was married to the head of the Luckenbach Steamship Line in 1919, and was his second wife. They have two children, Andrea and Edgar Jr.

Earl Christiansen, Miami star, took the play away from a crack field in winning the qualifying medal in the thirteenth annual Mid-Winter amateur golf championship at the Miami Country Club today. He paced a group of prominent linksmen by a stroke with 35-40-75.

Reply was filed with the Federal Trade Commisson today by the Metropolitan Boston Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, denying it had entered into a conspiracy with whisky manufacturers to fix retail prices.

A far-reaching plan to establish Pan-American post-graduate schools and hospitals in all the large cities of Central and South America, was revealed last night by Professor Jos6 Arce, dean of the University of Buenos Aires, before a distinguished gathering of physicians at the Metropolitan Club.
A plea for executive clemency for John Fiorenza, convicted murderer of Mrs. Nancy Titterton, on the ground that he was "a madman," was made today before Governor Lehman.

Between twenty and twenty-five lepers whom the medical experts say it is unnecessary to isolate are leading the lives of normal citizens in New York City, it was learned yesterday from the Health Department.

A delegation of 700 members of the Teachers Union visited the Capitol tonight and sent a committee to urge upon Governor Lehman support for restoration of salaries and repeal of the Teachers Oath Law.
Harvey C. Went of Brooklyn, N. Y., physical director in the Bridgeport public schools for forty-two years, died tonight at the age of 68.

Mrs. George B. B. Lamb gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for the executive committee of the Auxiliary of Women to the Society of St. Johnland. Among the guests were Mrs. Arthur Crocker, Mrs. Dana S.

A merger involving three companies specializing in supplying hotel and restaurant equipment was announced yesterday with the opening of the offices of Nathan StrausDuparquet, Inc., in the old SiegelCooper Building on Sixth Avenue between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets.

Colonel John A. Barrr, commandant of the Fourth Cavalry Regiment at Fort Meaude, near here, and an internationally known horseman, died of pneumonia at the post hospital yesterday. Ite was 56 years old.
One window rooms in small hotels facing the route of President Roosevelt's inaugural parade on Jan. 20 are being quoted at $25 for the big day.

The marriage of Mrs. Margaret Albert Ferber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Albert of Fall River, Mass., to Frank E. Agar, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James E. Agar of San Francisco, took place here tonight at the home of the bridegroom.

Emphasizing the continued improvement in the safety, efficiency, range, speed, comfort and capacity of American aircraft in the past year, the annual report of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, submitted today to Congress by the President, points out the necessity for the expansion of fundamental research in aeronautics in this country lest its present technical leadership be annuled by European effort.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The Discipline of Education," Louis K. Anspacher.
Frank A. Cook, who for thirty years had been the legal adjuster of the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus, died of a heart ailment last night in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 63 years old.
Diplomatic sources reported tonight that more than 200 Rightist hostages had been killed last Tuesday by mobs of extremists in Bilbao, Spain, after Insurgent airplanes had bombed the city.
After running in second place until the final strides, Sir Midas stuck his head in front to win the mile-anda-sixteenth feature for W. C. Reichert at the Fair Grounds today.
A book borrowed from the Syracuse Library May 10, 1897, and forty years "overdue," came back to the library with a group of gift books.

Mrs. Mary Weissleder, active in fine arts and musical circles in Cincinnati, died at her home here today. She was 78 years old. A native of Buffalo, N. Y., Mrs. Weissleder had been a resident here more than fifty years.
The Mexican Government will exchange 12,000,000 pesos in outstanding agrarian bonds for forty-year noninterest-bearing interior bonds, Finance Minister Eduardo Suarez announced tonight.

Because of the illness of Samuel Dushkin, who was to have been the violin soloist, the programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra which Igor Stravinsky will conduct this week have been revised, it was announced yesterday.

The Maine Racing Commission in its first annual report disclosed today $1,788,768 was wagered on pari-mutuel tracks during the two years betting has been legal. The State collected $62,412 from a tax on mutuel pools and an additional $3,200 in license fees.
Losep in its first two starts this season, the Naval Academy basketball team broke into the winning column to- day, defeating the University of Baltimore, 36 to 7.
Maria Wolf, in 205 E. 78th St. through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., and Pease Elliman, Inc.

LORDS AND MASTERS, by A. G. Macdonell. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A satiric novel. THE RECOVERY PROGRAM IN THE UNITED STATES. (The Brookings Institution, $4.) A study of the course of depression and recovery.

An alert C. C. N. Y. team, which saved its best basketball for the finish, came through with three points in the last two minutes of play tonight to defeat a small but hustling Wayne University quintet, 29 to 27, in the closest college game seen here this Winter.
The State Department today sent renewed messages urging Americans to evacuate danger zones in Spain and China.
A drop in the number of influenza and pneumonia cases in the city, coincident with the arrival of colder weather yesterday, indicated that the current outbreak of respiratory diseases may be checked.

72d St., 120-22 W., s. s., 50x102.2; 88 River, Inc., to Syncol Equities, Inc., 535 5th Av.; mtg., $125,000 ($6). 113th St., n. s., 100 ft. w. of 2d Av., 50x100.10; Maria la Vecchia to Antonio Sachell. 241-45 E. 113th St.
Arthur C. Johnson, publisher of The Denver Daily Record-Stookman, died Saturday of pneumonia at the age of 62.
The five United States Army officers who will compete in the international horse show here next month arrived this morning with their string of ten horses.

Having launched successfully one of the most ambitious spectacles of his career, "The Eternal Road," Max Reinhardt, its director, will leave Friday for Hollywood and the studios of the Warner Brothers.

As president of the Process Servers Association, may I enter emphatic protest against Commissioner Harnett's announced innovation of triennial registration for operators' licenses? No doubt the change will mean some saving of clerical labor, but what of the public weal? And what of the essential purpose of registration?
The motorship Vulcania of the Italian Line arrived from Naples and Genoa yesterday in charge of a new captain, Nestore Martinoli, who replaces Captain Roberto Stuparich recently retired.
Christadora House, a social settlement organization at 147 Avenue B, was the beneficiary of a special supper dance held last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The New York Stock Exchange has stricken from listing and registration Eastern Cuba Sugar Corporation certificates of deposit for fifteen-year 7 1/2 per cent mortgage sinking-fund gold bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1937, which were suspended from dealings on Jan. 4, and Francisco Sugar Company certificates of deposit for first-mortgage twentyyear 7 1/2 per cent sinking-fund gold: bonds, due on May 15, 1942, which were suspended on Jan. 2.

Morris S. Tremaine, as Controller of New York State, has purchased 390 mortgages on homes in that State aggregating $1,798,205 at 101 per cent of their face value plus accrued interest, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today. The RFC said he was "buying these mortgages as trustee for various sinking and trust funds of the State of New York."
Richard P. Chachati, 42, Baton Rouge linen salesman, said today he would claim a part of the fabulous estate of the late Sir Basil Zaharoff, European munitions leader.

Two special trains will carry New York's contingent of WPA "marchers" to Washington Thursday night, where they expect to join jobless persons from other parts of the nation in demanding that Congress appropriate $1,250,000,000 to meet Federal relief costs until June 30, Oscar R. Fuss, executive secretary of the City Projects Council, announced yesterday.

The Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, continuing yesterday its effort to boycott the activities of Max Schmeling, made known that it would oppose the boxer's proposed Southern tour before his fight with James J. Braddock as well as the championship contest itself.

Changing of the present midtown retail zone, which extends from Fifty-ninth to Twenty-third Street and includes Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues, to a super-retail zone for the specific purpose of preventing the further incursion of theaters, motion picture houses and dance halls was proposed by Borough President Samuel Levy yesterday in a letter to the Board of Estimate.

ABRAHAM-Stella Kern, devoted wife of Morris, darling mother of Henry, dear sister of Sarah Haas, Nora Fiebleman and Blanche Abraham. Funeral private. New Orleans papers please copy. ADAMS-Sunday, Jan. 10, Philip B., beloved husband of Elsie H. Adams, at 95 Christopher St. Services Wednesday, at 11 A. M., at Smith Seaman Funeral Home, Monroe, N. Y. Interment Vallau Cemetery, Ridgewood, N. J.

The companies of the Bell Telephone System in handling their pension funds have paid more attention to the advantages of the companies than to the interests of the trust funds themselves, a witness before the Federal Communications Commission asserted today.

Sixty-five WPA workers, assigned to the urban study of consumer purchases being carried on throughout the nation by the Department of Labor, began a "stay-in demonstration" in the project offices on the fourth floor of 44 East Twentythird Street at 5:30 P. M. yesterday.

Leslie Ames, versatile Kent professional and George Duckworth, veteran Lancashire wicket-keeper, starred in the Marylebone Cricket Club touring team's victory over a combined Tasmanian eleven by an innings and 4 runs today.

President Roosevelt today directed the Federal Power Commission to study proposed legislation which would create a body similar to the Tennessee Valley Power Authority to direct activities in the Columbia River basin in connection with the Bonneville Dam.

A legislative investigation of the city and county governments of Philadelphia, centering about municipal finances, was assured tonight when Democratic members of the General Assembly drafted a resolution authorizing the inquiry.

" Samson et Dalila" will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Metropolitan Opera Company tonight with Gertrud Wettergren, Rene Maison, Ezio Pinza and Chase Baromeo. Maurice de Abravanel will conduct.

Federal Judge Manton authorized yesterday Milton C. Weisman. equity receiver for the Fox Theatres Corporation, to continue the business of that concern for six months, at the end of which time the receivership will have been five years old.

Athletic authorities of Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Princeton and Yale today sent identical letters to the editors of their college dailies in answer to the concerted editorial plea that these undergraduate papers launched early last month for the definite formation of an Ivy Football League.
John Marshall College of Jersey City defeated the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy quintet by 40-30 in the latter's gym last night. Marshall led, 16-11, at the half.
A total of $75,727 has been contributed thus far by employe groups to the United Hospital Campaign, Stuart M. Crocker, general chairman, announced last night. The gifts are from 64,875 donors.

Puppy, Dogs (six months and under nine)First, Mrs. Richard S. Quigley's Pierrot Wee Ray of Orchard Hill; second, Misses S. F. Hodges and A. Perret's Ho-Lin of Dah Wong; third, Mrs. Richard S. Quigley's Yu Go Tu of Orchard Hill; fourth, Miss Margaret D. Miller's Teddy Tu of Joiland.

Walter B. Newman, an art dealer here for forty years, died at his home to day after a long illness. He was 59 years old. Before his retirement three years ago, Mr. Newman was associated with his father, the late Adolph Newman, founder of ,the family's art business.

Mayor La Guardia returned from Washington late yesterday. He said he had conferred with Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes on housing matters and other items, and talked with WPA Administrator Harry L. Hopkins on routine affairs.

President Roosevelt submitted to Congress a request for $790,000,000 to continue relief and work relief until June 30 and discussed administration labor policies with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
A special delivery letter sent to his home in Brooklyn revealed the suicide at the Hotel Commodore early last night of Edward J. Schwerin, an insurance broker, with offices at 100 William Street.

The first national exhibition of contemporary needlework, held under the auspices of Amateur Needlework of Today for the benefit of the New York Association for the Blind, opened yesterday morning at W. J. Sloane's little house, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.

The National Football Rules Committee will hold its annual sessions at the Seaview Club, Abescon, N. J., Feb. 12-14. Sitting with the committee of eleven in an advisory capacity will be four coaches and four officials, The Associated Press reports.
Alfred Muddge McCoy, Northeastern University's football, baseball and basketball coach, today submitted his resignation, effective June 30, to accept what he described as "a position elsewhere."

Joseph Rose, 64-year-old home relief recipient who startled Brooklyn authorities last Friday when he accused Louis Gorelick, a neighbor, of stealing gems he said were worth $250,000, found himself in a bad tangle yesterday.

On the eve of the opening of the 1937 Legislature, Governor Hoffman late tonight made several ad interim appointments that are viewed by political observers as retaliation against the action of the Bergen County Assembly delegation in voting for an anti-administration floor leader.
60th St., 1,316; alteration and extension in 1 and 2 story brick laundry; Viking Laundry Service, 303 W. 42d St., Manhattan, owner; J. Z. Cohen, architect; cost, $3,500.

December's total of 111 up-State building plans filed with the State Department of Labor was the highest for any December in the twelve years such plans have been submitted, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrew reported today.

LOHENGRIN, opera in German in three acts. Music and book by Richard Wagner. Conductor, Maurice de Abravanel; stage director, Leopold Sachse; chorus master, Konrad Neuger. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Scholarly, heavily factual, assertively impartial, the latest economic research volume from the experts of the Brookings Institution will be as welcome to economists and statesmen as Mr. Wodehouse's newest efforts are to a lighterminded group of readers. Yet, though professedly non-political and Olympian where factional specifications are concerned, "The Recovery Problem in the United States" offers far more pleasant reading to Palo Alto than to the White House.

Political developments in Europe were largely ignored as a market influence in wheat today. Prices in Liverpool were equal to 1/3 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower on wheat futures, and the markets in North America took their cue from the action of the English market.

F. Trubee Davison was re-elected president of the American Museum of Natural History at the annual meeting of the board of trustees of the institution held last night in the Governor's Room of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial. J. P. Morgan was re-elected vice president.

Ceremonies marking the 180th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton were conducted at noon yesterday at his grave in the churchyard around Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, by 150 officers and men of Fort Hamilton.

The total of its new life insurance written last year was $7,500,000 more than the aggregate in 1935, according to a report yesterday by the National Life Insurance Company. New business in 1936 amounted to $45,637,000, an increase of 19.8 per cent over the year before.

Delay in enacting the new city building code is holding up many building operations, according to John Lowry, vice president of the Merchants Association of New York and chairman of the committee which drafted the proposed code at the request of city officials.

The total of its new life insurance written last year was $7,500,000 more than the aggregate in 1935, according to a report yesterday by the National Life Insurance Company. New business in 1936 amounted to $45,637,000, an increase of 19.8 per cent over the year before.

Stocks of wheat and corn on the nation's farms are the smallest in the eleven years that records on them have been kept. The Federal Crop Reporting Board said today a Jan. 1 survey showed drought-shortened crops and attractive market prices had reduced farm stocks to the record lows.
Rudolf Serkin, the young pianist who a year ago created a furore on the occasion of his debut with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, gave his first New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall,

Dr. Charles V. Niemeyer, a specialist in the diseases of infants, died here today of myocarditis at his home, 4,610 Hudson Boulevard, at the age of 48. He had been seriously ill for a month. His widow, Caroline, and his father, Carl Niemeyer, also of this city, survive.

Sunday's announcement that a " positive result" had been achieved by Poland as intermediary in the League of Nations-Danzig dispute leaves little doubt that, though face may have been saved for the League, a victory has been won by the Nazis of the Free City. This "satisfactory" solution is interesting chiefly as a sign that PolishGerman relations, despite many rumors to the contrary, are still cooperative.

City Commissioner Reginald Parnell announced today that he had mailed to the State Board of Tax Appeals in Trenton a petition asking it to increase to $300,000,000 the personalty assessment for 1936 on the registered office of the Standard Oil Company, a New Jersey corporation, which is the holding company for the Standard Oil Company, a Delaware corporation.
The New York City Omnibus Corporation reported for November a gross operating revenue of $619,862, against $649,777 in October and $584,620 in September.
Dr. John Priestes, whose work during the St. Patrick's Day flood last year prevented a typhoid epidemic at Western Penitentiary, where he was resident physician, died yesterday.

An explosion burned sixteen men seriously in the Chrysler Motor Corporation's plant here today. The explosion occurred in the salt bath section after motor parts had been taken from a cyanide bath and put in the salt solution.

Gains in factory employment in the State from the middle of November to the middle of December, and the advance in payrolls of 1.2 and 5.7 per cent, respectively, increased the State Labor Department's index for employment to 85.6,
The Senate today approved a pension of $5,000 a year to Mrs. Grace G. Coolidge, widow of President Coolidge, the action being taken more than four years after the death of Mr. Coolidge.

Edward Thomas Murphy of 257 Valentine Lane, South Yonkers, died in Yonkers yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while driving his automobile. He was on his way to bring his 7-year-old son, Richard, home from school.
The Flintkote Company, Inc., has notified the New York Stock Exchange that P. C. Rowe was elected a member of the executive committee on Jan. 6.
Paulie Walker, veteran Trenton welterweight, hammered out a convincing decision over Joe Pennino of Brooklyn in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The FrancoGerman quarrel over Spanish Morocco, which last night assumed a distinctly formidable aspect; seems tonight on its way to settlement as a result . of formal pledges exchanged by the French Ambassador and Chancellor Adolf Hitler himself at the Fuehrer's New Year reception for the diplomatic corps at noon.
Citrus fruit, onions, and the Soutehrn vegetables are exceptions to somewhat higher food prices this Winter. This item of interest to housewives comes from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.
The first five days of the new year brought a slight increase in failures, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the period ended Jan. 7 was 177, against 173 in the previous five-day week.

Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. gave a tea at their home today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch of New York, who were here on their yacht Anahita. Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, Mrs. Harold A. Braman, Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton and Mrs. Lawrence A. Furlong presided at the tables.

A severe storm was raging last night over the North Atlantic Ocean from Labrador to the British Isles and at least seven large passenger vessels bound for New York were struggling against high seas and winds of full gale proportion.
The earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company for 1986 amounted to $1,100,888, against $879,141 in 1935, George V. McLaughlin, president, reported to the stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The Brooklyn Tech basketball team gained first place in Section 2 of the Brooklyn division of the P. S. A. L. by routing Bushwick High, 35 to 17, on the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court yesterday.

The Rev. Daniel Grieder, Presbyterian churchman, who was for thirty years Professor of Church Science at the University of Dubuque, Iowa, died here last night at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, the Rev. and Mrs. A. E. Abben, after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

J. H. Macheller, president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company, Newark, N. J., announced yesterday that the directors had authorized the retirement of $1,000,000 of preferred stock on Feb. 11. Directors at the same time, he said, declared a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock, payable on Feb. 1, to stockholders of record Jan. 22.
Arturo Toscanini will open the Salzburg Festival next Summer with Beethoven's opera, "Fidelio," on July 24, and will continue to direct at the festival through Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday.
An invisible barrier of ultra-violet rays through which air-borne bacteria cannot pass was demonstrated in tests on human beings at the Harvard University School of Public Health today.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the Lots For Little Shop will be held tomorrow morning at the Chase National Bank, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The shop, at 902 Third Avenue, was founded by Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes, who is president of the organization.

Somewhat colder weather and an advance of 1/2 cent a pound in choice fresh pork loins brought in all interests as fair buyers of hogs. The latter sold steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than on Friday, with most droves selling at 5 cents decline.
Rallying behind the thousands of Flint workers who have gone on record in opposition to the strike conditions which tonight find more than 28,000 out of work here,

The Amsterdam Stock Brokers Association won another point in its suit against the Royal Dutch Shell Company in connection with its 4 per cent dollar loan in 1930 when the Court of Appeal here today confirmed a lower court's judgment upholding the gold clause.

Connie Mack, veteran manager of the Athletics, Philadelphia's American League baseball club, was elected president and treasurer at the annual meeting today, succeeding John D. Shibe, who retired because of illness. Mack's eldest son, Roy, was reelected vice president and secretary.
In an effort to discourage American travelers from going to war-torn Spain the State Department disclosed today it was marking all American passports "Not valid in Spain."

Unusual lighting effects which brought spontaneous applause from the 10,000 who turned out for the opening of the skating carnival season and the never-failing appeal of expert ice comedy were outstanding features of the first all-professional event, "The Ice Follies of 1937," at Madison Square Garden last night.

The shipyards of the world were building 2,251,000 tons of merchant shipping at the close of the year, representing an increase of 139,764 tons for three months, according to the quarterly report of Lloyds Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday.
During several years, one of the most perplexing problems was the absence of new issues of securities on the American market.

An intersectional football engagement to be known as the Silver Football Game will be staged in the Yankee Stadium on Dec. 4, it was announced yesterday. The contest will bring together two of the major universities in the country.

The Chesapeake Corporation, one of the holding companies through which the Midamerica Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, bought $5,334,000 of its own bonds in 1936, it was disclosed in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday.

Pope Pius suffered a relapse tonight after a sinking spell earlier in the day, Vatican sources said. Considerable increase of the pain in his legs was reported, and attendants were worried lest the condition develop and affect his heart.

Earnings of the National Bank of Detroit available for common stock. after operating expenses, reserves, Federal income taxes and preferred stock dividends, amounted last year to $2,467,158, equal to $4.93 each on the 500,000 shares, Walter S. McLucas, president, reported to shareholders at their annual meeting in Detroit yesterday.

Luis Careaga, acting Spanish Consul General here, announced yesterday that by order of his government he had notified the Official Spanish Chamber of Commerce, 501 Madison Avenue, that its use of the name, "official" no longer was authorized.
Deep in the solid rock of Mount Royal the frail body of 91-year-old Brother Andre, known to hundreds of thousands on this continent as a miracle worker, was laid to rest this afternoon.

A fivepoint program of governmental reorganization, designed to restore to the President authority commensurate with his responsibilities, and involving fundamental changes in the executive branch from top to bottom, was flashed upon a startled Congress today by President Roosevelt.
Japan announced today that two new 515-ton torpedo boats would be launched, one on Jan. 20 and the other on Jan. 25. Each will be 265 feet long, with a 26-foot beam and draught of 6 1/2 feet.

The capital's public, which has few opportunities of hearing classical music, packed the theatre last night to listen to the symphonic concert given by George Hoyen, conductor, and Elizabeth Travis, pianist, both Americans.

One of the most important agencies for the defense of the civilian populace of Britain-a government-owned factory for the mass production of gas masks-was formally opened at Blackburn today by Geoffrey Lloyd, Under-Secretary for Home Affairs.

New York City must appropriate larger sums for park purposes as relief funds are withdrawn to prevent deterioration of the enlarged park resources established and maintained by huge grants of relief funds, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president, declared yesterday in her annual report to the Park Association of New York City, Inc., 295 Madison Avenue.

Confronted in the Assembly, where revenue producing measures must originate, by a Democratic majority and hostile Republican leadership, Governor Hoffman urged today in his annual message to the Legislature "an end of expediency and timidity and fear in dealing with our public problems" and substitution of "directness, decision and courage."

Dr. Elias Hudson Bartley, educator and author, who was Professor of Chemistry, Toxicology and Pedi-atrics at Long Island College for many years, as well as chief chemist of the Health Department in Brooklyn from 1882 to 1888, died yesterday at his home, 70 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. He was 87 years old.
Interest in political and diplomatic circles continues to be concentrated on the arrival of Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, in Rome tomorrow.
After a short illness Philip Harry Lustig, retired hat merchant, died of a heart attack in his home at the Granada Hotel, 268 Ashland Place, Brooklyn. He was 78 years old.

An elderly man, gone suddenly mad, killed three members of his family with a hammersand pistol tonight, wounded two others and threw himself in front of a speeding freight train. He was killed instantly.

Unexpected weakness in Liverpool was largely responsible for an early decline of about 1 cent a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today, but the break brought in commission house buying and later there was fairly general short covering and also buying attributed to leading local professionals which rallied the May about 1 3/4 cents from the low.
The animal-hunting Martin Johnsons, who escaped death in an airliner crash near Los Angeles today, smilingly agreed here only yesterday that they preferred a jungle to civilization for safety.

Approval by the city of the plan for rezoning the West Side district in Manhattan already is having a favorable effect on the development of this section, Harold W. McGraw, president of the West Side Association, reported at the annual meeting of that organization yesterday in the McGraw-Hill Building.

Many of us who have followed with increasing respect and admiration the career of Mr. JAMES M. LANDIS must have often pondered his future. His intellectual powers, maturing early, are of the first order.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday the placing in service of twenty-two motor omnibuses to provide connections between its stations in this city and its terminal in Jersey City.

Barney Fagan, once a leader of minstrelsy and a vaudeville headliner who earned $1,000 a week or more, died yesterday in poverty on his eighty-seventh birthday at the Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I., after a brief illness.

Charles Hayden left almost his entire estate, estimated by his executors at about $50,000,000, to establish a charitable foundation for the education of boys and young men and the advancement of their "moral, mental and physical well-being," it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in the New York County Surrogates' Court.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs.
More and more safety is being designed into motor cars every year, the Society of Automotive Engineers was told at its annual meeting here today by W. J. Davidson of General Motors.

The text of that section of the will of Charles Hayden, the banker, providing for the establishment of a charitable and educational foundation which will administer the bulk of his $50,000,000 estate, follows: CHARLES HAYDEN FOUNDATION AND RESIDUARY ESTATE FIFTH: In disposing of my residuary estate I have had two thoughts in mind. My first duty is to my own.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had made effective, as of Jan. 11, a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act- of 1935 for issuance by the Missouri Public Service Corporation of $4,445,700 of first mortgage 5 per cent bonds, Series A, due 1960;

Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, the Long Island amateur champion, and Charles Whitehead of South River, N. J., routed their respective opponents in the first round of the Midwinter amateur golf championship at the Miami Country Club today. Other favorites also came through successfully, including Earl Christiansen of Miami, winner of the qualifying medal.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 442--Charles J. O'Connor, et al, petrs., v. A. Lawrence Mills, et al Submitted for both. 241--George Pope, Theo. Tsounias, et al, applts., v. L. W. Blanton, County Judge, et al. Argued for both.

The statement of Chancellor Adoli Hitler in Berlin yesterday and the similar assurances given on Saturday to representatives of the French Resident General by the Spanish Acting High Commissioner at Tetuan, Spanish Morocco, have had a reassuring effect on French opinion here.
Magistrate Anna M. Kross of New York City pleaded innocent here today to a charge of driving her motor car recklessly through a public school zone.

The Rev. L. Hamilton Garner, pastor of the Universalist Church of the Redeemer, whose Sunday night community forum has gained considerable recognition, was removed from his post by a vote of the parish early today, mainly on the ground the parishioners opposed the forum and other "radical" activities of the clergyman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt conscientiously makes the long journey to South America; saluting guns; cheering crowds; flower-strewn streets; polite hosts, careful to express only agreeable opinions; mutual expressions of regret at parting and promises of close and friendly intercourse.

Maxie Berger, Montreal lightweight, gained an eight-round decision over Johnny Bonito of Washington Heights in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 10,000 witnessed the encounter.

Amherst College, the Massachusetts General Hospital, the New England Deaconess Hospital and the Boston Museum of Fine Arts benefit substantially under the will of William A. Sargent of Brookline, which makes direct bequests totaling three-quarters of a million dollars.

Gold worth $21,252,000 was brought here from Spain today on the steamer Tramontane and was taken to the Marseilles branch of the Bank of France. It is expected to be sent to Paris to be deposited to the account of the Leftist administration, as previous shipments have been.

Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler entertained Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Glasgow of London at a dinner in their honor last night at the Butler home, 60 Morningside Drive. Mr. and Mrs. Glasgow are in New York for a short visit.

Rutland Boughton, much of whose music reflects the fascination that Arthurian legend holds for him, has written the poetry and music of "The Lily Maid," produced at the Winter Garden Theatre tonight, around the tragic romance of Sir Lancelot and Elaine.

Eddie Brannick, recovering slowly from the effects of the voluminous quantities of coffee he consumed during the course of the testimonial dinner the baseball writers tossed in his honor at the Hotel Commodore Monday night, was a picture of happiness yesterday. For the first of the contracts which the Giants recently
Opposition began at once to form today to the President's reorganization program as the full import of the vast changes proposed began to sink into Congressional consciousness.

Harvard defeated Brown, 7 to 1, tonight before a crowd of 4,000 to break Brown's undefeated record. The triumph was Harvard's fourteenth in a row and the seventh this season. Ford, Harding and Mechem, all members of the first forward line, tallied the Crimson goals. Harding excelled with three tallies and an assist.

The Tammany Hall executive committee met yesterday afternoon and, in a short and harmonious A session, adopted a resolution denying that any dissension existed within the organization and pledging a vigorous campaign for the election of all Democratic candidates next Fall.
Steel ingot production increased last week and the adjusted index advanced to 124.8 from 123.2 in the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 11. 1936. it Was 84.9.

The proposed New York State War Memorial was opposed yesterday at a luncheon of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects in the clubhouse of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. About forty architects adopted a resolution to change the character of the memorial.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fai- of 1939, told veterans of the Seventh Regiment last night at the Hotel Commodore that their regiment was known for its great bravery all over the world."

The Columbia University freshman basketball team triumphed over the Horace Mann School for Boys quintet, 27 to 19, on the losers' court yesterday. The victors held the upper hand throughout, leading by 16-10 at half time.

Fire, caused by wax being melted for repairing a plane, destroyed Hangar J and airplane equipment here at 3:45 o'clock this afternoon. The hangar, a twentyyear-old wooden structure, was valued at $20,000 and the equipment ruined at $10,000. .

The simplest rites, in the brief Protestant Episcopal version, were observed at the New York funeral yesterday afternoon of Robert Hazelhurst McAdoo, son of United States Senator William G. McAdoo, who died at his Fifty-fifth Street apartment here on Sunday night.

Pneumonia developing from a fall Christmas Eve caused today the death of Dr. William Henry Scott, former president of Ohio State and Ohio Universities. Dr. Scott died at his home here at the age of 96.

The Outdoor Cleanliness Association was the beneficiary of a dinner dance held last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. A fashion show and a pageant depicting women's dress through ages, entitled "La Femme Eternelle," were features of the entertainment.
Major Alan Pendleton, detailed to the office of the Inspector General, died at Walter Reed Hospital this morning. He was born at Bryn Anhyn, Pa., on July 1, 1893.

In the Customs and Patent Appeals Court J. M. Cole from New York was admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3746--Ex part Charles E. Hoover. Dismissed for failure of applt. to prosecute the same under the rules. 3713 and 3714--Joseph J. Daley v. Carl E. Trube and Joseph J. Daley v. Edward H. Loftin. Argued.

Governor La Follette returned from a week-end visit to Washington-today to find his Capitol swarming with legislators buzzing among themselves about the removal of Dr. Glenn Frank from the presidency of the State University.

Movement of billions of dollars' worth of gold was under way tonight, with the first consignment, shipped from the-Philadelphia mint, scheduled to reach the government's fortified strong box at Fort Knox, in -Kentucky, tomorrow morning.

Edwin P. Maynard, chairman of the Brooklyn division of the United Hospital Campaign, reported at the final luncheon meeting of all participating units at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday, total receipts of $136,376 toward a reduced quota of $150.000.

Mrs. Mary Harriet Robinson Case, a slight, attractive young woman of culture and talent and a retiring disposition, rarely left the Jackson Heights home in which she was brutally murdered except for occasional quiet evenings in town, friends said yesterday.

Stocks improved and closed irregular after early heaviness; turnover, 3,564,775 shares, largest since Nov. 5. United States Government bonds lower, corporate and foreign issues irregular; transactions, $16,287,000.

For metropolitan skating enthusiasts who didn't see the opening of the "Ice Follies of 1937" at the Madison Square Garden Monday night, tonight's repeat performance is highly recommended. It is a fast, spectacular show, a full evening's entertainment.

Stockholders of the First National Bank of New York, at their annual meeting yesterday, elected Leon Fraser, president of the bank, to the board of directors, thereby increasing the membership of the board to eleven. The ten retiring directors were re-elected.

Two airplanes, after a search of several hours over the wilds of Vera Cruz State, returned to Minatitlan, Vera Cruz, this afternoon and reported finding no trace of the Mexican Aviation Company's airliner that has been missing since yesterday morning with nine persons aboard.

Prince Alexis Mdivani, at the the time of his death on Aug. 1, 1935, had total assets of $796,162.39, it was revealed yesterday in an accounting filed by administrators of the estate in Surrogate's Court.

Mrs. James Breckenridge Curtis gave a tea yesterday at her home, 470 Park Avenue, for debutantes who are participating in the sale of seats for the performance of "High Tor" tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the New York Kindergarten Association.

A tense atmosphere, in which many feared the worst but hoped that no more violence would occur, settled down tonight over this city of 160,000 population, following last night's battle between the city police and stay-in strikers at Fisher Body Plant No. 2, a General Motors unit, in which at least twenty-eight persons were injured.

The Metropolitan Opera Association presented Camille Saint-Saens's opera "Samson et Dalila" last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as the second in a series of five performances in its Brooklyn season. Singing the principal roles were Mme. Wettergren and Maison, Pinza and Baromeo. Maurice de Abravanel conducted.
The French Government has taken note of the Harvard Tercentenary by conferring the order of Commander of the Legion of Honor on President Conant.

In the light of what has happened and is happening in other countries the President's committee on governmental reorganization cannot be accused of exaggeration when it says that democracy must modernize its equipment if it is to meet the test of present competition.

Reports of annual meetings of banks held here and in other places yesterday at which important changes were made follows: Grace National Bank The annual report of the Grace National Bank, presented to shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting in the bank's office, 7 Hanover Square, showed net income of $166,500 from operations in 1936, or $11.10 a share, compared with $163,697, or $10.91 a share, in 1935.

St. Augustine's High maintained its unbeaten record in the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. basketball race by turning back the Cathedral Prep five, 42 to 12, at Cathedral yesterday. It was the sixth straight victory for the pace-setters, who remained in first place.

Loew's, Inc., in its report for the twelve weeks to Nov. 19 last, shows a net profit of $3,457,978 after depreciation, taxes, subsidiaries' preferred dividends and other deductions. After preferred dividend requirements, the profit equals $2.14 each on the average number of common shares outstanding in the period.

Friends and associates of the late James O. Spearing, automobile editor and first motion picture critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, paid honor to his memory at services held yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.
Penn's 36-to-29 basketball victory over Yale tonight kept the Quakers at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League with three victories in as many games.

Frank McHale, who for forty-five years was associated with the Hill and later the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company in New York as manager of the technical books department, died here yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Charles Kloss, of the infirmities of old age.
Harvard's elongated varsity basketball team routed M. I. T. at the latter's court tonight, 44-27, to gain revenge for the unexpected victory the Engineers scored against the Crimson last season.

There is a distinct atmosphere of calm after the storm in European affairs following yesterday's exchange of pledges by Chancellor Hitler and Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador, recognizing the status quo in Spanish Morocco.

The General Telephone- Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 1,301 companyowned telephones in service for the month of December, compared with an lncrease of 955 in December, 1935.

88th St., 177 W., n. s., 16.8x100.8; also 73d St., 122 W., s. s., 16.8x102.2; also 16th St., 627 E., n. s.. 25x92; Benart Holding Corp. to Lynar Realty Corp., 222 W. 83d St. (30 cents). 5th Av., 2,131, e. s., 16.7x75; Lynar Realty Corp. to 2,103 Eighth Av. Corp., 222 W. 83d St. (10 cents).

Joseph Rose,' 64-year-old home relief recipient-who accused a friend of stealing $250,000 jewelry only to have the police find he had a valuable-collection of gems in a Jersey City vault, possesses another safety deposit box, Brooklyn authorities disclosed yesterday.
President Roosevelt has set aside by executive order an 8.42-acre area in Hampton Bays, Suffolk County, L. I., as a refuge and breeding ground for migratory birds and other wild life.
