Colonel E. L. Daley, district engineer of the First New York District, United States War Department, announced yesterday the receipt of an application from the New York City Park Department to construct a bridge across Plumb Beach Channel, an arm of Rockaway Inlet, in Brooklyn.

Bernardo Pedreira, 37 years old, of 501 West 107th Street, a Puerto Rican who tried to extort $1,000 in November, 1935, from Herbert L. Bodman, a grain broker in the Produce Exchange, was sentenced to an indeterminate penitentiary term of not more than three years by Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday.

The fire and marine insurance underwriters of Greater New York became the first trade, industrial or professional group to exceed their quota of the pre-fair financing issue they undertook to sell when they purchased $505,000 of the New York World's Fair debentures, it was revealed yesterday.
Ordinarily a prima donna's recital, especially if she be of the coloratura persuasion, is a repetition of hackneyed bravura pieces, all too usually done in a hackneyed way.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress his program for governmental reorganization, issued an. appeal for national cooperation in apprehending the Mattson kidnapper, received a suggested farm program from the Farm Bureau Federation, discussed the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty with diplomatic officials and others, and held, with Mrs. Roosevelt, the annual White House reception to the judiciary.

A personal allowance of $9,000 for 1937 for Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, from the estate of her twelve-year-old daughter, Gloria, heiress to millions, was granted yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley, in a decision on a recent petition by Mrs. Vanderbilt for this amount.

Officials of the City of New York, members of society from New York, Washington and Newport and people prominent in the various fields that had interested the late Frederic Kernochan, presiding justice of the Court of Special Sessions of New York, crowded St. Mary's Episcopal Church here this morning to attend his funeral services. Burial was in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

Extension of the use of the "consumers' protection label" to the dress and underwear industries was predicted yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania, held in conjunction with the opening of the semi-annual convention of the executive council of the National Recovery Board of the Coat and Suit Industry.

Final steps were taken yesterday to complete the merger of the National Investors companies into a single $40,000,000 mutual investment trust according to an announcement by Fred Y. Presley, president of the National Investors companies. The action supplements.

A new high point in the number of retail buyers visiting this city in a single day was reached yesterday with a total of 929 store representatives reported in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The previous peak was reached on Feb. 5, 1928, when 787 buyers were reported. On Tuesday a week ago the total registered was 421 and on the corresponding day in 1929 it was 598.

On the basis of estimates made by "competent architects, engineers, builders and material manufacturers," Dwight L. Hoopingarner, as executive head of the American Construction Council, reported yesterday that by the use of simple plans and restrictions of expenditures to basic conveniences it appeared feasible to erect modern apartments for low-income families at a cost of between $700 and $800 a room.

When and if, with the consent of an alreadystunned and anxious Congress, the President recruits the six executive assistants "with a passion for anonymity" to perform the task outlined for them today by his Committee on Administrative Management, he will have discovered six Brother Josephs to his Richelieu, six Jonathans to his David, six eremites the like of whom Washington did not know existed.
Major Leonard Rider Gracy, bridge expert and editor of "Game Rules" for the United States Playing Card Company, died today of pneumonia at Mountainside Hospital. He was stricken six days ago.
Tonight's newcomer is the one called "Behind Red Lights," bearing the signature of Samuel Shipman and Beth Brown and said to be derived from the latter's novel, "For Men Only."
Premier Benito Mussolini, who has been a civilian pilot ever since the early days of aviation, brilliantly passed today a much more difficult examination necessary to become a military pilot.

Colgate conquered the St. Lawrence basketball team by 39-36 tonight in a fast game. Trailing at half-time by four points, the Colgate team, led by Debus, managed to forge ahead during a rally in the closing minutes of play.

Many full floors were involved in the commercial space reported leased yesterday. The International Printing Ink Corporation has taken a floor containing approximately 35,000 square feet in the Midtown Industrial Building, 628-44 Eleventh Avenue, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent, and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

New Traffic Code The new traffic code has been' reprinted from the City Record and may be had, in pamphlet form, at the Office of the Board of City Record, Room 2213, Municipal Building, Manhattan, for 10 cents a copy.

Plans for a six-story apartment to cost $160,000 in the Bronx and for a forty-eignt family house to cost $100,000 in Kew Gardens were among the projects filed by architects yesterday. The list follows:

Officials of Nassau County, L. I., have invited tenders for a new issue of $3,500,000 of land-purchase, emergency relief, public works, hospital and general county bonds, award of which will be made on Jan. 21.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 11: Dougherty, Col. C. A., Cav., Fort Oglethorpe. Ga., to the Philippine Department, to sail from New York about March 18. Tinker. Col. C. L. (Lt. Col.), Air Corps, attached to Boiling Field, Anacosta, D. C., for flying duty only, in addition to hid duties in the office of the Chief National Guard Bureau.
The whole story of this democratic and industrial civilization is summed up in the adventure of the one-eyed Negro driver and his $5
More than 300 persons were killed and several thousand wounded yesterday in an intense attack from sea and air on Malaga, Spain, by Rebel naval and aviation forces.
Wesleyan won from Middlebury at basketball tonight, 35 to 16. The game was Wesleyan's all the way, the half ending with the Cardinals leading by 21 to 7.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 11, unless specified: At Nawlliwili: Lark, Quall, Tanager. Balch, Guayaquil to Callao, Peru. Cummings. New York Yard to sea, Jan, 12. Cuyama, at San Pedro, Jan. 12.
The National Labor Relations Board received testimony today that the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation dictated the policy of the employes' representation plan.

A "banker-utilities-political combine" controlled by J. P. Morgan Co. of New York has been responsible for the unfavorable freight rate differential suffered for many years by Philadelphia, Mayor Wilson charged today.

Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor Jr. of Indian Field Road, Greenwich, vice chairman of the Greenwich Republican Town Committee, tendered her resignation today in a letter to Harold W. Allen, chairman of the committee.

Tearing off his evening clothes, John Murray Begg, 34 years old, a radio editor, 25 Sutton Place South, dived into the East River from a pier at the foot of Fifty-fourth Street at 1 o'clock this morning and rescued Mrs. Virginia Copeland, 30, who had been living at the Sutton Hotel, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street.
The Royal colors were carried to victory for the first time in King George VI's reign today when His Majesty's 5-year-old gelding Marconi won the two-mile Smethwick Handicap Steeplechase.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull returns today from Buenos Aires on the Southern Cross of the Munson Line at the head of the United States delegation to the InterAmerican Conference for the Consolidation of Peace, held recently in the capital of Argentina.

One reel of "X-ray talkies" recording the sounds of heartbeats and the murmur of diseased valves will be shown at the Pacific Coast Surgical Congress, opening in Seattle, Wash., Feb. 25, by Dr. Kunio Kawaishi, Assistant Professor of Surgery at Nagoya Medical College, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi.

The Newark Newspaper Guild was temporarily restrained today by Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow from removing the name of Jacob Mogelever, city editor of The Newark Ledger, from its rolls, and from stating to the American Newspaper Guild that he had been expelled.

William C. Hunt of Cape May County literally seated himself as a member of the New Jersey Senate today and thereby gave the Republicans control of the 1937 annual session by a bare majority of 11 to 10.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding were hosts at tea and cocktails today at Chiora. In celebration of their wedding anniversary Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry had a dinner tonight at their home.

William Carroll Wilson, floor member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Finch, Wilson Co., died yesterday at his home here after a year's illness. Born in East Orange, Mr. Wilson had been a resident of Montclair for twenty years.

Senator Royal S. Copeland of New York, introduced a resolution today requesting the President to enter into an agreement with the German Government for the settlement of 3,233 unadjudicated claims of American nationals.
Option agreements by various companies and their officers were disclosed yesterday in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

William H. Kilpatrick, general manager of the Chrysler Motor Parts Corporation and a close friend and business associate of Walter P. Chrysler in the automobile industry for many years, died at the William Taylor Hotel here today.
Red Dutton's almost vanishing Americans sent a rude shock into the system of the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan rebuked two city departments yesterday for delaying for "months and at times for years" in answering suits for reduction of assessments, and for "ignoring orders of the court" in a way that "threatens disaster to democratic government." Justice Callahan said the delays appeared to be deliberately planned "for reasons of administrative policy."

The first wool auction sales this year opened today with crowded attendance, and offerings totaled 8,791 bales, of which 7,746 were sold. The good selection offered was freely taken by all leading traders, and withdrawals were negligible.
Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "The Oriental Collection: Far East," General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Inproduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.
Stewart Hartshorn, manufacturer and founder of the community of Short Hills, died here today of pneumonia, at the age of 96.

MANHATTAN BARTNETT, WALTER J. (Aug. 26. 1935). Gross assets, $76,641; net, $69,059. To Frances G. Bartnett, widow, residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, , $55,912. MacFarland, Taylor Costello, attorneys, 74 Trinity P1.

What was believed to be the largest fine for passing a red light was imposed yesterday upon Kenneth Carroad, 26 years old, a lawyer, of 35 East Ninth Street, when Magistrate Samuel M. Katz in Traffic Court fined him $50. Carroad asked for time to pay, and got until Friday.

Mrs. Anna Fishman, 45 years old, of 102 East 105th Street, was killed at 8:10 o'clock last night by a westbound Lexington Avenue bus in front of 126 East 103d Street. The bus at this point in its run detours via 103d Street, Park Avenue and 102d Street to avoid the steep incline known as Duffy's Hill on Lexington Avenue between 102d and 103d Streets.

Discussing the possibilities of inflation, Walter E. Frew, chairman of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that he thought the country "could stand" a national debt of about $35,000,000,000.

Additional awards were announced yesterday for the entrants in the third exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today, now being held at the W. J. Sloane shop, Forty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. The exhibit is being held for the benefit of the New York Association for the Blind.

Colonel Alfred A. Chandler, former chief secretary of the Eastern Territory of the Salvation Army, in which he served for half a century, died last night in the Booth Memorial Hospital, East Fifteenth Street, after an illness of three weeks, at the age of 71. His widow, Elizabeth, who joined the Army in Boston in 1899, and a married daughter, survive.

Eight exhausted sailors, scrambling ashore from a surfsmashed lifeboat on South Ronaldshay beach, brought news today that the brand-new Finnish motorship Johanna Thorden, 3,223 tons, returning to Helsingfors from New York on her maiden voyage, had foundered on the Island of Swona or the Island of Stroma, in Pentland Firth, early today.

The annual Wagner matinee cycle of six operas at the Metropolitan Opera House will begin on Tuesday afternoon, Feb. 9. The cycle will include "Der Ring des Nibelungen" without cuts, a performance of "Die Meistersinger" and another work to be selected later.

Operations of the BancamericaBlair Corporation in 1936 resulted in net profits realized and booked of approximately $3,200,000 before estimated Federal income taxes of $481,500. At the close of the year assets appreciated about $1,394,000, compared with about $256,000 at the beginning of 1936.

Casper Abruzzi, New York welterweight, easily outpointed Nathan Boddick of Scotland in an eightround bout at Braddock Arena in Jersey City last night, according to The . Associated Press. Abruzzi weighed 150 pounds, Boddick 148.

The first magazine to appear in the British colonies in America, "The American Magazine, or a Monthly View of the Political State of the British Colonies," will be republished in a facsimile volume by Columbia University Press next month.

The National City Bank of New York in 1936 earned $13,243,674, exclusive of recoveries, but after deducting customary reserves amounting to $2,163,000 and reserves for depreciation of bank premises of $1,721,000, James H. Perkins, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The American Surety Company of New York in its report for 1936 showed total earnings of $2,519,312. This included $778,542 net income from investments, after providing $100,000 for depreciation of the home office building;
Transfers and Asalgnments LIEUTENANT-Frederlck G. Norman, 5th Division, assignment changed from supof visor of plainclothes patrolmen to.clerioal duty.
President Frank W. Johnson of Colby College, now attending educational conferences in Washington, today named Alfred M. McCoy to succeed Eddie Roundy as head football coach.

Senator A. Harry Moore or New Jersey said today that one of his major objectives in the present Congress would be legislation to prevent discrimination against applicants for civil service jobs because of age.

President Roosevelt, declaring that the "ghastly crime" had "shocked the nation," announced today a search for the Mattson kidnapper that "will be pursued relentlessly and will not be terminated until the murderer is caught."

MANHATTAN BRENNER, JOSEPH G. (Jan. 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 1,560 Amsterdam Av., Trudeau Sanitarium, Saranac Lake, N. Y., New Rochelle Hospital, Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 462 Madison Av., St. Benedict's Church, 342 W. 53d St.,
The highest weekly registration of buyers since 1929 was listed during the week ended yesterday, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the second of the state receptions of the season, entertaining in honor of the Chief Justice and Associate Justices of the United States Supreme Court and other members of the judiciary and their wives.

Miss Laura Liebman, president of the WPA Teachers Union, Local 453, of the American Federation of Teachers, has been denied a license by the Board of Examiners to teach English in the city high schools. This became known yesterday when Herman E. Cooper, counsel for the union, which has frequently differed with school and WPA officials on questions of policy, asked the board to grant a hearing on Miss Liebman's qualifications.
Several varieties of early blooming flowers have mistaken the recent warm weather for the coming of Spring, according to officials of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

The board of directors of the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company has extended from Jan. 15, until the close of business on March 13, the period within which the company's second preferred stock may be deposited for exchange into the new senior $5 convertible preferred stock and common stock under the plan for rearrangement of capitalization, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Charles Tutenberg of this place has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Emily Regina Abel, to Robert Lawrence Balzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Balzer of Beverly Hills, Calif. The wedding took place Dec. 24 in the Church of St. Mary Abbots, London, England..

Early sales of hogs-here today were steady to10 cents a hundredweight lower, but most, of. the late trading was at a decline of 10 to 20 cents, with some sales regarded as 25 cents. lower. Prospects of colder weather failed to have any effect on the market.

Despite continuing threats and blusterings, it has become evident that the government is hesitant about actually opening a new civil war by attacking General Yang Fu-Cheng and his Sian, Shensi Province, associates.

Gifts of $259 from fourteen contributors increased the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to a grand total of $269,644.18. "Here is my mite for the Hundred Neediest," wrote Albert Field, enclosing $2. "Every time I spend any money foolishly or needlessly, I set aside an equal sum for some one less fortunate than I.

Mrs. Alfred Bell, this place, gave a luncheon bridge today for Mrs. Huyler Held, Mrs. Walter Proom, Mrs. Charles Vanderveer, Mrs. Charles Roever, Mrs. James Addison Jr., Mrs. Richard Stoever, Mrs. Cornelius Reid and Mrs. Lee Albertson.

Contributions totaling $455,000 were reported to the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Socities at a final campaign rally yesterday afternoon at the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue.

Missourians, in a teapot tempest over Thomas Hart Benton's startling murals in the State Capitol lounge, can say what they will, but Mr. Benton wants it known that he did not use $2,751 worth of eggs in painting them.
Frank J. Clark of 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Kathleen Alicia Clark, to Chester J. Maxson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Maxson of Buffalo.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that A. W. Morris Co. would have membership on the Exchange. The partners in the new firm are A. W. Morris and Arthur Morris, a member of the Exchange.

The Guaranty Trust Company is prepared to deliver definitive Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company refunding and improvement mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series E, due Aug. 1, 1996, in exchange for temporary bonds.

The forty-five players entered in the women's annual metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship completed two rounds at the Colony Club yesterday, and one of the seeded entrants, Mrs. Leonard Marshall of Bronxville, went ahead of the rest of the field into the fourth round.

Senator Copeland, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, held a hearing this afternoon at which striking seamen proposed that certain features of the Copeland Maritime Act be changed. At its close the Senator said "real progress" had been made, that objections to the discharge book were not as serious as they had appeared to be before the hearing and that he thought certain other changes requested might well be made.

Skeletons of sixteen victims of the destruction of Pompeii in 79 A. D. were unearthed today, apparently lying where they had fallen while striving to flee the erupting volcano Vesuvius. Two of the skeletons were those of children.
Orders received by the General Electric Company in 1936 amounted to $296,748,219, or 37 per cent more than those of $217,361,587 in 1935, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday.

The nominating committee of the American Kennel Club yesterday submitted the names of Harry I. Caesar, Class of 1940, Clement M. Burnhome, Thomas H. Carruthers 3d and William R. Tucker, Class of 1941, as candidates for the board of directors at the directors' monthly meeting.
Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell has returned to 399 Park Avenue from Miami Beach, where she passed the holidays with her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell Jr.

The volume of sales of reporting chain store companies set a new record in December, and, with the exception of 1929, the business of the systems was the largest of any year in their history, according to the monthly compilation released yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

Frank Fischer, 53 years old, who had just completed a term in the City Prison on Riker's Island, was taken to Albany yesterday after being questioned by Albany and Bronx detectives in the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. in 1933.
Dr. Alexander Lee Bondurant, dean emeritus of the University of Mississippi Graduate School, died today of heart attack. His age was 71.

The first step in a concerted move by the five railroad transportation brotherhoods to bring about a general wage increase for nearly 300,000 railway employes who are members of the unions was taken here today.
St. Joseph's Church sold the fourstory house at 107 Jackson Street, Hoboken, N. J., to Hyman Barak, who intends to renovate the eightfamily structure. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Shipments of all types of hosiery during November amounted to 10,846,335 dozen pairs, compared with 12,234,846 dozen pairs in the preceding month and 10,231,026 dozen pairs in November, 1935, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Donaid Budge, the nation's No. 1 ranking tennis player, advanced easily today toward what he hopes is a second meeting with Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta giant-killer, who defeated him in straight sets at Coral Gables last week.

Charles S. Grant, vice president of the Draeger Shipping Company, was elected president of the New York Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association at the annual dinner meeting held last night at Essex House, 160. Central Park South.

Edward Harvey Lee, former president of the Chicago Western Indiana Railway, died last night at his home, 341 Belden Avenue, from a heart attack after a brief illness from influenza. He was 73 year old.

Turpentine firm, 43 1/2c; sales 71 barrels; receipts 136 barrels, Shipments 211 barrels; stock 31,448 barrels. Resin firm; sales 1,336; receipts 1,426; shipments 2,119 stock 76,334. Quote: B, $10-$10.10; D, $10.05-$10.10; E, $10.25-$10.40; F, $10.45-$10.50: G to N, $10.50-$10.60; WG, $12; WW, X, $13.

By THOMAS F. BURCHILL. Madison Av., 1,514, 103d St., 22-24 E., three 5-story tenements and stores, 100.11x70; Mutual Life Insurance Co. against Friedman-Jacobi Real Estate Co.; due, $108,874; to plaintiff for $50,000.

While business failures increased in the retail and wholesale groups in the five business days ended Jan. 7, compared with the previous holiday period, there was a decline in the manufacturing division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
After stabbing himself through the heart, and then failing in an attempt to throw himself from the window of his fourth floor room, Thomas Thornton Hart,

A more hopeful view of the international situation in addition to optimistic overnight reports from Wall Street reacted favorably upon the stock market here today. Although the volume of trading was on only a fair scale, prices in most groups of securities were higher.

Ernie Dusek, Nebraska heavyweight, last night threw Hank Barber of Cambridge, Mass., with a flying tackle in 51 minutes 19 seconds of their wrestling struggle before 2,000 at the St. Nicholas Palace. Dusek weighed 228 pounds and Barber 220.
Manhunters, spurred by public wrath said and Presidential action, pursued an almost microscopic search of the Everett area tonight for the trail of Charles Mattson's kidnap-killer.
Dr. Vladimir Matchek said today that the recent amnesty decree of the Belgrade government was "the biggest swindle perpetrated by any Yugoslav Government since 1928."
Sir John Aird, dean of Canadian banking, today announced his retirement from the presidency of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. He will be succeeded by S. H. Logan, general manager since 1926.
Shooting accurately, Lehigh's basketball team swung into winning stride tonight and overwhelmed Haverford. 56 to 20.

With the price of United States middling cotton advancing yesterday in Liverpool to the highest quotations of the season and an estimate by the Cotton Exchange Service here that domestic mills used 685,000 bales last month, a record for a December, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 11 points and closed at the top.

Larry Kelley, Clint Frank and all he other boys in Blue who did so much to add to the gayety and spice of the 1936 football season will assemble at the Waldorf-Astoria tonight for a Heigh-Ho from Rudy Vallee,

In his first discussion of Resettlement Administration affairs since its inclusion within his department, Secretary Wallace today set as the primary objective of the agency "the maximum of security for the farmers at the bottom of the pile" that make up two-thirds of the total farm population.
The 1936 horse-racing picture was a bright one. From Seattle to Miami, and from Los Angeles to Salem, N. H., there was more racing activity than this country ever before had seen.

The sum of $16,950.09 in contributions was reported yesterday by campaign workers in the annual drive of the Young Women's Christian Association, which is seeking $200,000 to complete its 1937 budget. The contributions, reported at a luncheon held at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A. 610 Lexington Avenue, brought the total raised thus far to S149.246.68.

Banking officials of the government conferred with Secretary Morgenthau today, principally concerning technical features of the banking laws. Among the conferees were Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency;

With Democratic cooperation, the Republicans, after another day of caucus and conference, late this afternoon effected organization of the Assembly by electing as speaker Assemblyman Oswald D. Heck of Schenectady, floor leader at the 1936 session.
Britain's influenza epidemic is still rising and is spreading from south to north, but the areas of infection are becoming patchy.
Four leases of entire buildings for commercial purposes, three in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, were reported yesterday by brokers.
The City Athletic Club team held its undefeated pace at the top of Group 2 in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association when play was resumed yesterday after nearly a month's vacation.

No further disclosures on the Soviet military establishment were made at today's sessions of the Soviet Central Executive Committee and officials discouraged speculation as to whether this meeting would witness another announcement of an increase in the Red Army's man power.

Realty transactions in Queens reported yesterday included sales of properties and a large lease in sections close to the World's Fair grounds and to the recently opened extension of the municipal subway.

FIRST ROUND Miss Nancy Putnam defeated Mrs. M. Bailey Clark, 15-5, 15-9, 15-4; Mrs. Roger Walcott defeated Mrs. William A. Strong, 15-10, 15-5, 8-15, 15-8; Miss Dorothy Schierenberg defeated Miss Constance Chambers, 15-8, 15--9, 15-6; Mrs. Tudor Simpkins won from Mrs. W. Black by default; Mrs. H. G. Burks defeated Miss Eleanor Dommerich, 15-11, 15-6, 15--10; Miss Katherine Webb won from Mrs. J. K. Crimmins by default.
By HENRY BRADY Carpenter Av., 4.433, 25x100; State Mortgage Commission against United States Co. Buildings. Inc.; due, $21,113; taxes, , $298; to plaintiff for $1,000.

A Negro porter, Major Green, 33 years old, of 68 West 118th Street, admitted early today that he was the slayer of Mrs. Mary Robinson Case in her apartment at 37-06 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, on Monday.
Mayor La Guardia hopes to link the country's non-commercial radio stations into a new broadcasting chain, with New York's municipal station WNYC as one of the links.

Mrs. Mary Odell Reismann, 23year-old former assistant postmaster of North Bellmore, L. I., who pleaded guilty Jan. 7 to embezzling $2,168 of postoffice funds, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in jail. She has repaid $768 of the stolen funds.

Functions of the government departments under the proposed reorganization would be as follows: STATE To advise the President on foreign affairs, conduct international relations and guard State documents.
Thomas D. Flynn of the Princeton Club accounted for an upset as the ninth annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament reached the quarter-final stage at the Yale Club yesterday.

United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery left Havana by airplane this afternoon for Miami, Fla., whence he will go by train to Washington to confer with the State Department concerning the Cuban situation. He expects to return to Havana in about ten days.
Shareholders of forty-five banks in Chicago and Cook County held their annual meetings today and elected officers for the new year. Few important changes were made.

The government's new import control regulations have so seriously disturbed markets that various commodity exchanges in Osaka and Tokyo have closed temporarily. Among these is the Sampen Exchange in Osaka, which handles raw cotton purchases.

The summary of the report by the President's Committee on Administrative Management in the government, as given out by the White House, was as follows: SUMMARY OF THE PRESIDENT'S COMMITTEE'S REPORT ON ADMINISTRATIVE MANAGEMENT IN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES, JANUARY, 1937.

Brook Av. (9-2287), w. s., 50 ft. n. of 142d St., 50x90; Sands Estate Corp. to Lance Realty Corp., 376 Powers Av. Popham Av. (11-2877), e. s., 288 ft. n. of 176th St., 81x100; Frances K. Whinston to Sagol Realty Corp., 975 Walton Av.

Establishments engaged primarily in the manufacture of -sporting and athletic goods, numbering 196, had total net sales of $34,987,000 in 1935, with $33,628,000 of the total representing sales through channels of primary distribution, the Census Bureau reported today.

Cecil B. De Mille's epic horse opera, "The Plainsman," a story of early Americana and the romance between Wild Bill Hickok and Calamity Jane, goes on exhibition this morning at the Paramount. Adapted from a story by Courtney Riley Cooper and the Hickok biography by Frank J. Wilstach, the film is played by Gary Cooper, Jean Arthur, James Ellison, Helen Burgess, Charles Bickford, John Miljan and Frank McGlynn.

The proposal to grade gasoline in New York State has begun to attract the attention of national advertisers, who are wondering what effect such a step would have on the effectiveness of brand. promo'tion.

Fifty artists, writers and editors returned yesterday afternoon to the rooming house at 61 Washington Square South, where they lived in their not-so-famous days, to attend a funeral service for Mme. Catherine R. Branchard, proprietor of the house for half a century.

The Municipal Art Committee has arranged in its Temporary Galleries at 62 West Fifty-third Street a retrospective exhibition that serves to summarize the activities of the gallery since its career began one year ago.

For the second consecutive day an advance of 20 points was made yesterday in the price of zinc. The new price at East St. Louis now is 6 cents a pound, the highest since November, 1929. The metal for forward deliveries is quoted at a substantial premium.

Distilled Liquors Corporation yesterday announced plans for turning over to Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., the distributorship for Hildick applejack brandy and the William Penn brands of straight and blended whiskies.

Edward C. Delafield announced yesterday that he was about to resign as vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company to become a member of Delafield Delafield, a brokerage firm which has been organized to begin business on Feb. 1. He will remain a member of the executive committee and of the board of the trust company.

Failure of the city to provide a budget item of $45,000 and withdrawal of a group of WPA workers, means that each day during the next year a fourth of the halls of the American Museum of Natural History must be kept closed to the public, Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, the director, said last night.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 535 Park Av. is fully rented, according to Pease Elliman, agents. J. L. Brandmarker again has opened a realty office in the Marble Hill section, at 5,227 Broadway.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading in non-kosher meats was uneven. Some cuts were in fair to good demand, others sold slowly.

Scoring ten successive points, St. Peter's of Jersey City came from behind to defeat Upsala tonight, 34-31. The score was 18-18 at the half. With five minutes left to play, St. Peter's trailed. 24-31.

Another charge that Swift Co. extended long periods of credit to restaurants, hotels and institutions without granting the same terms to retailers was made yesterday at the second session of a hearing in which the meat-packing concern is answering a complaint of unfair trade practices.
A million dollars worth of horses will begin to compete tomorrow for $400,000 in purses and stakes as Hialeah Park opens its forty-six-day meeting, the most important in the South.

Causes underlying the poor pheasant shooting, general throughout the Northeastern States during the past gunning season, will be analyzed at the annual session of the North American Game Breeders Association at the Waldorf-Astoria today.

A sevenpoint farm program, involving thirteen recommendations for new laws or continuance of temporary ones which otherwise will expire soon, was handed to President Roosevelt today by a delegation representing the American Farm Bureau Federation.

Lee Rosenberg's Kerry Patch, 7-year-old comeback horse with a Belmont Futurity to his credit, drove to a two-length victory in the Indian River Class C. Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature today, which brought to an end the most successful early Winter meeting in the history of Tropical Park.

The engagement of $1,232,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported no Imports or other transactions affecting the monetary gold stocks here.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced after a conference today with Homer Martin, president of the International Union, Automobile Workers of America, and other aides that it had been agreed to ask a Congressional investigation of the General Motors Corporation.

Here is a summary of the five-point program of government reorganization proposed by the President: 1. Consolidate all boards, commissions, corporations and agencies of the Federal Government under twelve major departments, the two new ones being social welfare and public works. Change name of Interior Department to "Conservation."

Today's proceedings in the patent infringement suit of the Julius Kayser Company, large manufacturers of women's silk hosiery, and the Textile Patents Corporation against the Rosedale Knitting Company, were taken up with testimony from technical witnesses for the plaintiff.
The Chicago Board of Trade had a loss of $132,730 in the year ended on Jan. 4, against one of $138,339 in the preceding year,

Mrs. Gertrude Hocheiser, 54 years old, a widow and proprietor of a women's dress shop here, was injured fatally at 7:45 o'clock tonight when struck by an automobile as she was crossing Montauk Highway near her home on Fire Island Avenue in this village.
Governor Lehman renewed his plea today for a "sound" minimum wage law for women and children in industry as the Senate prepared to pass the Social Security Bill tomorrow.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the following securities, which either have been called for redemption or have matured, have been stricken from listing and registration:

Borough President Samuel Levy's suggestion that a super-retail district be set up in Manhattan was endorsed yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association, which in the last year opposed eight attempts to introduce motion picture theatres on Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues. It is in this section Mr. Levy would have such a zone set up.

Authority to refinance $5,000,000 of bonded indebtedness of the Union Terminal of Dallas, Texas, through issuance of a like amount of new first mortgage bonds was requested of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by trustees of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company of Texas.

Others may have forgotten that a Mayor of New York is to be elected this year but Tammany has not. It is already making plans for what it hopes will be a return to its old home in the City Hall. First there are questions of party organization to be settled.
The explosion of a bomb near the office of Father Joseph Ledit, American priest who organized an anti-Communist exposition here, was disclosed tonight-nearly a month after the incident.

The basketball teams of Seward Park, De Witt Clinton and Abraham Lincoln registered their fifth straight victories yesterday to strengthen their holds on first place in their respective divisions of the Public Schools Athletic League.

The two outstanding sprinters of the new track season, Marty Glickman of Syracuse and Herbert Weast of Columbia, have been matched for the 60-yard sprint feature at the thirtieth annual Millrose A. A. games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz.
The Canadiens tightened their hold on the lead in the National Hockey League's International Division tonight by beating Detroit, American Group pace-setter, 4 to 1.
Plans for Inauguration Day at the White House were announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt. They include a luncheon for 400 or 500 gue? and a tea for "thousands" after the parade.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Burrell Hornby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Hornby of this place, to Lieutenant John de Peyster Hills, United States Army Air Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy D. Hills of Albany, N. Y.
The entire evening on next Tuesday of the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will be devoted to problems of consumer relations, it was announced yesterday.

Sales for the year 1936 of the J. C. Penney Company were the largest annual volume in its history, exceeding the previous high record which was established in 1935. The total for last year was $258,325,311, an increase of 14.34 per cent over 1935, when sales amounted to $225.936,101.
The Naval Historical Foundation announced today receipt of a gift of 1,500 naval prints, valued at $60,000, from Mrs. F. Eberstadt of New York.

Although Leopold Atlas is writing about a vital subject in "But For the Grace of God," which was put on at the Guild Theatre last evening, the play is strangely lacking in vitality. It is difficult on short notice to say why.
Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden lost no time tonight in welcoming and echoing the words of peace uttered by Chancellor Adolf Hitler at yesterday's reception to the diplomatic corps in Berlin.

United States Government bonds sustained the sharpest decline yesterday of the current downward movement in those issues, losses ranging from 1-32 to 18-32 of a point on a turnover of-only $1,116,000, compared to sales of $1,369,000 on Monday.
Deals for apartment properties on the upper West Side of Manhattan featured the realty sales reported in Manhattan yesterday.
Testifying before the royal inquiry commission today, Haj Amin el Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem, said Palestine Arabs' demands were:

A new treatment for dementia praecox, one of the most prevalent and serious forms of insanity, was said last night by eminent American psychiatrists to offer greater promise for the alleviation of the malady than any treatment available so far.
The New York Building Congress joined the Merchants Association of New York yesterday in urging the early enactment of the proposed new Building Code for the city.

Carlos Chavez, director of the Orquesta Sinfonica de Mexico, arrived yesterday from Mexico to prepare for his appearance as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra. Mr. Chavez will make the first of six appearances with the Philharmonic on Thursday evening, Feb. 11.

All payments of the final installment of the city's 2 per cent sales tax for 1936 must be made by midnight Friday, Controller Frank J. Taylor warned yesterday. Delinquents are subject to a 5 per cent penalty.
Plans for a new building for the Fulton fish market are being considered by the Department of Markets.
Mrs. Marshall Perry Slade has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Helen Elizabeth Crosby of Rhinebeck, N. Y., to Lewis Bates McCabe of Garrison, N. Y.
Bids were opened yesterday by the Board of Water Supply for the sinking of shafts for the water tunnel of the $273,000,000 Delaware Water Supply project.

The League of Nations observers sent here in connection with the FrancoTurkish dispute. over the Alexandretta district were loudly acclaimed by Turkish sympathizers. More than 15,000 demonstrated their pro-Turkish feelings by a parade in pouring rain.
Most of us think of BERTRAND RUSSELL as the most modern-minded of men. He is always abreast of the latest developments in science, morals and social reform.
The delegates to the Pan-American Press Conference motored to Santiago this morning and were received by President Arturo Alessandri in Moneda Palace.
The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Jan. 9: LIEUTENANT CORMANDER Smith, R. H., the Bonita. to Naval OPerations, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.

The average net income of- a farmer in the Upnited States in 1935 was $1,001, acceding to a study, made public last night by, the National Industrial Confer-ence Board. The farm income wascompared to an average wage of $1,041 in the same year of a fully employed factory worker.

A strong indication that President Roosevelt would again urge ratification of the St. Lawrence Waterway treaty by the Senate at this session of Congress was seen today in a conference held at the White House, although all those present declined to discuss the conversation.

The Board of Aldermen unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday calling for the appointment of a joint committee of Aldermen and members of the Board of Estimate fo lay before the Legislature a plan, yet to be formulated, for the relief of dwellers in old-law tenements.
The Government of Panama has decided to intensify its efforts toward collective control of malaria in the republic,

The Schola Cantorum, under the direction of Hugh Ross, will be heard tonight at Carnegie Hall. Bernard Gabriel, pianist, will lecture on "The Piano Music of Present-Day Composers," tonight at the Sherman Square Studios.

In the last few days of fairly heavy trading in securities with first one group of companies showing strength and then another, some shrewd observers of the market maintain that there has been quite a bit of liquidation.

After suffering two straight defeats, the St. John's University quintet returned to the victory column when it conquered Niagara University, 41 to 27, before a capacity crowd in the De Gray gymnasium last night. It was the eighth triumph of the year for the Redmen.

William Webb Davis, commuter for years, was found dead in bed today at his home here, 30 Hillside Avenue. Death was attributed to a heart ailment from which Mr. Davis had suffered for several years. He was 75 years old.

Albert Hirsh appeared in piano recital at the Town Hall last night, disclosing a grasp of technical problems that would be astonishing if so many other young artists did not display similar accomplishments.

Dr. Robert P. Ball, formerly director of laboratories in the Baroness Erlanger and Children's Hospitals, Chattanooga, Tenn., has been appointed Assistant Professor of Radiology at the Columbia University School of Medicine, Dean Willard C. Rappleye disclosed yesterday. He will take over his duties immediately.

The German Zeppelin airship Hindenburg is scheduled to make eighteen visits to the United States this year under the plans of Dr. Hugo Eckener if his proposals receive the approval of the United States Government.

Stricken with a heart attack here late last night following his arrival to attend the New York State Horticultural Society's annual meeting, Professor Cyrus R. Crosby, nationally recognized authority on spiders, died while being rushed to a hospital.

Acetylene lamps, tugboat searchlights and hand flashlights provided a weird illumination in the frosty early hours of yesterday morning as thirty-eight workmen of the American Bridge Company took advantage of the rising tide to begin to swing into place the 3,600-ton central span of the new $3,750,000 Marine Parkway Bridge across Rockaway Inlet.

Dropping long putts throughout, Joseph Schenck of New York chalked up the easiest victory in the first round of match play for the Lake Worth championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He overwhelmed E. L. Beard Jr. of Flushing, L. I., 7 and 6, relinquishing but one hole of the twelve played.

The text of President Roosevelt's government reorganization message to Congress was as follows: I address this message to the Congress as one who has had experience as a legislator, as a subordinate In an executive department, as the Chief Executive of a State and as one on whom, as President, the constitutional responsibility for the whole of the executive branch of the govern-ment has lain for four years.

Lieut. Col. Crawford Blagden, World War veteran of the 307th Infantry, who helped rescue the Lost Battalion in the Argonne Forest in October, 1918, died at midnight Monday night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 168th Street and Broadway, at the age of 55.

The formal casting of a single ballot by the secretary swept into office yesterday Orie R. Kelly as president of the New York Athletic Club and marked the completion of the eminently successful stewardship of William A. Dalton as head of the largest athletic club in the world.

Leon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader in exile here, charged Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, with sabotaging the Spanish "revolution." He asserted today that only enough Soviet help was being sent to Spain to salve the feelings of the laboring people of the world and that full measures were not being taken because the Soviet Government desired to save the feelings of the French bourgeoisie and other allies.

After he had inquired whether he was on the top floor of the building, Michael Gondar, 45 years old, of 609 West 158th Street, leaped from a window yesterday on the twenty-second floor of the Hotel New Weston, 34 East Fiftieth Street, and was killed when his bodly struck the second-floor extension, in an inner court.

An unusual picketing campaign, designed to force employers to enlarge employment opportunities, is being conducted jointly by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the American Federation of Actors.

Daily gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,117,800 barrels, compared with 3,121,400 in the previous week, a decline of 3,600, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Frank Buesser Sr. of 68 East Ninetieth Street, a retired lieutenant of the New York Police Department, died yesterday morning in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness at the age of 81.

Investigators and accountants working from the office of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, have subpoenaed the books of two large unions associated with the cleaning and dyeing trade, it was learned yesterday.

To supply the anticipated demand for proof of age in connection with Social Security benefits, the Census Bureau began today copying, in microscopic size, on film, the 50,000,000 names recorded in the 1,024 volumes of the 1880 census.

While the demand for serum in the treatment of pneumonia is-twice as great as it was last year, and that used for some of the rarer types of pneumonia may become exhausted. the supply of serum used in the two most prevalent types of the disease, coming from city, State and commercial sources, will be sufficient to meet the Winter's demand, Dr. John L Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

THE esteemed manager of the Montreal Maroons of the hockey circuit, "Tay Pay" Gorman, was having a dish of tea without interrupting the flow of conversation, which was all oneway. One of the helpful things about "Tay Pay" is that he is never at a loss for a few thousand words and most of them are nice, kind words. The following incomplete transcription is offered of notes made during the great flood:
Fifth and Park Avenues and the upper East Side residential area figured prominently in the apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday.
A new issue of 100,000 shares of common stock of Automobile Finance Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., will be placed on the market today by Webber-Simpson Co. of Chicago.

With a tube leading to her mouth from a small single-burner gas stove, the body of Mrs. Louise Kerber, 24 years old, said to have been a hostess in a midtown night club, was found about 4 P. M. yesterday in her third-floor furnished room at 200 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that E. M. Voorhees, vice president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, had been appointed vice chairman of the finance committee of the steel company.

The Progressive Students party at City College, an opposition bloc formed this semester against the established radical group which has dominated student politics and government during the last year, was victorious in the student council elections, gaining two out of three offices, it was revealed yesterday.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey heard pleas of guilty yesterday and imposed fines of $100 each upon the Well Known Glove Company, 468 Fourth Avenue, and upon Hyman Haspel and David Zanft, its officers, for shipping gloves from which the words "Made in Germany" had been removed.

SOME one once remarked that so far as he could judge from reading translations, modern French literature consisted largely of photographs taken in bedrooms (even "Man's Fate," he pointed out, opened in a bedroom) and of great and sweeping panoramas a la Jules Romains.

Crowds of wide-eyed sightseers continued yesterday their promenade through Grand Central Palace on still another day of the Springlike weather that is probably piling up an all-time record total for National Motor Boat Show attendance.

Deposits of Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London, reached the highest figure in the history of that institution on Dec. 31 last at [Pound]429,538,416, an increase of about [pound]23,000,000 from a year before, according to cabled advices received here yesterday by the New York representative of the bank.

New York City held yesterday the most successful bond sale since the greater city was formed, selling $50,000,000 of 3 per cent forty-year corporate stock to a syndicate headed by the National City Bank at a net interest cost of about 2,941 per cent.

Twelve flawless blue-white diamonds, cleft from the famous Jonker stone, were ready for sale yesterday in the offices of Harry Winston, dealer in precious stones, in the British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, officially opened yesterday afternoon the exhibition of photographs from the London Salon of Photography at the British Empire Exhibition in the British Building, 620 Fifth Avenue.

The need for adequate monetary controls to avert the dangers of a boom was emphasized by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, in his message to shareholders, presented at the.annual meeting of the bank at noon yesterday at the head office at Pine and Nassau Streets.

The crash of a Western Air Express transport plane into a mountain of the Sierra Madre range which loomed suddenly out of a raging snowstorm brought death today to one person and injury to ten others, including Mr. and Mrs. Martin Johnson, the explorers. Two escaped unhurt.

A contender for the world's middleweight title is expected to emerge tonight from the ten-round bout in which Solly Krieger, East Side candidate for the honor, battles Teddy Yarosz, Pittsburgher. who formerly held the championship, as the feature attraction at the Hippodrome.

SOME one once remarked that so far as he could judge from reading translations, modern French literature consisted largely of photographs taken in bedrooms (even "Man's Fate," he pointed out, opened in a bedroom) and of great and sweeping panoramas a la Jules Romains.

Varieties of fruit which will be in demand by the consuming public and nursery stock which will combine consistent production with maximum hardiness were cited as needs of growers today at the convention of the State Horticultural Society.

The Sinking Fund Commission at its first meeting of the year yesterday voted to cancel water rents and unpaid assessments on educational and charitable institutions in the city during 1937. Several times in the past Mayor La Guardia has opposed such a move.

The progressive and liberal leaders in American government today are "far behind the people they are supposed to be leading," and unless there is a change, the people will demand new leaders who will recognize the importance of aiding those at the bottom of the economic heap, Dr. Rexford G. Tugwell said tonight at a farewell dinner given in his honor.

The St. Francis College basketball team easily defeated the Cathedral College quintet last night, 45 to 28, on the Butler Street court. The victory marked the fifth for the sharpshooting Terriers in eight games.

Promotions of four executives of the Johns-Manville Corporation were announced yesterday by Lewis H. Brown, president, following the resignation of E. M. Voorhees as secretary and treasurer to join the United States Steel Corporation as vice chairman of the finance committee and a director.

The identity of a strange goldencolored "trout" found in Twin Lakes, Canaan, has been established by experts, according to an announcement yesterday by the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, but the mystery of its presence in the lake remains to be solved.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. George Alexander Abbott, QMRes., Arm and Service Assignment Group, now on active duty at the New York Port of Embarkation, 58th St. and First Av., Brooklyn, N. Y., in connection with CCC activities, pursuant to Paragraph 15,.Special Orders 150. War Department, June 27,
Preliminary announcements of the centenary celebration at Mount Holyoke College, to take place on May 7 and 8, were mailed today to about 500 colleges, universities and learned societies.

Dr. Charles Evelyn Rynd of 625 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, director for the last ten years of the gynecological and obstetrical division of Kings County Hospital, died on Tuesday night in the Midwood Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 53 years old.
Louis Leeker defeated Clifford Bash, 33-30, in a three-cushion match at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy yesterday. Each player had a high run of 4 in the encounter, which went 42 innings.
Professor Robin Tillyard, 55 years old, well-known Australian entomologist and author of many scientific articles, was killed today in an automobile accident.

Senator Norris of Nebraska stepped today into the thick of the fight to broaden Federal powers over industry and agriculture. The 75-year-old independent agreed to preside at a conference on amendment of the Constitution. He said to a group which solicited his leadership:

The case against P. Milton Smith, Mountain View editor, accused of libeling President Roosevelt in an editorial, was dismissed today because of "insufficient evidence." "My impression is that the allegations in the complaint are not libelous," said Justice of the Peace Grandin H. Miller.
Temple rallied in the second half to defeat Georgetown tonight, 29-27, in its first home game in the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference. It was the third straight league setback for the Hoyas.

The Atlantic Refining Company, announced yesterday that it had awarded a contract to the Sun Shipbuilding Company of Chester, Pa., for a tanker, which will be the largest welded ship in the world. It is now the largest commercial ship under construction in an American yard, it was said.

At the annual meeting of the directors of the Grace National Bank yesterday all officers were re-elected. J. J. Riley, assistant manager of the foreign department, was made manager of the department, L. A. Edwards was appointed assistant manager of the foreign department and A. M. Heaney was elected assistant trust officer.

Despite a lapse in his second shots and putting, Joseph Schenck of New York gained the semi-finals in the Lake Worth golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He snared a birdie on the concluding hole to win from Leon Sikes of West Palm Beach, 1 up, in the second round.

Dr. William E. Grady, associate superintendent of schools, whose term of office expires Jan. 27, was unanimously re-elected to his position for a six-year term at a meeting of the Board of Education, held yesterday afternoon at the board's headquarters, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Heaviness in gilt-edge corporation bonds as well as government issues characterized trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The day's business was the largest since Oct. 7, with a total of $19,685,500 turned over, compared with $16,287,000 on Tuesday.

The names of 139 persons who had passed the October examinations for licenses to practice law in New Jersey as attorneys were made public here today by the State Board of Bar Examiners. There were 398
The General Motors Corporation and the Automobile Workers Union accepted Governor Murphy's invitation to meet him in Lansing today to discuss the situation.

The Richmond County grand jury exonerated Magistrate Henry W. Bridges yesterday in connection with the death of Russell H. Hawks, 48-year-old clerk, who was fatally injured when the magistrate's car mounted a curb in New Dorp, S. I., and struck him.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Danbury (Conn.) Hospital of John Niven McCunn, formerly of Green Bay, Wis., who was United States Consul at Glasgow, Scotland, for some years following 1908. From 1887 to 1900 he was president and proprietor of the Green Bay Business College.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today the issuance of a complaint against Johnson Johnson of New Brunswick, N. J., charging unfair disparagement of competitors' goods.

The city's net funded debt at the end of 1936 was $1,667,020,375, or $10,452,903 less than it was at the end of 1933, the year the bankers' agreement went into effect, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday. And of the debt outstanding, he said, $297,151,399 is in securities held by the city's own pension funds.
Creation of a State Youth Commission to handle the special problems of youth was urged upon Governor Lehman tolay by a delegation from the New York City Council of the American Youth Congress.

After absorbing March contracts at 12.50 cents a pound in late trading on Tuesday and again early yesterday, the cotton market backed away from the 12 1/2-cent level and prices ended with losses of 2 to 4 points.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 750,000 shares of the $5 par common stock of the National Fireproofing Corporation.

Despite the caution that they displayed and the warnings that they uttered in their discussions of Dr. MANFRED SAKEL'S method of treating with insulin the form of insanity known as schizophrenia, the psychiatrists were distinctly hopeful at the New York Academy of Medicine the other evening. It is too early to speak of
Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, is returning from his annual vacation today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others coming on

There was no such thing as ringless" hosiery before the Kaufman patent of tree-carrier operation was put into superintendent of the H. C. Aberle Company, manufacturers of women's full-fashioned hosiery, testified, in effect, in Federal court today.

Mrs. Mary Belle Hudelson White, mother of Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the New York State W. C. T. U., died yesterday at her daughter's home, 605 West 184th Street, of heart disease at the age of 80. In addition to Mrs. Colvin,

Samuel Untermyer of New York, president of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, declared today the organization was boycotting the proposed Max Schmeling-James J. Braddock heavyweight bout because "Schmeling would take his share of the money back to Germany."

Business leases reported by brokers yesterday centered in the midtown district of the city. E. Leitz, Inc., manufacturer of the Leica miniature camera and of microscopes, rented the fifth floor in the Annex of the Heckscher Building, 730 Fifth Avenue, and half of the fifth floor in the main building, about 15,000 square feet of space.

The polling dates for provincial elections in British India, in which new legislative assemblies will be created in eleven provinces and legislative councils or upper houses in six of them were announced yesterday. All voting will be concluded
The State Department today recalled Guillermo Patterson, Cuban Ambassador to Washington. Reliable sources said he would be replaced by Pedro Martinez Fraga, Cuban Minister to London.

Clayton R. Burt, president of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company, was elected a director of the West Hartford Trust Company. Louis W. Slocum, industrialist and contractor, was made a director of the Capitol National Bank and Trust Company.

Ellsworth Vines, professional tennis star who has been in St. Luke's Hospital since Sunday with a mild case of influenza, said tonight he would leave Chicago by plane tomorrow for Pittsburgh, where he is to meet Fred Perry of England Friday in the fourth match of their nation-wide tour.
Queenie, the Democratic donkey, will leave Mississippi Saturday in a special car to attend the inauguration of President Roosevelt.

The prospect of a Legislative inquiry into the removal of Dr. Glenn Frank from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin dwindled today when Governor La Follette's Progressive followers succeeded in winning enough converts from Democratic and Republican ranks to seize control of both houses of the Legislature.

Mrs. Louise Carnahan Deming, wife of Dr. Nelson Lloyd Deming, retired physician of Litchfield, Conn., died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack while with her husband in Max Schling's flower store on Fifth Avenue near Fifty-eighth Street. She was 71 years old.

The dismissal of Professor Jerome Davis from the Yale Divinity School was termed a violation of academic freedom in a protest petition signed by 100 members of the Columbia University faculty and student body at a meeting yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Columbia branch of the American Teachers Union at Harkness Academic Theatre.

Minturn deS. Verdi, in 136 E. 67th St.. through Culver, Hollyday, Inc.; Mrs. Sarah L. Hine. in 40 E. 52d St.; Miss Margaret C. Perkins, in 22 E. 69th St., through Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc.; Burgoyne Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

A vigorous protest was made by the United States Embassy here this afternoon against misinformation published in a Paris evening newspaper that during a short visit paid to Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos this morning Ambassador William C. Bullitt discussed the debt situation and advised against raising the question at this time by the French Government.

Judge George A. Slater, Republican, took a second oath of office this afternoon as Surrogate of Westchester County after it was brought out in a court action this morning that he should have been sworn in by the county judge or county clerk instead of by a Supreme Court justice.
Jack Pearl, radio comedian, last night entertained about sixty transient and homeless boys at the Children's Aid Society's Brace Memorial Newsboys' Home, 244 William Street.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an additional list of securities registered recently under the Securities Act of 1933 including one by Southern California Water Company, Los Angeles, covering $3,400,000 of first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds. series of 1960,

Conrad Richter's novel of the Southwest, "The Sea of Grass," has been bought for motion-picture production by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The book itself will appear under the Knopf imprint early in February.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

One sitdown striker in the Cadillac Motor Car Company plant had to leave today. He was called for duty with his National Guard company which was mobilized to preserve law and order in connection with sit-down strikes.

The Federal Power Commission has adopted an order amending its uniform system of accounts for public utilities and licensees subject to the provisions of the Federal Power Act, which went into effect on Jan. 1, to make them applicable to those designated as'Class C utilities, having annual electric operating revenues between $100,000 and $250,000, and Class D utilities, with revenues between $25,000 and $100,000, effective in each instance on Jan. 1, 1938.

Attacks on Jews are marking the debates in the budget committee of Parliament. The so-called labor group is using every possible device to extract from the government a clear-cut declaration against the Jewish population.

Dr. D. P. Morgan, chemical economist of Scudder, Stevens Clark, has been elected chairman for the current year of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Morgan will succeed Dr. Lawrence W. Bass, who recently joined the staff of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research in Pittsburgh.

The annual Albany-to-New York marathon on the Hudson River, the signal of the opening of the Northern motor boating season, will be held on Sunday, May 9, it was announced last night at the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association, sponsor of the event.

Edwin James Brown, Seattle lawyer, was elected president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners today. Other officers are John Sloan of the New York State Racing Commission, first vice president; Ralph

An anonymous ransom note, believed by the police to be either an attempt at extortion or a hoax, was received by Bert J. Young, whose 16-year-old son, Robert J., ran away from home Jan. 4, it was disclosed today.

After forty days spent on his back owing to an accumulation of maladies, Pope Pius left his bed this morning and spent a few hours in his wheelchair. Two secretaries and a male nurse lifted him from his bed shortly after 10 and placed him in his chair, in which he remained until 1.

Harry J. Levine, a lawyer, with an office at 51 Chambers Street, whose conviction last Dec. 17 by the late Chief Justice Kernochan and Justices Bayes and Salomon in the extraordinary term of Special Sessions was the first under the law against solicitation in accident cases, enacted in 1898, received a suspended sentence yesterday.
Secretary Wallace today proposed to take $135,000,000 a year from sugar processors through an excise levy of perhaps a cent a pound on all processing of the commodity.

Assets of the new Atlas Corporation applicable to its capital stocks on Oct. 31 last, aggregated $106,578,591, a gain of $4,419,230 since the company's last report on Aug. 31, it was disclosed yesterday in an application to list 540,453 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock and 6,127,098 shares of $5-par common stock approved by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

Kid Chocolate advanced another step in his comeback campaign tonight, scoring a fifth-round technical knockout over Johnny Erickson of New York. The former world featherweight champion weighed 130 1/2 pounds and Erickson 132.

Although Mr. and Mrs. Martin Johnson traveled around the world many times, and faced all sorts of known and unknown dangers in little-known regions of the earth during their various expeditions, it was a happy accident which started them on their joint career.
Turpentine firm, 44c; sales, 21 barrels; receipts, 58 barrels; no shipments; stock, 31,506 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 180; receipts, 757; no

Chief Justice Hugh E. Rose of the High Court of Ontario ruled today that the section of the Power Commission Act of 1935 which declared invalid the contract of 1929 between the Beauharnois Light, Heat and Power Company of Montreal and the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario was ultra vires the Ontario Legislature and awarded damages of $573,750 to the power company.

One goal in the first period and two. more in the second by the Clarkson hockey team proved a greater margin than the Princeton skaters could overcome in their game at Hobey Baker Rink tonight, and the Engineers triumphed, 3 to 2.

The projected journey of John L. Lewis to Detroit will afford a new and needed facility to Governor Murphy, whose efforts to make an equitable peace between General Motors and the Union of Automotive Workers have impressed observers in this capital. After all, Mr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Arthur Krock, writing in THE TIMES of Jan. 8, asks why Great Britain, with war in the offing, should make a reciprocity trade treaty with America. His argument apparently aims to weaken his readers' support of an American neutrality law which would cover -many commodities and which would treat Great Britain the same as any other country.

Robert M. Carpenter 3d, 16-year-old sor. of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Carpenter of Shippan, a freshman at Yale University, died last night in New Haven General Hospital of septicemia after a brief illness.

The United States Steel Corporation has acquired, through the American Steel and Wire Company, $200,000 par value of preferred stock o the Gerrard Company, or 89 per cent of the total, and $309,000 par value of common stock, or 96 per cent of the total, it was disclosed yesterday in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Brooklyn diamond mystery grew increasingly complex yesterday as the authorities opened another safe deposit box and found what appeared to be another fortune in diamonds and jewelry belonging to Joseph Rose, the erstwhile recipient of home relief, who last week accused a friend of stealing $250,000 worth of diamonds from his mattress.

Detectives investigating the murder of Mrs. Mary Robinson Case announced last night that they were ready to book Major Green, Negro porter, on a charge of homicide and that they would have a special guard stand over him all night.

After one of his sabbatical leaves of absence, Samuel Shipman, the demon melodramatist, is back, collaborating with one Beth Brown on a Bowery dime novel entitled "Behind Red Lights," put on at the Mansfield last evening.

The least wory of George S. Spencer, who retired recently as inspector of the Pennsylvania Railroad police, New York zone, after thirty-three years' service, is that he will become homesick for the Pennsylvania station, which he frequented night and day since 1910, when it was opened.

In a sharply worded letter asserting that the welfare of the club should be the "only consideration," A. J. Lundstrom, chairman, and E. F. Driggs, secretary, of the nominating committee of the Crescent Athletic Club, Brooklyn, replied yesterday to a rebel group within the membership that las offered a slate in opposition to that selected by the committee.

Representatives of the leading households of New York City, from butlers to personal maids-hundreds of smartly gowned women and men in evening clothes - dined and danced as formally as their employers do, at the fourth annual Butlers' Ball held at the Hotel Commodore last night.
A proposal to seek legislation outlawing the surgical "debarking" of dogs was considered today by directors of the Erie County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

As part of a campaign to organize sentiment in favor of the Crawford-Rapp Tax-Limitation Bill soon to be introduced in the Legislature, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, and Major Henry J. Amy, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, addressed members of the West of Central Park Association at a luncheon in the Circle Club, 1,819 Broadway yesterday.

The $900,000 Administration Building of the New York World's Fair of 1939, with its 57,000 square feet of floor space, became nearer reality yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, made public the architectural drawings for the structure. The Administration Building will be the first of 300 buildings erected for the fair.

A store-door pickup and delivery service will be started by the New Haven Railroad at 140 of its 480 stations probably within 120 days, it was announced yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York.
The Committee for Industrial Organization moved yesterday to extend its campaign to "organize the unorganized" to 15,000 utility workers in the metropolitan district.
Peter Gouvernor of East Newark waited eagerly today for the opinion of an expert on the value of a pearl he found yesterday when he bit into an oyster purchased at a Newark market. Roy Fassett, a

Charges that, under the employee representation plan of the Carnegle-Illinois Steel Corporation, Benjamin Fairless, president of the company, ruled out compulsory arbitration of differences, were made today before the National Labor Relations Board by William E. Garrity, chairman of the employee representatives group of the Edgar Thomson plant, and Elmer Maloy, Duquesne plant representative.

On the occasion of CHARLES HAYDEN'S death, editorial mention was made of what was then thought to be his outstanding gift to the communitythe Hayden Planetarium, in which the relationship of this little earth to the universe with its stars, in number as the sands of the sea, is represented.

TOKYO, Jan. 13.-The United States naval program is causing great anxiety to Japanese naval authorities, according to the newspaper Asahi-especially the plan to create a new auxiliary fleet of fifty-four vessels at a cost of $200,000,000 in ten years.

Charles W. Maury, former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, who died at his Shippan Point home in 1935 at the age of 76, left an estate of $218,075.30, according to an accounting accepted by the Probate Court.

Acting suddenly and secretly yesterday afternoon, Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx, and Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph Reynolds, with a picked squad of detectives, raided two places which they said were being run as horserace betting establishments.
Sales and leases of housing properties in the Washington Heights and Harlem sections featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

Dr. L. M. Waugh was elected commodore of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club at the annual meeting of that organization held last night in the clubhouse at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
Hog prices in general declined here today 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight, with weakness in fresh pork loins a factor. The latter were 1 to 2 cents lower at 16 1/2 to 19 cents a pound, wholesale.

Once again it was Heinie Brock, the Minneapolis madman, who first aroused the spectators at the "Ice Follies of 1937" to real enthusiasm. comingg on near the start of the repeat performance at Madison Square Garden last night, Brock immediately warmed the capacity crowd of 15,000 to his funmaking and set the comic tone of the evening.

Mrs. Ada J. Cline, a frail, 64-yearold mother of an Ohio penitentiary convict, faced today twenty days in jail because she admitted smuggling to him hacksaw blades used for the escape of nine men from the county jail New Year's Day.

PARNELL, by Joan Haslip. (Stokes, $3.) A biography. ROAD TO AMERICA, by Frances Frost. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) Poems. SHAKESPEARE CRITICISM, 1919-1935, selected, with an introduction by Anne Bradley; (Oxford, 80 cents.) Present-day views of Shakespeare.

Richard R. Sinclair, 50 years old, of 225 East Seventy-third Street, and Charles H. Rangeley, 41, of 118 West Fifty-seventh Street, were charged yesterday in Yorkville Court with having taken hundreds of dollars from doctors on ParkMadison and Fifth Avenues through having them believe they were joining an exclusive doctor's club.

The million-volt X-ray tube that has been under construction at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center during the last two years as New York's newest weapon in the fight against cancer was officially dedicated yesterday by Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Crocker Institute for Cancer Research, Columbia University.

The nervousness that has been accumulating in the money market lately because of the delay by the Federal Reserve Board in taking steps to put into effect its expected second advance in member bank reserve requirements found expression yesterday in a general rise of 1-16 to 1/g per cent in the rates on bankers' acceptance.

The following are the Board of Trade's figures for December: Total imports, [Pound]83,650,000; exports of British products, [Pound]40,510,000; reexports, [Pound]6,100,000; total exports, [Pound]46,610,000; excess of imports, [Pound]37,040,000.
Charles Sweeney of Rumson has been added to the board of directors of the Sea Bright National Bank.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Jan. 11: Thompson, Commander R. R., Destroyer Division 4, Battle Force, to command the Cuyama.

The American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., announced last night that $14,783 had been realized at the first session of the sale of books, autographs and other items from the collections of Mrs. Peter Rouss and Dr. Reginald Burbank. E. H. Wells Co. paid
On the short end of a 4-to-1 score midway in the last period, the Andover hockey team pulled up to a 4-4 tie with the Harvard freshman, sextet today in the Boston Arena.
