The ballots for an employe-representation election for motormen and conductors of the Independent subway system were changed yesterday after officials of Transport Workers Lodge 1547 had protested to Mayor La Guardia that the set-up strongly resembled a company union type of organization.

A former California convict was being sought tonight in the widening hunt for the kidnap-killer of Charles Mattson, while police at Everett threw a close guard about an abandoned automobile supposedly contraining blood-soaked clothing.
Mr. EDEN told the London foreign correspondents that the people of Great Britain prefer butter to guns. In this respect they differ from the

The description in the report of the President's Committee on Administrative Management yesterday of the qualities desirable in the six executive assistants proposed for the President ("a passion for anonymity," "great personal vigor," ) caused several members of the press gallery to burst into verse today.

Mr. and Mrs. James F. Dunn of North Stamford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mae G. Dunn, to John F. Flaherty, son of Mrs. Fanny Flaherty and the late Martin J. Flaherty, Norton Heights, Conn.

The government announced the arrest of foes in a communique this morning as follows: "The government has had knowledge for some time that members of the Alianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana [Apra party] were plotting against the good order of the regime and that an uprising was scheduled for yesterday.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. officially upheld today the ruling of William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, barring the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of New York City from utilizing a special type of customer service.

Prompt passage of the proposed new building code was urged upon the Board of Aldermen by Jacob H. Haffner, chairman of the committee on public service in the metropolitan district of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a statement issued yesterday. Mr. Haffner held that

Three teams remained unbeaten in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday as the Harvard and Yale Clubs emerged victoriously from Group 1 encounters and the Downtown A. C. scored in Group 2.

Automobile accidents, according to figures collected from 131 large cities in the country, resulted in 9,599 deaths in 1936, the Bureau of Census announced today. This was a drop of 178 from the year before. The death toll rose in fifty-seven of the cities reporting.

At a press conference held in the office of William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of General Motors Corportion, this afternoon, he refused to say what his demands would be regarding the evacuation of the automobile plants by the stay-in strikers before joining at the conference table with Governor Murphy and union officials.

Beset with war alarms, shortages of food and raw materials and, according to Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, the danger of an "explosion," Germany has had little time to pay attention to the strike situation in the United States.

Thayer St., 98, 141.4x90; Maximum Holdings, Inc., Charles Struckler, vice president, to Beacon Management Corp., 292 Madison Av., prior mtg., $216,000, due Jan. 1, 1940, 6 per cent, purchase money; $5,000. 142d St., 605-09 West, 100x99.11: Victoria Properties, Inc., Sarah Levitt, president, to Hyman Bettigole, 9 East 40th St.. prior mtg., $151,500, due July 2, 1937, 6 per cent; $7,500.

Activities on the Stock Exchange here were quiet today but the tone continued firm. As they did yesterday, South African gold shares attracted the principal attention on strong buying both here and in Johannesburg.

Many luncheon parties will be given before the performance of "Tales of Hoffmann" this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over in behalf of the children's health work of the New York Diet Kitchen Association. Young matrons and

With Milt Perkel, stellar forward, scoring 18 points, the Brooklyn College quintet conquered Savage, 52 to 36, at the Union Temple court in Brooklyn last night. The victory was the fourth in a row for the Kingsmen and their seventh in eleven starts this season.

War threats and generally unsettled conditions in Europe in the last. few weeks have forced export credit executives to divide Continental nations into good, doubtful and poor credit risks in making time-payment shipments abroad, it was disclosed at a conference of foreign trade credit men at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

P. Albion Prescott, Assistant Deputy Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, and James J. Goodwin, an examiner in the same State department, both of whom gave affidavits in a recent court action criticizing the department's management of building and loan associations, were dismissed today by Banking Commissioner Carl K. Withers.
The Social Security Board announced today grants totaling $533,878 to aid States in administering unemployment compensation laws for the period from Jan. 1 to March 31. The figures included:

League for Political Education, the Town Hall. "Creseyde, the First Modern Woman," Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, 11 A. M.; "Should All Government Employes Be Under Civil Service?" Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, Luther Steward, Dr. Thurman Stoner.
Building plans filed yesterday by architects included various alteration jobs in Manhattan and Brooklyn, a dwelling and tenement in the Bronx and a tenement for forty-one families in Queens.

The wreck on Tuesday of a Western Air Express transport in the California mountains was the second for that company-after an unblemished record of seven years of flying-and the fifth fatal accident on domestic lines in about a month. Two passengers,
The net income of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in 1936 was $4,533,-073, according to an estimate filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission This is in contrast to a net loss of $3,180,909 in 1935.

Five passengers and a crew of thirty-six were removed today by the German ship Schwaben, from the Swedish motorship Buenos Aires which was grounded near Jaltepeque, twenty-five miles east of La Libertad, El Salvador, yesterday.
Municipal authorities of San Cristobal las Casas announced tonight that one of the two Mexican airplanes missing since Monday had been found wrecked, with its three occupants dead.

A demand that Mayor J. Henry Stump act immediately to end a wave of vandalism that had swept the city and surrounding area for more than two months was made today by 6,000 residents in a petition charging "official incompetence or unwillingness to apprehend these vandals."

Miss Eleanor Minott Waller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tom T. Waller of this place, has set Feb. 5 for her wedding to Judge Harold L. Knapp of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony will be performed at the Waller home by the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black, pastor of the First Congregational Church here.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 12 unless specified: Puget Sound Yard to San Francisco: Cushing, Perkins. Acushnet, Norfolk to Washington Yard. Arctic, at San Francisco, Jan. 13. Chaumont, Manila to Guam, Jan. 13. Clark. at Boston Yard.

Employes of the Longwood Farms of Pierre S. du Pont received about $200,000 in preferred stock in the E. I. du Pont de Nemours company as a gift which their employer advised them to place in irrevocable trust to provide necessities in their old age.

Establishment of a flat freight-rate differential of 3 cents a 100 pounds between "inland" ports such as Philadelphia and ports on the sea, such as New York, was advocated today by George W. Edmonds of this city at a hearing here before Charles M. Bardwell, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Trial of a suit based on alleged illegal control and misuse of stockholders' money against Henry L. Doherty and his interests began yesterday before Federal Judge John W. Clancy.

Nicaragua redeemed 80,000 cordobas bonds of 1918 at a public drawing held today by High Commissioner Irving A. Lindberg. Jose Benito Ramirez, Minister of Finance, said the drawing was the largest held since 1932.
Joseph Goldstein, an early dry goods merchant of this city, died last night at his home, 178 Garfield Avenue, after a four-day illness. He was 89 years old.

Two mass meetings, attended by more than 12,000 employes who protested against their enforced idleness brought about by sit-down strikers in General Motors plants were held today in,Detroit and Saginaw.

The flotation by the Guaranty Company of New York of a $30,000,000 note issue for the Van Sweringen Corporation which culminated in a loss of $15,759,000 to public subscribers was characterized today by Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, as "slipshod business" and as "purely a wildcat proposition."

The traditional double bill of "Pagliacci" and "Cavalleria Rusticana" was offered for the second time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and as an added attraction the ballet "The Bat" was given by the American Ballet Ensemble. The triple presentation attracted a large house.

Dr. Thomas J. Seaman was elected today a director of the Bank of Amityville to fill the vacancy on the board caused by the recent death of Millard F. Griffith. Lewis C. Evans, village attorney, was elected a director of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Amityville. Dr. Charles C. Murphy and Herbert H. Pinkham resigned as directors. The new board comprises only eight members.
Donald Budge, the nation's top-ranking tennis star, advanced to the third round of the annual Dixie tennis tournament today with an easy 6-2, 6-0 victory over Randall Rose of St. Petersburg, Fla.

Dr. Thomas Walker Page, vice chairman of the Federal Tariff Commission and chairman of the President's reciprocity committee, and Professor of Economics at the University of Virginia for years, died of a heart attack here today in the University Hospital, at the age of 70.
Mrs. Henry E. Coe of Mayfair House left last night for Mexico, D. F. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Poultney Cook, who were at the Pierre, have gone to Heathcote Farm, Kingston, N. J.

Martin Beck, Harry Borns, Asher Levy, Julian M. Livingston and Alexander Young Jr., constituting a stockholders' consolidated protective committee for Orpheum Circuit, Inc., filed a motion yesterday in Federal Court for permission to intervene in reorganization proceedings for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation.

In the drama "Crooked Cross," presented at the Westminster Theatre here tonight, Sally Carson relates a tragedy of a Bavarian girl's love for a Jewish doctor in the early days of the Nazi revolution without indulging in propaganda and without bias.

Electric power production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to a new all-time high of 107.0, compared with 103.1 for the previous week and 97.7 for the week ended Jan. 11, 1936.

The famous old Monteagle Hotel here was destroyed by fire last night. The building was of stone, five stories high, with wings of similar height on each side, the whole being topped by a tower twenty feet square and two stories high.

MARTIN JOHNSON, who came to know at first hand many of the little known parts of the planet, dramatized the life that he found there and brought their inhabitants, wild and human, whom he captured by his camera, into the midst of civilization.

Federal Judge William H. Holly had before him again today the affairs of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, which has asked permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the amended Bankruptcy Act, and for control of which Harley L. Clarke, its former president, and the Atlas Corporation of New York, headed by Floyd B. Odlum, are contesting.

A total of 180,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock of the Household Finance Corporation, of which 73,649 1/2 shares will represent new financing, will be offered today at $100 each. The stock has a par value of $100 a share and carries the full quarterly dividend due on April 15.

The Pan-American Press Conference voted unanimously today to hold its second conference at Bogota, Colombia, in August, 1938, on the occasion of the celebration of the 400th anniversary of the founding of Bogota.
Officials of Worcester, Mass., have invited bankers to submit sealed proposals today on a new issue of $1,000,000 of revenue notes. The notes, to be dated Jan. 15, will be due on Nov. 5, 1987.
A large attendance marked the tombola, staged today at the Everglades Club as the first of a series to be held weekly throughout the Winter. Mrs. Edward Howland

Stocks closed irregular in less active trading; turnover, 3,083,040 shares. United States Government issues irregularly lower, other bonds steady and mixed in largest turnover since Oct. 7; transactions, $19,685,500.

Mrs. Virginia George Donnelly of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. George of Kansas City, was married to Jean G. de Cavaignac of Paris yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Thomas L. Graham.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Some traefa meats were in good demand, others sold slowly.

The first evidences that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has been working out a scheme for settlement of the Sian, Shensi Province, crisis along lines Independent of Nanking's planned punitive expedition developed yesterday, when four airplanes left Nanking carrying General Chang Hsueh-liang and ten other important military leaders to Fenghua to confer with the Generalissimo.

Among those entertaining groups of friends for the opening this afternoon of Hialeah Park, the track of the Miami Jockey Club, where racing will continue until March 6, were Joseph E. Widener, president of the club; Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie
Eleven contributions totaling $156.70 were received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund. They brought the present aggregate of the -fund in this appeal to $269,800.88.

Formal offering will be made today by W. E. Hutton Co. of $1,600,O00 of Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad first mortgage Series B 4 per cent bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1937, and due on Jan. 1, 1967, at 102 and accrued interest.

Construction wage rates for January show a further rise and the average hourly wage for unskilled labor in this field has reached a record mark, according to a compilation of figures for twenty key cities in various parts of the country.

The Cashman Laundry Company has purchased a tract at. Hollander's Field, North Bergen, N. J., with a frontage of 160 feet on the State highway and extending back about 325 feet to Tonnelle Avenue, from the John Maneely Company of Philadelphia, and will build a two-story concrete and steel branch plant there, J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, announced.
Gus Charles Swartzfager, 32, of Buffalo, N. Y., was sentenced to two years in jail here for the death of George Karg, 17, of Fryburg, killed in a hunting accident.

Yale's football team, one of the most interesting of the past season, finished its post-season play last night amid songs and cheers and a great deal of good-natured excitement at the Waldorf-Astoria at a dinner tendered it by the Yale Club of New York.

The American Utilities Service Corporation of Savanna, Ill., a holding company with subsidiaries operating in eighteen States and assets of about $15,000,000, which has been contesting the validity of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, has registered under the act, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Charles Henry Culver of 327 Woodside Avenue died here this morning in the Presbyterian Hospital, to which he went five weeks ago for an operation. Mr. Culver, who was a retired builder, was 72 years old on Dec. 30.
Mrs. E. A. Uhler, wife of an investment broker, was found dead last night from illuminating gas in her apartment, on the fifth floor of 61 West Ninth Street. She was 35 years old.

An unused block of four stamps of the Louisiana Purchase commemorative issue, perforated horizontally, were sold yesterday afternoon for $1,250 at the auction ofUnited States stamps at the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Fortyseventh Street.

Redetermination of income tax deficiency assessments amounting to $1,649,546 was sought before the United States Board of Tax Appeals today by Samuel H., Rush H. and Claude W. Kress of New York, heads of the S. H. Kress Company, chain-store corporation.

The elimination of Charles Whitehead of South River, N. J., the defending champion, and the easy victory scored by Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Beach, the Long Island amateur champion, marked the second round of match play for the annual Midwinter golf title at the Miami Country Club today.

The United Corporation, a holding company which has large interests in the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, the United Gas Improvement Company and other utility systems, reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $10,269,858, or 19 cents a common share, against $9,049,837, or 11 cents a share, in 1935.
Estate, $1,665. To Maurice Powsner, son, 142-15 Cherry Av., Flushing, L. I., and Solomon Powsner, son, executor, 73 Princeton Av., Hewlett, L. I., one-half residue each.

Mrs. Eduardo Andrade, chairman of the junior committee for the performance of "Die Meistersinger" which will be given Feb. 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Smith College Club of New York, entertained with a tea yesterday at her home, 150 East Seventy-second Street, for the other members of the junior group.

Martin Johnson, famous for his explorations and movie photography in African jungles, died in Good Samaritan Hospital here this morning of multiple injuries suffered yesterday when a Western Air Express transport plane pancaked on a fogshrouded mountainside fifteen miles from its port at Burbank.

BLACK, JOHN V. (Aug. 13, 1935). Gross assets, $437,810; net, $302.929. To Henry V. D. Black, brother, $10,000 and life estate in $50,000; Katherine B. Jones and Dorothy Black, nieces, $10,000 and life estate in one-half residue each with power of appointment each; John V. B. Brady, grandnephew, specific personalty and succeeding estate in $50,000. Chief assets. stocks and bonds, $210,103. Nicholas R. Jones, attorney, 122 E. 42d St.
After a slow start, Syracuse's "S-men" flashed good form in the second half against Alfred's basketball team tonight to win, 46-23, for the home team's fourth victory in as many games this season.

A restriction of output in the United States is suggested here as the reason for an unexpected rise of a halfpenny per British gallon in the price of autombbile gasoline. The American gallon is five-sixths of the British gallon.

The United States Weather Bureau issued its weekly report of crop conditions yesterday as follows: Except for some ice and glazed condition over the western half of the Wheat Belt, which will cause some apprehension, if it persists, the week was generally

Having received the plaudits of the critics and the populace for her excellent series of characterizations in Noel Coward's cycle of one-act plays, "Tonight at 8:30," Gertrude Lawrence has arranged to reciprocate. She will do so by appearing

Mrs. John O. Zimmerman is chairman of the young women who will distribute programs at the motion picture entertainment for the benefit of the Brooklyn Children's Museum tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Steel ingot production this week remained unchanged at 79.5 per cent of the country's capacity, notwithstanding strikes in the automotive plants, according to Iron Age's summary, released yesterday.

Lewis John Wells, 55-year-old Raymondville farmer, pleaded guilty today to murder, second degree, for poisoning Joseph Jessmer and was sentenced by Judge Ellsworth C. Lawrence to twenty years to life.

President ROOSEVELT'S message explaining and endorsing his committee's plan for Government reorganization did not get a very cordial reception from Congress. There was some perfunctory praise, but a good deal of timid disapproval. This may have been the natural result of the fact that the report was too long and complicated to be taken in by a hasty reading.

Mrs. Cilla Johnsen of 189 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, well-known in women's club circles in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn Hospital after an operation. She was the widow of Alfred Johnsen and for a number of years was the owner of the Hallock House at Quogue, L. I. She was chairman of

The National Hockey League yesterday set March 23 as the opening date for the Stanley Cup competition, rejected the Montreal Canadiens' protest in the Paul RungeBill McKenzie player deal and elected Bill Dwyer of the New York Americans as a member of the board of governors, The Associated Press reported.
Machine guns protected the first installment of $4,000,000,000 of the nation's hoard of gold which was deposited in the Treasury's new vault here today.

Option agreements by various companies and their officials in 1936 were disclosed yesterday in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

A sharp warning to Americans on engaging in military service on either side in the Spanish civil war was issued by R. Walton Moore, Acting Secretary of State, tonight when he was informed by Mahlon Fay Perkins, United States Consul General at Barcelona, that seventy-six American volunteers had recently passed through that port for military service in Spain.

The Department of Agriculture found indication in foreign rearmament programs today that wool prices will maintain high levels during the next few months. It said "increased use of wool" for military officers' uniforms contributed to the demand in most consumer countries.

While leaders of the House began preparations today for early consideration of President Roosevelt's reorganization proposals, forces began to gather for at least two flank attacks upon the plan, intended to reshape the Federal establishment from top to bottom.

By arranging a settlement for the past agrarian debt and agreeing to issue ironclad bonds to provide indemnity for all the estates now being seized, including many belonging to Americans, President Lazaro Cardenas has removed virtually the last foreign complaint against his government, the Mexican press declares, with considerable reason.

Cardinal Hayes left yesterday morning for a brief stay in the Bahama Islands. He went by train to Miami and will embark there for Nassau, where he will stop with the Most Rev. John Bernard Kevenhoerster, Prefect Apostolic of the Bahamas, who for many years was a Bronx pastor.
Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, who was going to Paris ostensibly in connection with this Summer's exposition but incidentally to discuss a new trade agreement, has called off his trip.

The middleweight championship hopes of Solly Krieger, Brooklyn's threat for the title, perished last night in the Hippodrome when Teddy Yarosz of Pittsburgh, former holder of the crown, gained the decision in their ten-round bout.

James Monroe ??eated Morr??s, 26--15, on the victor's court yesterday to move into a tie with Evander Childs for second place in the upper Manhattan-Bronx P. S. A. L. basketball tourney. Captain Nick Shaback, with 13 points, led Monroe to its third triumph in four league starts.

A colorful celebration to usher m the Russian New Year took place last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. In a floral setting suggestive of Spring, several ceremonials of the old Russian Empire were observed by the guests, who included several members of the former Russian nobility.
Further testimony on behalf of the Arab High Committee was given before the Royal Commission of Inquiry this morning by Auni Bey Abdulhadi, Jerusalem lawyer.

A campaign to provide funds to establish the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra on a permanent basis will be started at a luncheon on Feb. 4 at the Hotel Biltmore. Miss Antonia Brico is the founder and conductor of the orchestra, which was- organized and gave its first concert three years ago.

Plans for a promotional program for the coat and suit industry for the forthcoming season will be prepared soon as the result of action taken yesterday at the second and closing day's session of the semiannual convention of the executive council of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

31st St., 112 W., 20.10x98.10; Eric Coupey to Esther Kurzon, 1,026 E. 22d St., Brooklyn; mtg., $20,000 ($12). 70th St., 211 W., 17x100.5; Bank for Savings to Eda Nussbaum, 50 W. 72d St. ($28). Jane St., 6, 20x60.1; Aelborough Corp., Herbert M. Stoops, president, to Elsie Stoops, 42 Barrow St.; mtg., $14,500 (50 cents).
Since the advent of professionalism in tennis as we know it today, with all the leading amateurs going over to the paid ranks, we are faced with the burning question: Open tennis.
The Long Island Railroad's practice of charging more than 2 cents a mile on short hauls within the city was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn.

Fifty residents of this township besieged the Town Hall here tonight, jeering and booing at the Township Committee, which was demanding that Russell Hillbert, police chief since 1928, take a literacy test to prove his right to keep the job.

With the help of Democrats the Assembly Republicans have at last elected a Speaker. Mr. STEINGUT, the minority leader, has shown forbearance and sagacity throughout a deplorable quarrel. The longer it lasted the worse for the Republican party of this State. Mr. STEINGUT preferred the public interest to partisan advantage.

Retall package dalivereas in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas increased 8 per cent during the week ended Jan. 9, as compared with the same week in 1936, according- to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain in the number of

Leaders of the Progressive and FarmerLaborite bloc in the House today assailed the Democratic majority, alleging unfairness and refusal to recognize the group in committee assignments. They protested that

The New York Building Congress has appointed a committee headed by Aubrey Weymouth to study the proposed city ordinance requiring supervision of all buildings in the course of construction by either a registered architect or a licensed professional engineer.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, warned more than 300 members and guests of the New York Board of Trade in a luncheon address at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that "there is bound to be change from the things we have known."
The threatening guns of a British destroyer caused a Spanish Insurgent trawler to free the British steamer Bramhill in the Strait of Gibraltar last night, official sources disclosed today.

The December grand jury investigating the garnishee racket, in which hundreds of city employes were victims, filed seventeen "informations" against twenty-five persons with Judge Collins in General Sessions yesterday. Judge Collins directed Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, to take the cases to Special Sessions for misdemeanor trials.

Miss Olivia Edgerly Frick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edgeworth Frick of this place, has chosen April 3 for her marriage to William Champlin Robinson Jr., son of Mrs. William Champlin Robinson of Baltimore and Green Spring Valley, Md., and the late Mr. Robinson.

The defensive play of Gordon Bennett and Don Otis was largely responsible for the Dartmouth hockey team's victory over Boston College tonight, 5 to 3. On the offensive, Sophomore Jim Allen, recently shifted to the forward line, won high point honors for the Green with two goals.

Those selected by the Junior League of Philadelphia this season as provisional members include the Misses Elizabeth Allen, Julia Allen, Jeanne Allison, Mary Alice Borie, Janet Bromley, Uytendale Caner, Eloise Chadwick-Collins, Sydney Ellis Cheston, Sibyl Coates, Mary Dayton, Evelyn Ellison Denison, Eliza Disston, Mary Dougherty, Edith English, Pauline Foraker, Patricia Grant, Dorothy Harrison, Ida Hessenbruch, Mary Stuart Houston, Letty Elise Jones and Elizabeth Ketcham.

The arrival of Colonel General Hermann Goering, Reich Air Minister and Commissar for the Four-Year Plan, in Rome tonight for a series of talks with Italian statesmen from which important decisions affecting the Italian-German attitude toward Spain are expected to result, was made the occasion of a warm demonstration of Italo-German friendship.
Lieut. Col. Walter L. Clark, executive assistant to the Chief of Manufacturing Service in the office of the Chief of Army Ordnance, died here today at the age of 51.

The architects' emergency committee of the American Institute of Architects has provided almost 6,000 jobs and raised $200,000 for architects and draftsmen forced out of work by the depression, according to Lucian E. Smith, the chairman. A report on the group's

Dilwyne Montauk Pilot, the sadfaced Chesapeake, is the champion retriever of 1936. The dog yesterday was declared winner of the Field and Stream Challenge Trophy by a committee consisting of Charles L. Lawrance, chairman; Dr. Samuel Milbank, Alfred Ely, J. Gould Remick and Jay F. Carlisle, The Associated Press reported.

Strength in foreign markets and reports that Germany and Italy had purchased about 1,500,000 bushels of Argentine cash wheat were instrumental in raising the level of prices in domestic markets today.

Net earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company from all sources for 1936, after all expenses and taxes and after deducting interest on capital notes and dividends on preferred stock outstanding, were $14,005,147, Harvey D. Gibson, president, reported to shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday at 4 P. M. in the bank's head office, 55 Broad Street.

Yesterday was not the best time in the world for ambitious landlubbers to visit the National Motor Boat Show and gawk about. It was, instead, a "repeaters' day," and Grand Central Palace was literally full of purposeful, serious-minded boatmen of experience who knew what they wanted from a previous visit and paid a repeat call to Lexington Avenue.
More than 100 delegates arrived tonight at the Roger Smith Hotel for the forty-first annual convention of the New York State Building Trades Employers Association which opens tomorrow morning.

The League of Nations Health Organization's quarterly bulletin published today a favorable report on public health and social problems in the United States by a group of public health authorities from Britain, France, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and Yugoslavia.

Today the Leftists staged the war's biggest tank attack, sending in eighteen tanks in a desperate effort to recapture ground. This correspondent saw through fieldglasses how the tanks, not backed up by infantry, had to retreat even before they reached the Insurgent trenches, being unable to face the murderous fire of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's anti-tank guns and other artillery, which as far as the writer could see, disabled at least two tanks.

Funeral services were held at Arlington National Cemetery this morning with full military honors for Robert H. McAdoo, son of Senator McAdoo, who died in New York of pneumonia. Chaplain J. H. Brooks of the navy officiated.

Launching a drive against racketeering in the electrical contracting industry, in which a toll of $10,000,000 a year is said to have been extorted from the public by a monopoly built up by ruthless strongarm tactics, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, made his first open move against it yesterday after thirteen months of secret investigation.

Two unseeded players yesterday won their way into the semi-finals of the women's annual metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship at the Colony Club, and each will oppose a seeded player today in an effort to gain the final.

Penn State's basketball team had little trouble with Lafayette tonight, defeating the visitors, 46 to 15. The Lions used three complete teams, the varsity playing only fourteen minutes of the first half.

The annual meeting of the Yorkville Community Association, Inc., was held yesterday afternoon at the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-first Street. Wiliiam J. McAuliffe, acting director of the Department of Extension Activities of the Board of Education, presided and Norman S. Dike, official referee of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial District, spoke.

Irritated by what he has characterized to friends as "a campaign of malicious talk" since his wife obtained a divorce at Ipswich Assizes on Oct. 27, Ernest Aldrich Simpson, it was learned today, is bringing court Action.
Miss Katherine Coleman gave a tea today in honor of Miss Margaret Jane Peterkin, who will be married to John Kirkman Gurney on Saturday.

Two paintings based on Scriptural texts, which were completed by Colonel A. A. Anderson, 87-yearold artist, during the past year, were exhibited yesterday at a reception to friends and associates in his studios atop tile Beaux Arts Building at ?? West Fortieth Street.
The lead which the New York Athletic Club has maintained over the other Class A teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League almost reached the breaking point last night.

Formation of the Westinghouse Radio Stations, Inc., by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company was disclosed yesterday in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Westinghouse introduced
Governor Lehman announced today the reappointment of Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, as a member of the Public Health Council. He also renamed

The engagement of $574,000 of gold in Great Britain for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement brought to $180,800,000 the total of gold obtained in that country for American account since Sept. 26 last.

The monthly business survey of the Bridgeport Chamber of Commerce reveals that all records for average weekly payrolls in the past six years were broken by the December figures, which were $1,143,663.
President Roosevelt discussed his reorganization plan with Secretary Wallace, received several callers and devoted his day chiefly to routine administrative affairs.

Vlado Kolitsch, violinist, will be heard tonight at the Washington Irving Auditorium. Ignaz Friedman, Polish pianist, who is scheduled to arrive at Hoboken today on the Batory, will give a recital at the Mosque Theatre, Newark, on Saturday night.

Tom Hamilton, coach of the Navy eleven for the last three years, in which his teams won two of their games with Army, after not a victory had been registered in thirteen years, will be succeeded as head football coach at the Naval Academy by his class-mate and team-mate, Hank Hardwick, it was announced today.
Dr. Charles B. Bastian, an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died of pneumonia today at his home here. He was 75 years old.

Mayor La Guardia inspected at noon yesterday in City Hall Park a Markets Department exhibition of apparatus used for testing scales and a collection of short-weight scales and measuring devices seized last year.

Captain Bob Ruge and Alan McFarland, Navy forwards, hit their true form today for the first time this season and the result was that the Midshipmen overpowered Western Maryland at basketball by 45 to 27.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in its report for 1936, issued today, shows net earnings, after deducting taxes,- depreciation and all charges, of $29,253,135, equal to $2.92 each on the combined 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B common stock outstanding.

Judge Robert R. Nevin in Federal District Court dismissed today the suit in which Mrs. Margaret Tuttle of Cincinnati charged that the copyright on her novel "Kingdoms of the Earth" had been infringed by the motion picture "The Unguarded Hour."

The decline in influenza and pneumonia cases and deaths continued yesterday, after a rise the day before, the Department of Health announced last night. The total of 148 new influenza cases was the lowest reported for any day. since Dec. 29 and the eight deaths were the lowest since Jan. 4.

Miss Muriel Langmore heads a group of younger members of society who will sell flowers, programs and Labrador handicraft at the special performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad, Lauritz Melchior and Kerstin Thorborg in the leading roles, the afternoon of Jan. 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Dividend arrears of $1,050,000 on 7 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock will be eliminated by the United Artists Theatre Circuit, Inc., through a recapitalization involving $450,000 in cash, common shares and new preferred stock, according to a plan submitted to stockholders yesterday by Joseph M. Schenck, chairman.

Dr. William H. Dieffenbach of 50 Central Park West, president of the board of trustees of the Community Hospital, 8 St. Nicholas Place, died suddenly yesterday in that hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 71 years old.

At the request of a committee of seventeen educators, social workers, labor leaders, employers and public officials, four constitutional lawyers are drafting an amendment to the Federal Constitution designed to "extend the scope of the commerce clause and restrict that of the due process clause."

The large-scale movement of railroad bonds to the market, which was a feature of Wall Street finance last year, will be continued- today with the offering of $50,000,000 of Great Northern Railway general mortgage 3 3/4 per cent Series I bonds of 1967.

Assemblyman Harold P. Herman, Nassau County Republican, reintroduced in the State Assembly today a measure calling for a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuel betting at New York race tracks.

Total gold imports for 1936 amounted to $1,144,177,000 and exports were but $27,534,000, the Department of Commerce reported today in a summary of monthly statements which it had made during the year.
The copper producing companies have temporarily removed the agreement to restrict output which has been in force since June, 1935.

Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr. was held prisoner in a Hoboken, N. J., apartment by his kidnappers, District Attorney John T. Delaney disclosed tonight at the close of the third day of the retrial of Manning Strewl for the 1933 abduction.

George Faber Downey, son of the late Brig. Gen. George F. Downey, U. S. A., died today in the Sewickley Hospital following a brief illness. Mr. Downey served as a captain with the Twelfth Field Artillery, Second Division, during the World War. He was graduated from Yale University in 1918.

The children of Chanute lost their home-town hero today. Playground clamor was stilled by news of the air-crash death of Martin Johnson, who forsook staid Kansas prairies for adventure on the African veldt.

The "suburban movement" was blamed today as a contributing factor in the development of the racketeer by the Rev. Charles H. Sears, general secretary of the Baptist City Societies of New York and Brooklyn, who addressed delegates at the annual convention of the Home Missions Council of the United States and Canada in session at the Hotel Berkeley Carteret here.

Retail prices advanced 1 per cent during December, scoring one of the largest monthly increases in the present upward trend, according to the Fairchild retail price index issued yesterday. The index on Jan. 2 stood at 91.7, compared with 90.8 on Dec. 1 and 88.2 on Jan. 2, 1936.

The Scarsdale National Bank and Trust Company in its annual report to stockholders reported net earnings of $80,449 for 1936. This was equal to $8.04 a share, of which $39,220 consisted of earnings from loans and service and $33,399 was net profit from the sale of securities. After payment of dividends

Coal gas fumes escaping from an open flue in the basement of a loft building at 5 West Thirtieth Street routed about thirty-five employes a little before 10 A. M. yesterday. Nine persons, including a police sergeant and a patrolman, who gave the alarm to those in the building, were treated for gas poisoning.

Sir Arthur William Johns, until recently director of naval construction at the Admiralty and one of the early experts in submarine and airship construction, died here today after a long illness at the age of 63.

Freddie Steele, world middleweight boxing champion, will defend his title against Eddie (Babe) Risko of Syracuse, from whom he won the diadem in Seattle last July, at Madison Square Garden Feb. 19. Arrangements for the match, which will be over the fifteen-round route,

Joseph B. Weaver, director of the Federal Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, announced yesterday that 8,000 seamen had accepted -the continuous discharge books which the Copeland safetyat-sea act provides they must carry as a record of their careers on American merchant ships.

The Polo Grounds, whose colorful history has been associated chiefly with baseball, will re-echo to the cheers of outdoor sportsmen and sportswomen next month when the famous ball park will be transformed into a huge snow bowl.
On the broad marble steps of the great purple-domed Temple of Heaven, with a crowd of 50,000 morbid onlookers gathered in the courtyard below, five dealers in narcotics were shot to death today.
Mrs. Ben H. Atwell, wife of the well-known theatrical publicity man, died last night of heart disease in Mount Sinai Hospital, where she had been a patient for six weeks. She became ill in

Not to be outstripped by their chain-store rivals, among whom even the Giants are now listed, the Dodgers have become gripped by the farming fever and through Business Manager John Gorman announced yesterday that arrangements have been completed for a considerable extension of the Brooklyn club's recruiting system.

One of the local advertising fields which registered a very substantial gain last year and gives indication of further improvement in 1937 was the hotel and restaurant group, according to comment here yesterday.

The two six-story apartment houses occupying the north block from Grand Avenue to Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the Norma Lila Estates. The buildings are on a plot 191 by 100 feet, irregular, and contain 261 rooms and five stores.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a five-year delay in the payment of a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan of $14,494,423.

The year just closed has been full of interest in the golf world, both on the playing and the administrative sides. As to the former, perhaps the most significant fact is that a record field entered each of the four championships conducted by the United States Golf Association.

The University of Pittsburgh put on a last-period rally tonight to conquer Notre Dame, 34 to 31, in an intersectional basketball battle. Notre Dame went ahead early in the contest and widened the lead to 23 to 14 at the intermission.

Paul L. Roy, executive secretary of the Pennsylvania State Commission, will ask more than a score of States. to contribute to a proposed peace memorial for the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg next year.

Joseph Rubin, 33 years old, and Harry Rubin, 30, both of 241 Central Park West, were placed on probation for six months in Special Sessions yesterday. They had been convicted last month of filing a false certificate for doing business under an assumed name, a violation of Section 440 of the Penal Law.
The St. Regis Paper Company will have a "substantial net profit for the first time since 1931," Roy K. Ferguson of New York, its president, announced today at the annual meeting of stockholders here.

Josephine Hutchinson, who appeared opposite Paul Muni in "The Story of Louis Pasteur," is to be teamed with Muni again in Warners' "The Story of Emile Zola." In the Pasteur Film, Miss Hutchinson's role was of minor consequence, an evil that is to be corrected in the new picture.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull and other delegates to the recent Pan American Peace Conference in Buenos Aires returned yesterday on the Munson liner Southern Cross. All were optimistic about the effect of the conference on peace in the Americas and its influence as a salutary example for the rest of the world.

In spite of low-money rates and the fact that commercial borrowing is not back to normal, the earnings of the Federation Bank and Trust Company have been satisfactory, Jeremiah D. Maguire, president of the bank, stated in his annual report to shareholders, Issued yesterday.
Charles John Grimm whipped out his pen today, signed a contract to boss the Chicago Cubs again in 1937, and immediately went to work on some good and bad news for his hired men.

The Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, gave a program which contained matter of exceptional interest last night in Carnegie Hall. This, at least, applies to the performance of movements from the Vesper Service that Claudio Monteverdi composed for St. Mark's in Venice in 1610.

The Brooklyn Trust Company sold to an investing syndicate headed by Abraham Meitin the adjoining two four-story walk-up apartment houses at 1,953 Seventieth Street and 6,920-Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn. The houses were sold

EVERY so often a man lives a life that becomes, when time has softened the outlines, the particular delight of biographers, dramatists and scenarists. Such a man was Charles Stewart Parnell, the Irish patriot and leader whose dramatic and perhaps romantic career has stirred Joan Haslip to the writing of a sparkling, fastmoving biographical interpretation, "Parnell" (Frederick. A. Stokes. $3).

Donald E. Sterner, State Highway Commissioner of New Jersey, will be the principal speaker at a dinner meeting of the Monmouth County Real Estate Board in the Molly Pitcher Hotel, Red Bank, N. J., on Jan. 20.

ANDREW - In Guilford, Conn., Jan. 13. 1937, Caroline Jenkins, widow of Rev. William Given Andrew. Funeral services will be held at Christ Episcopal Church in Guilford on Friday afternoon at 2:30. Interment at convenience of family.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Samuel Slaff, Gerald J. Craugh, Harold J. Treanor, Mortimer Hays, Richard Steel, S. Philip Cohen, George Bronz, William Gilligan, all of New York City, were admitted to-practice and the following proceedings were had:

Joseph Woods, 26 years old, a Negro convict, was stabbed to death at the State prison here today during a fight with Michael Legdon, 22, a white prisoner. Legdon has refused to talk, but Warden R. William Lagay said Woods apparently attacked Legdon with a dagger made from a table knife and that Legdon presumably wrested the weapon from him and used it in self-defense.

A thief escaped uninjured today because "Stonewall" Jackson's once trusty pistol would not fire and his saber was too short. Mr. and Mrs. Roy Bird Cook, owners of the historic weapons, returned from a late party to see a light extinguished in their home.
Rutgers won its seventh consecutive basketball game of the season, defeating Fordham tonight, 35 to 33, before a capacity crowd of 2,600.

Customs agents reported yesterday the seizure on the British freighter Maron of the Blue Funnel Line of 600 half-pound cans of opium prepared for smoking, worth $75,000 to $100,000. Three Chinese seamen were arrested.

Announcement recently that James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would resign to become dean of the Harvard Law School on Sept. 1 has aroused considerable speculation in Wall Street regarding the

The crash of a Western Air Express liner almost within sight of its destination at Los Angeles brought quick reactions today in government departments the functions and interests of which are identified with air safety.

United States District Attorney Francis W. Ford states that the government probably would have to get along without revenue from taxes on jigsaw puzzles, doubting, he said, that an appeal to the United States Supreme Court could be taken from the Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that the puzzles were not games.

Eight passengers and the crew of fifty escaped from fire and a series of explosions aboard the British motorship Silver Cypress today when the ship was run aground near the Port of Buena Vista, on Guimara Island. The fire was expected to burn for several days.

Toronto capital has taken over the city's International League baseball franchise, president Frank Shaughnessy of the circuit said tonight, and the Maple Leafs next year will have Dan Howley back as manager.
Army's basketball team scored its third victory in as many starts today, the Cadets' blinding speed, clean handling of the ball and deadly shooting bringing a 50-17 triumph over Johns Hopkins.

William P. Thomas was elected president of the Bronx County Bar Association at its annual dinner meeting last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse. He succeeds Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr. of the Board of Transportation.
Chinandega was severely shaken by eleven earthquakes yesterday. No lives were lost, but four houses were destroyed and the walls of many were cracked.
Russia will finance the largest defense appropriation in her history through profits from her food industry, it was disclosed tonight.
Mrs. Irene E. Armstrong, Mayor of Daytona Beach, told the Supreme Court today that Governor Dave Sholtz had neither authority nor reason to remove her from office.

Ten Philadelphia labor unions, representing-60,000 workers, swung their support to John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization today at a meeting marking the opening of a. drive. to unionize mass production industries in this area.

With impressive solemnity, the Rev. Dr. William Appleton Lawrence was consecrated Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts by his father, the Right Rev. William Lawrence, retired Bishop of Massachusetts, at Christ Church Cathedral today. Church dignitaries and Episcopal laymen filled the cathedral.

The New York Rangers reach the halfway mark in their National Hockey League campaign tonight on the ice in Madison Square Garden by opposing the champion Detroit Red Wings, who now lead them by two points in the American division.

Eight passengers and the crew of fifty escaped from fire and a series of explosions aboard the British motorship Silver Cypress today when the ship was run aground near the Port of Buena Vista, on Guimara Island. The fire was expected to burn for several days.

Toronto capital has taken over the city's International League baseball franchise, president Frank Shaughnessy of the circuit said tonight, and the Maple Leafs next year will have Dan Howley back as manager.
Army's basketball team scored its third victory in as many starts today, the Cadets' blinding speed, clean handling of the ball and deadly shooting bringing a 50-17 triumph over Johns Hopkins.

William P. Thomas was elected president of the Bronx County Bar Association at its annual dinner meeting last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse. He succeeds Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr. of the Board of Transportation.
Chinandega was severely shaken by eleven earthquakes yesterday. No lives were lost, but four houses were destroyed and the walls of many were cracked.
Russia will finance the largest defense appropriation in her history through profits from her food industry, it was disclosed tonight.
Mrs. Irene E. Armstrong, Mayor of Daytona Beach, told the Supreme Court today that Governor Dave Sholtz had neither authority nor reason to remove her from office.

Ten Philadelphia labor unions, representing-60,000 workers, swung their support to John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization today at a meeting marking the opening of a. drive. to unionize mass production industries in this area.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following list of additional applications from New York City for registration with it as brokers and dealers in the overthe-counter market:

Members of the Society of Automotive Engineers were told at their annual meeting here today that the day when automobile bodies and chassis will be constructed in a single welded unit probably is not far in the future.
Sharp gains in engineering construction awards throughout the country for private work are shown in the report for 1936 of the Engineering News-Record.

John Barbirolli, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra during the last ten weeks and the first permanent conductor to be signed by the orchestra in fifteen years, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Washington for his home in England.

Germany's increasing indebtedness to Yugoslavia and obvious inability to pay for the Yugoslav raw materials that she is continually trying to increase have led the Yugoslav National Bank to draw up a plan for limiting such "purchases" and simultaneously forcing Germany to reduce her debts.

Employes of the Maritime Telegraph and Telephone Company who helped in the rescue of Dr. D. E. Robertson and Alfred Scadding, Toronto men, from the Moose River gold mine in April, turned over today a check for $600 to the Nova Scotia branch of the Red Cross Society.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday one amendment to the constitution of the Exchange extending the power of standing committees to inflict fines upon members and another giving authority to the committee on odd lots and specialists to supervise certain types of transactions in stocks by members on the floor of the Exchange.

President Roosevelt was kept in touch hourly today with developments in the automobile strike, but pending developments in Lansing tomorrow at the conference arranged by the Michigan Governor, the White House will not intervene.

Testimony yesterday on the third day of the hearing on charges that Swift Co. had engaged in unfair trade practices brought out the complaint that meat distributors were able to compete with Western packers in open bidding for the business of the navy and other public organizations, but that the packers got an exclusive trade with shipping lines by promising increased freight in return.

Howard Oxenberg of Erasmus Hall High established a new P. S. A. L. mark for 220-yards free style when he led the qualifiers for the event in 2:22 at the Columbia pool yesterday. Trials in the 220 and in fancy diving were held to cut down the field which will compete in the P. S. A. L. individual swimming championships tomorrow evening at the same pool.

The Senate gave unanimous approval today to the Dunnigan bill embodying Governor Lehman's social security program. The measure was blocked by the Republicans last year, becoming a leading issue in the State campaign.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday approved an over-theweight featherweight battle between Mike Belloise, recognized here as the class champion, and Johnny Cabello, Puerto Rican, to be held Jan. 21 at the Star Casino.
Brazilians and Americans met today at the Brazilian Foreign Office to establish the BrazilianAmerican Cultural Society to develop the cultural relations of the two nations.
Taking advantage of his light. weight of ninety-nine pounds, Toby Tyler ran away from a field of players in winning the mile-and-one-sixteenth feature for S. Moretti at the Fair Grounds today.

The State Department was informed today that the Venezuelan Government, in view of the most-favorednation treatment accorded Venzuelan products by the United States, has instructed the Venezuelan customs authorities to extend to American products the customs benefits accorded to France in the Franco-Venezuelan trade agreement of August 7, 1936.

Max L. Simon of Garfield, N. J., publisher, who was admitted to the State prison here last March 30 to serve a sentence of two to three years for arson in connection with the burning of his newspaper plant at Elizabeth, was paroled today by the Court of Pardons. His fine of $2,000 also was ordered remitted.

The petroleum industry has indicated that its contributions to the United Hospital Fund campaign will total $40,000, or almost 50 per cent more than the oil companies gave last year, it was reported yesterday by Frederick S. Fales, petroleum division chairman of the drive.

Arthur G. Jaeger, who was undersheriff of Queens County under Sheriff William F. Brunner, was sworn in yesterday as Sheriff in a brief ceremony in the Court House in Long Island City. The oath was administered by County Judge Charles S. Colden in the presence of about a score of friends of Mr. Jaeger and members of his staff.
The Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., of New York have been denied permission by the Public Service Commission to merge with the Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., of Delaware.

An estimate of $60,000,000 as the volume of sales during the two weeks of the Winter furniture show at the American Furniture Mart was made today by Frank S. Whiting, vice president of the American Furniture Mart. The exposition, which opened on Jan. 4 will continue. through. Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Peggy Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Davis of this place, to Harold D. Seeling, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Seeling of New York, took place today at the home of the bride's parents.

Lochinvar swam the Esk River and Edward VIII abandoned a throne because they were great lovers. There is nothing great about Soubre, whose role as a lover is thrust upon him by circumstances and was appropriately, irresolutely and evasively expressed by M. Journet in Tristan Bernard's comedy "Le Sexe Fort," given by the French Theatre of New York at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening -a premiere here. it is believed.

As Governor Earle formally approved plans for a legislative investigation of Philadelphia's government, enabling it to get under way tomorrow, steps were taken in the General Assembly today to prevent a breakdown in unemployment relief early next month.

Comment here on Senator Royal S. Copeland's presentation of a bill empowering President Roosevelt to negotiate with the German Government for creation of - a new mixed claims commission indicates that Germany would like to present claims of her own, thus producing some welcome foreign exchange.

Dennis Conan Doyle, son' of the late Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of "Sherlock Holmes," arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania with his wife, the former Princess Nina Mdivani. They will stay in this country six weeks, during which time he may lecture on spiritualism.

Governor Lehman announced today the commutation to life imprisonment of the death sentences imposed upon Wentworth Springer, Lawrence Jackson and Robert Taliaferro, Negroes, for the killing of Morris Emart in a New York City hold-up. They were to have died tomorrow night.

The American Business Men's Research Foundation has approved an annual report of its research department declaring "the most serious feature of the present liquor problem is the evident aim of liquor propaganda to conceal and camouflage the increasing waste and loss flowing from the relegalized liquor traffic."

I think that surely God in heaven Must marvel at His creatures' courage! Let but a shred of light be given, How they pursue it-how they forage Among the meager sheaves of Chance To glean a stalk! How they stand up And hurl the glove at Circumstance.

Cecil B. De Mille's "The Plainsman," which brought the warwhoop, the scalping knife and the ivory-handled revolver to the Paramount yesterday, is another of those action-crammed, spectacular and inaccurate canvases that Mr. De Mille delights to paint and audiences generally are delighted to see It is a picture in which small details are faithfully reproduced and established historical facts scrupulously rewritten.

THERE has come a peremptory summons from the stout Mr. Bill Brandt of the National League headquarters to get that baseball ballot in before closing day, which is tomorrow. Five former diamond stars were, in last year's balloting, hoisted to such lasting memory as the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y., may afford.

A furious whip and heel finish smashed the Hialeah Park track record as the Miami Jockey Club opened its fortysix-day meeting before 15,000 men in whites and women in Summer furs today. Whopper, the biggest

When the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrived yesterday there were ten members of the crew in the ship's hospital suffering from what the chief surgeon, Dr. J. Hill, described as a "mild attack of flu." About a dozen of the passengers, among whom was the Viscountess Rhonda, also were ill.
In the roughest game seen here this season, Providence College pulled an overtime basketball game out of the fire against Dartmouth tonight, winning by 57-51. Two mild fights occurred.

Reade St., 62, 5-story loft, Mutual Life Insurance Co. against Carrie W. Riesenfeld; due, $35,313; to plaintiff for $15,000. 108th St., 58-60 E., two 3-story houses; Frank H. Sincerbeaux, Albert W. Pross and William E. Shrewsbury, trustees of William H. Gebhard estate, Against Lichtman Realty Corp.; due, $26,573; taxes, , $1,215; to plaintiff for $20,000.

Carrying replacements and equipment for building an airport, the Coast Guard cutter Duane sailed from Pearl Harbor this morning for Howland Island, situated on possible air routes between Hawaii, Australia and New Zealand.

Michael Zadora began his Town Hall piano recital last night with Liszt's "The Christmas Tree," a composition that is so rarely played that it may be considered something of a novelty. It is a series of little vignettes, some gay, some sentimental and some religious in feeling.

Peter A. Juley, long a noted art photographer, whose firm, Peter A. Juley Son, has photographed more than 100,000 art objects, died yesterday of pneumonia at 219 East Thirty-ninth Street, where his office and home were located, after a brief illness. His seventy-fifth birthday would have occurred on Jan. 30.
A decided upward trend in railroad accidents resulting in the death and injury to passengers was revealed today in the annual report of the Bureau of Safety of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Several dinner parties were given last night in conjunction with the second Starlight Roof subscription dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria under the direction of Miss Fanshawe. The series is for younger married couples.

Pope Pius was allowed by his doctor to spend a few hours in his wheelchair this morning for the second time, since he had suffered no ill effects from the first experiment of leaving his bed yesterday.

Miles Connors, organizer of the United Mine Workers, issued a statement yesterday denying published reports that the Committee for Industrial Organization, through the newly chartered Gas and Coke Local 12,015 of the U. M. W., had opened a drive to organize, among others, the gas employes of the Consolidated Edison Company.

Construction of a spur from the Queens Boulevard line of the Independent Subway into the heart o?? the World's Fair site and enlargement of the Willets Point Boulevard, or World's Fair, station of the jointly operated I. R. T.B. M. T. Flushing line have been recommended by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Trans?? portation, and William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commi?? ??on, in a joint report.
The two 35,000-ton battleships to be built by the navy will have a speed of 26 to 27 knots and carry three turrets containing nine 16-inch guns or twelve 14-inch guns.

121st St., 310 W., 27x100.11; Herbert N. Armstrong to William T. Mason, 853 St. Nicholas Av., purchase money, $5,000 ($7.50). Spring St., 118, 22.3x51: Henry Zeltner, referee, to Central Savings Bank; foreclosure ($2).
Freshmen Congress members eager to learn the "ins and outs" of their jobs have established a school of their own, and have invited veteran members, Cabinet members and bureau chiefs to be teachers.
ALTHOUGH nearly twenty years have passed since Claude Debussy died in Paris, and nearly forty years since -his name first became generally known, he is still a subject of controversy.

Because of the high cost of living the government will establish commissaries throughout the country to sell the prime food necessities-including beans, rice, corn and lard-and also agricultural implements.

President Roosevelt "is determined to press for a more efficient organization of the people's business through a long-needed reorganization" of the machinery of the Federal Government, . Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, told an audience in Town Hall last night in a symposium on the question of extending and improving the civil service.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading in non-kosher meats was generally slow, though as usual even on a dull market, some cuts were in demand. Beef was mostly steady, but all other classes registered declines. As usual on Thursday, trading in kosher meats was limited to lamb. During Wednesday's trading, kosher meats sold slowly and all classes declined.

Paced by Jim Hawkins, lanky sophomore guard, who sank five long shots from the field, Bucknell University's quintet opened its 1937 intercollegiate season tonight with a 43-27 victory over Lafayette. The Bisons held a 19-10 lead at half time.

The bootleg coat traffic into this city from the Pennsylvania coal fields was the principal topic of speeches last night at the seventh annual dinner of the Anthracite Club of New York in the Hotel Astor. The organization is composed of representatives of large coal companies and- coal-hauling railroads.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Yorkville Court yesterday urged an immediate change of the ordinance that "permits a two-man religious organization to solicit funds on the streets without obtaining a permit from the Welfare Department."

The Alabama Supreme Court outlawed traffic parking meters in Birmingham today as an "unauthorized exercise of the taxing power" of the city. The court ruled that a Birmingham ordinance authorizing the installation of parking meters on downtown streets was invalid.
A further decline of $102,000,000 in money in circulation was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the Federal Reserve statements issued yesterday.

Mrs. John Henry Hammond gave a reception yesterday afternoon for more than 200 members of the Chautauqua Woman's Club of the Chautauqua Institution, of which she is a life member, at her home, 9 East Ninety-first Street. Since Sunday the women, who come from all parts of the country and Canada, have been visiting New York.

After hearing sharply conflicting testimony as to the sobriety of a couple married in Harrison a year ago, Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme dismissed this afternoon the bride's application for an annulment, and referred the entire matter to the District Attorney in an effort "to stamp out this marriage mill."

Retention of the present provisions of Regulation T, allowing a customer three days in which to post margin on purchases of securities has been proposed by the New York Stock Exchange to the Federal Reserve Board, with the assurance by the Exchange that it will

An attack on an important phase of the emergency real estate laws enacted in New York after the depression began was heard and taken under consideration by the Supreme Court today, but soon afterward the court abruptly checked arguments on another aspect of the real estate control plan.
DEBUSSY, by Edward Lockspeiser. (Dutton, $2.) A biography. REVOLT ON THE CLYDE, by William Gallacher. (International, $3.) Autobiography of a- Communist M. P.

A woman pedestrian was gravely injured and four taxicab passengers and their driver were hurt about 5:30 P. M. yesterday in a collision between a mail truck and the cab at Avenue J and East Seventeenth Street in the Midwood district of Flatbush, Brooklyn.

Those who feel that major honors on the race courses of our country are passing from the wealthy sportsmen and sportswomen to comparative newcomers who race large strings of players partly as a business project had further support today at Hialeah Park when Genie Palatine galloped home first in the Vero Beach Handicap.

Arturo Godoy, 195, of South America knocked out Jack Roper, 198 1/4, of California last night in 1:40 of the seventh of their scheduled tenround bout at the Star Casino before 1,500 persons. Referee Joe Vaccarelli stopped the bout because Roper was badly cut under both eyes.
The Jackson Heights team maintained its place at the head of the Group 1 teams in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association last night by defeating the Crescent A. C., 4-1.

Realizing the necessity of organizing a national body to promote and improve conditions in the industry, a group of boat yard owners assembled yesterday at the Hotel Lexington and after a three-hour session formed the American Association of Boat Builders and Repairers.

Disagreement among railroad union chiefs as to what differentials should exist between the wage scales of various classes of workers caused today a delay in the formulation of demands for increased pay as representatives of the five transportation brotherhoods finished their third day of deliberations.

Raising for the first time locally a legal issue paralleling that in the Scottsboro case, attorneys for the defense in the alleged $2,000,000-ayear restaurant racket took several steps yesterday which may delay the start of the trial of ten defendants scheduled to be in the Supreme Court Monday.

It's a long way off to the opening of the trout season, but the wise fisherman will spend a few of these Wintry evenings looking over his tackle and getting things in shape, so that when the big day arrives he will not step into the stream and discover, to his chagrin, a loose ferrule or some other defect in his rod sufficient to-ruin the trip.

The strike in East Coast ports of the Masters, Mates and Pilots of America and the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, which began on Nov. 23, was called off today after a conference between officials of the two organizations.

Adolf A. Berle Jr. was again sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as City Chamberlain. He was relieved of the duties of the office two months ago so that he might attend the Pan-American Peace Conference in Buenos Aires as a delegate of the United States.
For the fifth consecutive year piano production in 1936 showed a large increase, reaching a peak, of 90,358 units manufactured,- which is 38.83 per cent greater than the 1935 total of 65,086 units.
Lumber production increased last week, but less than seasonally, and the adjusted index dropped sharply to 68.2 from 83.1, the previous week's figure. For the week ended Jan. 11, 1936, it was 86.6.

An Insurgent offensive under the direction of General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, which aims to capture the important seaport of Malaga was reported to have scored its first success today when a force of 20,000 overwhelmed Estepona, a strongly fortified government town on the coast about forty-five miles southwest of Malaga.

An exceptionally extra-illustrated work on the city, "Old New York: or, Reminiscences of the Past Sixty Years," by Dr. John W. Francis, was sold for $2,500 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of rare books and autographs. The sale included lots from the collections of Mrs. Peter W. Rouss, Dr. Reginald Burbank and others.

Herman A. Metz, former City Controller, left an estate the gross value of which was $927,246 and which debts and other deductions reduced to a net of $493,342, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Metz died May 17, 1934.
It is reported that Swallow authorities are paying especial attention to Japanese and Formosan visitors.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the resignation on Dec. 21 of Joseph R. Swan as a member of the group of nonmember advisers to the governing committee.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob A. Rubenstein of this city and Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Norma Rubenstein, to Benedict I. Lubell of Tulsa, Okla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Lubell of this city.

A lean, youthful-appearing man in a dishevelled checked overcoat approached a policeman on Fortysecond Street near Grand Central Terminal last night and offered to "give himself up" because he was hungry and did not wish to turn to crime.
Policemen formed a net here today, watching steamships, trains and highways in an effort to capture two army officers who sensationally bolted from a hospital where they were interned.
Student elections at City College indicate an antiLeftist trend in the youngest college generation.

The first legislative repercussion to President Roosevelt's governmental reorganization program came today when Senator Byrd blocked immediate consideration by the Senate of a resolution extending the lending powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which expire Jan. 31, until June 30, 1939.

Surrogate James A. Foley approved yesterday an agreement settling a controversy between the children of the late George Backer, wealthy real estate operator, and Borough President Samuel Levy, who with Waldron P. Belknap of Huntington, L. I., and Mrs. Sarah Backer, the widow, had been executors and trustees of the estate.
The following Marine Corps orders for the week ended Jan. 14 were announced today: Coffenberg, Maj. B. M., promoted to Major.

America's "first surgical unit and ambulance corps for Madrid" will sail tomorrow to assist the besieged Loyalist forces in Spain, it was announced yesterday by the American Friends of Spanish Democracy, whose medical bureau is sponsoring the project.

The transfer of one membership in the New York Stock Exchange and the prospective sale of three others were announced yesterday by the Exchange. The seat of the late Joseph L. Lilienthal has been sold to Thomas F. Troxell.
Knoxville whistlers found out today they are subject to a $50 fine if caught publicly tweeting "Ta-rara-boom-de-ay," "After the Ball"

The La Follette Senate subcommittee investigating violations of civil lib erties heard two witnesses today tell stories of police persecution and a flogging administered by persons who could not be indicted because of the fear that such action would antagonize the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company.

A bill to legalize the recent agreement entered into by Controller Taylor of New York City and bankers for modification of the. "bankers' agreement," was introduced today by Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader of the Assembly.

Contributions totaling $302 were received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total received to date to $270,102.88. Sixteen contributors were represented in the donations received during the day.

Mr. and Mrs. Landon K. Thorne will give a reception at their home, 740 Park Avenue, on Tuesday afternoon for their son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Landon K. Thdrne Jr. Princess Margaret Boncompagni, who arrived on the Bremen, is at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to her home in Washington.

Meat dealers in this vicinity and from Philadelphia testified yesterday concerning what they called discriminations of meat packing companies in matters of price and terms of credit, at the hearing by the Department of Agriculture on unfair trade practices in this field.

There is no hope for the establishment of real democracy in Spain in the near future, William P. Carney, Madrid correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, asserted yesterday at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore, giving what he called a newspaper man's impartial view of the "frightful, fratricidal conflict in Spain."

The Cincinnati Morris Plan Bank has elected Fred W. Hinkle first vice president, succeeding the late Morris J. Freiberg. Mr. Hinkle had been treasurer of the bank since its organization in 1918. Max Hirsch, secretary, becomes treasurer and Frederick V. Geier succeeds him as secretary.
Cardinal Hayes, who arrived by train from New York, was among those departing this afternoon. aboard the steamship New Northland from Miami for Nassau for a Winter vacation.

Amsterdam Av., s. w. cor. 108th St., 100.11x75; E. C. Equities, Inc., Etta Cherkos, president to 974 Amsterdam Av. Corp., 1,450 Broadway; purchase money prior mtg., $600,000; 5 years, 6 per cent. $35,000.
Squash racquets experts seeking the national professional singles title ended first-round play today on the Metropolitan Club courts with Ben Pope, home club player, making a successful start.
Judge James A P. Parmenter, for twenty-eight years a justice in the Boston municipal court, died at his home, 39 Russell Street, Arlington, today. He was 77 years old.

The net written premium volume of the General Reinsurance Corporation for 1936 was $5,217,511, the largest since 1929 and $503,122 in excess of the 1935 total of $4,714,389, it was announced. yesterday.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the second state dinner- on the White House social schedule, entertaining in honor of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and Mrs. Bankhead.
The five United States Army officers who will participate in the forthcoming International Horse Show at Valparaiso visited Santiago today. They were escorted by Colonel

A general offensive by all the forces at the disposal of General Francisco Franco, Spanish Rebel leader, in a final effort to crush the Leftists in Spain, is expected as the result of two conversations between Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister; Premier Benito Mussolini

Austin Ryan, 16-year-old schoolmate of Robert John Young, also 16, who ran away from his New Rochelle home Jan. 4, confessed to police here this afternoon that he was the author of "ransom" notes demanding $10,000 from his chum's parents for information as to Robert's whereabouts which he did not possess.
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta's Davis cupper. and Charlie Harris of West Palm Beach reached the singles semi-finals of the annual Dixie tennis tournament today with straightset victories.

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange have approved applications to list the following securities on the Exchange: Brown-Forman Distlllery Company-15,000 outstanding shares of $6 no-par cumulative preferred stock.

Payment of principal and interest on the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland 5 1/2 per cent twenty-year bonds, due on Feb. 1, will be made in accordance with the judgment to be handed down by the House of Lords on an appeal before the House of the decision of

State Senator James A. Simpson announced today a special committee of the American Ba Association, of which he is chairman; had recommended carrying the principle governing commerce in -prisonmade goods into the field of child labor.
The Zeppelin Transportation Company announced today that the new luxury Zeppelin LV-130 would be placed in service next Autumn and the old Graf Zeppelin would be withdrawn.

Turpentine firm, 431c; sales, 43 barrels; receipts, 57 barrels; shipments, 127 barrels; stock, 31,436 barrels. Resin quiet; no sales; receipts, 949; shipments, 2,270; stock, 75,770. Quote: B, $9.80; D, $9.90; E. $10; F, $10.50; G, H, I, K, M and N. $10.60; WG, $12; WW and X, $13.
While the demand for hogs was only fair today, prices advanced 5 to 10 cents in the face of reports of lower prices for fresh pork loins in the leading markets.
