Declaring the Federal Social Security Act is constitutional under the general welfare clause of the Constitution, Judge David J. Davis of the Federal District Court, dismissed suits of more than 200 Alabama concerns seeking to enjoin collection of the tax.

Hearing on a suit against License Commissioner Paul Moss to invalidate the city's right to regulate fees charged by private employment agencies has been begun in Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday, and a decision on its first legal skirmish was expected from Justice Aron Steuer today or tomorrow.
A tragic message written in the snow, "one dead-three sickneed medical aid-Prettyman party," caused a rescue group to redouble efforts today in an effort to reach a snow-covered cabin.

Louis Lazar, 29 years old, of 247 Rivington Street, Manhattan, convicted in 1935 of killing Morris Saskowitz, 55, at the latter's home, 430 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, in an argument over a $25 painting bill, was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison here tonight.

Discovery of a submerged mountain ridge, three ancient volcanoes, and a new deep spot in the Caribbean Sea was reported today by three scientists returning from the Navy Department's under-water exploration of the area.

After their parents had. been ordered to appear and "see their sons behind prison bars" and they had signed a pledge not to drink, Patrick Martin, 19 years old, of 174 East Seventy-fourth Street, and Andrew Giblin, 23, of 178 East Seventy-seventh Street, charged with damaging an Eighty-sixth Street crosstown bus Wednesday morning, were sentenced to six months in workhouse by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Yorkville Court yesterday. Sentence was suspended.
Upper Manhattan and Harlem housing properties again proved attractive to operators and investors in deals announced yesterday. Sales of multi-family buildings in the Bronx also were reported. .

A syndicate headed by William M. Girden has purchased the sixstory elevator apartment house on a plot 200 by 100 feet at 4,100 Forty-third Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, from the Arthur A. Johnson Corporation. The property was held at $400,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $290,000 at 5% per cent for five years.

MANHATTAN CATLIN, DONALD C. (Jan. 3, 1936); Gross assets, $6,421; net, a deficit. Wingate Cullen, attorneys, 142 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn. HENLE. JOHN (Dec. 3, 1933). Gross assets, $29,694; net, $29,249. To Estelle Henle, widow, whole estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $23,592. Wise, Shepard Hougton, attorneys, 30 Broad St.
Authorization of women as jurors and a statute hitting at -"radio courts" were recommended in the annual report of the Judicial Council submitted to the Legislature today.

Holding its opponent to a pair, of field goals in the last half, the Manual Training quintet accounted for its first triumph in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. tournament by vanquishing Samuel J. Tilden, 21-13, on the loser's ocur? yesterday. Previous to the contest.

Foreseeing an easy-going day with the sultry weather thinning out the crowds on the lower level and chasing them upstairs to the engines, gadgets and accessories on the mezzanine and third floors, many of the exhibitors and nearly all of the visiting yachtsmen played hookey from the National Motor Boat Show yesterday to gorge on luncheons, plain dinners and fancy banquets in the Lexington Avenue district.

I. Nicholas Gordon, the lawyer who successfully defended former Magistrate George F. Ewald against charges that he purchased the magistracy and has been a fugitive from justice for nearly three years, was held yesterday in $2,000 bail for trial on a charge of impersonating 'an army officer.

A demonstration of teaching methods will be given at the Annot Art School at 11 o'clock Saturday morning. Rudolph Jacobi will block in a painting while Annot will explain each step in the procedure. Free tickets of admission may be obtrained at the office of the school, 505 Fifth Avenue.

George Sandfuch. and Reinhold Brenner, welders, who said their homes were in Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, and that they were born in Germany, were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of attacking a passenger on a subway train last July 20 after he protested when they pulled the. beard of another passenger and laughingly yelled: "Heil Hitler!"

John Sanford of 9 East Seventysecond Street and Palm Beach has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his elder daughter, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford, to Mario Pansa, noted Italian diplomat, lawyer, soldier and big game hunter.

Mrs. Elizabeth Taylor Walker of this city, daughter of Mrs. Waller Taylor of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Taylor, was married yesterday afternoon to Walter Grey Dunnington, also of New York, in the bride's apartment at the Carlyle. Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church, a former law partner of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

Distribution of extra and special dividends before the end of 1936 enabled Supervised Shares, Inc., to avoid liabilities under the tax on undistributed profits, Merrill Griswold, chairman, and Mahlon E. Traylor, president, said in a quarterly report issued yesterday.
She heard Life whispering the final word And through the mist that closed about her eyes She saw Death hold aloft his flaming sword To sever the last shred of earthly ties.

The operations through which stockholders' money was dissipated by Cities Service Company interests, as charged by six investors, were indicated by their counsel yesterday at the trial for an accounting being held before Judge John W. Clancy in the Federal court, Foley Square.

In the twelfth successive week of advance The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 139.3 on Tuesday from 137.9 the Tuesday previous. Price changes were virtually all upward, only rye, butter, eggs and apples being lower. THE ANNALIST WEEKLY INDEX OF WHOLESALE COMMODITY PRICES

The New York figure-skating four-with the same members as last year, namely Miss Ardelle Kioss, Miss Nettie Prantel, Joseph K. Savage and George Boltres-has a new program which was exhibited for the first time last night at the weekly Thursday tea of the Skating Club of New York.

Something or other has been done about getting Frank Parker on the stage in "Howdy Stranger," which was put on at the Longacre last evening. Mr. Parker is a radio tenor of infinite fame with a pleasant voice and an unobjectionable personality.

In what Assistant District Attorney Americus Della Paoli described as "the biggest of the charity rackets yet unearthed," eight men and four women were arrested yesterday for allegedly defrauding members of Protestant and Catholic church parishes in the New York area.

THERE are some who say that the zone defense is killing college basketball, but, if so, it must be mass murder. The last time this observer saw the alleged "killing" going on it was surrounded by thousands of raving rooters who seemed to be enjoying the crime carnival no little bit.

Mrs. Hattie L. Dreyer, who during her residence in Brooklyn, where she was born, was active in women's charitable organizations, died today at the home here of her daughter, Mrs. Ira C. Jones. She was 70 years old.

Pleas of guilty to bringing into this city eight tons of coal which had been stolen in the anthracite region in Pennsylvania were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Pasquale Sognamiglio, 29 years old, of 758 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, and his driver, Milton Hobby, 29, of 366 State Street, Brooklyn.

Palestine Jewry gave an enthusiastic welcome, despite pouring rain. to the new Chief Rabbi, Dr. J. A. Herzog, on his arrival today. Dr. Herzog gave up a similar post in Ireland to, succeed the late Chief Rabbi Kook of Jerusalem.

These orders were isued in the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. Dana P. Todd, Inf.-Res., home address, 404 West 115th St., New York, N. Y., now at Walter Reed General Hospital, Army Medical Center, Washington, D. C., is relieved from further active duty with the CCC, effective Jan. 24.

There are in Washington a number of highly important regulatory agencies with which business men must deal: to name a few, the Federal Trade Commission, the Securities and Exchange Commission. the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal Communications Commission.

Miss Mary Webster Kay, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Richardson Kay, formerly of this city, was married this afternoon to Bellinger Dunham at the home here of her aunt, Mrs. J. Berton Carnett.

Owners and skippers of the Rumson Country Club ice boat fleet met yesterday and selected four craft, two of which will defend the organization's new Eastern Championship Ice Boat Pennant of America, the initial challenge for which was received from the Musconetcong Ice Boat and Yacht Club.
Although we are still in the middle of Winter and Davis Cup play does not start until May, every tennis enthusiast throughout the world is starting to predict the outcome of the 1937 competition.

A merit rating system, based on employment security, and a provision for contributions by employes as well as employers to the insurance fund would become features of the State Employment Insurance Law if amendments to that statute introduced today receive favorable action in the Senate and Assembly.

Miss Louise Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dunn of Tenafly, N. J., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension to John Randolph Rutherford of this city and Chicago, son of Mrs. Rutledge Rutherford of Larchmont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Rutherford. The Rev. Dr.

Remington Rand, Inc., in its report for the quarter ended on Dec. 31, 1936, which will be made public today, shows a net income of $1,057,243 after depreciation, taxes and all charges, including nonrecurring expenses incident to plant removal.

The immediate formation of a "board of public investment" to consider methods of investment to consider methods of combating the worst effects of a possible future depression is urged by John Maynard Keynes, British economist, in the last of three artides on "How to Avoid a Slump" which appears in The Times today.

Death Valley Scotty is broke, does not even have title to the automobile he is driving, his partner, Albert M. Johnson, declared today. "I don't know of any property he owns, and he owes a lot of money," said Mr. Johnson. "He's over in Kingman, Ariz., leading a parade or something in a jubilee.
Miss Marie Elizabeth Elg, a native-born and unmarried woman resident of New York, won today the first step of a battle she has undertaken to prevent her deportation.

Ohio -legislators tuned their ears today preparatory to the business of selecting an official State song. Senator E. N. Waldvogel of Cincinnati brought the matter up with a resolution seeking adoption of "Ohio Holds My Heart," with words by Mrs. Mabel Posegate and music by Miss Louise Snodgrass.
Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of-Chicago in 1936 were $932,178, according to the annual statement of the bank received here yesterday. Gross operating

President Arturo Alessandri continued this afternoon his effort to form a new Cabinet to replace that whose collective resignation was tendered yesterday as a climax to political difficulties that had been growing in intensity for a fort-night.

Announcement that a new "empire trade agreement" between Canada and Great Britain had been reached in principle was the most important item in the speech from the throne as the Dominion Parliament opened today.

JACOBS, LEONORA (Jan. 8). Estate, less than $5,000. To Seville Kruger, sister. | 565 W. 169th St., 2/5ths residue; Israel i D. Block, brother, executor, 565 W'. 169th St., 3/5ths residue; two bequests of personal property.

Man's ultimate in sport, especially in track and field, where marks are measurable, remains a matter of conjecture. The magnificent accomplishments of the past year, when records were toppled with astonishing frequency, demonstrated that the perfection of technique and other factors still bring forth incredible performances.

The investigation of the Van Sweringen railroad system by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today was a succession of charges against the Guaranty Trust Company and its security affiliate, the Guaranty Company.

Check clearings of the principal cities throughout the country amounted to $5,947,182,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a gain of 5 per cent over the $5,661,718,000 reported in the corresponding week a year ago.

John J. Cone, former Supreme Grand Knight of the Knights of Columbus, died at his home, 232 Ocean Avenue, Deal, near here, early today. He was 79 years of age and headed the Knights of Columbus in the United States from 1896 to 1900.

Sister M. Edwarda McDonough, O. S. B., a native of this city, died last night at the Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N. Y., after a long illness. Born in this city seventy-six years ago, she was a daughter of the late John and Elizabeth Moore McDonough.

Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday declined to permit Edward J. Hickey of Washington, D. C., a minority stockholder, to argue a motion attacking the plan of reorganization of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation.

No sooner had Senator NORRIS returned to Washington than the roughand-ready amenders of the Constitution went to him for advice. They also needed a little aid and comfort, for the President's message to Congress had left them in a somewhat awkward position.

Although speakers at the opening session here today of the forty-first annual convention of the New York State Association of Builders were optimistic in regard to a building boom, a warning on recent and future State and Federal legislation was given by Thomas Harris Cole of this city, president of the association.

This odd January weather is probably going to get the flowers into trouble, and if birds all over the New York area are having as much difficulty trying to get organized as those in Nyack, N. Y., they also are in a position to lose heavily through nature's recent chicanery.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended on Jan. 13 declined $937,802 from the previous week, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits by chartered banks showed an increase of $1,611,041 over the preceding week.

Misfortune continued to pursue the metropolitan skiing army yesterday, adverse weather conditions causing the New Haven and New York Central Railroads to announce last night the cancellation of their "snow trains" scheduled to leave tonight for Ticonderoga and the Catskills in New York; Manchester.

Johnny Vruwink tallied 17 points tonight to break Princeton's fourgame losing streak with a 31-27 victory over Cornell, sending the Ithacans to the bottom of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League with three losses in as many starts.

Francis Rawle Wadleigh, coal engineer and Federal Fuel Distributor during the Harding administration, died today in Alexandria Hospital after- an illness of more than a- year. He was in his seventy-second year.

President Roosevelt facetiously declined an invitation today to attend his own inauguration on Jan. 20, but reconsidered later and notified the Inaugural Committee that he "thought" he could arrange his affairs to permit him to be present.

Schuyler Merritt 2d and Paul M Strieffler have been admitted as general partners and Mildred Gwynne as a limited partner of Riter Co., from which firm Reinert M. Torgerson, general partner, and Arthur Gwynne, limited partner, have withdrawn.

The Republic of Chile has declared an interest payment, to be made on Feb. 1, at the rate of $6.05 a $1,000 bond on the thirteen direct and guaranteed external dollar loans of the Republic, it was announced yesterday by the Autonomous Institute for the Amortization

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar, conversion agent and agent for the exchange of temporary for definitive debentures, in New York, for an authorized issue of $10,000,000 of Union Oil Company of California fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due Jan. 1, 1952.

About 60 per cent of the government's public debt of more than $34,000,000,000 is in long-term bonds, the first block of which are callable in 1940, Secretary Morgenthau said today. This block, which will mature in 1943, amounts to $352,993,950.

The State of Minnesota awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,225,000 of certificates of indebtedness to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and the Manufacturers and Traders

The honeymoon of Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands was marred today by a touch of grip. The Princess, suffering from the malady, remained in her hotel apartment while her bridegroom, Prince Bernhard, went skiing alone.
The New Orleans Belt Railway has ordered three oil-electric locomotives from the Baldwin Locomotive Works, according to Railway Age. The Wabash Railway is in the market for 200 hopper cars.

Two Chinese members of the crew of the British motor vessel Maron of the Blue Funnel Line, on which customs inspectors seized 330 pounds of opium on Tuesday, were held in bail of $75,000 each on charges of possessing and smuggling opium by United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn.
Severe rains sent rivers and creeks pouring over their banks in Ohio tonight, causing considerable suffering to residents of low-lying sections and damaging factories in the valleys.

Governor Frank Murphy announced at 3 o'clock this morning that a truce has been arranged in the strike of members of the United Automobile Workers Union against General Motors Corporation, which has thrown nearly 120,000 men out of work in the last two weeks.

A large folio-covered lithograph by Currier Ives, "Home to Thanksgiving," was sold for $1,010 last night at the Plaza Art Auction Galleries at the sale of American lithographs from the collection of Mrs. Hayes Quincy Trowbridge of New Haven, Conn. The buyer was the Orsenigo Company.
Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio gave dinner party tonight in their residence on La Brisa Way, taking their guests later to see the motion picture "Romeo and Juliet." Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Robert D.

Dave Levin, Jamaica, L. I., grappler, threw Dr. John Murphy of Ireland in the finish encounter at the New York Hippodrome before 4,500 persons last night. The victor, weighing 198 pounds, employed a body spread in pinning his rival, who weighed 191, in 11:53.

Dr. William Henry Collins, director of the Canadian Geological Survey until a departmental reorganization, when he became consultant to the mines and geology branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, died today at the age of 58. He was an acknowledged
John Elverson, a reporter for The Asbury Park Press for seven years, died today at the Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune, N. J., of pneumonia at the age of 28.

An all time high in daily average sales of merchandise in small towns and rural areas was reached in December, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Representative Rankin of Mississippi tried to push through the House today a resolution to investigate the conduct of Judge John J. Gore of the Federal Middle District of Tennessee, with a view to impeaching him for his injunctions against the Tennessee Valley Authority and for other reasons, but his efforts were blocked temporarily by an objection of Representative Michener of Michigan.

Nuchols, a consistent plater from J. C. Ellis's barns, came from off the pace in the home stretch to annex the mile and seventy-yard feature and chalk up his second straight victory today at the Fair Grounds.

A change in admission requirements at the Harvard Law School was ordered today, effective at the beginning of the next academic year, as the result of a study which shows a close correlation between success in college and success in the Law School as well as a marked difference in the standards required in colleges.

While fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held within narrow limits yesterday for the fourth successive session and ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 5 points, features of the trading were the liquidation of March and relative steadiness of distant deliveries.
A new peak in cotton consumption by domestic mills for a single month in more than three years was reported today by the Census Bureau as it released December totals.

Edward Lyons was re-elected yesterday president of the board of trustees of the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn at the annual meeting of the board of trustees. This was the eleventh time that Mr. Lyons had been elected

Strenuous but inconclusive efforts were made here today by Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, and Malcolm MacDonald, British Secretary for the Dominions, to settle the trade war and other differences that have kept the two governments at loggerheads ever since 1932.

Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner here today, an early decline-in sympathy with Liverpool being followed by an advance of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the low level, but the buying was mainly of a local character.

The New York Florists' Club will mark the fiftieth anniversary of its founding at a golden jubilee dinner tomorrow evening in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mayor La Guardia has been invited as guest of honor.

Mrs. William Warner Hoppin, founder and president of Amateur Needlework of Today, announced yesterday the names of additional winners of awards in the organization's third annual exhibition, which is being held at W. J. Sloane's, Fifth Avenue and Fortyseventh Street, for the benefit of the New York Association for the Blind.

Readjustment of the tax base to encourage the cooperation of private property owners to provide lowrent housing and slum clearance was advocated yesterday by Dwight L. Hoopingarner, associate director of the Public Works Housing Division, before the Housing Section of the Welfare Council at the Russell Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.
Today, as so often in bygone years, John Van Buren- Thayer, dean of New York bankers, will be honored on the two-fold anniversary of his birth and the beginning of his career.

The sixteen-story apartment at 290 West End Avenue was bought at auction yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff, on a bid of $750,000, in an action against the 290 Holding Corportion for $1,090,000 and interest and taxes and other liens of about $35.000.

Illegal hunting by sportsmen who own their own game preserves and by "market shooters" makes continuance of the drastic wild-duck conservation regulations necessary, Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, declared last night at the first annual duck hunters' dinner of the American Wild Life Institute at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Former President Carlos Brenes Jarquin has been appointed Nicaraguan Minister to Washington and will leave with his family next week. Dr. Jarquin was Provisional President from June until Jan. 1.
Donald G. Ross of the law firm of Ross Miller heads the group of Toronto citizens who purchased the franchise and other assets of the Toronto Baseball Club in the International League.

The Atlas Powder Company yesterday announced the acquisition of "Revolite," a flexible resinoid coated fabric, formerly manufactured by the Revolite Corporation, a subsidiary of Johnson Johnson. The fabric will be made in Stamford, Conn., by the Zapon division of the company.
In the presence of a large number of leaders in the steel industry and others, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation will open its new 100inch semi-continuous plate mill here tomorrow.

The Mutual Investment Fund, operated by the Mutual Investment Management Company, reported for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1936, the value of $16.73 a share of Mutual Investment certificates after all expenses, dividends, deductionn for State and city taxes,

A man, said by police to be Dominick Guastella, 28 years old, of 229 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, was found dead at 1:30 P. M. yesterday in the cellar of a vacant house at 1,623 East Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, by William Dahncke, owner of the house.
Walter G. Austin, Democratic Mayor of Stamford in 1913 and 1914, died today at his home on Travis Avenue. He was 83 years old. He was a retired executive of the Yale Towne Manufuacturing a Company.

Wagner's "The laying Dutchman" had its second performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large and enthusiastic assemblage. The cast was identical with that of the previous presentation, with Kirsten Flagstad repeating her success as Senta, and Friedrich Schoor his in the title part.

Baron Leo de Graffenried, husband of the former Irma Stern of New York, died yesterday at Cannes, France, according to a cable received here by relatives. He was about 67 years old. The Baron's marriage to Miss Stern, daughter of the late Louis Stern, New York merchant, was performed on Dec. 10, 1907, by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A number of stores figured in the reports yesterday from brokers of commercial space rentals. Schooner, Inc., leased the store and second floor at 47 West Fifty-first Street for a restaurant, through Burgoyne Hamilton Company, Inc.

A decision to permit the Eastern Interclub Basketball League to join the A. A. U. as a unit, but to conduct its tournament as a closed competition was reached yesterday at a closed meeting of the metropolitan association's registration committee as a means of averting what threatened to resolve into open warfare between the A. A. U. and the club teams.
The Montreal Maroons and Chicago Black Hawks staged the biggest scoring spree of the National Hockey League season tonight with the Maroons coming out on the long end of a 7-3 score.

" Frederika" will open here on Feb. 4 at the Forty-sixth Street and not on Feb. 3 at the Imperial. as the Shuberts previously announced. ... Instead, the Imperial will get the premiere on Feb. 22 of "Jane

Protesting what they termed "poor food and high prices," fifty men and women students sat down in a coffee shop of the Young Men's Christian Association Central College. They brought their own lunches and occupied all tables, preventing other customers from entering. Dr.

The outlook for business in this country is good, George W. Davison, chairman of the board of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting at noon yesterday in the head office, 70 Broadway.

The Rumanian Government has decided upon the strictest neutrality in the Spanish conflict. All consular authorities have been instructed to prevent Rumanian citizens abroad from joining either faction. The Rumanian Legation at BurSpanish Insurgent headquar has been ordered to call on the seven Rumanian volunteers with General Francisco Franco's army to return immediately.

Little children at Center School who break the traffic laws do more than stay after 'school. Reckless bicycle riders are sentenced to bump around the rocky part of the playground; "runners," children caught darting across the road, trot around the school grounds until they are tired- out, and middle-ofthe-road walkers must trudge back and forth between home and school half a dozen times a day.

Two anonymous donations totaling $14,500 to the United Hospital Fund campaign were announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive to raise a minimum of $2,881,000 for the eighty-eight voluntary hospitals of the city. He made public the following gifts of $100 or more:

The New York Stock Exchange has subscribed to $100,000 of the New York World's Fair issue of 4 per cent debentures for pre-exposition financing, Richard Whitney, head of the fair's bond sales committee, announced yesterday.

Reference to the conflict between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor, as indicating that differences do arise within trade union ranks no less than between trade unions and so-called company unions, was ruled out as irrelevant by the National Labor Relations

Possible exemption of railroads from the payment of taxes on undistributed profits enacted in the tax law of 1936 was disclosed today at the White House by President Roosevelt, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and Carroll Miller,

Germany's political philosophy as it affects other countries of the world was vigorously defended yesterday by Dr. Hans Luther, Reich Ambassador to the United States, who returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after visiting his home for the first time in a year and a half.
Detroit's Red wings strengthened their grip on first place in the American division of the National Hockey League by defeating the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

Belief that police had found the lair of Charles Mattson's kidnapper-killer spread tonight when State officers were reported to have picked up apparently blood-stained clothing in a shack five miles from where the victim's frozen body was dumped.

The dauntless navy of motor boat pilots, both of outboard and inboard craft, will compete in a larger number of regattas in 1937 than during the last few years. Following a meeting of the racing commission of the American Power Boat Association yesterday, Charles F. Chapman, "czar" of the sport, announced the slate of events sanctioned.

The Third Reich put into service without fanfare today the first destroyer of its augmented fleet. The 1,625-ton warship, first of sixteen "of an entirely new type" to be laid down in consonance with the 1935 Anglo-German naval treaty, was launched secretly some time ago, it was learned.

Dr. George B. Emory, a member of the medical staff of the New York Stock Exchange and active in military circles, died here today at his home, 1 Franklin Place. His age was 57. Dr. Emory was born in Syracuse, N. Y., was graduated from Harvard College in 1902 and from the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia in 1905.

The Board of Directors of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association has taken cognizance of the growing need to protect the skiing public as well as the high reputation of the sport from the selfstyled instructors, it was learned yesterday.

Thomas Robins Jr., president of the Hewitt Rubber Corporation of Buffalo, announced yesterday that the company will register soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new issue of 52,000 shares of common stock, proceeds of which will be used to retire
In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Henry Weiner, John L. Flynn and Agnes S. Gilligan of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Opinions may differ as to the economic wisdom of the National Industrial Recovery Act, but there was no doubt among the justices of the Supreme Court that its enactment was wholly beyond the power of Congress, whether expressed 'or "conceded."
Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago mail order house, began distribution today of its 1937 Spring and Summer general catalogue to about 6,500,000 families.

The list of the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, due today from the Channel ports, includes Dr. Ernst Leo Baer, German consul general in Chicago; Dr. and Mrs. Walther Becker, William H. Davis, Emil C. de Leuw, Mr. and Mrs. V. Van der Linde, Mrs. James S. Wiles, James C. Moore, William Winter and Miss Doris Griffith.

The snow man left New England Winter sportswear vendors and mountain hotel keepers holding the bag tonight for the fifth successive week; Well-planned ballyhoo - which styled the section the "leading Winter sports area east of the Rockies" -has simmered down to a whisper as ski clubs, innkeepers, merchants and ' manufacturers frowningly gazed on hills and dales, as barren as they were in November.

Another sterling performance by Thomas R. Coward, national Class A champion fifteen years ago, who now is staging a brilliant comeback after many comparatively inactive seasons, featured the quarter-finals of. the annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tourney at the Yale Club yesterday.

The march of Miss Ann Weeks of Cedarhurst through the metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship was halted yesterday .by the more experienced Miss Susan Guion, No. 1 player on the Staten Island team.

William Moore, 25 years old, of 364 West Forty-third Street, died in Polyclinic. Hospital yesterday from a bullet fired by a policeman who caught him running from a tailor shop that was robbed shortly before midnight Wednesday. A companion, Alphonse Grillo, 27, of 339 West Forty-third Street, was captured and held on a burglary charge.

A brief asking that the impeachment of former President Miguel Mariano Gomez be declared unconstitutional has been presented to the Senate by Dr. Tomas Gutierrez Alea, former Assistant Secretary of Communications and secretary of the Republican party, headed by Dr. Gomez.

After thirty years of service with the National Theatre here in various capacities from handbill distributor to manager, S. E. (Steve) Cochran announced today that the New York owners of Washington's only active domicile of the legitimate stage had rung down the curtain on his stewardship.

A rally among United States Government obligations was the feature of an otherwise listless session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The governments enjoyed their best upturn since the downward trend in those issues began with the development of uncertainty over the immediate course of the money market.
The Rebels holding the Clinical Hospital in University City are cut off from their base of supplies and have to be fed from planes.

After hitch-hiking and riding a bus here from St. Petersburg, Fla., on a capital of $4, Mrs. Louise Ferris, 17-year-old mother of a 2-monthold baby, was taken to the Greenwich Street police station yesterday morning after she had collapsed in a restaurant where she had spent 25 of her last 40 cents.

Henri Morin de Linclays, United States representative of the French Line, returned yesterday on the Paris from a month's vacation in Europe. He inspected the Normandie in drydock at Havre and gave the opinion that the big ship would be capable of greater speed after returning to service March 10.

Four children were burned to death and a fireman was seriously injured when flames destroyed a small frame house here early today. The victims were Violet, 15; Rita, 11; Jean, 7 and Martha, 3, all children of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Petrillia.

Lionel F. Boffey, industrial purchasing agent and trade journal publisher, was found dead of illuminating-gas poisoning last night in his home at 116 Prospect Street here by his wife, Mrs. Viola M. Boffey. She found her husband lying on the kitchen floor, with his head in front of a gas-filled oven and a blanket thrown like a tent over his head and the cooking stove.

To Jerzy Fitelberg, Polish composer, has been awarded the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge prize of $1,000 offered in 1936 by the Library of Congress under the provisions of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation.

The Bureau Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 12: COMMANDERS Luckel, F. H., San Diego, Calif., to home, relieved all active duty, about June 15. Nelson, W., Washington, D. C., to instruction, Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla.
The Rev. Dr. Don S. Colt, who had served fifty years as a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died here this afternoon at the age of 75.

An elaborate satire on feminine faithlessness, Albert Arlen's dramatization of Charles Pettie's book, "Son of the Grand Eunuch," which met with success in the United States, was privately presented in Arts Theatre tonight.

The Advertising Federation of America yesterday entered a protest against passage of a bill in the Kentucky Legislature requiring every owner of a trade-mark or brand name to obtain State registration in order to do business in Kentucky, with payment of a fee of $45 for registering each trade-mark.
The American Federation of Labor reported today that 2,000,000 unemployed went to work in the year ended in November.

King Vidor and Paramount severed relations today, and the breach between the studio and Cary Grant over the terms of a new contract widened to such an extent that it is probable the actor will join R.-K.O. after his present agreement
Howard S. Mott, retired vice president of the Irving National Bank of New York, died here tonight at his residence, 25 Knoll Road. He was 63 years old.

Orders for machine tools last month reached the highest volume for any single month in the association's records, C. R. Burt, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, announced yesterday. Basing his statement on

W. Forbes Morgan, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, is considering a proposal from leaders of the liquor industry that he head the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., the self-regulatory body set up by the industry, it became known last night.

John E. Smith, in 71 E. 77th St., through Pease Elliman, Inc.; Miss Dorothy Carcenter, in 148 E. 61st St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker. Dr. Julian Welsh, in 203 W. 107th St.: Harry G. Twining, in 552 W. 141st St.: William Stubbs, in 670 Riverside Drive; Lillian

The Berkshire Knitting Mills strike reached a new stage of civic dissension today when the only nonSocialist City, Councilman, Frederick A. Muhlenberg, Republican and former chairman of his party's county committee, backed Mayor J. Henry Stump in the Mayor's retort to anti-vandalism petitions presented to the city government yesterday.

Tammany Leader James J. Dooling, who has been ill for many months, "is on the way to full recovery," Senator Royal S. Copeland told 1,800 persons attending the annual dinner of the Tammany Hall speakers bureau at the Hotel Commodore last night. His announcement was greeted with cheers.

" Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage" for 1937 published its 95th edition on the eve of the new year with King. Edward VIII on the throne. The reason is that the reference book of British nobility has a year of its own which begins on Dec. 10.

Problems' of in-between price lines, or the introduction of new price lines, due to advancing wholesale quotations and Increased taxation were considered yesterday at the meeting of store heads and merchandise managers held by the Cavendish Trading Corporation at its offices here.
Out of Tuesday's fatal airliner crash came Federal and county investigations tonight into operating conditions affecting transport flights in the Los Angeles area.
The committee on: stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the receipt of applications to list the following securities:

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn overruled yesterday the objections of a group of wealthy residents in Cornwall, N. Y., to the proposed construction of a short by-pass linking the Storm King highway to a point on the outskirts of Cornwall.

Alexander Basy, impresario, who booked American vaudeville acts for presentation in Soviet Russia, died on Wednesday night in his home at 1,073 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of three months. He was 54 years old.
With the end of the current account tomorrow night, profit-taking developed in trading on the stock market today. Conditions, however, continued quiet, with prices irregular.
Meeting of the Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt, 10:45 A. M. Speakers: Henry Albert Phillips, Monica Barry Walsh, Helen Varick Boswell.

Desiring to exalt the 1940 Olympics to the highest plane, a subcommittee of the Olympics organization committee today selected the celebrated Meiji Shrine grounds as the site for the next international games.
In a new drive against narcotic smugglers, Treasury officials asked cooperation today of shipowners, offering special inducements to them for reporting suspected shipments.

A solemn high mass of requiem will be celebrated at 10 A. M. tomorrow at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Mgr. William J. Flynn, Prothonotary Apostolic and director general- of the Marquette League for Catholic Indian Missions.

The income of the Port of New York Authority last year showed net and gross gains of 32.3 and 9.4 per cent respectively over the 1935 totals, according to the annual report, which was published yesterday.

With December reflecting Ithe largest volume of business for any one month in the last six years, the Morris Plan Industrial Bank reported yesterday total gains for the year 1936 of 12 1/2 per cent in deposits and 12 per cent in volume of loans. Total resources of the bank

Continuing a campaign against alleged bookmaking establishments in the Bronx which he began Wednesday with District Attorney Samuel J. Foley, Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph Reynolds led a raid yesterday on the Rod and Reel Club, in a back room at 484 Jackson Avenue, near 147th Street.

Mrs. Harriet Rose of 223 Madison Street, Brooklyn, wife of Joseph Rose, the retired diamond merchant who recently charged that he had been robbed of $250,000 worth of diamonds while he was on home relief, obtained a warrant for his arrest yesterday on a charge of non-support.

The New York racing season will open at the Jamaica course of the Metropolitan Jockey Club April 15 and close at Empire City Oct. 30, for a total of 171 racing days, according to the schedule the stewards of the Jockey Club yesterday submitted to the New York State Racing Commission for approval.

Agreements of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company with their officials in 1936 for options on stock were disclosed yesterday in reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

Band Notice The Fire Department Band will hold its annual entertainment and reception at the Hotel Astor on Thursday, Feb. 4. Name Changes The names of the following members of the department are changed on the records of this department to read as follows. They shall sign all payrolls and communications accordingly:

Retribution moved swiftly yesterday upon Major Green, 33-year-old Negro porter. Less than twelve hours after signing a fourteen-page confession he was indicted for murder, first degree, pleaded not guilty and was remanded to Queens County jail for trial on Feb. 1.

A fire, believed to have been started by a cigarette of a student who fell asleep in a dormitory, destroyed the Ursuline monastery at Rimouski, 160 miles below Quebec, last night, compelling 160 pupils 8 to 16 years old and 71 nuns to flee the building.

A registration statement covering $85,000,000 of bonds, the proceeds from which, with other funds, are to be applied to the payment at maturity on March 1, of $89,787,000 principal amount of the Government of the Dominion of Canada's 5 per cent war loans, was filed today by the

A bill extending for two years the President's power to negotiate reciprocal trade treaties, which expires June 12, was introduced in the House today by Representative Doughton of North Carolina, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

Willie Hoppe scored over Ralph Greenleaf in two types of billiard competition at the Fourteenth Street Academy last night. After triumphing in a three-cushion match, 35 to 25, in 41 innings, Hoppe took the measure of his opponent, 100 to 19, in 6 frames, in an 18.2 balkline encounter.

The value of broad academic programs for collegiate institutions, combined with strong requirementstending to develop intellectual discipline, was stressed tonight by James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, in an address before the Association of American Colleges, meeting here.

Operating revenues for December, 1936, of ninety-five Class I railroads were 22.6 per cent higher than for the same period in 1935, according to estimates made public today by the Association of American Railroads. The estimates show revenues
The Union League Club, whose membership has been closed to all but Republicans since it was organized in 1863, voted last night to lift this restriction..

That the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which lent $20,000,000 to the Prudence Company, Inc., is seeking to have modified injunctive protection afforded the latter company in reorganization proceedings under Section 77-b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act became known yesterday from papers filed in the Federal Court in Brooklyn.

Italo E. Verrando of Genoa, Italy, has been appointed general manager of the Italian Line in the United States to succeed Arnoldo Palanca, it was announced last night by Paul Occhipinti, passenger traffic manager of the line New York.

Unbeaten Washington and Lee and once-beaten Long Island University will meet at Madison Square Garden tonight in the feature game of the North-South basketball double-header that also will show North Carolina and New York University.

Determined to smash the $50,000,000 a year policy racket, the source of the biggest slush fund for organized crime in the United States, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, cracked down yesterday on what was said to be the largest policy ring in the city.

Samuel A. Besson, a United States commissioner for more than twenty-five years, died last night at his home, 244 Roseville Avenue. He was 83 years old. He was the father of Harlan Besson of Hoboken, former United States District Attorney for New Jersey. Also surviving are Mrs.

An amendment to the Social Security Act to provide for the inclusion of domestic and agricultural workers has been urged upon President Roosevelt in a memorandum on the Negro working population and national recovery submitted by the National Urban League.
Glenn Frank Jr., 18, Harvard freshman and son of the recently ousted president of the University of Wisconsin, paid a $5 fine today for driving an automobile without a license. He was acquitted on

The engagement of Miss Betty T. Roulston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Roulston of New Rochelle, N. Y., to Kenneth W. Payne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Payne of this city, has been announced by her parents.

All pretext that Colonel General Hermann Goering's trip to Italy is a mere vacation is now dropped even by the German press, which deals with the visit befitting its importance and is obviously delighted by the ceremonial honors paid the visitor.

An investigation of the affairs of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, $400,000,000 utility holding company, will be made by the United States District Attorney's office, Michael L. Igoe, District Attorney, announced today.

Nine dual matches have been scheduled for the New York University women's fencing team, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frances V. Froatz, director of women's athletics. The team also is to compete in the intercollegiate championships.

Two national figures in Y. W. C. A. work, Miss Sarah S. Lyon of New York and Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester, were guests of honor here this afternoon at a tea given by Mrs. Graham M. Brush at the Field Club.

A first mortgage loan of $215,000 at 4% per cent was arranged for the Garstaff Realty Company, Inc., A. M. Stavisky. president, by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., on the one-story business property at 968-90 Southern Boulevard. the Bronx.

With Max Levy tallying fourteen points, the Yeshiva College quintet halted the New York University College of Commerce five, 30-17, on the former's floor last night. The winners showed the way by 17-7 at the close of the first half.
The approach to New York Harbor from Fire Island was blanketed for several hours early yesterday by a fog so thick that the visibility was not more than 100 yards.

The reorganization of the program of studies for underclassmen in Columbia College crowns an effort that has been made during nearly a half century to improve undergraduate training and to give liberal education a deeper meaning.

Earl Christiansen, local policeman and winner of the qualifying medal, will meet John Cummings Jr. of Memphis, Tyler (Texas) baseball star, in the final for the annual midwinter amateur golf championship at the Miami Country Club tomorrow. Both recorded double victories today.

Wesleyan defeated Trinity at basketball, 36 to 23, tonight. Wesleyan gained a 10-to-0 lead in the first eleven minutes of play. In the second half Trinity cut the lead at one point in the game to 26 to 19. Sonstroem and Richards were the spark plugs for Wesleyan.

A firsthand report of the Inter-American Peace Conference was given to President Roosevelt at a White House luncheon conference today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull upon his return from Buenos Aires, where he was the chief of the United States delegation.

Officials of the United States and British Embassies are becoming highly incensed at the attitude of the Chinese Government concerning providing airplanes for evacuation of their nationals from Sian, Shensi Province, where rebellious troops hold sway.

Bryant Av. (11-3003), e. s., 269 s. of 176th St., 120x100; Max Epstein to Hysar Hold- 2 ing Corp., 16 Court St., Brooklyn; mtg. $124,950. 154th St. (9-2413), a. s., 175 w. of Courtlandt Av., 25x100; 332 E. 154th St. Realty Corp. to Queens County Savings Bank, Flushing, N. Y.

President Roosevelt discussed proposals to exempt railroads from payment of the tax on undistributed corporate profits, with Secretary Morgenthau and Chairman Miller of the Interstate Commerce Commission; talked over the foreign situation with Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the American Short Term Creditors of Germany, and tonight, with Mrs. Roosevelt, gave the annual dinner to the Speaker of the House.
Gunmen held up two stores in the Bronx last night and escaped with more than $1,000 in cash. The hold-ups occurred within twenty minutes of each other.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine had high praise yesterday for Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Ryan and the 100 detectives under him, who broke the Case murder mystery in less than two days.

General Domingo Batet, one of the "twin heroes" in suppression of the 1934 revolt of Catalan separatists, has been charged with treason by a Spanish Fascist military court, press reports said today. An Insurgent prosecutor demanded the death penalty for the military leader, who was commander of the Burgos army garrison when the Fascist rebellion broke out last July, it was reported.

Raiding an attractively furnished four-room apartment on the twelfth floor of an apartment house at 200 West Fifty-fourth Street, on the southwest corner of Fifty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, detectives arrested two men and seized a quantity of gambling paraphernalia and liquor late yesterday afternoon.
Deaths from influenza and pneumonia throughout the city dropped yesterday to a lower level than on any single day since Jan. 4, the Department of Health announced last night.

A new type of "lie detector," an electrical instrument known as a recording psychogalvanometer, was used on Wednesday by officials investigating the murder of Mrs. Mary Robinson Case. The machine, the invention of the Rev. Walter G. Summers, head of the Department of Psychology of the Fordham Graduate School, was brought into play in an official case for the first time in this State.

More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend the fourth annual midwinter festival and supper dance this evening at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for the benefit of the Grand Street Settlement, 283 Rivington Street. The event, which will 'be preceded by a series of dinner parties, will be featured by an entertainment program.

Because it is officially a matter of public record, the press of the country is now publishing long lists of persons receiving corporation salaries of more than $15,000 a year. This information is compiled and made public by the Treasury in accordance with Section 148-D of the Revenue Act of 1934.

Henry C. Smart, retired executive of the Standard Oil Company of New York, died here early today at his home, 34 Beechmont Drive. He was 70 years old. Born in Hampton County, S. C., he was associated with the Standard Oil Company from 1890 to 1930, when he retired.

A jury in General Sessions convicted John F. Bartels, 69 years old, of grand larceny yesterday for stealing $900 worth of airmail stamps last July 2 from Emil Bruechig in his office at 522 Fifth Avenue.
A plot on the east side of Main Street, 171 feet north of Berry Street, Hackensack, N. J., was sold by Mildred Davidson of Brooklyn to a purchaser who plans to erect a building containing shops.
Although a small amount of copper was sold in the domestic market- yesterday at 13 cents a pound, the leading producers made no change from 12.50 cents, established on Monday. With foreign quotations

Mrs. Frances Bodenheim French, who until recently managed newspaper contests, committed suicide yesterday by hanging herself in the apartment in which she lived with her father, Simon Bodenheim, at 260 Riverside Drive. She was 29 years old.

While J. M. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, was sending out copies of proposed revisions in the rules controlling air transport today, Senator McCarran was introducing a bill on Capitol Hill which would virtually strip the Bureau of Air Commerce of its powers over air transport and hand them over to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Broadening of the Walsh-Healey act by reducing from $10,000 to $2,000 the size of government contracts to which it applies was advocated today by Secretary Perkins. She asserted that "there ought to be a much lower limit" than $10,000 in order to make the act effective.
William V. B. Kip, descendant of one of New York's earliest families, died of pneumonia at 8 o'clock last night at his home, 550 Park Avenue. He was 65 years old.
Eugene Carr, New York City accountant who was stricken with pneumonia while In Geneva, N. Y., on business several days ago, died today in a Geneva hospital. He was 48 years old.
More than 200 alumni, including many of the stars since the late Nineties, acted as hosts to the Pennsylvania varsity football squad at the annual dinner at the Ritz-Carlton tonight.

While everybody here waited for results from Governor Murphy's conference in Lansing, and 600 more guardsmen poured into the city, making the total strength here 1,800 men, 4,000 non-striking General Motors employes held a mass meeting this afternoon at which they asserted their desire to return to work.

More and better furniture is being bought this year than a year ago, manufacturers said today at the semiannual show of the American Furniture Mart. A survey among exhibitors indicated that sales to attending buyers range from 40 to 75

The plan of reorganization of the Hudson River Day Line has been consummated, a committee headed by Henry L. Bogert Jr. announced yesterday. The plan, dated Aug. 1, 1936, previously had been confirmed by the United States District Court in reorganization proceedings under Section 77-B.

Nathaniel Lubell of the Salle D'Armes Vince and Norman Lewis of New York University led the eight competitors from the metropolitan district who qualified for the national junior foils championship at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Mrs. Margaret Jane Humphries Kinsey, formerly prominent in Cincinnati women's organizations and philanthropic work, died today at her home in Wyoming, Ohio. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Kinsey was the widow of George Kinsey, former local sales manager of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.

Charging that it has received several public complaints against "A World I Never Made," by James T. Farrell, the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice is attempting by court action to prevent the circulation of the novel, which was well received by literary critics, it became known yesterday.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,486,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 13: Colonels Schulz, E. H., Engrs., Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to retirement. Ruhlen, G.. C. A. C., Los Angeles, Calif., to the Philippine Dept., to sail about June 18 from San Francisco.

Miklas Szabo of Hungary, one of Europe's outstanding distance runners, will compete in the United States during the coming indoor season, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretarytreasurer of the A. A. U. He will run in the 1,500-meter event at the national championships at the Garden on Feb. 27 and in the mile at the Millrose A. A., Boston A. A. and New York A. C. meets that precede it.

Tax exemption was decried yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo as having become a "free-for-all contest on the part of State legislators," in an opinion in which he awarded a $245,000 exemption to Outer Court, Inc., a part of the Order of the Living Christ, on property in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

George Gaston, the oldest actor residing at the Actors Fund of America Home in Englewood, N. J., died there yesterday at the age of 93. Born in Lockport, N. Y., he began his theatrical career in the Civil War period in a company headed by Julia Daly.

The over-night statement or secretary of Agriculture Wallace that he would ask Congress to levy a processing tax on sugar to raise $135,000,000 yearly resulted yesterday in a decline in raw sugar and the securities of sugar refining and producing companies.

The New York Stock Exchange has stricken from listing and registration Bangor Aroostook Railroad Corporation 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock and will suspend from dealings today G. R. Kinney Company, Inc., 7 1/2 per cent notes, due Dec. 1, 1936.

Igor Stravinsky made his first appearance as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He appeared on the platform in the business-like manner which characterizes him and turned immediately, after acknowledging hearty welcoming applause, to his business.

Validation by the United States Supreme Court of the HawesCooper Act precludes the need for the proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution and provides the instrument whereby States with child labor laws may be protected against the competition of States with lower standards, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in a joint statement with R. E. Lee. Dr. Butler is
F. J. Sheed of Sheed Ward will arrive from England on Jan. 19 for a month's stay. While here Mr. Sheed will give a series of lectures over the country as far west as Minnesota.

The compositions of Dr. Daniel Gregory Mason will be featured in the Composers' Forum Laboratory tonight at the New School for Social Research. The Glee Club of Riverdale County School will give a concert tonight at the Hartley House.

The British destroyer Vanoc, which arrived at Ceuta last evening in response to an invitation. from the Spanish Insurgent authorities to investigate allegations of German military activity in the Spanish zone of Morocco, left this afternoon for Melilla for further investigation.

The net operating earnings of the Bankers Trust Company for 1936 were $7,326,847, S. Sloan Colt, president, reported to shareholders at their annual meeting at noon yesterday at the bank's main office, 16 Wall Street. This figure compared with $8,136,267 for 1935, as reported

A decline in the volume of engineering construction awards for the second week of 1937, as compared with the corresponding week last year, was accounted for by the sharp drop in the amounts allotted for public work, according to the report of The Engineering NewsRecord.

Extensive employment of White Plains public school children last Summer, some of them continuing to work during their leisure time in the school attendance period, was disclosed today with the .publication of the result of a survey conducted by the New York Child Labor Committee in cooperation with local school officials and the Westchester League of Women Voters.

Engagement of $910,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank announced that a shipment of $2,676,800 gold from England had arrived late on Wednesday, but reported no imports yesterday.

In fulfillment of his government's promise to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, Premier Leon Blum introduced in the Chamber of Deputies today a bill to give power to the government to prevent the recruiting of volunteers for either of the Spanish armies.

George A. Cutter, Massachusetts yachtsman, was elected commodore of the Cruising Club of America at the annual meeting of that seafaring body, held last night in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.
Avering St., n. s., 20 ft. e. of Tratman Av.; three-story brick tenement, 50x107; Addor Building Corp., John Sellitto, president, 1,044 E. Dusenbury, 10 E. 40th St., architects; cost, $50,000.

The "dullness" of Sunday schools was deplored here today by the Rev. Philip C. Jones, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York. He told delegates at the annual convention of the Home Missions Council of the United States and Canada at the Berkeley Carteret Hotel that "they do not need to be on the level of a variety show but they can be fresh and vivid."

The Federal 'Trade Commission- issued its first complaints today under the brokerage clause of the RobinsonPatman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, naming in separate actions the. Great' Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and the Biddle Purchasing Company of New York City.

Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title of actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 20, 1934.

A brief funeral service for Lieut. Col. Crawford Blagden was held yesterday morning in Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, with 150 friends and associates attending. The Rev. Dr. Walter Russell Bowie, rector, conducted the service.

Despite the comparatively simple inaugural ceremony planned by President Roosevelt, the political organizations from the five boroughs of New York City will send more than 500 leaders, officeholders and dignitaries to the event, was indicated yesterday.

Norman Bel Geddes, producer of "Dead End," yesterday came to terms with Clem Wilenchick, who left the road company of that play last November when the management filed charges with Equity that he had refused to take direction. Mr.
Slapped, 7-year-old son of PompeySmack, today won the featured Corona allowance race of six furlongs in 1:12 3-5. The victor, accustomed to longer distances, paid $19.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

The Appellate Division, Third Department, today affirmed the order of the Clinton County Court, which dismissed a writ of habeas corpus sued out by Charles Luciano, New York City vice racketeer, to obtain his release from Clinton prison, where he is serving a sentence of thirty to fifty years. Justices Rhodes,

Bert Acosta, American aviator, and his flying mate, Gordon K. Berry, returned from the wars yesterday through the fog which enveloped the French liner Paris and were greeted with a Federal grand jury subpoena.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's revival of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the New York Diet Kitchen Association was in part one of the really eloquent productions of the season, but in other places was a parody of the opera and in certain features a triumph of banality, ineptitude and bad taste.

An opinion quashing one of twentyfour similar indictments charging seven railroads, two New York Harbor lighterage concerns and sixteen shippers with violation of the Elkins Interstate Commerce Act by the granting and accepting of rebates was filed in Federal Court today by Judge Guy L. Fake.

Has LEON TROTSKY at last found in Mexico his longed-for haven for " study and literary efforts"? Or will this wanderer presently become again such a storm center as to cause, south of the Rio Grande as so many times elsewhere, his enforced departure?

Wholesale prices registered their eleventh consecutive weekly advance in the week ended Jan. 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average, is now 85.2, compared with 84.7 on Jan. 2 and 80.5 a year ago.

Ward Kremer, special city counsel, announced here today that he had obtained from Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie in Atlantic City, this morning, a writ staying the adoption by city officials of a refinancing plan demanded by the State Municipal Finance Commission.

The International Association of Clothing Designers brought its convention to a close today with a style show and the suggestion from an affiliated group that to be "well dressed" a man needs at least fourteen suits and five overcoats-no less.

Libel suits totaling $70,000 have been begun against Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons of this city, Republican National Committeewoman for Rhode Island, by seven Republican State Senators, who seek $10,000 each.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 2 totaled 287,659,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared to figures for the previous week, this total represented a decrease of 858,000 barrels, comprising decreases of

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange sent yesterday to the presidents of all companies having securities listed on the Exchange a letter requesting them to indicate the amount of surtax on undistributed earnings as a separate item

Stocks closed irregular after motor shares had rallied sharply; turnover, 3,259,510 shares. United States Government issues higher, corporate and foreign bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $15,678,500.

Mrs. Ralph H. Bollard of this place gave a tea today to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Katherine Bohard. Miss Bollard received with her mother in a setting of ferns and Spring flowers. She was gowned in blue lace over satin and carried yellow freesia and violets. Mrs. Bollard wore black velvet.

If Mayor La Guardia is not re-elected next Fall and Tammany comes back, the racketeers will return in New York City," William Fellows Morgan, Commissioner of Public Markets in the metropolis, said tonight at the annual dinner of the State Horticultural Society.

The House stripped committee seniority today from Representative Lemke, Republican, of North Dakota, the Union party's Presidential candidate last year, and from his colleague, Representative Burdick, Republican, of North Dakota.

The Giants' list of signed performers for 1937 was augumented by two yesterday, when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced that accepted contracts have been received from Clydell Castleman, freshman star of 1935 who fell a victim of "second-year jitters" last season, and Tom Ferrick, righthanded pitching product of the Greenwood farm.

The National Lead Company in December sold 5,000 shares of its Class A preferred stock to an insurance company for an undisclosed sum, reducing treasury holdings of the issue to 299,883 shares the monthly reports of reacquired stock by listed companies to the New York Stock Exchange showed yesterday.

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended Jan. 13 were announced today: Roemer, Comd'r. C. G., Depot, to Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y., and to command the Alexander Hamilton, when commissioned.

Though opinion on the question is divided, some of those familiar with the ways of Congress think the President will get a larger share of his reorganization program out of an omnibus bill than in a series of separate measures.
It was learned today the Air Ministry would place an order for fifteen bombing planes with the Fokker concern of Amsterdam.

On their own applications: To take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 20: SERGEANT-Edward L. Moran, 30th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Feb. 17, 1908. To take effect 12 midnight, Jan. 21: PATROLMAN - William J. McAndrews, 28th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909.

Plans for revision of the requirements for admission to membership in the New York Stock Exchange and to partnership in firms holding membership in it were disclosed yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, in an interim report to members and their
American National Livestock Association, ending its annual convention, delegates are on record today against ratification of the Argentine sanitary convention.
Russia may call in foreign engineers to speed her lagging automobile production, tripped by a missing automobile horn, it was disclosed today.

Madrid is going to need a new guide book soon, for the names of streets are being changed by dozens. Every street, avenue and promenade bearing an aristocrat's name will receive a different appellation in the course of time. The famous Castellana Avenue will be called Avenue

William Foulke of the Princeton Club, rated eighth, was the only seeded player of the five who saw action to be eliminated from the New York State squash racquets championship which opened yesterday on the courts of the Downtown Athletic Club. B. B. Adams,

Miss Grace Holden, daughter of Mrs. Edward Raymond Holden of this city and Baldwin, L. I., has selected Jan. 27 as the date of her marriage to John Whitney, son of Mrs. Arthur Noyes Whitney of 840 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Whitney.
The demand for hogs today was relatively slow, with prices steady to 15 cents down. Certain large packers refused to take animals except at concessions in prices, as compared with Thursday's close.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Randall Kindleberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Crosby Kindleberger of Flushing, Queens, and Jamestown, R. I., to Henry A. Stone Jr. of Manhattan, took place yesterday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Flushing. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Hubert S. Wood.

The Harvard and New York Athletic Clubs maintained their first place tie in Class C competition of the Metropolian Squash Tennis Association yesterday, each team winning its tenth victory in a dozen starts. The Crimson defeated the

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the application of the Chicago District Electric Generating Corporation for an order declaring it not to be a subsidiary company of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company.

Hoarse but happy, America's builders of pleasure boats, marine engines and yachting accessories who have been regaling vast crowds of Grand Central Palace visitors for more than a week will start this morning on the last leg of their annual January jamboree known as the National Motor Boat Show. Promptly at 10:30 tonight
Dr. John Motza and Dr. Basll Marin, two leaders of the Fascist Iron Guard, were reported today to have been killed Wednesday while fighting with the Rebels at Madrid.

With the preliminary case for the plaintiffs concluded, the defense in the patent infringement suit brought by the Julius Kayser Companyand the Textile Patents Corporation against the Rosedale Knitting Company opened its case today with the presentation of experts in textile patent laws and in the actual knitting field.

William B. Atwater, one of the first licensed airplane pilots in the United States and holder of the seaplane duration flight record, died on Thursday night of a coronary thrombosis in his home at 270 Park Aveue. He was 47 years old.

The First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis reported net earnings of $1,362,000 in 1936, a gain of $144,000 from 1935. Deposits were $145,110,218 on Dec. 31, up $11,000,000 from the total a year previously.

The four story brick apartment at 643 Hudson Ave., West New York, N. J., was sold by the Hudson Trust Co. to Anna Budka who will hold the parcel for investment. It contains twelve four-room units. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was broker.
The American Legion will throw its full strength toward keeping the United States out of war, the Legion's national commander, Henry W. Colmery declared here today.

Glenn Cunningham and Gene Venzke-although in different races--top the field that will compete tonight in the 69th Regiment A. A. games at the 165th Regiment Armory (the old 69th). Joe McCluskey is another Olympian who will start.
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $19,537,320, representing one State and thirty-nine municipalities. This compares with a revised total of $69,960,791 for this week.

The total expenditure for construction in the thirty-seven Eastern States in 1936 was $2,675,296,000, a gain of 45 per cent over the figure of $1,844,544,900 for 1935, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals in a decision today held that the government cannot avoid payment of interest on government gold-clause bonds by calling the bonds for redemption under a call which offers payment in currency based on the devalued dollar.

Contributions totaling $282,918, or $4,918 more than the campaign goal, have been received by the Family Service Fund of the Charity Organization Society for the coming year's work, it was announced yesterday at a final report luncheon of campaign workers at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Officials of the Kristiania Banking and Credit Company were mystified this morning when a smartly dressed young German woman giving the name "Frau Kreutzberger" presented a power of attorney to collect the Nobel Peace Prize money due Carl von Ossietzky who is understood to be in a Berlin sanitarium guarded by the secret police.

The National Lumber Manufacturers Association announced today that, in cooperation with the Federal Housing Administration, a nationwide demonstration of small-home construction will be undertaken between March 1 and May 1.

Sportsmen who attended the duck hunters' dinner of the American Wildlife Institute the other night are voicing their admiration of Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson for the forthright manner in which he stated the case of the migratory waterfowl.
Early this morning the temperature in New York City was expected to drop to freezing and thus bring a change from apparent Summer weather to that of normal Winter in less than twenty-four hours.

Seeking to maintain the important breeding work which has been carried on at Emmadine Farm. at Hopewell Junction, for more than a decade, J. C. Penney, chain-store owner of the farm, has endowed his widely known pure-bred Guernsey herd, insuring its continuance for sixty years.

So they are moving the gold to Kentucky, to bury it down deep in a vault of stone and steel. The vault is supposed to be the latest thing in gold protection-a fort, full of hidden guns, reputedly bombproof, floodable by the pressing of a button, surrounded by a moat, and far from the dangerous seacoast. It was built, and the gold is

The Manhattan College junior varsity turned back the Nassau Collegiate Center varsity quintet of Garden City, 38-13, and the St. John's University freshmen topped the Manhattan cubs, 26-24, on the Jasper court last night.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday against the Federal Government when the court upheld the application of two lawyers to compel payment of two judgments totaling $29,624 against the Moscow Fire Insurance Company of Russia.
Willys Peck, counselor of the United States Embassy, arrived safely in Sian by airplane yesterday afternoon to try to arrange for evacuation of Americans from the danger zone.

James P. Anderson, vice president of the Ringwood Company, real estate and iron mine concern, with headquarters in Jersey City, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home here at 723 East Twenty-third Street. A native of Springfield, Mass., Mr. Anderson was 67 years old.

John Hill Morgan Buys Country Place in Farmington, Conn. Mill Streams, the eight-acre estate of the late Winchell Smith, playwright, at Farmington, Conn., has been purchased for occupancy by John Hill Morgan of New York.

Trailing at 13-9 at the intermission, Fieldston rallied to down Barnard School, 23-22, at Fieldston yesterday and took undisputed possession of first place in the uptown division of the Metropolitan Association of Private Schools Basketball League with two triumphs in as many circuit starts.

" Ground rules" for a collective bargaining conference between the General Motors Corporation and officers of the United Automobile Workers of America will be drawn up tomorrow as members of the Michigan National Guard begin evacuating Flint, the result of a strike truce arranged in the office of Covernor Frank Murphy at Lansing near dawn this morning.

J. Arthur Lehman, former chief of detectives at the old WaldorfAstoria Hotel, died of a heart attack yesterday in the office of his physician, Dr. A. L. Goodman of 136 West Eighty-seventh Street. Mr. Lehman was 72 years old and lived at 324 West Eighty-eighth Street.

Miss Frances E. Gill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Howard Gill of this city, was married to Edward Patterson Birkholz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin L. Birkholz of Colonia, at Trinity Episcopal Church here last night. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Lee Bull Jr., the rector.

Patrolman Peter McCrea of 660 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, who died at his home yesterday afternoon under circumstances that led to a police investigation because of bruises found on his body, succumbed of cardiac failure and cirrhosis of the liver, according to an autopsy performed last night.

Two leading trophies were awarded to E. Monroe Osborne of the Three Mile Harbor fleet near East Hampton, L. I., at the annual dinner of the Snipe Class International Racing Association at the Architectural League last night.

Capturing the last three events, the Amherst swimming team vanquished Fordham's natators by 5120 in the Maroon pool yesterday. The victory was -the second in as many meets for the Lord Jeffs this season, while the setback was the first suffered by the charges of Joe Farley in three efforts.

Next month the Universal Camera Corporation will launch its campaign on Univex Cine 8 millimeter cameras and projectors, originally scheduled for before Christmas, but held up because of production difficulties.

To determine the opinion of bankers on the continuation of Title I of the National Housing Act, which is to expire on April 1, the committee on banking studies of the American Bankers Association has sent a questionnarie to banks which have operated extensively under the act, it was announced yesterday by Wood Netherland, chairman of the committee.

All the leading copper producers advanced yesterday the domestic price of the metal- to 13 cents a pound, the highest level since April, 1930, when the price averaged 15.74 cents. The copper fabricating

To the Editor of The New York Times: The new Russian Constitution is certainly having its desired effect when one is so obviously deceived as to say, as did William M. Cubert in his letter to THE TIMES, that a statement "which puts Russia in the same boat with Germany, does violence to my American spirit of fair play and candor." Mr.
A portrait by the Spanish artist Francisco Goya y Lucientes, of General de Villacampa, was sold for $1,150 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
