Sammy Julian, 137, Brooklyn, knocked out Johnny Toomey, 140 1/2, Newark, N. J., in 2:02 of the second round of the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds at Henderson's Flatbush Arena last night. A crowd of 1,300 saw the fights.

Anacleto Sermolino, host to a pre-war generation of writers and artists who helped to popularize the Italian table d'hote dinner in New York-from antipasto to cheese, with a pint of red wine thrown in-died Thursday night at his home, 35 West Ninth Street, after a long illness.

The formation of a National Advisory Board to the American Youth Congress, comprising fiftynine men and women prominent in the life of the nation, was announced yesterday by William W. Hinckley, chairman of the Congress. The board will push the

Louis Schleifer, Brooklyn operator, entered the Manhattan field yesterday when he purchased the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street from the People's Realty Company.

The Rev. Howard David Higgins, rector of the First Reformed Episcopal Church, 317 East Fiftieth Street, will be consecrated in that church at 8 P. M. Tuesday as Assistant Bishop of the New York and Philadelphia Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church. Mr. Higgins was reared in the parish.

Miss Ruth Pond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pond of this place, was married tonight in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Essex Fells, to Worrall F. Mountain Jr., son of Mrs. Worrall F. Mountain of East Orange and the late Judge Mountain. A reception in Essex Fells Country Club followed.

Federal Judge Goddard, presiding over reorganization proceedings of the Consolidated Textile Company, authorized yesterday the reemployment of Henry B. Stimson, former secretary-treasurer of the company, as assistant to its president, F. K. Rupprecht.

Following the impaneling of a special grand jury in Brooklyn last week to inquire into rackets, William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to appropriate $50,000, so that he can carry out his investigation successfully.

President Roosevelt's laugh rang out today when a reporter asked at a White House press conference if he planned to designate the two new battleships, recently ordered constructed, as the "Maine" and the "Vermont," in recognition of the only two States which voted the Republican ticket last Fall.

Estate, $700. To Charles V. Barbour, son, and executor, 7,440 64th Place, Glendale, L. I., residue; five specific bequests. BARON, ADOLPH (Jan. 2). Estate, less than $10,000. To Olga Baron, widow and executrix, 51 E. 90th St., residue. Olga Baron, daughter, 51 E. 90th St., executrix. CANAVAN. MARY T. (Dec. 5). Estate,

A total of $9,120 in cash was stolen from the Wood-Ridge National Bank at Columbia Boulevard and Hackensack Street here this morning when five armed bandits held up former Mayor George P. Young, president and cashier of the bank; John Holtz, a director, and two bank employes, one of them a girl.

The Board of Estimate indicated yesterday its intention of clearing the Queensboro Bridge of its last trolleys by ending the trolley franchise of the Steinway Division of the New York Queens County Railway Company to operate from Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, to Second Avenue in Manhattan.

New Utrecht High School's march toward the city P. S. A. L. hockey championship came to a temporary halt when the Green and White 6-3, skaters sustained their first setback in eight league engagements by a 1-to-O score at the hands of the Manual Training sextet at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

To expedite the issuance of 1937 license plates, which must be on all automobiles in operation after midnight on Jan. 31, Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced yesterday that, beginning Wednesday, he would open eleven branch offices of the license bureau at 9 A. M. daily.

Descriptions of the inaugural wardrobe selected by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt were made public yesterday by the makers, Arnold Constable Co., with a prediction that the colors, "Eleanor Red," "Victory Blue" and "White House at Blue" would set a vogue. The nomenclature is the store's.

Clarence J. Trader, owner of the Stockton Electric Light and Power Company, was found shot to death just before midnight last night in the home of his estranged wife at Stockton, a community of 300 persons nine miles south of here.

The issue of Congressional modification of the duties and powers of Federal courts was brought up in the Senate by Senator Black today. He urged legislation for prompt hearing by the Supreme Court of all injunction applications seeking to prevent the enforcement of a Federal statute.

Savings bank deposits in New York State on Dec. 31 amounted to $5,242,897,915, a gain for the year, including dividends, of $56,350,522, or a little more than 1 per cent, it was announced yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

An interchange of accusations and epithets between Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the State Assembly, and members of the Board of Education yesterday threatened to disrupt the Board of Estimate's discussion of selection of a site for new Public School 244 in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

The Mexican Aviation Company announced late today that an airliner missing three days had been found in a dense jungle in Vera Cruz State, with all its nine occupants apparently killed when the plane crashed and burned.

An injunction to prevent the Commonwealth Edison Company from holding a special meeting of stockholders on Jan. 23 at which approval will be asked of a plan to acquire the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois and the Western United Gas and Electric Company, was sought in a petition filed today before Judge Grover C. Niemeyer in the Cook County Superior Court.
Proposed dissolution of one firm holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and formation of three new firms was announced yesterday by the Exchange.

Less than ten miles to the southeast of Edinburgh, near where the two Lothian Esks meet, is Newbattle Abbey, the title to which by a happy fortune was a few years ago bequeathed to PHILIP KERR (as he is better known in America), who inherited, with this abbey, the title which recognized his nobility nor made him the less a true democrat. WALTER SCOTT in his early
Arthur C. Cunningham, 24 years old, a former Trentonian, was sentenced today by Mercer Court Judge James S. Turp to serve life imprisonment on a kidnapping charge.

Definite proof of the existence of the muchdisputed "phantom" fliers over Northern Norway was found yesterday in the fishing village of Harstad, where fishermen discovered floating near the coast a smoke bomb of the type used by pilots to determine the direction of currents over the sea.

Jack McCarthy, the lithe young first baseman who Bill Terry fervently hopes will permanently keep him in the role of bench manager this year, made his first step in the right direction yesterday by accepting terms for the 1937 season under the Giant banner.
The marriage of Miss Viola Elizabeth Gillette, daughter of Mrs. Abram Dunn Gillette of Burgoyne, Sabbath Day Point, N. Y., and the late Mr. Gillette, to Kent Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E.

A plot at the northwest corner of Wetherole Street and Sixty-fourth Road, Rego Park, was sold by Mrs. Blanche Urquhardt to I. Cline, builder, who will improve the property. Roman-Caswell Company. acted as broker.

Preparations for next month's international horse show are proceeding rapidly. All of the foreign teams were at the training fields of the Coraceros Regiment shortly after 7 o'clock this morning. Later they exercised along the seafront.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "In Defense of Congress," Oswald Garrison Villard. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "Painting in the Netherlands and Spain," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "The Art of el'Amarneh," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 2 P. M.; "Oriental Sculpture in Stone," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.: "The Making of a Stained-Glass Window;

Three sets of fingerprints of all except sixteen of the 1,312 children in the elementary grades of the four public and one parochial school here have been made by the local police department and now one set is on file here, one in the offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington and one at the headquarters of the State police in Trenton.
John J. Dennehey, who was in his early thirties and since 1928 a member of the Fire Department, attached to Engine Company 8, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital of cerebral meningitis.

Miss Frances Cole Waram, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Carne Waram of 414 East Fifty-second Street, was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to John Harrison Trowbridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Quincy Trowbridge of Oyster Bay, L. I. The Rev. Dr. Percy Gamble Kammerer performed the ceremony.

The Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge prize of $1,000, offered in 1936 by the Library of Congress under the provisions of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, has been awarded to Jerzy Fitelberg, a Polish composer, for a string quartet.
A shifting of differences developed on the Cotton Exchange yesterday on a falling-off of liquidation of March contracts and the list ended with a gain of 3 to a loss of 5 points.

Otto Motzan, composer of popular songs and light operettas, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Hotel Whitehall, where he resided. He was 57 years old. He wrote the music of many popular songs, perhaps the best known of which was "Bright Eyes."

Senator Vandenberg told the Senate today that Rexford G. Tugwell, retiring Resettlement Administrator, had excited the admiration and envy of heads of other governmental departments by the beauty and de luxe printing of the annual report he had just issued, describing the year's activities of his agency.

The Association of American Colleges closed its annual meeting here today with the election of new officers, elevating from the vice presidency to the presidency James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University.

Quite a few shows are closing today-probably, when the lists are assembled after the week-end, more than knew about it yesterday. Those that with knowledge are playing their last performances today are:

Once more the star-gazing White Cockade, Withers winner and potential champion, will get a chance to show that he is something more than a beautiful dark horse when he goes to the post tomorrow afternoon in the featured Fort Dallas Park handicap at Hialeah Park.

Cotton plantings in Argentina this year have reached a new high record of 1,015,000 acres, according to the first official estimate of the Argentine Government received today by the Department of Agriculture from its office in Buenos Aires.

Eugene Van Rensselaer Thayer, former president of the Chase National Bank, who died on Jan. 1, last, while on a visit to Chicago, left a bequest of $100,000 to Elizabeth E. Gorrie of 1,148 Fifth Avenue. This was learned yesterday

Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert Ide Low gave an old-fashioned reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 1,060 Fifth Avenue, for their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hine Low of Cedarhurst, L. I., whose marriage took place last Summer.

Manhattan Alterations 5th Av., 320-4; to 11-story offices and store; Dennistoun M. Bell. Amagansett, L. L. owner; F. G. Frost, architect; cost, $8,000. 59th: St., 332-4 E.; to 8-story laundry; Wallach Laundry, Inc., premises, owner; R. G. Cory, architect; cost, $5,000.

Contributions of $21,464 from employes of New York City to the United Hospital Fund campaign were reported last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive, with ten city departments still to report.

Governor Earle announced tonight that he would ask the Legislature to conduct an investigation of the Philadelphia courts. Charges reflecting upon the official actions of some of the local judges are being printed by The Philadelphia Record in a series of articles.

An investing client of Walter G. Phelps, attorney, bought from the Fanshaw Realty Corporation, Isaac Weinstein, president, the modern six-story elevator apartment house for sixty-four families at 2,755 Reservoir Avenue, the Bronx. The property was sold subject to a first mortgage of $178,105, the seller being represented by William L.

The Swiss authorities' decision to withdraw from Carlo Aprato permission to live here became effective today with his appeals to local and Federal governments pending. He crossed the frontier voluntarily before the time limit and will live in the village of Ambilly, near Annemasse, France, which is five minutes from Geneva.
Miss Mary Jean Nicholson daughter of Mrs. Arthur Edwin Nicholson of Oak Park, Ill., was married to Charles Augustus Briggs 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. T. Briggs of Paris, Ky., formerly of

The report of Prudential Investors, Inc., for 1936, sets forth that net assets, taking investments at market quotations as of Dec. 31, and allowing for Federal normal income tax on unrealized appreciation, amounted to $13,180,905, equal to $284.71 a share on the 46,296 shares of $6 preferred stock outstanding.
Manning (Manny) Strewl was headed back for Clinton prison tonight after dramatically ending his retrial on charges of kidnapping John J. O'Connell Jr. with a plea of guilty to blackmail.

The Gas Employes' Union went on strike at midnight in the Ohio Fuel Gas Company and Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company plants, leaving a skeleton crew of six men at key stations "only until 7 A. M."

Queen Wilhelminaleft Rotterdam by train tonight to meet her honeymooning daughter, Princess Juliana, and Juliana's husband, Prince Bernhard, in Austria. The couple have been at Krynica, Poland, but it waS understood they planned to go to IgIs, near Innsbruck, Austria, to meet the Queen.
Leaders of five transportation brotherhoods continued today their efforts at a conference to work out a compromise agreement in formulating demands for increased wages.

Piling up 392 runs for eight wickets, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team made a fine start in its three-day match against a combined Tasmanian eleven that included Clarrie Grimmett and Frank Ward, South Australian googly experts.

The Warners' "Black Legion," dealing with matter culled from recent newspaper headlines, will go on view this morning at the Strand. Based on a story by Robert Lord and directed by Archie L. Mayo, the film is acted by Humphrey Bogart, Erin O'Brien-Moore, Dick Foran, Ann Sheridan, Helen Flint and Robert Barrat, to mention a few.

Henry W. Bull again was elected president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at the annual meeting of the board of stewards held Thursday, the results of which were announced yesterday.
Mrs. Henry L. Cammann was elected a member of the board of managers of the Cooperative Social Settlement Society yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting in Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street.

The New York Bank's Glee Club will give a concert tonight at the Town Hall. The Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, under Vittorio Verse, will play tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum. Everett Stevens, pianist, will be heard this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it regarded its employes' representation plan as a legal method of collective bargaining and warned its 85,000 employes not to believe statements ascribed to union organizers of the Committee for Industrial Organization that the plan violated the law.

Elizabeth St., 267-67 1/2, 25x87; Thomas F. Daly, referee, to East River Savings; foreclosure ($17). Elizabeth St., 269, 25x87; same to same; foreclosure ($18.59). 101st St., 107 W., 25x100.11; Alfredo Sacco to Henry Ambecker, 36 W. 44th St. ($1).

Two men were arrested and $10,000 worth of jewelry, clothing and other articles said by the police to have been stolen in Washington, D. C., were seized early yesterday in a jewelry store at 80 Lenox Avenue.
Canadian production of platinum in 1935 was not so high as in 1934, the peak year to date, but during the first half of 1936 there was a considerable increase over the same period of 1935.

The widespread automobile workers' sit-downs added 1,500 persons today to Maine's roster of workers idle because of strikes. The Sanford Mills shut down 200 looms weaving automotive upholstery, throwing half the plush mill's 3,000 employes out of work.

Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, World War pilot and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, received tonight the gold medal of achievement presented annually by the Poor Richard Club to the citizen "whose life and interests best typify advancement in some field of endeavor."
President Roosevelt closed his offices at noon to begin work on his inaugural address. He held a press conference and received only two callers during the morning.

THE esteemed J. A. Robert Quinn, president of the Boston Bees, is an early bird in more ways than one. At home, or on the road, he's the first man up in the morning. What brings it to mind on a January day is that through the rain and the fog of New England there came the first faint sign that Spring will be coming along. Additional testimony relative to the sale of 200,000 common shares of the Cities Service Company for which Henry L. Doherty received $20,500,000 from his own Cities Service Securities Corporation was given yesterday at a stockholders' trial for an accounting before Federal Judge John W. Clancy.

Pope Pius spent a rather troubled night considerably disturbed by an intermittent pain in his right leg. Nevertheless he was sufficiently well this morning to obtain the doctor's permission to leave his bed for a longer time than on either of the two preceding days.

A decline in new influenza cases with an increase in pneumonia cases as well as in deaths of both diseases was announced last night by the Department of Health, In the twenty-four hours ending at 10 A. M. yesterday 118 influenza cases were reported, a decline of 49 compared with the preceding day. There were 13 deaths, or 6 more than the day before.

No longer having an all-winning record of its own to protect, the Long Island University quintet wrecked the all-victorious pretensions of unbeaten Washington and Lee last night, crushing .the Generals, 44 to 28, before a gathering of 8,500, after N. Y. U. had trounced

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls moved a step nearer to the firsthalf championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight, conquering the New York Rovers, 5 to 2. Herb Foster and Ray Levia shared scoring honors for the Gulls, with two goals apiece. Bill Davies tallied the other. Babcock and Fenn
Dr. Walter Becker, commercial attache of the German Embassy, with headquarters in New York, returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburgfrom a three-and-a-half-month visit to Germany.

Lecturing on "The United States in My Time," before the Royal Dublin Society this afternoon, Shane Leslie, well-known author, poet and lecturer, said the changes in the American mind in recent years had been enormous.

Hand $200 to a person of 60 or over and tell him he must spend it in a month! That is Isom Lamb's idea of how to prove if old age pensions will work. He has posted $1,200 in a bank for a six months' test. Mr. Lamb, a Townsend Club supervisor sponsoring the test, appealed today for suggestions on the fairest way to choose the spenders.

To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 16: PATROLMEN--Gerald W. Snowden, 70th Precinct, assignment to duty as attendan discontinued. (Res. Pct. 61.) Edwin A. Waitword, 70th Precinct, signed to duty as attendant. (Res. Pct.

This is a happy town tonight. Governor Murphy's arrangement under which the sit-down strikers will evacuate General Motors factories and the company agrees to begin collective bargaining negotiations means that, if all goes well, the biggest automobile concern in the country will soon have its men back on the payroll.

A precedent was established in Queens County yesterday when a Negro attorney was assigned by Judge Charles S. Colden to take part in the defense of Major Green, Negro porter, accused of the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case. No previous instance of a Negro being appointed to defend a member of his race in a murder case could be recalled yesterday by Queens County Court attaches.

Owners of old-law tenements thronged the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall yesterday and protested loudly against what they consider the iniquities of the Multiple Dwelling Law. Spokesmen for the group demanded "relief" for landlords and charged Mayor La Guardia with playing politics in the housing crisis.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Frank E. Simmons of 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn, gave a dinner last night at their home before a motion-picture entertainment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the benefit of the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

Alexander U. Mayer, retired lawyer and former Corporation Counsel for the old village of Williamsbridge, died Thursday night at his home, 4,163 Boston Post Road, the Bronx, of heart disease. He was 81 years old.

A few cuts were in demand, but trading generally in traefa meats lacked action and in some cases was unusually slow. Beef ruled steady to slightly lower. Other classes declined. Early trading in kosher meats indicated this market to be weak to lower, with demand slow.

Displaying a well-balanced attack, the Brooklyn Tech quintet increased its advantage over its rivals in Section 1 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. tournament by vanquishing Alexander Hamilton, 25--17, on the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court yesterday.

John S. Bridges, president of the Bridges Printing Company, died today at of his home here at the age of 80. Born in Baltimore the son of John C. Bridges and Mary Forney Bridges, he was graduated from Gettysburg College.
A drive to end spitting and smoking in the subways and on other transportation lines will be started soon by the Health Department, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner John L. Rice.
Emperor Hirohito today granted to two aged statesmen the highly prized privilege of carrying canes in the Imperial Palace.
AARON BREENE, clerk, 2,610 University Av.-Voluntary; liabilities, $1,058; no assets. HENRY HALMOS, real estate broker, 234 W. 48th St.-Liabilities, $35,185;
Commercial leases, reported yesterday, included contracts for a number of entire floors and for stores. Garment firms figured in many of the rentals. The list follows:

Charles W. Froessel, appointed a Justice of the City Court in Queens by Governor Lehman last week, took the oath yesterday at a ceremony attended by nearly 400 persons in Long Island City He succeeds Peter M. Daly, who became a Supreme Court Justice Jan. 1.
While the authorities were releasing more than 200 political prisoners at Sao Paulo the Rio de Janeiro police were arresting alleged leaders of another Leftist plot, the police disclosed today.
Two players, Ben Pope of Pittsburgh and Johnny Skillman, coach at Yale, moved into the semi-finals today with double victories in the national professional squash racquets championship.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Julian S. Stein, senior member of the banking house of Stein Brothers Boyce, died today at his estate in Pikesville. He studied at Hotchkiss School before entering Johns Hopkins University, where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1903.

The National Retail Credit Association reported today the average increase in collections for December, 1936, over December, 1935, was 8.4 per cent, compared with 7.2 per cent for December, 1935, over the same month in 1934.

Because of a strike by the teamsters' union, publishers of school textbooks are having difficulty in delivering school material at depots from which the city's schools draw their supplies, it was learned yesterday.
China's exports of tung oil through the Port of Hankow established a record last year, the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce reported today. A total of 79,449 short tons

John Warren, transport pilot, husband of Viola Gentry, noted woman flier, died today at the Presbyterian Hospital here of pneumonia. Mr. Warren, who was 36 years old, and lived at 99 North Sixth Street, had been ill several days.

Hundreds of lowlanders fled before the steady advance of flood waters in the Midwest today. Some left threatened homes on foot. Others were taken out in small boats. But the refugees were cheered by a forecast of fair and colder weather-expected to end protracted rains and check the swift rise of overburdened streams in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys.

The Newman clubs of the New York Province of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs opened their annual three-day convention with a reception and dance in the Starlight Roof at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The thirty-four "politically prominent" clerks in the Municipal Courts whose dismissal was ordered recently by the Municipal Civil Service Commission are still on the job, although their salaries have been stopped, James E. Finegan, the commission president, said yesterday.
The State Banking Department today announced the appointment of Irving A. J. Lawres of Scarsdale as confidential assistant in the department at a salary of $5,500 per annum.
W. A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, announced tonight that $60,000,000 will be spent in constructing and modernizing mills at Clairton and Homestead, Pa.

David T. Wadsworth, vice president and chief engineer of the Wadsworth Electric and Manufacturing Company, Covington, Ky., and a pioneer in the electrical industry, died today at Louisville, Ky., where he was attending a meeting of the Kentucky chapter of the International Association of Electrical Inspectors. Mr. Wadsworth was 67 years old.
Tammany's demonstrations of harmony this week have been unusually affecting. For a time certain leaders or war lords, as prudent men bound to consider their future, forgot their accustomed altruism.

Harold Samuel, pianist and regarded as one of the greatest Bach interpreters of his time, died at his home in Hampstead today at the age of 57. He came to international fame in 1921 when he gave a series of six Bach recitals on successive days, all different programs and all played without reference to the printed music.

Two Negroes were shot and wounded seriously late last night in Harlem by detectives hiding behind packing cases in a liquor store when one of the Negroes drew a pistol and attempted to hold up the store at 113th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.
Turpentine steady, 43 1/2c; sales, 52 barrels; receipts, 105 barrels; shipments, 90 barrels; stock, 31,451 barrels. Resin steady; sales, 540; receipts, 1,406; shipments. 1,684; stock, 75,492.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 9 amounted to 698,529 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 110,576 cars, or 18.8 percent, more than for the preceding week; 83,676 cars; or 13.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 145,011 cars, or 26.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Bridget Anne Moira HemsleyThompson, daughter of General and Mrs. Hemsley-Thompson of London, to Douglas Laird Busk, also of London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Laird Busk.

Dr. and Mrs. Walter P. Anderton of 59 East Seventy-seventh Street gave a dinner last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for their daughter, Miss Audrey K. Anderton. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. John B. Watkins, the Misses Marian C. Kingsland, Hope Douglas, Margaret Clinton, Amy Plant, Kate Murray, Hildegarde Graham, Evelyn Bruen, Betty Peyton, Diana McIlvaine, Anne Hoguet, Leslie Larned and Mary Cole.
An official statement this evening revealed the number of Austrian Nazis who received amnesty following the Austro-German accord of last July to have been 18,684.

Leftist militiamen, attempting to halt a projected Insurgent advance along the southern coast near Estepona, attacked Rebel positions today, according to Gibraltar reports to the emergency defense council. The Insurgent high command rushed fresh troops to the new battlefield bY trucks and taxis,
Eighteen of the nation's foremost trotters, including the last two Hambletonian winners, have been entered for the $17,500 All-American Stake, which will be raced for the first time this year.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the dismissal of two more patrolmen, bringing the total of men dismissed since he took office to 152. Both the men dismissed yesterday had been charged with making false statements to a superior officer

A new publication of the Health Department entitled "Our Nurses" will make its appearance today. Designed as an organ of the department's Bureau of Nursing, it will be issued five times a year and will contain news of the various activities of the bureau.

The Berlin Catholic Diocesan Journal challenges the State and the National Socialist party today with the declaration that until the semi-official attacks on Christianity cease the Catholics will continue to protest and counterattack.

The Prager Tagblatt's London correspondent reports that the Czechoslovak Government has suggested that the British Government send an official commission to investigate German charges that Czechoslovakia and Russia are closely cooperating in the matter of air forces and that several airfields in this country are specially outfitted for Soviet use.

A large group attended the second of the pre-Lenten dances given last night at the auditorium of the Naval Training Station by the officers stationed here, under the direction of a committee headed by Captain John M. Smeallie of the Naval War College.
The engagement of Lord Ashley, former husband of Mrs. Douglas Fairbanks, to Miss Francoise Souilier of Paris was announced today.

3d Av., 475, 24.8x85; Roman Ketterer to East River Savings Bank, $13,500. 138th St., 237 W., 17x99.11; Rexhold Realty Corp, James H. Cruikshank, president, to Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 1,560 Amsterdam Av.; purchase money, 5 years, 5 per cent, $5,000.
The Fisher Body plant operated here in conjunction with. a Chevrolet assembly unit was closed tonight as the result of Midwestern strikes which stopped the flow of necessary parts.

Salaries for the last fiscal year of the principal executives of the Atlas Corporation, Swift Co., the Associates Investment Company and the Martin-Parry Corporation were disclosed yesterday in reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission filed with the New York Stock Exchange. The Electric Storage Battery Company and L. C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., filed their salary lists confidentially with the commission under Rule UB-2.

The German press and radio are giving a surprising amount of attention to President Franklin D. Roosevelt's proposal for administrative reorganization. Such interest in American affairs is unusual, but may be attributed to preparations now being made here for changes in the Reich government.

Arthur T. Hill has joined Hartley, Rogers Co. and will be in charge of their research department. Because of lack of a quorum, the annual meeting of the Central Violeta Sugar Company, S. A., has been adjourned until Jan. 29.

President Roosevelt disclosed at his press conference today that there had been some recent discussion between the United States and the Canadian Governments regarding the St. Lawrence waterway project. He added, however, that the conversations had been talks designed to explore the possibility of formal discussions later.

Federal Judge Coxe granted a temporary injunction yesterday to Time, Inc., restraining the Voice of Time, a radio broadcasting enterprise of 1 Park Place from using the word "time" in a way that would infringe on the title, "The March of Time," monthly motionpicture feature put out by the plaintiff. In its suit Time, Inc.
Members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild will attend a dress rehearsal of Richard Hageman's opera, "Caponsacchi," on the morning of Jan. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Miss Jennie P. Knapp, daughter of Mrs. Jennie H. Knapp of this place and the late Edwin A. Knapp, was married to Henry N. Allen of Wallingford at the home of the bride this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, officiated.

The New York State Horticultural Society ended its convention today after hearing E. Stuart Hubbard, director of the New York and New England Apple Institute, say that "the December report shows that more apples have been consumed than a year ago, even though prices this season are 50 per cent higher."

Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of China's generalissimo, is understood to be considering sailing for America late in February or early in March, having been invited by Mount Holyoke College to attend its centenial celebrations next May to deliver an address and receive an honorary degree.

More than 2,000 marchers, gathered here by David Lasser, president of the Workers Alliance of America, paraded through Washington's downtown streets today, waving banners and chanting slogans, and presented petitions at the White

Fully justifying the seeding, Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club and Frederick B. Ryan Jr. of the Short Hills Club gained the final of the annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tourney yesterday by scoring wellearned triumphs in the semi-final round on the Yale Club courts.

The government announced today the first draft of a law to forbid the raising of carrier pigeons in Austria--a reaction to a spy scare which has swept the country. It was argued that pigeons might be used to carry unauthorsized information out of Austria.
Unity among Jews, and joint responsibility of layman and rabbi as "spokesmen" of the synagogue, were stressed today at the opening of the Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

The city was within its constitutional debt limit by $235,886,533 on Jan. 1, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday to the Board of Estimate. His report showed that since Sept. 1 the margin had been increased by $34,557,996.

Margaret Sanger, in response to the presentation to her of the Town Hall Club Medal for hr pioneer work in behalf of birth control, said last night that "the. shaking apart of the laws which at last separate scientific birth control from obscenity makes possible the creation of a new race and of a new generation brought into the world consciously conceived."

Seventy-five old-time vaudeville stars attended the funeral service yesterday morning for Barney Fagan, dancer and comedian of the last quarter of the nineteenth century, in the Actors' Chapel of St. Malachy's Catholic Church, 241 West Forty-ninth Street. Mr. Fagan died Tuesday on his eighty-seventh birthday.

The New Jersey Farm Bureau, in its eighteenth annual meeting in the Hotel Woodrow Wilson here today, adopted a resolution urging the State Public Utility Commission to force public utilities to base rates for electric current on "actual cost plus a fair return."

Louis J. Borinstein of Indianapolis, chairman of the legislative committee of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, urged today "governmental prohibition of coercion on both sides" in labor disputes.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd, (Canada) announced yesterday a net profit of $1,887,971 for quarter ended on Nov. 30 after depreciation; interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. No provision was made for Federal surtaxes on undistributed earnings. The profit is equivalent after dividend requirements on the cumulative preference shares amounting to-$115,202, to $2.45 a share on 721,533 no-par common shares.

By a unanimous vote of 591, the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon granted Premier Blum's government the powers it asked to take any measures it might consider necessary to prevent recruiting or transit of volunteers in French territory for service in either of the combatant forces in Spain.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow on the topic of "Church Unity" because Monday will mark the opening of the - annual world-wide Church Unity Octave, one of the few movements in which the Protestant and the Roman Catholic communions both participate.

The Bureau of Navigation released these orders today, dated Jan. 13: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Folz, A. F., the Trenton, to continue treat ment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif. Graves, E. D. Jr., staff, Commander Battle Force, to Destroyer Division 19. Walbridge, E. D., the Oklahoma. to duty as Assistant Naval Inspector of Machinery, New York Shipbuilding Corporation. Camden, N. J.
Birds and flowers in this torrid Northeast were reported in utter confusion. Crocuses, forsythia and pansies have been observed
Kenneth G. Ormiston, radio engineer who attracted wide attention in connection with Aimee Semple McPherson's disappearance eleven years ago, died today after an appendectomy. He was 41 years old.
Britain will celebrate the coronation of George VI on May 12 with an eleven-week program of dinners, levees, balls and reviews that are expected to surpass the pomp scheduled for Edward VIII.

Otto A. Ritter, 42 years old, of 434 East Fifty-second Street, who was arrested Jan. 5 after Walter Herdig, a visiting Swiss art student of 256 West Ninety-third Street, had complained that he had given him a worthless check, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Ford in the Felony Court.

Mrs. Newbold Morris has left the Pierre to visit her brother, George Lovett Kingsland, in Palm Beach. Miss Marian Kingsland will leave early next week to join her father. Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Delafield Jr. are now at Good Hope Ranch, Trelawny, Jamaica, B. W. I.

Lawrence S. Holt, textile manufacturer, merchant and banker, died at his home here today after several months of failing health. He was 85 years old. Surviving are a son and three daughters, including Mrs. Howard Lowry of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Walter Brooks of New York.

Eight men and four women who were arrested last Thursday for alleged frauds on members of Protestant and Catholic parishes in the city in advertising schemes, pleaded not guilty before Magistrate Ford in the Felony Court yesterday. At the request of seven lawyers representing the accused, the magistrate set their hearings for Monday.

The decision of the Copper Institute to make available to the public the monthly statistics that it compiles pertaining to production, deliveries and stocks of copper in the United States, was considered yesterday to be a step in the right direction. For years the copper

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: As you still are running letters on baseball, I have something to say. Being a baseball fan, I came from England last June especially to attend the games at the Stadium and the Polo Grounds.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Harland Bryant Tibbetts, George F. Lewis, and William Radner, of New York City, were admitted, and the following proceedings had: 347. City of New York, petr., v. Saul Goldstein, trustee in bankruptcy, etc. Motion for leave file petition for rehearing submitted for Petitioner.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 14, unless specified: At Guantanamo Bay, Jan. 15: Nitro. Semmes. At San Francisco: Cushing, Perkins. Acushet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Jan. 15. Antares, at Balboa, C. Z. Badger, Norfolk Yard to sea, Jan. 15 Barracuda, at Philadelphia Yard.

The Electric Auto-Lite Company, Toledo, Ohio, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $10,000,000 of 4 per cent debentures due on Feb. 1, 1952, and convertible until Jan. '31, 1947, and an undetermined amount of $5 par value common stock to be reserved for issuance upon conversion of the debentures.

Mayor La Guardia caused some excitement yesterday at a Board of Estimate meeting at City Hall when he revealed, in answer to a question, that he had not received an invitation to attend the inauguration of President Roosevelt in Washington next Wednesday.

Sid Lubar's foul shot and Hy Gimplowitz's field goal in the final minutes of play enabled the Brooklyn College quintet to break a 28-28 tie and defeat the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute five, 31-28, at Odd Fellows Hall in Brooklyn last night.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Business in the seaboard markets has been less active, but prices have been firmly maintained and are a little more uniform on the basis of last week's quotations.

Doubt among the nations whether any government or social regime would survive a long war is the most important of the deterrents to a new international conflict, James G. McDonald, former High Commissioner for German Refugees, said last night before the Teachers College Chapter of Kappa Delta Pi, honorary national educational fraternity, at Dodge Hall, Teachers College.

President Eamon de Valera returned to Dublin tonight, but refused to comment on his talks with Dominions Secretary Malcolm MacDonald in London. Tomorrow he will meet members of his Cabinet and report on the results of his conversations.
Tony Manero, national open golf champion, said tonight he would quit March 1 as pro at the Sedgefield Country Club to take the position at the Salem, Mass., Country Club.

Helen Teschner Tas, a violinist who has made many local appearances during her artistic career, gave a recital last night at the Town Hall which again demonstrated the musicianly quality of her attainments. Her program was, as

Because she is-a more experienced tournament player and because she knows considerably more about the game of squash racquets than her opponent, Miss Susan Guion yesterday became the new metropolitan Class B champion. She defeated

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company issued yester.day a preliminary report showing that last year, for the first time since 1931, it earned the $9 dividend that it has maintained since 1922. Much of the income in 1936.

Premier Benito Mussolini and Colonel General Hermann Goering spent the greater part of the morning together inspecting the Fascist Academy of Physical'Culture and met again for a short while in the afternoon before the reception given by the city of Rome in honor of the German visitors.

The sixteen-story. apartment house at the southwest corner of 108th Street and Amsterdam Avenue was bought yesterday by E. C. Equities, Inc., representing Etta Cherkos and Abrahram Weinstein, from a client of Schiff..Dorfman Stein.
Setting up of the machinery of the House majority whip to make ironclad the administration's control of the House through its leaders was completed today.

The Hamburg of the HamburgAmerican Line docked early last evening, several hours late because of stormy weather at sea. Captain Theodor Koch, master, said he had encountered storms and high wind all the way across, with the wind at times reaching hurricane force.

A Oman whose papers indicated he was Clifford C. Clark, 43 years old, of 2,114 Claremont Avenue, Norfolk, Va., first engineer of the laidup liner Leviathan, was found dead of illuminating gas poisoning yes-terday afternoon in a room at est Fortieth Street, apparently a suicide.
A "cloth annuity" provided in a 146-year-old treaty was collected today from Uncle Sam by Indians of the Six Nations on New York and Western reservations.

More than 100 junior members of the Sons of the American Revolution and the Daughters of the American Revolution, assisted by the Seventh Regiment Glee Club, presented a pageant depicting significant events in the history of the United States last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Guests were received tonight at the second Friday dinner dance in the Embassy Room of the Warwick by Mrs. Antony L. Geyelin, Mrs. Charles C. Norris Jr., Mrs. William Paul O'Neill and Miss Frances Clark.

The Scullin Steel Company, in a reorganization plan filed in Federal court under the amended Bankruptcy Act, proposed today a fifteen-year extension of a $3,062,500 first mortgage bond issue and reduction of fixed interest from 6 to 3 per cent.
In Rome the conferences and reported proposals of General GOERING and Premier MUSSOLINI cause them to appear for all the world like naughty children making faces behind the backs of their elders.

The Delaware River Joint Commission voted today to reduce the toll on the Delaware River bridge between Camden and Philadelphia from 25 cents to 20 cents, for a trial period of seven months. The new rate will go into effect at midnight, Feb. 1.

The Power Memorial Academy quintet went into the lead in the Manhattan-Richmond division of the C.H.S.A.A. by defeating De La Salle, 33-28, on the victors' court yesterday. Tom Gorman starred with 12 points. The winners are undefeated in two league starts.

Eight contributors sent gifts totaling $49 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the amount raised to date to $270,151.88. One donor, who sent $1 and signed the letter with the number, 3,231, wrote:

The study begun early last year by 4,500 relief workers to determine the income-spending and consumption habits of people in the different parts of the United States has reached the metropolitan centers, where for the first time families

Columbia's basketball team, unbeaten in fourteen consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate League games the past two years, was tripped tonight by Yale, whose 53-33 victory strengthened Penn's hold on first place in the circuit.

Retirement of Ernest C. Wagner as chairman of the executive committee and director of the Discount Corporation of New York was disclosed yesterday when the corporation published its statement of condition as of Dec. 31 last.

The Rev. Maitland Bartlett began his third term this week as stated clerk of the Presbytery of New York. Mr. Bartlett was unanimously re-elected by the Presbytery last Monday in the Welsh Church, 505 West 155th Street.
Magistrate Anna M. Kross of New York City was convicted today on a charge of reckless driving and Mayor O. A. Smith, judge of the Municipal Court, fined her $25.

New bond financing this week amounted to $117,436,200, compared with a total of $62,826,000 in new issues placed on. the market last week. This week a year ago new bond flotations amounted to $148,366,000.
The block of four five-story flats at 50-56 Manhattan Avenue was among the properties figuring in auction sales in Manhattan yesterday. The results follow:

The automotive-aeronautics trade division of the Department of Commerce reported today that shipments of aeronautical products in the first eleven months of 1936 were valued at $19,572,910, compared with $13,502,137 in the corresponding period of 1935, an increase of 45 per cent.

The official party organ for farmers, the National Socialist Landpost, has issued an appeal to produce better crops this year or "Germany will again become dependent on the foreigner for nourishment and the Fuehrer's struggle for protection from foreign influences will become more difficult."

Relentless in their search for the kidnap-slayer of little Charles Mattson, officers held a much-sought ex-convict and a former mental patient tonight as the Mattson family prepared to vacate its Tacoma home for a rest in "some secluded spot."

In a recapitulation of the affairs of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today in a letter to Senator Glass and Representative Steagall, dispatched while legislation for extension of the lending powers of the corporation was pending before Congress, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said that in 1936, excluding instances where money was advanced to other governmental agencies or disbursed for relief, collections had exceeded loans disbursed by $736,000,000.

Coming through in the closing bouts, Lehigh's wrestlers shattered a 13-13 deadlock and went on to defeat the University of Michigan team tonight for their third consecutive dual meet victory in less than a week.

The Rev. Edward J. Brennan, pastor of St. Mary's Star of the Sea Church, New London, died at St. Mary's Hospital early this morning of a stomach ailment at the age of 70. From 1910 to 1934 Father Brennan was pastor of St. Margaret's Church here, and he had been at New London for the last two years.

Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., the nation's No. 1 amateur tennis player, and Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, rated just below him, advanced to the semi-finals of the annual Dixie tennis tournament today.

Miss Katherine Christian Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Taylor of this place, has selected Feb. 9 as the date for her marriage to Lieutenant (Junior Grade) Allen Bond Adams Jr. U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Bond Adams of Moundsville, W. Va.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the net market purchases of government securities for Treasury investment accounts for December amounted to $24,174,100 compared with $5,912,000 the preceding month.

Calling the automobile truce "eminently satisfactory," John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America and head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, said that representatives of the workers in the coming arbitration conferences would insist upon recognition of the union as exclusive bargaining agency for the industry.

Eddie Schneider, 25-year-old aviator, who recently returned to the United States after serving a month in the so-called Yankee Squadron with the Spanish Loyalists, said yesterday that a New York lawyer had negotiated with him for his services abroad.

At today's wool auction 8,703 bales were offered, of which 7,340 sold. Selection was good, with crossbreds selling freely. Demand was active, especially from the home trade, and continental traders purchased merinos.

The appointment of Daniel McNamara, Brooklyn lawyer and former State Assemblyman, as building and loan consultant for the Federal Housing Administration was announced yesterday by Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald. Mr. McNamara

Paul Foy, 33-year-old orderly in Morrisania Hospital, was cleared yesterday of a charge of having used undue force while attending a Negro patient at the hospital when the Bronx County grand jury did not indict him.
Reminiscent of the United States wartime campaigns, the German Government has entered the junk business in old bottles and scrap in a big way.
The administration leadership of the Senate moved swiftly today to put down the first open sign of opposition to President Roosevelt's reorganization plan.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 927,000 bales, against 920,000 a week ago, 909,00 two weeks ago, 882,000 three weeks ago and 712,000 a year ago; 341.000 which American 364,000 bales, against 339,000 a week ago, 341,000 two weeks ago, 334,000 three weeks ago and 400,000 a year ago.

Discussions bearing upon trade relations of the United States and Great Britain, which may pave the way for important moves later, are expected to be held by President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, while the latter is a guest at the White House during the week-end of Jan. 23.

The action brought by Crawford Burton, gentleman jockey and member of the New York Stock Exchange, against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for $200,000 damages, has been settled out of court, Joseph R. Truesdale, attorney for Mr. Burton, announced yesterday.

The Chase National Bank, as successor depositary of certain ordinary stock of the Royal Dutch Company under agreement dated Sept. 10, 1918, has received a dividend of 5 guilders for each 100 guilders par value of the company's ordinary stock held by the bank.

An employes' profit and management participation program, retroactive to Jan. 1, and giving to men and women workers preference over regular stockholders in first profit sharing, was announced today by George R. Rich, president of Rich Manufacturing Corporation, automobile valve makers.
John Miltern, a veteran actor of the stage and screen, was fatally injured tonight when struck by an automobile in front of the home of his fellow actor, Basil Rathbone, where he was a guest.

A bronze mythological group by the French sculptor Antoine Louis Barye called "Hercule Terrassant le Sanglier" was bought by McClure Halley for $950 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.,

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, minimized the alleged advantages of the repeal of the prohibition amendment and predicted the return of prohibition within a few years, in addressing members and guests of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Commenting on the terms of the truce which has broken the deadlock in the automobile industry, Mr. JOHN L LEWIS said yesterday that it was "eminently satisfactory," but that the representatives of the workers [in the forthcoming negotiations] will insist upon formal recognition of the union as the exclusive bargaining agency for the industry.

A. bronze wayside shrine which had become a familiar sight to thousands of motorists since Samuel F. Houston, a banker, erected it in memory of the World War dead-on his Chestnut Hill estate in 1921, was found today to have been damaged by vandals.

A searching inquiry into some angles of the stock-listing practices of the New York Stock Exchange appeared tonight to be certain after the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee had suddenly adjourned until Jan. 25 its investigation of the Van Sweringen rail empire to enable members of the committee and its accountants and investigators to study a trunkload of documents from the files of the Exchange which today came into the committee's possession.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex include Charles Ayling, Mrs. John Van S. Bloodgood, Mrs. Richard E. Breed, George Breed, Mrs. Gilbert Cooper, Thomas Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. J. Mortimer Fox,

The increase in cotton mill activity was less than seasonal last week with the result that the adjusted index dropped back to 142.4 from 149.8 in the preceding week. For the week ended Jan. 11, 1936, the figure was 112.8.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected. in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Mrs. Rachel Nahon Toledano, widow of Phineas Habib Toledano, New York exporter, died Thursday at her home, 166 West Seventysecond Street. Mrs. Toledano was a founder of the Neighborhood House of the Spanish and Portuguese Sisterhood, at 128 Stanton Street, and of the Sephardic Community Center, now out of existence. She also was a member of

Copies of a plan to reform Westchester County government, prepared jointly by the County Federation of Women's Clubs, the League of Women Voters and the County Taxpayers Association, were sent today to the forty-two members of the Board of Supervisors.

Exports of petroleum products from the United States to Greece in 1936 were greatly stimulated as a result of exchange difficulties in Greek trade with Rumania, the Department of Commerce reported today from Assistant Trade Commissioner G. L. Jones in Athens.

The American premiere of a Symphony by Tibor Serly of New York, formerly a member of the viola section of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was greeted with enthusiasm this afternoon by an audience at the Academy of Music.

Syracuse's unbeaten basketball team, hitting its fastest clip this season, overwhelmed Harvard tonight, 52 to 18, before 2,200 spectators. The Crimson, although boasting a 46-point-per-game scoring average in previous trays, could not match the fast pace of the Orange after the opening minutes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that, at the request of the applicants, it had consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933:

Ralph Guldahl, lanky Chicago pro, outscored par, the elements and 215 opponents today to set the firstround pace in the $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament with a 64. His remarkable round, made despite driving rain, sodden fairways and mushy greens, clipped four strokes off the par 34, 34-68 Claremont course. The record is 62, held

The Labor Relations Board ordered Wiliiam Randolph Hearst and five Hearst companies today to offer Frank M. Lynch and Philip Everhardt Armstrong their former positions on The Seattle Post-Intelligencer.
A showdown between Chairman Arthur E. Morgan and David Lilienthal, director, for leadership of the Tennessee Valley Authority appeared tonight to be rapidly approaching.

Over protests of attorneys for Swift Co., meat packers, that the proceedings before the United States Department of Agriculture had "degenerated into a proceeding in which we are being persecuted under the guise of a government hearing," the department continued its inquiry at the old Postoffice Building yesterday into charges that the packers had indulged in unfair and discriminatory trade practices against independent competitors.

Statements by Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and by the special committee of the American Bar Association, which propose legislation on the principle underlying the sale of convict-made goods as an adequate substitute for the Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution, were attacked yesterday as "confusing the issue" and as "red herrings" in simultaneous replies by two groups favoring the proposed amendment.

Reports from various sections of the country indicate that the old political parties are preparing a strong campaign against General John Metaxas' dictatorship. Rumors of a forthcoming coup are current here.
Many American Ambassadors and Ministers are gathering here for periodic reports to the government and to attend the inauguration of President Roosevelt.

The largest recent listing of athletic insignia was announced at Yale University today. The Board of Athletic Control, upon recommendation of the Undergraduate Athletic Association, authorized 255 awards in recognition of activities during the Spring and Fall sport campaigns. Managerial insignia, as well as rewards for athletic competition were included in the total.

Marquand School rallied after trailing 13-12 at the half to subdue Columbia Grammar, 28-20, on the winners' floor in one of the outstanding non-league basketball games played yesterday. Kersey, right forward, was high scorer for the victors, with eight markers.

The Seth Low basketball team defeated the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, 63-23, for its fourth victory in six starts at the Columbia gymnasium last night. Trailing by 11-12 count midway in the first period, Seth Low rallied to score 21 consecutive points and lead 32-12 at the half.

Mrs. W. Ruloff Kip gave a luncheon at the Colony Club yesterday for her cousin, Countess Alexander Tolstoy. Other guests were Mrs. P. Sheldon Parsons, Mrs. Robert Zimmerman, Mrs. George B. Wagstaff Jr., Mrs. Martin von Dehn, Mrs. Stuart Gibboney, Mrs. Charles G. Meyer, Mrs. Reginald Burbank, Mrs.

High speed in a capital ship must be paid for usually by lightening armor. Since Jutland, naval architects doubt whether the sacrifice in protection is justified. Some also question whether the added weight in engines and the greater space they occupy pay for the somewhat higher manoeuvring ability that follows an increase of speed by a knot or two.

Thursday's improvement carried over yesterday in the market for United States Government loans, and was in line with the generally better tone that ruled bond trading through the session on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Santa Anita race track is now equipped to cope with all "unusual weather" that makes the track too muddy for good racing. Superintendent Rod has constructed a "track warmer," a twelve-foot square pan which becomes blistering hot when he lights the kerosene burners.

Exhibitions both here and in Washington, D. C., are being held by way of commemorating the hundredth anniversary of the birth of the American landscape painter, Thomas Moran, N. A., who was born in England on Jan. 12, 1837, and who died at Santa Barbara, Calif., Aug. 25, 1926.

Against a cloudy New Jersey background the Polish Slavonic Chorus, which recently began a five months' tour of the United States and Canada, sang four native hymns and the Polish National Anthem yesterday afternoon during the ceremonies of welcome that were accorded them by New York religious leaders on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building.

Mrs. Bertha Falk Steinmeier of 51 West Eighty-sixth Street died on Thursday at her home after an illness of several months. Her age was 67. She was the widow of Julius Steinmeier, a prominent merchant of Boise. Idahlo.

William C. Bruns, president of Bruns, Kimball Co., at 71. Fifth Avenue, one of the largest distributors of standardized motor boats sand engines in the world, died on Thursday at his home, 51 Fifth Avenue. His age was 57.

A housewife was beaten on the head yesterday in Brooklyn under circumstances somewhat similar to the robbery-slaying of Mrs. Mary Case, although in this instance the housebreaker's victim was not seriously injured.

The fact that William Maloy, Duquesne plant employee representative, had been receiving pay since September, 1936, as an organizer for the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers while serving as chairman of the Pittsburgh District General Council, under the company representation plan of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, was admitted by him today before the National Labor Relations Board.
The official marine publication, Verordnungsblatt, announced tonight that foreign warships may enter the Kiel Canal only "after having previously obtained consent by diplomatic procedure."

Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, made public yesterday its report for 1936, which showed the board was called upon to hand down more decisions last year than in any prior year. The board rules on the intent and meaning of construction laws.

In a statement issued yesterday commenting upon the charges filed against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company by the Federal Trade Commission, Caruthers Ewing, general counsel for the company, declared "the company has steadfastly adhered to the policy of neither seeking nor accepting any discriminatory prices."

" This Life I've Loved," by Isobel Field, stepdaughter of Robert Louis Stevenson, will be published by Longmans, Green March 17. It contains, together with other original material, four unpublished poems by Stevenson and pictures of Stevenson never before released.

Independence Av. (13-3425), e. s., 59 ft. no. of 254th St., 268x90: Riverdale Heights, Inc., to Investors Syndicate, 250 Park Av.; due as per bond (four building loans); $44,000. Plot begins (13-3425), w. s. of unnamed right-of-way, 71 ft. n. of 254th St., 277x 105; Riverdale Heights, Inc., to Investors Syndicate, 250 Park Av.; due as per bond (four building loans): $44,000.
Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, assisted by their groups, made their first appearance of the season last night at the Hippodrome in a benefit performance for the International Labor Defense.
The Italian Government announced today that it was prepared not to mount guns exceeding 14-inch caliber on future capital ships if all the important naval powers accepted the limitation.

One hundred members and guests of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners, who have been in convention at Coral Gables, were guests tonight of Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, at a dinner at the Roney Plaza Hotel.

Sanford Bates, Director of Federal Prisons, reported to Attorney General Cummings today that "grievously overcrowded" government penal institutions created conditions found in "no other civilized nation."

Objections by Deal residents that their children should not be sent to Asbury Park and Long Branch schools because their boys and girls were "superior" to those of the latter communities evoked protests today from mothers of Asbury Park and Long Branch children and an apology from the president of the Deal school board to the heads of the other two boards.

A three-judge tribunal today acquitted Robert A. Simpson, a band leader, of blame in the death of 17year-old Ellen Sullivan after the State joined defense counsel in a motion to dismiss charges of murder and criminal assault.
A prohibition repeal bill providing for a State store system was passed today by the Alabama Senate, 28 to 6, with the House-originated bill amended to provide for a State-wide referendum Feb. 23.

An American mission seeking the basis of a compromise to control heavy Japanese textile exports to the United States opened private conferences today with leaders of Japan's cotton industry. Otokichi Shoji, president of the Japan Spinners Association,

The objections of a group of Brooklyn property owners to the acquisition by the city of land for the widening of Tillary Street in Brooklyn were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, who declared that the borough sorely needs more of the same improvements.

T. O. M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, Endeavour II, is being prepared with Endeavour to leave Gosport, near Portsmouth, for America early in May. Sopwith has decided not to rig his challenger for racing on this side of the Atlantic, but to fit her out in New York and do all the preliminary racing and tuning-up in American waters.

The volume of shares bought and sold in round lots and that of trading by members for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange Increased in the week ended on Dec. 19; compared with the previous week, but the percentage of member trading to total volume was slightly smaller, 20.53 per cent, compared with 20.67, according to the weekly summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange, Commission.

As a result of your very arduous and sincere efforts to secure a basis upon which collective bargaining can be commenced, culminating in the conference held in your office today in the interest of expediting. a settlement, we hereby state the position of the corporation as follows:

Accepting the mandate of their national officers, the members of the local union of the Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association voted yesterday to end the strike which they have conducted against ship lines in this port since Nov. 24.
A group of American journalists will participate in a fifteen-week symposium at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, beginning on Feb. 1, it was announced yesterday.

While the unseasonably mild and unsettled weather this week restricted retail sales of Winter merchandise in many areas of the country, there was an active demand for goods in the wholesale markets as more buyers arrived in the leading trading centers than in any comparative period in seven years, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

The Hippodrome will stage its second intercollegiate basketball double-header of the week tonight when Manhattan meets Loyola College of Maryland and Long Island University faces Rider College of Trenton.

Mrs. William Griffith Henshaw of San Francisco and Cap Martin, France, who is at the Plaza, has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Mrs. Sara Tanner Pratt of San Francisco, to Hamilton Ward Bingham of Lynn, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton W. Bingham.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on view this morning for the first time four recently acquired drawings by old masters. These works are a study of two male figures' by Filippino, Lipi, a study for a figure of Jael by Carlo Maratti, a portrait of a young woman considered by the museum a drawing by Albrecht Duerer, and a study of a seated woman by Nicolas Lancret.

The Socialist weekly Neuer Vorwaerts, publishes a Munich report to the effect that all former inmates of the Dachau and other Bavarian concentration camps recently received official instructions that in case of mobilization they should present themselves to the nearest police station within twenty-four hours of the mobilization order.
Nebraska's new nonpartisan, onehouse Legislature declined today to erase from its procedure the ancient parliamentary device known as Committee of the Whole.

An exploding giant firecracker set off last night under the chair of Miss Edna Plante failed of its intended purpose of checking the paroxysms of hiccoughing from which she had been suffering for some 140 hours.

City Controller Frank J. Taylor, Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn and State Senator John J. Dunnigan will be speakers at the thirty-second anniversary dinner of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at the Hotel St. George on Jan. 23. Melville A. Kelsey, president of the board, will be toastmaster. John E. Henry is chairman of the committee.

A handful of scattered events, more or less stellar in nature, seems to be the entire card for presentation next week in the local night spots. The latter, as it happens, are just about entering the midwinter backstretch, where the going is sometimes pretty tough. So nothing particularly spectacular may reasonably be expected, barring, of course, a happy surprise.
Exploding oil at a pipe line break cremated four women spectators, burned two members of a repair crew to death, injured six and reduced an automobile to molten metal here last night.

Delegates to the forty-first annual convention of the New York State Association of Builders at the concluding session this afternoon at the Roger Smith Hotel adopted unanimously a resolution denouncing the Works Progress Administration as a "competitor of private industry."

The Board of -Estimate approved yesterday a request of the Park Department for permission to award a $586,361 contract for grading and draining the Northern Parking Field in Flushing Meadow Park, the site of the 1939 World's Fair. Another request, for approval of a $534,000 contract for providing topsoil for the fair site, was referred to the budget director for investigation.

Postmaster General Farley will be honored for his work as chairman of the Democratic National Committee at a dinner here on Feb. 15. It will be tendered by Democrats representing all sections of the country and President Roosevelt will

An agreement for stabilization of the lower-price branch of the millinery industry has been negotiated between the three larger producers and the Millinery Workers Union, it was announced yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the union.

Declaring that direct mail alone can be used by few industries for selling, Frank Egner, assistant vice president of the McGraw-Hill Book Company, yesterday urged its use as a "support and intensifier of newspaper and periodical advertising." He spoke at the first luncheon meeting of the newly formed Advertising and Marketing Forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

On the motion of James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, Justices Perlman, McDonald and Salomon in Special Sessions yesterday quashed policy gambling charges against Miss Fay Perlman, 20 years old, of 59 Lewis Street and Samuel Streisfeld, 40, of 128 East 113th Street, owner of a stationery store at 95 East 116th Street.

Schoolboy swimmers shattered two records last night in the Columbia University pool in the annual competition for individual P. S. A. L. titles. A crowd of 1,500 enthusiastic rooters saw Peter Kurlak of Stuyvesant retain his 50-yard back-stroke title in the record time of 0:29.1 and the James Madison High School team set a new mark in the 150-yard medley relay.
Ellsworth Vines, national professional tennis champion, handed Fred Perry, former czar of the amateur courts, his first defeat as a professional tonight. The scores were 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, 6-1.

The abnormally high temperatures for this time of year affected trade here materially this week. The call for Winter apparel was slowed down markedly and business in such items as furs, cloth coats and seasonal accessories fell well under expectations.

The mothers of three missing children together with several other women relatives attacked a man who had been brought in charged with kidnapping the children at 4:30 P. M. yesterday in the Empire Boulevard police station in Brooklyn.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad filed today in Federal court a petition requesting authority to buy fifty additional lightweight air- conditioned passenger coaches and five modern cafeteria cars.
In. an effort to offset lower yields on their investments, the major nonparticipating insurance companies throughout the country. will raise insurance rates on March 1 by approximately 3 per ceat.
Fairly general liquidation developed today in the grain markets, and while wheat and corn were slightly higher in the early trading, pressure increased and the close was near the bottom.

Peter Guarino, 38 years old, of 334 Tenth Street, this city, insisted upon acting as his own lawyer when his trial on a charge of participating in a $958 train robbery opened today in Federal court here before Judge Guy L. Fake and a jury of women.
President Roosevelt closed his office at noon today and retired to the White House library to begin work on the address which he will make at his second inauguration Wednesday.

The first match held for the world's racquets championship since 1929 will get under way at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon in the east court of the Racquet and Tennis Club. David S. Milford, an English schoolmaster at Marlborough School, will play Norbert Setzler,

The United States increased its exports to Canada, Central and -South America last November although the total of exports to all countries decreased more than $44,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Twenty-nine vessels representing nearly half the French navy effective left Brest today for the grand Atlantic manoeuvres, which will take them off the coast of Morocco. The war games began as soon as the ships were off shore, but off

The stockholders' reorganization committee of the Cosden Oil Corporation has been reconstituted arid. in the future will represent only the preferred stockholders, it was announced yesterday. J. S. Cosden, head of the company, is chairman of the committee.
In its statement of condition for Dec. 31, the Trust Company of North America reported total assets of $7,313,891 and deposits of $6,127,786. Surplus and undivided profits amounted to $217,521.
Canadian newsprint production in 1936 made a new high record of 3,190,559 tons, the News-srint Service Bureau reported today. The output was 15.9 per cent larger than in 1935, the bureau said.

Dr. Frederick A. Cook, who In 1909 announced he had reached the North Pole, was ordered by the Ap pellate Division yesterday to strike from his complaint in a suit against the Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., a paragraph in which he asserted he was accused of having obtained money under false pretense by the claim he discovered the North Pole.

Brooklyn schools took both ends of the scholastic basketball double header yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden as St. John's High won its seventh game in ten starts, scoring an easy 42-19 victory over La Salle School of Manhattan, and St. Francis defeated St. Michael's of Union City, 28-14.

Delibes's "Lakme" received its second performance of the Winter at the Metropolitan last night. A capacity audience was in attendance at this presentation in which Lily Pons made her initial appearance of the season at the Broadway house. Besides the assumption of

Hoyt S. Haddock, retiring president of the American Radio Telegraphists Association, was arrested yesterday afternoon and taken to Rockland County, where the authorities are investigating an attack on Raymond Wolf, 28 years old, radio operator of the Munson liner Western World, in his home at Spring Valley, N. Y., on Thursday night.

Despite illness affecting three teams, the polo schedule tonight is the most interesting of the season to date. Squadron A, Governors Island and the 112th Field Artillery of the Metropolitan League all have been struck- by illness, but one of the results will be to have an Internationalist appear against a Schoolboy team.

The War Deapartment released these orders today, dated Jan. 14: Brigadier General Smith, A. T., one month's leave, July 5. COLONELS Lecocq, F. X, C. A. C.; Inspector General's Department, Panama, to Baltimore, Md. Henry, W. R., F. A., Inspector General's Department. Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to Panama Canal Department, to sail from San Francisco about May 8.

Plans for the ninth annual flower show on Feb. 19, 20 and 21 at the Poinciana Conservatories were made today at the season's first meeting of the Garden Club of Palm Beach at the Everglades Club. Gordon Dunthorne of Washington and Kennebunkport, Me., spoke on "The History of Flower Prints," showing several from his own collection.

A lawyer, two labor leaders and a pie baker were arrested yesterday as conspirators in a bakery racket, the operations of which, cording to an aide of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, caused two murders, one of them that of Samuel Drukman in Brooklyn.
An appeal to the Department of Plant and Structures to install a higher barrier on the Williamsburg Bridge, between the traffic driveways and the river, was being formulated by the police yesterday.

A protest against the secrecy with which the Canadian Government cloaked its action in the recent monarchical crisis marked today's adoption by the Dominion Parliament of a resolution of loyalty to King George VI.

With most of the Democratic legislative chiefs in Washington next week for the inauguration of President Roosevelt on Wednesday, the Republicans in the Legislature will have the Capitol practically to themselves. The legislative machinery will be virtually at a standstill.
Elaine Jacobs Barrymore filed suit for divorce in Superior Court here late today against John Barrymore, actor. She charged mental cruelty. Mr. Barrymore had no comment to make on the suit.

The application of Henry G. Singer, former Assistant United States Attorney in Brooklyn, for a new trial of the charge that he conspired to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn.
The undefeated Rutgers basketball team won its eighth consecutive game of the season tonight, defeating Williams, 55-29. Only in the opening minutes of play were the losers able to hold the Scarlet.

Frederick Richardson, painter and illustrator, died yesterday morning at the Regent Nursing Home, 115 East Sixty-first Street, at the age of 74. Mr. Richardson, who resided at 7 West Forty-third Street, was taken to the hospital six days ago suffering from pneumonia.
Five of the seven properties involed in auction sales in the Bronx yesterday were bid in by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, the plaintiff. The list-follows:
MAC, who worked in the Clydeside shipyards during the war and has horny hands and a rich Northern accent to prove it, was surprised to hear that William Gallacher had written an autobiography.
