Gross assets, $10,924; net, $9,930. Samuel Barbour, husband, $9,930. Chic assets, stocks and bonds, 8,025. Morri McVeigh, attorneys, 60 Wall St. EDINGER. WILLIAM (May 29, 1936) Gross assets, $8,942; net, $7,380. Helen E. Bright, and William Edinger Jr. grandchildren, 1/8 of residue each; Louis F. Edinger, son, plumbing business 6-8 residue; one other bequest. Chief as sets, real estate, $7,048. Kenneth Chand ler Schwartz, attorney, 20 East First St. Mount Vernon.
Americans here are still awaiting the State Department's decision about closing the United States Embassy building.

Workhouse sentences were imposed by Justices Perlman, McDonald and Solomon in Special Sessions yesterday on four men for counterfeiting the trade mark of the Miles Laboratories in a plot to flood the country with a bogus product under the name Alka Seltzer. Herbert Yudkin, 44 years old,

Frederick L. Noble of 209 Hillcrest Avenue, Leonia, N. J., was killed and his wife, Mrs. Nellie Noble, critically injured about 9 o'clock last night by an automobile driven by Jeremiah Buckley of 17 Woodlawn Avenue, Jersey City, a delegate of a teamster's union with offices in Yonkers.

Fred Smith stole the show last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Biltmore. Besides being the guest of honor, he was the toastmaster, the principal speaker, the dignified gentleman sitting at the dais, the jolly fellow at table No. 1 and almost everything else.

Major Emil Fey, former Vice Chancellor of Austria, and Major Fritz Lahr, Deputy Mayor of Vienna, claimed damages for libel in a writ they served today against the printers and publishers of the National Review, and against Walter Crotch, writer of an article in that publication. It was understood the action

The Golden Hill Chorus, under the direction of Channing Lefebvre, gave its annual concert last night in Carnegie Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. The soloists were Wilbur Evans, baritone; Marie Curtis, soprano; Helen Harrington, mezzo-soprano; Veronica Harrison,

7 Park Av., (11-2903). e s 50 n of 171st St., 49x100; Wessam Realty Corp. to Parfox Holding Corp., 70 W. 40th St., mtg. $43,000. Oakland Pl., 710, (11-3095). Vincenza Mascio to Josephine Allega, 710 Oakland Pl. Stebbins Av., (11-2964). w s 260 n of Jennings St., 40-100; 1,397 Stebbins Av. Realty Corp. to 992 Freeman St. Corp., 6 Broadway.
Douglas J. Crawford, executive vice president of Rogers Peet Company, left here last night to make a survey of retail conditions throughout the country.

Mrs. Arthur Hanbury Godfrey of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Stella Godfrey, to Robert Wolcott Ripley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julien Ashton Ripley of Oyster Bay, L. I.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has announced appointment of new pastors, college faculty members and transfers of priests in the diocese, as follow:

On a water-soaked course three of the country's foremost links women fired steady golf today to tie for the lead in the opening round of the Augusta Country Club's 54-hole medal play titleholders' tournament.
Cornell's indoor polo team tonight lost its second home game in three seasons, bowing to Kenyon College, 23 to 171/2. Cornell defeated Kenyon earlier in the season.

NEW YORK CITY'S 1939 World's Fair is now on the threshold of actual construction. Within a few weeks work will begin on the Administration Building, first of the great structures which will ultimately dot the 1,200-acre site on Flushing Meadows in Queens.

The Brooklyn College wrestling team defeated Columbia 19 1/2 to 12 1/2, yesterday in the Morningside Heights Gymnasium. The visitors got off to a fine start by winning the first three bouts on falls and this advantage proved too great for the Lions to overcome.

The National Park Service has had another busy year-and not only in the parks. In addition to the development of our national playgrounds and the shepherding of tenderfeet on their park vacations, the park service acts as rental agent, janitor and protector of Federal buildings in Washington.

Financing of New Jersey schools, which has been a topic of discussion by the State Federation of Women's Clubs, was made the subject of a motion at the last meeting of the board of trustees in Newark by Mrs. M. Warren Cowles, chairman of education for the federation.

Constructive leadership on the part of the city and intelligent cooperation by lending institutions will do a great deal toward the solution of the present tenementhouse problem, according to Herbert L. Williams, president of the Realty Mortgagee Servicing Corporation.

BANK--CITRON--Mr. and Mrs. M. Citron, Columbia, S. C., announce the engagement of their daughter. Miss Dena Silber Citron, to Mr. Jules Bank of New York City. CALLAHAN - (COHEN)--RUBY--Mr. and Mrs. Max Ruby, West New York, N. J., announce engagement of daughter, Martha,to Mr. Lew A. Callahan (Cohen). Brookllyn.

Moderate improvement over a fairly broad list was reflected yesterday in the closing prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Buying activities were principally among the secondary railroad and convertible industrial loans, many of which responded with substantial gains.

Ellsworth Vines, showing no trace of his recent illness, vanquished Fred Perry in straight sets, 14-12, 6-2, 6-1, before 6,500 spectators tonight to draw within one match of evening the count in their professional tennis series.

Mrs. Zilpha Smith Storm Flagler, a descendant of the Storm family that settled in Dutchess County before the American Revolution and for which Stormville was named, died here Thursday night. Mrs. Flagler was the widow of Josenh Flagler.

The up-to-date view of science and religion is that they are not antagonistic but complementary, Professor Hugh Stott Taylor, dean of the Chemistry Department of Princeton University, told Catholic students from twenty-six Newman Clubs of the metropolitan area at the eighteenth annual convention yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Harvard College added a unique feature tonight to its student activities. This was the presentation by two students by themselves to society.
Senator NYE and his friends have known all along that eternal vigilance is the price of neutrality.

Miss Olive Winifred Grimshaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Grimshaw of this city, has set Jan. 30 as the date for her marriage to Robert Henry Schmelzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schmelzer, also of Passaic.

The Department of Agriculture said today that because of the drought and the maritime strike, exports of farm products in Nomember were smaller than in the same month a year before and that for the first five months of this marketing season they were valued at $343,968,000, against $379,355,000 from July through November in the preceding season, a decline of 9 per cent.

The Hercules Motor Corporation, whose operations were halted Dec. 10 by a sit-down strike, suggested today to its employes that they seek other jobs. In a newspaper advertisement the company stated that its 1,700 employes had now lost nearly $250,000 in pay. The statement went on:

Jacob Wolff Jr., an insurance broker with offices at 10 Gold Street, died yesterday at his home, 514 West 110th Street, after a brief illness of heart disease at the age of 64. His widow, Eva Wolff; two daughters, Mrs. Frieda Siesel and Miss Miriam Wolff, and a brother, Henry Wolff, survive.

Announcement has been made by Miss Marcella Meagher of this city of the engagement of her niece, Miss Lucile Duffy, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of Louisville, to James Arthur Ruddy, son of Mrs. Austin J. Ruddy of New York and the late Dr. Ruddy.
Belgium looked to her colonial empire today and laid plans to strengthen her bonds with the Congo in the face of revived plans to satisfy Germany's territorial dreams.

The Inter-American Press Conference, which finished its business sessions here this week, laid foundations for a permanent relationship among journalists of all American countries similar to the present relationship of American governments through the Pan American Union.

IT is a pleasure to see the Caravan again with its old editors, many of its early contributors and some newcomers It has always been very scrupulously a miscellany of various kinds of excellent and competent writing where other collections have been decidedly tendentious.

The irrepressible nature of the conflict between Nazi paganism and Christianity in the Reich was demonstrated again last Friday by a twofold Catholic offensive. The Berlin Catholic Diocesan Journal defiantly declared its determination to continue its defense of the Church so long as the Nazi party organs continued to assail religion.

Debits to individual accounts for the week ended on Wednesday, as reported by banks in leading cities, aggregated about $9,452,000,000, or 10 per cent less than the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 10 -per cent larger than the debits for the corresponding week of last year.
The third annual dinner dance of the Westchester Republican County Committee was held here this eveningat the Westchester Country Club.

Play in the first of the nine round of the international chess master tournament among Swedish, Dutel and American experts began today at the headquarters of the Schach salonger Chess Club, with ten experts contesting five games.

The national capital began to take on festival dress today in preparation for the second inauguration of President Roosevelt, Wednesday. Many of the buildings have completed their decorations of flags and electric lights, and the spectators' stands along Pennsylvania Avenue and in the plaza fronting the Capitol are almost ready.
Daniel A. Kessler, Mount Carmel wing shot, and Benjamin J. Hamilton of Coatesville scored 47 out of 50 fliers each from 32 yards' rise to divide honors in the Greater Reading White-Flier Derby today.

SOME years ago Berle Means published "The Modern Corporation and Private Property." in which they attempted to show that in our modern quasi-public corporation there had developed a divorce of ownership from management; that management consisted frequently of self-appointed, self-perputating irresponsible groups whose interests conflicted with those of ownership and resulted in exploitation of security holders.

American physicians seldom go to Chile, so American surgery is hardly known there, according to Dr. Italo Alessandrini, a surgeon from Santiago, who came here to study American medical methods and hospitals.

NOTHING on earth," the tool company president informed his stamp-crazy port manager, "broadens a fellow like travel. Travel enlarges the mind, widens the horizon, and increases one's knowledge of foreign markets."

The Boulder Brook Club here was the scene this evening of a dinner dance. Among those who entertained were Mrs. Joseph Lykes, Mrs. G. Richard Ludlow, Mrs. Raymond Gunnison, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher T. Chenery, Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Chenery,

In his annual statement to shareholders of the Boatmen's National Bank of St. Louis, Tom K. Smith, president, reported operating profits, exclusive of security profits and recoveries, of $392,228. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.76 a share on the common stock.

With its court fortunes apparently on the mend, the New York University basketball team returned to its University Heights gymnasium last night to defeat Colgate, 42 to 27, before a crowd of 1,200 persons. It was the sixth victory in nine starts for the Violet and its thirtyeighth consecutive conquest on the home floor.
Miss Carol Riegelman, who is employed in the secretariat of the International Labor Organization at Geneva, has returned to this country after an absence of fifteen months.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hamilton Dutcher of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Murray Dutcher, to Edward W. Swinburne, also of this city, son of Edward D. Swinburne of Milburn, N. J.

Seventeen juniors of the Simmons College School of Nursing comprise the first undergraduate group in New England to receive the insignia which enables them to assume responsibility in the care of hospital patients. The nursing caps were awarded by Miss Helen Wood, the director, during an impressive ceremony by candlelight on Wednesday evening.

The William and Mary chapter of Theta Alpha Phi, national honorary dramatic society, held an initiation ceremony on Thursday evening in the Great Hall of the Sir Christopher Wren Building for the six new members who were recently elected. The new members have taken part in many of the campus productions and now are eligible to belong to the society.
The New York Rovers after a slow start roundly outplayed the Boston Olympics in the second period to win an exhibition game tonight, 5 to 3.

THE Merchant Marine Act that went into effect on Jan. 1 laid down additional rules and laws for the regulation of the lives and treatment of seamen aboard American ships. The men of the merchant service were already more strictly under governmental control than any other trade or profession except those of the army or navy.

WHEN Louise Beebe Wilder presents a new book, the prospective reader knows in advance that she has something vital to say, and that it will be said in her own individual and delightful manner "Adventures With Hardy Bulbs" is no exception.

Running the fastest race ever to be turned in on a flat indoor track in New York, Leslie MacMitchell, 'George Washington High School ace, captured the one-mile invita'tion run, one of the features of the thirty-second annual Stuyvesant High School indoor interscholastic track and field games at the 102d Engineers Armory in Manhattan last night.

A denial that an editorial it published criticizing George Henry Payne, member of the Federal Communications Commission, caused an injury to Mr. Payne was contained in an answer to his $100,000 libel suit by Broadcasting, the radio trade journal.

Gas consumers here admittedly were "jittery" tonight as an emergency crew of twenty-five men maintained service under an agreement in a Gas Employes Union strike against the Ohio Fuel Gas Company and the Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company.

WINTRY nights call for hearty dishes, such as those with the dimensions of the old-fashioned meat pie. Many New York restaurateurs and housekeepers have long recognized this traditional British one-dish meal as the logical answer to coldweather appetites.
Scoring 418 runs in its first innings, the Marylebone Cricket Club touring team established a big lead over a combined Tasmanian eleven in the second day's play of a thtee-day match.

The aftermath of gossip which followed the visit of the Duke of Kent and Mrs. William Allen to a phrenologist in Fleet Street Dec. 31 provoked the following retort in Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard tonight:

Yale scored a 4-3 overtime hockey victory over Dartmouth tonight in the New Haven Arena when Gil with two minutes to play and Humphrey captured the rubber slashed a rapid-fire shot that eluded goalie Wes Goding for the winning goal.
Knitters now settling down to Work on their Spring wardrobes can avoid a lot of the guess-work that usually goes into knitting a dress by availing themselves of the use of block patterns.

THE Shikers are passing rapidly from America. A recent news dispatch reported that the "family" of Shakers at New Lebanon. N. Y., near the boundary line of Massachusetts. had been reduced to six elderly women and one aged man. In the flourishing days of that 'family" there were 4,869 Shakers on the peaceful slopes of Mount Lebanon.

ALL over Austria skiing has become the major sport of schools and from the third grade on, boys and girls alike compete in ski races. In city schools the youngsters are induced to save throughout the year a small part of their allowance for the purchase of a ski outfit or for replacing worn-out articles.

THE text of "The Window Garden" is the fruit of many years of rich personal experience with house plants Mrs. Buxton has always grown plants indoors as a successful hobby and in her preface she tells us that her plant descriptions have been written from living plants which she has owned and that most of the photographs are of plants which she herself has grown.

For the past few days rumors have been current that the so-called Pronounced Nationalists were striving to obtain from Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg permission to form a special political group, which would act in concordance with the official Patriotic Front.

Reluctantly and regretfully, New Yorkers gave up their annual January motor boat show last night. If the throngs of earlier days were large, those of the final morning, afternoon and night were record-breaking.
OUR United States leads the world in democratization--not only in politics but in the distribution of material things as well.

Mrs. Jane Laber Herman, 75 years old, a survivor of the Titanic disaster, died at her home near here today. Accompanied by her husband, a son and two daughters, Mrs. Herman was aboard the White Star liner when it struck an iceberg on April 15, 1912.

Disappointing a large number of the Portuguese colony here who had awaited his arrival, Joseph Costa, Portuguese-American flier from the United States, made a forced landing last night near Conceicao do Serro, State of Minas Geraes.

THE book-collecting hobby might be expected to provide a secure retreat from the political problems that torment mankind. But it does not. A collector need not turn to the daily newspaper to be reminded of the grinning specter of war and other evidence of man's inhumanity.

The Budapest University Chorus, under Viktor Vaszy, conductor of the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra, made its triumphant debut at Carnegie Hall last night, offering program of Hungarian music so superbly sung in all respects that nothing in the way of choral work in this country remotely compares with it.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was called on again today to approve financing plans of a major railroad company designed to escape a tax imposed by the 1936 Revenue Act on undistributed profits of corporations.

The strike which closed one of d the ten cafeterias operated by Consumers Cooperative Services, Inc., was settled yesterday. A resolution adopted by 500 of the 3,500 cooperative shareholders provided the formula for the settlement, Which was reached at a conference of Manning Johnson, business agent for Local 302 of the Cafeteria Employes Union, and Miss Mary E., Arnold, general manager of the cooperative organization.

Members and guests of the Criterion Society will appear in canary yellow and green gowns for the benefit ball Thursday night at the Hotel Plaza, if they carry out the suggestion of the committee in charge.
New York's National Guard was rated today by Major Gen. Albert H. Blanding, chief of the War Department's National Guard Bureau, as one of the nation's outstanding military organizations.

Under the sponsorship of the Ohio Newspaper Women's Association, the Women's Press Club of Indiana, the Press Women of Portland, Ore., and the Illinois Woman's Press Association, invitation have been sent to all newspaper women not affiliated with a club already federated to join the National Federation of Press Women, recently organized.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla.--The first of the 1937 weed-end parties of the Surf Club night, under the direction of Alfred I. Barton, club secretary.
Mexico faces an embarrassing problem with regard to whether planes from the United States, now at Tejeria Airdrome here, shall be permitted to leave on the Spanish Loyalist freighter Motomar.

Gardeners who, last Fall, had the foresight to put up bulbs of such Spring flowers as daffodils, tulips, hyacinths and crocuses, are now enjoying the thrilling experience of starting them into growth indoors in final preparation for the blossoms they will produce in a few weeks.

The King and Queen have left a family gathering at Sandringham to spend a few days in town, where they have been busy with coronation details. The plan is to take up residence in Buckingham Palace in mid-February, when many alterations now under way will be finished.

In the addled, feverish world of the sick-abed, there couldn't be too many nurses. Mathematics in the sane routine of healthy existence say there are, by some of the yardsticks now being applied to the profession particularly in New York State--mainly economic.
Zevson, consistent son of Kiev from Mrs. E. H. Bartlett's barn, chalked up his third straight victory in taking the six-furlong handicap which featured the Fair Grounds program today.

Dr. Charles Victor Noback, for the past ten years veterinarian of the New York Zoological Park, the Bronx, and widely known in the fields of pathology and zoology, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, after a week's illness. His age was 48.

" Candida," with Ann Harding in the leading role opened in Blackpool last Monday and intermittent reports drifting from there have been extremely favorable. It will arrive in London via Brighton, Manchester and Edinburgh, opening here at the Globe Feb. 10.

Prepared to handle the largest attendance of buyers in more than forty years, executives of the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., cooperative building housing showrooms of more than 500 furniture manufacturers, will open its seasonal showing of Spring and Summer furniture here tomorrow.

A fashion revue, to be known as a Flower Cart Fashion Show, will be held in conjunction with a reception Wednesday afternoon in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Alice Hall Ali Committee to raise funds for the organization's Milk Center at
Members of the Chi Kappa Club of Stony Wold Sanatorium have arranged a luncheon and fashion show for next Saturday at the Versailles to raise funds for the sanatorium.

More than 165 lines of table and floor lamps, shades and other accessories will be displayed here tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker with the opening of the seasonal Spring and Summer trade exhibit of the lamp industry. The event is expected to attract more than 2,000 buyers from all parts of the United States and Canada. The show will close Friday night.

A deadlock in efforts to agree on a united front for their wage demands was acknowledged today when many delegates of the "Big Five" railroad transportation brotherhoods went home for the week-end. However, they will return for another general meeting on Monday.

The Robert Burns Club of Yonkers will give a dinner Friday evening at the Hotel Gramatan here in commemoration of the 178th anniversary of the birth of the poet. The Rev. Robert MacGowan of Irvington-on-Hudson will deliver the oration. Redferne Hollinshead, Scottish tenor, will sing.
Paris's January series this year includes several talks of particular interest to English-speaking peoples.

Charles Grief, former president of the New York Association of Paper and Twine, died last night in the Morristown Memorial Hospital at the age of 56. Mr. Greif had been connected with the twine and paper firm of Henry F. Fulling Company, inc., 202 Greene Street, New York, for the last thirty-four years and had been its president for many years.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

WITH a membership which includes a large proportion of the men flying our airlines, the Airlines Pilots Association has issued a statement contending that before any real headway can be made in the direction of greater air safety, changes must be made in the basic laws governing this aspect of transport.
Major George L. Berry laid before President Roosevelt today the Industrial Council's proposals for Federal regulation of minimum wages and maximum working hours.
Premier Benito Mussolini, in an interview published today in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's paper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, assures the Germans that he is with them in their crusade against bolshevism.
ALL-WAVE listeners interested in tuning in the n ew radio-telephone stations have an opportunity these days to "contact" French Somaliland.

President Roosevelt's seven-billiondollar budget (of which roughly oneseventh is for defense) was made to look small last week by the announcement from Moscow of a 100-billionruble budget, of which about one-fifth is for defense.
She can't get up very well to greet her guests, but nobody in all New York relishes a good chatty call more than a bent little old woman on West Twenty-third Street.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Allow me to comment on two points in John Cournos's appreciative review of my edition of Pushkin's Works. The reviewer observes that the original of the lines that Miss Deutsch renders: I would know whence you are sprung.
The west coast of South America, as far as Santiago, Chile, is to be included in the air cruise plan launched last year on the east coast, it was disclosed yesterday.

AFTER carrying for thirty years a burden of unpaid taxes, a small, shabby, two-story brick building known as "The Birthplace of Old Glory." at 239 Arch Street, Philadelphia. has begun a new lease on life.

Cheered by a hundred friends and sympathizers of Loyalist Spain, the first American surgical unit and ambulance corps to go to the aid of the defenders of Madrid sailed yesterday on the French liner Paris.

More than 2,000 allocations of WPA Federal Art Project work were made in 1936 to the public libraries in greater New York, according to a summary released from project headquarters, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The marriage of Miss Georgia Williams Schermerhorn, daughter of the late Amos Cotting Schermerhorn and the late Mrs. Frank N. Miller, to Butler Cox, son of Mrs. Thomas George Cox of Boston and the late Mr. Cox, took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown.

Provoked at legal delays which he said had "virtually paralyzed" the Tennessee Valley Authority program, Senator Norris of Nebraska favors immediate action by Congress to curb the injunctive processes of Federal courts.

Yale's varsity and freshman wrestlers triumphed over Brown today, the varsity winning, 29 to 5, and the freshmen, 23 to 13. Bob Clark, Yale 175-pound contender, turned in a feature performance in disposing of K Nast in 1 minute 43 seconds. George Woodland was held to a decision over Howard King and Cooper Walker defeated Jim Lathrop, New England intercollegiate champion, on a decision in the 145-pound division.

Two evenly matched teams put up a thrilling battle in the first international Rugby contest of the season today, England gaining a 4-3 victory over Wales. Playing on a neavy ground before a crowd of 65,000, the home players compiled she points by scoring a dropped goal to a try.

The Borden's Farm Products Division of the Borden Company has purchased the six-story garage formerly owned by the Studebaker Corporation at 615 West 131st Street, and will alter it into a milk pasteurizing and distribution plant.
THE NOEL COWARD SYNDICATE, plus Doubleday, Doran, have bound up in "Tonight at 8:30" the entertainment of three full evenings. (At $4.40 a ticket to each third it becomes a practical charity.)

TRADE progress in the week was again handicapped by unusual weather conditions throughout the country and in particular localities by labor troubles. Increases over last year were considerably reduced in some sections.

CHINA is prepared for eventualities in the East with a capable air force, American trained and equipped. The Bureau of Aviation was conceived under financial tress and developed under strong opposition from Japan. The result has been that export figures from the United States Show far more accurately its strength than observers in China, with the possible exception of Japanese, can do.

Eddie King, 26-year-old radio announcer and operator of a dramatic school for children, was seized by an immigration inspector after he had completed the broadcast of a children's program from Station WCAP about noon today and was taken to Ellis Island to await deportation proceedings.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Supreme Court Justice James T. Cross of Rome granted a separation decree today to Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith of Syracuse in her action against Alfred E. Smith Jr. of New York, son of the former Governor.

The growing nervousness and uncertainty over the outlook for shortterm money rates and the bond market were reflected in the banking community last week as the time, for the expected announcement by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System of an increase in member bank reserve requirements came and passed without any action by the board.

Dr. Glenn Frank, ousted as president of the University of Wisconsin ten days ago, will return soon to the national speaking platform, with addresses scheduled in Chicago, Columbus, Ohio and New York City. Special interest was focused here today on his Minneapolis appearance on Feb. 12, which will be a Lincoln Day address over a national radio network.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.--Sports Sand entertainment for younger visitors dominate the picture this west coast resort this week. Tomorrow tennis fans will see Donald Budge of California and Bitsy Grant-of Georgia play an exhibition match at the St. Petersburg Tennis Club.
Miss Floy Paula Bassett, Duke University senior from New York City, was inducted this week as president of the Woman's College Student Government Association.

CHASING coyotes by motor car has become a popular Winter sport on the prairies of the Southwest. When autos were slower the fast-moving animal had more than an even chance to outrun his pursuers, but the only thing that will save him now is to choose a rough terrain where the cars are forced to slow down.
The War Department issued these orders today, dated Jan. 15: BRIGADIER GENERAL Smith, A. T., Philippine Dept.. to command Second Division, Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

BRAUN-FREEZER--Mr. and Mrs. Morris Freezer,. 825 West End Av., announce the marriage of their daughter. Florence, to Mr. Harry Braun, son of Mr. Henry Braun and the late Mrs. Martha Braun of this city.

The swimmers of Henry P. O'Neil Junior High School and Manhattan Aviation School, formerly Central Building Trades, dominated the respective junior high school and vocational-continuation school individual championships of the Public Schools Athletic League, conducted yesterday in the seventy-five-foot pool of Seward Park High School.
WHAT do visitors see from the pinnacle of the Empire State Building? What are their reactions to the city from the world's highest tower?

Hope that Congress will carry out the civil service recommendations of President Roosevelt's Committee on Administrative Management was expressed yesterday by Robert L. Johnson, president of the National Civil Service Reform League, in a letter to the President.

Believing that the prestige of this country in South America depends on the success or failure of our negotiations for a trade treaty with Argentina, foreign traders here are extremely anxious that a favorable agreement be worked out with that country in the near future.

That little story about the book which came back to the Syracuse Public Library after forty years was interesting. It happens occasionally, but with an infrequency which makes the event notable. In Philadelphia, at the turn of the century, when Mrs. Fiske produced "Becky Sharp," the stage version of "Vanity Fair," a friend borrowed my copy of the book.

With all the solemnity of the courtroom, the first session of the "school for jurors," believed to be the first of its kind in the country, got under way this morning in Federal Judge William Clark's courtroom in the Postoffice building.

ON the shores of the Bosporus, where for many centuries has flourished the city called New Rome and Constantinople by the Romans. Byzantium by the Greeks and Istanbul by the modern Turks. an English archaeological expedition led by Professor J. H. Baxter has been digging down through the dust and debris of ages to trace the fascinating record of ancient times.

A 26-23 victory over Williams in basketball tonight climaxed a successful day in sports for Princeton varsity teams. In feature engagements of an extensive afternoon program, Princeton's swimmers routed Lehigh, 66-9, in Brokaw Pool and the Tiger wrestlers turned back Penn State, Eastern Intercollegiate champion, 15-13, in the university gymnasium.

A motor cavalcade of striking seamen started for Washington last night from Stuyvesant High School, where they had held a meeting, to picket and urge reconsideration of the Copeland bill. The demonstrators-about seventy, twenty of them in a truck and the rest in nine private cars-expect to arrive at the capital tomorrow.

THERE is much sound information in the volume entitled simply "Dogs" by Dr. Alfred W. Meyer. There is also a sympathetic approach to the whole question of dog owning and keeping which indicates clearly that the author comes to his subject not merely as a doctor of veterinary medicine but as a true dog lover.

From regional directors of the Resettlement Administration, here for a series of conferences on its national program, today came accounts of conditions among farmers and farm laborers in the great agricultural areas. of the country which presented a graphic picture of the fight against odds of thousands to make a living on the soil.

Miss Caroline Taft Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Green of Flushing, was married to Charles Herbert Kilbourne Jr. of Trenton, N. J., yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Hanna MacKenzie performed the ceremony in the Reformed Church of Flushing. Mr. Kilbourne is the son of Mrs. Charles H. Kilbourne and the late Mr. Kilbourne of Bridgton, Me.

Construction of the 1937 White Plains Model Home is under way and plans are being made for ceremonies next Saturday afternoon marking the setting in place of the ridgepole, Francis S. Rosch, director of the White Plains Better Housing Bureau, reports.

To the Drama Editor: As a former dramatic critic, and one warmly interested in having our greatest dramatist on the stage, I should like to make one point about your critic's review of "Othello," as presented at the New Amsterdam.

Colonel General to Hermann Goering, German Air Minister and director of the FourYear Plan, had a long conference with Premier Benito Mussolini tonight. The subjects discussed were not disclosed, but it is generally assumed that the European situation as a whole was taken up.

Builders in many of the community developments in Queens and neighboring sections of Long Island report a very satisfactory continuance of sales activity, necessitating in several cases additional Winter construction to prepare for the expectant demand early in the Spring.

More and more people are finding jobs in the world. For nearly four years now the quarterly statistics of the International Labor Office have shown a steady decline in unemployment in most countries, including the United States.

A New College varsity basketball team, composed almost entirely of girls who recently returned from studying in Europe and who have been practicing together for only a week, defeated the Swarthmore women's team, 19-12, on the Thompson Gymnasium court yesterday afternoon.

Amendment of the State Constitution to reduce the tax limitation on real estate from 2 to 1 3/4. per cent of assessed valuation is advocated by Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The first suit brought to foreclose a Federal Housing loan on property in Jersey City was begun last week when the RFC Mortgage Company of Washington filed notice of suit with the county register at Jersey City.

Trailing by 13-4 at one stage of the game and by 14-11 at the half, De La Salle's basketball team rallied to score a well-earned victory over Iona School of New Rochelle by 28-23 in the final game of the scholastic program at the Hippodrome yesterday afternoon before 2,000 spectators.

It is not only elephants that never forget. Motorcycle Patrolman James Sullivan remembers a lot of things too--about elephants. So, when driving his car along the highway between here and Elizabeth tonight,

PAUL BEKKER has already a considerable number ot authoritative musical books to his credit. With this latest one he has added another, which will be counted not the least important of his contributions to musical literature.

A new element in the cast of "Die Walkuere"-new, at least, for this season yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, gave the occasion the glamour and the thrill which can confer upon opera its maximum intesity.
Trading in the two sugar futures contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange for the first twelve days of this year amounted

Commodity futures markets were generally higher last week in slightly improved trading. The United States sugar contract, however, had a rather severe setback on a statement by Secretary Wallace concerning enactment of a tax of 1/2 to 1 cent on refined sugar.

One of the gayest and most unusual parties in several seasons took place last night in the Jade and Basildon Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria, where a barn dance was given by Miss Elsa Maxwell for many of her friends in society and stage, screen and radio circles.

The performance of "The Eternal Road" tomorrow evening at the Manhattan Opera House will be for the benefit of the New York Committee of the Warm Springs Foundation, which is launching officially a $100,000 campaign to construct two free pools in local hospitals for the treatment of children affected by infantile paralysis.

Professor and Mrs. Arthur James Farley of this place announced at a luncheon given today at the Blue Hills Plantation, Dunellen, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Wheatie Farley, to Henry Frederick Skelton.

Karl Koch, 34 years old, of 96 Vermont Avenue, Long Beach, was fined $100 in Queens Felony Court yesterday by Magistrate Gustav Wiebold after he was found guilty of driving an automobile while intoxicated. A physician testified that Koch at the time of his arrest was suffering from an overdose of a sedative.

The marriage of Miss Letitia May Groehl, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. Groehl of 527 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, to John Shepardson McGovern, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. McGovern, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
The Child Study Association of America is sponsor of a conference to be held at its headquarters, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow afternoon on the kindergarten child.

An expanded program of activity in 1937 for the American Marketing Association, the combination of the American Marketing Society and the National Association of Marketing Teachers, which became effective on Jan. 1, was described here yesterday by Frank R. Coutant, research director of Pedlar and Ryan, and president of the association.

D. Henry Brown of Riverhead, L. I., former Sheriff and Democratic leader of Suffolk County, died last night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had been a patient for several months. He was born at Flanders, near Riverhead, eighty-six years ago.

Under the auspices of various organizations of Southerners living-in New York, a supper dance will be held Tuesday at Sherry's to mark the birthday of General Robert E. Lee. During the evening Justice William Harmon Black of the New York Supreme Court will speak.
Up in the last nod, according to the camera, was Finance, one of the stars in the string of the Chicagoan, Mrs. Emil Denemark, to give her a triple before 12,000 persons at Hialeah Park today.

A distinct improvement in employment conditions among architects in the metropolitan area has become observable, and many persons who were receiving aid have been placed in jobs, the Architects Emergency Committee reports.

Miss Enid Valerie Higgins, daughter of Mrs. Frank St. John of Butler Place and Captain Stanton Higgins of Fort Slocum, New Rochelle, N. Y., was married this afternoon to Alfred P. Heath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cuyler Heath of Wellington Road. The Rev. John Esquirol performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

AMnmy triumphed in two of its three engagements with varsity opponents this afternoon, turning back Dickinson at basketball and Fort Hamilton at polo, while the Cadet swimmers bowed in a dual meet with Amherst.

The Board of Supervisors is expected to approve on Monday a request of the Park Commission that the WPA Work Camp maintained at Elmsford under the National Park Service be permitted to move into the vacated buildings of the old Westchester County Home at East View.

WHEN we delve back into mists that are centuries deep its not always possible to pin facts to absolutely verifiable dates. Nor does that matter. The great Florentine, Giotto di Bondone, may have been born in 1266 or 1267.

The performance of the Schubert operetta "Frederika" the night of Feb. 5 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre has been taken over by members of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York to augment their scholarship fund. The show is scheduled to be opened on Feb. 4.

Progress in the development of a twenty-three-year-cycle weather hypothesis, by which variations of the weather may be forecast, is reported by Dr. Charles G. Abbot, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution.
Seventeen General Motors plants which have been closed by strikes will remain idle during the peace negotiations. They are situated as follows:
A course for prospective exhibitors in next Spring's International Flower Show will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday, at the Hotel Beechwood, Summit, by the Garden Club of New Jersey.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT enters upon another term of office as the most influential, if not the most powerful, figure in the world. The distinction is his own. He is not the man to underestimate the eminence he occupies, nationally or internationally.

Two hundred sit-down strikers at the Guide lamp plant of General Motors here ended today a seventeen-day occupation of the factory to the blare of a brass band. They were welcomed by wives and children.

Henry Rosenthal, president of the Industrial Cold Storage and Warehouse Company, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 77. He was also head of the Joseph Rosenthal Sons' metal firm and the M. A. Young Ice Company and was honorary president of the Philadelphia Metal Association.

The Lafayette College Decade of Progress Fund has reached $80,000, according to announcement by the directors of the drive. The fund, which is for $500,000, signalizes the close of ten years of the present administration of President Lewis.

A wanted circular for Max Silverman, already a fugitive in the Sam Drukman murder conspiracy, was authorized yesterday after detectives arrested his 27-year-old son Harold as the fifth figure in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's drive on a bakery racket.

Mrs. Albert B. Kerr heads a group of women in charge of arrangements for the supper dance in behalf of the Virginia Day Nursery to be held on Feb. 8 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. An entertainment will be given during the evening.

Dr. Henry T. Moore, president of Skidmore College, will be the guest of honor Thursday night at the annual dinner of the alumnae of the college in the metropolitan area, to be held at Schrafft's Restaurant, 556 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-sixth Street. About 200 are expected to attend the dinner, which will be held immediately after a meeting at the same place of the Skidmore Alumnae Association.
Often in city apartments or in homes of moderate size the plant lover is hard put to it to find so much as a windowsill or a square foot of sunlit space which can be spared for a bit of living green.

A pre-opening performance of "Tide Rising," a new play by George Brewer Jr., with Grant Mitchell and Tamara in the leading roles, will take place next Thursday night at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Wayside Day Nursery.

Yale today won its 152d consecutive dual intercollegiate swimming meet by outpointing Brown University 41-35. Monroe Hemmerdinger, who achieved the best performance of the day by winning the 50-yard freestyle event in 24 3-5 seconds and who swam on the winning Brown relay team, was the individual star.

BROWN, FLORENCE O. (Jan. 6). Estate, more than $10,000. To son, David S. Brown, executor, 210 W. 70th St., and daughter, Marianne Clayton Small, University, Va., one-half residue and one-half remainder interest in $7,500 trust in equal shares; Bertha Oberndorfer, 200 W. 70th St., life estate in $7,500 trust; also three minor bequests. Harold A. Content, 116 E. 68th St., co-executor.

The largest crowd to watch a hockey game here in several seasons-about 11,500-saw the Montreal Canadiens swamp their intercity rivals, the Maroons, 5 to 0, tonight and increase their lead in the international group of the National Hockey League to 6 points.

Mr. and Mrs. George D. Dunn of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Eastman Dunn, to Sanford Clarke Smith, son of Mrs. Harriet S. Smith of Brooklyn and the late George Henry Smith, formerly of Maplewood.

FOR obvious reasons not bearing a key signature, Arnold Schoenberg's Fourth string quartet, Opus 37, climaxed a cycle of four programs by the Kolisch Quartet Jan. 4, 6, 7 and 9 on the Los Angeles campus of the University of California.

Once during his lifetime Beethoven scored a big popular hit. This was with "Wellington's Victory, or The Battle of Vittoria," Op. 91, composed in 1813 after the news reached Vienna of the Iron Duke's defeat of the Napoleonic army in Spain.
The Junior League of the Woman's Club of Nutley gave a supper dance tonight at the Forest Hill Field Club in Bloomfield.

Johnny Skillman, Yale coach, and Ben Pope of Pittsburgh, qualified today for the final of the national professional squash racquets championship. Skillman rallied brilliantly to eliminate Tom Iannicelli, Short Hills, N. J., 9--15, 15--11, 15--6, 16--13, while Pope,

Staging a spectacular rally in the closing minutes, Lehigh University defeated the Swarthmore quintet, 27-25, today. Sensational field goals by Earl Russell and another by Milton Grannatt, Lehigh's 6-foot-5-inch center, knotted the score at 25-all with less than three minutes to go.

Miss Lena Kemp, retired principal of Public School 63, Manhattan, died on Friday at the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eighty-third Street, after a month's illness. Miss Kemp, who was about 60 years old and lived at 1,215 Madison Avenue, retired several years ago after having been a teacher in this city for more than twenty-five years.

The first practice of the Long Island University tennis team for the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tournament will be held tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank A. Fall, coach of the netmen.

Mrs. Stephen S. Wise will be the speaker and Dr. Wise will be a special guest at a membership tea under the auspices of the Manhattan membership of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress, at Essex House on Tuesday.

Members of the Montclair Junior League have concluded arrangements for the premiere performance tomorrow night of "The Masque of Kings," Maxwell Anderson's new play produced by the New York Theatre Guild.

Miss Elizabeth Hascal Riley, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. James W. Riley of Belle Haven, Greenwich, was introduced to society at a supper dance given by her parents at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. The ballroom was decorated with palms, ferns and smilax, with flowers on the tables.

Dr. Frank Porter Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, will be chairman of the fourth annual Brotherhood Day, arranged by the National Conference of Jews and Christians to be observed nationally on Feb. 20, it was announced yesterday.
South Florida society already is anticipating the Helen Lee Doherty Milk Fund ball, one of the events of the season, which will be held on Feb. 20 at the Miami Biltmore Country Club.
Conditions for the fourth annual ocean sailing race from Miami across the Gulf Stream to Nassau were received here yesterday by yachtsmen considering entering their sea-going craft.

Western influences seeping into Far Eastern nations have raised two queries now agitating women's groups and parents on the other side of the world, reported two Y. W. C. A. officials yesterday, on their return from a six months' journey.

Probation Officer Walter J. Byrnes and Judge John P. Kirby, working as a team to persuade excessive drinkers to support their families, have saved this city of 40,000 persons more than $22,000 in welfare expenses in three years, other officials estimate.
Thirty years ago Henry P. Strause of Richmond, gazing at an antique chair through the window of a London curio shop, was so impressed by its beauty that he bought it.

Another in a series of benefit card parties being held the first and third Mondays of each month under the auspices of the Loyal Workers will take place tomorrow afternoon at the McAlpin. Mrs. Edward A. Turner and Mrs. Frederick L. Yarrington will act as hostesses.

OWING to unusual conditions, all who had hunting and fishing licenses in New York State in 1936 and wish to get them again next year are urged by the Conservation Department to file complete reports of their takes in the seasons just passed. There has been a growing tendency to neglect that formality.
" Eddie" Foster, "hit-and-run" third baseman of the Washington baseball team from 1912 to 1919, died last night of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. He was 50 years old.

Joseph Genung, a near-champion fiddler, and his wife and accompanist will observe their sixtieth wedding anniversary tommorw. They attribute their marital harmony today to music and hard work. Add to this regular church attendance and married couples have a workable formula for happiness, they say. "If newlyweds want to stay married," said Mrs. Genung, "they should be congenial, she should know how to cook, and he"
AMERICAN broadcasters have made elaborate plans for international reception of President Roosevelt's inaugural on Wednesday.Numerous wave lengths will be utilized to cover most of the globe.

An injury-ridden Cornell basketball team lost its fourth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight, bowing to Harvard, 40 to 26. George Lowman and Ernest Gray led the visitors. The former scored 12 points while Gray, rangy center, tallied five baskets. The Cornellians were paced by Walt Foertsch with 9 points.

Readers have been thumbing through albums and poking around in odd corners the past week for snapshots they have taken on trips out of doors. A number of pictures, and good ones, too, have come in to the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest, sponsored by the New York Times Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show.

Mr. and Mrs. Danforth Starr gave a buffet supper for several members of the Greenwich Badminton Club at their home this evening, preceding the exhibition match between Jack Purcell and Stanley Cutts at the Greenwich Y. M. C; A.

Arrangements for the national series of dinners at $3 to $100 a plate on March 4 to erase the Democratic party's current. deficit of about $500,000 were announced today by Chairman Farley of the National Committee.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt, who are guests of American Minister Alvin Owsley at the legation, are having an exceedingly active and interesting first vactaion in Ireland. The colonel had scarcely stepped off the boat at Sobh when he made for Blarney Castle to kiss the famous Blarney stone.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Conried of 50 East Seventy-seventn Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice May Conried, to Henry Glendon Walter Jr., son of Henry Glendon Walter of Eimhurst, Queens, and the late Mrs. Walter.

A sensation was created throughout Yugoslavia by the news that Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, returning from Switzerland today, met Vladimir Matchek, the Croat leader, in the village of Prezhitza, near Zagreb. It was the first time that the Croat leader had met any Yugoslav Premier since the murder of Stepan Raditch in the Yugoslav Parliament in 1928.

King Boris told Bulgaria's women today: "No babies, no ballots." Only women with children and only men who can establish they are Bulgarians without revolutionary ideas may vote in forthcoming local elections, the King decreed.

The McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc., has notified the New York Stock Exchange that the options held by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., on 22,000 shares of common stock have been extended from Dec. 31. 1936. to April 1, 1937.
If a student in America received three hours to concentrate on one sub ject, he would die of shock," President Conant of Harvard told the Association of American Universities yesterday.

Early this morning telegrams were received in Shanghai from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's headquarters at Fenghua and also from government offices in Nanking announcing that there would be no civil war in Shensi Province.

Anti-trust suits brought by the General Talking Pictures Corporation and the Duovac Radio Corporation against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company were dismissed today by Federal Judge John P. Nields.
Problems of international peace and of American neutrality will be discussed on the two campuses of the University of Rochester Feb. 18, 19 and 20, when the Institute on War and Peace is conducted.

Walter Rogers, for fifteen years export service manager of the White Motor Company, died of a heart attack today. His age was 44. Mr. Rogers's duties kept him in foreign countries a large part of his time.

Seward S. Travis, retired school superintendent and high school principal of Sayville, died today at his home here. He was 61 years old. Born in Watervliet, N. Y., Mr. Travis had lived in Sayville since 1920. He was a graduate of the University of Oregon and upon his retirement in 1933 had completed thirty-five years of school work in New York State,

The Second Corps Area of the United States Army has been subdivided into three reserve areas in order to bring the 16,000 army reserve officers in New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Puerto Rico into closer contact with the regular army officers detailed to conduct reserve activities, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy at Governors Island.

Al Reid, Bronx featherweight, defeated Johnny Pena of South Brooklyn, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove Sports Club, Brooklyn, last night before a crowd of 2,500. Each weighed 1261/2 pounds. The semifinal, also an eight-rounder, was won by Tony Celli, 1711/2, of the Bronx. He outpointed Mark Hough, 172, Harlem.

Nassau College-Hofstra Memorial, New York University's educational center at Hempstead, L. I., has received the status of an academic affiliate and will immediately develop the first four-year co-educational liberal arts curriculum in outer Long Island, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Goodburn Chase, chancellor New York University.

With no need for a "weather permitting" phrase to be injected into its program for an evening's entertainment, the Snow Ball to be held on Wednesday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria will provide a thoroughly realistic wintry setting for the various divertissements planned for the occasion.
The season of 1936, all of us in polo felt, was one of the most successful the game has had in some time, chiefly because of the increased public interest shown in all parts of this country.

Enfield's oldest house, built in 1776 by one Robert Field, a Revolutionary soldier and a veteran of Bunker in Hill, has been bought by Mrs. James J. Pocock of Philadelphia and will be taken to Dorset, Vt., to be used as a Summer home by Mrs. Pocock.

The following table shows the names of ships, the lines operating them, their destination, when their regular and supplementary mails close at General Postoffice and City Hall station (regular mails close at Brooklyn General Postoffice one hour earlier and at the Morgan Annex one-half hour later), when they sail, location of piers and points for which they carry mail.

Adoption of a progressive program of labor legislation by the State Legislature this year which will constitute "a militant challenge to reactionary and subversive forces" was predicted yesterday afternoon by Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority leader of the Assembly.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Esberg of this cty and Purchase, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Esberg, to Henry Mosler Marx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Marx of this city, Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Birmingham, Ala.

The Federal Reserve Board announced today the appointment of Beardsley Rumi of New York to serve as a Class C director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the unexpired portion of the term ending on Dec. 31, 1938. It announced other appointments as follows:

Stocks closed higher with steel shares strongest; turnover, 1,705,240 shares, heaviest trading for a Saturday since Nov. 7. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, corporate and foreign issues steady and mixed; transactions, $8,563,000.

Miss Carola de Peyster Kip, daughter of Mrs. Garrett B. Kip of this city and Rhinebeck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Kip, was married to Benjamin R. Kittredge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge of Carmel, N. Y.,

Countess Folke Bernadotte of Sweden, who is active in Girl Guide organization work in her adopted country, brought the initial news of European plans to participate in festivities planned here to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Girl Scouts this year, when she visited headquarters at 570 Lexington Avenue yesterday.

George W. Mason, president of the new NashKelvinator Corporation, was a guest today at a luncheon attended by nearly 200 automobile editors and advertising representatives of newspapers and trade publications.

A gift of $4,000 from William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and an anonymous contribution of $2,500 were announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, campaign chairman of the United Hospital Fund Committee.

HOW often before and since a certain "noble experiment" has political theory aimed at a pigeon and killed a crow! Karl Marx held that State ownership of wealth was the only foundation for social democracy. and the first fruits of his doctrine are Statecontrolled economies and authoritarian governments, whose power. compared to that of the old despots. is as the steam hammer to the village blacksmith.
Mrs. Roosevelt gave a luncheon in the White House today for the wives of a number of foreign diplomats, Cabinet officers, Senators and Representatives.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hillson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Hillson, to Theodore Adelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Adelson of Holyoke, Mass.

Miss Vera Amalia Carlson, daughter of Major and Mrs. Oscar Carlson of 3,901 Avenue R, Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Nelson Arthur Loomis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Loomis of East Greenbush, N. Y. The ceremony, which took place in St. Bartholomew's Church, Manhattan, was performed by the Rev. Lynde E. May Jr.

Brown University this month is paying tribute to one of her most distinguished graduates, Horace Mann of the class of 1819, "father of the American public school system" and one of the foremost educators of his times.
Henry L. Doherty, head of the Cities Service Company and other concerns, is a patient in Temple University Hospital here, suffering from a throat ailment, it was learned today.
French sources indicated tonight that assurances had been received that Soviet Russia would conform to the policy adopted by Great Britain and France regarding the Spanish civil war.

Younger members of society will act as manikins in the fashion revue which will be a feature of the tea dance in behalf of the women's auxiliary of the Osteopathic Clinic to be held next Saturday in the Guard Room of the Park Lane.

WITH her usual happy faculty or picking diverse talents, Marie Sterner is this week and next exhibiting new sketches and watercolors by the Parisian painter of horses, Pierre Dubaut, who, incidentally, is the owner of a number of the Gricaults recently shown at the Sterner Galleries.

Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Cartier gave a dinner last night at their home, 15 East Ninety-sixth Street, for Andre Le Febvre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, and Mrs. de Laboulaye, and Marc Peter, the Swiss Minister, and Mrs. Peter.

Away fast at the break, Spey Fox, M. R. Cowell's 3-year-old chestnut gelding, defeated a fast field of 3-year-old rivals in the fifth and feature event, a $2,000 claiming affair, at Alamo Downs today.

Joseph P. Day has taken charge of the development known as Southern Parkways Gardens at St. Albans, L. I. He also has been named agent by the Andrew Freedman Home for the sale of four of its properties in Manhattan. They are the loft buildings at 39 E. 19th St. and 145-47 W. 27th St., and the property at 116 W. 71st St. and 49 E. 129th St.

The golden jubilee of the New York Florists Club was celebrated by 1,600 florists and their wives at a dinner dance last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Florists came from seventy-five cities of the United States and Canada to participate in the celebration.

O. D. Keep, New York City publisher, has purchased the C. N. Field farm at Williamstown, Mass., contain 461 acres, of which 200 acres are woodland. The transaction was closed through the National Real Estate Clearing House, Ensign Worthy of Williamstown being the local broker.

ROAD MAPS for 1937, produced on behalf of about thirty oil companies and the governments of fortyeight States, have begun to come off the color presses. Between now and May, so wide is the need of automobilists, about 120,000,000 copies will be printed.

Controller Frank J. Taylor was honored last night at a dinner, attended by 1,000 persons, tendered to him by the Cathedral Club of Brooklyn at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West. The speakers included the Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of Brooklyn; Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division and Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate.

George Toplitz and George O. Walbridge 2d, both of New York, have been named co-chairmen of the Columbia College annual junior promenade and will head a list of eighty-two members of the class of 1938 who are making arrangements for the event, scheduled for Friday evening, Feb. 26, at the Ritz Carlton.

Net income of Julius Kayser Co. and affiliated companies in the last six months of 1936 amounted to $477,353 after Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. After dividend requirements on employes' preferred stock, the income was equal to $1.13 each on 401,900 shares of $5-par common stock, excluding 82,220 shares held in the treasury.

Six months ago today officers and soldiers in Spanish Morocco revolted against the Madrid government; the next day Spain was plunged into civil war. For six months Spaniard has wounded and killed Spaniard; for six months the world has looked on--and in some cases taken part--in the shedding of blood, in the destruction of large areas of Spain.

THIS book is recommended for a special place of honor one one's bookshelves. It deals fluently and engagingly with the history of French verse from the medieval period through the symbolists and their successors, and requires no special knowledge on the part of its reader, only interest and an appredation of pleasant things.
Crown Princess Juliana's wedding gifts are being publicly shown here, the proceeds of the exhibition going to charity. The presents include a silver dish from German emigres living in Holland.

Lady Campbell, wife of the British Consul General, will be among the special guests at the bridge party to be given by members of King Edward VII Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, on Tuesday at the Roosevelt for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women at Ossining, N. Y.

Miss Marion Abbott, who appeared on the professional stage for thirtyseven years, during much of the time in supporting roles to outstanding actors and actresses, died of pneumonia in Hahnemann Hospital here last night in her seventyfirst year. She had been in the hospital eight weeks.
PALM BEACH, Fla.-Since the recent arrival of those colonists who waited to spend the holidays in the North, the barometer of sports events has risen rapidly.

A REDUCTION in the total motor fatalities for 133 cities as compared with a slight increase in the number for the country as a whole indicates that headway is being made by the cities in coping with the traffic safety problem, according to a statement made recently by Thomas P. Henry, president of the American Automobile Association.

THE Brothers Krimsky-not to be confused with the Karamazov boys-are up to knavish didoes at the American Music Hall again. They have purged the erstwhile mosque of the menace-dripping gypsies who knifed their sibilant way through "Murder in the Old Red Barn" and have gone collegiate with pennants and with a vengeance.

Throughout the eleven years that Dr. Glenn Frank was president of the University of Wisconsin, stalwart Republicans, Democrats and Progressives took turns sniping at him and the State's chief institution of higher learning.

THE WPA Theatre of Music, which opens next Sunday with a concert by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the Federal Music Project, will feature four types of musical presentation by Feb. 1.

Luncheon guests of Joseph E. Widener at Hialeah Park today were the Marquis de Saint Sauveur and his daughter, Miss Dodine de Saint Sauvier of Paris; Sir Humphrey de Trafford of London, senior steward of the English Jockey Club; Captain Cecil Boyd Rockfort of Newmarket, England, Captain A. Pearce of London, Captain Arthur Boyd Rockfort of Dublin and Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d.

Miss Ellen Hubbard Bones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Simmons Bones of Staten Island, was married yesterday afternoon to Herbert Murry Ludlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Herbert Ludlow of Morrison, Va., in Grace Church Chantry.
The disappearance of a gold ingot worth $14,000 from the mail room of the French liner Paris was revealed yesterday when the liner sailed again for Havre with the theft unsolved.

Syracuse University's boxing team, national collegiate champion, opened its 1937 season tonight by scoring a 7-1 victory over Toronto. The Canadians won only the 115-pound bout, which Jack Dillon took by a technical knockout when Francis Mullins suffered a cut over his eye in the first round.
The annual bridge party of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association will be held on Jan. 26 at the Plaza under the patronage of many women prominent in society.

The Princeton polo team defeated Pennsylvania Military College, 11 1/2 to 5, in the opening match of the indoor season tonight. Ted Eisner, Tiger No. 2, led with six goals. White topped the Chester cadets with three.

Twenty-two divisions of New York and Brooklyn department stores had substantial increases in advertising linage in December, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The total linage for the month was 4,111,535 against 3,933,323 in December, 1935.
John Benedict Fehr, who smilingly boasted he was the "world's champion pin-dropper" as custodian of the Latter Day Saints Church's tabernacle, died last night at the ae of 78.
The Louisville Retail Merchants Association has unanimously endorsed the minimum wage, maximum hour and misleading advertising program of the National Retail Dry Goods Association,
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Burton LaCour of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Burton LaCour, to James Eyre Ashburner, son of Mrs. Algernon Eyre Ashburner of New York.

Edwin Franko Goldman will bring forty members of his band to the Mount Holyoke College Centennial celebrations, planned for May 7 and 8, according to Dr. William Churchill Hammond, college organist and choirmaster.

Washington is again in its usual state of flux, as familiar and popular faces of former officials and favorites are appearing for the almost incessant festivities preceding the inauguration of the President next week.
Thomas Hart Benton and the murals of Missouri life he has just painted in the House lounge of the State Capitol at Jefferson City have provoked a controversy which follows traditional lines.
Here is a time-table of President Roosevelt's second inauguration on Wednesday: 11 A. M.-Supreme Court meets to don robes and proceed to the inaugural platform outside the Capitol.

MR. CHUBB'S poems on Georgia subjects are in teresting and amusing Americana. "Cliff Pace" is a narrative monologue in the cracker dialect describing a man who had a way with dogs. Other Georgia poems in this collection are the well-known "Yurkey Gobbler Land" and "How Spring Comes in Georgia."
NEAREST trick of the week was the conversion of "Beloved Enemy" from tragedy to romance. Perhaps you haven't heard about it.
AFTER THOUGHT: "We should always have been tougher, but the trouble always was that we did not know what to get tough about."--Rexford Guy Tugwell, discussing the New Deal's past.
Wagner College's basketball team trounced a quintet representing Mount Airy Seminary of Philadelphia last night, 35 to 16, at the Wagner gymnasium in Staten Island.

Reports of a lecture which C. R. Attlee, leader of the British Labor party in the House of Commons, made in Paris tonight proposing that Britain henceforth should "share the empire" have been received in London with astonishment.

Dr. W. W. Mattson tonight ascribed the kidnapping and murder of his son to a bungling fiend and an accomplice. While Federal and local officials weeded out arrested suspects from coast to coast, the physician expressed the conviction that the criminal would be "brought to justice" and said he then would tell more about the crime.

The engagement of Miss Octavia Hamilton, daughter of Mrs. James Hamilton of this city and the late Mr. Hamilton, to Philip Ryerson, son of Mrs. W. Newton Ryerson of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Ryerson, has been announced by her mother.

EVER since she endeared herself to the critics by asking Santa Claus to bring her a machine-gun for Christmas, instead of a nice doll such as Shirley Temple, the star, wanted in "Bright Eyes," Jane Withers has risen in public esteem until today she is America's favorite problem child.

Rutgers' veteran swimming team defeated Fordham tonight, 52 to 19, registering its second triumph in as many starts. Bill Schirmer, Fordham ace, was the individual star, scoring in the 220-yard and 440-yard free-style events.

RAADIO'S outstanding event this week is the second inaugural of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President of the United States. Washington will be the center of broadcasting from early morning on Wednesday until late afternoon.

Anxious parents who insist that Johnny room alone at college "to get more studying done" are confounded by a survey made at the University of Wisconsin. The college roommate, far from being a scholastic bane, is a good influence, the researchers find, tending to raise Johnny's marks.

Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, hailed today Federal acquisition of a large tract in the Montezuma marsh as a haven for waterfowl. The Migratory Bird Commission has approved protection of the area, located at the foot of Cayuga Lake, near Auburn, by the Biological Survey.

The scholarship fund maintained by the Vassar Club of New York for the purpose of aiding young women of the metropolitan district in continuing their education at Vassar College will be augmented by the performance of "Lohengrin," with Kirsten Flagstad in the leading role, on the afternoon of Jan. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
For the time being the crisis over Morocco has been allayed by the exchange of assurances between Berlin and Paris that neither intends to take aggressive steps in the Spanish zone.
If consumer interest warrants it, the Federal Trade Commission stands ready to sponsor national legislation for fiber identification.

A special sale of women's apparel and accessories will be held on Wednesday at the Nearly New Shop at 913 Eighth Avenue by members of Chapter No. 1 of the Berkshire Industrial Farm, which supports a group of boys at the institution.
The Bureau of Navigation released these orders today, dated Jan. 14: CAPTAINS Abbett, H. J., the Chester, to Bureau of Navigation, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.

BLOCK--Dr. and Mrs. M. I. Block (nee . Elsa Nettler) wish to. announce the birth of Joseph's sister, on Thursday, Jan. 14. BBAVERMAN--Dr. and Mrs. A. H. Braverman announce the birth of a son. Jan. 13, at Park West Hospital. BRENNER--Mr. and Mrs. Sam Brenner announce the birth of a. 'son Jan.' 12 at Park West Hospital.
Dr. James T. Tibbetts, who had practiced here since 1914 and prior to that had served in Boston and Manhattan, died today at his home here. His age was 82.

The process of revising retail price lines has already begun and will be well advanced before the Spring season is concluded, retail executives here said yesterday. The changes, however, it was indicated, will be experimented with very carefully and for the near future will be reflected for the most part in "in-between" price ranges, in order to diminish the possibility of consumer price resistance as much as possible.

Four men were held as vagrants today after engaging, police said, in a novel form of "panhandling"--by telephone. Under arrest were Joseph J. Sheehan of Fitchburg, Mass.; William McCready and John Hunt, no homes, and William Hooper, 36, of New York City.

The New York Athletic Club quintet remained unbeaten with three straight victories in the Eastern Athletic Club League when it defeated the Columbus Council K. of C., 33-23, at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn last night.

Ralph J. Ardolino Sr., nationally known in the stone sculptural field and president of the Long Branch Monument Company, died last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Tillie France, 240 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, N. Y. He was 61 years old and had been ill since May.

Gullible shoppers who have been misled in the past need fear no longer the authenticity of huge redlettered signs announcing "goingout-of-business" sales if the city is successful in enforcing its new ordinance for the protection of such buyers.
Taking the lead midway through the first half, Amherst coasted to a 42-24 basketball victory over its local rival, Massachusetts State, to remain undefeated, with three straight triumphs.

The stock market displayed yesterday unusual strength and activity for a Saturday. Led by steel shares in general and by -United States Steel in particular, stocks were firm at the outset and closed the two-hour trading period generally higher.

Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan H. Froehlich of 530 West End Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth B. Froehlich, to Harold E. Strasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Strasser of this city.

The world's greatest charitable foundations have been created by American millionaires. Andrew Carnegie, who considered a man of wealth "the mere trustee and agent for his poorer brethren," left $270,000,000 with the Carnegie Trusts to advance education, culture, social welfare and peace.

The New York Urban League, 204 West 136th Street, paid tribute, at its annual meeting last week to the memory of Justice Frederic Kernochan, who at the time of his death last Saturday had served that organization as chairman of its executive board since 1932.

Once more, as has happened twice before in the history of post-war Franco-German relations, the hope of getting rid of that cat-and-dog attitude which has poisoned this unreal peace period is being entertained.

The First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York loaned last year more than $1,000,000 on residential building in the New York City area, reports Gardner W. Taylor, president. This is the first time in 'its history that the annual loaning volume reached the million-dollar mark.

Educational work of members here by the Women's Committee of One Hundred has stimulated a group of its leaders to join the conference in Washington this week on slum clearance and low-rent public housing.

Eighteen Congressional supporters of the revised Townsend Plan for Old Age Pensions met today at the call of Dr. Francis E. Townsend, the founder, to formulate plans to push the bill they favor. Dr. Townsend was plainly disappointed at the small attendance.

The Texas Corporation plans Issuance of 1,557,000 shares of capital stock to stockholders, at the rate of one new share for every six held and at a maximum of $40 a share, according- to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

FILM producers have gone into the wilds of Africa to get authentic Ubangi life, into the heart of Mexico to get honest to goodness sombreros, but for orthodox skull caps, weathered beards and side curls, we had to go to Kazmierz, the little village where the only Jewish Queen that Poland ever had was born.

The Central and South West Utilities Company, affiliated with the Middle West Corporation, has called a special meeting of stockholders for Feb. 5 to reduce the par value of the common stock to 50 cents a share.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Estelle Laura Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner-Shaw of 500 West End Avenue, to Arnold Michael Denby, son of Mrs. Frederick B. Glaser of 220 West Ninety-third Street.
THIS Winter for the first time rural folk in many States will have little concern over the state of the roads when they go to school or church, haul their crops to market or go for the doctor.
The second Knights of Rhythm supper dance was given tonight in the Embassy room of the Hotel Warwick and was attended by 350 guests.

A dance was given by John Wesley Van Dyke for his debutante niece, Miss Margaret Emma Richardson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cornell Richardson, tonight in the ballroom of the Barclay. Miss Richardson was formally introduced at a tea in October.
For months Egyptologists of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been mystified by two wooden objects discovered by the museum's Egyptian expedition during the 193536 digging at Thebes.

Three New York University professors, each of whom has completed twenty years of teaching service in the university's Washington Square College, will be guests at a testimonial dinner by 150 of their colleagues Friday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Photographs and detailed plans of the forty-eight best entries submitted in the ninth annual small house competition conducted by "House Beautiful" will go on display tomorrow in the furniture department at Gimbel Brothers, Thirty-third Street and Broadway.
