The marriage of Miss Margaret Frances Glavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Glavin of Bloomfield, to Frederick Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Warner of West Orange, will take place on Feb. 6 in Sacred Heart Church here.

Mrs. Archibald Barklie of Inver House, Wayne, hostess to many prominent persons there and at her former town house in Philadelphia as well as at Palm Beach, Fla., died last night at Inver House after an illness of several months.

Printed and manuscript Americana, including items from the collections of Dr. Philip van Ingen, U. P. Hedrik, the late Ogden Goelet and the late Robert Bonner, will be sold at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

APUZZO, JULIA (Oct. 6, 1935). Gross assets, $141,182; net, $11,333 To chlildren Joseph, Vincent, Florence and Frances Apuzzo, one-fourth of real and personal property each and income om one-fourth of residue In trust each, 25 per cent of the principal at 30 and the balance of the principal at 35, and onefourth contingent interest ach in $1,000 trust fund;

Pennsylvania defeated Penn State in a swimming meet in Hutchinson pool today, 49-26. Gene Gisburne of East Orange won two events. He took the 50yard free-style in the fast time of 23.8 seconds and then won the century in 55.1 seconds.

Official Germany observed today "The Day of the German Police," which in outward appearance is a propagandistic effort to make the police popular with the masses but in its deeper significance initiated a drastic reorganization of the German police force into a purely National Socialist force designed to protect the Nazi regime and propagate its philosophy.

Sharply criticizing clubwomen of the State for lack of interest in promoting temperate drinking, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, member of the State Liquor Authority, declared yesterday that there ought to be a new women's club formed to wage a campaign against excessive use of alcohol.

Questions as to the responsibility of a college health officer in warning students of defects which periodic medical examinations disclose during the college years confronted Dr. Dean F. Smiley, medical adviser of Cornell University, and Dr. Adrain G. Gould of the Department of Hygiene and Preventive Medicine in 1922 and have now been substantially answered through a survey conducted by the two medical men.

With the real estate market in a more favorable position and with vast idle private funds apparently anxious to find proper investment outlets, legislators, mortgage experts and builders are considering means of safeguarding money which will flow into realty channels in the future.

AT the Marie Harriman Gallery has been installed, there to remain through the month, a group exhibition composed of paintings by Toulouse-Lautrec, Cezanne, Gauguin, Pissarro, Degas, Renoir, Picasso and Derain. In it also will be found a bronze portrait bust of Derain by Jo Davidson.

Miss Lucy Clabaugh Douglas, daughter of Mrs. Walter de Cazenove Douglas of Overbrook and of the late Mr. Douglas, was married this afternoon to Guilbert Quincy Wales. son of Mr. and Mrs. Quincy White Wales of West Newton, Mass.

The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday for the first eleven months of 1936 a net income of $17,242,471 after taxes and other charges. This was equal, after 4 per cent preferred dividend requirements, to $6.11 a share on 2,222,925 shares of common stock.

A SYMPHONY by Tibor Serly, the Hungarian-American composer, will be given its New York premiere by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy Jan. 26 in Carnegie Hall. The other numbers will be Schoenberg's "Verklaerte Nacht," for string orchestra, and Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony. Mr.

The story of Joseph Rose, the itinerant diamond peddler, who recently charged that he had been robbed of $250,000 worth of precious stones while he was on home relief, may sound fantastic. Yet the saga of Mr. Rose, who walked the city streets for years, his pockets bulging with gems worth a king's ransom, could probably be duplicated by many other jewel dealers.

Mrs. Millicent M. Jones of 17 East Ninth Street, widow of Rochester B. Jones and daughter of Mrs. Frederick Judson Mabon of Orlando, Fla., and the late Mr. Mabon, will be married to Clifford H. Ayres of Bridgeport, Conn., on Feb. 9 in the chantry of St. Thomas Church by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector.

" The warrior bowed his haughty head." The British Public Order Act, which went into effect Jan. 1, forbids any person to wear a uniform " signify"ing his association with any political "organization."

The students of the School of Science in Manhattan College have organized a new club, named the Nieuwland Chemical Society in honor of the late Rev. Julius Nieuwland, former head of the Department of Chemistry at Notre Dame and discoverer of a process for manufacturing synthetic rubber.
The Hapag Lloyd Line yesterday announced the appointment of Captain Carl W. Hagemann as relief commander of the liners Bremen and Europa, the largest ships of the company's fleet.

The Department of Health reported yesterday a continued decline in the number of new cases of influenza and pneumonia in New York City. For the twenty-four hour period ended at 10 A. M. yesterday seventy-eight new influenza cases and nine deaths were reported, as compared with 118 cases and 13 deaths Friday.
State police asked the aid of the fingerprint division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today in the inquiry into the death of Clarence J. Trader, Stockton utilities operator.

ACENTURY ago the University of Berlin enrolled among its new students an angular 18-year-old boy from Trier in the Rhineland. whose father, an advocate and minor official, wished him to become a lawyer.

A steady rise in the value of the Peruvian sol was ascribed today by officials here to improvement in Peru's financial and economic situation and to increased gold production. Quotations today were at the rate of 3.88 sols to the dollar, or approximately 25.755 cents to the sol.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, complaining humorously at a dinner of the Canadian Society last night that there was no longer any subject on which it was safe to speak, asked a surcease of every one criticizing every one else, of talk of war instead of peace, and of holding democracy and the British Empire too much in the limelight.

Miss Madeleine W. Smith, chairman of the eighth annual card party for the blind of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Conedition of the Poor, will be assisted by Mrs. George L. Cameron and Mrs. Mrs. Thomas M. McQuade as cochairmen. The benefit will be held March 13 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The Theatre Guild's presentation of Maxwell Anderson's new play, "The Masque of Kings," at the Montclair Theatre Monday and Tuesday evenings, is sponsored by the Montclair Junior League for the benefit of its community house, now in its tenth year.

Construction of a new infirmary for Amherst College, equipped with upto-date hospital facilities and having twice the capacity of the present infirmary, will be undertaken as soon as the weather permits.
Joe Miller of Buffalo tonight won the second of three blocks played here in the national match game bowling championships and whittled the lead of Champion Hank Marino of Milwaukee to five points.

The marriage of Miss Marion Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Russell of this city, to Henry Rowland Cornwall, son of Professor and Mrs. Ellsworth B. Cornwall of Middlebury, Vt., took place this afternoon in Olivet Congregational Church.
A benefit bridge party will be held next Saturday at the McAlpin under the auspices of the Phi Mu Alumnae of Greater New York, of which Mrs. Paul C. Boyd is president.

The Rev. Dr. Edmund A. Knox, former Bishop of Manchester and father of a famous family, died in Shortlands, Kent, today at the age of 89. One of his sons, E. G. V. Knox (Evoe) is editor of Punch. Another son, Mgr. Ronald Knox, was received into the Church of Rome in 1917, and a third, Canon Wilfred Knox,
A dinner dance will be held on Jan. 26 in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the American-Hungarian Student Exchange of the Institute of International Education.
Karl A. McCormick, a lawyer, is rounding out his third month in an experimental legal job-"proctor of the bar" for the Appellate Division in the Buffalo area.

THERE must be few people who have not been struck these last several years with the widespread interest in the South and Southern matters. For two generations now a great number of books by Southern writers have been appearing; the present decade has seen the number grow to more and more.

New building operations in the Bronx last year led the other boroughs of the city, Borough President James J. Lyons announced yesterday. The amount totaled $48,831,015, an increase of 225 per cent over 1935, Mr. Lyons said.
SPRING tours are now in the process of planning by an ever-increasing number of American dancers. Among the latest sets of announcements are the following:

With five of its components higher, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has regained part of its last loss by moving to 105.5 for the week ended Jan. 9 from 103.0 in the previous week. The index stood at 95.6 for the corresponding week last year.

Jack Purcell of Toronto, world's champion badminton player, and Stanley Cutts of New York defeated Lee Gustavson and Gill Carpenter in an exhibition that featured the program of matches at the Y. M. C. A. tonight. The score was 15-12, 15-4.

The marriage of Miss Lila Mae Roper of Upper Montclair, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Roper of Edgefield, S. C., to Edward Sellew Delamater, also of Upper Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Delamater of Windham, N. Y., took place today in the parsonage of the Upper Montclair Presbyterian Church.

A compromise between interests supporting the Multiple Dwelling Law and owners of the buildings affected is recommended by George S. Horton, president of the Bulkley Horton Company, to remedy the situation under which tenants of these buildings, unable to pay higher rents, are facing eviction.

On the Bourse the week ended with a new influx of business and with French securities especially strong. At the opening, the professional element was inclined to take profits, but pressure of public buying in the cash market kept prices up and drove them above yesterday's levels.

Breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets, E. J. Zeiner, a Class B gunner, won the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the handicap shoot, the Class A trophy went to A. S. Cornhill, who had 94.

Scoring in five of the eight bouts on the program, the Pennsylvania State Teachers subdued the Brooklyn Poly wrestling combination, 23 to 13, on the loser's mats last night. In a preliminary match, the Princeton jayvees blanked the Poly junior varsity, 34-0.
IN 1911, Mr. James Lafayette Hutchison, a young man fresh from college, sailed from San Francisco to China to sell American cigarettes, having been taken on the American Tobacco Company.

Labor's new weapon, the sit-down strike, may impel managers of business and industry to search for new means of defense and possibly to seek the aid of the courts in applying existing legal remedies to meet the exigencies of something new.

A century-and-half-old New England homestead in this town, which was the birthplace of Monroe Smith of Northfield, founder and national director of youth hosteling in the United States, will be restored and remodeled into a youth hostel in honor of Mr. Smith.

The distinction of serving on the directorates of more corporations than any other man, held in 1935 by Henry L. Doherty with 95 directorships, was wrested from him last year by J. Taney Wilcox, secretary of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who amassed 109 official positions, according to the' 1937 volume of Poor's Register of Directors, which was published yesterday. The compilation showed Mr.

WINTER PARK, Fla.--CHASING the circus is the latest outdoor sport for travelers in the South. This is a reversal of the usual order. Instead of the "big tent" coming to its audience, an audience of roving vacationists hunts down the circuses in "Winter quarters."

The Darlingtonia, a pitcherplant, a native of the bogs of high mountains, will live only in a cool room. There its strange tubular leaves, swelling into hoods with appendages that suggest the raised head of a basket full of cobras, mark it for instant attention. It is richly colored with veinings of lighter green, and has a metallic overtone.

With improving business conditions expected to augment the total, more than 5,000 store owners and executives will arrive here beginning tomorrow to attend the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association which begins tomorrow night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Yoshiko Tamamuro of Tokyo is in this country to study American home life. Miss Tamamuro, who is a representative of the progressive element of the younger generation in her own land, being only two years out of college and one of the few Japanese women journalists, reported yesterday her most typical encounter with the younger generation here.

A new minimum-wage proposal, intended by its sponsors as a substitute for the minimum-wage law enacted in 1933 and which has been held unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court, will be introduced when the Legislature resumes work tomorrow evening.
THE University of Oxford is publishing a new history of England. The survey is divided into fourteen periods. Each period is described in a convenient and self-contained volume.

All Wellesley College graduates in the area have been invited to attend a supper party and "professional women's show" sponsored by the New Jersey Wellesley Club, at the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church in East Orange on Tuesday.

Exactly six months before the day this dispatch appears in THE NEW YORK TIMES, the garrisons at Melilla, Larache and Tetuan in Spanish Morocco rose against the Madrid Government, at the command of their officers, and the Spanish civil war began.

TO enliven the show and to make it more attractive for a greater number of people and their diversity of moods, it is apparent at this early date in 1937 that the radio showmen have adopted variety as the main factor in their formula of entertainment.

Responsibility for reducing accidents in schools and college athletic contests rests upon administrators as well as coaches, according to three New York University professors, who have just published their results of several years' study of sport hazards.

George S. West of Boston will make the award of best in show at the sixty-first annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Feb. 10, 11 and 12. He will take the place of the Right Honorable Lorna, Countess Howe, the original selection.

Plans for the construction of the oftmooted canal through Nicaragua and Costa Rica from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean, principally as a measure of increased national defense, but also to expedite commercial relations with Latin-American countries, are being prepared anew for introduction in the House by Representative Carl Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

A coroner's jury today determined that Captain Evelyn Leonard Boothby, retired naval officer with a brilliant war record, committed suicide in his suburban home at Kenton, Middlesex. He was found gassed in his bedroom Thursday.

The establishment of a faculty health system is urged at Columbia University by Dr. William H. McCastline university medical officer, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

THE unusual series of accidents along the airlines during the past month has again fixed the attention of the public on bad-weather flying and has served to minimize the improving record of safety established by the lines over a long period. The airlines themselves are striving to adapt new safety equipment and modes of operations to prevent recurrences.

The Fordham Prep basketball team captured its first game in the Bronx-Westchester C. H. S. A. A. by defeating Mount St. Michael, 22-11, at the Fordham gymnasium yesterday. The victors led throughout, holding a 15-9 advantage at half time.

Department of Agriculture estimated today that sugar consumption in this country last year was 50,000 tons more than in 1935. It reported that deliveries of refined sugar by refiners, beet factories and importers, totaled 6,532,767 short tons, raw value, for 1936.

AUTOMOBILE dealers will seek State legislation this year to regulate the retail motor trade in the interests of fair trade practices, according to the consensus of retailers attending the meeting of the National Automobile Dealers Association during the past week.
Fuel oil in the boiler room of the aircraft carrier Furious suddenly burst into flames today, preventing the ship's departure with other units of the home fleet for the Spring Mediterranean cruise.

John Rogers of Denver, veteran of golf's golden trail, cracked par by four strokes today to take the lead at the halfway point in the 72-hole $5,000 Oakland open tournament with a 36-hole score of 133.
In appreciation of Sam Franko's services to the cause of music in this country, a reception in his honor will be held at the New York Public Library at 4:30 P. M. Wednesday.

PETIT point and crewel work are as fashionable now as they were in the days when Queen Elizabeth embroidered a cushion cover and her ladies in waiting stitched on chair coverings and curtains in their leisure moments.

At this moment-when the Old World is in turmoil and Asia is in fermentwhen only the New World still stands out firmly against social upheaval and the war spirit-there comes to these shores one of the world's greatest revolutionariesLeon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader.

In the week just completed, improvement in sentiment toward the stock market was better than the actual gains in share prices. Were it not for the price rise yesterday, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty representative stocks would have closed slightly lower on the week.
A jaywalking carrier pigeon tied up traffic at a busy downtown intersection during the rush hour. late yesterday.

President Hopkins has created the office of Adviser to Fraternities at Dartmouth College and has named Davis Jackson, '36, of Washington, D. C., to the new post, which is designed to aid in the readjustment of the Greek letter situation here.
Four seniors of the February graduating class at City College have been selected for the Student Council Insignia awards, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men.

Revenue totaling $62,162.21, which had been added to the general fund of the city for the reduction of taxes was listed by James F. Egan, Public Administrator, in his annual report filed with the Board of Aldermen last week.

Scoring its fifteenth straight victory, Harvard's varsity hockey team bolstered its grip on the lead in the American group of the International Intercollegiate Hockey League by beating Princeton, 6 to 2, before 6,000 spectators at the Boston Garden tonight.

In a striking speech on Tuesday the British Foreign Minister, Anthony Eden, suggested that the year 1937 "will perhaps decide the future of our civilization." Few would be so specific regarding the probable date of the definitive crisis. But all agree that Europe cannot long continue in its present precarious state,
Indications point to a large number of new housing operations in various parts of New Jersey this year and construction in the majority of them will be actively under way early in the Spring.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Martin Sr. of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary G. Martin, to Charles E. McDonald, son of Mrs. Walter G. McDonald of Gardiner, Me., and the late Mr. McDonald.

THE Chester Dales are back with us again, and this is certain to be cause for rejoicing in the art world. It is a long time since Mr. and Mrs. Dale have made an appearance in the local exhibition field. They have been greatly missed.
TO SPAIN AGAIN: Spaniards have praised "Death in the Afternoon," by Ernest Hemingway, as the most understanding picture of the art and the sprit of the

An increase of $906,578 in the value of the estate of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 12-year-old daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, was revealed yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley approved the bond filed to cover this amount by Thomas B. Gilchrist, general guardian of the child.

Europe emerged unscathed this week from another of those international squalls which have blown up at disturbingly frequent intervals in the past few years and which have threatened again and again to bring disaster to the entire Continent.

The marriage of Miss Elsa Talbot Adam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hector Cameron Adam of 156 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, to Charles W. B. Wardell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. B. Wardell, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights. The ceremony was performed by, the Rev. David T. Atwater, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. John Fitzgerald.

Miss Barbara Taber Murray, daughter of Mrs. Guy Taber Murray and the late Mr. Murray, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother to Townsend King Wellington of North Bennington, son of Mrs. Townsend King Wellington and the late

THE dress bought at the end of January is the link that binds Winter and Spring. Directly after the holidays the new styles appear; the fabrics have but recently been introduced in the market; the lines are those of a new season.

More than 2,000 civil engineers from all parts of the country are expected to attend the eightyfourth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, beginning on Wednesday and continuing through Saturday, at the society's headquarters, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.
The board of regents of the University of Texas tonight unanimously invited Dana X. Bible of Nebraska to come to Austin Wednesday for a conference regarding employment as head football coach.

Emperor Hirohito today granted permission to his brother, Prince Chichibu, and Princess Chichibu to make a sixmonths' tour of Europe and the United States after attending the coronation of King George VI in London.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mollie Wells Barnes, daughter of Mrs. George H. Barnes of 138 East Thirtysixth Street and Rye, N. Y., and the late Mr. Barnes, to Colonel Maurice Eugene Gilmore of this city.

AMONG the outstanding events of the professional sessions at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers in Detroit last week was a discussion of tourist trailers, introduced by a paper entitled "Where Is the Trailer Going?" by Philip H. Smith.

Mayor La Guardia wrote yesterday to Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, urging that all possible repairs be made to city schools in the Summer vacation period. He expressed surprise to find that much of the work was customarily done while' the schools are in session.

Discovery of a new gold field in Far Northern Ontario was reported this week. The actual discovery was made in the Summer of 1935 and since that time five mining companies have located in the area and several hundred claims have been staked.

Miss Elaine M. Toors, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Toors of Brooklyn, will be married on Feb. 19 to Walter E. Warner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Warner. The ceremony will take place in the Kings Highway Congregational Church and will be followed by a reception at the Heights Casino.

The Columbia College of Pharmacy basketball team defeated the New York Aggies, 45-20, at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. Columbia led, 16-7, at the end of the first half. Art Bersin, Columbia, was high scorer with 13 points.
Of the six New England Governors recently inaugurated, all are newcomers in their positions except Wilbur L. Cross, who began a fourth term in Connecticut.

Antonio Vazquez, 36 years old, of 1,020 Simpson Street, the Bronx, was held in $50,000 bail when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Felony Court on a charge of receiving stolen property.
Lawrenceville School's remarkable polo team met with defeat last night at Squadron A but lost nothing in the estimation of the watchers who filled the armory to the limit of its seating capacity.

A comparative unknown, David Urbach, a freshman at N. Y. U., grabbed the spotlight from Glenn Cunningham last night at the 165th Infantry Armory where the Sixtyninth Regiment A. A. staged its annual track meet before 2,000 persons.

NO period of Lincoln's life has been more inadequately dealt with than the years during which he practiced his profession. It is not necessary for us to stress the need of Mr. Woldiman's fine contribution on that long-neglected phase.

President Anastasio Somoza has requested his Prime Minister, Dr. Geronimo Ramirez Brown, to suppress gambling. All gambling devices will be seized and burned publicly unless gambling is stopped, he said.

Members of the Junior League of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children have arranged their annual card party in behalf of the two institutions for the afternoon of Jan. 25 in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador.

JOHN BARBIROLLI, with his engagement as conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra for the next three years in his pocket, has departed these shores for an interval, to the salvos of admirers and the wagging of heads on the part of doubting Thomases who have not so readily made up their minds as to his place in the category of modern wielders of the baton.

Corporate Communion of the Newman Club Convention, St. Patrick's Cathedral, 9 A. M., to be followed by Communion Breakfast at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Dr. Blanche Kelley and R. Dana Skinner.

No work and- all pay is supposed to be the sum total of the job of that fortunate fellow the motion-picture producer. Lazier than the hill-billy who outsat a tree stump and richer than Midas, he is reported by Hollywood rumorists to live the life of the legendary Mr. Riley and get a four-figured pay check every week for doing so.
RECENT news dispatches from abroad have brought announcements that ship companies in Great Britain and four other European countries are laying keels for big transatlantic liners.
A RETROSPECTIVE exhibition at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, sums up the first year of work under these auspices.

AN average of twenty-five tourists a day visit Mexico's "Monte de Piedad," the government owned and administered pawnshop. About 20 per cent of this number are purchasers. These visitors are from the United States, South and Central America, and a sprinkling to represent the countries of Europe. About 100 per cent of the Swedish tourists in Mexico visit the Mexican pawnshop.

Smashing victories by Second Division soccer teams saw three prominent First League clubs pass out of the English Cup competition as the result of today's third-round contests that provided many noteworthy upsets.

District Attorney John T. Delaney said today that three former associates of Carl Rettick, one-time New England underworld leader, would not be brought back here immediately to face indictment for kidnapping John J. O'Connell Jr., because they were serving terms in Alcatraz Federal prison.

A fusing of ideas from State, county and other educational authorities will distinguish the meeting of the Westchester County t Federation of Women, at the Contemporary Club in White Plains on Friday.

The largest auction sale of coins and other numismatic material in New York City for more than a year will be held this week by Thomas L. Elder beginning Wednesday afternoon at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street and continuing through Saturday.
PHOTOGRAPHING radium, a hitherto untried feat, will be attempted this week at the California Institute of Technology in the interest of one of Pete Smith's shorts.

Mr. and Mrs. Everett Lee DeGolyer of this city, formerly of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Margaret DeGolyer, to David Perry Stephenson, son of Mrs. Ida L. Stephenson of San Antonio.

Mrs. Samuel Dunlap Collett of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, and Shelter Island, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Tissot Collett, to Trafton Otis Badger, son of Mrs. Estelle Randall Badger of Forest Hills and William Otis Badger of Brooklyn and Shelter Island.

CALCULATION, rapid or otherwise, usually concerns the reporter only when he is involved in matters of expense accounts. Tiring of the usual, we venture afield to calculate that nine out of ten persons confronted with the words "secret orders" will conjure up mental pictures of secret agents, matters of espionage and highly mysterious goings-on at GHQ.

AS if in a familiar melody some dissonance were introduced, we catch in Mr. Millspaugh's lines echoes of other poets changed to suit this new young poet's purpose. Mr. Millspaugh is talented and very versatile in the use of poetic forms.

To remove surplus eggs from the market, counteract a drop in prices and encourage the hatching of a normal number of chickens, the Department of Agriculture today made large purchases in the egg market through the Commodities Purchase Section of the AAA, financed by funds taken from customs receipts as authorized by the amended Agricultural Adjustment Act.

The first person to be arrested as a result of the rackets investigation instituted by District Attorney Geoghan in Brooklyn was taken into custody yesterday. He was Joseph Kelban, 45 years old, of 726 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn, business agent of Local 306, Motion Picture Operators Union, with offices at 251 West Forty-second Street, Manhattan.

Fairly general selling of wheat developed today at the opening of the grain markets on the Board of Trade, but there was sufficient buying around $1.32 a bushel headed by mills and commission houses on resting orders to absorb the surplus in the pit.
Skillful handling untied a river tangle off the Chelsea piers of the Hudson River at noon yesterday when four departing liners, three cross-river ferries and an inbound ship met in the channel.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn registered its eighth basketball victory of the season by halting St. Peter's College, 42-30, at Collins Memorial Gymnasium, Jersey City, last night.

Widespread interest has been awakened here in a meeting tomorrow of Rotary members of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay on the frontier of Chile and Argentina at the foot of the gigantic statue of Christ, which, with arms extended toward the territories of the two countries, symbolizes the ties of friendship between them.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morris Krug of 33 Riverside Drive of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine T. Krug, to Mooney X. Kaye, son of Simon Kaye of this city and the late Mrs. Kaye.

That all doctors connected with the New York Academy of Medicine may be on time for all time, Henry P. Moseley, a Montecito resident who died January 4, has willed to that institution the antique hall clock which originally belonged to his great-grandfather, Dr. Elisha Perkins of Plainfield, Conn.

An effort to obtain freedom for Austin H. V. Ryan, 16 years old, held in the Bronx County jail on a charge of suspicion of blackmail, failed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin dismissed a writ brought by the boy's attorney, Leo G. Lippman of 598 Madison Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent dispatch from Belgrade announced that Yugoslavia and Bulgaria had signed a treaty of non-aggression and added that it was hoped this would be followed by similar treaties between Bulgaria and Rumania and Greece.
A bill that would establish minimum pay and other conditions favorable to employes in all private enterprises is causing anxiety in Chilean commercial circles.
Professor and Mrs. Theodore Sizer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Sizer, to Alexander S. Cochran, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cochran of Baltimore.

In a fluctuating struggle that held the packed gallery in suspense to the last point, Norbert Setzler called on the dregs of his spent physical reserve to eke out a victory over David S. Milford of England yesterday in the first half of their match for the world's racquets championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Unseasonably mild weather over a wide area of the country and cold and storms in other sections had a depressing effect on business in general last week, retail trade being especially affected by the adverse conditions.

Manager Tommy Gorman of the Maroons today advocated pooling of gate receipts as the solution of what he described as an "economically unfair" condition involving United States and Canadian teams in the National Hockey League.

An experimental plan of student guidance for those in teacher training, based on the principle that the responsibility of the college is not "college education but the education of college youths" was announced yesterday at the School of Education of New York University.

A small painting of a little girl in a crimson bonnet that the 81-yearold American artist, George De Forest Brush, painted six years ago brought a larger sum at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries yesterday 'afternoon thin the combined total of two good-sized portraits, one by Sir Thomas Lawrence, the other by Thomas Gainsborough.
The Corn Belt has taken its fling at trying to answer some of the puzzling questions involved in its peculiar problem of farm tenancy.
James Foley, 62 years old of 976 Sackett Avenue, the Bronx, was killed early last night on Bronxdale Avenue, near his home. The police believe he was the victim of a hitrun driver.

The pace-setting Brooklyn Prep sextet gained its third straight Private School Ice Hockey League triumph by halting St. Francis Prep, 2 to 1, in the second game of a twin bill at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday.
A Sunday commencement for Rutgers University undergraduates will be held this year for the first time in the history of the university, President Robert C. Clothier announced today.

SOONER or later the overwhelming majority of men who are sent to prison come out-some to lead normal and useful lives, others to fall into crime again. What happens to them while they are in prison has a good deal to do with what happens to them after they come out. Prisons are schools, whether we want them to be or not.

MARYUM M. HORN, soprano; Berenice Jacobsen, Bertha Ostrar and Alvis Horn, pianists, and William Faldner, violinist, were the winners in the recent competition for Chicago appearances with the Illinois Symphony Orchestra, which was sponsored by the Federal Music Project in cooperation with the Society of American Musicians. They were selected from more than 200 young musicians of Cook County, Ill.

With merchandise meetings, manufacturers' showrooms and local hotels crowded with a recordattendance of buyers from out-of-town stores, Spring purchasing activity in the wholesale markets made excellent headway last week, all reports indicated yesterday.

Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax for 1936 will be more than $45,000,000, Finance Department officials predicted yesterday. Up to yesterday noon, with 30,000 or more returns as yet untabulated, the total stood at $41,811,951.87.

The visit here of Colonel General Hermann Goering, the German Air Minister and Commissar for the Four-Year Economic Plan, is proof above everything else of the speed with which European reaction to the Spanish situation is moving toward a crisis.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. arrived here today to visit Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont on a convalescent vacation. He was greeted at the train by his fiancee, 'Miss Ethel du Pont.

Passports were issued to 14,996 Americans for-travel abroad in the calendar year 1936. a State Department report revealed today. Of that number, 43,451 were residents of New York City and 7,938 of New York State exclusive of New York City.

An amendment to existing neutrality legislation applying its prohibitions in case of insurrection or civil strife in any part of the world tending to endanger the neutrality of the United States will be introduced in the Senate on Monday by Senator Clark, he announced today.

Shooting when it was so dark that the targets were hardly discernible by spectators, Dr. Charles W. Scranton, East Orange, turned in a 23 for his final trip and successfully defended his .410 title in the Middle States skeet championships decided at the Loantaka Skeet Club today.

A Supreme Court jury today handed up verdicts totaling $117,000 in damage suits developing from injuries sustained in a head-on crash of two automobiles on New York Avenue, Huntington, L. I., June 23, 1935.

Out of a hundred women brought together in New York City fortytwo years ago by Mrs. William Gerry Slade, their New England ancestry their common bond and basis for organization, eleven charter members of the New York City Colony of the National Society of New England Women remain on the roster.

This is the story of how a burnt stew was responsible for the first airplane flight over Chimborazo, the third highest mountain peak in the Americas. Ruth, my wife, our two dogs, a three-legged deer, four rabbits and I live in Quito, the capital of this enchanting country.
Twelve contributors added a total of $146.50 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, the amount raised to date now standing at $270,298.38. One donor, who sent $100 "in memory of Roberta," wrote:

THOSE behind the television development in London are reported to be anxious to get outside the studios at Alexandra Palace and try the camera on a variety of outdoor scenes. To do this a television-equipped van is planned and a coaxial cable will be stretched through the heart of the city so that the mobile station can be linked with the image transmitter.

LAST Summer we immortalized in these columns Drs. W. F. Wells and H. W. Brown of Harvard's School of Public Health. And this for the reason that they had shown one method whereby influenza virus is transmitted.

The meeting of the Non-Intervention Commission in London the coming week will probably show whether other nations will follow the lead of France in voting powers to the government to prevent the enlistment of more Frenchmen to fight in the Spanish revolution. The British have already applied such a measure. It is to be seen if Germany, Italy and Russia will do likewise.

The Johns-Mansville Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to issue 100,000 additional shares of common stock, without par value, and to make them available for subscription by holders of common stock in the ratio of one new share for each seven and one-half shares held.

President Roosevelt this week sent to Congress his plan of governmental reorganization, and to say that Senators and Representatives were stunned by its terms would indeed be putting it mildly. The plan was the most daring, and certainly the most far-reaching, proposal for change in the administrative mechanism ever made to the American Congress.
A combination of accurate putting and long driving today sent Miss Helen Hicks of Woodmere, L. I., to a comfortable lead over the field in the fifty-four-hole women titleholders' golf tournament.

Many homes of moderate cost suffer unnecessarily from lack of plan in the planting which is done around them, according to landscape architects. These experts point out that in case the amount to be spent for planting does not justify the engagement of a professional landscape architect, reliable service may be had from landscape gardeners and from nurserymen, who maintain landscape departments.

The marriage of Miss Georgie Parker Bosley, daughter of Mrs. E. Stanton Bosley and the late Mr. Bosley, to Charles Girdwood Magnes took place this afternoon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Towson, near Baltimore. The Rev. Henry B. Lee officiated.

Miss Margaret Jane Peterkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Peterkin of Nassau Boulevard, was married yesterday afternoon to John Kirkman Gurney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Gurney of Rockaway Road in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente ruled yesterday that the thirty-four chief clerk in the city magistrates' courts were not in the exempt class and must pass a civil service examination to retain their positions.

For thirty years Harvard's student council, acting as an impartial educational research "institute" on behalf of both faculty and students, has been consulted on every major innovation in the college, but never has this committee so crisscrossed undergraduate life with investigations as in the past twelve months.
As every one knows, the change in Presidential inauguration day this year, from the March 4 following an election to Jan. 20, breaks a precedent as old as our Government.
Purchase of the Bijou Building, a sixteen-story loft structure at 1,237-9 Broadway through to 858-60 Sixth Avenue, at Thirtieth Street, was announced yesterday by William M. Girden, the buyer.

Wisconsin's Legislature has resumed its volunteering of advice to Congress. The adoption of two memorials to the nation's lawmakers at the first sessions of the Senate this week led one legislator to remark that he could not recall when Wisconsin did not indulge in this pastime.

A SPECIAL series of commemorative postage stamps for Alaska and the island possessions of the United States will be issued by the Postoffice Department this year, following the completion of the current army and navy series.

Five German prelates, elected at Fulda this week to represent the German Catholic Episcopae are reported to have arrived in Rome today. The commission is composed of Cardinal von Faulhaber of Munich, Cardinal Bertram of Breslau, Cardinal Schulte of Cologne, Count von Galen, Bishop of Muenster and Count von Preysing, Bishop of Berlin.

Miss Ruth Dunlap Moyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luther M. Moyer of this place, was married this evening to Benjamin Joseph Cullen of Montclair, son of Mrs. Helen L. Cullen of New York and the late Mr. Cullen. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church here by the rector, the Rev. James T. Lodge. A small reception and buffet supper followed at the Moyer home.

The Senate met for forty minutes today, principally to receive the favorable report from its Banking and Currency Committee on the Administration bill to extend until June 30, 1939, President Roosevelt's powers to use the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund and to alter the gold content of the dollar.
Ann Harding, film actress who fled America to keep the custody of her daughter and incidentally act in Britain, has found romance as well--with an American.

THE Astonished Ostnch, a farcical comedy by Archie Menzies, though a very trivial piece, is worth writing of for several reasons. The first is its name--a very provocative name when one remembers all the habits attributed to the bird.

The greatest gain in education in the last thirty years has been the diffusion of education through the junior college and through the adult instruction movement, according to President Robert Maynard Hutchins of the University of Chicago.

The marriage of Miss Annie Frances King, daughter of Mrs. Albert Mortimer King of Charleston, S. C., to Henry Soloday Shryock Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Shryock of Baltimore, will take place on Tuesday in the Citadel Square Baptist Church in Charleston.

ALTHOUGH a great many plays are published in the course of a season, Maxwell Anderson's are worth the closest reading. Unlike most contemporary plays, they are written in a style unfamiliar to the modern playgoer; parts of them are difficult to assimilate on the spur of the moment in the theatre. Again the analogy is with Shakespeare.
Under the auspices of the Women's Conference of the Society for Ethical Culture a bridge tea will be held on Jan. 25 at the Plaza for the benefit of the welfare work of the organization.

The General Committee for Prudence Securities, in a statement yesterday, reiterated its opposition to the plan of reorganization of the Prudence Bonds Corporation presented by it, terming the plan unfair and unjust to the holders of the eighteen series of first mortgage collateral trust bonds totaling about $55,000,000

The influx of buyers and storeowners to the New York wholesale market is increasing daily, and will probably reach a peak at the beginning of this week, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The report continues:

Before a large and enthusiastic crowd of spectators, the Squadron C trio scored impressively in its home armory in Brooklyn last night, downing the Gypsy Polo Club, 7 to 1, for its first Metropolitan Indoor Polo League victory of the season.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Copley Thaw are returning from Phoenix, Ariz., tomorrow and will be at the SavoyPlaza. Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien will leave the Waldorf-Astoria today to return to Palm Beach. William Evarts Benjamin is now at the Claridge, Atlantic City.

Since the demobilization of our World War army, nearly 1,600,000 veterans have been admitted to Federal hose pitals, the Veterans Bureau recently disclosed. Admissions during 1936 totaled 120,365, as compared with a peak of 148,662 in 1932.
NO PLACE LIKE HOME" is the sixteenth book by a young English author whose writings have ranged over many subjects and through many degrees of excellence and acceptability.

Oran Young of Wilton, Conn., and Charles St. John of Canandaigua, both seniors at Hobart College, and Miss Helen Maney of Geneva, a senior at William Smith College, have been designated as "faculty scholars" by the committee on education policy at the two colleges. Their election inaugurates a new phase of liberal education at both Hobart and William Smith.

New blizzards swept the Rocky Mountain region tonight, cutting off a rescue party in automobiles driving toward Las Vegas with five victims of a previous snowstorm and isolating thirty-five men tending 20,000 sheep.

Arthur O. Minnich, assistant to the president of International Utilities, 120 Broadway, who has just returned from Spain, disclosed yesterday how, with the assistance of the British and American Ambassadors and the approval of the autonomous Basque government,

While counsel for Major Green began yesterday their fight to save his life, the porter accused of murdering Mrs. Mary Harriet Case insisted in Queens County Jail that he was innocent, and a Negro group in Brooklyn opened a drive to minimize racial discrimination growing out of the crime.

Three lawyers hired by Nebraska's new unicameral Legislature began functioning today as a "little brain trust," commissioned to ferret out unconstitutionality in proposed new laws before they ever gain legislative approval.

Bill Anperson's Penn A. C. five defeated the Lafayette quintet on memorial floor gym tonight, 39-18. Led by Al Bonniwell, intercollegiate league high-scoring ace, and Joe Thomas, former Lafayette star, the visiting quintet got off to an early start and led, 20-5, at half time.

Although New Jersey Republican leaders attained their immediate political objective on Tuesday, when they permitted William C. Hunt to take his seat in the Legislature as the Senator from Cape May County and thereby gained control of the upper house by a bare majority of 11 to 10, observers are of the opinion that the party's prospects in the next Fall's campaign for Governor were hurt more than they were helped.
The sitdown strikes which stalled the mammoth General Motors automobile plant throughout the country appear at first glance to have been a great success.

Miss Helen H. Leetch, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Leetch, tonight was married to Joseph Seiffert Hall of New York. The ceremony was performed in the Second Presbyterian Church, Guilford, by Dr. Leetch, who is the pastor.

WHAT we call the Ballets-Russes is something that flowered in Western Europe from a Russlan stem. As an artistic whole, the twentieth-century Ballets-Russes had their real inception when some students in St. Petersburg formed a more or less deliberate group for the discussion of intellectual and esthetic interests. in the late Eighteen Eighties. Ballet was not their first enthusiasm nor their first adult activity; they themselves were not all of Russian race.
A STOCKADE is part of the restoration carried on by the National Park Service at Fort Necessity National Battlefield Site, Pa.

For nearly thirteen years the States of the Union have had before them for ratification a proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Constitution. Twenty-five States have ratified it, leaving eleven ratifications needed before the amendment can become a part of the organic law of the United States.

The 1936 volume of Jane's All the World's Aircraft, the compendious work that presents yearly the technical details of airplanes and aircraft engines of every major country, is being studied here. Held to the size of last year's volume,
Britisher who returned to Gibraltar from rebel-held Cadiz, Spain, today said he witnessed the landing there Tuesday of a fresh contingent of Italians which he estimated at 4,000 armed men.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--A number of New York business men are entered in the eighth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship, to be played off next Friday, Saturday and Sunday here on the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall courts.

Miss Betty L. Coon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Coon of 1,165 Park Avenue, was married to N. Eugene Reinfeld, son of Mrs. Henry Reinfeld of St. Louis and the late Mr. Reinfeld, yesterday morning at Sherry's by Judge James G. Wallace of the Court of General Sessions.

By what names shall we pledge you, since you bear So many names? Behind the footlights' glare This very night you may be peasants, peers, Or poets, Caesars, Shylocks, Hamlets, Lears, Or Falstaffs; Desdemonas, pale. Ophelias, Enchanting Rosalinds, Juliets, Cordelias, Shrewd fools like Touchstone, or elusive elves Like Puck, and still remain your secret.selves.
The royal commission of inquiry continued today to hear the testimony of witnesses on behalf of the Arab High Committee. Fuad Saba, secretary of the committee, testified on the subject of taxation.

All former German colonial territories, although lost in the World War and now administered under League of Nations mandates, by allied nations, are still considered "German colonies" by present-day Germany.
WHEN President Roosevelt is inaugurated on Wednesday for his second term the Boy Scouts will again serve with the Inaugural Committee.

Looking back on the memorable chapter written into British history during the first ten days of December, it seems incredible that only a little more than a month ago heralds, trumpeters and pursuivants marched through the fog-veiled streets of London proclaiming the beginning of a new reign.

AN experienced person would probably not go up to a policeman in Central Park near 110th Street and ask him whether any monuments, statues, statuary (in an endeavor to be more explicit) are to be found around his beat. So far as he knew, none could be found.

OF the nine plays by Henri Bernstein that have been seen in New York, all but two--"Promise," which Gilbert Miller put on at the Little very late last month, and "Melo," which was acted in 1931--were shown here before the war.

Definitely convinced that a majority of the 223,000 persons who witnessed the 1936 National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace were fascinated by the spectacular events performed by experts in the mammoth tank on the first floor, the management is arranging an even more attractive program for the 1937 exposition, which will be held Feb. 18-27.

Tomorrow's St. Louis Post-Dispatch will publish an extended copyrighted interview with Leon Trotsky, now in Mexico. In it the exiled Russian revolutionist discusses Stalin, Lenin, the "world revolution," his health and his own future plans.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls assured themselves of at least a tie for the first-half championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League with a 5-2 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

Over the lone protest of Senator BYRD, and by an impressive majority of 73 to 1, the Senate has voted to extend the present powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for two and a half years. Mr. BYRD is not an enemy of RFC.

The New York Athletic Club trio, national senior champions, nosed out the Ridgewood Polo Club, New Jersey titleholder, 11 1/2 to 101/2, tonight, before a capacity crowd of 3,000 at the Essex Troop Armory.
The annual supper dance of the Aviators Post, 743, of the American Legion will take place on Feb. 5 at the Pierre. Major Eugene F. Gillespie is chairman of the arrangements committee.

New methods of art teaching exemplified by the children's workshown currently at the Federal Art Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, are having repercussions in the teaching of adults and even in the regular art classes of the public elementary schools.

Former Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, whose interim appointment to the General Sessions Court ended on Jan. 1, said yesterday that he would not appear in the restaurant "shakedown" racket trial scheduled to begin tomorrow before Justice Philip J. McCook in Supreme Court, in which his brother and law partner, David Goldstein, is counsel for several of the defendants.

The Fordham University basketball team, looking more like Maroon teams of old, scored a 33-to-28 victory over Brooklyn College last night. A crowd of 1,200 persons in Fordham's Bronx gymnasium saw the two teams play a seesaw second half which kept the outcome uncertain until the very end.

The marriage of Miss Ruth M. Bender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Welcome W. Bender of Elizabeth, to Sylvester A. Schramm, son of Mrs. Joseph J. Schramm of Newark and the late Mr. Schramm, took place here this morning in St. Catherine's Church.
Four automobile union organizers accused of leading a mob which battled police here Monday night surrendered today and were arraigned in court. Warrants for three others have been issued.

The University of Toronto's varsity sextet today went into a tie wtih McGill University, Montreal, at the top of the Canadian Group standing of the International Intercollegiate Hockey League by defeating the University of Montreal. 3-2, at Varsity Arena.
Miss Mary Lee Ware of Boston, a descendant of the donors of the glass flower collection at Harvard, has left $300,000 to the university by will.
In a seventy-nine-page brief, quoting from scores of authorities, including St. Paul, William James, George Bernard Shaw,

John Barrymore, 54-year-old actor, worked as usual today on the set of a film romantically titled "Maytime," but refused to see reporters and maintained silence on the crash of his marriage to 21year-old Elaine Barrie.

A plan to set up the first chemical laboratory to be established at the site of a Greek archaeological excavation was revealed today with the announcement that a Princeton University professor will this Spring assist the excavators of the Agora, or market place, at Athens, Greece, in chemically identifying and preserving the objects found there.

Resuming direct negotiations after they had seemingly reached a hopeless deadlock, ship owners and maritime unions are now making real progress toward a settlement of the maritime strike which has paralyzed shipping on the Pacific Coast since Oct. 30.
A total of 1,510,463 persons were placed in private employment and more than 5,000,000 placements of all types were made by the Employment Service in 1936, Secretary Perkins stated today.

Last year the automotive industry made 4,500,000 cars and trucks, 2,000,000 of them bearing the various trade names of General Motors Corporation. It was the best year since 1929, 11 per cent ahead of 1935, and leaders predicted that this year the industry would really step on the gas.

Charles Fenske of the University of Wisconsin is the first American runner to be named to oppose Miklas Szabo of Hungary in the Wanamaker mile at the Millrose A. A. track and field meet at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz.

Rockland County police and State Troopers continued today their search for three armed assailants who entered the home of Raymond Wolf, 30 years old, of Spring Valley, last Thursday night and beat him after tying his mother and sister with electric-light cord and adhesive tape. Wolf is a radio operator for the Munson Line.

Judging from the genuine interest shown in Long Island North Shore property last year, all indications point to a steadily increasing demand for well-located home sites during the next few years, declares Henry A. Rogers, Long Island broker.

A movement to introduce the study of the Swedish language in the high schools of New England has been started in Massachusetts. Originally formulated by educators and interested citizens of the Eastern States. the plan has been sponsored by a Swedish-American newspaper published in Worcester.
Formation of a "National Citizens' Committee for Civil Rights in the Automobile Industry" was announced yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union. Representatives will be sent to

Germany's conservation campaign extended today into the newsprint field with thinner editions of newspapers. The Nazi party organ, the Angriff, had only twelve pages instead of the usual sixteen. Others reduced their page totals similarly.

appealed to him, while the traditional indifference of Austrians to the affairs of others rendered this country a peculiarly suitable place for relief from relentless publicity. Throughout the crisis in Britain the Austrian press showed sympathy for the King without criticizing Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's attitude.

Several sales in Putnam County, N. Y., are reported by the Edward Joyce Agency of Lake Mahopac. The country home of Florence Waldro Sullivan with thirty acres was sold to Miss Grace M. Austin of New York City.

Eighteen of the twenty-six new public schools being built here with Public Works Administration funds will be ready for occupancy when the Spring term opens Feb. 1, Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, announced yesterday.

The third "Morocco crisis" was settled nn Jan. 11, 1937, with dictatorial brevity by five minutes of conversation between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and the French Ambassador to Berlin, Andre Francois-Poncet. According to the German press and radio, there never was any crisis. Both sides seem to have come off unharmed.

Miss Anna Panczner of this city, formerly of Budapest, was married yesterday at noon in the Middle Collegiate Church to Morris Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Jackson of 879 St. John's Place, Brooklyn and Wallasey, Cheshire, England.

An entirely new status in the negotiations between the General Motors Corporation and members of the United Automobile Workers of America, scheduled to get under way in Detroit on Monday, was created tonight by the thousands of non-striking employes in Flint.
Governor E. W. Marland reported today that he had received an extortion letter, written in pencil, threatening his safety and Mrs. Marland's if he did not pay $5,000 in unmarked bills.

Now that Madrid has become the Verdun of world anti-fascism, its sandy little river, the Manzanares, is becoming as historic as Caesar's little Rubicon. Curling round the capital to the west and south, it has become the line of demarcation, broken in a few places only, between anti-fascism and fascism.

The first commercial non-stop flight from Miami, Fla., to Newark Airport over a 1,200-mile route was completed today by a fullloaded twenty-one-passenger Eastern Air Lines plane, company officials announced.

OUT of the host of English poets one small group, only five in number, has for generations been set apart under a defining label They are that handful of seventeenth-century versifiers, Donne, Herbert, Crashaw, Vaughan and Thomas Traherne, who have come to be known as the metaphysical poets.

Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden of this city and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Selden, to William Henry Sudduth 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Sudduth of Starkville, Miss.

SEVERAL Stravinsky works will be included on the programs of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra for the current week. Under the baton of its guest conductor the orchestra will also be heard in the Mozart piano concerto in G, with Beveridge Webster as soloist. The season's first "Siegfried" and the return of Giovanni Martinelli mark the fifth week at the Metropolitan Opera. Complete opera and concert programs follow:
Boxthorn, bearing the red bars and white of Ed Janss, achieved a clean victory today in the $3,500 added San Felipe Handicap before 35,000 fans at Santa Anita Park.
Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University, died at his home here early this morning after an illness of two days. His age was 69.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 15, unless specified: At Pearl Harbor, Brazos, Kanawha, Lark, Quail, Tanager. Argonne, Mare Island Yard to San Pedro, via Drakes Bay. Badger, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Henderson, San Francisco to Honolulu. Kane, at Gibraltar.

Next week-end, come rain, come snow, come any kind of weather, the annual Sno Birds figure-skating championship will take place at Lake Placid. This competition used to be held on the club's outdoor rink, and so temperature played as important a part as snow-or the lack of it--plays for skiing.

HISTORIC Appomattox, an almost deserted village in the heart of the fertile Pied mont section of Virginia, claims the attention and interest of America today as never before since that eventful April day in 1865 when Lee surrendered here to Grant.
Nine men, from widely separated parts of the country, are to go on trial in Federal Court here Monday on charges of being members of a nation-wide fraud ring.
Transfer and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Jan. 18, 1937: PATROLMAN Eugene F. Leonard, from 46th Precinct, to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, for duty with Midtown Squad.

The Biological Survey indicated today that it intended to press a charge of violating Federal game laws, brought against Justice Van Devanter of the Supreme Court, who went duck hunting without a $1 stamp required on all hunting permits.

Joseph S. Gelders of Birmingham, Ala., who testified on Friday before the Senate subcommittee investigating alleged terrorism and violation of civil rights in the Birmingham district, charged yesterday that the three men whom he accused of beating and flogging him

England's "cycling parson," the Rev. Frederick Hastings, who in the early days of the Canadian Confederation was a Methodist minister at Saint John, N. B., died today at the age of 99. He earned the sobriquet of "cycling parson" by making bicycle tours on five continents, including North America, often halting to preach en route. His books included "Spins of a Cycling Parson" and "Memories of a Million Miles."
Although reported "much improved," Grover Cleveland Alexander, former big league pitching star, will be kept in a Springfield hospital for a least three or four more days, Dr. Paul Levis said today.

Six original plays Will begin rehearsals tomorrow for Fordham College's annual varsity one-act play contest, according to an announcement made by the Rev. William A. Storck, moderator of the student dramatic group, the Mimes and Mummers.

The University of Michigan Athletic Board dispelled rumors that Harry G. Kipke would not continue as head football coach with an announcement late today that he will be retained for the 1937 season. The announcement, made by Professor Ralph W. Aigler, chairman of the Board of Control of Physical Education. said:

Kirsten Flagstad will be the soloist at the forty-sixth anniversary breakfast of the Haarlem Philharmonic Society on Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria, for which an attendance of several hundred persons is anticipated.
EGYPT is breaking all its records for Winter visitors. Last Winter its season was spoiled by the Italo-Ethiopian war and by occasional student disorders in Cairo.

While there were no developments yesterday in the United States Attorney's investigation of the procurement of Americans for service in Spain, the acting consul general for Spain and the attorney for American aviators who served the Loyalist cause issued conflicting statements regarding the pay they received.

The eleventh annual meeting of the First Avenue Association will be held on Wednesday in the Beekman Tower, First Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. Thirteen directors will be elected, reports of officers on the 1936 activities will be read and awards will be presented to the six merchants who won the association's window display contest during the Christmas holidays.

LOVERS of the Middle Ages ought to be warned in advance that Miss Park hurst's study of that period is something much more than a textbook on ecclesiastical architecture. The volume is divided into three somewhat unsymmetrical parts, entitled respectively the "Visible," "Invisible" and "Incorruptible"; and the first four chapters might, without a careful reading, easily confirm the textbook impression.
THE accession of King George VI to the British throne has brought a marked increase in the demand for postage stamps bearing the likenesses of the new King and Queen and of Princess Elizabeth.

Funeral services for Mrs. Elizabeth Flagler, mother of Homer J. Flagler, a commissioner of the Dutchess County Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, who died Thursday at her home at the age of 86, were held today. The Rev. B. Charles Ross officiated. She was the widow of Oscar Flagler. A daughter, Mrs. Herbert Seaman, also survives.

Heartened by their success at having snapped their long losing streak, the New York Americans will seek to experience the comparatively novel sensation of winning two games in a row when they oppose the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The Albany Society of New York will celebrate its forty-fourth anniversary at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt next Saturday. Plans are being made by George Tiernan, president of the organization.

THIS collection of stories and poems culled from the first ten issues of the monthly magazine of the same name reveals a standard of selection considerably better than average In the field of juvenile magazines. It is a distinguished group of contemporary authors and illustrators which has contributed to this volume.

Seven thousand workmen in the plants of the New Departure division of the General Motors Corporation in this city and Meriden have been compelled to operate on a shortened 32hour-a-week schedule because of the strike in Michigan.

The Savage Institute men's basketball team conquered the N. Y. U. Dentistry quintet, 44 to 17, and the Savage girls' combination trounced the Harrisonburg (Va.) State Teachers alumni sextet, 43 to 18, on the court of the winners yesterday.

WITH so many prominent English actors and actresses making their American debuts in New York this season-es witness John Gielgud, Peggy Ashcroft and Sir Cedric Hardwicke--it would appear that the balance of trade between the two countries in this particular theatrical commodity was badly out of kilter, if one were not immediately reminded of a most recent and highly esteemed American contribution to the felicity of the London stage.

Nationalism was declared the greatest threat to world security and peace, in a sermon delivered here this morning by Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron of Baltimore at Sabbath services attended by delegates to the joint convention of the. Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the affiliated national temple sisterhoods and brotherhoods.

A total of 342,730,372 passengers used subway, tube and elevated trains in the central mercantile section of New York City during the year ended June 30, 1936, according to an analysis by Joseph E. Kean, secretary of the Central Mercantile Association, of figures in the passenger traffic report for the year issued by the Metropolitan Division of the State Transit Commission.

THE islands of Sicily and Rhodes are among Mediterranean spots to be visited by passengers on the Roma, of the Italian Line, leaving New York on March 12 for a Spring cruise. Sailing while the weather here is, as a rule, still cold, the voyage leads to hamlets and cities brilliant with late Spring blossoms.

The lives of great men cross and recross in this world of political change. This was illustrated the other day when Senator Theodore Francis Green, new Democratic Senator from Rhode Island, suddenly found himself living in the apartment once occupied by his Republican predecessor and former opponent, Jesse Metcalf.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, and J. Herbert Case, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will be the principal speakers at the annual midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association to be held at the Federal Reserve Bank on Monday, Jan. 25, it was announced yesterday by the association.

Silence is maintained here on the question whether Japan will install 14-inch or 16-inch guns on the new capital ship soon to be laid down. Apparently the Japanese naval authorities are awaiting better proposals than any yet made to them.
Dazzling Western Reserve with a tricky passing attack and sinking goals from difficult angles, the Syracuse University basketball team won tonight, 35 to 21, for its sixth consecutive victory.

On the premise that 28,000,000 voters cannot be entirely wrong, John D. M. Hamilton recommended yesterday to 1,500 Republican wo??en at the Hotel Astor a realignment of their party's platform to approximate that which attracted so many Democratic ballots last November. The chairman of the National Republican Committee combined bluntness, candor and optimism in his brief address at the sixteenth anniversary luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club.

Exeter's basketball team defeated the Yale freshmen today, 38 to 34. The Exonians were trailing till within a few seconds before the gun ended the second quarter when Dave Allerdice shot a basket from the side, giving Exeter a 17-to-15 lead.

IN her new novel, "The Faithful Wife," Sigrid Undset squares a triangle, so to speak, as one step toward her solution of a marriage crisis. In their childless union, Nathalie and Sigurd, both absorbed in their separate professions. had begun to take their smooth routine of life too blandly for granted. An address this week by Dr. Walter Van Dyke Bingham, New York City psychologist, opened a new series of Bucknell University chapel programs designed to counsel students in shaping their personalities and selecting vocations.

Silence is maintained here on the question whether Japan will install 14-inch or 16-inch guns on the new capital ship soon to be laid down. Apparently the Japanese naval authorities are awaiting better proposals than any yet made to them.

Miss Miriam Lee, daughter of Edward E. Lee of Hollywood, Calif., was married at her home here this afternoon to A. Roberts Chamberlain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Roberts Chamberlain of Meriden, Conn., by the Rev. Oscar Maddaus of the Manhasset Dutch Reformed Church. There was no attendants.

Mrs. Lillian R. Sire was the guest of honor yesterday at a "farewell" luncheon given by the Women's National Democratic Club, of which she is the president, at the Hotel Ansonia, Seventy-third Street and Broadway.
Howard Dietz, the song writer, married Mrs. Tanis Guinness Montagu of England at Juarez, Mexico, today forty-five minutes after they arrived here by airplane from the East.

Carroll Club-Tea dance, 4 P. M., at clubhouse. College Women's Club - Annual guest day. Carl Carmer, speaker. Tea, 3:30 P. M., Jackson Heights Club. Junior Woman's Club of Paterson (N. J.)--International Tea. Speaker, Elliot Taylor of the Near East Foundation.

The weight of two 13-point scoring outbursts carried Long Island University and Manhattan College quintets to victory at the Hippodrome last night, each by a decisive enough margin to preserve their reputations of being New York's outstanding teams.
The engagement of $1,501,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported also the arrival here of $1,109,900 gold from

Playing a superb brand of squash tennis, as fine an exhibition as has ever been witnessed in the final of the event, Philip T. Moore, member of the Columbia University Club, yesterday won the season's honors in the Clyde Marti Memorial tournament at the Yale Club.
Mr. JOHN L. LEWIS has often described, in writing or in speech, the aim of his movement to bring all workers within one vast organization. It is, he explains, to establish a true labor democracy.

Clubhouses of the yacht organizations that dot the cozy harbors and rivers of the metropolitan area may be desolate ??nd bleak spots these wintry days, gut the members of these nautical groups interrupt the lull between seasons at this time of the year to set up their official rosters for the ensuing campaign.

AUGUSTA, Ga.--Finals in the Augusta women's titlist golf tournament, and the second polo game of the season between the Augusta Four and the Governor's Horse Guards of Atlanta, are being played today. Interests of the Winter colony thereafter will turn temporarily from sports to one literary and one social event scheduled for this week.
YESTERDAY'S epigrams are today's platitudes in the written page, and in the photographic literature of the screen yesterday's symbolism becomes today's cliche.
Peter Fick, veteran campaigner for the New York A. C., won the metropolitan A. A. U. senior 100yard free style swimming championship last night in the Winged Foot pool.
Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday dismissed two more patrolmen, bringing to 154 the number discharged from the department since he assumed office in 1934.
Senator Sheppard, author of the Eighteenth Amendment, said today that "social considerations are being ignored" in. a "mad scramble" for tax revenue since repeal.

Hopeful that the Legislature will enact laws at the present session which will permit the consolidation of the magistrates' courts and the court of special sessions, Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that he would not appoint a successor to the late' Frederic Kernochan as Chief Justice of Special Sessions.

Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., who ranks first among the nation's amateur tennis players, gets a chance tomorrow to avenge the defeat to which he was subjected by Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta last Sunday.

Although the Soviet Union's 20,000,000,000 ruble military budget adopted this week is the highest ever allotted by any government in peacetime, the country is fully able to stand it without straining its economic resources.

Four more of the seeded players in the New York State squash racqets championship in progress at the Downtown Athletic Club advanced yesterday as the second round was completed. Thus seven of the ranking contestants are in the third round, scheduled for tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Isabelle Ann Woodhall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Woodhall of Jersey City, N. J., to Robert Morgan Stopford of this city, son of Colonel and Mrs. Frederick William Stopford of Beverly, Mass., took place here yesterday in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

The annual report of the Maternity Center Association, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street, announces that interested groups have been formed in virtually every State to study and improve local maternity facilities.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Krumholz of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Krumholz, to Dr. Nathan R. Tolk, son of Mrs. Jessie Tolk of Bridgeport, and the late Hyman Tolk.

Installations of Summer air-conditioning units increased by 44.2 per cent in 1936 over 1935, according to the annual statistical review of the heating and air-conditioning industries which appears in the current number of Heating and Ventilating, issued today.

THOSE who criticize others must expect to be criticized in their turn, and writers who are literary critics by profession cannot be surprised when they find themselves targets for the slings and arrows of people who are dissatisfied with their judgments.

A series of teas has been arranged by the Associate Alumnae of Packer Collegiate Institute, of which Mrs. Tremper Longman is president, on Tuesday in the alumnae rooms at the institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.

Temple University's quintet turned back Villanova, 28-23, tonight in the second game of a college basketball twin bill at the Philadelphia Arena after North Carolina had snapped the seven-game winning streak of St. Joseph's with a 36-34 triumph in the opener.

Miss Barbara Kirkby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Kirkby of this place, was married in the home of her parents this morning to James Eastwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Eastwood of Paterson, N. J.

Local minimum construction standards have been established in seventeen insuring offices of the Federal Housing Administration and they are expected to become operative by Feb. 15, reports Administrator Stewart McDonald.

Major Gen. John A. LeJeune, superintendent of Virginia Military Institute since 1929, today tendered his resignation to the board of visitors of the college. The resignation is to take effect on Oct. 1.

DESPITE the recent announcement that Bruno Walter would conduct Gluck's "Iphigenia in Tauris" at Salzburg next Summerword has now come that he will do Weber's "Euryanthe" instead. This would mean a belated observance of the 150th anniversary of Weber's birth, which occurred a week before the past Christmas.

Staff members who will head the next annual writers' conference at Olivet College, Mich., include: Carl Sandburg, Dorothea Brande, Jean Starr Untermeyer, Allen Tate, Caroline Gorden, Nannine Joseph, Kenneth Horan, Alice Gersteinberg, Franklin Meine and Paul Engle.

THE drama is perhaps the oldest of the arts. if we trace it back to the gesticulations of primitive storytelling or to the rites performed by almost all savages to propitiate the tribal gods. In its great days it is a popular art, not merely a box-office enterprise. Music, painting, sculpture and, of course, poetry, are bound up with it.

War upon "gangsters of the revolution" and "uncontrollables" who have been guilty of acts of terrorism and assassinations in defiance of all authority has been ordered by the new Catalan government and its High Commissioner of Public Order, Rodriguez Salas, who has just taken office.

Judge Robert C. Baltzell in Federal court here signed today in the case of the closed Washington Bank and Trust Company of Indianapolis an order requiring the American Surety Company of New York, which provided bonds for officers of the bank, to pay $120,917 to Oren S. Hack, receiver for the bank.
