The Rev. Dr. Charles P. H. Nason, a retired Presbyterian minister who had served thirteen years as an American Consul in France and become a recognized authority on the life of Joan of Are, died at his home in Chestnut Hill today after a week's illness. His age was 94.

Establishment of a credit union central bank for this State was proposed in legislation drawn up at the quarterly meeting of the board of directors of the New York State Credit League held here today.

The Atlantic City Electric Company, wholly owned by the American Gas and Electric Company, sought today registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of an issue of $18,000,000 of its general mortgage 31/4 per cent bonds due in 1964.

The Plainfield Yale Club celebrated its fiftieth anniversary tonight at a dinner at the Plainfield Country Club, with a number of Yale graduates and undergraduates and others prominent in university affairs as guests. Delano Ladd, president of the local club, introduced Allan V. Heeley, head of Lawrenceville School, as toastmaster.

Manufacturers in the United States consumed 573,522 long tons of crude rubber in 1936, compared with 491,544 in 1935, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Consumption in December was 49,626 tons, against 50,303 in November and 42,474 in December, 1935.

Announcement was made yesterday that a special scholarship award of $2,000, covering four years' tuition at Smith College, would be offered this year by the Smith College Club of New York to a candidate or candidates presented by the Smith Clubs of the metropolitan area.

Officers of 1937 for the Jewish National Fund of America were announced yesterday by Zionist headquarters at 111 Fifth Avenue. Rabbi Israel Goldstein will head the fund for the fourth consecutive term.
Southern Illinois, the lower half of Indiana and Southern Ohio continued today to feel the effect of floods from the swollen Ohio, Wabash, White and Kaskaskia Rivers.

Dartmouth's basketball team led Pennsylvania for more than half the game tonight, but a second half surge kept the visitors unbeaten in the Eastern Intercollegiate League with a 34-22 triumph. It was the Quakers' fourth straight circuit victory.
Ten thousand birds, sufferers of a rigorous Winter, have been given a lift southward in airplanes so far this season.
Mr. and Mrs. Percy C. Stuart of Brewster, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Stuart, to Sherman M. Bijur of this city.
Eightyseven new houses which rent for $12 to $16 a month, built by the government for workers and their families in a slum-clearance project, formally were opened today by President Oscar Benavides.

The eleventh midwinter indoor polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club, to be held on the night of Feb. 13 at the 105th Regiment Field Artillery Armory, Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, is being sponsored by the Ladies Auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital.

Plans for the promotion of peace which have been formulated by all the important agencies considering the subject, form the basis for a study outline prepared by Mrs. Arthur D. Jaques, chairman of the Department of International Cooperation of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

Under the auspices of the Sanctuary Society of St. Francis de Sales Church a card party will be held next Saturday afternoon at the Biltmore to raise funds for carrying on the charitable work of the organization.
The Jonker diamond, now in the form of twelve polished -bluewhite stones, was returned .to the American Museum of- Natural History yesterday for a threeday exhibition.
ONE of the most pleasant experiences in the Group Theatre's existence occurred during the past week.

Fordham University will pay tribute to the founders of its College of Pharmacy at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Feb. 9, when 1,000 members of the Alumni Association of that department of the university gather on the occasion of its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration.
The Kansas City Southern Railroad was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to assume obligation for $2,020,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Port Arthur Dock and Canal Company.

Slum living conditions and child labor were emphasized as basic t causes of crime by Mayor La Guardia and Austin H.MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, at a luncheon held yesterday by t the Public Education Association and forty-five civic, educational and welfare organizations at the Hotel Commodore.

Pittsburgh Plate Glass officials and union leaders conferred today on the differences which led to a strike and made idle more than 13,000 workers who produce about 90 per bent of the industry's flat glass.

The Rev. John LaFarge, Jesuit writer and educator, will speak at a communion breakfast of the Laymen's Union, Catholic interracial group, at 10 A. M. today at the Harlem Y. M. C. A., 180 West 135th Street.
Pope Pius, after having suffered pain and difficulty with breathing during the night, was. visited at 5 A. M. today [11 P. M. Saturday in New York] by Professor Aminta Milani, his physician.

ARCHIBALD GORDON MACDONELL is one British novelist at least whom one cannot accuse of literary fiddling while preparations are going on for what may, unless sanity prevails, turn out to be a bigger and more diabolically disastrous world war than that already waged. "Lords and Masters" is more pungent and, in manner, less insouciant than "England,

AFTER working all through the year 1935 as a sharecropper and discovering at the end of the year that the farm showed a profit of only $2.80 without paying any wages, Stuart David Engstrand gave it up and wrote a novel based upon his experiences. It is to be published on Jan. 25 by Alfred

Gus Mancuso, swarthy-complexioned Italian youth of San Antonio, Texas, who has been the main-stay of Bill Terry's catching department the past four seasons, became the eighth Giant to fall in line yesterday for the 1937 campaign when his signed contract landed on Secretary Eddie Brannick's desk.
A meeting of the Greenwich Committee for the Seeing Eye campaign will be held on Thursday at the home here of Mrs. Prescott Bush, committee chairman.

Joseph H. Oglesby gave a supper dance tonight for Miss Annette Brogden Cheston, daughter of Mrs. Alexander R. Cheston, and for Charles King Lennig Jr., son of Charles King Lennig of Wistaria Cottage, Langhorne, whose engagement was recently announced.

Charles Vere, a French citizen born in Guadeloupe and widely known throughout the West Indies, died last night following a long illness. He was 75 years old. He was decorated with the' Legion of Honor and sent three sons to the World War with the French army.

A meeting to discuss the more pressing real estate problems of the present day will be held at the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday, Jan. 27, under the auspices of the Metropolitan Real Estate Conference Committee.

Please note the gallant golfer as from tee to green he hies, For fun (or doctor's orders) he is taking exercise. His head he carries (rather high), one club (that made the stroke), He also carries matches just in case he wants a smoke. And with the gallant golfer, as he wanders west and east,

Formation of an independent committee of holders of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Huyler's of Delaware, Inc., was announced yesterday by Winston Paul, chairman; John W. Fries, Charles J. Gregory and R. S. Jones.

An official of the Ministry of Finance announced today that three American oil companies had accepted a proposal it had made for thawing about $10,000.000 in frozen credits held by the companies here but which they have not been able to transfer to the United States.

For some months individual members of the Tammany executive committee were heard grumbling that "something ought to be done about it"-meaning the replacement of Tammany Leader James J. Dooling by a man in better health, who could actively direct the organization in one of its most crucial years.

Dr. Tibor de Cholnoky, president of the Hungarian Committee for the Budapest University Chorus, and Mrs. de Cholnoky, who' heads the women's division, entertained with a dinner last night at the Cosmopolitan Club before the first concert of the chorus at Carnegie Hall.

Mrs. Susan Willson Adams Brooks, wife of A. Palmer Brooks, died here suddenly this afternoon of a coronary thrombosis at their home, 225 East Sidney Avenue. She was about 59 years old. A former resident of Manhattan, Mrs. Brooks, until recently, had been president of the Married Woman's Society of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue.

Canada regained the Lapham Cup, emblematic of international squash racquets supremacy, today by defeating the United States, 8-7. in a thrilling series decided on the final of the fifteen-match tournament.

WHEN the post-bellum roimanticists wrote of the old South they insisted upon a background of wholly classical culture. They made their theses coincide perfectly with the traditions of an aristocratic South in which there were only plantations of broad acres presided over by benevolent colonels and their beautiful daughters.

EVEN though Mr. Alfred E. Matthews still insists that he is not photogenic, and that the proficiency of the picture people alarms him, he permitted his two decades of unfaltering devotion to the stages of two hemispheres to be interrupted by the cinema last Summer, and the moment finds him in a typically frivolous mood with Miriam Hopkins in Mr. Korda's "Men Are Not Gods" at the Rivoli.

A tea will be given by Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow at her home, 722 Park Avenue, on Tuesday for Mme. Lotte Lehmann, who will sing the leading role in a special performance of "Die Meistersinger" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Feb. 12 for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York, which each year aids girls from the metropolitan area to continue their studies at Smith.

EVER since the dark days begain an axiom of this business has been that any show must be (1) a quick success (2) a quick failure. When "The Women" opened on Dec. 26 to what could be called at best "mixed notices," it seemed to be headed toward fate No. 1, or worse than death.

Discussing the marked revival during the past year of home building in Bergen County, N. J., and looking ahead to the opportunities of the coming year, J. W. Binder, secretary of the Bergen County Chamber of Commerce, says that the leading builders are predicting that residential construction this year will increase from 65 to 100 per cent over the 1936 volume.

Mrs. Maud K. Royall of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Youle Royall, to Edwin Burns Hinck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Hinck of Montclair, N. J. Miss Royall was graduated from Bradford Junior College, Bradford, Mass., in 1931, and two years later from Connecticut College for Women, New London, Conn. Mr.

Etchings, engravings, and original drawings by old and modern masters, collected by the late William N. Morice of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and by Mrs. Loomis C. Johnson and William Ryle, with additions from other consignors, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening.

About 400 members of the Class of January, 1937, at Hunter College will participate in senior festivities to be held from Jan. 25 to Jan. 29, it was announced yesterday by Alice Kearin, president of the class. A luncheon, tea, theatre party, dance and class night have been planned for the students' last week

With President Roosevelt's second inauguration only a few days distant, with the heat and bitterness of the electoral campaign fast fading into oblivion, many who supported him with an ill grace or with their fingers crossed are now saying that he has changed his ways since the night of Oct. 31, when he breathed threats and vengeance in Madison Square Garden.

During 1936 50 per cent more aliens than in 1935 applied to the Governor in Council for permission to purchase property in Bermuda for residential purposes under the law which requires individual applications before non-Britons can purchase land.

Ohio State University gained its second Western Conference basketball victory tonight, holding the ball for three minutes without attempting a field goal after coming from behind to take a 23-to-22 lead over Minnesota.

A total of 475 students, the majority in upper classes, registered in five courses on modern affairs given by the Departments of History and Government, reveal an increasing interest by Smith College students in current events.

Although Navy showed improvement in its basketball play today and gave Pittsburgh the hardest kind of a fight at all stages of the game, the midshipmen were not quite equal to the task of holding their opponents in check and the Panthers won, 35 to 28.

Business totaling $1,681,200 was transacted by the firm of Frank O'Hara, Inc., of Jackson Heights during 1936. The transactions included the sale of eighty houses for a total of $604,000 and eleven investment properties for $522,200 and apartment and store leases aggregating $525,000.

Prolongation of the teamsters' strike, which has tied up deliveries of school supplies, would confront the city school system with an "acute" situation, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.
" EUROPE in violent turmoil" is a mental image farmliar to most Americans who read the news papers; so familiar that an American can scarcely glance at a map of Europe without fancying

THE new American opera-it will be Edward Johnson's first production of a native work in his two years as manager-should reach the Metropolitan Opera stage in a fortnight. The date will probably be Saturday afternoon, Jan. 30.

Bank of England officials announced today that Sir Otto Niemeyer, one of the bank's directors, who is en route to the United States, would discuss problems of the Foreign Bondholders Association. Informed sources said the negotiations would probably center on defaulted German and South American bonds.

The Judicial Council renewed at Albany last week its recommendation to the Legislature that women shall be authorized to serve as jurors in the courts of New York State. The fate of the recommendation in past sessions has been to be buried in committee. The movement for women on juries has had better success elsewhere.
The Brooklyn-Long Island Club of Fordham College will hold its annual Winter dance at the Hotel Biltmore on Jan. 29, it was announced yesterday by James Joyce, president of the club.

With domestic mill consumption running at the highest rate on record, and manufacturing profits the best in many years, trade buying continued as the outstanding feature in operations yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

Richard H. Noble, a leader in the civic and industrial development of East Hartford, died last night at the age of 65. He was treasurer of the Noble Westbrook Manufacturing Company, which he organized with George Westbrook. It makes metal and rubber stamps.

In behalf of the Italian choral associations in New York an entertainment to be known as the Coro d'Italia Ball will be held the night of Jan. 28 at the Plaza under the auspices of the Italian Embassy and the New York Italian Consulate General.

The bodies of two Massachusetts National Guardsmen whose army observation plane fell into the Illinois River here late Monday night were recovered today when the plane was raised from the bottom of the river.

Assured that the buying wave expected for the last eighteen months is finally under way, machine-tool builders yesterday freely predicted that first-quarter business this year will establish an all-time record for the industry.

Miss Elsie Linde Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto T. Meyer of this town, was married this evening to Richard Chapin Griggs, son of Mrs. John Stillwell Griggs of Salisbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Griggs. The ceremony took place in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Church here, and was performed by the Rev. Luke M. White.

MUSSOLINI has always shown a marked preference for young collaboratory and has never hesitated to throw heavy burdens of hard work and responsibility onto the shoulders of men who in other countries would be considered barely out of their infancy, as far as public life is concerned.

The St. Bonaventure Medal for Catholic Action will be conferred on Patrick F. Scanlan, managing editor of The Brooklyn Tablet, at a testimonial banquet in the Columbus Club, Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, Feb. 7, it was announced by the office of the president at the college.

ALF STEPS OUT: Last week Walter A. Huxman, Democrat, became Governor of Kansas, succeeding Alfred M. Landon, Republican. Mr. Huxman promised to "recognize no political divisions or narrow partisanships" Mr. Landon asserted that "the application of sound business practices to government" had been his administration's achievement.

Announcement has been made by Miss Helen Biggar of Greenwich of the engagement of her niece, Miss Florence Janet Biggar, to F. Gilbert Wheeler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Wheeler of Locust Point, N. Y.

Two new projects at the City College of New York this year are awakening evening session students from their former indifference toward extra-curricular life. One, a cooperative buying organization, provides a large portion of the funds for carrying on the other, a series of semi-weekly socials.

Dr. Kurt Warnow, in whose name Oslo reports indicate that payment of the Nobel Peace Prize, recently awarded to Carl von Ossietzky, was requested, is a Berlin attorney who apparently does not practice. He has no office here and appears in no official register.

THE SPANISH FRONT -- Hard fighting took place on the southern coast after the Rebels succeeded in landing an expedition at Estepona and were pressing on toward Malaga. A second column also advanced. At Madrid the Rebels again attacked the northwestern suburbs of the city, but the Loyalist lines held.

Mrs. W. H. Harkness became last night the first woman to attend an annual dinner of the Explorers Club. She came as official escort of her baby giant panda, Su-Lin, ceremoniously announced as the one and only guest of honor.
Mr. and Mrs. George A. Powers gave a dinner tonight for Dean and Mrs. Arthur B..Kinsolving 2d, Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. St. John, Dr. and Mrs. Stoddard Dooman and Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Weed.
Mr. and Mrs. S. Laurence Bodine of Philadelphia entertained sixteen at luncheon yesterday at their home in Weymouth Heights following the drag hunt with the Moore County hounds.
Among those who will entertain before the premiere tomorrow of "Masque of Kings" for the benefit of the Montclair Junior League's Community House will be Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Perkins of Montclair.

Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L. I., who made a grand slam in all the amateur court tennis fixtures during 1936, forged the first link in another chain of victories today when he won the sixteenth annual Gold Racquet tournament at the Tuxedo Park Racquet and Tennis Club.

The Supreme Court may rule tomorrow on the constitutionality of the Washington law establishing minimum wages for women and on whether the 1933 Congressional resolution prohibiting payment of obligations in gold applied to.bullion as well as to coin.

The Commonwealth Fund made gifts amounting to $1,967,153.26 in 1936, with more than two-thirds of the total going to medical research and the improvement of medical service in rural sections of the country, according to the annual report, made public yesterday.
There is a ray of hope that the threat to several hundred miles of good trout fishing water in the Catskills involved in the construction of the Neversink-Rondout-Delaware reservoirs will be averted.

Mrs..Kate Berg, a leader in the work of several Jewish philanthropic societies and wife of William Berg, head of the Criterion Shirt Band Company, died Saturday in the Royal Hospital, Bronx, of pneumonia, at the age of 40. She resided at 3,205 Country Club Road, Bronx.

Trade journals declare that the weakening of the grain market since the end of 1936 represents reaction after the activity of the preceding months, and that a shortage of tonnage has created a false impression as to the condition of the market.

Direction of the intellectual and spiritual growth of youth is the most neglected phase of Jewish education, Dr. Samuel M. Blumenfield of Chicago said today in discussing "Youth Education" at the joint convention here of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Affiliated National Temple Sisterhoods and Brotherhoods.
C. Douglass Buck will retire Tuesday from the office of Governor of Delaware, after having served two full terms.

The German trade delegation that has been in Vienna for a month, trying at intervals to negotiate a new Austro-German commercial treaty, came to Semmering today and was entertained by the Austrian trade delegation.
The week's stock market here was dull, with little change in the general level, although there were considerable differences among movements in the several major groups.

Boston's durableBruins blasted the Americans' dream of a victory string at Madison Square Garden last night. The sharpshooting Massachusetts sextet, flashing a speedy, heads-up brand of hockey, beat Lorne Chabot once in each period to register a 3-0 triumph over the hapless New York six.
Three residents of Poughkeepsie were killed and three seriously injured when their automobile crashed into the rear of a tractor-trailer on the Albany Post Road near Staatsburg early today.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The great lessons Jesus taught and the authority with which He spoke were attributed to the "great subjects" He chose by the Very Rev. Dr. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in his sermon yesterday morning.
Cole L. Blease, former South Carolina Governor and United States Senator, married Mrs. Carolina Floyd Knott today at the home of the bride's parents here.

The Papco Rible Club of Paterson won the Middle Atlantic indoor rifle championship at the Essex Troop armory today, compiling a total of 1,119 to finish four points in front of the Brooklyn Edison team, which competed yesterday.

Casper Oimoen of Anaconda, Mont., a member of the United States Olympic ski team, won the Norge Ski Club tournament at Fox River Grove today. The finish was so close it took several hours before the officials could announce the results.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood, on Jan. 13, at 80.7, compared with 79.3 a fortnight before, 77.8 on Dec. 9, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Fifty graduates of the Groton School and their families gathered yesterday morning at the St. Thomas Chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, 230 East Sixtieth Street, for the third annual Groton family reunion service.
The House Judiciary Committee will take up on Tuesday a bill to give Supreme Court justices retirement privileges under which six of the nine present members would be eligible immediately.

J. Frank Harper, former State Senator from Queen Annes County and for the last seventeen years a member of the Public Service Commission, died today in the Union Memorial Hospital. His age was 67. He had been suffering from arthritis for several months.

The nomination of the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot, minister of Unity Unitarian Church of St. Paul, as president of the American Unitarian Association, executive body of the Unitarian churches of the United States and Canada, was announced today by the Rev. Charles E. Snyder, acting board chairman.

Richard Boleslawski, motion-picture direotor for the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios, died at his home here today after a heart attack at the age of 47. He had been in apparently good health when he returned to his home from the studio last night.

W. F. Knox, with 89--21--68, led thirty entrants in the eighth and final qualifying round of the twentyeighth annual snobirds' golf tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club today. Jerome Thralls was second among the ten who turned in scores with 87--16--71.

Problems in the establishment of a permanent housing program for New York State were discussed yesterday afternoon at the closing session of a two-day State legislativ conference at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, under the auspices of the Trade Union Institute.

With the midyear examination period at the Washington Square center of New York University beginning today, only one woman student out of some 8,500 will be permitted to substitute an oral examination for the customary written one.

Oats supplies are the smallest in recent years, particularly those held on farms. Consumptive requirements on account of feeding operations in the country are heavier than usual and processors are also using more oats than in average years.

Electrification of farms, often remote from electrical inspectors, is creating a new field of fire hazards. This was among the reports at the annual midwinter directors' meeting of the National Fire Protection Association, closing here tonight. All lines of business and industry in the United States and Canada were represented.

Discussing organized labor from New York City pulpits yesterday, one minister declared the church should help labor fight its battles for equity and justice in the American way and another described the General Motors strike as part of a general adjustment between employer and employee.

Townsend and Townsend, Inc., advertising specialists, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Times Metal Specialty Corp., in 128 Bleaker St.; Del-Mar Hat Co., in 28 W. 38th St.; Benjamin Schwartz. in 45 E. 20th St.; Harry Underwieser, in 100 5th Av.:
George Shouse, 27, died today, the innocent victim of a mountain mother's attempt to avenge the murder of her son.

Hundreds of prisoners in the Ontario Reformatory rioted tonight, fought off guards and city and provincial police for hours and wrecked the interior of the big gray prison. Before the rioting was quelled, the convicts held the prison building.
Robert Van Arsdale Norris of 108 East Thirty-sixth Street and Wilkes-Barre, Pa., a consulting mining engineer, died yesterday in the New York Hospital of heart disease at the age of 42.

The fifty-four fellows of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences announced yesterday their award of the Sylvanus Albert Reed Medal for 1936 to Professor Edward S. Taylor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The text of the French Government's reply to Great Britain's appeal to prohibit volunteers for Spain was published here tonight.

John Clayton Haldeman, an operative builder here for more than half a century before his retirement, died yesterday in his eightyfifth year. He was a former president and a former historian of the 150-year-old Master Bricklayers Company of Philadelphia.

A. L. Loomis of Omaha died in a Glendale hospital today, the third fatality of the transport airplane crash Tuesday near Newhall, about twenty miles from here. The other victims were Martin Johnson, explorer, and James A. Braden of Cleveland.

American Catholics owe a missionary debt to Europe which must be paid back in funds and in missionary priests, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared yesterday morning at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

-Terre Haute, scene of a paralyzing general strike with martial law a year and a half ago, was without street car or bus service today as employes of the Indiana Railroad struck for a 20 per cent increase in wages.
Penn A. C. gained its fifth straight Eastern athletic club basketball victory by beating the Crescent A. C. of Brooklyn today, 29-16. It was also the eighth in a row for the Penn quintet.

F. C. Ogden of Baltimore led the first group of qualifiers in the Miami Biltmore invitation amateur golf tournament today. He turned in a card of 37, 42-79. Only eight teed off and for the first time the new rule adopted by the United States Golf Association providing

Scribner's report that "Of Lena Geyer," Marcia Davenport's novel of the musical world, is now in its eighth large printing. Sir James G. Frazer's supplementary volume to "The Golden Bough" will be published by Macmillan early in March under the title of "Aftermath."

David W. Haynes, a retired theatre and company manager, who had worked for George C. Tyler, B. C. Whitney and other producers, died yesterday in the Knickerbocker Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 81.
The trial of nine men charged with conspiracy and extortion as part of a $2,000,000 a year restaurant shakedown racket will begin today before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Scoring its third sweep of the season today, the Montclair Athletic Club maintained its tie for first place with the Englewood Field Club in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. The two leaders are scheduled to clash next Sunday.
Johnny Skillman, Yale coach, captured his fourth national professional squash racquets championship today by defeating Ben Pope of Pittsburgh in their four-game final.
To the New Amsterdam Theatre last night, in honor of Daniel Frohman and his Actors Fund, went all of Broadway for which there was room on either side of the footlights of that capacious house.

Fire loses In New York in 1936 were the lowest in twenty-one years, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott reported yesterday to Mayor La Guardia. The loss for 1936 was $7,723,630, a decrease of $1.007,935 under the 1935 total. The per capital loss was $1.05, the lowest in twenty-six years and ten cents less than the 1935 loss.

Cash and security restitutions amounting to $264,706 were effected in 1936 by the New York City office of the State Bureau of Securities, according to the annual report of the bureau made public yesterday.
Suffering from stab wounds, two young men who said they had come from Cincinnati for a vacation in New York, were taken to Bellevue Hospital early yesterday.
Effects of suspensions of steel shipments to the General Motors Corporation and other consumers affected by labor difficulties have been negligible, according to the magazine Steel.

A campaign for fair trade legislation will be started at a luncheon on Feb. 4 in the Hotel.Astor, according to an announcement by William A. Hollingsworth, president of the Allied Retail Federation of New York State.

President Roosevelt's second administration, providing another world war can be avoided, will be devoted to reorganizing the capitalistic system in an effort to make it profitable and just and the people happy within the old order, John Haynes Holmes predicted in his sermon yesterday morning at the Community Church, Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

The securities markets here, while displaying some hesitancy, show no real loss of vitality. There are too few new industrial profit and dividend statements at the moment to give any fresh stimulus to industrial securities, although the commodity groups of securities do not lack for stirring and helpful incidents.

The general feeling here has been much better this week. In fact the market had not been seriously disturbed by the alarming rumors about Spanish Morocco, which were received with caution in financial circles.

The first team of the Loantaka Skeet Club, shooting on its own field, today won the Middle Atlantic team championship and a leg on the Bushmill Trophy, up for the first time this year. The competition took place during a steady downpour.

After a day spent hunting in the company of King Victor Emmanuel at Castel Porziano, where Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano did and Premier Mussolini did not put in an appearance, Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, had a brief impromptu talk with Mussolini at the Palazzo Venezia late this afternoon.

Columbia's first defeat in the Eastern League in two seasons shared the spotlight with the continued success of Long Island University and Manhattan in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles during the past week.

A speeding automobile containing at least two persons plunged into forty-five feet of water early this morning at an open bridge over the Hackensack River on the Lincoln Highway between Kearny and Jersey City.

Ft. Washington Av., 100, n. e. cor. 163d St., 1022x121; Hudson Rock Realties, Inc., and Samuel Gersten. president, to Brewater Properties, Inc., 295 Madison Av.; prior mortgage $230,000, 6 per cent, $15,000.

State Representative Billy Barrett, author of a liberalized divorce bill, announced today a determination to put Georgia in competition with Reno for the nation's divorce trade. He said that in addition to his legislative proposal he would seek a constitutional amendment to make divorce easy.
A fine of $50 was imposed on. Theodore Mack, 43 years old, of 59-23 Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, Queens, by Magistrate Anthony Savarese in Flushing, Queens,

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.7, which compares with 90.1 the week before, 88.8 two weeks before, 87.9 three weeks before and 87.3 four weeks before.

Two museum exhibitions head a varied list of new attractions this week in the art galleries. Tomorrow the Whitney Museum of American Art will initiate a showing of its recent acquisitions in painting, prints and sculpture, together with a selection of water-colors from the permanent collection.
The Board of Trade's index number of wholesale British prices in December, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 100.8, compared with 98.3 for the preceding month and 91.5 for December, 1935.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions HOWARD CO., INC., jewelers, 18 E. 56th St.-Involuntary proceedings filed by creditors under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $22,558 and assets of $6,841. Petitions Filed--By JOHN ANTHONY CANCRO, restaurant manager, North Tarrytown,--Liabilities $26,531, assets $2,996. GEORGE KREUTER, plumber, 230 E. 78th St.--Liabilities $3,406, assets $145. NICHOLAS HESS, manager, 320 W. 34th St--Liabilities $9,882. no assets.

Geprges Bonnet, newly appointed special Ambassador to the United States, in an address before a Radical Socialist meeting at Bordeaux tonight said that the fear of a European war was the only obstacle now to world economic recovery.
The fate of a thousand refugees under the protection of the Chilean Embassy in Madrid will be decided within the next few days, according to reports received here.

Yeichi Nimura, Japanese dancer who has been absent from New York for the last five years touring the Old World from Scandinavia to Egypt, returned last night with a recital at the Guild Theatre assisted by his American partner, Lisan Kay.

Ann Harding, now appearing in a provincial tour of Shaw's "Candida" prior to a London opening next month, was married today at Caxton Hall Registrar's Office to Werner Janssen, American symphony conductor and composer.

The Nicaragua canal has been with us since the days of the Forty-niners. Engineers hoped at the beginning of the century that it had received its quietus when it was decided to cut through the Panama Canal.

Jay Begtrup, 45 years old, was found dead in his repair shop at 523 Tonnele Avenue today of carbon monoxide poisoning. The body was in the front seat of an automobile, the engine of which was still running.
The Indians traded Joe Vosmik, Bill Knickerbocker and Oral Hildebrand to the Browns for Julius Solters, Lyn Lary and Ivy Paul Andrews tonight. C. C. Slapnicka, head of the Indians' business office,

When December's figures on Brazilian cotton exports are released it is considered they likely will show outward shipments at close to 1,000,000 bales, valued at about 1,000,000 contos, for the entire year, a gain of 300,000 contos over 1935.
Fort Washington Av., 100, n. e. cor. of 163d St., 102x142x99.11x-121; Lawyers Title and Guarantee Co. and another, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., as trustee, 115 Bway; mtg., $226,100.

A new era in airplane comfort will open tomorrow when the first of a fleet of extra-fare luxury airliners will leave Newark Airport for Chicago. The passenger equipment is the nearest thing to a railroad club car yet devised, according to an announcement by United Air Lines, sponsors.

Eight thousand workers in Philadelphia's 150 dress and blouse factories have received general strike orders and are preparing to leave their jobs within the next forty-eight hours, according to officers of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Assemblyma Moffat, New York Republican, announced tonight that he would submit to the Legislature a new minimum wage bill which "approaches the problem and reaches the desired result from a new angle."

Representatives of the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs gathered yesterday afternoon on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, at Wall and Nassau Streets, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States.

Despite a heavy downpour, more than a score of persons, including the local Assemblyman and Alderman as well as representatives of organizations interested in the improvement of the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, turned out yesterday afternoon to inspect a new streamlined trolley car.

Only a passing reference to the church among the forces for crime prevention was made at the Public Education Association luncheon on Saturday when a movement was launched to prevent juvenile delinquency, the Rev. Francis H. Craighill Jr., assistant minister of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, complained in his sermon yesterday morning.

A denunciation of a large section of the London press is expressed in a letter printed on the editorial page of The Times today, written by William E. D. Allen, husband of the former Paula Gellibrand, whose visit to a phrenologist with the Duke of Kent three weeks ago caused a newspaper sensation.
Scorning extra guards, Governor E. W. Marland went about his routine today, ignoring the threats in a $5,000 extortion letter delivered at his executive offices yesterday.

Most of. Manhattan's garbage will be turned into electricity that the city expects to sell at a profit when the new PWA-financed incinerator at Fifty-sixth Street and Twelfth Avenue is put into operation, Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, announced yesterday.
Igor Stravinsky concluded the first half of his engagement as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at yesterday afternoon's concert at Carnegie Hall.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Jaeger of Denville, N. J., have arrived at their new home, Happy Landing, at Cable Beach, for the season.

Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands of the West Point Fencing Club, holder of the national epee title in 1935 and a member of of last year's team champions, yesterday captured the Leo Nunes gold medal by triumphing in the senior epee competition with electrical scoring apparatus at the Salle Santelli.

Delivery terms for steel again have been lengthened. Output of pig iron in Germany in December was 1,258,400 tons. Average production for each working day declined. For all of 1936, output reached 15,303,100 tons, against 12.539,400 tons in 1935.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Bradshaw of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Cisneros Bradshaw, to Benjamin Evans Billings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver C. Billings, also of Morristown.
Great Brit ain's foreign trade in 1936 has followed with increased emphasis the trend that has been noticeable for at least three years.

At the organization's monthly meeting here today, the Young Republicans of New Jersey adopted a resolution asking the Republican-controlled State Senate to open to the public its proposed investigation of the election of William C. Hunt as Senator from Cape May County.
Walter B. Switzer, 35-year-old Hasbrouck Heights (N. J.) aviator, died here late tonight of internal injuries suffered when his plane crashed today at North Walpole, N. H.

Trapped in a converted residence without fire-escapes and with iron bars over the ground-floor windows, a graduate nurse lost her life, another was critically injured, four other persons were less seriously hurt, and several were rescued under spectacular circumstances when fire swept part of the nurses' home of the Israel Zion Hospital in Brooklyn early yesterday.

The world-wide rise in commodity prices is the result of various factors. Its basis was laid four years ago, when nearly all commodity producers worked at considerable losses and hand-to-mouth buying reduced consumers' stocks to a minimum.
Asserting that rapidly increasing populations of Germany, Italy and Japan are a menace to peace because of the "inevitable need" for territrial expansion,

The first wheel chair race held here was a feature of the day at the Everglades Club. Breasting the finish in a tie were the teams of George Kamir and Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle of New York, and Alexander Hess of Philadelphia and Miss Lillian Feitner of New York.

Stirred by the brutal killing of Mrs. Mary H. Case in Queens a week ago, Alderman A. Newbold Morris announced yesterday that he would work for laws requiring hotel and apartment house employes to be fingerprinted.

Nation wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 80 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and compared with an average of 79 per cent last November, the high month in the movement.

Arthur Potterton, director of revenue and finance of Jersey City, has announced the receipt of bids from various New York and Jersey City banking institutions covering commitments from them to the municipality for current budget financing on tax-anticipation notes of 1937 in the amount of $3,500,000.
A man committed suicide in Central Park, near the center drive opposite Sixty-second Street, about 8 A. M. yesterday by shooting himself through the head with a revolver.
Negotiations between the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company and union representatives, headed by Philip Murray, continued tonight,
The maritime Commission has called on the American shipping industry to aid in re-establishing a commercial sovereignty of the seas through designing better ships at lower cost.

Brilliant little Larry Aurie and sharpshooting Marty Barry continued their close fight for National Hockey League scoring honors tonight, each counting a goal to give Detroit's high-flying Red Wings a 2-0 decision over the Chicago Black Hawks before 13,000 spectators.

Citing his belief in the principles of the American Civil Liberties Union, the Rev. L. Hamilton Garner, whose contract as a pastor of the Universalist Church of the Redeemer here was terminated last Tuesday by a majority vote of the congregation, based his sermon today in the church on "The Rights of Man."

Following refusal of sit-in strikers in Flint, Mich., yesterday to evacuate plants, General Motors called off the scheduled conference set for today between its officers and the United Automobile Workers of America.

Atlantic City clinched the first-half championship of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight by defeating Baltimore, 4 to 2, in overtime. The Sea Gulls scored twice in the last minute of the extra period.

Zisha Landau, poet, writer and Yiddish director of the department of public information of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, died of a heart attack on Saturday night at Ninety-fifth Street and Broadway. He was 46 years old and lived at 321 West Ninety-fourth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Foley of Kenyon Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Foley, to Theodore Leroy Chamberlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Chamberlin of Glastonbury.

The current week's decline of [pound]7,655,000-in the circulation of the Bank of England, although large, was no greater than expected in view of the exceptionally big rise in circulation which occurred in December, while it was only slightly under the fall in the corresponding week of last year.
Striking members of the gas employes union granted a request of gas company officials today for increased emergency workers to assure normal service to Toledo during the strike.

A fatal stabbing in a ballroom where 1,500 persons had gathered for a testimonial dinner caused the police to isolate the Manhattan Opera House at 321 West Thirtyfourth Street, west of Eighth Avenue, last night, while they searched for the participants.
The Colombian sugar industry is threatened with complete ruin by a cane plant disease, "mosaic," a fungus growth that discolors the leaves in a form of mosaic.

The repercussions of the startling footracing feats of the incomparable Jesse Owens last year reached out yesterday to the All-America track and field team for 1936 when the fastest of all human beings was named for four places in the annual compilation of Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union.

Egbert Moxham Jr. won three out of four races in Class B onedesign in today's Frostbite racing. Allan Clark nosed Leonard Romagna out of the day's top score in Class D by a single point. The races were sailed in a light easterly breeze and smooth water.

The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching concluded in a 182-page public report here yesterday that it is the present world-wide problem of organized education "to avoid the emergency of educated proletariats with the tragedies that' have been witnessed in Europe as the-direct results of overcrowding in certain professions."

Harold Albin, a chauffeur, turned lawyer for a couple of days last week, drew up an application for a writ of habeas corpus and obtained his release from Sing Sing prison Wednesday on the ground he was being detained illegally beyond his term for forgery.

The report of the Railway and Light Securities Company for 1935 showed net assets of $11,706,039 on Dec. 31, with securities based on market quotations on that date, after allowance for possible normal Federal income tax if the indicated appreciation were realized.
Estate properties in Connecticut that have been held by the sellers' families for more than a century passed to new control in deals announced over the week-end.

Because of the freezing temperature Iast week the Danube River is becoming increasingly dangerous to shipping, ice drifting constantly downstream from the source. Boats have been brought to Winter harbors near Braila and Giurguo.

The subsidence of excitement over Morocco and improved prospects for a nonintervention agreement in the Spanish situation failed to reanimate the week's security market here, which remained dull, with reactions predominating.

With the number of employed married women steadily growing, advertisers of feminine and home products should in the future give more attention to them as a market and less to the housewives, according to comment here. Because of the preponderant attention given to the latter class, many advertisers have been making serious mistakes in their media selection, it was pointed out.
Queen Mary will attend the coronation of her son King George VI on May 12, thereby setting a precedent, reliable informants said tonight.
" Of One Mother," the new offering at the downtown National the Theatre, is a revision of a play by Samuel H. Cohen, "Her Golden Dream," previously produced by Miss Jennie Goldstein.

Sixteen government agencies awarded eightyfour contracts valued at $3,298,405 under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Thursday, the Department of Labor announced today. Of these, nearly one-fourth were awarded to concerns in New York State.

There seems to be an unusual amount of confusion and heartburn this year in connection with invitations to President ROOSEVELT'S inauguration. More tban one man accustomed to taking his place among the seats of the mighty has exhibited his hurt feelings.

Sam Snead, lean mountaineer. from West Virginia, shot a final parsmashing 67 to win the %5,000 Oakland open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 270 today. The 24-year-old shot-master, who learned the game as a caddie and turned professional only three
The twelfth season of the New York Chamber Music Society, founded by Miss Carolyn Beebe, who is pianist of the organization, began last night with a concert at the Plaza.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,572,788,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

In basketball and hockey, on the rink and on the court, There are found official bounders of a most annoying sort; Men who atop a dashing winger or a forward on the run With a shrill, officious whistle calling halt to all the fun.
The general view of the market here on the suspension of the copper-restriction plan is that a wise decision has been reached.

Statisticians in the United States and in Canada and other foreign countries are presenting what is considered by many in the trade as the greatest array of figures for bullishness in wheat that ever has been known.

The railroads have contributed to business recovery, although they have been confronted with "formidable" competition from other agencies of transport, J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, told the Central Railroad Club of Buffalo at its recent annual meeting.

Harold Nathan took charge yesterday of a swiftly mobilized search in this area for the Charles Mattson kidnap-killer, it was said in an official source early today. It was added that the Federal officials were in possession of the kidnapper's fingerprints and that his identity was known.

Mrs. Ida Jessie Walker Riggs, widow of the Rev. Charles B. Riggs, a home missionary of the Congregational Church, died here last night of a heart ailment in the Home for Incurables. She was in her eightieth year.

Dr. Frederick Gardener Cottrell of Washington, who perfected a process that lowered the cost of helium gas from $1,700 to 10 cents a cubic foot, has been chosen to receive the Washington Award, an engineering honor. for 1937.
Six young members of All Souls Universalist Church, Ocean and Ditmas Avenues, Brooklyn, conducted the morning services yesterday, commemorating National Youth Sunday.
Harry Atkinson will be guest of honor at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore today to observe his promotion to general New England agent of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

Retarded by stubborn opposition on the part of B. Sundberg, his Swedish opponent, Reuben Fine of New York, representing the United States in the international chess masters tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club, failed to make any gain in the second round today, inasmuch as his game stood adjourned after a prolonged struggle lasting sixty moves.
Colonel and Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby of New York were the guests tonight at dinner at the Egyptian Legation, at which Mrs. I. Said Zulfikar, the wife of the attache, was hostess.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Harry Fromkes, president of the City Title Insurance Company, 42 Broadway, has announced that the company has been qualified for business by the State Insurance Department. The concern, which received its charter in 1929, plans branches at 44 Court Street, Brooklyn, and 9,034 161st Street, Jamaica.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, the Atlanta giantkiller, won his second successive tennis final from Donald Budge, the nation's No. 1 ranking amateur, by defeating the Oakland, Calif., ace, 4--6, 6--3, 6--3, 2--6, 6--2, in the Dixie tournament today.

Robert D. Carey, former United States Senator and Governor of Wyoming, died suddenly here tonight. He was a Republican. He was defeated for re-election last November by Harry H. Schwartz, Democrat. Death came while Mr. Carey was at the home of his late brother, Charles D. Carey. He had business interests in Cheyenne.

Changes in the penal law to permit the disposition of minor offenses in the magistrates' courts were suggested yesterday by James J. Wilson, assistant District Attorney in charge of prosecutions in Special Sessions court.

The engagement of Miss Agnes Forshew Schlegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Schlegel Jr. of Scarsdale, N. Y., to Herbert Spencer Gardner Jr., son of Herbert S. Gardner,' also of Scarsdale, and the late Mrs. Gardner, has been announced by her parents.
The statement of the Bank of France dated Jan. 8 shows a decline of 1,340,000,000 francs in the item of bills discounted, due to the collection of bills matured at the end of December.

An open letter calling on Congress to extend the Trade Agreements Act as a contribution to peace, was made public here yesterday over the signatures of 1,000 leaders in business, education, banking and religion.

The United States was invited today by the Egyptian Government, through United States Minister Bert Fish, to appoint delegates to the Montreux conference April 12 to conclude an agreement between Egypt and the powers enjoying extraterritorial rights for revision of the extraterritorial regime here.

Gains by all divisions in the finance section of the United Hospital Campaign in amounts raised this year as compared with last were reported last night by Stuart M. Croker, general chairman of the campaign.

With his foot on the gas and his hand on the horn, a taxi driver raced down Madison Avenue from Forty-fifth Street to Thirty-first Street shortly before 7 o'clock last night in a futile effort to attract the attention of the police to a holdup. man who was beating his victim in a back seat of the taxi.
With half an inch of rainfall recorded at 10 o'clock last night, the Weather Bureau predicted continued rain throughout the night, with occasional light rains today and possibly rain tomorrow.
ALLAN NEVINS has all kinds of nice things to say about the Dictionary of American Biography in his survey of

Hilaire Belloc, novelist, critic and historian, will join the faculty of the Fordham University Graduate School for the Spring semester, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

Mrs. James Roosevelt will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 47 East Sixty-fifth Street, for members of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the Birthday Ball to be held the night of Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria to mark President Roosevelt's fifty-fifth birthday.

Referring to the Case and Mattson murders, the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, told his congregation in a sermon last night that those crimes "have recently startled America into a vivid consciousness as to the possible bestiality of man." Dr. Reisner added:

Charles H. Wanzer has been reelected president of the Dominican Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Evan E. Young will serve as vice president and Harry G. Vollmer as treasurer, while Christian Lugo will continue as secretary.

A suspicious fire in a five-story tenement at 495 East 167th Street, the Bronx, routed twenty tenants about 3 A. M. yesterday. The blaze, however, was confined to a hallway, where it started. The damage was slight.

The Detroit Edison Company reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $10,670,592 after all expenses, charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $8.39 a share on the 1,272,260 capital shares of $100 par value outstanding.

Under a reorganized course at the Divinity School of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Philadelphia students will be required to spend at least three months of each year in practical work in hospitals and prisons and with social service agencies and other institutions, it was announced today.

The prices of cattle and hogs here were on the downgrade most of last week, with the finish about at the bottom. At the same time, fat lambs were in active demand and closed at higher prices. Supplies of all livestock were ample for requirements.

A collection of early editions by American and English authors showing the modern treatment of the legends about King Arthur has been presented to the Princeton University Library by Mrs. William Pitman Earle Jr. of Brooklyn, it was announced today by Dr. James Thayer Gerould, librarian.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity last week were more diversified than in the preceding week and for larger amounts. The payment dates, as in the previous week, were generally for future months, only small lots of municipals being posted for January.

Halsted L. Ritter, removed last year as South Florida Federal District judge, said tonight that he was appealing to the United States Supreme Court "to tell the Senate a judge is entitled to the same basic liberties as any other human being."

L. L. Perrin, advertising manager of the Northern Pacific Railway, was elected president of the American Association of Railway Advertising Agents at the annual meeting of the organization in Washington, it was announced here.

Financial circles here do not understand the meaning of President Roosevelt's new plans and the evolution of United States policy but are still confident in the soundness of the United State's recovery.
General Francisco Franco pledged he would keep "Spain for the Spaniards" in an interview published today by The London Daily Mail.

America has "gone gambling mad," with churches among the offenders, Dr. Charles Francis Potter declared yesterday morning before the First Humanist Society, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street. He continued:

A few minutes after a man had been held up near McLean and Central Avenues early this morning, eleven police radio cars surrounded the vicinity and the patrolmen of one of the cars captured three suspects an hour later.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, dined by invitation last night at the French Embassy with Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet, newly returned from Paris, where he had long conferences not only with his own chief

Some light on the mystery of how Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, is financing rearmament is available in the chapter on Germany in the League of Nations' Year Book, "Balances of Payments in 1935."

Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras headed the Turkish delegation that left for Geneva yesterday for the meeting of the League of Nations Council next Thursday, when the status of the autonomous Sanjak [district] of Alexandretta will be examined.

The medical advisory board of Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, announced yesterday that the institution had received a threeyear grant of $10,000 annually from the Commonwealth Fund for research into the rheumatic heart disease of childhood.

Quite unexpectedly, this season bee has acquired a new candidate: las "Glory for All," by Nat Perrin, to be staged by Frank Craven and presented by (though not with) George Jessel, who avers that he represents "a group of comedians." List it, tentatively, for the week of Feb. 22.

While preparing to heat a bottle of milk for her 4-month-old daughter, youngest of her four children, Mrs. Maryon Robinson, 29 years old, was asphyxiated early today in the kitchen of her home at 370 Oak Street here.

Mrs. Virginia Snyder, 33 years old, of 27 Allison Avenue, was injured seriously and her husband, John Snyder, also 33, suffered minor bruises and shock when they were struck by a McLean Avenue trolley car about 7 o'clock tonight in front of 295 McLean Avenue.

Labor's Nonpartisan League. stated today that representatives of employes at the Bayonne plants of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Tide Water Oil Company had agreed to discuss unionization under the auspices of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The statement of ARTHUR E. MORGAN, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, printed in yesterday's TIMES, is a model of what a state paper should be.

Queenie Adams, who came from Fort Myers, Fla., eleven years ago to cook in the household of Thomas A. Edison and became a favorite of the family not only for her culinary accomplishments but for her cheerful disposition, died among her home folks last Tuesday, according to word received here today.

The onus for subsidizing and proselyting in many college athletic circles was placed on organized alumni groups rather than on coaches today by William J. Bingham, Harvard athletic director, in his annual report to President James Bryant Conant.

Mrs. Elsa Hemberger Guttman, 53 years old, president of the Boonton Woman's Club and former principal of St. John's School, a private institution in Mountain Lakes, committed suicide last night by hanging herself with a clothes line from a rafter in the attic of her home at 258 Rockaway Avenue, Boonton Park. According to the police, no note was left.

A majority of the membership of the Textile Fabrics Associationboth in numbers and in volume of business-have approved and accepted the clause to be used on sales contracts and orders for future deliveries covering all-cotton fabrics and cotton-and-rayon mixture fabrics the chief value of which is cotton (finished goods), as recommended by the tax committee of the association.

Cotton prices last week fluctuated within a relatively narrow range to which they had kept in the preceding four weeks. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected advances of only 1 to 5 points in the period.
The Department of Commerce has reported that business and industry in the Hawaiian Islands registered substantial improvements in 1936.

Governor CURLEY of Massachusetts had a heart that beat warmly for "the boys." He crowded the departments with them. Civil service rules were made to be broken. His successor, Governor HURLEY, has notified heads of departments that henceforth appointments to classified posts must be made from the list of eligibles.

At least 100 persons, it was estimated, died when they were trapped in a disastrous fire that swept through coaches of a Canton-Hongkong train yesterday. More than fifty persons are said to have been injured.

Karl D. Hesley, State Director of the National Youth Administration, announced yesterday that funds totaling a little more than $51,000 a month had been allotted for the second three-month period in the State, exclusive of New York City, for the administration's student aid program.

John J. Cain, former Mayor of Bayonne, died today at his home, 777 Avenue C, at the age of 76. He was elected Mayor on the regular Democratic ticket in 1909 for a two-year term but was defeated when he sought re-election on an independent ticket in 1911.
Frank Krimszal, 28 years old, of 33 East Eleventh Street, Linden, died at the Elizabeth General Hospital today of injuries he received when a five-foot portable gasoline tank exploded yesterday.

Charles H. Jennings of Miami Beach won the eighteen-hole medal play handicap competition of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Country Club today. He had a net score of 66.
Net assets of the Adams Express Company on Dec. 31, 1936, were $51,226,621, an increase of $14,066,367 over Dec. 31, 1935, according to the annual report to stockholders.
Gordon Kingsley, brother of the lost American airman, E. W. Kingsley, was reported missing tonight as nine United States Army planes searched fruitlessly for the latter.
A new incident on the border between Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia, with which Russia has a mutual assistaace pact, was reported tonight by Tass, the Russian news agency.
Three women and a man who had

Recent events in some of the European countries have given the people here a renewed appreciation of democracy, the Rev. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said last night at a public meeting at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 122d Street and Broadway.
Mrs. John W. Converse of Rosemont, known as an accomplished horsewoman, was injured seriously yesterday afternoon while riding with the Radnor Hunt Club on the Nelson estate near Paoli.

The game between the New York American soccer team and the German-Hungarians at Starlight Park was called after fifteen minutes of play in the second half yesterday on account of rain, with the Americans leading, 4 to 0.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Anne Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip N. Curtis of Worcester, Mass., to Julian Curtiss Pease, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Pease of New Britain, took place yesterday in the Central Congregational Church. Worcester. The Rev. Dr.
All the activity on the Madrid front last night and today was concentrated in University City, where government troops again exploded a heavy charge of dynamite under a part of the Clinical Hospital.

The New York Rovers played before 15,108 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, but despite this loyal setting, spent a highly uncomfortable sixty minutes. For the Hershey hockey team seemed never more fit and never more determined to win. which it did by the score of 8 to 2.

The Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine of the Department of Agriculture today recommended continuation of the gypsy moth control work now being carried on by the Civilian Conservation Corps in New England.

Twenty sailing dinghies competed in a cold and rainy regatta today off the Larchmont Yacht Club, the fleet being divided equally between Class B One-Design and Class X boats. Only three races were held and Corny Shields won all of them in his B craft, Prudence.
Tattooing of poultry by New Jersey State Police having proved effective in recovering stolen chickens, the practice may be adopted by members of the New Jersey Beekeepers' Association.
Alfred E. Smith, determined to forget politics for a while, said today that his idea of a good time just now is a nice long walk, a swim and sleep.

Mrs. Frank H. Gunther will give a luncheon Saturday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Audrey Hobbs, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Hobbs. Mrs. Mather Cleveland will give a luncheon tomorrow at Sherry's.
Captain George S. C. Swinton, authority on Scottish heraldry, was found dead today in his London residence. He was 77.

Frank J. Marshall, former chess champion of the United States, met A. Edward Santasiere, club champion, yesterday in the third round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club and, after a session of 40 moves, play was adjourned, with honors practically even and indicative of an eventual draw when carried to a conclusion.

A suggestion that an appeal be made to Governor Lehman by interested residents to stop the proposed construction of the Storm King Highway by-pass, linking the highway to a point near Cornwall, was made yesterday by the Garden Club of America.

An influenza wave which is assuming the proportions of a mild epidemic has crippled production on every lot. Yesterday morning several units with ailing members called a halt to allow players and crews to rest over the week-end in the hope that shooting can resume tomorrow.

Active field operations fdr soil conservation were concluded in ten areas last year, and will cease in about seventy-five more areas by July, the Soil Conservation Service reported today. More than 550 control projects are in operation in fortythree States.

The Seventy-fifth Congress has been in session less than a fortnight, but during this short period three state papers of more than usual significance have defined the policies of the Roosevelt Administration on three highly important points.

A lecture tour under the auspices of the National Public Housing Conference will be made in principal cities of the East by Captain Richard L. Reiss, British housing expert, scheduled to arrive here tomorrow on the Berengaria.

The appointment of Jacques Stueckgold as visiting Professor of Voice Culture at City College, beginning with the February term, was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president. Professor Stueckgold is expected from Europe tomorrow.

The mightiest and most impressive arm of Britain's sea power will set out for the troubled waters of the Mediterranean tomorrow when the vessels of the Home Fleet steam from the harbors of Portsmouth, Devonport, Sheerness and Chatham for the annual manoeuvres.
A 63 year-old unemployed orchard worker set out today to spend within the next month $200 awarded to him in the first practical experiment of the Townsend pension plan.

St. Francis Prep swimmers gained major honors in the annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association individual swimming championships at the Columbus Club pool in Brooklyn yesterday, capturing five of the eight titles at stake.

Although Governor Lehman in the last two weeks had granted executive clemency to seven out of ten slayers sentenced to die in the electrio chair, Sing Sing records for the last twenty-two years show that he has exercised that power 6.6 per cent fewer times than the average of his predecessors.

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $3,000,000 of City of Providence, R. L, 2 1/4 per cent bonds by a banking group headed by Dick Merle-Smith, and including Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., Spencer Trask Co., Bacon, Stevenson Co., Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc., Gregory Son, Inc., Equitable Securities Corporation and Robinson, Miller Co.

Governor Frank Murphy announced at his home here early today that he would reopen negotiations to settle the General Motors strike at once. His announcement followed the statement by union officials that they would not evacuate the two Fisher Body plants at Flint which are held by sit-down strikers.
Canadian purchases of coal from the United States decreased last year, while those from other countries increased, the Department of Commerce has reported.
The French wholesale price index at the end of December stood at 499, against 473 in November, and 357 in December, 1935. The retail price index was 534 against 520 and 435, respectively.

Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis girl wonder, today shot a sensational 73, six under women's par, to win the women titleholders' 54-hole golf tournament here. Miss Berg's game suddenly came to life after she posted 80--87 on her previous eighteen-hole rounds,

George C. Hicks, a retired mining engineer, formerly with the Westinghouse interests, died yesterday at his home in La Jolla, Calif., after a brief illness, according to word received by his sister, Miss Amy Hicks of this city, the only surviving member of his immediate family.

John G. Brothwick, manager of the Caledonian Insurance Company of Edinburgh, Scotland, In Canada and Newfoundland for many years, and former executive of the Caledonian American Insurance Company of New York, died yesterday at his home here.

A $100,000 campaign for two free pools in this city for infantile paralysis victims will be started by the New York Committee of the Warm Springs Foundation this evening with a benefit performance of "The Eternal Road" at the Manhattan Opera House.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., in a statement issued today to holders of dollar bonds of the Chilean Government, the Mortgage Bank of Chile and Chilean municipalities, reiterated its stand taken a year ago in advising them not to accept the proposal of the Chilean Government for interest on the bonds.
Japan's retail prices in December registered an average increase of 3.2 points. They are now 27.9 points above the 1929 level.

British steel output in December amounted to 1,019,200 tons, compared with 811,500 in the last month of 1935, and the total production for 1936 amounted to 11,698,200 tons, which was the largest for any year on record.

The New York Photo-engravers Union went on record yesterday at its twenty-ninth annual meeting in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn,as opposed to the Committee for Industrial Organization. Nearly 3,000 members heard Edward J. Volz, international president, outline the policy.
Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell gave a dinner last night at the Colony Club. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ferris Simmons and Dr. and Mrs. Richard N. Pierson.
Heavy selling of lard, attributed to Eastern interests which had been active on the buying side and lifting prices, caused a sharp break in prices here late last week.
With Earl Hopping, United States star, playing No. 3 position for the visitors, Australia's polo team defeated Los Tamaraos, 9-8, today.

Sir Peter Bark, director of the Anglo-International Bank, died today at St. Pierre les Aubagne at the age of 68. During the World War he was Minister of Finance to the Imperial Russian Government. Sir Peter Bark rose to heights in European governmental finance directly preceding and during the World War.

BARSON--Charles H., of 451 Minnieford AV., City Island, suddenly, at Taunton, Mass., husband of Katharine Barson. Notice of funeral later. BECHER--Harris B., after a prolonged illness, devoted husband of Rachel and beloved father of Sylvia. Harold M., Clara, Billie, Norman and Vilma; faithful brother of Irving, Alexander, Jacob and Joseph Funeral from home, 230 West 105th St. Monday, Jan. 18, 1937.
More than 900 Roman Catholic college students were advised yesterday "to steam out bravely into the center of things" by Bishop Edwin V. O'Hara of Great Falls, Mont.

The Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestley delivered his first sermon as associate minister yesterday morning at the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fourth Universalist Society, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.
The feature of corn trading last week was the variations in the movement of the market from all points in the Corn Belt. Part of the corn from Indiana and Ohio is moving eastward.
The W. K. Vanderbilts are going on a several months' air cruise of South America, it was disclosed tonight, in a luxurious airliner complete with parlor, bedroom and bath.
Mayor Wilson's son, Aldan, 18 years old, splashed to a threepoint landing on the municipal airport during rain this afternoon "just to demonstrate that we do have a real airport here."
The Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, Conn., has acquired Claude Lorrain's painting, "St. George Slaying the Dragon," it was announced yesterday.

Attributing the exodus of manufacturing to the inefficiency of the present law, the American Institute of Steel Construction has addressed to the Board of Aldermen a protest against delay in adoption of the new building code now before the municipal Legislature.

LANCER AT LARGE, by Francis Yeats-Brown. (Viking, $2.75.) The author of "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" returns to the East. ANTON CHEKHOV: THE VOICE OF TWILIGHT RUSSIA, by Princess Nina Andronikova Toumanova. (Columbia, $3.) A biography.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs. Open to amateurs anywhere. Deadline for mailing entries-midnight Feb. 12.

Death has robbed Dr. CLARENCE BARBOUR, president of Brown University, of the earthly vacation upon which he was to have entered at the end of this month. But his spirit is now free to spend an immortal one in the world of the unseen, of which his faith had evidence.
Repeal of the Silver Purchase Act is urged by Handy Harman, leading bullion dealers, in their annual review of the silver market, published today.

The Soviet Government in a note by Maxim Litvinoff, Foreign Commissar, objects to the "unilateral" prohibition of volunteering for civil war service in Spain, as recently imposed by Great Britain and France, on the grounds that such action would handicap the Loyalist forces and benefit the Insurgents.

The Bible is worthy of belief, not only as a civilizing and moralizing force but as a panacea for all troubles, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson asserted in a sermon yesterday at the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street east of Broadway.

A motor tour through Spanish Morocco disclosed no sign of German military occupation in a full sense of the word but revealed many signs of indirect German influence and the use of the Spanish zone as a base for air operations.

The Methodist Federation for Social Service, which says that it speaks for more than 2,000 Methodists, lay and clerical, but not officially for the Methodist Episcopal Church, declared yesterday that recent pronouncements from the Vatican had confirmed its findings last November as to the pro-Franco, proFascist policy of the Vatican.
The Social Security Board since its funds first became available in February, 1936, has aided 1,478,400 persons, a summary issued today states.

Marshall M. Bartholomew, for sixteen years director of the Yale Glee Club, will be honored at a "singing dinner" Wednesday at the Yale Club of New York City "to recognize the great contribution" which he has made to music at Yale.
A former New York sailor shinnied fourteen stories down a dangling fire hose early today to become the first person ever to escape from Dade County's skyscraper jail.

Marking an important step in the development of cricket in the Dominion, a team of English players will visit Canada next Summer. Announcement was made today that the Marylebone Cricket Club, governing body of the sport in England, had decided to send a strong eleven late in July.

The battle between champions and opponents of the Federal Child Labor Amendment, which is expected to reach a climax this year as advocates of the amendment seek approval by at least eleven States, the number still required to make the amendment part of the nation's organic law, grew more intense yesterday with moves by both sides.

The vanguard of thousands of visitors to President Roosevelt's second inauguration began arriving today to find a cold rain falling upon the newly erected stands and the buildings from which the inaugural events will be viewed on Wednesday.
The Insurgents last week attempted to give effect to their long-announced but really non-existent blockade of Spanish Mediterranean ports.

William D. Gherky, a consulting engineer, inventor and manufacturer, died of acute coronary thrombosis today at the home of his son-in-law, Dr. Gilson Colby Engel, with whom he lived in Chestnut Hill. He had been failing in health since the death of his wife, the former Hannie Fearing Goodall, last Summer. He was in his seventieth year.
Jose Costa, American flier from Corning, N. Y., forced down Friday night near Conceicao do Serro, probably will remain there until Thursday, dispatches from Bello Horizonte said tonight.

John O'Connor, 70 years old, living at the Men's Hotel of the Salvation Army, 225 Bowery, fell or jumped in front of a southbound Third Avenue elevated train from the Fordham Road station about 4 P. M. yesterday and was killed instantly.
John H. Stewart has been elected a vice president of Cassatt Co., Inc. Lewis C. Sheridan, a member of the New York Curb Exchange, has been admitted to general partnership in Berdell Brothers.

The first resuits published by the League of Nations in its inquiry as to whether the Council or Assembly can ask for a World Court's advisory opinion by majority vote instead of unanimity, as at present, show only Poland- and Turkey of fourteen States insisting on unanimity.
