To the Editor of The New York Times: The far-reaching and carefully prepared proposals for the reorganization of the administration of the Federal Government at Washington, which the President has recently recommended to the Congress in such clear and convincing terms, is, in my judgment, the most important proposal having to do with the form and conduct of our government which has come from the White House in my memory.

Wages and living conditions in the maritime industries are still "far from what they ought to be," and are likely to remain so until the ranks of seamen are purged of pseudo leaders, malcontents and agitators who make a living by stirring up trouble, according to Ivan Hunter,

Joseph A. McCann, former warden of New York County Penitentiary, on Welfare Island, died Saturday night at St. John's Hospital, Long Island City. He had left his home, at 31-12 Seventy-eighth Street, in Jackson Heights, Queens, about 11 P. M. for a short walk. Four blocks away, at Roosevelt Avenue and Eighty-second Street, apoplexy seized him. He died fifteen minutes later.

Exercises at City Hall and at Franklin Statue in City Hall Park in observance of 231st anniversary of birth of Benjamin Franklin, noon. Speakers: Mayor F. H. La Guardia, William E. Grady, Mrs. Betty A. Hawley, William H. Friedman, Lawrence A. Pendergast, Frank A. Young.
Three German Cardinals and two German Bishops were received today by Pope Pius.
Not the least of the virtues of the New Friends of Music concerts is the variety of ensembles and solo artists brought before the public in the course of the series.

Daniel Branson Coltrane, banker, textile mill organizer, oldest Rotarian and oldest North Carolinian in active banking, died last night of a heart ailment at his home here after two weeks' illness. He celebrated his ninety-fourth birthday on Christmas Day.
Stocks irregular in largest weekly turnover since the week ended Feb. 22, 1936; total sales, 17,590,945 shares. All classes of bonds irregular;

Wholesalers' showrooms here ter were crowded last week, and, despite the effect of unseasonable sta weather upon retail sales, generous ter orders were placed for ready-towear and accessories. The new dress lines, featuring wide-spaced floral prints, dark street sheers and sheer wool costume suits, met with excellent response.
Millinery is going Mexican in the French capital. Parisian women bound for the Riviera are tucking sombreros into their luggage along with their striped flannels and plaid wools.

Mike McTigue, former light heavyweight champion, was beaten up by six men in a northbound Third Avenue elevated train nearing the 129th Street station about 4 A. M. yesterday. He received a black eye, mouth lacerations and head bruises from blows which at first were thought to have fractured his skull.

Those who wonder what Christ would do about present world conditions should find Him first, then they will know, the Rev. Dr. Henry Evertson Cobb, senior minister of the Collegiate Church, said yesterday in his sermon at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.
The Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the Hosiery Local team of Philadelphia, 6-0, yesterday in the first round for the national challenge soccer cup.

While investigation of the disappearance of a gold ingot worth $14,000, presumably from the hold of the French liner Paris, continued yesterday, Edward Knight, a spokesman for the line; said it was possible the theft had occurred while the metal was in transit from Zurich, Switzerland, to Havre.

The season's first performance of "Tannhaeuser" and the return to the company of Paul Althouse, tenor, and Eide Norena, soprano, will mark the sixth week at the Metropolitan Opera next week, it was announced yesterday.

Fourteen passengers and a crew of three escaped injury today when a northbound Eastern Air Lines plane ran off the runway into a ditch at Municipal Airport. The front of the plane was badly damaged and air line officials held it there for repairs.
MAJOR FRANCIS YEATS-BROWN is known to our generation for his "Lives of a Bengal Lancer," which five or six years ago had a wide public reading and led to one of Hollywood's better productions.
Employment on Works Progress Administration projects during 1936 reached the lowest figure of the year in the last week in December, when 2,187,944 persons were listed.

Announced subscriptions and commitments for New York World's Fair debentures reached $14,325,000 yesterday and included two purchases of $100,000 each and two of $50,000 each. The fair's bond sales committee is campaigning to distribute $27,829,500 of the issue.

Additional flood damage threatened the Midwest today. General rains fell throughout the area, pouring more water into steadily rising rivers. The Ohio, White, St. Francis, Kaskakia and Wabash Rivers were above flood stages.

There is nothing more beautiful, sacred or intimate in all life's relationships than that which should exist between a pastor and his congregation, Bishop Charles K. Gilbert suggested in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 127th Street.

The world's leading indoor sports arena, Madison Square Garden, tonight will be the stage whereon homage will be paid to the late Joe Humphreys, the man whose silvertongued oratory in life stilled many threatened disturbances, crowned countless ring champions and lifted the hopes and ambitions of many obscure boxers.

Bids will be asked shortly on six or more structures along the AllAmerican Canal, the eighty-mile irrigation ditch which is being constructed by the Bureau of Reclamation in Southern California, it was announced today.

Despite guesses that more spectacular developments were in prospect, there is the best authority for assuming that the visit to Washington of Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, will be concerned almost entirely with the possibilities of a trade agreement between Great Britain and the United States.
In a surprise move, the executive committee of the Republican State Committee tonight elected State Chairman William S. Murray as its chairman to succeed the late Clarence R. King of Syracuse.

Three apartment houses and two one-family houses, assets of title and mortgage companies in liquidation or rehabilitation, have been sold by the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department.

Gates Ferguson, regional director of the Federal Housing Administration, and John Moroney, tax expert, will address a meeting of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners this evening at the Bronx County Court House.

The Corset Show opened at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday with the longest list of exhibitors which has participated in this semi-annual event. The thirty-nine organizations taking part include thirtyfour manufacturers and several publications.

Two firemen were injured and a fire captain who had just returned to duty after sick leave collapsed at a three-alarm fire which swept through the sixth floor of the John Mullins Furniture Company building at Newark Avenue and Grove Street today. Hundreds of workers bound for New York were delayed in reaching the Grove Street tube station when traffic was tied up in Newark Avenue by fire apparatus.
William MacPherson Hornor, a retired lawyer, died of cerebral thrombosis today at his home in Bryn Mawr in his seventy-seventh year.
-In order to reduce the retail price of beef, the government is considering the transportation of cattle to the mainland from the Galapagos islands.

About 200 students of the Florida Agricultural and Mechanical College for Negroes refused to attend classes today and J. R. E. Lee Jr., business manager, said they were on strike for "more and better food."
Wallace J. Grove. in 400 Park Av., through William A. White Sons. Samuel C. Rudolph, sublease from Ted Lewis. in Majestic Apartments, 115 Central Park West; Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., broker.

Michael H. Sexton, former president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, an organization under which all the minor leagues operate, died of a heart attack at his hotel apartment here today. He was born in this city in 1863 and had been active in baseball for nearly forty years.

Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Francis Lee of Dayton have announced the marriage of their daughter, Katharine, to James W. Sanders Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Sanders of Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed last Friday in the First Presbyterian Church at Brooklyn by the Rev. Morgan Phelps Noyes, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church of Montclair.

Speaker Bankhead is doing his part to guarantee ideal weather for President Roosevelt's inauguration Wednesday. From a vest pocket today he pulled in turn a rabbit's foot and a glistening "buckeye" nut.
Business failures for the week ended Jan. 14 moved up for the third consecutive week, but the aggregate continued lower than in the comparative 1936 period, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The wheat market on the Board of Trade here was erratic today, with prices fluctuating within a range of slightly less than a cent a bushel.
A railway robber turned lawyer failed in defense of himself here today when an all-woman jury, the first to sit in Federal court, turned its collective thumb down on his tearful appeal for freedom.

Bankers' acceptance outstanding in the United States on Dec. 31 amounted to $372,816,963, an increase of $23,763,473 in the month, but a decrease of $24,140,541 from the amount outstanding on Dec. 31, 1935, according to figures issued yesterday by the Acceptance Analysis Unit of the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
Mrs. Marie S. Grant Holmquist, wife of Charles H. Holmquist, director of the Division of Sanitation in the State Deapartment of Health, is dead from a week's illness of pneumonia.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted permission to the Moffat Tunnel Commission, builders of the railroad bore through the Continental Divide carrying lines connecting Salt Lake City and Denver, the right to intervene in the

It was officially revealed today that the express train fire near Canton yesterday involved about eighty fatalities. Nearly forty are in hospitals suffering from burns. Some of these are expected to die.

Holding that allegations of an unequal burden upon transit companies resulting from the city's 3 per cent utility tax were sufficient to constitute a cause of action, Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer has denied motions by the city to dismiss suits by the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation for recovery of $2,165,576 paid under the tax, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Little Italy Neighborhood Association at 146 Union Street, Brooklyn, was aided last night by a theatre party which was preceded by many dinners. The directors took over the orchestra seats or a performance of "The Wingless Victory" at the Empire Theatre. Miss Louise Goetze was chairman of the benefit.

With the attendance of buyers and merchandise executives in the markets here increased by the opening last night of the National Retail Dry Goods Association convention, Spring purchasing yesterday began to approach its early seasonal peak.
-Phelps Smith, the son of Paul Smith, whose name has been connected with Adirondack hostelries, land and power developments for nearly a century, died last night of pneumonia. He was 84 years old.

Because the Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting in New York, ruled eighteen days ago that New York City had a prior right to sales taxes collected by a merchant before his bankruptcy, the Supreme Court reversed itself today and agreed to hear a previously denied case affecting the same issue.

For the first time since the active promotion of I. E. S. lamps was started, manufacturers will engage in a Spring promotional and advertising campaign this season. More than $50,000 will be spent by sponsors of the scientifically tested table lamps in national magazines and other publications between Feb. 1 and April 1, this year.

The Assembly adopted a resolution tonight asking the Port of New York Authority to name the new Hudson River vehicular tube the Weehawken-Midtown Tunnel after Assemblyman Harry E. Bishoff had told it, in effect, that Weehawken deserved to be on the map.
A further decline in the number of new influenza and pneumonia cases in New York City was reported yesterday by the Department of Health.

When HORACE MANN was president of the Massachusetts State Senate in 1837 he signed an education bill providing for a State Board of Education. Not only was the Governor himself to be an ex officio member of the board, but he was to appoint eight private citizens as the other members.

Dean Detton of Salt Lake City, one of the claimants to the world's wrestling title, threw Bob (Bibber) McCoy of Worcester, Mass., before a crowd of 4,000 in the feature bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that the tenders for approximately $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury bills, dated Jan. 20 and maturing on Oct. 20, which were offered on Jan. 15, amounted to $124,392,000, of which $50,015,000 was accepted.

William Fellowes Morgan was the guest of honor at the annual dinner meeting of the general assembly of the Young Men's Christian Association, held last night at Sloane House Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirtyfourth Street.
Former Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter, whom the Senate removed from office in April because of "high crimes and misdemeanors," carried his case to the Supreme Court today.

The Kristiania Bank og Kreditkasse has agreed to transfer the Nobel Peace Prize fund amounting to $40,000 to a German bank tomorrow except for $200, which will be paid in cash to Mrs. Alexandra Kreutzberger, who is acting as proxy for the winner of the prize, Carl von Ossietzky.

The indications are for fair and colder weather today. Tomorrow will be cloudy and moderately cold, probably followed by rain or snow in the afternoon, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The official organ of the Protestant Church in Germany, containing the protest of the government's own church administration against the arrest of seven pastors in Luebeck, has been seized and suppressed by the political police.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall 11 A. M . "The Liberations of Art, "Louis K. Anspcher.

Professional football attendance during the past year increased more than 20 per cent over the mark set the previous year, which we consider highly encouraging and even better than the increase noted in other sports.
The first $5 of Townsend revolving pension money went today for a permanent wave for the wife of the "pensioner."

Soon after he was sworn in this morning as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Charles Edison turned his attention to overcoming obstacles in the operation of the Walsh-Healey Act, which has worked hardship in the procurement of copper, steel and other necessaries of the naval building program.
Death came today to Charles Richard Wagner, 18, one of two brothers who have been afflicted for several years with a strange disease that has caused slow ossification of their flesh.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Affiliated National Temple Federations of Brotherhoods and Sisterhoods today went on record as favoring a more extensive use of ancient, traditional symbols, ceremonies and customs by reform Jewish congregations in their Sabbath services.
Winthrop Rockefeller, 24-year-old son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., rounded out three years of ground work in the oil business today and prepared to depart tomororw for New York.

President Roosevelt today named a committee, headed by Secretary Ickes, to recommend legislation which would establish a broad national policy for the generation, transmission and distribution of electric power.
Governor and Mrs. White of Mississippi were the guests for whom Senator and Mrs. Pat Harrison kept open house this afternoon at their home in Cathedral Avenue and tonight at the Mayflower.

Two similar hockey teams will clash on the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight in a National League conflict when the New York Rangers play host to Cecil Hart's Montreal Canadiens. These sextets specialize in a fast, aggressive open style.

The admirable outline of a government power policy that was drawn by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan yesterday on the background of his social-economic philosophy brings into the open a controversy in the Tennessee Valley Authority on the outcome of which depend profound public matters.
The University of Pittsburgh basketball team dropped its first Eastern Intercollegiate Conference game to Georgetown tonight, 30-27.

Mrs. Mary Browder Lynch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Bailey Browder of Washington, and a sister of Mrs. George H. Earle, wife of the Governor, will be married to Thomas R. Wickersham of Harrisburg at the Executive Mansion Feb. 2.

Salvatore Balbo, Italy, and Felix Zbyszko, Poland, wrestled 1:12.34 to a draw in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 1,500. The bout was ended by the New York State Athletic Commission's 11 o'clock curfew. Balbo weighed 185 and Zbyszko 180.

Miss Line Zilgien, French organist, made her first American appearance in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She presented a program of music by Bach, Saint-Saens, Schumann, Mendelssohn, Widor, Messiaen and Dupre. It was evident that hers is a discriminating, experienced approach to the organ and its literature. She displayed an assured technical command and an understanding of the possibilities of the organ.

The first New York performance of "The White Bird," an American opera by Ernest Carter, with book by Brian Hooker, will be presented at the Hudson Theatre Sunday evening, Feb. 7, with the composer conducting, it was announced yesterday.
President James B. Conant of Harvard was among three prominent men elected today to the Athenaeum, the most famous club in London.

Dr. Luther Fiske Warren, Professor of Internal Medicine at the Long Island College of Medicine, died last night at his home, 81 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 51 after an illness of ten months.

State Chairman MURRAY gets another testimonial of merit. His short service in his difficult post has given such satisfaction to the executive committee, for some time the driving force in the State committee, that it has made him its chairman.

The trial of Gladys MacKnight and Donald E. Wightman, Bayonne schoolday chums, for the ??atchet murder of the girl's mother last July 31 may not be scheduled for six weeks or two months, because of a plea by Wightman's attorney for a separate trial.

Plans for a $400,000 apartment house in upper Broadway and for the remodeling of many structures' in various parts of Manhattan have just been filed. The list, together with building projects for other boroughs, follows:

Sir Frederick Pollock, whose writings and teachings inspired generations of lawyers on both sides of the Atlantic, died at his home here today. His health had been failing since his ninetyfirst birthday, which he celebrated last month.

More than 200 members of railway, steamship and industrial traffic departments gave a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore yesterday to Harry Atkinson, who has been appointed general New England agent of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. Mr. Atkinson has been assistant general freight agent here for several years.
Word was received today of the death of Edwin R. Stonaker, Rochester mechanical engineer, yesterday in Tucson, Ariz. The body will be taken to East Orange, N. J., for burial.

Four trying years in the White House have left President Roosevelt physically as strong as when he first entered it. "Without question the President's physical condition is excellent," Captain Ross T. McIntire, his naval physician, said today. "Outside of the fact that he is four years older there is not a thing to worry about."

Strike plans of the Waist and Dressmakers' Union were held in abeyance today when at the request of Dr. Jacob Billikopf, impartial chairman of the industry here, the union agreed to confer with the manufacturers on the terms of a new contract to replace the one that expired on Dec. 31.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Ida Klaus of Brooklyn, N. Y., James E. Doherty Jr., A Joseph Geist, Robert F. Mahoney, C. Joseph Danshy and Samuel Frankel of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had. The Chief Justice announced the following orders of the court:

One issue now dominates the stroke situation in the automobile industry. That issue is whether the United Automobile Workers Union is to be recognized as the "sole" bargaining agency between the General Motors Corporation and the 200,000 people on its payrolls.

The Rev. Dr. William Page Dame, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in the Worthington Valley near Baltimore, and descendant of an English family that settled in Virginia in the seventeenth century, died here today at the age of 65.

Once again the government is reported to be on the eve of launching a punitive expedition against rebellious Sian, in Shensi PrqCnce. It is reported that Jan. 15 had been secretly set as the date upon which General Yang Fu-cheng must agree to accept the government's orders and that this date was later extended to last midnight.

The stock market here was irregular today as the new account opened. Gilt-edge securities declined because of talk of a new defense loan. Foreign bonds were strong, with a fresh rise in German loans. International issues were active, led by United States Steel.

M. C. Seelig, president of. the Mesch Construction and Equipment Company, received a prison sentence of three months and a fine of $900 when he pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Gaffey to an indictment charging fraud involving the WPA.

The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia announced today that it had decided to challenge for the Davis Cup in the North American zone this year. One reason for the decision was that less long traveling will be required.
Mayor Jasper McLevy today rebuked the Board of Police Commissioners for holding a "star chamber" session yesterday from which newspaper men were barred.

Hans Peter Luhn, an inventor, who says he developed a method of making women's full-fashioned silk hosiery without "rings" before it was done by Charles Kaufman, head of the hosiery department of the Julius Kayser Company, was one of the chief defense witnesses today in the patent infringement suit of the Textile Patents Corporation and the Julius Kayser Company against the Rosedale Knitting Mills.

Three men, who escaped in evening dress Sunday night before the police arrived at the scene of the Manhattan Opera House murder, cuss dodged more than a score of detectives yesterday afternoon and last night.

Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, now in charge of the Tax Division of the Department of Justice, was designated today as head of the Anti-Trust Division to succeed John Dickinson, resigned.
Lester Wittenberg, executive vice president of the Barrett Company, New York chemical firm, died today at New Rochelle Hospital after an illness of five weeks.

Construction began today on a branch of the Reich Chancellery at Berchtesgaden, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's home in the Bavarian Alps. The Fuehrer himself was present at the ceremony, making a brief address in which he emphasized that he had once been a building trades worker.

Three Brazilian pioneers have found city streets as complicated as the jungles of South America. One member of the party got lost when they arrived here Saturday night from Little Rock, and it required two days to get the group together again. They were almost homesick for the jungles.

Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign Committee, announced last night. that fourteen divisions in the industry section had exceeded last year's divisional totals. The section is headed by Clarence Francis,. president of the General Foods Corporation, and to date has raised $418,039, or $40,000 more than last year.

A bill designed to separate the Army Air Corps from the General Staff and create a United States Air Corps of 4,500 flight officers and 45,000 enlisted men, with an air marshal responsible- only to the Secretary of War at its head, was introduced in the House today by Representative Wilcox of Florida. He has long been an advocate of a greater air force.

Mrs. James Roosevelt gave an informal reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 47 East Sixtyfifth Street, for a group active in behalf of the Birthday Ball to be held the night of Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria to mark President Roosevelt's fifty-fifth birthday. Proceeds of the ball will be donated to the relief of sufferers from infantile paralysis in New York and to the sanitarium in Warm Springs, Ga.

Mayor La Guardia, long a "front row" spectator at two and three alarm fires, was made an honorary member of the Chief Officers Association of the New York Fire Department yesterday at a. luncheon in his honor at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

Preparing for the proposed James J. Braddock-Max Schmeling heavyweight championship bout scheduled by Madison Square Garden for June in Long Island City, Joe Jacobs, manager of Schmeling, yesterday made public a tentative exhibition tour he has mapped for the German, who is to arrive here within a month.

At last General FRANCO has let the world know who the enemy is that he has been fighting for six months. It is, he declares, communism. There is enough plausibility about this to give it a right to a hearing.

The House Coinage Committee today approved an administration bill to extend to June 30, 1939, the Treasury's gold stabilization fund and the President's authority to alter the gold content of the dollar.

A New York member, Robert Finney, today stroked his way to the qualifying medal in a record field of at fifty-seven players in the twentyninth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests.

Thirty-three of the 300 largest commercial banks and trust companies in the United States are located in this city. The Chase National Bank is still the leader, followed by the Guaranty Trust Company and the National City Bank, according to the copyrighted annual roll-call of the American Banker for 1936.

More than a hundred Tammany members left Pennsylvania Station last night on a special train bound for Washington for the second inauguration of President Roosevelt. The train left at 6:15 o'clock, with Thomas A. Ruddy, son of Stephen Ruddy, in charge of the tickets and hotel accommodations.
The Chase National Bank has Ne been appointed registrar for the capital stock of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.

Audubon Av., 145, n. e. c. 172d St., 94.6x 95; Highboro Realty Corp., Iside Garbi, secretary, to Judson S. Todd at Lake Mahopac, N. Y.; purchase money, prior mortgage, $114,000; due Jan. 1, 1947; $7,750.

Indignant that the Museum of Modern Art included work by children and the insane in its recent exhibition of fantastic art, dada and surrealism, Miss Katherine S. Dreier, president of the Societe Anonyme, long active in the modern art movement here, has declined to lend works requested by the museum to the exhibition when it is circulated to institutions - in other parts of the country.

MANHATTAN BURR, CHARLES A. (Jan. 2). Estate, about $300. To Kate Burr Ward, sister, executrix, 610 W. 110th St., residue. Willard G. Ward, 610 W. 110th St., executor. CLEMENTS, ELIZABETH G. (Nov. 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gertrude G. Clements and Florence E. Clements, daughters, executrices, 101 W. 85th St., residue equally.

Vice President Garner anchored himself today at a safe distance from the inauguration's social activities. "You can say for me," he declared, "that I have no social plans and won't have any. I'm going to bed at 9 o'clock this week, as usual."

A Greenwich Village deal involving the five-story apartment house at 76-80 Bedford Street was announced by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker in the sale of the property by Philip L. Goodwin to an investor.

Reversing the decision of the stewards, who previously had reejected his claim, the Contest Board of the American Automobile Associtation yesterday ruled in favor of Wild Bill Cummings of Indianapolis and officially allotted him seventh place in the Columbus Day Vanderbilt Cup race instead of eighth position.

The sausage industry established a new alltime production record during 1936, theInstitute of American Meat Packers reported today. Sausage output gained 10 per cent over the 1935 volume and was 16 per cent larger than the average of the last five years.

Production of steel ingots this week, estimated at 80.6 per cent of theoretical capacity, will reach a level unequaled in almost seven years. Despite the labor controversy in the motor industry, the high rate of activity may be accounted for by the fact that steel mills have sufficient outlets for current delivery to offset more than the suspended orders of the automobile plants.
Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, and Mrs. Goering went to Naples from Rome this morning, accompanied by the Prince and Princess of Hesse and high Italian army officers.

John C. McCarthy, superintendent of the New Haven, Conn., public school system, died early today in the Brunswick General Hospital at Amityville of pneumonia following an operation performed on Friday. Mr. McCarthy was 54 years old.

Production of the new Willys automobiles for the first full month of manufacturing, from Dec. 16 to Jan. 15, amounted to 5,484 cars, according to David R. Wilson, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc.

Pope Plus passed a good night so today he felt better than in a long time. The improvement continued throughout the day for he was almost completely free from pain and in a happy, contented frame of mind.
Lieutenant James J. Melia of Engine 272 died Jan 16. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 55-48 137th St., Flushing, at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday, Jan. 20. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

Allegations that terminal elevator companies were obtaining loans in the United States at interest rates below Canadian bank rates were made before the Turgeon Royal Grain Commission this afternoon by M. M. Porter of Calgary, counsel for the Alberta Wheat Pool.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Slaughterhouse supplies were uneven, light to normal. Demand for non-kosher meats was only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were lower, veal mostly steady, calf barely steady with Friday's close,

As part of a reorganization plan approved by the Supreme Court on April 16, 1936, the George E. Roosevelt Committee, a bondholders' organization, bought the nineteenstory Hotel Dorset at 30 West Fiftyfourth Street yesterday at a foreclosure sale on a bid of $800,000.

Mannerly, a 3-year-old son of Misstep, drove to a nose victory in the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today. Carrying L. J. Marks's silks, the gelding came from second place at the head of the stretch to defeat Laro Keys, a 4-year-old owned by Coward and Coffey. Wee Emma was a fast-closing third.

In three hours yesterday a jury with an alternate was chosen in General Sessions from a special panel of talesmen for the extortion trial of J. Henry Ross, a young Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, on the complaint of Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor. Mr.
Louis L. Wisner of Hackensack, former president of the Industrial Dyeing Company of Charlotte, N.C., and Maspeth.
Definitely, the Theatre Guild's sixth and last production in New York this season will be "Storm in a Teacup," James Bridie's adaptation of "Sturm im Wasserglass," by Bruno Frank.

Some 300 actors on the Federal Theatre Project in New York soon will be transferred to other jobs in the theatre program here or to other bureaus of the WPA, officials said yesterday following the report of the board appointed to investigate the qualifications of players.

The advertising provisions of the new amendment to the Food and Drug Law were commended yesterday by John Benson, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, in a letter to Senator Royal S. Copeland, author of the measure.
Reflecting the recent rise in crude rubber prices, the leading tire manufacturers placed into effect yesterday a new schedule of retail prices 6 per cent higher.

William F. X. Geoghan, Kings CountyDistrict Attorney, announced last night that he had found no facts that warranted a criminal action as a result of the fire in the Nurses' Home of the Israel Zion Hospital, 4,721 Fort Hamilton Parkway, on Sunday morning. In the fire one nurse lost her life and five other employes were injured.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs.
President Roosevelt today named three residents of New York, Eugene F. Savage, Paul Manship and William F. Lamb, to membership on the Fine Arts Commission.

Extensive rewriting necessary to make "Boy Meets Girl" an acceptable vehicle for Marion Davies has caused the Warner Brothers to sahedule "Ever Since Eve" as the actress' next, abandoning the Bella and Samuel Spewack play for the present. Miss Davies has many exacting stipulations governing her scripts, rules with which "Boy Meets Girl" was not in keeping.

The Senate, which has voted to make its own investigation of the election of William C. Hunt, Republican, as Senator from Cape May County. was informed tonight that a similar proceeding before Circuit Court Judge Wilfred H. Jayne will not be completed for five or six weeks.
John Steinbeck's sixth book, a short novel entitled "Of Mice and Men," is a joint March selection of the Book of the Month Club. It will be published by Covici, Friede on Feb. 26.

Dr. Clare C. Baldwin, confidential secretary to James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, will map a six-year plan for school building under the new City Charter if the board ratifies his nomination by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to a $6,500-a-year post as assistant administrative director.
High administration officials today viewed with considerable concern the inability to obtain yen exchange in Japan after a currency embargo that was clamped down suddenly by that government.

John Cummings Jr. of Memphis, runner-up for the Midwinter crown at Miami last week, led a record field of seventy starters in the qualifying round of the annual Miami Biltmore amateur golf tournament today. He turned in a card of 35, 38--73.

For a comparatively new sport, basketball's early years are practically unknown and unrecorded. But a court historian has arisen in George Bernert, Springfield College, '24. He has .delved deeply into the happenings of ye olden days, has authenticated his material beyond any shadow of doubt and has found a fascinating subject at his command.
This city was plunged in gloom today by the collapse of the negotiations at Detroit between the General Motors Corporation and the automobile union.
The chairman of Governor Martin L. Davey's "Action Committee" recommended today the creation of a non-political State administrator with absolute power over all departments.

Four conditions which would not occur together once in a million times caused the recent disaster to an aircraft near Newhall, according to a canvass of opinion at the California Institute of Technology today.
The rise in prices which occurred in this country during 1936 on top of the previous very substantial advance since 1932, and which is still proceeding, has attracted wide notice.

Dr. Byron Stookey, Associate Professor of Neurological Surgery at the Columbia University School of Medicine, has been named by the Columbia trustees to succeed Dr. Charles Albert Elsberg, who has resigned as chief of neurosurgical service at the Neurological Institute of New York, an affiliate of the Columbia Medical School.

President Roosevelt plans a conference soon after his inauguration on means of limiting the power of the Supreme Court to pass on legislation, Senator Minton declared today after a visit to the White House.

Louis Beitcher, the "No 2 man" in gangster control of the restaurant racket, for which he and eight others went on trial yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, pleaded guilty toward the close of the day and went back to the Tombs to await his call as a prosecution witness.

The American Yacht Club will retain its traditional racing and cruising fixtures for the coming season, it was announced last night by William L. Crow, chairman of the race committee, following the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the club at Rye, N. Y.

Maharajdhiraja Raj Rajeshwar Sawai Yeshwant Rao Holkar Bahadur, the youthful Maharaja of Indore, who has been touring this country and the Hawaiian Islands under the shorter name of Sir Yeshwant Rao Holkar, returned to New York yesterday morning.

Lord Wigram, Permanent Lord-in-Waiting to the King, announced today that their Majesties would go to the Earl of Derby's seat at Knowsley, in Lancashire, March 18, and will attend the Grand National at Aintree on the following day.

Earle Meadows, the Olympic pole-vault champion, and George Varoff, the holder of the world record, will clash in the annual Mill rose A. A. track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6, it was announced yesterday.

Detroit had another banner week in National Hockey League competition. Official scoring statistics issued tonight showed the Red Wings retaining most of the individual honors, while holding their place at the top of the American group.

The Rev., Julius Boyd, a member of the Passionist Order of St. Michael, this city, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, of pneumonia at the age of 66. Born in Carrick-on-Shannon, County Roscommon, Ireland, Father Boyd was ordained in 1899 in Baltimore.

Joseph Dowd Jr., 18 years old, a first-year student at La Salle Military Academy, Manhattan, was killed by a .22-caliber bullet through his head Saturday night as he lay in bed at his home at 59 Vanderbilt Avenue, Manhasset, police disclosed today.

Representatives of the conductors and engineers brotherhoods disclosed tonight proposals for a 15 per cent wage increase for approximately 300,000 railroaders which have been submitted to the trainmen, firemen and switchmen.

On the eve of her departure for Washington to preside over the annual meeting of the National Public Housing Conference, which opens Friday, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch declared yesterday that government subsidies for low-rent housing should not be considered an added expense to the community at large.

Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon granted yesterday a motion by Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCal to continue, pending trial, a temporary injunction restraining the Television Corporation of America, its president, Oliver C. Harriman, and six others from transactions in the corporation's stock.
Thomas E. Watson, a building superintendent, apparently committed suicide this afternoon by gas in the basement of his home at 22 Nirvana Avenue, Great Neck, according to the Nassau County police.

Sharp increases in the number of automobile accidents and persons injured marred the safety campaign of the Police Department for the second week in succession compared to the corresponding weeks of 1936, it was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner.

While crowds of visitors that promised to set new records poured into the capital today, President Rooosevelt, the focal point of interest in the inauguration program which will occupy most of Wednesday, remained in the library of the White House, working on his inaugural address.

President Roosevelt appointed a committee to formulate legislation to carry out a national power policy, conferred with Senator Minton on suggested legislation to modify the powers of the Supreme Court, discussed the proposed farm-tenancy bill with Senator Bankhead and worked on his inaugural address.

Orders for $2,500,000 worth of merchandise, a record for any opening day in the forty-three years the New York Furniture Exchange has been operating, were booked yesterday by manufacturers participating in the regular seasonal Spring and Summer furniture market.

Charles Melville Dewey, landscape painter, died on Sunday at Hotel Chelsea, 222 West Twentythird Street, in his eighty-eighth year. He had painted up to within six months of his death and was able as late as last Friday to leave his apartment.
The Ministry of Finance announced today that the Greek Government had concluded a deal with the German Government whereby a credit of $40,000,000 is extended to Greece for the purchase of armaments.

A gigantic colonization program for politically oppressed Jews in Central European countries is being studied by the government of the Republic of Santo Domingo and officials of American Jewish agencies, it became known yesterday on the return from Santo Domingo on the Puerto Rico liner Borinquen of Dr. Howard W. Blake, a dentist of 580 Park Avenue.

A minimum of seventy-two hours sick leave and transportation in Police Department automobiles for members of the force who act as blood donors for injured comrades or relatives of policemen was authorized yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

Lane Bryant, Inc., dry goods store chain, announced yesterday the results of operations in the six months to Nov. 30 last, showing a net income of $80,344 after depreciation, interest and Federal taxes. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, who is Mrs. Luboshutz, made their first New York appearance as a two-piano team at the Town Hall last night. They gave a lively account of themselves. Their playing had coordination, buoyancy and grace, and on occasion it was searching in its grasp of feeling and flavor. There were some flaws, but this is the initial season of public concerts for the couple.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler gave a dinner in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador yesterday for Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell, Mr. and Mrs. Hulbert Bassett, Mr. and Mrs. William Ely Chambers, Mrs. Jean Wuertz Edwards, Mrs. Jane Kryn, Melville Rosinow and Reuben Crane.
Jay Ankrom of Detroit, defending champion, fell before a fellowtownsman, Art Primeau, in the first round of the national amateur three-cushion billiards tournament tonight, 50 to 47, in 69 innings.

The world-renowned German school system, already coordinated and curtailed into a mere shadow of its former self, suffered another serious wrench today when Chancellor Adolf Hitler issued the following cryptic decree typical of the manner in which vital changes are being wrought in the new Germany:

Herbert L. Pratt has been elected a member of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, according to announcement made yesterday at the museum following the annual meeting of the corporation.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition NATIONAL GUNITE CONTRACTING CO.. 82 W. Dedham St., Boston. Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the bankruptcy law listing liabilities at $89,876 and assets at $138,816. The company maintains local offices in the Grand Central Terminal.
The swiftly mounting cost of the rearmament program threatens to overshadow all other issues when Parliament reassembles tomorrow for six months of hard work.
The Federal Music Project is presenting a series of popular priced concerts beginning tonight at the Master Institute with a program of nineteenth century music.

Heavy seas kicked up by a major storm spreading over most of the North Atlantic caused a revision of shipping schedules yesterday, with some of the larger liners reporting to New York that they would arrive a dav late.

Alexander M. Thackara, war-time American consul-general in Paris, died early today in the American hospital at Neuilly. He was 88 years old. His death resulted from bronchial pneumonia. At his bedside were his daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Cauldwell of Paris.

Honorary membership in the Explorers Club of New York will be accepted by Alexander Troyanovsky, Russian Ambassador, on behalf of Professor Otto Yulievich Schmidt, director of the Soviet Arctic Institute, at a luncheon today at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, D. C., it was announced yesterday.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 16: COLONELS Richardson, J. B. (Adjustant General's Dept.), General Staff Corps, Phillippines, to headqquarters, Fort Hayes, Ohio; Previous orders amended.

Asserting that Luis Carlos Prestes, who is charged by the government with having headed the Leftist revolt of November, 1935, was a confessed Communist, Representative Amaral Peixoto testified today before the Security Tribunal that he believed Prestes to be mentally deranged.

Although Harold Samuel, pianist, who died on Friday, was best known as an interpreter of Bach, the slow movement from Beethoven's quartet in A minor, opus 131, was played this evening at a service honoring his memory. It was said Mr. Samuel thought this was "the greatest work Beethoven ever wrote."
Mrs. Ella Potter Hoyt, widow of George R. Hoyt, former school official, and mother of G. Robert Hoyt, Chief of Police of West Long Branch, died today at her home. in North Long Branch.

James Hilton's novel, "And Now Good-Bye," published in England six years ago, serves as the foundation for Philip Howard's play, presented this evening by John Golden at the Plymouth Theatre for the first time on any stage.
Juliana Force, director of the Whitney Museum of Art, it announced yesterday an important change in the policy governing the museum's annual showing of new work by American artists.

With standing room at a premium, Maxwell Anderson's new play, "The Masque at Kings," was given its world premiere tonight at the Montclair Theatre by the Theatre Guild under the sponsorship of the Montclair Junior League. The show will be repeated tomorrow evening before another capacity house.
While two Deputy United States marshals from Boston were having breakfast early yesterday morning in a restaurant in the midtown district, one of two prisoners who were in their charge escaped.

Commercial aviation as a career was closed tonight to German youth by an order of the Air Minister, Col. Gen. Hermann Goering. Henceforth, any German ambiitious to become a flier must offer himself as a volunteer to the military air force.
An unidentified airplane dropped six bombs near the French destroyer Mail1o Breze off the Spanish Mediterranean coast today, - but did not damage the vessel, naval officials declared.

In one of the most exciting basketball games ever played here, Pennsylvania conquered Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest tonight, 38 to 36. Tired from two stiff games over the week-end with Syracuse and Cornell, the Crimson at times was unable to stave off concerted Red and Blue attacks.

Walter Reisch wrote "Men Are Not Gods," the new London Films production at the Rivoli, and Walter Reisch directed it. The presumption, then, is that Mr. Reisch not only knew what he wanted to do but did it.

While patrolmen and soldiers stood guard, and many New Yorkers wondered why the police were providing motor-cycle escorts for mail trucks, 120 tons of gold moved through the streets last night from the financial district to Pennsylvania station.

Phelan Beale, prominent attorney of New York City and owner of a large estate near Cedar Point, is the new owner of a tiny island off Sag Harbor which had been a government lighthouse site since the old days of the Long Island whalers.
Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at a price equivalent to 12.65 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, or 35 points below the domestic level.

Vast sums of relief money that have been poured into the city, State and national parks have created a maintenance problem which, if not solved, may result in the "creation of a vast system of recreational slums," speakers declared yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the American Society of Landscape Architects at-the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

IT was a bit alarming to have M'sieu Lestairre Patrick slap his desk pad and say in a good loud voice that lacrosse was dead. Just down the hall, within easy earshot, was stout Jack Filman, who would go as far as homicide or manslaughter in several degrees on the person of any one talking in that fashion about the lively game of lacrosse, the alleged national pastime of Canada.

Freeman Hopwood, a founder and former general secretary of the American Association for the Advancement of Atheism, died Saturday night in San Jose, Calif., where he had been living since 1933 under the name of Donald J. Kendall. Announcement of his death was made here last night by Charles Smith, president of the association.

A motion-picture theatre representing an investment of about $500,000 will be built at the corner of South and Pine Streets, Morristown, N. J., according to Walter Reade, president of the American Community Theatres Corporation, who purchased a plot 151 by 276

A. Hollander Son declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on common stock. On Dec. 15 an extra amount of $3 was paid and on Nov. 16 extra and quarterly distributions of 12% cents each were made.
Dan Risko, unattached, featured the amateur boxing program at the New York Athletic Club last night by knocking out Jack Jordan in 47 seconds of the first round with a right to the jaw.
The strike against General Motors will be discussed by Secretary Perkins and Governor Murphy at a conference here tomorrow, with James F. Dewey, Labor Department conciliator, participating.

The Commonwealth Fund, as reported yesterday, spent nearly $2,000,000 last year, more than two-thirds of which was devoted to the promotion of medical education and research in cities and the improvement of medical and nursing service, especially in rural areas.
Federal Judge Clancy heard the testimony of one witness yesterday in the suit brought by six stockholders against Cities Service Company for an accounting and then adjourned the trial until tomorrow.

In what he said would be his last appearance here, Philadelphia's 34year-old Tommy Loughran won a ten-round decision over George (Sonny Boy) Walker of Phoenix, Ariz., before 9,000 spectators tonight. Loughran weighed 189 1/2 and Walker 197.
When the Robert L. Martins moved to Denver last November they took their dog Max along. But Max was not happy. It may have been nostalgia, or perhaps the altitude. He left Denver in a week.

Morris Av., 2,343 (11-3183); Eureka Terry Mills, Inc., to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av., extends mtg. to Dec. 1, 1941, at 4 1/2 per cent; $30,500. Townsend Av. (11-2849), w. s., 190 ft. s. of 175th St., 33x100; John B. Ricca to Oscar Lowenstein, trustee, 220 W. 87th St., extends mtg. to Jan. 15, 1942, at 5 per cent; $16,000.
Limiting its entry to Class A players for the first time in five years, the women's metropolitan squash racquets championship tourney got under way on the courts of the Junior League yesterday.

The trustees of Sailor's Snug HarHarbor have leased to the University Place Theatre Corporation the property at 257-63 Greene Street and a store in the abutting building at 9-11 University Place, in the Washington Square district, through Du Cret Co., in cooperation with Aaron Zanger.
Henry Ford watched the 25,000,000th automobile to bear his name made today in the Ford Motor Company River Rouge plant here, culminating his thirty-three and a half years of motor car manufacture.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN--Joseph F. Wixted, 73d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 27, 1910. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN--Rubin Unterweiser, from 62d to 28th Precinct. Francis J. Fowler, 84th to 70th Precinct. Claude M. Smythe Jr., 123d to 7th Precinct.

Mayor S. Watkins Overton and Miss Bessie Ganong, until a week ago his secretary, were married today at a simple ceremony. Mrs. Overton is the daughter of Mrs. Walter S. Ganong of Memphis. She was educated at St.

Harry Rachevsky of 44 Boerum Street, Brooklyn, who is 70 years old, and Rachel Giska, who is 67 and lives at 85 Gerry Street, in that borough, are enrolled in a class in naturalization preparation at the Williamsburg Vocational High School, 95 Boerum Street, Brooklyn.

The Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities reported today earnings of $2.21 a share on the capital stock for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 last. This compares with $2.08 a share for the preceding twelve months.

Estimates of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public last night, showed a 2.3 per cent increase in unemployment during November, with 8,968,000 persons out of work as against 8,770,000 in October.

The great war fleet of rusty merchant vessels, squadrons of which lie anchored stem to stern off Staten Island and in other backwaters of commerce, will be formally withdrawn from the market, the Maritime Commission stated today.

The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today against the Badiglo Company, Inc., 37 West Twentieth Street, New York, alleging use of unfair trade practices in connection with the sale of soap, which was represented to be olive oil castile and of Spanish or Italian origin, when the commission said such was not a fact.

Superintendents, janitors, housekeepers, elevator, operators, doormen and all other employes engaged in maintenance service in apartment houses would be required to register with the Tenement House Department and obtain a certificate of fitness from that department as a condition of employment, under a bill introduced this evening by Assemblyman William J. Sheldrick of Manhattan.
The flood of signed Giants' contracts pours steadily in at the club's offices, making lighter the work of Secretary Ed Brannick.

Continuing their rapid drive toward the important Loyalist port of Malaga, the Spanish Insurgents, after a fierce two-day battle, captured Marbella today and made a further advance toward Los Boliches and Fuengirola, villages twenty miles from Malaga.

Anxiety for the lives of six British officers and men from the British Antarctic research ship Discovery II, feared lost on King George Island on the South Shetlands, was dispelled early this morning by a message received by the Colonial Office from the British cruiser Ajax.

Burial in a national cemetery rather than in a grave in potter's field loomed yesterday for Robert Merritt, 80-year-old ex-Indian fighter, as the result of an investigation by Detective William Parks of the Missing Persons Bureau.

Ending the silence that he maintained all through the recent monarchical crisis, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King today revealed to the Dominion Parliament that the Canadian Government had directly advised King Edward VIII not to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, whether she was to become Queen of England or merely a morganatic wife.
Stocks closed irregularly lower, motor shares weakest; turnover, 2,860,550 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporate and foreign bonds mixed; transactions, $12,749,500.

The Princeton Club team kept its position as the undefeated pace-setter of the Class B, Metropolitan Squash Tennis League's double round-robin by scoring its thirteenth consecutive victory last night.

Joseph Kelban, Brooklyn business agent of Local 306, Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, was held in $2,500 bail in Special Sessions in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of violating Section 1530 of the Penal Law, dealing with the commission of an act endangering the lives of other persons.

The wholesale and illegal slaughter of ducks by the millions for commercial markets, the intimidation of Federal game protectors and the protection of violators by public officials along the Atlantic seaboard from Cape Charles, Va., to Havre de Grace, Md., was charged last night by Harold K. Whitford, director of the Nature Study and Wild Life Conservation Association.

The Washington State activities of Federal agents assigned to the Mattson kidnapping case were concentrated in the Everett area, it was said today by Earl J. Connelly, agent in charge during the absence of Harold Nathan, who flew to Los Angeles yesterday. It was at Everett that the body of Charles Mattson, 10year-old victim of the kidnapping, was found.
Shaftel Stores, Inc., store for restaurant at 430 7th Av., from the Drymar Corp. for 15 years at total rental of about $350,000; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., and Adams Co., brokers.

Two armed men held up twentytwo men and one woman in the clubhouse of the Rugby Post of the American -Legion in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, at about 11 o'clock last night and robbed them of about $2.500 in money and Jewelry.

This is John R. Taft's story of Teddy, an independent dog. He said the family was discussing recently the purchase of a $2.25 license for the 12-year-old springer spaniel while the dog lolled at their feet with one ear cocked.
THE COLLECTED POEMS AND PLAYS OF RABINDRANATH TAGORE. (Macmillan, $3). The work of the 1913 Nobel Prize Winner.

An annual award for the nation's No. 1 air traveler has been established by four of the country's leading domestic airlines. The award for 1936 will go to Andre Kostalanetz, orchestra leader, who flew 126,000 miles as a passenger last year.

Being well aware of the New Jersey salt-water fisherman's affection for the sport, it was no surprise to this department to discover that the first annual dinner of the Tuna Club of Jersey City on Saturday evening was one of the most lively and diverting functions of the Winter season.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Tatum of Rumson, N. J., gave a dinner last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the twenty-first anniversary of their marriage.
A strike led by a 45-year-old woman closed the Continental Rubber Works today, throwing idle about 600 employes.
A Popular Front of Spain's militant youth today was drawing up a solemn pact whereby it stands pledged to carry on Spain's transformation in youth's own way.

Following upon a protest by Riza Khan Pahlevi, Shah of Iran [Persia], against a joke printed about him in a French magazine, Iran's Minister iii Paris tonight left hurriedly for his home capital of Teheran, sources close to the Foreign Office disclosed.

live hundred members and guests of the Society of the Genesee from New York City, Rochester and other Eastern points attended the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the society last night at the WaldorfAstoria.

Bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was extremely dull. Price movements in the various classifications gave a highly mixed tone to the market generally, with quotations a shade easier at the end of the day.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Shack of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Shack, to Melvin David Brod, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Brod of New York, formerly of Gadsden, Ala.

Orsola Buvoli, daughter of a poor Milan family, will be introduced to Rome society, it was learned today, at a large reception after she becomes. the bride of Vittorio, eldest son of Premier Benito Mussolini, Feb. 6.
About 2,000 friends and admirers of the late Joe Humphreys gathered last night in Madison Square Garden at a beefsteak dinner arranged by the Boxing Writers Association of New York.

With prices of apparel and household goods advancing, a growing trend to installment buying of these items will develop, Allen J. Michaels of Michaels Department Store, Newark, and president of the Credit Retailers Association, predicted yesterday at the opening of a three-day convention of the association in the Hotel Biltmore.

The thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Young Women's Hebrew Association at 31 West 110th Street will be celebrated there next Sunday at 3 P. M. Invitations have been issued by Mrs. Felix M. Warburg and members of the board of directors, of which Mrs. Warburg is president.

Many who originally opposed the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act now favor it, and further experimentation and study of the act to determine its real effectiveness is "wise," Gilbert Montague said yesterday in an address at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Associtation of Retail Secretaries, in conjunction with the meeting of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

County Judge Franklin Taylor strongly criticized Governor Lehman yesterday for his leniency toward convicted murderers. He warned that commutations of death sentences never should be exercised "in such a way as to raise widespread doubt and distrust," and the parole power should not be used "to the point of encouraging crime."

Ellsworth Vines squared his professional exhibition tennis accounts with Fred Perry by defeating the British star, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3, 5-7, 7-5, before a paid crowd of 9,753 tonight at the Boston Garden. It was the American's third straight victory in his six pro starts against the Briton.

Federal Judge William H. Holly today took action designed to clarify the legal status of the affairs of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, the utility holding company for control of which Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation of New York, and Harley L. Clarke, former president of the holding company, are contesting.

Joseph Compton, a member of the House of Commons and former chairman of the Labor party, died today. He was 55 years old. Mr. Compton was assistant secretary of the National Union of Vehicle Builders.

Edwin Goldschmidt of the Pastime Athletic Club defeated William Hepner of the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A., 21-10, 21-6, as play in the New York State A. A. U. four-wall handball championship opened at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.

Weekly apparel wool consumption in November at 6,010,000 pounds was the highest since 1922, with the exception of the November, 1985, period, according to figures released yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Our Bud, K. M. Holman's 4year-old brown gelding, captured the $600 Alamo Heights purse for 3-year-olds and upward at Alamo Downs today. In racing the mile and seventy yards in 1:503-5, Our Bud finished half a length ahead of Ace of Spades, while Lady Confucius was a length back of Ace of Spades in third place.

38th St., 38 W., s s, 21x98.9; Mary N. Holmes, et al. to Adin Realty Co., 475 5th Av. ($50). 94th St., 102 W., s s. 35x100: Mary A. Woods to 102 W. 94th St. Corp., 25 E. 129th St.: mtg., $18,000 ($17). Manhattan Av.. 22, e s, 27x100; Elizabeth Angevine to Amity Operating Co.: mtg., $22,500.

All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society were represented in the large audience which today heard Miss Helen Jepson, soprano, and Ezio Pinza, basso, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who were presented by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at her ninety-fourth Musical Morning at the Mayflower Hotel.
With Johnny Moir, sensational junior, setting the pace, Notre Dame upset the previously unbeaten Syracuse five, 52-31, tonight, ending a six-game winning streak for the Orange.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Douglas Sloane, daughter of Mrs. William Sloane of this city and Mount Kisco, N. Y., and of the late Mr. Sloane, to Dr. Robert Lee Patterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Patterson of Athens, Ga., has been announced by her mother.

Reuben Fine of New York today scored his first victory in the international chess masters tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club, defeating G. Danielsson, one of the Swedish representatives, in the third round.
Real estate assessors and members of the Board of Viewers were placed under fire today as a legislative committee began its investigation into the operations of Philadelphia's city-county government.

Eighteen organizations connected with the printing industry and the teaching of printing in New York joined yesterday morning in commemorating the 231st birthday of Benjamin Franklin in the Aldermanic Chamber in City Hall. After the exercises a wreath was placed upon the Franklin statue in Park Row.
Thousands of residents in lowland sections along the 980-mile Ohio River valley and tributary streams evacuated their homes tonight before a threatening flood.

Mrs. Herbert I. Foster of 3 Beekman Place and Cedarhurst, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betty Benjamin, to Peter Bradley Clark of New York, son of Mrs. Peter B. Clark of Westport, Conn., and of the late Mr. Clark.

Francis T. Hunter, former Davis Cup tennis player, and Miss Marjorie Franklin of New York obtained a marriage license here today. They will be married on Saturday at noon in the Pickwick Arms Hotel here by a justice of the peace. After the ceremony a reception will be held at the 21 Club, New York.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 13 shows a decrease of $56,000,000 in total loans and investments, and increase of $137,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, a decrease of $47,000,000 in government deposits and an increase of $119,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Declaring-that crimes of violence have been increasing on Morningside Heights, more than 600 residents of that area have petitioned Mayor La Guardia to provide more adequate police protection for Morningside Drive and vicinity.

Officials of the Irving Trust Company, consignee of the gold ingot that was missing from a shipment of 421 bars when the liner Paris arrived last week, said yesterday they had notified the shipper of the gold in Zurich but had received no answer.
Religious and moral grievances of the Arabs were heard at today's sessions of the Royal Commission, which ended its work in Palestine.

Great Britain is committed in world politics to the development of security, but she "could not undertake to buy off trouble" by offering trade concessions to aggressive nations in an effort at economic pacification, Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, declared yesterday.

The Argentine Republic intends to retire by Aug. 1 out of cash resources of its treasury $39,600,000 of its external 6 per cent bonds due in 1961 and 5 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1962, it was announced yesterday by C. Alonso Irigoyen, financial attache here, on behalf of Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz, Argentine Minister of Finance.

While John Gallagher, a station agent of the Ninth Avenue Elevated, lay in Bellevue Hospital in a critical condition yesterday, Michael Finnegan, 36-year-old ex-convict, admitted- in the line-up at police headquarters that he and an accomplice had held up Gallagher on Sunday night at the Fifty-ninth Street station of the elevated and forced him into a taxicab.
Textile machinery hummed at the Cabot Manufacturing Company plant in Brunswick today after a two weeks' strike, while labor troubles in Skowhegan and Millinocket remained unsettled.
Complimenting Prince and Princess Boris Scherbatow, Prince and Princess Balthasar Odescalchi entertained today with a tea at their villa.
Mrs. James A. Moffett, the former "Kim" Moran, said today that she planned to divorce her husband, former head of the Federal Housing Administration, "on grounds just as mild as can be."

The first result of the renewed conversations between the French Ambassador, Andre Francois-Poncet, and the German Foreign Minister, Baron Constantin von Neurath, which were recorded in yesterday's dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES, appears to be an increased inclination in important quarters toward a practical rapprochement with the Western democracies.

Robert S. Sinclair, who was credited with a large share in the development of the Essex County park system, died last night in Beth Israel Hospital at Newark. Mr. Sinclair, who was 84 years old, was president of the Essex County Park Commission for seventeen years.

The three five-and-a-half-story garden apartments covering the block at Freeman Street, West Farms Road and Boone Avenue, the Bronx, recently acquired by Samuel Resnick, operator, have been sold to Abraham Weinstein, in a deal' involving approximately $1,000,000.
State authorities were called into action today to halt delivery of coal in New York from the "bootleg" industry of Pennsylvania.

Counsel appointed to defend Major Green, Negro porter accused of the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case, interviewed their client yesterday for the first time and in subsequent remarks seemed to hint at a defense based on mental irresponsibility.

Acting on complaints received by the Dental Grievance Committee of the State Education Department, James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, started an investigation yesterday into what he described as "a new dental racket."

Acting on complaints received by the Dental Grievance Committee of the State Education Department, James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, started an investigation yesterday into what he described as "a new dental racket."

The processes of economic recovery now under way here and abroad justify the belief that despite political tensions the world is facing an era of peace, which will find expression, among other things, in the resumption of American investments abroad.

The equalization ratings which form the basis for apportionment of the $7,622,804 in county and State taxes betWeen the eighteen towns and four cities of Westchester County. for. 1937. were. presented to the Board of Supervisors today by the equalization committee and made a special order of business for next Monday.

A registration statement covering an issue of $75,000,000 first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series due in 1967, and 275,000 shares of no-par value cumulative preferred stock, $5 series, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company of 1935 by the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota, a member of the Standard Gas and Electric System.

The voluntary platform for retailing, adopted at a recent meeting of directors in Atlantic City, provoked unexpected and determined opposition when it came before the opening session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.
After starting at a lower level, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered under persistent trade calling yesterday and ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 1 point.

By a vote of 2 to 1, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals reversed yesterday an order of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson in which he enjoined Torr Co., stock brokers, from using the mails in their sale of stock of the TransLux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation.

Vernon Whittle vanquished Herbert Courtney, New York State amateur champion, 75 to 52, in 20 innings in the opening block of their 300-point pocket billiard match at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy last night.

J. C. Dolley, athletic council chairman, said tonight Dana X. Bible of Nebraska University might arrive tomorrow for a conference regarding his employment as head football coach at the University of Texas.

Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef will give a dinner dance at the Colony Club on Feb. 8 to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Mary Armstrong. Miss Jacqueline Godwin and her sister, Mrs. Ira Lawrence Hill,

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt left early this morning aboard their private air liner on a cruise of 14,000 miles in South America. They have as their guests Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington of New York and Palm Beach.
The British defense scheme in the Far East advanced another step with the announcement today that military defense works and barracks will be constructed at Penang.

MANHATTAN COLIN, BERNARD (March 9, 1936). Gross assets, $10,551; net, $8,741. To Lena R. Colin, widow, $8,741. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $6,744. Lawrence J. Ackerman, attorney, 123 William St.
Jobs were found yesterday for 280 of the 400 workers facing dismissal from the staff of the National Re-employment Service.

The city of Los Angeles Bureau of Power and Light will receive sealed bids today for the entire issue of $47,000,000 of revenue bonds, one-half of which will be in the form of serial bonds and the remainder in forty-year term bonds.
Aldo Spoldi, Italian lightweight, built up an early lead to gain a close ten-round decision over Phil Baker, sturdy boxer from Norwalk, Conn., in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The hog market was unsettled today, but showed an undertone of weakness. Early sales were made at 5 to 10 cents in advance of Saturday's prices, but later in the day most trading was at 10 to 20 cents under last week's close, with underweights off as much as 30 to 40 cents.

If the Spanish people are as thoroughly weary of their civil war as their Portuguese neighbors-and all reports here are that the civil population of Spain is sick to death of the sanguinary struggle-then an opportunity exists for outside intervention to end the agony.

Major John Henry Ingraham, formerly a member of the staff of Governor Charles Evans Hughes and captain of the 106th Infantry of the Twenty-third Regiment, New York National Guard, until his retirement a few years ago with the rank of major, died early this morning at the North Country Community Hospital after an illness of several weeks. His axe was 72.

The foreign exchange market moved narrowly yesterday and many of the leading currencies closed unchanged. The pound, however, was down 1-16 cent to $4.91 1-16 and the franc's final price of 4.67 1-16 cents was off 1-16 point.
Wary holders of gold sent $676,000,000 back into circulation during the last three months of 1936, the League of Nations announced today.

Steel operations for this week are estimated by the American Iron and Steel Institute at 80.6 per cent of ingot capacity, the highest level since March, 1930, and a new high record since the institute began compilation of estimated weekly operations in 1933.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set March 4 for hearing on an application by the Boston Stock Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in the no-par common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, and Studebaker Corporation's $1-par common stock.

An amendment to the Federal Trade Commission Act broadening the powers of the commission to allow it to take action in cases where it believes unfair competition is being used to the detriment of consumers and the public interest was introduced in the House today by Representative Lea of California, the new chairman of the Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, to which the bill was referred.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 15: LIEUTENANTS Bixby, H. L., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif., to the Utah. Duke, J. M., to duty as aide to the commandant of Naval Air Station, Pensacola,
Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, headed by Charles R. Gay, its president, conferred today with the governors of the Federal Reserve Board.
All seven remaining seeded players in the New York State squash Facquets championship at the Downtown A. C. advanced to the quarter-final round yesterday.

Robert Knuth, 46-year-old horticulturist, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in his car in the garage of his home at 1,535 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, at 7 o'clock last night. Police said his death was accidental.

The steamer Lafcomo, owned by the Lykes Brothers coastwise lines, which struck a sunken object in Vineyard Sound New Year's morning, was drydocked for repairs at the Bethehem Shipbuilding Corporation's East Boston yard today. Officials of the yard said it would cost $42,000 to repair the vessel.

The movement to rescue the lifesize bronze statue of Oscar Hammerstein from a second-hand shop and set it up in Central Park has brought in a few contributions, but the prospect of raising the $350 needed is not very promising, according to Edward Altman, trustee of the fund.
A formal order issued by the Supreme Court today closed the door to the efforts of William Lauro to test the legality of the act creating the New York Mortgage Commission.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York informed the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that it approved the proposal to require installation of automatic alarms on American ships of more than 5,500 gross tons, but opposed establishment of three radio watches.
Customary preparations are being made for the former Kaiser's seventy-eighth birthday on Jan. 27. The usual visitors are expected.

Discovery of a $10,000,000 combine which had put great quantities of crude tea 1 seed oil on the market as olive oil was announced today by Federal agents, who said they would seek indictment of at least ten persons, including officials of two New York refineries.
Mayor LA GUARDIA at a conference of child specialists brought forward the interesting suggestion that perhaps the average

Joseph Curran, leader of the rank-and-file seamen's strike committee in New York, led a delegation of 1,200 marchers from East Coast cities into Washington today to protest the continuous discharge-book provisions of the Copeland act.

Automobile production dropped last week due to the strike and the adjusted index receded to 95.2 from 100.6, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 18, 1936, the index was 110.8.

In answer to a statement by Mr. Homer Martin as published today, we wish to state as follows: Workers in the parts department of Cadillac were notified to report Monday in accordance with representations made to Messrs.

Despite curtailment measures for strict and record output figures month after month, Japanese rayon yarn producers continued with new installations of spindles late in 1936, F. A. Schuler Jr., vice consul at Kobe, reported today to the Department of Commerce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be hoped that THE NEW YORK TIMES will encourage its correspondent, Frank L. Kluckhohn, to develop in detail declarations in his recent dispatch from Mexico, D. F., headed 'Mexico Silencing Criticism Abroad," through "removing all grounds for complaint" by "indemnifying landowners" for the enormous amount of rural property that has been confiscated.
J. A. Sisto Co. today offer at par 75,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred $25-par stock of the Davega Stores Corporation.

In furtherance of its school expansion program the Board of Education awarded contracts yesterday for new building projects totaling more than $800,000 at a special meeting at the Department of Education Building, 500 Park Avenue.
William (Bill) McCorry, former manager of Albany teams in the International and Eastern Leagues, left today for Scranton, Pa., seeking a New York-Penn League franchise.

Sales in December by twentyseven chain store companies, including two mail-order houses, amounted to $367,722,326, an increase of 19.19 per cent from December, 1935, when sales were $308,516,869, according to a compilation by Merrill, Lynch Co.
