A large audience attended Albert Morris Bagby's 396th Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Miss Marjorie Lawrence, who sang instead of Miss Lucrezia Bori, who was unable to appear; Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera, and Beveridge Webster, pianist. The accompanists were Pablo Miguel and Frederick Bristol.

Paul Hindemith, German composer, will appear before the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's public when he comes to this country, for the first time, in April. He will be heard as soloist in the New York premiere of his concerto for viola and orchestra, "Der Schwanendreher," it was announced yesterday.

The Peddie School basketball team today defeated the Princeton freshmen, 41 to 23, for its fourth straight victory of the season. Dick Hanley and Jack Cronin were high scorers for Peddie, tallying ten and eleven points respectively. Jordan, with nine points, was high for Princeton.

The Iranian Parliament is considering ratification of an oil concession in the districts of Khorassan in Eastern Iran and in Eastern Mazanderan, which has been granted to the new Amiranian Oil Company formed under the auspices of the Seaboard Oil Company, Texas Oil Corporation and other American groups.
The Maritime Commission announced today that it would advertise for bids on Feb. 1 for one-year charters for four government-owned steamship lines now being operated by agents for the commission.

A bill authorizing the City of New York to erect and equip, at a cost of $15,000,000, a building to take the place of the Criminal Courts Building and Tombs Prison, was received at the Capitol tonight.

Swift Co., in conjunction with Armour Co., held a virtual monopoly until last Spring on the meat business of ten ships operated by C. H. Sprague Sons Co. for the United States Government, it was disclosed yesterday at the hearing of a complaint of unfair trade practices against Swift Co.
A small group of Republican district leaders started a drive in Brooklyn yesterday to supplant their county chieftain, John R. Crews, but at a late hour last night they had not made much headway.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 16 unless specified: At San Pedro: Argonne, Bobolink. At San Diego: Marblehead, Perry. Antares, Balboa to San Diego. Asheville, Hong Kong to Swatow, Jan. 18. Brazos, Pearl Harbor to Mare Island Yard. Bridge, San Pedro to Pyramid Cove, Jan. 18.

Mrs. May Jerauld, wife of Dr. Frederick N. C. Jerauld, was found dead in bed in her apartment here today. She was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Huddleston of Buffalo and 'a cousin of Mrs. Thomas J. Preston, the former Mrs. Grover Cleveland.

The movement to rescue the lifesize bronze statue of Oscar Hammerstein from a second-hand shop and set it up in Central Park has brought in a few contributions, but the prospect of raising the $350 needed is not very promising, according to Edward Altman, trustee of the fund.
A formal order issued by the Supreme Court today closed the door to the efforts of William Lauro to test the legality of the act creating the New York Mortgage Commission.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York informed the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that it approved the proposal to require installation of automatic alarms on American ships of more than 5,500 gross tons, but opposed establishment of three radio watches.
DETROIT--Governor Murphy left for Washington to seek Federal aid in the automobile strike, after a new breakdown of peace negotiations.

Reuben Fine of New York added two games to his score today in the international masters' tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club, thereby moving into first place for the first time and leaving G. Stahlberg and G. Stoltz, two of Sweden's finest players, in second and third places, respectively.

Various devices for the selling of advertising space in chain stores are under consideration by leading organizations in the drug, tobacco and food field and within another few weeks are expected to be offered to manufacturers, according to comment here yesterday.

Net earnings of the First Boston Corporation for 1936 were $3,172,351, or about $6.34 a share on the 500,000 shares of capital stock, according to the annual report of the corporation, received by shareholders yesterday. These earnings compared with $3,308,786, or $6.61 a share, in 1935.

Threats of a damaging flood in the Pittsburgh industrial region passed today with the waters of the three rivers converging in the "Steel City" reaching a peak level of 28.1 feet-far below the disastrous highwater mark of the big March flood.

The tension between the strikers and "loyal" employes here of the General Motors Corporation was somewhat eased today by the willingness of the Flint Alliance to avoid pressing its demands for an immediate conference with the company.

Alberto de Oliveira, author of a dozen volumes which won him the title of "Prince of Brazilian Poets," died today. He was 79 years old. Antonio Mariano Alberto de Oliveira, university professor as well as an author, was born in Palmital de Saguarema, State of Rio de Janeiro, on April 28, 1857, son of Jose Mariano and Anna Mariano

Japan's new exchange policy, which has caused some anxiety in Washington, is aimed only at checking speculative buying abroad, according to information received in Japanese banking circles in New York. The object is to keep the country's currency in harmony with the agreement between the United States, Britain and France.

Fearing legal reprisals because of his refusal to fulfill his contract with the Warner Brothers, Robert Donat has advised R.-K.-O. that he will not come to Hollywood in April to make the frequently postponed "Clementine."

Jesse Bernhard, deputy chief clerk of the Traffic Court, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 123-20 Eighty-fifth Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, of a coronary thrombosis at the age of 64. His widow survives.

Judge George T. McDermott of the Tenth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals died of pneumonia tonight in a hospital here. He was 50 years old. A native Kansan, Judge McDermott was one of the youngest men to hold the posts of Federal circuit and district judge.

SOME years ago I came into possession of a curious volume dedicated to the proposition that Mark Twain was not only Mark Twain but also Edgar Allan Poe, Nathaniel Hawthorne and Lewis Carroll. From time to time since then I have, in idle moments, pored over the evidence offered: the paragraphs of argument, the diagrams, the footnotes and the illustrations, applying what powers of reason I had, what discern-ment, what patience.

The Andrew Radel Oyster Company of South Norwalk, Conn., filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to restrain George M. Still, Inc., of this city from alleged infringement of its trade-mark, "Robbins Island Oysters."

Government reports declare that General Peng Teh-huai, famous Communist leader, has been made field commander of all the troops in the vicinity of Sian, General Yang Fu-cheng retaining administrative control of the city after having donated $250,000 for the upkeep of the Communist armies and having supplied the Reds with munitions and other war materials.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Captain Joseph Marino, Med. Res., 1,737 W. 4th St., Brooklyn, N. Y., 8th Medical Regiment (RAI), is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Jan. 20. He will proceed to Headquarters, Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for duty in connection with CCC activities. Captain Marino will rank from Jan. 20.
Elliott Roosevelt Jr., 7 months old and youngest grandchild of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, was christened this afternoon in the White House.

BACHMANN, ANNIE FLORENCE (Jan. 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Norbert H. Bachmann, husband, executor, 791 Park Av., residue. BERNSTEIN, TILLIE BENEDICT (Jan. 13). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lina Benedict, sister, Stamford Hall, Stamford, Conn., life estate in residue; Margaret Benedict, niece, 901 Lake Dr., Baltimore, Md., and Mindelle Pinto, niece, 98 Riverside Dr., household, personal effects and remainders in residue.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that the time for exchanging its $7 cumulative second preferred stock for common stock and new $5 'convertible preferred stock has been extended to the close of business on March 13.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company had a net loss of $177,501 in 1936, George McAneny, chairman of the board, reported to shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday. This loss, which Mr. McAneny said was entirely in the first six months of the year, compared with a net loss of $244,253 for 1935.

Postmaster General Farley alone of President Roosevelt's Cabinet will be reappointed, it was learned today. The President will send Mr. Farley's name to the Senate for confirmation within the next few days.

Compromise, as the very art and life of politics, has been praised by many public men, writing from different points of view. Compare MACAULAY, for instance, with JOHN MORLEY. Both wrote about compromise, the former with the relish of "the great Whig pamphleteer," as he has been called, the latter with the austerity of a severe political moralist, but both came to conclusions not so far apart.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, appealed to the voluntary hospitals of New York yesterday to enter a "gentlemen's agreement" with the city institutions to provide more facilities during disease epidemics. He has proposed that the voluntary hospitals postpone non-emergency surgical cases at such times to augment the municipal facilities.
Jimmy McLeod, Tacoma (Wash.) lightweight, battled to a draw with Johnny Morro, Bronx veteran, in the main bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night before 8,000 spectators.
Unable to reach an accord, representatives of the "big five" railroad brotherhoods adjourned today without having reconciled their differences on proposed wage increase demands.

Members of the Medical Society of Westchester County, oldest county medical society in the United States, meeting tonight in the auditorium of the local branch of New York Hospital, adopted a resolution urging the American Medical Associtation to set up a public relations department to combat by propaganda efforts to establish compulsory health insurance.
Fred Lux, former contractor, was killed instantly this morning when his car was in a head-on collision with a seven-ton beer truck on the Boston Post Road here.
Mrs. Joseph Scotko, 22 years old, mother of two children, was evicted by a city marshal yesterday afternoon from a three-room rear flat at 160 West 100th Street.

Miss Elizabeth Wathen Spalding, daughter of Mrs. William Francis Spalding of Atlanta and the late Mr. Spalding, was married here yesterday noon at the Gotham to James White Jr., son of Mrs. James White of Athens, Ga. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George H. Smyth of Scarsdale, N. Y., in the presence of the two families.

Canada's national defense estimates, now before the House of Commons, have soared this year. For the military, naval and air forces $33,703,873 is asked, an increase over last year's main estimates of $14,368,434.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made known today that the Derby Gas and Electric Corporation, a Delaware concern, had decided against the issuance of a $5,000,000 collateral judgment 5 per cent note to the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Ltd., of Canada, for which a covering declaration had been filed.

Nearly all sections of the stock market here today had a uniformly dull day. There was little selling pressure, but trading was at a low ebb. British Government issues followed a downward trend, both the war and the old consolidated loans declining.

Albany, N. Y., was conditionally voted a franchise in the New YorkPennsylvania League at a meeting of club owners today, replacing Allentown, Pa. The Scranton team was continued as a member of the circuit.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara L. Silvers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Homer I. Silvers of this place, to Josiah C. McCracken Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Josiah C. McCracken of Shanghai.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN John Hummel, 92d Precinct at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 10 1911. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Charles F. Armstrong from 7th Division to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued. Jacob A. Licker, from 8th Division to 7th Division, assignment to desk duty continued.

The story of a loan shark victim who paid $640 interest within a year on a $100 loan which still is outstanding, was revealed last night with the arrest of three men in a drive against usury by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney.

Sales of several apartment houses and of a site for a new multi-family building were listed among the Bronx real estate transactions yesterday. The five-story house at 2,065 Walton Avenue, adjoining the corner of Burnside Avenue, was bought by Irving 0. Freedman from Jospeh A.
Brother Adolph Leo, master of novices at the Marist Brothers Novitiate St. Ann's Hermitage near here, died today after an illness of less than a week.

Seventy-three pupils of the city schools and their parents were in the ballroom of the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon for the award of prizes at the close of the Outdoor Cleanliness Poster Contest.

Starting a new type of passenger air service, the first "sky-lounges" of United Air Lines flew in both directions between Newark and Chicago yesterday. Fourteen revolving chairs in a 21-passenger cabin gave unusual freedom of movement and spaciousness to the Douglas Dc-3 planes.
A special committee of the House to handle President Roosevelt's plan for governmental reorganization was appointed by Speaker Bankhead today.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Monday at his home in New Haven, Conn., of George Adams Woods, vice president of the A. C. Gilbert Company and a former realty operator in Boston and Winchester, Mass. In Boston he built the Wilbur Theatre and the west wing of the State House.

The old-style boarding house seems to be regaining popularity, Miss Irma Berger, executive secretary of the Association to Promote Proper Housing for Girls, told members of the association at its annual meeting yesterday in the Club Marshall, 109 East Thirteenth Street. The increased demand for boarding house accommodations in recent months has been considerable, she said.

The National Power Policy Committee, formed yesterday by the President to draft a legislative program with respect to power from Federal hydro-electric projects, met this afternoon and began consideration of ways and means to make the President's suggestions effective.

The Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children at Farmingdale, N. J., gave 65,683 days' service to 783 children in 1936, it was reported yesterday by Bradley Martin, president of the institution, at its annual meeting at its New York office, 171 Madison Avenue.

Most commodity futures sold off again yesterday in active trading. Sugar and silk futures were firm. On the cash markets all the grains, dairy products, cotton, printcloths, lard, rubber, silk and tin declined.

Carnegie Hall housed Ferde Grofe, the jazz maestro, and his orchestra last night. And judging by the spontaneous outbursts of applause from the moderate-sized audience, Mr. Grofe scored a hit with his program of American compositions.
Hobart Av. (15-4170), n. w. cor. of Roberts Av., 100x100; Thomas C. Patterson Jr., referee, to P. Walker Morrison, trustee, 122 E. 42d St. Stratford Av. (14-3743) n. w. cor. of Watson Av., 100x100;

Capacity air traffic for fourteen scheduled flights of Eastern Lines to Washington today in connection with the inauguration of President Roosevelt was announced last night by Captain E. V. Rickenbacker, general manager.

Members of various organizations of Southerners living in New York attended the supper dance held last night at Sherry's to mark the birthday of General Robert E. Lee. During the evening Justice William Harman Black of the New York Supreme Court spoke.

WPA expenditures in this city in January will total between $16,000,000 and $17,000,000, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, estimated yesterday. In addition, the WPA will draw about $1,500,000 worth of materials from its warehouse stock.

Has anybody explained why the descendants of a Scots saddler who settled in London about the time of the American Revolution should for generations attain distinction in many fields, most notably in the law? Sir FREDERICK POLLOCK, dead in his ninety-second year, was perhaps the most accomplished member of the famous line. Coauthor with the incomparable MAITLAND of the "History of English Law,"

Evidence that the bitterness stirred up by the Archbishop of Canterbury in broadcast remarks Dec. 13 on King Edward's abdication was still very much alive was illustrated on the floor of the House of Commons today when a member was cut short by the Speaker in the midst of an attack on the prelate and the British Broadcasting Corporation.

The Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland had an underwriting profit of $1,369,810 in 1936, Charles R. Miller, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the stockholders in Baltimore. The underwriting profit in 1935 was $490,169.

The attorneys in the restaurant racket trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook undertook yesterday the exhaustive task of selecting a jury sympathetic to labor from a blue-ribbon panel. At the end of the day one man was in the jury box.

The great losses sustained by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad from what he terms the road's "outside investments" were today cited by O. L. Mohundo, an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, in recommending that the commission's powers be extended by law over such investments for all railroads.
Peter J. McGuinness, Kings County Sheriff, admitted yesterday that he had accepted on Monday the resignation of William R. White, a deputy who had been emplayed in the Sheriff's office for six years.

Disclosure that the State Milk Control Division was seeking to revoke the license of the Borden Company as a milk dealer was made here today after a private hearing at which Borden officials opposed the revocation.

Henry Janssen, president of the Textile Machine Works of Reading, manufacturer of full-fashioned hosiery knitting machines, was called to the witness stand in Federal court here today by counsel for the defense in the patentinfringement suit brought by Julius Kayser Co. and the Textile Patents Corporation.

Fresh significance to President Roosevelt's moves for world peace based on economic stabilization along liberal lines was given today in the selection of Dr. Henry F. Grady, dean of the College of Commerce at the University of California, and former chief of the Trade Agreements Division of the State Deapartment, as the American member of the Economics Committee of the League of Nations.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public the following amendment to its rules governing the issuance of subpoenas requiring submission of personal or documentary evidence:

More than 18,500 students at Columbia University will take final examinations, beginning this morning and ending on Saturday, Jan. 30, Edward J. Grant, registrar of the university, announced yesterday.

Acting as a district judge, Martin T. Manton, presiding judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, yesterday authorized a 5 per cent dividend, amounting to $285,693, to the holders of allowed claims against the Fox Theatres Corporation.
McCombs Rd. (11-2865), s. e. cor. of Mt. Eden Av., 151x114; also Inwood Av., s. w. cor. of Mt. Eden Av., 49x200x irregular; Macombs Inwood Realty Corp. to Irving Trust Co.;

The Greenwich Rosemary Alumnae, of which Mrs. David S. Baker and Mrs. George W. Vanderhoef Jr. are co-chairmen, gave a tea at the Field Club today in honor of Mrs. Huntington Hooker Cary, new administrative director of Rosemary Hall School here.

With only one important New York State Federal post open, that of District Judge in the Western District, a surprisingly large number of New Yorkers have arrived for President Roosevelt's second inauguration.

Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood ruled today that the Tennessee Valley Authority could proceed in Georgia with its power program, which had been halted following a temporary restraining order granted in Tennessee.

Business failures increased in four groups but declined in the retail division in the week ended Jan. 14, compared with the previous five business days, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Five almost forgotten best sellers of another day are being reprinted by the American Book Company and are scheduled for publication in early February. They are to be part of the new American fiction series.

The circumstances of the dismissal last week of five government dockyard workers became an issue in the House of Commons today when Clement R. Attlee, the Opposition leader, pressed Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, for details of the Admiralty's action.

The average price received for raw sugar by the Punta Alegre Corporation last year, both in the domestic and world markets, was slightly better than .9 cent a pound, William C. Douglas, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. He added that refiners had entered the market early, and that no unsold sugar remained on hand on Nov. 1.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Jan. 16: Lhamon, Comdr. R. M., Med. Corps, to continue duty at the Naval Hospital, Mare Island, Calif., pending further orders; previous orders modified.

The police have arrested many persons, including several women, after investigations in connection with the raid made last week on an allegedly Communist hangout in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro. Documents seized in the raid, according to the police, revealed the existence of a well-planned movement to reorganize the outlawed National Liberation Alliance.
The middle and lower Ohio River Valleys organized rescue and relief forces tonight for a prolonged siege of flood waters promising to reach heights comparable to those of the 1936 inundation.

Chelan watched the "kitty" grow tonight as C. C. Fleming, who must spend $200 in a month as a test of the Townsend plan, went happily on his way buying toothpaste and cordwood and talking of a movie career for himself.

Because the prosecution's principal witness testified that he had asked a woman undertaker if she knew a lawyer, Carl R. Wittekind, a lawyer with an office at 277 Broadway, and Nicholas Ferranti, one of his aides, were acquitted yesterday by Justices Salomon, Bayes and Kocizki in the Extraordinary Term of Special Sessions on an ambulance-chasing charge.

Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana of Lenox, Mass., are at the Gotham. Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef will give a dinner-dance to introduce her daughter, Miss Mary Armstrong, on Feb. 5 at the Carlyle before the final Junior Assembly for this season.

J. A. Sisto Co. announced yesterday that subscription books covering their offering of 75,000 shares of Davega Stores Corporation 5 per cent convertible preferred stock had been closed and that subscriptions exceeded the offering.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 18: Smith, Brig. Gen. A. T., ordered to command Third Brigade, instead of the Second Division, at Fort Sam Houston, Texas. Olmstead, Col. D., Signal Corps, Washington D. C., to Army and Navy General Hospital, Hot Springs National Park, Ark., for observation and treatment.

Sir Leicester Harmsworth, long a Member of Parliament and younger brother of Lord Rothermere and the late Lord Northcliffe, died today at his country home in Bexhill after a long illness at the age of 66.

Mrs. Charlotte Connah Brown, temperLnce leader, church worker, philanthropist, suffragist, club woman and musician, died at her home, 95 Pennington Avenue, at 11 o'clock last night, in her eighty-ninth year. She was the widow of A. Swan Brown.

A strong field, headed by Glenn Cunningham, is being lined up for the special three-quarter mile handicap event which will feature the Grover Cleveland-Osceola Club games at the Seventh Regiment Armory Saturday night. Cunningham filed his entry yesterday.

President Roosevelt expects to take the oath of office tomorrow on the same family Bible upon which his hand rested four years ago as he repeated the oath after Chief Justice Hughes. The only thing that may prevent the use of this relic is rainy weather; in that case the cherished volume will be supplanted by another.

The marriage of Mrs. Winifred Cartwright Holhan Hooker, daughter of Mrs. Francis Holhan of 950 Park Avenue, to Dimitri Sergius von Mohrenschildt took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother.
Foreseeing a turbulent session when the Imperial Diet reconvenes tomorrow, the government has enrolled and armed a corps of 1,500 special guards for the Diet premises.
The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during December at 134.5 per cent of capacity, compared with 129.9 in November and 103.8 in December, 1935.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would like very much "to go to Washington and stay there" as he talked at police headquarters to a delegation of 163 selected policemen who left at 11 o'clock last night to represent the city at the inauguration of President Roosevelt today.

Four hours after he had fired three shots through a window of his home here to drive away persons he believed were trying to break in, Salvatore Lamonica, 80 years old, stepped onto the porch and found that his son Paul, aged 52, had been the victim of the shots and lay dead. The aged man, horrified at his discovery, rushed to neighbors, who notified the police.
Governor Lehman's Social Security Bill, upon which the Senate, with its ample Democratic majority, has acted favorably, is slated for passage in the Assembly, where the Republicans are in control.

James E. Bennet, attorney, spent the second session of his ecclesiastical trial yesterday in the church house of the First Presbyterian Church, 12 West Twelfth Street, contesting the jurisdiction of a special judicial commission elected by the Synod of New York to try him.

President Roosevelt has told some members of his Cabinet that in his inaugural address tomorrow he will deal specifically and in detail with the principal problems confronting the nation and that they might expect in it a frank discussion of the course he intends to pursue in the next four years.

The Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries expended $9,654,858 on additions and improvements to their property during 1936 and retired from service and charged against depreciation $4,707,156 of plant property, Alex Dow, president, said yesterday in his annual report.

President Angell of Yale University announced today the selection of Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States and France, for the Henry E. Howland Memorial Prize of a medal and $1,500 awarded "in recognition of marked distinction in the field of literature or fine arts or the science of government."

Hoskins VanHooser, controller and assistant treasurer of the Times Printing Company, by which The Chattanooga Times is published, died of a heart attack this afternoon in Erlanger Hospital, after three weeks of illness.

President Roosevelt voiced faith tonight in the adaptability of democracy to modern needs. In a written message to a dinner of the National Electoral College Committee, Mr. Roosevelt said: "The overwhelming victory which your votes registered is a measure of the responsibility which goes with so overwhelming a popular mandate.

To prevent any slackening in the anti-Jewish boycott, the Central National Health Office has issued a new appeal to all Germans to boycott Jewish physicians. The appeal, published in the periodical Aim and Way, reads:
Southern California citrus growers were warned today to prepare for a second general freeze similar to that ten days ago in which damage estimated by some at $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 was done.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today appointment of members of a joint board for Maryland, Pennsylvania and West Virginia to have jurisdiction over operations of motor carriers. They are Harold E. West of the Maryland Public Service Commission, Baltimore;

George Arthur Smith, principal of Public School No. 2 here since 1905 and who four years ago completed his twentieth year as principal of Yonkers Evening High School, died this morning at St. John's Riverside Hospital of pneumonia after an operation.
Thomas K. O'Brien, large house in Gedney Farms section of White Plains; Ioughton Co., broker. M. S. Burroughs, at 126 Walworth Av., White Plains; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker.

Funeral services for Dr. Herman H. B. Meyer, former chief bibliographer of the Library of Congress and chief of its legislative reference service from 1921 until his retirement in November, 1935, were held here today, with a number of representatives of the scientific and learned societies of which Dr. Meyer was a member attending.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Trott Pearman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Pearman of Pembroke, Bermuda, to Walton Ferguson 3d, son of Mrs. Walton Ferguson Jr. of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Ferguson, will take place at noon today in St. John's Church, Pembroke.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 19, unless specified: Asheville ,at Swatow. Badger, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Tompkinsville. Balch, Callao, Peru, to Valparaiso, Chile, Jan. 18.

A gift of $4,000 from Hubert E. Rogers to the United Hospital Fund campaign was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive. He also reported that employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the American District Telegraph Company of New Jersey had donated $1,767.

Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Meyer of 1,225 Park Avenue will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary with a reception on Monday afternoon, Feb. 15, at the Women's Faculty Club of Columbia University, Morningside Drive at 117th Street.
The extradition of Miguel Figueroa from Cuba on a charge of the murder of Mrs. Martina Lebron in New York on Oct. 13, 1936, was asked today by the United States Embassy..

A large portion (about threefourths) of the Vincent Van Gogh exhibition that in 1935 broke attendance records at the Museum of Modern Art has returned to the museum after traveling about the country and will be opened to the public today.

A goal in the third period by Butch Keeling put the Rangers on even terms with the Canadiens of Montreal in their game at Madison Square Garden last night. Keeling's thrust sent the rival sextets into overtime, but no score was forthcoming in the extra session, with the result that the teams had to be content with a 1-to-1 tie.

Restrictions imposed by Japan on foreign exchange operations and a reactionary tendency in commodity markets generally brought sufficient selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday to drop prices 4 to 10 points. Commission houses and spot interests distributed contracts, with buying tempered by the approaching release of government cotton and the developments in the motor industry.

Renewal of the drive for a constitutional amendment establishing an over-all limitation on real estate taxation by municipalities was announced today by Ray Hofford, secretary of the State Tax Limitation Committee.

A project that would make Spanish citizenship available to many foreigners if enacted into law was disclosed tonight as under consideration by the Spanish Government. [Rome reports Monday took for granted that such a law was already in operation.
Stock of the United States Steel Corporation outstanding on Dec. 31, last, amounted to 8,703,252 common shares and 3,602,811 preferred shares, the corporation announced yesterday.

Patrick J. Condon, an undertaker here for fifty-three years and a former Hudson County Freeholder, died last night at St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, after an operation performed Saturday for a stomach ailment.

Lieut. Col. Cronhope Baille-Wright, father of former Lieutenant Norman Baille-Stewart, who is serving a five-year sentence for betraying British Army secrets to Germany, died of a heart attack in Bristol tonight within eighteen days of a scheduled reunion with his son, in whose honor he never lost faith. He was 61.

For the first time since Marshal John Metaxas established his dictatorship a Greek newspaper has been able to publish a report indicating that feeling against the regime is growing throughout the country, according to news reaching here.

In the most insistent appeal to Germany that has yet come from any British statesman, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden begged the rulers of the Nazi Reich tonight to consider where they were going and to cooperate with the rest of Europe while there still was time.

Members of the American Society of Landscape 'Architects approved yesterday the appointment of a committee to collect data on the cost of maintenance of various park areas throughout the country at the second day's session of their annual meeting, held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ratsey of Cowes, Isle of Wight, England, gave a tea yesterday at the Weylin. Among their guests were Mrs. Skeffington S. Norton, Mr. and Mrs. Skeffington S. Norton Jr., Mrs. Norton Soule, Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Smith,

Viola Gentry, flier, went aloft at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday and scattered the ashes of her husband, Ensign John R. Warren, who died last week. She was a passenger in a plane of the Naval Reserve unit stationed at the field, to which her husband belonged, flown by Lieutenant John L. Remmert.

Robert Weston Faulls, 19, of Warwick, N. Y., Louisiana State University freshman cadet, was found seriously wounded by a shot tonight on a Mississippi levee near the university campus. Authorities began an immediate investigation.

Sam Ackerman conquered Charles Cass, 100 to 49, in forty innings, and Edward Sussman halted Harry Schuler, 100 to 79, in sixty frames in the national snooker championship tournament at McGirr's Academy last night. High runs were: Ackerman 21, Cass 7, Sussman 8 and Schuler 11.

Another great public treason trial will begin here Saturday, when Karl Radek, former Soviet commentator, and sixteen others will face the military collegium of the Supreme Court. Simultaneously with the announcement today of the start of this trial it became known that Nikolai Bukharin, well-known Bolshevik, had just been removed from the editorship of Izvestia, Soviet Government organ.

Miss Mary Robinson of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married here to Gerard G. Barber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Barber of Hartford, Conn., and Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie.

A chemist, about 52 years old, who recently had been working as a photographer because he could not find work in his profession, committed suicide at noon yesterday by drinking the contents of a small bottle of poison in an anteroom near the lobby in the Rockefeller Institute, Sixty-sixth Street and York Avenue. He died eleven minutes later.

The kingpin of the Giants' pitching staff, the redoubtable Carl Hubbell, yesterday joined the ranks of signed athletes under the banner of Horace Stoneham, bringing the total under agreement to eleven.

Two men sought since Sunday night, when Frank Cicero of Stamford, Conn., was stabbed to death before 677 dinner guests in the Manhattan Opera House, surrendered to the police yesterday. They were booked at the West Thirtieth

Stocks closed slightly firmer at generally lower levels after several selling waves; turnover, 2,619,110 shares. United States Government bonds lower, corporate and foreign issues irregularly lower; transactions, $13,884,200.

A gas shut-off affecting the whole west end of Toledo was averted late today when operating engineers of the Northwestern Ohio Gas Company's artificial gas plant postponed a threatened walkout for twenty-four hours.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, prepared today to invest $1,798,205 of New York State funds in Federal Housing Administration mortgages against 390 new residences erected in the State. Authority for investment in the per cent mortgages, to be made in behalf of the State Retirement Fund, was granted by the 1936 Legislature.
The Westchester Golf Association yesterday announced the selection of the Pelham Country Club as the scene of its annual amateur championship this year, the dates set for the event being June 10-12.
A shipment of $3,363,700 gold from Canada was received here yesterday. No engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported, but a decline in the price of sterling,

William A. Greer, 66-year-old banker and a son of the late Bishop David Hummell Greer, was declared mentally incompetent to manage his personal business in a competency proceedings brought before Commissioner Daniel W. Blumenthal and a Sheriff's jury of thirteen men in the Hall of Records yesterday.
Many upsets, including the elimination of the medal winner, were registered in the first round of match play in the annual Miami Biltmore invitation amateur golf tournament today.

Heavyweights will provide the action at the Hippodrome tonight when Gunnar Barlund, the Finnish fighter with the paralyzing punch, continues his campaign for recognation as a title threat by meeting a newcomer.

Mrs. E. Nelson Fell, the former Anne Palmer of New York, died at Sutton-Valence, Kent, England, on Jan. 13, after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. She was about 80 years old.

Freak cross-fox pelts brought from $155 to $200 today at the auction of the Canadian Fur Sales Auction Company, with demend good for all types of skins on the block, including white fox, blue fox, lynx, beaver and wolf.

A broker is an agent for his customer, but the relationship is not one of lawyer to client or of physician to patient, and he is not privileged to withhold records on the ground that their surrender for official scrutiny would be a breach of confidence, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

The Cunard-White Star liner Berengaria is due today from Southampton and Cherbourg. Among those on board are Miss Sara Allgood, Irish actress; Miss Anne Chilton, daughter of the British Ambassador to Spain; the Duchess of Leeds, Countess Sylvia de Nevasquez, W. R. D. Perkins, Gerald Sanger,

Frederick W. Erdtmann has been elected president of the Jamaica Real Estate Board for another year. Other officers to serve with him again are James G. Debevoise, vice president: Thomas F. Reid, vice president; Herman Seldin, treasurer, and Harry Tankoos, secretary.
Gordon Kingsley, aviator searching for his brother, William Kingsley, who was lost a week ago, has now been missing since last Saturday after being forced down in the mountains in Eastern Nicaragua.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT will take his oath of office today as President of the United States in circumstances that differ greatly from those which marked his first inauguration. The measure of the change is not alone the fact that depression has yielded to recovery. There is a new spirit of confidence which rests on a broader basis than the evidence furnished by gains in industrial activity, in employment, in payrolls and in profits.

Mrs. Olivia Phelps James Hoe, widow of Robert Hoe 3d of the Hoe printing press company, left an estate valued yesterday in the transfer tax appraisal at $282,951 gross and $187,917 net. Mrs. Hoe, who was an aunt of Arthur Curtiss James, financier, left property at Sea Cliff, valued at $4,000, to the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. She died on Aug. 3, 1935. at the age of 98.

Funeral services for D. Henry Brown of Riverhead, former Sheriff of Suffolk County, former county Democractic leader, banker and retired merchant, held in Grace Episcopal Church here today, were attended by several hundred persons.

James H. Hansen, secretary-manager of the Brick Manufacturers Association of New York, told the opening session of the annual convention of the Brick Manufacturers Association of America today that "50 per cent" of building codes in cities of the United States were out of date.
One of the game's young stars who made great strides in the past season, Stanley Galowin, N. Y. U. student, gained the semi-final round of the New York State squash

Questioned by the police since 4:30 P. M. yesterday when he was picked up at Grand and Columbia Streets, Joseph Stella, 19 years old, of 153 Broome Street, was booked at the West Sixty-eighth Street station at 2:20 A. M. today on a charge of first-degree robbery as one of five men who held up Barney's Clothes, Inc., Seventh Avenue and Seventeenth Street, on Jan. 2.

Declaring determination to pay his debts to the last sen, Marquis Yorisada Tokugawa, former millionaire member of the House of Peers, patron of music and art and host to hundreds of visiting celebrities, has, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi, abandoned his fortune, including his villa in the outskirts of Tokyo, for the benefit of his creditors.
In his eightieth year Harry W. Watrous, former president of the National Academy of Design, is preparing for his first one-man exhibition of paintings.

With the usual Tuesday increase due to the late reporting of new cases that developed over the weekend, yesterday's report on new influenza and pneumonia cases showed a slight increase over the report for the preceding forty-eight hour period.

" Popeye," the altogether unpredictable monkey whose mad antics led the fleetest of the Jersey City police force a thankless week-long chase about the dockyards a year ago after he had escaped from a fruit boat, was the victim of a hitand-run truck driver today while he was playing in the street in front of the junk yard which had become his home.

Federal aeronautics officials heard today the first authentic report of the Western Air Express transport wreck of Jan. 11 from the bruised lips of the pilot, William W. Lewis. Major B. W. Schroeder, airline inspector for the Bureau of Air Commerce, and James Kinney, his Los Angeles aide, were the listeners.
The Earle administration bill setting up a commission to study the bootleg coal problem was passed unanimously by the House today and sent to the Senate for concurrence.
An army amphibian bomber of the latest type arrived at the Coast Guard air base at 5 P. M. (Eastern standard time), today after a flight of nearly ten hours from New York.
Republican leaders in the Assembly today offered the position of journal clerk, paying a salary of $7,500 a year, to Miss Natalie Couch of Nyack, to succeed William Brennan of Herkimer County.

A suggestion that communities of the State gradually place home relief on a pay-as-you-go basis, preferably on a five-year program to start in 1938, will be made to Governor Lehman by the State Board of Social Welfare, it was announced yesterday.

Foolproof, a black and white pointer dog owned by Hilsman Walters of Albany, Ga., lived up to his name today to capture first place in the all-age stake that closed the sixth annual Southern amateur field trials.
Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. has written to the clerks of the various magistrates' courts in Brooklyn urging that the number of adjournments be reduced, it was announced yesterday.

Manhattan York Av., 1,114-16; 72x28; 1-story gas station; Socony Vacuum Oil Co., Inc., 26 Broadway, owner; C. M. Spindler, architect; cost, $10,000. Madison Av., 280; alteration to 5-story tenement; Nomad Realty Corp., 58 E. 1st St., owner; R. Shutkind, architect; cost, $12,000.
Major Patrick J. Walsh, president of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U., yesterday reappointed Harry R. Langdon as chairman of the boys' activities committee.
Sales of properties reported yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn include a number of one and two family dwellings and apartment houses.

Miss Elizabeth G. Shape, in 24 W. 59th St., through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc. Frank Starr, in 230 E. 50th St.: Bernard DeRaay, in 307 E. 44th St.; Dr. William Scott. in 325 E. 72d St.; Payson McL. Merrill Co., Inc., broker.

Several hundred members of the Campfire Club of America will break bread over red-checked tablecloths at the annual "buckskin dinner" in the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow night. It will be a colorful event, as usual, and this year the presiding genius will be the club president, picturesque Colonel A. J. (Sandy) Macnab...

Three Bishops and eleven Presbyters participated last night in the consecration of the Rev. Howard David Higgins as Assistant Bishop of the New York and Philadelphia Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church.

A War Office communique today announced court-martial sentences on seven more officers and eight civilians implicated in the mutiny in Tokyo last February. It also gave a striking picture of the mind and faith of one of Japan's Nazified young officers.

J. E. McAuliffe of New York registered the only upset in the first round of match play for the twentyninth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

Many supper parties were given in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria after the first concert for this season of the St. Cecilia Club held last night in the main ballroom of the hotel. Among the hostesses were Mrs. J. T. Johnston
Joe Dusek, Nebraska heavyweight, last night threw Sandor Vary, Hungarian, in 34 minutes 35 seconds of their finish wrestling exhibition before a crowd of 1,000 at the St. Nicholas Palace.

John T. Hubbard, president of the Litchfield County Bar Association, died last night in Charlotte Hungerford Hospital, Torrington. He was 81 years old. Mr. Hubbard had practiced law in Litchfield for fifty-four years and represented Litchfield in the Legislature in 1901 and 1903. He was a graduate of Yale University in 1880.

With throngs gathering from all parts of the country, rapidly swelling the population of Washington to twice its normal size, preparations were practically completed tonight for the second inauguration tomorrow noon of President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner.

Four hundred C farmers from various parts of the State gathered here today at the call of John J. Dillon, editor of The Rural New Yorker, and demanded reforms in the milk business. He and his State milk committee proposed that the prices of milk be posted before it leaves the farm.

Century-old manifests, the yellowed and brittle voyage records of clipper ship days, were removed from their Customs House files yesterday and introduced as evidence by attorneys representing several hundred of the 17,000 claimants who are seeking shares in the $17,500,000 estate of the late Mrs. Henrietta Edwardine Schaeffer Garrett of Philadelphia.

Golf is growing at a steady, healthy pace. During 1936 the actual increase in play neared 25 per cent. Many who formerly felt they could not afford the game now are playing it regularly and finding it no more expensive than a ticket to a good football or baseball game or many other forms of sport and entertainment.

The five-story building at 340 Madison Av., was leased by the State Superintendent of Insurance, as liquidator of the State Title Mortgage Co., to 7rvington Haberdashers, Inc., Samiuel A. Lunine, president, for twenty-one years from March 15, 1937, at an annual rental of 10 per cent of the gross annual cash receipts of the lessee's business;

It has come to the attention of THE NEW YORK TIMES that an appeal for funds in behalf of the Home of Old Israel, Inc., represents that the names of donors will be listed on a so-called "Dedication Page" of THE NEW YORK TIMES and wing with the suggestion that checks be sent to-THE TIMES.

When the Central Savings Bank sold to 419 Lafayette St., Inc., Isidor Werbel. president, the premises at 419-21 Lafayette St. for an indicated consideration of $100,000, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $85,000. due Jan. 12, 1944,

Serious inquiry is being made by the French Ministry of Colonies into the possibility of establishing somewhere among France's overseas possessions a settlement for persons of the Jewish faith who have been forced to take refuge here by political oppression in other countries.

The Atlas Corporation confirmed yesterday the reported sale of 18,000 shares of common stock of the Madison Square Garden Corporation to Stanton Griffis, chairman of the board of the latter corporation, for an unannounced consideration. Garden shares closed yesterday on the Stock Exchange at $14, indicating that the market value of the block of stock was $252,000.
The National Security Corporation had total operating profits of $1,597,325 from underwriting and investment income in 1936, after Fedwral income taxes, Vincent Cullen, president, reported yesterday.

While retail merchants and associations do not oppose- the establishment of consumer cooperatives, retailers must be on their guard against government subsidies which would give the "co-ops" a discriminatory advantage over other forms of distribution, Colonel C. O. Sherrill, president of the American Retail Federation, said yesterday, at the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Pacific Railroad were about $12,600,000, against $10,818,305 in December, 1935, according to Carl B. Gray, president. He said that the weather had been favorable to railroad operation, but that more snow Would have been welcomed as an aid to agriculture.

William H. Ricketts, a member of Goodyear Local No. 2, United Rubber Workers of America, filed a $100,000 slander suit today against Clifton Slusser, vice president of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, alleging that Mr. Slusser told the union that he "was not to be trusted," and that he would "turn traitor for 15 cents."

Selling of public utility stocks followed yesterday news of yet another group of Washington officials entrusted with the duty of working out a national power policy. The new group is to embrace the Bonneville project, which will have power available for sale in Western Oregon and Washington in a few months, as well as TVA.
The two buildings at 281-5 East Forty-second Street, running through to 232-8 East Forty-third Street, have been leased by the Federal Government for the use of Federal Arts Project of the WPA.
Ensign Fred (Buzz) Borries, AllAmerica football and basketball player while he was at Annapolis, will become assistant coach there next season. He will join Lieutenant Harry J. (Hank) Hardwick,

Shamefacedly admitting that he had stolen a $1,000 diamond ring from a wealthy woman who had befriended him and had pawned it for $15, Jack Downs, 21 years old, was arrested yesterday at Sloan House, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street, by Detectives Frank O'Neill and John Tuttle of the main office division.

Public offering of $40,000,000 of fifteen-year 31/2 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company was made yesterday by a nation-wide banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Lehman Brothers. The debentures, which are dated Jan. 1, 1937, and are due on Jan. 1, 1952, were priced at 101 and interest from Jan. 1 to date of delivery.

Acquisition of 225,000 shares of common stock of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation from Charles S. Payson in exchange for 65,700 shares of its own common stock was disclosed yesterday by the American Rolling Mill Company in an application to list the additional shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

Members of the United Mine Workers of America, the industrial union headed by John L. Lewis, have been assessed $1 each for January and February to build up financial reserves for organization purposes, it was learned here yesterday.

Demand for hogs was much more active today and, while underweight ones were quoted as much as 10 cents lower, most of the offerings from 180 pounds upward sold at steady prices. The day's top of $10.25, although about 10 cents above the nominal outside figure at the close yesterday, was 20 cents under the highest price paid on Monday and was the lowest top for a day since Dec. 21.

With forty-five new cases of diphtheria reported for the week ended last Saturday, the disease continued to run higher than last year in the city, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

Following are the most important parts, textually, of the address made by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons tonight: If 1937 must be a year of acutely difficult international problems--and of that there can be no doubt--it is also a year of international

The second most important man in Washington tonight was Charles L. Mitchell, the government weather forecaster, a solemn-visaged man with pince-nez, upon whose shoulders falls the task of advising inauguration visitors whether woolens or silks are indicated and upon such vital matters as overshoes and umbrellas.

France, irked by the bombing of the destroyer Maille Breze by an unidentified airplane -off the Catalan coast, ordered her warships tonight to fire on any attacking craft. Following the lead of Britain, which some months ago similarly warned that shellfire would meet any interference with British shipping,

Almost unanimous agreement was expressed on the desirability of an eight-hour day for nurses in a panel discussion of the question at a here meeting last night of the New York State Nurses Association, District 13, in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Miss Laura Logan, a registered nurse in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, acted as chairman of the panel.

The Smiths, who should be used to it by this time, stand at 'the head of the Federal Social Security Board's numerical listing, with 294,000 persons of that name registered among the nation's wage earners.

An expansion program which will give to the Glenn L. Martin Company's plant here the largest assembly floor in the world for the manufacture of aircraft was announced today by Glenn L. Martin, president and chairman of the board.

The Horace Mann School for Boys gained undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League race as the result of a 40-16 victory over the Irving School for Boys quintet of Tarrytown on the formher's court yesterday.

Edward Barrows, 18, first sergeant of cadets at Manlius School, died in a Syracuse hospital tonight a few hours after he was struck by an automobile in front of the school. State police said the car was driven by Mathew Reynolds, who was not held.

Police Commissioner Valentine is going to reorganize the police department of Houston, Texas, along the lines of New York's "finest" in the course of a month's vacation on which he will depart at noon today, he announced yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Mrs. Juliet May Davis of 30 Hillside Avenue, widow of William Webb Davis, who was found dead in bed of a heart attack a week ago, died today of a heart ailment aggravated by the shock of her husband's death.

The appeal last week of Foreign Minister Josef Beck of Poland for the emigration of Jews and attacks on Jews in the Polish Parliament were cited yesterday by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, as just reasons for all Americans to unite to help the oppressed.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, is expected back in Rome from Capri on his way to Berlin Thursday as originally planned and will break his journey to pay Premier Benito Mussolini a farewell call.

In a closely fought match, the City Athletic Club gained a narrow victory by 3 to 2 over the Block Hall Club on the' latter's courts last night to maintain its undefeated record and leadership of Group 2 in the Eastern Squash Racquets League championship.
John Bradley died today at the Southampton Hospital. He was 59 years old. He had been president of Bradley Brothers, real estate dealers, for fifteen years. His brother, Charles, survives.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust's net asset value on Dec. 31, last, was $28.87 a share, according to its annual report, issued yesterday. With allowance for the reduction brought about by the distribution in December of $1.05 a share on account of income derived from capital gains, this figure is compared to $27.89 on Sept. 30 and $24.03 a share on Dec. 31, 1935.

The National Hockey League's leading scorer, 146-pound Larry Aurie, led the champion Detroit Red Wings ent to a rollicking 7-to-2 victory over Chicago's luckless Black Hawks before 10,000 spectators tonight.

Many luncheons will be given in advance of the special performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad, Lauritz Melchior and Kerstin Thorborg in the leading roles, this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House which has been taken over for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador.

The Yale squash racquets team defeated Wesleyan on the Alumni Field House courts today, 5 to O. Hollister, the Elis' No. 1 man, had no difficulty in winning from Tuttle, acting captain of the home gyms team, triumphing in three straight games.

The Spanish Leftist and Insurgent governments rejected today the nonintervention committee's proposal to control munitions shipments to both sides in the Spanish civil war. The action by the Burgos and Valencia governments met a gloomy response in British circles, where it was stated:

The Trinity School quintet, which is heading the Eastern Private Schools League with two victories in as many games, turned back the Hackley School five of Tarrytown, 32 to 13, in a non-league contest on its own court yesterday.

Needy Jews in Berlin received 77,757 free meals and 21,806 food packages in 1936 from six kitchens aided by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, according to an announcement yesterday by Joseph C. Hyman, secretary and executive director of the committee.

A six-hour day in the building trades "would immeasurably hamper any extensive development of home building," and, would increase the cost of construction projects, according to Christian G. Norman, chairman of the board of the Building Trades Employers Association of New York, it became known yesterday.

For the second time since January, 1932, when their salaries were drasticaly cut, 6,000 Jersey City employes, including school teachers, and 2,250 Hudson County employes will receive increases beginning July 1, it was announced today by Commissioner Arthur Potterton, Director of Revenue and Finance of Jersey City.

Miss Gloria Hollister, chief assistant to Dr. William Beebe, who is ill in New York, tonight addressed members of the Committee of One Hundred on Dr. Beebe's studies of marine life, in the clubhouse at Miami Beach.

The Consumers Power Company has called for redemption on March 20 all of its outstanding 6, 6.6 and 7 per cent preferred stock at 105 per cent of the par value, plus accrued dividends. The Crown Zellerbach Corporation has called for redemption on March 1 all of its 6 per cent debentures of 1940, at 101 and accrued interest.

President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt and Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman are among those who have subscribed for square feet in the block of land on Riverside Drive between 119th and 120th Streets which was purchased by Barnard College recently and on which an academic building will be erected, it was announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve.

Hudson Building and Loan Assn. resold to Curtis Fields the four-story flats with stores at 785 Ocean Av., Jersey City. The new owner gave back In Payment a purchase-money mortgage for $14,000, due Jan. 13, 1940.

Frank J. Prial, former City Controller, was appointed yesterday impartial chairman for the Textile Refinishers Association to succeed the late Dr. Henry Moskowitz. Mr. Prial will adjudicate labor and trade disputes in the textile shrinking and refinishing industry.

Busy as he is with plans for two impending plays, Brock Pemberton has nevertheless found time to become more than interested in the script called "Red Harvest." He may even be on the verge of buying it. That would be the work of Walter Charles Roberts, with which the Theatre Foundation of America was toying earlier in the seasonsomething about Red Cross nurses during the World War. It was tested at Ithaca College in 1935.

General Motors Corporation employes injected a new angle into industrial disputes tonight by voting to conduct a sit-down strike against the sit-down strikes elsewhere as the result of which two plants here are to close.

Funeral services for Miss Caroline Morris Galt, Professor of Greek and Archaeology at Mount Holyoke College, were held this afternoon in Mary Lyon Chapel. Miss Galt died Sunday night after a brief illness.

Dr. Kurt Wannow, Carl von Ossietzky's attorney for the collection of his Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo, Norway, finds himself in the peculiar situation of being unable to establish connections with his client. He has joined forces with the Deutsche Bank for the transfer of the money to Germany,

The five-day joint convention of the Union of Jewish Congregations and its connected National Federations of Temple Brotherhoods and Sisterhoods, ended today with the latter organization re-electing Mrs. Leon L. Watters of New York City, as president.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 12.25 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. Although transactions were made early at 12.65 cents, the greater part of the trading was done at 12.275 cents. On Monday the range was between 12.65 and 12.725 cents.

MANHATTAN AUBERT, LENA S. (Sept. 25, 1935). Gross assets, $39,261; net, $33,392. To Charles E., Frank E. and Alvin Sheridan, brothers, one-third residue each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $33,130. Smyth Meleney, attorneys, 420 Lexington Av.

Plans for a flying expedition from New York to the jungles of New Guinea to collect mammals, birds and plants and study the life history of birds and animals in those regions were announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.

West Side houses formed the bulk of the properties figuring in Manhattan realty deals reported by brokers yesterday. The fifteen-story and penthouse building at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West Seventy-eighth Street, on a plot 102 by 75 feet, was purchased by an investing client of George Zinberg, attorney, from the People's Realty Company, a holding company for the John W. Herbert Estate, John A. O'Brien, president.

Striking seamen who went to Washington to protest labor items in the Copeland Safety-at-Sea Act to Secretaries Roper and Perkins yesterday straggled back to New York and resumed picketing, satisfied with the results of their journey. Joseph Curran, chairman of the joint marine strike council, said he felt certain the trip would result in a six-month suspension of the act, as provided in a resolution now before Congress, sponsored by Representative Sirovich.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it has given formal permission to the Consolidated Edison system to put into effect on Feb. 1 the revisions in electric rates for commercial, manufacturing, wholesale and charitable purposes. The new rates will save customers about $4,700,000 a year.

Eighty-fourth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers begins at 33 West Thirty-ninth Street at 10:30 A. M. and continues Thursday, Friday and Saturday. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "This Changing World," Dorothy Thompson.

A boy weighing seventeen pounds four ounces was born today to Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Fleck of Ari, northeast of here. Dr. Jesse Briggs of Cherubusco said it was the largest baby he had ever assisted into the world. He reported the mother and baby "doing nicely."

A suit by Mrs. Mary F. Stanard, niece of the late Bishop John J. Dunn, for one-third of his estate was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Mrs. Stanard and Cardinal Hayes, named as defendant, filed cross-motions for dismissal. The Cardinal was made defendant individually and as executor of Bishop Dunn's estate. Mrs. Stanard asked for $66,666, a third of the $200,000 that she said the estate was worth.

The Maritime Commission will start conferences Monday with companies holding ocean steamship mail contracts to arrange for their adjustment and termination. Under the Merchant Marine Act of last year all present contracts must be terminated and new mail agreements made by June 30, 1937.

E. Broadway, 256, 23x56.6; Benjamin Eskolsky et al. to Rebecca Eskoleky, 256 E. Broadway; mtg. $8,500. Broadway, 631-635, also 200-204 Mercer St., 75 on former and 70.1 on latter; Prlnceway Realty Corp. to 14 John St. Corp.,

Sir John Aspinall one of the foremost British railway engineers, died today at the age of 85. Formerly a pupil of John Ramsbotton and F. W. Webb, who successfully directed the Crewe Works of the London Northwestern Railway, he became general manager of the Lancashire Yorkshire Railway and later, 1919-27, was consultant mechanical engineer to the Ministry of Transport.

William F. S. Pell, secretary of the West India Steamship Company of New York, died this morning of pneumonia at his home, 443 East Fourth Street. He was 63 years old. Mr. Pell, who was born in New York, was with the steamship company for thirty-five years.
The death of Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor was charged to her finance, Kentucky's former Adjutant General, Henry H. Denhardt, in an indictment returned by the Henry County grand jury here today.

An offering of 154,757 shares of $2-par value common stock of the Diamond T Motor Car Company will be made today by Hallgarten Co.; Granbery, Safford Co.; A. G. Becker Co. and Jackson Curtis at $20 a share. The offering is subject to reduction by as many of 1,343 shares as are subscribed for by three shareholders who have not waived their pre-emptive rights in respect of 47,240 shares.

A denial that President Roosevelt plans to confer with Congressional leaders on possible legislation to curb the power of the Supreme Court was made by the White House today, after publication of stories quoting Senator Minton, Democrat of Indiana, as having said yesterday that the President planned to call such a conference.

Harry Cohn, president of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, received compensation of $182,040 in the last fiscal year and Jack Cohn, vice president, was paid $104.260, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, as made public at the New York Stock Exchange.
The monthly meeting and annual election of officers of the Merchant Tailors Society of New York will take place tomorrow night at Schrafft's, 13 East Forty-second Street.
The principal events of Inauguration Day follow: 10 A. M.--President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt, with Cabinet members and their wives, will attend religious services at St. John's Episcopal Church.

Mrs. Katherine Converse Strong, daughter of the late Edmund C. Converse, first president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, and former wife of the late Benjamin Strong, second president of the Bankers Trust Company and first Governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died here this morning at her home on Las Tunas Road after an illness of several weeks.

FrancoTurkish talks on the Alexandretta dispute are due to begin here tomorrow with the League of Nations Council's rapporteur or mediator, the Swedish Foreign Minister, Rickard J. Sandler. Tewfik Rushdu Aras, the Turkish Foreign Minister, arrived tonight with his ally and fellow Council member, Victor Antonescu of Rumania. Yvon Delbos, the French Foreign Minister, is expected tomorrow morning.

Government troops today stormed and captured Cerro de los Angeles, the geographical center of Spain, eight miles south of Madrid, and a strategic point of utmost importance. The capture was regarded here as one of the greatest Loyalist vicstories since the first week of the war.

Invitations to American shipbuilders to bid on a combination passenger and cargo liner to take the place of the Leviathan were sent out today by the Maritime Commission. They are to be opened April 1.

Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky of 147 East Fiftieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Princess Daria Obolensky, to Hans George Spitzer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Spitzer of Wupperthal-Barmen and Berlin, Germany.

All landplane distance speed records were broken yesterday by Howard Hughes, millionaire sportsman pilot, who reached Newark Airport 7 hours 28 minutes and 25 seconds after he took off from Los Angeles, Calif. He was then forced to stay aloft until the runway at the field was clear and landed at 1:03 P. M.
The eyes of Texas were on Coach Dana X. Bible tonight, with a deal on the fire that may take the football master away from Nebraska with a big salary.

Retail prices of cigarettes are scheduled to advance by a cent a package, beginning Monday, it was made known last night following the announcement earlier of wholesale price increases by two major manufacturing companies.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, will confer at 2 P. M. tomorrow in Washington with Secretary Perkins and Governor Murphy of Michigan in an effort to arrange a peace conference between the United Automobile Workers of America and company officials.

The Wood Memorial, most important of the 3-year-old stakes to be run at the Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica, will once more serve as a test for the candidates for the Kentucky Derby, according to the tentative dates arranged by General Secretary. John Kane.

Egg prices, even after a break in the retail markets yesterday and the day before by the large chains, have been askew, with the result that there may be a relative scarcity of broilers next Spring and of roasting chickens in the Fall.
Selma Kramer, pianist, has postponed her concert, which was to have taken place at the Town Hall tonight, to Feb. 9. Louis Malerba, tenor, will give a recital at Steinway Hall tonight.

Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch gave a tea yesterday at her home, 46 East Seventy-fourth Street, for a group of young women who are assisting her in organizing the debutante and junior committees for the Butterfly Ball to be held on April 9 at the Ritz-Carlton. The ball, as in the past, will benefit the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers.

Benny Lynch of Scotland won the world's flyweight championship today by outpointing Small Montana of Manila in their fifteen-round title fight. Lynch, holder of the British crown, scaled 111 pounds 6 ounces for the bout.

Eight epee wielders came through two rounds of hard competition last night on the strips of the New York Athletic Club, thus earning the right to represent the metropolitan area in the national junior championships, which are scheduled for the New York University gymnasium on March 4.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., of New York and associates won today the award of $47,000,000 of forty-year power revenue bonds of the City of Los Angeles Board of Water and Power. The proceeds will be used by the Municipal Bureau of Power and Light to acquire the electric system of the Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation.

Anklets, a son of Rolled Stockings which seldom finishes out of the money, came through with another victory today in carrying Mrs. C. C. Winters's silks home first in the mile and a sixteenth race for players at the Fair Grounds.

Clare Consuelo Sheridan, sculptress, writer and traveler, disclosed today that her son, Richard Brinsley Sheridan, had died in Algeria soon after having broken a legendary 400-year "curse of the Sheridans."

An ex-convict who for five years believed he had been wanted in Massachusetts for violation of parole was arraigned yesterday in Jefferson Market Court as a vagrant after he had surrendered to Detective Edward Hoolahan of the West Twentieth Street station on the advice of a priest.

A bill proposing the creation of a State labor relations board was presented to the Wisconsin Legislature today. Endorsed by Governor La Follette, it was prepared by officials of the State Federation of Labor with the assistance of Dean Lloyd K. Garrison of the University of Wisconsin Law School, former chairman of the National Relations Board.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new high record of 3,184,650 barrels. The previous record was in the week ended on Dec. 19, 1936, when production averaged 3,145,700 barrels daily. Last week's output was 66,850 barrels more than the daily average output of 3,117,800 in the previous week.

In the face of sharp criticism by County Judge Franklin Taylor of Brooklyn regarding his policy on commutations, Governor Lehman's office announced today that the Governor had commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed upon

J. Spencer Weed was elected president of the National Horse Show Association for the sixth consecutive year at a meeting of the board of directors at the organization's offices yesterday. Mr. Weed also was named chairman of the executive committee.
New York may see a race between the America's Cup defense yachts next Spring in its watery backyard. One of the Class J sloops has not been even in Long Island Sound for seven years.

Enlistment of consumer support to combat adverse legislation and adaptation of reta??ng practices to consumer habits rapidly changing with the advent of the motor trailer, increasing divorce and a decreasing birth rate were urged upon the nation's retailers in session at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Campaign workers for President Roosevelt, together with members of the family party now assembled at the White House, were guests at a dinner given tonight by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

The newly distributed purchasing power and the prospect of further increases in income indicate a rise in sales trends to record levels and preparations must be made accordingly, A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., told members of the New York Purchasing Agents Association at a meeting at the Builder Exchange Club last night.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies arrived in Moscow today, accompanied by his wife and daughter, Emlen; two personal secretaries, Donald Bloomingdale and J. D. Stamm, and his wife's secretary, Miss Edith Wells.
For inaugural weather in Washington the forecast yesterday was a meager "Rain, possibly mixed with sleet or snow."

Police Commissioner Valentine publicly commended sixteen detectives and promoted one of them yesterday for the speedy solution of the murder of Mrs. Mary H. Case in Queens last week. He also commended the police work in several other recent cases and promoted a patrolman to the rank of detective.
Leases for restaurants and for investment and brokerage offices figured in many of the commercial rentals announced by brokers yesterday. Several clothing stores took new retail quarters.

In a drive against the sale and use of air rifles, Police Captain Walter Hourigan of the West Forty-seventh Street station caused the arrest of two storekeepers yesterday for selling the weapons to minors and assigned patrolmen to visit the schools in the neighborhood and appeal to youngsters to surrender the guns.

With none of the dramatics which marked his trial yesterday before an allwoman jury in Federal court, Peter Guarino, 38 years old, former roadhouse operator, was sentenced today to ten years in a Federal penitentiary for stealing $900 from an Erie Railroad train in Nutley last April 17. Judge Guy L. Fake also fined him $5,000.

Surrogate Joseph L. Donahay today appointed Mrs. Phoebe Cary Brisbane and her two eldest children, Seward Brisbane and Mrs. Sarah Brisbane McCrary, as the guardians of the three minor Brisbane children, Emily, 18 years old; Alice, 15, and Elinor, 12.

Further moderate weakness in United States Government bonds was followed by lower price levels in other domestic groups yesterday, with total transactions on the New York Stock Exchange $13,884,200, against $12,749,500 on Monday.

Tiebout Av., 2,330, 5-story tenement, 36x 164, irregular; Churchill B. Phyfe against Cuyahoga Realty Corp.; due, $59,222; taxes, , $205; to plaintiff for $1,500. By JAMES R. MURPHY Webster Av., 1,355, 4-story tenement, 25x90;

Michigan State scored a 36-30 victory over the Syracuse University basketball team tonight in a driving finish. In the last two minutes of play, with the score 31-29, the Spartans sprinted away from the Orange five.

THERE was some discussion of the Tom Beaupre-Gunnar Barlund bout scheduled for the Hippodrome this evening. A couple of bystanders suggested that this might be an important fight. The Gunnar from Finland looked like a good man.
President Roosevelt designated Henry F. Grady as the American member of the League of Nations Economic Committee and, with Mrs. Roosevelt, entertained campaign workers at dinner tonight.

Insuranshares Certificates, Inc.On Dec. 31, last, net assets, with securities at bid prices, were $6,519,938, equal to $7.70 each on 847,100 shares of $1-par capital stock, excluding 2,900 shares purchased by company in December. A year before, net assets were $6,756,066, or $7.95 a share.
' Scoring an easy victory in a small but select field, Major Austin C. Taylor's Special Agent captured the $1,500 Glendale Handicap at Santa Anita today.

Fred D. Hesley was elected president of the Todd Galveston Dry Docks, Inc., yesterday, succeeding John D. Reilly, who was elected chairman of the board. The Galveston plant is a subsidiary of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, of which Mr. Reilly is president. Mr.
Three hundred American broadcasters and the most powerful transmitters in at least six foreign countries will broadcast President Roosevelt's inaugural around the world today.

The French Government, apprehensive lest a French magazine's joke lead Iran [Persia] to break off commercial and diplomatic relations with France, instructed her Minister to Iran tonight to try to soothe the Shah's ruffled feelings.

Alfred E. Smith Jr. spent half an hour on the witness stand yesterday at the start of his testimony for the State in the General Sessions trial of A. Henry Ross, a young Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, on the extortion charge made by him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When I began your editorial "Speed, Guns, Armor" on the announced characteristics of our two new battleships, I was gratified to realize that you regarded -America's fleet construction as a subject worthy of editorial notice. As I continued, however, I was not so well pleased to find that your conclusion appeared to reflect adversely upon the two ships and upon the department whose policies dictated their design.
Napoleon Lajoie, Tris Speaker and Cy Young, three of the greatest diamond heroes of the past, have been voted positions in baseball's permanent hall of fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.
