Vittorio Mussolini, the Italian Premier's son, and Orsola Buvoli, the pretty Milanese whom he will marry Feb. 6, will visit New York on their honeymoon, it was learned today. Vittorio, who is intensely interested in American movie production, wants to study the industry first hand.
Dr. Levering Tyson of New York was elected president of Muhlenberg College today by the board of trustees. He succeeds Dr. John A. W. Haas, who had announced his retirement.

Mrs. James H. Kennedy gave a dinner followed by contract tonight at Kenlewinai for Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Bode, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan D. Bil, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Kroger, Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Pettengill, Mrs. Herbert E. Gale, Mrs. Frank Osgood Butler, Mrs. Zenas Sears, Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow and John B. Irwin.

The French Government has decided to sell its interest in the Jibuti-Addis Ababa railroad, the Chamber of Deputies Colonial Committee disclosed today, The decision was made, it was said, after the Italians, who now control Ethiopia, had threatened to build a competing line.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week and the adjusted index remained at 124.8, the figure for the previous week. For the week ended Jan. 18, 1936, it was 77.5.

Kid Chocolate of Havana stopped Tony Pagano of the East Side before 3,000 at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Referee Jimmy Crowley stepped between the boxers in 2:05 of the fourth of the listed eight-round feature to save Pagano from further punishment.

Frederic C. Wheeler, vice president of the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company, and Abraham Samson, a chicken dealer, were held for the grand jury today on charges of criminal negligence in connection with the deaths of seven persons in the collapse of two tenement houses on Dec. 19.
The one, two knockout punch of Mrs. Emil Denemark's stable was delivered at Hialeah Park again today when Genie Palatine and Two Bob ran as named in the featured General Robert E. Lee Purse.

Wheat prices declined 2 1/2 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel to the lowest level in nearly a month on the Board of Trade here today as the result of fairly general liquidation induced by continued weakness in Liverpool.

Prospective changes in six firms holding memberships in the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday by the Exchange. On Jan. 31, Gutenstein Lasdon will dissolve and on Feb. 1 a new firm of the same name will be formed by Ferdinand Gutenstein, Milton A. Lasdon and Oscar Lasdon.

Henry Phipps Estates won in the Court of Appeals today an affirmation of an order of Justice Carew, which directed Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses of New York, to approve a permit for a motion picture house at Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street.

The American Foreign Trade Zone, Inc., of Jersey City, a private corporation, filed an application with the Foreign Trade Zone Board today for permission to establish a zone in the Greenville section of Jersey City.

Trouble was more general, more critical and more dramatized on the day before the President's first inaugural than-it is on the recurring occasion, today. Then the depression had returned with full force and the bank closing was at hand. Now recovery has arrived, and there is guarantee of bank deposits.

After a long and dreary afternoon when members of Congress and visitors here for the inauguration peered gloomily out of the Capitol windows at slanting rain, some unidentified member of the Capitol staff added a touch of irony to the gray picture.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday were slightly fewer than the peak of last week, but numbered well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Miss Eleanor Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barry of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, was married to Allan A. Ryan Jr. of this city yesterday in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, who performed the ceremony in the presence of relatives of the couple.

The officers and crew of the German cruiser Emden, which now is visiting Yokohama, are having a good time as a result of Japan's friendship for Germany. Captain Walter Lehmann and Lieut. Commander Bernhard
J. Cal Ewing, "grand old man" of Pacific Coast baseball and leader in civic and sports activities for almost half a century, died this morning in his Oakland home at the age of 70.

The Pope took a slight turn for the worse today. The pain in his right leg again became acute, with the result that his general condition suffered. He had a poor night, Sleeping only a few hours. Brother Faustino, on duty as his nurse, was active virtually all night ministering to the Pope's needs.
Stewards of the Grand Circuit today will hold their annual meeting in New York for the first time in many years, convening at the Murray Hill Hotel at 10 o'clock this morning.

Two more second-round matches in the women's Metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship were played at the Junior League yesterday. Miss Margaret Bostwick defeated Mrs. E. Trevor Hill, 15-12, 15-8, 8-15, 15-11, and Mrs. Rogers Dunn conquered Miss Frida Scharman, 17-18, 15-10, 15-12, 15-12.

The other day FRED PERRY argued in the columns of THE TIMES for the holding of open tournaments between amateur and professional tennis players. He asserted that the leading professional players today could defeat the leading amateurs. When one thinks of VINES, PERRY, TILDEN, COCHET, BARNES, STOEFEN, LOTT, in the professional ranks, against such players as BUDGE, von CRAMM, CRAWFORD and QUIST, as the amateur leaders, this statement is probably true.

Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, spent the first day of his visit in New York yesterday in sight-seeing, according to his secretary, J. R. C. Helmore. Mr. Runciman and his party planned to go to the theatre last night. "He is just having a holiday," the secretary said.
The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette said today that it had learned on reliable authority that the strike of 6,000 employes of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company would end today.

Newark women, who have been distinguishing themselves this week in jury duty, were called on in United States District Court today to decide no less important a matter than whether the Federal Government had done wrong.

NOVEL ON YELLOW PAPER, OR WORK IT OUT FOR YOURSELF, by Stevie Smith. (Morrow, $2.) An unconventional novel. BERNARD SHAW, FRANK HARRIS AND OSCAR WILDE, by Robert Harborough Sherard. (Greystone Press, $3.50.) Called "a complete exposure" of Frank Harris's "Oscar Wilde."
Penn State jumped into the lead of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference tonight by winning its opening league game from West Virginia, 28 to 21.

Had Ross Alexander, young actor who ended his own life, postponed his death one month, his estate would have been $31,500 richer, Benjamin Levan, insurance counselor, said today. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Ross Smith of Rochester, N. Y.,
A day-old strike at St. Cecilia's High School became a lockout this morning when fourteen students were turned away from the school doors by the principal, Sister Margaret Theresa.
The will of Horace Binney, a life-long resident of Newport, who died Jan. 7, was filed in the Probate Court of this city today. The estate will exceed $200,000.

The water resources committee of the National Planning Committee appointed by President Roosevelt in June, 1934, has "generally recommended the completion of debatable undertakings already under construction, even though the committee might not have recommended the undertakings in the first place."

An appeal that the world adopt an "open door" policy of free trade in all colonies to give poor nations access to essential raw materials was made at the opening of the Diet (Parliament) today by Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita.

A warning that the current rapid improvement in business may have an unhappy aftermath was voiced yesterday by Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, in his message to shareholders at their annual meeting, held at 3 P. M. at the bank's head office, 165 Broadway.

Owners from Kentucky, Illinois and New York were the winners of the featured races at Hialeah today as colorbearers of Hal Price Headley, Mrs. Emil Denemark and Charles H. Thieriot captured the graded handicaps, A, B and C respectively.

Captain Rand Percy Crandall, M. C., U.S.N., retired, will celebrate tomorrow at his home here his seventy-first birthday and the fiftieth anniversary of his appointment as an officer in the United States Navy, which occurred shortly after he was graduated as a surgeon from the University of Pennsylvania.

Russian police and customs officers made an eight-hour search of the Japanese steamer Siberia Maru at Vladivostok yesterday, the Domei [Japanese] News Agency reported today. The search provoked "great concern" in Tokyo, the agency said.

Mr. and Mrs. Presley Morgan Taylor of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of Mrs. Taylor's daughter, Miss Anna Lodge Minot, to Henry Canby Biddle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Canby Biddle of Green Garden, Wayne, and Jacksonville, Fla.

A small and select group of government officials received new leases on their offices today. They were the members of the President's Cabinet, ten citizens who hold public office at the pleasure of the Chief Executive and who, with one exeption, have no fixed term of office.
A four-story apartment at 898 New York Avenue, Union City, N. J., was sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company to Abraham Levy for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was broker.

Fred Perry stopped Ellsworth Vines's winning streak in the seventh match of their professional tennis series tonight by taking two sets out of three, 6--4, 6-8, 6-2. Perry thereby took the lead in the series. The Briton has won four matches and Vines three. He has won 29 sets and Vines 24.

Sir Otto Niemeyer, director of the Bank of England and a leading British economic diplomat, whose trip to the United States has stirred reports in financial circles here and abroad that major conversations on debts and trade agreements were pending, arrived quietly yesterday denying that his visit had any international significhance.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Jan. 19, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of health education in day high schools the names of the following applipants, who have been granted said license:

Henry F. Atherton, in 180 E. 79th St., through the Tishman Realty Co.; Hamlin F. Andrus, in 1,140 5th Av., through the Fred F. French Co.: Robert J. Marony, in 130 E. 75th St.: C. E. Fauntleroy, in 350 E. 57th

Police Commissioner Valentine sailed yesterday for a month's vacation in the Southwest, part of which he will devote to a survey of the police system of Houston, Texas, at the request of the city's Mayor.

Members of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club re-elected Commodore Arnold P. Kohler for 1937 at their annual meeting tonight. John J. Warsaw, vice commodore; Frederick W. Johnson, rear commodore; Ernest P. Simon, treasurer, and H. W. Loweree, secretary, also were named to serve another term.

Harry Klar, 36 years old, of 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, last of the three men sought in connection with the murder of Frank Cicero in the Manhattann Opera House on Sunday night, surrendered yesterday to police of the West Thirtieth Street station.

The colorful annual Snow Ball was given last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Ladies' Aid Society of the Lenox Hill Hospital to aid that institution's maintenance fund.

The underground movement against the Hitler regime has gained momentum in Germany within the last three months, according to Wilhelm Sollmann, German exile and former Minister of the Interior in two Stresemann Cabinets, who arrived yesterday on the Berengaria for a lecture tour in this country.

The Polaris Development and Mining Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Jan. 30 to consider the formation of a new company, the Polaris Mining Company, to be incorporated in Delaware, to take over all its assets and assume its liabilities.

The small three-story modern dwelling at 100 Riverside Drive, together with the adjoining old houses at 102 Riverside Drive and 331 West Eighty-second Street, will be torn down shortly to make way for a tall apartment house.

Two Sian steamers were stopped by. Spanish Insurgent warships in the Strait of Gibraltar today and taken to Ceuta, Morocco, Lloyds was advised from Gibraltar. The steamers were the Dickson and the Ural Masch.

Unanimous approval of the project for another NEW YORK TIMES Book Fair in 1937 and a proposal for the establishment of an institute of publishing were highlights of the annual meeting and luncheon of the National Association of Book Publishers held yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.

Winter's first snow and a falling mercury. That means hard times for the birds and animals in the wild, and for those song and insectivorous birds that stay with us in the cities and suburbs throughout the Winter months.

Major Gen. Vladimir Deslovitsky, friend of the late Czar and the imperial Russian family, who brought the Dowager Empress Degmar, sister of Queen Alexandra from Russia to England during the revolution, died here todayat the age of 80.
For the first time in history four generations of a President's family were on the platform today as President Roosevelt was sworn in for the second time.

The position of the Roman Catholic Church in the present Spanish civil war was explained by William F. Montavon, legal adviser to the National Catholic Welfare Conference at Washington, in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.
Republicans in the Assembly find themselves in a position where they must place their chief reliance on Governor Lehman for averting a partisan row in the Legislature over minimumwage legislation.

The elevated tone of President Roosevelt's inaugural address, especially his redeclaration of the principle that government should be the instrument of our "united purpose to solve for the individual the ever-rising problems of a complex civilization," was the memory which thousands of visitors took home with them tonight.

One thing may confidently be said of the one-man Townsend plan that is being tried out in Chelan, Wash. The plan will work better with one man than with the 10,000,000 originally contemplated. It requires, for one thing, only $200 a month to make it go instead of $2,000,000,000 a month. The other aspects of the scheme are more dubious.

When low-income families lose their homes because of civic improvements, the city should see that "decently habitable" homes at the same rentals are made available to them, Sydney Maslen, secretary of the Charity Organization Society's tenement house committee, said yesterday.

Casa Marcheta was the scene tonight of a buffet dinner followed by dancing in the patio with which Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff entertained. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Howland Graham, Mr. and Mrs.
Investment buying of housing properties in Manhattan covered a wide area yesterday, extending from the downtown area to Harlem and Washington Heights. Two old houses at 388 and 389
A modern invention was used to protect the 200-year-old Roosevelt family Bible from the driving rain when the President was sworn into office by Chief Justice Hughes today.

The government promised today the erection of a $169,000 revolving beacon as a WPA project on a bluff overlooking the Matamoras, Pa., airport, near the mountain side where Pilot Dick Merrill and ten passengers escaped death in a forced landing Dec. 19.

His larder well-stocked and $93.76 yet to spend, "Pensioner" C. C. Fleming lolled at ease tonight while anxious Chelan citizens pondered the first serious problem of their Townsend plan test--the menace of souvenir hunters.
A large number of the leases for commercial space reported yesterday by brokers were for quarters for retail stores and for firms in the garment industry. The list follows:

The treason trial opening here on Saturday will throw a blaze of light on the mystery--to foreigners, at least--of the Zinovieff-Kameneff affair. Not, of course, on the abject confessions of the accused on that occasion, which can only be explained, first, by the Russian character under stress of a guilty conscience--as any reader of Dostoyevsky will understand;
The Twenty-third Street Association, at a meeting in the Aldine Club yesterday, voted to support the Merchants' Association of New York in asking the Board of

Six hundred guests at a buffet luncheon, 3,000 at the reception and tea given by the President and Mrs. Roosevelt after the inaugural parade, and a family dinner established a new record for social activity at the White House today.

Mr. Gourin, vice president of the military and marine committee of the French Chamber of Deputies is expected in Casablanca in a few days to study measures for the effective defense of French Morocco.

The program for the celebration Jan. 30 of the fourth anniversary of Adolf Hitler's attainment to power in Germany is now out. It seems likely to have more domestic than foreign significance, although the Fuehrer, in the speech with which he will mark the occasion, will undoubtedly discuss German foreign policy as well as domestic affairs.

The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation shut down completely today for lack of materials in some departments, adding 10,000 to the ranks of the unemployed in this city of 165,000 population.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's defense of British foreign policy as presented to the House of Commons yesterday provoked only a shrug of official shoulders here and the press is even more emphatic in charging the British statesman with failure to contribute anything new or constructive on the Spanish and other European problems.

The present difficulties of American business men in obtaining Japanese exchange are purely technical and due to delays involved in the new regulations. There will be no difficulty regarding cotton future contracts, "if the futures are not too far off." The sole object of the new regulations is to stabilize yen exchange. The government is determined and fully prepared to maintain the yen at its present value.

" Back rooms" virtually ceased to exist at the end of the saloon era, but in their place has risen a new "evil," women drinking at bars, according to Charles G. Bond, Commissioner of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board of the city.

A portrait of Stephen Collins Foster, painted by Thomas Hicks, contemporary of the composer, has been given to the University of Pittsburgh's Foster Memorial and will be placed in the memorial building when the structure is dedicated, in June.

Senator Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, introduced today a bill proposing the creation of a commission to preserve the natural beauty of the Hudson River. Governor Lehman in his annual message recommended "the Legislature should give thought to a comprehensive plan for the preservation of the natural beauty of the Hudson River and for its improvement and development."
A mixed German-Japanese commission has been named to carry out provisions of the anti-Comintern agreement of last November, it was learned from a semi-official source tonight.
The change in the date of the inaugura tion and the abolition of "lame duck" sessions backed Congress completely off the inaugural stage today.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas increased 15 per cent for the week ended Jan. 16 over the comparative 1935 period, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

The sensational 19-year-old player, Stanley Galowin of the City A. C., yesterday accounted for one of the upsets of the season when he eliminated the national champion, Germain Glidden, in the semi-final round of the New York State squash racquets singles championships.

The marriage of Miss Elizabe M. Riordan of this City, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James J. Riordan, to Richard R. Porter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Porter of Forest Hills, Queens, took place yesterday morning in St, Ann's Church.
Four deaths and two train wrecks were attributed to a subzero cold wave which gripped the Rocky Mountain region tonight.

State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale had to resign precisely 472 times today to quit a single job. He was one of the three mortgage trustees of Westchester County, and he had to file a resignation for each of the mortgage series in which the trustees had acted.

After a whole week during which he had improved sufficiently to spend a few hours each morning reclining in a wheel-chair, Pope Pius today was forbidden by his doctor, Professor Aminta Milani, to leave his bed, his general condition having taken a turn for the worse because of the reappearance of violent pain in his right leg.

In a carefully timed and earnest appeal, which can be read also as a solemn warning, Great Britain urges upon Germany the adoption of a policy of economic collaboration and political appeasement with the whole of Europe.

Operators of motor trucks won a victory here today when the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, with Judge John J. Parker presiding, handed down an opinion holding that the State law limiting the size and weights of motor trucks in interstate commerce was an "unreasonable burden" upon such commerce so far as the hard-surfaced main highways of the State were concerned.
Cherokee Red, a 5-year-old daughter of Cherokee and Red Head, captured the mile-and-a-sixteenth race for $1,500 players at the Fair Grounds today for her second straight victory.

Although outplayed in the second half La Salle College defeated Rider tonight, 34-31. The Trenton team trailed at the half, 22-11, but the clever shooting of Joe Shelley and George Abel threatened the Explorers near the finish.

Worcester Tech's varsity basketball team defeated Brown, 45 to 38, tonight. Worcester moved out to a 28-13 lead at half-time, and halted a desperate Bruin drive at the close. Clements was lost to Brown on fouls. Raskavsky was high scorer with 16 points.

For more than seven hours this afternoon and evening the 1,500 soldiers of Fort Slocum, on a small island in Long Island Sound near here, fought a fire that eventually wrecked half of Barracks 85, a forty-five-year-old brick building. The fire deprived 110 men of their quarters and they were assigned to other buildings.

Harvey Weeks, assistant vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, was elected president of the Financial Advertisers Association of New York at the annual meeting yesterday at the Lawyers Club.

The claim that France is getting out of the depression period and that business activity is increasing month by month to the benefit of the Treasury was made by Finance Minister Vincent Auriol at the weekly luncheon of the Anglo-American press correspondents today.

A new automotive strike organization, the "Women's Emergency Brigade," was ready for action today. Composed of women who have husbands, sons or brothers in the General Motors strike, it claimed a membership of fifty.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $12,000,000 of State of Louisiana highway bonds on a bid of 100.13 for $5,500,000 of Series Q bonds as 3 3/4s and $6,500,000 of Series R bonds as 3 1/2s. Dated Jan. 1, 1937, both issues of bonds will mature serially on Jan. 1, 1941 to 1960.

Negotiations with Dana X. Bible of Nebraska on the football coaching vacancy at the University of Texas were as much a mystery as ever tonight after a four-hour closed conference of the parties concerned.
Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd told interviewers tonight that he is going to the Antarctic again and then to the Tropics.

The National Labor Relations Board yesterday served John E. Craig, vice president of the Clyde Mallory Lines, and A. J. McCarthy, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, with subpoenas requiring their presence in Washington tomorrow at a hearing resulting from charges filed by striking seamen.

The eleven members of the editrial staff of The North Shore Evening Journal in Flushing who are members of the Newspaper Guild of New York officially went on strike yesterday. The eight men and three women reporters have not been at work since Dec. 7, when they announced that, although not striking,

Greater care in the selection of students for department store training was advocated by Dr. Harold G. Shields, director of the Prince School of Store Service Education, affiliated with Simmons College, Boston,

Gustav Schoenchen, transferred principal of Public School 5, at Edgecombe Avenue and 140th Street, the Bronx, was exonerated yesterday by Justices Hackenburg, Brady and Renaud in Special Sessions of striking and kicking a 14year-old Negro boy visitor to his office last Oct. 21.

The election of three new members of the board of trustees of the American Retail Federation, chosen by their State retail associations as their representatives, was announced yesterday by Colonel C. O. Sherrill, president of the federation, following a luncheon of the board of the organization yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

Cotton textile manufacturers in the first six months of 1936 had a substantially greater profit than in the preceding six months, according to a report of the Federal Trade Commission, made public today. The only exceptions were the groups engaged in stock dyeing and finishing.

The inaugural address of President Roosevelt at noon yesterday was, on the whole, fairly well received in Wall Street. Followers of the share market quickly scanned the highlights of the address as reported on the financial news tickers and just as quickly decided that it contained nothing that might be considered disturbing to the markets.

Bennington R. Gordon has purchased a large corner plot on Axtell Drive and Lockwood Road, Berkley, Scarsdale, and will build a ten-room dwelling of Colonial style there from plans now being prepared by Douglas M. Malcolm, Crane-Berkley Corporation, developers of Berkley in Scarsdale, report.

William Heyer, 46 years old, a woolen salesman, died yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of his apartment at 35 Hamilton Place, at 138th Street, in an explosion of illuminating gas which knocked down walls in the Heyer apartment and two others adjoining it.

Yale defeated Wesleyan by 52 to 23 tonight to register its 153d consecutive dual swimming victory. The visitors gained firsts in the breaststroke by Hinsdale, in the 400-yard relay with D. and S. Davis, Blizard and Baird and in the furlong freestyle by D. Davis in 2 minutes 23.4 seconds, a new Wesleyan record.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $43,496,092, the largest in its history. This was equal to $5.67 a share on the common stock, against $4.03 a share in 1935. The statement follows:
The Federal Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the Federal Mediation Board had full authority in settling disputes between opposing labor unions in collective bargaining.

Lou Burns, Manhattan College's I. C. A. A. A. A. outdoor 800 and indoor 1,500 meter champion, who accounted for the best time in the featured 1,000 yard run at the Sixty-ninth Regiment A .A. meet last week,

Dr. Eugene Hinman, nose, throat and ear specialist, died at his home tonight following a heart attack. His age was 62. Born in Albany, a son of Addison J. Hinman, he was for many years secretary of the Commerce Insurance Company. Dr.

The property at 234-44 West Fortyfirst Street, adjoining the twentystory Herald Tribune Building at 228-32 West Forty-first Street, has been purchased by the New York Tribune, Inc., from the Greenwhich Savings Bank, subject to a mortgage of $170,000. The plot has a frontage of 100 feet and a depth of 98.9 feet.
ROMANTIC ADVENTURE: BEING THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF ELINOR GLYN. (Dutton, $3.50.) The life story of the author of "Three Weeks." THE COLOSSUS OF ROADS: A LIFE OF JOHN LONDON MCADAM, by Roy Devereux.

The Peddie School basketball .team defeated Lawrenceville, 34 to 30, in a fast contest today. The home team got away to an early lead, but Lawrenceville's rally in the last half provided a thrilling finish to the battle.

John H. Abeel of New York eliminated the defending champion in the second round of match play for the twenty-ninth annual championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Country Club today. He vanquished George H. Hartman of Chicago, who had won the league crown in both 1925 and 1936, by 2 up and 1 to play.

Dr. Max Imhoff, leader in the silk industry of the East for several years, died of a heart attack at his home, 141 Washington Avenue, Clifton, last night. He was 55. Born at Basle, Switzerland, Dr. Imhoff was graduated from the University of Zurich in 1905.
Removal of the headquarters of the Distilled Spirits Institute from Washington to this city around March 1 will be announced here shortly by officials of that

Miss Helen Mary Elliffe, daughter of Mrs. William Kearns Elliffe of the Bronx, and the late Mr. Elliffe, was married to Edmund Sens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund William Sens of Fleetwood, this city, tonight in the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Fleetwood by the Rev. John V. Delaney, the rector.
The "officer in the tower"--the man around whom centered one of the greatest British army scandals in years-won freedom from jail today because of his father's death.

Curtailed editions of The Beaumont Enterprise and Journal, morning and afternoon papers respectively, were published today after printers went on a "sit-down" strike yesterday afternoon. The printers returned to work tonight under an arbitration agreement.

The High Court has approved an agreement for the sale by the trustees of the will of the late Sir Thomas Lipton of the important wholesale tea businesses of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., of New York, and Thomas J. Lipton, Ltd., of Toronto, together with rubber and tea estates in Ceylon.

Two players who have been teammates since their junior high school days will be in the line-up of the George Washington quintet when the Colonials take the floor against Long Island University at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

Robert Wiseman, 19, observed the birthday of General Robert E. Lee yesterday by announcing that he possessed the original manuscript of what is believed to be the last proclamation issued by Jefferson Davis, -President of the Confederacy.

Governor Murphy of Michigan, at the end of another long conference here today on the General Motors strike situation. indicated that it seemed difficult, if not impossible, to break the deadlock through State action.

Looking forward to the celebration of the sesquicentennial of the Constitution next September, THE NEW YORK TIMES has cooperated with the State and local departments of education in giving support to two series of contests relating to this historic but living document.
An investing syndicate bought from Richmond Rosen, builders, the five-and-a-half-story walk-up apartment house at 1,259 Grant Avenue, the Bronx. Assessed at $90,000,

Incorporated Investors-Dec. 31: Liquidating value was $25.77 each on 3,000,000 shares, against $20.87 each on 2,625,000 shares a year before. William A. Parker, president, announced that the size of the fund would be voluntarily limited to the 3,000,000 shares now outstanding.

Lieut. Col. William Benjamin Jackson, retired rate engineer and consultant for the New York Edison Company, died today of a heart ailment and complications at House of Mercy Hospital. He was in his sixty-seventh year.

The New York A. C. held its narrow lead over the Columbia Unilversity Club last night as the two teams scored shutout victories in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League. The wearers of the Winged Foot, led by Harry F. Wolf, national champion, turned back the visiting Princeton Club, 5-0, and Columbia

Washington Park's Jockey Club pushed plans today for revival of the American Derby after announcing that the value of its stakes and purses would be increased at least 10 per cent. The increase will raise the track's distribution of purses to more than $300.000.

Except for the reference of the Archbishop of Canterbury in an address to the Upper House on the convocation of Canterbury, which opened in Westminster Abbey today, the anniversary of the death of Britain's beloved King George V passed almost unnoticed.
Instead of bobbing up on Broadway the week after next-that is, the week of Feb. 1-George M. Cohan and "Fulton of Oak Falls" will pause for six days at the Shubert Theatre in Newark.

Four socially prominent women, members of feminist associations, were among sixty persons indicted today for alleged parts in the revolt in November, 1935. Among the indicted men is Eliezer Magalhaes, brother of the Governor of the State of Bahia, and Odilion Baptista, son of Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro.
Leaders of the five big railroad brotherhoods voted here tonight to demand a 20 per cent pay increase for about 300.000 members of the unions.
Mass raids on shack towns and "hobo jungles" in two States today put dozens of men into the hands of officers pursuing the fingerprint trail of Charles Mattson's kidnapslayer.

The National Crushed Stone Association brought its annual convention to a close today amid forecasts of still better business for this year. M. J. Gormley of Washington, D. C., executive assistant of the

Women jurors tackled a rare constitutional problem in Federal court here today, and it proved insoluble. At 8:05 tonight the panel of ten women and two men drawn yesterday to pass on a special defense plea to the Port Newark National Bank case were discharged because they could not agree on a verdict.

Negotiations between Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France and Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras of Turkey on the status of Alexandretta when Syria becomes independent are understood to have brought some concessions from France. The negotiations began here today.

The railroads suffered upsets in their plans for the inauguration because of the storm. With special trains on sidings in New York, Philadelphia and other Eastern cities, cancellations of reservations began to come in early this morning.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, has among her passengers Italo Verrando, newly appointed general manager of the Italian Line in the United States and Canada, and Aroldo Palanca, whom he succeeds and who will become managing director of the company at Genoa.

Thomas B. Casey, a retired lawyer who formerly specialized in transfer tax cases, died yesterday at his home, 2,272 University Avenue, Bronx, at the age of 78. He had been ill for sixteen years following a stroke of paralysis.

A motorcycle patrolman shot and killed his brother-in-law early yesterday In the latter's apartment on the upper West Side and then committed suicide by firing a bullet into his own head. The tragedy followed an argument that started when the policeman demanded to know the whereabouts of his estranged wife and the brother-inlaw said he did not know. The policeman's wife left him about two weeks ago.
A Japan that is single-handed and friendless and striving to maintain herself amid envious aggressive powers was portrayed in a War Office pamphlet issued today as the Diet assembled.

Verdi "Aida" was given its second presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The performance was one that held the interest of the capacity audience firmly at all times and moved along with animation and address.

Officials of banks and savings institutions all over Britain were busy after the close of business today computing contributions to be charged to their depositors in one of the most unusual fund-raising schemes ever devised here or abroad.
Fresh from their victory in Boston on Tuesday, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight tackle Red Dutton's Americans in a National Hockey League skirmish on the ice in Madison Square Garden.

The information Yankee baseball players have been anxiously awaiting willbe in their possession within the next few days, ome of them receiving it today if their Winter homes are close enough to New York for overnight postal delivery.
The South and the West have registered the greatest business comebacks since the early part of 1933, L. D. H. Weld, director of research, McCann-Erickson, Inc.,

Governors of many States, with former Governors and others, headed a long list of distinguished visitors here for the inauguration. Among them were Governor Lehman, accompanied by a large staff, and many officials and his secretary, Walter A. Brown, and Mrs. Brown.

A sextet composed of former Princeton hockey players tonight won a 4-2 victory in Baker Rink, defeating the present Tiger freshman, varsity and jayvee teams, each of which played one period of the contest.

Alfred Carpenter Andrews, former vice president of the Chase National Bank, was killed between noon and 12:30 yesterday when he fell or jumped from a rear window of his eleven-room apartment on the fifth floor of 1,040 Park Avenue, at the northwest corner of Eightysixth Street.

Despite the handicap imposed on her foreign trade through boycotts, currency devaluations, clearing arrangements and her own policy of economic selfsufficiency, National Socialist Germany has been able to make a better showing in world trade, at least on paper, than most other countries, including Great Britain and excepting only the United States, Sweden and Belgium-Luxemburg.

The first January inauguration day dawned with clouds down over Washington- like a black pall and a cold Winter rain making movement through the streets, save in cars, one continuous period of discomfort.

New Jersey poured hosts into the capital today to witness the inauguration as special trains from Jersey City, Trenton and Atlantic City brought crowds almost up to the expected quota, despite inclement weather.

Secretary Swanson of the Navy found the rain pelting down too hard for him to stand upon the inauguration platform after the invocation today, and his leaving occasioned reports he had collapsed and had been taken home.

Sam Franko, veteran violinist, conductor and teacher, who made music history in this city with his concerts of old music more than thirty-five years ago, was honored by the trustees and administrative officers of the New York Public Library yesterday afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph R. Loening have come from Glimpse Water, their place in Glen Cove, to the Sherry-Netherland, where they will be until they sail Saturday for the Mediterranean. Later they will go to Switzerland.

Rehabilitation of old-law tenements to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law rather than the construction of new housing by government subsidy is the logical and economic procedure to be followed in the removal of slum conditions in New York, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the First Avenue Association in the Beekman Tower Hotel.

Mrs. Busch Greenough will give tea today at the St. Regis for members of the executive committee of the Coro d'Italia Ball, to be held at the Plaza on Jan. 28 in behalf of the Italian choral associations of the city.
Two matches tonight filled the lower quarter-final bracket of the invitation Class B squash racquets tournament at the Essex Club, the first event of its kind ever held in the State.

The amount of private mortgage money used in Westchester County last year increased by $9,175,582 from the $21,458,598 of 1935, according to the annual report of William F. Condon, County Register, made public today. Mr. Condon said the gain more than made up for the withdrawal of the Home Owners Loan Corporation from activity.

The first Canadian Government financing to be undertaken in this market in about a year will take place today with the offering by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of $85,000,000 of Dominion of Canada bonds The financing consists of $30,000,000 of seven-year 2 1/4 per cent bonds due on Jan. 15, 1944,

An auction of Americana, printed and in manuscript,; brought '$9,188 yesterday at. the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the first of two auction sessions. The lots came from the collections of Philip Van Ingen, U. P. Hedrick, the late Ogden Goelet and the late Robert Bonner.

Nine United States Army planes searching for the American aviators William and Gordon Kingsley since Saturday returned to their base today because of their inability to obtain the proper kind of gasoline here for their planes.

Nutting Wigton, up-State general commercial manager of the New York Telephone Company, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. Mr. Wigton was born fifty-one years ago in Phillipsburg, N. J., and was a graduate of Lehigh University.

The legal rights of taxpayers wishing to recover processing and floor taxes paid under the A. A. A., a question which is expected to come before the Supreme Court within a few months, will be argued by senior students of the Harvard Law School tomorrow night in this year's finals of the Ames competition between the student law clubs.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer denied yesterday applications by the Consolidated Edison Company and other defendants to dismiss five of six causes of action in a stockholder's suit to recover $610,000 in bonuses and gifts paid in 1929 and 1932 to officers of the Consolidated system and others.

Ralph Greenleaf defeated two opponents in impressive fashion in pocket billiard matches at the Fourteenth, Street Academy- yesterday. Greenleaf downed George Burns, 100 to 14, in six innings and scored over Jack Lorenze, 100 to 16, in four frames. In each of the matches -Greenleaf recorded runs of 58.

The attacking Government forces failed to dominate the important height of Cerro de los Angeles, eight miles south of Madrid, in the face of a heavy counter-attack last night, and fierce fighting has raged all during today.

Manhattan College has awarded athletic insignia to sixty-nine participants in football and cross-country during the Fall, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. Four managers also were rewarded.

There is great satisfaction here regarding the Italo-German arrangement for developing possible iron, copper and other deposits in Ethiopia. The conclusion of this agreement is recognized as one of the main results of the trip made to Italy by Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, although negotiations had been under way for some time and it had been known that Germany would take part in some way in developing Ethiopia.

Portugal, on Spain's western border, rejected today an international supervisory plan to curb war shipments into the zone of civil battle. Informed sources said Lisbon had formally notified Great Britain she was unwilling to permit the European nonintervention committee to install observers to watch exports into Spain.

Police Sergeant John J. Devery, in charge of Emergency Squad 19, stationed at Bayside, Queens, died of an acute heart attack yesterday while riding with the squad to answer a call. As the truck was passing 212th Street on Northern Boulevard the sergeant collapsed. Two patrolmen carried him into a gasoline station, but he was already dead.

John D. Wilson, Brooklyn merchant, president of the Frank Wilson Co. department store, at 1,287 Broadway, Brooklyn, died of pneumonia yesterday in the Jewish Hospital. His home was at 53 Woodbine Street.

A telegram demanding that all facts in the license revocation case against the Borden Company pending before the State Milk Control Division be made public, and that an audit of the books of the Dairymen's League also be made, was sent yesterday to Peter G. Ten
Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, announced yesterday thirteen promotions, six of them to vice presidencies. The list follows:

Only eight survivors, all hospitalized, were left today of the thirteen persons aboard a Western Air Express liner when it crashed on a snowy mountain ridge near the Burbank airport Jan. 12. C. T. Owens, co-pilot, died in a hospital last night, the fifth victim of a disaster for which the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce expects to hold a public hearing tomorrow.
Representatives of cigar manufacturers from various parts of the country formed yesterday an organization to be known as the Cigar Manufacturers Association of the United States.

A philatelic find was reported yesterday by Herman Herst Jr., a stamp dealer of 116 Nassau Street, who returned recently from the Pacific Coast. He brought a United States stamp estimated to be worth about $4,000 which he bought for $3.

The efforts of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull toward inter-American peace, exemplified in the recent Buenos Aires conference, were hailed yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Pan American Society in India House, Hanover Square.

Centralized buying by smaller stores to meet chain-store competition and caution against overexpansion of the installment business were among the recommendations of speakers at the twenty-sixth annual convention of the-National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Yale freshman hockey team routed the Pawling School six today, 9 to 2. The Blue cubs tallied three times in the opening session and never were headed. George Seabury, former Andover ace, starred for the victors, scoring twice unassisted and twice more aided by Clem Kite.

Officials of the American Tobacco Company announced yesterday an increase of 15 cents a thousand in the wholesale price of Lucky Strike and Sweet Caporal cigarettes, two of the popular-priced brands manufactured by this company.

County Counsel John M. Mills died here at his home early today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old. Mr. Mills was graduated from Rutgers College in 1897. He studied law in the offices of the late Circuit Court Judge Willars W. Cutler and was admitted to the bar in 1899.

President Manuel Azana left the solitude of a monastery today to visit Leftist government troops in the Madrid front. He was expected to establish residence at Valencia after completing the tour, yielding to the pressure of the Leftist administration there.

Miss Dorothy. Locke of the sale d'Armes Vince was back in splendid form and swept-aside her eight opponents last night to triumph in the fencing competition staged on her club's strips. Winning-three bouts in the first round, the former national titleholder and Olympic team member disposed of five more challengers in the final round-robin to win first prize, presented by Joseph Vince.

In his four years of administration Governor FUTRELL of Arkansas has won golden opinions. His acts have praised him. The Arkansas Gazette now celebrates his literary style. From his message to the Legislature upon his retirement from office, it takes a passage characteristic of his official writing.

With only four games remaining on the schedule, Brazil and Argentina today were undefeated in the South American soccer football championship tournament. Brazil has scored four straight victories, and Argentina three. Paraguay is in third place with two games won and two lost, Chile and Uruguay fourth with one victory
Although it may make no alteration in the long-range history of the country, the United States coasted along for twenty-eight minutes today without a President.

Raymond Thon, 23-year-old CCC recruit, of 608 Twenty-first Street, who gave another CCC recruit an injection of narcotics yesterday in an effort to cure him of a "hangover" and nearly killed the man, was arrested at pistol point this morning as he was descending a fire escape to get away from Federal narcotic agents and local detectives.

Many parties were given yesterday afternoon in conjunction with the fashion revue, entitled the Flower Cart Fashion Show, held in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Alice Hall Ali Committee's Milk Center at Avenue B. Boutonnieres of

Held in check during most of the opening half, Wesleyan's unbeaten quintet rapidly drew away the second session to defeat Massachusetts State tonight, 55-36. It was the seventh straight triumph for the Cardinal and Black team.

Reopening a two-decade battle over the Elks Hills naval oil reserve lands, a suit was filed on behalf of the United States here today against the Standard Oil Company of California, Pan-American Petroleum Company, executors of the estate of the late Edward L. Doheny and nearly a score of other defendants.

Herzig Hart, Inc., and J. H. Bleistein, Inc., fur dealers, have formed a working arrangement, whereby the latter will act as buying agent for Far Eastern and South American goods, and the former as selling agent for the combination. Each company will retain its identity.

Surprising upsets featured replayed third-round English football cup games today. Accrington Stanley, York City and Luton Town returned victories against seconddivision opponents and will go into the fourth round with Bolton Wanderers, winner by 1-0 over West Ham United.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was presented for the third time of the current season yesterday afternoon before a capacity audience. The performance, enthusiastically greeted, was for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador and North Newfoundland.

Failure of the conference today in Washington arranged by Secretary Perkins to bring about resumption of the truce in the General Motors strike, led to hurried action by the automobile and glass affiliates of the Committee for Industrial Organization to settle two other strikes so as to bring further pressure on the G. M. C.
THOSE fellows laughing heartily as the snow came down yesterday were skiers. It just reminded them of something.

An estimated 20,000 persons were homeless tonight in the Middle West and Southeast because of flood waters. Unofficial estimates placed the number of homeless in Missouri at 2,500 persons; 2,550 in Southern West Virginia and 1,600 in Ohio.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for 296,069 shares of common stock of the Gulf States Steel Company. Julia A. Glenn, director of publicity of the Greenpoint Savings Bank of Brooklyn since 1932, has resigned to pass a few months in California and Hawaii.

Repayments in 1936 by policy holders of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company on loans against policies were 15 per cent greater in 1936 than in 1935, reducing these loans from $9,336,478 to $9.203,906.

George A. Kinney has resigned as a vice president of the Chase National Bank to establish a trust deapartment for the Bank of Bermuda, Ltd., at Hamilton. He will move to Bermuda on Feb. 1. Mr. Kinney was with the Hamilton Trust Company of Brooklyn more than twenty years.

A 6 per cent increase in employment and a rise of nearly 38 per cent in wage disbursements in Pennsylvania's anthracite mines from the middle of November until mid-December were reported today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. The bank's indices were compiled from reports to the Anthracite Institute by thirty-two companies employing more than 76,000 workers with earnings of $2,250,000 a week.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, averted shutting off of the artificial gas supply to a large part of Toledo today and then set out to settle the strike which has threatened the service for five days.

John Nance Garner of Texas, the third man in American history to succeed himself as Vice President, took the oath of office fifteen seconds before 12:27 o'clock this afternoon and established the precedent of being the first Vice President ever sworn in on the same platform as the President.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall. "The Far Away Princess," Henry Noble MacCracken, 11 A. M.; "Consumers Cooperatives and Private Business," Murray Lincoln. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "The Art of Italy," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; 'The Art of Egypt."

About twenty United States airplanes that arrived in Mexico before the United States embargo on arms for Spain was proclaimed have been responsible for the Mexican Government's formally declaring its intention to continue to send arms to the Spanish Loyalists at a delicate moment when the European partisans of both Spanish factions are struggling to arrange a new and real neutrality agreement.

The American International Corportion reported yesterday that on Dec. 31 last its net asset value was $2,588.76 for each $1,000 of outstanding indebtedness, including a bank- loan payable on that date, comparing with $1,878.39 a year before.

Because of the General Motors strikes, work is halting at the Fisher Body plant here, and today notices were posted in the Chevrolet plant that work would cease there tomorrow. Meanwhile, the 2,800 men who face enforced idleness were planning a march on Washington next week in an effort to seek Federal intervention in the strike.

Asserting that bookings thus far in January by a few of the larger companies have been in excess of shipments, Iron Age, in its weekly review of the industry, says that the continuance of the automobile strikes is the only unfavorable

Many seats have been purchased for the pre-opening performance of "Tide Rising," a new play by George Brewer Jr., with Grant Mitchell and Tamara in the leading roles, tonight at the Lyceum Theatre, which has been taken over by officers and members of the board of managers of the Wayside Day Nursery to raise funds for the work of that organization.

Herman Hahn, president of the tr 32 Avenue B Corporation, interrupted his trial in Federal court yesterday to plead guilty to an indictment charging him with filing false claims with the Public Works Administration, for which his company was doing construction work.

Earnings of The Guaranty Trust Company of New York for 1936 were $13,409,158, compared with $12,795,875 in 1935, according to the report issued yesterday by William C. Potter, chairman of the board, and presented to stockholders at their annual meeting. In the absence of Mr. Potter, the meeting was presided over by W. Palen Conway, president, who read the report.

An issue of 60,000 shares of Class B common stock of the Serrick Corporation of Defiance, Ohio, is being offered today at $12.50 a share by Harrison, O'Gara Co.; Sills, Troxell Minton, Inc.; the PolkPeterson Corporation, and Festus J. Wade Jr. Co.

ELINOR GLYN'S autobiography is even more curious than might have been expected, and quite as interesting. In "Romantic Adventure" (Dutton, $3.50) she has round the perfect title, for her own "True Story." More fortunately imaginative than most, she has seemingly succeeded in enveloping her whole life as she looks back upon it in a kind of moon haze of fancy with all unpleasant realities blurred.

The engagement of Miss Katherine Wellington Auryansen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Denley Auryansen, to Samuel Armstrong Talbot of Baltimore has been announced by her parents. Miss Auryansen was graduated from Mount Holyoke College and received her doctorate from Radcliff College last June.

Pensioned On Police Surgeon's certificate: PATROLMEN-Jacob F. Felix, 7th Precinct, at $1,188 per annum. Appointed April 25, 1921. Frank R. Consalvo, 15th Precinct, at $1,020 per annum. Appointed July 11, 1923. Henry L. Lehr Jr., 43d Precinct, at $840 per annum. Appointed Dec. 21, 1925. James J. Dowd, 67th Precinct, at $804 per annum. Appointed June 16, 1926.

ADLER, ROSE L. (Jan. 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Leon N. Adler, husband, executor, 325 West End Av., one-third residue; Stanley-L. Adler, son, Hereford, Arlz., life estate in two-thirds residue. Central Hanover Bank Trust Co.,

The Williams varsity basketball team broke a four-game losing streak tonight with a 43-36 victory over Northeastern University. Mike Latvis, with 16 points, and sophomore Pete Seay, with 10, took the Purple's scoring honors. Henry Bialkowski, husky guard, led the losers.

To 73-year-old Peter Schultz the answer to the problem of perpetual motion is just around the corner. The former cabinetmaker, watchmaker and machinist declared today that when the machine he has spent thirty-five years and $35,000 to model is perfected "it will generate enough power to put Niagara Falls out of business."

Judge F. P. Schoonmaker in Federal court sentenced two paroled convicts to life penitentiary terms today after they pleaded guilty to charges of bank robbery and kidnapping. One of them, Harold M. Brest, 27 years old, of Sharon, Pa., shouted to Judge Schoonmaker:
A "sit-down" strike at the KellySpringfield Tire Company's plant here threw about 1,800 employes out of work today. Production at the plant was halted.

J. Edward Knight of Ocean Grove, judge of the Monmouth County Common Pleas Court, and Miss Ortrude Slocum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Slocum of this city, were married this morning at St. James Episcopal Church.

D. H. McConnell, founder and president of Allied Products, Inc., of New York City and Suffern, manufacturers of, perfumes and toilet articles, died at his home here this morning o a streptococcic infection. His age was 78.

Jewelry that was formerly the property of John M. Phillips, known at the time of his death in Atlantic City, N. J., on July 3, 1928, as the "Sewer Pipe King" of Queens County, was the prize sought in a suit started yesterday by the government in Brooklyn Federal Court.

A basket by Bob Miller, with less than a minute to play, enabled the Stevens Hoboken Academy basketball team to vanquish the Flatbush Academy quintet, 13 to 12, on the losing team's floor yesterday. Flatbush rallied to take the lead, 12-11, after trailing, 7-3, at the half. Then Miller's shot decided the issue.

Alfred E. Smith Jr. finished his testimony yesterday in General Sessions as a State witness in the trial of A. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, on his charge that they extorted more than $8,000 from him in 1933 under threat to expose him in a suit in behalf of a young woman.

One of the most elaborate radio hook-ups in the history of broadcasting enabled many millions of listeners, not only in the United States but in other parts of the civilized world, to hear President Roosevelt take the oath of office.

There will be a repetition of the 1935 final of the women's metropolitan squash racquets championship on the Junior League courts this afternoon at 4:30, when Mrs. Ary J. Lamme faces Mrs. John Bierwirth for this year's title.

A verdict of "no cause for action" was reached late last night by a Federal court jury in the $250,000 suit of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia against the city of Ocean City. It ended a five-day hearing.

Senator Norris, legislative father of the Twentieth Amendment to the Constitution, under which President Roosevelt was inaugurated today for the first time, refused to assume any responsibility for the weather conditions.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler gave final approval yesterday to the plan for reorganization of the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Company, one of the forty-seven closed mortgage-guarantee companies.

Seven thousand Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company workers prepared today to go back to work with a pay rise of 8 cents an hour. Calling off its three months' strike, which tied up 90 per cent of the nation's flat-glass industry,

Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien gave a reception and dinner last night at the River Club before leaving to pass several days with Mrs. James E. Davidson in Bay City, Mich., after which she will visit in Baltimore.

Notice of a resolution--precursor of a bill based upon itto reorganize the capital structure of the Canadian National Railways is given by C. D. Howe, Minister of Transport, in today's votes and proceedings. The resolution is scheduled for introduction into the House of Commons tomorrow. It provides for:

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Practically the first snowstorm of this Winter failed to stimulate trade to any great extent either in traefa or kosher meats. Price trends, though slightly mixed, tended downward in most classes.
Seven members of the Supreme Court around which controversy has revolved during the Roosevelt administration, attended the second inauguration of President Roosevelt today.

Yale tonight won an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game from Princeton, 36 to 30. A dazzling second-half rally which raised the visitors from a 28-10 deficit to within 7 points of victory brought a crowd of 1,500 enthusiasts up with a roar in one of the most exciting finishes of the season.

President ROOSEVELT will have as his week-end guest one of the most influential members of the British CabinetMr. WALTER RUNCIMAN, President of the Board of Trade. His visit will be wholly personal and unofficial; but on both sides of the Atlantic it has prompted a discussion of Anglo-American trade relations.
Amherst was dropped from the ranks of the undefeated tonight as Springfield's quintet won a hard-foughti contest, 40-36. Nuttall was high scorer for the victors, with 14 points.
The Catholic Diocesan Choristers of Brooklyn presented its annual concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night before a capacity house of 2,200. The Rev. Lawrence H. Bracken was the conductor.

Colgate's experience told in a see-saw basketball struggle in the Drill Hall tonight and Cornell lost, 43-40. Littie Ray Dieffenbach, Maroon forward, ran wild in the last five minutes to score 8 points and pull his team up from behind.

W. R. Grace Co. of New York have taken control of the London banking house of Grace Brothers Co., Ltd., it was reported today. Five English members of the board of directors, including the chairman, resigned, owing to the change, it was said.

Dorothy Thompson's book, "I Saw Hitler," was officially banned today in Germany. "I Saw Hitler," published early in 1932 by Farrar Rinehart, is a brief sketch of Chancellor Adolf Hitler before his rise to power.
Bernard L. Cremin, chairman of the music department of Far Rockaway High School, Queens, died Tuesday night of a heart ailment at his home, 1,047 Forest Avenue, Far Rockaway, after a long illness,
Sarah F. Bubendey will file suit for a divorce tomorrow morning against Paul F. Bubendey of New York on a charge of cruelty. charge of cruelty.
John J. Gartland, for forty years a clerk in the Kings County Court and brother-in-law of the late Democratic County Leader John H. McCooey, died yesterday at his home, 1,390 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

These National Guard commissions were issued today: Cowles, Lt. (J. G.) Frederick D., N. Y. Naval Militia, assigned to 9th Battalion, for further assignment to 11th Fleet Division. Snyder, Ensign Lee G., N. Y. N. M., assigned to 9th Battalion for further assignment to 15th Fleet Division.

Notice has been received by Goldman, Sachs Co., as representatives of the underwriters, that 479,412 shares of capital stock of Sears, Roebuck Co. were subscribed by stockholders under the company's offer to them of about 488,655 shares, in the ratio of one new share for each ten shares held of record on Dec. 26, 1936. The offering expired on Jan. 15.

The list of imports forbidden from non-clearing countries without special permits from the national bank has been extended to include patent medicines, chemicals and pharmaceutical preparations, pure silk goods, aluminum, steam pumps, turbines, steam engines and all machines worked by internal combustion engines.
Contrasts as sharp as the difference in the weather at his first and second inaugurations marked President Roosevelt's inaugural speech and its immediate reception by the throng at the Capitol today.

Twentieth Century-Fox is negotiating with agents for Gracie Fields, England's leading box-office film attraction, for a series of four films during the next three years. Monty Banks, who has directed the Lancastershire comedienne in her recent pictures, is in Hollywood, and may be engaged by the studio to direct Miss Fields's work here.

The Savings Banks Trust Company, the capital stock of which is held by savings banks of this State, reported a net profit for 1936 of $1,124,030 in its annual statement, issued yesterday following the annual meeting of shareholders.

The Princeton polo team scored its fourth victory in six starts today by riding to a 15-7 triumph over the Lawrenceville School trio, which has twice conquered the Tiger yearlings this season and repulsed the jayvees once.

The Tallo Realty Co., Inc., Leonard Kanter, president, gave to the Dry Dock Savings Institution three mortgages for $3,325. each, due on demand at 4 per cent, on the three parcels at 533-43 W. 158th St., which the mortgagor has just acquired in foreclosure proceedings. Jacob R. Schiff assigned to Betty Finkelstein a mortgage for $4,611 on 323-25 E. 37th St.
Liquidation in the grain markets was resumed today following a fair upturn at the opening of the Board of Trade in sympathy with unexpected strength in wheat futures in Liverpool.

A finish meeting between Dave Levin, Jamaica heavyweight who formerly claimed the world title, and Robert Bruns, rugged German, is scheduled as the feature of the wrestling carnival tonight in the Hippodrome.

Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, former Foreign Minister of Brazil and a special envoy to represent his country at the inauguration of President Roosevelt, who missed the ceremony in Washington today because the Pan American Clipper ship in which he and members of his party left Rio de Janeiro was grounded yesterday afternoon at San Pedro de Marcoris, Santo Domingo, arrived here this noon.

Manager Frankie Friseh of the Cardinals brought his troubles to. St. Louis, today but Pepper Martin wasn't among Frisch's trials and tribulations. The Wild Horse of the Osage drove into town in a truck, galloped into the Cardinal office and speedily signed his 1937 contract. He said he was "tip-top and ready to go."
Virginio Gayda in an editorial in this evening's Giornale d'Italia strongly denies that Italy has any intention of proposing the resuscitation of the FourPower pact.

The Dominion Bank reported net profits of $951,222 (Canadian) in 1936 after making provision for Dominion and Provincial taxes. After paying 10 per cent dividends in the amount of $700,000, contributing $75,000 to the officers' pension fund and writing off $100,000 from bank premises, $76,278 was added to profit and loss account.

Hearing of charges that Swift Co., meat packers, indulged in unfair trade practices was resumed yesterday before Raymond L. Dillman, examiner for the Department of Agriculture, in the old Postoffice Building.

An animated pageant, depicting the struggles, emotions and ambitions of the Communists, was staged before more than 20,000 members of the Communist party at the Thirteenth Annual Lenin Memorial meeting held last night in Madison Square Garden.
Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne tonight endorsed a suggestion by Governor Lehman that complete control of bag limits and open seasons on wildlife be given to the Conservation Department.
Trading continued light on the stock market here today, but the price level displayed a firmer tone. British Government issues opened weak but rose in the afternoon, closing slightly higher.

Dudley W. Johnson, 45 years old, of 15-20 126th Street, College Point, Queens, fell to his death shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon from the sixth floor office of the Imported Textile Designers, Inc., 29 East Nineteenth Street. He had been a salesman for the concern for twenty-five years.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank has placed on display a collection of seventy-five toy savings banks owned by Mrs. George Thompson of 162 East Sixty-first Street, Manhattan. The collection ineludes several banks more than 100 years old, as well as many intricate mechanical banks of the type that was popular just before the turn of the century.

Homewood Flirtatious, white and black pointer which won the 1935 national championship, added the continental field trials subscription all-age stake to her laurels today. In spite of hot, dry weather that made the going difficult, the pointer, owned by H. M.

The annual statement for 1936 of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $24,207,632 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, Federal surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.

Corporation bonds were firmer in a slightly accelerated pace of trading yesterday, while United States Government issues eased 1-32 to 1/4 point in quiet trading, although the volume was nearly double that of Tuesday.

There have been second inaugural addresses by American Presidents that were of the highest historical significhance. The most memorable was LINCOLN'S in 1865. We were still in the throes and uncertainties and anxieties of the Civil War, though it was nearer an end than most people believed.

BRIGGS HELEN F. R., (Feb. 5, 1936). Gross assets, $18,795: net, $12,657. To husband, Marvin Briggs, 50 shares of American Telephone and Telegraph Co., personal effects and life income from residuary estate in trust with power of invasion; St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church and Beth Birel Methodist Episcopal Church. $500 contingent interest each in trust fund; cousins, Emma Faulkner, $1,000 contingent interest In trust fund, Ethel M. Collins, contingent remainder of trust fund.

Brooklyn Poly's basketball team defeated the Upsala College quintet, 25 to 21, at Odd Fellows Hall, Brooklyn, last night. William Waller, with 8 points, led the victors, who were in front, 19 to 10, at the intermission.

Dr. Alexander Hamilton Phillips, retired chairman of the Department of Geology of Princetion University and an authority on the mining of radium, died of a heart attack tonight at his home, 54 Hodge Road. He was 70 years old.

Palestine again has the privilege of hearing a world-renowned musician with the arrival of the German violinist Adolph Busch, who came here to play as a guest artist with the newly organized Palestine Symphony Orchestra and also to give recitals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler has written a splendid letter to the Governors of the nineteen States where Legislatures are in session, opposing the proposed child labor amendment. Instead of realizing the convincing force of Dr. Butler's statements, some of those favoring the amendment rush into print to abuse Dr. Butler, Fortunately, he stands in a position where the mud-throwers are unable to reach him.

The invocation at the inauguration of the President by the Rev. ZeBarney T. Phillips, Chaplain of the Senate, was as follows: "Almighty God and Heavenly Father, ruler and guardian of the world: Sanctify to the nation the meaning of this hour that Thy people with one heart and mind may acknowledge their fealty to Thee.

When Senator Norris successfully advocated the amendment by the terms of which American Presidents take office January instead of in March after their elections, the weather was a secondary consideration.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader in the Eleventh Assembly District, was an associate of defendants in the restaurant racket case now being tried in Supreme Court before Justice McCook and will be mentioned more than once in the testimoney, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey said yesterday.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and other members of the British delegation left London today to attend the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations called to discuss a number of questions of secondary importance like the Turkish claim against France in Syria and the Polish troubles in Danzig. The meeting will begin tomorrow in Geneva.

Pensloned On their own applications after more than twenty years of service: Captain Michael J. Nagle of Engine 258 on an annual pension of $2.250. Captain John J. Cashman (1) of Engine 278, on an annual pension of $2,250. Engineer of Steamer Hugh C. O'Neill of Engine 228 on an annual pension of $1,700.

Reorganization of the Toronto Maple Leaf Baseball Club was completed today with election of officers and directors. Donald G. Ross, largely responsible for the formation of the company which prevented the franchise going outside the city, was elected President.

Gerard Av. (9-2482), w. s., 168 ft. s. of 157th St., 239x189; 751 Gerard Av. Realty Corp. to Gerard Housing Corp., 1,450 Bway; mtg. $19,000. Beaumont AV.. 2,445 (11-3090); Mary Rida to Helen Hickey, 37-27 73d St., Jackson Heights, iL. I.

In specifications filed in Federal court yesterday Alfred C. Frodel, a creditor, contended that Dudley Field Malone, international lawyer and former Collector of the Port of New York, should not be discharged from a bankruptcy proceeding because he had "knowingly and fraudulently concealed" assets.

On the main portico of the Capitol, his head bared to a chill, driving rain, Franklin Delano Roosevelt soon after noon today took for the second time the oath as President of the United States; and to a streaming crowd in front of, beside and behind him reconsecrated the government to leadership of "the American people forward along the road over which they have chosen to advance."

To permit the Interstate Commerce Commission to make a ruling on it, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today continued until March 22 a hearing on the plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

For the first time in many months Americans in London were able today to hear the voice of their President over the regular broadcasting system when the Roosevelt inaugural address and the ceremonies in connection with that event were relayed from Washington.

Five more unions joined the Philadelphia Council of the Committee for Industrial Organization today, and a campaign fund of $25,000 was subscribed to start a drive to organize Philadelphia labor in the mass-production industries.

A leap to the streets from the five-story high platform of the Interborough elevated line station at 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue proved fatal yesterday to an unidentified woman about 25 years old.

Never pressed once they struck their scoring stride, Fordham University's basketball forces swept to a 38-to-23 triumph over Seton Hall College in the Fordham gymnasium last night to deadlock their fourteen-game series at seven victories apiece.

The engagement of Miss Elise Sieker, daughter of Mrs. Adolphus T. Sieker of this place and the late Mr. Sieker, to Warren W. Walker of Montclair and Stoughton, Mass., has been announced by her mother.

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn endorsed yesterday the 1937 appeal of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association for $150,000, which will open on Monday with a luncheon at the Hotel Bossert and will continue through Feb. 9.

Gunnar Barlund, the Fighting Finn, didn't knock out Tom Beaupre, Texas heavyweight, last night in the ten-round bout at the Hippodrome. He didn't even knock Beaupre down. But he did about everything else to the Texan, and when the decision at the final bell went to the husky from the Northland there was no disagreement in the crowd of about 4,000, which included James J. Braddock, current heavyweight champion, and Jack Dempsey.

As the artistic culmination of a day of solemn ceremonial and military parades, the National Symphony Orchestra and a quartet from the Metropolitan Opera gave a concert in Constitution Hall tonight,. the one social function of President Roosevelt's second inauguration.

Mrs. Herman L. Cochran, Democratic National Committeewoman, today came to the defense of Governor Blanton Winship with the publication of a letter asserting Governor Winship favors the New Deal and supports the national administration, even though some of his associates are Republicans.

4th St., 226 W. 26.5x101; Rose S. Freidus and William P. Morris to 226 West 4th St. Corp., 61 Broadway; mtg., $30,000, held by grantee. 35th St., 36-38 W.. 40x98.9; Oakdale Holding Corp. to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., mortgagee.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Trott Pearman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Pearman of Cedarcrest, Pembroke, Bermuda, to Walton Ferguson 3d, son of Mrs. Walton Ferguson Jr. of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Ferguson, took place today at noon, in St. John's Church, Pembroke.

Winning his fourth game in the fifth round today, Reuben Fine of New York, leader in the international chess masters' tournament here, increased his margin over his nearest rivals, G. Stahlberg and G. Stoltz, at the Schacksalonger Chess Club.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

The building at 935 Park Av., southeast corner of 81st St. and Park Av., bought for a syndicate represented by the Tishman Realty and Construction Co., Inc., in the Spring of 1934, is fully rented, the Tishman Company reports.

The gold medal of the National Institute of Arts and Letters for history and biography was awarded last night to Charles McLean Andrews at the annual meeting and dinner of the institute at 633 West 155th Street.

A sit-down started by two men working on a large crane, company spokesmen said, brought production in the steel products plant of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company to a halt today. About 700 men are employed in the department.

Many events collateral to the inauguration were held today in connection with the presence of State officials and delegations. Among the functions were a luncheon at midday and tea this afternoon at the White House, given by the President and Mrs. Roosevelt for Governors and their wives.

Angelo Trulio of the New York Athletic Club, the defending titleholder, triumphed over Ed Knolhoff of the Trinity Club, 21-2, 2118, in the second round of the New York State four-wall handball championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night. Trulio drew a first-round bye.

Martin Kastengren, consul general of Sweden, told a group of traffic executives and shipping officials last night that prosperity "previously unheard of in the history of the world" would result from a world-wide application of a liberal foreign trade policy such as Sweden has had for many years and which the United States is now developing.

What promises to be an art event of unusual interest will be held through February at the Albright Art Gallery in Buffalo. It is called "Master Bronzes" and the items assembled will cover "nearly 5,000 years of artistic bronze making," as announced by the director of the museum. Gordon B. Washburn.

It is believed that the German and Italian answers to the British proposals of Jan. 9 have been drafted with a play for time as the major objective and that they will not embody a point-blank refusal to accept a ban on the enlistment of volunteers for the civil war in Spain.
