Silk Mask, 5-year-old gelding of the Rosedale stable, made his first start at Santa Anita Park an auspicious one today, staging a stretch drive to win the $1,500 El Dorado Handicap and pay the long odds of $60.80, $16.60 and $5.40 for $2 tickets.

Scoring the easiest victory in the tourney to date, Charles Whitehead of South River, N. J., the defending champion, advanced to the quarter-final round in the annual Miami Biltmore invitation amateur golf tournament today. He won his second-round match from C. A. Phinney of Miami, 8 and 7, without relinquishing a single hole.

The annual report of the American Superpower Corporation for 1936, issued yesterday, shows that the Bankers Trust Company, under an agreement made on Nov. 22, 1935, sold 964,400 shares of common stock of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for $3,026,279, leaving 323,000 shares unsold.

Two men who shot a patrolman after the hold-up of a beer garden at 1,800 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, on Nov. 12, were found guilty of robbery by a jury in Bronx County Court yesterday. They are Frederick Scott, 26 years old, of 516 East 141st Street, and Henry Brenner, 22, of 243 East 141st Street, the Bronx.

Directors of the American ReInsurance Company yesterday recommended that stockholders at their annual meeting on March 11 act on an increase in the capital stock of the company to 200,000 shares of $10-par value from 100,000 shares.

State Trooper Richards G. Hammond was killed early today after he had been overpowered by a prisoner in a patrol car and had been shackled to a rural mail box with his own handcuffs. The prisoner, a paroled convict, shot the trooper through the head.

Ankle deep in mud, huddled under umbrellas, with rain that was half sleet pelting them in the face, thousands stood shivering in a raw wind. today while Franklin D. Roosevelt swore for the second time, upon the Bible of his ancestors, to "preserve, protect and defend" the Constitution of the United States.

The third session of the Japanese-American cotton parley in Osaka yesterday saw the American case expounded in detail with full statistical data by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute. The conference has agreed not to publish daily reports but Mr. Murchison's argument, aside from his statistics, was repeated in a nation-wide broadcast from Osaka last night.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that discussions between the management and employes have resulted in wage increases, to become effective Feb. 1, which will add about $2,400,000 to wages paid in 1937.

Following an early decline yesterday, which carried quotations on the Cotton Exchange to their lowest figures since Jan. 6, prices recovered under trade calling to end 1 point higher to 3 points lower.

The Most Rev. Michael J. Gallagher, Catholic Bishop of Detroit, died at 8:20 o'clock tonight in Providence Hospital. He had been in the hospital only ten minutes. He had been ill of a throat ailment since Jan. 10. His age was 70.

Peter B. Juster of Minneapolis was elected president of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers today. The group, meeting in the Congress Hotel in its twenty-third annual convention, elected six vice presidents. They are J.

Electric power production continued to move upward last week, contrary to seasonal trend, and the adjusted index reached a new alltime high of 107.5. It was 107.0 for the previous week and 97.5 for the week ended Jan. 18, 1936.

The University Club of Stamford, Conn., strengthened its hold on third place in the Eastern Athletic Club League by defeating the Crescent A. C. quintet, 38 to 36, last night on the loser's court, in Brooklyn.
Six steamboats of the Hudson River Day Line were included today in company property covered by two mortgages filed with the Albany County Clerk and totaling more than $1.000,000. A. "first preferred"

Miss Natalie Couch of Nyack was formally named today as Journal Clerk of the Assembly, at a salary of $7,200 a year. Miss Couch succeeds William Brennan of Herkimer and will be here on Monday to take up her duties. She is the first woman so honored by the Assembly.

Playing at home for the first time in three weeks, the Blackbirds of Long Island University overwhelmed the East Stroudsburg Teachers College quintet, 55-22, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.
Inauguration Day was "remarkably free" of accidents, police said tonight. One death and few mishaps, only one serious, were reported.

The Hon. Mrs. Robert H. Brand, the former Miss Phyllis Langhorne of Virginia, died today at her home, Eydon Hall, near Banbury, in Northamptonshire. She was a sister of Lady Astor, who was at the bedside, and was one of the original "Gibson girls."

Mrs. Ruth White Colton of 28 West Twelfth Street, a lecturer on psychology and education, died Tuesday night at Bellevue Hospital after having been stricken suddenly by a cerebral hemorrhage while at work during the afternoon at the Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries, 247 Park Avenue.

An anonymous contribution of $5,000 to the United Hospital Fund campaign was announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive. The campaign committee is trying to raise a minimum of $2,881,000 for the eighty-eight voluntary hospitals of the city.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., plans to offer to stockholders soon rights to subscribe to 950,000 shares of new common stock in the ratio of one new share for each four shares now held, it was announced yesterday. Hayden Stone Co. are expected to head a syndicate to underwrite the offering and market any shares not subscribed for by stockholders.

The first real snow this Winter draped the city yesterday with a heavy covering of white that soon turned to slush and sleet. Rising temperatures and sleet turning to rain last night softened the snow and lightened the work of the city's snow removal forces.

The net profit of the Irving Trust Company for 1936 was $3,691,941, Lewis E. Pierson and Harry E. Ward, chairman and president, respectively, reported yesterday to shareholders at the bank's annual meeting, held at noon at the principal office, 1 Wall Street. This compared with a net profit of $3,150,930 for 1935.

A new work by the authors of "Middletown," Robert S. and Helen Merrell Lynd, is scheduled by Harcourt, Brace for publication on March 25. The book will be called "Middletown in Transition" and will deal with the social changes that the last decade has brought to America's "Middletown."

Officers were chosen, dates for the season granted and the proposed drastic new rules governing starting were adopted without a dissenting voice at the annual meeting of the stewards of the Grand Circuit at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.
In the aggregate, 294,000 Smiths are a lot of Smiths. That is the number listed among the 26,000,000 persons on the roster of the Federal

Hogs were in good demand today and the much smaller receipts sold at an advance of 5 to 15 cents. Unfavorable weather conditions over the West were said to be responsible for the lighter arrivals here and in the West.

It is now apparent that there will be little substantial improvement for Austria in her trade with Germany as a result of the negotiations that have been going on here between the two countries since the beginning of December. The results are expected to be announced Monday.

With a happy disregard for bad weather, discomfort and fatigue, Franklin D.Roosevelt stood bareheaded today in swirling rain to deliver his second inaugural address, rode at a walking pace the length of Pennsylvania Avenue bareheaded in an open car while rain beat down and then stood for an hour and a half without respite to review the inaugural parade.

Boston Rd. (11-2940), n. s., 134 ft. e. of 173d St., 162x130. 1,683-1,685 Boston Rd. Corp. to East River Savings Bank; extends mtg. to Nov. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent; $238,400. Gerard Av., 731 (9-2482), Gerard Housing Corp. to Isidor Lorberbaum, 8,728 21st Av., Brooklyn; installments, 6 per cent; $12,000.
Today's inaugural ceremonies under inclement weather recalled to veterans of such ceremonies the Taft inauguration in March, 1909, when trains were stalled in a blizzard on all sides of Washington.

One of the key measures of Governor Lehman's anti-crime program of last year which led to a heated controversy in the Legislature was invalidated today when the Appellate Division in the Third Department declared unconstitutional the McNaboe act.

In a comprehensive decision temporarily restraining Jersey City police from prohibiting meetings of the Communist Party, Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder declared in Chancery Court today that it was the right of "every citizen to belong to a party organized for a purpose hostile or in opposition to existing government and. to advocate a change in the form of government by lawful means."

Dominions Secretary Malcolm MacDonald's version of his talks withy Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, last week, when given to the House of Commons yesterday, hardly keyed with the optimistic reports circulating in the lobbies.

The Columbia Club unit administered a whitewash to its Dartmouth Club rivals last night, thereby maintaining its position near the top of the list among the Class C teams fighting for honors in Group 2 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Stuart Wilson, for the past six years principal of Junior High School 141 Astoria, and teacher in the New York City education system for forty years, died suddenly at his home, 29-31 159th Street, Flushing, of a heart ailment.

Desmarias's goal and two assists were in vain as the New York Rovers were defeated by the Hershey Bears, 5-3, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League contest tonight. The setback kept the Rovers in fourth place.
The largest State-wide influenza epidemic of recent years is now in progress, Dr. Edward S. Godfrey, State Health Commissioner, announced today on the basis of reports from health officers.

Joe Bree captured the WagnerReiner Trophy for winning the fivemile speed skating race, the featured event at the annual ice carnival sponsored by the Middle Atlantic Skating Association at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

The gravest and tensest situation obtains in Sian, capital of Shensi Province, in the opinion of the seventy-seven foreigners who were evacuated from that beleaguered city on Monday and arrived in Loyang on the second stage of their journey last night.

There are violinists born with a native talent for the fiddle, and there are violinists, some of them splendid musicians, who unfortunately are not born with a specific fiddle talent. This means that they cannot summon the facility of execution and charm of tone that please a great public.

Declaring that a building boom has started and will continue for several years, Dr. George F. Warren, Cornell University economist, told the State Nurserymen's Association today that its members should profit by the upturn.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, testifying yesterday before the Public Service Commission, urged approval of the company's application to merge the Mohawk Hudson Company with the Niagara Hudson company.

Attending St. John's Episcopal Church for special services before his inauguration, President Roosevelt heard this morning a prayer for his guidance said by the Rev. Dr. Endicott Peabody, venerable rector of Groton School.

Plans for several tenement houses in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens were filed yesterday by architects. The projects include a six-story building for the Inwood section of Manhattan, a fifty-three-family flat for a site in East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, and large houses in Elmhurst and Jackson Heights. PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP).--A second general rain within twentyfour hours in the upper Ohio River watershed brought predictions tonight of high water about this city which ranged from three to five feet above the "danger point."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21.--A capacity audience of 1,100 greeted the world premiere of "Hey Diddle Diddle" here tonight at the McCarter Theatre. Produced and staged by Anne Nichols and writ ten by Bartlett Cormack, the play has Hollywood for its background.

Six thousand passengers in the Eighth Avenue Independent Sub way System were delayed for more than an hour when fire in a subpower station disrupted all train service yesterday morning between the Ninety-sixth Street and 145th Street stations.
John J. Killian, former inmate at Massachusetts State Prison under life sentence for murder, was re united with his mother yesterday in Jefferson Market Court.

BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 21.--W. W. Lewis, pilot of the airliner which crashed in Placerita Canyon on Jan. 12, fatally injuring five passengers, said today the localizer radio beam which would have guided him safely over the mountains "never came in."

Deep undercurrents of discontent are troubling the surface of Japanese political and economic life. The stormy reception accorded Government leaders yesterday as they tried to defend their foreign and domestic policies at the opening session of the Diet was no mere partisan demonstration.

A recommendation that the English-speaking nations propose a six months' moratorium on war, made by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was made public yesterday by Dr. Butler.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP).--Buyers who stood in line all night bought thirty-two lots of business property, placed on sale today for the first time, for $350,000.

Mrs. Alice Florence Steinhart, wife of Frank Steinhart Sr., president of the Havana Electric Railways Company, died here this afternoon of a heart attack after a long illness. She was 65 years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The effort of the State Highway Department to build an 80-foot highway along the eastern slope of Cro's Nest Mountain means further spoliation of the highlands of the Hudson. Premier George Kiosseivanoff of Bulgaria will leave Sofia tomorrow, arriving in Belgrade Sunday, to sign a new Bulgaro-Yugoslav friendship pact.

A fourteen-man jury was completed yesterday to hear the evidence in the $2,000,000 restaurant extortion conspiracy case on trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

In aid of its scholarship fund, the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Agnes Seminary will hold its midwinter luncheon, bridge and fashion show today at the Biltmore.
Dr. Charles P. Opdyke, who had practiced medicine here for the last forty-seven years, died yesterday at his home, 10 Summit Avenue, Verona. He was 73 years old.

Another comparatively slow week, so far as new events are concerned, seems to be drifting down upon the night clubs. President Roosevelt held two conferences today on legislative procedure to carry forward his program for drastic reorganization of government agencies.

Bob Cummings of Bedford Heights knocked out Mickey Paul of Borough Park in the feature eightround boxing bout at Henderson's Flatbush Arena last night. The bout ended after 2 minutes and 6 seconds of the seventh session. Cummings, who dropped his rival with hard body blows five times, weighed 145 pounds and Paul 144 1/4.
The New Utrecht hockey team defeated Textile, 2 to 0, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace and assured itself of at least a tie in the Public Schools Athletic League race.
Plans for new construction field in the city yesterday included specifications for a health and teaching center to be erected by the city in West 168th Street at a cost of $400,000.
State Senator Pliny W. Williamson announced here tonight he had introduced into the Legislature today a bill for the reorganization of Westchester County government.

The mighty Ohio River, gorged with more than seventy feet of water, unloosed on Cincinnati the greatest flood of its history and wrote a story last night of privation, death and destruction along a 300-mile front of the State bearing its name.

A registration statement involving $14,200,000 first-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds of 1967 and $2,200,000 of serial debentures due on Feb. 1, 1938 to 1947, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Iowa Public Service Company of 'Sioux City, Iowa, a subsidiary of the Penn Western Gas and Electric Company.

In a circular addressed to banking institutions in this Federal Reserve district, George L. Harrison, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, called attention yesterday to the fact that Federal Reserve Banks had been designated by the Treasury, effective on Jan. 16, as places for the redemption of Adjusted Service Certificates, the so-called veterans' bonus bonds.

The compositions of Alda Astori and A. W. Binder were featured last night at the Composers ForumLaboratory, sponsoring contemporary American music, at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventythird Street.

A total of $37,989.47 has been collected by workers of the Musicians Emergency Fund from membership contributions and special functions, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Vincent Astor, acting president of the fund and chairman of the membership campaign which opened last October and which will continue through the Winter.
The entire Japanese Cabinet, unable to reach a compromise between angry army leaders and anti-military political parties in the Diet, decided to resign today.

Dropped down to a distance more to her liking, Clyde Troutt's Hastinola made good in the five and a half furlongs allowance purse, which topped the Fair Grounds card today. The 5-year-old mare had been quitting at six furlongs but today she trailed the early pace, set by the highly regarded Good Omen.

The marketing of $85,000,000 of Dominion of Canada 2 1/4s and 3s lifted the total of new bond placements this week to $192,514,000, the largest comparable volume since early in December. This week, a year ago, $93,803,000 in new issues was offered.

Jacque E. Van Gieson of Picatinny Arsenal, Picatinny, N. J., was designated by President Roosevelt today for the examination on March 2 with a view to admission to the United States Military Academy at West Point on July 1.

Charges were made today before the Senate subcommittee investigating alleged labor espionage that the Army and Navy worked with a labor spy service to maintain production in plants filling government contracts.

Robert Travis, organizer for the United Automobile Workers Union here, said tonight that the sit-down strikers, who seized the two Fisher Body plants here three weeks ago, would stay in the factories unless they were "pulled out."

Charles Felix Burke of 375 Riverside Drive, real estate operator and philanthropist,, died on Thursday night in the New York Hospital after an illness of a year. He underwent an operation six weeks ago. His age was 56.
A fashion show and luncheon in aid of Stony Wold Sanatorium will be held today at the Versailles under the auspices of the Chi Kappa Chapter of Stony Wold.

The singing of Maurice Ames, mezzo soprano, at her recital in Town Hall last night showed decided improvement over that in her debut here in the same auditorium last season, commendable as her vocalism was at that time.

The April choice of the Literary Guild will be "Away From It All: The Journal of an Escapologist," by Cedric Belfrage, which Simon Schuster will publish. It is a story of a trip around the world. The book will be published late in March.

Four more of the new Long Island Sound class of racing sloops built in Norway are on the deck of the Norwegian America liner Bergensfjord, due today from Bergen. The boats are: one, yet unnamed, for Charles B. Stuart; the Rascal, for Frank E. Campbell;

Representative W. Sterling Cole of Bath, N. Y., asked Congress today to repeal the salaries publication provision of the 1934 Revenue Act. Recalling the successful fight for the "pink-slip" repealer in the last Congress, Mr. Cole introduced a bill under which salaries of corporation officers and employes receiving $15,000 or more a year no longer could be made public.
James J. O'Shea, former bank officer convicted of aiding Harry M. Tyler in looting city trust funds of nearly $350,000, was sentenced today to serve eight years in a Federal penitentiary.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the interest of the estate of William Carroll Wilson in Finch, Wilson Co. ceased on Jan. 11 and that Arthur W. Sesselberg had been admitted to W. B. Hibbs Co.
" Dr." Anna Swift, convicted head of the "Danish Institute" in New York City, has paid the State $48,069.38 in income taxes, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, announced today.
Large apartment houses in the West Side and Washington Heights areas passed to new control in transactions announced yesterday. The Wales Management Corporation, represented by Max Olesker, attorney,
More than 85,000 General Motors dealers and new-car salesmen have been affected by the strike in General Motors plants, it was learned today. Of this number, 17,000 are dealers.

Major Caspar R. Crim, regular armyofficer on duty with the Reserve Officers Training. Corps at Ouachita College, Arkadelphia, Ark., died in the Army and Navy General Hospital. at Hot Springs, Ark., yesterday at the age of 44.

Settlement of the labor difficulties in the local motion-picture industry was delayed yesterday afternoon when representatives of the Independent Theatre Owners Association and the two leading motionpicture operators' unions failed to reach an agreement concerning a contract between the owners and the unions after a three-and-a-half-hour conference with Mayor La Guardia's Board of Survey.

Twenty-seven German Archbishops and Bishops, who assembled recently at Fulda, have directed the reading from all Catholic pulpits on Sunday a pastoral letter charging the German Government with obtaining illegal school election majorities for the suppression of Catholic schools.
The year 1937 has been set apart by the General Council of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. for a celebration of the completion of 100 years by its Board of Foreign Missions.

Miklas Szabo of Hungary, a great half-miler a few years back and now, seemingly, a greater runner at longer distances, arrived in town yesterday on the S. S. Europa of the North German Lloyd Line for an invasion of American tracks.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Professor Roswell Magill of New York, Professor of Law at Columbia University, as Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Having passed its fiftieth anniversary, "Camille" is less a play than an institution. Just as "Hamlet" is the measure of the great actor, so has the Dumas fils' classic become the ultimate test of the dramatic actress.

Commissions paid to a Louisiana State Senator because of his personal influence with the State administration are not deductible for income tax purposes as ordinary and necessary business expense, because the agreement under which they were paid was "void and unenforceable as against public policy," the Board of Tax Appeals ruled today.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 16 amounted to 700,238 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
A mass exodus of 1,500 persons from the Birds Point-New Madrid spillway began today in heavy sleet and freezing weather, which added to the hardships of refugees in flood-stricken Southeast Missouri.

Stanley V. Gibson, duplex in 969 Park Av., through Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc.: Mrs. Helen Beals Corballis, in 1,155 Park Av., from Robert Tinsman; Mrs. Otto Theodore Hess, in 111 E. 88th St., from Charles Butler; Port Burke, Inc., brokers.
Charles E. Hodges, chairman of the board of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company, died today in Brookline at the age of 77.

The Flatbush School basketball team turned back Riverdale, 19--16, at the victors' court yesterday. At half time the winners held a one point margin, 6--5. St. Nicholas of Tolentine High scored over Regis, 35--23, at the latter's court.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Jan. 15 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation declined from 139.65 per cent on Dec. 31 to 139.39 per cent on Jan. 15. The -reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liaabilities changed from 92.80 to 92.72 per cent.

Professor Roscoe Pound, Dean Emeritus of the Harvard Law School, will start next week on a seven-month lecture tour around the world. He will speak at the University of Tokyo, the Comparative Law School of China at Shanghat and at the Universities of Oxford, Cambridge, London and Birmingham and attend international law conferences at Paris and The Hague.

The General Motors Corporation will make every effort, pending settlement of the strikes in some of its plants, to provide as much work as possible for all employes made idle through no fault of their own, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the company, declared yesterday.
Mexican bullfighters forsook the bullring yesterday to fight their Spanish brother-artists of the sword and red rag in the open.

A mixed undertone predominated in all major groups of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Gains and losses in United States Government obligations were about evenly divided, while corporate issues eased slightly.
Mobilization of available Coast Guard motor lifeboat forces for service in the Middle Western flood areas was rushed yesterday in New Jersey and on Long Island.

Overseas Securities Company, Inc.--Dec. 31, 1936: Net assets, $3,344,238, equal to $3,212.52 per $1,000 of debentures and to $15.65 a share of capital stock. This compares with $2,230.44 per $1,000 of debentures and $8.68 a share of stock correspondingly in 1935.

Miss Marion Martha Broderson, daughter of 'Mr. and Mrs. Peter Broderson of this town, was married this evening to Clifford Tage Melander of Kansas City, Mo., son of Mrs. August H. Melander of Duluth, Minn.

Three New York University professors, each of whom has completed twenty years of teaching service in the university's Washington Square College, were honored last night at a testimonial dinner given by 150 of their colleagues at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Kingsboro Mortgage Corporation reports building loans totaling $405,000 as follows: $225,000 to Buckminster Apartments, Inc. for the 6-story apartment house under construction on the block front from 72d to 73d Sts., in Hayes Av., Jackson Heights, Queens: $95,000 to Kapson Building Corp..

Fred Perry of England, former world's amateur tennis champion, gave a superb demonstration of how to play under pressure in again beating Ellsworth Vines, professional champion, in a hard-fought match, 6-3, 9--7, 1-6, 6-3, before a paid attendance of 6,040 at Convention Hall tonight.
As floods endangered railroad tracks in the Ohio Valley today, one company canceled temporarily its Chicagoto-Florida trains and other lines revised schedules.

The House today passed the bill to extend until June 30, 1939, the lending power of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to continue the life of its satellite agencies, the Commodity Credit Corporation, the Electric Home and Farm Authority, the Export-Import Banks and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Mortgage Company, completing Congressional action on the measure. The vote was viva voce.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 21 unless specified: At Pearl Harbor: Avocet, Cuyama, Swan. At Hongkong, Jan. 22: Mindanao, Tulsa. Babbitt. Hampton Roads to sea, Jan. 22. Balch, at Valparaiso, Chile, Jan. 22. Cummings. at New York Yard. Medusa. Mare Island Yard to San Pedro. Rail, Wilson Cove to San Diego, Jan. 22.
The inaugural address of President Roosevelt will be commented on in many sermons tomorrow. Pastors will also refer to the fact that next Saturday will be the birthday of the Chief Executive.

The Pratt Institute quintet scored its seventh victory in eight games last night when it defeated the alumni five on its home court, 4122. Nick Zuraw of the varsity was the high scorer with 12 points. The winners led at half time, 17-6.

The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Watson, president of the American University, Cairo, Egypt, is back in his native America for a time and he will preach tomorrow morning in the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Dr.

An official communique today states that by command of King George VI, the British High Commissioner here has invited Amin Abdulhadi, a member of the Moslem Supreme Council, and Itzhak Benzvi, a member of the General Council of Palestine Jews, to represent Palestine at his coronation. Both have accepted.

An informal investigation into the recent activity of the common stock of the Indian Refining Company, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, is being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange, it was stated yesterday.
Two Montrealers and two New Yorkers survived quarter-final matches today in the Canadian racquets championship as Huntingdon D. Sheldon, the defending champion from New York, bowed by default.

The Metropolitan Indoor Polo League race continues tonight with games at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and at Squadron C in Brooklyn. At the latter armory, the feature brings together the surprising First Division team and Winmont Farms, the only two unbeaten trios in the league.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company sought today authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $3,750,000 of 2 1/2 per cent equipment-trust certificates. The proceeds are to be applied toward the purchase of $4,794,850 of new rolling stock.

A husband cannot be relieved of his marital obligations and win a legal separation just because his wife drinks "more than a wise and prudent woman would" and indulges in "bacchanalian hilarity" on New Year's Eve, Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck ruled yesterday.
The State Banking Department has issued a new authorization to J. P. Morgan Co. of New York to continue business, because of the death of one partner and the retirement of another.

For a time yesterday it seemed that the dove of peace might find a New York refuge from her European perplexities. According to reports, the dispirited bird had found a haven in the hearts of members of the Society of Independent Artists.

Albert Primeau of Detroit coasted into the national amateur threecushion billiard championship today, although he had one match remaining to play. Four times the new champion marked up victories this week, but whether he won or lost his final match made no difference, as Edward Spitz of Boston sprang his second straight upset by conquering Max Shimon of Milwaukee, 50 to 39, in seventy-three innings today.

With cotton mill activity last week continuing unchanged, when a small rise is seasonal, the adjusted index declined two points. The figure now is 143.8 as compared with 145.8 (revised) for the preceding week and 107.9 for the week ended Jan. 18, 1936.
General liquidation was under way in the grain markets today with wheat, corn, oats and rye futures at the extreme showing 2 cents or more a bushel under yesterday's final prices.

The main ballroom of the RitzCarlton was the setting last night for the second of the Friday Assemblies for this season. Subscribers to this annual series of dances are young matrons and debutantes of former years, the majority of whom had been subscribers to the Junior and Knickerbocker Assemblies, and their young men friends.

The electric service of the Long Island Lighting Company in Nassau and Suffolk Counties was disrupted intermittently for about three hours early this morning when a series of short circuits occurred on hightension power lines at the New Glenwood Landing generating plant.

Charles F. Roeser, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, in a statement forwarded here from Fort Worth, Texas, declares that failure of the large companies substantially to increase the price of crude oil has
It is now possible to set an approximate date when the Democratic party will be crushed at
The French liner Champlain sails today for Plymouth and Havre, carrying among her passengers Robert Casadesus, French pianist, accompanied by his wife, Mme. Gaby Casadesus;
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 22.

Placing a 74 beside the par-shattering 70 he shot yesterday, Sammy Byrd, Rochester outfielder, led the field by five strokes with a total of 144 when the National Baseball Player golf tournament reached the halfway mark today.

Seton Hall registered its first victory of the season in defeating St. Peter's quintet tonight, 30-23. Seton held a slight lead throughout, being ahead at the half, 19-15. Jimmie Gallagher of St. Peter's took high scoring honors with 10 points.

While a survey by the National Association of Manufacturers reveals clearly the progress that has been made in the task of re-employment, a Federal census of the jobless is "absolutely essential" for the elimination of unemployment, William B. Warner,

The proposal of the striking seamen of this port which would end their walk-out after nearly three months of fruitless effort to win recognition by Atlantic ship lines was transmitted yesterday to comrades in Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports with a request for action.

Boundless is the range of collectors, Collecting is a passion, and he ought to be praised who has the originality to snap up what the riders of other hobbyhorses may regard as unconsidered trifles. In Paris, according to Le Soir, there are keen hunters of queer visiting cards.

Oliver Burnside Andrews, president of the 0. B. Andrews Company, one of the largest paper box manufactories in the South, died this afternoon at 5 o'clock of a heart attack. He was stricken as he was dictating a letter in his office. He was 54 years old.
Sleet storms today whipped across the southern Illinois flood basin, adding to the misery of suffering flood victims and breaking communication lines.

President Roosevelt conferred on government reorganization and labor legislation with members of Congress, discussed the flood situation with his Cabinet, enjoined silence on the parties in controversy in the automobile strike, appointed Roswell Magill to be Under-Secretary of the Treasury, and talked with a long list of callers at the White House.
Governor Lehman signed today the Murray bill sought by the La Guardia administration and designed to stay wholesale evictions from tenements in New York City.

One of the most attractive college basketball double-headers of the season will be presented in Madison Square Garden tonight when Manhattan and Long Island University, the two outstanding quintets of the metropolis, clash with powerful foes from-out of town.

New life insurance production in 1936 was 1.3 per cent less than in 1935, according to a report to the United States Department of Commerce yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents. For December, however, new production was 2.9 per cent higher than a year ago.
David T. Bennett, who served three of New York City's health commissioners as secretary, died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. Estelle Thorner, 485 Ocean Avenue.

Eugene M. Stevens, who worked his way up from office boy in a wagon works at the age of 16 to become one of the leading bankers of Chicago during the last two decades, died this morning in his home in Evanston. He was 65 years old.
Effingham B. Morris, financier, died of a heart attack today at his home in Ardmore. He was in his eightyfirst year.

More than two dozen figure skaters from New York and Boston were practicing on the ice of the Olympic Arena today in preparation for the annual Snobirds' competition tomorrow morning and night. The smooth indoor surface will be in prime condition regardless of the blizzard raging outside tonight.

The Public Service Commission authorized the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation today to reduce electric rates which the company estimated would save consumera $201,800 a year, effective Feb. 1.

Approximately 1,604,000 more wage earners than the average number employed in the first eleven months of last year would be required to reach the 1929 per capital volume of production in manufacturing, with the average 1936 work week, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has been somewhat erratic this week but generally strong. The outstanding movement of the week has been that in medium scoured wools, especially a pulled wools which have been genrally firm at former rates.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Spaulding of Greenwich, Conn., who are aboard their yacht, will have guests at the ball at the Surf. Club tomorrow. Others of the Miami Beach colony having guests will be Mr. and Mrs. Philo M. Gelatt, Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Brush, Mr. and Mrs.

Scenes from the past, present and future of Rutgers University were depicted in seven tableaux at the annual dance and entertainment of the Women's League of the university in the college gymnasium this evening.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for no par preferred and common stock of Hudson River Day Line.

Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, issued an appeal tonight for $2,000,000 to aid flood sufferers in the Middle West. The 3,700 chapters of the Red Cross throughout the country were urged to cooperate in raising this relief fund without delay.

Full details of the cotton textiles agreement reached at Osaka yesterday were disclosed today by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute and a member of the United States delegation, as follows:
Jack Corbett, veteran boss of the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League, became sole owner of the club today amid talk that the Chiefs would become a farm for the Reds of the National League.
W. Curtis Rockefeller, 26-year-old California Institute of Technology instructor, was announced as winner today of the Sperry Memorial Award for distinguished service to aeronautics in 1936.

A grant of $165,000 over a fiveyear period to the Committee on Research in Medical Economics has been made by the Julius Rosenwald Fund, it was announced yesterday by Edwin R. Embree, president of the fund.

Advances in Knowledge of the mechanism by which the body maintains its normal balance between acidity and alkalinity were described last night by Dr. Donald Dexter Van Slyke, chief chemist of the Hospital of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, on receiving the Philip A. Conne gold medal of the Chemists Club of New York.

Many witnesses, intimidated by racketeers with threats of reprisals next. year "when Tammany gets back," are withholding vital information from the Markets Department and Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey in their efforts to stamp out graft in the food trades, William F. Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, charged yesterday.
Two weeks ago the United States Supreme Court unanimously concurred in a lecture on fundamental democratic principles to the authorities of Oregon, including the Supreme Court of that State.
The Mexican Government, which is helping the Spanish Loyalists, has informed the Italian Government, which is aiding the Rebels, that it will not appoint a new Minister to Rome.

The American Red Cross estimated tonight that more than 30,000 were homeless in Southern Indiana as relief agencies battled snow, sleet and bitter cold weather to get food, clothing and medicine to stranded victims of the most serious flood in the State's history.
The WPA Theatre of Music will be the scene of a concert tomorrow night by the Federal Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the project.

Amounts voluntarily paid as employes' tax by an employer, without collecting these amounts from the employes, are not wages subject to tax under Title. VIII of the Social Security Act, according to Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Excelling with his magic putter, Leon Pettigrew of Pendleton, Ind., a student at Indiana University, annexed the annual Miami Biltmore invitation amateur golf tournament today. He defeated Dr. L. J. Barnette, pastor of the Congregational Church here, in the thirty-six-hole final, 10 and 9.

The last Junior dinner dance of the season was held tonight in the Red and Clover rooms of the BellevueStratford, when Mrs. Daniel L. Hutchinson Jr. had as her guests Governor and Mrs. George H. Earle 3d.

The property at 320-28 W. 55th St. and at 329-33 W. 55th St., with the furnishings and personal property therein, was leased by the 107 East Thirty-fourth Street Corp., Alexander H. Pincus, treasurer, to Frances Foster from Jan. 15, 1937. to Sept. 29. 1941.

Forging ahead in the final period, the 112th Field Artillery polo team defeated Squadron A of New York at the East Orange Armory tonight, 14 1/2 to 13 1/2. The local club had a one-goal handicap. Warren Wentzel of the 112th and Harfold Talbott of the New York trio led in the scoring with six goals apiece.

Issuance of regulations by the Securities and Exchange Commission within the next ten days to further curb speculation by members of national stock Exchanges is expected. Officials said the regulations were nearly complete and would be placed in effect probably within two weeks.

The fifteenth annual observance of Race Relations Sunday will be held throughout the country on Feb. 14, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches. The program will include interracial mass meetings and the exchange of pulpits and choirs between Negro and white churches.

Describing newspapers as the "main highway to the consumer markets of this country," John Benson, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, yesterday urged the Oregon State Publishers, meeting in Eugene, Ore., to assist reliable advertising agencies and to undertake extensive research of newspaper markets.

Legislation based upon "the praotical idealism of the NRA" is needed to prevent the return of economic abuses, Major George L. Berry, coordinator for industrial cooperation in the national administration, told members of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors yesterday at their convention in the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. George S. Graham of Islip, L. I., who is at Brazilian Court, entertained with a party there today. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Stebbins of Hobe Sound, Colonel and Mrs. Dorsey Cullen, Colonel and Mrs. Bentley Mott,
Operations in 1936 of the Caterpillar Tractor Company resulted in a net profit of $9,849,592 after expenses, depreciation, interest, provision for Federal taxes and other charges.

Representative John Rankin, Democrat of Mississippi; announced today that a bloc had taken form in the House to "save for the American people, now and for all time to come, the hydroelectric power of the nation, one of the greatest natural resources in all the world."

Maritime interests appealed yesterday morning to the army engineers for protection of navigation during the construction of the Manhattan-Queens tunnel, at a hearing at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

An analysis of monthly building reports by the Department of Labor for 1936 for the twenty-five leading cities, made by the Building Trades Employers Association yesterday, showed New York far in the lead with a total of $223,101,000 against $153,884,000 for the previous year.
A government committee sounded today what may be the death knell of Gretna Green's famous wedding anvil.

Dr. James Quayle Dealey, editor-inchief of-The Dallas Morning News and allied-publications since Oct. 1, 1929 educator and sociologist, died this. afternoon- of a heart attack- in his office in the News Building. His age was 75.

Lloyd E. Glab, formerly a member of the news staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday at Kings County Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Glab, who resided at 1,671 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, was 42 years old.

The New York A. C. and the Harvard Club scored sweeps in the weekly matches yesterday to remain tied at the top of the standing in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League. Aided by defaults, the Winged Foot gained a 5-0 decision over the Elizabeth Town and Country Club at home, while the Crimson invaded the Columbia University Club courts for a similar result.

Air-mail contractors, it was revealed here yesterday, have been notified by the Postoffice Department that it will be necessary to curtail the service, due to costs in excess of the amount appropriated, not later than March 1 next.

That the projected version of "The Prisoner of Zenda" will be one of Selznick-International's important productions this season is indicated by the signing yesterday of Douglas Fairbanks Jr., now in England, and Mary Astor to appear in support of Ronald Colman.

The first sale in the downtown shopping district of Jersey City for some time took place this week when the 129 Newark Avenue, Inc., Harry J. Perlberg, President, sold to the Go-Lit Realty of New Jersey Inc.,

McClure Newspaper Syndicate and Robert H. Wager, in 75 West St.; Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., broker. Scovell, Wellington Co., accountants, in 111 Broadway; Horace S. Ely Co., brokers. Charles Guttman, wines and liquors, in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

The Rev. and Mrs. Edwin Tuttle Lewis of Whittier, Calif., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Lewis, to John Ditmas Talmage, son of Mrs. John Frelinghuysen Talmage of 104 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, and East Hampton, L. I.; and the late Mr. Talmage.

Premier Benito Mussolini has granted to his son, Bruno, permission to fly across the Atlantic, according to an interview with a French correspondent which was reprinted in Rome. San Francisco is the goal of the flight.
Rebellious armies of China's turbulent Northwest received the alternative tonight of three more days to decide between war or compromise.

An embarrassed but winsome middle-aged widow, haled before 1,000 of the nation's retailers at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, gave a setback to the theory that employes past 40 are ready for the scrapheap. She also challenged the theory that a life of ease is preferable to work.
The gloom of hopelessness descended on the Vatican today after Pope Pius XI was reported to have spent an almost sleepless night, tormented by pain and shortness of breath.
Old-fashioned coal-oil lamps were at a premium in Louisville stores today as citizens prepared for the eventuality of being without electricity.
Miss Pauline L. Robinson entertained at dinner last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for her debutante niece, Miss Anna Glen Butler.

Edward Joseph O'Connor, 38 years old, lawyer and civil service expert, of 69-41 Seminole Avenue, Forest Hills, who was convicted of accepting money from two men on promises of obtaining high ratings for them on civil service lists, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court to two to four years in Sing Sing.

Disposition in November of 60,000 shares of common stock of the F. W. Woolworth Company by Jessie Woolworth Donahue, reducing her holdings to 519,250 shares, was disclosed yesterday in summaries of transactions of the officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed companies made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON--Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, introduced a resolution which would impose an embargo on all arms and munitions in case of war and would empower the President to withhold any other "articles or materials" from belligerents. Page 1.
State Senator L. J. Sulak raised an objection today to the University of Texas hiring Dana X. Bible, Nebraska football coach, at $15,000 a year for ten years.

The diversity of demand as a result of the wide spread in weather conditions throughout the country enabled retail trade to make a better showing this week, the estimated volume of sales ranging from 10 to 18 per cent more than for the corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Most key cities reported an increase of 2 to 5 per cent over last week's volume.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, 11 A. M. "Broadway in Review," John Mason Brown.

Continuing its investigation of Distributors Group, Inc., of New York, one of the largest investment banking houses in the country, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that there was a net loss to the investors from the fixed trusts sold by the company, over a long period, of $72,221.000.

Baron Kichizaemon Sumitomo has decided to give the Japanese Army from 20,000,000 to 30,000,000 yen (approximately $5,710,000 to $8,565,000), the newspaper Yomiuri reported today in a dispatch from Osaka.

A slight increase in employment and a considerable increase in production in 1935 in manufactures of confections in the United States was reported today by the Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census. Wage earners employed in 1935 numbered 52,092, against 50,609 for 1933, the last census year.

The Weather Bureau held out no hope of immediate relief today from thirty-six days of cloudy or rainy weather which have sent Eastern North Carolina Rivers out of their banks and resulted in the closing of scores of country schools.

The Chicago Rapid Transit Company (elevated lines) filed today a petition in Federal court asking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws. Announcement was made yesterday of the company's intention to proceed with the step as a means of lifting the receivership under which the lines have operated since 1932.
The death of the Rev. Dr. G. A. Johnston Ross, professor emeritus of Union Theological Seminary, at his home in Honolulu yesterday morning was reported here last night at the Seminary.

Major L. L. B. Angas, investment consultant and former London broker, predicted an early rise in interest rates, accompanied by a fall in the bond market and a shook to common stocks in an address yesterday before a luncheon meeting in the Municipal Bond Club of New York, held at the Bankers Club.
A daughter, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward Vanderlip Reith of 210 Riverside Drive yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hospital.
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company obtained extension until June 1 of time which it must file its plan of reorganization, following a hearing in Federal court here today.

Lawrence A. Reilly of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street, former president of the copper refinery of Thomas J. Reilly, Inc., died Thursday in United States Veterans' Hospital 81, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.

Miss Elizabeth Shelton Tall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alfred Tall of 114 Stratford Road, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Warren Blossom, son of Mrs. Frederick Warren Blossom of Brooklyn and Quogue, L. I., and the late Mr. Blossom, in St. Paul's Chapel by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Patton McComas.

Miss Diana Dollar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Stanley Dollar of Piedmont, was married to Joseph C. Hickingbotham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hickingbotham, also of Piedmont, at noon today in St. Paul's Church in Oakland.

Lee Pattison, New York City director of the WPA Federal Music Project, will be in charge of the Metropolitan Opera House's next popular Spring season, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association.
The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, has authorized the collection of money to aid Catholics in Spain.

The building containing forty apartments and eleven stores at 37-80 Sixty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens, was sold by the Waverly Management Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $123,750. It occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet It occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet.

Notice Deputy chiefs are notified that the quota of officers and members having been made up for the 1st, 3d and 8th Divisions, no requests for transfers to or from those divisions shall be forwarded.

Five persons, screaming for help, clung perilously to a house floating down the flooded Ohio River today. A rowboat, following, returned with a woman, believed to have been rescued from the floating house.

Government war planes bombed Rebel entrenchments in sudden sallies at dawn today to avenge Wednesday's damaging air raid on the capital. Five times the planes swooped over western and southern barricades of the Insurgents, who began their siege of Madrid three months ago today. Heavy Rebel losses were reported.

Testimony that the International Mercantile Marine Company prefers to buy its supplies from companies using its lines was given yesterday by Martin J. Sullivan, purchasing agent, in a government hearing investigating the trade practices of Swift Co., meat packers.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Germany's first post-war colony may be a slice of Africa considerably larger than the Fatherland and containing many precious raw materials, reliable sources predicted tonight.

Amendments to tighten up the Coal Weighing Law so as to halt the flow of "bootleg coal" from Pennsylvania will probably be proposed by the New York State Retail Solid Fuel Merchants Association, Inc., it was revealed here today after a conference of officials and coal merchant representatives.
Frederick W. Murphy, lawyer and football official, died yesterday afternoon in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Major Ray Perkins, M.I.-Res., 350 Central Park West, New York, N. Y., Arm and Service Assignment Group, is ordered to active duty Jan. 21 at Governors Island, N. Y., for duty in the Office of the Assistant Chief of Staff. Major Perkins will rank from Jan. 21. He will be relieved from active duty Feb. 3.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission's proposal that salary increases to low-paid city employes as authorized by a recently enacted local law, be limited to employes with excellent service ratings was opposed yesterday by city officials and representatives of civil service organizations.

The French police, it was learned tonight, have been working for more than a month without success in an effort to identify persons who broke into the funeral chapel of Sir Basil Zaharoff at Chateau Balincourt in the Oise Department.

Charging that Alfonso de Borbon, Count Covadonga, eldest son of the former King of Spain, had fled the jurisdiction of the New York courts by going to Cuba, counsel for the Countess Covadonga asked the Supreme Court yesterday to appoint a receiver for Spanish crown jewels which constitute the only property of the Count in this State.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE TIMES John Alexander of Brooklyn, while taking a verbal poke at the over emphasis placed on football, took a round-house punch at my alma mater, Michigan. He said there wer e 250,00 spectators at the Michigan home games last season and then asked, "What on earth does it do with the money?
WASHINGTON--President Roosevelt made a two-sentence statement that was taken as a rebuke to John L. Lewis for suggesting Executive support for the General Motors strikers.
The St. Augustine's basketball team moved another step toward the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. crown with a 30-20 triumph over St. John's Prep in the latter's gymnasium last night.

Robert Coyle of the Montclair Athletic Club, second seeded player, was eliminated by a clubmate, Herbert Hanschka, in the quarter-finals of the invitation Class B squash racquets tournament for Jersey players at the Essex Club tonight. Coyle took the first two games at 15-8, 18-15, but Hanschka captured the next three, 15-6, 15-10, 15-9.

Raymond B. Stevens, who has been a member of the United States Tariff Commission since 1935, was named vice chairman of the commission today by President Roosevelt to fill the vacancy caused by the death recently of Thomas Walker Page.
John M. Davis of 1,035 Fifth Avenue has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mildred Davis, to John Bradley Gates, son of Albert O. Gates of New Haven, Conn.

Formation of a subsidiary company of the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd., for the sale and distribution of gasoline and fuel oil in the Mediterranean basin - and Red Sea area was announced here today.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that holdings of Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock by the Chesapeake Corporation had been reduced by 6,283 shares this month by conversion of the holding company's bonds. This reduced the holding company's control of the C. O. to about 33 per cent, compared with an original total of 51 per cent.
South Side High School scored a 42-to-36 victory over St. Benedict's Prep tonight. It was the first time St. Benedict's, in the history of basketball, had dropped three games in a row.

ANDERSON, HELEN (Dec. 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Helen Buttrick Van Dyke, cousin, Fox Point, Milwaukee, Wis.; Frances Bagley Wallace, cousin, 1,905 N St., N. W., Washington, D. C., and Esther C. B. Wallace, cousin, Ford Building, Detroit, Mich., interests in shares of stock of Bagley Land Co., Ltd.; John F. Gallagher, Colorado Springs, Col.,
Word was received here of the death today at Nokomis, Fla., of Parker Webster Page, retired patent lawyer, who lived at 160 Summit Avenue, this city.
A bridge party arranged by members of the New York Club of Hollins College, in Virginia, will be held this afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria.

J. A. Sisto Co. have exercised an option to buy for $4 a share 30,000 shares of the Seversky Aircraft Corporation, Farmingdale, L. I. This was the first of a series of options at $3 to $9 a share which Sisto Co. hold on 560,000 shares of Seversky stock. The proceeds from the transaction will be used for a new airplane design.

Destruction, suffering and deaths mounted with rapidly rising rivers along the farflung flood fronts today. More than 150,000 persons were homeless. Sixteen deaths were recorded. Damage ran into the millions.

Welcomed by Mrs. Roosevelt and inspired by messages of encouragement from President Roosevelt and Senator Wagner, the National Public Housing Conference opened here today its fourth annual meeting with the announced intention of pressing for Federal aid for its tenyear plan to "abolish slums and rehouse the lower-income groups at rents they can afford to pay."
The open season on holdouts is expected to reach its peak following the mailing of contracts to thirty-three members of the Dodgers yesterday.
An exhibition of drawings from red-figured yases in the museum's permanent collection will open at the Metropolitan tomorrow, remaining on view for a fortnight, until Feb. 7.

Light hogs were in demand today and generally 10 cents higher. Other types were steady. The day's top was unchanged at $10.45, while the average price was steady at $10.30. Most of the sales were at $10.25 to $10.40.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS PATROLMEN--Joseph J. Lannin, 9th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum (appointed Nov. 8, 1911); Samuel W. Toepfer, Traffic D, at $1 500 per annum (appointed March 18, 1908); Sabbath Centrello, 7lst Precinct, at $1,500 per annum (appointed June 10, 1911): John McCormack, 19th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum (appointed Dec. 26, 1905).
ARGUIMBAU--Eline Ramee, in her ninetyfirst year, widow of Joseph L. Arguimbau. Funeral Mass 11 A. M. Saturday at the Holy Trinity Church, Hackensack, N. J.

Sergeant John Fogarty accompanied by Sergeant Richard Britten, both of the United States Marine Corps, while making an observation flight over St. Thomas yesterday encountered sleet and snow at an altitude of 16,000 feet.

President C. C. Williams of Lehigh University suggested tonight that large colleges and universities solve the problem of "overemphasis of spectacular athletics" by sponsoring professional teams in addition to their student teams.
A joint Senate and Assembly open hearing on proposed new minimum wage legislation was set today for Feb. 4 by agreement of Democratic and Republican leaders.

Safeguards against the misuse or power by labor leaders were requested by the New York Board of Trade in a letter sent to President Roosevelt and made public yesterday. The letter was written by Percy C. Magnus. president of the board.

After eleven years of waiting the common stockholders of Armour Co. are to receive a dividend of 15 cents a share. The disbursement voted today by the directors was not designated as a quarterly dividend.

National Guardsmen patrolled the streets of Louisville tonight as the rain-choked Ohio River crept relentlessly over large sections of the city and inundated thousands of acres of land throughout Kentucky.

The Wagner performances at the Metropolitan continue on their triumphal way. That of "Siegfried" last night was signalized by the appearance of a new and excellent Mime in the person of Karl Laufkoetter, who joined the company this season, and it reached one of the great climaxes of recent operatic history with Kirsten Flagstad's Bruennhilde, whose part in "Siegfried" she interpreted for the first time here. And in so doing, she made history.

From 10 this morning until 2 this afternoon Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, with his wife beside him, stood in the big reception room at the Reichsbank receiving congratulations on his sixtieth birthday.
Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, in a petition filed today, recommended to the United States District Court payment of $398,000 overdue interest.

Charles A. Davila, Rumanian Minister at Washington, gave a dinner and reception last night in the Oval Room and Palm Court of the Ritz-Carlton, for the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society and Georges Enesco, Rumanian guest composer-conductor.

Abbe Ernest Dimnet, author of several books widely read in this country, including "The Art of Thinking," arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to deliver fifteen lectures on literary and sociological topics.
Members of the Swiss Society of New York will hold their fiftyfifth annual dinner and dance tonight at the Plaza. Guests of honor will include Marc Peter, Minister of Switzerland, and Mrs. Peter;

Lawyers' fees and other charges amounting to about $200,000 were allowed yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy to participants in the reorganization of the SavoyPlaza Corporation, operator of the hotel by that name.

Miss Doris Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Havemeyer of 960 Fish Avenue and Islip, L. I., and Dr. Daniel Catlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel K. Catlin of St. Louis and Dublin, N. H., whose engagement was announced in the Autumn, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.
Miss Mary Eggleston, daughter of Mrs. Robert D. Eggleston of Montclair, and Howard Abbott, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Abbott of Tucson, Ariz., were married tonight at the home of the bride's mother.

Winter struck the half-billion dollar California citrus fruit industry its hardest blow in twenty-four years today. Damage from the worst freeze since 1913 may total at least 50 per cent of the current crop of oranges, lemons and grapefruit.

It may be due to the softening tropical influences of Nassau, where he is vacationing to recuperate from the last of a series of critical hip-bone operations, but Columbia's Lou Little counsels his fellow football coaches to "softpedal" any lingering desire to seek drastic changes in the pass interference rule for 1937.

Today is a day of mourning throughout the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in memory of Nikolai Lenin, whose death was made known this day thirteen years ago, and in memory of workers massacred on the Lena River in January, 1906.

Oxford rowing authorities were faced today with the difficult problem of whether to pick Hart Massey as the Oxford coxswain in the university boat race with Cambridge to be rowed on the Thames March 24.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against 1. DONSKY, INC., rhinestone setting, 545 8th Av. by Teller Grossberg, for $500; City Novelty Corp., $33; Amity Notion Co., Inc., $13.
Isolated except for uncertain wire and radio communications, Portsmouth's 45,000 citizens battled flood waters tonight in half the city.
Walter Willson Cobbett, patron of music who fostered the. composition of chamber pieces by financial support and personal participation, died today at the age of 89.

The "vast opportunities" offered for more orderly development of American cities in the immediate future due to slum-clearance programs, the prospect of further expansion, in the building of small homes and the opening and widening of streets to relieve traffic congestion were emphasized yesterday at the annual conference of the American City Planning Institute.

OF all the recent books dealing with the Constitution and the Supreme Court, none seems to me quite so persuasive and generally intelligible as Morris L. Ernst's "The Ultimate Power" (Doubleday, Doran, $3), Mr. Ernst is a distinguished lawyer whose interest has been less in conducting income-tax detours and high-priced divorces than in campaigns for the general welfare.
C. Raymond Shelley, president of the Asbury Park and Ocean Grove Bank and president and general manager of the Seaboard Ice Company, died of a heart attack here today. He was 55 years old.

Stocks eased and closed irregularly lower after industrial shares had reached new high levels; turnover, 2,683,080 shares. All groups of bonds irregular in moderately active trading; transactions, $12,903,700.
The Rev. Dr. Ernest J. Dennen, Archdeacon of Boston and founder and head of the Episcopal Order of Sir Galahad, died suddenly this morning at his home in Cambridge.

Dr. Isidore E. Kaplan, 48 years old, of 537 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, who also has an office at 140 Rivington Street, was arrested yesterday in the Accident Fraud Bureau, the twelfth physician to be involved in alleged fake accident indemnity claims on insurance companies in an investigation by Bernard C. Botein', Assistant District Attorney, head of the bureau.

The marriage of Miss Rosemary Ward, daughter of Mrs. Newell J. Ward of East Hampton, L. I., and Middleburg, Va., and the late Mr. Ward, to George W. Blabon 2d, son of Mrs. Edwin L. Blabon of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mr. Blabon, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers performed the ceremony.

Not a dissenting voice was raised in the Senate today when the rules were waived to permit immediate confirmation of action by President Roosevelt reappointing James A. Farley for a second four-year term as Postmaster General.
Despite the easier tendency in most commodity markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange held within narrow limits yesterday and ended unchanged to 2 points higher than on Thursday.

One part or the plan for Government reorganization is the placing of all Federal employes, except those having to do with policy making, under the civil service rules. This is the most sweeping endorsement of the merit system known since the beginnings of the reform.

Commissioner Charles A. Harnett of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles expressed disappointment yesterday because his appeals to motorists urging early registration had gone "practically unnoticed." The commissioner warned again that use of 1936 plates after midnight, Jan. 31, will not be legal.
In an unenterprising day's batting, the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team made 236 for six wickets at the end of the first day's play in its match with South Australia.

Under the sculptured figures of those cardinal virtues, Prudence, Temperance, Justice and Fortitude, two former Lord Mayors of London, one aged 77 and the other 78, shattered the dignity of ancient Guildhall today.

Mr. JOHN L. LEWIS knocked at the door of the White House yesterday and presented a bill for services rendered. The Administration, he said, had "asked labor for help" in winning the election. This help was given.

Plans for extending the strike to General Motors units not yet affected will be taken up here tomorrow by the Automobile Workers Union board of strategy, which will convene on the arrival of union officers from Washington, it was learned here tonight.

The stock markets were generally cheerful today, although somewhat irregular. Gilt-edge securities declined, but foreign issues strengthened, led by German issues. Japanese bonds were an exception in this group, and weakened on news of the political situation in Tokio.

Germain G. Glidden of New York, national and intercollegiate squash racquets champion, led the field into the round of sixteen in the eighth annual Atlantic Coast championship tonight on the courts of the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Racquet Club.

Charles H. Sterenfeld, Deputy Grand Master of the Independent Order of B'rith Abraham, made public yesterday a letter he had received from Professor Albert Einstein expressing appreciation of the order's action in naming a lodge in the scientist's honor.

Contributions in the United Hospitals campaign totaling $1,970,813 in cash and pledges were announced yesterday at the final report luncheon in the directors' room of the United States Steel Corporation, 71 Broadway.

A bill which would bar from public service all women whose husbands have an annual income of $1,500 or more was advanced through second reading in the lower house of the State Legislature today and sent to the Assembly Committee on Public Welfare for hearings.

By large majorities, Congress voted on Tuesday to extend to June 30, 1939, the President's individual power of dollar devaluation and his authority to use the $2,000,000,000 "stabilization fund" derived from the devaluation of January, 1934.
Andrew Kocik, 71, a casual, who was almost roasted alive, today promised to select his lodgings more carefully. In near zero temperatures, last night, he crawled into a foundry oven.
Head Coach Jimmy Phelan, who led his team to the Rose Bowl in 1936, will guide the football destinies of the University of Washington for another three years, it was made known today.

Charges of participating in an assault upon a ship's radio operator, filed against Hoyt Haddock, president of the American Radio Telegraphers Union in New York, have been dismissed, District Attorney George Dorsey said today.

Sir Otto Neimeyer, a member of the British Council of Foreign Bondholders, and Douglas Reid, secretary-general of that organization, paid a courtesy call yesterday upon the officers of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., it was announced by the council.
The Hun School hockey team recorded its fifth straight victory tonight on Baker Rink, defeating Morristown School, 2-1, in overtime. MacNamee opened the scoring for Hun in 10:10 of the second period.

The world's tiniest radio vacuum tubes, producing wave lengths one centimeter long, or about a third of an inch, have proved efficient in tests and may be of medical value, Professor G. W. Potapenko said today.

The Airline Maintenance Committee at a dinner here tonight made the first award of a bronze plaque for distinction in maintenance work to Walter A. Hamilton, assistant chief of maintenance of the TWA.

Freedom of the press is directly violated by the Wagner Labor Relations Law, The Associated Press told the Supreme Court today as the way was paved for arguments against the act. As applied to The Associated Press,
The American public is beginning to control its tongue when it comes to calling the national scenery by "freak" names.

An invitation to play a number of games in England during the early Summer has been extended to the Lawrenceville School polo team of Lawrenceville, N. J., by a group of polo enthusiasts and Lawrenceville friends overseas.

Two youths were found dead in a New York Central freight car in the yards here early today, apparently overcome by fumes from a charcoal burner. The car was loaded with mineral water and the burner was intended to keep the water from freezing.

Charles H. Jennings of Miami Beach regained the championship of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests by defeating John H. Abeel of New York by 4 and 3 in the 18-hole final at the Palm Beach Country Club today. Jennings also won the distinction of being the fourth member to capture the crown for the second time.

Seventy-nine representatives for collective bargaining will be chosen by 3,950 employes of the Board of Transportation in a secret election next Friday. The election will be limited to employes engaged in operation and maintenance of the city's Independent Subway System.

Total round-lot volume of shares bought and sold and member trading for own account on the New York Stock Exchange decreased in the week ended on Dec. 26, compared with the previous week. The percentage of member trading to total volume also was smaller, 19.94 per cent, against 20.53 per cent, according to the weekly summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Six thousand shivering fans peered through the smudge-pot haze over Santa Anita Park today and saw Cross S. capture the $1,500 Santa Anita Handicap, and Slapped, G. T. Williams's 7-year-old gelding, gain its fourth straight victory this season in winning the $1,200 San Bernardino Handicap.

A. Henry Ross, 28 years old, a lawyer, testified in his own defense yesterday at his General Sessions trial on the extortion charge made by Alfred E. Smith Jr. against him and Max D. Krone, a private deteetive.

THERE was a rumor that a Romney was on exhibition in West Sixty-third Street yesterday and it turned out to be true. But the Romney, when found, was something of a surprise package. It wasn't an oil portrait by the defunct Royal Academician from Lancashire but a live subject, a working model, a talking picture, one E. L. (Dick) Romney from Logan, Utah.

Six men who were very much surprised to find themselves alive today stood opposite this writer and a British colleague in a room of the military prison here and told us of conditions in the Rebel army.

Paired with G. Stoltz, former champion of Sweden, in the seventh round, Reuben Fine of New York was held to a draw in the international tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club today. The American, nevertheless, kept the lead, one point ahead of G. Stahlberg, who also had to be content With a draw in his match with N. Bergqvist of this city. Each game lasted thirty moves.

Frank J. Marshall and David Polland both scored yesterday in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club and remained tied for the lead with totals of 3-0. Marshall, playing ahead of schedule, defeated Sidney Bernstein in a queen's pawn opening after fortyfour movies, while Polland won from Dudolph Smirka in an adjourned game from the third round.

With the hope of encouraging the millions of New Yorkers who use the telephone every day to develop a "sparkling" telephone personality, the New York Telephone Company has prepared a ten-page pamphlet on how to be a good telephone speaker. The pamphlet Is entitled "The Voice With a Smile,"

Retail trade here was only fair during the week, reports yesterday indicated. Gains of 3 or 4 per cent over the comparative 1936 period were noted, but trade last year was poor at this time, due to the sleet storm and other markedly adverse conditions.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Loring Lane of 395 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Crows Nest, South Kent, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eloise Wentworth Lane, to Edwin Willis Hicks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hicks of Westbury, L. I.

The administration's hope of expanding foreign markets for American products fast enough, by means of the reciprocal foreign trade program, to avoid restriction of agricultural and industrial production in this country was voiced by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, before the Ways and Means Committee today.

A 60 per cent gain in business this year, compared with 1936, was forecast by members of the Air Conditioning Manufacturers Association in a statement issued here yesterday. Last year established a new high record for the industry, with total sales of $52,500,000, but producers confidently expect, according to the statements, that the 1937 figures will reach $85,000,000.

Fred J. Odenbach, president of the Hotel Hayward in Rochester, and president of the New York State Hotel Men's Association, subscribed yesterday to $2,000 of New York World's Fair 4 per cent deventures, with the assertion that the exposition will illustrate "the fact that all of New York State is increasingly becoming a partner in the economic fortunes of New York City.

The Works Progress Administration of New York City spent more than $237,000,000 in 1936, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell reported yesterday in a summary of employment data covering the period since August, 1935, when the present work relief program was started.
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $12,845,508, one State and forty-six municipalities being represented. This week's revised total is $71,957,329.

The Ohio River rolled onward and upward tonight along the West Virginia-Ohio line, driving thousands from their homes. Rain continued to fall. More than 20,000 fled about Wheeling and 5,000 left their homes along the forty-one-mile stretch between Point Pleasant and Huntington, where the crest passed the 1936 peak.
Doctors and nurses tried tonight to preserve the life of the only surviving Rondeau quadruplet after her two brothers and sister died, only a day and a half old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Helen Senter Stamps, daughter of Mrs. Arthur D. Stenger of this city, and of Jesse M. Senter, to Henry R. Stern Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Stern of New York.
The Weather Bureau said tonight that an average of more than six inches of rain in two days over the Ohio River Valley had caused the highest flood crest in bureau records.

Prince and Princess de CaramanChimay, who have been at Mayfair House, are sailing today for Europe. Mrs. Lansing C. Holden has returned from Bermuda and will be at 14 East Sixtieth Street for the remainder of the Winter.

William Pitcher Bowman, vice president and treasurer of John A. Roebling's Sons Company of New York and former Republican New Jersey State Committeeman, died this morning in the Post-Graduate Hospital, New York City, after a short illness.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 916,000 bales, against 927,000 a week ago, 920,000 two weeks ago, 909,000 three weeks ago and 712,000 a year ago; of which American, 374,000 bales, against 364,000 a week ago, 339,000 two weeks ago, 341,000 three weeks ago and 400,000 a year ago.

Michael J. (Umbrella Mike) Boyle, "czar" of the Electrical Workers Union, tied up most of Chicago tonight for two hours and a half with a strike of city electrical workers which shut off street lights.

Alcide (Frenchy) Benoit, confessed slayer of State Policeman Richards F. Hammond, was sentenced to life imprisonment in Southern Michigan prison today after he pleaded guilty to a first degree murder charge.
