The National City Bank of New York delivered yesterday to the city a check for $50,251,301, the amount due on the new issue of 3 per cent corporate stock maturing Jan. 1, 1977, which was sold to the bank and its associates on Jan. 12.
Tall gray-haired W. C. Devereaux sal beside a battery of telephones today answering hundreds of calls and predicting that the Ohio River flood would continue at least seven more days.

Marcel Jouhaux, son of Leon Jouhaux, secretary general of the French Federation of Labor, was arrested here Wednesday in connection with illicit traffic in arms for Spain, it became known tonight. Police had withheld the news because Mr. Jouhaux's identity was not certain.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels's Angriff puts on its front page an editorial by one of the leading National Socialist educators demanding that one-third of the German universities be closed and confessing that few if any candidates are available to fill empty professorial chairs.
Mr. Bryant was commissioned by the New South Wales Government to paint a large canvas in oils showing the United States fleet entering Sydney Harbor in 1925.

Gross assets, $47,573; net, $45,321. To widow, Elizabeth King Black, residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $24,213. Herman Goldman, attorney, 120 Broadway. CHEDSEY, FRANCIS B. (Aug. 25, 1934). Gross assets. $387.858; net, $300.489.
George Washington University gained its eighth straight basket-. ball victory by beating Villanova tonight, 33-23, before a crowd of 2,000 fans.

Glenn Cunningham, beaten in a handicap race a week ago, will start in another such contest tonight. He is entered in the threequarter mile special limited handicap that will feature the Grover Cleveland-Osceola Club track and field meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
The Yale freshmen today defeated Lawrenceville School and Andover Academy in a triangular meet in the Payne Whitney pool. The yearlings tallied 37 points, Lawrenceville 30 and Andover 20.
Switzerland was held up as an example to the world by four of the speakers last night at the fiftyfifth annual dinner of the Swiss Society of New York at the Hotel Plaza.

The opening performance of "The Robber Symphony," described as the first surrealist symphonic cinema fantasy, tomorrow night at the Venice Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, has been sponsored by Mrs. Cobina Wright and several assisting committees as a means to aid the work of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute.

Princeton's varsity wrestling team defeated Pennsylvania on the Palestra mats today, 24--8, this being the first setback of the season for the Red and Blue. The Tigers, who upset Penn State, 1936 intercollegiate champions, in a dual meet only a week ago, won six of the eight bouts, including three falls.

It is yet a bit early for sowing the seeds of most flowering plants. But there are some plants that require a considerable period before they begin to bloom, and seeds of these may well be sown now or in the near future. Among the flowers in

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Two events of major importance listed for this week in Bermuda are the Burns Night dinner and dance, to be held tomorrow by the Caledonian Society of Bermuda, and the President Roosevelt Birthday Ball arranged for Saturday.

About 2,000 electrical engineers from various parts of the country are expected to attend the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, opening here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and continuing through Friday.

Some of the undergraduates at Brown University this term are edging in on a graduate project. They are indexing the phonographic records of the "Linguistic Atlas of New England," noting such things as the Yankee's pronunciation of "glass," "pasture." "afternoon"

AMERICA'S transportation executives are watching with keen interest the vast extension of the Winter vacation cult to classes of people who a few years ago could not be induced to leave their desks except for a Summer holiday.
A dangling youth hung out of a disabled plane in midair to repair its landing gear here today, possibly saving the lives of its pilot and five passengers.

Music, long considered a "pipe" course at Bowdoin College, has become this semester one of the most important offered by the college, to the credit of Professor Frederic Tillotson, concert pianist, who came here in September to take charge of the department.
The Ballet Espanol of Juan Martinez gave the first of its final series of four performances at the Bayes Theatre yesterday afternoon, with several new numbers introduced into the program.
Evacuation of women, children and elderly persons among the 1,200 residents of Shawneetown, oldest settlement in Illinois, began today over the rising waters of the Ohio River.

While there was rather free selling of grain futures today at the opening of the Board of Trade, with new low levels established on the current downturn, general short covering developed when local professionals became active in evening up their position for the week-end, and the close was on a strong rally.
THREE open events, and a pair tournament that only newspaper men may enter, make up the schedule for the Atlantic national tournament which begins Wednesday afternoon at the Hotel Edison.

It always happens, after a year has ended with continuance of a forward movement in general business confidently expected, that early in the new year the qualifying considerations begin to be tentatively discussed. Some public utterances of the kind are already heard. As a rule, they do not

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended on Jan. 20, aggregated $10,164,852,000, or 7 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 17 per cent above that for the corresponding week of last year.

A suit to safeguard journalists' sources of information began yesterday in the District Court here. It was filed by Dr. Heberlein, the National Zeitung correspondent, against the district prosecuting attorney, who sentenced the journalist to five days in prison and fined him 100 francs because he refused to say who gave him information regarding the arrest of some Communists.
The General Motors Corporation announced here yesterday that 125,613 of its automobile employes were idle in fifty plants because of strikes and the curtailment of operations resulting from them.
Sam Atcheson of Memphis won the Y. M. C. A. national four-wall handball singles championship for the sixth time tonight by overwhelming Stanley K. Hitz of Harrisburg, Pa., 21-2, 21-2.

Mr. and Mrs. H. H. Schell of Cathedral Avenue entertained at dinner tonight for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. William P. Brown and Miss Virginia Brown of Lancaster, Pa. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Ralph B. Scharman, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond McNulty and Mr. and Mrs. August Scharman.

The fifty-ninth annual conference of the American Library Association will be held in New York during the week of June 21, Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg, director of the New York Public Library, announced yesterday.

The Trinity School team retained the lead in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League by defeating the Blair Academy quintet, 32-28, at the Trinity court yesterday. Trinity tops the list with victories in as many games.

Miss Virginia Hardy Slaughter, daughter of Robert Kemp Slaughter of Washington and the late Mrs. Slaughter, was married to Ernest Judson Clark Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Judson Clark of Guilford, Baltimore, this evening in the presence of relatives. A reception at the Mount Vernon Club followed the ceremony.

WINTER in the North Atlantic is a trying time. Winds of gale force, mountainous seas, fog, rain and snow combine to disrupt steamer schedules and bring ships into port days late, with battered rails and frozen spray on bridge and funnels.

Miss Margaret Dixon Stroud, daughter of Mrs. R. Sanford Saltus Jr. of Hollow Tree, Villanova, and of the late Morris Wistar Stroud Jr., was married this afternoon to John Alden Ragister Dalley, son of Mrs. F. Bartol Dalley of Haverford.

GENEVA. TWO peaks stand out today in the tranquil lyric panorama of Lake Leman: a rehearing, thirteen years after the local premiere, of Stravinsky's "Sacre," again given by the Orchestre Romand under Ernest Ansermet, and the return to Geneva, likewise after a long absence, of Pablo Casals.
IN A NEW FIELD: For nineteen years, seven in the Federal service, Sanford Bates has devoted himself to the science of imprisoning, and

The Boston University freshman basketball team defeated Phillips Exeter, 32 to 22, today. The defeat was the first for the schoolboys this season. Exeter trailed the entire game with the exception of a brief period in the third period when a basket from the floor by Bennett gave the Red and Gray a 17-to-16 lead.

Washington is noting four signs that its rank and file statesmen are shaking down to hard work after the exhilarations of the inauguration. They are: (1) The morning after the great day upward of 200 Congressmen and their secretaries took the "pick me up"

While other river valley communities have been deluged with flood waters causing damage running into the millions, Dayton and other cities in the Miami Valley, protected by five conservancy dams, sit high and dry, unharmed by the raging waters of three rivers flowing through the valley.

A reformed method of equity procedure for the reorganization of railroads to replace the provisions of the Bankruptcy Law now used for that purpose is recommended by Louis B. Wehle of Marshall Wehle in a summary of progress to date in the retrieval of railroads from bankruptcy or receivership.

Yearling deer taking short cuts across the frozen lakes from one wooded territory to another in this region have given plenty of trouble to Edward Jones, park ranger for the Palisades Interstate Park.

A period of unusual stimulation in the real estate field, with permanent benefits to the city depending in large measure upon the wisdom with which real estate owners and operators utilize suddenly expanded opportunities, is in store for New York as a result of the coming World's Fair, according to Douglas L. Elliman, president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.

THE first tribute to the memory of Isadora Duncan in the year 1937, which marks the decade since her death, will be an exhibition of photographs, drawings, sculpture and other memorabilia, to be held at the School of the Isadora Duncan Dance Art, 168 East Fifty-first Street, for a week beginning Friday, Jan. 29.

THERE is bound to be some lying about ages under the Social Security Act. Also some honest disputes. How is the government to know whether an applicant who asks for his first payment is actually 65? Birth certificates are not easily obtained for years prior to 1915.

The value of newly constructed homes amounted to 55 per cent of the total value of mortgages accepted for insurance by the Federal Housing Administration during the final six months of 1936, reports Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald.

Helen Hayes, who is appearing in "Victoria Regina," at the Broadhurst Theatre, received a gold medal yesterday from the National Speech Arts Fellowship in recognition of her diction and speech during 1936. The presentation was made by Dr. Mary McGovern,

REALLY PREFERRED: Spinach, the legendary bane of childhood, was revealed last week as second only to potatoes in the vegetable preferences of 10,000 boys and girls. The survey was begun last Summer by the Children's Welfare Federation among the youngsters in its Summer camps.

Prince Michael. 15-year-old heir to the throne of Rumania, underwent an appendectomy at a hospital here today. A hospital bulletin said he was progressing "nicely." King Carol, his father, inquired by telephone concerning Michael's condition.

GEORGES ENESCO will be the second of the Philharmonic-Symphony guest conductors of the season. Mr. Enesco's opening program will include the first performance in America of Mihail Jora's "March Juive," and his own symphony in E flat, No. 1.

The Rev. Michael J. Walsh, since June, 1914, pastor of St. Sebastian's Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, L. I., died yesterday morning in his rectory, 39-36 Fifty-seventh Street, after an illness of six months. His age was 72.

The ensembling idea that has been worked out to the nth degree in clothes and accessories has invaded the housewares industry, with the result that the woman with an eye to the esthetic quality of humble household equipment can work out a color scheme for her kitchen and cupboard appurtenances.

Airplane flights over Western Massachusetts are being made by Mrs. Victor H. Wesson of Longmeadow, vice president of the Connecticut Valley Riding Association, to plot a route linking the Cape Cod Trail with the bridle paths of the Berkshires.

The trunk highway between the East and West through the Mohawk Valley, which converges into a bottle-neck in this city, is in the process of being widened. Contractors have holes drilled and are about to start blasting a $1,000,000 road through the rocks.

Mrs. Maude Robinson, who has been described as the wife of the notorious blackmailer, Charles E. Robinson, connected with the mysterious "Mr. A" case in London and Paris in 1924, sailed yesterday on the French liner Champlain as a voluntary deportee.

EVEN the optimists were about ready to give up before George Jessel got around to saying that he had not forsaken Broadway completely-that he would produce "Glory for All" around here next month, even though he is delegating most of the work to others and will be here in person only for the opening. But that is something,

Wiping the slate clean of frozen funds held here for the account of United States exporters awaiting exchange coverage, the Banco do Brasil today definitely thawed out 60,000 contos at twelve milreis to the United States dollar, or $5,000,000 for the account of the oil companies. Previously, on Dec. 30, $1,500,000 for the account of various United States exporters was thawed.

THE Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, which rose out of the remains of a stable ten years ago to become the shrine of lieder and sturm und drang cinema until fury against the current political regime in Germany forced a change in policy, is celebrating its tenth birthday this week with a return to the type of picture that made it famous.

Cotton of the 1936 growth ginned prior to Jan. 16 was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 11,956,808 running bales, including 80,669 round bales, counted as half bales, and 14,686 bales of American-Egyptian.
The Northeastern University freshmen sextet, paced by Howard Milner of Newton, beat Andover, 4-3, on the Boston Arena ice tonight.
The recent tremendous onslaught on militarism in the Tokyo Parliament was led by a former Speaker of the House, one

Employment equivalent to yeararound jobs for 126,000 men in the building trades was provided by the credit which savings, biulding and loan associations disbursed for new home construction and for modernization and repair work during 1936, according to estimates made by the United States Building and Loan League.

Employment agencies and housewives in New York report a shortage of domestic help. As many women now as at the beginning of the depression are doing paid house work, but few recruits have been added to supply the widened demand for that type of service.

A chart four feet by five with the name Arthur Flegenheimer, alias Dutch Schultz, at the top, was hung on the wall behind Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday as the prosecution's first exhibit in the trial of eight defendants charged with a $2,000,000 restaurant shakedown racket.

With their large crops already perhaps half lost, Southern California fruit growers defended their orchards tonight against another killing freeze in the offing. Damage already suffered in the worst weather since 1913 may run to $60,000,000, counting fruit and tree damage and costs of orchard heating.
Congress today passed a law whereby clerks in stores will receive two hours off for lunch. The law becomes effective immediately. Shopkeepers who fail to comply will be fined.

RADIO, a year or two ago, picked up the old American Town Meeting idea and electrified it with the aim of interpreting public affairs in terms of democracy rather than partisanship. The platform of Town Hall,

For individuality tigridas stands near the top of the list among all garden flowers. They are plants of many paradoxes. Although they come from the tropics-they are native to the high plateaus from Southern -Mexico down. almost the entire length of Central America-they are surprisingly hardy and can be grown as far north as Canada.

A spectacle entitled "The Nations' Tribute," and described as a pageant of the Western Hemisphere, will be one of the main features of the fourth Birthday Ball for President Roosevelt, which will take place next Saturday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The conflict in Spain, now in its seventh month, has lost nothing of its original character of a fight to the death between the opposing factions. In this respect it is more implacable than ever; but it is developing characteristics on the Valencia-Madrid government side that did not exist last July.

In the event of a continued impasse between the New Deal and the Supreme Court with regard to the constitutional powers of the Federal Government, Congress will be compelled to choose other courses of action than those followed during the first term of the New Deal if the objects stated in the inaugural speech of President Roosevelt are to be attained.

ST. GEORGE'S, Bermuda. BERMUDA is coming into the limelight as a new spot for game fishing and next Spring, when air service begins to operate between New York and Darrell's Island, America's saltwater sportsmen will be able to fly to the island for a week-end of deep-sea fishing.
The names of Fritz Crisler, head football coach at Princeton, and Slip Madigan of St. Mary's cropped up tonight as nominees to succeed Dana X. Bible as gridiron mentor at the University of Nebraska.

NEARLY 5,000 years of artistic bronzemaking are to be covered in the Exhibition of Master Bronzes to be held at the Albright Art Gallery, Buffalo, during February. This "world's history of bronzes" is to be composed of statuettes of animal and human forms and is to be limited to complete figures in three dimensions.

Under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, N. J.. a bridge party and tea will be held on Feb. 6 at the Ritz Tower for the benefit of the organization's two competitive scholarships. A feature of the afternoon will be a fashion show in which younger members of the association will act as manikins.

ON a twelve-acre site formerly used by the Ardsley Golf Club in Ardsley Park, Westchester County, a new apartment project known as Hudson House, consisting of three units to accommodate eighty-five families, is nearing completion.

Temple University jumped into second place in the Eastern Conference standing by turning back the champion Carnegie Tech team tonight, 38-27. Mike Bloom, the towering center for the Owls, led the scoring parade with seven field goals and a foul for 15 points.
On selling him an old iron safe, Mrs. Boyd Steele laughingly told Gervis F. Lemley, town postmaster, that if there were any secret compartments filled with money, "it's mine."

French eighteenth century furniture, paintings and Oriental rugs, comprising the collection of Mrs. Talbot J. Taylor, removed from Chateau de Saint Vigor, near Versailles, France, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

In behalf of the Jesuit Missions a Mi-Careme luncheon and card party will be held on March 9 at the Ambassador under the auspices of the Loyola School, of which the Rev. Francis E. Garner is headmaster. The funds realized will be used in the maintenance of the various houses of study furthered by the Jesuits for training young men for the missionary field.

Funeral services for Charles N. Thomas, retired general manager for Underwood Underwood, photographers, will be held at 2 P. M., today, at the Burroughs Funeral Home, Madison, N. J. Mr. Thomas, who died Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz., at the age of 67, had been with the Underwood firm since shortly after its establishment many years ago in Ottawa, Kansas. He retired in 1936.

Employes' representatives made plans here today to unionize the Standard Oil and Tide Water refinery workers in Bayonne, N. J. With John Lewis they discussed a campaign to bring the New Jersey refinery workers into the Committee for Industrial Organization. The workers, they said,

For better or for worse, it is a far cry from the freedom-ofthe-seas position which has been one of the cornerstones of the foreign policy of the United States for more than a century to the policy which would assume its most definite form in the adoption of the bill just introduced by Senator Pittman, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. We have fought bitterly in the past

The marriage of Miss Martha Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Adams of 32 East Sixtyfourth Street, to Gregory John Tobin, son of Mrs. William J. Tobin of this city and the late Mr. Tobin, took place yesterday. morning in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

Elaine Barrie wants John Barrymore to pay $2,525 a month temporary alimony. She petitioned the court to that effect today, and in a separate petition asked a restraining order to prevent the 54-year-old actor

The Ridgewood Polo Club came from behind to conquer the Squadron C trio of Brooklyn, 11 to 10 1/2, in the feature game at Essex Troop Armory tonight. A last-minute tally by Buddy Hopper clinched the honors for Ridgewood. The visitors, who enjoyed a six-goal handicap, held a lead of 10 1/2 to 5 1/2 at half time.

Mr. and Mrs. George D. McEntee of this city, formerly of Jersey City, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jamison McEntee, to Howard Burrell Matthews Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Burrell Matthews of East Orange, N. J.

Armament manufacturing and trade renations, which more and more are being regarded here as twin subjects because of their interrelationship, were uppermost when President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, began their weekend fireside conversations in the White House this afternoon.

Charles A. Davila, Rumanian Minister to Washington, gave a reception yesterday in the Colonnades of the Essex House for Georges Enesco, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
THOSE who have traveled over the scarred face of Europe in recent years have noticed that a certain lack of harmony prevails.

A total of 6,000 buyers spending upward of $8,500,000 last week gave a decided lift to the housefurnishings industry here. The buying, confined largely to the furniture and lamp markets, was done at trade shows held by both industries. Another active period

Several inquiries from agrarianminded residents of Brooklyn have prompted the announcement that the Board of Education, in cooperation with the WPA, is willing to establish agricultural courses in that borough if the demand warrants such a project.

Although heavy rainstorms have steadily augmented the supply of water in the chain of New York City reservoirs behind the big Cornell Dam in Croton but have not so far started an overflow on the spillway, it was reported today that the water level was less than three feet from the top and that a splashing cataract is likely to start down the spillway within a few days.
Miss Elizabeth Hildyard, daughter of Brig. Gen. Harold C. T. Hildyard of the British Army, arrived today to be the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton H. Gilkyson Jr. of Monte Clare, near Phoenixville.

AMERICA'S great railroads, determined to regain patronage lost during the depression, have made many new friends with their air-conditioning, streamlining, more comfort for passengers and faster schedules.

One of the finest collections of United States coins, including many of the rare early issues, that has been offered at auction in this city for some time was sold yesterday by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street, O. R. Gilbert acting as auctioneer.
Unqualified opposition to all compulsory health insurance schemes was expressed yesterday by Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, president of the American Medical Association.

Permission to live and work in Geneva was again denied to Carlo Aprato, journalist, in a decision handed down today by the Council of State of the canton. Mr. Aprato, who had been compelled to leave the country Jan. 15 and had gone to France, appealed to the Council, and the appeal was rejected.

In the presence of an overflow crowd of 7,000, including a host of city, State and Federal dignitaries, Glenn Cunningham led a strong field in the special three-quartermile handicap race, feature of the Grover Cleveland-Osceola meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night.

The United Automobile Workers Union, which is directing the strike against the General Motors Corporation, represents only a small minority of the corporation's employes, according to Leo Wolman, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, formerly chairman of the Automobile Labor Board and recognized authority on labor relations in the industry.

Colonel General Hermann Goering's Rome visit and his numerous conversations with Premier Benito Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano though still to some extent enveloped in mystery, have made one point abundantly clear-the RomeBerlin axis is still one of the forces with which it is necessary to reckon in Europe.

Free trade, even as an ultimate goal, is being considered seriously by no nation in the world, said Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, in testimony today before the Ways and Means Committee. He advocated extension for three years of the reciprocal tariff bargaining powers Congress granted to President Roosevelt in 1934.
The Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company announced today it had offered an increase of 6 cents an hour in wages to its 7,100 employes called out on strike Dec. 15 by the Federation of Flat Glass Workers.
December, 1936, was the eleventh consecutive month in which gains in factory employment had been shown in the United States, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced today.

Sammy Byrd, former Yankee player, all but put the national baseball players' golf championship "in the bag" today with a one-under-par 70 that left him eleven strokes ahead of the field at the end of the fifty-four holes. Byrd, now with Rochester, played brilliantly today to compile a total of 214 in the fight for the Powel Crosley trophy.

ATHOUGH the theatre is a godless institution, "the vestibule to hell," as a New York Jeremiah once called it, one of the few notable productions of the season is a humbly moving religious play, Franz Werfel's "The Eternal Road," which

Ohio State's fast-stepping Buckeyes dropped Michigan's basketball Wolverines from the role of Big Ten title contender to that of a second division team tonight. The final score was 37 to 32. A crowd of 7,500 watched the game. Ohio State led at the half 19--17.

PORTLAND, Ore. THE arrival of a new year invariably prompts the alpinists of the Far West to look toward the summits of their favorite peaks. Every experienced climber on the sundown side of the Mississippi seeks the honor of beIng the first argonaut of the year

Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. McDermott gave a dinner dance at their home here tonight to celebrate the birthday of their younger daughter, Miss Patricia McDermott, who will begin her freshman year at Marymount College next month.

After an early loss of a few points in consonance with an easier tone in most commodity markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday to close with a gain of 2, to a loss of 3 points. Some selling followed reports that the strike in Detroit had drawn requests for a delay in deliveries of cotton goods pending the restoration of normal conditions.

Plans for reconstructing housing and business properties in Manhattan were revealed in connection with sales announced yesterday. The five-story American basement dwelling at 16 East Ninetysecond Street was sold by the estate of William C. Orr to a buyer for remodeling into small apartments.

Wherever flood or fire or famine goes, There, too, go I. This is the assuring and reassuring word of the American Red Cross in every time of wide disaster and distress. Instantly the forces of rescue,

Some 750 children from such sections as the Gas House District, Hell's Kitchen and Duffy Hill occupied golden chairs yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Hotel Astor, where they Were the luncheon guests of the Adventurers Club of New York.

Sixty inhabitants stricken with influenza on lonely Soay Island off Scotland's mainland are in critical need tonight, cut off from medical aid by a six-day storm. The fishing village has no doctor, no nurse, no telephone. All but ten islanders are ill.

THE age in which we live is an age of intense national patriotism. The World War, we now perceive, not only marked the fruition of previous nationalistic aspirations but likewise sowed rich new seed for the far more abundant and widespread nationalism of the present day. There was nationalism in 1914, but there was more of it in 1919, and there is vastly more of it now in 1937.

Three men, who, according, to the police, are responsible for the. theft of more. than $10,000 worth of goods from piers and parked trucks along the waterfront in the last three weeks, were in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning, charged with grand larceny.

Miss Mary Angela McDonnell, debutante daughter of Mrs. Robert Emmett McDonnell, heads a group of young women aiding in arrangements for the annual supper dance in behalf of the Barat Settlement, which will take place on Feb. 8 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Pope Pius has felicitated President Roosevelt on his second inauguration, it was announced today. His message was sent by Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, to the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, apostolic delegate to the United States, who embodied it in a letter to the President, as follows:

Miss Eugenia Ward Riley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilson Riley of Belle Haven, Greenwich, was married to Lieutenant Joseph Crook Anderson, U. S. A., of Memphis, Tenn., this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich, by the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson, the rector.
Agents of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals declared war today on a marauding hawk in the congested downtown area and then awaited city permission for their first attack.

Rudy Marshall, Harlem middleweight, serving as a substitute, registered an upset before 2,000 at Rockland Palace last night when he received the decision over Atilio Sabatino, crack Puerto Rican middleweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds.
Kentucky, gripped by the most devastating flood in its history, sought relief tonight for more than 50,000 homeless persons.

After interviewing many musicians over a period of two weeks, the United States Army found one who could play a helicon of the bass bb-flat variety. Soon he will be marching with the military band in the Canal Zone, encased by a big horn that will sound a deep oompahh" against the shrill trills of the clarinets.

The Manhattan Prep quintet turned back Fordham Prep, 20-16, at the victors' court in a Bronx Westchester C. H. S. A. A. contest yesterday. The winners led at halftime, 13-4. Barney Hassett scored 7 points to lead Manhattan Prep.

From 7 o'clock this morning until nearly 1 o'clock this afternoon the center of this city was subjected to the heaviest artillery bombardment since the siege started with 8-inch shells, the biggest yet employed in the civil war.

BROADS-SIEGEL-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Siegel of 225 West 86th St. announce the engagement of their daughter, Blanche. to Mr. Irving J. Broads, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Broads of Yonkers. FIGLER-GOLDSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Louis Goldstein of 4,920 17th Av., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Frances, to Mr. George E. Figler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Figler of Boston, Mass.
Specifications for the new liner to take the place of the Leviathan put emphasis upon comfortable, roomy quarters for the crew.

Miss Virginia M. West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. West of Middleburg, Va., was married here today at the home which her parents have taken for the Winter, to Uzal H. McCarter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. McCarter of Rumsonhill, Rumson, N. J. Only, members of the two families were present at the ceremony.

With four of its components lower, two higher and one unchanged, THE TIMES weekly index of business activity receded to 105.3 for the week ended Jan. 16, 1937. The revised figure for the previous week is 105.6. A year ago it stood at 94.1.
Harold R. Moskovit of Brooklyn was elected president of the Affiliated Young Democrats yesterday at a meeting at its headquarters, 1,440 Broadway.

The future of the Committee for Industrial Organization, in its relations to the American Federation of Labor and to the mass-production industries whose workers it is trying to organize, rests upon the outcome of the present automobile strike situation.

College students everywhere are complaining about the inconvenience and needless work they are subjected to because of term examinations. The original purpose of examinations was to precisely find out just what the students knew. Today, however, nobody knows

Dr. Melbourne A. Carriker, associate curator of the Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia, and a widely known ornithologist, has returned from a collecting expedition to Bolivia. In nine months he captured about 14,000 birds of 2,000 different species, 200 of which he believes are hitherto unknown.

The first six months of the campaign to reduce illiteracy among the city's foreign-born white population shows a successful beginning with the enrollment of 12,223 adult students and a constantly increasing registration.

Reviews of the many-faceted program of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations during1936 will constitute one of the most important items on the program of the annual convention and luncheon to be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor.

Sur-re-al-ism: n. [F. surrealisme]. A French movement in literature and art influenced by Freudianism, purporting to express the subconscious activities of the mind by presenting images without logical order or sequence, as in a dream. The surrealists were not the first to recognize the possibilities that lie in the subconscious mind.

Gardeners everywhere are now planning improvements this coming year. To the beginner especially there is adventure in discovering a1l the various kinds of flowers and bulbs, shrubs and vines that can be grown. Gradually he decides what he wants to grow, or, since most garden space is limited, what he wants to grow most.

The University of Maryland basketball team coasted along to a 37-to-28 victory over the University of Virginia quintet tonight. The Cavaliers were easily checked by the Maryland first team and registered most of their points when the rival second-stringers were on the floor.

House plants, whether few or many, are always much more attractive if they look flourishing. Hence the temptation to overfertilize is strong, since every gardener knows how frequently garden soil needs to be enriched.

The engagement of Miss Leonice K. Merrels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Merrels of this city, to Robert C. Knox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Knox, also of Hartford, has been announced by her parents.

Winter sports, including skiing, skating, tobogganing and dog-sledding, will be features of the Ski Carnival arranged for today at Skytop Lodge in the Poconos by members of society in aid of the Virginia Day Nursery.

Gilda Gray, the dancer, filed suit today for divorce from her husband, Tector de Briceno de Saa. Charging cruelty, she accused Mr. de Saa of applying "profane and opprobrious" epithets to her in the presence of friends and of displaying "marked indifference" to her.

Sails seven years old are to be used by Harold S. Vanderbilt on the America's Cup yacht he is having built in the expectancy of meeting T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II off Newport next Summer, according to present plans.

Activities of Russian representatives seeking large-scale equipment and offering cash payment from Moscow forty-five days after delivery of documents again swung export attention to the Soviet market this week. Because of the size of
St. Valentine's Kettledrum, New York's oldest "charity fair," an annual event in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged, will be held on the afternoon of Feb. 6 in the ballroom suite of the Plaza.

MIND, MEDICINE AND METAPHYSICS. By William Brown. 270 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $3. THE title of this collection of fourteen essays suggests an expanse of subject-matter quite daring in its vastness. But strangely enough it is hardly adequate.

Speech authorities agree with the general public that it is not only what President Roosevelt says but also the way he says it. Objective analysis of his second inaugural performance, weighing the pros and cons, proves once again that he is a truly great artist in speech.

WINTER sports promise to revive an old institution in Eastern Canada-the week-end visitor from the United States. Montreal and Quebec have not forgotten those bountiful times, before repeal and the depression, when American

IT is of no use for authors to write books unless satisfactory means can be found of insuring that they shall reach prospective readers Accordingly. the surveys of the output of literature during 1936, reported in a previous letter, need to be supplemented by some account of the year's developments with regard to the machinery of book production and distribution.

Virginio Gayda, in the Giornale d'Italia, this evening tilts at President Roosevelt's inaugural message, and especially at the statements that democracy has overcome the depression and improved the standards of life of American citizens.

The Estonian people are keenly await??n the opening on Feb. 18 of the National Assembly, whose only task will be to frame this small repubice's new Constitution, which is expected to be based on a democratic pattern.

Although the British people may "definitely prefer butter to guns," as Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said the other day, their elected .representatives in the House of Commons will be kept busy. until adjournment at the end of July in providing guns and determining how to pay for them.

Masters of ships arriving here last week reported that Winter had definitely returned to the Atlantic, with high winds and rough water. Even some of the largest liners were nearly twenty-four hours behind schedule and were further handicapped in reaching their piers by dense fog in the harbor.

The body of Miss Catherine Steyer, 32-year-old hotel hat check girl of 304 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, was found yesterday afternoon in her two-room apartment, where, according to the police, she had been killed by an electric shock from an improvised burglar alarm.

Miss Laila Schou-Nielsen of Norway, holder of the world 500meter speed-skating record of 49.3 seconds, today established a new mark for the distance in the women's Norwegian championships. She was clocked in 47.9 seconds.

Four Wellesley professors will leave the college next week to spend the next six months in study and research. Three other members of the faculty are already engaged in independent projects subsidized by sabbatical grants provided by the college.

Abnormal weather conditions in many sections, destructive floods in a number of States and serious labor disturbances in some industrial centers served to check business activity in various districts of the country last week.
Plans have been completed for "Opera Day," to be sponsored by the Cardiac division of the Social Service Auxiliary of Kings County Hospital, on Saturday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT has taken on for the second time the toughest job in the world-a job which, as he said in his recent reorganization message, it is "humanly impossible" for him completely to fulfill under present conditions. Reorganization, he believes, will make the work easier.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild will present an intimate reading of Wagner's "Der Ring Des Nibelungen," on Tuesday evening, Feb. 2, in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre. The various elements of the drama will be presented by Olin Downes, and musical illustrations will be given at the piano by Ernest Hutcheson.

In Washington this week the Women's Patriotio Conference on National Defense will reiterate its opposition to any peace program which calls for disarmament. As part of the legislative program the delegates will be asked to foster the "universal service" plan of the American Legion, which its auxiliary has been advancing militantly in New York State.

The School Art League, an organization which fosters artistic talent in the high schools of the five boroughs, announced yesterday the winners of its ten scholarships and seventy-six medals. The awards will be made tomorrow afternoon in the auditorium of the Roosevelt Memorial on Central Park West.

Almeria authorities charged today that German seaplanes had bombed the government airplane base at Roquetas, on the Southern Mediterranean coast. The report to the Loyalist Air Ministry asserted five airplanes from. a German warship dropped bombs on the air field twelve miles southwest of Almeria.
The Stevens Tech basketball team defeated Rensselaer Poly by a single point, 25 to 24, tonight, winning by the same margin as they had lost the three previous annual encounters.

Miss Lois Ella Olson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Olson of Naugatuck, Conn., was married to Robert Collett of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Collett of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.

Just 101 "cures" for hiccoughs were sent to the family of Miss Edna Plante of this town when she recently suffered the paroxysms for 150 hours. Her father, Herbert La Plante, tried out one suggestion of lighting a firecracker under her chair, on the "shock" theory. It was not a success.

The annual meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals will be held on Friday afternoon at the home of Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street. Reports on the work of the league during the last year will be made by Mrs. J. Dyneley Prince, president of the organization, and by Henry C. Holt, treasurer.

IN "Voltaire en robe de chambre," by Ch. Oulmont (Calmann-Levy, 224 pp., 15 fr.), the man primarily, rather than the writer or the thinker, is depicted from his letters, from the memoirs of his contemporaries and from a few interesting untapped sources.

The Root-Pitney Club won in the final arguments of the Ames speaking competition at the Harvard Law School. It supported the right of the taxpayers to recover processing taxes paid under the AAA. Its speakers were W. Parmer Fuller of San Mateo, Calif., and Gerald H. Trautman of this city.
Industrial self-government by codes is gaining in Canada, according to George S. Hougham of the Retail Merchants Association of Canada, with headquarters in Toronto. Mr. Hougham, who was here

The Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association of this city has been appointed fiscal agent of the Federal Government in the sale and servicing of United States Savings Bonds, popularly known as "baby bonds."

ST. PAUL, Minn. - Minnesota, where skiers, bob-sledders and skaters know without examining weather charts there will always be snow and ice from November to April-if not from October to May--will end its series of Winter sports meets with a week-long Winter Carnival in St. Paul from Jan. 30 to Feb. 6.

IF you remember "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," you must then remember the dashing Friedrich Feher, the young man in the Inverness cape whose fervid enactment of the imaginings of his own tortured mind forms the thread of the picture.

The semi-centennial of Dwight Hall, interdenominational religious center of Yale University, will be celebrated Sunday, Feb. 21. All Yale alumni back for the annual Alumni Day events will be invited to be present, attend a supper at 6 P. M. and formal exercises at 8 o'clock.
Miss Fay Givens Sumner, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Henry N. Sumner, was married to Lieutenant Francis Thomas Pachler, U. S. A., at the home of her parents her last night.

HENRY KLEEMANN has put on another of his intimate shows of small oils and water-colors by American artists of this and the preceding generation. Representing the latter there is a quietly persuasive portrait of a woman, by Eakins, to balance the somewhat diabolic portrait of a man, by Luks; and there

Very puzzling indeed to the lay public, and perhaps even to the surrealists themselves, is the anger of Miss KATHERINE DREIER. Miss DREIER had loaned some paintings for the surrealist exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, and was indignant to discover that pictures by the insane and children were also included. She has refused,

The Catholic Student Peace Federation of the Middle Atlantic States, consisting of representatives of more than forty Catholic colleges and Newman clubs in nonsectarian colleges, will hold its second conference of the school year Feb. 13, it was announced yesterday.
WEATHER handicaps upon retail trade became more severe in the week with floods in eleven States added to the unseasonal cold in the Far West and warmth in the East. Most reports told of reduced

Boy and girl members of the New York Naval Cadets, Inc., donned gas masks last week to take part in a theoretical "gas raid" staged at 135th Street and the Hudson River, near the training ship Illinois of the New York Naval Militia.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will act as manikins in the fashion revue entitled "Abroad and At Home," which will be held during the luncheon hour Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled.

The two major requirements of any Manhattan traffic plan are new and improved arterial highway facilities for traffic to enter or leave the borough, and independent highway facilities for traffic desiring merely to pass through Manhattan, Borough President Samuel Levy told the members of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at their dinner meeting last week in the Hotel Astor.

Illinois took undisputed possession of first place in the Big Ten basketball title scramble by defeating Chicago, 28 to 22, tonight, but only after a hard battle from the lowstanding Maroons. The Illini missed numerous shots, both short and long, and at halftime Chicago held a 12-11 margin.

The Williams yearling natators captured their opening match of the season today by beating Deerfield Academy, 46--20, in Lasell pool. Sanburn of Deerfield tied the Williams varsity record of 0:56.8 in the 100-yard free-style event, while Creede starred for the home team.
Equaling the track record, Major Austin C. Taylor's Special Agent conquered a field of candidates for the coming $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap before a crowd of 15,000 at Santa Anita today.
Charles Landstone has changed the title, of his play from "Front of House" to "Behind Your Back" so as not to mystify the public.

Miss Dorothy E. Young, daughter of Mrs. Howard E. Young of Swarthmore, Pa., and the late Mr. Young, was married yesterday morning in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, to N. Hunter Keedy, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Keedy of Martinsburg, W. Va. Dr. Clinton B. Adams of Philadelphia performed the ceremony, which was followed by a wedding breakfast in the Sert Room of the hotel.
FELDMAN-SOLOMON-Mr. and Mrs. William Solomon, Pittsburgh, announce marriage of daughter, Helen, to Joseph Feldman, son of Mrs. Flora Feldman of New York.
Fears for the safety of several hundred marooned persons were intensified here tonight as relief officials appealed for 200 boats needed for rescue work.

Max Dick, president of the Home of the Sons and Daughters of Israel at 232 East Twelfth Street, died yesterday at his residence, 2,265 University Avenue, the Bronx, of heart disease at the age of 60. His widow, Mae Dick, and a daughter, Gero Georgette, survive.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Fitchen, youngest daughter of the Rev. J. Frederick Fitchen and Mrs. Fitchen to Brian Patrick Matthews of Eastburn, Yorkshire, England, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Matthews, took place this afternoon at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, of which the bride's father, who officated, is minister.

The new Polish Minister, Dr. Casimir Papee, today presented his credentials to President Eduard Benes. In brief speeches both expressed the desire to bring about a rapprochement and to eliminate points of friction between their nations, which have many close racial relations.

Old Russian ceremonials will be revived at the annual Russian naval ball which will be given by the Association of Former Imperial Russian Naval Officers the night of Feb. 4 in the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland.

Four new records were established as Dickinson High, with 35 points, captured the Hudson County interscholastic swimming championship for the second straight year at the Dickinson pool in Jersey City last night. Henry Snyder finished second with 19 and Bayonne was third with 15.

The Belgian Ambassador, Baron de Cartier de Marchienne, gave a dinner at the embassy for the French Ambassador, Charles Corbin, the Earl of Ancaster, Lady Bingham, Lord and Lady Camrose, Mrs. Arthur James and John St. Maur Ramsden and Lady Catherine Ramsden.

T. H. Lewis and J. M. Schirmer tied for the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each had 94 out of a possible 100 targets. In the shoot-off Lewis, a Class A gunner, broke 24 to triumph, Schirmer, who shoots in Class B, finishing with 23.

More time was devoted by the First Avenue Association in 1936 to the problem of the proposed East River Drive than to any other activity, according to the annual report submitted by L. Gordon Hamersley, president.

The Berkshire town of Richmond. with 557 inhabitants and 343 voters, is sending out an S O S call for a Democratic leader to succeed William H. Sherrill, who resigned this week as chairman of the Democratic Town Committee after continuous service of fifty years.

During the year 1936 there were registered in the stud book of the American Kennel Club 84,475 dogs, according to figures released yesterday by the governing body of canine affairs in the United States. This breaks all previous records in the industry of breeding thoroughbred dogs.
Once more the Council of the League of Nations, now holding its ninety-sixth session, has given European Foreign Ministers an excuse for coming together. Since the session that

Members of the Science Departments at Mount Holyoke College will cooperate with Roger W. Holmes, assistant professor of the Department of Philosophy and Psychology, in the presentation next semester of a new course covering the philosophy of the biological sciences.

Walter Harvey Close, retired wool merchant, died yesterday at his residence, 131 East Sixty-sixth Street. He was born sixty-nine years ago at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street when that now busy corner was part of a quiet residential district.

Frank J. Marshall, former United States chess champion, and A. Edward Santasiere, 'champion of the Marshall Club, yesterday played to a finish in their adjourned game from the third round of the annual Marshall Club tournament.
The Commercial Telegraphers' Union filed a brief in the Supreme Court today contending that the Wagner Labor Relations Act is constitutional.

Hans Kohn, Professor of History at Smith College, will deliver a series of lectures this month on the origin and development of democracy, under sponsorship of the department of social philosophy of Cooper Union, New York City. Dr. Kohn has lectured at the New School for Social Research in New York and has conducted public forums at Springfield, Mass., and

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ford Hall of Merrywood, Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their younger daughter, Miss Lucille Hall, to Burrall Barnum, son of Mrs. Rowena Stewart Barnum and of. Walter Barnum of this city.
Mr. and Mrs. John B. Thayer 3d of Haverford gave a dinner and dance tonight for Vicomte and Vicomtesse Eric de Spoelberch who will sail on Wednesday for their home in Brussels.
Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Phelps Merriam have announced the engagement of Mrs. Merriam's sister, Mrs. Eleanor Briggs Turner of Riverdale-on-Hudson, this city, to George C. Miles of Norfolk, Va.

The Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. quintet accounted for its second Eastern Athletic Club League triumph in eight starts by gaining a 30-29 decision over the Prudential A. A. five of Newark on the former's court last night.

After holding a fast Lawrenceville quintet to 3 points in the first half, Choate put on the pressure to vanquish its traditional rival, 26-14. Dick Davis of Choate led in scoring with 12 points, while Captain Ellis was outstanding for the losers.
LONDON. The most gigantic lark in the European motoring calendar starts from all over Europe tomorrow and ends at Monte Carlo four days later.
The Norwegian steamer Carriere, loaded with supplies for Asturian miners, was detained today by the Insurgent cruiser Espana near Aviles. The Carriere was escorted in the direction of Ferrol.

Walter Runciman's week-end visit to the White House as the first foreign guest to be received there since President Roosevelt's second inauguration has inevitably brought a train of speculation, public and private, as to the by-products that might result from what the President's household terms a purely social and friendly sojourn.
Big Chief Russell Hilbert, one-man (but plenty of him) police force of Montville Township, will learn his fate when things come out of a hat, it was decided this afternoon.

To the great discomfiture, apparently, of some of its propounders in other parts of the world, the social credit theory is slowly but inevitably approaching in Alberta its first and perhaps final test.

The Robinson-Patman law has forced voluntary and cooperative food chains to become better merchandisers and more efficient operators, because of the elimination of substantial advertising allowances, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

The International Institution founded here in connection with the Olympic games, bore strange fruit today when the International Central Bureau for Strength and Joy issued an elaborate 150-page magazine devoted almost entirely to uncamouflaged anti-Soviet and pro-Nazi propaganda.

Charges made yesterday before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage that army and navy intelligence units had worked with the National Metal Trades Association, a labor spy and strikebreaking agency, to maintain production in plants supplying government orders, were discredited today by L. A. Stringham, chief of the Eastern Spy Service, when he was recalled to the stand.
The crest of high waters which gave Pittsburgh its third highest flood of the century began rolling past Wheeling tonight without changing perceptibly the Ohio River's height.
DUTY: "Oh, yes, I'll have to wear those fancy pants and one of these coats. There's no way out of that, I suppose. The occasion demands them." -Vice President Garner, on the inaugural.

THE coming safety conference, called for Feb. 4, 5, and 6 by Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, is likely to do more than call attention to the weaknesses of radio beams, the dangers of bad weather flying and the fact that flying, advancing as fast as it has in the last ten years, still has its' problems.
Jake Powell howled loudly and joined the ranks of the holdouts when he received his 1937 contract from the New York Yankees in this morning's mail.
Franklin A. Merriam, former owner and publisher of The Argus in Mount Vernon, N. Y., and a Winter resident of Daytona Beach for more than fifteen years, died here today of a heart attack.

A party to be known as a "bundle" bridge and tea has been arranged by Mrs. Clarence Millhiser for Thursday afternoon at the Ritz Tower to aid the merchandise committee of the Irvington House Thrift Shop. Guests are requested

The wisdom and common sense of Benjamin Franklin, if applied to our national life, virtually would eliminate the pitfalls and dangers that confront the nation on its road to prosperity after seven years of depression, William Guggenheim, honorary president of the International Benjamin Franklin Society, declared in a letter read yesterday to 200 members of the society at its fourteenth annual luncheon meeting at the Hotel Plaza.

Chicago is apparently facing another suspension Monday night of essential electric services such as that experienced for almost three hours late yesterday when city electrical workers walked out and most street and traffic lights were darkened.

In a free-scoring basketball game where defense was as outmoded as the dodo bird, Manhattan vanquished the colorful troupe from Utah State, 39 to 32, to the vast entertainment of a crowd of 12,000 in Madison Square Garden last night, while Long Island University brought the unbeaten record of George Washington to an abrupt end with a 37-to-26 victory.

Ambassador and Lady Lindsay have as guests at the embassy Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, and Mrs. Runciman. Lady Lindsay will give a tea tomorrow and dinners on Feb. 8 and 11.

OUTSTANDING on many Boy Scout council programs this month is the presentation of the Silver Beaver to volunteer leaders. This award is a miniature beaver in silver, suspended from a white and blue ribbon worn around the neck.

AUGUSTA, Ga.-Social interests of the Winter colony here are centered this week on the three Roosevelt Birthday Dances to be given next Saturday night as part of the nation-wide movement to raise funds for the Warm Springs Foundation, where President Roosevelt has a home.

The arrival here late on Friday of $1,493,900 of gold from England was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Additional amounts of gold were reported to have arrived here yesterday, but were not included in the Reserve Bank's daily statement.

Several hundred women of prominence in society have subscribed to the special matinee performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "Le Coq d'Or," with Lily Pons and Ezio Pinza in the leading roles, which will be given on Feb. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the maintenance a fund of the Schola Cantorum.

THEY have landed, the first chapeaux from Paris for 1937. A goodly lot they are, full of animation and spirit. Hats are always the precursors of new styles in dress, so one may judge from these that collections now in the making in Paris (they will be shown the first week in February) will create a stir.
The latest prospect in the heavyweight ranks gets his chance Friday night in the ring at Madison Square Garden to vault right into the limelight or be lulled to sleep.

The President's pointed rebuff to John L. Lewis for publicly demanding from the administration a quid pro quo in exchange for support in the 1936 election came a little earlier than had been expected. But that it was inevitable and is the precursor of even sharper exchanges has. been plain to any observer who took note of three things.

A nation-wide drive for amendment of the Constitution to permit delegation to Congress of the power to regulate hours and wages of labor will be started Feb. 1 when the National Committee to Clarify the Constitution by Amendment is scheduled to hold its first meeting in Detroit.

Army engineers repaired a threatened break in the Mississippi River levee southeast of here today and averted, at least temporarily, the inundation of 131,000 acres of the Birds Point-New Madrid floodway. Late tonight the engineers reported the barrier still holding.

The government, in briefs filed today in its suit to compel the Appalachian Electric Power Company to obtain a Federal license for its $12,000,000 hydroelectric project near Radford, contended that New River is "navigable" under the Federal Power Act of 1920.

Uncle Robert, lecturer on safety to school children and sponsor of entertainments for children, said yesterday he expected more than 40,000 persons to attend his tenth annual Parents' Day program, May 9 on the Mall in Central Park.

Accused of trying to sell a fake stamp, which he insisted was a "five-cent red" well-known to stamp collectors, Henry R. Jarrett of Bethlehem has been convicted by a Federal Court here. In a court room crowded with philatelists, who have regarded the case as something of a "cause celebre," Judge Albert B. Maria, a stamp collector himself, yesterday
The Dartmouth Outing Club today announced complete plans for the twenty-seventh annual Winter carnival here on Feb. 5 and 6.
An exhibition commemorating the 500th anniversary of the invention of printing by Johannes Gutenberg will open tomorrow at the downtown center of New York University.
Men's clothing prices within the next few weeks will range 10 to 15 per cent higher than they were last Fall, clothing manufacturers and retailers here warn.

In connection with the National Conference for Palestine to be held in Washington Feb. 6 and 7, the United Palestine Appeal made public yesterday an economic survey on "How Many Jews Can Palestine Hold?" by Joseph L. Cohen, British member of the advisory committee on social insurance of the International Labor Organization.
W. F. McDonald, principal meteorologist of the New Orleans Weather Bureau, predicted today the Mississippi River would continue rising in the lower valley until about the middle of February.

Arrangements have been completed for the first Metropolitan Realty Conference to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday under the sponsorship of the real estate boards of New York City and Westchester County.

TWO of Manhattan's leading tourist attractions-the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Grant's Tomb-are in high favor just now with a special class of visitors whose interest in both the fine arts and patriotic shrines is negligible.

The inauguration of Paul Swain Havens as president of Wilson College has been set for the morning of May 22, the inaugural program opening May 21 with a conference on "looking forward in women's education." A reception and dinner for representatives of colleges and learned societies and other invited guests will be given May 21.

Nearly 2,000 persons in Baker Rink tonight saw the Yale hockey team combine an alert offense with spectacular defensive work and take a 5-goal lead over the Princeton sextet which dwarfed the Tigers' 3goal rally in the final frame of their International Intercollegiate League game.

BERLIN. UNDER the direction of Chemja Winawer the first European hearings of Jacob Weinberg's "Sabbath Eve Service" were recently given in Berlin. Mr. Winawer, who conducts a choir of thirty voices which has concertized with exceptional success in several of the Jewish Cultural Leagues in Germany, produced the work for the first time in October at the New Synagogue, in Berlin.

The government may demand that General Motors officials and striking automobile workers open peace negotiations, official conciliators indicated tonight. The way Secretary Perkins put it today was that if other means failed she might send out- "a formal invitation" for negotiations.
Charles A. Harrell resigned today as Binghamton City Manager to head the city administration of Schenectady. The Schenectady post will pay $11,000. Mr. Harrell's salary in Binghamton was $8,100.

In Soviet Russia recent political mass trials have been marked by the almost complete unanimity with which defendants, in the shadow of the firing squad, vied with one another in proclaiming their own guilt, in implicating fellow-conspirators, and in naming Leon Trotsky as the arch-plotter.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, replied yesterday to criticism that Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, directed on Friday against State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Orie R. Kelly and Anthony J. Kerin, who as rehabilitation trustees for 472 issues of mortgage certificates sold the mortgage servicing of the Title and Mortgage Company of Westchester County to the Hudson-Harlem Vallev Title and Mortgage Company.

The Pittsburgh district has again pulled the throttle of optimism wide open. With substantial advances in business recovery, it is now celebrating what it regards as the best evidence that it has recaptured its position as the world's steel capital.

The Marylebone Cricket Club touring team carried its overnight score from 236 runs for six wickets to 301 on the second day's play against South Australia, the home team replying with 194 for four before the close of play today.
The Alumnae Association of the College of New Rochelle will sponsor a dance for the benefit of the library building fund, to be given with the assistance of the senior class of the college.

Flashing brilliant basketball but failing to convert on ten consecutive foul tries in the second half, Williams College fell before the closing rally of Springfield College, 25 to 22, before 1,500 enthusiastic spectators at the Lasell court tonight.

Delegates at the annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association yesterday went on record as favoring the playing of the 1937 national intercollegiate championship in the East on grass courts once more.
"Early Spanish Painting" is the subject of a free lecture by Dr. Walter W. S. Cook, to be given on Wednesday evening at the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

Something has been happening here so gradually that only in the last few weeks has it been possible to pin it down definitely. It happened in the French and the Russian revolutions; so it should have been expected here.

Lee Thompson Smith, formerly vice president and secretary of Pease Elliman, has been appointed president of the Joseph P. Day Management Corporation and Vice president of Joseph P. Day, inc., beginning Feb. 1.

The marriage of Miss Marian MoAvoy, daughter of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. John V. McAvoy, to Melville H. O'Neill took place yesterday at the home of the bride, 1,120 Park Avenue. Justice McAvoy performed the ceremony in the presence of immediate relatives.

Hunter College will hold mid-year commencement exercises for more than 475 seniors on Wednesday morning at Carnegie Hall. The baccalaureate address will be given by Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Stenographers and secretaries will hear a discussion of their vocational problems and possibilities at an occupational meeting to be held at the American Woman's Association clubhouse Wednesday at 8:15 P. M.
Mrs. Geraldine A. Buerger of Philadelphia broke a bottle of champagne over the prow of the Tanker Gulftide and sent it down the ways into the Patapsco River at the Bethlehem Shipyards today.
A leading social event of the season in Fairfield County was the bachelors' ball tonight at the Fairfield County Hunt Club. The guest list included:

Sales of residences in various parts of Westchester County were reported by brokers yesterday. A deal also was closed for five acres overlooking the Bedford Golf Club in Bedford Village. The seller of the acreage was the Manufacturers Trust Company, and the buyer was D. Edward O'Brien. James F. Greene negotiated the deal.
The Burgos (Insurgent) Government is preparing to list in a card index 80,000 Spaniards with "Red or Leftist political backgrounds," according to a local paper.

An unusual kind of crib on wheels is prominently shown in the children's furniture department of one New York store. An extra-high paneled screen fence surrounds the crib, which can be used as a play pen when the child leaves babyhood behind. When he is tiny, the

A revision of the statement of the functions of the personnel bureau, the student guidance office at City College, was issued yesterday by Dr. Arthur Frank Payne, director of the bureau. The revision was made by Dr. Payne and his two assistants, Dr. George Forlano and James Perry.

A study of youth residing in Essex County, N. J., which reveals a disheartening picture of widespread unemployment, low wages and misdirected vocational training in the schools is soon to be published by the Research Center at the University of Newark.

This city, pioneer settlement of the Northwest territory, paradoxically was wet and dry today. Ohio River waters, expected to reach a fortyeight-foot crest, swirled in the streets, but there was not a-drop of liquor to be had. The State Liquor Department closed its store and bars followed suit.

With the peak of the arrivals here of out-of-town jobbers to be reached this week, they have already placed a volume of Fall business larger than at any time in nearly twenty year, reports here yesterday indicated.

It has been a long time since a filly was best of the 3-year-olds, but today the first big test of the year for horses of that age, the Hialeah Stakes, saw the only two fillies in the race finish one, two at Hialeah Park. Log won in the colors of E. D. Shaffer of Chicago and made it four in a row in this State, where she is undefeated.

IT must be some kind of record. The first six weeks of the Metropolitan Opera season-this week' is included-do not find a single opera by Giacomo Puccini performed or scheduled for performance. It seems hardly possible that
Sixty-five Americans, reported to be en route to Spain to fight for the government despite an official warning from the United States, landed here tonight from the liner Paris.

The New York Athletic Club quintet remained undefeated in Eastern Athletic Club League play by defeating the Columbus Council, K. of C., 54-24, for its fourth straight circuit triumph at the New York A. C. last night. William Conroy tallied fifteen points for the winners, who led, 25--13, at half time.

Seward Park High and Benjamin Franklin High, two of the four local quintets seeing action, came through with victories yesterday in the fifth of a series of scholastic basketball bills at Madison Square Garden. A gathering of 4,000 saw

Having only a description of the car and its occupant, the Holland Tunnel police recently stopped a young woman about to enter the tunnel en route to Florida and gave her an important telephone message.
Hitler has accomplished "far more" than Roosevelt in coping with unemployment, Professor Julius Richter of the University of Berlin said yesterday after his arrival from Germany on the Deutschland.

ELEVEN portraits by early Amercan painters have been placed on view at the Macbeth Gallery, where they may be seen until Feb. 1. Several of these were lentthe Stuart portrait of-Colonel William Stephens Smith by Herbert L. Pratt; the Copley (a dark canvas,

Although the completion this past week of a rather dismal metropolitan squash racquets Class A championship of nine starting entries would seem to deny that the squash season is nearing its height or that the general interest and caliber of play has increased tremendously this year, it is nevertheless true that squash as a Winter sport for women has picked up considerably.

In a basketball game which was in doubt until the final whistle, the Lafayette freshmen defeated the Hill School five, 30--24, today. Rallying in the fourth quarter, the visitors went into the lead on baskets by Thom and Fitzpatrick after being deadlocked at 19-19 at the end of the third quarter.

The first of two After Dinner Dances for this season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The subscribers for the annual series are young matrons and former debutantes, each of whom is entitled to two guest's cards for men.
With radio, stage and screen stars sponsoring decorated tables, the first Spring china, glass and housewares show will open to members of the trade today at the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 200

Officials announced today a record number of nominations, 109, for the Nursery Stakes No. 1 at Hialeah Park on Feb. 13. It is a three-furlong straightaway event for 2-year old colts and geldings only.

St. Joseph's College basketball team regained its winning stride tonight, whipping the Pennsylvania Military College quintet of Chester, 50--23. The Hawks bad little trouble, taking the lead at the start and having a margin at half-time of 23-10.

Irving Freeman, 23 years old, of 1,116 Kelly Street, the Bronx, was arrested about 5 P. M. yesterday on a charge of attempted kidnapping after relatives of Nicholas Loiacomo, 2 1/2, said Freeman was walking away with the child when they prevented him.

The assets of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company at the close of last year amounted to $209,882,551, an increase of $14,489,000 during the year, Arthur M. Collens, president, says in his annual report for 1936. Insurance in force at the end of the year was $610,499,294, a net gain of $20,635,000 over 1935.

Hospital authorities held hope tonight for the life of a tiny baby girl survivor of quadruplets born Thursday in a rural St. Thomas farmhouse. Two brothers and a sister of the baby, Marie Rita Rondeau, died yesterday in St. Justine Hospital incubators, to which they had been rushed over icy roads, on which the ambulance crashed into a snow-plow.

The wrought iron gates of St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity parish, swung open yesterday afternoon after being closed for three days in accordance with a custom begun in 1766 that annually establishes the church's right to keep its yard from becoming a public thoroughfare.

New York business men interested in the foreign trade zone or free port to be established on and around the $30,000,000 city piers at Stapleton, S. I., have been notified that the official opening of the zone will take place on Feb. 1, as required by the Federal permit issued to the city last year.

Burdett Kipp of Alger Park, Bronxville, a civil engineer, who had been engaged on much subway construction in New York, died yesterday in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a short illness, at the age of 62.

Fifteen acres of woodland have been added to the Connecticut Arboretum at Connecticut College in a gift from forty donors interested in the development of the arboretum. The names of all the donors have been affixed to the deed, which specifies that the property shall be set aside forever as a wild-life preserve.
THE aviation industry will stress an educational program next Thursday with the first National Aviation Show held in New York in seven years. This year's show will

IF Clayton Glyn, an amiable and charming but unromantic English squire, had not been bored by his wife's rhapsodies over the blueness of Swiss lakes and the whiteness of Swiss mountain tops-and if his wife had not been too conscientiously respectable to seek more sympathetic companionship elsewhere-the world would have missed an outstanding succes de scandale in the way of fiction.

Adolf Wagner, now Bavarian Minister of Education and Minister of the Interior, issued an order forbidding churches to have services for children on Sundays except between the hours of 7 and 9 A. M. so attendance at church will not interfere with the Hitler Youth exercises.

The Board of Estimate favors reduring the 10 per cent penalty on real estate tax arrears to the former rate of 7 per cent, Controller Frank J. Taylor last night told 1,000 attending the annual dinner of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at the Hotel St. George.

Governor Lehman is expected to submit to the Legislature by Feb. 1 the largest budget in the history of the State, possibly as high as $365,000,000, according to indications here today. The exact figure will depend in a large degree on how much he will recommend for appropriation out of current revenue for financing the unemployment relief program.

The General Alumin Society of the University of Pennsylvania, at the close of exercises today honoring the university's founder, Benjamin Franklin, adopted a resolution requesting that if the face of Abraham Lincoln is transferred to a new nickel, Franklin's likeness be placed on the penny.

Heinrich Mataja, former Foreign Minister of Austria, died today after a stroke. He was 60 years old. Dr. Mataja was appointed Foreign Minister in the Cabinet of Premier Rudolf Ramek in November, 1924. Previously he had been

The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the New York Rangers, 4-0, in their third National Hockey League clash of the season at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. It had been the other way in the previous meetings, the Rangers winning, 5 to 1 and 5 to 3.
A lawyer's brief should be all that its name implies and the lower the court the briefer the brief, Federal Judge Phillip Forman commented today.
Mayor La Guardia's Committee on City Planning announces that a national planning exhibition and institution will be held under its auspices next Fall at the American Museum of Natural History.
THE technique of making hooked rugs. widely used in fashioning quaint early American floor coverings, bids fair to become an important modern handicraft.

Union College students will be heard in eight round-table discussions that will be broadcast internationally because of the success in inaugurating these informal debates last year by the college International Relations Club. Arrangements were completed today to start the series on Feb. 1 and continue every second Monday night thereafter until May 10.

Sale of the Gables, an estate of twenty-one acres at Warwick, N. Y., was reported yesterday by the National Real Estate Clearing House. J. S. Thompson of New York was the buyer, and W. Sanford Durland acted as broker.

On his old page of The Saturday Review of Literature Mr. HENRY S. CANBY writes pleasantly, and for the most part tolerantly, of " Rights and Wrongs in English." The usual whack at "newspaper usage" may be passed over; for one reason, because there is no such thing.
LONDON.-The scheme to encircle Greater London with a narrow belt of parks, open spaces and playgrounds, within reasonable distance of the city's center, is nearing completion.

ADELMANN-Delta, beloved wife of the late John H. and mother of Irene Velten, Loretta Kelly, Harold and Victor Adelmann, on Jan. 23, in her sixty-second year at her home, 115-42 Lincoln St., South Ozone Park. Solemn Requiem Mass on Tuesday. Jan. 26, at 10 A. M., at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.
