Members of the Drama Department of the Junior Woman's Club of Maplewood will give a performance of "This Thing Called Love," a comedy by Edwin Burke, Saturday, at their clubhouse in Woodland Road, Maplewood, N. J. In the cast will be Janet Smith, Virginia Lichtle, Helen Reiss, Dorothy Braun, August Baum Jr., Frederick W. Hopping, Martin Mauss, Robert K. Ostrander and M. Winslow Smith Jr.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

The pockets of 196 members of the Madison Square Boys' Club were emptied and appraised Friday night at the third annual pocketcensus-taking at the club headquarters, 312 East Thirtieth Street. The pockets yielded $7.18, showing an increase of 1.9 per cent over last year's pocket-census, which Albert B. Hines, director of the

Basketball's first game, staged in a Springfield college gymnasium in 1892 with nine-man teams, will be reproduced in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday between the two games of a college court doubleheader that will mark the fortyfifth anniversary of the sport.

To the Music Editor: One cannot refrain from saying "It's about time!" that, at long last, the critics have doffed their uniforms of soporific technical hairsplitting and paid adequate, long overdue homage to one of the few genuinely great artists of the age, Mme. Lotte Lehmann.

AS I WAS SAYING. By G. K. Chesterton. 228 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead Co. $2.50. IT is hard to imagine the Eng lish literary landscape without the hulking figure of G. K. Chesterton. Awkward in appearance, he had all the grace of an awkward person when he is graceful. This extended to his speech. I remember a P. E. N.

Miss Rita Kiernan, daughter of former Alderman and Mrs. James F. Kiernan of Brooklyn, will be married to W. John Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Devine of Ozone Park, L. I., on the morning of Feb. 6 at St. Mary, Mother of Jesus Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

Eddie Maguire, Irish middleweight, and Eric Seelig of Germany battled to a draw in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night. A capacity crowd of 3,500 fans saw the battle, which was evenly waged throughout. Maguire scaled 165 1/2 pounds and Seelig 163 1/4.

Notre Dame's basketball team came through with a brilliant rally in the last seven minutes to turn apparent defeat into a fine 41-36 triumph over a fighting Pennsylvania five at the Palestra tonight before a capacity crowd which jammed every inch of space in the vast arena.

Seven skeletons, believed to be those of war veterans who perished in the Labor Day hurricane of 1935, were found yesterday by workmen rebuilding the Overseas Highway to Key West at Lower Matecumbe Key.
The Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor reported today an encouraging decline in the infant mortality rate and a slight decline in the maternal mortality rate.
Late data issued by W. C. Devercaux, meteorologist, indicated no change in the expected river crest of 73 to 73.5 feet for Cincinnati, but revised crests for several points as follows:

With Anthony Eden's dramatic appeal to Germany to drop her supernationalistic ambitions and ideological crusades and join the rest of Europe in "economic collaboration and political appeasement of the Continent," the challenge of the Western powers to the whole National Socialist program and the fateful- choice they have been putting up to Chancellor Adolf Hitler are now being given official standing and concrete formulation.

Rutgers University has more than forty of its alumni active in the governmental affairs of New Jersey, Ernest E. McMahon, alumni secretary, announced today. This, he said, was in keeping with President Robert C. Clothier's policy that the university train its students for leadership in the life of the Commonwealth.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Elliott Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Gordon Wilson of this city and the late Dr. Wilson, to Dr. Herbert Budington Wilcox Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Wilcox of New York.

Viriginia's boxers opened their home season tonight with a splendid 6 1/2-1 1/2 victory over Virginia Polytechnic Institute. The Cavaliers required only fourteen rounds for their triumph before a crowd of 4,700.

Special study opportunities will be given beginning next Fall to students of exceptional aiblity at the New Jersey College for Women who major in history, economics or sociology, it was announced today. A plan by which such
Dean Clay Osborne, an organizer and chairman of the board, of the Dentists Supply Company of New York, died yesterday at his home, 839 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 69.

Suburbanites are seldom thought of as intellectuals who would rather study than play. Yet that comes near to being the case this Winter in South Orange and Maplewood, N. J. Six o'clock trains bring in loads of home-coming commuters eager to tear through dinner to get over to the community Adult School for the course on Shakespeare or consumers' chemistry.

UPROARIOUS Latin laughter and shouted conversational ripostes that made even the switchboard girl at the Lambs Club wince in something like terror announced to the neighborhood of Times Square, on a certain afternoon last week, that Leo Carrillo had come to town.

The Blue Ridge Industrial School, in Greene County, Va., which provides agricultural training and domestic science for more than 200 boys and girls from isolated mountain districts, will be the beneficiary of the annual Blue Ridge ball to be held Friday night at the Plaza.

A CANVASS of the automobile situation in the metropolitan area last week indicated that while there was as yet- no general shortage of 1937 cars to deliver to the buying public, the supplies in dealers' hands and the relative condition among dealers were decidedly "spotty."

William Agnew Johnston, for more than fifty years a member of the State Supreme Court, died unexpectedly of heart disease at his home today. His age was 89. He retired as chief justice July 1, 1935. He wrote more than 3,500 judicial opinions.

Chaste Toyen of Newark has been appointed by the East Newark Realty Corporation as agent for the former Clark Thread Mills property in East Newark, N. J., consisting of fifty-three buildings containing more than 1,000,000 sq. ft. of manufacturing space. More than half of the space has been leased. The properties now are owned by the corporation.

A dance will be given on Friday at the Ambassador under the auspices of the alumnae of Notre Dame de Lourdes Academy to aid the educational work of the French nuns of Sainte Ursule de la Sainte Vierge. The order, whose mother house in Bruges, Belgium, maintains a convent in Tours, France, and one in Rome.
CONCERNING books on Chekhov one feels much as Kipling felt concerning tribal lays: there are five and forty ways of composing them and every blessed one of them is right, or at least intereating.

Scor ing 23 points in the last two periods to Andover's 4, the Northeastern freshmen spoiled the clean slate of the home quintet today, winning by 34 to 20. With Andover leading by 16 to 11 at the end of the second period, the visitors riddled the Andover defense in the two final stanzas to Rain a well-deserved victory.

Suits are being instituted in several State courts by local bar associations, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to debar real estate brokers from drawing up the ordinary instruments of agreement which form a large part of their business and even to make it necessary to employ a lawyer to draw the papers for practically every phase of a real estate transaction.

Splendid teamwork carried the pace-setting First Division riders to their fifth straight Metropolitan Indoor Polo League victory at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night as they downed the Winmont Farms team, 14 1/2 to 8.
OF the two new plays this week, one has been written by Henri Decoin, the husband of the young film star, Danielle Darrieux, in order that she should play the chief part in it.

SLUM clearance and housing are once again commanding widespread attention in New York The "emergency" shortage of low-rental dwellings recently moved Mayor La Guardia to institute public hearings looking toward remedial legislation.

Mrs. Frank H. Gunther and her daughter, Miss Priscilla Gunther gave a luncheon yesterday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Miss Audrey Hobbs, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Hobbs. .

The engagement of Miss Marjorie M. Lovett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Lovett of this city, to Chester L. Duff Jr. of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester L. Duff of Syracuse, has been announced by her parents.

Cornell's indoor polo trio conquered Penn Military College, 20-12, in the riding hall tonight. Tommy Lawrence, Cornell's No. 2, scored 11 goals and was charged with only one foul. Ryan, P. M. C.'s No. 1, also starred.
As the Seventy-fifth Congress assembles its first session chart of potential worries and headaches it finds one phase of its prospects highly comforting. Its chances of acute

THE first of the seven departments of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts to celebrate its half-century anniversary is the Department of Prints, just turning its fiftieth year on Feb. 1. To give some idea of the department's resources and to mark the occasion an extensive exhibition has been opened to remain on view until March 10.

The campaign for government-subsidized housing for low-income groups was discussed today by President Roosevelt and Nathan Straus of New York, who called at the White House for a conference on the bill to be introduced next week by Senator Wagner.

THE two hundredth anniversary of the birth of Thomas Paine, which is to be celebrated next Friday, is a thought-provoking reminder of the element of chance that enters into the making of human reputations. The late Theodore Roosevelt, who should have known better, called Paine a "filthy little atheist." The self-styled "freethinkersrs" of

Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club, second seeded player, led the field of thirty-five players into the third round of the fifteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today. Moore defeated C G. M. Ives of the Yale Club and d Philip B. Lawrence of Elizabeth, b both by scores of 15--9, 15-10.

The public schools have an obligation in their teaching to maintain the principles of democracy and encourage support of the political philosophy of the nation, according to Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, Superintendent of Schools of Previdence and chairman of the educational policies commission of the National Education Association.

Miss Kathryn Elsa Prudhon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Prudhon of this city, was married this afternoon to Dr. Robert Peterson Boyd, son of Charles Boyd of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Mrs. Boyd. The Rev. Clifford Wesley Collins of the Congregational church performed the ceremony in the home of the bride's parents.

The first showing of its second program of foreign motion pictures will be offered by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library at 8:30 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History. The program, entitled

A high-class residential development in which the projected homes will range in price from $12,500 to $25,000 is being started in Montclair on a fifteen-acre tract known as Stonewood Park. Martin T. Flanagan, builder and owner of the property, has made arrangements with the New Jersey FHA office for financing every house under the long-term single mortgage system.

Every time one of a dozen picked men students on the Swarthmore College campus becomes angry he interrupts his activity to jot down the circumstances and his reaction, whether passive or violent. This is part of an experimental study being conducted by members of the experimental and child psychology classes under the direction of Dr. Edwin Newman and Mrs.

The, Eta Circle of Omioron Delts Kappa, national honorary fraternity for men, honored six men at a tapping service last Monday evening in Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall at the College of William and Mary. Those elected for membership were the following: Lee D: Callans of Hopewell, Va.; Frank Livesay of

MADRID-a city under siege, vibrating to the thunder of guns and the crunching of air bombs. Life goes on, but it is not the life of a normal city; rather the furtive, hidden life of people who one moment dare danger and the next shrink from it into the nearest hiding place. It is a city riven and wrecked, filled with debris, more damaged

The resignation of the Japanese Cabinet, announced yesterday, is no solution of the parliamentary crisis and merely postpones the settlement of the crucial conflict between the Army and the political parties.

The marriage of Miss Emily Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lanier Lawrence of this community, and Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr., son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Frelinghuysen of New York and Far Hills, N. J., took place this afternoon at St. Marks Episcopal Church.

Member of the 'English-Speaking Union have taken over the performance on Feb. 8 ofPhilip Howard's dramatization of James Hilton's novel, "And Now Goodbye," with Philip Merivale in the leading role, for the benefit of their scholarship fund. Tickets for the performance
Bob Feller may be a strike-out king to the Cleveland Indians, but he's just another schoolboy to education authorities at Van Meter, Iowa.

Erle Reiter, 20-year-old contender for national figure skating honors and a member of last year's Olympic team, added his name to the Henry W. Howe Trophy by outclassing his two rivals in both free skating and school figures to win the men's senior event of the Snobirds' annual competition tonight.

Journalism thrives at Yale, so much so that 328 undergraduates are willing to forego their leisure time to write and work for the four of the student publications, The Yale Daily News, The Yale Literary Magazine, The Yale Record and The Yale Scientific Magazine. The closing of the editorial year of the publications finds them exerting a larger, stronger and more direct influence on student life.

The Friends of the Sick Poor will give their annual card party on Friday afternoon at the Plaza for the benefit of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor, whose headquarters are located at 140 West Sixty-first Street. The sisters minister to the destitute sick in their homes, without compensation and without regard to race, creed or color; and also distribute baskets

Out of President Roosevelt's power policy committee, named the past week, is expected to come a concrete national program for power rates and dealings with private utilities which at the same time will settle the present conflict within the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The mine and plant of Johns-Manville Company, Ltd., were tied up today after a walkout of 1,150 employes last night. Strikers claimed that their demands for increased wages went unheeded. Negotiations opened today and there were no disturbances.
Mr. and Mrs. Tom Duke were burned to death and their three children were probably fatally injured by being sprayed with gasoline in the locked kitchen of their farm home near here today.

THE full significance of outline and detail of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" will never be entirely grasped by the American public unless and until this "fantastic opera" is adequately translated and sung in English and a stage manager both great and practical directs a performance given by highly intelligent and distinguished artists.

Mrs. James Paulding Murdoch of this place has announced the engagement of her younger daughter, Miss Mary Paulding Murdoch, to Hugh McDonald Martin Jr. of Washington, D. C., son of the Rev. Hugh McDonald Martin of Fredericksburg, rector emeritus of Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, Rapidan.

A St. Valentine's supper dance under the auspices of the New York State Chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will be held Feb. 5 in the Cascades of the Biltmore to raise funds for the philanthropic enterprises of the organization.

In spite of snow-covered fields and a flurry of sleet in the faces of hounds and horses, the Meadow Brook Hunt, in charge of Harry T. Peters of Islip, left the kennels on the Robert E. Rod estate this morning for a chase through the Burden, Maynard and Aldrich estates.

A fashion show and luncheon for the benefit of the Little Missionary Day Nursery will be held on Feb. 9 in the Regency Rooms of the Carlyle. Guests have been requested to bring packages of articles suitable for resale in the Thrift Shop maintained for the benefit of the organization.

The midseason dance of the Greenwich cotillion was attended by 100 members of the younger set at the Milbrook Country Club tonight. Miss Mary Alice Wall of Riverside and Curtis Sanford entertained guests for dinner at their homes prior to the cotillion.

THE air tourist is becoming a definite picture against the sky. More and more he is visiting distant parts of the United States on week-end trips arranged by the transport companies, and also is going on longdistance all-expense cruises to foreign lands.

The Department of Health reported 58 new influenza cases and130 new pneumonia cases for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 10 A. M. yesterday. This was a decrease of 10 influenza and an increase of 9 pneumonia cases as compared with the preceding twenty-four-hour period.

The annual supper dance under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of Mount Saint Vincent will be held Friday at Sherry's. Miss Anna C. Dowling heads the group in charge of the arrangements and assisting her are Mrs. Francis J. Quillinan, Miss Ella Galvin, Miss Mary Needham and Miss Loraine Swin.

Facing a student enrollment which has increased in the last few years from 2,000 to 4,000, Stanford University at Palo Alto, Calif., is beginning an impressive program of building expansion. In addition to a memorial theatre and an open-air amphitheatre planned to seat 15,000, already under way, ground will be broken this month for a new $525,000 education building.

STAMPS issued for charitable purposes have been holding the spotlight on the philatelic stage recently Collectors have been kept busy during the past month. gathering new sets printed by at least- a score of foreign countries in -behalf of various wrthy causes.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General, who is expected to leave the Roosevelt Cabinet within five or six months, said yesterday that he had received several offers to return to private business, but declined to discuss their nature.

Inability of sighted workers to accomplish the task with any degree of skill or speed has resulted in the employment of forty blind persons in the manufacture of electric gramophones designed to play the "talking books" of the American Foundation for the Blind, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Health Department drive against subway smokers and spitters has resulted so far in the issuance of 721 summonses, Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday. The summonses were given out during two-hour periods Thursday morning and Friday afternoon.

THE Emil Hertzka prize contest for 1937 is open to composers of all countries. The award of 1,000 Austrian schillings (about $200) will be given for the best choral work submitted. Choruses may be sacred or secular, a cappella or accompanied, and preferably fifteen to twenty minutes in performing time.

In a clear, colorless voice, as precise and unemotional as that of a professor addressing his class, Gregory Piatakoff, former Assistant Commissar for Heavy Industry, today threw away his life and the lives of his sixteen fellow-accused as their trial as conspirators against the Soviet regime began.

After more than forty years of service, the Consumers League of New York has taken stock of itself, analyzed its sphere of usefulness, inquired whether its work could be carried on by any other organization now extant, answered itself in the negative, and has set to with determination on a revised program.

Robert H. Hutchins. president of the University of Chicago, will be the principal speaker at the annual luncheon of the New York City Association of Teachers of English on Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

AT long last, as the Duke of Windsor said to the world, we are going to play again. This city, where the legitimate theatre has been in its deaththroes for several years, has suddenly become -drama-conscious.

It was a saying among railroad men forty years ago that if the Spencer family went on strike, the New York, New Haven Hartford lines would cease to operate. Today only one of twelve members of the Spencer family of West Stockbridge once employed by the railroad is with the company.

THE annual rush of music's young hopefuls is on. They are flowing steadily into New York, the music center of America, from every State and nation; and all have two objectives-fame and fortune. They are practitioners of every musical skill; they sing, they play the violin, piano or 'cello, and they manipulate even the bull fiddle or the xylophone.

Wild game, as well as human beings, felt the scourge of flood today in the far-flung lowland regions of the Mississippi River valley. Rabbits, although good swimmers, took to floating debris and protruding objects.

Five discussions of Spanish life and the Spanish war situation will comprise the annual series of liberal arts lectures at the Pennsylvania State College, beginning Feb. 23, Professor J. H. Frizzell, chairman of the committee, announced today. The series will open with an address by Dr. Francis J. Tschan, Professor of European History, on "The Decline of Spanish Greatness."

Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Tinker of New York, who have taken Guy Murchie's house for the season, entertained last evening at dinner Sir Bede Clifford, K. C. M. G., Governor of the Bahamas, and Lady Clifford. Mr. and
Six-year-old twins, a boy and a girl, both deaf and practically blind and mute, today began their schooling at Perkins Institution for the Blind--thanks to a suggestion of Helen Keller.

ONE of the ultimate results of President Roosevelt's plan for Federal reorganization would be abolition of the Federal Communications Commission and. the transfer of its functions and personnel to the Commerce Department, which supervised radio and other forms of communication until the formation of the Federal Radio Commission on Feb. 23, 1926.

Defeating Arthur S. Cookman Jr. of the Englewood Field Club in the final, Ralph M. De Mott of the Montclair A. C. won the first annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament for New Jersey players at the Essex Club today. He gained a year's possession of the John R. Hardin Perpetual Trophy.

Miss Mary Van Stavoren McCoy, whose career as a medical laboratory technician, hospital departmental superintendent and Red Cross nurse extended over nearly forty years and included service in China as well as in various cities in this country, died yesterday in Kane Pavilion, 4,422 Third Avenue, the Bronx.

MAMMOTH CAVE, Ky. THE Mammoth Cave area's first eight months as a national park not only have seen a 10 per cent increase in tourist attendance over the record-breaking total of 1935, but a remarkably changed atmosphere in this region, which has been visited by world travelers for 100 years.

A five-inch snowfall paved the bottom of the West Canada Creek, Black River and other streams of the Southwestern Adirondacks this week, according to reports of lumbermen, trappers and members of a camping party.

The Advertising Federation of America, through Alfred T. Falk, director of its bureau of research and education, declared yesterday that the production and distribution of General Motors products accounted for "something like onetwentieth of the economic activity of the United States."

Featured at its start by perhaps the sharpest conflict of views which has ever marked an annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, that gathering of merchants last week nevertheless made several solid contributions to the progress of distribution, retail executives agreed.

Finding the basket much more accurately than in any previous game this season, the Naval Academy won from Lafayette on the local court today by 63 to 33. The victory gave the Navy team an edge in its games for the first time this season, four having been won to three lost.

The $200 prize and the two honorary mentions in the annual collaborative competition sponsored by the Association of the Alumni of the American Academy in Rome were all won by teams from the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday.

Emphasis is being placed on the practical aspects of architecture, as well as study of the economic, sociological and geographic factors influencing structural design in the Department of Architecture of the College of Fine Arts at Syracuse University.

Sickness and looting spread over the flood-stricken area of Southern Indiana tonight. Governor M. Clifford Townsend placed the city of Aurora under martial law when officials reported abandoned homes and stores were being looted and local officers were unable to cope with the situation.

ONLY twenty States and the District of Columbia have standard drivers' license laws, according to the Automobile Manufacturers Association, which is supporting the efforts of almost a dozen nationally recognized safety organizations to bring. about, through legislation, standard laws for all the States.

Members of the Ivy Club for Girls, with two exceptions, are practicing old songs popular half a century ago, to sing on their fiftieth anniversary to be observed at a dinner Tuesday at the Hotel Empire.

Mayor La Guardia, whose public addresses of late have been studded with wisecracks reminiscent of the best days of Jimmy Walker, is by preference an extemporaneous speaker. Only when occasion demands it, usually in the case of radio speeches, does he read from a prepared manuscript.
Yale romped into second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by outscoring Cornell, 49 to 39, before 1,800 enthusiasts in the Payne-Whitney Gymnasium.

IT is ironic and tragic, too, that we cannot praise Hollywood for its courage without mocking it for its cowardice. "Black Legion," which the Warners are showing at the Strand, is one of the most courageous, forthright and bitter editorials the screen has written. Its indictment of the hooded

Justice Thomas J. Nolan of Special Sessions died yesterday morning at his home, 9 Madison Street, at the age of 64. He became ill last Monday and suffered a stroke on Wednesday. He was born on the lower East Side and spent his entire life In the same neighborhood, a neighborhood which produced many famous figures in New York political life.

The American people were called upon in a proclamation today to contribute promptly and generously to the relief fund of $2,000,000 which the American Red Cross is raising as a minimum sum necessary to aid the victims of the floods in the Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys.
Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 1,115,840 shares. All classes of bonds irregular; transactions, $7,001,700.

McGill University Redmen swamped Queen's University 11-2 today in an international intercollegiate ice hockey league contest. The Montreal Collegians scored in every period. The Redmen, undefeated in four starts, now top the standing in the loop with Toronto, University of Montreal and Harvard tagging close at their heels.
The General Motors Corporation plans to exhaust every legal remedy to compel sit-down strikers to evacuate its plants and to exert pressure on Governor Murphy and the courts to that end.
Donald Reed of the publishing department of Grosset Dunlap will be the guest speaker at a tea and literary discussion of the Marymount College Literary Society in Butler Hall here tomorrow afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The annual Atlantic City Ice Carnival will be held on the Convention Hall rink on Feb. 21, with outstanding national and international skaters taking part. It is being staged by the Philadelphia Skating Club, under the auspices of the Atlantic City Business and Professional Women's Club.

Although the net changes in the stock market averages last week were comparatively small, the week did experience an improvement in the quality of leadership. The dividing line in the market in this respect was at midday on Wednesday, when President Roosevelt delivered his inaugural address.

Jasmine and azaleas, Gloire de Lorraine begonias and Roman hyacinths, feathery heaths offsetting clumps of Paper-White and Solell d'Or narcissi-such is the scene arranged for visitors to the special display house in the main conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden, open daily, 10 to 3 o'clock.

Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont and Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow have joined with the American Committee of International House at Geneva in planning a reception tomorrow for Dr. Manley 0. Hudson, judge of the Court of International Justice at The Hague.
The New York Junior League Glee Club has sent out invitations for its fifteenth annual concert to be given on the night of Feb. 5 at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Women, who do the majority of the spending for the family, may learn how best to save and invest their funds at a finance meeting to be held tomorrow at 8 P. M. at the Biltmore Hotel by the New York League of Business and Professional Women. Miss Isabella Henderson will preside.

Grosvenor B. Clarkson, who in December, 1918, succeeded Walter S. Gifford as director of the Council of National Defense, of which he was a member for three years, 1917-20, died yesterday in the Harbor Sanitarium, 667 Madison Avenue, at the age of 54.

Spain was the chief, indeed almost the only, subject discussed in a two-hour meeting that Colonel General Hermann Goering had with Premier Benito Mussolini between his arrival from Naples this morning and his departure for Berlin this evening.

LOS ANGELES. UNDOUBTEDLY the most convincing demonstration of the wide popularity of Winter sports is that which comes from a Summer land. Southern California, where, the natives like to brag, the sun passes the Winter, is wild over all sorts of snow and ice games, having suddenly realized that it has close at hand an unsurpassed Winter sports land.

Between those things in which a college girl is interested and those of which she might make a plain bread-and-butter proposition in a workaday world not so very remote lies a wide gulf, according to Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, managing director of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations at Connecticut College, New London.

Brooklyn Prep stretched its winning streak to four games by deeating the La Salle Military Academy sextet, 4--0, in the opening match of a Private Schools Ice Hockey League double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. St. John's Prep downed Poly Prep, 1 to 0, in the other contest.

Mrs. Zenas Sears gave a dinner tonight at the Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. E. G. Howes, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Dobyne, Mr. and Mrs. W. R. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Gedney, Mr. and Mrs. Loring Q. White, Mr. and Mrs. G. Horton Glover, Mr. and

A fire in the chimney of the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street, near Fifth Avenue, caused a crowd to collect shortly after 6 o'clock last night when fire engines arrived. Automobile traffic in the block, between Sixth and Fifth Avenues, was cut off for about twenty minutes.

The hard-working New York Rangers, who have fallen into rather a slump of late, hope to check their string of home reverses tonight when they engage the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The upward trend in big league baseball salaries will send the aggregate payroll beyond $3,000,000 for 1937, an Associated Press survey indicated yesterday. The total for the sixteen major league clubs will be the highest since 1930-31, the peak years.

While Canadian provinces and New England States will exploit the advantages of hunting and fishing in their respective areas, the more than quarter million spectators expected at the annual National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace will be told by motion pictures and speeches of the interesting spots along the Long Island and New Jersey shorefronts.

Some of the annual and semiannual magazines put out at the turn of the year by New York City high school students are as professional looking as offerings on public magazine stands. And the contents are surprisingly mature.

Miss Claribel Mitchell Banks daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Banks of East Orange, was married to John Dickerson Elliott of Philadelphia, son of Mrs. John G. Elliott, also of East Orange, formerly of Tuxedo Park, N. Y. and the late Mr. Elliott,

THE COVERED BRIDGE. By Cornelia Meigs. Illustrated by Marguerite de Angeli. 145 pp. New York: The Macmilan Company. $2. CORNELA MEIGS may be depended upon to provide a story that has not only interest but a fine integrity, and her books, with their authentic pictures of American life, shed a light over many periods of this country's history.

This State is noted for its unusual and vivid public officials, but the State Senate is now meeting in stormy session at Olympia under a politician unique in Washington's history, Lieut. Gov. Victor A. Meyers. Five years ago Vic, as he wants to be called, was the leader of a jazz band in a Seattle night club.

Total assets of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company at the close of last year amounted to $291,429,494, a new high record, James Lee Loomis, president, said in his annual report to stockholders, which was made public yesterday. Total income last year was $55,626,964, an increase of $741,176 from that of 1935, while surplus increased $847,758 to $10,858,887.

A collection of sixty ancient Chinese bone relies, bearing inscriptions said to have been written more than 3,000 years ago, has been lent to Columbia University. They are regarded by Dr. L. Carrington Goodrich, Chinese expert at Columbia, who departed for the Orient via Europe yesterday, as "by far the most fruitful archaeological find" yet unearthed in China.
To the Drama Editor: Many of the season's dramas are overlooking an important factor. when they disregard the importance of incidental or thematic music in their presentation.

REVENUE passenger miles flown by the United States domestic air lines during the month of December reached 35,000,000, a 77 per cent increase over the 19,820,000 for December, 1935, Colonel E, S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, announced last week.

WHEN the big red second hands of the many Radio City clocks fleetingly weep across 8 o'clock on Monday nights an audience of thirty or forty persons looks down from glass-enclosed balconies on the scene in that acoustically perfect' compartment of broadcasting known as "Studio 3-C."
The debris-laden Ohio River, moving sluggishly at unprecedented flood stage, claimed tonight its fifth and sixth lives in the Greater Cincinnati region.

AN ACTOR NAMED MOLIERE. By Dussane. Translated from the French by. Lewis Galantiere. 304 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, $2.50. A NUMBER of French publishers have during recent years established various series of brief popular biographies of literary and other figures.

A concerted effort to bring about prompt adoption of the proposed new Building Code for New York has been started by realty groups, civic organizations and builders who are convinced that the long delay in passage of the measure has been retarding the rate of recovery in construction operations here.

New York's air was slightly cleaner last year than in 1935 and considerably cleaner than the average for the last seven years, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park. The observatory is maintained by the Department of Parks under the direction of the United States Weather Bureau.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Ellen Douglas Bruce Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane of Westover, Va., to Frederick S. Fisher Jr., son of Frederick S. Fisher of this city and the late Mrs. Ottilie P. Fisher.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 9 totaled 286,912,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 747,000 barrels, comprising a drop of 842,000 barrels in domestic crude but a rise of 95,000 barrels in foreign crude.
NANKING.-Tourists who arrive in China with cameras after meeting disappointing obstacles to picture-taking in Japan and Russia quickly discover that China, too, has become camera-shy.

LONDON-In the current year the British regular army will need 35,000 fresh recruits in order to make up the wastage of men leaving various branches of the service; but at the present rate of voluntary recruiting it is unlikely that more than 21,000 will be obtained.
Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson has been advised by the Scotland Yard detectives who guarded her during her first weeks at Cannes not to return to England.

Funeral services for Dr. Alexander H. Phillips, former chairman of the Princeton University Department of Geology, were held at Trinity Episcopal Church this afternoon. Burial was at the Lawrenceville (N. J.) Cemetery.

Chairman William C. Duell of the Board of Supervisors will announce on Monday the personnel of a fiveman committee of supervisors which has been authorized by the board to survey the vocational education needs of Westchester County.

A new "high tide" in naval construction has been reached, and "not since the great war ended has such a quantity of new tonnage been authorized," according to the 1936 edition of the marine year book, Jane's Fighting Ships, copies of which have just been received in this country.

Colonel Frederick G. Stritzinger Jr., a retired army officer and member of a prominent Norristown family, died in Riverside Hospital here today after a long illness. He was 66. Colonel Stritzinger was graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1894.
Princeton gained a 6-to-1 decision over the University of Pennsylvania squash team today. Penn's only score came on Leroy Lewis's victory over Ben Ridder.

Following three weeks in which the volume was large, activity slackened last week in the calling of bonds for redemption before maturity. The announcements, except for two fair-sized industrial and public utility calls, were principally for small amounts of securities, mostly of foreign registry.
Three boys were drowned today as two of them made a vain effort to rescue the other after he fell through ice on Lake Erie. Tenyear-old Peter Meyer looked on from the shore as his two brothers,

General Francisco Franco's Southern army has struck another sledgehammer blow against Malaga. The forces operating from Granada in two columns advanced twenty-two miles in one day as a result of a thrust along the Granada-Malaga highway which further threatens the city from the northeast.
Indignant authorities started a counter attack today against what they called a threat to "ruin" the Townsend old-age pension test they conceived.

CHARLES OMAN was senior scholar at Westminster when he was 12 years old. During the sixty-five years that have elapsed since then he has enjoyed one of the most distinguished careers in the scholarly world.

HOMELESS-Almost 300,000 in ten States-Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, West Virginia, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas, Illinois, Mississippi and Pennsylvania. Maryland, Louisiana and North Carolina experienced minor floods.

Northwestern defeated Michigan State, 44 to 29, in a slow basketball game tonight, showing superiority from the opening tip-off. The Wildcats led at half-time 23 to 12. The visitors made their best bid midway in the first period when Osternik scored three of his four field goals in succession to cut the Wildcat margin to 15--11.
Two Californians-Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles and Elwood Cooke of Hollywood--will meet tomorrow in the finals of the Florida State open tennis tournament.
A series of garden lectures to be given on four successive Tuesday mornings, at 11 o'clock, beginning Feb. 2, has been announced by the New York Junior League.

WHEN the Supreme Court upholds New Deal legislation in these Rooseveltian times, people say, "Mr. Dooley must have been right," and everybody understands the allusion. Perhaps he was not entirely correct, back there in 1901,

To the Music Editor: I don't know but I would go a bit farther than you when you speak of the "Contes" as being "great art" according to the rules of the Bouffes Parisiennes. Isn't that a shade too-restrictive? To me, that last act is so difficult to associate with the creative mentality for, say, "La Perichole,"

Princess Alexis Obolensky heads a group of women in charge of plans for a dinner dance for the benefit of the philanthropic enterprises of the Russian Refugee Children's Association and the Russia Nobility Association to be held on Wednesday in the Trianon Room the Ambassador.

The Royal Commission of Inquiry ended its task in Palestine this week after two months of almost daily hearings, but its work is yet far from complete. It still has before it the most difficult part of its mission.

LONDONERS are seeing "big picture" television projected on an eight-by-six foot screen. An audience of 3,000 watched the show in the Dominion Theatre. While the quality of the picture was described as "suffering a little from immediate comparison with the cinema," it was pointed out that the tele-pictures were dimmer and less distinct.

When Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine arrives here Tuesday from New York to aid in the reorganization of the Houston Police Department, he will find that his task has been simplified by sweeping changes already put into effect by Chester A. Williams, new chief.

The season's last Yorkville dinner dance, a series conducted annually for twenty-three years, will be held on Feb. 2 at the Ritz-Carlton. The dances provide funds to carry on the vocational and recreational projects of the Yorkville Community Association. The association conducts Summer camps for children and is active in general social welfare work.

With one vacant seat at the gathering, President Roosevelt will observe the fifty-fifth anniversary of his birth next Saturday with the group of old friends who have been helping him celebrate that occasion for twenty years.

Detroit's powerful Red Wings played a 1-1 draw with the Montreal Maroons tonight in a National Hockey League game before 7,000 fans. The tie increased Detroit's lead in the American Group to eight points over the New York Rangers and Boston Bruins.

Mayor La Guardia declared flatly yesterday that he would not countenance the Municipal Civil Service Commission's proposal to grant salary increases to only such low-paid city employes as have satisfactory service records.
While the Turks and French have been bargaining in Paris and Geneva over the future of the sanjak, or district, of Alexandretta; tension has risen in this region.

Two professors of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have been chosen fellows in the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences in recognition of high achievement in their special lines of research.

The wedding of Miss Helen W. Fox, daughter of Mrs. Charles N. Read of Elkins Park, to Laurence J. Brengle Jr., son of Mrs. Laurence J. Brengle of Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. Brengle, will take place Feb. 5 in St. Paul's Church, Elkins Park.

IN recent years most of the philosophers--at least those of English-speaking coun tries-appear to have been dismayed by the difficulty of discovering any consistent rational pattern or order which could be responsible for the complications, the paradoxes, the errors, the absurdities and the outright contradictions of human motives and behavior.

A night club party was held last night in the ballroom of the Brooklyn Academy of Music after the second and final performance of the tenth annual "Colony House Capers," presented by the senior and junior guilds of Colony House for the benefit of the Settlement House at 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

The Army hockey team vanquished Union College of Schenectady, 3 to 2, tonight, to complete a sweep of six contests for the teams of West Point. This afternoon the Cadets' gained varsity victories in polo, gymnastics and fencing, the jayvees won at-polo and the plebes triumphed in basketball.

bliss Mary Helen Brown. a composer living at 234 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, died on Friday morning in her home of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 72 years old. Miss Brown was born in Buffalo, N. Y., and studied music there under Lucien G. Chaffin. She later studied in England and Germany.

WHEN heavy frosts recently visited the California citrus orchards and injured a large part of the fruit on the trees there was a flurry not only among brokers and dealers in the principal marketing centers but on the part of consumers as well. For oranges, grapefruit and

Adolph Schraeder's field goal in the last ten seconds of play enabled Hudson College of Jersey City to conquer the Cooper Union five, 34--32, at Collins Memorial Gymnasium, Jersey City, last night. The victors were ahead at half-time, 14--13.

The Rev. A. Z. Conrad, for more than three decades pastor of Park Street Congregational Church, died at Phillips House, Massachusetts General Hospital, last night at the age of 81 after an illness of more than a year.

THE ULTIMATE POWER" achieves importance by virtue of the fact that Mr. Ernst is a brilliant if somewhat slap-dash and haphazard writer and a crusading lawyer who has been engaged by the administration to defend the Wagner Labor Bill before the Supreme Court.

Out of last Spring's disastrous floods, in which nearly all big rivers east of the Mississippi overflowed, one river town emerged unwetted. Portsmouth, Ohio, on the Ohio, had completed six years earlier a flood wall three miles long and sixty-two feet high, costing $750,000. On March 23,

Miss Elizabeth Brownell Maynard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Eaton Maynard of this city, was married here tonight in St. Martin's Church to Henry Edwin Stanton, also of Providence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Beecher Stanton of Pittsburgh.

Paul Marcel Jouhaux, son of a French labor leader, tonight denied complicity in an alleged plot to smuggle arms to Spain when questioned by Liege police. Authorities said that four others arrested had admitted engaging in arms traffic.

Trailing by two games and 6-12 in the third, Neil J. Sullivan of Philadelphia, former national squash racquets champion, staged a thrilling rally today to defeat Richard Wakeman of Boston in the Atlantic Coast championship at the Chalfonte Haddon Hall Racquet Club.

Persons prominent in financial affairs in New York and Philadelphia attended a funeral service today for Horatio G. Lloyd, a partner of J. P. Morgan Co. and Drexel Co., who died on Thursday at his estate in Haverford.

Formation of the women's advisory committee, which will originate and direct the participation of all women's groups in the World's Fair of 1939, has been completed and invitations extended to prominent women from the forty-eight States, it was announced yesterday from headquarters of the exposition in the Empire State Building. Mrs.

Henry A. Alexander, an Atlanta lawyer, urged the Supreme Court today to put President Roosevelt in his constitutional "place." A petition filed by him said that the President's message to Congress was contemptuous of the Court and encroached upon its authority.

A beginning was made in the past week in Berlin by the French Ambassador, Andre Francois-Poncet, on the difficult task of trying to discover on what basis Germany would consent to practice the policy of the good neighbor and what return she would voluntarily make for the economic and financial help she so sorely needs.
THE following irrelevancies were born of three conversations, a visit to the Metropolitan and works executed by the WPA Federal Art Project.
Marquis Chokun Asano, 95, the last surviving Japanese feudal lord, was taken seriously ill today. Specialists were summoned to treat him and the members of his family were called to the bedside.

Minnesota's timber workers' strike, which halted one of the State's major industries for more than three weeks, was settled tonight in conferences of workers, employers and committeemen appointed by Governor Elmer Benson. The workers agreed to return to their jobs Monday morning at a

The Chevrolet automobile plant here is expected to attempt a resumption of operations on a partial basis some time this week, as a result of today's statement in Detroit by W. S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, of the company's intention to reopen those of its plants where strikes are not in effect.
Members of the St. Mark's Ladies Emergency Society will give a card party Wednesday afternoon at the McAlpin to augment their general fund, which is used to aid various charitable organizations.

Plans for senior class life insurance, making Williams College sole beneficiary of a $20,000 fund at the end of twenty-five years, await only approval of the Undergraduate Council. Originated by the class of '14, the idea consists of buying $200 policies on members of the class. The college is the beneficiary when the policy matures.
Final examinations based on life situations and drawn up by pupils were advocated yesterday by Dr. Earl R. Gabler, Associate Professor of Education at the New York University School of Education. Dr.

While the Coast Guard rushed additional aid to flooded Ohio Valley areas yesterday by plane and rail, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced that it had been asked to raise $300,000 of the $2,000,000 flood-relief fund sought by the national organization. A drive to this end was started.

Dreel, chestnut gelding from the San Antonio-owned D. J. Sullivan stables, captured the six-andone-half-furlong feature race, the Plaza Hotel Handicap, at Alamo Downs today. The time was 1:21 4-5. Boston Sound was second and Teddy Haslam third. Seven other handicap stars also ran. Charley Schultz was on the winner for his second victory of the meet.

The marriage of Miss Grace George of 16 Sutton Place, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert George of Long Island City, to Walter P. Susslin, son of the late' Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Susslin of Paterson, N. J., took place here yesterday morning at the George Washington.

Bonds drifted irregularly lower in typically dull week-end trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Except for fairly wide price swings in a few issues because of specific developments directly affecting them, movements mostly were restricted to a point or less.

Now that the Westchester Board of Supervisors is preparing to reopen the question of possible reorganization or revision of the county government, leading Westchester women's organizations and community groups of men and women combined have launched a county-wide program to familiarize themselves anew with the factors involved.

The long and futile maritime strike on the East and Gulf coasts was considered at an end yesterday as local unions along the Atlantic seaboard prepared to meet this week to take a vote on the proposal of the New York strikers to call off the walk-out.

While continued business recovery at the 1936 rate may result in the addition of 2,000,000 workers to payrolls by the end of this year, the inability of general business to absorb the approximate 600,000 new eligible workers each year makes it seem likely that a permanent body of unemployed is the prospect for this country for some years, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by economists.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Cable in Lima of the management of their daughter, Miss Alice Mary Cable, to Samuel P. Hayes Jr., son of Professor and Mrs. Samuel P. Hayes of Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, Mass.

The recent flurry in the egg market. has made a considerable difference in the budget of the New York housewife. Two weeks ago she paid an average of 8 cents a dozen more than she need pay today. Grade A white eggs of large

Freddie Fitzsimmons, rotund chicken farmer of California, who was the most tragic figure in last year's world series, will be back at the old stand next year, which is another way of saying he will be on the firing line for Bill Terry's Giants.

Evacuation of the 2,900 men and women prisoners in the State Reformatory here was planned late today after the flooded structure had been without heat and light for twenty-four hours and two dozen inmates had attempted to escape by swimming the icy waters of the Kentucky River.

More than 600 bankers have made reservations for the annual midwinter meeting and dinner of the New York State Bankers Association, which will be opened here tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the association.

THE INVADERS. By Stuart David Engstrand. 265 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $2.50. MR. ENGSTRAND'S first novel about farm life in the Southwest is no gen tle idyll. If you can imagine a composition which begins with the peasant stillness of "The Good Earth" and ends with some of the Faulknerian starkness of "Absalom, Absalom!" you will get a good notion of the range of mood in this able writing.
Having been in existence hardly more than two weeks, Nebraska's new unicameral Legislature has little in the way of completed accomplishment by which to judge it.

Center Sid Fenn of the New York Rovers, smashed a loose puck into the Pittsburgh net in the middle of the third period tonight to give the Rovers a 3-2 victory in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

UT in the Pompton Lakes area Shufflin' Joe Louis has been giving his sparring partners a boisterous belting. Joe was farm-bred in Alabama and he likes the country life for his training sessions. Bob Pastor, being city-bred, has been handing his sparking partners what-for and harkfrom-the-tomb in a local gymnasium where the familiar rattle of city traffic coming through the windows is soothing to his ears.

The new WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, will officially open tonight with an inaugural symphony concert under the direction of Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the music project. The orchestra, known as the Federal Symphony, will be heard regularly on Sunday evenings under the direction of various conductors.
A former Vassar College student, who sat sightless in her classes a few years ago studying journalism, has become a newspaper reporter, an author, teacher, traveler and lecturer.

John J. Sheehan, who has been re-elected chairman of the St. Patrick's Day parade and celebration committee, predicted yesterday that this year's celebration would be larger than last year. He said the Fifth Avenue parade, in which 40,000 persons participated in 1936, would be "even greater."

Japan's new Cabinet, replacing that of Premier Koki Hirota, which resigned yesterday, will be a military bureaucratic administration, it is everywhere admitted. Attempts by the late Viscount Makoto Saito, the late Keisuke Okada and Mr. Hirota to form so-called national Cabinets pursuing a middle policy and admitting political parties have failed.

Net profit of the Sutherland Paper Company in 1936 amounted to $729,116 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings. This is equivalent to $2.54 each on 287,000 shares of $10-par capital stock. In 1935 the company earned $818,369, or $2.15 a share. Net sales last year increased to $7,494,750 from $6,636,211 in 1935.

Miss Charlotte Tinker, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Wellington H. Tinker of 47 Claremont Avenue, New York City, is one of the two students who will represent Oberlin College at Oberlin-in-Shansi, China, for the next three years.

Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Silpe of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian D. Silpe, to Sylvan Roos Hirsch of East Orange, N. J., son of Mrs. Sol Hirsch of Savannah, Ga., and the late Mr. Hirsch.
The Amherst wrestling team held Wesleyan to a 16-16 draw today. The Jeffs built up an early lead when Bartlett won from Aylsworth by default and Reid threw Rennie in the 126-pound class.

Education has gone on the air from Massachusetts State College with a new series of radio programs just getting under way over a near-by radio station. Supplementing a long-established program concerning agriculture and home economics presented by the extension service at the college, the new radio series stresses 'liberal arts, recreation and popular science.

A "laboratory workshop," intended to train drama students in the integrated arts of music, dancing, speech and stage design, will be installed at Teachers College with the beginning of the Spring semester on Feb. 2, Dr. Belle Northrup, Assistant Professor of Fine Arts, announced yesterday.
The manager of a Brooklyn Negro basketball team was killed today and six players were injured when their automobile plunged down an eight-foot embankment and hit a tree.

Mr. and Mrs. Ole Singstad of 1,035 Fifth Avenue gave an afternoon reception with dancing yesterday in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to introduce their daughter, Miss Rita Singstad. The occasion marked the twentyfifth anniversary of the marriage of the debutante's parents.

FOR the first time the hitherto almost inaccessible palace and fortress of King Henri Christophe of Haiti is being brought within reach of the eager feet of tourists. A new steamship service is being inaugurated to Cap Haiten, supplementing the more familiar port of call and capital, Port au Prince.
Thomas Stall Marvel of Roland Park, naval architect and marine engineer, died last night at the age of 58. He was born in Newburgh, N. Y., and was graduated from Cornell University in 1900.

Building up a 21-point lead in the opening half Massachusetts State gained a surprisingly easy victory over Boston University in the Physical Education Building tonight, 47--31. The Terriers braced in the second period, but could not make much headway cutting State's big margin.
The third free symphony concert under the direction of David Mannes attracted an audience of 8,500 persons last night to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Miss Maddy Horn of Beaver Dam, Wis., bettered a national record today in the first day's racing of the second annual Great Lakes speed skating carnival, and she and Delbert Lamb of Milwaukee, a member of the 1936 United States Olympis team, lead the women's and men's title chases.

The Springfield College baseball team is planning to make its sixth Easter vacation trip to the State of North Carolina. The Massachusetts nine has a sixgame schedule, beginning on Monday, March 22, and continuing through Saturday of that week.

An international match for the Canadian amateur racquets singles championship was assured today in the tournament at the Montreal Racquets Club. Finals in both singles and doubles will be played tomorrow.

An exodus is already in progress of Eastern executives and delegates of affiliated groups of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, for the twelfth annual conference-the first to be held outside the national capital. Sessions will open Tuesday at the Palmer House in Chicago.

The new Moscow trial provokes astonishment in the principal circles of public opinion. However, the second trial was prepared during the first. The principal defendants of the present trial were named by the accused of the first trial of sixteen [persons].

MODERNIZATION of the broadcasting set-up through gradual changes in waves and power, through a .formula that might clear the way for several hundred new stations, is recommended to the Federal Communications Commission in a report from its engineering division.

JOAN HASLIP, whose biography received a front-page review in our issue of Jan. 17. was born in London in 1909. Her father was a distinguished English physician, and her mother a Viennese. Her early life was spent between Mayfair and a convent school in Rome.
Freezing weather in Pittsburgh today halted, the rise of the city's three flooded rivers. Hundreds of threatened homes and business properties were saved.

Four speakers, three of whom are from a group of ten exchange students at Barnard College this year, will take part in an informal discussion of foreign universities before the Westfield (N. J.) College Women's Club at the Masonic Temple there tomorrow at 8:15 P. M. Miss Ilse Dunst of Germany, Miss Renee Pequet of France and Miss Gioietta Bompiani of Italy will analyze, respectively, the pre-university, university and graduate work abroad.

ALL of the official pronunciamentos issued by the production geniuses of the industry at the beginning of the year stressed the opinion that 1937 is to be a season of comedy, that there will be little room on the screen for films of somber hue.

It was no idle jest to describe the thirty-second annual Motor Boat Show which ended a week ago as the curtain-raiser for the 1937 power boat season. This year there is practically no gap at all between the indoor fleet display and the outdoor schedule for speed drivers.

Frank Orren Lowden intimated today reorganization of the government as outlined by President Roosevelt's committee would result in increased efficiency and economy. The elder statesman of the Republican party also envisioned the proposed revamping of Federal administrative machinery as an opportunity for the Chief Executive to "discharge more efficiently the duties which are laid upon him by the Constitution."

THE ARROW POINTS TO MURDER By Frederica de Laguna. 283 pp. Garden City, N. Y.: Published for The Crime Club, Inc., by Doubleday, Doran Co. $2. AT last we have that mysterious South American arrow poison where it properly belongs-in a museum.

Judge John C. Pollock, 79, of the Federal District Court of Kansas died early today at his suburban home. Judge Pollock, who had been on the Federal bench since 1903, had been unconscious since Monday, when he was brought to his home ?? his Texas ranch.

Yale today defeated the University of Pennsylvania, 60-15, to run its string of consecutive swimming victories to 154 and capture its first meet in the new Eastern Intercollegiate League, in which Princeton, Columbia, Harvard, Navy and Dartmouth also are enrolled.

SHE was the daughter of the great Henry, one time of Navarre, who had decided a few years before her birth that Paris was "well worth a mass," and in becoming a Catholic had become de facto King of France.

More than 200 members and guests of the Albany Society attended the organization's fortyfourth annual dinner held last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. A delegation of nearly 100 residents of Albany arrived earlier in the evening by special train to attend the affair.
The Portsmouth Times suspended publication in its Ohio Riverfront plant today. The staff moved to a hilltop commercial printing plant to issue a "dodger paper" with flood bulletins.

Phelps Smith, power manufacturer and son of the late Paul Smith, pioneer Adirondack hotel man, in his will offered for probate today, made provision for a co-educational college to perpetuate his father's name.

In these words, spoken from a rainswept platform at the main portico of the Capitol to a thoroughly soaked crowd which had turned out to witness his second inauguration, President Roosevelt last week hailed what he termed the greatest change brought about by his first New Deal administration--"the change in the moral climate of America."

Precise measurements of the changes in brightness of eclipsing variable stars a project in which the Princeton University Observatory has been engaged for the last thirty-two years, have now passed the half-million mark, it was revealed today by Dr. Raymond S. Dugan, Professor of Astronomy at Princeton.

Life insurance policies on the twenty-payment plan are to be written on the lives of parishioners of St. Marks Methodist Episcopal Church, Ocean Avenue and Beverly Road, Brooklyn, in return for loans made to the church to liquidate $50,000 of indebtedness on a parish house.

NOTWITHSTANDING the phenomenal development of downhill and slalom running during the last four years, ski jumping, with its spectacular and dangerous qualities, continues unchallenged as the king of the Winter sports.

With all of its higher executives out of town, the Hotel Association of New York City issued no official reply yesterday to the strike threat served on the association by the hotel division of the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32 C.

SIFT out the performance figures in gasoline mileage tests on the 1937 model automobiles and in them you will find the most spectacular chapter in technical progress that has been written in any engineering field in more than a year.

With nearly 100 paintings fewer than usual and with a less crowded sculpture section, the 132d annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts opened tonight with a private view. It will be open to the public from tomorrow until Feb. 28.

Ellsworth Vines, youthful American tennis star, defeated Fred Perry, 6--1, 7--5, in an exhibition match tonight. Perry was badly off form in the first set, losing six games after winning only the first.
A SURVEY of the piano records in American release during the past year should convince any one of the mechanical progress that has been made during the period. Naturally, these

When Louis Beitcher, the No. 2 man in the restaurant racket, chose to plead guilty last Monday as he went on trial with others before Supreme Court Justice McCook, a slight fuss was made about it by attorneys for the defense. They objected because Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, let Beitcher make his plea before a panel of jurors waiting examination.

Plans have been completed for the President's birthday ball to be held next Saturday at the county center here, under the chairmanship of Thomas L. Cotton. All communities and cities throughout the county will sponsor this event with the exception of Yonkers, which is having its own celebration in the State Armory.

Bank bandits, burglars, stickup men and other malefactors who in the future may have fatal gunplay contact with Santa Barbara police may die assured that there will be no dispute over who shot them. There will be no possibility of their being recorded as suicides if in truth they have not turned their own weapons on themselves.
International basketball rules, governing Olympic Games play, have been revised to eliminate the center tap-off, but otherwise to conform generally with the American style of court competition.

On a hunt for the wax flowers that once bloomed in grandmother's parlor under a shining glass dome and for the hair wreaths considered the acme of decoration in an earlier day, members of the Woman's Club of Orange are ransacking their attics and storerooms, by request.

The text of the proclamation by President Roosevelt, asking contributions to the Red Cross for flood sufferers, was as follows: Disastrous floods in the Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys already have driven 270,000 men, women and children from their homes. There is every likelihood that until the crest of the flood waters is reached this number of homeless refugees will be largely increased. Snow, sleet and freezing

Miss Sylvianne Kendall Blanchard, daughter of Mrs. Walter James Herzfeld of 50 East Seventy-seventh Street and of Dr. William H. Blanchard of Boston, has chosen Feb. 20 for her marriage to Carl Gunther Triest, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Gustav Triest of 1,100 Park Avenue.

Mrs. James Garrett Wallace gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 434 East Fifty-second Street, for Miss Eleanor Kavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kavanagh of 14 East Ninetieth Street, whose engagement to George Healey of this city was recently announced.

The following works have been recommended by the selection committee of the British section of the International Society of Contemporary Music for the consideration of the international jury of the society's Paris festival in June: William Walton's symphony in B flat;

Some Representatives said tonight that President Roosevelt's $790,000, 000 relief request won the approval of a house appropriations subcommittee this afternoon. Mr. Roosevelt requested the fund recently to carry on relief for the next five months.

A charge of "deliberate tampering" with important records in the Garrett will case involving $20,000,000 threw a hearing on the claims of some of the 20,000 self-styled relatives of Mrs. Henrietta E. Garrett into an uproar at the City Hall today.

Special courses for architects, contractors and others in the building field will be offered by the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts in the second term, which will begin next week, Dean E. Raymond Bossange announced yesterday.

The average area of face which a man shaves is forty-eight square inches. The average number of individual whiskers which grow on this area is 25,000. The average growth of each whisker in twenty-four hours is onehundredth of an inch.

The Lord Jeffs of Amherst proved masters of the Army quintet tonight, winning by 38-33 before a crowd of 3,500. Taking an early lead, the Amherst five enlarged it to 26-15 at the half. As the second session started,

Rambling 'round the outdoor circuit: Some of the lucky fishermen who tied into the big ones in Long Island waters last Summer received tangible evidence of recognition when the East End Surf Fishing Club presented the awards in the 1936 contest the other evening...

After a close struggle between several clubs since the start of the campaign, Arsenal and Charlton Athletic have finally cut loose from the pack in the race for the English Football League championship.

The Automobile Club of New York, after a check-up of conditions with the American Automobile Association yesterday, urged motorists to stay away from the areas affected by the present floods until conditions improve.

Overcoming frozen fairways and greens for a second sub-par round, Ed Dudley of Philadelphia continued to pace the field today at the half-way mark of the 72-hole $3,000 Sacramento open golf tournament.
Spokesmen said today that a committee of cabinet members and private citizens reviewing the defunct National Recovery Administration. soon will report approval of its basic objectives.

EXERCISES in commemoration of the centenary of the death of Alexander Pushkin, the great Russian poet, whose works form the basis of some of the most important musical compositions of his native-land, will be held this afternoon at 2, at International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe will leave today to pass the remainder of the season at their Winter home, Cherokee Plantation, Yemassee, S. C. Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston and Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson will accompany them for a visit.

The marriage of Miss Henrietta Green Duffield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Green Duffield of Princeton, to John Lowry Roe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lowry Roe of Jacksonville, Fla., took place this afternoon in the university chapel.
For the fifth time since the Sian coup on Dec. 12 a truce or government ultimatum has formally expired and again the rebels have received additional time to negotiate a peaceful compromise.

In recovering jewelry valued at $300,000 which had been stolen only thirty-six hours before from the home of Mrs. Frederick H. Bugher in Washington, the New York police also found last night $50,000 in jewelry which they believe to have been stolen from households in Connecticut which formerly employed a butler, who was arrested while in the service of Mrs. Bugher.

ABRAHAM-Born to Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Abraham (nee Vivian Gottlieb), a daughter, Sydenham Hospital, Jan. 22, 1937. APPEL-Mr. and Mrs. John J. Appel announce the birth of a daughter. Joan, on Jan. 20, 1937, at Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, N. Y.

A board of five Princeton seniors has been appointed to edit The Nassau Herald, annual publication of the graduating class of the university, it has been announced by John N. Irwin 2d, of Keokuk, Iowa, president of the Undergraduate Council.
An upward movement of used car sales is reported in trade circles in certain sections of the country as a direct result of the growing curtailment of factory deliveries of new cars to dealers.
A meeting to celebrate. the sixteenth anniversary of the founding of the Judson Health Center will be held on the afternoon of Feb. 5 in the studio of Colonel A. A. Anderson, 80 West Fortieth Street.

The controversy over tutoring methods at Yale, Harvard and Princeton has aroused a lively fight on the Princeton campus over the exact aims and methods of the various tutoring associations in town and the extent to which these methods affect the scholastic work of the university.
Representatives from the flooded Ohio River Valley agreed tentatively today to seek an immediate appropriation of some $320,000,000 for flood control and prevention projects.

Francis T. Hunter, former international tennis star and former newspaper publisher, was married to Miss Marjorie Franklin of New York in the Lattice Room of the Pickwick Arms Hotel here today by a justice of the peace. A reception followed at the Twenty-one Club, New York.

Power to act for the State Federation of Business and Professional Women at a hearing on the minimum wage law at Albany Feb. 4 was delegated yesterday to Mrs. Miriam A. Schindler, legislative chairman of the organization, at a meeting of the State board at the Hotel Biltmore.

Henry Hahn, State Supreme Court Commissioner and a Special Master in Chancery, died today at his home here of pneumonia. He was 64 years old. Mr. Hahn was born in Newark, the son of the late Rabbi Joseph Hahn. He was a graduate of the

Commodity futures markets were generally lower last week, reflecting in part the subsidence of speculative activities in the London markets. In the cash market, coffee and antimony were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, lard, tin, cotton, rubber, butter and eggs were lower.

Cold, hunger, snow and disease plagued nearly 300,000 refugees driven from their homes by icy flood waters today. Twenty-six deaths were counted as the record-smashing flood cut an ever widening swath through the lower Ohio Valley and the menacing Mississippi burst through its levees.

The State Tax Limitation Committee, at a meeting today, made an attack on the State Conference of Mayors for its criticism of the committee's proposal for a lower overall limitation nn real estate taxation.

"The Tales of Hoffmann," a work which grows upon the beholder with every hearing, was given its second performance of the season yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, and the performance as a whole, which attracted a large and very
Mrs. Norbert Morin of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Wills, to John Corson Blair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sherman Blair of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street.
VIENNA. FOUR months have gone by since the Kerber regime was established at the Staatsoper and yet few things are conspicuously better than they were under Weingartner.
Florida read "rain, snow and sleet" in Northern weather forecasts today and hoped that competition with its sunshine was over for the Winter.

Diplomatic and newspaper circles here were shocked upon learning today that Vladimir Romm, former Washington correspondent of Izvestia, had been accused in the Radek trial in Moscow of being a plotter and is under arrest.
AMID the flood of pirates, fairies, acrobats and clowns who invade the theatre at Christmas-time, there has appeared this year one serious play, "Heart's Content" by W. Chetham Strode.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson will give a card party, fashion show and tea next Saturday at Sherry's. Proceeds will be donated to the building fund of the college.

The President's rebuke to John L. Lewis errs on the side of moderation. It is significant, however; that he allowed a direct quotation of his cryptic understatement. There can be only one interpretation of this departure, namely, that Lewis, with his public demand for Presidential support, had angered him. It was, 0f course an insult.

THE cross-eyed index of movie arcan holds no file that bulges with insanity so much as E. under .which heading comes "empathy." The movies, in their own quiet unobtrusive way, have boosted mass empathy to the heavens of the fine arts.

THE first of a series of good-will concerts planned for an international audience is scheduled for Jan; 30 at 3 P. M., when WIXAL, Boston's short-wave educational transmitter, will broadcast a symphony program by WPA musicians.
THE steady tattoo of the auctioneer's hammer marks the inevitable conclusion of the thousands of little wars that are fought each year for the possession of literary prizes in this country.

With the Ohio River again on the rampage through most of its length, the question has again arisen as to what can be done, and how soon, to eliminate many of the floods which have visited this territory.
The Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association, of which Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen is president, will open its 1937 appeal for funds tomorrow with a luncheon at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

Gifts to the United Hospital Fund campaign of $4,000 from Church Dwight Company,. Inc., $2,500 from the Consolidated Oil Corporation, $1,500 from Young Rubicam, Inc., and $5,205.75 from the city Department of Sanitation were announced last night by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of the drive.

While Congress considered President Roosevelt'a appeal last week for renewal of the authority under which his administration has negotiated reciprocal trade agreements the court fight here to prove the existing act unconstitutional entered a new phase yesterday when importers intervened in support of the present law.

Riis House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "And Now Good-Bye," a play adapted by Philip Howard from the book of the same title by James Hilton, with Philip Merivale and Marguerite Churchill in the leading roles, the night of Feb. 4 at the John Golden Theatre.

A perceptible improvement in the Pope's condition was indicated today. Not only did he pass perhaps the best sight since he became ill more than seven weeks-ago, but he was also almost completely free of pain all way and was able greatly to increase the number of audiences with high church officials.

TO meet the demands of a traffic burden which has been increasing during the past decade at an average rate of 10 per cent a year, the highway departments of counties, cities and townships on Long Island engaged in a broad program of highway improvement during 1936. Their plans call for continued activity this year.

Whatever new moves President Roosevelt may have in mind, or develop later, to continue the march toward ideals he brought to the government, he has made it quite evident that he does not intend immediately to drop any of the important emergency devices with which he has been fighting the depression since March, 1933.
