Angelo Trulio of the New York A. C. and Vladimir Kotal of the West Side Y. M. C. A. advanced to the final of the State A. A. U. fourwall handball singles championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. yesterday. The two stars, who met for the crown last year, will play Tuesday night.

Union of the four large electric utility properties In the Chicago metropolitan area into one closely knit corporation headed by the Commonwealth Edison Company was assured today when Commonwealth Edison's shareholders authorized their directors to take the steps necessary to carry out the program.

The low interest rates for Federa financing, of which the Treasury boasts, were cited as one of four factors in the dissipation of the "national patrimony" yesterday by Professor Walter E. Spahr of the Department of Economics of New York University.

Borrowing Captain C. W. Westlund from the First Division, the Gypsy Polo Club gained its first victory of the indoor season last night when it turned back Squadron A at the latter's armory. A goal by Captain Westlund, scored just as the final bell rang, put Gypsy in front at the end of a long stern chase.

The "cultural Olympics" program, sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania to provide competition in the fields of the fine arts, will get under way with a series of district and regional exhibitions in April, according to detailed plans announced on the campus today by Dr. Frederick C. Gruber, the director.
Ray L. Neal of Philadelphia won the 18-hole Medal Play Handicap, final event on the competition program of the Winter Golf League of Advertising Interests at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

Former Probate Judge Robert Stephen Emerson died at his home here early today. He was 62 years old. A prominent corporation lawyer, Mr. Emerson's activities in legal, business and fraternal circles were many. He was a stamp collector
Marko Ozaniz, a member of a Croat terrorist organization, was sentenced to: day by a Hungarian court to seven years' imprisonment for killing a Yugoslav political agent in Zagreb in 1921.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-Sports and cultural events share this week's crowded program. With an entry list of nearly 6,000, triple that of last year and six times that of the year before, the third annual Silver Sailfish Derby begins today, to continue until Feb. 14.

Some are criticizing President ROOSEVELT for not having been more emphatic and explicit in offering American aid to maintain peace in Europe. Not one of his messages to the new Congress thus far has taken direct cognizance of the conditions abroad that threaten war.

Mrs. Elsie Petri of the Women's Swimming Association last night set a standard in the 100-yard breast stroke for future contenders to shoot at by winning the New York State A. A. U. championship in this class, which was held for the first time.

IT is a privilege to be able to renew acquaintance with the Van Gogh paintings and drawings at the Museum of Modern Art. Although some of the most notable things contained in the exhibition as. it was in 1935 are gone now, more than enough remains to make this brief return a worth-while experience.

Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, and Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the American Social Hygiene Association, joined yesterday in urging support of National Social Hygiene Day, to be observed on Feb. 3.

POMPEII. By R. C. Carrington. Illustrated. 197 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $4. POMPEII was a town of about 20,000 inhabitants, a residential center for wealthy Romans, and the little metropolis of an agricultural countryside. Unlike its Hellenistic neighbor Herculaneum, it was typically Italian in its plan as well as in its civic and social development.

PANAMA, R. P.-The renewed proposals that the United States build a canal through Nicaragua at a cost of $722,000,000, more as a measure of national defense for the transfer of the navy from ocean to ocean than as a commercial project, has again stirred up the hornets' nest of controversy.

John Hauser of Yorkville, near Utica, N. Y., and Miss Constance Terry of Southold, L. I., will preside as King and Queen over St. Lawrence University's fourth annual Winter carnival as a result of a vote taken by the student body.
Hungary led the United States, 6 matches to 2, today at the end of the opening play in the two-day table tennis competition between teams from the two countries.

An outstanding feature of the Young People's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Ernest Schelling, at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, was the brilliant pianism of Balbina Brainina, the assisting artist on the program. Miss Brainina, who made

A second half rally, led by Miss Jeanne Andrews, enabled the New College girls' basketball team to defeat the Panzer representatives, 28 to 25, yesterday on the Thompson Gymnasium court at Columbia University. It was the second straight triumph for the winners and the first setback for the visitors.

The twenty-four American delegates invited to attend a world meeting of the International Missionary Council in Hangchow, China, in September, 1938, have been announced at the headquarters of the council, 156 Fifth Avenue.

Reuben Fine of New York and Gideon Stahlberg of this city, the two leaders in the international chess masters tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club, won their games in the eighth and semi-final round tonight.
Keeping intact a consistent record, Mrs. E. H. Bartlett's Zevson won his fourth straight race at the Fair Grounds today in accounting for the mile of the NOAC Handicap.

Maurice Lavanoux, secretary of the Liturgical Arts Society, will introduce the speaker at the final lecture on Wednesday night at Sherry's in a series by Father Cyprian Truss, O. S. F. C., in behalf of the work of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd. The subject of the lecture will be "The Wreckers."
The annual report of the Community of Mission Health Sisters has been made public by the Rev. Edward F. Garesche, head of the Catholic Medical Mission Board, at 10 West Seventeenth Street.

Jacob Gitelman, City Court judge, said today he would ask the Legislature again to legalize week-end jail sentences in Rochester as an "experiment" preliminary to Statewide legislation. The sentences, he said, would apply only to those convicted of misdemeanors.

Premier Leon Blum tomorrow at Lyon will deliver a speech which many hope and believe will mark the beginning of a new era in Franco-German relations. He will, it is expected, present the whole problem as one whose settlement is of vital interest to both countries and in which prestige must not be allowed to prevent an agreement.
Homer Martin, president of the United til Automobile Workers of America, in a statement here today charged officials of General Motors Corporation with a "stupendous and dastardly double-cross."

The New York Branch of the Southern Woman's Educational Allance will hold a three-session forum at the Roosevelt Hotel on Feb. 2 to discuss "the need for more nursing service in rural areas." In announcing the forum, the alliance says:

Gene Cavallero, co-proprietor of the Colony Restaurant at 667 Madison Avenue, greeted guests in the thickly-carpeted lobby last night with something less than his usual subtle good cheer. He had been summoned to the telephone on Wednesday and told some one aboard the Italian liner Rex was calling him.

Discovery of a coffin believed to hold the body of Chevalier Pierre Bayard, France's "most pure knight" and hero of sixteenth century wars, was announced tonight by the Ministry of Education. The famous knight, "Sans Peuret Sans Reproche," died in 1524. His coffin had been the object of search for more than 100 years.

Richard Brinsley Sheridan, who broke the legendary 400-yearold "curse of the Sheridans" only to die shortly thereafter, was buried here today. His mother, Clare Consuelo Sheridan, British sculptress, writer and traveler, was at the graveside.

Acquisition by the Fogg Museum of Harvard University of several major art works and money gifts totaling over $52,000 in the past year were announced today by Edward W. Forbes, director of the museum, in his annual report.

Wallpapers that no longer inspire nightmares or comedy skits, kitchen stoves as decorative as they are useful and furniture that has long since shaken off the Morris influence reflect increasing public interest in the designs of these famitiar household objects, especially among women consumers.
Plans are now being made for the annual International Skating Carnival at Madison Square Garden, which will be an event of the Easter season in this city.

Firm in its opposition to proposals to regulate trade unions, the labor committee of the Socialist party is launching a campaign to mobilize every labor union in the State against the enactment of legislation carrying out such proposals.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Tyler of this city, formerly of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Miller Tyler, to James Doudge Tate, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Williamson Tate of Baltimore.

AT different periods in the history of human society the theatre has had a different meaning. Sometimes it was the theatre of the people and at others that of the aristocracy. The Greek tragedies were people's tragedies. The dramas of Aeschylus and
The two-story factory building at 115 Clay Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Kompolite Corporation, floor coverings, from the Greenpoint Savings Bank. C. Grant Keck was the broker.

Proper zoning of the cities along the Ohio River would have prevented much of the personal distress caused by flood conditions, Tracey B. Auger, planning engineer of the Tennessee Valley Authority and vice president of the American City Planning Institute, declared at a meeting of the institute yesterday at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.
TOKYO.-The bloom is off the rose of conquest for Japan and the thorns are beginning to prick. Like many another country before it, Japan is learning that national glory is costly. Years of triumph,

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his "Red Pacifism" Herbert W. Stanley noted the confusion of thought in the public mind of the United States in respect to his theme. "Unquestionably," he says, "the number * * * who are conscious supporters of Communist revolution is small." Nevertheless, he

IN his rural retreat at Segeon, India, Mahatma Gandhi raises his voice once more against Untouchability. He urges that his followers make use of the forthcoming election campaign in India as a means of educating the voters on the. subject.

MIAMI, Fla.-Throughout the closing week of January the committees and other groups charged with the arrangements for important midseason events will be busy with their preparations. Immediate attention is commanded by the annual balls to honor President Roosevelt on his fifty-fifth birthday next Saturday.

Residents of the area adjoining Wills Creek, a Potomac tributary, moved furniture to the second floor today as rising waters surged over retaining walls and around their homes. The Potomac reached 14.9 feet, slightly more than two feet below flood stage, and was rising today.

City Council members sympathize with residents who buy automobiles that turn out to be "lemons" in their estimation, but they have now under consideration an ordinance to make it illegal for any such owner to plaster his car with signs expressing his opinion.

Crumbling levees and slowly rising flood waters drove thousands of persons from the lowlands of. Northeast Arkansas today while freezing weather left the State locked in an ice sheath estimated to have done $10,000,000 damage to timber lands.

CONSIDERED both as arguing anew a progressive recognition of the sort of museum service that benefits artists, and as indicating "heightened public interest in all phases of contemporary American art," the announcement made last week by Juliana R. Force, director of the Whitney, is significant.
A keg of blasting powder blew up the Albert Taylor home today, leaving three members of the family dead, three others in a critical condition and five seriously ill of burns and other injuries.
The Pawling School swimming team of Pawling, N. Y., is slated to open its six-meet schedule on Wednesday by encountering the Yale freshman in the Yale pool at New Haven.

Motherhood's bright halo is in for a tarnishing, what time the General Federation of Women's Clubs has finished thumbing through the mass of statistics on the toll it takes, now in preparation on request by the Maternity Center Association.

General business conditions were discussed by President Roosevelt today with Rudolph Wurlitzer, head of the Wurlitzer Music Company of Cincinnati, in one of a series of conferences the Chief Executive has been holding for several months with business leaders.

THE PHILOSOPHY OF RHETORIC. By I. A. Richards. 138 pp New York: Oxford University Press. $1.75. OF recent years the entire. subject of rhetoric has fallen under a shadow. Largely in reaction to the pedantry of former writers in this field, we have come to look with distrust on anything pertaining to rhetoric; we have come to shy

The investigation of investment trusts and investment companies by the Securities and Exchange Commission was switched today to an inquiry into the program of the Equity Corporation which had as its object the exchange of Equity's common shares for the stocks of various investment trusts and other investment units in which Equity acquired control.

A plot of fifty lots in the vicinity of Thirty-sixth Street and Twentieth Road, Astoria, L. I., has been pur- bill. chased by the Island Building Corporation, subsidiary of N. K. Winston Co., enlarging the home community center which was started there by the Winston interests last year.

Large orders placed in the wholesale market, and the desire of retailers to obtain Spring merchandise early, have made it difficult for manufacturers to arrange prompt deliveries, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers here.
The American Car and Foundry Company has received orders for 500 steel hopper cars, 500 fifty-ton gondola cars and twenty-five seventy-ton dry bulk hopper cars from the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

THE humanist, as Mr. More tells us once again, is simply one who takes his stand on being human. Beneath him is the animal kingdom, the anarchy of natural impulses. Above him is the supernatural absolute, the ultimate repose of the spirit Somehow, but never clearly enough, the humanist mediates between both, denying the existence of neither. but finding its purpose and values essentially in itself, in the civilizing process of mankind.

Miss Faith Spiers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. C. Spiers of Brooklawn, N. J., and granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. H. B. Spiers of St. David's, with whom she has made her home, was married this afternoon to Edward G. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben B. Clark of Ardmore.

TOURS to include the coronation and the Paris International Exposition, two high spots of the coming European season, are being booked over itineraries of varying lengths. A seven-day jaunt leads to The Hague, Amsterdam and Brussels, then on to Paris, with sufficient time in each city for sight-seeing.

The trend of building permits rose contra-seasonally in December, Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor announced today. While the actual number of all permits declined 18.9 per cent from November, the estimated value rose 8.2 per cent.

Federal and State governments cooperated in 731 major research problems in agriculture last year, it was recently disclosed by the Department of Agriculture. Every State experiment station participated in these cooperative enterprises.

The Union Temple quintet scored its fourteenth victory in fifteen starts by subduing the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., 39--22, before an overflow crowd of 800 -persons at the Y. M. H. A. court last night. Paced by Jack Krugman and Lester Trokie with eight points each, the Templers led by 20-18 at the intermission.

Little Hank Marino of Milwaukee, United States match bowling champion, increased his lead over Joe Miller of Buffalo, N. Y., to 23 1-50 points tonight as they completed 80 of the 120-game match. Despite Miller's smashing windup game of 288, the best rolled thus far in the series, Champion Marino maintained a steadier pace to count 2,273 to the Buffalo bowler's 2,217 in the ten games.

The appointment of the mixed commission provided for in the German-Japanese "anti-Communist" pact to make the accord effective seems to have been a signal for a new and intensified campaign against bolshelism, for which the entire German press and a host of Nazi party speakers are being mobilized.
Ontario's producing gold mines yielded gold and silver bullion to the value of $7,373,183 in December, a new high record for a month, according to the bulletin of the Department of Mines.
40th St. 532 W.. 10x20; 1-story electrical circuit breaker house; New York Central Railroad, owner; John P. Gallagher, architect; cost, $3,000.

To have meaning, life, like a painting, must have design, the Rev. Dr. Sydney Bruce Snow, president of the Meadville Theological School, Chicago, said yesterday morning in a sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Freezing weather, which brought relief yesterday to flood-harassed Western Pennsylvania, gave way today before heavy rains over the entire Monongahela River basin and scattered rains along the Allegheny.

Samuel Otto, Philadelphia manager of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced tonight that members of the union's joint board would set a date tomorrow night for the beginning of a strike in the silk dress, blouse and cotton garment industries here.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,572,726,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

Jersey City, the recently acquired farm of the Giants, was formally admitted into the International League yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore. The league gave its approval to the Jersey City Exhibition Company and sanctioned the switch in franchise from Albany to Jersey City.
Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here last week was smaller in wheat, corn and rye compared with the previous week, while oats increased.

Mayor Nevillle Miller of Louisville, Ky., in a telephone conversation with THE NEW YORK TiMES at 2:30 A. M. today described flood conditions in his city as follows: "We take hope from the fact that the rain stopped shortly after midnight and from the fact that the river is now rising more slowly," he said.
Retiring trustees of Westchester mortgages will meet Thursday at White Plains and consider answering charges made by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, it was said today by Anthony J. Kerin. Mr.

Walter (Death Valley) Scotty, who as late as last week reported himself "broke" and more than a million dollars in debt, startled bartenders here last night by offering a $10,000 bill to buy "drinks on the house."
The American Legion will not ask for pensions so long as Harry W. Colmery is national commander, Mr. Colmery declares in the February issue of The American Legion Monthly, published today.
Niagara's strong basketball team ran away with the game against St. Bonaventure today and amassed a score of 50 to 20. It was Niagara's forty-ninth victory in the last fifty games at home.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, offered to Governor Davey of Ohio today the facilities of the railroad in taking relief to the people in the flood areas. "If there is anything the Baltimore Ohio can do to be helpful, I would be glad to have you call on us," he said in a telegram.

ALE -- Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Dale (Marian L. Duschnes) announce the birth of a son, Harvey Philip, Sunday, Jan. 24, at the Park East Hospital. KRINSKY-Dr. and Mrs. Milton Krinsky (nee Josephine Evelyn Bachrach) announce the birth of a son, Robert Daniel, Sunday, Jan. 24, at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 81 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the two preceding weeks. Daily tonnage slightly exceeds the average in 1929.

Despite a downpour of rain, a puffy northeast wind with weight in it, twelve dinghies sailed today in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Wet and shivering, Corny Shields and Arthur Knapp wound up in a tie at 75 points each after four races among the Class B OneDesign craft.

President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, who is a week-end guest at the White House, chatted informally today over trade relations between the United States and Britain.

During the next few weeks aircraft and their operation will be very much in the public eye. New York's aviation show, the first in seven years, which opens next Thursday, will draw an unusual concentration of experts to the city.
The telephone company's little sermon on how to speak clearly and pleasingly over the wire contains many useful hints. People will take them to heart after making the usual humorous remarks.

The Montclair Athletic Club's decisive victory over the Englewood Field Club today virtually clinched the championship of the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for the winners. Montclair won the Class B title last year and Englewood finished first in Division C. This year's league is a combination of B and C.

The Family Adjustment Society of Queensboro this week will begin a drive for $10,000 to defray the estimated cost of the 1937 program, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Smith Alford, executive director.

Senator Robinson of Arkansas declared here tonight that public opinion "looks with dread on the coming of the day when a few gigantic monopoHes of capital shall control the production and sale of the necessities of life."
Variations in the spelling of President Roosevelt's name are many and unique, bonerss" culled from regents examination papers of Buffalo public school students show.

Dvora Lapson, Chassidio dance mime, who has appeared hereabouts in informal performances for several seasons, made her formal debut last night in a recital at the Adelphi Theatre before a large and friendly audience.
Biographical sketches of 1,438 Americans of Italian extraction and of Italians residing in this country are contained in the second edition of the Italian-American Who's Who, to be published today.

The plan to draw names from a hat to form a committee to give Police Chief Russell Hilbert a literacy examination collapsed today when two of the four who were to do the drawing announced they would have nothing to do with it.
Soy-bean trading here last week was spasmodic, with processors buying cash beans on weak spots, while pit traders who bought early in the week took profits on features at the close.
The one-family dwelling at 310 Kinderkamack Rd., Hillsdale, N. J., was sold by Samuel Asleben to Thomas H. Kinkead through J. I. Kislak, Inc.

The Hershey team of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 1, tonight. Mancuso and Russell scored for Hershey in the first period and Tuten, Frost and Lauzon tallied in the third.

With an icy rain keeping part of the frostbite fleet on the beach, two new winners turned up in the Manhasset Bay regatta today. Bob Fraser Jr. won in class D, with three first places and a second in four races, and Bill Camppell nosed out Vic Romagna in class B on points, although each won two of the four events.

The Pulaski Skyway was closed from 112:45 to 2 o'clock this afternoon while workmen spread sand the entire length of the slippery roadway. During the time traffic was suspended, motorists were routed over the Newark Turnpike and the Lincoln Highway.
The Jew "must play life's game fairly," the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise told the Free. Synagogue in Carnegie Hall yesterday, "or else he will go down in hatred to oblivion and destruction."

Kenneth Mecker, in 15 W. 8th St.: Mrs. Alyse Abrams, in 189 W. 10th St.; Vera Dangerfield, in 220 W. 10th St.; Louis Doherty, in 224 W. 10th St.; W. M. Hupfel, in 270 W. 11th St.; William Johnston, in 220 W. 21st St.; Herbert F. Laing,
Governor M. Clifford Townsend placed all of flood-ravaged Southern Indiana under martial law today, and the whole State joined in efforts to provide haven for about 55,000 home-less.

An analogy between the sit-down strikes in industry and the lethargy characterizing many of the Christian churches was drawn yesterday morning by the Rev. Charles C. Cole, pastor of Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th- Street, in his sermon on the "Sit-down Strike in the Churches."

A heavy rainstorm mixed with sleet today caused the cancellation of the meet which was slated to open the Telemark Ski Club's new slide. It was the third sanctioned event called off in as many weeks in the East.

The United States Government mobilized its forces on a "war-time" basis tonight to fight high waters and relieve suffering in the flood-stricken Ohio and Mississippi Valleys. From now until the emergency is past, all the government agencies engaged in flood relief will be on a twentyfour-hour basis.

Cotton prices continued to move within a narrow range last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange the net changes for the week were a decline of 2 to 13 points, except on the March delivery, which was unchanged.

The only way to save our country and our heritage is to bring them completely under God's control, declared Cecil Abel in an address yesterday morning at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Important events of the seventh week of the Metropolitan season will include the American premiere of a new opera in English, the first production of "Le Coq d'Or" in its original form at this house, and the debuts of Gertrud Ruenger and of Gina Cigna, dramatic sopranos.

Lieut. Col. Eugene Reybold, United States District Engineer, announced tonight that a detachment of the Missouri National Guard had been directed by the Governor of that State to stand guard on the Missouri side while engineers dynamite the "fuse plug" levee below there, flooding the Birds Point-New Madrid floodway.

Varying views are being expressed here about the rise in commodity prices and the causes and probable duration of the movement. In a general sense, it may be said, post-war conditions and the recent depression provide the principal reasons.

Grand Av., 2.084 (11-3194): Chapel Realty Corp. to Union Dime Savings Bank; extends mtgs. to Aug. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent; $103,000. Grand Av., 2,622 (11-3205); Charles E. Mathewson to Douglas Mathewson, trustee, 2,024 Creston Av.; extends mtg. at 6 per cent: $12.500.

NAUGHTY-NAUGHT '00 "a musical drama of life at Yale" in three acts, by John Van Antwerp. Lyrics by Ted Fetter and music by Richard Lewine. Scenery by Eugene Dunkel. Presented by John and Jerrold Krimsky. At the American Music Hall, 141 East Fifty-fifth Street.

" The Robber Symphony" of Friedrich Feher, Viennese composer and cinema director, will have its American premiere tonight at the Venice Theatre, formerly the Jolson Theatre, and will continue as a two-a-day attraction.
S. H. Kress Co., store chain, and its subsidiaries, report a net income for 1936 of $5,852,395 after expenses,
Nash Buckingham of Memphis, widely known sportsman-author, believes public opinion must be aroused before a solution of the game-bootlegging problem can be obtained.

Premier Benito Mussolini revealed today that Italy had begun the construction of a new fleet of tanker motor ships, determined to avoid experiencing the lack of oil transports that developed when sanctions were imposed during the Ethiopian campaign.

Deanna Durbin, latest of Mr. Cantor's radio protegees, is making her screen debut in Universal's "Three Smart Girls" now appearing at the Roxy. Miss Durbin, 14year-old soprano, carols most sweetly in an immature, but surprisingly well trained voice.

The power problem at the beginning of 1937 has resolved itself with greater clarity than before into its simplest form, in which three general schools of thought have taken up positions. On the one hand are grouped legislators and regulators who believe in complete government ownership of power, from its source to the point of distribution; on the other,

The stock market here this week was inactive and prices of first-class papers in general sagged, with, however, recovery on Wednesday and a slight improvement toward the close of the week. For the week as a whole, few leading industrial stocks showed appreciable gains.

Myra Hess gave her first piano recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon and enriched her large audience with some superb interpretations. It is conceded that Miss Hess is outstanding among the women pianists of our time.

The National League of Women Voters made public a letter today to President Roosevelt disclosing that a vote of its board of directors had endorsed his governmental reorganization recommendations, and particularly that of the Civil Service Commission to include a single administrator and non-salaried, nonpartisan board.

Brookhattan 5. Baltimore S. C. 1. St. Mary's Celtics (Brooklyn) 5, Paterson Caledonians 1. Philadelphia Germans 5, Trenton Highlanders 2 (extra period). American League New York Americans 3, Irish-Americans (Newark) 0.

The assets of the Home Life Insurance Company of New York on Dec. 31 last were more than 25 per cent larger than on Dec. 31, 1929, according to the seventy-seventh annual report to stockholders, issued today.

BAAS--Carl August, suddenly, in his fortyninth year. beloved husband of Lillian Michaels and father of Carl, Henry and Lillian. Services at residence, 18 Norwood Road, Westchester Hills, Yonkers, N. Y., Tuesday, Jan. 26, at 8:30 P. M. Funeral private. Trains leave Grand Central 7:40 P. M. to Tuckahoe Station. BABCOCK-Addle Murr, beloved wife of Edwin Gates Babcock, on Friday, Jan. 22, at Rex Hospital, Raleigh, N. C. Notice of funeral later.

We are today in the midst of great social and economic changes, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said yesterday in his sermon at the Little Church Around the Corner, Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue.

A bill for fair trade in the tobacco industry, intended to comply with the Constitution and give the protection and regulation needed by the industry, will be introduced at this session of Congress, Siegfried F. Hartman, counsel for the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, Inc., announced yesterday.

British gold imports in December amounted to [pound]35,817,774 and exports to [pound]15,838,203, making net imports of [pound]19,979,571. Of the imports, [pound]24,015,805 were from France, [pound]7,295,204 from the Transvall, [pound]1,419,568 from India and the balance from other countries. Of the exports, [pound]12,821,152 went to the United States, [pound]1,538,830 to Sweden,

Mrs. Laura Ciccone, 50 years old, of 1,305 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, burned herself painfully in her home yesterday in what the police described as an attempt at suicide. She was taken to the Morrisania Hospital.
The Social Security Act is America's greatest insurance policy against revolution, Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein declared yesterday at the Institutional Synagogue, 148 West Eighty-fifth Street.

Detectives of the West Fortyseventh Street station started a search last night for a man described by them as "New York's meanest swindler." By promising them jobs, he stole the overcoats from two high school boys who were about to enter a Times Square movie.

With the steel industry having heavy backlogs of orders for all forms of its products, the magazine Steel says the strike in the plants of the General Motors Corporation is causing little disturbance now to the steelmakers.

Oats reelected liquidating pressure here early last week and the market became oversold, but a buying wave arrived in the last few days which caught the trade short and forced a fair advance from the low point.

A pillar of flame shot seventy-five feet in the air above the Cutter Mill Road Bridge over the Long Island Railroad tracks at 2 o'clock this morning after an automobile with three occupants crashed through a guard rail at one end of the bridge, broke a gas main of the Long Island Lighting Company and tumbled twenty-five feet down the embankment.

Captain C. K. Darling of the United States Military Academy won the individual military jumping championship of the annual Winter horse show given under the auspices of the West Point Horse Show Association in the great riding hall today.

The annual Dixie dinner dance of the New York Southern Society will take place Feb. 19 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The entertainment committee ineludes Edmund Ruffin Beckwith, chairman; Inman H. Payne and Philip W. Tucker.

Terming Hitler "the gift of the allies to Germany," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning expressed the opinion that Nazism would not have been able

THE major novel of this month is a picture of a world turned upside down. During the World War no population was pushed farther toward the end of defeat than the civilians in the neighborhood of Lille, in France near the Belgian border. The Uhlans that had so surprised Joffre by passing through Belgium arrived in the vicinity of the city in September, 1914.

The New York Rangers earned a much needed victory at Madison Square Garden last night. The blue jerseyed stick-wielders, who had been beset by a famine of goals, broke out against the Toronto Maple Leafs and scored four times, to send the visitors down to a 4-2 defeat.

The Chicago Park District substantially improved its financial structure in the last three months of 1936, according to a statement of its debt to be released today by Robert J. Dunham, president. A reduction of $6,246,618 in its debt in three months was indicated.

David C. Stewart, one of the earliest builders of oil pipe lines in the United States, died Saturday night in a Dallas (Texas) hospital, according to word received by friends here yesterday. Mr. Stewart-was 73 years old and had been in ill health for some time.
Flaming gasoline, which enveloped a motor boat rescuing a family from a flooded home, burned a grandmother and granddaughter to death today and critically injured two others.

The activities of the Salvation Army in the flood-stricken area were described here last night by Captain Harold W. Jackson of the army's publicity department. Captain Jackson received his information by telegraph from Salvation Army officers and workers in the area.

Substitution of women for men at lower pay "strikes a real blow at men's wages," Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department, declared today in her annual report, which told of the bureau's efforts to aid in the determination of wage policies for women.
The 200th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Paine was celebrated by the Community Church yesterday morning at a special service at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

This community's Townsend Club today followed an example set in Chelan, Wash., by announcing rare that $200 would be given to one of its members over 60 years old to spend within a month as another "test" of the Townsend plan.
Prices of grains and other commodities which have been advancing in leading world markets for more than a month reached last week a level where holders began taking profits.

Industry in Germany is quieter, but the electrotechnical branch is active. The average daily time worked in all industry in 1936 was 7.68 hours and almost reached the level of the boom year 1928, when the figure was 7.76.

William Woodburn Potter Jr., son of a prominent architect of this city, died yesterday following an attack of cerebral malaria while aboard the liner Carthage, bound from Bombay to Ceylon, India, according to a cablegram received by his family.

To follow the dissolution today of the firm of Webster, Kennedy Co., Inc., of New York and Boston, Raymond K. Webster, as president, has announced the formation of R. K. Webster Co., Inc., to deal in municipal and tax-exempt bonds.
Charles G. Johnson, State Treasurer, announced yesterday that 88,000 registered warrants of the State of California, amounting to approximately $21,500,000, would be called for payment in February.

The stock market this week has been dull and depressed. References to the Reich in the House of Commons by Britain's Foreign Minister, Anthony Eden, were badly taken and it is not expected that Chancellor Hitler's forthcoming reply will smooth out the situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary of Agriculture Wallace's recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine is certainly an effort to cover an almost limitless territory. Cabinet members or other high government officials when they write for the public press should expect to have their productions judged freely by the public in a somewhat different attitude from that taken toward the efforts of private individuals.

In response to appeals from Louisville officials, Philadelphia reorganized the Mayor's Emergency Flood Relief Committee, re-established its emergency medical department of ten units and loaded trucks tonight with blankets and other supplies for the Ohio flood district.

Earnings of the Bank of Nova Scotia in 1936 were $1,926,686, an increase of $92,512 from those of 1935, after deducting Dominion and Provincial taxes amounting to $474,268, according to the annual report of the bank, published today.

The Flint Alliance issued a call today for all General Motors workers and other citizens of Flint to rally together at a back-to-work mass meeting here Tuesday afternoon. Earlier in the day speakers at a union mass meeting threatened to call a sit-down strike at the Chevrolet automobile plant if it attempted to reopen this week.
Stony Point Township is divided into two warring camps today, and, as usual, the name of its most distinguished native, James A. Farley, is being invoked to settle the issue.
The stock markets here are shaking off the mild depression which affected them early in the week. The foreign-policy speech of Anthony Eden, Minister for Foreign Affairs, made a favorable impression.

Mr. and Mrs. George Roberts will give a dinner on Feb. 5 at the Ambassador before the third and last Junior Assembly of the season for their debutante daughter, Miss Constance Middleton Roberts. Miss Leonora Baring will arrive today on the Manhattan from London and will join her uncle and aunt, Lord and Lady Ashburton, at the Pierre. Her father, the Hon.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club squash racquets team gained undisputed possession of first place in the Westchester division of the Metropolitan League competition by defeating the Bronxville Field Club combination, 5 to 2, on the latter's courts in Bronxville yesterday.

City Manager C. A. Dykstra quoted President Roosevelt as telling him by telephone tonight: "The Federal Government Is standing behind Cincinnati and the entire Ohio Valley flood zones. I am dispatching more Coast Guard life-saving crews to your aid.
Joseph Trovato. store in 95 Christopher St., through Frances Spencer, Inc. American Blue Print Co., and Isidor Shor, jewelry supplies in 48 W. 48th St.; Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc.. broker.

" Give me the first six years of a child's life and you can have the rest." Looking back from this my seventieth year, it seems to me that every card in my working life has been dealt me in such a manner that I had but to play it as it came. Therefore, ascribing all good fortune to Allah the Dispenser of Events, I begin:
James John Humphreys, chief engineer of the gas department of Montreal Light, Heat and Power Consolidated for eighteen years, died at his home here tonight at the age of 66.
Anti-German demonstrations by sympathizers with the Loyalists in Spain marred the visit of 200 sailors and officers from the German battleship Schleswig-Holstein, which is anchored at Puerto Limon.

Winning six of the final eight matches, the Hungarian table tennis team defeated the American unit, 12 to 2, petition ending today. As was the case in yesterday's opening play, the United States women were the only American winners.

Stocks irregular, steel and electric equipment shares strongest; turnover, 15,541,930 shares. United States Government bonds lower, convertible issues higher, other groups steady and mixed; transactions, $75,282,400.
MORRIS BASKIND, unemployed, formerly dress goods and notions business at 611 Blake Av., residing at 1,630 St. John's Pl.. Brooklyn--Liabilities $3,030.96, no assets.

Once more tentative terms for settlement of the Sian rebellion have been agreed on but this time the proposed settlement probably will be made effective because Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is reported to have arranged the details in conferences at Fenghua with General Yang Fu-cheng's delegate.
INVASION, by Maxence van der Meersch. (Viking, $3.) A novel of life in France under German rule during the World War. THE LIFE OF RICHARD WAGNER, by Ernest Newman. (Volume II,

The first of the new Federal floodcontrol projects in the Mississippi River Valley was being put to the test for the first time today as flood waters from the Ohio River poured through a crevasse opened in the riverside levee between Cairo, Ill., and New Madrid, Mo., into the new Birds Point-New Madrid floodway.
Father Charles E. Coughlin began a new series of fifty-two Sunday broadcasts today with a memorial service for Bishop Michael J. Gallagher, who, he said, inspired his return to the air.

A Senate committee investigating allegedlabor espionage shifted its attention to the automobile industry today, summoned officers of the Chrysler Corporation and a Cleveland efficiency engineering firm to describe their relations with labor unions.
The Brookhattan soccer eleven eliminated the Baltimore F. C. by 5-1 at Starlight Park yesterday in the first round of the annual cup competition of the U. S. Football Association.
Herman Haas, who fought Indians from the driver's seat of a stagecoach, died yesterday of pneumonia at his residence, 500 West 112th Street. at the age of 83.

Germany offered today to trade machinery for grain. She is faced with a wheat shortage that some estimate will be 1,000,000 tons. Yugoslavia and Canada have provided some grain, it was said, and officials hoped to strike a deal with Argentina.
The Indians' business chief, Cyril C. Slapnicka, said today: "The Yankees will have to beat the Tribe to win a pennant this year." He advanced as his major reasons for the assertion:

Dr. Ward Andrews Holden, an oculist in this city for the last forty-seven years, died of a stroke yesterday at 1 West Fifty-fourth Street. He was in his seventy-first year. His residence and office were at 2 East Fifty-fourth Street.
Germain Glidden of New York, national and intercollegiate squash racquets champion and holder of the Rockaway Hunt Gold Racquet, added the Atlantic Coast title to his collection today.
The tank steamer Edward L. Doheny put in here early today with her bridge structure damaged, several plates on her starboard side bent, and her No. 1 lifeboat wrecked.

Frank Otis Baldwin, retired educator and business executive, died today in Evanston at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Florence Lee, wife of Professor Oliver J. Lee, Northwestern University astronomer. For several years before his retirement in 1917, Mr. Baldwin was Chicago manager of the Durable Wire Rope Division of the John A. Roebling Sons Corportion. His age was 83.

Sammy Byrd, one-time New York Yankee and Cincinnati Red outfielder, walked off with all the honors in the baseball players' national golf tournament today. Byrd posted a one-under-par 70 on the final round to lead his nearest competition at the end of the event by fourteen strokes.

The body of an unidentified woman about 40 years old was washed up on the oceanfront at Beach 123d Street, Rockaway Park, early yesterday. Mrs. C. J. Marquard of 122-10 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, strolling along the boardwalk about 7:30 A. M., discovered the body and notified the police.

A desire of individual members of Congress to do something immediate and substantial for the flood sufferers in the Mississippi and Ohio Valleys may give the administration its first serious legislative test of the present session during the next two weeks.
Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie McAlpin, to Calvin Wright Dail, son of Mrs. Levin S. Dail of Cambridge, Md., and the late Mr. Dail.
New bond issues for financing the output of raw materials under the Four-Year Plan appear to be favorably regarded here by investors.

More than 300,000 converts to Roman Catholicism a year in New York City may be expected if a general understanding of Catholic doctrine and Catholic "morality" is effected by the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine,
Pope Pius passed another good night, enjoying about seven hours of almost uninterrupted sleep without any artificial aid, and he awoke this morning rested and free of pain.

Sir Charles Higham, British publieist, arrives on the United States liner Manhattan this morning accompanies by Lady Higham. Other travelers from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh include Peter Freuchen, Danish explorer and author, and the following:

American European Securities Company-Report as of Dec. 31, 1936: Market value of securities was $15,850,561, compared with $12,347,018 a year earlier. Net asset value applicable to common stock was $19.57 a share on 345,500 shares, against $9.43 a share at end of 1935.

President Roosevelt's inaugural address has not thrown much light on his plans. It is wondered whether he is considering a revision of the Constitution so as to give the central administration powers which were denied by the Supreme Court.

There has been a large subscription for the annual Authors Matinee for the benefit of the Mary Fisher Home, which will take place this afternoon at the Commodore. In addition to the appearance of John Martin, Margaret Widdemer and Arthur Pound, authors, there will be a musical program by Jacob Feurring, pianist, and Lela Flossman, contralto.

Rare astronomical instruments and books from the collection of Dr. David Eugene Smith, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Columbia University, have been lent by the university for display in the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West.
Americanbred horses, led by the favored Muscletone, owned by G. Miani of Italy, swept the first three places today in the 200,000-franc trotting Prix d'Ameriquen among seventeen entries.
That America in time of sudden and widespread disaster looks first to the neighborly spirit of the people to care for the sufferers is of gratifying significance.

The annual boxing championship tournament of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. comes to a close tonight, with a field of thirtyseven warriors scheduled to compete at Madison Square Garden in the semi-final and final rounds.

United States players gained two Canadian amateur racquets championships today as Robert Grant 3d of New York defeated J. A. Rolland of Montreal in the singles final and teamed with C. C. Pell Jr., also of New York, to win the doubles from G. D. Husband and S. H. Dobell, Montreal.

With Governor Lehman putting the finishing touches to his executive budget, the members of Senate and Assembly will gather again on Capitol Hill tomorrow, prepared for a season of activity after the lull of the past week.

Under the appraising eyes of such boxing notables as James J. Braddock, Joe Gould, Mike Jacobs and James J. Johnston, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, Joe Louis, went through his training chores today in preparation for his tenround fight with Bob Pastor, husky young Washington Heights battler, in Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

After the expected identification today of about $300,000 worth of jewelry stolen from the Washington home of Mrs. Frederick H. Bugher last Thursday, New York police will begin an intensive effort to discover the ownership of some $65,000 to $80,000 worth of other gems recovered Saturday with the Bugher loot.

Always something new from Africa, was the old saying. In our time it seems to be transferred to Soviet Russia. Her capacity to astonish the world might seem to have been exhausted before this, but Saturday's proceedings in the new criminal trial at Moscow add a fresh surprise.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Hope Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winchester Noyes of 45 East Sixty-second Street and Huntington, L. I., to James Mulford Townsend Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Mulford Townsend of this city and St. James, L. I., which will take place on Feb. 13 at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

More than 500 members and guests of the New York Urban League attended the annual meeting of the organization yesterday afternoon at Mother Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church, 140 West 137th Street, and heard Grover Whalen, president of the New York World Fair, promise that Negroes would not be discriminated against "in any way" by the management of the project.

A blizzard has dislocated shipping between the Black and Aegean Seas during the last twenty-four hours and has covered Istanbul with snow. Some vessels have been stranded and others involved in collisions.

John Sanford was host to a large group for cocktails today to welcome his daughter, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford, and her fiance, Mario Pansa of Rome, who arrived from New York. The party was held at Villa Marina.

The Coast Guard reported today it had mobilized the greatest flood relief force in its history. Eight hundred men, 200 boats, 12 airplanes, 8 communication trucks and 24 portable communication outfits have been ordered into the stricken areas, officials said.

Nicholas Legat, premier danseur and maitre de ballet of the Czarist Russian Marinsky Theatre, died in London today at the age of 67. Among the many who came to him for advice were such dancers as Paylova, Karasavina, Dolin, Markova, Danilva. Baronova and Toumanova.

The Reading Company reports for 1936 a net railway operating income $13,944,785, an increase of $1,382,425, compared with the preceding year. Operating revenue for 1936 amounted to $59,291,758, a gain of $7,931,350, while railway operating expenses amounted to $40,518,205, an increase of $4,766,000.

Fulfilling general expectations, based upon his consistent record in European competition, Reuben Fine of New York, triumphed in the ninth and final round today and took first prize in the international chess masters tournament at the Schacksalonger Chess Club.
Former Mayor James J. Walker told the Grand Street Boys Association at the Hotel Commodore last night that the present political scene made laughs run up and down his sleeves.

Fritz Pollard Jr., third in the Olympic 110-meter high hurdles, has accepted an invitation to compete in the 60-yard timber-topping event which will be one of the features of the thirtieth annual Millrose A. A. meet at Madison Square Garden Feb. 6.
Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange, announced tonight that he would introduce tomorrow a bill to regulate billboard advertising.
National Guardsmen reported tonight that Negro and white prisoners were battling each other at the water-logged Frankfort Reformatory and that twelve were dead in rioting.
Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.2, which compares with 90.7 the week before.

Financial opinion is reported as not perturbed by events in Spain and the international policy. It is considered no serious complications will arise from this side. As to the domestic situation there is an optimistic air.

A mortgage for $8,000 on 402 E. 10th St. held by the Bowery Savings Bank from the Elak Realty Corp., Heyman Kaplowitz, president, was extended to Dec. 1, 1941, at 3 cer cent until Dec. 1, 1939 and 3 1/2 per cent thereafter.

VOX POPULI and secret ballots carried the day int he voting for the baseball names to grace the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y., and in a democracy the decision at the polls should run for more than the fabled Mr. Sweeney.

Frederic W. Shepard of Woodmere, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Cornelia Shepard of 222 East Fiftyseventh Street, to Dr. John L. Riker, son of Mrs. Henry Ingersoll Riker of 7 East Seventy-second Street.

W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, reported today the lines cartied 16,780 passengers in December, more than in any previous month in its history and 53 per cent more than the same month of 1935.

Looting started throughout the flood-covered Portsmouth business district tonight as the Ohio River rose steadily to 70.56 feet and relief authorities made frantic efforts to remove the refugees to Chillicothe and Columbus.

Sanction in New York State of divorce by mutual consent was advocated yesterday morning by Algernon D. Black, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, in an address at the society's meeting house, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

The British Home Fleet arrived here today for its annual Spring cruise. Preceded by the cruiser Cairo with the Fifth and Sixth Destroyer Flotillas, the battle squadron under Admiral Sir Roger Backhouse, commanderin-chief of the Home Fleet, came in in the morning.

Expressing his determination to "keep after crooked lawyers and doctors," District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday he planned to establish on a permanent basis the bureau he organized last July to curb the filing of fraudulent accident claims.

Leo Fish, New York insurance executive, said today he had extended his campaign to have escalators installed in Grand Central Terminal, Manhattan. A month ago he interested the president and other officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad in the proposal but no action has been taken by them.
Playing in the rain, the St. Mary's Celtic soccer team defeated the Paterson Caledonians, 5 to 1, at Celtic Oval in Brooklyn yesterday, in the first round of the National Challenge Cup competition.

While C. C. Fleming, spender in this town's Townsend plan experiment, took another hitch in his purse strings, the city administration ignored today the "petty jealousies which are developing in neighboring towns."

Consuming interests are taking corn readily in all markets. The Argentine staple is said to be offered freely on the Atlantic Coast. None, however, is coming to Chicago, and it may not come unless the local price is advanced to a level which will permit profitable imports.

A large group of younger members of society headed by Miss Helen Hope is active in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Lohengrin," with Kirsten Flagstad in the leading role, next Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by the Vassar Club of New York for the benefit of that organization's scholarship fund.

Rose Turner, 15 years old, a pupil in the eighth grade at St. Jerome's Parochial School, was severely burned yesterday in her home at 282 East 134th Street when her dress caught fire from a coal stove.

Kazushige Ugaki, a retired general of the army and formerly Governor General of Korea, was entrusted by Emperor Hirohito this morning with the formation of a Cabinet to take the place of the fallen Koki Hirota government. He was recommended by Prince Saionji, the last of the Genro [Elder Statesmen].

A proposal by the Civil Service Reform Association to eliminate the fixed term of clerks in the Municipal and magistrate's courts was endorsed yesterday by Pelham St. George Bissell, Presiding Justice of the Municipal Courts;

The National Youth Administration spent $3,165,794 in this city last year, helping 22,212 high school and college students to continue their studies and providing part-time work outside of school for 13,113 young persons, Mark A. McCloskey, regional NYA director, reported yesterday.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. has increased the number of fellowships it awards annually to six post-doctorate fellowships and eighteen post-graduate fellowships for the academic year 1937-38.

The proposal to peg scrap iron prices at 40 per cent of the composite price of semi-finished steel, Pittsburgh base, with differentials for various grades of scrap and for different markets, made at the recent convention of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., has drawn a mixed reception in the trade, according to reports here yesterday.

" The importance of a world horizon in religion" was discussed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Watson, president of the American University in Cairo, at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
Engine trouble forced the trawler Girl Pat to put back into Georgetown Harbor today nine hours after she had set out for Cayenne, French Guiana, on the first stage of a return voyage to England.

Forty-one of the total entry list of eighty-two will begin play today in the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton High School indoor interschoplastic tennis tournament on Nick's Courts at the 369th Regiment Armory, 143d Street and Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. The competition will start at 1 o'clock.

Accompanied by high Sofia officials and thirty Bulgarian newspaper men, Premier George Kiosseivanoff of Bulgaria made a triumphant entry today into the Yugoslav capital. Thousands gathered at the beflagged station, where Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia greeted him affectionately.

The northeastern part of Bergen County is being overrun by red and gray foxes, who make their homes during the day in the adjoining Palisades Interstate Park, where hunting is prohibited, and prey during the night on the small wild game and domesticated poultry outside the park's confines.

Food is the principal problem in the isolated Little River communities of Delhi, Sayler Park and Fernbank, below here. Residents are cooking what little they have in open fireplaces. Gasoline is rationed out in one-gallon lots.
Light hogs were in demand here last week, packers and shippers taking all offerings in a steady market, with the best grades of 210 to 300 pounds bought at $10.25 to $10.35 a hundredweight.
Firemen dragged heroic telephone girls from their posts and rescued four persons from the upper floor as fire swept the building in North Main Street last night with an estimated loss of $100,000.

Darkened cities, looting and threats of clashes between armed bodies of men were added early today to the stark terror produced by the disastrous flood swelling down the Ohio and upper Mississippi River Valleys.

Unconditional cooperation with Germany on the basis of absolute equality was proposed to Chancellor Adolf Hitler by French Premier Leon Blum in a speech here today for the realization of the Reich Chancellor's often declared ideal of peace.

An intercollegiate literary conference, in which prominent men of letters have been invited to join with representatives of eighty Eastern colleges in a two-day discussion, will be held at Princeton University April 23 and 24, it was announced today by Professor Christian Guass, dean of the college.

A derelict, 250,000-gallon tank of gasoline, which had broken loose and was drifting slowly on flood currents, threatened a renewal early today of the disastrous fire that had already caused damage of $3,000,000 in this inundated city.
The widow of the assassinated Chancellor Engelbert Dolifuss has returned to- rural life to seek forgetfulness and simplicity for herself and her two young children.

Mrs. William G. Reynolds and Miss Fay Devereaux Keith gave a tea dance yesterday at 120 East End Avenue for members of the junior committee working toward the success of the Coro d'Italia ball to be held Thursday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Italian choral organization, comprising more: than 250 young men and women.

Rutgers St., 35-37, 48x104.6; 35-37 Rutgers St., Inc., to Mason Hanger Co., Inc., and City of New York (release). 112th St., 323 E., 27x101; Thomas A. Carberry to Bunker Realty Corp., 285 Madison Av., care of Gettner S. and Asher ($4).
It is a sad and dreadful thing to see your friends on trial for their lives. And it is sadder and more dreadful to hear them hang themselves with their own words.

Holding a 14-10 lead at the halfway mark, the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, quintet turned back the Crescent Athletic Club, 32-25, in an Eastern Athletic Club League clash on the New Mooners' court yesterday.

Sir Hamilton Grant, former Chief Commissioner of Northwest Frontier Province of India, who negotiated the British peace treaty with Afghanistan in 1919, died of a heart attack today. He was 64 years old.

The champion Detroit Red Wings finally broke their Montreal jinx tonight, scoring a 2-to-1 victory over the Maroons before 12,000 spectators. Three previous encounters this season have ended in ties, the latest in Montreal last night.

With a total of 58,295 shipments, gross revenue from the air express business of the Railway Express Agency for December showed an increase of 80 per cent over the gross revenue for the new and old contract airlines in the same month last year.

The statement of the Bank of France of Jan. 15 shows a decrease of 553,000,000 francs in advances on securities and thirty-day advances on bonds. On the other hand, advances to the State increased a further 550,000,000 francs.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Kenneth Davidson, professional badminton champion of the British Isles, defeated Howard Brand, Canadian ace and one of the leading professionals in the East, 15-12, 10-15, 15-10, in an exhibition match before a crowd of more than 200 today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Governor Lawrence W. Cramer of the Virgin Islands said today that the United States could look for an early end to what he described as "pouring money down a sinkhole" in the islands. Here to ask Congress for new legislation, he said that results were already beginning to show from the Federal millions expended

Gordon Kingsley's plane was located this morning by an airliner flown by Pilot Spillman in a jungle ten minutes by air north of the Bonanza mines, whence Kingsley had taken off Jan. 16 to search for his brother.

Gladys Felicano, 18-year-old maid who had been sought since New Year's Eve when she escaped from the woman's detention pen in the West 123d Street police station, was captured by detectives last night in a room at 50 St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.
Fire swept through sound stages and cutting rooms at the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Studios today, destroying $200,000 worth of scenery, equipment and unreleased films.
The New York Americans defeated the Irish-Americans of Newark in an American Soccer League fixture, 3 to 0, before 1,500 fans at Clark's Field today.

Hospital authorities disclosed today that Crown Prince Michael of Rumania underwent only a local anesthetic for an emergency appendectomy when he was stricken here while visiting his mother, former Queen Helen.

Although President Roosevelt's second term of office opens with a threatening labor situation in the United States, it is felt here that the good luck and good judgment which characterized his first term will persist and that the United States will experience steadily advancing prosperity.

A note of decided optimism is running through the views expressed by British bankers in their annual addresses to shareholders. Not only is the volume of bank advances steadily rising but their spread is much wider, indicating a general expansion of business activity.

The New York University-Fordham football game, a Thanksgiving Day fixture for the past few years, has been shifted to Saturday, Nov. 27, this year, Al Nixon, N. Y. U. graduate manager, announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

The Gourmet Society went Arctic yesterday, dined on Alaskan reindeer loin, heard Vilhjalmur Stefansson extol the "delights" of seal blubber and listened to Gelett Burgess recite "An Epic of Arctic Grub."

The choice of the Catholic Book Club for February will be "A Flower for Sign," by Louis Stancourt, a convert to the Roman Catholic faith. The book is his autobiography. It will be published on Feb. 2 by Macmillan.

Mrs. Herman L. Heide will give a luncheon tomorrow at her home, 210 Riverside Drive, for directors of the Alumnae of the Sacred Heart Convent. Later she will take her guests to the lecture on "The New Civilization in Religion and Morals"

Tonight's new play-and the only Broadway opening of the week, for that matter-is "Tide Rising," once known as "Small Town America." Signed by George Brewer Jr. and produced by the new firm of Richard Aldrich and Richardson Myers, it comes to the Lyceum to tell a story of a strike in a small town.

The Sunday of the Renovacion Espafola, the Spanish Alfonsist saint's day, was commemorated throughout Insurgent territory with church services, monarchist rallies and newspaper articles paying homage to the exiled monarch.

F. A. Cauchois and A. L. Burns each finished with an excellent card of 95 despite the handicap of rain in the 100-target shoot at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Cauchois scored in the shoot-off, taking the high-scratch trophy by 24-22.

Only two players participated in the first qualifying round of the left-handers' Winter golf championship at the Miami Biltmore Country Club today. A. R. Trumbo of Ottawa, Ill., turned in a card of 44, 47-91 to lead Walter E. Wright of Chicago, who came in with 44, 51-95.

The apostolic benediction of Pope Pius XI was conveyed to two Roman Catholic congregations yesterday morning in the Diocese of Brooklyn by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy, who presided at solemn high mass in commemoration of anniversaries.

Six of the eleven members of a tenant miner's family are dead, victims of an explosion of a keg of blasting powder in their home. Three died soon after the blast. The other three died in a Canton, Ill., hospital.

A conspiracy to sabotage the entire Soviet railway system in order to assure the defeat of Russia in the event of war with Japan and Germany was related today by Karl Radek, a former editor of Izvestia and one of seventeen defendants who have pleaded guilty of treason.

The Treasury reported to Congress today the $2,115,313 turned back to the Ford Motor Company of Detroit was the largest single tax refund in the last fiscal year. Big business and big names were interspersed in the refund list with thousands that never made a headline.

Although some confusion is bound to arise from the imposition of foreign exchange restrictions by Japan, the London market so far has not experienced any serious difficulty in liquidating its contracts.

Sixty-nine corporations with net incomes of $5,000,000 or more in 1933 received nearly a third of the total income of all corporations in the-country, according to a report made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc.

The WPA Federal Music Project opened its own Theatre of Music on West Fifty-fourth Street last night. Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the project, presided as guest conductor over the Federal Symphony Orchestra of 100 players.

Urging income taxpayers to file their returns early, the Bureau of Internal Revenue disclosed yesterday that many taxpayers in the last-minute rush on March 15 make errors that cause them in many cases to pay more than the tax due.
The Red Bank Polo Club won an indoor round-robin polo match today at the Red Bank Armory with a total score of 13 1/2 goals. Winmont Farms was runner up with 10 1/2 and Ponolo third with 5 1/2.

Advertising budgets of seventy major American corporations, with assets totaling more than $50,000,000,000, will be 10 to 50 per cent higher this year than last, according to replies to a questionnaire sent out by Colonel Benjamin F. Castle, vice president of the Administrative and Research Corporation.

Ogden Av. (9-2524). w. s., 50 ft. s. of 162d St., 50x95; Jean O'Byrne to Annie Elliott, 248 Wadsworth Av. 169th St. (10-2612), s. w. s., 105 ft. n. w. of Franklin Av., 35x116; Randolph Trading Corp. to Fannie Berger, 2,055 Cruger Av.
Realty transactions reported in the city over the week-end included the sale by Ella M. Crow of the fivestory professional building for physicians and dentists at 111 West Seventy-second Street.

Trailing five goals to one with less than ten minutes to play, the stumbling and stalling Boston Bruins snapped out of their most futile exhibition of the season tonight and drove in enough goals to gain a 6-6 overtime tie before 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

Walter Gropius, German architect, one of the originators of the modern architectural movement in Europe and considered one of the world's most brilliant designers of industrial buildings, has been appointed Professor of Architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Designing, it was announced tonight.

Business expects a general rise in wages and prices and believes that shortages in some raw materials and delayed deliveries of some raw and manufactured products are likely, but sees no general tendency toward speculative buying, according to answers to a questionnaire sent by the Guaranty Trust Company to a selected group of business concerns.

Many parties were given today at the Bath Club and at the Surf Club here. Prince Nicholas Tourmanoff of Paris was a luncheon guest of Mrs. R. H. Hasler of Old Westbury, L. I., at the Bath Club, where Mrs. N. B. Woolworth of New York had with her Mrs. Elliott Fox of New York.
Anthony B. Cassedy, Vice president and general sales manager of William Jameson Co., Inc., makers of Irish-American whiskey, announced the following sales appointments: M. P. (Casey) Jones,
A taxicab driver and two policemen barely escaped injury in Brooklyn last night when a charged trolley wire on the Gates Avenue line snapped suddenly and fell at Fulton Street and Flatbush Avenue.

Invoking authority given her by the law that created the Department of Labor to make a new attempt to solve the General Motors strike deadlock, Secretary Perkins today called a conference for Wednesday, at her office here, of leaders of the corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America.

Another effort to obtain an appropriation from the Legislature to build a modern cell block to replace the 112-year-old stone cell block in Sing Sing prison will be made this year. It was understood that the request would be for $900,000.

Miss Maddy Horn, a Beaver Dam, Wis., girl, took a place among the nation's leading skaters today by improving upon two more national speed skating record times in the conclusion of the Great Lakes ice carnival.

Resolutions commending President Roosevelt for his "frank and courageous recognition of the need for a housing program adequate to national necessity," and urging the immediate enactment of legislation to give effect to his recommendations, were adopted unanimously at the closing session today of the National Public Housing Conference.

The Nonpartisan Committee for Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment sent a letter yesterday to the Governors of nineteen States that have not ratified the amendment, indirectly replying to the objections to ratification set forth last week by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

Communication and transportation facilities to the inundated areas of the Ohio Valley were taxed to a breaking point yesterday as flood waters continued to rise. While all available equipment has been pressed into service and emergency field crews have been struggling day and night against the flood, local offices of communication and transportation companies reported last night thatservice had been washed out in all but the larger cities of the area.

The opera concert last night at the Metropolitan was heard by a large and responsive audience. An elaborate bill was presented. The artists were Elisabeth Rethberg, Gertrud Wettergren, Hilda Burke, Susanne Fisher, Irene Jessner, Queena Mario, Lucielle Browning, Anna Kaskas, Joseph Bentonelli, Charles Kullmann, Sydney Rayner, Richard Bonelli, Carlo Morelli and Ezio Pinza.

As a result of his recent dispute with the Air Ministry, Lord Nuffield has formed a new company for the manufaoture of armaments. Capitalized at [Pound]250,000 in shares of El each, the new company, called Mechanizations, will carry on the manufacture of armaments of all kinds, specializing particularly in the production of tanks, armored oars, trucks and other conveyances. It will also make airplanes.

The Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall, pastor of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street, and the Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestly, associate minister, delivered a joint sermon yesterday on "Age Speaks to Youth" and "Youth Speaks to Youth."

Thomas J. Kinsella of 108 Dwight Street, Brooklyn, who resigned as an Assistant Corporation Counsel in 1926 to resume private law practice, died yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital of a brief attack of heart disease. He was a bachelor, 47 years old.

Henry Norris Young, a descendant of the Bounty mutineers, left for Pitcairn Island last night on the motor liner Rangitiki after a fourday visit here. It was the first time he had left the island since his. birth there forty-nine years ago.

Displaying a fine technique in all her bouts, Mrs. Dolly Funke of the Greco Fencing Academy accounted for the first major triumph of her career when she won the second of a series of women's competitions for the Santelli Trophy at the Salle Santelli yesterday.

Representative Andrew Jackson Montague, former Governor of Virginia, died this morning at his home in Urbana, Middlesex County, Va. His death, attributed to a heart attack, followed a long period of ill health. He was 74 years old.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had issued an order directing the Raladam Company, Detroit, to discontinue alleged misrepresentations that its product "Marmola" provides in the "average" case "the right way to reduce" and that "this modern method of reduction is now used by doctors the world over."

Miss Dorothy Lampen of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Charles Lampen of Great Falls, Mont., was married to Willis Irving Thomson of New Rochelle, son of Mrs. Metullus Thomson of Minneapolis and the late Mr. Thomson, yesterday afternoon in the manse of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Edmund M. Wylie, the pastor.

A voyage through the Mediterranean today is disappointing to travelers who debark at ports like Gibraltar or Algiers or scan the coasts of Spain and Spanish Morocco for signs of tension or excitement. Fewer warships than usual are anchored in Mediterranean harbors.
Leon Degrelle, leader of the Rexist party, has begun six meetings in Brussels to test his popularity and that of his Fascist movement in the Belgian capital.

The new "Summer hours" which closed places of business between noon and 5 P. M. to avoid the heat were modified today to permit the heads of commercial houses to give three hours of rest in the middle of the day.

The New York World's Fair bond sales committee announced yesterday the receipt of ten subscriptions for bonds in amounts of $20,000 and over, including two for $100,000 each. On the basis of last week's figures, the committee has sold $14,325,000 of the total amount of $27,829,500 offered to finance the exposition.
The German wholesale price index on Jan. 13 stood at 105.3, against 105.2 on Jan. 6. The December monthly index was at 105.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M., "Realities of Russian Life," Maurice Hindus. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Devaluation and Foreign Trade," Dr. H. Parker Willis.

Desperate and weary citrus growers, beset with a shortage of fuel and faced with a prospect of more subfreezing weather, made ready tonight for another battle against the fruit-destroying frost in Southern California.
Louisville's power plant failed at 11:37 o'clock, Central time, tonight, plunging the flood-stricken metropolitan area into darkness save for candles and kerosene lanterns.
Clarence Cottier Vernam, vice president and a director of the Street Smith Publications, 79 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday at his residence, 480 Park Avenue, after a long illness, at the age of 64.

The annual report of the Archivist of the United States speaks of the technique of "microfilming" and points out that the growing demand for storage space makes it necessary to consider seriously how valuable records may be photographed on reduced scale and thus made available without injuring the originals.

The act of kneeling by the side of autos on Sunday morning in making preparations for a trip instead of going to church, was described as a form of idolatry in a sermon yesterday morning at the Hanson Place Baptist Church, at South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn.

The four-story apartment house at 43-19 Thirty-ninth Place, Sunnyside, L. I., was sold by NormanLila Estates, Inc., operators, to an investing client of Horace Marks. There are forty suites in the building, which occupies a plot 95 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages of $100,000.
Highway traffic through much of the Middle West and the Mississippi Valley was impeded today by a coating of ice which made all motoring hazardous and kept most automobiles off the roads.
The 1938 board of editors of The Yale Daily News tonight assumed office, headed by Robert S. Shriver Jr. of New York City, '38, as chairman. His associates the coming year will be:

Practically all departments were represented in the influx of arriving buyers last week, and the wholesale markets reported active interest in ready-to-wear, accessories and other items. Despite unfavorable weather conditions,...

The seamen's strike on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts was formally declared at an end last night when Joseph Curran, chairman of the International Seamen's Union strike committee, announced that nine of the thirteen striking ports had voted affirmatively.

Amid the glittering appointments of the Rockefeller Center Rainbow Room, fogbound last night at its sixty-five-story level, representatives of the cinema art and those of the stage who can find time occasionally for the movies gathered last night to celebrate the distribution of guerdons bestowed by the New York Film Critics on the productions, players and director considered by them the best in screen productions of 1936.
A ten-year development program for the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, with a series of objectives estimated to cost $15,500,000, was announced today by the board of trustees.
