A sweeping investigation of the legal fees paid out by the public utilities in New York State in the last six years has been ordered by the Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday. The step was decided upon at a meeting of the commission last week.

Figures for France's foreign trade in December are not very satisfactory. Imports amounted to 3,013,000,000 francs, against 2,707,000,000 in the preceding month and 1,968,000,000 in December, 1935. Exports last month amounted to 1,637,000,000 francs, against 1,720,000,000 and 1,290,000,000 for a month before and a year before, respectively.

The score or more of new art exhibitions this week include a number of group and individual shows of considerable interest. Among them are the annual exhibition by members of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, at the Galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, opening with a reception this evening and to the public tomorrow.

The American Legion Monthly publishes today an article by the new national commander of the veterans' organization, Mr. COLMERY. In it he denies that the Legion is shaping an " entering wedge" for a general pension plan.
The fate of Paducah, Ky., was known only to the inhabitants of that water-isolated city tonight. The last word Paducah sent here was a radio message this morning.

Again this afternoon the center of Madrid was blasted by high explosives, although not so badly as yesterday. Eight persons were known killed and twenty-five wounded. This time the Rebel batteries seemed to be feeling their way carefully. They started with shrapnel and seventy-fives, then rose to sixinch and finally eight-inch shells, their aim improving as they proceeded.

Miss Doris Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Havemeyer of 960 Fifth Avenue and Olympic Point, Islip, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Daniel Catlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel K. Catlin of St. Louis and Dublin, N. H., which will take place the afternoon of Feb. 9 in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Ed Dudley, veteran golf campaigner, came charging home today with two sub-par rounds to post a 72-hole total of 273 and win the $3,000 Sacramento open from a formidable field. Twice a member of the Ryder Cup team and winner of the last Philadelphia and Shawnee opens, Dudley cracked par, the course record and the opposition in putting together one of the lowest 72-hole totals in golf records.
The latest monthly index published by the Department of Labor shows that factory employment in December last reached the highest level since December, 1929.

December passenger traffic on both the subway and elevated divisions of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was lower last month than it was the year before, Thomas E. Murray, Interborough receiver, announced yesterday. He was inclined to put part of the blame on the weather.

One seeded player was eliminated from the fifteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club as the field moved into the quarter-finals today. E. Percy Field Jr. of Short Hills, who plays with the Princeton Club, registered his second upset in two days when he defeated William J. Hall of the Crescent Club in straight games, 15-11, 15-3.

A total of 17,344 jobs in private industry were filled by the New York State Employment Service and the National Re-employment Service during the month of December, according to Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews today.

The review by John Corbin of Morris L. Ernst's "The Ultimate Power," in the Book Review of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, incorrectly said that Mr. Ernst "has been engaged by the administration to defend the Wagner Labor Bill before the Supreme Court."

An organization called the National Tenants Council, Inc., aiming to protect the tenant against exhorbitant rental charges, has been formed here, and plans to organize branches in New York and other cities.

Ed Kretz of Pomona, Wash., won the 200-mile Southeastern Motorcycle Association road race today. Kretz, the first driver to win the event twice, was clocked at 74.1 miles an hour, a new record for the association.

A telephone call to the police by a representative of the Save-a-Life League, an organization devoted to a campaign against suicide, saved the life last night of Dr. John B. Woodman, a dental surgeon with offices on the fourteenth floor of 60 Broadway.

Plans for the formation of the Newark Committee on Youth Guidance, which will attempt to coordinate the activities of this city's youth groups, will be discussed at a luncheon meeting at the Newark Athletic Club Friday.
Henry Elsworth Gregory, retired lawyer and member of an old New York family, died in his apartment at the Heathcote Inn here yesterday of pneumonia. He was 79 years old.
At the beginning of the week there developed a somewhat sharp setback on the Stock Exchange, but the decline was principally in consequence of profit-taking by speculators.

An experimental flight, deliberately made in the worst weather the East had to offer, ended yesterday near Princeton, N. J., in a forced landing. The start had been made at Kansas City in overcast weather by D. W. Tomlinson, assistant to Jack Frye, president of T. W. A., Inc., and chief research pilot of the line.

A political deal by which Senator George McGill of Kansas would be appointed to a new vacancy on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Tenth Judicial Circuit and Guy T. Helvering, the present Commissioner of Internal Revenue, would succeed to his Senate seat was reported to have been worked out here among a group of leaders late last week.

Christians are too complacent and smug and need the divine discontent of Jesus, the Rev. Mr. Harry James Knickle said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East Eighty-sixth Street.

The "sit-down" strike idea has spread to convicts employed in the Eastern Penitentiary shops here, but Warden Herbert B. Smith said today that he and the men had "laughed it off." Four of the leaders, however, were reported to have been placed in solitary confinement.

Air Minister Hermann Goering returned from Italy today, coming direct from Rome to Berlin, and Chancellor Adolf Hitler came up from Berchtesgaden to meet him and hear his report of all that had passed between Premier Benito Mussolini and Col. Gen. Goering last week.
Igor Stravinsky concluded his fortnight's stay as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon amid shouting and tumult.

Jobs have not kept pace with production, and this is reflected in the large number of persons who have to be taken care of by relief agencies, Commissioner of Public Welfare William Hodson said yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies in the Hotel Commodore.

The Social Security Board announced today a ruling that wage earners shall not be required to sign "severance" reports, the form used by employers in reporting to State unemployment compensation administrations when

Possibility of the Republican offered party's disappearing, as did the Federalist and Whig parties in the earlier days of the Republic, is discussed in the February issue of Fortune Magazine in an article headed "His Excellency's Loyal Opposition and How It Will Play Its Hand, being a discussion of whether the Republican party should stand on a pair of deuces or draw to a red-card flush or turn in its chips and go home."
Russia rejected today a Japanese protest over the search of two Japanese steamers at Vladivostok last Tuesday.

For the second successive week metropolitan colleges emerged with all the laurels in their encounters with out-of-town basketball rivals. Long Island University continued to set the pace and turned in two victories to bring its total for the season to eighteen against only one defeat.

The sixtieth annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association will be held here from Wednesday evening through Saturday, with day sessions at the headquarters of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, and night meetings at the Manhattan Club and the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

A country doctor who braved wild seas on a trip to the island of Soay reported tonight that forty-six of its fifty-one inhabitants were stricken with influenza and that a number were "on the brink of starvation."
Plans for the agricultural conservation program in Rhode Island and New Jersey during 1937 have been approved by Secretary Wallace, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.
A treedwelling earthworm, strange frogs from a mountain-top, specimens of rare mammals and nearly 2,000 birds-some of which may be varieties new to science-are among specimens obtained by H. G.

James J. Bambrick, president of the Greater New York Council of the Building Service Employes International Union, set a one-week deadline yesterday for voluntary compliance by owners of loft and office buildings with the terms of the Silcox award, which ended the building service strike here last April.

August W. Brockmeyer, for thirty-two years secretary and treasurer of C. Schmidt Sons, brewers, died at his home in Brookline, a suburb, last night after an illness of six months. He was 65 years old. Born in Hoboken, N. J., he came to Philadelphia fifty-five years ago and entered the employ of the brewery a few years later.

Miss Grace Bernard Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Arnold Hamilton of this place, was married to Willard Maxwell Kellogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Kellogg, last evening in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William T. Hooper.

The second half of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League's split season was duly launched yesterday afternoon and a crowd of 15,371 persons sat in Madison Square Garden as witnesses. But there was one thing lacking in the colorful picture.

Christians must keep faith and follow their leader, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine said yesterday morning in his sermon. "There is such a thing as religious sanity and this is the way to keep it," he declared.
Henry D. Silverman, president of the Brookhaven (L. I.) Town Board of Trustees, died here at 7 A. M. today in the Marlborough Hotel. He was 76 years old.
The pairings for the second round of the National Challenge Cup competition were announced last night by J. J. Barriskill, chairman of the cup committee of the United States Football Association.

Judge John C. Pollock, 79, of the Federal District Court of Kansas died early today at his suburban home. Judge Pollock, who had been on the Federal bench since 1903, had been unconscious since Monday, when he was brought to his home from his Texas ranch. He was suffering from a diabetic ailment. Friday physicians reported that he had been stricken with pneumonia.

Many eating places were closed by the flood tonight, but not that of Christ Thodis and Nick Patakides, - who boast that their lunch room has never shut its doors or turned off its stove since the Armistice.

Recommendations for an economic policy for the United States designed to promote world peace were announced yesterday by the National Peace Conference, representing thirty-seven of the largest American organizations in the field.

A new issue of $3,400,000 Southern California Water Company first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, series of 1960, will be offered publicly today at 103 1/2 and accrued interest by Chandler Co., Inc.; G. L. Ohrstrom Co., Inc.; Swart, Brent Co., Inc.; Burr Co., Inc.; Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc.; Dulin Co., Bond Goodwin, Inc., and Boenning Co.

Railroad repair crews toiled today in an effort to restore service on the Erie's Graham freight line, where thirty-seven cars of an eastbound train piled up in a rock cut two miles west of here last night.
Lotte Lehmann's Elisabeth was the focal point of the dull and undistinguished performance of "Tannhaeuser" given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Fifteen seniors of Hunter College received "H" pins yesterday at a luncheon held by the class of January, 1937, at the Hotel Rosoff, 147 West Forty-third Street. More than 100 of the students who will be graduated tomorrow were present.
Salomon BroS. Hutzler won yesterday the award of $7,080,000 of 2 per cent Series B equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company on their bid of 97.777.

Mayor La Guardia, confined to his bed with a cold, was keeping in close touch last night with the strike situation in the B. M. T. power plant in Williamsburg. While he had made no open move to intervene he was being advised of every development.

Blair Gullion, coach of the Tennessee basketball team which meets Long Island University tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, arrived here late last night from Lexington, Ky., after a wild auto drive which got him across the flooded Ohio River just thirty minutes before the last bridge was closed.

Mrs. F. D. Roosevelt'attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's musical at the Mayflower Hotel this morning, having as her guests Mrs. James Roosevelt and Mrs. Price Collier, mother and aunt of the President, who returned in the afternoon to New York.

Here in the capital of non-intervention diplomacy, the German and Italian replies to the British notes are felt to be reasonable in tone and as satisfactory as could be expected. At first sight they seemed to strengthen the impression that neither Germany nor Italy wants to provide a European war over Spain.

In deposits, total assets and number of depositors, the mutual savings banks of the country established high records on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. Deposits amounted to $10,101,073,980, a net gain of $183,260,928 in the year.

Walter C. Berran is with Babcock, Rushton Co. and will have his office at the branch at 225 Broadway. Eugene F. Kinkead, chairman of the executive committee of the Colonial Trust Company, has been elected a director of the Eisler Electric Company.

City Court Justice William B. Hazelwood of Queens, the only Republican on the City Court bench and long a leader of his party in the county, died suddenly early yesterday of a stroke at his home, t 109-10 Park Lane South, Kew Gardens. He formerly was Queens County Commissioner of Jurors. His age was 56.

Tension over the Cumberland River floods eased today and Middle Tennessee turned to a fight against disease. The river reached 58,5 feet at Nashville and was virtually stationary. Meteorologist R. M. Williamson forecast that it would crest tomorrow or Wednesday at 54 feet, 14 above flood stage.

Colonel James C. Thornton, brother-in-law of Governor Robert E. Quinn and former Racing Commissioner of Rhode Island, died at his home here today. He became ill while attending the Roosevelt inauguration with the State's official party last week and succumbed to scarlet fever and heart disease. He was 35 years old.
Between forty and forty-five prisoners were reported missing when prison clerks made a check after evacuation of the flooded State Reformatory was completed here tonight.

Miss Ida Angleman, who was editor of the Young People's publications of the Methodist Book Concern of New York for twenty years, retiring three years ago, died today at her home here in her seventyseventh year.

Senate Democrats refused tonight to have anything to do with the Republicans' proposal that, sitting as a committee of the whole, the Senate investigate the right of Senator William C. Hunt of Cape May County, a Republican, to retain his seat.

The first of a series of sporadic strikes threatened by the Building Service Employes International Union started yesterday in two buildings downtown and two in Brooklyn. The union said that forty-nine men had left their jobs, but a representative of the owners said that twenty-five men had gone on strike and that four already had returned to work. :

Disheartening news of still higher water ahead spread tonight through flood-ravaged towns along the 250-mile stretch of the Ohio River from Wheeling to Huntington, as West Virginia's refugees increased to more than 30,000 and the death list to nine.

Governor Lehman accepted the resignation of Wendell P. Barker as chairman of the State Mortgage Commission and sent to the Senate the nomination of Benjamin J. Rabin of New York City as his successor.

Dr. William Pitt Mason, one of the country's leaders in sanitary engineering, particularly as it applied to municipal water supplies, died today at his country home in Little Boar's Head, N. H., at the age of 83. He retired as head of the Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in September, 1925.

Compensation for the year ended Sept. 30, 1936, of the principal executives of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation was disclosed yesterday in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

Frank Di Marco of the Trinity Club became the metropolitan amateur boxing champion at 112 pounds last night in Madison Square Garden by winning. two close decisions, one of them from the defending titleholder, Joe Wall.

Mrs. Amy Wilkes Zwemer of Princeton, N. J., wife of Professor Samuel M. Zwemer of the Princeton Theological Seminary, died suddenly yesterday of heart disease in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, at the age of 71.

Landlords in search of a moratorium in the enforcement of fireprotection and sanitation provisions of the Multiple Dwellings Law in tenements gave their support yesterday at a meeting of the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate to a resolution introduced

Governor Lehman sent telegrams tonight to Governor Chandler of Kentucky and Governor Davey of Ohio expressing the deep sympathy of the people of New York State for those who are suffering because of the floods.

River communities from Cairo, Ill., to New Madrid, Mo., waited with apprehension tonight while mingled waters of the Ohio and the Mississippi poured into the 131,000-acre Birds Point-New Madrid floodway.

Assets of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia at the end of 1936 amounted to $315,544,000, an increase of $17,027,000 from a year before, M. A. Linton, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday. This was the largest gain in the history of the company.

James B. Field of 140 East Twenty-eighth Street, general counsel for Radio-Keith-Orpheum, Inc., died late Sunday night in the Polyclinic Hospital of pneumonia, following an operation, at the age of 37.

That overcautious nature of Caspar Milquetoast has got him into trouble again. The story of his latest travail--a parable of an automobile accident suit-was embodied yesterday in the judicial archived of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Mrs. N. Bronson Williams gave a luncheon yesterday at the Gladstone for Miss Ann R. Foster, daughter of Mrs. Barrows Porter, whose engagement to Thomas Le Boutillier 3d was announced recently. Other guests were Mrs.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate was urged yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the World's Fair of 1939, to give prompt approval of the proposed spur extending the Independent subway to the fair grounds and the enlargement of the Willets Point Boulevard station on the Corona branch of the I. R. T.

Thr Trotsky trial unrolls like a Greek tragedy, with a picture of weak men caught in a net of circumstances and of strong men fighting for friends and ideas they believed to be right. And as a foil to the weak and the strong-a young engineer, M. S. Stroiloff, and a veteran soldier, N. L Muraloff-there was a voluble citizen, A. A. Shestoff, who blatantly avowed himself a cynical offender.

The nominations of John G. Winant as head of the Social Security Board and George H. Combs Jr. to be New York director of the National Emergency Council were held in the Senate Finance Committee today by Chairman Harrison.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses will receive the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society's annual gold medal for being the man who rendered the most important service to the country's parks last year.

While buying activity by retailers in other sections continued brisk in the wholesale markets here yesterday the flood difficulties brought an almost complete halt to shipments to stores in the Ohio Valley, particularly in Cincinnati and Louisville.

Tennessee's Southeastern Conterence champions will arrive in New York this morning and get in at least one brisk workout before meeting Long Island University in the feature of the Madison Square Garden double-header tomorrow night. ... The Vols employ the same type of attack that Purdue uses, the long pass and the quick break.... Coach Blair Gullion is a Boilermaker product.

Flood relief was made the first order of government business by President Roosevelt today when he ordered six major departments and Federal agencies to cooperate in every way with the Red Cross for relief.
An issue of $35,500,000 of Canadian National Railways Dominion-guaranteed bonds to be offered throughout Canada on Thursday was announced tonight by Charles Dunning, Dominion Minister of Finance.

The sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday at $105,000, a decline of $29,000 from the last previous sale. This was the third transaction in seats to take place this year, the two previous sales, at $130,000 and $134,000, being made on Jan. 8.
The annual card party under the auspices of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association for the benefit of Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, will be held this afternoon at the Plaza.

Miss G. Killeen's 4-year-old Wardell Ormont, showing plenty of speed in the stretch, finished a half length in front of Nocturnlabe to win the feature race at Alamo Downs today. The winner ran the mile and seventy yards in 1:471-5. Volomite was third, a head behind Nocturnlabe.

West St., n. c. Dey St., 40x67; Meyer Handelmen to trustee will of James Al Macdonald, 39-01 Main St., Flushing. 72d St., 111 W., 23x102.2; Elia W. Crow to 88 River, Inc., 391 E. 149th St.: mtg., $45,950 ($1).

In a series of conferences at the Treasury today Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. met with his special financial advisers in a survey of the monetary situation that had the earmarks of a further move to stabilize world currencies.

Title to the property at 13640 Greenwich Street, at the northwest corner of Cedar Street, has been taken by Albert FrankGuenther Law, Inc., advertising agency, whose offices are at 131 Cedar Street, adjoining the plot just acquired.

The crest of the Ohio River's greatest recorded flood came on this city to- night. With the water nearly twentyeight feet above the stage where the river spills over its inadequate banks, this queen city of the Ohio and its Kentucky suburbs, a community with a population of 650,000, was a metropolis stricken powerless in an age of power.

William Campbell, Professor of Metallurgy at Columbia University, who died last Dec. 16, left virtually all his estate to the university. This was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. The estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000."

Aided by an eagle 3 on the long seventh hole, Joe Switzer of St. Louis won the medal in the qualifying round for the annual Winter championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup on the St. Augustine links today. He led a fine field with a card of 35, 39--74, two strokes over par.

Conquers Compo in Semi-Final -Four Knockouts Scored in Preliminary Contests Lew Feldman, 133, Brownsville, outpointed George Zengaras, 134, East Side, in the eight-round feature bout before a crowd of 4,000 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The Union Pacific is to buy twenty-five Mallet-type locomotives for fast freight service at a cost of $3,500,000, the company announced yesterday. This will be additional to the purchase of fifteen recently made, bringing total orders for locomotives in less than a year to sixty, at a cost of $8,500,000.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wellington West of Shelly Hall, Shelly Bay, Bermuda, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Marian West, to Arthur Cartwright Sculley of Garden City, L. I., son of John D. Sculley of Garden City and Mrs. Genevieve Sculley of New York.

Governor Lehman sent to the Senate tonight for confirmation the nominations of members of the State Board of Social Welfare. He had made the same appointments ad interim last Summer, but formal confirmation was needed by the Senate.

Taking issue with a statement by Louis Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, that the contract sold last Spring to the Hudson-Harlem Valley Title and Mortgage Company provided that servicing should be done "at cost," Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme filed a memorandum today in which he quoted from the contract to show- that a fee above cost was paid for the servicing.

Regisration statements of securities to educe the par values of outstanding common stocks have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Central and south West Utilities Company and he American Public Service Company, both of Chicago, it was announced today.
Prince Louis Ferdinand, second son of Crown Prince Wilhelm and heir-apparent to the non-existent German throne, has won his reserve lieutenant's commission in the German air force.

Mrs. Mabel Baylis Eldridge of 105 East Fifty-third Street, widow of Chauncey Eldridge, and William Crane Ivison of this city obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. Their marriage will take place tomorrow noon in the Church of the Ascension.

227th St. (17-4828), s. s., 133 ft. w. of Lowerre Pl., 66x100; Doris I. Byrne, referee, to New York State Teachers Retirement System, Albany, N. Y. Tratman Av. (15-3980), e. s., 109 ft. n. of St. Peters Av., 149x92; Sadie Meryash, referee, to New York State Teachers RetireAlbany, N.Y.

Tenders for the issue of 273-day Treasury bills, to be dated Jan. 27 and maturing on Oct. 27, amounting to about $50,000,000, totaled $134,878,000, of which $50,038,000 was accepted, according to an announcement today by the Treasury Deapartment.

Ted Lord of the New York Athletic Club, former metropolitan titleholder, defeated his team-mate, Loran (Tex) Elliott, to annex the 165-pound class honors in the amateur wrestling show conducted at the New York A. C. last night. Lord won on the judges' decision.

Laddie Stone, second in his last start, carried his speed for the full five-and-a-half furlongs today to win the feature at the Fair Grounds In contrast to his last race when he quit after setting the early pace, the 5-year-old son of Sir Galahad III from M. Simmons's barn came from behind, and got up in the final strides to nose out E. K. Bryson's Jadaan.
The international stock market indices for Jan. 23, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Detroit's Larry Aurie is undisputed top man of the National Hockey League scorers, Official league statistics tonight credited him with 29 points, one up on Dave Scbriner of the New York Americans, who moved up from fourth place to second.

Local chapters of the Red Cross mobilized all their forces yesterday to aid the victims of the floodravaged areas in the Midwest. Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation appealing to all citizens to contribute. The New York Chapter received $28,780.50 during the day.

Max D. Krone, 34 years old, former licensed private detective, on trial in General Sessions with A. Henry Ross, Brooklyn lawyer, on an extortion charge made by Alfred E. Smith Jr., insisted before Judge 'Nott and the jurors yesterday that his only connection with the charge was as an "agent" of Mr. Smith.

Orville Roulston, rookie defense man substituting for the injured Doug Young, captain of the Detroit Red Wings, has suffered the same fate as his predecessor-a broken leg. An X-ray examination today revealed the break, received in last night's game against the Maroons.

Remarking that timekeepers and other supervisory employes on WPA projects recently had found it difficult to occupy their time on the Job, Lieut. Col; Brehon Somerveil, WPA administrator, announced yesterday that the staff of supervisors would be cut by 5,000 to 6,000 jobs.
The ranks of the favorites remained unbroken at the conclusion of the first two rounds of the women's New Jersey squash racquets championship at the Short Hills Club today.

STRAW IN THE WIND, by Ruth Lininger Dobson. (Dodd, Mead, $2.) The novel that received the Hopwood Prize in 1936. TOLD WTTH A DRUM, by Edward Harris Heth. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.) A story of a German family in America during the World War.
Patrick H. Kelly, contractor who since last March had been supervisor of city WPA projects, died of heart disease today at his home in Falls of Schuylkill. He was 65 years old.
The stock markets here were dull today, with prices generally lower. The greatest activity was in South African gold mine stocks, which eased after a strong opening.
The announcement comes from Paris that Jules Romains, new president of the International P. E. N. Club, has just been married to his secretary, Miss Dreyfus.

Cincinnati and the Ohio River lowlands, Southern Indiana, Kentucky from Louisville to Ballard lie partly under water. In nine States half a million wander about homeless-200,000 in the Louisville area alone.

Business failures declined to 163 for the week ended Jan. 21, compared with 186 in the previous week and 246 in the corresponding week of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The decline follows increases in each of the three preceding weeks.

Turpentine nominal, 42c; no sales; receipts, 163 barrels; shipments, 145 barrels; stock, 30,640 barrels. Resin nominal; no sales; receipts, 2,090; shipments. 826; stock, 79,415. Quote: B, $9.25: D. $9.35: E. $9.50; F to N, $10.05; WG, $10.50; WW, X, $13.

Operations in the steel industry are estimated for this week by the American Iron and Steel Institute at 77.9 per cent of ingot capacity, a decrease of 2.7 points, or 3.4 per cent, from the recovery high level of 80.6 per cent of last week.

Prices on the grain markets advanced fractionally today due more to lack of pressure than to aggressive buying. Strength in Liverpool, uneasiness over the possible damage to Winter wheat and the belief that important amounts of cash corn and oats had been lost in the flooded areas in the Ohio Valley furnished the foundation for the scattered buying on the Board of Trade here.

Young Jake Schaefer of Chicago took a 98-point lead over Willie Hoppe of New York in the play for the world's 28.2 balkline billiard championship by winning the opening block of a 2,500-point match, 250 to 152, tonight. Schaefer went out in fourteen innings.

Practically no cancellations of the heavy orders placed in recent weeks were received yesterday by manufacturers here from retailers in the flood areas, a survey showed. However, most shipments to stores in the Ohio Valley section, particularly in Cincinnati and Louisville,

Etienne Amyot, young South African pianist, who made his American debut a year ago, returned to give a recital at the Town Hall last night. Where the emphasis last year had been on the intimate and miniature, virtuosity and the bravura style were stressed last night. Mr. Amyot has apparently gone from one extreme to the other. When he finds the happy medium he should be a rewarding pianist.

Simplification of reports to shareholders is one of the most important tasks facing corporations today, John Haskell, executive secretary of the Committee on Stock List of the New York Stock Exchange, declared in an address tonight before the Pittsburgh Control of the Controllers Institute of America.

The trial of Major Green, Negro porter charged with the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case in her apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, was postponed yesterday by County Judge Charles S. Colden at the request of defense counsel.
Popular-priced brands of cigarettes were increased in price yesterday in the chain outlets to meet the increases in wholesale prices that went into effect last week.
A complete reorganization of the administrative division of the State government was proposed today in a report submitted to the Governor by the Reorganization Commission.

Radio short-wave broadcasting played a tremendous role yesterday in the battle of the Ohio Valley against the worst flood in its history. The dramatic "calling all boats, calling all boats" was a constant appeal for help throughout the day from the powerful transmitters of stations WHAS and WAVE at Louisville, WLW and WKRC at Cincinnati and an unprecedented emergency network of Columbia and NBC cooperating stations.
Penn State went into a tie with Temple University for second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference by defeating a scrappy Carnegie Tech five, 35 to 30, tonight.
Tiachiro Morinaga, Japan's leading candy manufacturer, died today at the age of 72.
The New York Americans, fighting to leave the cellar in the international group, will face the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Columbus Av. and 74th St., 61 W., 7-story apartments, 54.2x100; Harlem Savings Bank against 61 W. 74th St. Holding Corp.; due, $167,788: taxes, , $7,315; to plaintiff for $10,000. By RALPH W. LONG 115th St., 353 W., 5-story tenement, 25x100;

The Soldier's Medal was awarded by the War Department today to Private Thomas W. Treloar of Jamaica, L. I., in Battery E, Sixty-second Coast Artillery at Fort Totten, New York, for heroism in rescuing a comrade from drowning at Fort Totten on Aug. 24, 1936.

Dollar sale value of all registered securities exchanges in December, 1936, was $2,676,525,432, a decrease of 5.2 per cent from November and an increase of 16.7 per cent over the value of sales in December, 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Thirteen prizes were awarded yesterday at the forty-sixth annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, to be opened to the public at 10 o'clock this morning in the American Fine Arts Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Senate passed tonight a resolution for a Constitutional amendment to establish a four-year term for Governor and Lieutenant Governor and also approved a bill asked by Governor Lehman to permit juries to recommend life imprisonment in felony murder cases.
Austria's official hangman, Karl Lang, today joined scores of other signers of a petition to save 22-year-old Edward Illetschko from the gallows.

FOR forty years and more Ernest Newman has. been known as a brilliant music critic and as the author of some of the most delightful books on music in English. In 1933, as a sort of climax to a career, appeared the first volume of his "Life of Richard Wagner."

Gordon Abbott, long active in Boston and New York banking circles, died last night at his home here at the age of 74. Mr. Abbott was until recently chairman of the board of the Old Colony Trust Company.
Increased receipts of hogs today more than offset the effect of stronger markets for fresh pork loins, and the former sold steady to 10 cents lower, compared with Saturday's closing prices.

The Bronx Borough Taxpayers League, Inc., will meet tomorrow night in the Bronx County Building. Legislation affecting real estate and plans for the organization's annual dinner on Feb. 21 will be discussed. Sixty-five loans totaling $269,890 were arranged for the Trump Holding Corp. on construction in its development at Clarendon Road and E. 42d St., Brooklyn, by J.

The only manager in either major league who isn't bothered by the direction in which the trade winds blow, who has not a worry in the world about his batting order, pitching staff or any other department of his baseball club was in town yesterday punching the bag with the baseball writers.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, announced in a letter ton00ht to Secretary Perkins that he and his associates could not see their way clear to accepting her invitation to a conference with the union on Wednesday, while union representatives "continue to hold our plants unlawfully."

The cost of living increased only about 8 per cent between 1933 and 1936, as compared with an increase of about 33 per cent in income, indicating that the necessary spread for a healthy business recovery between consumer income and outgo has been maintained, according to a study of income factors and retail prices issued yesterday by the American Retail Federation.
The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough are expected to arrive on the Aquitania. They will be at the Waldorf-Astoria until they go to Palm Beach to join Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan.

Miss Dorothy Mathilde Thebaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gilbert Thebaud Jr. of White Plains, has completed plans for her marriage to Richard Earl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Earl of Kew Gardens and Westhampton, L. I., which will take place on Saturday in St. John's Church, White Plains.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler cannot attend the coronation of King George VI. He is barred by a curious convention. Invitations have been sent by the British Government to other countries inviting them to send representatives.

William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T., who warned last night of a twenty-year prison sentence for those who interrupt the operation of a railroad, was referring to Section 1,991 of the New York State Penal Code. It reads:

William K. Coors of Golden, Col., has been elected chairman of this year's Princeton University Junior Promenade Committee. Other members are Charles D. Agnew of New York, Norman A. Carter, Plainfield, N. J.; William B. Craig, Short Hills, N. J.;

Mayor Neville Miller announced tonight that United States troops would arrive late tomorrow to succor flood-beleaguered Louisville. Kentucky's Governor, A. B. Chandler, proclaimed martial law in Louisville late today upon request of Mayor Miller and his emergency relief committee, and called upon President' Roosevelt to put a Federal military governor and regulars in charge of the city to combat threatened pestilence, starvation and panic.

Brook Av., 1,247, 3-story tenement, 18x90; Harlem Savings Bank against Harriet J. Schubert; due, $3,752; taxes, , $28; to plaintiff for $1,000. By EDWIN J. McDONALD La Salle Av., 2,889, 25x100; Jefferson Title
The cotton trade received from the Commodity Credit Corporation today an inventory on 3,000,000 bales of government loan cotton to be released between Feb. 1 and April 1.

In preparation for final action by the Assembly on Governor Lehman's Social Security Bill, the Assembly Committee on Public Relief and Welfare, of which Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth is chairman, held a public hearing this afternoon at which organizations representing the blind filed numerous objections to provisions affecting them.
Thomas Linton Floyd-Jones, a piano manufacturer and a member of an old New York family, died today at United Hospital of a sinal infection after an illness of a week. He was 61 years old.

Long Jim Barnes, member of the old triumvirate that ruled the golf world not so long ago when he, Walter Hagen and Jock Hutchison were winning everything in sight, played the first nine holes on the old course at St. Andrews, Scotland, yesterday in forty strokes.

British exports of alcoholic spirits to the United States more than doubled last year both in quantity and in value, showing the benefits to the British Empire of the CanadianAmerican treaty signed in November, 1935, and effective Jan. 1, 1936.

Michigan clung doggedly to its first-division perch in the Western Conference basketball race tonight, handing Chicago's Maroons a 3219 defeat before a crowd of 3,500. The Wolverines, stung though they were by Ohio State's victory Saturday, which all but shattered their title aspirations, were slow to get under way but rallied to lead, 12-6, at the half.

A plan of President Roosevelt to cut the Works Progress Administration rolls by 600,000 in the period from February to June of this year became known today upon publication of the testimony of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, at secret hearings before the House Appropriations Committee considering the first deficiency bill.

The National Red Cherry Association, an organization of New York, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin red cherry yes canners, has appointed the Chicago office of the L. W. Ramsey Company as its advertising agency.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In its issue of Jan. 18 THE NEW YORK TIMES printed the so-called findings of the Methodist Federation for Social Service on the anti-democratic, proFascist policy of the Vatican.

Mrs. Louis B. Rolston is chairman and Mrs. Jean R. Peacock acting chairman of the committee for a luncheon and fashion show to be held on Feb. 9 at the Carlyle in aid of the Little Missionary's Day Nursery.

The Bethlehem Steel Company has received an order for 2,600 tons of pipe from Toledo, Ohio. The United States Government has awarded 2,150 tons for a Mississippi River dam to the Lakeside Bridge and Steel Company of Milwaukee.

The Rev. George Rittenhouse, who was pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, Fourth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, N. Y., from 1919 to 1924, died here today in St. Francis Hospital, a few hours after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was born at Hunter's Point, Long Island City, fifty-nine years ago.

ANDERSON--Elizabeth, mother of Lily Robbins, devoted grandmother of Gilbert Robbins Jr., beloved aunt of Clara P. Doherty, in her eighty-seventh year. Funeral from her late residence, Methodist Episcopal Home, 242d St. and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, at convenience of family.
Plans to raise $500,000 for flood relief were made today at an emergency organization meeting of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Chapter of the Red Cross. Donations of $10,

Harry J. Rudolph, president of the Rudolph Motor Company of New Brighton. S. I., and former Sheriff of Richmond County, died at Miami Beach, Fla., on Sunday, according to word received here yesterday. He was 63 years old.

The furnishings and fixtures of the former Elks Clubhouse at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, went "under the hammer" yesterday to clear the structure for its use as the main administrative office of the Board of Education.

Defense attorneys in the restaurant. extortion conspiracy case. on trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury spent all of yesterday outlining evidence which, they contended, would prove their clients to be labor leaders who were victimized by mercenary thuggery and never got a dime out of a racket which Special Prosecutor William B. Herlands charges took $2,000,000 a year from the industry.

An announcement that loan cotton would be released on the grade differences prevailing on Jan. 2, although low middling penalties have increased from 114 to 125 points recently, had a steadying influence on the cotton market yesterday.
Miss Ruth K. Doehrmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Doehrmann of this city, will be married on Feb. 11 to Paul F. Peter, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Peter of Flushing, L. I.

Consumers Hygenic Ice Company sold to Senger Coal and Ice Company its ice plant, a two and threestory brick building on a plot 212 by 125 feet at 910-30 New York Avenue, Union City, N. J. The revenue stamps on the deed indicated a consideration of $67,000.

Total assets of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company at the end of 1936 amounted to $23,260,620, compared with $20,949,294 at the end of 1935, it was announced yesterday. Surplus for policyholders was $5,000,000, against $3,200,000.

Frank L. Briarly, former Democratic leader of the Fiftenth Assembly District, who waged an unsuccessful fight against John F. Curry in the primaries of 1931, died yesterday at his home, 115 East Eighty-ninth Street, after a long illness. His widow, the former Sarah F. Cunningham, and a sister, Miss Lilliam Briarly, survive.

As army opposition to the naming of General Kazushige Ugaki, former Governor General of Korea, to become Premier, grew, Privy Councilor Eizo Ishizuka this morning visited General Count Juichi Terauchi and represented that the army's opposition to a man who had received the Emperor's command to form a Cabinet was an infringement of the imperial prerogative.

Bob Pastor finished the boxing end of his training yesterday for his ten-round fight with Joe Louis at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Before a number of his spectators, including James J. Braddock, the Washington Heights heavyweight engaged in three rounds of ring work at Stillman's gymnasium.
Dr. August J. Bucher, editor, teacher and minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died at Bethesda Hospital here today. He was 75 years old.

Father Divine, Negro cult leader, will not have to appear this week for further questioning as to his knowledge of the financial affairs of his "kingdoms." Cash to the extent of $7,724.15 poured down from some undisclosed source near the Harlem "heaven" to satisfy two

For the year ended on Nov. 30, 1936, the Wayne Pump Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1,325,279 after depreciation, interest, subsidiary preferred dividends, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Miss Helen Jane Waldo, former as- h sociate editor of the children's periodical, John Martin's Book, died here yesterday in the Mountainside Hospital, after a four-year illness, at the age of 60. A sister, Mrs. James Henderson of Green Bay, Wis., and a half-brother, Ellsworth Griffith of Toledo, Ohio, survive.

The Cities Service Company, principal stockholder and creditor of Warner-Quinlan Company, filed an appeal yesterday in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals from the recent order of Federal Judge Hulbert directing the sale at public auction of 231 Warner-Quinlan service stations on Feb. 5 for not less than $4,181,000.

In various parts of the world the basic elements of our freedom are being attacked, according to-James G. McDonald, former High Commissioner for German Refugees, who spoke last night at the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway, on "Today's Challenge to Freedom."

Jonas C. Andersen, for many years a governor of the organization and chairman of the athletic committee, was elected president of the Crescent Athletic Club at the annual meeting and election which was held in the city house, 129 Pierpont Street, Brooklyn, last night.
Mayor La Guardia will be guest of honor at a meeting of the Retail Stores Executives Association tomorrow evening in the Hotel Governor Clinton.
Twenty persons lost their lives today in the raging waters of a record Southern flood which strained main line Mississippi River levees and drove countless thousands from their homes.
The Chicago Curb Exchange's annual report shows a deficit of $6,239 for 1936. This compares with deficits of $17,271 in 1935 and $17,931 in 1934.

Trapped Lewis, chairman when an express bus veered from the Tamiami Trail, turned over and rolled into a canal today, seventeen persons perished before help could reach them. fifteenn others fought their way out or were rescued, most of them injured.

The skeptics who deny the possibility of peace in the Balkans have again been surprised. The popular manifestation of rejoicing in Belgrade last Sunday, when the pact of friendship between Yugoslavia and Bulgaria was signed, gives added significance to that encouraging, formal act.

American boys will be fighting all of Chicago's National Hockey League battles within the next two years. Starting by announcing that his club, the Black Hawks, will become the Chicago "Yankees" next season, Major Frederic McLaughlin, stirred by the team's poor showing this season, today made known plans for throwing off the traditional Canadian influence over the game.

Members of the woman's division of the American Council of St. Luke's International Medical Center in Tokyo, Japan, will give a benefit luncheon on Feb. 9 at the Pierre. The guests of honor will include Sir Herbert Marler, Canadian Minister to the United States;

The bond market was weak in all departments yesterday, with United States Government securities leading the decline. Foreign issues, however, did somewhat better than domestic obligations, but they, at the best, irregular.

A charge of disorderly conduct against thirty-one pickets, including twenty-six women, arrested last Friday in front of the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Robert S. Allyn when Bertrand Veaton of 36 West Seventythird Street, appearing for the league, asked permission to withdraw the complaint.

The Certain-teed Products Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that the time for the exchange of the 7 per cent preferred stock for common stock and 6 per cent cumulative prior-preference stock of the corporation has been extended to Feb. 23. 1937.

Inclusion in any continuation of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act of a provision that future agreements must be ratified by the Senate before they go into effect was urged today before the Ways and Means Committee by three witnesses at the hearing on a resolution to extend for three years the tariff bargaining powers which Congress delegated to President Roosevelt in 1934.

The League of Nations published today the proposed membership of the experts' committee on "equal commercial access for all nations to certain raw materials." Although the list was not adopted by the Council today, there is no doubt that it will be.

The United States Bureau of Biological Survey announces the establishment of the Hart Mountain Antelope Refuge in Oregon as one of the steps in the preservation of prized American game animals. The project consists of a 276,000acre refuge and a near-by 539,000 Winter and Spring range.
Dr. L. A. Thompson, research director of the Cincinnati Employment Center, said tonight that 90,000 to 170,000 persons normally employed here were out of work as a result of the flood.

Erection of the -bronze statue of Atlas in the east forecourt. at the entrance of the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, in Rockefeller Center, has been completed. The statue, which is the work of Lee Lawrie, portrays Atlas carrying on his shoulder a sphere composed of concentric rings representing the universe.
The Mississippi River Commission "hoped for the best" today in the first major test of the flood control works started after the 1927 ter in the lower valley.

The Corporations Auxiliary Company, an organization serving more than 500 clients in nineteen States and employing 200 labor "spies" whose object is to prevent strikes, pays its president $75,000 annual salary and its general manager $62,300, the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage was told by company witnesses today.
The Treasury has granted an extension of sixty days for the payment of the Federal payroll tax for unemployment insurance, which otherwise would have been payable for the first time on Jan. 31.

Reports from Florence, Italy, indicate that Crown Prince Michael is suffering from bronchitis following his appendectomy and has a high fever. His condition is reported to be serious but not dangerous.

New three-cent stamps in the ArmyNavy heroes series will be put on sale at the Washington postoffice on Feb. 18, and at other postoffices as soon thereafter as distribution will permit, Postmaster General Farley announced today.

Impatient over what he considers to be the inaction of Governor Hoffman of New Jersey, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn decided yesterday to proceed to trial next Monday in the case involving the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, in which Ellis H. Parker Sr., the New Jersey detective; his son, Ellis, Jr., and three Brooklyn men are accused.

CINCINNATI--City Manager Dykstra was named "disaster dictator" of the city. Fire and flood losses mounted to $10,000,000. Six-sevenths of the normal power was cut off. Drinking water was polluted. Some 65,000 were homeless. The Ohio River rose to nearly 80 feet, an all-time peak. Twenty-five square miles were under water. The threat of new fires increased the tension. Coast Guardsmen rescued citizens from trees and floating buildings. Eight deaths were counted.
Government weather experts blamed today the freak Winter weather on persistent movements of cold dry air from the polar regions and warm-moist air masses from the tropics.

Trading in synthetic gray goods last week was quiet, in comparison with the heavy volume sales earlier in the month, according to the market report of Nickel, Barrett Lieberman Quinn, Inc., tontile brokers.

Silver Burdett Co. of Newark, text book publishers, two floors In Everett Building, 45 E. 17th St., through M. L. Hess, Inc. Orion Dress Co., in 545 8th Av.; Alnor Coat Co., Katz Lelbowitz, coats, in 265 W. 37th St.; Abbey Coat Co., Inc., in 230
The Baldwin Locomotive Works announced today that the value of orders taken in December by the company and subsidiaries was $11,183,894, compared with $1,650,577 in December, 1935.
John Stroh, vice president of the Hudson County Trust Company, Union City, died yesterday in his home in Weehawken, of a heart ailment after a long illness.

Prizes and medals, won in the international chess masters' tournament, concluded here last night, were formally awarded this evening at a dinner arranged for the competitors and officials at the Hotel Regina.

J. A. Delanoy, president of the Netherland Club and vice president of the Netherland Chamber of Commerce, has been elevated to knighthood in the Order of Orange Nassau by Queen Wilhelmina, it was announced yesterday.

The American General Corporation's net assets a share of common stock were $16.11 as of Dec. 31 last, according to the concern's annual report issued yesterday. This figure compares with $11.19 at the end of 1935, indicating an advance of $4.92 a share, or 43.9 per cent.

Frank Crum of Williamson, W. Va., runner-up last year in the Virginia amateur championship, paced a field of only eight starters in the qualifying round of the annual Florida Winter tournament for lefthanders at the Miami-Biltmore Country Club today.

President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, found themselves during their week-end conversations in complete agreement with respect to their love of the sea and ships.

The Brazilian Presidential and Congressional elections have been set for Jan. 3, 1938, under a ruling of the electoral tribunal. Thus is ended a constitutional controversy over whether the Congressional election should be separate front the Presidential election.
Miss Laura M. White, musician, writer and missionary, who had spent more than forty years in China, died in the Germantown Hospital yesterday.

The heavy Rebel bombardment of the past two days was not resumed here today, perhaps because- of the low visibility. In any event, there is never anything systematic about these shellings of the center of the city. The main purpose that the latest bombardments have served is to speed up the lagging evacuation of the capital.

Indiana's southern borderland was abandoned tonight to the mounting fury of the Ohio River's highest flood. Whole cities were being evacuated. Special trains sped thousands of bedraggled and heart-sick refugees northward to food, shelter and helping hands.

Domestic orders of R. Hoe Co., Inc., for the first quarter of its 1937 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, last, exceeded those for the corresponding period of the 1936 fiscal year by $900,000 and the first quarter of the 1929 year by $1,300,000, according to a statement issued yesterday by Fred L. McCarty, president.
The rising tide of anti-Semitism sweeping Poland threatens to engulf Jews all over Eastern Europe in the fate of their brethren in Germany.

More than 75 per cent of food manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers who replied to a questionnaire sent out by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., approve the intent of the Robinson-Patman Act, it was announced here yesterday in a statement summarizing final results of the survey, issued from the association's headquarters.
An air of optimism and business confidence was evident today among the 15,000 food manufactures, canners, grocers and brokers in Chicago to attend six conventions allied with the food industry.

Associate Professor Emeritus William Koren, a member of the Princeton University faculty in the Department of Modern Languages from 1901 until his retirement in 1933, died in the Princeton Hospital this afternoon after a long illness. He was 72 years of age and resided here.

A contract for sale of approximately $5,000,000 worth of pulpwood to the Marathon Paper Mills Company of Rothschild, Wis., was announced today by A. L. Johnson, president of the General Timber Company, which holds pulpwood limits in the Thunder Bay district.

An invitation to industry to go to his State with the assurance that it would be safe from further taxation was extended yesterday by Governor Richard W. Leche of Louisiana in an address at the Univerity Club before fifty business men and bankers.

Reunion of Northern and Southern Ireland was one of the subjects raised by President Eamon de Valera on his recent visit to London, it was revealed in the House of Commons today by Malcolm MacDonald, Minister of Colonies.

Probably this is an occasion on which the drama should be genially looked upon as a show. For "Tide Rising," in which Grant Mitchell appeared at the Lyceum last evening, makes a good melodrama without making much hard-headed sense.

Governor Lehman announced tonight the appointment of Benjamin J. Rabin of New York as chairman of the New York State Mortgage Commission to succeed Wendell P. Barker of Yonkers, who resigned after serving nearly two years.

The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will start a new dividend policy with its next payment in March by declaring "an individual or interim dividend in each quarter, depending on the conditions prevailing at that time, rather than declare what have come to be regarded as regular quarterly dividends," the company announced yesterday.
Forty-third annual convention of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association opens at Hotel Pennsylvania this morning and continues Wednesday and Thursday.
The Securities and Exchange Commission heard Chase Donaldson, president of Distributors Group, Inc., recommend today that investment trusts be regulated by the government.

Gloucester men and dories, veterans of the Grand Banks, were offered to relief agencies today for duty in the Midwest flood areas. The boats alone were first offered, but so many fishermen and war veterans volunteered as crews that plans were hastily changed to include the men.
Despite reports of a compromise, Central government forces continued last night to advance swiftly toward Sian, capital of this rebellious province, and several minor clashes occurred.

IT was learned recently, to the mild horror of this observer, that the powers that be in billiards were drawing new lines on the green baize of the tables to make it tougher for the wielders of the cues.

Mrs. Julia L. Beitler, widow of Judge Abraham M. Beitler, died at her home in Germantown today after an illness of several months. Her husband, who had been a member of the Philadelphia bar for sixty years and a Common Pleas Court judge from 1896 to 1907,

If you cross-examine a child of seven or eight on his day's doings (specially when he wants to go to sleep) he will contradict himself very satisfactorily. If each contradiction be set down as a lie and retailed at break-fast, life is not easy.

Two high school pupils with the aid of some rope and fellow students rescued a 5-month-old setter pup from swiftly flowing Onondaga Creek today at the risk of drowning. They were Jack Baker, 13, member of his school's traffic safety patrol, and Jean Fyler, 14.

The operators of the Delmonico Hotel at 502 Park Avenue, New York, may continue using the name of the famous old Fifth Avenue restaurant which closed under its original management in 1918, Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B.

Factory sales of motor vehicles produced in the United States totaled 498,721 in December, compared with 404,528 in December, 1935, and 153,624 correspondingly in 1934, according to a report today by the Department of Commerce.

From the New York offices of various industries and transportation and communication companies there came yesterday news of the disruption by the flood of railroad, plane and bus services. Telegraph and telephone wires were out of commission. Hundreds of manufacturing plants were flooded and closed.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad earned a net income of about $4,980,000, or $2.92 a capital share, Ralph Budd, president, said yesterday. This would compare with $1,842,844, or $1.08 a share, in 1935. Estimated net income was $710,000 in December, against $462,461 in December, 1935.

A proposal that aims to bring about a considerable lowering in the cost of medical care to the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers in the "moderate income" group was advocated last night by Dr. Adolph G. DeSanctis at his induction as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York at the Academy of Medicine.

The syndicate headed by A. Simon, now erecting a twenty-story apartment house at the south corner of Riverside Drive and Seventythird Street, announced yesterday the completion of the assembling of a large plot at the north corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-second Street for improvement with another twenty-story structure, for occupancy in the Summer of 1938.

A dinner was given by the Secretary of State and Mrs. Cordell. Hull at the Carlton Hotel tonight in honor of Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, former Foreign Minister of Brazil, who was special Ambassador to the inauguration of President Roosevelt.

No commercial or industrial revival would seem adequate to absorb the present swollen bank reserves, according to J. Herbert Case, who retired last year after nineteen years as deputy governor and chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to become a general partner in R. W. Pressprich Co., investment bankers.
Traffic accidents, fatalities and injuries increased last week as compared with the corresponding period of 1936, it was announced yesterday by First Deputy Police Conmmissioner Harold Fowler.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 20 shows decreases for the week of $140,000,000 in total loans and investments, $15,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $95,000,000 in government deposits, $62,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $46,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

The Coast Guard, the navy, the Works Progress Administration and many other public and private agencies in New York and the vicinity were either rushing aid to the flood sufferers last. night or preparing to do so.

Relief forces were marshaled in Northern Mississippi today as several hundred persons fled waters of the rain-swollen Coldwater and Tallahatchie Rivers. A lowland area twenty-five miles long and seven miles wide was under water in Tunica and Quitman Counties.

Peter Freuchen, Danish sailoradventurer and author of "Arctic Adventure" and other works about his explorations of the frozen North, arrived yesterday on the United States liner. Manhattan to lecture on the Eskimo people.

A strong plea for the cooperation of all members of the International Business Machines Corporation in seventy-nine countries to work for sound and fair economic conditions among nations as a basis for permanent world peace was made by Thomas J. Watson, president, to 1,300 representatives assembled in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for the opening of the thirteenth annual convention.

After a spirited debate in which the Republicans charged that Governor Lehman was attempting to "duck" responsibility for solving the farmers' milk problem, the Assembly unanimously adopted a Democratic resolution tonight providing for a legislative investigation of milk control.

President Roosevelt devoted most of the day to the flood situation. He installed Harry L. Hopkins in the White House to coordinate the flood relief activities of six agencies working under the President's direction.

Seamen quit the picket lines yesterday and went in search of employment as their strike committee announced the unsuccessful end of an eleven-week drive to obtain recognition from the Atlantic and Gulf steamship companies.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs. Open to amateurs anywhere. Deadline for mailing entries - midnight Feb. 12.

A "lucky mistake" by a postman who misread the almost illegible inscription on a parcel insured for $5 and delivered it to the wrong addressee enabled postal inspectors to recover the $300,000 in stolen jewelry that it contained at about the time the owner, Mrs. Frederick H. Bugher, was reporting her loss to Washington (D. C.) police, it was revealed yesterday.
RUDYARD KIPLINCG'S first years in England were not spent amid the oak and ash and thorn of the enchanted land of

Internal strife in the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., over the rival claims to social prominence of Mrs. Oliver Harriman and Mrs. Francis D. Gallatin was alleged yesterday in an affidavit submitted in Supreme Court by Solomon R. Kunkis, attorney.

Germany's reply to the British note suggesting legislation on the British model to prevent further volunteering for Spain went forward this morning. It is couched in conciliatory terms. The German Government, the note says, has drafted a law prohibiting German nationals from going to Spain to take part in the civil war there on either side;

Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse entertained fifty for supper tonight at the Everglades Club in honor of her house guest, Miss CorneliaOtis Skinner, who was presented in a program of original sketches at the club as the initial offering this season of the drama department of the Society of the Four Arts, of whose board of directors Mrs. Woodhouse is chairman.

Miss Louise M. Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Reed of 175 West Seventy-second Street, and Laurens H. Rhinelander, also of this city, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

The Victorias maintained their two-point lead over the Baldwin Hockey Club in the Tri-County Hockey League by holding the Nassau sextet to a 2-2 tie at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. A goal by Ed Maher in 9:04 of the final period gained the deadlock for the league leaders.

Dr. Richard H. Bennett, attending physician of the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives, 240 Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn, announced yesterday afternoon that members of the medical staff there had developed a new "diagnostic and prognostic test for tuberculosis."

Offering will be made to the public today of a new issue of $15,000,000 of Otis Steel Company firstmortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, dated Jan. 15, 1937, and maturing on Jan. 15, 1962, by a banking group headed by A. G.

Before a capacity crowd of 4,000 at the University of Maryland Collseum Ellsworth Vines, lanky American ace, downed Fred Perry, 6-4, 6-2, tonight to deadlock their exhibition tour competition at five victories each.

City Manager C. A. Dykstra, declared flood dictator here today, left City Hall late tonight for his first sleep in thirty-six hours. He had been on the flood front constantly, meeting with the Disaster Council and with other city officials and with Governor Martin L. Davey.
The House Appropriations Committee objected today to a sales tax of about $100,000 which they heard California planned to assess against materials for a $7,280,000 Federal building at Los Angeles.

The Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw 89,772 shares of par common stock from listing and registration on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of to trading on Feb. 5.

It is significant that no attempt has been made in the automobile strike to invoke the National Labor Relations Act--significant, because this fact reveals something about the strike and something more about the act.

New officers of the Corporate Bond Traders Club of New York will be inducted tonight at the club's third annual dinner, to be held in the Hotel Pennsylvania. They are Claude F. Leaman of Hemphill, Noyes Co., president; James Colthup of Freeman Co.,
Harry L. Jones of Middleville, N. J., won the men's approaching and putting contest at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today, taking only six strokes for the three holes contested.

More than 1,000 buyems zealshing all types of china, glass and general homewares visited the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday and Sunday to view 200 exhibits in the firs Spring trade show of the kind held here. The event will continue through Saturday.

While John L. Lewis had expected to attend Secretary Perkins's automobile peace conference Wednesday, until the General Motors refusal blocked the plan, informed persons said tonight that he was extremely displeased with the terms of the invitation.

The premature explosion this morning of 1,500 tons of dynamite that had been set for a demonstration charge at the Chuquicamata Copper Mines, largest in the world, killed sixteen Workmen and injured 201 others.
Mrs. Evan J. Kimble of Vineland, N. J., gave a luncheon today at the Whitman Hotel, Miami Beach, later taking her guests for a cruise on Biscayne Bay aboard the yacht Amigo.

Positions remained unchanged yesterday in the metropolitan squash tennis Class B team championship as the Princeton Club players continued their undefeated drive for premier honors. The Yale Club's quintet was shut out, 5-0, at the Yale Club for the fourteenth straight victory scored by Princeton.
Twelve hundred families in the Pittsburgh district fled from their homes today before the onrush of the highest flood waters since last year's St. Patrick's Day disaster.

General and Mrs. Howard S. Bov den of 280 Park Avenue and Old Oaks, Rumson, N. J., have announced the engagement. of their daughter, Miss Doris Borden, to William Boardman Leonard, son of Mrs. William B. Leonard of Rumson, formerly of Albany, N. Y., and of the late Mr. Leonard.

Displaying the brand of golf that carried her to the semi-finals in the national last year, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., led 27 starters in the qualifying round of the annual Charlotte Harbor championship of golf champions today.

Holders of more than $3,000,000 of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway's first mortgage bonds have approved, the plan of reorganization for the company filed by a committee headed by Irving A. Sartorius in the Federal court in New Haven on Jan. 4, Mr. Sartorius

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday the issuance of $500,000 in special revenue bonds for snow-removal work. This amount will supplement $200,000 voted in November for new equipment and personnel in the Department of Sanitation.

Eddie O'Brien of Syracuse, invincible on board tracks -last season, yesterday filed his entry for the Millrose 600 that will be one of the features of the Millrose indoor carnival at Madison Square Garden, Feb. 6. This race marked the beginning of O'Brien's unbroken streak through the campaign a year ago.

Marvin Kantrowitz, top-ranked player from De Witt Clinton, led the way into the third round as the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tournament got under way on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory in Manhattan yesterday.

Within a week of the time when he was to have delivered his first lecture against Joseph Stalin's administration in Soviet Russia, Dmitri Navashine, former Soviet representative abroad and friend of many Soviet leaders, was shot dead in the Bois de

Two hundred and fifty sit-down strikers, who had dictated operations in the main power plant of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation for more than fifteen hours, began voluntary evacuation of the plant at 6:20 o'clock this morning, twenty minutes after the hour they had set for shutting off the current on which 2,000,000 persons depend for subway, elevated and trolley transportation.

The knox Trophy, presented annually by the Society of the Sons of the Revolution of Massachusetts, was awarded today to Battery A, Sixtythird Coast Artillery, anti-aircraft, at Fort MacArthur, Calif., for the best target practice performance among coast defense units last year.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Garwood Potter of Newark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Whitfield Potter, to Whitney Guerin Ball, son of Mrs. John Guerin Ball of Maplewood and the late Mr. Ball.

The National Socialist campaign here for registration in Nazi unified schools as distinguished from Catholic confessional schools continues with unabated intensity. Newspapers devote their front pages to it.

The Penn Athletic Club basketball team won its eleventh straight victory disposing of the Utah State Aggies, 38-29, before 3,000 fans at the Arena tonight. Al Bonniwell starred with six field goals and a foul, while Ken Hashagen had four field goals. Shelby West and Arden Peterson excelled for the Westerners with six points each.

A trio of new films, one from Hollywood and the others from England, will open here today. The domestic item is RKO's "Criminal Lawyer," with Lee Tracy, Betty Lawford, Margot Grahame and Eduardo Ciannelli, at the .Rialto.

Six persons received minor injuries last evening when the rear truck of a Manhattan-bound Flushing Avenue trolley car swung from the rails on Brooklyn Bridge over South Street-and blocked the motor and trolley traffic from 4:50 P. M. to 5'50 P. M.

The market for Stock Exchange seats received another setback yesterday with the announcement of a sale at $105,000, a decline of $29,000 from the preceding transaction. Possibly the fear that the Securities and Exchange Commission will promulgate in the near future its own rules restricting trading by members of the Stock Exchange has affected the present market price.

Virtual control of Charlton Athletic, coleader with Arsenal in the First Division of the English Football League, has been obtained by Albert and Stanley Glicksten, London timber merchants. The brothers completed a deal for $155,000 today, bringing their investment in the London club to $335,000.

Colonel Charles Bratton Stackpole, oil and mining company executive and a former newspaper publisher, died on Sunday night at Flushing Hospital, Queens, after a brief illness. He resided in Manhattan and had his offices at 90 West Street.

The "sit-down" strike at the B. M. T. Kent Avenue power plant grew out of the suspensions of James McKinney and Albert Morgan, boiler room engineers for ten years, on Saturday afternoon, because of their alleged failure to live up to the company's rules and regulations.

Philip Gordon, director of the orchestra and band projects for the WPA in Essex County, N. J., has submitted his resignation, effective next Monday. A series of six lecture-recitals on the music-dramas of Wagner will be presented by Miss Antonia Brico at 53 West Fifty-seventh Street, beginning next Tuesday morning

Hundreds of thousands of residents of Brooklyn, without automobiles and dependent on B. M. T. elevated and subway, bus and trolley lines to reach Manhattan and other parts of the city, as well as other residents of the city who travel daily to some sections of Brooklyn, would be without means of transportation if the strikes threatened on B. M. T. lines shut down service.

The Department of Commerce reported today that the aggregate arrivals in France of ginned cotton in the first ten months of 1936 were 243,794 tons valued at $72,500,000, compared with 165,146 tons valued at $48,200,000 in the corresponding period of 1935.

Favorite players who managed to survive the upsets of last week, especially those caused by such odds-on choices as Tintagel, Whopper and Ward-inChancery, received more rough treatment as another week of racing opened at Hialeah Park today.
Sheriff Bert Yells wants to butter the bread of prisoners in the Seneca County jail and he does not think that is pampering them.
Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky appealed in a nationwide broadcast yesterday for information about his 77-year-old mother in the flood zone, The Associated Press stated.

An agreement in principle on the desirability of negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and the United Kingdom has been reached as a result of the week-end conversations of President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, Britain's President of the Board of Trade.
The right of any mem ber of the British Commonwealth of Nations to secede from it was raised in the Union Parliament today.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Hollywood, Calif., of Thomas M. Marson, formerly secretary of the United States Fire Companies Conference, with offices in this city.

Plans for a five-story industrial building to cost $175,000 and for alterations to a fourteen-story apartment house to cost $55,000 in Manhattan, and for a six-story tenement house in Rego Park, Queens, have just been filed. The list follows:

A thousand miles long, and here and there--as at Louisville--broad as a lake, the Ohio River has spent almost half its existence since it was discovered by the Sieur de la Salle trying to wipe out the great cities for the placement and growth of Which it was primarily responsible.

The mightiest flood in the Mississippi River's turbulent history was officially predicted last night as the swollen Ohio, already at recordbreaking crests, continued to rise along the 950-mile stretch of valley from Pittsburgh to Cairo, Ill.
Influenza cases reported yesterday by the Health Department totaled sixty-eight for the forty-eighthour period ended at 10 A. M., compared with fifty-eight for the previous forty-eight-hour period.
Criticizing Mayor La Guardia for refusal to support the city Fusion party after he had used it for selfish purposes, Charles Belous resigned yesterday as Queens chairman of that organization.
Mrs. Virginia Guerra, mother of seven sons who at one time constituted practically the entire official family of Starr County, died last night at the age of 77.

Production of refined lead in the United States in December amounted to 47,085 tons, compared with 43,831 in the preceding month and 42,020 in December, 1935, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The output for 1936 was 463,187 tons, against 421,764 in 1935.

Up-State New York mobilized swiftly tonight aid for the flood regions. Topping contributions to the Red Cross was a pledge of $50,000 by 20,000 tanners and shoeworkers of the Endicott-Johnson Shoe Company at Endicott.

The Chevrolet division of General Motors, completely shut down since Dec. 30-31, recalled today 12,000 workers to begin curtailed operations on Wednesday. Altogether upward of 40,000 men in various cities have been recalled.
