Mark A. Hanna 3d, who on his recent arrest described himself as a grandson of the late Mark A. Hanna, National Republican leader in the McKinley regime, waived extradition in General Sessions yesterday as a fugitive from Cleveland on a worthless check charge.
A large one-man show of sculpture by Ossip Zadkine opened yesterday at the Brummer Gallery, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until- March 20.

A new electrical air purifier that produces 99 1/2 per cent pure air in one-fifth of a second and removes dust particles of sizes that approach the resolving power of the ordinary microscope was described yesterday before the opening sessions of the annual Winter convention of the Amnerican Institute of Electrical Engineers.
Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican. of Allendale, N. J., asked Congress today to require labels on manufactured goods showing the amount of taxes paid on each article.
1. The Italian Government has carefully examined the memorandum of the British Embassy of Jan. 11 regarding the question of non-intervention and more particularly the question of volunteers.

Frank Zamaris of Orange, scored his second successive one-round knockout victory tonight by stopping Billy Ketchell of Philadelphia, in 2 minutes 41 seconds of a feature boxing bout scheduled for ten sessions. Ketchell weighed 170 1/2 and Zamaris 176.

Members of the trust division of the American Bankers Association have received an income-tax memorandum from the division pointing out that banks and trust companies making income-tax returns as fiduciaries need not give, according to a ruling by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, detailed information regarding interest received from the calendar year 1936.

Charles Johnson, fugitive from floods sweeping Wheeling's "island" residential district, credited his black collie Nellie today with saving his life. Mr. Johnson stumbled while moving furniture and was knocked unconscious. He said Nellie barked and tugged at his sleeve until he was revived with water creeping around him on the floor.

The flood emergency in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys prevented President Roosevelt from joining the national committee for the Birthday Ball for the President in a nation-wide radio appeal last a night on behalf of the sufferers from infantile paralysis.
The directors of the Center Theatre are scheduled to meet next week to decide whether that temple's next musical show might be one by Laurence Stallings and Arthur Schwartz.

Ninetyseven of the 100 boys who went "on strike" at St. Cecilia Roman Catholic School because their basketball team had been suspended for playing - on Sunday returned to school this morning, still wondering if they would be deprived of their Saturday holidays.
More than 600 flood refugees boarded two relief trains outside Portsmouth late tonight for Columbus. More than 5,000 are to be thus removed from the perilous regions here in a mass evacuation.

President Roosevelt has been invited by the British' Government to send a representative to the coronation of King George VI in May and has designated James W. Gerard, the White House announced tonight.

Continuation of the government's policy of using a devalued dollar, which has created a situation where the United States is exporting goods in return for "gold that we did not want," may lead to a financial crisis far worse than the nation has just experienced, Dr. H. Parker Willis, Professor of Finance at Columbia University, warned yesterday.

Clajaca, Inc., Clarence J. Carroll, president, gave a second mortgage for $1,900, payable $158.33 monthly at 6 per cent, to Leroy M. Barkin on 604 2d Av., subject to a first mortgage for $18,000. A mortgage for $18,800 held by the Franklin Savings Bank from Philip Grieser and his wife on 146 W. 91st St. was extended to Dec. 28, 1939, at 5 per cent.

Stockholders of the Melchers Distilleries, Ltd., voted in Montreal yesterday to approve the capital reorganization plan under which holders of Class A shares will receive $3.50 a share in cash, $3 to be paid fifteen days after consummation of the plan and the balance on July 2.

General Conditions Trading was not very active this morning. Steer hinds and ribs were steady, although some sales of mixed lots were somewhat lower than last week's quotations. Steer cuts were steady to sharply lower. Veal and calf cuts were weak to sharply lower.

Wesley Sisson, formerly secretary for many years of the Postal Life Insurance Company of New York, died last night of a heart attack at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert Kirkland, at Lake Katonah, near here. He was 83 years old.

Florence Madelle La Rush, the first person in Canada to supply the medical profession with preparations for treatment of hay fever and asthma, died yesterday following an operation. For her work she was made an associate member of the Toronto Academy of Medicine.

Pope Pius spent another good night and was again allowed to pass about six hours sitting up in his wheelchair during the morning and afternoon. He was so well, indeed, that his chair for the first time was wheeled onto the magnificent loggia standing above the famous Loggia of Raphael.
Automobile production dropped off still further last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 87.1 from 95.8, the revised figure for the previous week. It was 101.8 for the week ended Jan. 25, 1936.
The government is moving to protect from extinction animal life in the Galapagos Islands, where animals and birds do not fear humans and domestic animals taken there have gone wild.

Gifts totaling $22,540 have been received toward the $150,000 fund sought by the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn. This was reported yesterday at the opening luncheon of the campaign in the Hotel Bossert, 98 Montague Street, Brooklyn, by Mrs. J. Morton Halstead, chairman of the women's special gifts committee.

Increasing its advertising and promotional budget by more than 50 per cent, the Kelvinator Corporation will spend in excess of $3,000,000 this year, dealers attending the showing of new lines in the Hotel Astor, were told yesterday.

The Fordham Prep quintet caused a triple tie for first place in the Bronx-Westchester division of the C. H. S. A A. by repulsing the Iona Prep team, 16 to 13, on the latter's floor in New Rochelle yesterday. Other squads involved in the deadlock with the Maroons are Manhattan Prep and Mount St. Michael, each with two triumphs in three starts.

Ed Knolhoff and Harold Montague of the Trinity Club were among the seven teams which advanced to the second round in the State A. A. U. handball doubles championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night. They turned back Tom Kielbasa and John Robertson of the Bedford Y. M. C. A., 18-21, 21-18, 21-13. Five combinations representing the home club were among the first-round victors.

Establishment of a governmental agency with authority to create a longrange, integrated program of power development and regulation, flood control and soil erosion prevention appeared likely today as it became known that President Roosevelt's power policy committee was giving much thought to recommendations of a broad character designed to mitigate the effects of the Ohio River flood and similar disasters.
General GOERING'S personal newspaper organ serves notice that in international negotiations the German Government will scorn the argument from money-bags.

Statements that the flood situation in the Ohio Valley will grow steadily worse for three or four days were made today by General Malin Craig, Chief of the Army General Staff, and Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Chief of Engineers, when they appeared before Senators and Representatives from the Ohio and Mississippi Valley States who asked for the facts of the situation.

Frank Snowden Thomas, a member of the-New York Stock Exchange firm of Munds, Winslow Potter, 40 Wall Street, died suddenly of a heart attack as he was dressing yesterday morning at his home, 1,105 Fifth Avenue. He was born in Baltimore, Md., sixty-four years ago.

Heamaw, their oceanside villa, was the setting tonight for a dinner to which Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps were hosts. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Vanderbilt and their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davis of New York;
The proceedings of the Securities and Exchange Commission against Charles C. Wright and eleven other respondents for alleged manipula tion of the common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor

Huge sums in advertising revenue are being lost to newspapers and other media in the flood areas, as a result of the paralysis of trade in so many cities, according to comment here yesterday in advertising circles.

Daily average gross crude oil prodiction in the United States last week was 3,205,150 barrels, a new record high, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represents a gain of 20,500 barrels over the daily average of 3,184,650 in the preceding week, the previous high level.
Governor Lehman, addressing the annual dinner of the State Agricultural Society, urged farmers to cooperate in determining what form of milk control they desired.
With a Naval Board of Inspection aboard, the Clark, a 1,850-ton treaty destroyer, steamed out of the Navy Yard today on her final acceptance trial cruise.

Frederick S. Axtell, formerly vice president and superintendent of agencies of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Baltimore, died suddenly today at the age of 78. When a young man he came here from his native Brooklyn and for several years was on the staff of The Baltimore Herald and later on The Philadelphia Times. A son, Harold T.

Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, again stressed the importance of immunizing children against diphtheria as his weekly report of the city's health yesterday disclosed thirty-four new cases of the disease and two deaths.

Maurice Reddy, National Red Cross director, estimated tonight, on the basis of latest figures available, that the Red Cross was caring for 416,250 homeless persons in five flood States. He added that "my estimate is conservative."

Many dinners will be given tonight in connection with the dinner dance arranged by Princess Alexis Obolensky for the benefit of needy Russian families in this country and abroad, which will take place in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
A sufficient quantity of vaccine to immunize more than 50,000 persons was sent from Boston to Louisville by plane today as all New England continued to rally to the aid of flood sufferers.

Support of a legislative bill which would provide State financial aid for kindergartens in the public school system was urged yesterday at the forty-seventh annual meeting of the New York Kindergarten Association at its headquarters, 524 West Forty-second Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ditmas Lott of 540 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Mary Osborn Polak of 825 Fifth Avenue, to Donald Mitchell Oenslager, stage scenic designer of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Oenslager Jr. of Harrisburg, Pa.

Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange and a member of its governing board, disclosed today that the existing rigid regulations of the Exchange governing the listing of securities may be in for a further overhauling as a result of testimony given before the Senate Committee on Interstate
Stocks reactionary, closed lower; turnover, 2,174,830 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower; foreign issues steady; sales, $14,927,100.

President Roosevelt abruptly ended today elaborate studies which he ordered Sept. 30 on the pooling of public and private electric power transmission facilities in the Tennessee Valley, bowing before an injunction obtained by private power companies which, he said, "precludes a joint transmission facility arrangement."

Albert W. Sherer, for the past eight years vice president and director of Lord Thomas, Chicago, has resigned, effective March 1. Prior to his connection with Lord Thomas, he was with the Chicago office of the Curtis Publishing Company for twelve years, the last three of which he was Western manager.

Testimony that two skilled draftsmen were "planted" as spies in the engipeering division of the Chrysler Motors Corporation to learn the identity of members of the Society of Designing Engineers was put before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage today by Chester L. Robertson, an official of the society.

Revival in business activity, accpmpanied by a decline in unemployment to the point where skilled labor is becoming scarce, is almost universal today, according to representatives from nineteen countries in North and South America, Australasia, Europe and Asia, who attended sessions of the annual convention of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The second exhibition of sculpture designed and executed under the supervision of the sculpture division of the WPA Federal Art Project in New York opened with a private view yesterday afternoon in the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Mayor La Guardia, apparently recovered from the cold that kept him home for a week, put in a full day at his desk at City Hall yesterday. He caught up with much of his mail and discussed city problems with several of his commissioners.

LOUISVILLE-Exhausted police and National Guardsmen welcomed the arrival of Federal troops. Military rule went into effect. A varnish plant was destroyed by fire. Scattered cases of typhoid, scarlet fever and measles appear. Looting was reported. Some 230,000 are homeless. The river reached 56.9 feet, with water two to six feet deep in the streets.

For Flood Relief Due to the deplorable condition of inhabitants of the flood areas we have been requested by the American Red Cross to appeal to the members of this department for voluntary contributions to be used for the relief and care of the refugees.

Grain markets fluctuated in an erratic manner today, but the undertone was firm. Wheat and corn advanced around a cent a bushel in the early trading, only to ease toward the end. Wheat closed 3/8 cent higher on May and 1/4 to 3/8 cent lower on the new-crop months.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Julian Zolnay of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Zolnay, to John Churchill Newcomb of this city, formerly of Louisville, Ky., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Danforth Newcomb of Louisville and Greenwood, Va.

Thomas F. Doherty, a former City Court Judge in Troy, N. Y., who had been employed recently in the Corporation Counsel's office, this city, died Monday night of gallstones in the Webb Sanitarium, 2,400 Webster Avenue, Bronx, at the age of 68.

Mr. SANFORD BATES, for the last six or seven years Superintendent of Federal Prisons and back of that Commissioner of Prisons in Massachusetts for ten years, has emphasized the importance of preventive. work as against punitive or reformatory, by accepting the position of executive director of the Boys' Clubs of America.

George Herman Ruth, promising New York left-handed golfer, spread his 240 pounds over a new Christmas chair yesterday and cheerfully discussed Lou Gehrig, baseball, the future, the past and the sad state of his putting.

Stuyvesant Fish, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange house of Calaway, Fish Co., and a member of the Exchange since 1909, was the seller of the seat that was purchased Monday for $105,000, according to information made available yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Robert Jr. have come from Washington to the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Shattuck, Mr. and Mrs. William Copper Dickey and Mrs. Burgess Gurnee will sail Saturday for a southern cruise.
With the arrival of a half-dozen outdoor pictures from Oklahoma the number of States now represented in the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest has risen to ten.

The House today passed the first deficiency bill, carrying an appropriation of $899,227,318.99 for the balance of this fiscal year, of which $790,000,000 represents the President's request for funds to continue the work of the WPA, the Resettlement Administration and a few minor relief agencies.

The Federal Government today threw all its resources of men and money into the battle along the flood front. Backed by the President's pledge that every cent would be used for flood relief if necessary and responding to pleas of Representatives from the devastated areas for immediate action, the House passed without record vote the $790,000,000 appropriation, asked for general relief before the Ohio went on the rampage.
Nearly a thousand of the Catholic clergy attended funeral services today for the Most Rev. Michael J. Gallagher, Bishop of the Detroit Diocese, who died on Wednesday.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission ended yesterday its examination of witnesses in this area in its hearing of charges that the Kraft-Phenix Corporation had violated the Robinson-Patman act, dealing with discounts to retailers on quantity purchases.

H. D. Gibson has been named by the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation to assist refrigeration distributors and the field organization in developing key accounts in trade centers. Richard H. Moulton has been appointed personnel manager for the general office and the field forces of the General Foods Sales Company.

Mrs. Lydia Southwick Warren, wife of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin C. Warren of Rehoboth Beach, Del., retired member of the New York Methodist Episcopal Conference, died here at the Beebe Hospital yesterday after a brief illness: Her age was 69. Burial will take place Thursday in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., where she was born.
Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and Graham, Parsons Co. purchased yesterday a new issue of $750,000 of bonds of the city of Kansas City, Mo., as 2 3/7s. The bonds will mature on Feb. 1, 1939 to 1975.

The Triborough Bridge Authority won almost unanimous support for its proposal to build a 2,300-foot bridge across the East River from Old Ferry Point, the Bronx, to Whitestone, Queens, at a hearing yesterday morning before Army engineers at 39 Whitehall Street.

A great fight .to strengthen strained levees of the Mississippi, gravely threatened by the historymaking flood on the Ohio River, was begun last night as the outlook in the Ohio Valley brightened. Altogether the floods, reaching from the upper Ohio to the deep South, had taken more than 135 lives; made an estimated 750,000 homeless, and caused property damage estimated at more than $300,000,000.
The New York Rangers put on a late drive to shut out the Bruins, 3-0, in a well-played National Hockey League game tonight before a crowd of 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

King George VI asked Parliament today to make permanent provision in the shape of a Regency Act for carrying on the functions of the Crown not only during the childhood of Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose, should either be called to the throne, but also during "any incapacity of the sovereign" or his absence from the realm.

The swollen Ohio River reached what United States engineers said was a crest of 48.7 feet tonight, with one-third of this city under water. The tide blanketed parts of the downtown business section six to eight feet, and covered about 8,000 homes.

Funeral services for City Court Justice William B. Hazelwood of Queens were held last night in the Simonson Funeral Parlors, 86-01 Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill, by the Rev. Kenneth B. Grady, pastor of Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, Richmond Hill.

The Maritime Commission anbounced yesterday that hearings would be started Feb. 3 in New York and five other port cities to determine minimum wage scales, working conditions and manning scales on all ships receiving government subsidies. The local hearings will be held at 45 Broadway.

THE power of plain story-telling is beautifully demonstrated in Edward Harris Heth's little novel called "Told With a Drum" (Houghton, Mifflin, $2). Somewhat .over a year ago Mr. Heth's first novel, called "Some We Loved," was highly praised by the local press; and this, his second, ought to have a like reception.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 25: COLONELS McCabe, E. R. W., F.-A., General Staff Corps, relieved from assignment to the General Staff, with troops, and from duty as Chief of Staff of the Sixth Corps Area, Chicago, Ill., and ordered to General Staff, Washington, D. C., July 1.

An investigation by the Senate Judiciary Committee of criticisms of some of the Supreme Court justices in the book, "The Nine Old Men," by Robert S. Allen and Drew Pearson, was asked today by Senator Guffey.

Working along the theory that it is no worse to lose a game by a dozen goals than by one, the New York Americans absorbed a 9-to-0 trouncing from the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.

More than 1,000 persons crowded St. James Catholic Church, at 32 James Street, yesterday morning at the high mass of requiem for Special Sessions Justice Thoma J. Nolan, who died on Saturday at the age of 64.

The practice of splitting medical fees among physicians in this city has become so widespread that the public is suffering from excessive medical costs as a result, it was charged yesterday by Dr. Harold M. Hays, president of the Association of Private Hospitals.

17th St., 331-333 E., 46.5x92 Lynde Catlin and wife to Baron de Hirsch Fund, mortgagee; same property, Bank of Somerset, Princess Ann, Md., to same (quitclaim). 75th St., 52 W., 20x102.2; Rox Realty Co., Inc., to Ada F. Bierhof, 52 W. 75th St.

In all Shakespeare tragedies, which Russian trials surprisingly resemble-except for the somewhat important difference that when the curtain falls on the play the actors go to supper or go home and in Russian trials of this kind in many cases a dishonored grave is the only last long home-there always is comic relief. Today the comic relief was provided by a citizen named Arnold,

Carles L. Frink, former Mayor of North Adams, and a deputy sheriff for fifty years, died last night at the home of his son, Edgar Frink, at Kansas City, Mo., where he had been living since August. He would have been 68 years old on Feb. 16.

Dynamite blasts for the second time in as many days ripped vast chunks from a crumbling levee to speed Mississippi flood waters across deserted Missouri lowlands today in a battle to keep the Ohio River out of Cairo.

Albert C. Simonson tied Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, for first place in the title tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when his game in the final round with E. S. Jackson was forfeited to him by the tournament committee.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 25, unless specified: Norfolk to sea, Jan. 26: Acushnet, Tucker, San Diego to sea: Chandler, Sandpipen, At Honolulu: Cushing, Perkins. At San Diego: Neches, Wyoming. Clark, Bost. Yard to sea, Jan, 26.

The new tactics used by certain labor unions and labor leaders have not only puzzled but somewhat alarmed many Americans. What can they do against the sit-down strike ? It is a French importation, but teems for the time to be highly effective here.
Herbert R. Anderson, a vice president of Distributors Group, Inc., has been elected a director. Eugene M. Matalene and J. Raymond Smith have been appointed assistant vice presidents.

Something of an occasion was the American premiere on Monday night of Friedrich Feher's "Robber Symphony" at the Venice (formerly the Al Jolson) Theatre on West Fifty-ninth Street. The picture's reputation had preceded it.

The annual reports of the Church Life Insurance Corporation and the Church Properties Fire Insurance Corporation, as affiliates of the Church Pension Fund, were presented at directors' meetings yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan, president.

Business failures declined in all trade groups last week in comparison with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Insolvencies in the retail division dropped from 113 to 103, and compared with 153 in the corresponding period last year. The detailed report is as follows:

The inhabitants of this town were in a state of mind just short of panic tonight because they feared they were the unsuspecting victims of a night air raid by the Japanese or the Spanish Rebels or any one else who might find it strategically advisable to bomb Merrick, L. I., at this time.
Wreckers started to tear down the- wrong house in Brooklyn yesterday, and before their error was discovered damage of $500 had been done.
ALFRED P. SLOAN, in his letter to Secretary of Labor FRANCES PERKINS, takes a stand on the minor issue of the automobile strike which
Maxie Berger, Bronx lightweight, pounded his way to a decision over Eddie Brink, Scranton, Pa., in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night.

Hunts Point Av., 827, 4-story tenement; Dollar, Savings Bank against 819 Hunts Point Av. Co.: due, $19,858; taxes, , $1,193; to plaintiff for $16,500. By B. Hollander Son. 175th St., 740 E., 2-story dwelling; Belle Prince against 601 W. 135th St. Corp.
The annual statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today, shows profits of $2,008,124 for 1936, after making provision for contingencies and reserves.
An application for a deficiency judgment of $20,655 was canceled yesterday under the law concerning "reasonable value at time of sale" by Justice Thomas J. Cuff in Supreme Court, Queens.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week when a small increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index fell to 122.5 from 124.8. A year ago, it was 76.5.

The New York Athletic Club hockey team turned back the Bear Mountain Cubs, 4 to 2, in the indoor rink tonight. Lyndon Wilson, star of last season's Yale sextet, paced the attack for the Winged Foot skaters with two goals, both in the second period.

Projects filed for in the city yesterday included plans for an ice plant in Manhattan and various small buildings in other boroughs. Details of the plans follow: Manhattan 47th St., 635-7 W. and 48th st., 634-638 w; 171-50; for 1-story ice plant;

The building at 39-13 23d St., Long Island City, has been leased by Dunrite Cleaning Corp. from Alexander Coulter, through Lehr Benes. Butler Baldwin report the following buildings fully rented: 51 W. 12th St. 169 E. 33d St., 49 W. 39th St., 353 E, 50th St. and 306 E. 52d St.

Donna Fox, a member of the United States bobsled team which competed in the Winter Olympic Games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in Germany last year, was feted by more than 300 friends at a dinner dance held at the Concourse Plaza Hotel last night. Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx was toastmaster.

In the first chapter of his autobiography KIPLING thanks Allah for his good fortune. It began with his birth. His earliest recollections are of the strong light and hue of India. He was in the elementary grades of his cosmopolitan education.

The Montreal Canadiens increased their lead in the International Group in the National Hockey League by turning back the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, 3--1, in a contest that drew a crowd of more than 12,000.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 26 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

An agreement on Danzig seemed definitely reached tonight among the League of Nations Councils committee of three, composed of the British, French and Swedish Foreign Ministers; Josef Beck, the Polish Foreign Minister, and Arthur Greiser, President of the Danzig Senate.

" Rats," said Basil Brown, florist, when he observed what had happened to his window display of carnations. He was right. Pedestrians reported seeing gray rats scurry into the window, chew the stem of a carnation a few inches below the blossom, and scramble off carrying the flower.

When the-late Sam Hildreth was the country's leading trainer his success was laid by many to the fact that Hildreth literally slept with his horses and knew their peculiarities and feelings to such an extent that he was unerring in his judgment both as to condition and how to place a horse. Sam would, on occasion,

On their own applications: PATROLMEN--Chester A. Patterson, Mounted Squadron 2, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 30, 1910. John J. Buechler, Traffic Precinct P. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 5, 1911.

The Rev. Alexander T. Newman, retired cantor and superintendent of the Home for the Aged of Pittsburgh for fourteen years, died at his home here Sunday night at the age of 76. He was a native of Russia, and had served as a cantor in Toronto and Hamilton, Ont. Surviving are his widow, formerly Miss Hattie Louis of Baltimore;

The wear and tear of New York's first sit-down strike, involving the electrical workers in the Williamsburg power plant of the B. M. T. system, yesterday forced a postponement of a discussion of the issues between the employes and the company until 10 o'clock this morning.

Gerhard Schutes, a young artist from Elkhart, Ind., testified yesterday to the close and constant association of most of the eight defendants in the restaurant racket trial with Jules Martin, murdered racketeer who worked for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

Fixing by the Federal government of minimum wages and maximum hours, which are accepted as the "desirable" limits, was opposed yesterday by Donald R. Richberg, former head of the NRA, in an address at a luncheon meeting of the Trade Association Executives in New York City at the Hotel Astor.

With faltering power, by hand, and by mimeograph, newspaper editors in the folld areas struggled today to continue publication. In some cities and towns presses capable of printing thousands of copies an hour were under water, but the newspapers still appeared as handbills.

The press this morning prepares its readers to expect General Kazushige Ugaki's submission to the army in the course of the day. He will inform the Emperor that he is unable to execute the mandate, given to him early Sunday, to form a Cabinet, and will return to private life, this time permanently.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bascom of 24 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Marie Bascom, to Howard Lovell Wright Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Wright of Buffalo, N. Y.

Favorites, led by Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., and Joe Switzer of St. Louis, the medalist, came through the first match round of the annual Winter Championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup today.
Official reports dispelled today any possible fears of floods in New York State, while waters in rivers and streams receded from peaks reached after heavy week-end rains.

Accidentally injured on the left hand during a dress rehearsal of the opera "Caponsacchi," by a stiletto in the hand of Lawrence Tibbett, Joseph Sterzini, 52 years old, a bass choral singer, died five hours later yesterday in the Manhattan General Hospital.

James Dorsey Bashford, former treasurer of Wayne County, died at his home here this afternoon. Survivors are his widow, Mrs. Lillian Barton Bashford, and several nieces. Son of the late James and Susan Dorsey Bashford, he was born seventy-six years ago in Lyons.

Two institutions for education of the blind receive more than $109,000 from the estate of Mrs. Georgia M. Hathorne, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Hathorne, who died on March 3, 1936, left an estate valued at $207,066 gross and $189,347 net.

A State income tax bill calling for levies ranging from 2 to 5 per cent was introduced today in the Senate of the Connecticut General Assembly. The measure was offered by Senator William M. Curtis, Bridgewater farmer, who said it was sponscored by the Connecticut Grange. Senator Curtis said the tax was based "on ability to pay" and it would bring to the State $4,000,000 annually.

The National Guard will not be used to break the strike of automobile wiers or take the part of either side, Governor Frank Murphy declared today after he had arranged a method of assuring all sides that there would be no trouble when the Chevrolet plant at Flint reopens tomorrow.

The American Red Cross intensified its drive yesterday to raise $1,605,600 in Greater New York for the relief of flood sufferers in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys. At the same time charitable, civic, political, theatrical and other organizations launched or organized movements for the aid of flood victims.

Business properties formed the bulk of the real estate turnover in Manhattan yesterday. Apartment houses and a garage changed hands in the Bronx. The Union Dime Savings Bank, which recently foreclosed the fourstory building at 78 West Fortyseventh Street, southeast corner of Sixth Avenue sold the property to Herman King's Whitetop Realty Corporation.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading still showed signs of sluggishness in most classes and prices tended lower on traefa meats. Early trading in Kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be steady and lamb lower.

Public hearings on the $436,000,000 rapid transit unification plan advocated by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. will be closed within the next two weeks, John J. Curtin, special counsel for the Transit Commission, indicated yesterday.
Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in a special letter to members yesterday, stressed the need for immediate help to the thousands made homeless by the floods.
Miss Hazel Evarts Depew, daughter of Mrs. Frank Depew of Montclair, has completed plans for her marriage to Roger Pierce Holden, son of Mrs. Leon C. Holden, also of Montclair.
Germany and Italy have made another move in the tortuous and seemingly endless game of evading responsibility for the continuance of foreign interention in Spain.

The New Jersey State women's squash racquets championship resolved itself into a contest between New York and Philadelphia players today, as Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis and Miss Charlotte Darling, the defending champion from the Philadelphia Cricket Club, made their way through the quarter and semi-final rounds into the final.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders tolay, dated Jan. 23: Thom, Comdr. J. C., Naval Academy, ordered home about June, relieved of all active duty. Hundt, Lt. Comdr. L. T., Washington, D. C., to the Enterprise and on board when commissioned.

Within less than an hour after a radio appeal by Mayor Neville Miller. of Louisville for "at least 500" uniformed policemen to supplement the all but exhausted Louisville force Governor George H. Earle had ordered 100 members of the State police to stand by for airplane transportation to the Kentucky city at dawn Coincidentally. Mayor S.

In the dinner party given by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nay Morris last night at the Westbury were Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte, Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. Elbert F. Wilmerding, Mrs. Charles Livingston Hyde, Eustis Langdon Hopkins and Edward S. Martin.

William E. Iselin of the prominent New York family of bankers, merchants and yachtsmen, died last night after a month's illness at his home, 720 Park Avenue. His eightyninth birthday occurred two weeks ago.

The League of Composers will give two concerts for the joint benefit of the Composers' Fund of the league and the scholarship fund of the Neighborhood School of the Theatre on the Sunday evenings of March and April 4, it was announced yesterday.

Cooperative associations, agricultural, consumer and distributive, today occupied the attention of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association, one of six trade groups meeting here this week to discuss interrelated problems of the food industry.

The Board of Aldermen approved yesterday the issuance of $29,340 in special revenue bonds to pay the salaries of Federal customs inspectors who are to be assigned, starting Feb. 1, to the free trade zone on Staten Island.

A directed verdict by Judge Guy L. Fake in Federal court today in favor of the defendants in the Port Newark National Bank case relieved eight women jurors of the necessity of deciding a knotty constitutional problem, but brought about a friendly discussion between the women and the court on the problems of the housewife-juror. f the housewife-juror.

Persons living in or traveling to flood areas where the water supply may be polluted temporarily can assure themselves of a safe drink of water by adding a drop of iodinen to each glass of water, army doctors said today.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Coberly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. B. Coberly of this city, to Alan Henry Hoover, son of former President and Mrs. Herbert Hoover, was announced today by the mother of the bride-elect.

Sales of fertilizer by the International Agricultural Corporation in the last half of 1936 were 18 per cent ahead of those for the corresponding period in 1935, John J. Watson, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting-here yesterday.

An award for distinguished service to-agriculture was made to Maurice Adin Blake, Professor of Agriculture at Rutgers University, at the opening session of the State Agricultural Convention in the Assembly Chamber at the Capitol today. Professor Blake has developed some 100 new varieties of peaches.

Preliminary reports on a wide range of subjects, covering registration of securities, standards for determining adequate distribution and activity in connection with unlisted trading upon exchanges and overthe-counter rules and regulations, were presented at the annual meeting of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., held here today. B.

One of the Bolshevist officials reputed to be responsible for the slaying of Czar Nicholas and his family in 1918 faced the prospect of death today. Alexander Georgivitch Belaborodoff, former President of the Orenburg Soviet, was arrested at Rostoff-on-the-Don after M. S. Boguslavsky, one of the seventeen on trial here as Trotskyist plotters, implicated him in a plot to overthrow the Soviet regime while an exile at Rusk, Siberia. in 1928.
Netter Netter, attorneys, purchased the three six-family houses at 25-43, 25-41 and 25-37 Thirtythird Street, Long Island City, from the Ecco Realty Corporation, William Eckert, president.
The list of commercial leases for Spring occupancy and for Immediate changes of location and expansion was heavy yesterday. Renting was active in the Garment Center and store space was in demand.

The manuscript for a final collection of short stories by the late G. K. Chesterton has just been received by Dodd, Mead. The volume will be entitled "The Paradoxes of Mr. Pond," and March 9 is the publication date.

Making a great late-inning rally, Willie Hoppe of New York swept into the lead tonight in his 2,500-point match with young Jake Schaefer of Chicago for the world's 28.2 balkline billiard title. Winning the second block, 348 to 191, Hoppe's as grand total rose to 500 points, to 441 for his opponent.

Johnny Clinton of the West Side knocked out Tommy Bland of Toronto in 2:45 of the third round in a scheduled eight-round clash before 1,500 at the Broadway Arena last night. The victor scaled 148 3/4, Bland 144.

Cathedral Prep's basketball forces dislodged St. John's Prep from fourth place in the Brooklyn division of the C. H. S. A. A. by routing the Redmen, 32 to 18, on the winner's court yesterday. The rivals had been tied for the position, each with three triumphs. Arthur Fitzgerald led the attack with thirteen tallies.

G. Spillman, an aviator of the Central American Transport Company, continued dropping supplies and medicines today for Gordon Kingsley, one of the fliers lost in the Nicaraguan jungle. It will take four days for men from the Bonanza mines to reach the aviator.

The Board of Examiners reports ?? there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service day high schools the names of the follow ing applicants, who have been granted it censes, as indicated.

Dr. Frank Rhodes Fry, widely known neurologist and practicing physician, died last night in St. Luke's Hospital, to which he had been taken two weeks ago from his office, after he had suffered a heart attack while treating a patient.
A dramatic struggle to conserve rainfall in the Great Plains continued today while floods swept the Ohio River Valley. Soil conservation service officials said little rain had fallen in the nation's

Coming from behind, Mars Shield of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Milky Way Farms won the $1,200 La Crescenta mile race for 3-year-olds today in the good time of 1:371-5 at Santa Anita. Hondo was second and Teddy Green third.

Dr. Theodore G. Huntington, for many years a dentist practicing at Madison Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, New York, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Ralph A. D. Preston, 44 Rockridge Road. He was 77 years old. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Adelaide Waterman Huntington; a son,
The heaviest snowfall here in many years will keep former Kaiser Wilhelm confined to his home tomorrow, his sventy-eighth birthday.

Deliveries of copper for consumption in the principal countries outside of the United States averaged 103,122 tons monthly in 1936, compared with 101,320 monthly in 1935 and 90,085 in 1934, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.
Another "Coast Guard special" train, carrying nine boats and thirty-two men drawn from stations near here, left Jersey City yesterday afternoon for the flood areas to aid in relief work.

The Fifth Avenue Bank, as trustee of the will of Thomas Franklyn Manville, sold to the Bleecker-Perry Corp., Edward Martin, president, 96-98 Perry Street and took back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $40,000, payable in five years at 4 per cent.

Funeral services for William J. Robertson, who had been sexton of Grace Church, Brooklyn, for more than forty years, were held there last night. Mr. Robertson died on Monday at his home, 65 Joralemon Street.

The consolidated net income of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries, according to the preliminary statement for the year ended Dec. 31, 1936, released yesterday, amounted to $13,349,810 after interest, amortization, provision for retirement reserve, minority interests,

189th St. (11-3076), s. e. cor. Hughes Av., 175x100: Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co., trustee, to Arbel Realty Corp., 103 Park Av.; mtg. $60,000. White Plains Rd. (14-3500). s. w. cor Lacombe Av., 96x25; Rose Finkelstein to Alfonsina Di Lello, 3,146 Park Av.

Nine patrons of a Turkish bath at 9 Essex Street, near Canal Street, were affected by carbon monoxide gas at 5 A. M. yesterday. Two police emergency squads and an ambulance from Gouverneur Hospital provided apparatus with which they were revived.

Continuing their efforts in behalf of Vladimir Romm, former Washington correspondent of the Moscow newspaper Izvestia, who has recently made confessions in the conspiracy trials in Russia, a group of Washington correspondents called upon Alexander Troyanovsky, the Soviet Ambassador, today to express their "shock and dismay" at the news of his arrest.

Transportation and communication facilities to the flood zone remained largely disrupted yesterday as the waters of the Ohio and its tributaries swept over telephone and telegraph lines and flooded highways, railroad tracks and airfields.

Domestic bonds were subjected to heavy selling pressure during most of yesterday's trading period on the New York Stock Exchange with the result that substantial dedines were recorded over a broad front and in virtually all the major classifications of the domestic list.
Danielle Darrieux, European film luminary who recently completed "Mayerling" with Charles Boyer in London, was signed today by Universal's British agents to a fiveyear contract.

John M. Schiff. a partner in the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., and Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, have been elected to the council of New York University, Dr. Fred I. Kent, president of the council, announced yesterday.
Patchpocket, a 6-year-old gelding which seldom finishes out of the money, dropped down a notch in competition today and scored an easy victory in the six-furlong headliner at the Fair Grounds.

Analysis of the United States Steel Corporation's preliminary report for 1936 indicates that the amount of undistributed surplus remaining after deduction for the Federal surplus profits tax was $4,600,000.

Following the selection of a jury in the Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday for the trial of three men charged with robbing a bank messenger in Farmingdale, L. I., of $12,500, one defendant withdrew his plea of not guilty and entered a plea of guilty.

In a House of Commons that at times became tempestuous, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, tonight defended the government for its summary dismissal, it is believed on suspicion of sabotage, of five dockyard workers, without giving them a chance to hear the charges against them or frame a defense.

Net assets a share of common stock in the Equity Corporation, an investing company, virtually doubled during 1936, according to the annual report issued yesterday. The figure for Dec. 31 last was $3.12, against $1.58 for the same date in 1935.

Charles A. Wunderley, an immigrant boy who rose to be one of the city's foremost art dealers and critics, was found dead late last night under circumstances which led police to believe he had suffered a heart attack while resisting a holdup.

President Roosevelt late today rebuked Alfred P. Sloan Jr., presnident of General Motors Corporation, for his refusal to attend further conferences with Secretary Perkins and union representatives looking to a settlement of the strike in the automotive industry, as long as union men continue "to hold our plants unlawfully."
Silliman Evans, president of the Maryland Casualty Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of directors, and Edward J. Bond, senior vice president, was elected president.

Frost nipped at citrus fruit early today for the nineteenth time this month, requiring light but widespread heating in Southern California groves. Federal Meteorologist Floyd D. Young warned that another wave of frigidity might arrive from the Northwest within three or four days.
A retired member of the New York Fire Department will complete next month his first year of studies at Fordham College, it was revealed yesterday by college authorities.

Informed that Dennis McLaughlin, 53 years old, formerly assistant superintendent of Postoffice Station W, in West Eighty-third Street, had committed suicide in Atlantic City, a charge of stealing from the mails pending against him was declared abated yesterday by Isaac Gutman, Assistant United States Attorney.

Contributions to the Red Cross flood relief in the form of checks, currency or money orders should be sent to any of the following city chapters: New York Chapter (Manhattan and the Bronx), 315 Lexington Avenue, New York City. Brooklyn Chapter, 130 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

W. N. Fannign of Yonkers, treasurer of the Westchester County Publishers Association, today headed publishers of the New York State Associated Dailies, succeeding Ralph E. Bennett, publisher of The Binghamton Press.

France's military preparedness, should a European break occur, was the subject of an extensive debate that opened in the Chamber of Deputies today. The discussion will be followed with tense interest in the entire country, which feels a need for a reassuring answer to the question as to whether France is ready, come what may.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Howell Behr of Morristown, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Vernam Behr, to Donald Bogart Kipp.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. George A. Berger Jr., Q. M.-Res?? will proceed on or about Jan. 26, 1937, from Governors Island, N. Y., to Albany, N. Y. for temporary duty in connection with CCC activities, and upon completion of this duty will return to his propet station, Governors Island, N. Y.

The Standard Silicate Co. sold to the Diamond Alkali Co. a two-story building on a plot 146x201, at 661-69 Tonnele Av., extending through the block to Carroll Av.. Jersey City. The New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Co. sold to Fannie Silon of Hoboken for $16,000 the one-story frame building at 402 Central Av., near Bowers St., Jersey City.

A motion by the State Attorney General to continue an injunction restraining Better Houses, Inc., 79 Walker Street, and its officers from selling stock to the public was granted on default yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan.

The New Brunswick High School basketball team defeated St. Benedict's Prep of Newark in a thrilling game tonight, 31 to 30, before a crowd of 3,000. With only twelve seconds remaining and the score tied at 30-all, Joe Harlukowitz sank a free throw to win the game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Neither Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's letter to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, proposing a war moratorium, nor Dr. Butler's enthusiastic reply makes any reference to the late William Jennings Bryan's peace plan first presented by Mr. Bryan to a peace

More than 200 women attended a luncheon bridge party given yesterday by Mrs. Margaret M. Sawyer at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in aid of the blind of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Appalled by the disaster that has overtaken Louisville, Ky., his home city, the United States Ambassador to London, Robert W. Bingham, will speed homeward on the liner Bremen tomorrow to help his fellow-townsmen. llow-townsmen.

Harry Emmett Pollard died today in his home here. He came here in 1923 to be vice president of the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank on its establishment and resigned in 1928 to be vice president of the Home National Bank of Brockton. His age was 57.

A twelve-story apartment building at 216 West 100th Street was added yesterday to the list of buildings in which strikes have been ed called by Local 32 B of the Building Service Employes International Union in its campaign to force compliance with the wage and hour provisions of the Silcox award.

Governor Lehman tonight told farmers from all sections of the State, at the annual dinner of the New York State Agricultural Society, that he was pondering whether arbitrary price control of milk should be continued, and added that he believed the mind of the Legislature also was open on the question.

State control of the location of industries was brought a step nearer in the House of Commons today when Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin announced the abandonment of a plan to build an aircraft factory that would employ 5,000 men at White Waltham, in the Thames Valley, less than thirty miles from London.

From Memphis, Tenn., the home of his new boss, yesterday came the signed contract of Lou Chiozza, the 26-year-old third baseman whom Colonel Bill Terry of the Giants pried loose from the Phillies last Fall, using considerable cash to do so.

State banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, but which are not members of the Federal Reserve System, are subject to unemployment and.old-age pension taxes under the Social Security Act, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

George S. Kaufman, playwright, took a Supreme Court jury through the theory and practice of "play doctoring" yesterday in a suit involving the amount of rewriting required to turn an unsuccessful play into a successful' one.

This flood-stricken city and adjacent communities. ruled by martial law, battled tonight against ever-increasing terror and misery as they watched the Ohio River rising toward a new record-breaking stage of fifty-nine feet.

Charles R. Vincent of Plainfield died today at the home of his son, Charles R. Vincent Jr., in Livingston, N. J. He was born in Erie, Pa., eighty-two years ago. For twenty years he was president of the Ball-Wood Engine Company of New York and then became president of the VincentGilson Engineering Company, New York, retiring in 1928.

Two hundred and fifty Federal troops arrived here today from Fort Thomas, Ky., and were stationed around the temporary site in East Frankfort for convicts evacuated from the flooded State Reformatory.

Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis school girl, advanced through the first round of the Charlotte Harbor women's golf tournament without losing a hole today. Her 9-and-7 triumph over Mrs. Frank Trainor of Tampa was hardly more one-sided than other scores turned in by the first-flight players competing in the initial Florida event of the season.

The City Athletic Club maintained its grip on first place in the race for honors among the Group 2 teams of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association yesterday by winning its eighth consecutive match of the season.

The Insurgents drove a hard blow today at the government's positions in the Casa de Campo, on the western outskirts of Madrid, but without much success. It was typical of the innumerable local engagements that have taken place in recent weeks, affecting the general situation only slightly.
A birth is expected in the royal family, it became known today. It was announced a few days ago that Queen Joanna had canceled all engagements.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at Kent, Conn., of Herman T. Schladermundt, an artist known especially for his mural paintings and his work in stained glass. Born in Milwaukee, Wis., seventy-three years ago, Mr. Schladermundt received his art training at the Delacluse and Julian Academies in Paris.
Yellowstone Park rangers baited corrals with hay to lure 2,000 elk, which are doomed to slaughter so the remainder of the herd of 10,000 can survive on Winter range.

The Senate approved the Doyle "Pay Envelope Coercion" bill today. Meanwhile the Assembly passed and sent to the Governor three measures affecting New York City: the Farrell bill, unifying control of the Triborough Bridge and the projected Whitestone-Bronx bridge in one State Authority;

The Bayonne City Commission entered into a new contract today with Central District, Inc., under which the corporation becomes the city's agent in the construction of the proposed New York Bay port terminal.

Desolated cities, towns and tremendously extensive rural areas bordering the swollen Ohio River and its many tributaries came under the keel of a special TWA Douglas transport plane today in a 1,105-mile flight from New York to St. Louis which covered more than 700 miles of flood country.

Frazer Coulter, who had appeared on the New York stage for more than half a century in support of many stars, died today at the Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I., after a long illness. He was 88 years old. Since his retirement, in 1931, he had passed his declining years at the Percy Williams Home for Actors here.

A prediction that Chicago's $400,000 quota for the Red Cross flood relief will be raised to $1,000,000 tomorrow was made today by James T. Nicholson, chairman of the Chicago chapter. He cited the speed with which funds had reached headquarters.

Angelo Trulio of the New York Athletic Club annexed the New York State A. A. U. four-wall handball championship for the eighth successive year by defeating Vladimir Kotal of the West Side Y. M. C. A. in the final at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.

John E. Kennebeck, managing director of the Paramount Film Service, Ltd., distributors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., motion pictures in Australia and New Zealand, died on Saturday in Sydney, Australia.

An eccentric robber who wore a tan lumberjack and spoke with a drawl abandoned his intention of holding up a millinery shop in downtown Brooklyn last night when the proprietor, Mrs. Jennie Greenstein, insisted there was only $2 in the cash register.

The New York University rifle team, Metropolitan Intercollegiate League champion. for the last two years, will engage in nine shoulderto-shoulder matches and seven telegraph engagements, according to the schedule announced yesterday.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the State dinner in honor of the diplomatic corps, the third on this year's White House schedule. The next, and last, in honor of the Chief Justice and the Associate Justices of the Supreme Court, will be given next Tuesday night.

Allen W. Beam, a former member of the Maryland Legislature from Baltimore and for years active in Republican political circles, died at his home here yesterday, aged 67. He had been engaged in the plumbing business more than thirty years and was twice president of the National Master Plumbers Association. Surviving are his widow,

Members of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers Inc., at their annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night decided to maintain the prevailing discount of 8 per cent on coats and scarfs and to sell trimmings at net.

Then came school at the far end of England. The Head of it was a lean, slow-spoken, bearded, Arab-complexioned marl, whom till then I had known as one of my Deputy-Uncles at the Grange--Cormell Price, otherwise "Uncle Corm." My mother,

Dr. W. R. Valentiner, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts and an authority on Dutch painting, has identified a picture owned by a New York collector as a portrait of John Speed (1552-1629), English historian and cartographer, by "an artist close to Michiel Jansz van Mierevelt (1567-1641), Dutch painter.

Only two days' play was possible in the cricket match between the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team and South Australia, the game being declared drawn. Heavy rain fell yesterday and today. When play closed Saturday, the home team had carried its first innings' total to 194 for four wickets in reply to the English score of 301.

The widow and the sister of Frank Cicero, stabbed to death at a dinner at the Manhattan Opera House on Jan. 17, attempted yesterday to wreak personal vengeance on two men accused of the murder at their arraignment in Homicide Court, 300 Mulberry Street.

T. Louis A. Britt, attorney, was elected president of the Alumni Association of the College of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street, at a dinner last night at the Hotel Astor commemorating the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the college.

Business in the stock market here fell off today as commitments were reduced before the end of the account. Giltedge issues, although they have been sagging in the last few days, opened strong but they weakened again near the close of the session due to the uncertainties regarding the government's financial program. Foreign loans were quieter and some Brazilian issues eased slightly.

Anne Mary Bentley, young American pianist, gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. She played Bach's Partita in B flat, two works by Rameau, Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 27, No. 1; a group of works by Chopin and another by Paderewski, Stojowski and Liszt.

The net income of the United States Steel Corporation for 1936, after all deductions for reserves, taxes and charges, amounted to $50.525,684, the largest since 1930, and equal, after annual dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $2.91 each on 8,703,252 common shares, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday. For 1935, net income was $1,146,708, equal to 32 cents each on 3,602,811 preferred shares.

Paul Waner of the Pittsburgh Pirates and J. T. Rogerson of Miami Springs, finalists in last year's tourney which was won by the baseball star, won their first-round matches in the annual Winter lefthanders' golf championship at the Miami Biltmore Country Club today. Waner trounced, Walter E.
Three four-story tenement houses with stores, at 920-922 Second Avenue and 302 East Forty-ninth Street, were among the properties figuring yesterday in auction sales in Manhattan.

Connie Mack's Athletics and the Senators will open the American League baseball season at Washington Monday, April 19, a day in advance of the regular opening date, President Will Harridge announced today.
Johnstown, almost destroyed twice in the past fifty years by major floods, is remembering and digging down in well-worn pockets to do its bit for cities now feeling the brunt of rampaging streams.

Frightened thousands fled up-State today as the Ohio River's flood crest billowed along the Southern Indiana boundary. Trains, buses and trucks, filled to capacity, rolled northward carrying those who deserted their homes as the steadily rising stream turned the Ohio Valley into a watery waste, and, according to Governor M. Clifford Townsend, the evacuation on a major scale "has only started."
James Frank has been elected president of the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, after thirty-nine years of association with the institution, it was announced yesterday.

While use of fiber glass for industrial purposes has developed rapidly, progress in adopting the product to the wearing-apparel field has been much slower, D. C. Simpson, head of product analysis of the industrial and structural products division of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, yesterday told members of the Textile Square to Club at a luncheon at the Arkwright Club. Some of the industrial uses were for filter cloths and insulating purposes, he said.

The Municipal Club of Brooklyn, of which William Stanley Miller is president, held its annual dinner dance last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. James J. Reynolds was chairman of the dinner committee, assisted by Tremper Longman, the Rev. Cornelius Greenway, Howard B. Tompkins and Don L. Stevens.

The expectation that the upward movement of average security prices during the last two years would be interrupted in 1937 was voiced last night before an audience of 500 members and dinner guests of the American Statistical Association.

The State administration proposed today a $5,000,000 appropriation for flood control, the money to be spent to cover land damages involved in the construction of flood-prevention dams and reservoirs, surveys and land purchases.

The old and the new in basketball will be on display at Madison Square Garden tonight when a reproduction of the sport's first game of 1892 will be staged between contests of a double-header. Springfield and St. Francis will be in one encounter and Long Island University and Tennessee's Southeastern Conference champions in the other.

While her brother, unaware of her presence in New York, was in another room at the same hotel Miss Marjorie E. Miller, 42 years old, daughter of a Pittsfield, Mass., newspaper publisher, fell or jumped eleven floors to her death there yesterday, according to the police.

The proposal by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to except from salary increases those city employes who failed to receive a meritorious service rating for a year had the unanimous support of the commission, James E. Finegan, president of the commission, asserted yesterday in denial of a report that all three members had not approved it.

The trailer home has assumed sufficient importance to be considered among the major factors in the mass marketing problems of American lumbermen, Vernon M. Hawkins, president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermens Association, warned delegates attending the organization's three-day convention which opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A novelty, a symphony by Tibor Serly, formerly a viola player in the organization which performed his work, was introduced to a New York audience by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Serly was born in 1901 of Hungarian parents in Losonc, which is now a part of Czechoslovakia.

The AustroGerman negotiations for a new trade agreement, which began in December, ended today. A final communique with protocols will probably be published tomorrow. The outcome of the negotiations is described in official circles here as satisfactory but relatively limited,

Obtaining subscriptions for $51,000 of World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, the photographic divisions of the Fair's Bond Sale Committee yesterday became the second of the sixty-two divisions engaged in the distribution of the $27,829,500 issue to exceed its quota. Its quota was $50,000.

While reports from the regions inundated by the Ohio liver floods indicated substantial losses in property damage and suspension of traffic, preliminary railway reports for 1936 issued yesterday reflected substantial gains.

Following a two-day trial, I. Nicholas Gordon, the attorney who successfully defended former Magistrate George F. Ewald against charges that he had purchased his post on the bench, was convicted yesterday by a jury before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson of impersonating an army Officer with intent to defraud.

Mrs. Ralph Tapscott of Third Street gave a tea today for a large company in honor of her house guest, Mrs. Abbott Hastings of Troy, N. Y. Mrs. Arthur Sherwood of Sixth Street gave a luncheon at the Cherry Valley Club for Mrs. Edward McKellar, Mrs. William Hutchinson, Mrs. Dudley Fuller, Miss Mary Slattery and Mrs. Sylvanus Ward.

The speed with which outside relief rushed to flooded Louisville's aid was indicated by the log at the Bowman Airport, open to big planes today for the first time since the waters of the Ohio swept over the city.

A resolution charging the courts with abusing their powers in appointing attorneys and urging the establishment of competent "administrative agencies chosen by civil service examinations" to perform such functions, was adopted last night at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the National Lawyears Guild.

The drive of Promoter Mike Jacobs to develop an outstanding contender for the world's middleweight title now held by Freddie Steele will be resumed tonight at the Hippodrome when Fred Apostoli, San Francisco's threat to the crown, battles Ken Overlin, Richmond, Va., contender, in a bout scheduled for ten rounds.

Rallying in the final period after the score had been tied three times, the Columbia College of Pharmacy basketball team vanquished the New College quintet, 32 to 30, at the Thompson Gymnasium on the Columbia University campus last night.

Several luncheon parties were given in connection with the fashion revue entitled "Abroad and At Home," held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the occupational therapy department of the Hospital for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled.
Formation of the new firm Harris, Blauner Ferry, with memberships in the New York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange, was announced yesterday. It will start business on Feb. 1.

Australia Day, commemorating the founding of the first British colony in Australia on Jan. 26, 1788, and the creation of the Commonwealth on the same day in 1901, was celebrated yesterday by business men and officials of the British Empire in the British Luncheon Club, 53 Broadway.
All German business and pleasure will be brought to a halt for three hours Saturday so that all the Reich's citizns may hear Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech reviewing his four years in power.

The credit situation of the United States, regarded by many experts as offering a foundation for dangerous inflation, was considered today by the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System, headed by M. S. Eccles, chairman, and the resuits were laid before the board for future consideration.
Applications for registration of brokers and dealers were announced by the Securities and Exchange Commission today. The period covered was from Jan. 1 to 15.

President Roosevelt criticized Alfred P. Sloan Jr. for refusing to participate in the strike conference called by Secretary Perkins. He conferred with several groups separately on proposed labor legislation.

The thirty-room home of Henry J. Whitehouse, retired New York broker, on Sarles Street, Bedford, was burned to the. ground early this morning. The house was unoccupied, as Mr. and Mrs. Whitehouse are in the West Indies. The damage was estimated at $100,000.
The American Smelting and Refining Company of New York City filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 365,988 shares of no-par-value common stock.
Canadian wheat in store on Jan. 22 showed a decrease of more than 3,000,000 bushels in the week and a decline of almost 143,600,000 in the year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, issued this statement today: "It is customary at this time of the year to distribute the proceeds of the corporation's employes' savings and investment plan, one class of which terminates each year. This is the class of 1931.
Fingerprinting of all service employes of hotels and apartment houses in the city is provided in a local ordinance introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen by Alderman John F. Lantry.

IT seems that Catcher Moe Berg of the Fenway Millionaires had been inviting Al Schacht, late coach of the Fenway Millionaires, to go down to Princeton with him-next Friday. "It was always next Friday," explained Dr. Schacht, who is a famous dietitian, according to his own account. "Not this Friday-always next Friday.

Amherst defeated Yale, 30 to 26, in a hard-fought basketball game tonight. The baffling left-handed pivot tosses of Captain Jack Coey of Amherst played an important part in the triumph. Coey led the scoring for both teams with six field goals and a foul for 13 points.

The teams of De Witt Clinton and Boys High School were tied last night at eight points apiece after the second day's play in the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tournament on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory in Manhattan.

A call for a six-power conference by President Roosevelt would prevent war in Europe and the ultimate entrance of the United States, Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared here today at the opening of the National Conference on the Cause and Cure of War.
Representative Caroline O'Day of Rye, N. Y., asked Congress today to authorize coinage of 25,000 special 50-cent pieces to commemorate changing the name of Sawpit, N. Y., to Port Chester.

The New York County grand jury refused yesterday to indict Mrs. Agnes Olsen Johnson, 48 years old, a cook, of 221 East Seventy-sixth Street, for her receipt by mail of a package containing $25,000 of approximately $300,000 in gems stolen from the Washington home of Mrs. Frederick H. Bugher, widow of the former Police Commissioner in this city.
Mrs. Pauline Whitney, Miss Gail Whitney and William D. Sargent of New York were guests today of Mrs. William Dane of Marblehead, Mass., at the Bath Club, Miami Beach. Mrs. Joel Hurt Jr.,
Rumors of an impending reduction in the exchange value of the French franc were reinforced yesterday by weakness in that currency in the foreign exchange market.

Realty and tax problems will feature the discussions at the metropoltian district realty conference to be held today at the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the realty boards of New York and Westchester and several civic and taxpayers' organizations.

National Champion Harry F. Wolf of Montclair overwhelmed Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia Club to enter the semi-final round of the fifteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club tonight. The New York A. C. player won by 15-1, 15-6.

Pittsburgh's three rivers retreated toward their banks tonight. leaving heavy losses. Their third and mightiest surge in two weeks forced the high water level to 34.5 feet early this morning, a mark held for three hours, after which the waters fell back slowly as the muddy crest raced down the Ohio Valley. The stage went below 33 feet and was still dropping.

A part of Arkansas went under martial law today while this and adjoining States of the Lower Mississippi Valley assembled an army of workers to prepare for a predicted record flood. United States Army engineers called for emergency crews to heighten the banks of the big stream against torrents sweeping down from the Ohio and its tributaries.

The United States liner Manhattan sails today for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg. Among those sailing are Donna Fox, Clifford B. Gray, A. Dupree, James Bickford, James Short, W. G. Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Divine, Captain Frederick B. Thurber, S. E. Bramer, Thomas Adams Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Charles Morley, Mr. and Mrs. J. Leslie Harries, Mrs. Thomas Carter, Mrs. A. E. Carpenter, Dr. and Mrs. S. S. Samuels.

The Rev. W. H. Heckman of South Lancaster, Mass., was reelected yesterday afternoon president of the quadrennial convention of the Atlantic Union Conference of Seventh Day Adventists, which opened Monday night in City Temple, 562 West 150th Street, and will continue through Feb. 4.

BEATMAN, AUGUSTUS SAMUEL (Jan. 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Clara Beatman, widow, executrix, 527 W. 121st St., 40 per cent residue in trust; Evelyn M. Yeomans. stepdaughter. 14 per cent St. residue in trust; Philip Beatman, 8 per cent residue in trust; John Beatman, 9 per cent residue in trust,

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Fidelity Fund, Inc., and also at the meeting of the board of directors, Albert L. Sylvester was elected as president of the company and also a director. Richard P. Cromwell, formerly treasurer, was elected as a vice president and a director; Hugh Cabot Jr. was made a vice president and a director; Ralph B. Williams, formerly assistant treasurer, was elected a director and treasurer.

Supplies of hogs were larger and sentiment generally bearish today, influenced to some extent by flood conditions in the Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys and reports of a less active demand for fresh pork. Prices declined 10 to 15 cents, with some sales which appeared to be 25 cents under the extreme of the previous day.

Assets of the Home Insurance Company of New York rose in 1936 to $139,759,200, showing a gain of $26,552,338 over the year before and setting a new record, according to a statement made public yesterday by President Wilfred Kurth. The previous record was $128,914,080 at the end of 1929.

DALY, CATHERINE (Oct. 16, 1936). Gross assets, $1,008; net, $354. To Patrick Mullarkey, brother, one-third residue; Eugene Burke, nephew, one-third residue; two nephews share one-third residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $659. George B. Fargis, attorney, 11 Park PI.

Emphasizing a realistic program of instruction and research in publie administration which will require the cooperation of outstanding Federal, State and municipal officials, a special commission made public today its recommendations for the organization of a new graduate school of public administration at Harvard University. Lucius N. Littauer of New York City has given $2,000,000 for the project.
The compositions of Norman Cazden and Frederick Woltman will be featured tonight at the Composers Forum-Laboratory at the WPA Theatre of Music.
Bright sunshine and cool, crisp weather brought hope to Southern Ohio flood refugees today in the face of scant water Supplies and a staggering rehabilitation task.

George A. Sloan, for many years prominent in the textile industry, was elected yesterday a director of the United States Steel Corporation for the term expiring in April, 1937. Born in Nashville, Tenn., on May 30, 1893, Mr. Sloan was graduated from Vanderbilt University in 1916.

Dr. Jonah B. Wise, rabbi of the Central Synagogue and co-chairman of the Jewish Joint Distribution Committee campaign, issued a special plea yesterday to "all men and women who are interested in human rights and saving human life" to contribute to the immediate assistance of the Jews in Poland in response to their "frantic requests for aid."

An expression of the sympathy and concern felt in France for victims of the flood disasters in the United States was made by Edouard Herriot, President of-the Chamber of Deputies, at its opening session this afternoon. He asked the Chamber to authorize the sending of a telegram of sympathy to the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than in the preceding week, the total was substantially ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week arrivals were 1,208, as against 1,722 in the previous week and 940 in the same period last year.

The Real Estate Board of New York announced yesterday that it had reached an amicable understanding with the Consolidated Edison Company whereby the company had "agreed to cease their attempt to eliminate submetering and had granted partial rate and other concessions."

Testlmony that a labor "spy" was emplayed at the Duquesne plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation until exposure of the "system" by the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage made "trouble" was given today to the National Labor Relations Board.

The Berkshire sextet, playing at Fawn Lake- in Sheffield, today routed South Kent, 6 to 1, to score its second successive victory. Sutphen, center, tallied three times, while Captain Faxon, with one goal,

As the opening feature of its annual three-day meeting, the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences will send up a radio meteorograph-a small automatic transmitter sending signals of altitude, temperature and humidity-attached to a little balloon, from the Pupin Laboratory, Columbia University, at 11 o'clock this morning.

After a stipulation had been signed between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Aaron S. Saphier and Lester S. Saphier of L. S. Saphier Co., Federal Judge Julian W. Mack signed yesterday a consent order discontinuing the injunction suit of the SEC, seeking to restrain the Saphiers from alleged improper transactions in General Bronze Corporation and Park Tilford stock.

" Victoria Regina" will be closing its run on the evening of Saturday, May 1, according to Helen Hayes, who definitely would know. She said yesterday that she would sail for England immediately after the final performance; she wants to see the coronation of another Queen.

Hunter College will hold mid-year commencement exercises for 471 graduates, today, at 10:30 A. M., in Carnegie Hall, Fifty seventh Street and Seventh Avenue. Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, will deliver the principal address.
Dr. Victor B. Hall died during his sleep at his home here last night. He was 94 years old. His second wife, the former Marie Yeager, and a daughter survive.

Five awards have been made at the annual members' exhibition of painting and sculpture at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, which began on Jan. 6 and will end on Friday. A prize of $100 was given to Ernest L. Blumenschein for the painting "Jury Trial of a Sheepherder for Murder."

Business men of the world are prepared to follow the Roosevelt-Hull foreign trade policy looking to the reduction of "unreasonably" high tariff barriers, the Ways and Means Committee was told today by Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, appearing on behalf of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, retired, executive director of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday that the contributions to the flood relief fund to date totaled $121,728.38. Gifts received yesterday included the following:
