Shares of the Consolidated Investment Trust had a net asset value of $60.50 on Dec. 31, last, according to the annual report, issued yesterday. Assuming exercise of 425,276 options to purchase a like numbers of shares on that date, assets were $41.94 to the share. Corresponding net asset values on Dec. 31, 1935, were $43.02 and $34.82.

So slowly as to be imperceptible to any but army engineers with their delicate instruments, the Ohio River began to fall today at Cincinnati, and this city of the unwashed, the unshaven and the idle gloated over its first real sunshine in a week while praying that the flood waters would not rise again.
Cincinnati officially appealed to President Roosevelt today for government aid in removing the menace of floods such as already have caused damage of millions of dollars in the Ohio River Valley.

President Roosevelt and Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, have found that it cannot be decided whether a basis exists for negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and the United Kingdom before experts have spent considerable time studying technical trade questions.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler issued after the Cabinet meeting today a decree uniting with the city of Hamburg the adjoining Prussian towns, Altona and HamburgWilhelmsburg, which are in fact parts of greater Hamburg.

Dr. Leo L. rockwell of Colgate University declared today the whole world eventually would speak English if spelling were reformed and a simplified vocabulary adopted. In a speech prepared for delivery before the Exchange Club, the director of the School of Languages asserted that an "adequate" simpllified vocabulary, consisting of about 800 words, already has been developed.

Ellsworth Vines, gangling Californian, who holds the world professional tennis championship, defeated Fred Perry, English star, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, tonight to take the lead for the first time in their cross-country tennis tour. Playing in the smoke-filled Blues' Armory before a crowd of 3,000, including GovernorGeorge C. Peery of Virginia, Vines made it three matches in a row over the graceful Briton.

Joining the company of New York seamen, who arrived here today and were at once put to work bringing relief supplies across the river from Jeffersonville, Ind., the writer was taken aboard a cutter manned by ten men, with Anthony Gallo of Paterson, N. J., as coxswain.

After backing away from the 12 1/2 cent level for March contracts on every advance in the last month, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose abruptly into new high ground for the season yesterday and at one time showed gains of a dollar a bale. A quantity of scale selling orders was executed on the rise, which carried May above 12 1/2 cents a pound.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations now has before it, and may begin today to consider, Mr. PITTMAN'S newest "neutrality" plan. It proposes several changes in existing law. Under the present act the President is required to place an embargo on "arms, ammunition and implements of war" whenever he finds that a state of war exists "between, or among, two or more foreign States."

Mayor La Guardia endorsed yesterday the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association's 1937 campaign to raise $150,000 to support its free nursing program. The endorsement was contained in a telegram sent by the Mayor to the association's headquarters, 138 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

Senator Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, in his maiden speech attacked today the sale of Canadian bonds in the United States as a violation of the Johnson act, which forbids loans to nations which have defaulted on debts due the United States.

Compensation of the principal executives of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company for the year ended Sept. 30, 1936, was disclosed yesterday in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange. S.

Any doubt that the overwhelming majority of the 43,000 General Motors employes here want to work and are opposed to the strike which has thrown 38,000 of them off the payroll since Jan. 1, was dispelled this afternoon on the eve of the reopening of the Chevrolet plant tomorrow morning.
Switzerland was shocked today by news of the killing of Eugene Bourquin, leader of the Nationalist Youth, at Lachaux de Fonds during street fighting last night between Marxists and Fascists.

Alfred Dobree, Asiatic expert, died today at his home in Le Fainel, Guernsey, at the age of 72. For many years Mr. Dobree was one of the government's muintions authorities. His hobby was swords and the best of his collection is now at Victoria and Albert Museum.

Coroner James J. Corrigan declared today that Marie Hucul, night club dancer, and Frank Kroupa, her fiance, were the victims of slayers the night of Jan. 1 and did not die of carbon monoxide poisoning meal alone, as had been believed at first. They were found dead in Kroupa's car in Guilford at daybreak Jan. 2.

Harold Isenberg, cotton goods dealer, of 175 Fifth Avenue, described yesterday how his mother, Mrs. Adeline Isenberg, nearly 85 years old, was taken from her home at 820 South Second Street, l Louisville, to a haven in the higher part of town to the east and southeast.

United States Senator-elect William H. Smathers of this resort said today that Atlantic City should become exclusive and follow the lead of Miami in charging the public a nominal fee for some of the privileges now granted for nothing.

Fears that the business losses due to the floods in the Ohio Valley will exceed those of last year were expressed yesterday by credit executives here. They urged manufacturers to seek confirmations from retailers on the orders they have placed and recommended that credit policies be based chiefly on

For his comeback after suffering another attack of spinal meningitis, Bruce Campbell, outfielder of the Indians, was given the "most courageous" athlete award at the thirty-third annual dinner of the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association at the Benjamin Franklin Hotel tonight.

There is every indication that the influenza outbreak is at its end, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday. The daily report for the twenty-four hours ended at 10 A. M. showed only twenty-five new cases and three deaths, the lowest number since Dec. 26, when the outbreak started.

George Herbert Bostwick, penthouse in the New Weston, 49th St and Madison Av.; Mrs. Joseph Higgens, penthouse in 430 E. 57th St.; Mrs. Juliette Donnett, in the Carlyle, 35 E. 76th St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker.

Representative Frank W. Boykin, Democrat, of Alabama, proposes that the government put a 5 per cent tax on all money bet on horse races. He estimates that his bill, which would station internal revenue agents in betting rooms at every track in the country, would bring in $20,000,000 annually.

Pope Pius fully maintained today the improvement in his condition that set in just before last week-end. He spent what was described as the best night since he was taken ill and was so well this morning that his doctor cut short his usual visit, remaining in the Pontiff's bedroom only half an hour.
Hank Barber, Cambridge, Mass., defeated Joe Dusek of Omaha in 27:31 of their finish wrestling match before a crowd of about 1,000 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Metropolitan Realty Conference, Hotel Commodore, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Roy M. Hart, George L. Allin, Charles Partridge, Robert L. Hoguet, William Church Osborn, Luncheon, 12:30 P. M. Afternoon session, 2:30 o'clock.

J. Lewis Luckenbach was reelected president of the American Bureau of Shipping at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the bureau offices, 24 Old Slip. Joseph W. Powell, president of the United Drydocks Corporation and of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, was elected an honGrary vice president.

The Inland Steel Company and subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit in 1936 of $12,888,647 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday.

The sixweek strike of the Federation of Flat Glass workers against the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, affecting 7,100 employes in four cities, ended today when the company granted a blanket wage increase of eight cents an hour.

The Central Savings Bank sold to Bengar Estates, Inc., representing Garfield Benach, the five-story apartment house at 1,048 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx. There are fifty rooms in the house, which occupies a plot 40 by 100 feet and is assessed at $33,000. Nehring Brothers, brokers in the sale, will manage the property.

Gertrude Ederle, who set the world talking a decade ago when she swam the English Channel, the first woman to accomplish the feat, but who is now a semi-invalid, is suing the owners of a Hempstead apartment house for $50,000 on the ground a fall suffered there three years ago is responsible for her disability.

Samuel Solow, nonagenarian American, who ten years ago left the United States to become a pioneer in Palestine, today shared the joy of some of the younger pioneers, students of the Hebrew University, at the dedication of the first univer sity students' club in Palestine. Completion of the two-story structure was made possible by Mr. Solow's generosity.

The Cuban Cabinet voted today to propose President Roosevelt as a candidate for the 1937 Nobel Peace Prize because of his efforts for peace last year at the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace in Buenos Aires Argentina.

Britain's gigantic program of air rearmament is only three months behind schedule and is gaining speed every day, Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for Coordination of Defense, told the House of Commons this afternoon.

Mrs. Sherwood Hubbell of Rockaway Road entertained today with a tea at her home in honor of Mrs. Abbott Hastings of Troy, N. Y. Mrs. Hubbell's guests included: Mrs. Wallis Howe, Mrs. Rutherford Platt, Mrs. Frederick Olmstead, Mrs. E. M. Townsend Jr.,

Housing properties in the Washington Heights and Harlem sections proved attractive to buyers, according to deals announced yesterday. The six-story apartment house on a plot 98 by 134 feet at 250 Fort Washington Avenue, northeast corner of 170th Street,
Al Smith, New York Giants' southpaw, underwent a tonsilectomy today in an effort to build up his health for the coming baseball season.

Harold Schaen's field goal with less than two minutes to go enabled the Brooklyn College basketball team to come from behind and defeat Lowell Textile, 29-28, last night in the Union Temple gymnasium.

A girl and a boy who have risen above adversity and lack of means to excellence in both character and their studies, were honored yesterday afternoon at the graduation exercises of the Inwood School, Junior High School 52, Broadway and Academy Street, which were held in the auditorium of P. S. 98, Broadway and 212th Street.
Finding the basket with greater accuracy than in any previous game this season, the Naval Academy five won from Virginia Poly, 45 to 17, today.

Harold Wilson Hoffman, secretary of the Mamaroneck building supply firm of Adams, Fowler Hoffman, died last night of a heart attack at his home in the Pelham Manor Garden Apartments. He was 51 years old.
This weary city turned eagerly to the tasks of rehabilitation tonight, hopeful that its trial by flood and fire was ending but warily on guard aginst an aftermath of disease.

The membership of the Boy Scouts of America was 1,069,165 Scouts, cubs and leaders at the close of 1936, a record for the organization's twenty-seven years, it was announced last night by Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive, at a meeting of the national executive board in the Hotel Biltmore.

Julius H. Thomas, owner of the Norwood Bowling and Billiard Academy, 35-15 Thirtieth Avenue, Astoria, died yesterday at his home, Fat 45-07 Broadway, Astoria, after a two day illness at the age of 54.
Following is the statement of Alfred P. Sloan Jr. to General Motors' employes, which was posted on plant bulletin boards yesterday: To All Employes of General Mo-tors Corporation:

While officials, including President Roosevelt, worked on flood relief plans at the White House today, many having been without sleep other than for brief periods for four days, a reminder of the public's problem was put on a table in the lobby of the Executive Offices.

The marriage of Miss Grace Holden, daughter of Mrs. Edward Raymond Holden of 2 East Eightysixth Street, to John Whitney, son, of Mrs. Arthur Noyes Whitney of 840 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Whitney, took place yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle.

The Gulf Oil Corporation today will advance the price of bunker C fuel oil 5 cents a barrel at Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports. The Tide Water Associated Oil Company has announced that it will meet the advance.

The murder of the Russian economist Dimitri Navashine here Sunday has been linked with the case of the White Russian General Alexander Paul Koutiepoff, who mysteriously disappeared in Paris seven years ago.

Foreshadowing early court action to remove the sit-down strikers from two Fisher Body plants in Flint, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, asserted today that the majority of General Motors employes were being "deprived of the right to work by a small minority who have seized certain plants and are holding them as ransom to enforce their demands."

The Yale freshman hockey team topped the Hotchkiss School sextet in a closely fought battle today, 5-4. George Seabury broke a 4--4 tie in the middle of the second period, scoring unassisted. Seabury led the Elis' attack with two goals and two assists, while George Young and Scotty McLennan both scored twice for the losers.

It is doubtless a significant fact that President ROOSEVELT has abandoned the idea of a joint "power pool " in the Tennessee Valley. But the "power pool" itself was never a plan which promised to settle the real controversy between the utilities and the advocates of Government operation.

With Pete Hiaman scoring six goals, the New Rochelle High School hockey team routed the Dobbs Ferry combination, 11 to 0, tonight in the Playland Ice Casino here. It was the second victory for New Rochelle in as many starts in the Westchester Interscholastic Hockey League. Hiaman tallied all three times in the second period.

A three to five year term in State's prison, believed to be the heaviest penalty ever inflicted by a Connecticut court upon a drunken motorist for causing loss of life, was assessed against Michael S. Durica, 35-yearold butcher, by Judge John Richards Booth today.

The opening session of the second annual Atlantic National Bridge championships, conducted under the auspices of the United States Bridge Association, was held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Edison with five teams competing in the qualifying round of the teamof-four championships for the Douglas W. Paige trophy.

ABRAHAMS, MARK (Dec. 13). Estate, less than $1,000. To Jane Bachman, daughter, 41 W. 72d St., executrix, residue.. ADAMS, PHILIP B. (Jan. 10). Estate, about $10,000. To Elsie H. Adams, widow, executrix 95 Christopher St., about $8,000.

After receiving a report from Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, acting chief medical examiner, that Joseph Sterzini, 52 years old, a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company chorus, had died from a heart condition, the District Attorney's office yesterday completely exonerated Lawrence Tibbett.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave a luncheon today for more than forty guests, including Mrs. John N. Garner, Lady Lindsay, Mrs. Ertegun, Mrs. De Alfaro, Mrs. Peter, Mrs. MacWhite, Lady Marler, Mrs. Claude A. Swanson, Mrs. Elmer Thomas and Mrs. Warren Austin.

The opening of permanent headquarters of the American Labor party at 151 West Fortieth Street yesterday gave rise to reports that the organization would place a full slate in the field for the city election in November, including candidates for Mayor and places on the Board of Aldermen and City Council as constituted under the new charter.

Seventeen registration statements involving $234,846,658, including $222,143,024 in new issues, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Fifteen issues of the commercial and industrial type amounting to $131,143,024 headed the list.

Liquidation developed in the grain markets today, partly as an aftermath of the statement made yesterday by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace in which he indicated increased production on a number of major commodities would be acceptable this year. The statement was regarded as bearish by traders in Liverpool and wheat futures there declined 2 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 12 per cent for the week ended Jan. 23 over the corresponding week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise compares with a gain of 15 per cent for the preceding week. For the four weeks ended on Jan. 23 the increase was 11 per cent, unchanged from the previous four weeks' period.

What the police described as a dispute over the custody of three children resulted last night and early this morning in the shooting of four persons at South Floral Park and New Hyde Park, L. I. All of the victims, a man, his wife and two detectives, were taken to Nassau Hospital at Mineola, where the condition of all of them, save one of the policemen, was described as serious.
A purse containing $12 was returned today to a Riverside (Calif.) woman who lost it on a shopping trip here twenty years ago.

The recent peace conference demonstrated that America's destiny is to give to the world an example of an entire continent bound together for the preservation of peace, in the opinion of Dr. L. S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, who returned on the Grace liner Santa Barbara yesterday.

Former Secretary Newton D. Baker asserted in Western District Federal Court here today that the government's plea to force the Appalachian Electric Power Company to obtain a Federal license for its $12,000,000 hydro-electric project on New River at Radford was "an ambitious scheme to become ultimately the creator and dispenser of water power in this State."
Mrs. Lourie Cochran Wilhelm, a prominent member of the Baha'i faith in this country, died here early Tuesday morning at her residence, 1,274 Alicia Avenue, in her eighty-seventh year.
Federal indictments charging conSpiracy and mail fraud were returned today against Mrs. Violet Wells Norton who asserts that her daughter is the child of Clark Gable.
The following telegram was sent to Admiral Cary T. Grayson, head of the American Red Cross, at Washington, today, by Joseph A. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club:

Argentina had a favorable balance of trade last year amounting to 535,737,647 pesos, or approximately $178,650,000 at the official rate of exchange, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. Total imports for the year amounted to 1,116,710,994 pesos, or $372,250,000, while the value of exports was 1,652,448,641 pesos, or $550,900,000.
Governor Lehman and the Legislature took prompt action today to place New York State in a position to respond quickly to any call for aid which may come from flood-ravaged sister States in the West.

Jack Weitz and Max Fishman of the Castle Hill A. C. accounted for an upset victory in the first round of the New York State four-wall doubles handball championship last night at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. by defeating the former national champions, Leo Manka and Henry Herz of the Bedford Y. M. C. A., 21-15, 6-21, 21-16.

The managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday granted licenses to store raw sugar for delivery against the No. 4, or world, sugar contract to two warehouses at Cardenas, Cuba. Previously, a warehouse at Matanzas, Cuba, had been licensed.

The Greek Government has made overtures for the conclusion of an accord with Bulgaria, it is learned here from a most reliable source. This decision evidently is the outcome of the conclusion of the Yugoslav-Bulgarian pact, which has caused a certain uneasiness in Greek political circles.

On their own application: SERGEANT--John Burberg, 120th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed May 17, 1902. PATROLMEN--Thomas Berry, 19th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 23, 1911. Leo Gisselbrecht, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 18, 1906.
Ephraim Keyser, sculptor, for years teacher in modeling at the Maryland Institute School of Art and Design, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 86.

AMERICAN HURLY-BURLY, by Ernest Sutherland Bates and Alan Williams. (McBride, $2.50.) High spots of 1936, reported and commented upon. OUR INEFFECTIVE STATE, by William H. Hessler. (Holt, $2.50.) America's problems of government.

Ludlow St., 41-43, 25x87.6; Sam Cohen and wife to Adele Cohen, 540 W. 180th St. 11th St.. 646 E.. 25x94.9; Dina Yanishevltz to Anna Gellis. 1,437 52d St., Brooklyn; mtg., $8,000 ($1). 11th St., 613 E.. 25x103.3; Hyman Schiff et al. to Joseph Rabinowitz, 1,839 Park Pl.. Brooklyn. Greenwich Av., 98. 20.10x76.4; Goldie Safian to Abraham Lewis et al., 565 1st Av. ($1).

The number of dead in the most devastating flood ever to strike this nation reached the hundreds yesterday and the army, bolstering the levee defenses of the Mississippi, prepared-should the worst cometo evacuate the endangered in its path.

Louis Frederick Berneker, nationally known artist, died today at his home. He was 65 years old. Mr. Berneker, whose home was in New York, had been spending his Summers here for twenty years and became a permanent resident last year.

Hogs met with a slow demand here today and closed 15 to 20 cents a hundredweight lower after a few early sales at steady prices. The extreme top of $10.30 was paid sparingly and at the last the practical top was $10.10, with many smaller packers refusing to go over $10.05, while the large packers bid $10 for the best.

Mrs. Louise P. Benjamin of the Ladies Home Journal, Sarah Pennoyer, publicity director of Bonwit Teller, and Elizabeth Hawes have been elected vice presidents of the, fashion group. Martin M. Stuart, manager of the glycerine sales department of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, has been appointed manager of the industrial sales department in addition to his present office, to succeed Arthur F. Danz, who has joined Kirkman Son as vice president and general manager.

Captain Richard J. Meehan, Engine 37. Charge 1: Violation of Section 72, R. R., 1926 (allowing department apparatus - to be driven in a reckless manner causing a collision). Not guilty. Complaint dismissed. Charge 2: Violation of Special. Order 66, Part III, dated April 16, 1936 (allowing department apparatus to be driven through a one-way street against traffic). Not guilty. Complaint dismissed.

Floods have reduced production of steel sharply in the Ohio River Valley, but elsewhere neither high water nor automobile strikes have affected the industry appreciably, The Iron Age finds. The industry is working at top speed on heavy backlogs, plus new orders that for many companies exceed those for any month last year, excepting December, according to a summary released yesterday.

The Cabinet announced today that it would not approve amnesty for students serving sentences for terrorism. Students were warned that the liberation of any depended on the reestablishment of normal conditions in educational institutions which have been closed.

The Noticia, a Managua newspaper, announced today that the Correo, a Granada newspaper, had been suppressed by the authorities because Carlos A. Baumbach, the Mexican Charge d'Affaires, had protested to the government against the paper's continuous attacks on Mexican policy.
Stocks rallied and closed higher with steel shares strongest; turnover, 1,936,736 shares. United States Government issues higher, corporate and foreign bonds irregular; transactions, $13,767,300.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrives today from Channel ports. On board are the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, the Duchess of Marlborough, Mrs. John T. Morgan, S. Pinckney Tuck, Colonel Wylie G. Borum, Sir Michael Duff Assheton Smith, Sir Westrow Hulse, W. Langton Cavers, N. ??. Graham Donaldson, J.

northwestern tip of the United States, has given 100 per cent to the Red Cross flood relief fund. Fred Myers, meteorologist of Tatoosh, in a message today said that the island's eight families of lighthouse, Weather Bureau and naval radio men have given $3 each.

The Senate confirmed today the appointments of Roswell Magill of New York as Under-Secretary of the Treasury and Justin Miller of North Carolina as a member of the Board of Tax Appeals. Other appointments also were approved.

Mayor La Guardia appointed two active Republicans to city judicial posts yesterday. He promoted Magistrate Thomas F. Doyle, Queens Republican, to the Special Sessions vacancy caused by the death of Justice Thomas J. Nolan, and named Nicholas H. Pinto, Brooklyn Republican, to the vacancy on the magistrates' bench caused by Magistrate Doyle's promotion.
The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, continuing its investigation of the listing practices of the New York Stock Exchange in so far as they involve the securities of holding companies,

A large gathering of representatives of teachers and parents appeared -yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education to protest overcrowding in the schools and to demand employment of more teachers, but changed their demeanor and applauded vigorously when the board approved some 700 new appointments.

Terror dogged the steps of weary men here tonight in their back-breaking fight against a mighty river which has vanquished other men's efforts to control it in its rain-swollen rush down the Ohio Valley to the Mississippi.

Atlantic City defeated the Hershey Bears, 3 to 1, in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight. Cairns was the first to score, taking a pass from behind the goal from McKinnon at 6:20. Levia registered at 15:02 when Goalie Damore fell. Herbie Foster counted in the second session and Blinco scored for Hershey in the third.
The Pope passed another very good night last night, fully maintaining the improvement that set in late last week.

The Commissioners of Agriculture of the thirteen principal cotton-growing States, at a conference in Memphis, Tenn., unanimously adopted late on Tuesday night a resolution calling on the legislative and executive branches of the Federal Government to consider means for the expansion of farm markets, particularly cotton, according to a copy of the resolutions forwarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In connection with the introduction for general sale of the Dr. J. Howard Crum complexion stone, a campaign in the rotogravure sections of newspapers is being planned, beginning early in February. The Frank Presbrey Company is the agency, with Louis H. Frohman serving as account executive. The stones, which have been in use privately for four years, are being made by the Supreme Beauty Laboratories.

Sealed cabin substratosphere planes for commercial flying at ceilings of-30,000 feet can now be successfully constructed and will be ready for regular transport flight in about eighteen months, it was t revealed yesterday before the fifth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University.

All restrictions on working hours and loom operations by members of the Indian Jute Mills Association will be removed on March 1, permitting unlimited burlap production, according to cable advices received here yesterday. The association released all members yesterday, in admission of the breakdown of efforts made for the last year to establish maximum working hours.

More than 300 persons attended tonight's gala supper dance opening the season for the Colony Club. Mrs. James P. Donahue brought one of the largest parties, entertaining first with dinner at Cielito Lindo.
Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today allowed $57,500 in additional and "final" fees and $3,454 expenses in connection with the reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company.

The mystery of why two labor spies for the Chrysler Motors Corporation spent $1,152.71 in a month to entertain a "smart" young employee, "whose attitude puzzled the plant manager," occupied the attention today of the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage.

Mayor La Guardia and Deputy Controller John Dwight Sullivan, the representative of Controller' Frank J. Taylor, engaged in a heated argument yesterday at a meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission at City Hall over the desirability of the removal of Emergency Relief Bureau offices from the Harlem Y. W. C. A. building, 74 West 125th Street,

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, feminist leader, declared here tonight that the primitive institution of war could be undermined only by the rising of another great institution-that of the advocates of peace, banded together with clear aims and policies.

The extension of electric power service to the rural areas of the nation, a proposal which is favored by President Roosevelt, was dedared impractical and needless last night by John C. Parker, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.

The Mahoney estate, consisting of a ten-room residence and three acres on the Roslyn Greenvale Road, adjoining the Engineers golf course and opposite the Percy Pyne estate, Roslyn, L. I., was sold to Mrs. Francis Lenygon for occupancy.

A movement to enlist all Kentucky Colonels in aid of the flood sufferers was started yesterday when eight New Yorkers, all holding the honorary rank, each contributed $5 to aid Kentucky's flood refugees.

As a move to reduce collisions between horse-drawn vehicles and automobiles on the city bridges, F. J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, set aside yesterday a roadway for horses on the Williamsburg Bridge.

The last class gathering for many of the owners and skippers of the famed Interclub sloops of Long Island Sound was held in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, last night. They have purchased into the new International class of boats built in Norway, but gathered with the others for dinner and a review of the eleven years in Interclubs.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey made a furious attack yesterday upon one of his own witnesses in the restaurant racket trial who tried to change a previous statement that placed Paul N. Coulcher, labor leader defendant, in the home of Jules Martin, murdered racketeer.

Plans got under way yesterday for a large theatrical show at Madison Square Garden, to raise funds for flood sufferers, as the casts of at least two Broadway productions--"Idiot's Delight" and "White Horse Inn"-already had begun colelection of food and clothing to be sent to the Red Cross.
Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd told interviewers here there are 1,000,000 square miles of unexplored Antarctic territory rich in coal and oil.

Wireless messages from British ships reported today that a gale sweeping the North Sea had sunk two trawlers with a total loss of forty-six lives. The French trawler Lorette was said to have gone down with thirty men, while the Amethyst, a British vessel was lost with sixteen.

The New York Stock Exchange admitted yesterday the following issues to listing: Pacific Gas and Electric Company-First and refunding 3 1/2 per cent mortgage bonds due in 1966. Abbott Laboratories-Common stock, no par value.
Mr. Bones, John Hay Whitney's candidate for the Santa Anita Handicap next month, won the $1,500 Alhambra Handicap at Santa Anita today. His time for the six furlongs was 1:11 1-5.
The Rev. Dr. Robert Hetherington, a Methodist Episcopal minister for forty-five years, died in the Methodist Hospital here last night at the age of 71.

The "red cards" issued close to a year ago by the Fashion Originators Guild of America against thirteen member stores of the Associated Merchandising Corporation were withdrawn yesterday and business relations, suspended for this period, were resumed by the stores with the guild manufacturer members.

The Northern States Power Company today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to the company's utility declaration in connection with the issuance of $75,000,000 3 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds and 275,000 shares of $5 preferred stock, naming underwriters of the two issues.

Warning against forces of despotism in the world, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an address yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Pilgrims of the United States in the Bankers Club, appealed to the English-speaking peoples to preserve and protect the principles "upon which our historic democracies rest." Dr. Butler is president of the Pilgrims.

In view of the strike-situation in the motor industry and the floods in the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys, the sharp recovery in the shares market yesterday, following the rather drastic decline on Tuesday, was the subject of much comment after the cessation of trading.
Building projects filed yesterday included plans for a tenement in Manhattan and homes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. Details of the plans follow:

Smead Jolley, hard-hitting outfielder of the Albany Senators last year but now with Jersey City, carried off a major share of the individual batting honors in the International League during 1936, according to the official averages released yesterday.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Pasadena, Calif., of Samuel Ware Packard, formerly one of the leading lawyers of Chicago. Mr. Packard, who was 89 years old, had made his home in Pasadena since his retirement forty years ago.

Ken Overlin, Virginia's threat to the middleweight crown held by Freddy Steele, still is an eligible in the unofficial elimination tournament being conducted by Promoter Mike Jacobs because he profited by an unpopular decision in his tenround battle with Fred Apostoli of San Francisco in the Hippodrome last night.

The marriage of Mrs. Mabel Baylis Eldridge of 105 East Fifty-third Street, widow of Chauncey Eldridge and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Baylis of Baltimore, to William Crane Ivison of this city took place yesterday noon in the Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the church.

Miss Ada Elizabeth Watkins, daughter of Mrs. Robert Henry Thompson of Glen Ridge, was married this evening to William Bell Hatch Jr. of Twenty-Nine Palms, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Hatch of Pasadena. The ceremony was performed in the Golden Ridge Congregational Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton.
The Duke of Norfolk, called "England's most eligible bachelor," married the Hon. Lavinia Strutt today while hundreds of women outside the chapel fought policemen in a wild melee.

A mortgage on the old Northwestern Hotel. south corner of West and Chambers St., held by the trustees of the will of Helen S. Kingsland from Caroline Truax, fee owner, was extended to Feb. 1, 1940, at 5 per cent. The lien is for $81,000. A mortgage on the east side of Park Av. from 56th to 57th St., a first lien for $450,000, was assigned by the Guaranty Trust Co. to the Equitable Life

The outlook for Canadian business, both domestic and export, favors continued improvement, provided peace is maintained, J. A. McLeod, president of the Bank of Nova Scotia, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Halifax.

St. Nicholas Av., 889, s w cor 155th St., 6-story apartment: Title Guarantee and Trust Co. against Otto Grimmer: due, $105,488; taxes, , $16,712; to plaintiff for $75,000. By HENRY BRADY 111th St.. 83-85 E.. 6-story tenement: Bowery Savings Bank against Libbie Sift; due, $34,964; taxes, , $3,000; to plaintiff for $27,000.
Mrs. Sidney Borg entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Cornelius Tiers, Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, Mrs. Oliver Harriman and Mrs. Frederick Hill Wood.

C. N. Mooney's 4-year-old gelding, Teddy Haslam, closed with a rush today and finished a half length in front of Gallienne to win the $600 Fort Worth purse, the feature race at Alamo Downs. Teddy Haslam sped over the sixfurlong route in 1:12.

I am poor Brother Lippo by your leave. You needn't clap your torches to my face. Fra Lippo Lippi. So, at sixteen years and nine months, but looking four or five years older, and adorned with real whiskers which the scandalised Mother abolished within

Prime Minister Mackenzie King has requested the Canadian Minister at Washington to convey to the Secretary of State an expression of the deep sympathy and concern with which the government and the people of Canada have learned of the devastating progress of the floods which are causing such great losses, hardships and suffering in many parts of the United States."

Interest in space downtown was a feature of commercial renting reported by brokers yesterday. Leases from other sections were also noted, among them that taken by the Jules Jurgenson Corporation of Bienne, Switzerland, in the International Building in Rockefeller Center through A. Sheldon Jaffe

Boxing circles were upset yesterday by a report from Joe Louis's training quarters in Pompton Lakes that the Brown Bomber had been dropped by Eddie Malcolm, one of his sparring partners, in a boxing drill.

Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor of Bermuda, helped to inaugurate the public activities of the Bermuda Caledonian Society formed last month, when he- spoke at the. first annual Burns dinner held at the Hamilton Hotel tonight.

The retirement of Clarence E. Bacon as manager of the New York Clearing House and the appointment of Edward L. Beck, formerly assistant manager, to succeed him, were announced yesterday by William S. Gray Jr., president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, who is chairman of the Clearing House committee.

Ellsworth Vines, the lanky Californian, toppled Fred Perry, British ace, tonight in their cross-country tennis marathon. Vines won the match, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4, after vanquishing the Briton last night at Richmond, Va. The victory put him two up on Perry in their series. Vines has won seven matches and Perry five.
Judge Harry Stackell in the Bronx County Court imposed heavy sentences yesterday on two men recently convicted of robbery in which a policeman, James Conway, was shot. Conway, despite his wound,

Peace Justice O. B. Sutton said tonight thirty persons, among them ten survivors, would testify at the inquest tomorrow into Monday's Tamiami Trail bus accident, in which seventeen passengers were drowned.

The Papal Nuncio, Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, is understood to have filed at the Foreign Office a formal Vatican protest against alleged infringements of the concordat between the Holy See and Germany. The issue is the regime's treatment of the confessional schools and Catholic youth organizations.

The proposed four-point improvement program to enable the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to carry its share of the 50,000,000 visitors expected for the. 1939 World's Fair was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack despite vigorous opposition from the Manhattan Railway Company, operators of the elevated lines leased from the I. R. T.

Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday that women "are much, much easier to work with in public affairs" than are men. Speaking at a luncheon given at the Hotel Bossert by the Downtown Brooklyn Association in honor of Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., recipient of the 1936 gold medal for distinguished service to the borough, the Mayor observed in low tones but with marked emphasis:

Observing dryly that he was beginning to think international conferences were only a means of doing nothing, Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King refused today to accept the resolution of A. A. Heaps, a Labor Member of Parliament, requesting the government of Canada to urge the United States to call a peace parley of all nations.
The first volume of a monumental work on armaments has just been added to the Oxford University Press Spring list. The title is "The Private Manufacture of Armaments."

Net assets a share of the National Bond and Share Corporation on Dec. 31 last were $62.19, against $53.51 on Dec. 31, 1935, and the $50 originally paid in on March 6, 1929, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Gayer G. Dominick, president.

President Roosevelt discussed the power question, the flood situation and governmental reorganization with Senator Norris at luncheon, and conferred with Secretary Wallace, Senators Wheeler and Bankhead, Representative Jones and others on an agricultural legislative program.

The names of attorneys who qualified as counselors in the October examination conducted by the State Board of Bar Examinators were announced today. There were 120 successful candidates and seventy-eight who failed to qualify.

Joseph E. Fox, a member of the vaudeville and minstrel team of Fox and Ward, who retired in 1927 after a partnership of nearly sixty years, died in St. Agnes's Hospital here Monday night after a brief illness. He was 84 years old. William H. Ward, his former partner, died three years ago.

Reports which have been circulating in London and New York for several days to the effect that a further lowering of the gold parity of the French franc will be necessary brought forth a reply today by Vincent Auriol, Minister of Finance, in the form of an interview which he gave to the Havas News Agency.

Adrian Van Sinderen was appointed yesterday a director of the New York Telephone Company. He is a member of the firm of W. A. A. M. White and is a director of the Brooklyn Trust Company and the Brooklyn Savings Bank.

" The Plough and the Stars," adapted by Dudley Nichols from the Sean Q'Casey drama and directed by John Ford, will open an engagement today at the Radio City Music Hall. Barbara Stanwyck and Preston Foster enact the principal roles, with a supporting cast that includes Una O'Connor, J. M. Kerrigan, Erin O'BrienMoore and such Abbey Theatre members as Barry Fitzgerald, Dennis O'Dea, Eileen Crowe, Arthur Shields and F. J. McCormick.

A. Henry Ross, 28 years old, a lawyer, of 2,069 Pacific Street, and Max D. Krone, 34; a former private detective of 255 Eastern Parkway, both in Brooklyn; were found guilty in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon on the extortion charge made by Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor.

A marked expansion in employment and payrolls and a maintenance of industrial production in a season when a decline is usual were indiated in the Federal Reserve Board's monthly review of business conditions, issued today.

The deadlock in General Kazushige Ugaki's efforts to form a Cabinet was still complete at noon today. It is clear that the opposition to General Ugaki is due to internal politics in the army and the part General Ugaki is alleged to have played in past troubles.

A hearing on the appointment of trustees for the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railway is to be held on Saturday before Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye in the Federal Court in Minneapolis. The company, which is a subsidiary of the Canadian Pacific Railway, filed under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Law on Jan. 2.

The American Federation of Lab6r offered its services yesterday in an effort to determine the authorized wage-bargaining agency of seamen in the Atlantic ports. The federation offered to conduct an inquiry, starting Feb. 8, and, if necessary, to hold elections, The Associated Press reported.

All chapters of the Red Cross in the metropolitan area intensified their drive for flood relief contributions yesterday as civic, political, patriotic and other organizations joined forces to alleviate suffering in the disaster zone.

The Board of Governors of the New York Curb Exchange has approved the following memberships for transfer: Cecil Schwartz to G. Donald Gallagher, care of Zoline Co. W. E. Tobias Jr. to G. P. Lynch of F. P. Ristine Co.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, told 474 graduates of Hunter College yesterday morning at the mid-year commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall that the horizon of opportunities for the college graduate was wider than it had been for eight years.

The State Commission for Tax Law Revision filed with the Legislature today a report terming real estate tax limitation "an unwise fiscal policy." The commission, of which former Senator Seabury C. Mastick is chairman, said that it had reached its conclusion after "careful examination" of the experiences of Ohio, Michigan and Indiana.

While the marines take their name from the sea, their achievements attach to the land or to the shore that is sometimes sea and sometimes land. Only a few weeks ago word came from Greece of the recovery of a shield supposed to have belonged to the Spartan General BRASIDAS, which fell between the two when he was landing at Pylos;

George Anton, 33 years old, of 139 Shepherd Avenue, Brooklyn, who installed a burglar-alarm system in the home of Miss Catherine Steyer, a hat-check girl, at 304 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, which resulted in the girl's accidental death, received a suspended sentence from Magistrate Wieboldt in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, yesterday. He had been charged with installing electrical wiring without the necessary permit.

Motorists are reminded by Deputy Commissioner I. James Brody of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles that they have only until noon on Saturday to obtain new license plates, which must be on all cars in operation after midnight Sunday.

Red-haired Miss Berg of Minneapolis defeated Miss Helen Detweiler of Washington, D. C., 3 and 1, in the quarter-finals of the annual Charlotte Harbor women's golf tournament today. Miss Berg, defending champion, overcame a one-hole lead held by Miss Detweiler, Maryland State titleholder, at the turn.

Donald C. Richberg, former administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Act, told members of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association today that business may expect continued, and perhaps increasing, intervention by the Federal Government in the problems of maintaining fair competition and harmonious labor relations.

Park Tilford, Inc., entered into an agreement with the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, the Chase National Bank, the Manufacturers Trust Comapny and David A. Schulte on Nov. 18, 1936, permitting the company to pay two quarterly dividends of 50 cents each on

All the domestic air lines of the country holding air mail contracts are asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to recommend drastic changes in the present air mail act governing the method of payment. Ten air mail contractors through the Air Transport Association of America have filed a brief.

The Millrose A. A. yesterday completed assembling a field of high jumpers who among them hold all the world's records. Dave Albritton of Ohio State and Ed Burke of Marquette were the latest to send in their entries for the annual track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

Mrs. Nelson B. Warden of Philadelphia, who bought the Penney estate. on Belle Isle, Miami Beach, will be among the score of young matrons and debutantes modeling lace gowns at the Helen Lee Doherty Milk Fund ball, which will take place at the Miami Biltmore Country Club, Coral Gables, on Feb. 20.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is paying agent for $14,000,000 Central Main Power Company 3 1/2 per cent Series "H" bonds. The fourth annual meeting of the stockholders of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York will be held today at 2 P. M. in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In the last seven years I have journeyed all over the world in my efforts to improve my game and study those of other tennis players. Those seven years have also afforded me an opportunity of studying the conditions in all countries, and the fact that I have been able to overcome those conditions has enabled me to win a few matches here and there.

The New York Curb Exchange has approved the application of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation to list 893,607 shares of common stock, $1 par value, in substitution for an equivalent number of shares of common stock, no par value, listed at present.

A verdict for $75,000 damages, which is believed to be a record for such cases in Brooklyn, was returned by a jury in the Supreme Court yesterday in behalf of the estate of Benjamin Lessig, a stevedore who fell against a third rail while unloading flour bags from a New York Central freight train, and was killed.

Andrew J. Kenny, a member of Borough President George U. Harvey's cabinet in various positions since 1929 and at present Queens Superintendent of Sewers, was awarded $4,380 back pension-money, with interest, by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in Queens yesterday. Justice Wenzel indicated, however, that the pension from now on could be stopped by action of the Police Commissioner.

Officials of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Combined Circus announced tonight that the Hagenbeck-Wallace Circus had been acquired by Edward Arlington, veteran circus man, and J. Frank Hatch of Miami Beach.

Ranger is to be the name of the new America's Cup defense yacht now being built at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Me., for Harold S. Vanderbilt. The selection was made by Mr. Vanderbilt a few days ago, and he announced it yesterday while in this city for a few hours on a fast trip up from Florida and back.

Mayor La Guardia offered the full facilities of the city for aid in the flood areas yesterday as scores of public and private organizations continued the greatest emergency relief mobilization since the World War.

Since nothing of primary importance is taking place on the Madrid front, attention is being concentrated on such problems as political orientation, the feeding of Madrid, espionage and the evacuation of the civil populace.

Young Jake Schaefer, San Francisco cue wizard, regained the lead in his world championship 28.2 balkline billiard battle with Willie Hoppe of New York today and increased it tonight by winning the fourth block of the 2,500-point match, 250 to 191.

That Bermuda will make several contributions to flood relief in the United States became evident today as a special local committee of the American Red Cross Society, headed by Mrs. Harry L. Less, daughter of Henry E. Butler of New York City, began island-wide colletions.

With the close yesterday of the annual Camellia show held by the Dand Hills Garden Club, social interest of Augustans and Winter guests is turning to the annual Junior League ball to be held the night of Feb. 5 at the Bon Air Hotel.

An offer to send a medical and nursing unit, fishermen and boats to the relief of floodstricken areas of the United States was made today by Premier Angus L. MacDonald in a message to Dr. Thomas G. Parran, United States Surgeon General.

Harry P. Bonties of Otter Rock Drive, Greenwich, Conn., a retired dry goods merchant, formerly president of Claflin's, Inc., died yesterday morning at his Winter home in Winter Park, Fla., according to word received here by a granddaughter, Mrs. C. Y. Morse of 404 East Fifty-fifth Street. He was born in Petersburg, Ill., seventyfour years ago.

Henry A. Theis, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, has been re-elected president of the Corporate Fiduciaries Association of New York City, it was announced yesterday. William C. Murphy,' vice president and trust officer of the Fifth Avenue Bank;

After prolonged debate in the Senate today concerning the efforts of power Companies in the South to restrain the activities of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and the court conflicts which have arisen, Senator McKellar introduced a bill to prohibit inferior Federal courts from enjoining the administration of any federal statute until the Supreme Court had held it invalid.

The New York A. C. continued to maintain its slight lead over the Columbia University Club in the Class A division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night as both teams again won conclusive victories.

The Duke of Windsor came to Vienna today from the Enzesfeld Castle of Baron Eugene de Rothschild, where he has been a guest since he left England after his abdication. In a tailor shop he took chalk from the proprietor and drew a design for a ski jacket.

The negotiations for a new AustroGerman commercial treaty were finished today when an agreement covering the year 1937 only was signed by Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt and Franz von Papen, the German Minister.

Charles Whitehead or Plainfield, N. J., scored an easy victory in the second match round of the annual Winter golf championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon, Cup on the St. Augustine Links today. He triumphed over Dana Steele of Boston by 4 and 2 to enter the semifinals.

The Ninetysixth Council of the League of Nations settled peacefully today the Alexandretta dispute, which had caused so many alarming reports in recent weeks. While the Council was accepting new duties for the League in this
On technical grounds, at east, the share market was entitled to a recovery yesterday following the sharp declines of Tuesday and Monday. After a lower opening,

ANNOUNCER-Salary $1,800 per annum, in the Department of Plant and Structures; $2,160 per annum ($1,440 for four months of service), in the Department of Parks; pension; fair sick leave. Ages, 25 through 39. on Feb. 11.

Gordon Stewart, president of Park Tilford and Park Tilford Import Corporation, died suddenly yesterday, after a brief illness, at his city apartment, 10 Park Avenue. Mr. Stewart's home was at Beechhurst, L. I. He was 51 years old.

All but four out of sixty-six divisions of local department stores showed increases in sales in December, compared with the corresponding month in the previous year, according to the monthly analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. With an increase of 37.4 per cent, the umbrella, parasol and cane divisions led all other departments, followed by sporting goods and cameras, which showed a rise of 36.6 per cent.
Charles W. Beachem, alumni secretary of Gettysburg College since the office was created in 1929, died today after an operation. He was 34 years old.

William Brunner of 217 Beach Ninety-ninth Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens, father of William F. Brunner, President of the Board of Aldermen, died yesterday at his Winter residence in Miami, Fla., at the age of 70, following a heart attack which occurred on Monday. His son flew to Miami on Monday and was at the bedside. A brother, Frank Brunner of Maplewood, N. J., also survives.
German imports of meat in the first eleven months of 1936 increased 165 per cent over imports in the same period of 1935, according to a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The flat statement that "there definitely will be no civil war" was made here today by General Fan Soong-pu, the trusted and able commander of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's own Fortysixth Army, in a front-line interview with this correspondent.

Mrs. Trevania Blair-Smith of 25 Fifth Avenue, widow of Hugh Blair-Smith, former treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has selected the afternoon of Feb. 4 as the date for her marriage to Daniel E. Pomeroy of Englewood, N. J., leader in Republican politics, retired banker and big-game hunter.

Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, speaking today on the new civil service decree, pointed out that the German civil servant now found himself in the same position as under the old monarchy.

The Hundred Percent Club of the International Business Machines Corporation had a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in connection with its thirteenth annual convention. Fifteen hundred persons were present. A variety show was given by employes of the company, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the company, made an address and announced awards.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall. "Economic Forces and World Peace," Sir George Paish, 11 A. M.; "How Can Labor and Industry Solve Their Problem," Charles P. Howard and George E. Sokolsky, 9:30 P. M.

The advances in retail prices starting now will probably gain greater momentum during the Fall months and should show an average rise of 7 1/2 to 10 per cent for the year, A. W. Zelomek told members of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at a meeting at the Advertising Club last night. Mr. Zelomek is economist for the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., and the Fairchild Publications.

H. J. Kenner, who has been general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City since 1923, was elected yesterday to the presidency of the organization. Mr. Kenner will also remain as general manager. J. Taylor Foster of Foster Co., investment bankers, was elected treasurer.

Some improvement in communication facilities in areas ravaged by the Ohio floods was reported here yesterday by the main offices of the telegraph and telephone companies. Transportation facilities, however, were still operating with great difficulties, and for long stretches along the river bottom lands service was still entirely at a standstill.

Federal and National Guard soldiers, enforcing martial law in this inundated city of the Ohio River Valley, worked determinedly tonight with local authorities to forestall an outbreak of pestilence and further fires.

The Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, in its report to the New York State Insurance Department, showed an increase in surplus for policy holders as of Dec. 31, 1936, to $11,309,622 from $10,673,486 at the end of the previous year.

A GermanJapanese war against the Soviet Union was planned for this year, two of seventeen confessed conspirators to overthrow the Soviet Government testified tonight. The witnesses were the writer, Karl Radek, and a former railway chief, I?? Alexandrovitch Kniazeff.

Mrs. Chauncey Olcott, here for a short vacation, revealed today that the inspiration for the song "My Wild Irish Rose," written by her late husband in 1898, was a tiny yellow flower she recently found pressed in an album.

American Re-Insurance Company--Dec. 31: Total assets amounted to $13,647,300, against $10,611,156 a year earlier. Unearned premiums last year were $1,190,142, against $1,043,143 for 1935. Workmen's compensation and liability legal loss reserve was $2,990,869 on Dec. 31, against $2,694,248 a year earlier.
